title: Four Die in 2-Car Crash in Ohio
description: Three teen-agers and a 59-year-old man were killed yesterday in a two-car head-on automobile crash caused by speeding, the authorities said.

title: OPERA: 'LUCIA' PERFORMED AT JULLIARD
description: The Juilliard American Opera Center potentially fulfills several functions in New York's operatic life, one of which is the grooming of young singers to perform in the intellectually moribund productions that proliferate in this country for standard repertory. The ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' that ends a four-performance run this afternoon at the Juilliard Theater fulfills that function all too well.

title: Navy 68, Army 66
description: Rob Romaine scored 11 of Navy's 14 points in overtime to lead the Middies to a 68-66 victory over Army today.

title: MRS.FENWICK SEES MARRIAGE TAX'S END
description: WASHINGTON FOUR times she proposed, only to be left at the altar. But now, after her fifth proposal in as many years, the new man in the White House has accepted, pledging: ''I will.''

title: Columbia and New Paltz Lead in Met. Swimming
description: Columbia and New Paltz took leads in their respective divisions last night in the Metropolitan Collegiate swimming championships, being held at the United States Merchant Marine Academy.

title: BIAS TO SUN BELT SEEN IN REAGAN BUDGET
description: As Congress absorbs the details of President Reagan's proposed budget and tax cuts, a growing number of Northeastern and Middle Western lawmakers are expressing concern that the plan would accelerate the decline of their areas while encouraging the growth of prosperous states in the South and the Southwest.

title: ABSTRACTION WITH A RELAXED AIR
description: HEMPSTEAD ABSTRACT art may not be so popular nor so prevalent as realism these days, but it is far from dead, as some doomsayers have maintained. As an exhibition of contemporary abstract art at Hofstra University's Emily Lowe Gallery affirms, abstraction still has its devoted proponents, who are confident that it continues to be a valid art form.

title:
Antiques;
TWO SHOWS TO OFFER OLD TOOLS
description: SOME people collect old tools because they are still useful for today's needs. Others collect old tools that no longer have a function, but are beautifully made or are a part of America's past. But now there are collectors who buy a tool to serve as a tabletop or to decorate the wall.

title: 'Bluefish Cove' Draws Applause
description: First off, I want to thank Alvin Klein for his article about ''Last Summer at Bluefish Cove'' (''Play's Theme: Lesbians Without Apology,'' Feb. 8.) Secondly, I think it's about time people see lesbians as just that - people.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing in Weekend gave the wrong time for a performance this evening of Mussorgsky's ''Khovanshchina''by the Opera Orchestra of New York at Carnegie Hall. The performance will begin at 7:30 P.M.

title: No Headline
description: Your theater critic sneers at the dialogue in Mr. Litt's play ''Moment of Truth.''

title: A MEETING OF ARTISTIC MINDS
description: The history of collaboration between artists and architects, in our times at least, has been a dismal one. For all the talk of ''public art,'' of sculpture in civic squares and murals in skyscraper lobbies and of extravagant corporate art collections, there has been little in the way of true joint efforts between artists and architects. The spirit of cooperation that prevailed in the Beaux-Arts period of the 19th century, to mention just one era when artists and architects saw themselves as enhancing and deepening the meaning of each other's work, has seldom been present.

title: CITY COUNCIL BEGINS TO CHANGE DISTRICTS
description: Amid bickering over racial and political representation, the City Council has begun reapportioning districts to reflect the 1980 Census.

title: Emily Ostheimer Fiancee Of Kenneth Dayton Jones
description: The engagement of Emily Walker Ostheimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Ostheimer of Manchester, Mass., formerly of Southport, Conn., to Kenneth Dayton Jones, son of Mrs. Dorcas D. Jones of Rowayton, Conn., and Theodore A. Jones of Newport, R.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents. The wedding is planned for May 16.

title: Theater in Review; 'BOYS IN THE BAND' HITS UNHAPPY CHORD
description: FARMINGDALE ''THE Boys in the Band'' is suffering from a sad case of the wrinkles - that malady most dreaded by its mirror-addicted, skin-deep characters.

title: MASS TRANSIT IS AN ALL-AMERICAN PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKING THE SHACKLES OFF BUSINESS
description: EXCEPT for the chilly weather, it seemed like a Fourth of July parade. The Weber High School band, decked out in red, white and black, struck up the tune ''God Bless America'' as the color guard of the First National Bank of Chicago stood rigidly at attention.

title: DEREGULATORY BILLS PROPOSED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey today offered a package of 22 bills to reduce state regulation of business, including a proposal to aid the development of electronic branch banking in the state.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 19 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $15.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 2 2 10 ANSWER AS A MAN, by Taylor Caldwell. (Putnam's, $12.95.) A man who has made it big in early 20th-century America struggles against the corruption that engulfs his life. 3 6 7 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) A fantastic tale about the Sun, the Moon and a lost treasure. 4 3 20 COME POUR THE WINE, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $12.95.) A woman's long journey to self-discovery. 5 4 23 THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $12.95.) German espionage in Cairo during the desert campaigns of 1942. 6 9 3 BRAIN, by Robin Cook. (Putnam's, $11.95.) A young physician copes with a conspiracy of medical researchers who steal young women's brains to create an artificial intelligence. 7 5 28 FIRESTARTER, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) E ightyear-old Charlie can look at anything and turn it into flames.

title: STATE SEEKS ROLE IN RECYCLING ON L.I.
description: PORT WASHINGTON POTENTIALLY dangerous concentrations of methane gas have been found in homes near the North Hempstead Town landfill here, and while the discovery has left homeowners worrying that methane explosions could set their homes on fire whenever it rains, town officials have proposed a long-term solution that would allow the landfill to be phased out.

title: Immigration and the Missing Nail
description: Who should decide which foreigners are allowed into the United States, the foreigners or the United States? In a responsible society, the question would answer itself. But that's not the way things now work in the United States.

title: POLICE SEEKING LEADS IN FLORAL PARK SLAYING FROM WIFE OF VICTIM
description: Queens detectives waited yesterday outside the hospital room of a seriously wounded woman to get a description of the gunmen who shot her four times and killed her husband during a robbery in a luxury apartment complex Friday morning.

title: Children's Books
description: JESSE & ABE Written and Illustrated by Rachel Isadora. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow. $7.95. (Ages 4 to 8) By KARLA KUSKIN

title: THE AFRICAN INFLUENCE ON POP AND JAZZ MUSICIANS
description: Africa might seem too large, imposing and omnipresent a continent to be subject to something so ephemeral as a pop and jazz ''revival.'' But right now we seem to be in the midst of just such a revival, nonetheless. Everywhere Western musicians are turning to Africa, either for reaffirmation of a lost or dimly remembered ethnic heritage or for a more abstract kind of inspiration.

title: Larry R. Spielfogel to Marry Elizabeth Golder on June 27
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ted Golder of East Hills, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Golder, to Larry R. Spielfogel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Spielfogel of Port Washington, L.I. The wedding is planned for June 27 at the Plaza.

title: FOLK: MCGARRIGLES AT BOTTOM LINE
description: The McGarrigle Sisters may be divinely content in their selfimposed retreat to their home in Montreal. It is even quite possible that were they to pursue a recording and concert career more avidly they would be different, less valuable people. But the infrequency of their records and appearances these days remains a source of great regret, because they are still about the most moving and appealing ''folk'' performers we have.

title: Holocaust Library
description: To the Editor:

title: BEVY OF CHALLENGERS FOR '83 CUP
description: The lure of breaking the longest winning streak in sports, the United States' 130-year grasp on the America's Cup, is proving increasingly irresistible to foreign sailors. New York Yacht Club officials report that, to date, a record 10 challenges have been received for the next cup series, to be held in 1983 off Newport, R.I.

title: REPUBLICANS TO SPEND $1 MILLION ON EFFORTS FOR 'FAIR' REDISTRICTING
description: The Republican National Committee will spend $1 million this year to help state Republican parties with redistricting, but only the ones that seek no more than ''fairness,'' according to Richard Richards, the party's national chairman.

title: JUDGE BAZELON CRITICIZES BURGER'S SPEECH ON CRIME
description: David L. Bazelon, senior circuit judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, said in a speech here today that efforts to deter crime by increasing penalties would not address the cause for continuing increases in lawlessness.

title: ARE LIGHT DISPLAYS ESSENTIAL TO AUDIO?
description: With arrays of colored lights flashing on their face plates, some recent sound components look like pinball machines in a penny arcade. Ostensibly, all those lights convey information about the working of the equipment, but one suspects that the mode of display was chosen for other than functional reasons. After all, the information might have been conveyed less flamboyantly.

title: Annenberg Gives a Life Injection to Public Television
description: None of those pledge cards for Walter H.Annenberg. In announcing his long-expected gift of $150 million to Public Broadcasting Corporation last week, the former ambassador to Great Britain and founder of TV Guide magazine, claimed to have saved two endangered species with one gesture of philanthropic largesse.

title: ...AND TAKE OTHER STEPS TO HELP THE AGED
description: HOME fires in the state, which have occurred with appalling frequency, have once again focused public and media attention on one of our most serious community problems.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: METS (NL)-Traded Steven Henderson, outfielder, to the Chicago Cubs for Dave Kingman, outfielder.

title: SAAD MUHAMMAD KEEPS TITLE ON KNOCKOUT
description: Matthew Saad Muhammad had just scored his almost inevitable knockout of Vonzell Johnson, but the other lightheavyweight champion of the world, the man Saad Muhammad had been scheduled to fight last Monday, was unimpressed.

title: NOW UP FOR DEBATE, A CHAIN OF PROPOSALS ON ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: Illegal aliens regularly scamper across the United States-Mexican border, 140,000 Cubans and Haitians swamped south Florida last year, and more than 7 million Americans are out of work. Yet a Federal study commission called last week for a ''modest increase'' in the number of visas granted to immigrants.

title: STATE PASSES $20 MILLION TO MASS-TRANSIT SYSTEMS
description: New York State has passed along $20 million more in tax revenues from oil companies to its mass-transit systems, bringing to more than $30 million the money given to them through the state's 2 percent gross receipts tax.

title: Art; CORPORATE SELECTIONS IN SHOW
description: GREENWICH BUSINESSES have been buying art for a very long time -since the 15th century, if you count the Medicis, as corporate collectors are fond of doing. But the present surge in commercial patronage, which parallels the boom in art education, began in the 1950's. By 1960, the Whitney Museum was able to muster for its show ''Business Buys American Art'' no fewer than 58 companies owning works by artists as prestigious as Noguchi, Calder and Hopper, as well as several firstgeneration Abstract Expressionists.

title: Nancy Smith Has Nuptials
description: Nancy Lismore Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Smith of New York, was married yesterday afternoon in Washington to Michael Smith Nebeker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Nebeker of Salt Lake City. The Mormon ceremony took place in the Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

title: Stamps; INTERPEX SHOW WILL FEATURE SPACE SHUTTLE EXHIBIT; by Samuel A.Tower
description: Like the first robin, the advent of INTERPEX, arriving regularly at its destined time, heralds an end to winter's chill and the beginning of an extended weekend to enjoy stamps.

title: SLIGHT DECLINE REPORTED IN THE SLAYING OF OFFICERS
description: The number of law-enforcement officers slain in the line of duty in the United States declined to 103 in 1980, from 106 in 1979, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has reported.

title: FORM IS FOCAL POINT FOR HARTSDALE POET
description: IF contemporary poetry is reaching a wider audience, Anne Marx may be part of the reason. The Hartsdale poet has drawn both increasing local attention and international acclaim with her verse. With more than 1,000 published poems, this almost 68-year-old, German-born grandmother, (''68 or 86, what does it matter'') has received more than 150 prizes for individual poems. Mrs. Marx has been regularly published in major poetry journals and national magazines and has seen her work translated into several foreign languages.

title: SENATOR KENNEDY SAYS REAGAN'S BUDGET CUTS ARE 'UNFAIR SACRIFICE'
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, criticized President Reagan's economic program today as one ''of unfair sacrifice and unequal benefit.''

title: POP: CRISP CHEAP TRICK
description: Cheap Trick is one of the better Middle Western hard-rock bands who have built a large teen-age following by constant touring. What sets this Chicago-based quartet above the competition like Styx and Reo Speedwagon is the crisp way they combine and rework formats that were developed a decade ago by Engish prototypes like the Who and Led Zeppelin, while sparingly ornamenting their sound with arty touches from the Beatles and Electric Light Orchestra.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
DAVE WINFIELD, THE $24 MILLION YANKEE
description: HEN Reggie Jackson sold his expensive torso to the Yankees four years ago, he gave Sport Magazine an interview that made his life miserable all through that season of 1977. In the interview Jackson spoke with something less than servile respect for Thurman Munson, New York's star catcher, and confessed modestly, ''I am the straw that stirs the drink.'' All that summer the Yankee clubhouse was a house of horrors for him.

title: About Long Island
description: THE word breakdown seems to have become the watchword of our times. People break down when life overloads them. The Long Island Rail Road system breaks down when signals stick or minor mishaps exert a domino effect (''domino effect'' is another modern symbol, taken from a game that few people now know how to play but whose pieces can be arranged to fall down, cunningly and inexorably). Government services break down. All this I can somehow survive. What hurts is when my car breaks down.

title: NORTHEAST CORNER TAKES A STEP FORWARD
description: KILLINGLY FROM the magnificent New England country estates of Pomfret to Killingly's century-old brick Town Hall, evidence abounds of the wealth and style that the textile industry brought to northeastern Connecticut in the 1800's. But for most of this century, since the textile companies moved south and a 1955 flood destroyed much of the remaining industry, the 10 towns from Canterbury to Thompson have been an economic backwater. While there are signs that the economic pace is now quickening, the area remains vulnerable.

title: Assessment Bureaus
description: Bronx. Address: 1932 Arthur Avenue, Bronx, N.Y. 10457. Telephone: 294-0800, extension 42. Brooklyn.

title: Stacie E. DeCrane Plans June 7 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. DeCrane Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stacie Elizabeth DeCrane, to Jeffrey Reeves Shaddock, son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Shaddock of Boulder, Colo.

title: 'Lolita' to Open March 19
description: The Arts and Leisure section reports today that ''Lolita,'' the play by Edward Albee, will open at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Wednesday. After the section went to press, however, the openingnight date was changed by the producer. ''Lolita'' will now open March 19.

title: PINTER'S NEW PLAY EVOKES 'THE HOMECOMING'
description: Benedict Nightingale writes about theater for The New Statesman. By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE LONDON If Harold Pinter's standing in the stockmarket of international taste remains higher than that of any other living British dramatist, it isn't because of his own unrelenting efforts to keep it there. In the whole of the 1970's, he produced only three works for the stage, and ''Family Voices,'' the first time he has broken his silence since, lasts a mere 35 minutes. His scarcity value is such, however, that the play has been performed on BBC radio and, immediately afterward, was added to the repertory of the National Theater, with no less a director than Peter Hall in control of its mysteries and no less an actress than Peggy Ashcroft in one of its three key roles.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN is a New Jersey correspondent for The Times. By JOSEPH F.SULLIVAN

title: NO U.S. ARMS FOR EL SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Water, Water Everywhere
description: The article ''As Water Levels Fall, Restrictions Are on the Rise'' (Feb. 1) contains a serious error.

title: RIDE-SHARING PROGRAM READY TO GO
description: sharing organization formed last fall to serve companies in lower Connecticut starts service on its first three routes tomorrow - a week after receiving approval from the Connecticut Department of Transportation to tap Federal Highway Administration funds for up to 75 percent of its operating budget.

title: Judge Alters Title IX Outlook
description: Word spread slowly at first, but by last Thursday telephones were ringing on the desks of coaches and athletic directors everywhere.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Cheryl Kirk Sings Folk Works and Spirituals
description: Whether holding her hand up to stave off applause before a coloratura display or leaning back coyly against the piano, whether mouthing a sung stage whisper or flirtatiously winking at the audience, Cheryl Kirk enchanted listeners in her debut recital of spirituals and folk songs at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night. Miss Kirk has trained at the University of Southwestern Louisiana and the University of Texas at Austin.

title: AN ENGLISH COMPOSER MATURES
description: Ten years ago, Peter Maxwell Davies went along with the then-common idea that the symphony orchestra was a dying institution, facing extinction. On Wednesday in Carnegie Hall, the Boston Symphony Orchestra - which is in ruddy good health, as far as anyone can ascertain - will present the New York premiere of Mr. Davies's Symphony No. 2 as part of its commissioning program in celebration of its 100th anniversary.

title: A Welfare Benefit in Political Ambition
description: Who has inflation hurt most? A good case can be made for New York State's 500,000 welfare families. The last time their benefits were raised was in 1974, and even then the increase was based on prices already two years old.

title: CLASSIC GO GO WINS BOWIE STAKES EASILY
description: Classic Go Go, the leading money-winner among 3-year-olds this year, remained undefeated in 1981 with a 5 1/2-length victory over Honorable Man today in the 64th running of the Bowie Stakes.

title: Elizabeth Karl Married To Bidyut K. Goswami
description: St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in White Plains was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Elizabeth Anne Karl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Justin J. Karl of Dallas, formerly of Purchase, N.Y., to Bidyut Kumar Goswami, son of Parbati K. Goswami, retired Justice of the Supreme Court of India, and Mrs. Goswami, of New Delhi. Msgr. Francis X. Duffy performed the ceremony.

title: Some Help for Striped Bass
description: MILLION dollar Federal-state effort is under way aimed at restoring dwindling populations of the East Coast striped bass, a species that from New Jersey north is the region's most coveted light tackle marine game fish.

title: Critics' Choice; JAZZ
description: Max Roach, who was one of the movers and shakers who created be-bop in the 1940's, along with Charlie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie and Bud Powell, has evolved into an unusual type of virtuoso: a drum soloist who is intent on projecting the melodic as well as the rhythmic qualities of the drums.

title: In Spain, Monarchy Saves Democracy From the Military
description: Francisco Franco was still in his grave last week and Spain's fledgling democracy almost joined him. Seeking a return to military rule, 200 rightist soldiers seized Parliament and held most of the country's leaders at gunpoint for 18 hours before surrendering on orders from Spain's supreme authority, King Juan Carlos.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS SEEKING TO LIMIT INVOLVEMENT BY U.S. IN EL SALVADOR
description: A group of House Democrats is maneuvering to dissuade the Reagan Administration from military involvement in El Salvador's guerrilla conflict, but its members concede they lack the strength to block President Reagan if he wants to send arms and military advisers to the Central American nation.

title: Food; DELICIOUSLY UNEXPECTED BEGINNINGS
description: ppetizers or hors d'oeuvres are the pacesetters of any formal meal and the main feature of cocktail parties, those predinner festivities that have come back into fashion in recent years. The problem that most people have with these all-important nibbles is the rarity with which they prepare such foods; most hosts serving full-scale dinners put their energies into entrees and desserts rather than appetizers, and the basic fare for cocktail parties has long been chips and dips, cheese and crackers or, more recently, raw vegetables served with a variety of dips. Those not content with these expected offerings can try the recipes outlined here. The eggplant dip and seviche are from the owners of Soho Charcuterie, one of the most celebrated delicatessens and restaurants in Manhattan, and the other two -smoked-salmon mousse with black-bread toast and salmon caviar and curried tuna in endive sheaves - are the results of experiments by the owners of Remember Basil, an esteemed Brooklyn-based catering firm. Each of these dishes will make a lasting impression, whether it is a forerunner to a grand meal or the main culinary event of an evening's gathering for cocktails.

title: MANY OF OUR HIGHWAYS ARE SICK
description: FOR those of us elected guardians of society's future, the word transportation seems more often to mean mass transit than highways. We ponder whether the American public can really be weaned from its dependence on the auto. Will people flock again to trains, buses, jitneys, trolleys, vans, stage coaches, what have you, when gasoline finally reaches $2 a gallon or $3 a gallon? How much can we afford to invest in these fond hopes? This debate continues daily, along with bitter battles over whether this or that new highway makes sense in the face of growing costs and shrinking fuel supplies.

title: RESEARCH THAT MAKES MOVIES 'REAL'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Kirk Honeycutt, a freelance writer, frequently reports on the film scene. By KIRK HONEYCUTT LOS ANGELES

title: Beth Trier Fiancee Of Robert Ackelson
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Peter Trier of Woodbridge, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Beth Joan Trier, to Robert Ackelson of San Francisco, son of Arthur Chikar of Dublin, formerly of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., and the late Mrs. Chikar.

title: LONG BEACH'S 'NEW LOOK'
description: THE recent article ''Long Beach Getting a New Look,'' on Page 1 of the Long Island Weekly section, was most welcome as a tribute to the progressiveness of Long Beach and its City Council, of which we are two of five members.

title:
Dining Out;
P.S.: THE BILL ALSO INCLUDES A 15% TIP
description: NOWHERE is it decreed that a restaurant has to serve perfectly cooked, exciting food in an elegant setting to succeed. A number of very successful establishments manage to avoid both, yet remain crowded. However, they usually have special features to distinguish them from other restaurants in the immediate area.

title: MOTORISTS TURNING TO SMALLER CARS
description: BENSON (BUZZ) SCHULTZ of Huntington sold off a piece of the great American dream when he traded his eight-cylinder, roomy Americanmade station wagon with automatic transmission and power options for a compact foreign station wagon with a five-speed transmission and four-cylinder engine.

title: Family
description: There are 11 different definitions of the word ''family'' in Webster II, but the one closest to its root, familia, which means household, is the second: ''the body of persons who live in one house....''

title: OFFICE MARKET ADJUSTING TO INFLATION
description: The new wave of office construction in Manhattan is bringing with it a transition in fundamental relationships between builders and lenders, between owners and tenants, and between developers and the city government.

title: Mailbox; Inflated Salaries For Pro Athletes Are a Public Tax
description: To the Sports Editor: Many feel that the grossly inflated salaries paid to professional athletes are justified because sports fans are paying the tab by purchasing tickets. This appealing and seemingly logical free enterprise rationalization is wrong.

title: JACOB H. GILBERT, 60, AN EX-REPRESENTATIVE AND BRONX LEGISLATOR
description: Jacob H. Gilbert, a liberal Democrat who represented the southeast Bronx in the United States House of Representatives for 10 years after having served nearly a decade in the New York State Assembly and Senate, died Friday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: WHAT IS TRANSAMERICA?
description: THE Transamerica Corporation has an image problem. Mr. Average American, it seems, is hard-pressed to know what it is that Transamerica does. In the investment community, as one Wall Street analyst put it, ''There are only a handful of people who can even spell Transamerica.'' Ask someone what Transamerica is - all $4.4 billion of it - and you draw long hard stares.

title: Soccer Returning To Washington
description: Professional soccer will be played in the nation's capital this season if the North American Soccer League approves the transfer of its Detroit franchise.

title: DO GRAYS HAVE MORE FUN? JUST ASK THEM
description: In a world of eternal blondes, brunettes and redheads there are certain women of a certain age who would rather not have what Clairol calls "a coloring experience." They would rather have gray hair, although their hairdressers, their husbands and even their mothers do not always approve of gray hair. Some of their mothers are blondes.

title: NABOKOV'S 'LOLITA' BECOMES A PLAY BY ALBEE
description: In 1958, G.P. Putnam's Sons published a novel that, because of its sensational theme - a grown man's unquenchable lust for a 12-year-old girl - was already the center of controversy both here and abroad. Its author was Vladimir Nabokov, a Russian emigre and a professor of literature at Cornell, and the book had the distinct commercial advantage of having spurred the French authorities, no less, to pronounce it obscene when it was published in Paris three years earlier.

title: N.Y.U.'s Catch
description: On a scale of 10, New York University has scored an impressive 9.5 in luring John Brademas to become its 13th president. In every respect but one, he obviously has the credentials to lead the country's largest private university.

title: IRAN: THE ROLE OF CITIBANK
description: Just after the seizure of the American Embassy in Teheran in November 1979, Citibank established a team of executives to monitor the disruption of the bank's dealings with Iran. One member of the team was John E. Hoffman Jr., a partner in Shearman & Sterling, Citibank's principal legal adviser. On Feb. 19, he and Hans H. Angermeuller, a senior executive vice president of the bank, testified before the Senate Banking Committee on their role in the events leading to the release of the American hostages. The following is an abridged version of Mr. Hoffman's testimony.

title: A SOVIET PERIL: BASES IN LIBYA
description: A strong probability that the Soviet Air Force would have use of Libyan bases in the event of a crisis in the Mediterranean is causing growing concern to NATO planners.

title: SAM GOODY COMPANY ACCUSED AS 'PIRATE'
description: Sam Goody Inc., one of the leading chains of recorded-music stores in the country, and two of its top officers will go on trial in Federal District Court in Brooklyn tomorrow on charges of dealing in counterfeit cassette and eight-track tapes of popular music.

title: SOME REASONS FOR KEEPING SCARSDALE SYSTEM
description: MARCH 17 is a day of choices in Scarsdale. The choices are to continue the excellence of our citizen volunteer government or to open it up to politics as usual.

title: Delphine Espy To Be a Bride
description: The engagement of Delphine Seely Espy to Frank Eberhart Jr. has been announced by Mrs. James Epsy of Washington, mother of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Virginia Fayssoux Eberhart of New York and the late Mr. Eberhart.

title: 'CREATIONISTS' GATHER TO TRY TOPPLING DARWIN'S PEDESTAL
description: Fifty-six years ago, a Tennessee biology teacher named John T. Scopes was placed on trial for teaching his pupils the theory of evolution. Tomorrow morning, in a curious echo of history, lawyers will meet in a California courtroom to debate precisely the same issue:

title: U.S. Water Policy Office Planned
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt said yesterday that he was creating an Office of National Water Policy to improve the coordination of Government action on water development.

title: UNIONS ARE BATTERED IN SEOUL SWEATSHOPS
description: Labor unrest flared briefly in South Korea a few weeks ago for the first time since Gen. Chun Doo Hwan assumed power and imposed martial law nine months ago.

title: Australia Holds German As a Suspected Terrorist
description: Federal authorities raided a suburban house here today and arrested a man believed to be Peter Hans Knoll, a member of West Germany's Baader-Meinhoff terrorist gang who has been at large for 10 years.

title: Rookies Supply Lift To Sliding Islanders
description: The three rookies Coach Al Arbour brought in to shake up his ''mentally soft'' Islanders turned in key performances last night in Vancouver and were being relied on again tonight against the Los Angeles Kings as this pivotal road trip ended.

title: BRING BACK 'THE CITY GAME' TO ITS GARDEN SHOWCASE
description: PICK the greatest basketball games ever played at Madison Square Garden. City College-Kentucky? Knicks-Lakers for the title? They are at the head of my list along with several others, including my personal favorite, played 21 years ago this season, between Boys High School and George W. Wingate.

title: WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR SMITHVILLE PROJECT CALLED A 'SHAM'
description: ABSECON THE chairman of the Property Owners Protective Association of Galloway Township charged last week that the wildlife-management program of the Historic Smithville Development Co. was ''a sham and totally inadequate.''

title: No Headline
description: It may be of interest to Terry Robards and your readers to know that the soil around Chablis is chalky, and not bituminous (''Tasting Chablis at Its Celebrated Birthplace,'' Jan. 25).

title: Ash Resigns
description: Roy L. Ash, co-founder of Litton Industries and budget director in the Nixon and Ford Administrations, joined Addressograph-Multigraph (now AM International) in 1976 in an attempt to guide the foundering duplicator company into the high-technology age.

title: 3 THIRD-PERIOD GOALS GIVE PENGUINS 6-4 VICTORY OVER RANGERS
description: Rick Kehoe, Pittsburgh's leading scorer, scored his 45th goal of the season early in the final period to tie the game, 4-4, and Rod Schutt scored on a power play at 6 minutes 52 seconds for the go-ahead goal as the Penguins gained a 6-4 victory over the Rangers at the Civic Center tonight.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
THE LESSONS OF 'THATCHERIZATION'
description: A new verb has entered the Washington lexicon. It is said to be possible to ''Thatcherize'' an economy. The verb is not precisely defined, but many see it as a bad thing to do. Since ''Thatcherization'' bears a conservative label, some people fear that our new conservative President will lead us down the same disagreeable path.

title: Princeton 60, Dartmouth 56
description: Steve Mills scored 20 points to lead Princeton to a 60-56 victory over Dartmouth tonight that kept the Tigers tied for first place in the Ivy League.

title: METROPOOL RIDES FOR COMMUTERS ARE READY TO GO
description: sharing organization formed last fall to serve Westchester and Connecticut, starts service on its first three routes tomorrow - a week after receiving approval from the Connecticut Department of Transportation to tap Federal Highway Administration funds for up to 75 percent of its operating budget.

title: Carol Lifshatz Betrothed
description: The engagement of Carol Lynn Lifshatz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Lifshatz of Orange, Conn., to Barry Jay Swidler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Swidler of East Hills, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: A VICTORIAN UTOPIA IN THE HILLS OF TENNESSEE
description: GLYNNE ROBINSON BETTS, a photojournalist who lives in New York, is the author of ''Writers in Residence: American Authors at Home,'' to be published in June. By GLYNNE ROBINSON BETTS

title: By States News Service
description: WASHINGTON A FREEZE on Federal purchases of private land, combined with proposed reductions in spending, could sharply decrease the money available to acquire acreage in the Pine Barrens, Federal and state officials say.

title: NOW HEAR THIS
description: Even before it has penciled in its overall foreign policy outlook and goals, the Reagan Administration has chosen to draw the line against ''Soviet expansionism'' in the turbulent third world in El Salvador.

title: DDT BURIED NEAR BARNEGAT BAY
description: BARNEGAT TWENTY to 30 drums containing residues of DDT were buried here by the Ocean County Mosquito Exterminating Commission about 10 years ago, following the Federal Government's imposition of severe restrictions on the use of the hazardous pesticide.

title: Woodard Jumps to Fame With U.S. Mark
description: At 6:15 P.M. Friday, two hours before he would high jump in the USA/ Mobil national indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden, Jeff Woodard left his hotel room across from the Garden. As he waited for the elevator, he turned to his University of Alabama teammate, Emmit King, and said:

title: Productivity
description: To the Business Editor: In attributing major responsibility for the downward trend in United States productivity to ''American management's emphasis on short-run profits,'' (Feb. 8) Lester C. Thurow lets American labor unions off scot-free when he cheers American workers who cling to ''restrictive work rules and resist technical changes'' to safeguard themselves against unemployment.

title: U.S. SENDS EL SALVADOR 6 NAVY TECHNICIANS
description: In the Reagan Administration's first assignment of United States military personnel to El Salvador, the State Department announced today that a six-man naval training team was being sent to help that Central American country's small navy patrol its coastal waters.

title: Reading and Writing; MYSTERIOUS SHORT STORY
description: The condition of the short story is being discussed on the front page of this section, in other book reviews and critical studies, and in colleges and adult extension courses all over the country. One of the reasons for this intense scrutiny lies in the fact that many readers are puzzled by certain kinds of short stories that seem to move in mysterious ways. Sometimes, in their equally mysterious ways, authors offer us hints as to how to approach their work. The following account may be taken as such a hint, even a parable.

title: THE BEGINNING OF A NEW MENUHIN ERA
description: While 20 floors below passers-by cursed a cold and punishing wind, Yehudi Menuhin, the violinist, gazed at the sun through the curtained windows of his Sherry Netherland suite and exclaimed, ''What a beautiful day!''

title: 500 PLAYERS OF ALL AGES TAKE A BREATH FOR RECORDER FESTIVAL
description: EAST NORTHPORT THERE is something about a recorder. And although many of the 500 children and adults who will participate in Saturday's Long Island Recorder Festival in Dix Hills cannot explain exactly what it is about the ancient instrument that fascinates them, they keep going back, making the event, now in its 13th year, the oldest music festival on the Island and what is believed to be the largest one-day recorder festival in the world.

title: HOW THE FAMILIES OF HARRIS JURY FARED DURING SEPARATION
description: WHITE PLAINS WHILE jury deliberations in the murder trial of Jean S. Harris became the longest in the memory of veteran court observers, the families of the eight women and four men who made up the jury had to bear up under the lengthy separation.

title: Dining Out; A MODEST SETTING,A CAPABLE TONE
description: MERIDEN GOOD restaurants sometimes blossom in unlikely places, like roses in vacant lots. Such a one is Chateau Bianca, a welcome addition to the Meriden dining scene. It has been nurtured on a stretch of the Berlin Turnpike (Routes 5 and 15) in a one-story building that once housed a Howard Johnson's and later two other restaurants.

title: About Sidewalks
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTRACTOR ON U.S.-BACKED PROJECTS IN BRONX IS TIED TO ORGANIZED CRIME
description: A reputed organized-crime figure has become a dominant subcontractor, through four companies that law enforcement officials say he ''owns or controls,'' in federally financed construction to rehabilitate tenements in the Bronx.

title: C.W. Post 83, Adelphi 82
description: Mike Dias scored a career-high 37 points to lead C.W. Post to an 83-82 victory over Adelphi tonight at Woodruff Gymnasium.

title: IS PAYING PLAYERS AN ANSWER?
description: To the Sports Editor: Senator Chambers' plan fails to address the major problem facing college athletes today: academic neglect. He concedes "...that not all (not even most) athletes pass through the system without learning anything, without improving themselves."

title: A BREEZEFALL AWAITS DIVORCED PEOPLE
description: NEWARK MORE than 23,000 present or former New Jersey residents have moved a step closer to receiving a small-scale windfall from the state. A Federal Court judge here has issued an opinion confirming the unconstitutionality of a law affecting people in divorce suits. The law, which has since been repealed by the State Legislature, required persons filing for divorce to pay a fee of $50 in uncontested cases and $60 in contested cases, in addition to the $60 charge for the filing of all suits in State Superior Court.

title: St. John's Ends Skid By Beating Syracuse
description: The Rev. Joseph T. Cahill went to the dressing room minutes before the St. John's basketball game against Syracuse yesterday. It was his first visit since he became president of St. John's in 1965. He told the players, who had lost four straight games, ''Win or lose, everybody at St. John's is behind you.''

title: Democrats Set Up Study Group Aimed at Developing New Ideas
description: Expressing the fear that their party had become one with little new to say, a group of Democratics has announced the establishment of a research organization to bring fresh ideas to Democratic politics.

title: New Legal Weapon; For Illegal Aliens
description: The Federal Government last week established a precedent that, if it survives appeals, would add significantly to the arsenal of protections for illegal aliens. In the first Federal prosecution of its kind, a jury in Phoenix convicted Patrick W. Hanigan, a member of a prominent southern Arizona ranching family, in the torture and robbery of three illegal Mexican alien farm workers in 1976.

title: Long Islanders; OBSTETRICIAN ALSO DELIVERS NOVELS
description: READING matter is a normal part of the decor in a doctor's office. But not long ago, on the desk of the receptionist of Dr. David M. Shobin at 285 Middle Country Road in Smithtown, there appeared some reading matter with a difference. It was a new novel entitled ''The Unborn.''

title: Ice Cream
description: To the Business Editor:

title: NORTHPORT DIVIDED ON HISTORIC-DISTRICT PLAN
description: NORTHPORT NOWADAYS when the regulars gather over coffee at the Northport Sweet Shop, the conversations often concern what many consider are the horrors of the village's proposed historic district. Down the street at Haberdashery Limited, however, others argue that the district is essential if what's left of the old seaport's 19thcentury charm is to be preserved.

title: Mary V. Curtayne Bride of Gerald D. Wellman, Teacher
description: Mary Vincent Curtayne, daughter of Mrs. E. Vincent Curtayne of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Curtayne, was married yesterday in Santa Rosa, Calif., to Gerald David Wellman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Wellman of Santa Rosa. The Rev. Donald A. Vogl, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Ursuline Convent chapel.

title:
Dining Out;
CHANGE IS LOW-KEYED AND SIMPLE
description: UNLESS you have been over Route 35 in South Salem lately, the name Tatters may be new to you, but Tatters is not a new restaurant - it is only last year's Alexander's in a revised version. John Zipser, who also owns the lively Rags in Bedford Hills, has revamped his candle-lighted barn of a restaurant with bright patchwork hangings and blue and white china crockery on the walls, with handsome 10-foot gray birches in tubs and with jars of flowers to provide a pleasant low-keyed casualness.

title: The Producers
description: One additional point needs to be made concerning the estimable careers of Nelle Nugent and Liz McCann (''Presenting McCann & Nugent,'' by Elin Schoen, Feb. 1).

title: L. C. Blount Weds Susan A. McDaniel
description: Susan Alane McDaniel and Lawrence Clare Blount were married yesterday at St. Martin's Lutheran Church in Annapolis, Md. The Rev. Richard Reichard, executive director of the National Lutheran Home in Rockville, Md., performed the ceremony.

title: Thailand's Democratic Party Pulls Out of Ruling Coalition
description: Thailand's Democratic Party said today that it was withdrawing from Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda's three-party coalition Government after two weeks of bickering between the other members.

title: Understanding Black Slang
description: The analysis of black slang may be responsible for its demise. The larger society tends to discount or devalue those things it can't understand.

title:
Gardening;
ORCHID NOT JUST A HOTHOUSE FLOWER
description: IF you were asked to name the most exotic of all flowers, you would probably respond ''the orchids.'' Fortunes have been spent collecting new species from tropical jungles, and romantic novelists have woven their plots around the mythical black orchid, which doesn't exist. However, there are enough gorgeous blooms in this family to more than compensate for this particular deficiency.

title: BROTHER AND SISTER WITH WORLD TO CONQUER
description: WILMINGTON, Del. IT was 1:40 P.M., the hour Kitty and Peter Carruthers, the United States champions in pairs figure skating, were scheduled to work out at the Skating Club of Wilmington. Neither was here.

title: Time for Change In Scarsdale
description: In ''A Chance to Choose in Scarsdale,'' (Feb. 8), Paul Feiner factually reports, ''Unlike other Westchester municipalities, in which the predominant issues are the candidates' views, the major issue in the 1981 Scarsdale village election is the election procedure.'' I agree 100 percent with Mr. Feiner's analysis.

title: It's a No-Frills Life For Cup Champions; INGLEWOOD, Calif.
description: LIFE on the run for a hockey team is a series of bus rides over lookalike highways, three-abreast airplane lunches with paper napkins, skating sessions commanded by a coach angered by sloppy play, games in front of hostile, jeering fans, and a view of a world that is bounded all other times by a hotel lobby.

title: INVESTIGATIVE REPORTER AT WALL STREET JOURNAL
description: Jerry G. Landauer, a correspondent for The Wall Street Journal who won several prizes for investigative reporting, died last night in George Washington University Hospital after he was stricken with a heart attack on Tuesday. He was 49 years old.

title: Vatican Official Is in Hong Kong For Talks With a Chinese Bishop
description: The Vatican's Secretary of State, Agostino Cardinal Casaroli, arrived here today for talks with Bishop Deng Yiming on China's relations with the Roman Catholic Church.

title: RECITAL: STEPHANIE JUTT PLAYS FLUTE SONATA
description: The flute can be a bland instrument, and Stephanie Jutt didn't entirely escape the charge of blandness during her recital Thursday night at the Abraham Goodman House; her account of Prokofiev's Sonata in D (Op. 94) in particular could have benefited from more tension and pep.

title: Westchester Guide; by Eleanor Charles; MEDIEVAL FACTIONALISM
description: Pierre Capretz, director of the Yale Language Laboratory, will relate in French the 11th- and 12th-century conflicts arising among medieval factions involved in the search for the Holy Grail.

title: A VOTE FOR CHANDLER, AN IGNORED PIONEER
description: IN more than a century of major league baseball history, only a handful of men have single-handedly changed the direction of the game:

title: SEPARATING FACT AND FANTASY IN REGULATION
description: To the Business Editor: Mr. Green and Mr. Waitzman, apparently believe that cost-benefit analysis overstates the costs and understates the benefits of government regulation. Almost certainly the opposite is true.

title: 5 SEIZED IN ASSAULT ON BLACKS BY AUTO
description: Five white youths who allegedly attempted run down three black young women in Rockaway, Queens, yesterday were charged with attempted murder when they were caught after the incident, the police said.

title: MRS. THATCHER BACKS U.S. ON SOVIET 'ENCROACHMENT'
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher yesterday pledged Britain's support for President Reagan in blocking what she described as Soviet ''encroachment in regions vital to the interests'' of the North Atlantic alliance, including El Salvador, Africa and the Persian Gulf.

title: DANCE: MOULTON'S ATHLETICS
description: Sports fans sometimes liken athletes to dancers. Charles Moulton's Thursday night program at the American Theater Laboratory reversed that comparison by making dancers resemble athletes.

title: SEPARATING FACT AND FANTASY IN REGULATION
description: To the Business Editor: Mark Green, is referred to in your article as ''a public interest lawyer.'' I think it is timely that this misuse of a term is suspended. The voters of the 18th Congressional District defeated Mr. Green decisively last November -affirming that in their public opinion he does not represent the public interest. Mr. Green is a special interest lawyer and should be labeled as such. MICHAEL D. ROBBINS

title: BAY SHORE, L.I.
description: FOR many Suffolk County residents, food is already too much of a problem for food stamps to solve. Toward the end of the month, they must rely on emergency supplies provided by charitable organizations such as the Society of St. Vincent DePaul.

title:
The Lively Arts;
ADDING GEOMETRIC ENERGY TO DANCE
description: GREAT NECK BETWEEN coffee and homemade cinnamon cake in the basement studio of St. Paul's Parish House in Great Neck the other morning, six of the eight members of the Consolidated Energy Dance Company rehearsed three works for a performance they are giving on Saturday at 8 P.M. at the North Middle School's auditorium, on Arrandale Avenue in Great Neck.

title: The Careful Shopper; by Jeanne Clare Feron; Kitchen Equipment And a Lot More
description: The Cook's Corner, a division of Food Equipment Systems Inc., is more than a retail source for kitchen gifts in Chappaqua. It is a place to revel in opportunities for careful preparation and thoughtful presentation of all those inevitable meals, and especially for group cooking. Leonard Stern, owner of Food Equipment Systems, supplies executive dining rooms and corporate kitchens from headquarters in Chappaqua, and Harmony Stern supervises the retail business, which can therefore pass along the advantages of bulk buying and the elimination of any middleman.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE TOPS SETON HALL
description: John Bagley scored 28 points tonight to power Boston College to a 64-57 victory over Seton Hall, giving the Eagles the regular-season championship in the Big East Conference.

title: News for $18,000
description: ''It's a very small market,'' Stanley Stillman conceded when he set up Access, a news service for top business executives.

title: Reagan's Personal Budget in Balance
description: Thanks in part to inflation, Ronald Reagan's net worth has increased considerably in recent years. According to estimates compiled last week by The New York Times, the value of Mr. Reagan's holdings add up to $4 million; in 1976, the President reported assets totalling $1.5 million.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Fed's Burden

title: Paperbacks:New and Noteworthy
description: THE GIRL IN A SWING, by Richard Adams, NAL/Signet, $3.50.) As a British schoolboy, Alan Desland discovers he has clairvoyant powers but chooses to pay them no heed; as a mature man, he takes a trip to Denmark to buy rare porcelain and, after meeting a beguiling girl named Kathe, starts to see and hear strange thing. Our reviewer Robert Kiely called this "a beautiful, haunting novel," its love scenes "lyrical," its ghost scenes "psychologically penetrating."

title: School's Only Service: To Initiate Learning
description: Dr. Lubus's article is based on two assumptions: a) that it is possible to monitor what a child is learning, and b) that it is possible to outline a curriculum that will insure that development of ''useful and specific skills.''

title: 'ZONING' ISN'T THE WAY TO PROTECT WATER
description: ONCE again, the Environmental Protection Agency is confronted by a problem of great scope and consequence. It is ironic that this problem, the contamination of our nation's ground water, has been caused in part by a zealous effort to decrease the pollution of air, surface waters and oceans.

title: Scientists
description: To the Business Editor: I applaud Michael Schulof's ''Scientists in Business'' (Feb. 1). Unfortunately, some of your readers have missed the point completely, if one may generalize from two letters in the Feb. 15 issue that call instead for ''overhaul of societal ... reward systems,'' and improving the skills of financial executives, respectively.

title: Fern Cohen Is Engaged to Robert Billet, Law Student
description: The engagement of Fern Suzan Cohen to Robert Douglas Billet, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Billet of Livingston, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Allen Cohen of Teaneck, N.J. Plans have been made for a wedding in July.

title: TERRORISM TRACING THE INTERNATIONAL NETWORK
description: Four well-groomed men bearing sawed-off shotguns approach a car on a busy street in Milan; bullets rip through the body of the passenger, chief of one of the city's largest hospitals. The Red Brigades, the nation's most-feared terrorist group, claims responsibility. In Northern Ireland, a band of armed men uses explosives to blast its way into the castle of Sir Norman Stronge, an 86-year-old Protestant leader and longtime speaker of Northern Ireland's Parliament; the bodies of Sir Norman and his son, James, 48 years old, are found later, bullets through their heads, and guerillas of the Irish Republican Army (I.R.A.) say it was their work.

title: E.P.A. Works to Prevent Toxic-Waste Overflow
description: Federal environmental experts working in driving sleet today raised the level of a retaining wall to prevent the overflow of a rain-swollen lagoon filled with nearly one million gallons of toxic waste.

title: 3 EX-CONGRESSMEN LOOK BACK AND AHEAD
description: WASHINGTON

title: Jersey Calls Up an Anticrime Reserve
description: There was good news last week for New Jersey motorists who may have wondered why state troopers spend their time writing tickets instead of catching criminals. A team of 35 troopers will soon forsake the highways for the streets of Trenton as part of an experiment to reduce urban crime.

title: SPORTS EVENT TAXES HARTFORD'S STAMINA
description: CONFRONTED with the delicate task of satisfying the appetites of more than 200 figure skaters, coaches and judges from 25 countries, Judy Te Selle and Paul Bourdeau have been somewhat apprehensive about welcoming those participating in the 1981 World Figure Skating Championships that begin a six-day run at the Hartford Civic Center Coliseum on Tuesday.

title: OPEC AND INFLATION
description: To my astonishment, I have just discovered that since 1972 the increase in the price of imported oil has had little impact on inflation in the United States. It represents only one-eighteenth of the inflation during the entire period, or less than 0.5 percent of the 8 percent average yearly inflation.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Zia Tells His Foes Who's in Command
description: Since September, Pakistan's President, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, has been basking in diplomatic limelight - addressing the United Nations and attempting peacemaking between Iran and Iraq as chairman of the 38-nation Islamic Conference, and courted by Washington and Moscow over possible resolutions to the Afghanistan conflict next door.

title: West Chester State Takes E.C.C. Wrestling Crown
description: Jorge Leon, John Moser and Mike Moyer won individual titles today to lead West Chester State to the team title in the seventh annual East Coast Conference wrestling championships.

title: ISRAELI PARTIES FOCUS ON ECONOMY AS KEY TO ELECTION
description: As both the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin and the opposition Labor Party prepare for the national elections June 30, each is turning its attention to the ravaged Israeli economy.

title: J.M. Fowler Fiance Of Jennifer Walter
description: Jennifer Rose Walter, who is in her second year at the Brooklyn Law School, plans to be married in June to Joseph Martin Fowler of Stamford, Conn., president of the American Actuator Corporation there.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: J. B. Folts Marries Cynthia Warrick
description: Cynthia Warrick, daughter of Mrs. Paul Vestal of Greensboro, N.C., and the late Bascom Lewis Warrick of Dothan, Ala., was married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., to John Burr Folts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burr C. Folts of East Aurora, N.Y. The Rev. Richard F. Van Wely performed the ceremony in St. Barnabas Episcopal Church. The couple live in Greenwich.

title: Dr. Rosalind Schaefer Bride of J. A. Abram
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Tannenbaum of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Rosalind Amy Schaefer, to Jonathan Adam Abram, son of Morris B. Abram of New York and Jane M. Abram of Atlanta.

title: Klan vs. Preacher
description: It was a Saturday afternoon, the Rev. Michael S. Curry related, and after working on a sermon at the United Methodist Church in Smithburg, W. Va., he walked from the church office to the parsonage, and there he found a butcher knife piercing the upholstered backrest of his chair. ''You will be dead,'' a note said.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
MATCHING ROOMERS WITH ROOMS
description: HACKENSACK ''IT WAS tight sledding, to put it bluntly,'' said a woman who has had a roomer in her home here since last November. ''With expenses being what they are, especially oil and electricity, I needed a supplement to my salary.''

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Congressional Hearing On Arts Funds Tomorrow
description: A House subcommittee will hold a hearing tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on President Reagan's proposed cuts in Federal support for the arts and humanitites.

title: Taxes and Options
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''Taxes and Options'' (Feb. 15), note the word option; it calls for the individual's judgments and offers no guarantees. Giving the executive the benefit of reasonable approximation, the appreciation from $500,000 to $900,000 perhaps took two years.

title: Headliners; Fit for a King
description: The world got two demonstrations last week of why some democratic peoples still keep royal families around at great public expense. While King Juan Carlos fended off a serious military threat to Spain's democracy, Britain's Prince Charles did his careworn countrymen a service of a distinctly lighter sort, giving them, in one Londoner's words, ''the kind of news that makes you happy to be British again.'' Buckingham Palace announced that Charles, the 32-year-old successor to the throne now occupied by his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, had chosen a bride: Lady Diana Spencer, the 19-year-old daughter of the Earl Spencer. They'll be married in July.

title: Miss Sheard And a Lawyer Will Be Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles Sheard of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Carol Sheard, to William G. McGuinness 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. McGuinness Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

title: CONVENTIONS: BETTER RULE OUT BALI
description: M EMBERS of the South Carolina Society of Certified Public Accountants held their 1980 annual meeting last May on a cruise ship to Bermuda - but they probably won't do it again. If they did, they would be faced with the dismal prospect of having to pay all of the expenses themselves, rather than writing them off their Federal income taxes.

title: Theater; O'NEILL'S LAST PLAY: EMOTIONAL THEATER
description: THE easiest way to find the Main Street Theater, which is in a corner of the vast shopping mall known as The Galleria, is to ask directions to the movie theaters that are next to it and can be spotted by their marquees. The Main Street Theater, with no marquee to point it out, is to the left. Despite an unseasonably warm night, which raised the theater's temperature close to the melting point, I would recommend you see ''A Moon for the Misbegotten,'' Eugene O'Neill's last play.

title: THEATER: LEONARD MELFI'S 'BUTTERFACES'
description: In ''Butterfaces,'' Leonard Melfi has written a love letter to Off Off Broadway, the theatrical arena in which he has been a faithful participant for almost 20 years. As it happens, his new play is also a murder mystery with a twist of Pirandello. Sweet and sour, sentiment and irony, do not quite mix, but there is ample entertainment in this backstage comedy to appeal to onlookers as well as to insiders.

title: Beth Bloomfield Fiancee of Michael Altschul
description: Beth Susan Bloomfield, a program analyst on the resource management staff of the Director of Central Intelligence in Washington, and Michael Field Altschul, a trial lawyer with the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice in Washington, plan to be married in New York on April 12.

title: Roberts: Master of Motorcycling
description: Kenny Roberts surprised even himself in 1978 when he became America's first world champion motorcycle racer. ''I really didn't expect to win the championship that year,'' Roberts said recently of his first year of European competition. ''I don't dream quite that heavy.''

title: Theater; HENRY FONDA:BROADWAY NO LONGER GOAL
description: IN 1948, in his review of ''Mister Roberts,'' Brooks Atkinson of The New York Times expressed gratitude to ''have Henry Fonda return to the stage after 11 years.'' There have been many other returns over the past three decades, but very few that involved a developing regional stage like the Hartman Theater in Stamford.

title: A Theory of Thermostats
description: We were saying the other day that judicious Federal regulation of, say, electrical appliances can help hold down the real cost of energy while reducing the nation's dependence on imported oil. Relying on the free market's high costs of energy won't necessarily speed conservation.

title: A Report: Remarkable Generosity
description: Three months ago The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund issued an urgent appeal on behalf of the poor, the ill, the lonely. The plea was made with some apprehension.

title: APPRAISALS & EXPLICATIONS
description: MEMORIES OF THE MODERNS By Harry Levin. 257 pp. New York: New Directions. $15.95.

title: Drug Agency Shake-Up
description: Since the Northeast is the center of the nation's heroin traffic, it stands to reason that the region also should be the center of policing efforts. According to an internal evaluation by the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, though, it isn't.

title: HEIR TO MICKEY MOUSE?
description: Air France, Owens-Corning Fiberglas and the Safeco Insurance Company use him in their advertising. The Brabo Corporation sells him as a bendable doll, Stromberg-Carlson will introduce a $99.95 telephone shaped like him and D. Gottleib & Company is planning to use him on a pinball machine.

title: FOUR NOVELS
description: BRAIN By Robin Cook. 283 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $11.95.

title: RAVENNA:ITALY'S TREASURY OF BYZANTINE SPLENDORS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- SARAH FERRELL is an editor on the staff of the Travel Section. By SARAH FERRELL

title: WASHINGTON
description: W HILE the Justice Department has spent six years trying to break up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, two relatively obscure Washington hands, in less dramatic ways, have already helped to reshape the telecommunications industry - and Bell.

title: Practical Traveler; KEEPING UP TO DATE WITH GUIDEBOOKS
description: The list price of the paperback edition of ''Fodor's Europe for 1981'' is $10.95. If you do not mind buying the 1979 edition, however, it is still available by mail for $2.49, and you may soon be able to find it in a Barnes & Noble discount bookstore in New York for $1.

title: OPTIMISM ON LONG-RANGE WATER SUPPLY
description: IN the midst of the water crisis gripping the metropolitan area, some government officials and business leaders in Westchester have turned their attention to the long-range outlook for water availability and are generally optimistic about its potential for attracting and keeping industry in the county. At the same time, however, they have expressed concern that this economic resource be protected by both conservation and adequate planning on a regional or state level.

title: NATURE VS. NURTURE: A NATURAL EXPERIMENT
description: IDENTICAL TWINS REARED APART A Reanalysis. By Susan L. Farber. 383 pp. New York: Basic Books. $26.50.

title: COURT BARS DUES TO UNIONS WITH CONVICTED OFFICERS
description: An appeals court has ruled that unions on the New York waterfront can be barred from collecting dues if they retain convicted criminals as union officials.

title: KEEPING BUSINESS TENANTS FIT AND HAPPY IN SUBURBS
description: Richard Nidds finds he can work longer hours and ease the pressure of his job as a trainee with a Lyndhurst, N.J., development company because he has access to an exercise room in the office building where he works.

title: U.S. Group Leaves for Seoul
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, an Illinois Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and Anna Chennault, the widow of Gen. Claire L. Chennault, will lead an American delegation to the inauguration Tuesday of Chun Doo Hwan as President of South Korea, the White House announced today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The one thing all successful counterinsurgencies have had in common is patience. The most dangerous thing is to overreact and try to move faster than one can raise, equip and train a few good counterinsurgency units.'' -Prof. Edward Luttwak of Georgetown University, discussing response to guerrillas in El Salvador. (8:5.)

title: ALEXANDER M. PYRRHUS
description: With an insistence bordering on obsession, Secretary of State Haig has focused his weeks in office on the Communist menace in El Salvador. One would think that El Salvador presented the gravest current threat to Americian security, that Communists were the main reason for its misery and that U.S. arms were a likely cure. But those propositions are all false.

title: Canadiens 5, Maple Leafs 3
description: Brian Engblom and Mario Tremblay scored second-period goals to lift Montreal to victory over Toronto and extend the Canadiens' undefeated streak to 12 games.

title:
Gardening;
ORCHID NOT JUST A HOTHOUSE FLOWER
description: IF you were asked to name the most exotic of all flowers, you would probably respond ''the orchids.'' Fortunes have been spent collecting new species from tropical jungles, and romantic novelists have woven their plots around the mythical black orchid, which doesn't exist. However, there are enough gorgeous blooms in this family to more than compensate for this particular deficiency.

title: Constance Bradlee Thayer Is Wed To David Devens
description: Constance Bradlee Thayer of New York, widow of Francis C. Thayer, was married yesterday to David W. Devens, also of New York, a retired vice president of Johnson & Higgins, the international insurance brokers. Bishop Paul Moore of the Episcopal Diocese of New York performed the ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: SEX VALUES FOR TEENS
description: Secretary of Health and Human Services Richard S. Schweiker has been criticized for saying that the Government should not promote sex education or pay for contraceptives for teenagers under Medicaid. He is quoted as having said: ''Sex education is primarily a responsibility of parents.'' He is right.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Lillian Barry and James Suslavich to Be Married in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bartholomew D. Barry of Stoneham, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lillian Marie Barry, to James A. Suslavich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Suslavich of Darien, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Had Reason, Grand Jury Finds
description: In Garden City, L.I., town and gown relations, strained since the fatal shooting of a student by a police officer on the Adelphi campus two weeks ago, were further stressed last week.

title: STRIPPED OF POWER IN '79, EX-L.I.R.R. CHIEF CHARGES
description: Francis S. Gabreski, who resigned under pressure last Thursday from his post as president of the Long Island Rail Road, said yesterday that for the last year and a half he had ''the responsibility, but not the authority'' to run the system.

title: Sarah S. Lyon Is Betrothed: Bridal in May
description: Mrs. Frank R. Lyon Jr. of Rye, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Sarah Stewart Lyon, to George Wallace de Menocal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Crosby de Menocal of Rye and Nantucket, Mass. A wedding in May is planned.

title: BREEDING ANOTHER 'SACRED TUITION COW'
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Clinic; KNOCKING THE NOISE OUT OF RADIATORS
description: AKNOCKING or noisy radiator or one that does not heat all the way across is annoying and can also be inefficient, wasting energy because heat is not being delivered uniformly.

title: PATERSON, N.J.
description: Afew weeks ago, a deficit of $37.5 million in New Jersey's medicaid budget nearly forced what Gerald Reilly, the deputy commissioner of state's Department of Human Services, called ''Draconian'' program cuts. Only a last-minute reprieve - more money from the state legislature - eliminated the threat.

title: Former Head of Harlem Hospital Must Be Reinstated, Court Rules
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation has been ordered by the State Supreme Court in Manhattan to reinstate Albert Jackson to his position as acting executive director of Harlem Hospital Center.

title: COMPANIES ACT ON DRUG USE BY EMPLOYEES
description: INDUSTRY is becoming increasingly aware of drug abuse by employees. Many employers on the Island who have long acknowledged alcoholism as a deterrent to productivity, and have set up programs to help employees with the illness, are now acknowledging that addiction to both drugs and alcohol, as well as dependency on drugs from marijuana to heroin, is becoming more prevalent in the work force.
