title: Ithaca Gymnasts Win
description: Ithaca won the gymnastics championship of the New York State Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women today at Brockport State. Beth Sholtes of Cortland State won the all-round competition.

title: THE ART OF AMERICAN SHORT STORIES
description: ELLIS ISLAND And Other Stories. By Mark Helprin. 196 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $10.95.

title: Music; YOUTH SYMPHONY IN SPOTLIGHT TODAY
description: ''WE'VE had our ups and downs,'' said C. Victor Leonti, conductor of the 85-member Westchester Youth Symphony, which is giving a free concert at 3 o'clock this afternoon in the Yorktown High School. ''But the orchestra is definitely on the upswing now. Perhaps because a lot of school music programs have been cut back lately, we seem to be serving more of a need in the county, giving our gifted kids important training and performing outlets.''

title: Fairfield 68, Manhattan 65
description: Hank Foster scored 19 points and Mike Palazzi 17 as they led Fairfield University to a 68-65 victory over Manhattan College tonight.

title: Critics' Choice
description: Each week several Times critics will offer tips on attractions around town.

title: CONSERVATION,SHARING URGED AT WATER PARLEY
description: HARTFORD ''SHUT down things like decorative fountains, even if they use recycled water; take away the visible signs that water is cheap and easily available,'' said Anne M. Blackburn, a water-use planner, as 45 representatives of drought-affected towns and water companies listened attentively.

title: CANADA'S CONSERVATIVES REAFFIRM CLARK AS THEIR PARTY CHIEF
description: Former Prime Minister Joe Clark, who broke 16 years of Liberal Party control of the federal Government in 1979 only to be defeated six months later, has received qualified support from his Progressive Conservative Party.

title: Hunt Family Silver Sent To Delaware, Paper Says
description: Nearly half of the silver fortune of Nelson Bunker Hunt and his brother W. Herbert Hunt has been moved from Chicago to Delaware, where taxes are lower, The Wilmington News-Journal reported today.

title: PAISLEY AGAIN STIRS ULSTER PROTESTANTS
description: Two thousand Ulster Protestants, their Union Jacks snapping in the cold evening mist, marched for an hour through the main streets of this grim little town, following high-stepping bands that played ''Rule, Britannia!'' and ''Keep the Home Fires Burning.''

title: On Language; LANGUAGE LIB; by William Safire
description: The counterreaction is upon us. For nearly two decades, ever since Merriam-Webster's Third International Dictionary refused to put a ''substandard'' label on all forms of ''ain't,'' language lovers have been up in alarums.

title: Television Week; by Gene Lambinus
description: Pros and Cons ''It drives you crazy, but it keeps you very honest.'' Joan Tewkesbury was describing the demands as well as the benefits that the pressures of making a television movie put on a director. The project in question is ''The Acorn People,'' which stars Ted Bessell, LeVar Burton and Cloris Leachman and which NBC will show on Monday at 9 P.M.

title: Speaking Personally; ANYONE HERE SPEAK EUPHEMESE?
description: THE scene is registration. The people around me are conspicuously younger, including, alas, the counselor himself, or, as he is called in 1980, the Student Development Specialist. He is fluent in Euphemese.

title: DRAMATIZED PORTRAIT OF CHURCHILL AT WAR
description: Michael Billington, who is London theater critic for The Guardian, also maintains an interest in television. By MICHAEL BILLINGTON LONDON Jack Le Vien is clearly a man who likes to walk with kings. Or, at the very least, soldiers and statesmen. The walls of his Mayfair office are liberally festooned with pictures of himself in company with such men as Winston Churchill, Dwight Eisenhower, George Marshall and Field Marshal Montgomery. And, as a producer, Mr. Le Vien has devoted most of the past 20 years to celebrating the famous on film. This led to ''The Valiant Years,'' a television documentary series, and to ''The Gathering Storm,'' a drama about Churchill (which starred Richard Burton). It also led to ''A King's Story,'' a film about the Duke of Windsor.

title: ARGENTINA ARRESTS KEY RIGHTS ACTIVISTS
description: Argentina's national police have arrested the leaders of that country's internationally recognized human rights movement and seized files on more than 6,000 missing persons, according to reports reaching the State Department.

title: A VISIT TO KOREA, FAMILY TO FAMILY
description: DON BRAMAN is a Minneapolis-based writer and consultant in financial public relations. By DON BRAMAN

title: New Jersey Guide; GOING TO THE DICKENS?
description: It was 30 years ago that Emlyn Williams, the eminent 75-year-old Welsh actor, playwright and author, first offered a one-man show based on the life of Charles Dickens. Since then, he has taken it all over the world.

title: Banker to Wed Wendy French
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond French of Locust Valley, L.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Collison French, to William J. Nolan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nolan Jr. of Irvington, N.Y.

title: Acosta Wins Bowling
description: Mal Acosta of Hayward, Calif., rolled seven straight strikes en route to capturing the $100,000 Cleveland open bowling tournament today. He beat Marshall Holman of Medford, Ore., in the final, 235-170.

title: 'GUARDIAN ANGELS' GET MIXED REACTION
description: The Guardian Angels are spreading their protective wings to the state capital, even if their halos of late have not been too luminous.

title: DOLLARS AND ARTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Drexel 74, Wagner 73
description: Mike Moran registered two free throws with 18 seconds remaining to lead Drexel to a 74-73 upset of Wagner Saturday night at Sutter Gymnasium in Staten Island.

title: Wine; FLAVORED BY THE WIND; by Terry Robards
description: The mistral is the wind that blows down through the Rhone Valley of France, the same wind that turned back the leaves on the trees that Van Gogh painted a century ago, the wind that whistles through the grape vines of the Cotes du Rhone en route to Provence and the Mediterranean Sea. The mistral is a part of everyday life there, and it is especially important to the makers of wine, for it dries out the vineyards after the rain and it is always accompanied by sunshine, which enables the grapes to achieve the great ripeness that is essential for making the intensely flavored wines of the region.

title: Officials on Coast Plan to Charge Prisoners for Time Spent in Jail
description: The chairman of the San Diego County Board of Supervisors says the cost of imprisoning lawbreakers should be paid by inmates, not by taxpayers.

title: Children's Books
description: A PLACE CALLED UGLY By Avi. 141 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $8.95. (Ages 9 to 13) By BRYNA J.FIRESIDE

title: LAURA:THE 40'S LIVE AT CENTER STAGE
description: PARAMUS ''LAURA'' is great fun. As presented by Center Stage, the Vera Caspary-George Sklar dramatization of Miss Caspary's famous mystery novel is crammed with red herrings, tantalizing entrances and exits and bewildered silences broken by amorous Freudian outbursts.

title: PAIRS SKATING: A TEST OF SKILLS IN TANDEM
description: There are four types of competition in the world figure-skating championships - men's singles, women's singles, pairs and dance.

title:
COMMENT;
LABOR ON REAGAN
description: A MERICAN workers share the economic goals announced by President Reagan - less inflation, more jobs, improved productivity stronger industries and more effective government.

title: Cleveland Keeps Superintendent
description: Superintendent of Schools Peter P. Carlin retained his job today after a Cleveland Board of Education meeting, called for the purpose of dismissing Mr. Carlin, did not attract enough members to vote on the issue. By law, Mr. Carlin had to be told by tomorrow if his contract was not going to be renewed; otherwise he would receive an immediate one-year extension. Only three of seven board members appeared at the meeting.

title: THE SHAPE OF DETAILS
description: The designer Zoran combines high- heeled satin pumps with a knee-length gabardine shirt and slightly longer cashmere cardigan for a long, lean look. Shoes by Mario of Florence, $220.

title: Westchester Journal; by Gary Kriss
description: IF winter is here, can Pepsico Summerfare be far behind? The State University of New York at Purchase and Pepsico have decided to join forces to present another five-weekend festival of dance, music and drama during July and August. Last year's activities attracted more than 50,000 people, according to Brookes Jones, artistic director of the university's Center for the Performing Arts, which oversees Summerfare.

title: REBELS ECHO A DEAD EPOCH AND THEY ALMOST REVIVED IT
description: The signs of an impending military coup were there for those who could decipher them. ''As a soldier who has dedicated all his life to the service of Spain,'' wrote Fernando de Santiago y Diaz de Mendivil, ''I believe that the hour has come when all Spaniards must put an end to the destruction of our unity and prevent the disappearance of our fatherland.''

title: On the Quality Of Cable Television
description: I have just finished reading Betsy Brown's article on cable television (''Cable TV: A Plus and Minuses,'' Feb. 8). She talks about most subscribers not getting what ''was promised a decade ago: live local coverage, educational programs'' and so forth.

title: BIRMINGHAM TRANSIT SYSTEM SHUT DUE TO LACK OF MONEY
description: The 201 buses of the Birmingham-Jefferson County Transit Authority made their last runs yesterday, shutting down the transit system for about 30,000 regular riders, many of them low-income workers who depended on the buses to get to their jobs, and about 5,000 pupils who rode them to school.

title: Soviet Rescue Ship Reaches Disabled Vessel Off Alaska
description: A Soviet freighter today pulled alongside a disabled South Korean cargo ship that had burned through the night in the north Pacific as about 20 of its crew members abandoned ship, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

title: 41ST ALL-BREED DOG SHOW PLANNED AT COUNTY CENTER
description: AT the 41st annual All-Breed Dog Show, to be held by the Saw Mill River Kennel Club next Sunday at the County Center in White Plains, hundreds of dogs will compete in showmanship, obedience and for selection as best specimen of a breed.

title: COUNTRY MUSIC, PINES STYLE
description: WARETOWN IT IS DUSK in the Pine Barrens. The sky has softened from brittle blue to warm orange, and the pines make eerie patterns against the sunset. A soft breeze off Barnegat Bay skims along the thirsty sand and hisses through the underbrush.

title: Weekend Vacations
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lithuanian Pole
description: To the Editor:

title: The Other Side Of Publishing
description: To the Editor:

title: RESNICK PLANS TO BUILD NEAR SEAPORT
description: The New York Telephone Company has exercised an option to purchase from the city a block near the South Street Seaport in lower Manhattan for $8 million and has entered a contract to sell it to Jack Resnick & Sons for $13 million.

title: Critics' Choice; ART
description: The painterly stroke as a subject in itself has been with us since Abstract Expressionist days, and it's still the province of Joan Mitchell, one of the most admired of the so-called ''second generation'' painters of the school. At the Xavier Fourcade Gallery, 36 East 75th Street, she exhibits a group of large-scale oils and a series of high-keyed pastels, in which intense, energetic bursts of color are created by paint freely stroked yet with such discipline that it almost amounts to calligraphy.

title: Madeleine Marcouyeux to Wed
description: The engagement of Madeleine Lucienne Marcouyeux to Benjamin Francis Brown of Kampala, Uganda, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jean Guy Marcouyeux of Hilton Head Island, S.C., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin A. Brown of Idaho Falls, Idaho.

title: UNUSUAL WATCHES FIND NEW FAVOR
description: The brisk bidding at a New York watch auction on Feb. 18 surprised virtually everyone in the field, which in recent months has experienced a mild recession after a three-year boom. The auction at Sotheby Parke Bernet's York Avenue Galleries proved far more successful than anticipated, with the top quality watches outperforming all others. Indeed, one timepiece - a British, turn-of-thecentury design - became the most expensive watch ever sold at auction in this country when it was purchased by an American collector for $145,000.

title: No Headline
description: William Honan gave us thousands of words on Mr. Koch but never raised the question of why services have declined under this Mayor. Who are the people this Mayor appointed to run the city's agencies and departments? What directions or standards do they get from the Mayor? In short, Mr. Honan gave us background for the Mayor's evolution as a politician, excellent examples of his wit, but not a hint of how the Mayor does the job he's paid to do: run the city.

title: City Council Meetings Scheduled This Week
description: The following City Council meetings have been scheduled for this week: MONDAY - Committee on State Legislation, City Hall, 10 A.M. TUESDAY - Committee on Housing and Buildings, City Hall, 10 A.M. THURSDAY - Committee on General Welfare, City Hall, 10 A.M. FRIDAY - Committee on Economic Development, City Hall, 10 A.M.

title: Critics' Choice; by Gene Thornton
description: PHOTOGRAPHY New Orleans street people, neighborhood kids, dwarfs and athletes are the subjects of the handsome yet disturbing black-and-white portraits in George Dureau's first one-man show in New York at the Robert Samuel gallery, 795 Broadway between 10th and 11th Streets, through Saturday. Like Irving Penn, Dureau knows how to organize figures, background and props into compositions that are formal, even classical, without ever seeming unnatural, and he uses natural light to achieve monumental sculptural effects.

title: Rutgers 61, Pittsburgh 60
description: Roy Hinson hit a short jumper from the lane with six seconds remaining to give Rutgers a 61-60 victory over Pittsburgh today in a game that closed out the regular season for both Eastern Eight teams.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 1, 1981 International American involvement in El Salvador is opposed by a group of Democrats in the House, and they are maneuvering to dissuade the Administration from sending arms and military advisers. Nevertheless, the Democrats concede they lack the strength to block the Administration. The Democratic opposition in the Senate is overwhelmed by a fairly solid Republican majority. The Democrats' position is strikingly different from the situation in December 1975 when a Democratic majority blocked President Ford's proposals to send aid to anti-Communists in Angola. (Page 1, Column 1.)

title: THE FORMAN FORMULA
description: Terrorists have seized the Morgan Library. They have planted dynamite. The touch of a plunger will destroy the building and its precious contents. Police and troops line the streets outside. New York City is in turmoil. Coalhouse Walker Jr., the leader of the terrorists, has sent away his confederates. He holds the library alone. A man who befriended him long before has entered under a flag of truce. They sit, facing each other on gilded Renaissance thrones, while the man begs Coalhouse to give himself up.

title: ISLAMIC PEACE MISSION BEGINS MAJOR ATTEMPT TO END IRAN-IRAQ WAR
description: A high-level Islamic peace mission arrived here today in a major bid to end the five-month war between Iran and Iraq.

title: To Kill President and Junta Aides
description: The Government has uncovered a plot to assassinate President Luis Garcia Meza and his two partners in the ruling military junta, newspapers reported today.

title: No Headline
description: Bean Takes Lead in Florida on 67-197

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title:
Antiques;
PRESCOTT COLLECTION SURPRISES AUCTIONEER
description: GREENWICH FROM her early youth until the day she died at 87 last July 23, Marjorie Wiggin Prescott bought, sold and collected books, manuscripts and prints. Her early interest, inspired by her father, Albert Wiggin, a president of Chase National Bank and one of a small group of financiers credited with stabilizing the economy after the stock market crash of 1929, was nurtured by her husband, Sherbourne Prescott, who served as president of the same bank, renamed Chase Manhattan.

title: Slavery and Ideology
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics; GOVERNOR MAY ASK TO REWORK BUDGET
description: HARTFORD CONNECTICUT'S fiscal picture, which was cloudy to begin with, has become even more blurred in the past two weeks, adding to the problems facing Governor O'Neill and the General Assembly, which is now in the process of putting together a new state budget.

title: PRIVATE BUSINESS TO BE ENCOURAGED
description: China's chief economic planner announced today that the Government would sharply cut spending and closely monitor supply and demand in an effort to improve the economy.

title: Fighter Very Critical After Brain Surgery
description: Fred Bowman, knocked out in a preliminary fight on the Matthew Saad Muhammad-Vonzell Johnson card today at Bally's Park Place Hotel, was listed in very critical condition after undergoing brain surgery tonight.

title: Chess; WHEN THE BARRAGE FAILS, EXPLOIT THE ADVANTAGE
description: Defensive technique has reached such a level of competence these days that unlimbering the 16-inch guns of a powerful mating attack leads not to a quick victory but only to a small leak in the enemy's ship - a leak that must be carefully exploited to end in victory.

title: Westchester Housing; 'MEETING' CONDOMINIUM NEIGHBORS
description: ''WHEN my parents moved to our old neighborhood, they got to know people when they were all wheeling baby carriages up and down the street,'' said Donna Lyons of Rye.

title: TRYING TO STOP THE FLIGHT FROM SHLITZ
description: MILWAUKEE S HORTLY after Frank J. Sellinger went to work at the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company in November 1977, he faced the first in a long list of problems.

title: SAUCE BY THE GALLON, HERBS BY THE POUND
description: OCEANSIDE ''THE mood of the people today is to buy something that says 'Not for Retail' because they think it's a bargain -it's like beating the system,'' said Mitch Nagler, owner of High Bar Wholesale Foods in Oceanside. ''For the most part it's true - they do save money,'' he added.

title: ANN LOWE, 82, DESIGNED GOWNS FOR EXCLUSIVE CLIENTELE IN SOCIETY
description: Ann Lowe, who designed gowns for debutantes and society brides, including the gown Jacqueline Bouvier wore when she married Senator John F. Kennedy, died last Wednesday after a long illness in the Queens home of her daughter, where she had lived for the last five years. She was 82 years old.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS IN BUFFALO FIGHTING TO SAVE A MEMORIAL
description: The Federal Government and a group of Vietnam veterans have become involved in a confrontation over a chunk of granite that the veterans installed in the lawn of the Federal building in downtown Buffalo as the pedestal for a war memorial they hope to erect.

title: SENATORS SEEK CURB ON UNION OFFICIALS
description: Two Senators said today that six days of hearings on waterfront corruption had shown the need for a law permitting the Government to remove any union official as soon as he was convicted of a serious crime.

title: CONSUMER PRICE INFLATION SHOWS
description: Consumer prices increased at a slower pace. The Government's index showed a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent in January, an 8.4 percent annual increase and the smallest rise since last July. An easing in the rise of food and housing prices accounted for much of the slowdown.

title: TABLE OF CONTENTS MARCH 1, 1981
description: NONFICTION CRIME, DETECTIVE, ESPIONAGE, MYSTERY, AND THRILLER FICTION & FILM: A Comprehensive Bibliography of Critical Writing Through 1979. Compiled by David Skene Melvin and Ann Skene Melvin..........26 THE EXPANDING CIRCLE: Ethics and Sociobiololgy.

title: IS PAYING PLAYERS THE ANSWER?
description: To the Sports Editor: The introduction of Nebraska State Senator Ernie Chamber's bill, which supports the legal payment of college football players ("A Nebraska Legislator's Proposal! Pay the Players." The New York Times Feb. 22), ignores the most serious college sports problem, namely the deleterious academic consequences of intercollegiate sports participation.

title: HOURS AND PRODUCTIVITY
description: Explanations for America's declining rate of productivity growth may be rooted in sources other than aging plant and equipment and inadequate quality control.

title: Notes; SUMMER CAMP WITH MUSIC
description: Summer may seem a long way off, but it is not too soon to start thinking about going to a summer music camp. The American Music Conference, 1000 Skokie Boulevard, Wilmette, Ill. 60091, estimates that there are about 300 camps and summer music sessions in the United States and some foreign countries. Although the largest proportion of campers are high school students between 14 and 18, the camps are not just for children, says the conference. Among the campers are young adults, parents and grandparents, about 90,000 music lovers altogether attending annually.

title: BEING SQUEEZED BY ASSESSMENTS? SOME RECOURSES
description: Clarence Miller, a former high school teacher, lives in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, in a modest stucco house he bought five years ago for $28,000 and that he estimates has a present market value of not more than $35,000.

title: MAGIC WEAVES LAKER VICTORY
description: The plan had been carefully constructed for weeks. When the doctors looked at Earvin Johnson's surgical left knee and decided he could return to the Los Angeles Lakers Feb. 20, Jerry Buss, who owns Johnson's smile and his knee, looked at the schedule and decided to wait another seven days.

title: Census Gets a Fix On Black Population
description: The Census Bureau last year said it would attempt to determine more precisely than ever before the racial and ethnic subdivisions of the ''one nation...indivisible.'' Last week, the bureau reported that the effort had produced reasonably reliable figures on only one group.

title: Jean Smith Fiancee Of Timothy Straus
description: Mr. and Mrs. James F. Smith of Atlanta have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jean Allison Smith, to Timothy A. Straus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Straus of New York.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title:
Art;
TWO NEWARK ART DEALERS REMEMBERED AT KEAN
description: THE careers of Nathan Krueger and Bernard Rabin, art dealers in Newark for almost 40 years, are examined in a very unusual and interesting exhibition at the Kean College Art Gallery in Union. It is titled simply, ''Rabin & Krueger Gallery, 1935-1974: Reconstructed.''

title: New Delhi Suspends Legislature In Manipur After Party Stalemate
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government has suspended the legislature in Manipur State and imposed central rule in the region following the collapse of her party's government there.

title: JOTTINGS ON THE HILL
description: ROLL CALL One Year in the United States Senate. By Senator William S. Cohen. 344 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: LARCHMONT GROWING AS HOME TO FRENCH
description: LARCHMONT IN August 1978, Remy Caillaux and his wife, Claudia, arrived in New York City, checked into the Regency Hotel, and spent the next hot and humid few days looking for an apartment.

title: INFLATION AND FLOATING-RATE NOTES
description: T HE bond market has been a painful place for investors in the last two years as soaring interest rates chopped a fourth or more off the value of fixed-rate bonds. As the single-digit bond yields of the 1970's were overtaken by double-digit inflation, many bondholders fled the market entirely.

title: KENTY SIGNS FOR BOUT
description: Hilmer Kenty, the World Boxing Association lightweight champion, has signed a contract to fight Sean O'Grady, the World Boxing Association's top-ranked contender. The bout is scheduled for April 12. O'Grady, who lives in Oklahoma City, said he would get the chance at the championship only if he beats Jose Cabrera here March 17.

title: MUSIC: UNDERSTATED MAHLER
description: Mahler's Seventh Symphony is the composer's stepchild, a rarity even in this day and age, when scarcely a week seems to pass without a Mahler symphony turning up in a New York concert hall. And a strange work it is, as one could tell even from the rather understated performance the Seventh received from the New York Philharmonic led by Rafael Kubelik Thursday night in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: WYOMING TOPS UTAH, 53-50, STAYS IN CONTENTION IN W.A.C.
description: Charlie Bradley and Ken Ollie sank two foul shots each in the last minute today, enabling Wyoming to upset Utah, 53-50, and keep in contention for the Western Athletic Conference title.

title: Signs and Portents; Of Budget Struggle
description: The big battles are yet to be fought, but last week President Reagan won two modest victories in his declared war on Government bloat.

title: GLITTERY ALBUMS BY DIAMOND AND MANILOW
description: The latest albums by Neil Diamond and Barry Manilow, ultra-popular purveyors of pop schmaltz, are typically glittery products with mass appeal. Mr. Diamond's soundtrack for his first starring movie, ''The Jazz Singer'' (Capitol SWAV-12120) is an expansive score that uses two orchestras, a choir and a rock band. The project embodies the contradictory ambitions that have plagued Mr. Diamond ever since he grew from a successful pop tunesmith into a superstar entertainer with artistic pretensions.

title: CANADIENS ARE RISING AGAIN
description: MONTREAL A MONTH ago, it wasn't quite inevitable. It appeared the surge the Montreal Canadiens make nearly every year toward another Stanley Cup might not occur.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Feb. 15 on the proposed right-to-life amendment erroneously attributed a quotation.

title: Crime; by Newgate Callendar
description: Emma Lathen's John Putnam Thatcher is a New York banker, and Joe L. Hensley's Don Robak is an Indianapolis lawyer, but they have one thing in common. They get mixed up with murder, and they both have to act as private eyes. The Lathen series is the older and much better known of the two. Mary J. Latsis and Martha Henissart have been writing Thatcher mysteries, under the name of Emma Lathen, since 1961. Mr. Hensley, a lawyer and now a judge in Indiana, started his Don Robak series in 1971.

title: U.S. SALES OF SPORTING GOODS LAG
description: While the number of Americans participating in one sport or another remains high, the battle for consumers' discretionary income is getting tougher for manufacturers of sporting goods.

title: Sound; ARE LIGHT DISPLAYS ESSENTIAL TO AUDIO?; by Hans Fantel
description: W ith arrays of colored lights flashing on their face plates, some recent sound components look like pinball machines in a penny arcade. Ostensibly, all those lights convey information about the working of the equipment, but one suspects that the mode of display was chosen for other than functional reasons. After all, the information might have been conveyed less flamboyantly.

title: MORTGAGE INSURERS OPPOSE FEDERAL RIVALS
description: Following a year in which record high interest rates helped to reduce substantially the level of home-building in the United States, the private mortgage insurance industry is stepping up its efforts to eliminate competition from Federal agencies in insuring unsubsidized mortgages.

title: School Guidelines From 4 Decades Ago
description: I would agree with Dr. Lubus that innovation for innovation's sake, very prevalent in the 60's and 70's, did little to raise the level of pupil achievement. However, I feel he is looking at the wrong causes for our present state. He's concerned about the six-hour, fragmented day during which children not only have to handle arithmetic, reading, language arts, social studies, and science, but also art, gym, music, recess, lunch, assemblies, educational television, field trips, library, health instruction and band. He calls upon educational leaders and curriculum specialists to formulate guidelines to govern what we want children to learn and to know. Do we really need a curriculum specialist to tell us what we want our children to learn?

title: DEBATE OPENS IN CONNECTICUT OVER CASINO PROPOSAL
description: Connecticut, which already has a state lottery, offtrack betting, jai alai and a dogracing track, is taking its first wary look at the idea of casino gambling in Bridgeport.

title: Tax Cuts
description: To the Business Editor: In ''Tax Cuts: First, Business Wants Fast Depreciation'' (Feb. 1), Edward Cowan brings to light the current list of strategies open to Congress and President Reagan for providing relief from both business and personal income taxes. The solutions seem to focus on first, increased capital cost recovery (by way of faster depreciation schedules) and second, preferences for interest and dividend income (by larger exemptions for these items).

title: WOMEN AND SCHOOLS: SOME BRIGHT SIGNS CAN BE SEEN
description: DISCRIMINATION against women in public education in New Jersey seems to have continued unabated over the last 10 years. Many educators cite declining enrollments as a factor; others suggest that the commitment to affirmative action has been insufficient.

title: COUPLE RETURN TO REV UP FOR THE WORLD OF AUTO RACING
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON TWO years ago, after having attracted nationwide attention with his successes in both amateur and professional sports car racing, Tony Cicale, a native Long Islander, received a lucrative job offer from a prominent California race team to serve as its technical adviser and chief engineer. Mr. Cicale accepted, and he and Janis Champion - pit crew and general manager of their own racing operation - packed their belongings and headed West.

title: ONE-ROOM SCHOOL HANGS ON IN SUBURBAN CHICAGO
description: Snow swirled around the McAuley School here, frosting a dozen children, two-thirds of the enrollment, who were playing tag at recess, and, for a moment, obscuring the one-room school's unlikely site in the midst of suburban Chicago.

title: In Global Context, Reagan Tries a New Gambit in Mideast
description: As in El Salvador, the Reagan Administration last week inserted its Middle East diplomacy into the larger context of the East-West struggle. Seeking to improve ties with anti-Soviet Saudi Arabia, it lobbied on Capitol Hill for approval to sell fuel, tanks and other equipment to Riyadh to enhance the range and firepower of 62 F-15 jet fighters purchased by the Saudis since 1978.

title: L.I.U. 81, Hofstra 80
description: Earl Fuller scored on a jump shot from the top of the key with five seconds left, giving Long Island University a 81-80 victory over Hofstra today.

title: No Headline
description: I think it is important to correct William Honan's description of Caryl Chessman as a ''convicted rapist and murderer.''

title: FIVE RURAL DISTRICTS ADD CLASS IN DANCE
description: FOR the next seven weeks, dance instructors sponsored by federally funded Artists-in-the-Schools program will be teaching and performing in the elementary school classrooms of five communities in the northeastern part of the state, Putnam, Pomfret Thompson, Eastford and Woodstock

title: Connecticut Guide; by Eleanor Charles; MEXICAN TOY EXHIBIT
description: There is more to Mexican toys than the pinata - a frilled paper donkey that children break open with sticks to get at the prizes inside. From 2 to 5 P.M. today the Brookfield Craft Center will sponsor an open house for a new exhibit of Mexican folk toys, crafted between 1930 and 1977 and collected over a 10-year period by Robert Pettit, a photographer, and his wife, Florence Pettit, a fiber artist.

title: WHAT NEXT? DEMOCRATS SEEK A WAY TO REBOUND
description: WASHINGTON CHARLES T. Manatt, elected last week as the new Democratic national chairman, will lead a party that is in trouble, and for more reasons than there were serious candidates for the chairmanship. It is yet to be seen whether the Democrats after 1980 will be comparable to the Republicans after 1964, the Republicans after 1952 - or the Whigs after 1852.

title: Brett in Hospital for Surgery
description: George Brett, the American League's most valuable player last season, was admitted to a Kansas City hospital early today and underwent surgery for removal of hemorrhoids, a spokesman for the Kansas City Royals said.

title: CHINA'S ARMY FOLOWS NEW MARCHING ORDERS, NOT HAPPILY
description: Lei Feng was not exactly the Sergeant York of the People's Liberation Army when, on March 5, 1963, Mao Zedong eulogized him a ''hero-soldier'' worthy of emulation and thereby turned the enlisted peasant into one of China's most famous nobodys.

title: BASS RIVER MAYOR SEEKS PERSKIE'S SEAT
description: SPOKEN, somewhat shy transplanted Texas Republican is quietly exploring the possibility of opposing State Senator Steven P. Perskie for his Second District seat this fall.

title: AIR CONTROLLER IN 'NEAR MISS' IS STILL FEELING SHOCK
description: year-old air traffic controller whose radio warning diverted an Argentine jetliner from a course headed toward the World Trade Center in downtown Manhattan a week ago, said today that he still had not got over the shock of the incident.

title: DIANE SPIEGEL TO BE BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Spiegel of Springfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Spiegel, to Dr. Gregory Belok of New York. The future bride is a social worker at the Daughters of Israel, Pleasant Valley Home in West Orange, N.J.

title: Northwestern 69, Ohio State 64
description: Rob Roberson hit two free throws with eight seconds remaining tonight and lifted Northwestern to a 69-64 upset of Ohio State. It was the Wildcats' first Big Ten basketball victory over the Buckeyes in four years.

title: Emily C. DiMaggio, Christopher Gates, I.B.M. Aide, Wed
description: In St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Wellesley, Mass., yesterday evening, Emily Collette DiMaggio, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dominic Paul DiMaggio of Boston and Marion, Mass., became the bride of Christopher Clark Gates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Clark Gates of Milwaukee. Msgr. Russell A. Davis performed the ceremony and the Rev. Robert L. Griesse of the Lutheran Church of Newton, Mass., participated in the service.

title: The Problems Of Youth Programs
description: I was very impressed with the growth of youth projects in Pleasantville as reported in the article by Lynne Ames (''Youth Projects Grow in Pleasantville,'' Feb. 8).

title: THE REGIONAL PROSPECT IS ALL CLOUD AND NO SILVER LNING
description: HARTFORD SO far this winter, the price of oil has jumped 30 percent, gas and electricity have gone up by smaller amounts, and 55,000 Connecticut residents have found they can't afford to keep warm. So they have come to the state for a share of the $39.8 million available for fuel aid.

title: Careful Shopper; by Jeanne Clare Feron; Extra Markdowns At Danbury Outlet
description: Shoppers have become used to the Grand Fashion Outlet in Danbury in the last 10 years. They expect to find a limited range of sportswear discounted by one-third or more at a location open only three days a week and the first Saturday of each month. Until mid-March there is an extra markdown of 20 percent on fall and winter items.

title: Education Is More Than the '3R's'
description: Norman S. Lubus needs to be taught ''How Do Our Children Learn?'' (Feb. 1) lest his inquiry influence others. When asked what gave him the inner support for survival, one of our 52 former hostages recently stated he was sure our American educational system was at its root. It gave him the flexibility to withstand changing circumstances and environment. If Dr. Lubus thinks the hostage meant reading, writing and arithmetic, he is mistaken. It is precisely the areas Dr. Lubus castigates as timeconsuming - art, music and physical training - that foster and stimulate the imagination and should be catalysts to the incorporation of all education into the totality of a human being.

title: LISTENING TO SALIERI AND LEARNING ABOUT MOZART
description: Only two unimportant works by Antonio Salieri are listed in the current Schwann Catalogue. But that does not mean the music of Salieri is entirely unobtainable on records. The enterprising musiclover can investigate import companies, such as International Book and Record Distributors (40-11 24th Street, Long Island City, N.Y. 11101). There he will be able to purchase two disks of Salieri's music, one containing the Piano Concertos in B flat and C, played by Aldo Ciccolini and the Solisti Veneti conducted by Claudio Scimone (Italia ITL 70028) and the other containing the ''Sinfonia Veneziana,'' the Sinfonia ''Il Giorno Onomastico,'' and the ''Variazioni sull'aria La Follia di Spagna,'' with the London Symphony under Zoltan Pesko (Italia ITL 70052).

title: KNICKS LOSE TO BULLS BY 101-97
description: The Knicks held pregame ceremonies last night at Madison Square Garden honoring Red Holzman's 1,000th game as the New York coach. There was a gift from the team and a speech by Ray Williams, the Knicks' captain. But the gift Holzman really wanted, his 655th victory as the Knicks' coach, was not forthcoming. Instead, Holzman wound up with his 549th loss as the Knicks were beaten by the Chicago Bulls, 101-97.

title: The Pannonia Express
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW HOLLYWOOD HAS PORTRAYED HISPANICS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allen Woll, an associate professor of history at Rutgers University in Camden, is the author of ''The Latin Image in American Film.'' By ALLEN WOLL

title: Judy Robbins to Be Married To Christos Christodoulides
description: Helen Robbins of Pequannock, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Judy Robbins, to Christos Christodoulides of Athens, press counselor of the Greek Mission to the United Nations.

title: 5 L.I. HOMEOWNERS ORDERED TO VACATE
description: A state appellate court has ordered the owners of five homes in Selden, L.I., to move out and turn their houses over to the estate of a Brooklyn woman after the court found that the houses had been built illegally on her land more than a decade ago.

title: CHERRY HILL TRACK ON THE MARKET AGAIN
description: THE Garden State Park race track, whose grandstand and clubhouse burned down almost four years ago, is for sale again, and John Nero, a controversial businessman, wants to buy and restore it.

title: TV View; MORE MILEAGE FROM AN OLYMPICS VICTORY; by John J.O'Connor
description: Tonight's ''Miracle on Ice,'' a three-hour television movie on ABC beginning at 8, is something of a model of merchandising. A little more than a year after the United States Olympic hockey team won the gold medal at Lake Placid, the stunning victory has been repackaged in a dramatization that manages to capture a good deal of the excitement of the original event. At the time, the developing hockey story gave ABC Sports precisely the kind of special angle that builds record audience ratings, and it is hardly an accident that the same network is trying to capitalize on the same event once again. A good story is a good story is a good story.

title: LAWYER FOR THEATER PERSONALITIES
description: L. Arnold Weissberger, a theatrical lawyer with an international clientele, died Friday night at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan of an embolism in the lungs, three days after returning from a vacation in Acapulco, Mexico. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: STRICTER RULES ON CO-OPS ARE PROPOSED BY ABRAMS
description: Twenty changes in cooperative conversion laws that would give greater protection to tenants whose buildings are converted from rentals were proposed yesterday by Robert Abrams, the New York State Attorney General. He said the changes were needed to ''equalize the bargaining power between tenants and landlords.''

title: LATEST BUDGET CUTS TO AFFECT FARMERS AND JOBS PROGRAMS
description: The new budget cuts that President Reagan approved yesterday would fall heavily on farmers and training for the unemployed, White House officials said today.

title: A MOTHER-AND-CHILD SHARING OF LEARNING AND FUN
description: IT is about this time of the year, after months of being indoors, that women with small children start to feel a little ''stir crazy,'' as one mother of a 17-month-old put it. ''I'm into motherhood, right now,'' said another, ''but if I don't get out of the house, I'll go out of my mind.''

title: Janet M. D'Angelo, Ph.D. Student, Wed
description: Janet Madeline D'Angelo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Robert D'Angelo of Cresskill, N.J., was married there yesterday to Robert Francis Siliciano, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Victor Siliciano of Elmira, N.Y. The Rev. Kenneth Moore performed the ceremony in St. Therese Roman Catholic Church.

title: HENDERSON TRADED TO CUBS
description: The New York Mets ended their long search for a power hitter tonight when they traded Steve Henderson to the Chicago Cubs for Dave Kingman, three and a half years after they had traded Kingman in a contract dispute.

title: BASQUE GUERRILLA FACTION DECLARES A TRUCE
description: In reaction to this week's unsuccessful military coup, the @''political-military'' branch of the Basque separatist organization E.T.A. declared an ''unconditional cease-fire'' today in the northern region and freed three honorary consuls that it had held captive for eight days.

title: REAGAN AND THE OIL FIELDS
description: At some point fairly soon, the Reagan Administration will have to explain to Congress its strategy for dealing with the Soviets in the area between the Mediterranean and the Indian Ocean.

title: Anne White Sets Wedding on Oct. 10
description: Mr. and Mrs. Loomis L. White of Jacksonville, Fla., formerly of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Tiffany White of Washington, to Thomas Lee Oberdorfer, son of District Court Judge Louis F. Oberdorfer and Mrs. Oberdorfer of McLean, Va.

title: THE ART OF BUSINESS
description: GREENWICH BUSINESS has been buying art for a very long time - since the 15th century, if you count the Medicis, as corporate collectors are fond of doing. But the present surge in commercial patronage, which parallels the boom in art education, began in the 1950's. By 1960, the Whitney Museum was able to muster for its show ''Business Buys American Art'' no less than 58 companies owning works by artists as prestigious as Noguchi, Calder and Hopper, as well as several firstgeneration Abstract Expressionists.

title: Polish Leadership; Still on Probation
description: In Poland, ''the pillars of the socialist state are in jeopardy,'' Leonid I. Brezhnev warned last week, but he indicated he wasn't ready yet to order Warsaw Pact troops to prop them up. ''The Polish comrades are redressing the critical situation,'' Mr. Brezhnev assured the 26th Soviet Communist Party Congress in Moscow.

title: Man Tied to Point-Shaving Pleads Guilty in Drug Case
description: Paul Mazzei of Pittsburgh pleaded guilty yesterday to a reduced charge of fourth-degree conspiracy for involvement in a $1.5 million Long Island drug ring. Mazzei, a 37-year-old dog groomer, had been charged with two counts of seconddegree conspiracy but pleaded to the reduced charges before Judge Edward Baker of the Nassau County Court.

title: FINDINGS ON THE FOUNDERS
description: EXPLAINING AMERICA: THE FEDERALIST By Garry Wills. 286 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95.

title: WHEN RAINS COME, SO MAY EXPLOSIONS
description: ON rainy days, Isabel Patrick and Ellen Markowski worry that high concentrations of methane seeping beneath their houses may trigger an explosion. They say the nontoxic but highly volatile gas has already touched off two minor blasts in Mrs. Patrick's house and one in Mrs. Markowski's.

title: Army to Study Its Commissaries
description: The Army will study all of its 72 commissaries in the United States over the next four years to determine whether they should be converted to operations by commercial contract, the Army announced yesterday. Commissaries overseas will be excluded from these studies.

title: SOME GUIDANCE FOR HOMEOWNER
description: Nontraditional living arrangements are becoming increasingly more commonplace and are raising a host of new tax considerations for the homeowners.

title: CBS OFFICIAL TO DECIDE ON REPORT ON HAITI WALLACE SOUGHT TO KILL
description: The executive producer of the CBS News program ''60 Minutes'' says he will decide today or tomorrow whether to assign and produce a story on Haiti that the correspondent Mike Wallace had asked a colleague, Morley Safer, not to do, apparently for personal reasons.

title: Milwaukee Firefighters Vote To Authorize A Walkout
description: City officials and representatives of the firefighters' union began intense negotiations today in an effort to reach agreement on a new contract before a midnight strike deadline.

title: 'PRESUMED INNOCENCE IS NOT PROVED INNOCENCE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Joan Strashinsky Bride of Alan L. Kjelleren
description: Holy Trinity Russian Orthodox Church in East Meadow, L.I., was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Joan Ann Strashinsky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Strashinsky of Uniondale, L.I., to Alan Lee Kjelleren, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Alfred Kjelleren of Baldwin, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard Tinker.

title: Pilgrim in Asia; Returns to Rome
description: The character of his message changed last week as Pope John Paul II moved from overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Philippines to Japan, with only 400,000 Catholics in a population of 117 million. Speaking less often of traditional Catholic moral matters, he stressed a message of peace.

title: Across the Border
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW THE DICKENS DID IT END?
description: THE MYSTERY OF EDWIN DROOD By Charles Dickens. Concluded by Leon Garfield. 352 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $12.95.

title: Laura Cannamela Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Cannamela of Metuchen, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Laura Jean Cannamela, to James T. Costello, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Costello of Niagara Falls, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Clippers 104, Rockets 103
description: Swen Nater had 22 points and 14 rebounds as San Diego ended Houston's five-game winning streak.

title: NO END IN SIGHT TO STRUGGLE OVER WESTERN SAHARA
description: The conflict between Morocco and the Polisario Front for control of the Western Sahara has entered its sixth year with no immediate prospects for a peaceful settlement.

title: 3 DIE IN A MARYLAND HOUSE FIRE
description: An early morning fire destroyed a town house and damaged two adjacent homes today, killing a 3-month-old girl and her parents, the Baltimore County police said. The police identified the victims as Charles R. Holmes, 30 years old; his wife, Elaine, 26, and their daughter, Brandy.

title: SHE'S FREE NOW - EXCEPT...
description: HOUSEWORK! Every woman's burden, but also Everywoman's duty. There comes that time when she must confront that which she has been avoiding. There's work to be done, and no matter how much she tries to avoid it, it will not go away.

title:
Gardening;
ORCHID NOT JUST A HOTHOUSE FLOWER
description: IF you were asked to name the most exotic of all flowers, you would probably respond ''the orchids.'' Fortunes have been spent collecting new species from tropical jungles, and romantic novelists have woven their plots around the mythical black orchid, which doesn't exist. However, there are enough gorgeous blooms in this family to more than compensate for this particular deficiency.

title: SOME COMRADES QUESTION SOVIET POLICY
description: Discord among West European Communist parties has cast the only shadow across the preordained Marxist-Leninist harmony of the 26th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party, which completed its first week today.

title: Jennifer Shatkin Fiancee Of Dr. Frederic R. Gross
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Shatkin of Rego Park, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Beth Shatkin, to Dr. Frederic Richard Gross, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gross of New York, and Livingston Manor, N.Y.

title: Art View; A DASH OF MARIN AT THE MET; by Hilton Kramer
description: Without fanfare or a catalogue or even the faintest attempt at any advance warning, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has mounted a very appealing exhibition of the work of the American painter John Marin (1870-1953). Organized by Lowery Sims, associate curator of 20th-century art at the Met, the show seems to have slipped into the museum's Harry Payne Bingham Galleries a few weeks ago while nobody was looking, and at this writing, it is scheduled to come down two weeks from today. (The Bingham Galleries are located just to the right inside the gallery at the top of the main stairway.) This writer stumbled upon the show while visiting the museum on another mission - which is, I suppose, how a few others have also found it. All in all, a very odd way for a great museum to treat an artist of Marin's quality.

title: Connecticut Housing; HOUSING MARKET REGISTERS UPSWING
description: WHEN Betty and Vaughn Darnell placed their $129,000 split-level home in Wilton on the market at the end of January, they so doubted that they would be able to find a buyer that they listed it as being for sale or rent.

title:
Gardening;
FOR GREENER GRASS ON THIS SIDE OF FENCE
description: TO some a lawn is a cursed thing, with its never-ending problems of crab grass, thatch and dandelions; to others it may be viewed as a challenge - a battle against foes that, unlike competing business associates and cantankerous clients, never talk back. Armed with sprayers, spreaders, aerators and bags of fertilizer and chemicals, the latter march forth each weekend to do battle with enthusiasm and vigor. The former either hire a lawn maintenance service to do battle for them, or sell their suburban houses and move into condominiums.

title: SYMPOSIUM AT SKIDMORE
description: READERS of old Partisan Reviews will recall those symposia in which intellectuals tried to figure out where they stood. During the late 1930's, the issues they debated were Communism, the Depression, the impending war. In ''The Situation of American Writing,'' published in 1939, they addressed themselves to the question of their role in American life: Was there ''any place in our present economic system for literature as a profession?'' Was there a ''usable past?'' By 1952, however, ''for better or worse, most writers no longer accept alienation as the artist's fate in America,'' declared the editors, introducing a symposium on ''Our Country and Our Culture.'' ''On the contrary, they want very much to be a part of American life.''

title: NEEDIEST CASES FUND CLOSES 69TH APPEAL
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended its 69th annual appeal yesterday having received a total of $1,265,351.87 from 10,008 contributors.

title: Kremlin Seeks Early Summit, but It's Too Soon for Reagan
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev last week answered the Reagan Administration's challenge to play diplomatic hard ball with a floater pitch. During a three-hour speech at the Communist Party congress in Moscow, the Soviet leader proposed a meeting with President Reagan and offered conciliatory-sounding suggestions on nuclear weapons negotiations, arms control measures in Europe and submarine-launched missiles.

title: Tanner, Mayer Advance to Final
description: Roscoe Tanner routed Tom Gullikson, 6-1, 6-0, and Gene Mayer ousted Yannick Noah of France today, 7-6, 6-0, to advance to the final of the $200,000 United States Indoor National tennis championships.

title: Caribbean Cruise
description: To the Editor:

title: Monica Hogan Is Wed to William Mullin 3d
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola yesterday, Monica Hogan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Hogan of Bethesda, Md., was married to William J. Mullin 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mullin Jr. of Westwood, N.J. The Rev. John McConnell performed the ceremony.

title: MASS TRANSIT IS AN ALL-AMERICAN PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: North Pole Camping
description: The world record for a stay at the North Pole was 28 hours when David Porter, a television engineer of Hope, N.J., said in early 1980 that he would lead a party of 12 on a four-day campout there. The group planned to stay in tents insulated against the cold, which averages 40 degrees below zero.

title: More Pandaring
description: We mused a few days ago about how Ling-Ling of Washington, D.C., would be able to tell that Chia-Chia, her new mate being flown in from the London Zoo, was not Hsing-Hsing, her hitherto rejected suitor. We still don't know.

title: 20 Years for a $1.38 Murder
description: A 21-year-old man who robbed and murdered an elderly man for the $1.38 he was carrying has been sentenced to 20 years in prison.

title: PIONEER IN CARE FOR DYING WINS TEMPLETON PRIZE
description: Dr. Cicely Saunders, a British medical doctor who started an international movement for improved care for dying people and their families, has been named winner of the $220,000 Templeton Prize for ''progress in religion.'' The award will be formally made by Prince Philip in May.

title: Children's Books
description: SOUP ON WHEELS By Robert Newton Peck. Illustrated by Charles Robinson. 101 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $6.95. (Ages 9 to 12) By DON LESSEM

title: ALL GENERIC DRUG MAKERS HELD LIABLE IN DES SUIT
description: A state appeals court ruled last week that a consumer harmed by a generic drug could sue a drug manufacturer for damages even though it could not be established that any particular company had made the drug that caused the injury.

title:
On the Isle;
PARRISH REOPENING
description: All spick-and-span after being closed two months for renovations, the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton opens today with "Alive at the Parrish," a group exhibition featuring the works of contemporary articts represented in the museum's permanent collection. With paintings, drawings, prints and photographs by such local artists as John MacWhinnie, Paul Georges, James Brooks, Larry Rivers and Hans Namuth, as well as such other Americans as John Opper, Lowell Nesbitt, Jim Dine and Red Grooms, the exhibition will run through May 17 and can be seen at the Parrish, 25 Job's Lane from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays and from 1 to 5 P.M. weekends.TREE WALK

title: FUEL AID: A LOOK AT GOVERNMENT GROWTH
description: THE rapid growth and increasing costs of emergency home energy programs, designed to help people cope with the vagaries of winter on the Island, illustrate how governmental programs tend to mushroom from year to year.

title: PRINCETON TO INTRODUCE COURSES ON ROLE OF WOMEN IN SOCIETY
description: After 11 years of coeducation and lengthy debate among students and faculty, Princeton University will begin a formal women's studies program next fall, for the first time allowing students to study women's roles in society through a variety of academic disciplines.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; OVID DEMARIS
description: Whoever said crime doesn't pay has never spoken to Ovid Demaris, author of a new bestseller, ''The Last Mafioso'' (Times Books). ''I'm the only man still alive who has written three best sellers on the mob,'' he said with a nervous laugh from his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. ''I'm making more money out of the mob than they're making.''

title: Susan Jones Is Married to James R. Scala
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest yesterday, Susan Langford Jones, a consumer economist with the CBS-TV, was married to James Robert Scala, an associate with the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett. The Rev. Stephen Rodgers performed the ceremony.

title: Penn 83, Harvard 70
description: Angelo Reynolds scored 19 points and George Noon 17 to lead Pennsylvania to an 83-70 victory over Harvard tonight as the Quakers retained a share of first place in the Ivy League.

title: Brademas Agrees He's a 'Natural' For N.Y.U.Job
description: He was a valedictorian in high school, a Phi Beta Kappa at Harvard and a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford, where he earned a Ph.D. in social studies. At St. Mary's College in South Bend, Ind., he was an assistant professor of political science.

title: SYNANON MEMBERS ACCUSED IN BEATING
description: Seventeen members and former members of Synanon, the drug-rehabilitation organization turned religious cult, face charges of kidnapping and assault growing out of the alleged beating of a former member suspected of disloyalty.

title: Music; 3 CHORALE GROUPS OPEN SPRING SEASON
description: IT usually takes choirs, large or small, several months to recover from their musical revels at Christmastide before they can prepare a repertory for their spring outings. Well, March has arrived, and with it three notable concerts: today's performance of the Mozart C Minor Mass by the Craven Singers, a very interesting mixed program on Saturday by the Fairfield County Chorale and an unexpected foray into 17th-century opera by the Pro Arte Chamber Singers next Sunday. Add to those events a couple of lute-song recitals by Richard Ullman and Robert Puleo and you have a veritable feast of music for the voice.

title: LAOTIANS IN A NEW LAND
description: Mike Norman is a writer based in Lawrenceville, N.J. By Mike Norman The Sithavadys are here. The Laotian family arrived at 2 A.M. on Feb. 29, the coldest day of the winter, but their apartment in the Robert Lee (formerly Lawson) House is cozy and warm. - The Lyme Church News, Lyme, N.H., March 1980. One winter has passed and another is almost spent, but still she cannot seem to bear the chill from the frozen road beneath her feet. On this particular raw and frigid afternoon, Paphanh Sithavady is on her way to pick up some groceries. She walks quickly. Her arms are clutched to her chest and her neck is drawn down into her jacket, as if she were trying to take refuge inside herself.

title: REAGAN'S BENEFACTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Recordings; LISTENING TO SALIERI AND LEARNING ABOUT MOZART
description: Only two unimportant works by Antonio Salieri are listed in the current Schwann Catalogue. But that does not mean the music of Salieri is entirely unobtainable on records. The enterprising music-lover can investigate import companies, such as International Book and Record Distributors (40-11 24th Street, Long Island City, N.Y. 11101). There he will be able to purchase two disks of Salieri's music, one containing the Piano Concertos in B flat and C, played by Aldo Ciccolini and the Solisti Veneti conducted by Claudio Scimone (Italia ITL 70028) and the other containing the ''Sinfonia Veneziana,'' the Sinfonia ''Il Giorno Onomastico,'' and the ''Variazioni sull'aria La Follia di Spagna,'' with the London Symphony under Zoltan Pesko (Italia ITL 70052).

title: Greek Government Is Urged To Quit Over Nuclear Issue
description: The major opposition party in Greece called on the Government today to resign after news reports that nuclear warheads were being stored in Greece under the exclusive control of the United States. The charges, which the Government has not directly denied, come at a delicate point in Greek affairs, both because of the forthcoming general election and the current Washinton-Athens negotiations on the American bases here.

title: WHAT PRICE DEVELOPMENT?
description: DICK CREMA and Don Maxwell are two strong men among the many who make their living by digging shellfish from the bottom of the Great Bay. The bay, whose pristine waters lie inside the barrier islands of New Jersey, is north, but within sight, of Atlantic City.

title: Katherine Swenson to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Roy Swenson of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Ann Swenson, to Thomas Louis Chapman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Chapman of Pine Beach, N.J. Miss Swenson teaches English and her fiance history at the Pinelands Regional High School in Tuckerton, N.J. They will be married in June.

title: RESERVOIR PLAN PROTESTS SURPRISE PLANNERS
description: TWO members of the state's Commission on Capital Budgeting and Planning said last week that they were unaware of environmental objections to the Manasquan River reservoir project and that the commission itself had no specific objections to the proposal.

title: Connecticut Educator Is Named University of Nevada's Chancellor
description: Robert M. Bersi, president of Western Connecticut State College, had been chosen chancellor of the University of Nevada system.

title: Saving Turtles
description: Engaged in a project at Michoachan, Mexico, to save the green turtle from extinction, the World Wildlife Fund in Washington learned that the problem was bigger than merely keeping the turtle from soup pots. The turtle's eggs were a delicacy in Mexico.

title: Katherine Mitchell, George Williams 3d Wed in Greenwich
description: Katherine Fontaine Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Harold Mitchell Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to George Cabell Williams 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md. The ceremony was performed in Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich by the Rev. Edward A.M. Cobden Jr., assisted by the Rev. Charles Sheerin of Charlottesville, Va.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson 94 St. Francis 84
description: Ken Webb scored 29 points in the final game of his collegiate career tonight, leading Fairleigh Dickinson to a 94-84 victory over St. Francis of New York.

title: No Headline
description: I agree that Mayor Koch is one of the most popular elected officials in our country. However, if the Mayor is doing a good job and is liked by the people of New York City, why is he trying so hard to placate Republican Party leaders into endorsing him for reelection so that he'll run unopposed?

title: Work Begins at Derailment Site
description: Workers today began to right about 50 cars of a Chessie System train, including one that spilled hydrochloric acid, after a derailment that forced the evacuation of nearly 200 nearby residents yesterday, the state police said.

title: ON TV AT 19, HE LEAVES THEM LAUGHING
description: EDDIE MURPHY's comedy career seems to have been unaffected by the law bearing his surname, which states that if anything can go wrong, it will.

title: Maria Catsoulis Fiancee Of Lawrence P. Kempf
description: Dr. and Mrs. Evangelos Catsoulis of New York and Athens have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria Catsoulis, to Lawrence Peter Kempf, son of Comdr. Lawrence Albert Kempf, U.S.N., retired, of La Mesa, Calif., and Antonia Kempf of Chevy Chase, Md., and Athens.

title: 'KHOVANSHCHINA' IN THE CONCERT HALL
description: Mussorgsky's "Kovanshchina," a craggy and unwieldly opera but almost certainly a masterpiece of the Russian repertory, has always stubbornly resisted effective stage treatment.The Opera Orchestra of New York, conducted by Eve Queler, presents the American premier of Dmitri Shostakovich's 1958 orchestration of the score tonight in Carnegie Hall. This will be a concert performancebetter than nothing, to be sure, but such a grandiose historical pageant demands the full technical resources of a major opera company as well as a director who can cope with its visual complexities.

title: A SHOW OF MASTERLY DRAWINGS
description: The most remarkable exhibition of ''European Drawings: 1375-1825'' at the Pierpont Morgan Library includes drawings by Botticelli, Raphael, Michelangelo, Pieter Brueghel the Elder, Correggio, Durer, Tintoretto, van Dyck, Guercino, Rubens, Rembrandt, Watteau, Fragonard, G.B. Tiepolo, Caspar David Friedrich and Ingres. Almost without exception, they are of commanding quality. But it is not a vainglorious big-name exhibition, well placed as the Morgan is to mount such a show. It is devised, rather, to answer the question: ''What did the Old Masters mean by 'a drawing'?''

title: Unions Planning Rally March 28 For Three Mile Island Shutdown
description: A coalition of labor unions advocating the permanent shutdown of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant is planning a protest rally March 28, the second anniversary of an accident at the facility.

title: NETTLES EYES RIVALS, SAYS HE'S RECOVERED
description: Someone must be worried about his recovery from hepatitis, Graig Nettles realized, even if he wasn't. ''I see there's a lot of people lined up to play third base now,'' he said with a trace of resentment.

title: WEST GERMANS CLASH AT SITE OF A-PLANT
description: Demonstrators clashed with police today at the site of a planned nuclear power plant at this village near Hamburg in northern Germany.

title: CAPITAL STATION IS TROUBLED AND EMPTY
description: At Union Station, toadstools grow in abandoned offices, rats prowl upstairs corridors and pigeons roost among the cobwebs.

title: TRANSIT BUDGET GAP HELD 'UNDERSTATED'
description: New York City's Transit Authority has underestimated its operating budget deficits ''substantially'' for 1981 through 1984 and the fare on the city's buses and subways may have to rise as high as $1.30 by 1983 to ease the deficit, the State Comptroller's office announced yesterday.

title: 'WHO'S PLAYING 3D?' AN OLD MET REFRAIN
description: Third base, the hot corner, a glamour position, the home of Mike Schmidt and George Brett, remains the great white whale of obsession for the Mets this spring.

title:
Future Events;
Notes For Bank Notes
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.Chords & CaloriesMarch 6 -Marvin Hamlisch sings at the piano accompanied by the Mannes Philharmonic for the second half of tonight's concert at the Hunter College Assembly Hall before he rushes home a few streets north on Park Avenue to welcome holders of $500 tickets for cocktails and dinner. Holders of $125 tickets follow the concert with a one-block walk to the Westbury for a supper dance and small concert by ensembles playing anything from dance tunes to chamber music. Sold out are the $75 tickets that let holders warm up with cocktails at the Spanish Institute before crossing Park Avenue to the 8 o'clock concert that opens with Yakov Kreizberg, a 21-yearold candidate for a master's degree at the Mannes College of Music, conducting the orchestra for Verdi's Overture to ''La Forza del Destino.'' Then Allan Won, the 20-year-old saxophone student at Mannes who was born in Japan and grew up in Hawaii, will be soloist for Ibert's Saxophone Concerto. Mr. Hamlisch's ties to Mannes started some years ago when, as a student at Queens College, he studied with Felix Salzer, the Mannes musicologist. Founded by David and Clara Damrosch Mannes in 1916, the school offers bachelor's and master's degrees in its college division. However, other classes are open to students as young as 4 in its preparatory division, and to both professional and nonprofessional adult musicians in its extension division.

title: Down the Colorado River in the Grand Canyon by Dory
description: Programs ranging from underwater photography in the Virgin Islands to whale watching in Alaska are offered by the American Wilderness Alliance, a nonprofit conservation organization based in Colorado.

title: SEPARATING FACT AND FANTASY IN REGULATION
description: To the Business Editor: Some of your readers consider the article ''Cost Analysis Needs Analysis'' (Feb. 8) by Mark Green and Norman Waiztman worth serious consideration, especially those of us who find it unfortunate that Murray Weidenbaum and his former associates at the Center for the Study of American Business did not produce a companion volume to ''The Future of Business Regulation,'' which might have been titled ''The Alarming Costs of Non-Regulation.''

title: Miss Specht Will Be Wed On May 23
description: Christine Kay Specht of New York, a producer for radio station WYNY-FM, plans to be married May 23 in Fort Collins, Colo., to Raymond DeWitt Mallary 3d, director of operations for the Leslie A. Harris Broadcasting Company.

title: NEUTRALITY IS TOUGH IN THE BUDGET BATTLE
description: When the Reagan Administration published a moderately optimistic economic forecast instead of the highly optimistic outlook first sketched by its supply-side economists, the staff of the Congressional Budget Office experienced a sense of relief, according to accounts circulating on Capitol Hill.

title: CONSERVATIVE GROUP SEEKS TO INTERVENE IN PINELAND SUIT
description: PHILADELPHIA A LEGAL foundation here that is affiliated with a similar one headed by James G. Watt until he became Secretary of the Interior is seeking to intervene in a court case as counsel for opponents of the Pine Barrens Comprehensive Management Plan.

title: Understanding Black Slang
description: I think William Safire's article ''Getting Down'' (On Language, Jan. 18), was serious (of excellent quality).

title: THE STARLING IS A REAL AMERICAN
description: I HAVE been putting bird feeders out for six years and have yet to see a bald eagle. What I have seen a lot of is starlings. This winter I have thought a great deal about the matter and have decided that the starling ought to be the national bird.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Microbooks. If you like to read, a just-published paperback offers some ideas to boggle your mind:

title: Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: Sunday Observer; THE LEGAL PITCH; by Russell Baker
description: Since the Supreme Court granted lawyers the right to advertise, a few of the more adventurous new law firms which cater to middleincome Americans have been testing the television commercial as a way of attracting mass business. So far their commercials have been duller than a lecture on torts, which is a pity, because we middleincome folks really need reasonably priced legal services and would flock to them in droves if they were advertised persuasively.

title: BERYL BAINBRIDGE AND HER TENTH NOVEL
description: A STUFFED buffalo named Eric, with a 48-inch horn span, blocks Beryl Bainbridge's entrance hall. Upstairs a pink plaster leg, shod in a silver high-heeled dancing shoe, projects from the wall above her brass bed. Over the lintel of the bed-sitting-room door runs a stuffed fox in hot pursuit of two hens; a life-sized model of Neville Chamberlain with his Homburg hat and umbrella occupies a nearby chair. The walls are covered with fading photographs of family and friends - images of stubborn mouths and sullen, moody faces. All seem clues to stormy secrets, all typical of the jacket for a Beryl Bainbridge novel.

title: SOCIAL IMPACT OF REAGAN'S BUDGET CUTS CITED IN STUDY
description: A total of 20,000 children in New York State will lose federally supported day care and 30,000 fewer people in the state will be served by centers for the elderly if the Reagan Administration's spending cuts are enacted, according to an analysis by the staff of the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: 67 NATIONS DEBATING ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: Under the intense gazes and passionate glowers of conservationists and animal traders, representatives of 67 governments are meeting here through the next week to debate how the multimillion-dollar international traffic in endangered species of plants and animals should be restricted. The technical chore facing the delegates is a review of the appendices to an eight-year-old treaty that limits trade in one category of plants and animals but forbids it entirely for another group deemed to be more seriously endangered.

title: JERSEY CENSUS DATA EXPECTED TO ASSURE JUNE VOTE
description: Final New Jersey census figures are expected to be in the hands of state officials by tomorrow, virtually assuring that the state's June 2 primary elections for governor and 120 legislative seats will be held as scheduled.

title: About Westchester; by Lynne Ames
description: WHITE PLAINS ''I'M in love with aviation,'' said George Wagner, a 57-year-old mechanic and one-time pilot. ''If I can't have the real thing I'll take this.''

title: HORNED LARK; Eremophila alpestris
description: Size: 7 1/2 inches. Color: Grayish, brown upper parts, white below.

title: JAZZ AND POP COMPOSER
description: J.C. Johnson, the jazz and pop composer who wrote ''The Joint is Jumpin,' '' died Friday night in St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 84 years old.

title: Catholic Track Title Taken by Loughlin
description: ''Everything fell in place for us while our competition fell off'' is the way Ed Bowes, coach of Bishop Loughlin, summed up his team's victory yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor track and field championships at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Nina Vitale Bride on L. I. of Hans Huber
description: Nina Vitale, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Alexander Vitale of Woodbury, L. I., was married yesterday in Huntington, L. I., to Hans Huber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Huber of Locust, N J. The Rev. Pascqual Renzulli performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Numismatics; IS UNITED STATES COINAGE OVERDUE FOR A FACELIFT?; by Ed Reiter
description: Is it time for a change in America's pocket change - or at least in the designs that are on those coins? It is indeed, according to a number of top medallic artists, for in their judgment the designs of United States coins are uninspired, undistinguished and utterly unworthy of such a first-rate nation.

title: Nobel Laureate Protests U.S. Aide's Latin Tour
description: Adolfo Perez Esquivel, the Argentine who received the Nobel Peace Prize last year, has released an open letter to President Reagan expressing concern over the mission of former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence Vernon A. Walters to Latin America and the possibility of United States military intervention in El Salvador.

title: Long Island Journal
description: DEMOCRATS in the Town of Hempstead are chronically short of campaign funds, so they've hit on a new fund-raising scheme of having a series of breakfast ''roasts'' of prominent lawyers and business executives. The object of the ''roast'' today at the Salisbury Park Restaurant in Eisenhower Park will be Neil T. Shayne, a prominent negligence lawyer.

title: SAN FRANCISCO Ten years ago, the northern California filmmakers were pioneers.  Francis Coppola, George Lucas, John Korty, Sol Zaentz, Michael Ritchie, and Philip Kaufman had fled from Hollywood - what it entailed or what it symbolized - and were camping out near San Francisco, 400 miles north.
description: When they arrived, there was no San Francisco film industry, only an occasional Hollywood movie using the steep streets and exhilarating skyline of the city as colorful background. ''In 1964,'' says Mr. Korty, who was the first to come, ''in all of San Francisco there was only one place that had double system projection - film on one track and sound on another. Now there are 20.''

title: Leisure
description: AN EXPERIENCED GROWER EXPLAINS HER SUCCESS WITH SIX PROLIFIC CROPS Ruth Tirrell grows her crops in a Massachusetts garden. By RUTH TIRRELL

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE COLLECTED STORIES OF ELIZABETH BOWEN. (Alfred A. Knopf, $17.95.) Seventy-nine stories, many of them masterpieces. THE COMPANY OF WOMEN, by Mary Gordon.

title: Dining Out; FOR ANY APPETITE, ALMOST ANY HOUR
description: THE Old Tubby House in Roslyn is one of those restaurants that keep reviewers in business. The place changes hands and reopens under a new name with almost predictable regularity. Previous incarnations include Excalibur and, before that, Truman's. Not too many years ago it was Minka, a Japanese restaurant.

title: Columbia 63, Yale 49
description: Columbia ran off a string of 10 points at the end of the first half and pulled away from Yale in the second for a 63-49 Ivy League victory at Levien Gym Saturday night.

title: Sports of the Times; Jim Plunkett's Blind Parents
description: JIM PLUNKETT is on a roll. After two seasons in oblivion, the 32-year-old quarterback took the Oakland Raiders to Super Bowl XV and was selected as the most valuable player in their 27-10 triumph. For that, he collected a black and silver Toyota automobile and a Seiko watch from Sport magazine at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria last week. And while he is a celebrity, he is hoping to complete a pass at the Raiders' treasury for a new contract that might double his $180,000 annual salary.

title:
Living Food;
MORE WOMEN IN 40'S HAVING BABIES
description: PHYSICIANS say they are a new breed, these women who are having children in their 40's -generally women who had their first families at a much earlier age and now desire another child. Part of a national trend toward later parenthood, they are the first generation to reap the benefits from advanced medical techniques - among them amniocentesis - that have mitigated the risks and removed many of the fears of childbearing in midlife.

title: 2D REQUEST PLANNED FOR PARK 'GATES'
description: The artist Christo will ask for ''reconsideration'' of Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis's decision last week not to allow him to make a temporary installation of thousands of bannerlike ''gates'' in Central Park. The decision was set in the context of an elaborate report on park use.

description: Dear Editors:

description: Prof. Edward C. Carter 2d and Mrs. Carter of Rosemont, Pa., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Carter's daughter, Charlotte Wright Bucknell to Charles Theodore Kappler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kappler of Washington. Miss Bucknell is the daughter also of the late John Addison Cobb Bucknell of Washington.
