title: Laurie Lichter Wed To Donald Heath
description: Laurie Jean Lichter, until recently a lawyer with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in New York, was married last evening in Tarrytown, N.Y. to Donald W. Heath, State Commissioner of Insurance for Nevada. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony at the Tappan Hill restaurant.

title: Eleanor Funkhouser, a Publishing Aide, Will Be Married to Michael Doar in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. Paul Funkhouser of Jacksonville, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor Kent Funkhouser, to Michael Doar, son of John Doar of New York and Anne Leffingwell Doar of Brooklyn. A July wedding in Philadelphia is planned.

title: GAINS STATE A.I.A.W. FINAL
description: Tracy Hanlon, a freshman guard, scored 6 points in overtime last night as Army upset top-seeded St. John's, 69-56, in a semifinal of the state Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women Division I championship at Iona College.

title: Ellen Sommers Married To Rev. William Beery
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Pleasantville, N.Y., yesterday, Ellen Sommers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Sommers of Kwajalein, Marshall Islands, was married to the Rev. William S. Beery, son of Dr. Edwin N. Beery of Brooklyn and Evelyn Onken Beery of Southbury, Conn. The ecumenical ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lloyd Uyecki, rector of St. John's; the Very Rev. Mark Sisk, Archdeacon for Region II of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, and the Rev. Peter Gavigan of St. Teresa of Avila Roman Catholic Church in North Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Teledyne
description: To the Business Editor: ''A Conglomerate that Works'' (Feb. 1) failed to mention that Teledyne's record has not been one of universal success.

title: SILLINESS IN SPACE
description: It is the 31st century, and man has learned to build a robot that looks like a Playmate of the Year and can fly a spaceship, too. What a hoot! ''Galaxina,'' which opened yesterday at the Cinerama and neighborhood theaters, is your basic interplanetary raunch.

title: SECRECY OF U.S. RECONNAISSANCE OFFICE IS CHALLENGED
description: The exceptionally secret status of the National Reconnaissance Office, one of the nation's most expensive and sensitive intelligence organizations, is likely to be reviewed by the Reagan Administration, according to senior Government officials.

title: IN A LOW LEVEL CONFLICT, NEITHER SIDE SEEMS ABLE TO WIN QUICK VICTORY
description: The war here is a low-level affair involving two unsophisticated forces locked in a partial military standoff.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: ORDER OF BLACK NUNS DEVOTES IT'S LABORS TO HARLEM
description: Sister Hyacinth, untethered by her long, dark blue skirts and veil, shuttles a blue station wagon among Harlem's parochial schools, picking up children of working parents for safekeeping after school. Mornings, this Franciscan Handmaid of Mary shepherds the aged to clinics or does errands for the house-bound.

title: Drake Zaharris Fiance Of Kimberly A. Eppley
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roland R. Eppley Jr. of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kimberly Ann Eppley, to Drake C. Zaharris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Zaharris of Andover, Mass.

title: CONFUSING PARTY CROSSWINDS IN CONGRESS
description: IN the back seat of a Boston taxicab, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House of Representatives, listened impatiently last week as the cabbie enthusiastically praised President Reagan's proposed tax and budget cuts. Taxes were far too high, the driver said, and it was in fact time to get the Government off the backs of the people.

title: No Headline
description: Hurry Up Blue, ridden by Carlos Lopez, put away favored Tunerup at the top of the stretch and held off 80-1 Yosi Boy today to win the $176,750 Gulfstream Handicap by a length.

title: TEANECK PURSUES UNITY IN DIVERSITY
description: TEANECK ''TEANECK is more urban, broadly based and dynamic than most suburban communities,'' says Leslie McKeon, a sculptor who spent years in Israel and Sierra Leone. ''It's really a majority of minorities.''

title: Ipswich and Aston Villa Record Soccer Victories
description: Ipswich and Aston Villa remained first and second in the English League soccer race with victories today.

description: To the Editor:

title: A FAMILY IN ATLANTA TRIES TO PUT LIFE BACK TOGETHER
description: The Atlanta police went to the South Side apartment of Annie Grace Rogers a few days ago with a surprising request. They wanted to question her son, 16-year-old Patrick Rogers, in connection with a burglary in the neighborhood.

title: FOREIGN AID: DEBATING THE USES AND ABUSES
description: M. Peter McPherson, confirmed last week by the Senate as administrator of the Agency for International Development, will hit the ground worried. As the annual battle over foreign aid warms up in Congress, Mr. McPherson will defend funding levels won by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. Federal budget director David A. Stockman and a transition team headed by Edward J. Feulner Jr., president of the Heritage Foundation, favored deeper cuts.

title: No Headline
description: Perhaps it was the angle and texture of Robert Grossman's drawing. As I contemplated the drawing of Mayor Koch, the illustration suggested something to me: Wouldn't this make a marvelous balloon for the Macy's parade?

title: Miss Gertler Is Fiancee Of Dr. Mark B. Schiffer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Menard M. Gertler of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie Jocelyn Gertler, to Dr. Mark Benjamin Schiffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey F. Schiffer of Watchung, N. J.

title: SKIING THE CLUB MED WAY IN COLORADO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- PATRICIA A. LANGAN is a reporter for Fortune magazine. By PATRICIA A.LANGAN

title: A HAPPY MIX: THE YOUNG AND OLD
description: LIKE the rest of America, Westchester keeps getting older. A County Planning Department study discloses that in the next 20 years the population will become increasingly aged. ''The challenge to county government is to adjust social-service programs,'' Planning Commissioner Peter Q. Eschweiler said. ''We'll be moving out of day-care and into programs for seniors.''

title:
Art;
TRUTH REDEFINED BY PHOTOGRAPHS
description: CENTERPORT WHEN someone tells us that ''the camera doesn't lie,'' the remark is quite rightly greeted with skepticism. We know that there are as many versions of photographic truth as there are photographers, and that's a very large number indeed.

title: ALBANY NOTES;
description: After weeks of trying to come up with a press secretary who could deal with both the temperamental Governor Carey and his temperamental media consultant, David Garth, the administration is now wooing Jill Schuker, who was press secretary of the United States mission to the United Nations in President Jimmy Carter's Administration. Miss Schuker met with the Governor this week, apparently impressed him, and is now said to be mulling it over while everyone waits for Mr. Garth to return from a trip and add his appraisal. If all sides approve, Miss Schuker would be the first woman to serve as a New York Governor's press secretary.

title: IS PAYING PLAYERS AN ANSWER?
description: To the Sports Editor: Have Mr. Chambers or his colleagues ever thought that, since bigtime college football actually has no relevance to the raison d'etre of a university, the bill under consideration really should propose the establishment of a football team to be sponsored by the State of Nebraska and administered by a Nebraska State Department of Athletics.

title: DEMOCRATS: AN AYE FOR BUSINESS
description: WASHINGTON W HEN Senator Paul E. Tsongas was a City Councilman in Lowell, Mass., he became concerned about the blighted core of that old New England mill town. He helped create a national park that would restore and protect some of the town's historic buildings, but he soon realized that was not enough.

title: De Paul 105 Loyola of Chicago 95
description: Mark Aguirre scored 31 points and De Paul shot 68 percent from the field in the first half in a 105-95 victory over Loyola of Chicago tonight.

title: N.J. Governor's Cup Runneth Over
description: The call to public service can be compelling, but rarely have so many responded so eagerly as in the race for governor of New Jersey. The number of announced candidates grew to eight Democrats and nine Republicans last week as Governor Byrne signed an appropriations bill guaranteeing some and perhaps all of them public funding for their campaigns.

title: THE BIG COUTURE RIP-OFF
description: Susan Heller Anderson is a writer based in France. By Susan Heller Anderson ''When counterfeiting was artisanal, it didn't bother us much,'' says Adrian de Flers, head of the Comite Colbert, a French couturier and perfumer trade group. ''Now it's become industrial, and we're frankly very worried.''

title: Maria E. Arista, a Lawyer, Is Married to George Volsky
description: Maria E. Arista, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold R. Arista of Lowell, Ind., was married yesterday to George Volsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Volsky of Coral Gables, Fla.

title: TELLING TOO MUCH
description: A famous line of Sir Francis Bacon's can be modified for bridge purposes: Reading maketh a full player; conference a ready partnership; and writing an exact opponent.

title: Stage Dialogue Found Appropriate
description: In response to the recent Theater in Review article entitled ''2 Short Plays Share Bill With Chekhov,'' I would like to share my views. These plays were presented at our library to a fascinated and involved audience.

title: IT'S TIME TO ACT ON FIRE SAFETY...
description: ONCE again, fire has devastated a structure that met the code requirements, leaving a trail of death and suffering in its wake. How many more people have to die before the value of automatic sprinklers is recognized?

title: The Pannonia Express
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance View; 'PARADE'-NEW LOOK FOR A DIAGHILEV LANDMARK
description: The new triple bill the Metropolitan Opera has presented under the title,''Parade, an Evening of French Musical Theater,'' makes for a delightful evening even if the least delightful component is an entirely revised version of the 1917 ''Parade,'' a landmark of Diaghilev's Ballets Russes. Erik Satie's music has been retained but the original ballet has been entirely rechoreographed and given a totally new scenario.

title: U.S. Official Opens Talks With Egypt on Sinai Force
description: Michael Sterner, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Near East Affairs, began talks with Egyptian officials today on the creation of an international force to police the Sinai peninsula.

title: Stage View; TREACHEROUS TERRAIN FOR PLAYWRIGHTS
description: It's only a couple of years ago that an astonishing number of plays turned up, on Broadway and off, with principal characters who were terminal cases, men and women waiting-edgily or serenelyfor certain death. We met them in wheelchairs on hospital roofs, we met them in cottages on hospital grounds, we met them in therapy centers struggling to recover from strokes only to be firmly felled by the last stroke of all. Oddly, this preoccupation with mortality wasn't particularly morbid. Some of the plays-and some of the condemned figures in them-were remarkably funny, and quite a few of the narrative lines had to do with a last-ditch and eventually successful effort to mend broken relationships before it was too late. Medically, there was no hope. Otherwise, there was hope all over the place, hope and a hand stretched out.

title: No Accident, Says Tough Harris Jury
description: Jean S. Harris was accused of no uncommon crime - Americans kill each other at an alarming rate, possibly as often for love as for money. But over the last 12 weeks, public fascination with her trial was remarkable. Even the decision handed down last week was a final jolt of surprise. The jury, after eight days of deliberation, returned the harshest possible verdict, guilty of murder in the second degree.

title: BOOM DECADE FOR TRADE
description: The 1970's was a period of unprecedented growth in world trade, according to statistics compiled by the International Monetary Fund. Average annual growth in the value of imports and exports exceeded 20 percent for the period, compared with a 10 percent increase during the 1960's, and an 8.4 percent rise during the 1950's.

title: THE EASING OF CREATURELY PAIN
description: Revolutions often brew quietly for a long time before bursting into the open. For more than a century, groups fighting against the use of animals in scientific research that causes pain have been assailed with charges ranging from ignorance to lunacy, while winning a few painstakingly slow and modest successes. In recent months, however, the cause of animal welfare has won several battles.

title: NO U.S. ARMS FOR EL SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: They Keep the Pot Boiling in Teheran
description: In typical Teheran fashion, three British ''hostages'' were told to leave, then stay, then leave last week. John and Audrey Coleman, an Anglican medical missionary team, and Jean Waddell, an Anglican bishop's secretary, finally were released on Friday and returned to London yesterday.

title: Camera; SHOOTING PICTURES OUTDOORS IN COLD WEATHER; by Jack Neubart
description: Jack Neubart is a freelance writer and photographer.

title: BALLET IS ALIVE AGAIN AT THE MET
description: Although critical reception of Gray Veredon's choreography for Erik Satie's ''Parade,'' which opens the Metropolitan Opera's new French triple bill, has been lukewarm at best (see Anna Kisselgoff's assessment elsewhere on this page), the Metropolitan Opera Ballet is happy merely to be dancing on home ground again after suffering through years of indifference and neglect. This is, in fact, the first time the company has performed on its own in the opera house for 15 years.

title: Tennessee 75, Auburn 63
description: Gary Carter scored 20 points to lead Tennessee to a 75-63 victory over Auburn in a Southeastern Conference game tonight.

title: Mayor Koch: Pros and Cons
description: In his article on Ed Koch (''The Man Behind the Mayor,'' Feb. 1), William Honan seems to say that it is the cosmetic things - his showmanship, his open manner and his political skills -that are the reasons for the Mayor's popularity and success.

title: POET'S PROGRESS
description: SOME AMERICANS A Personal Record. By Charles Tomlinson.134 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: University of California Press. $10.95.

title: Politics; THE DEMOCRATIC LIST IS ALMOST COMPLETE
description: NOW that Representative Robert A. Roe of Wayne and State Senator Joseph P. Merlino of Trenton have formally entered the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor, the cast of major candidates is almost complete.

title: THIEF SHOOTS 2 GUARDS IN MACY'S WHEN SEEN TAPPING CASH REGISTER
description: Two security guards for Macy's department store were shot last night as they attempted to stop a thief from leaving the building at Herald Square in midtown Manhattan.

title: Fast Reaction on Pension Proposals
description: It took four years for the Commission on Pension Policy to produce its final report, which urges far reaching changes in the nation's Social Security system. Last week, when those proposals were formally presented, it took President Reagan ''approximately 40 seconds'' to dismiss one of them, a White House spokesman said, and the Administration also indicated that it wants no part of most of the others.

title: LOUISVILLE RESIDENTS GO HOME
description: Fifty-six of the 96 families evacuated after sewers exploded on Feb. 13 were allowed to return home yesterday.

title: A TRANQUIL RETREAT IN LOWER AUSTRIA
description: JULIE V. IOVINE is a writer who lives in New Haven. By JULIE V.IOVINE

title: Defense Spending
description: To the Business Editor: Publishing Gene R. LaRocque's article, ''We Spend Too Much on Defense'' (Feb. 1) was a great service to the business community. To expand our nuclear arsenal so that we may kill every Russian 15 times over instead of only 10 times at the expense of strengthening our conventional forces is, indeed, counterproductive. ROBERT L. POPPER

title: Children's Books
description: THE MAN WHO LOVED BOOKS By Jean Fritz. Illustrated by Trina Schart Hyman. Unpaged. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $8.95. (Ages 7 to 10) By GEORGESS McHARGUE

title: Court Refuses to Stay Injunction Against Cargo Rule Enforcement
description: Shipping companies and longshoremen have been unable to obtain a stay of an injunction prohibiting them from enforcing rules in their latest contract on the handling of container cargo.

title: Music View; MARIA CALLAS- HER DECLINE AND FALL
description: The conspicuous consumption of great talent has always been a hallmark of the extremely rich and powerful. In its most benign form, as in the alliance of a Haydn and an Esterhazy, we call the phenomenon patronage of the arts. Both parties benefit, and sometimes the artist turns out to gain more than the patron. But here I am talking about a different and more pernicious consuming, not only of the artist's works but eventually of the artist.

title: OREGON'S BAR PILOTS LINK RIVER AND OCEAN TRAFFIC
description: The Oregon State Pilots Commission recently passed muster with the Legislature's ''sunset review'' committee, which cleans the state's bureaucratic house, and there is a sense of relief at the Columbia Bar Pilots' office along the docks here.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: WITH bikeways gaining in popularity, the state's Department of Transportation has completed a study that shows there are at least 17 railroad rights-of-way that can be converted to cycling use without difficulty.

title: CHURCH AT CITICORP CENTER IS FACING FISCAL TROUBLE
description: Ten years ago, St. Peter's Lutheran Church collected $9 million for selling its property on Lexington Avenue at 54th Street to Citibank. The congregation planned to spend half the money to buy back a portion of the land and build a modern church. The rest was to endow an extensive program in religion and the arts in mid-Manhattan and free the parish from the financial woes of most city churches.

title: ABOUT WASHINGTON
description: There was a rainbow here last week. It arced stunningly over the city at the close of an afternoon storm, bringing legions of workers to stare at the sky from office windows all over the capital.

title: PLAID IDEA FOR FALL
description: Plaid was reborn last fall when many fashion designers of women's clothes discovered that it is one of the best ways to introduce pattern and color into garments in an acceptably outrageous manner. But designers of men's fashions have always been partial to plaid, and for fall Jeffrey Banks, a young American designer known for his traditional clothing, uses it strikingly in red tartan plaid trousers paired with a tuxedo jacket.

title: Airline Goes In-House
description: Pacific Southwest Airlines, San Diego, Calif., which spent about $5 million for advertising last year, has decided to go in-house, which is a blow to Della Femina, Travisano & Partners of California, which turned out some award-winning advertising for their client. Reportedly, Bill Bailey Communications of La Jolla will serve as consultant, Western International will buy media and freelancers will do the creative. Sounds simple.

title: Long, Bitter Strike Shatter's Tranquillity of Guam
description: The tranquillity of this most remote American possession has been shattered by the first strike of public employees on an island where the Federal and territorial governments together provide about 38 percent of all jobs.

title: THE U.S. CONVERTIBLE MAKING A COMEBACK
description: The convertible, relic of the wind-in-the-hair era of driving, seemed consigned to the scrap heap of automotive history along with rumble seats and running boards when the last Cadillac Eldorado soft top rolled off the assembly line in 1976.

title: All in the Family
description: In 1955, Nashua won the Flamingo, the Florida Derby, the Wood Memorial, the Preakness, the Belmont and the Jockey Club Gold Cup, but he lost the Kentucky Derby to Swaps. Although Nashua later beat Swaps by 6 1/2 lengths in a match race at Washington Park and won horse-of-the-year honors, his season is chiefly remembered for losing the Derby and missing the Triple Crown.

title: GENERAL FOODS' GERMAN PUSH
description: When the General Foods Corporation bought Kaffee Hag, the West German coffee company, two years ago, both companies were struggling in West Germany.

title: Miss Pardell, Social Worker, Is Bride of Keith R. Marshall
description: The marriage of Sharon Marcia Pardell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Pardell of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., to Keith Richard Marshall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Marshall of Fair Lawn, N.J., took place yesterday at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Solomon Rothstein officiated.

title: MUSIC: TELEMANN HAS HIS EVENING
description: The Ensemble for Early Music's Grande Bande-Baroque Chamber Orchestra joined the continuing celebration of Telemann's birthday Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall, and the composer's music responded in its unflaggingly amiable way. This concert, which featured music from ''Die Tageszeiten'' and the cantata ''Der Weiberorden,'' ran the range of Telemann's personality - from the genuinely entertaining and descriptive wit of ''Burlesque de Don Quixotte'' to long stretches of the bland and almost soporific.

title: Henderson: Goodbye To Mets and Dreams
description: On the day he was supposed to begin spring training, Steve Henderson walked into the locker room of the New York Mets for the last time today and said goodbye to the men and the dreams of the last three and a half years.

title: CAREY TRYING TO UNRAVEL A WEB OF TRUCKING RULES
description: A proposal by Governor Carey this weekend to repeal regulations in such areas as the trucking and limousine service industries would begin to dismantle parts of a vast transportation regulation system created by the state in the late 1930's in imitation of Federal initiatives.

title: A GAME SUPERPOWERS PALY
description: To the Editor:

title: IT'S BACK TO FIRST BOSTON
description: Alvin V. Shoemaker, 41, has been nominated chairman of the executive committee of First Boston Inc. This is the investment banking concern that he left in 1978 to head the firm then called Blyth Eastman Dillon & Company. He is being succeeded as chief executive officer of Blyth Eastman Paine Webber by Frank L. Mansell, 59, who continues as chairman.

title: News Analysis
description: The resumption Wednesday of the antitrust trial against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company represents an unfavorable turn of events for the huge company, many industry analysts say.

title: OPERA: 'MARY, QUEEN OF SCOTS' BY CITY TROUPE
description: THEA MUSGRAVE'S ''Mary, Queen of Scots'' has found its way into many of the world's opera houses since its premiere at the Edinburgh Festival in 1977. At its first New York performance last night, by the New York City Opera, the reasons for such currency were sometimes easy to understand. Miss Musgrave's work, a retelling of the Scottish queen's rise, struggles to maintain power and sudden fall, has a few telling moments when her music and the dramatic action interlock and reinforce one another. Perhaps the opera's richest such episode comes at the end of the first act, in a ballroom interlude that does not stop the action to permit the ballet to come on, as in most opera dance scenes, but propels the drama forward. Wendy Hilton's choreography and the nimbleness of the City Opera cast, headed by Ashley Putnam as Mary, helps Miss Musgrave's score mightily at this point.

title: HIGH COURT TO HEAR INMATES'RIGHTS SUIT
description: One of the most important prisoners' rights issues to reach the Supreme Court in years, the question whether the Constitution permits two prisoners to be housed in a cell designed for one, is to be argued tomorrow in a case involving ''doublecelling'' at Ohio's maximum security prison.

title: Elisa R. Schindler Wed To Jeffrey D. Ginzberg
description: Elisa Ruth Schindler, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Alexander M. Schindler, was married at her parents' home in Westport, Conn., yesterday to Jeffrey David Ginzberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Noel P. Ginzberg of Fairfield, Conn.

title: Firefighters in Milwaukee Strike in Dispute Over Pay
description: This city's 1,100 uniformed firefighters, ignoring a state law prohibiting strikes by public employees, walked out early yesterday in a contract dispute. National Guard troops were called up for fire duty in their absence.

title: More Oil Set By Indonesia
description: Indonesia, the sixth-largest supplier of imported oil to the United States, plans to raise crude oil production above the current level of 1.6 million barrels a day during the fiscal year 1981-82, the news agency of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries reported Friday.

title: AT THE PENTAGON AND STATE DEPT.: PRAGMATIC TONE
description: Though he was often identified with doctrinaire positions on foreign policy as a candidate, Ronald Reagan as President has assembled a largely nonideological team of managers and career Government officials to direct foreign and defense policy in his Administration.

title: CONCERT: WURTTEMBERG PLAYERS
description: There was very little to trouble the mind or ruffle the senses in the safely predictable program presented by the Wurttemberg Chamber Orchestra in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. Maurice Andre was the featured trumpet soloist for the evening, which meant a generous helping of this popular musician's specialty, pyrotechnical display in music for trumpet and orchestra from the Baroque era.

title: RANGERS, CANADIENS IN 4-4 TIE
description: Rallying on goals by Don Maloney and Mike Allison, the Rangers fought to a 4-4 tie with the Montreal Canadiens last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: No Headline
description: 'How'm I Doing?' Mayor Koch joined by the cast of the Broadway musical, ''42d Street,'' for some soft-shoe shuffling at the end of the 1981 dinner of the Inner Circle, a group of New York City reporters, Saturday night at the New York Hilton. The show was titled, ''King Koch, or, Who'm I Doing?''

title: Amoco to Close Illinois Refinery
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said it would close its Wood River, Ill., refinery by about Oct. 1, affecting about 300 jobs, because of what it called continued declines in demand for petroleum products.

title: New Mexico Plane Crash Kills 5
description: Five people were killed when a single-engine airplane crashed into a gully in overcast weather, the state police said. The Beechcraft Bonanza was traveling from Farmington to Albuquerque, according to workers at the Farmington airport. Witnesses told the police that the plane circled two or three times, headed southeast and buzzed around nearby cliffs just before it crashed.

title: ADVERTISING By Philip Dougherty; Gillette Divides Shaving Accounts
description: Gillette has divided its domestic shaving equipment advertising assignments according to gender and that made Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, a big winner; Marschalk, a little winner, and McCann-Erickson, a loser.

title: OPPONENTS OF CITY HOUSING PROGRAM PREDICT LOSS OF $2 BILLION IN TAXES
description: New York City will be committed to as much as $2 billion in tax abatements and exemptions over the next 20 years under one of the more important tax-incentive programs for developers, according to an analysis by the office of the City Council President.

title: TV: DISABLED CHILDREN AS SUMMER CAMPERS
description: IF it's poignant, courageous and inspiring, this must be television's land of the handicapped. No one, obviously, is going to begrudge any handicapped person a place in the electronic haze, but anyone watching television these days can't help wondering if the entire country hasn't suddenly become disabled. Week after week, television movie after television movie, the dominant subject is some sort of illness, personal disability or social disease.

title: Half of Blacks in a Poll Question Busing's Value
description: Half of the black population in America believes that busing to achieve school integration ''has caused more difficulties than it is worth,'' according to a poll by the Gallup Organization.

title: Senate to Vote on Credit Fees
description: The Senate is expected to act Tuesday on legislation that would continue a ban on extra charges for credit card purchases.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you come to the conclusion that we have launched the aggression, then you must fight us.

title: David Shakow, Pioneer In Schizophrenia Studies
description: Dr. David Shakow, a psychologist and scientist emeritus at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., died Thursday of a heart ailment at Sibley Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: POLICE ARE AMBUSHED DESPITE BASQUE TRUCE
description: Less than a day after one branch of the Basque separatist organization E.T.A. announced an ''unconditional ceasefire,'' guerrillas in the troubled northern region today ambushed a police patrol car, wounding three policemen. A woman was also hurt in the shoot-out between the policemen and their attackers.

title: Wider Exposure for Henry Fonda, the Artist
description: He had his first brush with painting backstage at the Omaha Community Playhouse in 1925, and the artistic talents he demonstrated in designing and painting sets during the next three years were good enough to win him an offer of a scholarship to the Parsons School of Design.

title: TV: AN HOUR OF DIANA ROSS
description: DIANA ROSS keeps her engine running all through her high-speed onehour special on CBS-TV at 10 o'clock tonight, and what's more, she will probably have you throbbing, too.

title: VIRGINIA CONFIDENT FOR A.C.C. TOURNAMENT
description: When the Virginia Cavaliers began the basketball season, Coach Terry Holland had three objectives: to win the regular Atlantic Coast Conference championship, to win the conference's postseason tournament and then to play well in the National Collegiate tournament.

title: Advertising; Not Just Another Bank Ad
description: Those of you in the New York area who noticed the TV spots for Sterling National Bank on the late news and reacted merely with ''Oh, another bank ad,'' were, in fact, ignoring moments of advertising history.

title: SPORTING GEAR
description: Jump Rope With Digital Counter

title: 'GIN GAME' ON PAY TV APRIL 21
description: ''The Gin Game,'' D.L. Coburn's Pulitzer Prize-winning twocharacter play that opened in 1978 and ran for 517 performances, will be televised by Showtime on cable television April 21 and a few times thereafter for three or four weeks.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: *Allegheny Beverage Corporation, Baltimore, has named A. J. Hering vice president and treasurer.

title: WHAT IS GOVERNMENT FOR
description: John Locke, the philosopher of political democracy, had a fairly good idea of why people formed governments: to protect ''life, liberty and property.''

title: Va. Commonwealth 62 Alabama-Birmingham 61
description: A free throw by Edmund Sherods with 4 seconds left in overtime today gave Virginia Commonwealth a 62-61 victory over Alabama-Birmingham and its second straight Sun Belt Conference postseason tournament championship.

title: Mayer Beats Tanner In U.S. Final, 6-4, 6-2
description: Gene Mayer won the United States indoor tennis championship today with a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Roscoe Tanner. With his deceptive two-handed shots, Mayer did not lose a set in the tournament.

title: March 2, 1981 GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on Namibia.

title: Philadelphia Bank Officer Slain
description: Gayle Gerken, 39 years old, a vice president of the Philadelphia National Bank, was found stabbed to death early today at her home in the city's fashionable Society Hill area, the police said. The authorities said Miss Gerken's neighbors reported seen a young man fleeing down the back steps of her apartment building.

title: INVESTORS SHUNNING LONG-TERM ISSUES
description: Treasury bonds open this week yielding over 13 percent, up from 12.5 percent a week ago and 12 percent on Jan. 20, but securities dealers say that investor demand is light.

title: THE CHOICE FOR KIDNEY PATIENTS SHOULD BE UP TO THEM
description: To the Editor:

title: LAWYER SAYS 9-YEAR OLD BANK ROBBER WAS INFLUENCED BY TV CRIME
description: The lawyer for the 9-year-old boy who surrendered after the robbery of a midtown Manhattan bank last week said yesterday that the boy was influenced by crime programs on television and that he was only playing when he pointed a toy gun at a teller at the New York Bank for Savings and demanded money.

title: DOUBLE ZERO ADDS UP FOR THE CELTICS
description: BOSTON HE played in the league four years and his identity level was only a few points higher than the double zero he wears on his uniform. Robert Parish was known, if at all, as the college player whose scoring records were purged from national ranking because of a dispute over his admission tests. He was known, if at all, as a 7-foot player who didn't always hustle, and didn't often talk.

title: 3 Magazines Challenge Rivals' Demographic Data
description: Many mass circulation magazines that already have regional editions have instituted demographic editions. Some of these are designed to attract advertisers wishing to reach the higher-income, bettereducated crowd, either in society generally or in business particularly.

title: Ammunition Called Bound For Lebanon Is Confiscated
description: More than 52,000 rounds of ammunition that the Federal authorities say was to be shipped illegally to Lebanon was seized yesterday at a dock here.

title: UNREALISTIC ADVISE TO ADOLESCENT GIRLS
description: To the Editor:

title: SHORT OPERAS: 2 BY GOLDEN FLEECE
description: THE Golden Fleece is a group dedicated to the laudable cause of producing new operas and musical theater works by American composers. On Friday night two 25-minute one-act works, Ned Rorem's ''Bertha'' and Thomas Benjamin's ''The Rehearsal,'' received their New York premieres at Theater 22, 54 West 22d Street.

title: Typecasting
description: There must be something about Harry Davis, an actor, that makes a lot of people think about an Italian uncle visiting from the old country. Last year he showed up in that role in a Pepsi Cola commercial and now he's starring again in behalf of Prince spaghetti. As a matter of fact, he would have been in both last year, but Vanet Advertising, which has Prince, saw the Pepsi spot first and decided to wait a year.

title: FOR PARTY LEADER FROM SIBERIA, 'CAREER IS AN ALIEN NOTION
description: Among the delegates to the 26th Communist Party Congress here, a special bustle surrounds the men in their 40's and 50's who have made their way to key positions in industry, agriculture and the party apparatus. It is they who constitute the talent pool from which the next generation of Kremlin leaders will most likely emerge.

title: DIRECTORS RAIL AT SALE OF OBSERVER
description: Atlantic Richfield's plans to sell The Observer, one of Britain's oldest newspapers, to Lonrho Ltd., with its stormy chief executive, has unleashed a roiling controversy.

title: R.F. Quaintance Jr.  Weds Jane M. Azia
description: Jane Melissa Azia, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Azia of Hewlett, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Forsyth Quaintance Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Quaintance of Wilmette, Ill. Civil Court Judge Helen Freedman performed the ceremony in a Chelsea loft.

title: DETROIT WORKERS FAVOR SPENDING CUTS
description: ''It's easier to be liberal,'' said Richard Wertz, ''when you're not worried about losing your job.'' Mr. Wertz, a steelworker who has been a union man for 34 years, considers himself a lifelong Democrat. But although the leadership of his union, the United Steel Workers of America, endorsed Jimmy Carter for President, he pulled the Republican lever for Ronald Reagan, and although the country's labor leaders are fighting the President's spending cuts, Mr. Wertz wants Mr. Reagan to cut deeper.

title: PIANO: VARSANO U.S. DEBUT
description: DANIEL VARSANO is a 27-year-old pianist who has been stirring up quite a bit of interest in his native France. A pupil of Magda Tagliaferro, Pierre Sancan and Rosalyn Tureck, Mr. Varsano already has a number of highly regarded recordings to his credit, most recently a two-disk set on CBS devoted to Beethoven's ''Diabelli'' Variations and Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COOL CORNER

title: MARKET PLACE by Robert Metz; C.A.B. Decision Awaited on Tie
description: SOMETIME today, the Civil Aeronautics Board will announce its decision as to whether Texas International Airlines may vote its 42 percent of Continental Air Lines shares against the merger with Western Airlines at Continental's special meeting March 12.

title: Salvador Cleric Condemns Arrest of Ex-Junta Member
description: Archbishop Arturo Rivera y Damas of El Salvador today criticized the Government's arrest last week of a former junta member, Col. Adolfo Arnaldo Majano, saying the colonel was ''a man of great sympathy who was seeking political pluralism.''

title: MIDEAST ARMS RACE
description: The sale of F-15 fighter bombers with extended range and bomb-racks to Saudi Arabia is moving to completion, and the dangerous implications are being brushed aside with precious little thought for the future.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: If a player in the National Hockey League stick-handles the puck so that his body crosses the blue line before the puck, is this an offside?

title: SIGHTING OF 4 GALAXIES AT A RECORD DISTANCE REPORTED BY SCIENTESTS
description: After 40 hours of observation conducted over three years, astronomers have identified a galaxy estimated to be 10 billion light-years away. Previously the most distant galaxy was estimated to be eight billion light-years away.

title: THE HISTORICAL RECORD
description: Does the historical record provide any clues to creativity and aging? ''Matisse, Renoir and Monet produced magnificent works in their later years,'' said Harry R. Moody of the Brookdale Center on Aging of Hunter College, at last week's conference on age and creativity. ''Age has never been an inhibitor of great art.''

title: White Tops
description: If one thinks that America is producing some late bloomers in winter sports, such as John Broman, one might want to check the competitive rolls at Hunter Mountain on Wednesday morning when more than 100 skiers are scheduled to compete in a meet. The rules specify that the competitors be 70 years or older.

title: P.S.C. Asked to Ease Conversions to Coal
description: It would be ''prudent'' to let the Consolidated Edison Company begin converting three major electric generating units to burn coal before all approvals are obtained, an administrative law judge has told the state's Public Service Commission.

title: IRAN TAKES HARD LINE WITH MOSLEM MISSION ON ENDING GULF WAR
description: Iran told an Islamic mediation mission today that it would not negotiate with Iraq on ending the five-month old war in the Persian Gulf until Iraqi troops withdraw from Iranian territory.

title: SOUTH KOREA ANNOUNCES AN AMNESTY FOR 5,221
description: President Chun Doo Hwan's Government today announced an amnesty for 5,221 people, but the list apparently did not include any prominent dissidents or opposition leaders.

title: 'Before Columbus' Group Presents Book Awards
description: The Before Columbus Foundation's own American Book Awards, designed to promote the multicultural arts and recognize literary achievement by people of various ethnic backgrounds, presented its second annual awards to a group of writers at the Public/Anspacher Theater last night.

title: REPUBLICAN PEACE PREVAILS, EVEN AT MICHIGAN SORE SPOTS
description: Gov. William G. Milliken told Michigan's Republicans to be united if they wanted to win. President Reagan sent a friendly telegram. And Melvin L. Larsen, the Governor's choice for Republican state chairman, easily defeated a challenge from the right.

title: U.S. RETURNS ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS WHO ARE FLEEING SALVADOR WAR
description: Refugees from the fighting in El Salvador are streaming into the United States in ever-greater numbers, in many cases having sold all they own to finance the difficult, expensive and illegal journey from their Central American homeland. But they are being sent home again nearly as fast as they are captured, to what many of them fear may be mistreatment or death.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MARCH 2, 1981
description: International Postponement of a scheduled arms talk with the Soviet Union that would deal with questions of compliance with previous strategic arms limitation agreements is being considered by the Administration. Officials said that the regularly scheduled session of the Standing Consultative Commision on March 25 would probably be delayed for a month or two to allow the United States time to work out its future policies on strategic arms issues and to fill key staff positions. (Page A1, Col. 4.) Moderates in the Administration are directing the President's foreign and defense policies, though he was often identified with doctrinaire positions as a candidate. This has upset Republican conservatives, like Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina. With some notable exceptions, the newly appointed policy makers appear to represent the mainstream of the Republican Party. (A1:5.)

title: POLLUTION ASSESSED IN OHIO RIVER VALLEY
description: Stricter environmental controls on electric power plants could prevent 54,000 pollution-related deaths and avert billions of dollars in crop losses in the Ohio River Valley by the year 2000, a new Government study says.

title: DRUG COMPUTER COMPANY
description: Arthur J. Pellegrino, 55, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Health Care Computer Systems, a subsidiary of American Medical Affiliates Inc. He succeeds Morris Yoffe, 52, who remains chairman of the software development company and president of its parent corporation based at Fort Washington, Pa.

title: Harriette Friedlander Is Married to Alan B. Bernstein
description: Harriette Friedlander, director of social services for Selfhelp Community Services Inc., a private geriatric and homecare agency in Manhattan, was married in New York yesterday morning to Alan B. Bernstein, president of PASE Inc., a New Brunswick, N.J., publicaffairs and consulting concern specializing in law enforcement agencies and private security clients. Rabbi Lawrence Raphael, associate dean of Hebrew Union College, performed the ceremony in the college chapel.

title: Miss Hanika Victor
description: Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, a 21-yearold southpaw with a heavy topspin arsenal, won the $125,000 Avon tennis tournament today by beating Barbara Potter, another lefthander, 6-2, 6-4.

title: The Case Against Mr. Lefever
description: What has prompted the Reagan Administration to nominate Ernest Lefever as director of the State Department's human rights office? There can be no quarrel with assigning the post to a certified conservative. But Mr. Lefever is a tetchy academic who has shown himself to be openly dubious about the very existence of the office he is being named to administer.

title: Owner Shot to Death In Bronx Restaurant
description: The owner of a Chinese restaurant in the Bronx was shot to death early yesterday in an apparent robbery attempt, the police said.

title: Kentucky Snaps L.S.U. Streak
description: Sam Bowie, one of four Kentucky players with 11 points, blocked a shot with two seconds left today as the Wildcats upset Louisiana State, 73-71, snapping college basketball's longest winning streak.

title: AT SHOW, REIGNING CATS AND KITTENS
description: There was a congress of cats over the weekend convened by human beings, who, after long deliberation, chose the best members of more than 50 different cat breeds - enough to fill eight judging rings.

title: L.P.G.A. Rained Out
description: Heavy rain today washed out the scheduled third and final round of the $150,000 Olympia Gold Classic at Industry Hills.

title: Namely Speaking
description: Among the great college scorers, Zambolist (Zam) Frederick may have the most intriguing first name since Togo Palazzi starred at Holy Cross in the early 1950's. Frederick says his mother named him - with a slight spelling alteration - after the actor Efrem Zimbalist Jr.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page on Jan. 16 incorrectly identified a child-care center directed by Meryl Glass. It is the University of California, San Francisco Child Care/Study Center.

title: 2 Guards Recovering After Macy's Attack
description: Two Macy's security guards were recuperating satisfactorily yesterday after they were shot Saturday attempting to apprehend a robber at the Herald Square store in Manhattan.

title: TAX BREAKS COULD FIGHT URBAN BLIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I.U Plays Wagner in Tourney Opener
description: Pairings for several Eastern college basketball conference tournaments were announced yesterday. In the Eastern College Athletic Conference, Long Island University will play at Wagner and Iona at Siena tomorrow night at 8 P.M. in first-round Metro games.
