title: JOSEPH F. SEBALD
description: Joseph F. Sebald, president of Heat Power Products Company of Bloomfield, N. J., and a former vice president of the American Society of Mechancial Engineers, died Feb. 20 at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. Mr. Sebald, who was a resident of Bloomfield, was 74 years old.

title: EXPLORING THE PAST: CREATIVITY IN OLD AGE
description: Are all of us doomed to an old age of declining creativity - a future of failing intellectual powers and innovative ability that must be faced, and ultimately accepted?

title: Helen Scott and Ira Nordlicht, Lawyers, Wed At Congregation Habonim yesterday
description: Helen Scott, an associate with the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, was married to Ira Shale Nordlicht, a member of the New York law firm of Holtzmann, Wise & Shepard. Rabbi Arthur Zuckerman performed the ceremony.

title: L.I.R.R. Search Group Sought
description: Long Island Consumer Action Inc., a group frequently critical of the Long Island Rail Road, called on Governor Carey yesterday to appoint a committee of commuters, union officials and railroad experts to find a new president for the beleaguered line. Francis S. Gabreski resigned as its president last Thursday.

title: HERBERT C. STRUPPMANN
description: Herbert C. Struppmann, an architect and retired Navy captain who remained active in the Naval Reserve, died Feb. 12 at Veterans Hospital in Canandaigua, N.Y., after a long illness.

title: OLD CITY DOCUMENTS LIE IN MILDWOOD DECAY
description: Pier 32, one of many jutting into the Hudson River, is one of New York City's dumping grounds for its past: bound volumes mapping 19thcentury wards, leather-edged ledgers chronicling decade-old land deals, green cabinets jammed with disintegrating court records. In a musty, unheated steel warehouse, amid filth and mildew, rests more than a century of the city's documentary record.

title: CELTICS' COACH FITCH EJECTED ON ZONE CALL IN VICTORY OVER 76ERS
description: The Boston Celtics had just defeated Philadelphia, 114-107, in an important Atlantic Division game, and in the dressing room at the Boston Garden, Coach Bill Fitch of the Celtics stood in front of a color television monitor. There he pleaded a case that he had lost on the court.

title: REAGAN MAY DOUBLE SCIENCE AGENCY CUT AND ADD FARM FEE
description: As much as $40 million, in addition to the $47 million already announced, may be trimmed from the Federal funds for education programs of the National Science Foundation, Reagan Administration sources said today.

title: JERSEY AIDES QUESTION SAFETY AT HOMES FOR ELDERLY
description: In faded boarding homes and hotels along the New Jersey shore and in decaying inner-city tenements, about 40,000 elderly people with physical and mental infirmities are living in conditions that some officials say are unsafe.

title: BRENT SUTTER FINISHES STINT WITH ISLANDERS
description: Brent Sutter left the Islanders today the way he had arrived five days earlier: toting a green equipment bag with the name ''Broncos'' stenciled on it.

title: MARTINEZ REPORTS TO CARDINAL CAMP
description: Silvio Martinez, maintaining he is "healthy now" following a 1980 season during which the right-hander was plagued by injuries, reported two days late today to the training camp of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: JAZZ DANCE: GUS GIORDANO AND HIS CHICAGO TROUPE
description: GUS GIORDANO personifies jazz dance to many Americans after his years of teaching - in Chicago, where he is based, and at dance conventions across the country - and of choreographing in the jazz dance style. And so an appearance by the Gus Giordano Jazz Dance Chicago Company on Friday at the Theater of the Riverside Church was something of a surprise.

title: OREGON ST. TOPS U.C.L.A., 82-76
description: After 29 years as a college coach, Ralph Miller of Oregon State says he likes to keep his team's style simple. But what has never been simple is winning at Pauley Pavilion against U.C.L.A.

title: Police Study Car List In Queens Shootings
description: Detectives are checking lists of license plates of vehicles that entered the front gate of the North Shore Towers apartment complex in Floral Park, Queens, in their investigation of the fatal shooting Friday morning of a resident, Elliott R. Hyman, who was in the clothing business, and the critical wounding of his wife, Ellin.

title: 27 Ex-Players Unite Against Kush's Trial
description: A former Arizona State football player has formed a movement to protest the civil suit against the university's former coach, Frank Kush.

title: A ROUNDUP OF 1980 SALES AND PROFITS FOR 233 MAJOR CORPORATIONS
description: THE oil companies remained the pre-eminent profit makers last year. Although percentage gains fell far short of the triple-digit increases of the year before, profits for this sector rose more than 25 percent.

title: STAGE: ELLINGTON'S 'SOPHISTICATED LADIES'
description: IN the course of his extraordinary career, Duke Ellington did just about everything with jazz that any mortal could be expected to do. Yet, strangely enough, there was one goal that eluded this giant of American music right up to his death in 1974: he never had a hit Broadway show to call his own.

title: News Analysis
description: Like a couple of boxers retiring to their corners after a grueling round, the Government and the independent trade union movement are each looking ahead to a respite from strikes and confrontations.

title: Florida State 81 Marquette 78
description: Mickey Dillard and Kris Anderson made key free throws in the final two minutes today to lift Florida State to an 81-78 victory over Marquette.

title: The Talk of Scarsdale
description: Mayor Grady Jensen received a clipping about the trial of Jean S. Harris from a California resident a few weeks ago, attached to an irate note criticizing the life style of the victim, Dr. Herman Tarnower, and asking why Scarsdale ''was not backing up'' the defendant more vigorously.

title: 2 Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE POLYGAMIST. By B.H. Friedman. 220 pages. Atlantic-Little, Brown. $11.95.

title: Japan Run to Gomez
description: Rodolfo Gomez, a 30-year-old Olympian from Mexico, overcame a blistered foot to win the Tokyo Marathon today in 2 hours 11 minutes. Gomez, who was sixth in the 1980 Moscow Olympics, sprinted out from a front-running five-man group at the 23-mile point. Tommy Persson of Sweden, finishing 400 meters behind, was second in 2:12:07, followed by Randy Thomas of the United States in 2:12:31.

title: The Sewer Of Beaverkill
description: One stormy April night three men rode out of the darkness into the streets of the Catskills village of Roscoe. ''Gentlemen,'' said Sparse Grey Hackle, ''remove your hats. This is it.'' ''This is where the trout was invented?'' the driver asked.

title: Endangered Species in the White House
description: The Council on Environmental Quality, a tiny but important unit that advises the White House, has been placed on the endangered species list. High officials of the Reagan Administration are considering doing away with the council as part of a reorganization of the President's executive office. The stated reason is that other agencies could perform its functions. An unstated reason may be that the council's environ-mental thinking is not welcome in an Administration pledged to rapid economic revival and development of energy.

title: 2 INJURED BY GUNSHOTS AT MADRI GRAS PARADE HONORING EX-CAPTIVES
description: A man firing from a crowd of spectators shot and wounded two persons and sent screaming spectators fleeing for cover tonight at the Bacchus parade honoring nine marines who had been held hostage in Iran.

title: HASIDIC FACTION BESIEGES RIVALS IN WILIAMSBURG
description: Hundreds of Hasidic Jews hurled rocks, bottles and vehement curses at the synagogue of a rival group of Hasidim in Brooklyn last night and faced off with scores of police officers in a two-hour confrontation in which dozens of worshipers were trapped inside the temple.

title: Polk Journalism Awards; Are Disclosed by L.I.U.
description: Long Island University yesterday announced the winners of the 33d annual George Polk Awards in Journalism. Among the recipients were the editorial board of The New York Times for ''keen perspectives on local, national and world developments'' and the local staff of The Miami Herald for investigation of police conduct toward the black community of Miami.

title: RCA'S EX-PRESIDENT FINDS WALL ST. NICHE
description: Maurice R. Valente, the 52-year-old executive who was dismissed by the RCA Corporation as president and chief operating officer last June, has joined Wolsey & Company as a general partner. Wolsey, a New York investment banking firm established five months ago, specializes in mergers, acquisitions and leveraged buyouts.

title: THE BAIT IS AS VARIED AS THE METHOD OF FISHING
description: WITH spring not far away, I should like to give succor to the bait fisherman, a fellow who has fallen into disrepute in the past three decades.

title: By Jim Benagh
description: Sports World Specials Success Story

title: Words of Warning From a Reagan Supporter
description: President Reagan has enjoyed a generally favorable press since he took office, and Washington society has, by most accounts, taken well to the man from California.

title: Jackson Draws $2,500 Fine
description: When Reggie Jackson arrives in the Yankee camp, he will learn that even the cost of reporting late to spring training has been hit by inflation.

title: Fighter Very Critical After Brain Surgery
description: Fred Bowman, knocked out in a preliminary fight on the Matthew Saad Muhammad-Vonzell Johnson card today at Bally's Park Place Hotel, was listed in very critical condition after undergoing brain surgery tonight.

title: FIGURE SKATING IS ENJOYING THE BEST OF TIMES IN AMERICA
description: MONSEY, N.Y. ELAINE ZAYAK glided along the ice and prepared for her next move like a dancer on center stage. When she reached her spot, her arms, legs and body spun in a dazzling execution of a triple toe loop.

title: Report on Shcharansky Is Denied
description: A New York rabbi who was reported to have worked out a deal with the Soviet authorities to gain the freedom of the Jewish dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky said today that no such agreement had been reached. ''I wish it were true,'' Rabbi Ronald Greenwald told the Israeli radio in a telephone interview. He was referring to a report in a Johannesburg newspaper that the Soviet Union had agreed to free Mr. Shcharansky in exchange for a Soviet citizen imprisoned for espionage in South Africa.

title: NETS LOSE THEIR FIFTH STRAIGHT
description: The New Jersey Nets made official today what had been expected for some time: they were eliminated from playoff contention by losing to the Detroit Pistons, 117-104.

title: Writs in Argentina Seek Detained Rights Activists
description: Legal groups have filed writs of habeas corpus requesting that the national police produce six humanrights activists who were apparently arrested in Buenos Aires on Friday night, relatives of the activists said today.

title: HEARD THE ONE ABOUT THE FEMALE COMIC?
description: ''You know the kind of stuff we hear?'' the comedian Abby Stein says. ''I'll tell you. 'Show me a funny woman and I'll show you a man.' That's what it's all about. At least that's what it was all about. That's the way women were looked at. I guess in some ways they still are.''

title: Exxon Daystar Sold
description: The American Solar King Corporation said it had acquired the Exxon Corporation's Daystar subsidiary and the solar-related assets of its solar thermal systems unit. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Commodities; Reversal In Cotton Profits
description: MANY cotton futures buyers fell victim once again last week to both market logic and some clever operations by professional traders. As a result, many cotton longs gave back most of their gains of the previous week.

title: IT ISN'T SHAMEFUL TO BE 'A NATION OF WAITERS'
description: It is unlikely that developing countries will fulfill their dreams of prosperity by following the route of United States and Western European industrialism.

title: MARCOS SAID TO PLAN A NEW GOVERNMENTAL STRUCTURE
description: When President Ferdinand E. Marcos seeks a new mandate in May, it will be for a job quite different from that he currently holds, according to high Government officials.

title: Brewers Get Lerch From Phillies
description: The Milwaukee Brewers, searching for more pitching, acquired Randy Lerch from the Philadelphia Phillies today in exchange for Dick Davis, a reserve outfielder.

title: CITY ASSERTS MOVE BY CALTEX ISN'T SIGN OF BAD JOB MARKET
description: New York officials said yesterday they regretted a decision by the Caltex Petroleum Corporation to move its headquarters out of the city, but they insisted that while the loss was serious it did not signal a weakened job outlook in the city.

title: CONRAIL'S FUTURE
description: Imagine the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut region and the rest of the Northeast without any railroad freight service. Picture the vast Conrail railroad system -17,000 miles of track in 17 states - in bankruptcy, with thousands of miles of track abandoned. This is the bleak prediction being made by some rail shippers in light of the Administration's decision to phase out all Federal subsidies for the struggling Conrail railroad system. What to do with Conrail?

title: BIG STOCKS OF GASOLINE SOFTEN PRICE
description: Gasoline stocks in the United States are nearing record levels, and oil company officials and independent analysts are beginning to suggest that the ample inventories could stem the upward rush in retail prices, and perhaps even begin to push them downward.

title: SHYNESS: COMMON AFFLICTION
description: One of the qualities that has endeared Lady Diana Spencer to the British public is her shyness. When her engagement to Prince Charles was announced last week, Lady Diana was described by friends as ''shy and gentle.'' The press has nicknamed her ''Shy Di'' because, among other things, she still blushes when followed by photographers.

title: Susan Barnes Wilson, Actress And Photographer of Birds, 66
description: Susan Barnes Wilson, an actress and photographer, who was also director of the dance division of the American Theater Wing immediately after World War II, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Friday at Princeton Hospital in New Jersey. She was 66 years old and lived in Griggstown, N.J.

title: Waltrip, in a Buick, Takes Carolina 500
description: Darrell Waltrip, who took the lead with just three laps to go, risked running out of fuel and sputtered across the finish line today to win the Carolina 500 Grand National stock-car race.

title: Washington Watch; Bank Battle Shaping Up
description: Washington Opponents of interstate banking are marshaling their forces for a big battle expected later this year in the Congress after some of the dust has settled from the Reagan economic bombshell.

title: MONTANEZ ABSENT FROM THE EXPOS
description: The first baseman Willie Montanez, who was excused because of his wife's illness, was the only player absent today for the start of the Montreal Expos' full spring training camp. A spokesman for the National League baseball club said Montanez was given several extra days to report because his wife was in a hospital in Puerto Rico and may have to undergo an operation.

title: A Judge's View From the Other Side of the Bench
description: As a judge in New York City's Housing Court, Jay S. Dankberg deals almost daily with landlord-tenant disputes, such as eviction proceedings.

title: Coast Guard Ends Search For South Korean Crewmen
description: The Coast Guard late tonight suspended its search in the storm-whipped North Pacific for 23 crewmen missing in their attempt to flee the burned South Korean cargo ship Dae Rim.

title: AT STRATFORD FESTIVAL, HIRSCH WELCOMES TALENT THE WORLD OVER
description: John Hirsch, the new artistic director of the troubled Stratford Shakespeare Festival, was holding cast tryouts the other day in the borrowed basement of St. George's Church here.

title: Saban Changes Sport and Joins Yankees
description: In a 30-year career as a football coach, Lou Saban has held 11 jobs, one of them for only 19 days, and now he has surfaced at the age of 59 in the unlikely role as president of the New York Yankees.

title: Fated to Be Fat
description: For years, this weight-obsessed nation has considered fatness and slimness matters of willpower. The corpulent are blamed - by others or by guilty conscience - for a disgusting inability to turn down dessert. And the verdict is surely just in some cases. But more and more evidence suggests that many fat people may be in the grip of biochemical forces that are indeed hard to control.

title: City Sanitation Dept.  Fills Operations Post
description: A 26-year veteran of the city's Sanitation Department, Vincent P. Whitfield, has been appointed to the new post of deputy commissioner for operations of the department, Sanitation Commissioner Norman Steisel announced.

title: STRATEGY SHIFT AT GENERAL FOODS
description: For a few days each winter the nation's food analysts gather in Florida for an annual ritual - rubbing elbows with industry executives at cocktail parties and luncheons, over tennis games and golf matches. At these conclaves, drinks and camaraderie flow freely.

title: Poles Cut Sugar Rations; Meat Will Be Restricted
description: The Government, giving the details of previously announced programs, said today that it had cut sugar rations by half, to 2.2 pounds per person per month, and that it would impose meat rationing April 1.

title: SCIENTESTS PRESENT RESULTS OF NEW GENETIC RESEARCH
description: The genes that dictate all hereditary traits of animals and humans are proving more complex and versatile the more scientists study them.

title: ARCHITECTURE: SUNY PURCHASE CAMPUS REFLECTS DESIGN INNOCENCE OF THE 60'S
description: quiet Westchester village. It was An Appraisal conceived in the late 1960's, at the height of the power of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and at the crest of a moment in history when the idea that modern architecture might be able to re-shape the world seemed still to have credibility. The Purchase campus emerged, thus, out of the eager reaching of an entire era, and its mass of brick buildings clustered together in the midst of 500 acres of open fields was intended to be as idyllic a surrounding as any university could offer.

title: WALL ST. HAILS WILLIAMS' RECORD
description: In April 1977, when Harold M. Williams became chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the public's perception of corporations was at a nadir, and the commission's enforcement division was at its zenith.

title: THE SUPERIOR FEDERAL EMPLOYMENT TOOL
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of indistinct printing in some copies of Business Day on Thursday, a corporation name was obscured in a Company News brief. It was the Geico Corporation that said directors had authorized management to buy up to 1.5 million of the company's common share equivalents, depending on market conditions.

title: ARTHUR GUY WILLIAMS
description: Arthur Guy Williams, a computer science specialist with the J.C. Penney Company, died Saturday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The New York Market To Finally Get Yoplait
description: In about a month the New York market, at long last, will get Yoplait, ''The Yogurt of France,'' which is already available in the rest of the nation and in 31 other countries.

title: Syracuse Captures Wrestling Crown
description: Gene Mills and Chris Catalfo of Syracuse, top seeded and unbeaten in dual meets this season, recorded pins in the semifinal round this morning in the 77th annual Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association tournament at Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: Helms Says Administration Has Cut Off Nicaraguan Aid
description: Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, said today that the Reagan Administration had already cut off United States economic aid to Nicaragua because of that nation's role in the relay of arms to El Salvador's leftist insurgents. A State Department spokesman said later that his statement was ''technically correct.''

title: ALMOST EVERYBODY SEEMS TO WANT TO WRITE CAREY
description: Interest groups who want to make sure their arguments are heard by the right parties write to Governor Carey. So did a New York City man who needed help in resolving a traffic-ticket problem, a couple who wanted something special to commemorate their 50th wedding anniversary and a 10-year-old boy who wanted to know if Mr. Carey enjoyed his job.

title: Zungul, Segota Pace 9-5 Rout by Arrows
description: Steve Zungul and Bronko Segota registered three goals apiece to lead the New York Arrows to a 9-5 victory over the Philadelphia Fever in a Major Indoor Soccer League game yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Propane Gas Blast at a Carwash Kills Employee; 15 Others Hurt
description: A propane gas explosion destroyed a carwash on a busy city street yesterday, killing one man and injuring at least 15 persons.

title: Sharif Kahn Wins
description: Sharif Khan of Toronto won a $4,000 squash racquets open tournament yesterday at the Park Avenue Squash Club. Kahn, the 11-time North American open champion, defeated another Torontoan, Gordon Anderson, 18-16, 18-16, 16-18, 17-14, for the $900 first prize.

title: Murphy Misses, Ending Streak
description: Calvin Murphy's streak of consecutive free throws ended at 78 today as the Houston Rockets lost, 102-86, to the San Antonio Spurs.

title: BLACK AFRICA OUTRAGED BY QUADDAFI'S CHAD ADVENTURE
description: There has been war here for nearly all of the two decades since Chad got its independence from France in 1960. In the beginning, desert Moslems from the north were fighting black tribes from the south, but toward the end it was rival Moslem factions doing battle.

title: Big Leap Forward
description: John Broman began ski jumping near his native Duluth, Minn., when he was 5 years old. He worked at the sport for two to four hours a day almost year round, and got to the point that he would make about 600 jumps a year in practice and competition off those towering ramps.

title: HIGH RATES SHRINK NEW ISSUE LIST
description: The high cost of borrowing continues to deter many companies, particularly industrial enterprises, from selling bonds at this time. Even though it costs 15 percent or more to borrow in the commercialpaper market and a prime-rate bank loan costs 18 1/2 to 19 percent, many corporate treasurers prefer to borrow short-term money and wait for long-term interest rates to decline before selling bonds or debentures.

title: U.S. LIKELY TO DEFER MEETING WITH SOVIET ON CONTROL OF ARMS
description: The Reagan Administration was reported today to be close to a decision to postpone a regularly scheduled meeting with the Soviet Union that deals with questions of compliance with previous agreements on limitation of strategic arms.

title: Energy
description: Near record gasoline supplies promise to slow prices rises at the pump, according to petroleum industry economists. They noted that the record 280 million barrels on hand a year ago helped stabilize gasoline prices last summer. (Page D1.)

title: DISPUTES AWAIT REAGAN ON CANADA TRIP
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has indicated that he is making President Reagan's forthcoming visit to Ottawa a test of American friendship.

title: NEW SAN ANTONIO MUSEUM CREATES ARTISTIC FERMENT
description: The old building, relic of an earlier, simpler age, rises dramatically above its surroundings, its creamcolored twin towers and battlements four and five stories high lording it over the warehouses and small industries that spread out along the northern fringes of downtown San Antonio.

title: The Stastny Brothers
description: FOR three seasons the Stastny brothers were the folk heroes of Czechoslovakia in hockey. Marian, Peter and Anton Stastny (pronounced Stash-nee) formed the high-scoring line last year on their Olympic team at Lake Placid and on the national team. But only Peter and Anton are together now after having defected seven months ago to play for the Quebec Nordiques of the National Hockey League, where they are thriving, each with 29 goals this season, each with a reported six-year contract worth $250,000 annually. Marian, the other brother, with a wife and three children, remained in their home town of Bratislava, suspended suddenly from the national team, out of hockey, even out of a job.

title: Bridge: Garozzo, Who May Be Best Of All, Had Role in Tristate
description: A man who would get many votes as the best player in history was part of the throng at the Tristate Regional Championships in Port Chester, N.Y., earlier this year. He is Benito Garozzo of Italy, whose remarkable international career began in 1961 and has brought him 13 world team titles.

title: BUDGET CUTS CAN SLASH OUR NATION'S FORESTS
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERAL BLOCK GRANTS ALONE MAY HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: French Leftists Name Candidate
description: The Radical Left Movement today chose its president, Michel Crepeau, to run in the first round of the presidential election on April 26. The party is expected to draw 1 percent of the vote, according to a recent survey.

title: League of Nations
description: In 1968, the National Hockey League reports, there were only 12 non-Canadians on its rosters.

title: Plankton Takes Handicap Easily
description: Plankton scored a 6 3/4-length victory over Nalee's Fantasy yesterday in the $83,550 Next Move Handicap at Aqueduct. Plankton, a 5-year-old mare, was ridden by Ruben Hernandez and carried the top weight of 123 pounds.

title: CROWD PLEASERS
description: At this time a year ago, Zam Frederick was a junior at South Carolina and felt that his prospects in the National Basketball Association draft after his senior year were poor. "No round," is the way he put it, considering that he had started only eight games and averaged 7.9 points.

title: SCARE STORY
description: To the Editor:

title: FAST AND EFFICIENT, MORE UNIT TRAINS ARE RIDING THE RAILS
description: It was ''astonishing,'' recalls John J. Cirigliano, an investment banker and railroad expert. ''The huge volume of coal pouring into the cars was almost like an upside-down volcano. The train itself was tremendously long, and when it took off it was at a majestically steady speed.''

title: Some Cautionary Advice on the Use of Advisers
description: Municipal officials are forever seeking help from academic and professional consultants, but the results rarely live up to their potential. That, at least, is the conclusion of Peter Szanton, an urban affairs consultant, whose study of municipal governments and their consultants, ''Not Well Advised,'' is to be published today by the Ford and Russell Sage Foundations.

title: Burroughs Trade Set
description: The Atlanta Braves said today they expected to settle the Jeff Burroughs trade tomorrow, with the outfielder going to the Seattle Mariners. Burroughs was traded this winter for an unnamed player, but he could not leave until he had cleared up a loan from the Braves. Regulations prevent a player from owing a team money while playing for another team.

title: DANCE: ALICE FARLEY'S 'ATOMIC THIEF' IN TWO ACTS
description: On weekends, certain movie theaters often show late-night horror films. Whereas some of them are classics of the genre, others, instead of being scary, are tacky or even dramatically incoherent.

title: ESPOSITO, IN SURPRISE, QUITS COACHING JOB
description: Less than two months after he had taken the job, Phil Esposito announced yesterday that he had quit as assistant coach of the Rangers.

title: THREE MOSCOW JEWS INTERROGRATED IN CASE OF UNDERGROUND JOURNAL
description: Three Jews have been questioned in the case of Viktor Brailovsky, a Jewish activist who was arrested and jailed in November, his wife, Irina, said today.

title: JETS' HESS HOLDS 75% OF TEAM
description: Townsend Martin, who bought 22 1/2 percent of the Jets for $225,000 in 1963, but who had become a critic in recent years of their nonwinning record, sold his quarter-share yesterday to Leon Hess for $5 million.

title: Ruling Is Upheld In Microwave Death
description: The New York State Workers' Compensation Board has upheld a ruling that an employee of the New York Telephone Company who worked with television relay equipment at the Empire State Building was killed by prolonged exposure to microwave radiation.

title: Market Place; A Livelier Role For A.T.&T.
description: Nobody buys A.T.&T. shares hoping for large speculative profits. As a regulated utility, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has to justify its rates to the Federal Communications Commission and to state regulators, and it must fight for every increase.

title: C.A.B. BACKS TEXAS AIR ON ITS BID FOR CONTINENTAL
description: The merger between Continental Air Lines and Western Airlines was dealt a potentially fatal blow yesterday when the Civil Aeronautics Board approved a bid by Texas International Airlines to buy control of Continental. The five-member panel's vote was unanimous.

title: Mets Counting Mixed Blessings
description: The Mets braced with mixed feelings today for the arrival of Dave Kingman. And, in the chain-reaction effect that his arrival is creating, Hubie Brooks has already lost his job at third base to Joel Youngblood.

title: Boston's WCVB-TV Sells Play With Fonda to ABC
description: In the first sale of a locally produced entertainment program to a television network, WCVB-TV in Boston has sold the rights to ''Summer Solstice,'' a drama starring Henry Fonda and Myrna Loy, to the American Broadcasting Companies.

title: JAILS' CROWDING AT CRISIS LEVELS, BOARD TELLS CITY
description: Peter Tufo, chairman of the city's watchdog Board of Correction, declared yesterday that New York City jails were so overcrowded that the situation had reached ''crisis proportions.''

title: RACISM ON CAMPUS: DIALOGUE IS RENEWED
description: Isolated incidents of racism on college campuses in recent months appear to have had the effect of enlisting greater numbers of white and black students in efforts to create better relations. Most students and college administrators reject any suggestion of an upsurge of antiblack bias on the campuses. Nevertheless, Derek Bok, president of Harvard University, last week issued an ''Open Letter on Issues of Race at Harvard'' in which he said that the goal of bringing about social interchange between minority and white students had only been ''partially achieved'' and that efforts were needed to assure minority students that they are not ''guests in a strange house.''

title: Jackson Planning To Report Today
description: Reggie Jackson said today that he planned to begin spring workouts with the Yankees tomorrow, two days late, matching last year's schedule precisely. But he did not say he would arrive at camp with check in hand to cover his $2,500-a-day fine.

title: NEW TEAM AT U.N.: COMMON ROOTS AND PHILOSOPHIES
description: The new team running the American mission here resembles an extended family whose lineage extends from Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief delegate.

title: Venezuelan Housing Loan
description: Venezuela's National Housing Institute will sign a contract tomorrow for a $186 million loan granted by an international banking syndicate headed by Citicorp, a spokesman for Citibank de Venezuela said today. The oneyear loan carries interest of three-eighths of a percentage point above the London Interbank Offer Rate and will be used to finance low-cost housing programs.

title: GISCARD'S CANDIDACY IN APRIL IS OFFICIAL
description: President Valery Giscard d'Estaing announced his candidacy today for the April presidential elections. Mr. Giscard d'Estaing's brief television appearance in the company of his wife, Anne-Aymone, made official what the rest of France has always taken for granted. It was the last of the four major candidacies to be announced, following those of the Socialist, Francois Mitterrand; the Communist, Georges Marchais, and the neo-Gaullist, Jacques Chirac.

title: 3 I.B.M. Executives Named in Drug Case
description: Three present or former International Business Machines Corporation executives were among 11 persons indicted on Federal charges of smuggling ''substantial'' amounts of cocaine into this country by air and by sea. The company was in no way connected with the alleged operation.

title: Gulf Audit Change
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said that its auditors, Coopers & Lybrand, had removed their qualified opinion from financial statements, retroactive to 1978. The auditors had qualified Gulf's financial statements for 1978, 1979 and 1980 because of the uncertain outcome of several uranium-supply suits faced by Gulf. Gulf said that by the end of 1980 it had resolved most of its disputes with the utility customers of its General Atomic Company subsidiary, recorded a provision for possible loss from supply of the uranium and settled its dispute with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

title: Dow Is Up Again, Adding 3.41
description: Stock prices recovered in late trading yesterday to post their sixth consecutive advance amid buying demand by institutional investors.

title: BRINGING CALM TO THE TRAGEDY IN DIX HILLS
description: Almost nothing touches people as much as the death of a child. The waste of a life at a young age is deeply disturbing, but it is made even the more poignant as many parents almost unavoidably identify with the loss. When two young boys attending the same school died 10 days apart in Dix Hills, L.I. recently, there was even more than the usual community pain. It was possible, at least in the minds of the parents and some doctors, that some deadly contagion was in the air. The parents not only identified with the loss of other parents but imagined it happening to themselves.

title: M.T.A. IMPROVEMENTS TOTALING $5 BILLION PROPOSED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey called today for a $5 billion five-year program of improvements in the Metropolitan Transportation Authority system ''on an emergency basis,'' and asked that the agency be excluded from a broad range of regulatory procedures in acquiring land and equipment.

title: HIRING FREEZE HITS TWO CETA PROGRAMS
description: The Reagan Administration today put a freeze on the hiring of public service workers under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.

title: Body of Executed Murderer Is Exhumed in California
description: The body of John A. Spenkelink, an executed murderer, was exhumed today for an autopsy to allow coroner's investigators to check his mother's contention that he was unconscious or dead when he was electrocuted nearly two years ago in Florida.

title: TAX LEVIED BY CANADA IN OIL RIFT
description: The conflict over energy policy between the federal Government and the province of Alberta intensified today when the central Government placed a special tax on crude oil and blamed Alberta for having forced the levy.

title: Penney's Earnings Increase by 20.3%
description: The J.C. Penney Company, the nation's third-largest retailer of gerneral merchandise after Sears, Roebuck & Company and the K mart Corporation, reported yesterday that net earnings in the 14 weeks ended Jan. 31 rose 20.3 percent, to $160 million, or $2.29 a share, from $133 million, or $1.92 a share, in the 13 weeks ended Jan. 26, 1980. Sales increased 9 percent, to $3.89 billion, from $3.57 billion

title: DECLINE FORESEEN IN PENSION SHARE OF CITY'S BUDGET
description: The portion of New York City's budget that goes to pay for municipal employees' pensions is likely to drop sharply in the next decade, according to a memorandum sent by the City Comptroller yesterday to two major bond-rating agencies.

title: BRAIN CANCER: DEATHS IN CHEMICAL PLANTS SPUR INTENSE INQUIRY
description: Medical researchers have recently found an abnormally high number of cases of fatal brain cancer, a relatively rare disease, among workers in several American oil refineries and petrochemical plants.

title: NEW TRIAL ON EVOLUTION OFF TO SLOW START ON COAST
description: The trial of religious fundamentalists' attempts to open public school science classes in California to the teaching of the Biblical doctrine of the Creation opened slowly in Superior Court here today.

title: Radio Shack to Sell Dow Jones Service
description: Dow Jones & Company announced yesterday that its information retrieval service for business news would be made available to owners of Radio Shack personal computers under an agreement signed between Dow Jones and Radio Shack.

title: Dr. Seuss's Creator 'Smothered With Love' at 77
description: He started out in advertising, but for the last 44 years Theodor S. Geisel has been writing children's books that have made his middle name a household word. So much so, that when the celebrated author celebrated his 77th birthday yesterday, the governors of 12 states proclaimed it Dr. Seuss Day.

title: POLICEMAN SUSPENDED IN SHOOTING AT MARDI GRAS THAT INJURED 2 MEN
description: A New Orleans police detective was suspended today for shooting into a Mardi Gras crowd last night and injuring the drum major of a high school band and a spectator.

title: Transit Officer Shoots Woman
description: A woman who was acting irrationally on a Queens subway train was shot and critically wounded by a Transit Authority police officer last night, after she lunged at him with a knife, a spokesman for the Transit Police said.

title: STATEN ISLAND WINS CITY U. TITLE
description: The College of Staten Island won its second City University of New York championship in three years, defeating Queens College, 83-72, last night at Fitzgerald gymnasium at Queens. The victory gave Staten Island one of 32 berths in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III basketball tournament.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FROM THE WEST SIDE

title: Auto Output Tumbles 22%
description: Production by the five major United States auto makers last month was 22 percent below February 1980, the companies reported today.

title: Father-Son Stuntmen
description: One of the most horrifying scenes in the current crop of movies comes in ''Fort Apache, the Bronx,'' and it leaves audiences gasping with revulsion. In it, two policemen watch another, from a distance, as he picks up and hurls from a rooftop an innocent teen-ager who had been watching a violent street demonstration.

title: MAX WALDMAN, PHOTOGRAPHER, 61
description: Max Waldman, a dance and theater photographer, died Sunday at his studio in New York. He was 61 years old Mr. Waldman's dramatic photographs ranged in subject matter from football players and immigrants to experimental theater and most of the major contemporary ballerinas and premier danseurs.

title: Article 027261 -- No Title
description: The International Monetary Fund today approved a $550 million loan to China, marking that country's largest borrowing from any financial institution.

title: Trucks Should Pave Their Way
description: As most drivers are painfully aware, the once-proud Interstate Highway System has become an obstacle course of potholes and crumbling bridges. It needs a major rebuilding effort costing tens of billions. It's not clear, though, who will foot the bill. Congress will no doubt look first to the Federal fuel tax. The 4-cent-a-gallon levy hasn't been raised since 1959. But a larger part of the burden should be borne by the heaviest users: heavy trucks.

title: Chemical's Prime at 18 1/2%
description: Chemical Bank, the nation's sixth-largest commercial bank, lowered its prime corporate lending rate yesterday to 18 1/2 percent, down one-half of a percentage point from the banking industry's prevailing rate. The reduction, made without comment from Chemical, matched the rate set last Monday by Chicago's Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the seventh-largest American bank. Some smaller banks are quoting an 18 1/2 percent prime, but major banks other than Chemical and Continental Illinois are holding to the 19 percent prime that has prevailed since early last week.

title: Simmer of Kings Breaks Leg
description: Charlie Simmer of the Los Angeles Kings, the league's second leading goal-scorer with 56, suffered a broken lower right leg in the third period tonight during a 1-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: ARTS DONORS CAUTION ON U.S. AID CUTS
description: Voicing dismay over President Reagan's proposal to cut Federal support for the arts and humanities in half, Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d and other witnesses told a Congressional subcommittee yesterday that the Administration was wrong in assuming that private philanthropy would help make up for the governmental cuts.

title: COMPUCORP'S ELECTRONIC DICTIONARY
description: In the battle for a slice of the booming word processor market, I.B.M. and Xerox are encountering tough competition from a small California company. It has developed a desktop system that identifies and corrects spelling errors in several languages.

title: Chess: Some Fear Using a Gambit, But Some Relish Challenge
description: The trouble with a gambit is that one man's sacrifice is another man's gain of material. Most players may be intimidated by a gambit, but some are glad to go a pawn or a piece ahead and face the task of defense with a mood of cool optimism.

title: Vietnam War Stone Vanishes in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO (AP) - A piece of granite that a group of Vietnam veterans intended to use as a pedestal for a war memorial disappeared from the lawn of the Federal Building here over the weekend.

title: PROSECUTION AND DEFENSE REST IN UTAH TRIAL INVOLVING DEATHS OF 2 BLACKS
description: The case of Joseph Paul Franklin, the onetime Ku Klux Klansman and American Nazi accused of the racially inspired sniper slaying of two blacks who were jogging in a city park last summer, will go to the jury without testimony from the defendant.

title: Rewards Offered In Slaying of Cabbies
description: Two groups of independent taxi operators offered $1,000 rewards for information about the slayings of two cabbies in robberies in less than 24 hours.

title: CITIBANK PAYING $500,000 TO SETTLE USURY LAWSUIT
description: Citibank said yesterday that it had agreed to repay an average of $5 apiece to 91,000 of its customers to settle a suit brought against it by the New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams. The total payment will be about $500,000, the bank said.

title: POINTS OF CONFLICT EMREGE SWIFTLY IN HEARING ON CLEAN AIR STANDARD
description: Areas of conflict emerged today as Congress held its first hearing on the reauthorization of the Clean Air Act, which is the law with the most important impact on the environment that Congress is likely to take up this year.

title: ATOMS WOMEN DOMINATE COLGATE TRACK
description: The four members of the team that established a world-indoor best time in the one-mile relay at the Millrose Games Feb. 6 scored individual victories yesterday at the seventh annual Colgate Women's Games at Madison Square Garden.

title: SHARP CUTBACKS IN U.S. EMPLOYEES IN REGIONAL CENTERS CONTEMPLATED
description: The Reagan Administration is contemplating reducing sharply the number of Government employees in New York City and nine other Federal regional centers, a White House official said today.

title: DOCTORS SUSPECT THAT THOUSANDS ARE ADDICTED TO NASAL SPRAYS
description: When Peter Barrett was growing up more than 30 years ago, he used to take rambling walks in the Maine countryside around his hometown of Biddeford, despite the fact that he was allergic to much of the plant life that he found in the outdoors that he loved -ragweed, timothy and even certain kinds of trees.

title: Sports of the Times; Billy Ball Still Wants Guidry
description: Overnight, the Valley of the Sun had turned into the Valley of the Rain, washing out the Oakland A's workout. But in the warmth of his clubhouse office, Billy Martin, alias Billy Ball, was joking about his dual role as director of player development, another term for general manager, and dugout manager.

title: Volvo Unit Seeks Texas Oil Concern
description: Volvo Energy, a unit of Volvo, the Swedish auto maker, said it was negotiating the purchase of Fred Olsen Inc., a Houston-based oil company, for an undisclosed price.

title: Israeli Planes Raid Bases Of Palestinians in Lebanon
description: Israeli planes raided Palestinian positions northeast of Tyre today, according to the Lebanese radio.

title: Olin to Raise Prices of Its Caustic Soda
description: The Olin Corporation said it would raise its prices of liquid caustic soda by $30 a ton, for both spot and contract customers. The company also said that there would no longer be a price advantage for shipment from Acme, N.C.

title: POLISH MEAT-RATIONING PLAN CALLED HIGHLY COMPLEX
description: A three-month meat-rationing plan that will begin April 1 is a complex program involving four categories of meat and six or seven different groups of consumers and will regulate both quality and quantity.

title: I.B.M. EXPLORES NEW TIE WITH MATSUSHITA
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has proposed to the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company that the Japanese concern make small computers for it, industry sources here say.

title: THE INTERGROUP LESSON MAYOR KOCH MUST LEARN
description: To the Editor:

title: 12 M.P.'S QUIT BRITISH LABOR PARTY, PLAN TO FORM A NEW CENTRIST
description: GROUP By WILLIAM BORDERS

title: BUSINESS INSTITUTES ON THE RISE; PAUL L. MONTGOMERY
description: Though money for higher education is as tight as ever in most sectors, a rising market has been developing in recent years in one of the quieter corners of university life: business financing of chairs or institutes devoted to the study of private enterprise.

title: Mitsubishi Receives Kennecott Holding
description: The Kennecott Corporation said it had transferred a one-third interest in its Chino copper mining and processing facilities near Silver City, N.M., to the Mitsubishi Corporation for an initial cost of $116 million.

title: Perjury Trial Ends In Deadlocked Jury
description: The perjury trial of John Spain, a prominent Putnam County businessman, ended in a mistrial yesterday when the jury said it remained deadlocked after five days of deliberations in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Bridge: Smoking Issue Represents A Problem for Organizers
description: The smoking issue has long been a source of contention among players and organizers. There are those who wish to puff away incessantly and there others who object strongly to being puffed at.

title: S.E.C.'s New York Chief
description: Donald N. Malawsky, 45, has been appointed administrator of the New York regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The appointment was made last Friday by Harold N. Williams on his last day in office as S.E.C. chairman.

title: Peru Cuts Mineral Tax
description: The Peruvian Government reduced taxes on mineral and petroleum exports today to 12 percent, from 17 1/2 percent, effective immediately. The changes were contained in a legislative decree published in the official state bulletin.

title: ST. LOUIS MAYOR IN CLOSE PRIMARY
description: This Missouri city holds its Democratic primary election tomorrow, and there is a strong chance of defeat for the Democratic Mayor, Jim Conway, who was considered a cinch for reelection only a few months ago.

title: WATT VOWS SHIFT ON KEY MINERALS
description: Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt today promised to rearrange national priorities and to allow private interests to search for strategic minerals beneath public lands.

title: FILM-TV WRITERS VOTE NOT TO STRIKE
description: At a meeting in Los Angeles last night, members of the Writers Guild of America agreed almost unanimously not to go on strike against movie and television producers at this time. The guild's contract expired yesterday. However, more than 1,500 members at last night's meeting accepted a recommendation from their 15-member negotiating committee to extend the contract for at least two weeks while talks continue.

title: SO, CHILE'S 2 MURDERS ARE NOW FORGIVEN
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to embrace the Chilean dictatorship has turned its so-called war against international terrorism into a cynical exercise in hypocrisy.

title: Egypt's Defense Minister Killed in a Copter Crash
description: Defense Minister Ahmed Badawi and 13 senior Egyptian Army officers were killed today when their helicopter crashed near the Libyan border.

title: PARTIAL VICTORY AGAINST DRUG ABUSE BY THE YOUNG
description: To the Editor:

title: Further Delay Seen on Tram
description: The expected resumption of service on the Roosevelt Island tramway this week could be delayed, an official of the Division of Housing and Community Renewal said yesterday. The official said it was feared that the Swiss company that built the East River cable car system might cause further delay by refusing to delegate responsibility to its local representative to approve a certificate of work completion. Such approval by the Swiss company, Von Roll, is necessary before service can be resumed, the official said.

title: SENATE HEARING OPENS ON FARM BILL
description: Senator Jesse Helms, opening Senate hearings on a new farm bill, said today that the United States needed an agricultural policy in which the Government ''supports but does not dominate the farmer.''

title: ARMED ROBBERY IS COURT CHARGE FACED BY BOY, 9
description: A 9-year-old suspect in the robbery of a midtown bank last Wednesday was formally charged with armed robbery and possession of a weapon yesterday in a juvenile-delinquency proceeding that was open to the public in Family Court.

title: TV: 'THE PRIDE OF JESSE HALLAM' STARS JOHNNY CASH
description: In ''The Pride of Jesse Hallam,'' on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock tonight, Johnny Cash, the country-music star, plays a man with problems. His wife has died. He has to sell his rural Kentucky home in order to pay for his daughter's serious operation in an Ohio hospital. Moving to Cincinnati, he is faced with the uncomfortable fact that his son is flunking out of the new school. On top of everything else, Jesse is having a tough time getting a job as his urban neighbors scarcely disguise their contempt for country hicks.

title: Braniff Union Backs Aid Plan
description: The Braniff International Corporation said today that its workers who are members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters had agreed to contribute 10 percent of their salaries to help the airline ease its severe cash shortage.

title: AN ADDED PETROLEUM RESERVE
description: A central goal of America's energy policy is the reduction of vulnerability to interruptions of oil imports, and it is now generally recognized that building up a strategic petroleum reserve is a key element in this policy.

title: SOUTH AFRICA IS AGAIN DENIED A SEAT BY GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: South Africa briefly returned to the General Assembly today for a debate over its control of South-West Africa, but it was promptly expelled again at the urging of other African nations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are out of jail space. We have no more room.''

title: OPERA: 'KHOVANSCHINA'
description: The Opera Orchestra of New York has given the city some exciting musical events over the last 10 years, but Sunday night's concert performance in Carnegie Hall of Mussorgsky's ''Khovanshchina'' will linger in the memory as one of the group's most triumphant evenings. A 15-minute ovation greeted the final chord of this three-and-ahalf-hour epic, and every second of applause was richly deserved.

title: Aga Khan Urges Sharing Of News Organizations
description: The Aga Khan called here today for the development of shared ''newspaper companies and news organizations between the industrial world and the developing world.''

title: Salem No. 1 Reactor Closed for Repairs
description: A reactor at the Salem Nuclear Generating Station may be out of service for six days so that a steam pump can be fixed and other repairs made that were ordered by Federal authorities, a utility official said.

title: Liberian Ship Is Reported Sinking In Mid-Pacific, Coast Guard Says
description: A Liberian vessel with 31 crew members was reported sinking about 600 miles west of Midway Island because of a large gash in its hull, the Coast Guard said tonight.

title: Vatican Reaffirms Its Ban On Membership in Masons
description: The Vatican today reaffirmed the centuries-old church prohibition against Roman Catholics becoming Freemasons. A statement by the Congregation of the Doctrine of the Faith, the former Holy Office, said there is no change in the church law that bars Roman Catholics under penalty of excommunication from joining Masonic organizations and similar secret groups that it sees as rivals to religion.

title: RURAL AREAS END TREND, SURPASS CITIES IN GROWTH
description: For the first time since 1820, rural areas and small towns are growing faster than the nation's metropolitan areas, and the growth in some sections is occurring at a rate more pronounced than demographers expected when the turnaround in migration patterns was detected in the mid-1970's.

title: CANADIAN GAS LURES DRIVERS FROM BUFFALO
description: The most popular attraction for foreign visitors in all of Canada, some Federal officials here agree, may not be Niagara Falls or any of the country's other spectacular stops, but the Robo gas station over at the corner of Princess and Waterloo.

title: Jury Chosen for Berrigans' Trial
description: A jury of eight women and four men was seated today to hear the trial of the Berrigan brothers and six other persons accused of breaking into a suburban Philadelphia missile assembly plant. The Rev. Daniel Berrigan, his brother, Philip, and the other defendants said the jury selection was racist because no blacks were seated. Judge Samuel W. Salus of the Montgomery County Court said prospective jurors were chosen at random by a computer from voter registration lists.

title: Gas-Treating Plant Planned by Chevron
description: Chevron U.S.A. Inc. said it would build a second gas-treating plant in the Tuscaloosa Trend area of southern Louisiana, a geological formation estimated to contain up to 20 trillion cubic feet of recoverable natural gas.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Company of America began an $8 million research and development effort in aluminum continuous strip casting, intended to at least double the production rates available from their current roll casting units.

title: Soccer in Europe Falling From Pedestal
description: Late in the morning of Feb. 23, officers of the Bayerische Hypotheken-und-Wechselbank told the directors of the TSV 1860 Munich soccer team that they were closing off the last of its credit lines. The decision meant that the club was effectively bankrupt - no more money on hand to pay players' salaries, or to deal with its $2.09 million in debts.

title: '60 MINUTES' WILL GO AHEAD WITH REPORT ON HAITI
description: Don Hewitt, executive producer of CBS News' ''60 Minutes,'' announced yesterday that he would assign a report on Haiti, which Mike Wallace, citing concerns about the safety of relatives in the Caribbean nation, had asked a fellow correspondent, Morley Safer, not to do.

title: 6 NAZIS AND FOLLOWERS ARE SEIZED IN CAROLINA IN PLOT TO BOMB TOWN
description: Six American Nazis and supporters were arrested today on charges of conspiring to stage a series of terrorist attacks in the event that a group of Ku Klux Klansmen and Nazis was found guilty of murdering five leftist demonstrators last year.

title: No Headline
description: In a case with far-reaching implications for organized labor, the Supreme Court agreed today to define the category of ''confidential employees'' who are excluded from the protections of Federal labor law, including the right to join a union.

title: CAMPAIGN FINANCE CASE TO GET REVIEW
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Federal limits on campaign financing allow the national political parties to assume some of the fund-raising authority that Congress placed in the hands of the state party organizations.

title: KEY POINTS IN REAGAN SPEECH AND LEAGUE STATEMENT
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a speech by President Reagan today to the convention of the National League of Cities and from a section on spending reductions in a policy statement issued Saturday by the league: Reagan Speech

title: Westgate Receives Higher Airline Bid
description: The Westgate-California Corporation said it had received a new bid for Air California that tops the $47.5 million offered by Air Florida last November.

title: Talking Business with W.N. Walker of Anticounterfeit Coalition; The Pirating Of Brand Goods
description: The counterfeiting of brand-name products is affecting growing numbers of legitimate manufacturers. For years, Cartier watches and Levi's jeans have been favorite targets, and now designer jeans are being copied. The counterfeiters' prey, however, ranges from such mundane items as toiletries and flashlight batteries to technological products, including spare parts for aircraft and automobiles. Copyrights, as well as trademarks, are vulnerable.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS UP IN JANUARY
description: Spending on new construction in the United States rose in January for the sixth consecutive month, continuing the industry's moderate recovery from last year's recession, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Thinking Out Loud
description: The remarks of Treasury Secretary Regan are becoming a handy guide to the Administration's inner doubts on matters economic. A few weeks ago Mr. Regan, a newcomer from Wall Street, kept changing his mind publicly about economic strategy.

title: MAKING AN ENTRANCE INTO THE CITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Grace Oil Spending
description: W.R. Grace & Company said it plans to spend $130 million for domestic oil and gas exploration in 1981. The amount is 20.4 percent more than the 1980 expenditures of $108 million. The company also said that a subsidiary, the Grace Petroleum Corporation, had formed a limited partnership and raised $25 million in additional funds for the 1981 exploration and development program.

title: Books Of The Times
description: Christopher Lehmann-Haupt A GOOD SPORT. By Julia Whedon. 197 pages. Doubleday. $10.95. KISS MOMMY GOODBYE. By Joy Field- ing. 308 pages. Doubleday. $11.95.

title: Paris Withholds Boats for Libya
description: The French Government confirmed today that it was halting delivery of 10 missile-carrying patrol boats ordered by Libya four years ago. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said that ''delivery of the boats is not envisaged at the present time.'' Reliable sources said that the decision was prompted by Libya's military intervention in the central African nation of Chad.

title: SEGAL TO SUCCEED AMES AS LINCOLN CENTER CHAIRMAN
description: The Lincoln Center board of directors unanimously elected Martin E. Segal yesterday as the center's chairman, effective June 1. The nonsalaried position is one of the most powerful in the field of American arts administration. The chairman of Lincoln Center helps determine policy for the nation's largest performing arts institution and, in so doing, influences arts policy in the country at large.

title: Milwaukee Firemen's Strike Settled in Judge's Chambers
description: A one-day strike by 1,090 firefighters in this southeastern Wisconsin city of 700,000 people ended today with an agreement worked out in the chambers of a circuit judge who sought ''to avoid a lengthy and bitter strike.''

title: Networks' Cable Ads
description: Some of the Ted Bates & Company crowd showed up at the Time-Life Building to hear their client, Home Box Office, announce a $10 million advertising promotion campaign that would use network TV for the first time.

title: Litton NATO Job
description: Litton Industries said it had been awarded a $103 million contract from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for a missile system to be deployed in Italy and France. The company said the system could be deployed in other NATO nations, particularly Greece and West Germany. The French company Sintra will produce the systems as a subcontractor, Litton said.

title: BLACK STEREOTYPES FEATURED IN DARTHMOUTH EXHIBIT
description: ''Images of blacks in popular culture have been an important vehicle for the transmission of the myth of black inferiority,'' says the sign at the exhibit entrance.

title: ARMY RECRUITERS ALERTED AFTER TERRORISTS' THREATS
description: The Army has ordered recruiting officers and sergeants around the nation to take special precautions after an increase in threats from Puerto Rican terrorists, according to Army officers here.

title: EXPERT IN FROZEN FOOD LED PUBLISHING HOUSE
description: Dr. Donald K. Tressler, chairman of the AVI Publishing Company of Westport, Conn., which specializes in books on food science, nutrition and related subjects, died Saturday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Westport.

title: MET OPERA: JUDITH BLEGEN AND PAVAROTTI IN 'ELISIR'
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI was, of course, the centerpiece of the first ''L'Elisir d'Amore'' of the season Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera. Even in his somewhat slimmed-down shape, the world's bestknown tenor can fill up any stage he stands on, as the big artists always seem to do. His voice, too, filled the space with ease, even if not invariably with the sweet purity that once was its most striking quality in the role of Nemorino.

title: SENSE OF VULNERABILITY CREEPS INTO AFRIKANER VISION
description: Seven years ago Jan Lourens imagined an avenue of majestic shade trees leading to the spacious house he had just built on the perfectly ordered, highly productive farm that had also existed in his imagination before it was developed out of malarial bush here near the Mozambique border.

title: COYOTES ARRIVE IN THE NORTHEAST AFTER AN EVOLUTIONARY TREK ACROSS THE
description: U.S.

title: 'IDENTIFICATION DAY' AT MUSEUM
description: Anyone with a shell, stone, skeleton, flower, or any stuffed or live fauna that needs to be identified can it to the American Museum of Natural History at 79th Street and Central Park West on Saturday afternoon. The museum's scientists will examine the specimens and tell the visitors what they are.

title: Museum Picks Williams
description: Harold M. Williams, who left the chairmanship of the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday, has been named to the new posts of president and chief executive officer of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., the museum announced yesterday. Mr. Williams will move to California in the spring to begin his new career, at a salary that the museum did not disclose.

title: HOW A WASHINGTON FLOP BECAME A BROADWAY HIT
description: The word of mouth on ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' which is based on the music of Duke Ellington, was bad. The word was even dreadful. They should close the show, wiseacres said when the musical was in Washington; it will never make it in New York. Then the improbable, if not the impossible, happened. On Sunday night, ''Sophisticated Ladies'' opened on Broadway, and yesterday it was pronounced a hit.

title: TOP WINNER IN WESTINGHOUSE SCIENCE SEARCH IS HUNTER HIGH PIANIST
description: A 17-year-old senior at Hunter College High School in Manhattan, who worked for five months on experiments in genetic engineering that helped explain resistence to disease, won the top prize today in the annual Westinghouse Science Search.

title: EX-NUCLEAR CHAIRMAN WHOM CARTER OUSTED IS NAMED ACTING HEAD
description: Joseph M. Hendrie, who was dismissed more than a year ago by President Carter as chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission amid criticism of its handling of the nuclear plant accident at Three Mile Island, has been named acting chairman of the agency.

title: Telephones for the Deaf
description: Very often, the human eye and brain can recognize familiar configurations even if all but a few significant data points are left out - a creative power of perception that may someday allow totally deaf people to converse in sign language over a special ''telephone.''

title: GUARD SET FOR BELZ RABBI AS HASIDIC TENSION GROWS
description: The Grand Rabbi of Belz is expected to arrive in New York from Israel this morning amid heavy police security following threats of violence by a rival Hasidic sect in Brooklyn over religious issues.

title: Swede Buys U.S. Yacht
description: Louisiana Crude, whose performance as the winner of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference had virtually assured it a spot on the three-boat American team that will compete this summer in England for the Admiral's Cup, has been sold to a Swedish interest.

title: Sawhill Rejoins McKinsey & Co.
description: John C. Sawhill, 44 years old, the first head of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation who resigned that post in January, has rejoined McKinsey & Company, the big management consulting firm, as a director and senior partner in its Washington office. Early in his career, Mr. Sawhill was an associate at McKinsey.

title: A TOP REPUBLICAN STATE SENATOR CALLS WELFARE INCREASE PROPOSAL A 'FRAUD'
description: The deputy majority leader of the State Senate said today that proposals by Governor Carey and the Senate majority leader for a welfare grant increase were ''dishonest'' and ''a fraud'' because they would lead to an equivalent drop in the Federal food-stamp allotment.

title: 26 Elected to the Theater Hall of Fame; 26 From Broadway Voted Into Theater Hall of Fame
description: Twenty-six Broadway personalities have been elected to the Theater Hall of Fame by a group of drama critics and editors. They will be inducted on April 5 in ''A Tribute to Broadway'' at the Uris Theater, where the hall is situated.

title: Hearns Will Fight Shields
description: Thomas Hearns, the Boxing Writers Association's Fighter of the Year for 1980, who has had trouble finding someone to meet him in 1981, will defend his World Boxing Association welterweight title against Randy Shields of Chicago.

title: 3 More Refiners Raise Prices
description: Three more United States refiners raised their wholesale gasoline prices yesterday amid indications that Saudi Arabia, America's largest foreign oil supplier, may cut production by 500,000 barrels a day to remove some slack from the global oil market.

title: ONE PROJECTED SACRIFICE TO REAGAN ECONOMICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Agency Is Right On Track
description: STANLEY RAPP thinks his agency is on a winning streak. He has every right to. Rapp & Collins, since 1976 the direct marketing subsidiary of Doyle Dane Bernbach, ended last week by picking up its third piece of new business for the month, a short month at that.

title: Q. Why are trees with needles usually found in cold regions?
description: A. Some trees in colder climates have evolved with needle-like leaves because these leaves offer greater protection in extreme weather. Broad leaves are more effective in food production, but smaller-surfaced needles can withstand damage from wind and snow and they lose less water.

title: STATE'S TOLL CONTRADICTED ON EXPOSURE TO TOXINS
description: The Broome County Health Commissioner said today that 100 people in addition to firemen and cleanup workers had been exposed briefly to toxic chemicals in a contaminated Binghamton state office building before the cleanup of the building was ceased last week.

title: AM International Reports a Deficit
description: AM International Inc., reported a threemonth loss of $6.9 million. In the similar quarter last year, it earned $262,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Montgomery Ward Credit Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell $50 million of notes due 1986 through a Lehman Brothers group.

title: 'LOLITA SYNDROME' IS DENOUNCED
description: A group of professional women yesterday denounced what they called ''the Lolita syndrome,'' which they described as ''the rapidly growing number of images that make sexual objects out of little girls and legitimize their sexual abuse.''

title: REAGAN DEFENDS CUTS IN BUDGET AND ASKS FOR HELP OF MAYORS
description: President Reagan defended his budget-cutting program today and called on the nation's mayors to help him through ''a political gantlet of interest groups'' gathering to defeat it.

title: EL SALVADOR REPORTED TO ASK U.S. FOR EMERGENCY AID OF $200 MILLION
description: The Reagan Administration is considering a Salvadoran request for an emergency economic aid package, according to sources close to negotiations under way here.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the Late TV Listings in section 1 on Sunday, an incorrect entry appeared for ''60 Minutes.''

title: North Carolina Grand Jury Indicts 3 Ex-Jaycee Officers
description: A grand jury indicted three former national, state and local officers of the Jaycees today in connection with the misapplication of funds raised for charity in North Carolina.

title: SHOOT NOT TO KILL
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY ASSERTS NEED TO SAVE WATER PERSISTS DESPITE FEBUARY RAINS
description: Rainfall in New York City's watershed area last month was more than twice normal levels for February, but the city's Department of Environmental Protection said yesterday that continued vigilance was needed if the city was to avoid a serious water shortage in the summer.

title: Medical World News Sold by McGraw-Hill
description: Medical World News, for 21 years one of the most popular publications among physicians, has been sold by McGraw-Hill Publications to Hospital Equities, Houston, operator of health care facilities.

title: 5 Burned in Car Near Everglades
description: The bodies of five persons, some with their hands tied behind their backs, were found yesterday in a burning car near the Everglades, the authorities said. Witnesses at the scene said that the two men, a woman and two children may have been shot. The police in this Fort Lauderdale suburb said that firemen had found the bodies and that the case was being investigated as a homicide.

title: Navajo Group Asks Judge to Bar Building of Ski Resort in Arizona
description: A group of Navajo Indians asked a Federal judge today to veto a proposed Arizona ski resort, saying its construction would anger their gods by desecrating a mountain range that is sacred to their tribe and the Hopi Indians.

title: Olympia Will Seek More Abitibi Stock
description: Olympia and York Investments Ltd. said that it intended to stay in the bidding for control of Abitibi-Price Inc. and would amend its current $28-a-share (Canadian) tender offer to increase the number of shares sought to more than 50 percent. Olympia also said it would reserve the right to to improve its bid.

title: Pakistani Hijacks Airliner With 148 to Afghanistan
description: A political dissident armed with what appeared to be a grenade hijacked a Pakistani jetliner with 148 people aboard today and forced it to land in Kabul, the capital of neighboring Afghanistan, the Government said.

title: MARDI GRAS CHEERS THE FLOAT MAKERS
description: As the last of the 51 parades celebrating the pre-Lenten Carnival here roll along the streets of the French Quarter tomorrow, on Mardi Gras, there will be among the viewers some exhausted but exhilarated artist-businessmen who helped make the show possible.

title: 2 IRANIAN LEADERS SUGGEST CHANGE IN STANCE ON TRUCE
description: For the first time since the Iraq-Iran war began, two Iranian leaders broke today with the previous Government position of refusing to consider a peaceful solution until after Iraqi troops are withdrawn from Iranian territory.

title: PNEUMONIA IS DIAGNOSED IN MUMMIES
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Studies of 108 South American mummies show pneumonia was a major cause of death in that continent 3,000 years ago, and that its incidence was close to the modern rate.

title: Warren, a Veteran at 52, Starts a New Agency
description: Douglas J. Warren, who was one of the founders of Warren, Muller, Dolobowsky a decade ago, is coming out of semi-idleness at 52 to give agency-founding another try. This time the name is Warren & Epstein, and this time the creative partner is Lee Epstein, 53, who left Doyle Dane Bernbach after almost 20 years as a vice president/senior creative supervisor.

title: San Diego Judge Approves Settlement for 1,900 Elderly
description: A judge approved a $21 million settlement today between a bankrupt chain of retirement homes sponsored by the United Methodist Church and 1,900 elderly people in three states who paid as much as $100,000 each for lifetime care.

title: Ex-Hostage Proposes
description: During a Mardi Gras visit to New Orleans, Sgt. Rodney V. Sickmann, who was held hostage in Iran, quietly proposed marriage to his high school sweetheart, Jill Renee Ditch.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: Anyone who has tried can tell you -a good pair of leather pants is almost impossible to find. The leather is often too stiff and the cut is usually all wrong.

title: Edwards Backs Increase In Nuclear Arms Work
description: Secretary of Energy James B. Edwards said today that the nation must produce more weapons-grade nuclear materials or it would not have enough for weapons systems to be built in the 1980's.

title: Seoul Drops Merger Plan
description: South Korea said today that it had scrapped a plan to merge the Saehan Motor Company, in which the General Motors Corporation has a $30 million investment, with the Hyundai Motor Company, wholly owned by Koreans.

title: U.S. Judge Urged to Order More Beds in Texas Prisons
description: The Department of Justice asked a Federal judge today to order the Texas prison system to provide beds for about 2,600 inmates now sleeping on floors and window ledges, and to end the practice of putting two inmates in a single cell by 1983.

title: Drawing Distinctions at Harvard Law
description: ''Law Review'' is shorthand for the top students in a law school, and nowhere more so than at Harvard. The latest issue of The Harvard Law Review will tell you more than you'd think to ask, even if you're a lawyer, about investment law, nuclear power litigation, insanity acquittals and half a dozen other subjects. The latest action of The Review's editors tells the law school and the outside world that some of the nation's brightest students are wrestling with one of the nation's most elusive problems.

title: GROUP PRESSING STATE TO REVIEW POLICE SHOOTINGS
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union yesterday urged Governor Carey to authorize a special prosecutor to investigate five shootings of civilians by policemen in New York City and on Long Island in the last three weeks.

title: Six-Month Bill Rises to 14.13%; Three-Month Rate at 14.46%
description: Short-term and long-term interest rates rose yesterday as traders adjusted to higher overnight interest rates and light investor demand for issues due in more than two years.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MARCH 3, 1981
description: International Economic aid for El Salvador of $200 million to $225 million over the next seven months is being considered by the Reagan Administration, according to sources close to the negotiations in San Salvador. Citing the country's troubled economy, one negotiator predicted that the Salvadoran Government ''will fall in six months if it does not get aid.'' (Page A1, Column 1.) More military aid for El Salvador was announced by the State Department. It said that $25 million worth of additional equipment and 20 more United States noncombat military advisers would join the 25 advisers there. (A1:2.)

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Maize Products Company, Stamford, Conn., has elected Charles A. Koons vice president of corporate planning and development.

title: IF MULTIPLE MISDEMEANORS BECAME A FELONY
description: To the Editor:

title: JWT Group's Earnings Up
description: The JWT Group announced yesterday that its fourth-quarter revenues were up 34.9 percent, to $113.3 million, from $84 million in the same 1979 period, while net income improved only 19.4 percent, to $7.6 million, or $1.44 a share, from $6.3 million, or $1.40 a share, in the same 1979 period. The full year saw revenues up 32.8 percent, to $352.2 million, while net income rose 23 percent, to $16.8 million, or $3.42 a share, compared with $3.01.

title: S.E.C. CLEARS 2 LAWYERS ON FRAUD REPORTING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission dismissed disciplinary proceedings today against two New York lawyers accused of unethically and illegally acquiescing in fraudulent financial reporting by their corporate client.

title: JERSEY BARS SHIFT IN PRIMARY FINANCING
description: The New Jersey Assembly today defeated a bill backed by Governor Byrne that would have increased to $150,000 from $50,000 the amount a candidate for governor must raise to qualify for public financing in the June 2 primary.

title: SOCIAL DEMOCRATS OFFER TO ACT AS MEDIATORS IN SALVADOR
description: The Social Democratic parties of Latin America offered last night to act as mediators in the conflict between the United States-backed Government in El Salvador and its guerrilla opponents.

title: HAIG PLANS A MIDEAST TRIP IN APRIL TO REASSURE ARABS ON U.S. STANCE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. will travel to the Middle East next month to make a major effort to persuade friendly Arab countries that the United States will respond firmly to what he perceives as a Soviet threat to the region, Administration officials said today.

title: FEELING THE CHILL
description: A short time ago, I went to the cold shelter to see a family in trouble. The family had been found living in Grand Central Station, along with scores of other unfortunates - ''bag people,'' ''Bowery men'' uptown, mentally deranged travelers, individuals discharged from state hospitals, and random lost souls. Since the family refused any placement and was ''out in the cold,'' the police sent them to the temporary-housing shelter, at the National Guard Armory, at 142d Street and Fifth Avenue, that had been set up by the city for people without heat.

title: Prince Charles to Visit New York Before Wedding
description: Although he'll be busy preparing for his forthcoming wedding, Prince Charles plans to take time out for his first visit to New York, on June 17, just weeks before the royal wedding.

title: A DEMOCRAT'S APPROACH TO CUTTING THE BUDGET
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY POLICE SAY REVIEW REFUTES CLAIMS LINDBERGH BABY SURVIVED
description: The New Jersey State Police said yesterday that a new review had refuted claims that the kidnapped baby of Charles A. Lindbergh might still be alive. Instead the review confirmed that a corpse found May 12, 1932, was that of the 20-month-old baby.

title: BANK TARGET: GLASS-STEAGALL ACT
description: A lot of bankers are currently intrigued by history, especially by the career of Carter Glass, a Virginia publisher who lost an eye in a gun battle over an editorial and eventually abandoned journalism for politics.

title: Santee Figures He Can Be No. 1
