description: David Santee is frustrated, and who can blame him? He finished second to Terry Kubicka in the 1976 United States figure skating championships, third to Charles Tickner and Scott Cramer in 1977, second to Tickner in 1978, third to Tickner and Cramer in 1979, second to Tickner in 1980 and second to Scott Hamilton three weeks ago.

title: Gerulaitis Finally Does It
description: Vitas Gerulaitis beat Bjorn Borg in an exhibition today, 6-4, 3-6, 6-4, 7-6. The victory was his first over Borg after 17 consecutive losses.

title: BIRMINGHAM COMMUTERS CONTEND WITH LIFE WITHOUT TRANSIT SYSTEM
description: Thousands of commuters today hitched rides with friends or used old church buses, vans and taxis to get to work because Alabama's largest city was operating without a transit system.

title: JUDGE BACKS ABC RIGHT TO SKATING COMPETITION
description: The exclusive coverage by ABC-TV of the 1981 World Figure Skating Championships, which will open here tomorrow, was upheld today by the chief judge of the Federal District Court, T. Emmet Clarie, who ruled that the exclusion did not violate freedom of the press.

title: Steel Production Rises
description: Steel production rose to 2.55 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 3.1 percent from the previous week's 2.47 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: These are days of change for Dart & Kraft Inc., the corporation born of last fall's merger of Dart Industries and the Kraft Corporation.

title: by Malcolm W.Browne
description: Beyond Cape Horn: Travels in the Antarctic By Charles Neider. 387 pages, illustrated. Sierra Club Books, San Francisco. $16.95 Antarctica, My Destiny By Capt. Finn Ronne. 278 pages, illustrated. Hastings House, New York. $12.95 Assault on Eternity: Richard E. Byrd and the Exploration of Antarctica, 1946-47 By Lisle A. Rose. 292 pages, illustrated. Naval Institute Press, Annapolis. $19.95

title: Markets
description: Gold prices fell to their lowest levels in 14 months as traders turned to high-yielding, dollar-denominated assets. Gold fell $24.75 an ounce, to $465.75, in London. The dollar climbed to 2.1510 marks in Frankfurt from 2.1295 on Friday. (Page D1.)

title: IN ALL SHAPES, THE SUIT IS BACK
description: The suit, once as irrevocably linked with spring as the Easter bonnet, has at times appeared to be an endangered species. Sweaters, shawls and odd jackets served as covering when cover-up was needed and the suit's domain was limited to the very conservative or very mature woman.

title: THEATER: 'BLACK CAST STAGES O'NEILL
description: ''LONG DAY'S JOURNEY Into Night,'' Eugene O'Neill's most harrowingly autobiographical drama, would seem to be a definably white experience. Yet, the cast of black actors that has been assembled at the Theater at St. Peter's Church under the astute direction of Geraldine Fitzgerald has instilled the play with a freshness and an immediacy. The considerable strengths and the primary shortcoming of the production have nothing to do with a question of color.

title: SAIPAN EAGER FOR CHANGE TO COMMONWEALTH STATUS
description: A few months ago Betsy Robb, who lives on Capitol Hill, the American-style community built here by the Central Intelligence Agency 20 years ago, saw a group of men in her back yard with sticks. Another man with a gun was walking around in the front yard.

title: TEMPLE OUSTS HOFSTRA IN EAST COAST PLAYOFFS
description: Keith Parham sank six foul shots in overtime tonight to give Temple a 68-63 victory over Hofstra in the first round of the East Coast Conference basketball playoffs.

title: PARTIES VS. TV
description: The United States Supreme Court today is scheduled to hear lawyers from the three major television networks and the Government argue the question of when a Presidential campaign actually begins.

title: F.C.C. TO RULE ON BETTER CAR PHONES
description: The Federal Communications Commission this week is expected to approve a car telephone service that could sharply increase the number of customers served and would sound as clear as ordinary telephone service.

title: The Fruits of 'Eden'
description: Since she appeared in last month's three-part television adaptation of John Steinbeck's ''East of Eden,'' Jane Seymour has been inundated with scripts, according to the actress, who said most of the offerings called for her to play ''evil women.''

title: PARTIAL VICTORY AGAINST DRUG ABUSE BY THE YOUNG
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Retiring DeBusschere '22'
description: The Knicks will retire Dave DeBusschere's number 22 in ceremonies before their game with the Boston Celtics March 24 at Madison Square Garden.

title: MARIJUANA FOUND IN MANY U.S. PARKS
description: Marijuana is being illegally cultivated in all 17 national forests in California, in many forest areas of the Pacific Northwest and in almost all of the national forests in the southern states, the United States Forest Service has reported.

title: CHARITIES TO RETURN PART OF $4 MILLION TO ENERGY DEPT.
description: Four national charities today agreed to return 25 percent of the total of $4 million granted them to distribute to the poor to help pay fuel bills by a Carter Administration official just before he left office. In return, the Energy Department has agreed to drop its efforts to have all the money returned.

title: The U.N. Today; March 3, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets on Namibia at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Subway Roulette
description: The newest ploy in the M.T.A.'s befuddle-the-rider campaign is subway roulette. The subways are becom-ing illiterate; indeed unlettered. A friend reports waiting for a D train in midtown the other night when along on its track came a train with no D, or any I.D., on the front.

title: Earnings Gain For Andersen
description: Arthur Andersen & Company, a large multinational accounting firm, reported yesterday that its earnings in the 1980 fiscal year increased 31 percent, to $182 million, compared with $139 million in 1979.

title: LINE AT WELL IN JERSEY COMMUNITY: 'LIKE GOING BACK TO PIONEER DAYS'
description: Townspeople are flocking to a brick pumphouse here - carrying glass jars and bottles, empty onegallon plastic milk containers, five-gallon jugs and even picnic coolers - to draw water from the borough's only safe well.

title: BRASCAN CONFIRMS ADDED SCOTT HOLDING
description: Brascan Ltd. confirmed yesterday that it had increased its holdings in the Scott Paper Company to 12 percent through the acquisition last Friday of an additional 3.1 million shares and that it might seek a 20 percent stake.

title: Johnson Replaces Brooks As Hockey Coach of U.S.
description: Bob Johnson, hockey coach at the University of Wisconsin and father of Mark Johnson, a member of the gold-medal winning United States Olympic hockey team, was named yesterday to replace Herb Brooks as coach of the United States national team.

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate, 18.50-19.00** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Chiaroscuro
description: Observing that dimming the lights at his daughter's 10th birthday party reduced the level of squabbling considerably, a man we know was reminded of his own good cheer when he steps into the dim illumination of a neighborhood bar. In weaker lighting, both his cantankerousness and some of his inhibitions fall away. He even becomes a bit of an actor. He can lie a little, on days when it seems to ease the heart to stretch the truth, or pretend to be happier (or unhappier), younger (or older) than he really is. Wearing his choice of a drink like a favorite hat, he compares Harry ''the Cat'' Brecheen's pitching tricks to Catfish Hunter's, to a patent attorney who remembers only the latter.

title: Buitoni Is Moving Account to Compton
description: The Buitoni Foods Corporation will be moving its advertising account to Compton Advertising. The account has been billing in the neighborhood of $1 million, but judging from the remarks of William P. Smolka, the new vice president, marketing and sales, it is due for growth, just as the company is.

title: Demand for Beer in China
description: China plans to produce more beer this year than ever before, but the supply will not match the growing demand, the newspaper Workers Daily said today. The paper said existing breweries would be expanded and new ones built to raise output to 850,000 tons this year, 180,000 tons more than last year. But market forecasts indicate China needs at least 2 million tons a year to satisfy domestic demand, the paper added.

title: St. Paul's Chosen as the Site For Charles's Wedding
description: St. Paul's Cathedral, the Renaissance masterpiece of Sir Christopher Wren and a prominent landmark here for 273 years, is where Prince Charles will marry Lady Diana Spencer on July 29.

title: Red Flannel Hash
description: 2 cups diced boiled potatoes 2 cups diced boiled beets 1 large onion, diced 2 cups diced corned beef (or other leftover meat, such as roast beef) Salt and pepper to taste 2 or 3 slices bacon or equivalent of salt pork.

title: UA-Columbia Bid Increased to $75
description: Robert M. Rosencrans, president of UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc., said yesterday that Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. and Dow Jones & Company had sweetened their offer to jointly acquire UA-Columbia to $75 a share, up from $72 in a previous offer.

title: New Literary Quarterly, Grand Street, Coming Out
description: A literary quarterly called Grand Street, which promises to be in the tradition of the pioneering ''little magazines'' produced in the 1920's, is being readied for publication, according to Ben Sonnenberg, the publisher. It will be edited by Mr. Sonnenberg, a playwright and teacher, and Elizabeth Pochoda, who is on leave as literary editor of The Nation.

title: THE ROOTS OF REVOLT IN SPAIN: MILITARY PLOT EVOLVED AFTER A REBUFF BY KING
description: The plotting that led to the seizure of Spain's Parliament by rebellious Civil Guards began late last year. A group of senior generals and colonels met in Madrid to discuss their fears that the Government of Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez was leading the nation to disaster.

title: Cost Versus Nutrition
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: ''Penny-Pinchers and Inflation-Watchers Tell How They Save'' (Feb. 18) was a gallant attempt to illustrate how one might drastically cut food bills by prudent shopping and careful meal planning. However, as a nutritionist, I feel compelled to comment on the wholesomeness and ingenuity of the one-week menu described.

title: GOURMET MAIL FOR THE GUIDE
description: Basic to the entire operation of Michelin inspectors is correspondence from consumers. Nearly 30,000 letters a year pour into the Avenue Breteuil office, more of them critical than laudatory. All are read and answered and most, especially when they show a pattern, are acted upon. A flood of complaints about a highly regarded restaurant will prompt a visit, as will a batch about a new place, as long as it is not obviously a campaign orchestrated by the owners.

title: UNUSUAL ALLIANCE SEEKING TO POSTPONE POLUTION CURBS ON STEEL INDUSTRY
description: The steel industry, in an unusual alliance with environmentalists, asked a Senate committee today to act quickly on legislation to give it three additional years to meet clean air standards.

title: News Analysis
description: Six weeks after President Reagan's inauguration, a variety of strikingly different and strongly held views continue to mark an economic team in which, by all accounts, David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, remains the central figure.

title: VW of America Says Sales Rose by 4.6%
description: Sales of American-built Volkswagens rose by 4.6 percent last month from their level of February 1980, VW of America reported.

title: Simmer Undergoes Surgery
description: Charlie Simmer of the Los Angeles Kings underwent surgery today on the broken right leg that will keep him out of action the rest of the season.

title: BAPTIST MEDICAL CENTER FILES MOVE FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: 4 By RONALD SULLIVAN

title: EUROPEANS ASSAIL U.S. HIGH RATES
description: The governments of Western Europe, with support from some major international economic institutions, are struggling to protect their economies against the impact of a strong United States dollar and the high interest rates that bolster it, which they fear could push them into another recession later this year. But many seem privately skeptical about their chances of success.

title: Spinal Meningitis Kills L.I. Student
description: A teen-ager who attended Oceanside High School died of spinal meningitis. Two of his friends had contracted the disease within the past five weeks, but they have fully recovered, health authorities said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * CAE Electronics Ltd., a unit of CAE Industries Ltd., has been awarded a $34 million Canadian Government contract to develop and manufacture three flight simulators for the Canadian Armed Forces.

title: Executive Vice Presidents Appointed by Agencies
description: There seems to be an epidemic of new executive vice presidents at the agencies lately.

title: COST OF AVERAGE MARKET BASKET IS UP AGAIN
description: THE average weekly cost of feeding a family of four in New York City inched up 47 cents, reaching $103.13 during the period of Feb. 17-27, according to the city's Department of Consumer Affairs. During the same period a year ago the average market basket cost $92.44.

title: NEW ISSUE IN CHINA: TRUTH IN ADVERTISING
description: China's two-year-old advertising industry is already running into truth problems. Some of the creative comrades, it seems, have succumbed to an affliction not unknown on Madison Avenue: hype. And the Government doesn't like it.

title: DEMOCRAT SUPPORTS TAX MOVE
description: The Democratic chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, threw his support today behind a Republican move to commit the committee and Congress to an early effective date for tax relief for business.

title: PLAN FOR A NEW FIFTH AVENUE JEWELRY BUILDING IS STUDIED
description: The jewelry industry loathes decentralization. Manufacturers, retailers, brokers handling new merchandise and traders of older diamonds and other precious stones all seem to want to operate cheek by jowl, under conditions of tight security.

title: Article 028576 -- No Title
description: In an effort to compete with money market mutual funds, the Western Savings Bank in Philadelphia today will begin to offer sixmonth money market certificates on which interest rates will be readjusted weekly.

title: Pianist: Seymour Lipkin
description: SEYMOUR LIPKIN gave his first piano recital in 20 years Saturday night at the 92d Street Y. If another year goes by before his next one, it will be too long.

title: Careers; Dual Major: Leverage in Job Market
description: TAKING double majors in college is the look of the future, according to many educators. The impetus for this trend has come from the students themselves rather than from college administrations.

title: LONG-TERM CONTRACTS FOR PURCHASE OF ARMS PROPOSED AS COST MEASURE
description: The Reagan Administration plans to experiment with buying arms on long-term orders, a move that officials hope will reduce spending by more than $1 billion a year by 1985.

title: Iona Advances, 64-48
description: Steve Burt scored 28 points to help Iona defeat Siena, 64-48, tonight in the opening round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro playoffs. Iona (14-13) will meet St. Peter's Thursday night in the semifinals of the tournament, at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I.

title: Moderate Quake Strikes Northern California Coast
description: A moderate earthquake shook 100 miles of the northern California coast from Monterey to Marin County today, breaking windows and tumbling goods off store shelves. No injuries were reported.

title: A Louis Armstrong Hiatus
description: Because he began playing professionally when he was in his 16th year and kept it up more or less continuously during good health until his death two days after his 71st birthday, it has been a commonplace to refer to Louis Armstrong's ''55-year career.''

title: RATING ROASTING CHICKENS: A GUIDE FOR BUYERS
description: NEW YORKERS buy an average of 6.5 million chickens a week, so it's no wonder that chicken companies compete for customers here with the intensity of promoters of designer jeans. Forty-five percent of the New York market is estimated to prefer brand-name chickens: Competition among Perdue, Cookin' Good and Paramount involves millions of dollars, and New Yorkers have been subjected to a barrage of advertisements in subways, on radio and television and in newspapers.

title: L.I.U. OUSTS WAGNER IN METRO TOURNEY
description: In a sharp reversal of their earlier meeting this season, Long Island University defeated Wagner, 89-79, on the loser's court last night and advanced to the semifinals of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro tournament. Last Dec. 13, the Sea Hawks won, 112-86, on the Blackbirds' court in Brooklyn.

title: Diana Ross and the Joffrey In Gala at Met March 15
description: Diana Ross, Douglas Fairbanks Jr. and the Joffrey Ballet will appear in a gala performance at the Metropolitan Opera House on March 15.

title: Jury Begins Deliberations in Trial Of Suspect in 2 Utah Shootings
description: A jury of 10 women and two men began deliberations in the trial of Joseph Paul Franklin, who is charged with killing two young black men as they jogged in a Salt Lake City park last Aug. 20.

title: U.S. AID FOR THE P.L.O. AS A BUDGET ITEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Phillies Still Divided, But Not on Objective
description: For the first time since they won the World Series more than four months ago, the Philadelphia Phillies assembled their full squad for spring training today and predicted they would again survive their feuds and antagonisms.

title: BAUHAUS, ENGLISH ROCK
description: Bauhaus, the English rock quartet that made its debut in New York at Club 57 last Saturday, is a theatrically oriented post-punk band whose sources are all too obvious. The focus is the lead singer, Peter Murphy, whose Gothic pretensions caricature both Jim Morrison and Bryan Ferry.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''President Reagan says the one thing we're not talking about is going back to discrimination.

title: REICHMANNS RAISE ABITIBI OFFER; THOMSON, NU-WEST WITHDRAW
description: The $601 million struggle between two prominent Canadian business families for control of Abitibi Price Inc., the world's largest newsprint maker, took two dramatic turns here today when the secretive Reichmann family suddenly raised to $32 a share its bid for all shares of Abitibi.

title: New I.C.I. Division
description: Imperial Chemical Industries said today that it had merged its plastics and petrochemicals divisions into a single unit. The new division will have sales of around 1.5 billion, or about $3.3 billion, a year and will begin operations in April, the company said.

title: 2 Escape as U.S. Jet Crashes
description: A United States Air Force F-4 Phantom jet crashed during a training flight today but the two crew members ejected safely. The plane, based at the Hahn Air Base near here, plummeted to the ground about 18 miles northwest of Zweibrucken.

title: No Headline
description: SWORN TO OFFICE IN SEOUL: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea being congratulated by Charles H. Percy of Illinois, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Mr. Chun, a former army general who seized power through a military coup in 1979 after the assassination of President Park Chung Hee, took over the presidency of South Korea last September. In an election held last month, he was voted to a full seven-year term.

title: Indians Did It In Smoke
description: Diplomacy nowadays is mostly a matter of sending signals. Suppose you want to let country X know you are sick and tired of its insolence and likely to give it a rap on the snout unless you start getting a little respect. How do you send the message?

title: Ohio Investors Raise Wheeling Steel Stake
description: The American Financial Corporation, a diversified investment company controlled by two brothers, Carl and Robert Lindner, said it had raised its stake in the Wheeling Pittsburgh Steel Corporation to 9.3 percent.

title: A First for the First Family
description: The parents of one of New York's much-talked-about young ballet dancers will see him perform professionally for the first time at a gala benefit March 15 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: REAGAN TO REQUEST $38 BILLION INCREASE IN MILITARY OUTLAYS
description: The Reagan Administration plans to ask Congress tomorrow for increases of $33.8 billion in military spending, including nearly $1 billion more for the Rapid Deployment Force and operations in the Indian Ocean, military officials said today.

title: MOSLEM ABDUCTED BY HER FAMILY IS BACK WITH HUSBAND IN CANADA
description: Almost three years after being forcibly separated from her non-Moslem husband in Montreal and flown back to her native Algeria, Dalila Maschino is back in Montreal and reunited with him.

title: Gunmen in Heidelberg Hold 28 Hostages in Bank Theft
description: Two gunmen held five senior bank officials and their families hostage for nearly 12 hours today, forcing them to help steal $1.37 million in the biggest bank robbery in West German history.

title: THE CHARMS OF PORT-THE 'ENGLISHMAN'S WINE.'; by Terry Robards
description: IT was a sedate dinner party given in London by an American banker and his wife for a group of fellow Americans on a chill evening in March, a season that is no longer really winter but not yet spring either, a time when the daffodils are beginning to bloom in Hyde Park but the rain is persistent and cold. The town house was like many in the Belgravia section: kitchen, dining room and library on the ground floor, living room and sitting room upstairs, with bedrooms above.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Anatole Broyard THE LONE PILGRIM. By Laurie Colwin. 211 pages. Knopf. $9.95.

title: Tests on Children Are Postponed For Synthetic Growth Hormone
description: A synthetic human growth hormone, produced by so-called gene-splicing techniques, will not be available for tests on abnormally small children until new studies are made on adverse side effects, doctors at Stanford University said today.

title: DINNERS HIGHLIGHT TOWN MEETINGS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Elaine F. Weiss is a journalist who is writing a social history of Vermont. By ELAINE F. WEISS WINDHAM, Vt. AT noontime yesterday inside the town halls, schoolhouses, churches and grange halls of Vermont's 237 towns, citizens of the state sat at long tables, ate baked beans and apple pie and carried out the rituals of a civic holy day.

title: Pittsburgh Ousts Rutgers
description: Sam Clancy scored 16 points to lead a balanced scoring attack that rallied Pittsburgh from an early 12-point deficit to a 67-62 victory over Rutgers tonight in the opening round of the Eastern Eight playoffs.

title: HOSPITALS STRUGGLING TO CONTAIN SOARING FUEL COSTS
description: On a cold day, Hartford Hospital burns as much oil as 15 average residential houses use in a year. Twenty years ago, $100,000 was the annual heating bill for the facility. Last year, its oil and gas costs totaled $1.7 million, and this year they will be even higher.

title: PRESIDENT DOUBTFUL ON U.S. INTERVENTION
description: President Reagan said today that he saw no likelihood that the United States would send fighting forces to El Salvador in an effort to help the Government there defeat leftist insurgents.

title: VOLUME UP
description: The stock market plunged yesterday, registering its first loss in more than a week in accelerated trading as many traders sold their stocks, apparently to earn profits on the past week's market rise.

title: Index; International
description: Allen implements scaled-down version of adviser's role A2 On Chad's uneasy frontier, foreign agents languish A3 Loyalty oath ordered for recruits to China's army A3 Around the World A5 People of Nice now export their winter carnival A7 Reporter's Notebook: At Soviet congress, praise for Brezhnev A8 Soviet party congress affirms leadership A9 Moslem flees her family to rejoin Catholic husband in Canada A10 Government/Politics Reagan nominates 17 for key Ad- ministration posts A18 Delay on pollution curbs urged for steel industry A22 House panel hears report on cuts in Veterans Administration A24 Mayor Koch names a new panel to look at the taxi industry B3 Anderson blocks Carey plan for Medicaid cost takeover B6 Koch's aide defends tax incentive programs for landlords B8 General Around the Nation A12 Rubin Carter wins new hearing on 1966 murder charge B2 Long Island's North Fork be- comes a wine-producing area B2 Health/Science Tests of synthetic growth hor- mone delayed for children A22 The Reagan Administration re- jects water aid for New Jersey B5 Baptist Medical Center files bank- ruptcy petition B5 News Analysis Howell Raines on Reagan's drive for states' rights A1 Steven Rattner discusses the Rea- gan economic team D1 The Living Section Food Rating roasting chickens: a guide for buyers C1

title: Islanders, on Kallur's Late Goal, Tie Oilers, 8-8; Bossy Scores 4
description: The Islanders thought they had it out of their system. After giving up a club-record 11 goals in Calgary last Wednesday night, they had concentrated on defense and allowed only two goals in their next two games. They had won both and returned home tonight to show their fans they were once again on the right track.

title: ISLAMIC GROUP SEES GAIN IN IRAQ-IRAN PEACE EFFORTS
description: An Islamic commission trying to end the Iraqi-Iranian war decided today that its three-day visit to Teheran and Baghdad this week was so promising that it would return to the Iranian capital tomorrow.

title: Con Edison Fined For Flooding at Plant
description: The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission ordered Consolidated Edison to pay a $210,000 fine for violations in connection with flooding in October at the utility's Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant in Westchester County.

title: KNIT A RIBBON SWEATER, AND TRY A $6 MOCCASIN
description: 1. Ribbon Sweaters

title: Alan L. Dingle, 85, a Civic Leader Who Served on City Charter Unit
description: Alan L. Dingle, a lawyer and civic leader in Harlem for many years, died Monday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 years old and lived in Harlem.

title: BLUES BEAT BRUINS, EXTEND LEAD
description: Wayne Babych and Mike Zuke scored powerplay goals to lead the St. Louis BLues to a 4-2 victory tonight over the Boston Bruins.

title: British Reserves Up
description: Britain's official reserves of gold and foreign currency rose $40 million in February, to a record $28.434 billion, according to Treasury figures published today. But the increase was much smaller than the $1 billion rise in January, and officials said there was an underlying decrease because of the falling value of the British pound, which lost 17 cents in trading against the United States dollar last month.

title: WRONG U.S. STANCE ON EL SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT BACKS PATENT IN COMPUTER PROCESS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, by 5 to 4, that an industrial process could be eligible for a patent even if it incorporated a mathematical formula or computer program that would not in itself be patentable.

title: NEW PUBLICITY FOR NEW AUTOS
description: One cherished tradition of the domestic automobile industry that has crumbled before the onrush of imports is the annual fall new-model introduction, with its elaborate prerelease secrecy followed by hard-sell hoopla.

title: Minor Hotel Fire in Las Vegas
description: A thousand gamblers and guests had to leave the 380-room Silverbird Hotel today because of a brief fire under the stage of the empty nightclub. A hotel executive said that casino employees returned to their posts shortly after 5 P.M. and gambling resumed in half an hour.

title: Sadat Leads Funeral March For Egypt's Defense Chief
description: Egypt today buried with full honors its Defense Minister, Ahmed Badawi, and 13 senior officers who died yesterday in a helicopter crash.

title: Accounts
description: * Gillette Company to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc., Boston, for trade advertising of blades, razors and Cricket lighters.

title: 'Grandmother's' Closes Sunday
description: The producers of ''To Grandmother's House We Go,'' at the Biltmore Theater, have announced that the play will close after Sunday's matinee.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE refrigerator was full, but not with the usual American fare. No eggs, cheese or cold cuts, no butter or margarine, no beer or soda pop, and no ice cream, steaks or roasts in the freezer. The cupboard was hardly bare, but lacked the sugared cereals, salted crackers, canned soups, jellies, cookies, packaged puddings, white bread, polished rice, salad oil, salt, coffee or tea found in typical American pantries.

title: U.S. CITES RECENT RAIN
description: The Reagan Administration, contending that above-normal rainfall in February had lifted the ''threat of a disaster'' in New Jersey, refused yesterday to declare a state of emergency in the state or grant $116.3 million that Governor Byrne had sought for water-relief projects.

title: CBS-TV FINISHES FIRST IN LAST 'SWEEPS' WEEK
description: The dominance of the CBS prime-time schedule was demonstrated again last week - the final week of the critical ''sweeps'' rating period - as the network's regular series easily outpointed a series of special programs on NBC, including the two-part showing of ''Evita Peron,'' starring Faye Dunaway.

title: Changing Times As an Ad Medium
description: When the 33-year-old Changing Times magazine finally decided 15 months ago to take advertising, it got 200 angry letters and 129 subscription cancellations. That is about the only bad thing that has happened as far as Nicholas H. Niles, the publisher, is concerned, except that not enough people in the advertising community realize the magazine is now an ad medium.

title: No Headline
description: The Mets counted their first injury of spring training today when Lloyd McClendon, a minor league catcher, was struck on the left forearm by a bat and suffered a hairline fracture.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THIS Friday, that renowned sailor Walter Cronkite will cast off from his moorings on the ''CBS Evening News.'' It is a circumstance that, Felicia Lamport believes, the American poetic tradition ought not to ignore. Miss Lamport - the Cambridge author, chess fiend and versifier extraordinaire - wrote the following encomium to mark the occasion. As someone else at CBS used to say: Good night, Walter - and good luck.

title: TAX INCENTIVE FOR LANDLORDS DEFENDED BY HOUSING OFFICIAL
description: At the start of what promises to be a long, contentious debate in the City Council, the Koch administration yesterday strongly defended one of the city's major tax incentive programs for landlords and developers while conceding that a review of some aspects of the program might be warranted.

title: SINGLE-ADVERTISER MAGAZINES
description: The United States Army tries many ways to persuade young men and women to sign up and serve their country. It advertises on television. It sends out direct mail. It runs magazine and newspaper ads. It hands out booklets at recruiting stations.

title: MAJOR BANKS LOWER PRIME TO 18 1/2%
description: Major banks across the country, in a reaction to competition from cheaper sources of credit and sharp declines in demand for business loans, lowered their prime rates yesterday by half a percentage point, to 18 1/2 percent.

title: PEUERTO RICO'S CONSUMER AGENCY OUTLAWS TALC ON RICE
description: The use of talc on rice imported into Puerto Rico or processed or sold there was prohibited today by the Commonwealth's Secretary of Consumer Affairs.

title: BLACK UNEMPLOYMENT IS NO MERE MATTER OF NUMBERS
description: To the Editor:

title: JACKSON REPORTS, OWNER BRISTLES
description: Reggie Jackson joined the Yankees today, two days late for spring training; intent on fighting his $5,000 fine, but otherwise desirous of keeping the peace with George Steinbrenner. The owner, however, was not in the same conciliatory mood.

title: THEATER: 'GOYA' ON WAR
description: IN Goya's historic series of etchings, ''Los Desastres de la Guerra,'' people are trapped in the thrall of death - the starved, the maimed and the wounded crying soundlessly while phantoms watch. In ''Nada,'' a man, lifting himself from his grave, inscribes a final word, ''nada,'' or ''nothing.'' The mordant spirit of this dance of death, the artist's response to the Napoleonic invasion of Spain, is the essence of ''Goya,'' a new theater piece designed and executed by the Bread and Puppet Theater. ''Goya'' is on a double bill with ''Venus Rising From the Water'' at Theater for the New City.

title: No Headline
description: PICKETS FAIL TO HALT NUCLEAR CONTAINER: Policemen in Seabrook, N.H., remove demonstrator from the path of reactor vessel being transported to the nuclear power plant there. Though about 175 protesters gathered for the demonstration, none were arrested. The plant has been a focal point of antinuclear activism.

title: STATEMENT ON BITTERMAN IN COLOMBIA CALLED RUSE
description: A statement by leftist guerrillas that the fate of Chester A. Bitterman 3d, the kidnapped American, has been sealed appears to be ''psychological warfare,'' a source close to the case said today.

title: Billy Carter's Negotiates I.R.S. Deal to Save His House
description: Billy Carter's home was to have gone on the Internal Revenue Service's auction block yesterday, but a last-minute agreement saved it, at least for now.

title: Bubonic Plague Case Is Suspected in City
description: A case of suspected bubonic plague has been reported in New York City, Mayor Koch announced yesterday. The Mayor emphasized, however, that there was no threat of contagion from the 38-year-old man who was said to be in isolation at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: BUT, U.S. BUSINESSMEN, DON'T JOIN THE TWAIN
description: It is fashionable to examine with awe the Japanese economy's achievements and to single out for particular praise management style and the social arrangements on which it is based. Both are extolled as models that the United States ought to emulate. I believe that such emulation is neither feasible nor desirable.

title: TV STATION DEFIES COURT ON SKATING-CONTEST BAN
description: A television station here showed highlights of the opening day of the 1981 World Figure Skating Championships on its noon news program despite an exclusive contract held by ABC-TV.

title: Thousands Turn Out to Seek 90 Job Openings in Toledo
description: Some of the approximately 5,000 applicants who lined up yesterday in Toledo, Ohio, to file for some 90 job openings with Johnson Controls Inc., a manufacturer of automobile batteries. The applicants waited for up to 18 hours in a line that stretched for blocks for jobs that will pay $7 to $10 an hour in a plant that is scheduled to open this summer in nearby Holland. About 10 percent of the work force in the greater Toldeo area is unemployed.

title: Change in Priorities for Fotiu
description: Nick Fotiu, the Ranger left wing, spent his first four years in the National Hockey League establishing himself as an intimidator, quick and effective at punching in the nose the ruffians of other teams. Many of the Madison Square Garden fans howled encouragement, delighting in Fotiu's brawling, in the first three years he played here.

title: Genetech Sees '84 Market
description: Genetech Inc. said today that it would begin marketing three health-related substances that utilize recombinant DNA by the end of 1984, and expressed confidence that it would maintain a lead in the commercial applications of genetic engineering.

title: CHINA'S ARMY PLANS AN OATH OF LOYALTY
description: China's leaders have ordered the army to administer a loyalty oath to all new recruits, requiring them to swear allegiance not only to the Communist Party and the Government but also to the present regime's modernization policies.

title: Court Finds Bias in Layoffs Of Toledo Firefighters
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled today that the Toledo Fire Department's policy of basing layoffs on seniority was improper because it had a ''devastating effect'' on integration.

title: MICHELIN CHALKS UP ANOTHER STELLAR YEAR
description: Whenever restaurant men gather in France they retell the story of Jacques Maniere and the Michelin inspector. Twenty years ago, before becoming famous in St.-Germain-des-Pres here with Le Pactole and later Dodin-Bouffant, Mr. Maniere had a place at Pantin, a tough industrial area just over the Paris city line.

title: PROGRAMS FOR VETERANS WILL BE CUT IN BUDGET, PANEL IN HOUSE IS TOLD
description: President Reagan's budget-cutters want to lay off 20,000 medical personnel in the Veterans Administration and scrap the readjustment counseling program for Vietnam veterans, a Congressman reported today.

title: Advertising; Cable TV: Control At Issue
description: AS the cable television industry opened its first national conference on advertising yesterday, there seemed to be an undercurrent of concern about how much of the camel to allow into the tent.

title: Economic Scene; The New Faith Has Its Skeptics
description: ON Jan. 4, 1923, a Frenchman named Emile Coue, who had spent most of his life as an obscure pharmacist in Troyes but who had invented a system for curing mental and physical ills, arrived in New York. He was met at the pier by a great crowd, eager to learn his doctrine of autosuggestion. You were supposed to have faith in yourself, which you gained by repeating constantly, ''Every day in every way I am getting better and better.''

title: O'Neill Interceded With Reagan To Get Early Pension for Official
description: It was with the help of Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House of Representatives, that Charles D. Ferris arranged with the Reagan Administration to be kept on as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission until early next month so he would qualify for a $25,000-a-year Federal pension two years ahead of normal retirement time.

title: Firestone to Sell 75% Of South Africa Unit
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said that it would sell about 75 percent of its South African subsidiary to Federale Volksbeleggings Beperk for undisclosed terms.

title: Madison Unit Names Yeowell President
description: Brian M. Yeowell, 43 years old, has been elected president and chief executive officer of Mass Marketing Systems International. This company, a newly created subsidiary of Associated Madison Companies, an insurance holding company, will be based in Encino, Calif., and sell insurance through the mail, underwritten by the National Benefit Life Insurance Company, another Madison subsidiary.

title: Thomson-CSF Gets Order
description: Thomson-CSF S.A. said today that it had been awarded a contract to build 35,000 visual display units for GTE Communication Network Systems Inc, a unit of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation. The company did not disclose the value of the contract. Thomson said the units, to be delivered next January, are ''intelligent'' terminals similar to ones designed to take the place of the telephone directory in French homes.

title: STAGE: 'THE SURVIVOR,' ENDURING NAZI HORROR
description: AS many others have noted, the Holocaust is a story that can't be told by just anyone. If the unfathomable horrors of Nazi genocide are to remain forever in the forefront of the world's conscience, they must be conveyed by writers, historians and artists who can make them as palpable as is humanly possible. (No one, after all, can truly recreate the Holocaust for those who didn't experience it.) Simply put, this means that hacks have no right to use this piece of history as a grazing ground. Slipshod dramatizations don't keep the nightmare fresh. They trivialize it, depersonalize it, distance it. They turn the Holocaust into popcorn entertainment that audiences can all too comfortably consume and forget.

title: U.S. ADHERING FOR NOW TO ATOMIC ARMS PACTS PROVIDING SOVIET DOES
description: The Reagan Administration pledged tonight that, pending completion of an overall policy review, it would adhere to existing strategic arms limitation agreements with the Soviet Union so long as the Russians did the same.

title: America, Again
description: Just last week the idea was expressed in gray, abstract words in the report of a Federal commission on immigration: ''Historians, in their support of increased immigration, have cautioned against overly restrictionist tendencies. They point out that U.S. citizens have always been concerned about the arrival of immigrants, but note that immigrants have always made contributions to U.S. society.''

title: THE LOW COST OF FEELING EXTRAVAGANT
Matthew Houston, 70; Jazz Funeral Marshal
description: Matthew (Fats) Houston, the grand marshal at many of the jazz funerals in New Orleans, had his own funeral yesterday on the eve of Mardi Gras. He died last Wednesday at the age of 70.

title: U.S. BARS TREATY FOR NOW ON USE OF SEA RESOURCES
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it would not go along with previously agreed-upon efforts to conclude a treaty this spring to regulate the use of the oceans and their riches at the United Nations Law of the Seas Conference.

title: To Put Transit Together Again
description: The big news about the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is that it is decaying at an alarming rate. As safety and timely performance decline, so does ridership, imperiling the economies of New York -city, region and state. Governor Carey has now sent a plan for capital improvements to legislative leaders. So far so good - but not far enough. It will not work unless Mayor Koch and officials of suburban counties served by the M.T.A. are also involved.

title: CARRUTHERS PAIR 7TH AFTER SHORT PROGRAM
description: The world figure skating championships began today with the men's compulsory figures, a semi-sedentary activity that ranks in excitement somewhere between chess and deep breathing.

title: PLEASE, JAPAN, RETURN THE FAVOR: OCCUPY US
description: After World War II, Americans spent 80 months in Japan building a peace-loving, democratic, and self-supporting society. It was the most ambitious large-scale exercise of peacetime diplomacy in American history. Now is the time for the Japanese to reciprocate. The United States needs renewal, ''a new beginning'' in the words of President Reagan. Japanese leadership, supported by American hard work, could accomplish this noble purpose. Without a preliminary war, we should ask the Japanese to come here, occupy us, and do exactly those things we did for them from 1945 to 1952.

title: WHAT TO LOOK FOR IN A CHICKEN
description: A few facts to keep in mind when buying a chicken: Skin should be fairly taut, but not mottled looking or rough with translucent dry spots. Skin color is no indication of a chicken's flavor.

title: No Headline
description: REAGAN NOMINATES 17 TO KEY POSTS IN STEP TO FILL TOP-LEVEL VACANCIES

title: SOVIET LEADERS AFFIRMED IN OFFICE AS CONGRESS ENDS
description: Despite the advanced age of most of them, the leaders of the Soviet Union were confirmed in office today as the 26th Congress of the Communist Party came to a close.

title: Hearings Begin On Rail Merger
description: The Union Pacific Railroad began presenting its case today for its proposed acquisition of the Missouri Pacific and Western Pacific lines, a merger that would create the nation's third-largest rail system.

title: JANUARY NEW HOME SALES DOWN
description: The market for new houses continued to deteriorate in January, with sales dropping 6.5 percent from December on a seasonally adjusted basis, the Government reported today.

title: Toxic Levels Rise In Town's Last Well
description: Increased levels of the toxic chemical @tetrachloroethylene in the last untainted well in this Morris County community have prompted its mayor, Robert H. Johnson, to urge its 6,800 residents to get their water for drinking and cooking from emergency tanker trucks already here.

title: Manir Ahmed's Tandoori-Style Chicken
description: 1 3-to 3 1/2-pound chicken, carved at joints and cut into pieces 1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon each of cinnamon, cardamon, bay leaf, minced fresh ginger, ground cumin, ground fresh chilis 2 teaspoons each of minced fresh garlic, minced fresh coriander (Dhaniea) 1 cup fresh yogurt 1/3 cup fresh cream

title: EDNA BEILENSON, 71, GRAPHIC ARTS EXPERT AND BOOK PUBLISHER
description: Edna Rudolph Beilenson, head of the Peter Pauper Press, publisher of decorative books distinguished by their fine paper and typography, died Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 71. She lived in Manhattan.

title: TV' 2 HOURS OF STALKING AND SUSPENSE
description: ''NO PLACE TO HIDE,'' CBS-TV's movie tonight at 9 o'clock, is billed as a psychological-suspense thriller. It is the kind of project that the old Alfred Hitchcock series did very nicely in the space of an hour or less. Stretched to two hours, this story suffers from the familiar television affliction of conspicuous bloat.

title: IN FRENCH CITY, PARTY'S OVER... BUT IT'S FOR SALE
description: Carnival fun ends here tonight and carnival business begins tomorrow. The carnival at Nice is one of the best known in Europe, but the people of Nice, who have used their pre-Lenten high jinks to lure off-season tourists for almost a century, have added a new twist in recent years: they not only put on a carnival, they export it.

title: IN PEKING, BAGELS WITH A FLATBUSH FLAVOR
description: Behind the Forbidden City, down a narrow walled street and in a sunny little two-family house filled with plants and Chinese books there exist, for fleeting moments on some Saturday afternoons around coffee time - so what can I tell you? -bagels.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table accompanying a survey of corporate earnings in Business Day on Monday gave an incorrect figure for 1980 revenues of Owens-Corning Fiberglass Corporation and thus an incorrect percentage change.

title: A REPUBLICAN SEEKS TO RUN IN RIVAL RACE
description: Eric J. Schmertz, a Republican and a former member of the New York City Board of Collective Bargaining, said yesterday that he was seeking permission from the city's five Democratic county leaders to run for Mayor in their primary.

title: Infant Dies in a Fire in Hartford
description: A 5-month-old girl was killed in a fire today at her family's apartment, fire officials said. The girl, Takama Warner, was found on a couch on the first floor of the apartment in the Dutch Point section of the city.

title: Leonard's Title Defense Will Have $60 Top Ticket
description: The Sugar Ray Leonard-Larry Bonds fight for the World Boxing Council welterweight title in the Syracuse Carrier Dome March 28 will have a ticket price range of $10 to $60. Mike Trainer, Leonard's attorney, said yesterday that he expected all 25,000 seats to be sold.

title: News Analysis
description: ''What once was a Federal helping hand is quickly turning into a mailed fist,'' President Reagan complained yesterday in a speech to a group of mayors. Then he rejected the notion that the American people were to blame for a half-century of decline and added: ''If we are not, what is different? Well, the answer to that is the increased intervention of Federal authority.''

title: Q. During a trip to North Carolina, my husband dined on ham with red-eye gravy. I was told it is made by cooking ham and then pouring in black coffee and Tabasco. I tried this with a slice of leftover ham and it was terrible. What have I done wrong?
description: A. You've used the wrong kind of ham. To achieve perfect results you must use a good, well-cured country ham. Smithfield and genuine Virginia hams are ideal.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MARCH 4, 1981
description: International A negotiated peace in El Salvador will be sought this weekend in West Germany by President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador, according to sources close to him. West Germany's two major parties have been in close contact with both the junta and the left-wing insurgents and have reportedly sounded out possibilities for peace talks. (Page A1, Column 1.) No likelihood of combat involvement in El Salvador by American forces is foreseen by the Administration, President Reagan said. He denied that there was any parallel between the planned increase in military advisory aid in the conflict and the beginning of American involvement in Vietnam. (A1:2.)

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: AT SOVIET PARTY CONGRESS, EFFUSIVE PRAISE FOR BREZHNEV
description: Geidar A. Aliyev, the Communist Party leader in Azerbaijan, had only 15 minutes to speak to the 26th Congress of the Soviet Communist party last week, but he managed to set a minor record all the same.

title: Stevens's Net Off by 39.5%
description: With the absence of union pickets reflecting a historic labor agreement, J.P. Stevens & Company,the big textiles concern, held its annual stockholders' meeting today and reported a 39.5 percent drop in earnings in the first quarter of the current fiscal year from the comparable 1980 period.

title: Enserch Will Drop Offer to Buy Davy
description: The Enserch Corporation of Dallas said that it would allow its offer for the Davy Corporation to lapse following a decision by the British Government to refer the proposed merger to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission.

title: SENATE LEADER PREDICTS BACKING FOR INCREASE IN MILITARY AID TO EL SALVADOR
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader, predicted today that Congress would support increased American military aid to El Salvador despite what he termed a ''high level of concern'' among many senators and protest from liberal House and Senate Democrats.

title: Market Place; High Returns And Low P/E's
description: ALTHOUGH the stock market advanced substantially last week, there still appear to be a number of overlooked values for the discriminating investor. A ''Shopping List'' issued recently by Oppenheimer & Company based on a computer screen contains the names of more than 100 companies that appear to be attractive on the basis of return on equity and low price/earnings ratios.

title: 2 DEMOCRATIC LEADERS ASK CAREY TO EXPLORE TRADE-IN ON WESTWAY
description: The Democratic leaders of the State Assembly and Senate called on Governor Carey today to explore whether trading in Federal funds earmarked for the Westway highway project could help finance Mr. Carey's $5 billion, five-year improvement program for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority system.

title: Agency Changes
description: Mathier, Gerfen & Bresner, already the agency for a number of brands from Foreign Vintages, is also being assigned Amaretto di LJarono Liqueur. The brand was previously at E.T. Howard, whose executive vice president, Alvin R. Kracht, is seeking consolation in the fact that the Howard shop has just become the first agency for the Loranger Manufacturing Company. The first assignment will be to promote a new blank tape cassette line for the Loranger Entertainment division.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: A NEIGHBOR, in glancing through my files where these columns are not too neatly stored, commented that one of her favorite foods was missing from the menus.

title: Lots of Coupons, Lots of Cents Off
description: Last year saw another record number of manufacturers' cents-off coupons distributed - 90.6 billion, up 11.6 percent from 1979 - according to the Nielsen Clearing House.

title: Dean of Deans
description: As the number of potential college applicants grows smaller, the typical high school ''college night'' is becoming an exercise in hype. On one such occasion, we heard one student say of the parade of admissions officers, ''They're acting like a bunch of used-car salesmen.''

title: Senator Hatch Says Labor Panel Will Study CETA Program Grants
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, who is chairman of the Senate Labor Committee, announced today that his panel would hold hearings later this month on what he termed last-minute grants given out by the Department of Labor before the end of the Carter Administration.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Bill Madison's office at the Dispute Resolution Center boasts five pictures and ornaments depicting an emaciated Don Quixote riding into the thick of the human muddle on top of his dilapidated steed, Rocinante.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said the average yield at its auction of paper rose to 15.835 percent, from 15.205 percent last week.

title: CARTER AND ARTIS GRANTED HEARING IN LATEST APPEAL
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today ordered an evidentiary hearing for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis in their appeal for a third trial in a 15-year-old murder case.

title: DR. R. C. LANCEFIELD, BACTERIOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Rebecca C. Lancefield, a bacteriologist who developed the Lancefield classification system of streptococcal bacteria that scientists use throughout the world and whose basic research helped control streptococcal infections, died yesterday at her home in Douglaston, Queens. She was 86 years old.

title: CHARLES E. BROWN 3D
description: Charles E. Brown 3d, a private investment counselor and lawyer, died Saturday at his home in Kent, Conn. He was 59 years old. Mr. Brown had been in business for himself for 15 years.

title: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.
description: New York water may be at a premium in New York, but it's available in Los Angeles. ''Celebrated New York City Water - the Drink of Millions,'' a slightly filtered and carbonated version of the city's water, is now being offered to some restuarant patrons here.

title: KNICKS LOSE, 100-93
description: The Knicks, shooting 39 percent from the floor and 60 percent from the foul line, received boos from the fans and a 100-93 defeat from the Atlanta Hawks last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: 13 Plead Guilty In Jersey Drug Case
description: Thirteen people pleaded guilty to trying to smuggle almost 30 tons of marijuana, worth more than $32 million, into New Jersey. Prosecutors said the 1979 drug seizure - at a dock in Ottens Harbor, in Wildwood - was the largest ever made in the state.

title: WOMEN'S GROUP SET TO ORGANIZE OFFICE WORKERS
description: A big A.F.L.-C.I.O. union and a national women's group announced today that they had joined forces for a permanent campaign to organize the nation's 20 million office and clerical workers, most of whom are women.

title: SALVADORAN PLANS WEST GERMANY TRIP TO TRY TO END WAR
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador is planning to go to West Germany this weekend in search of a negotiated solution to the civil war here, according to sources close to Mr. Duarte.

title: Kentucky's Call-a-Bet Gets Off to a Fast Start
description: Call-a-Bet, an innovation that enables a racing fan to make his wagers by phone and then watch the races on television, made such a hit at Lousiville Downs on Monday night that the president of the harness track said yesterday he was pushing plans to expand the program to nine other cities in Kentucky.

title: ABOUT SAUCEPANS
description: GLASS saucepans make my blood boil. They are pots that give the impression of being able to do a job, but they can't do much, because glass is a terrible conductor of heat. The flame immediately creates hot spots that will scorch food. As a result, a glass saucepan is useless for making sauce, although it is, of course, adequate for boiling water.

title: LEADER OF BELZ HDASIDIM BEGINS HIS VISIT UNDER HEAVY GUARD
description: Thousands of followers of the Grand Rabbi of Beltz broke into joyous song and rhythmic clapping last night as their 33-year-old leader entered a steamy Brooklyn elementary school gymnasium, escorted by a heavy guard of New York City policemen and the rabbi's own security men.

title: Gala at Carnegie May 5 For Hall's 90th Birthday
description: Carnegie Hall and Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner & Smith have announced plans for a 90-birthday concert and gala party on May 5. The brokerage concern's underwriting of the evening marks its first major venture in support of the arts.

title:
RED SMITH;
Mister vs. Jumbo
description: IN this corner, wearing white trunks, weighing 218, is Renaldo (Mister) Snipes, formerly of Waukegan, Ill., now a native of Yonkers (as the old fight announcer Harry Balogh might have put it). His worthy opponent, wearing black trunks, weighing 230, Floyd (Jumbo) Cummings, of Joliet, Ill.

title: A CULINARY 'LITTLE INDIA' ON EAST 6TH STREET
description: IN the beginning was Shah Bag. And Shah Bag begat Kismoth. And Shah Bag also begat Romna. And Shah Bag and Kismoth begat Nishan. And Nishan begat Anar Bagh and Shamoly, which in the course of time begat Mitali and Bangladesh. And East Sixth Street looked upon all this Indian cooking and saw that it was good.

title: Arab Students Protest in Israel
description: About 100 Arab students from Israeli universities demonstrated outside Parliament today to protest what they call provocations of violence by right-wing Jewish students. The police reported no incidents during the demonstration. The protest was prompted by an attack last month on three Arab students by unknown assailants at Haifa.

title: Davis Coach of Year
description: Tom Davis of Boston College has been named Big East coach of the year in a vote by the league's coaches. Davis, in his fourth season with the Eagles, led them to a 21-5 record and the Big East title.

title: RECAPTURING THE MAGIC OF THE EARLY ELVIS PRESLEY
description: and-roll fans from England, Europe and Japan seek him out regularly, for he is one of rock's first guitar heroes, an important influence on Eric Clapton and many other rock innovators of the 60's, and a man to whom the magic of Elvis Presley and of rock-and-roll's beginnings still clings.

title: Joseph Maranne Jr., 62, Chairman Of Drama Department at Pace U.
description: Dr. Joseph J. Maranne Jr., chairman of the speech and drama department of Pace University's Dyson College of Arts and Sciences, died of a heart attack Friday at St. Francis Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 62 years old and a resident of Manhasset.

title: ON CHAD'S UNEASY FROTIER, THE FOREIGN AGENTS LANGUISH
description: The bored foreign agents are to be found each starry night on the dirt veranda of the Relais du Logone, the one hotel in town. After a day of monitoring the activity, or lack of it, across the river in Ndjamena, the capital of Chad, they do not so much share information as pick at one another's national eccentricities.

title: G.M. POSTS SHARP LOSS IN EUROPE
description: The General Motors Corporation, which reported a loss of $763 million for 1980, had minimal losses in the United States despite sharply reduced sales, but suffered heavy losses in Europe, the company's annual report shows.

title: DeLorean Plans Securities Issue in U.S.
description: The DeLorean Motor Company said it was planning its first public offering of securities in the United States to finance future models of the sports car it is producing in Northern Ireland.

title: Police Test June 20
description: The New York City Police Department, whose last examination for police officer attracted nearly 37,000 applicants and resulted in a legal battle involving the issue of racial discrimination, announced plans for a new Civil Service test on June 20, along with a new effort to recruit qualified minority candidates.

title: NICHOLS NOW DIRECTING 'KULYENCHIKOV'
description: Mike Nichols has replaced Gordon Davidson as the director of Neil Simon's ''The Curse of Kulyenchikov.'' The comedy, which is to open on Broadway at the Eugene O'Neill on March 31, is now at the Shubert Theater in Boston, where it opened last Thursday.

title: Key Rates
description: Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Hunt Family In S.E.C. Suit
description: Six members of the Hunt family of Dallas have filed suit in Federal court here in an attempt to void a Securities and Exchange Commission subpoena for family loan records.

title: U.S. IS URGED TO OVERHAUL INDEX FOR RISE IN BENEFITS
description: In a politically sensitive move, the General Accounting Office today recommended a major overhaul of the procedures by which cost-of-living increases are automatically granted to Social Security recipients, Federal retirees and beneficiaries of social welfare programs, including the food stamp and child nutrition programs.

title: FANNY B. ROSENAU, FOUNDED MASTECTOMY PROGRAM
description: Fanny Baum Rosenau, a co-founder and the New York area coordinator of the Reach to Recovery counseling program for mastectomy patients, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived on East 87th Street.

title: MEDICAID COST TAKEOVER IS BLOCKED BY ANDERSON
description: Governor Carey's plan to begin a four-year takeover of local Medicaid costs in the upcoming state budget was apparently killed today by the majority leader of the Republicancontrolled Senate.

title: Clearing the Air for Clean Air
description: The Clean Air Act comes up for renewal this year and the cannon are already blazing. Candidate Reagan charged that the act had stifled economic growth. After the election, Budget Director Stockman argued that it represented ''staggering excess'' built on dubious premises. But a report just issued by the National Commission on Air Quality suggests that the Clean Air Act needs to be both loosened and tightened. For every provision that is needlessly strict, there is another from which there should be no retreat.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN INTERVIEW
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the interview by Walter Cronkite of CBS News with President Reagan last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Brascan Expanding In Consumer Fields
description: Brascan Ltd. said it had increased its interest in John Labatt Ltd. to 42 percent from 34 percent and in the London (Ontario) Life Insurance Company to 39 percent from 33 percent through purchases in the open market during the fourth quarter.

title: THEATER: 'IN TROUSERS'
description: IN ''In Trousers,'' the musical at the Second Stage, the parts are better than the whole. In most musicals that don't work the parts are usually better than the whole, of course, but ''In Trousers'' is original enough to make you wish that the gap between what is, and what might have been, wasn't so large as it is. William Finn, the composer, has tried to tell a story almost entirely in song. If he had not been so precious, he would have succeeded.

title: Metal Trader Picks Foy
description: Lewis W. Foy, 66, who retired last June as chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, has been elected chairman of the Continental Metals Corporation, a New York trading company with annual volume of more than $100 million. He succeeds Henry J. Leir, 81, who was named to the newly created post of vice chairman.

title: THE 'GUTS' TO REVIEW FEDERAL PROGRAMS
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Albertson's Inc., Boise, Idaho, a food and drug company, has elected to its board William H. McMurren, president and chief executive officer of the Morrison-Knudsen Company.

title: U.N. MAITRE D'HOTEL IS A DIPLOMAT, TOO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Ripp is a journalist who lives in New York. By ALLAN RIPP UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. FROM his desk on the fourth floor of the United Nations Secretariat Building Norman Manjaka enjoys a unique view of the world. A few yards away is the entrance to the delegates' dining room, where he presides daily as maitre d'hotel. Spanning the top of the desk like one long pennant are 152 miniature flags representing the member countries. Considering the flags and then the dining room, Mr. Manjaka offers his summary of international affairs.

title: The Future Past
description: In ''Looking Backward, 2000 to 1887,'' a vastly popular book of a century ago, Edward Bellamy imagined fantastic new technologies permitting people to see themselves on film and TV screens. Two recent news stories offer a basis for imagining technology that could, a century from now, permit people to see, for instance, Edward Bellamy.

title: HAIG'S SENATE 'PARTNERS'
description: When Al Haig was confirmed as Secretary of State, he proposed a ''partnership'' with the Senate in the conduct of foreign affairs, but he's already running into trouble with some leading Democrats over his military diplomacy in El Salvador.

title: 'BLACK' MEDICAL COLLEGE BATTLES DEFICIT
description: In thousands of American communities, Meharry Medical College is synonymous with providing health care where it was nearly, if not entirely, nonexistent. Since its founding in 1876, Meharry has trained almost half the nation's black physicians and dentists, who have provided health care in urban and rural communities that had been largely ignored by their white counterparts.

title: Big Oil Project For Venezuela
description: Venezuela, a major foreign oil supplier to the United States, is planning an $8 billion project to develop the Orinoco oil belt, which is expected to produce one million barrels a day of heavy crude by the turn of the century, the official news agency of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries reported today.

title: Bulls Extend Nets' Slump to Six
description: James Wilkes, a reserve, and Artis Gilmore scored 21 points apiece tonight to help the Chicago Bulls beat the slumping New Jersey Nets, 128-102.

title: How the Roasters Compare
description: THE chickens were tested over a four-week period and were roasted both individually and in groups. The new, professional kitchens at the New York Cooking Center, 27 West 34th Street, were made available to The Times for testing.

title: CAREY PROPOSES BUILDING PRISONS WITH BOND ISSUES
description: Governor Carey submitted to the Legislature today a $375 million public safety bond issue that includes almost $332 million for the construction and rehabilitation of prisons, and additional funds for new facilities for juvenile offenders, the state police and psychiatric patients.

title: SANDWICH DETERRENT
description: To the Editor:

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Hundreds of thousands of people celebrated Mardi Gras today with parades and street dancing, but the festival was marred when a 2-year-old girl was struck and killed by a parade float.

title: CRYER-FORD LYRICISTS GET THE ACT TOGETHER AGAIN
description: GRETCHEN CRYER and Nancy Ford, who created the hit Off Broadway musical ''I'm Getting My Act Together and Taking It on the Road,'' brought their act to the 92d Street Y's ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series on Sunday in the first of two evenings. Like Carol Hall, who appeared last month, Miss Cryer and Miss Ford are middle American populist voices.

title: CO-OP PRICES CLIMBED IN '80 DESPITE HIGH INTEREST RATES
description: Despite high mortgage interest rates, sale prices of cooperative apartments in Manhattan continued to climb dramatically last year, according to real-estate executives.

title: 'Texts,' Based on Beckett, At the Public for 3 Weeks
description: ''Texts for Nothing,'' a one-man show based on two works by Samuel Beckett and performed by Joseph Chaiken, began a three-week engagement yesterday at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Bridge: L.I. Player Who Was Killed In Accident Was on the Rise
description: Bridge players at the Vanderbilt Club in Manhasset, L.I., miss Michael Merrill, a regular and enthusiastic competitor who was killed recently in an automobile accident. He lived in Hicksville and, at the time of his death, was on his way to a life master's rank.

title: The U.N. Today; March 4, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets on Namibia at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Cities Service Plant
description: The Cities Service Company said it plans to spend $45 million for a 45 percent expansion in the gas-processing capacity of its plant at Mont Belvieu, Tex., near Houston. The addition, which will increase capacity by 80,000 barrels daily, to more than 265,000 barrels daily, is scheduled to begin operation in mid-1982. Citco said the plant would treat liquids owned by other gas processors as well as by Cities Service.

title: NEAR LONG ISLAND'S TIP THE NEW CROP IS WINE
description: When Alec and Louisa Hargrave bought a 66-acre potato farm here in 1973 and began planting it with tender European grape vines, their plan eventually to make French-style wine was widely viewed, they readily admit, as an eccentricity.

title: Commodity Unit's Chief
description: Philip F. Johnson, nominated by President Reagan yesterday as chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, is no stranger to the commodities industry.

title: The Economy
description: Setting an early date for business-tax relief was supported by the Democratic chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, Representative Dan Rostenkowski. His support made it likely that the depreciation provision would be retroactive to Jan. 1. (Page D1.)

title: A SCALED-DOWN VERSION OF SECURITY ADVISER'S TASK
description: A reporter recently complained to a colleague that he had telephoned Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's adviser on national security, and waited two days before getting a reply from an aide who explained that Mr. Allen was too busy to handle his call.

title: Allbritton Sues Over Riggs
description: Joe L. Allbritton, the head of a Washington communications company and the former publisher-owner of The Washington Star, filed suit today asking a Federal judge to stop the Riggs National Bank from blocking his attempt to buy an addition 20 percent of the bank's common stock for $40.5 million.

title: Foreigners Buy Treasury Issues; Notes, Bonds Gain 5/8 to 1 1/2
description: Foreign investors emerged as buyers of United States Treasury issues yesterday and helped to spark a rally that raised note and bond prices by 5/8 to 1 1/2 points.

title: Woman and Her Son, 8, Slain in Brooklyn Home
description: A 35-year-old woman and her 8-year-old son were found stabbed to death yesterday in their apartment in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: BETHLEHEM MAY OWE $210 MILLION IN TAX
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, in a little-noticed report to stockholders, has disclosed that it may have to pay additional income taxes totaling some $210 million for the 10 years ended in 1970.

title: Degnan Resigning To Enter Jersey Race
description: John J. Degnan, the New Jersey Attorney General, will resign tomorrow to begin his campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor. Mr. Degnan, who had been expected to join the campaign next week, decided to waste no more time after meeting yesterday with Governor Byrne.

title: LANGUAGE IS IN THE MIND AS WELL AS THE MOUTH
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOUNGE TIME

title: Tony Martin Nearing Show Business Milestone
description: At the moment Gigi's sparkle turned to fire and her warmth became desire, Iris Mufson reached up and stroked her husband Robert's back, and Mr. Mufson reached back and squeezed his wife's hand.

title: Village in Austria Is Quarantined
description: A two-week quarantine has been imposed on the village of Thalheim because of an outbreak of hoof-and-mouth disease, and 1,800 head of cattle and pigs have been ordered slaughtered, health officials reported today. Villagers and residents in a 25-mile radius will be prohibited from leaving or receiving visitors, the authorities said, and food supplies will be relayed by health officials.

title: KOCH APPOINTS A NEW PANEL TO MONITOR TAXICAB INDUSTRY
description: Saying that he was dissatisfied with taxi service, Mayor Koch appointed a 12-member committee yesterday to examine the regulation of New York City's taxicab industry, from the way licenses are issued to how fares are set.

title: UNILEVER REPORTS DROP OF 16.5% IN QUARTERLY NET
description: The Unilever Group of Companies, the giant British-Dutch food and industrial-products concern and the world's largest consumer-goods producer, announced yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 fell 16.5 percent while sales climbed 12.6 percent.

title: ALDERMAN BEATS MAYOR SOLIDLY IN ST. LOUIS PRIMARY
description: Considered a shoo-in for re-election two months ago, Mayor Jim Conway suffered a stunning defeat in today's Democratic primary by his chief opponent, Alderman Vincent G. Schoemehl Jr. Unofficial returns from all 387 precincts showed Mr. Schoemel with 70,507 votes, about 67 percent, and Mayor Conway with 32,683, or about 31 percent.

title: Jack Ogilvie Horton, 43, Ex-Aide in Interior Dept.
description: Jack Ogilvie Horton, a former Assistant Secretary of the Interior, died Saturday in Denver of leukemia. He was 43 years old and had been working as a consultant in natural resources before he was taken ill.

title: I.M.F. SEES SAUDI HELP ON LENDING
description: Saudi Arabia may agree shortly to contribute more than $3 billion a year to a new lending facility for poor countries, a facility managed by the International Monetary Fund, Finance Minister Rene Monory of France said today.

title: A 'ONE ROOM SCHOOL' TEACHES A NEW LIFE
description: The children are from Taiwan, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Canton and remote mountain villages of China. Some have never been to school before; others have never been in a place with running water.

title: Bench Prepares For Fill-In Role
description: Johnny Bench, Cincinnati's regular catcher the last 13 seasons, says he isn't fretting over his future with the Reds although his career as a regular catcher is over.

title: Mother of Slain Girl Stabs Her 2 Children
description: A 42-year-old woman whose oldest child was murdered during the summer stabbed her two other children and herself in their home in the Great Kills section of Staten Island, the police said.

title: A.T. & T. ASKS RIGHT TO EXPAND
description: A campaign by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for the right to expand into advanced fields of communications opened on a new front today. Bell asked a court in Newark to modify a 25-year-old consent decree that has confined A.T.& T. to the phone business.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 2 COURT VACANCIES CAST SHADOWS OVER COAST POLITICS
description: Two vacancies on the California Supreme Court are casting shadows over state politics as Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., who would fill the posts, moves toward a campaign next year for the United States Senate and Attorney General George Deukmejian, who would pass on the nominations, moves toward a campaign for Governor. Both officials are expected to face primary challenges.

title: The Economy
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee approved a temporary freeze on dairy price supports, giving President Reagan his first key Congressional victory in his bid to curb U.S. spending. (Page A1.) Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said sharply increased military spending, as proposed by the Administration, would ''significantly and quickly strengthen our ability to respond to the Soviet threat at all levels.'' (A1.) But leaders of organized labor called the economic plan ''disastrous to working Americans.'' (B12.)

title: DECORATING SERVICES: SHOPPING THE STORES
description: AS far as most people are concerned, there are three ways to go about decorating a home: Get the best decorator money can buy; get a designer who will work within a moderate budget, or do it yourself.

title: Reports Say Fotiu Suspended
description: Although John A. Ziegler, the president of the National Hockey League, has yet to make an official announcement, reports circulated at last night's Ranger game that Nick Fotiu and Don Maloney would draw suspensions for an altercation with fans in Detroit Feb 19.

title: Round Table Conference Discusses Cable Television
description: While the crowd was gathering yesterday morning at the New York Hilton for the second day of the Advertising on Cable TV Conference, a smaller group was assembling in a Jordan, Case & McGrath conference room to attack the same subject.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt GENTLE VENGEANCE. An Account of the First Year at Harvard Medical School. By Charles LeBaron. 272 pages. Marek. $12.95.

title: AN ACCURATE 'LA BOHEME'
description: In the first act of the opera ''La Boheme,'' the libretto has the character Colline announce that he is going to get a shave. Colline, therefore, is supposed to show up in the second act cleanshaven.

title: Bridge: Value of Even a Small Card Can Often Be a Vital Factor
description: A declarer who pays careful attention to spots can earn considerable dividends. In the end-game, the difference between, say, a five and a three may be crucial.

title: Agway's New Leader
description: William Hiller, 53, a former Pennsylvania farm boy who grew up to become a corporate executive, has been named president and chief executive officer of Agway Inc., a major farm cooperative, effective July 1. Mr. Hiller will succeed Ronald N. Goddard, 65, who will retire.

title: UA-Columbia Backs Merger
description: Columbia Cablevision Inc. announced last night that its directors had approved the joint offer by Dow Jones & Company and Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. to buy the cable television company for $75 a share in cash.

title: Braniff Attendants Accept 10% Pay Cut
description: Braniff International said its flight attendants had agreed to a 10 percent pay cut as 39 creditors of the beleaguered company signed a formal consent postponing payments on the airline's loans.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE by Barbara L. Isenberg and Mary Smith DRAPERY TIEBACKS; by Barbara Isenberg and Mary Smith
description: DRAPERY tiebacks can add a finished, if somewhat theatrical, touch to your decorating scheme. Fashionable in the Victorian era, tiebacks are now used in restorations or for opulent window treatments.

title: French Cut Neo-Nazi's Sentence
description: The French Court of Appeals today reduced and suspended the prison sentence of Marc Fredriksen, a neo-Nazi leader, but ordered him to pay $6,600 for articles he wrote for an extreme-right publication. A court ruled Oct. 17 that his articles incited ''hate and racial violence'' and sentenced him to 18 months in prison. That sentence was reduced to 13 months today and was suspended.

title: OIL CONCERNS INFLATE PRICES, OTTAWA SAYS
description: ''Predatory and restrictive practices'' by large oil companies, most of them American-controlled, have cost Canadian consumers billions of dollars, the Canadian Government charged today.
