title: Kenneth Ash, Ad Man, Marries Barbara M. Day
description: Barbara Meals Day, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Casper D. Meals of Camp Hill, Pa., was married yesterday evening to Kenneth A. Ash, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Ash of Atlantic Beach, L.I. Acting State Supreme Court Justice Jack Rosenberg performed the ceremony at the University Club in Manhattan.

title: Suspect Indicted In Macy's Shooting
description: A 29-year-old man was indicted on charges of attempted murder and robbery in the shooting of two security guards at Macy's Herald Square store last Saturday.

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS PATIENTS' BENEFITS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Congress did not violate the constitutional rights of patients in public mental hospitals when it excluded them from a Federal program that provides $25 a month in personal spending money to indigent patients in other types of public hospitals.

title: Around the World; Egypt Names Military Chief To Replace Crash Victim
description: President Anwar el-Sadat today appointed Lieut. Gen. Abdel Halim Abu Ghazzala as Minister of Defense and Military Production and Commander in Chief of the armed forces.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TOUR PLAN ASSAILED
description: A proposed tour of South Africa by the Boston Ballet has been criticized and has caused divisions within the dance group itself.

title: Turnover at Clorox
description: Calvin S. Hatch, 60, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the Clorox Company, based in Oakland, Calif. He succeeds Edwin H. Shutt, 53, who resigned after only eight months in the position.

title: Study in Economics
description: Things are getting rough all over because of the economy. In Keene, N.H., Barbara Seelye, the incoming president of Keene State College, says that she'll probably have to cancel her own inauguration to save the school money.

title: WATCHDOGS OF CORPORATE ETHICS
description: At International Harvester's annual meeting a few weeks ago, the Sisters of Charity of the Blessed Virgin tied up the proceedings by discussing the morality of the company's $66 million truck operation in South Africa.

title: 4 ECONOMISTS AT TAX HEARING IN HOUSE SPLIT ON CUTS
description: Two supply-side economists, Arthur B. Laffer and John Rutledge, advised Congress today to cut income tax rates without delay, even before spending cuts are decided.

title: Squirreling Away a Play
description: David Mamet is a playwright for whom the manuscript as much as the play is the thing. ''I write all my plays in bound notebooks,'' Mr. Mamet said the other day, explaining that he had a special aversion to the new video display typewriters in which words are reduced to impersonal electronic bits and stored on computer disks.

title: Celtics Defeat Rockets and Move Into First-Place Tie With 76ers
description: Larry Bird scored 20 points in the second half, leading Boston to a 108-101 victory over the Rockets last night in Houston and enabling the Celtics to move into a first-place tie with Philadelphia in the Atlantic Division.

title: THE NEW ECONOMICS VIEW:FROM THE SUPPLY SIDE
description: As recently as a year or so ago, supply-side economics was a subject for derision among mainstream economists. Now, with President Reagan as its champion, this newly articulated economic theory is both the basis of national economic policy and a topic of respectful attention in academic circles.

title: Dr. Gertrude Borgeson, 84, Dies; Ran Hunter College Department
description: Dr. Gertrude M. Borgeson, former chairman of the department of home economics at Hunter College, died Feb. 25 at a nursing home in Columbus, Ohio.

title: NEWHOUSE AGREES TO BUY VISION CABLE
description: Newhouse Publications, one of the country's biggest newspaper publishers, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Vision Cable Communications Inc., a small but fast-growing cable television operator, for an undisclosed sum.

title: BRIEFS
description: * The Bacock and Wilcox Tubular Group of McDermott Inc. said it intended to divest itself of its fittings and forging operations in Koppel, Pa. and Elkhart, Ind.

title: ENTREPRENEUR FROM THE NETHERLANDS
description: A.C.R. Dreesmann, a Dutch businessman and part-time economics professor who has built a vast corporate empire in the Netherlands, admits to feeling a bit claustrophobic in his country of 14 million.

title: Florida Commission Clears Pilot Of Freighter That Struck Bridge
description: A state board today unanimously exonerated Capt. John Lerro, the pilot of a freighter that toppled part of the Sunshine Skyway Bridge in a storm last May, sending 35 persons plunging to their deaths in Tampa Bay.

title: WILL THE CHINESE SATISFY A THIRST FOR THE WEST?
description: DURING the Cultural Revolution, Western ideas were anathema in China. But a remarkable amount of interest in Western culture was in fact maintained during that period beginning in the late 1960's. And now, working desperately to catch up, China seems hungry for all things Western. The aim is not to abandon its own culture, but to reinterpret the West in a Chinese way.

title: CAREY, CRITICIZING PRESIDENT, OFFERS A BROAD HEALTH PLAN
description: Governor Carey issued a detailed assault today on President Reagan's proposal to limit Medicaid funds allocated by the Federal Government to the states. The Governor charged that the President's plan was inconsistent with Mr. Reagan's stated commitment to help ''those who through no fault of their own depend on the rest of us.''

title: Variable-Rate Certificates Halted
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation yesterday ordered the Western Savings Bank in Philadelphia to temporarily stop offering variable rates on consumer money market certificates, the bank said.

title: CARNEGIE HALL FESTIVAL SET
description: Carnegie Hall will present a 13-concert festival of the music of Schubert and Bartok from May 28 through June 11. The festival marks the most ambitious programming effort ever attempted by the hall, which has heretofore either rented its facilities or presented concerts in a more limited way.

title: Key Rates
description: Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE BURGEONING CRAFT OF BASKET MAKING
Paulsen Memorial Scheduled
description: A memorial to Monrad G. Paulsen, founding dean of the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law at Yeshiva University, will be held at 2 P.M. Sunday at the law school, 55 Fifth Avenue.

title: Plague Diagnosis Termed Unlikely
description: The chief epidemiologist at Presbyterian Hospital yesterday all but ruled out a diagnosis of bubonic plague for a patient admitted Sunday with an infection of the leg and lymph nodes of the groin.

title: Proposal for Armory Is Declared Dead
description: A proposal to build a hotel or luxury apartments over the landmark Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue between 66th and 67th Streets, was pronounced dead yesterday by the state's Urban Development Corporation. The announcement came just before a rally against the project tonight.

title: A NEGLECTED U.S. TRADE POTENTIAL
description: To the Editor:

title: * To the Editor:$
description: William Safire could set the world afire if he has his way. In his Feb. 26 column, he offers two reasons for U.S. intervention in El Salvador: (1) ''We must break the Communist winning streak'' and (2) ''El Salvador is a place where we can win.''

title: REPLACING A DOOR LOCK WITHOUT A LOCKSMITH
description: REPLACING an old door lock that is broken or unsightly, or replacing one with a new lock that will provide better protection against break-ins, is a job that any do-it-yourselfer who is reasonably familar with basic woodworking tools can easily handle.

title: N.C.A.A. TITLE BASKETBALL SOLD TO CBS FOR $48 MILLION
description: CBS Sports, demonstrating it is committed to pay whatever is necessary to win prestigious television contracts, gained the rights yesterday to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's championship basketball tournament for three years, 1982-84.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration's military budget, coming on the heels of the big domestic budget cuts two weeks ago, signals a reversal of national priorities as basic and significant as did the Great Society programs of President Johnson in the mid-1960's. If the Administration has its way, its new military program will commit the nation to major long-term growth in Pentagon spending, just as the Johnson Great Society initiatives committed the nation to a huge buildup in domestic spending, long after Mr. Johnson had left the White House.

title: REACHING FOR THE 'GOOD GUYS' IN EL SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; PICTURES FROM THE PAST; Blow-Up
description: ''That story yesterday,'' writes a friend who knows B movies, ''about that possible case of bubonic plague will be easy to cast. Richard Dreyfuss plays the husband, Genevieve Bujold the wife.... A sunny day in New Mexico.

title: James E. Madden Is Dead at 54; A Banker and an Insurance Aide
description: James E. Madden, an investment banker and member of the treasurer's office of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in New York, died last Thursday of a heart attack at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived in Lakeville, Conn.

title: The U.N. Today; March 5, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on Namibia.

title: PRESIDENTIAL PANELS HAILED AND FORGOTTEN
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: Governor Carey's program to help the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is causing a flurry of tart statements and controversy, but they are not all what they seem.

title: BACHELORS WHO MAKE MORE DESIGN DEMANDS
description: IN the past, bachelors were thought of in two ways. There were the sophisticated ones who created a legendary life style for themselves, complete with the perfectly appointed penthouse. And there were the solitary single men, who lived in makeshift quarters and never got around to replacing the card table, having the sofa reupholstered or redoing the kitchen. Those were the ones who rationalized that their personal situations would soon change and that's when they would start getting their places together.

title: NEW SOVIET PARTY PANEL REFLECTS BREZHNEV'S POWER
description: The Communist Party's new policy-making Central Committee, whose membership was announced today, reflects even more than its predecessor the style and power of the party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: JANEAR HINES
description: Janear Hines, an actress who appeared as the babysitter in the television series ''Julia,'' died of Bright's disease in Kaiser Hospital, San Francisco, on Monday. She was 30 years old, the daughter of Earl Hines, the jazz pianist. Miss Hines lived in Manhattan.

title: AIR FORCE TEST PILOT AND ENGINEER
description: Brig. Gen. Benjamin Scovill Kelsey, U.S.A.F., retired, a test pilot and aeronautical engineer, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Stevensburg, Va. He was 74 years old.

title: Kingman Pledges a Fresh Start
description: Dave Kingman returned to the Mets today after three and a half years of baseball travel and controversy, reclaimed his job as cleanup hitter and announced, ''I'm starting over.''

title: Measles Emergency Ended
description: A measles epidemic in Westchester County was declared under control today, although two more elementary school children were reported to have contracted the disease. Dr. Aurelia Raciti, in charge of efforts to curtail the epidemic, said that the health emergency declared Feb. 23 was being lifted because there was a significant decline in cases and also because enough children between the ages of 5 and 18, the most susceptible group, had been immunized.

title: U.S. Agency to Study Hooker Plant in Jersey
description: A Federal investigation into allegedly hazardous working conditions at the Hooker Chemical and Plastic Corporation plant here will begin within two weeks, authorities said today.

title: LONDON HOUSE RETAINS VICTORIAN SPLENDOR
description: LONDON THE mounting interest in Victoriana, which has led to high prices for Victorian art and furniture, has received a new focus with the opening of the former residence of Linley Sambourne as a house museum.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: URBAN BLIGHTY

title: VIOLENCE AND GRAFT INCREASE IN FLORIDA ALONG WITH ITS $7 BILLION FLOW OF DURGS
description: Through this city of sunlight and excess, where now and then a child will turn up at a corner store with a $100 bill, demanding candy bars and change, there flows a river of narcotics bringing with it so much opulence and violence, so much money and corruption, that public officials look back to Prohibition for comparisons, and even those fail.

title: Internorth Planning To Stay in Omaha
description: Internorth Inc., in an apparent bid to squelch rumors that it planned to relocate in Houston, announced it will build as many as six office buildings in Omaha over the next 10 years to accommodate an estimated 1,400 additional employees.

title: Why Reward Failure in Detroit?
description: Detroit is panting for import controls on Japanese cars. Lest anyone doubt it, one group of auto workers made the point in front of the cameras this week by smashing a Toyota with sledgehammers. And slowly but surely, the Reagan Administration is moving to accommodate them.

title: Stylish Minnelli Send-Off
description: ''We've known one another since we were so high in Hollywood, and we've always been pals, and he's written a terrific book and I'm in it, so I wanted to give Rock this party and show my friends my new apartment at the same time,'' said Liza Minnelli, her words running together in breathless enthusiasm.

title: RECITAL: MISS CABALLE
description: MONTSERRAT CABALLE sang a recital in Carnegie Hall Monday night, which automatically guaranteed that the soprano's many fans spent two hours basking in a wash of entrancing vocal sound. This has always been the essence of Miss Caballe's appeal, a sensuously warm spinning tone, no less beguiling at a pianissimo thread than when unfurled at full voice.

title: Shell Oil Tests in Michigan
description: The Shell Oil Company said today that it had found oil and natural gas in the first well drilled under a new program of exploration in the Pigeon River Country State Forest. ''It's looking like a good one,'' a Shell spokesman said. The company said it had also begun drilling a second new well in the 96,000-acre Michigan forest.

title: FIRE DEPARTMENT GIVES IN ON GETTING SUBWAY KEYS
description: The New York City Fire Department, bowing to Transit Authority objections, has dropped efforts to obtain keys to subway-car doors, which it had sought to give firefighters quicker entry in an emergency. The Transit Authority had contended there was not enough risk of dangerous fires to warrant such access and had said it feared that distribution of extra keys could cause security problems.

title: HOW TO GET A TREE PLANTED ON YOUR STREET
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Linda Yang is a regular contributor of gardening articles to The Home Section. By LINDA YANG

title: ORDERS OFF BY 0.3% AT FACTORIES
description: New orders for factory goods fell threetenths of 1 percent in January, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the first decrease since last spring's recession, but had been predicted by economists for some time.

title: Q. We recently had aluminum replacement windows installed in our upstairs rooms. Now, whenever the weather turns cold, condensation develops on the inside on the exposed metal of the window frames, and during the night ice sometimes forms. Do you have any suggestions on how to minimize or eliminate this problem? -M.S., Brooklyn
description: A. Your metal-frame windows apparently do not have a built-in thermal barrier. The metal conducts heat out so rapidly that the inside soon gets as cold as the outside and the moisture in the air inside the room then condenses on it (and freezes when it gets cold enough). In frames with a built-in thermal barrier this doesn't happen because there is a plastic insert that stops the transmission of heat. At any rate, your only solution now is to put up storm windows in the cold weather -either inside or outside, or maybe both.

title: Coca-Cola Promotes Keough to President
description: Donald R. Keough, 54 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Coca-Cola Company. He had been senior executive vice president in charge of operations for the Atlantabased soft drink giant.

title: REAGAN BACKED BY SENATE PANEL ON DAIRY PRICES
description: In the first key Congressional victory for President Reagan's program of Federal spending reductions, the Senate Agriculture Committee today overwhelmingly approved a proposal to freeze temporarily the level of dairy price supports.

title: Around the Nation; Socialist Candidate Defeats Burlington's 5-Term Mayor
description: Bernard Sanders, an avowed Socialist and cofounder of the the Liberty Union, a radical party in the state, achieved an upset victory over the five-term Democratic Mayor, Gordon Paquette.

title: AUTO SALES CLIMB 22% AT BIG 3
description: Spurred by the biggest rebate campaign in the industry's history, new car sales by the Big Three auto makers increased 22 percent in the last 10 days of February.

title: GROUPS THAT CARE FOR STREET TREES
description: There are several nonprofit groups involved in the care of street trees. The Parks Council. If you can't face planting a street tree yourself, the council will do it for you for a 20 percent service charge.

title: WEIDENBAUM URGES FED TO CUT GROWTH IN MONEY
description: Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, called on the Federal Reserve today to reduce the rate of growth of the money supply by about 25 percent this year.

title: Around the Nation; Atlanta Police Begin Search For Missing 11-Year-Old
description: The police began a new search tonight for an 11-year-old black child who apparently did not come home from school today.

title: Boston Ballet to Present New 'Swan Lake' Staging
description: The Boston Ballet will present a new production of ''Swan Lake,'' choreographed by Violette Verdy and Bruce Wells, at the newly renovated Metropolitan Center in Boston from next Wednesday through March 15.

title: CAR IMPORT CURB SPLITS CABINET
description: The Reagan Cabinet has become locked in a debate between free-trade purists and political pragmatists over whether to restrain imports of small, fuel-efficient Japanese cars. While both sides shun protectionism, the pragmatists argue that Japanese car imports represent a special case.

title: MUSIC: CONTEMPORARIES
description: LYRICISM is evoked in manifold ways in contemporary music. But the least successful attempt presented by the Group for Contemporary Music at Symphony Space on Monday night was written by its most successful composer. ''In Sweet Music,'' by the ''dean'' of American composers, William Schuman, was inspired by Shakespeare's song ''Orpheus with his Lute.'' The traditionally lyrical harp, viola, flute and soprano voice mixed Tudor airs and modern dissonance, but gestures meandered about in sighs and outbursts, breaking off, beginning again, leaving an unconvincing and confused image of the lyrical powers that Shakespeare said could make the billows of the sea hang their heads.

title: ENOUGH ENGINEERS BUT IN THE WRONG SLOTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Macy's Revises Expansion Plans
description: R.H. Macy & Company said that it was revising its new-store expansion plans to provide for the opening of two stores in 1982 and the building of between 12 and 15 stores between 1984 and 1986.

title: KOCH SEEKS STATEWIDE TAX FOR M.T.A.
description: Mayor Koch yesterday revived his proposal for a new statewide tax to help finance the operation of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. He also said the city still had the option of trading in Federal funds for the Westway highway project if state financing did not materialize.

title: Dr. Harvey A. Gollance; Directed Drug Program
description: Dr. Harvey A. Gollance, a former deputy commissioner of the Department of Hospitals and a leading proponent of methadonemaintenance programs, died Tuesday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ART AND CRAFTS SHOW AT PARSONS SCHOOL
description: ''The Art of Clay, Fibers, Glass and Metal,'' a group exhibition of 50 faculty members from the Parsons School of Design and the department of crafts of the New School for Social Research, is on display through March 25 at the Parsons Exhibition Center, 2 West 13th Street.

title: OIL DEALERS SAY THEY'RE HURTING TOO
description: People in this area of wooded hills say that firewood, unlike oil, heats you twice - once when you chop it and again when you burn it. Another advantage is that the wood bill does not approach $200 a month.

title: TV: CHURCHILL BULLIES AND INSPIRES BRITAIN'S GENERALS TO VICTORY
description: TONIGHT at 8, WNEW-TV, Channel 5, offers the BBC-LeVien International production of ''Churchill and the Generals,'' a dramatized military history of World War II as seen through the explosive figure of Prime Minister Winston Churchill. As a presentation of the Mobil Showcase Network, the three-hour program will be shown without commercial interruptions.

title: Reliance Buys 5% Of Southwest Forest
description: Reliance Group Inc. disclosed that it had acquired a 5.04 percent interest in Southwest Forest Industries Inc., a producer of building materials and paper products based in Phoenix.

title: ACCIDENTS CLOUD THE FUTURE OF WESTCHESTER AIRPORT
description: Westchester County Airport, where officials say more corporate jets are based than anywhere else in the world, has reached what many believe is a crucial moment in its 36-year history.

title:
DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
THE UNREAL WORLD OF WAITING ROOMS
description: WAITING is a large part of living. Great, passive, negative chunks of our time are consumed by waiting, from birth to death. Waiting is a special kind of activity - if activity is the right word for it - because we are held in enforced suspension between people and places, removed from the normal rhythms of our days and lives.

title: REAGAN'S VIEWS ON SOUTH AFRICA PRAISED BY BOTHA
description: President Reagan's remarks on South Africa in a television interview last night were hailed here today by Prime Minister P.W. Botha and other leaders as evidence that the United States is now taking a more ''realistic'' attitude to this country.

title: Mobil Starting First Coal Mine
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had begun construction of a coal mine in the Powder River Basin near Gillette, Wyo., marking the oil company's first venture in the coal mining business.

title: CLANTON TO HEAD F. T. C.
description: David A. Clanton, a Republican member of the Federal Trade Commission, was chosen by the White House today as acting chairman of the independent regulatory agency.

title: OLYMPIA AND YORK SEEMS ABITIBI VICTOR
description: Thomson Newspapers Ltd. and Nu-West Group Ltd. have apparently abandoned their bid for Abitibi-Price Inc., the world's largest newsprint producer, because of an increased offer by Olympia and York Investments Ltd.

title: POLAND AND SOVIET AGREE ON THE NEED FOR 'URGENT' ACTION
description: Senior Polish and Soviet officials met unexpectedly in Moscow today, and, according to the Polish press agency, agreed on the need for ''urgent'' action to counter the threat to ''socialist Poland.''

title: Oilers Rally to Tie Rangers, 5-5
description: The Rangers twice wiped out one-goal deficits in the third period, then could not hold a two-goal lead and had to settle for a 5-5 tie with the Edmonton Oilers last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Closing Christo's Gates
description: New York's Parks Department has denied a permit to Christo, an artist who specializes in transforming landscapes and whose latest proposal is to erect 11,000 steel-supported, golden-orange banners on 25 miles of pathways in Central Park. The department says it is the wrong project in the wrong place at the wrong time. Though it finds the project ''visually seductive and of great esthetic charm,'' it has nonetheless reached the right decision for all the right reasons.

title: EXCERPTS FROM KIRKLAND'S TESTIMONY TO CONGRESS
description: Following are excerpts from the testimony today of Lane Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, before the House Budget Committee:

title: Arco Alters Terms Of Observer's Sale
description: In a bid to head off a long review by the British Government, the Atlantic Richfield Company said today that it had revised the terms of its proposed sale of the Londonbased Sunday newspaper The Observer to the George Outram Company of Glasgow.

title: Sports of the Times; Fingers Spells Relief for the Brewers
description: OUT on the mound during batting practice, the desert sun glinted off the waxed, twirled mustache of the old relief pitcher who suddenly stopped his windup and shook his shoulders.

title: Hamilton, Jackson Gain P.S.A.L. Basketball Semifinals
description: Alexander Hamilton of Brooklyn and Jackson of Queens advanced to the semifinals yesterday of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: The simplest, most rational reply to the Reagan Administration's recent attempts to show that leftist countries are providing support to the insurgent forces in El Salvador is ''So what?'' v. hy do we blindly assume that, because the Communists (and many in the Catholic Church) are helping the poor in their struggle for human dig-nity, we have to support the oligarchy in its attempt to perpetuate a feudal system?

title: 'Overserious' Adults
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I read with considerable amusement, and some dismay, a recent letter published in response to Bernard Gladstone's plans for making a toy chest (''Home Improvement,'' Jan. 22). The letter writer was concerned that a child, having a toy chest rather than open shelves, would not learn to classify, categorize and care for his toys.

title: A $500,000 Jewelry Theft in Italy
description: Burglars got away with gold jewelry worth $500,000 from a shop in the downtown area of this central Italian town, the police reported today. Sometime in the night, the police said, the burglars entered the shop through a hole cut in a side wall and forced open a safe with the help of a blow torch.

title: Torin Thatcher, Actor Of Films, Stage and TV
description: Torin Thatcher, a veteran of Broadway and the movies who often played pirates, died of cancer at his home today. He was 76 years old.

title: A Star-Spangled Day for a British Drinking Tune
description: It was 50 years ago yesterday that President Herbert Hoover signed Public Law 823, making a British drinking tune with words by Francis Scott Key the national anthem.

title: Bruins, Stars Tie, 3-3, In a 'Mild' Rematch
description: When Minnesota played in Boston last Thursday night the teams set a National Hockey League game record of 406 penalty minutes, and 12 players were ejected.

title: POLICE FORM NEW UNIT TO COMBAT ROBBERIES IN CITY, NOW AT A RECORD
description: With robberies at a record level in New York City, a new 120-man unit will be set up and about 2,400 other detectives and uniformed police officers will be redeployed to combat such crimes, Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire announced yesterday.

title: by Carolyn G. Heilbrun
description: MAE WEST liked to say, long years ago, that marriage was a fine institution, but she wasn't ready for an institution. The other uncompromising observation about marriage I remember (voiced by many, but the earliest published version I know is in a Hardy novel) remarks that women accept sex for the sake of marriage, and that men marry for the sake of sex. It would be hard to decide which of these observations has become more outdated in the United States.

title: 'The Survivor' to Close Sunday
description: ''The Survivor,'' a play by Susan Nanus based on a book by Jack Eisner recalling his life in the Warsaw Ghetto in World War II, will close after Sunday's matinee at the Morosco Theater.

title: ROSEDALE PUPILS ARE TRICKLING IN DESPITE BOYCOTT
description: Parents in the Rosedale section of Queens have been gradually allowing their children to attend two schools that have been the targets of a boycott prompted by the closing of a school annex, according to Board of Education attendance statistics.

title: ASH WEDNESDAY SERVICES HERALD PENITIENTIAL SEASON
description: The somber theme of yesterday's Ash Wednesday service marked the beginning of the penitential season of Lent for millions of Christians. While self-denial and solemn reflection on sin and suffering are most commonly stressed during Lent, the Rev. Aldo Tos, pastor of St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church on Staten Island, also observed tradition with a somewhat different theme.

title: WATER-WELL DRILLERS ARE KEEPING BUSY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Arlene Fischer is a freelance writer. By ARLENE FISCHER

title: Around the World; Kuwait Gets New Cabinet In the Wake of Elections
description: Kuwait's Crown Prince and Prime Minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, formed a new 15-member Cabinet today to guide the desert oil state on its return to parliamentary life.

title: THE MAKING OF A WRITER: TELL A YARN OR NO DINNER
description: ''When I was young, we lived in a large, large house in Ossining, and there was a huge diningroom with a long table like you see in New Yorker cartoons. My father had hired a chef from the Hotel Pierre and he used to make these incredible dishes. I would come in at dinner time, and before I could sit down, my father would ask, 'What did you do at school today?' and I would tell him. 'That's not enough,' he'd say. 'What did you do at school today?' Then I would try making something up - still not good enough. Before I could eat, I had to satisfy my father with a tale that would entertain him. Telling stories began as sort of a food-gathering reflex.''

title: NICARAGUA,ATTACKED ON RIGHTS, DEFENDS ITS RECORD
description: When the long-ruling Somoza regime was ousted after a civil war in July 1979, the new Sandinist leadership pledged to respect human rights and promised a ''generous revolution'' in which captured National Guardsmen would not be tortured or executed.

title: FRUSTRATION KEEPS GROWING FOR MCADOO
description: The long, flailing arms and the mournful eyes that look searchingly for a teammate's pass - Bob McAdoo's trademarks - have been missing from the pro basketball scene.

title: U.S. JURY CONVICTS FRANKLIN IN SLAYING OF 2 UTAH BLACKS
description: After 14 hours of deliberation, an allwhite jury of 10 women and two men returned guilty verdicts tonight against 30-year-old Joseph Paul Franklin for civil rights violations in the sniper slayings of two young black men as they jogged in a Salt Lake City park last August.

title: ALLEGED NAZI ADMITS LYING FOR VISA
description: A Ukrainian immigrant accused of hiding his alleged background as a guard in Nazi death camps admitted today at his deportation trial that he had lied on his visa application, but he insisted that he had acted out of fear of being sent back to the Soviet Union.

title: GEORGIA BUILDER FINDING ROAD TO GROWTH
description: An item on The Atlanta Journal's front page of Nov. 23, 1962, began this way: ''The Atlanta Chamber of Commerce has invited a Negro to become a member of its 3,000-member all-white organization.'' The article made it clear that the invitation had been sent inadvertently. It was mailed to Herman J. Russell, owner of the H.J. Russell Plastering Company. He accepted.

title: De Paul Routs Dayton
description: Mark Aguirre scored 24 points and Skip Dillard 21 to lead second-ranked De Paul to an 84-64 victory over Dayton tonight, the 13th straight triumph for the Blue Demons (26-1).

title: Jimmy Stewart Replaced In Firestone's Tire Ads
description: To replace kind, trustworthy, believable Jimmy Stewart as an advertising spokesman for the tires of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn has created a superdedicated, but completely imaginary, tire engineer named George Peabody.

title: BELL SAYS ADMINISTRATION SEEKS GREATER CUTS IN AID TO EDUCATION
description: The Reagan Administration will ask Congress next week to approve a spending reduction of 25 percent in key Federal programs for educating the disadvantaged and handicapped in the nation's elementary and secondary schools.

title: LITERARY AGENTS' 10% FEE GOES DOWN MEMORY LANE
description: The 10 percent commission charged by literary agents, a decadesold publishing tradition, may soon go the way of the $4.95 hardcover and the 95 cent paperback. A growing number of agents are raising their fees to 15 percent, and many who have not done so say they are considering following suit.

title: A Fearful Symmetry
description: The sharp change in human rights policy announced by the Reagan Administration has just had a first diplomatic test, and the result was instructive. The new approach alarmed some of our friends, who were afraid it would comfort the official torturers. But in the end a compromise was worked out.

title: U.S. ACTS TO IMPROVE AIR BASE IN TURKEY
description: A major effort is under way to improve both the military ability and the quality of life at Incirlik, the base of operations for the only significant United States military presence in the Middle East.

title: Brett Leaves Hospital
description: George Brett, who underwent hemorrhoid surgery last Saturday, left St. Luke's Hospital today, but Kansas City Royals officials said it would be at least 10 days before the third baseman could return to training camp at Fort Myers, Fla.

title: POP SINGER: TONY MARTIN
description: THIRTY years ago, Tony Martin was one of the finest romantic pop singers in America. Although he never achieved the sustained popularity of Tony Bennett, Perry Como or Frank Sinatra, Mr. Martin brought a direct sensuality to his style that was singular among crooners.

title: Around the World; 50 Ukrainian Catholics From U.S. Meet With Pope
description: Pope John Paul II greeted 50 Ukrainian Catholics from the United States today during his weekly general audience.

title: Junta in Nicaragua Consolidates, Dropping Two of Five Members
description: The ruling junta said today that it would reduce its size from five to three members to guarantee ''more cohesion, effectiveness and efficiency.'' The change leaves the Sandinista National Liberation Front in control.

title: EXCERPTS FROM WEINBERGER STATEMENT ON MILITARY BUDGET OUTLAY
description: Following are excerpts from a prepared statement delivered today by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger on the Reagan Administration's military budget proposals before the Senate Armed Services Committee:

title: KIRKLAND DECLARES BUDGET INEQUITABLE
description: Leaders of organized labor went to Capitol Hill today to oppose President Reagan's economic package, which they called ''ill-conceived,'' ''inequitable'' and ''disastrous to working Americans.''

title: 50 ORDERED RELEASED FROM OVERCROWDED JAIL IN JERSEY
description: Because of overcrowding, officials in Union County, N.J., yesterday ordered the release of 50 persons awaiting trial or grand-jury appearances who could not afford to make bail.

title: Technology; The Membrane Keyboard
description: THOSE space-age flat buttons - the type that don't yield when they are pushed - have proliferated in the last five years. Because of their low price and sleekness, the buttons are used on calculators, copiers, microwave ovens, appliances and electronic games.

title: U.S. SAID TO WEIGH EXTENSIVE ARMS SALES TO PAKISTAN
description: The prospect of renewed and extensive American arms sales to Pakistan is reportedly being considered because of that country's importance to the security of the Persian Gulf region and its situation as the only available conduit for supplying weapons to anti-Soviet guerrillas in Afghanistan.

title: HERBICIDE CASE IN ARIZONA IS SETTLED
description: The Dow Chemical Company and the United States Forest Service have agreed to pay an undisclosed sum to five families in Globe, Ariz., who said they suffered permanent injuries 12 years ago when a defoliant was sprayed over their homes.

title: Around the World; Press Institute Challenges U.N. Agency on Licensing
description: The International Press Institute ended its 30th general assembly today with a resolution challenging the fitness of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to protect and license journalists.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Celanese Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer $100 million in convertible subordinated debentures due in 2006, through a First Boston group.

title: CALENDAR: FLOWERS AND FURNISHINGS
description: Flower and Plant Show, State University of New York, Farmingdale, L.I.

title: Much of Greece Is Struck
description: The third strong earthquake in less than two weeks shook most of Greece just before midnight yesterday, taking at least one life and slightly injuring 30 people.

title: U.S. BLAMES CUBA FOR EXPULSION OF 6 AMERICANS FROM MOZAMBIQUE
description: The United States charged Cuba today with trying to force an American diplomat in Mozambique to agree to spy for the Havana Government and then pushing the Mozambican Government to expel him and five other Americans when the effort failed.

title: L.I. Board Fails to Bar Trial on Book Removal
description: A divided Federal appeals court refused yesterday to reconsider a decision requiring a trial of a dispute over the removal of nine books from the school libraries of the Island Trees Union Free School District in the Town of Hempstead, L.I.

title: Coke Bottlers Suing Parent Company
description: The Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Elizabethtown, Ky., said that it and 95 other Coke bottlers were suing the parent Coca-Cola Company over its use of a cheaper sugar substitute in its syrup and for alleged overpricing.

title: Topics; PICTURES FROM THE PAST; Baby Face
description: One can't help wishing it were an occasion for laughter: a 9-yearold boy holds up a bank, using what we're told was a toy pistol. There was, in fact, a time when it would have been, when this small version of Willie Sutton would have been photographed later wearing a policeman's hat and licking an ice cream cone.

title: 'Qaddafi In Chad'
description: When Ronald Reagan was asked by Walter Cronkite about the Soviet feelers for a summit conference, the President allowed as how ''it would make it a lot easier'' if the imperialism of Soviet surrogates were to be moderated. The first example he pointed to: ''Qaddafi in Chad.''

title: G.A.O. URGES EASING OF CORRUPT PRACTICES ACT
description: The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said today that the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act should be amended to eliminate criminal penalties for all but the most flagrant violations of the law's accounting requirements.

title: Steel, Transport Issues Strong; Dow, Up 5.42, Resumes Trend
description: The stock market ended moderately higher yesterday in active trading with the steel and the transportation issues posting the best gains.

title: MUSIC: ANDREW RUDIN
description: THE extended showcase of music by a Philadephia composer named Andrew Rudin Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall taxed one's attention - especially since Mr. Rudin seems an unusually variable composer. Most of the music, composed between 1966 and 1981, was in an arid chromatic idiom.

title: TV NEWS CREW BARRED FROM SKATING EVENT
description: A camera crew from WFSB-TV, the CBS affiliate here, was barred from the 1981 World Figure Skating Championships today at the insistence of ABC-TV because the WFSB showed portions of the competition yesterday. ABC has purchased the exclusive television rights to the six-day event.

title: NEW YORK NEEDS AN ELECTED OMBUDSMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Supply Side Gaining in Texts
description: If textbooks help determine how economists of the future will think, supply-side economics is gaining there, too. For while most texts refrain from advocating any particular course of action, a theory's presence in a popular book can help legitimitize that approach.

title: WCBS-TV News Wins Nine New York Emmys
description: TV, Channel 2, dominated the New York area Emmy Awards, presented by the New York chapter of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, sweeping nine of the 11 awards in the news division.

title: REAGAN'S DELAY ON SEA PACT A SOURCE OF DISMAY AT U.N.
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to delay a sweeping new set of rules governing sea lanes and the mineral wealth of sea beds was greeted here today with dismay and concern.

title: Airbus Order Cancellation
description: Toa Domestic Airlines, Japan's domestic air carrier, has decided to cancel orders for three Airbuses valued at $121 million because of slumping passenger traffic and revenues, industry sources said today. Toa has also asked the builders, Airbus Industries, to delay delivery of three other A-300 Airbuses, originally scheduled to join the Toa fleet this year.

title: JUDGE BARS 4 DEFENSE WITNESSES IN BERRIGANS' TRIAL
description: A Montgomery County judge today barred from the stand four witnesses proposed as experts who were ready to testify in defense of Philip F. Berrigan, the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan and six others accused of breaking into a General Electric Company plant near here and damaging the nose cones of nuclear missiles.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The umbilical cord of the industrialized free world runs through the Strait of Hormuz into the Arabian Gulf and the nations which surround it.

title: 16 Dunham Dancers To Be Honored March 15
description: Sixteen dancers who performed with Katherine Dunham in the early 1940's will be honored in ''A Celebration of Women in Dance,'' to be presented by the Thelma Hill Performing Arts Center on March 15 at 5 P.M., in the Klitgord Auditorium of the New York Community Technical College, 300 Jay Street, Brooklyn.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 5, 1981
description: International A need for ''urgent'' action in Poland to counter a threat to Communism was agreed on by senior Polish and Soviet leaders in Moscow, according to the Polish press agency. The report said that the two sides had agreed that the preservation of Communism in one country concerned all Communist nations. Western analysts viewed the unexpected meeting as a new warning to Warsaw's leadership that it must resolve economic turmoil in Poland quickly. (Page A1, Column 1.) Fears of a rightist coup in El Salvador were raised as a military leader denounced any negotiations between the governing junta and the leftist insurgents. Sources close to President Jose Napoleon Duarte said that a trip to West Germany he had planned for the weekend had been canceled, apparently because of fear of a coup. The American Embassy issued a statement opposing any coup attempt after shots were fired at the embassy from a passing truck. (A1:1-3.)

title: Accounts
description: * Gillette Company to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc., Boston, for trade advertising of blades, razors and Cricket lighters.

title: Appeal Filed for Slayer Despite His Wish to Die
description: The American Civil Liberties Union appealed today for clemency for Steven T. Judy, a condemned murderer who is to be executed next Monday. However, Mr. Judy opposed the request and Gov. Robert D. Orr said that he did not plan to halt the electrocution.

title: WEINBERGER BEGINS DRIVE FOR BIG RISE IN MILITARY BUDGET
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger went to Congress today to propose a huge spurt in the military budget that he said would ''significantly and quickly strengthen our ability to respond to the Soviet threat at all levels of conflict and in all areas of the world vital to our national interest.''

title: VIEWS VARY ON SOVIET ARMS COST
description: In requesting major increases in its 1981 and 1982 budgets, the Defense Department said today that military spending by the Soviet Union ''has exceeded'' that of the United States for more than a decade.

title: HOME BEAT
description: TWO recently published books provide an entertaining look at interior design and decorating. One is of the ''tell-all'' variety - the memoirs of the interior decorator who has designed his way around the world.

title: by Carlos Fuentes
description: Throughout this hemisphere, these are the questions that we Latin Americans are urgently asking ourselves: Is the Reagan Administration out to prove the born-again machismo of the United States? But, then, why doesn't the United States show its bravery in Kabul or Warsaw? Since it cannot take vengeance in Iran, must it take it in El Salvador? Is it bravery or cowardice to bully and slap around a pale, underfed 9-year-old child? Why are Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s sabers rattling?

title: Index; International
description: Nicaragua, accused on rights, de- fends record A2 Loneliness afflicts American workers in Nigeria's oilfields A3 Iran and Iraq receive Islamic peace proposals A3 U.S. said to weigh large-scale sale of arms to Pakistan A3 Reagan's delay on sea pact a source of dismay at U.N. A4 Around the World A5 New Soviet Central Committee re- flects Brezhnev's influence A7 Shcharansky put in prison within his labor camp A8 U.S. seeking to improve key air base in Turkey A11 U.S. blames Cuba for expulsion of 6 Americans from Mozambique A14 South African premier hails Rea- gan's words in TV interview A15 Government/Politics Two court vacancies cast shadow over California politics A17 F.B.I. and Soviet step up counter- intelligence efforts A20 Supreme Court reverses ruling on grants to mental patients A24 Judge rules alleged prostitutes are entitled to a jury trial B2 General Around the Nation A16 Alleged Nazi guard says he feared being returned to Soviet A16 Judge bars four defense witnesses in Berrigans' trial A18 Small oil dealers say high prices are hurting them, too B6 Settlement is reached in Arizona herbicide case B10 Fire Department yields in effort to get subway car keys B14 Features/Notes Notes on People B9 Going Out Guide C18 Religion Ash Wednesday Services herald penitential season B1 The Home Section Home Bachelors who demand more of design C1

title: MUSIC: SYMPHONY NO.2 OF PETER MAXWELL DAVIES
description: PETER MAXWELL DAVIES made an international splash in the 60's with works such as ''Eight Songs for a Mad King'' and ''Vesalii Icones,'' in which he blended intellectually convoluted music with sensational theatricality. Since then, the British composer has moved in other directions, one of which was made evident last night at Carnegie Hall, where the Boston Symphony under Seiji Ozawa's direction gave the New York premiere of his Symphony No. 2.

title: Advertising
description: THINGS would be really great for Joseph T. Plummer if it weren't for this nagging worry about his chosen field. Here he is only 40 years old, with a doctorate from Ohio State in his pocket, and a job as the head of research at Young & Rubicam, U.S.A., the country's largest ad agency, where his bosses think enough of him to promote him to executive vice president after only two years with the company.

title: Contractor Indicted in 4 Deaths
description: A private contractor was indicted on manslaughter charges today stemming from the allegedly improper installation of a Heatilator fireplace heating unit. Fire investigators said the unit was responsible for a fire last Nov. 9 that killed four members of the Richard Galavotti family of Cicero, about seven miles north of Syracuse. The contractor, George Beaulieu, 46 years old, of Baldwinsville, near Cicero, is alleged to have knowingly failed to place about a foot of masonry insulation around the Heatilator installed in the Galavotti home, according to Richard Lyons, senior Onondaga County District Attorney and head of the county's arson task force.

title: ISLAMIC MISSION TAKES PLAN FOR A TRUCE TO IRAN AND IRAQ
description: An Islamic peace mission visited Iran and Iraq today for the second time this week and presented a detailed proposal for a cease-fire in the two countries' war and for negotiations for a settlement.

title: By ANGEL CASTILLO
description: A judge in Criminal Court in Manhattan has declared unconstitutional the local practice of denying alleged prostitutes the right to a jury trial. The ruling, if upheld on appeal, could further strain New York City's congested Criminal Court.

title: Continental Expansion
description: The Continental Grain Company said today that it would spend more than $50 million to expand facilities at the site of an export grain elevator that exploded in December 1977, killing 36 people and seriously injuring 13 others. The elevator capacity will be doubled, to 12 million metric tons a year, making it the largest agricultural export facility in the nation, company officials said. A metric ton is approximately 2,205 pounds.

title: KOCH NOW EXPECTED TO OPPOSE A SWAP ON TUDOR CITY PARKS
description: In a sudden reversal, Mayor Koch will announce today his decision to oppose the exchange of a city playground for two private parks in Tudor city, according to the Commissioner of the City Planning Commission, Herbert J. Sturz.

title: 3 Resign From Cabinet in France To Work for Election of Giscard
description: Three members of the French Cabinet resigned tonight so they could devote their time to working for the reelection of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, Elysee Palace announced.

title: SHCHARANSKY IS PLACED IN LOCKUP WITHIN HIS LABOR CAMP IN SOVIET
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, a convicted dissident, has been placed in a prison inside the labor camp where he is serving a 13-year sentence on charges of treason and espionage, his brother, Leonid, said today.

title: SALVADORAN LEADER CANCELS TRIP AS COUP FEARS GROW
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said today that no ''preparations'' had been made for negotiations with the leaders of the leftist guerrillas.

title: DAPHNE FURNITURE AWARDS ARE PRESENTED
description: THE Daphne Awards, given for ''outstanding furniture design and superior value,'' were presented for the first time Tuesday evening at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: MURCER, 34, A YANKEE WITHOUT ANY FUTURE
description: When Dave Winfield arrived in the Yankee camp Friday, he was the center of attention. When Reggie Jackson did not arrive Sunday, then arrived yesterday, he was the center of attention. Once upon a time, Bobby Murcer was the center of attention in the Yankee camp.

title: Jury Awards Close to $1 Million For Death of Drunken Bus Rider
description: A jury assessed nearly $1 million in damages yesterday against a New Jersey bus company for the death of a passenger who was allowed to get off a bus ''dead drunk'' in a hurricane.

title: SALVADORAN GUERRILLAS DENY OBTAINING ARMS FROM COMMUNIST BLOC
description: The political commission representing El Salvador's guerrillas has denied receiving arms from Vietnam, Ethiopia, Cuba, the Soviet Union or ''any other government.''

title: ISOLATION SAPS AMERICANS ON THE OIL RIGS OF NIGERIA
description: They come here with the rich black soil of the Mississippi delta, the gumbo of Louisiana or the dust of Texas still on their boots, and 28 days later they fly back to whatever patch of America they call home, and 28 days after that they are back in this oilfield for another tour. Such is the bubble in which they live that not one of them can name the President of Nigeria.

title: by George M. Raymond
description: Consider this scenario: A city fiscally on the skids - as most are - decides to make a major effort to stem the drain of economic activity to the suburbs. At the cost of millions of dollars, much of it in Federal aid, it straightens out the street system in its beleaguered central business district, builds parking garages, and acquires several privately owned buildings and vacant lots to assemble a site suitable for development of a new shopping mall, complete with a department store and hotel. At long last, the city is at the point of executing a contract with a major developer, when a news story breaks that 100 acres of land has been rezoned for a shopping center for another developer just beyond the city line.

title: Nippon Steel in Pact With Armco Unit
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation, Japan's largest steel producer, said it had signed a contract to export 7,000 tons of seamless steel pipes to the National Supply Company, an American manufacturer of oil drilling equipment wholly owned by Armco Inc.

title: SANTEE LEADS
description: David Santee of Park Ridge, Ill., with a strong performance in the short program, took the men's overall lead today in the world figure skating championships at the Hartford Civic Center.

title: THE REGION
description: Democratic leaders of the General Assembly proposed today a package of $28.5 million in new taxes to take effect next month, and a cut of at least $3.4 million in state aid to education, to help reduce a budget deficit now estimated at $45 million for the fiscal year that ends June 30. The biggest tax would be a 1 percent levy on real-estate sales that would yield the state $15 million by the end of June if it took effect by April 1.

title: CAREY WOULD SIP A GLASS OF PCB'S
description: Governor Carey volunteered today to drink a glass of PCB's from a contaminated state office building in Binghamton to demonstrate that the building was safe.

title: Around the Nation; Jury Indicts 2 in Michigan For Not Filing Tax Returns
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted an automotive engineer and an ironworker for failure to file income tax returns.

title: The Hunted in Argentina
description: ''They toasted the news with champagne,'' says an Argentine democrat, speaking of his hard-line countrymen. ''They saw the change in American policy literally as a hunting license.'' To the Reagan Administration, this judgment of its new human rights policy will seem harsh, and premature. But tell that to the hunted, the eight courageous, nonpolitical leaders of Argentina's human rights movement arrested last weekend; five are still held, incommunicado.

title: U.S. NOTE AND BOND PRICES DROP
description: The prices of Treasury notes and bonds closed lower yesterday after trading at higher levels earlier in the day.

title: Silver Concerns Bar Sunshine Takeover
description: Directors of the Silver Dollar Mining Company, Sunshine Consolidated Inc. and Silver Syndicate, all of which hold an interest in the Sunshine Silver Mine in Idaho, rejected a proposed takeover offer by the Sunshine Mining Company of Dallas.

title: AIDE BALKS AT RELEASING TAX DATA
description: An official of the Bureau of Economic Analysis refused today to turn over Internal Revenue Service data tapes to a Bellevue Wash., couple, because the Government fears the information could aid tax cheaters.

title: Around the Nation; Authorities Seek Arsonist In Fire at Las Vegas Hotel
description: The authorities here were seeking an arsonist who set a fire yesterday afternoon at the Silverbird Hotel, forcing 1,000 guests and gamblers to flee.

title: Coca-Cola Net Up 7.6% in 4th Quarter
description: The Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft-drink concern, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of last year rose 7.6 percent, to $95.9 million, or 78 cents a share, from $89.1 million, or 72 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979. Sales increased 20.8 percent, to $1.51 billion, from $1.25 billion.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bowne & Company has appointed Victor Simonte Jr., president and chief operating officer, to the additional post of chief executive officer, succeeding Edmund A. Stanley Jr. who remains chairman.

title: SUSPECT IS ARRESTED AT KENNEDY AIRPORT IN THE THEFT OF $1.2 MILLION
description: An unemployed longshoreman who is accused of stealing $1.2 million that tumbled into the street from an armored car in Philadelphia a week ago was arrested yesterday morning at John F. Kennedy Airport as he was checking in for a flight to Acapulco, Mexico.

title: Market Place; The Apache Partnership
description: FOR the first time in New York Stock Exchange history, partnership units have been approved for listing, and traders seem to like the idea. Some weeks ago after reviewing the Apache Petroleum Company, a partnership that has its headquarters in Minneapolis, the exchange decided the ''depositary'' units met its breadth of ownership, capital and earnings requirements and granted trading rights.

title: HAIG OPPOSES A COUP BY SALVADOR'S RIGHT
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that a rightist military takeover in El Salvador would have ''serious consequences'' for continuation of Amerian military and economic aid to fight a leftist insurgency in that Central American country.

title: House to Press Lederer Inquiry
description: The House voted overwhelmingly today to proceed with a disciplinary inquiry into Representative Raymond F. Lederer, a Pennsylvania Democrat who is the last of six Congressmen convicted on Abscam charges to remain in the House. By a 390-to-1 vote, the House gave its ethics committee the power to subpoena witnesses and obtain Justice Department data.

title: FED BOUGHT MARKS
description: The Federal Reserve Board disclosed yesterday that in the three months ended with January the Fed and the Treasury were net purchasers of $4.4 billion of German marks and almost $105 million of Swiss francs. The Fed also reported that foreign currency reserves rose to a record $10.7 billion at the end of January.

title: F.B.I. STEPPING UP EFFORTS ON SOVIET
description: The field office here for the Federal Bureau of Investigation has increased its counterintelligence manpower by about 15 percent at a time when agents of the Soviet bloc have stepped up their activity to learn about the new Reagan Administration, a bureau official said today.

title: energywatch
description: FEB. 27 Crude oil stocks climbed to 383.1 million barrels, up 6.5 million.

title: SCIENTISTS SAY FUTURE IS IN SOLAR ENERGY
description: Take a small country with no oil, plenty of sunshine and lots of scientists, and you have a perfect laboratory for intensive research into solar energy.

title: HOUSE HEARING TOLD A WESTWAY TRADE-IN MIGHT BE DIFFICULT
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis suggested today that New York City might have difficulty trading in funds earmarked for construction of the Westway and using the money for mass transit.

title: I.L.O. ASSAILS SOVIET LABOR TACTIC
description: The Soviet Union was rebuked by the International Labor Organization today for its treatment of workers who had sought to form trade unions free of government control.

title: Combined Seeks Filmways Units
description: Combined International Corporation, a holding of W. Clement Stone, the Chicago financier, said it had agreed in principle to purchase two wholly owned subsidiaries of Filmways Inc. for about $110 million. They are the Union Fidelity Corporation and Neshaminy Valley Information Processing Inc.

title: Eagleburger Nominated To the State Department
description: President Reagan yesterday nominated Lawrence S. Eagleburger, a colleague of Henry A. Kissinger when he was Secretary of State, as Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs.

title: REAGAN AIDES MEET SHARP ATTACK IN HOUSE ON NEW SALVADORAN AID
description: Reagan Administration officials today defended increased military aid to El Salvador against sharp criticism during a Congressional hearing from House Democrats and a Roman Catholic bishop.

title: NEW YORK CITY BOND PRICES UP
description: Prices of New York City bonds, already well above the lows reached during the 1975-76 fiscal crisis, rose further yesterday after the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced a BBB rating for the city's outstanding and upcoming bond issues.

title: Utah Seeks Death Penalty In Its Case Against Racist
description: Utah prosecutors said today that they would ask the death penalty in the state case against Joseph Paul Franklin, who was convicted yesterday of Federal civil rights violations in the deaths by shooting of two black joggers.

title: Energy Stocks Lead Retreat
description: Stock prices weakened in late trading yesterday, with energyoriented issues leading the decline. Schlumberger, an institutional favorite, dropped 4 1/4 points, to 103.

title: No Headline
description: Dr. Nathan Brown, a former acting superintendent of schools in New York City, died yesterday at his home in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 68 years old.

title: Swedes Protest Over Salvador
description: More than 1,000 demonstrators gathered in a snowstorm in Stockholm's main square tonight to protest American involvement in El Salvador. Pictures of victims of the fighting in El Salvador were projected on a huge screen in scenes reminiscent of protests here against United States policies in Vietnam a decade ago.

title: NEW CHIEF BACKS F.T.C. LIMITS
description: David A. Clanton, the newly appointed acting chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today that he expected the regulatory agency to initiate fewer of the rule-making cases that have aroused industry opposition.

title: SPANISH PREMIER VISITS BASQUE REGION AFTER SLAYING
description: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo flew to the Basque provinces this evening hours after terrorists assassinated a police chief there.

title: JURY TOLD GOODY CO. HAD KNOWINGLY DEALT IN COUNTERFEIT TAPES
description: A Federal prosecutor charged yesterday that top executives of Sam Goody Inc., one of the leading chains of recorded-music stores in the country, sought to make big profits by knowingly dealing in counterfeit cassette and eight-track tapes of popular music.

title: News Analysis
description: ''The word for it is stasis,'' a Western diplomat said. ''No new people, no new ideas. This was the ultimate nonevent of the Brezhnev era, the ultimate proof that when confronted with a choice their instinct tells them to do nothing rather than doing something.''

title: JAZZ SERIES AT CARNEGIE CELEBRATES THE BLUES
description: ''I HAD the voice when I sang the blues in my youthful days. I didn't gyrate to them. The blues are supposed to be serious, and I sang them as the master taught me.''

title: Stevens Blocks Release Of Internal Revenue Tapes
description: Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court today temporarily blocked the release of computer tapes that the Government says could help tax cheats.

title: CLIFFORD TALKS OF TRUMAN AND JOHNSON
description: ''BILL MOYERS' JOURNAL'' continues, tonight at 9 on Channel 13, with the second hourlong half of a conversation with Clark M. Clifford. Mr. Clifford, now 75, is the Washington lawyer who, as an adviser to Presidents, became what some observers saw as the most powerful private citizen since Bernard Baruch.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny Ludlum Industries intends to ask its shareholders to change the name of the corporation to Allegheny International.

title: LITERARY COMMANDMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicklaus, Ziegler Share Inverrary Lead at 65
description: Jack Nicklaus survived 30-milean-hour gusts and shot a seven-under-par 65 today to tie Larry Ziegler for the first-round lead in the $300,000 American Motors Inverrary Golf Classic.

title: Jose Chiriboga Is Dead; Quito's Ex-Foreign Aide
description: Jose Ricardo Chiriboga Villagomez, a former Foreign Minister of Ecuador who ran for that country's presidency in 1952 and 1956, died here today after a heart attack.

title:
Sports of the Times;
A Gallant Lady And a Fast Lord
description: AVIE WALKER of Unionville, Pa., is a gallant lady who has been paralyzed below the waist for 20 years. On March 21, 1961 - ''at 3:05 P.M.,'' she said on the phone - she took a fall in a point-to-point race, and she hasn't walked since, although she still tools around breeding, buying, selling and training race horses.

title: 10,000 Jobless Protest in Naples
description: About 10,000 jobless Neapolitans demonstrated in the city center today to press demands to be hired on earthquake rebuilding projects. November's quake left up to 50,000 people homeless in Naples.

title: SALE OF 9 RENTAL BUILDINGS: 'WHOLESALE' CONCEPT USED
description: The familiar direction of Manhattan rental apartments when they change ownership is toward cooperative sale. The apartments are either ''retailed'' to shareholders in a cooperative corporation, or sold to an entity that intends to follow a path toward cooperative conversion.

title: REAGAN CUTS VIEWED AS THREAT TO CITY SEWAGE TREATMENT PROJECT
description: After more than a decade of delays, New York City was ready to begin a billion-dollar effort to complete its basic sewage treatment system. But city officials now say President Reagan's proposed budget cuts once again threaten the entire program.

title: Stalking Stock Trading Abuses
description: Within the past month, a flurry of stock-trading scandals has tested the detective skills of a little-publicized team of analysts at the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Ogilvy Paving Way In Cable Marketing
description: Ogilvy & Mather Direct Response is getting in the ground floor of something big, something that could be the shopping wave of the future.

title: Zeller's Urges Acceptance
description: Zeller's Ltd. said today that its directors were recommending that shareholders accept the Hudson's Bay Company's offer of $18 a share (Canadian) or an equivalent amount of preferred stock. Hudson's Bay already owns 62 percent of Zeller's.

title: Oriental wares for the bidding
description: COLLECTORS of Oriental art with a penchant for lacquerware, ceramics, prints and paintings may be shuttling between two of New York's auction houses next week. Gaveling begins Wednesday at 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet's York Avenue galleries, with Japanese lacquer. There are 78 lots of netsuke (toggles small enough to disappear in the palm of your hand), inro (small lacquer boxes used for carrying necessities) and larger lacquer boxes, all part of a collection assembled by Adolph Kroch, founder of the Kroch's & Brentano's bookstores in Chicago, and his daughter Gretchen Kroch Kelsch.

title: 129 Park Areas in City Set for Improvements
description: Beginning this spring, New York City will begin rehabilitating 129 playgrounds and neighborhood parks in the five boroughs, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: DEMOCRAT GIRDS FOR BUDGET FIGHT WITYH EYE ON DATA, EAR ON TULSA
description: When Representative James R. Jones describes his task as the House Budget Committee chairman, who must help marshal the Democrats' case for or against the Reagan economic program, he talks of Vietnam and his learning days on the staff of President Johnson.

title: At The Movies; by Chris Chase; Daniel Petrie, a director who takes chances.
description: DANIEL PETRIE directed ''Resurrection,'' a universally admired (if poorly attended) picture that has brought Academy Award nominations to Ellen Burstyn and Eva Le Gallienne. He also directed ''Fort Apache, the Bronx,'' a not-so-universally admired (but very well attended) picture that is making lots of money.

title: PIANO RECITAL: MICHAEL OELBAUM
description: MICHAEL OELBAUM'S pianistic conversations with the masters are not one-sided affairs. Mr. Oelbaum's concert of Berg, Beethoven and Schubert at Tully Hall Wednesday evening rejected the role of amanuensis-the kind of passive filter through which the imagination of others flows. Here the performer aggressively shared the spotlight with his material; indeed, the more reverent in the audience might have felt he hogged it.

title: Offer for Hobart
description: Canadian Pacific Enterprises (U.S.) Inc., an affiliate of Canadian Pacific Ltd., said it is extending until noon, March 20, its $38.50-a-share tender offer for all of the shares of the Hobart Corporation, a Troy, Ohio, manufacturer of kitchen appliances. Dart & Kraft Inc., a corporation resulting from last fall's merger of Dart Industries and the Kraft Corporation, is offering $40 a share for Hobart. Directors of Hobart have recommended that the Dart & Kraft offer be accepted by shareholders.

title: Heating Oil Prices Found to Stabilize
description: For the first time since mid-November, the price of home heating oil has stabilized in New York City and on Long Island, according to the director of a Long Island consumer group.

title: A PROFESSIONAL WITH NO APOLOGY FOR AMBITION
description: Truth to be told, said Barbara Singer Thomas, she's had a very traditional career. She was a cum laude graduate of the New York University School of Law, where she placed second in a class of 323, she was associated with two Park Avenue law firms and finally became a partner in one of them, and now she's the newest commissioner of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: UNIONS TO HOLD 'PEACEFUL' PROTEST ON THREE MILE ISLAND PROCEDURES
description: Elements of organized labor announced today the formation of an antinuclear coalition whose first effort is to be a union-sponsored protest march in Harrisburg, Pa., on the second anniversary of the accident at Three Mile Island.

title: There's No Escaping Salvador's Politics
description: It took just one week for the Reagan Administration to drop its pretense of indifference to political events in El Salvador. Suddenly, and belatedly, it had to declare itself ready to use American aid as a club to keep President Jose Napoleon Duarte in power. There is simply no way to separate American military involvement from a plausible political program.

title: SANTEE 2D
description: Scott Hamilton of Haverford, Pa., whose growth was stunted by a childhood illness, rose to his full 5 feet 3 1/2 inches and 110 pounds tonight and won the world men's figure skating championship.

title: STRAUSS EMERGES FROM HIS ELECTION DEFEAT REBORN AS A REAGANITE
description: Always good for a one-liner, Franz Josef Strauss said, ''Helmut Schmidt has about as much control over what's going on in West Germany as a kid with his hands on a toy steering wheel in the back seat of a car.''

title: 'THERE IS NO SIGNIFICANT BUDGET DEFICIT'
description: To the Editor:

title: BOSTON COLLEGE, ST. JOHN'S LOSE
description: The second Big East Conference basketball playoffs opened with a major upset this afternoon when Ricky Tucker sank a 12-foot jump shot with two seconds left to give Providence a 67-65 victory over Boston College, the tournament's top-seeded team.

title: BANKS STUDY NEW LOANS FOR POLAND
description: Western banks agreed today to study Poland's request for a $3.1 billion refinancing of commercial debt due this year, part of a $10.9 billion package to cover its 1981 payments shortfall, banking sources said.

title: War Account Challenged At Denaturalization Trial
description: The account that John Demjanjuk gave of his whereabouts while he supposedly was a German prisoner of war is at least in part historically impossible, the court at his trial was told today.

title: ART: ROSALIND BROWNE, A FEMINIST LESSON
description: CALLED liberation may have increased the number of working women artists tenfold, but it hasn't done much for art beyond widening the choice of cliches. The odds are 10 to one that a fair-size group show by women will be heavy on female genital images; at least one of its participants will be ''the eternal child,'' and the best work in all probabilty will be the least feminist.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S 'COLOREDS' ARE UNAPPEASED BY A BETTER LIFE THAT LACKS RIGHT TO VOTE
description: From a railway overpass on a suburban avenue that serves as one of this city's numerous racial boundaries, it is possible to peer into two adjacent middle-class communities. One is reserved for whites, the other for the people of mixed race who are officially classified as coloreds.

title: RATING ON BONDS OFFERED BY CITY NOW FAVORABLE
description: For the first time since New York City's long-term credit dried up in 1975, a major securities rating service said yesterday that the city's bonds were a reasonably good investment risk.

title: By DEANE McGOWEN
description: The National Hockey League suspended Nick Fotiu for eight games and Don Maloney for two yesterday as punishment for being among seven Ranger players who charged into the stands in an effort to get at taunting, debris-throwing fans at Detroit two weeks ago.

title: U.S. Wheat On Way to Iran
description: The first shipment of United States wheat to Iran since the release of the American hostages is on its way, an Agriculture Department official said today.

title: Mortgage Rates Average 15.34%
description: Mortgage rates for new single-family homes held virtually steady in early February, well above the 15 percent mark, the Government reported today.

title: MADISON FUND STAKE
description: MADISON FUND INC. a closed-end investment fund, announced that it will acquire, before the end of the month, 1.47 million common shares of AM International Inc. formerly the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation, giving it a 14.8 percent stake in the manufacturer of duplicators and advanced electronic products. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Madison said it was acquiring the shares for investment purposes and thatr it would pay about $25.5 million for the stock. The fund said that it planned to increase its stake in AM International to at least 25 percent.

title: Phoenix's New President
description: John Gummere, 52, the newly elected president and chief operating officer of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company in Hartford is candid when he talks about the future.

title: First Couple Mark Their 29th Anniversary
description: The Jockey Club is one of Washington's most elegant French restaurants, which made it an ideal choice Wednesday night for a couple celebrating their 29th wedding anniversary.

title: GENETICIST DEVLOPED HARDY HYBRID ONION
description: Henry A. Jones, a geneticist who was known as the ''father of the hybrid onion,'' died Feb. 24 at his home in Cave Creek, Ariz. He was 91 years old.

title: Lawyer Admits Guilt In Bilking the City
description: A lawyer who admitted cheating New York City out of more than $15,000 pleaded guilty to grand larceny charges in State Supreme Court.

title: Spreading Brushfire To the South
description: The policies now being adopted by President Reagan on El Salvador were essentially already decided by the Carter Administration before last year's elections. And they were already being challenged by insiders on the grounds that they would boomerang against the U.S.

title: Rather than on evolution  COAST TRIAL ON STUDY OF EVOLUTION FOCUSES ON LANGUAGE OF GUIDELINES
description: The trial of the Segraves family's suit against the California educational bureaucracy, now nearing a conclusion, has turned out to be a dispute over the language of state guidelines for organizing public school science courses rather than a new Scopes trial, pitting evolutionists against fundamentalists.

title: Need for Hearing on Venting Gas; At Crippled Reactor Is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld a ruling that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission should have held hearings on the release of radioactive gas from the damaged nuclear plant at Three Mile Island.

title: Conservative Democrats Urge More Budget Cuts
description: Conservative Democratic Congressmen gave President Reagan suggestions today for $11.2 billion extra in spending cuts.

title: U.S. Wants Sea Treaty To Give Access to Minerals
description: The United States will not agree to a new international sea treaty unless it guarantees access to seabed minerals by American mining companies, a State Department official told a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee today.

title: GUNMAN SEIZES JET IN 11-HOUR ORDEAL
description: A gunman who seized a jetliner today at the Los Angeles International Airport surrendered peacefully after an 11-hour standoff in which he demanded $3 million, the authorities said.

title: PUBLISHING: RARE VOLUMES AT FANCY PRICES
description: WHILE some book buyers complain about prices that are climbing relentlessly toward the $20 mark, others are more than willing to pay $60 for a copy of Tennessee Williams's first play, $75 for a facsimile manuscript of Vladimir Nabokov's lectures on ''Ulysses'' or $3,900 for a facsimile manuscript of Joseph Conrad. Even with a list price of $12,000 for the facsimile edition of Leonardo da Vinci's ''Codex Atlanticus,'' fewer than 100 copies are left.

title: Sweeping Changes At W.R. Grace
description: A reorganization of the top management of W.R. Grace & Company, affecting its five most senior officers, was announced yesterday. Leading the list of appointments was Carl N. Graf, 54 years old, who will become president and chief operating officer of the chemicals, natural resources and specialty consumer-products corporation.

title: A $50 Reagan Check Is Sold for $3,800
description: Spirited bidding for a Ronald Reagan check to the Americans for Democratic Action was won last night by Malcolm Forbes, the magazine publisher, during an auction at the Charles Hamilton Gallery at 25 East 77th Street in Manhattan.

title: U.S. TO GIVE ATLANTA NEW AID IN SLAYINGS
description: Atlanta will receive nearly $1 million in Federal grants to finance mental health and social programs related to the case of the city's missing and murdered children, President Reagan announced in Washington today.

title: REAGAN IS MOVING TO END PROGRAM THAT PAYS FOR LEGAL AID TO THE POOR
description: President Reagan plans to ask Congress to eliminate the $321 million Federal program that finances legal aid for the poor and to abolish the independent corporation that administers the program, the Office of Management and Budget said today.

title: IONA OUSTS ST. PETER'S
description: Fordham and St. Peter's, the top two seeded teams in the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro playoffs, were upset in semifinal games at Nassau Coliseum tonight. The Rams lost, 85-78, to Long Island University, and the Peacocks were ousted, 41-38, by Iona.

title: by Robert Mosbacher
description: Jr. HOUSTON - While the American business community may hope to prosper under the new Republican regime in Washington, it almost certainly is unaware of the extent to which it can positively affect that prosperity.

title: Auto Layoffs Slip in Week
description: Auto industry layoffs fell slightly this week, according to reports today from the nation's major auto makers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Micro Devices Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., has named Anthony Holbrook, George Scalise and Richard Previte senior vice presidents.

title: Chorale on Madison Ave.
description: The St. Andrew Chorale will perform two 19th-century masses, Schubert's Mass in A flat and Franck's Mass in A, on Sunday at 4 P.M. in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 73d Street.

title: Mazda Raises Car Prices
