description: Mazda Motors said today that it was raising prices by $100 to $400 on its 1981 Japanese passenger cars sold in the United States.

title: GUNMAN SLAIN, OFFICER SHOT IN BATTLE ON FIFTH AVENUE
description: Police officers and a bank-robbery suspect exchanged shots on a crowded Fifth Avenue corner yesterday in a shootout that left the suspect dead, one officer wounded and scores of startled midday pedestrians scrambling for cover.

title: Parole Approved for Four Back From Jail in Turkey
description: The United States Parole Commission has approved parole later this month for four Americans released recently from a Turkish prison where they had been serving long sentences for smuggling drugs.

title: VANDERBILT RALLIES TO UPSET KENTUCKY
description: Vanderbilt, trailing by 10-0 after nearly seven minutes, came back to score a major upset tonight, beating Kentucky, 60-55, to advance to the semifinals of the Southeastern Conference basketball tournament.

title: by John Pilger
description: Americans were recently treated to the voice of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, with its tone hectoring, obsessive, and cold. Above all, cold. Among all the comment that surrounded her visit, I cannot find a warning of the specter she raises in the lives of millions of Americans.

title: Addendum
description: Science Digest magazine increasing both its circulation rate base, to 450,000 from 400,000, and advertising rates the same 12.5 percent, effective with the July issue.

title: ART: REALISTS ENLIVEN SHOW AT ACADEMY
description: THE National Academy of Design, which is situated at 1083 Fifth Avenue, just a few steps north of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum at 89th Street, is one of New York's most venerable art institutions. Its annual juried exhibitions have been in progress without interruption since the academy first opened in 1826. Yet I wonder how many visitors to the Guggenheim have ever ventured into the academy galleries? If they do so venture, they are likely to be in for something of a shock. For nothing more remote from the modernist art we usually see at the Guggenheim can be imagined than the art that hangs on the walls of the academy. At times it is almost as though the 20th century, with all its celebrated innovations and outrages, had somehow failed to take place.

title: THEATER:FESTIVAL OF ONE-ACTERS
description: THE Lincoln Center Theater Company reopened the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater last night with the first round of a festival of one-act American plays, under the artistic direction of Edward Albee. In his own work as a playwright, Mr. Albee has proven that the one-act can be a pure and self-sustaining dramatic form.

title: Restaurants; by Mimi Sheraton; Good south Italian, Broadway landmark.
description: IF New Yorkers are fortunate in having a rapidly growing list of excellent and fashionable restaurants featuring the elegant cuisine of northern Italy, they may be paying a price by having lost most of the simple, casual and dependable neighborhood restaurants that served the more familiar dishes of southern Italy. The simpler restaurants with their familiar if less fashionable southern fare cannot command the prices that enable owners to meet rising costs. One southern Italian restaurant that has managed to remain successful, however, is Joe's on Macdougal Street in Greenwich Village.

title: At Big A: Win, Place, Snow
description: Yesterday's heavy snowfall, which caused the cancellation of harness racing at Freehold Raceway in the afternoon and at the Meadowlands and Roosevelt Raceway in the evening, did not prevent Aqueduct from running its nine-race thoroughbred card.

title: No Headline
description: Federal legislation has again been introduced to prohibit the use of excessive violence during a professional sports event.

title: by Michael S.Baram
description: The Northeast is running out of water. Vital supplies are contaminated by pollutants, depleted by drought, and have lost natural recharging from wetlands now filled in by construction. But demand from residential and industrial users increases.

title: KOCH, IN REVERSAL, OPPOSES TUDOR CITY LAND EXCHANGE
description: Mayor Koch yesterday reversed himself and announced his opposition to the proposed exchange of the city playground at 42d Street and First Avenue for the two parks in the Tudor City apartment complex, effectively killing the deal.

title: 2 HASIDIM HELD IN PLOT TO HARASS
description: Two Hasidic men were arrested last night and charged with plotting to set off a stink bomb in a Brooklyn public school where the Grand Rabbi of Belz was scheduled to officiate at Sabbath services tonight, the police said.

title: VW Will Still Send Engines to Chrysler
description: Volkswagen will continue to supply an unspecified number of engines to the Chrysler Corporation and go along with other suppliers in cutting prices 5 percent, Chrysler says.

title: Northeastern, Holy Cross Gain
description: Eric Jefferson's 18-foot jump shot with 45 seconds left in regulation time sent the game into overtime, and Roland Braswell's four free throws in overtime helped Northeastern beat Vermont, 76-69, tonight.

title: Westward in Queens
description: Photographs, paintings and prints that record Westward migration in the United States from 1850 to the early 1900's make up an exhibition called ''Western Views and Eastern Visions,'' which is on display through March 29 at the Queens Museum in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: MUSICAL:'BIRDIE' AFTER THE BYE BYE
description: MANY musicals save their best numbers until the very end, but ''Bring Back Birdie,'' at the Martin Beck, is the first musical I've seen that saves its best number until after the very end. It isn't until this show is officially over, until the curtain calls are under way, that its stars finally glide about to a tune that the audience really wants to hear. Though the song, ''Rosie,'' isn't listed in the Playbill, no introductions are necessary. This number was the looselimbed, moonlit finale of ''Bye Bye Birdie,'' which played the Beck 21 years ago. And it's a song that still sends you out of the theater humming.

title: FIRST STRIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: The Importance of Being Walter A blizzard of bouquets already threatens to smother Walter Cronkite, but there is one more point worth exploring. Tonight's final ''That's the way it is'' on the CBS Evening News is a Media Event.

title: Broadway; Moony Shapiro's life and times in song to hit boards May 4.
description: ''THE MOONY SHAPIRO SONGBOOK,'' produced by Stuart Ostrow in association with T.A.T. Communications, will open on Broadway on May 4. ''Moony Shapiro,'' depending on how you look at it, is either an Anglo-American, or an American-Anglo, musical, while Mr. Ostrow is the man who produced, among other musicals, ''1776'' and ''Pippin.'' T.A.T., meanwhile, is an acronym for a pleasantly vulgar Yiddish expression, and it is also the corporate name for the television and movie activities of Norman Lear and Jerry Perenchio. T.A.T. has never been involved in a Broadway production before.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The senseless and brutal murders of these children is deeply and painfully etched in the consciousness of our people.

title: Military Budget Includes Chemical-Weapon Fund
description: The military budget proposed by the Reagan Administration contains $20 million to build a plant that could resume production of chemical weapons, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Nigeria Farm Plan Gets U.S. Support
description: The Reagan Administration has given full support to an agricultural development plan for Nigeria, set up last year by the Carter Administration, that is based on cooperation between United States agribusiness corporations and private Nigerian farmers.

title: GOSSAMER VISITOR PAYS CALL AT A CITY MUSEUM
description: As the Gossamer Albatross, the delicate creation for his last aeronautical triumph, went on display at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday, Paul B. MacCready spoke of the next goal he has set for himself - the flight of a sun-powered airplane from Paris to London in June.

title: Mobil Oil Canada Has Offshore Hint
description: Mobil Oil Canada Ltd. said that a newly drilled well, 23 miles southeast of the promising Hibernia field off the coast of Newfoundland, may contain oil or natural gas.

title: MISS STREISAND IN 'ALL NIGHT LONG'
description: AS a general rule, it's not a good idea for a movie critic to have too much supposedly inside information about what went on during the production of a film he's going to review. If he isn't careful, the critic then tends not to review what's on the screen but to see things that aren't there or to respond to grand intentions that may or may not have ever existed. That is, it's emphasized, a general rule. However, in the case of ''All Night Long,'' a new comedy in which Barbra Streisand receives second billing to Gene Hackman, I'm not at all sure the reviewer can make any sense of it without some knowledge of what happened while the film was being made.

title: OBJECTIONS OF MEDIA STALL PRIVACY CODE
description: A three-year effort to legislate stronger state protection of individual privacy rights has been stalled by objections by press groups that contend that a proposed code would increase the power of local government officials to conceal documents.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; VILLAGE MEMORIAL CONCERT
description: Elaine Comparone, the harpsichordist, and other performers will inaugurate a series of concerts tonight at 8 at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich Village, 371 Avenue of the Americas, in honor of Vernon Kroening, the 32-year-old music director of the church who was killed last November by a man who shot into a crowd of people on West Street. The program includes works by Bach, Handel, Telemann and Mozart. Proceeds are earmarked for the purchase of a concert grand piano for the use of artists performing at St. Joseph's, a project begun by Mr. Kroening shortly before his death.Tickets are $7 ($4 for students and the elderly). Information: 741-1274. A GARDEN OF FACES ON 57TH ST.

title: King of Morocco Visits Paris
description: King Hassan II of Morocco arrived in Paris today on a 48-hour private visit to France. French and Moroccan officials said he would have dinner talks with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing

title: IN WASHINGTON, A NEW SUPPER CLUB RECALLS THE PAST
description: Everyone, it seems, harbors a secret yen to own a restaurant. For Ron Nessen, press secretary to President Gerald R. Ford, it was a chance to fulfill ''a Walter Mitty dream to have a bar of my own where I could sit around at night with my friends.'' For Robert Martin, a native New Yorker, it meant a chance to create a supper club that would recall the Blue Angel and the Cotton Club of his youth. For Bess and Tyler Abell - she was staff director for Joan Mondale and he is a former Chief of Protocol at the State Department - it was a way to entice Charlie Byrd back to Washington.

title: EX-HEAD OF CONSUMER AGENCY SEES BUDGET CUTS AS THREAT TO ITS POWER
description: Susan B. King, former chairman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, testified today that the agency's ability to function would be severely curtailed by budget cuts proposed by President Reagan.

title: ACCORD ON M.T.A. PLAN SET BY CAREY, KOCH AND OTHERS
description: Governor Carey, Mayor Koch, Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink and Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, reached virtual agreement today on the details of a plan to pump $5 billion of improvements into the M.T.A. system over the next five years.

title: SOCAL FAILS TO WIN SUPPORT FROM AMAX FOR $3.8 BILLION BID
description: The Standard Oil Company of California, the nation's fourth-largest oil company, failed yesterday to win the support of the directors of Amax Inc. for what would be the largest corporate merger in United States history. California Standard is seeking to widen its stake in the natural resources company to 100 percent from 20 percent.

title: Albert Frank Gets Two New Bosses
description: One of the oldest ad agencies on the scene, Albert Frank/FCB, has just gotten itself two top managers from the outside. Stephen J. Witt, a 46-year-old executive vice president at McCann-Erickson, will be chairman and chief operating officer, while Michael A. Taylor, 43, and a senior vice president at Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, the brokerage firm, will be president and chief executive.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Hijackers of Pakistani Jet Issue New Warning in Kabul

title: Bridge: French World Titleholders Favored in European Play
description: The young French players who won the 1980 world team championship are favored to win the 1981 European championships scheduled in Birmingham, England, in July. If they win there, they will have the opportunity to play in Rye, N.Y., this October in the Bermuda Bowl event for the world title, and they are quite capable of winning three in a row.

title: U.S. AGENCIES HELD LAGGING ON 25 BILLION OVERDUE DEBT
description: The Government is owed more than $25 billion in delinquent loans, unpaid taxes and other overdue debts, and Federal agencies have not performed well in collecting the money, according to a report by the Office of Management and Budget.

title: DAIMLER-BENZ SET TO BUY U.S. TRUCK-MAKING UNIT
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. of West Germany, manufacturer of Mercedes Benz cars and trucks, has reached tentative agreement to buy the truckmaking operations of Consolidated Freightways of San Francisco for at least $225 million in cash, the two companies said yesterday.

title: Exxon Announces Colombian Project
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that an affiliate, the International Colombia Resources Corporation, and the Colombian Government-owned coal company, Carbones de Colombia S.A., had awarded a $1.7 billion contract to the Morrison-Knudsen Company for development of a coal-mining project in Colombia.

title: SALVADORAN SAYS FEAR OF DEATH PUSHED HIM ON HARD TREK NORTH
description: The whispers began to float through the Salvadoran village of Atiquizaya in the weeks before Christmas, but Tulio Mendoza Figueroa paid them no heed. Mr. Mendoza, an elementary school principal, had heard the whispers before - this man or that one had been ''marked'' for death by one of the rightist paramilitary ''terror squads'' that hunt the towns and villages of El Salvador for those it believes sympathetic to the leftist guerrillas.

title: Conservative Group Plans Attack On Foes of the Reagan Program
description: The American Conservative Union said today that it would spend a ''considerable amount'' on a major advertising campaign against members of Congress who oppose President Reagan's economic program.

title: 2 Held by Florida Police In Deaths of 5 Near Glades
description: Two men were arrested today in connection with the deaths of five persons found Sunday in a blazing automobile on the edge of the Everglades, the police said.

title: Sam Waterston Immortalized in Sardi's 'Gallery'
description: He made his first stage appearance at the age of 6, had his first Broadway role (''Oh Dad, Poor Dad'') in 1963, a year after his graduation from Yale, and now, 18 years later, Sam Waterston, has finally made it to the top. His caricature has been added to the more than 1,000 others on display at Sardi's.

title: DANCE:SARA SUGIHARA
description: SARA SUGIHARA calls her dance company fresh dance with the fresh part seeming quite apt for a premiere she presented Wednesday night at Riverside Church.

title: NATHAN S. SCHWARTZ
description: Nathan S. Schwartz, a printer and former typographical union chairman at The New York Times, died last Friday at the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst in Queens after a brief illness. Mr. Schwartz, who was a resident of Woodside, Queens, was 84 years old.

title: Assets Rise Again At Money Funds
description: The total assets of the nation's money market funds increased sharply again in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: MISS COMENECI, 19, MAKES FRESH START
description: Suddenly the music stopped. Nadia Comaneci turned, her body frozen still as a park statue, arms extended, balletic toe dipped, and looked over her shoulder to see what was the matter.

title: Frank Maguire, Ulster M.P., Dies; Helped Defeat Callaghan in 1979
description: Frank Maguire, a Northern Ireland Member of Parliament who helped bring down James Callaghan's Labor Government in 1979, died in a hospital here today after a heart attack, a hospital spokesman said.

title: POLES INTERROGATE A LEADING DISSIDENT
description: Jacek Kuron, Poland's best-known dissident and an adviser to the independent trade union organization, was detained by the police for seven hours today and informed that he was under investigation on charges of having slandered the Polish state, according to Mr. Kuron's family.

title: TARRYTOWN,WATCH OUT!
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Injured in Fire
description: Five unidentified men suffered smoke inhalation and burns yesterday when a fire of suspicious origin engulfed a three-story brownstone in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, fire officials said.

title: Key Rates
description: Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The U.N. Today; March 6, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets on Namibia at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PANEL TOLD OF LAG IN A-PLANT INSPECTIONS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's chief safety official told a Congressional subcommittee today that only 30 percent of the expected amount of routine inspection work was being completed at the Indian Point nuclear plant before the flooding last year that led to its shutdown.

title: Dr. Paul F. Kerr, 84; Mineralogist Who Aided in Manhattan Project
description: Dr. Paul F. Kerr, a former Newberry Professor of Mineralogy at Columbia University who specialized in studies of uranium deposits for the Manhattan Project, died last Friday at Stanford University Hospital in California after a heart attack. He was 84 years old.

title: Georgia Democrats Recoup on a Slight to Carter
description: Last December, when Democratic Party leaders in his home state of Georgia announced plans for a fund-raising dinner, to be held March 13, they said that Jimmy Carter, then in his lame-duck days as President, would not be asked to be keynote speaker.

title: 3 in Cabinet Vow Drive; On Union Corruption
description: Three members of the Cabinet are promising an aggressive campaign against alleged union corruption in an apparent effort to blunt charges that protection of worker pension funds has been only half-hearted in recent years.

title: Market Place; U.A. Theatre And Cable Deal
description: MAYBE United Artists Theatre Circuit Inc., owner of 28 percent of UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc., holds the key to the success of the plan of Dow Jones & Company and Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. to acquire the cable company for $247.5 million.

title: The Economy
description: The U.S. is considering measures to help savings and loan associations if an industry crisis arises, although the thrift institutions are not now in ''serious danger,'' Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said. Regulators are concerned about the movement of deposits into money market mutual funds. (Page D1.)

title: Rudy May Predicts A Fantastic Season
description: At $1 million for three years, Rudy May has been one of the best bargains in the five-year history of free agency. In the first year of that contract last season, he pitched 15 victories, lost only five times and compiled a leagueleading 2.47 earned run average.

title: New Harvester Blades
description: The International Harvester Company said today that it had produced stronger and longer-lasting disk harrow blades than any previously offered - a breakthrough in farmimplement metallurgy. Disk blades made of the new formula, which was nine years in development, will last up to 20 percent longer and are up to 30 percent stronger than previous products, the company said. Total United States and Canadian markets for disk harrows and replacement disk blades amount to more than $200 million annually.

title: TRAINING PLANNED FOR ROBBERY UNIT
description: Two years ago, there was a simulated bank on the grounds of the New York City Police Department's outdoor shooting range in the Pelham Bay section of the Bronx that was held up once or twice each day while scores of officers looked on and did nothing.

title: 1 KILLED, 12 INJURED AS TRUCK HITS BUS CARRYING JURORS
description: A disabled Transit Authority bus carrying sequestered jurors from a motel on Staten Island to State Supreme Court in Manhattan was struck by a tractor-trailer on the Staten Island Expressway in heavy snow yesterday morning, killing one juror and injuring 12 other persons.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE ETRUSCANS. By Michael Grant. Il- lustrated. 317 pages. Scribners. $17.50.

title: KIEV WOMAN RISES IN PARTY JOB, BUT NOT TO THE TOP
description: ''Our task is to make politics available to every working woman,'' Lenin wrote in 1919, confident that the Bolshevik Revolution would usher in an era of full political participation for both sexes. The Bolsheviks, he said, would build a society in which every cook could learn to administer the state.

title: Auto Racing War Ends
description: The Formula One auto racing war is over, and the United States West Grand Prix, the first race of the 1981 world championships, will take place as scheduled at Long Beach, Calif., a week from Sunday. After a year-long struggle, representatives of the International Auto Racing Federation, the Formula One Constructors Association and constructors loyal to the governing body today signed an agreement designed to establish ''for a long time in the future a solid basis of stability of progress'' for the sport.

title: Advertising
description: RUSS, the division of Russ Togs that is in women's sportswear, is going to bypass the trade and take its promotion directly to the consumer via television.

title: SMITH ORDERS STUDY ON VIOLENT CRIMES
description: Asserting that violent crime had increased 59 percent in the last decade, Attorney General William French Smith appointed an advisory committee today to tell him what the Federal Government should do about it.

title: DEVIL A LA DISNEY
description: WHY is it that stories about people who makes deals with Satan remain so popular even though, with two or three exceptions, the works themselves aren't very interesting? Possibly it's because, life being what it is, most of us suspect that we'd sell out in a minute. The humiliation is that no one (or should that be No One?) has ever come by with an offer, even on bad days when we'd sign anything in return for a toaster, a vacuum cleaner or a set of dishes of the sort that seem to have become the principal business of many American savings institutions.

title: A WARNING IS ISSUED
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was concerned over signs that the Soviet Union and some of its allies were about to begin military maneuvers in and around Poland, reviving the possibility of an armed intervention in that country.

title: MILESTONES ON NEW YORK CITY'S ROAD TO FISCAL HEALTH
description: To the Editor:

title: Quebec Rejects Asbestos Plea
description: The Quebec Court of Appeal today rejected an appeal by the Asbestos Corporation Ltd. of a lower court judgment upholding the Quebec government's right to expropriate the United States-controlled company's assets in the province.

title: ACCOUNTING FOR ELMER STAATS
description: The last official message of Elmer Staats, who this week completes a 15-year term as Comptroller General of the United States, was both fitting and substantial. In a report issued this week, he said that as much as $4 billion could be saved by 1985 in 15 areas of Defense Department operations. During Mr. Staats's tenure as head of the General Accounting Office, the agency has made many such suggestions. This one, too, deserves Congressional attention.

title: AID STUDIED FOR SAVINGS INDUSTRY
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that, while savings and loan associations were not now in ''serious danger,'' the Government was considering standby measures to help the industry if a financial crisis arose.

title: by Miles L.Wortman
description: Popular assumptions underlying the policy debate over Central America are misleading. They reflect more the ideological biases of our domestic politics than the reality of the problems.

title: Pop Jazz; BLUEGRASS BROTHERS AT BEACON
description: BLUEGRASS music, with its commercialized offshoots, is a thriving American subculture, not just in the South, where it originated, but in the New York area as well. In the coming months, more than a dozen bluegrass events are scheduled locally, including a series at New York University and the annual festival at the South Street Seaport in the summer. Tomorrow, two of the most popular bluegrass acts, the Osborne Brothers and Jim and Jesse, will appear at the Beacon Theater's Grand Ole Opry Bluegrass Festival. Both are brothers acts who have been Grand Ole Opry stars for the last 15 years. But their performance at the Beacon will mark their first appearance together in this city, as well as the first Osborne show in New York in six years.

title: Turkish Leader Appeals For Antiterror Measures
description: After the murders of two Turkish diplomats in Paris, Turkey's head of state, Gen. Kenan Evren, appealed today to all peace-loving nations to take stronger action against international terrorism.

title: A DREAMLIKE SOVIET 'OBLOMOV'
description: The Russian film version of Ivan Goncharov's 1859 novel, ''Oblomov,'' begins and ends with the sight of a child running rapturously in search of his mother, even though the book's bestknown image is that of a grown man who won't get out of bed. The shift is most appropriate, because Nikita Mikhalkov's film places its chief emphasis on the innocently dreamlike aspects of the story.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph in Business Day yes- terday, with the article on supply-side economics, was incorrectly identified as that of Jude Wanniski. The photo was of Paul Craig Roberts.

title: SITE FOR A SUMMIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrows Rout Hartford
description: Steve Zungul, the leading scorer in the Major Indoor Soccer League, scored five goals as the New York Arrows defeated the Hartford Hellions, 11-4, last night at Madison Square Garden. Zungul now has 101 goals this season.

title: Occidental Plans Venture With Italy
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent with Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, the Italian national energy corporation, to form an equally owned joint venture with a $1.10 billion capitalization.

title: CAREY PLANS TO NAME ASSISTANT COUNSEL NEW P.S.C. CHAIRMAN
description: Governor Carey plans to name Paul L. Gioia, his first assistant counsel, to be chairman of the State Public Service Commission, state officials said today. He is also expected to name Richard E. Schuler, a Cornell University professor, to be deputy chairman.

title: Video Corporation Chief
description: Alfred Markim, the 53-year-old president of the Video Corporation of America, has been named to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective June 30. He will succeed George K. Gould, 66, who will continue as chairman and serve as a consultant to the video casette duplicating and distributing company, which has long been strong in the industrial market.

title: 8 INCH SNOWFALL CANCELS FLIGHTS, DUSRUOTS TRAFFIC
description: A late winter storm dropped eight inches of snow on the New York metropolitan area yesterday, canceling some flights at all airports in the area, delaying trains, clogging traffic and causing generally hazardous driving conditions.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the News of Music column yesterday, a conductor who visited China recently was misidentified. His name is David Gilbert.

title: DANCES MADE FROM POEMS ON TWO STAGES
description: YOU can't, a choreographer once said, make ballets about stepmothers. But can you make a dance about a blue-eyed rose? Or ''love's skein upon the ground''? Can a curving arm or stabbing foot replicate the penetrating glance of a poem? Two choreographers will give it a try this weekend in dances set to 20th-century poetry. Ara Fitzgerald and the com-poser Wall Matthews will present collaborations inspired by two poem cycles by William Butler Yeats at the American Theater Laboratory tonight, tomorrow night and Sunday afternoon. And the Greenhouse Dance Ensemble will offer ''I Am Rose, and Other Songs,'' a new piece by Lillo Way, tomorrow and Sunday afternoons at the 92d Street Y.

title: TREASURY'S OUSTED CHRYSLER CRITIC
description: It's not easy to be a whistle-blower, and becoming one usually happens in stages, for a series of different reasons. At least that is the way it happened to Elaine Joan Mittleman, a 32-year-old Washington lawyer.

title: Union Offers to Help Carey Raise a Toxic Toast
description: Governor Carey thinks unionized state employees have exaggerated the dangers of a contaminated state office building in Binghamton, and on Wednesday, to dramatize the point, the Governor offered to go to the building and ''swallow an entire glass'' of the building's major contaminant - polychlorinated biphenyls, an oily liquid.

title: News Analysis
description: ''I want to let you all know that we have decided to preserve the Urban Development Action Grant function in the Presidential program,'' President Reagan told an audience of cheering mayors Monday at the convention of the National League of Cities.

title: Greek Lithographs Show
description: Fifty lithographs by 20 Greek artists of this century will be on display through March 20 at the Consulate General of Greece, 69 East 79th Street. Admission is free. Hours are Monday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Information: 751-8788.

title: Index; International
description: Soviet woman rises high in party but not all the way A2 Strauss is reborn as a Reaganite A3 Around the World A5 South Africa's ''coloreds'' unappeased by a better life A8 I.L.O. rebukes Soviet on treatment of free union organizers A10 Government/Politics Democrat girds for the budget fight with an eye on the data A12 Drive for constitutional convention flares again A16 Attorney General begins study of violent crime A16 Congressmen told of inspection lag at Indian Point plant B3 State Senate panel is backed on alcohol abuse measures B4 Opposition of media groups stalls action on privacy code B14 General Around the Nation A10 Salvadoran says fear drove him on hard trip to United States A10 Union group plans protest on Three Mile Island anniversary A10 Gunman surrenders after holding jetliner for 11 hours A10 The City B3 City police prepare training plans for new antirobbery unit B3 Opening arguments heard in counterfeit-cassettes trial B3 Juror killed as truck hits bus on Staten Island B4 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. All other parking regulations remain in effect. Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Theater: Broadway C2

title: ISLAMIC PEACE PLAN CALLS FOR IRAN-IRAQ TRUCE NEXT WEEK
description: A nine-member Islamic peace mission disclosed today that it had called on Iraq and Iran to declare a cease-fire in their war starting at midnight next Thursday to be followed a week later by the beginning of an Iraqi withdrawal from occupied Iranian territory.

title: CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT DRIVE ON BALANCED BUDGET PUSHED ANEW
description: The drive to call a constitutional convention to propose a constitutional amendment requiring the Federal budget to be balanced has started up again, and two State Legislatures narrowly failed to adopt the measure today.

title: Mets Loath to Rush Leary Into Big Time
description: Backstage at the New York Mets these days, the biggest argument is whether to make room on the pitching staff for a 22-year-old rookie with only one summer of professional baseball.

title: HEADY JOURNEY OF A DIRECTOR AND HIS 'SECAUCUS SEVEN'
description: For a movie that cost $60,000, ''The Return of the Secaucus Seven'' is traveling in heady company. Most $60,000 movies play at two film festivals, then end up on a 16-millimeter projector in their director's living room. ''The Return of the Secaucus Seven,'' about seven antiwar activists who spend a weekend together 10 years later, was the surprise hit of last spring's Los Angeles Filmex festival. The movie was also selected as one of the 10 best films of 1980 by The Boston Globe, The Los Angeles Times and Time magazine, and last week it was nominated by the Writers Guild as best comedy written directly for the screen.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Subway cars without proper lighting are becoming more the rule than the exception.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: The smallest, youngest and most blase guest at a dinner dance at the New York Statler Hotel last weekend was a 9-year-old third-grader named Pedro Soler, who is an old hand at such events. He was also the most enthusiastic of the overflow crowd of 440 at the first major social gathering sponsored by the New York chapter of the Coalition of Labor Union Women.

title: Tear Gas Ends Protest in India
description: Policemen used nightsticks and tear gas today to break up a protest by 2,000 students at Baroda, in Gujarat State, during a general strike protesting enrollment privileges for Hindu outcasts, the United News of India reported.

title: LEONARDO TREASURES FROM BRITAIN AT THE MET
description: There can be few banners as compelling as the one that now floats down the facade of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. ''Leonardo da Vinci: Nature Studies from the Royal Library at Windsor Castle,'' it says, and it is one that every museum director in the world would be proud to display. For it is a recurrent dream with every member of the profession that he or she will one day be allowed to borrow some Leonardo drawings from the royal library at Windsor Castle. Not all the Leonardo drawings, you understand: just a few of them.

title: U.S. Concerned by Threat To Shell Town in Lebanon
description: The State Department said today that it had confirmed reports that the leader of an independent army in Lebanon was threatening to shell the town of Sidon unless the Lebanese Government paid him $5 million in ransom.

title: It won't play in Peoria.
description: NO one could ever accuse Peoria, Ill., of being an avant-garde outpost. Last month, a proposed $100,000 work by the Minimalist sculptor Richard Serra for Peoria's new Civic Center was unanimously rejected by the Civic Center Authority, after weeks of public outcry, which brought more letters to The Peoria Journal Star than any other event within memory. The 40-foot-high sculpture - two slabs of Cor-Ten steel joined in a highly visible weld and set on a cracked base - was commissioned by the Junior League, which raised $50,000 toward its cost, matched by another $50,000 from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: MUSIC: DE WAART AND MISS DE LARROCHA
description: IN an effort to avoid the ordinary, many symphonic programs are enlivened - or distorted - by blockbuster oddities: works of such a rarity or novelty or grandiosity that they command instant attention. But the New York Philharmonic, in the first of four subscription concerts last night at Avery Fisher Hall, proved there is still room for the judiciously balanced, sensitively performed program that lacks such an attention-grabber.

title: Tsyganov, 24, Takes First Downhill for Soviet
description: The American leg of the World Cup skiing season began today as Valery Tsyganov became the first Soviet skier in history to capture a Cup downhill.

title: NOMINEES FOR AMERICAN BOOK AWARDS ANNOUNCED
description: Eighty hardcover and paperback books have been nominated for the second annual American Book Awards by representatives of the book community in 10 categories. The winners will be announced on April 30.

title: SETTING THE SCENE FOR SUBWAY CHAOS
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Reagan Facing Car-Trade Issue
description: ONE of the hottest issues facing the Reagan Administration is whether to impose import restraints against small, fuel-efficient Japanese cars. The major United States auto producers and the United Automobile Workers union, with the backing of Michigan political leaders, are pressing the Administration for such protection. But the Reagan Cabinet is split on the issue, and the President is still holding his cards close to his vest.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MARCH 6, 1981
description: International Fear of Soviet intervention in Poland was suggested by the Reagan Administration, which expressed concern over signs that the Warsaw Pact allies were about to begin their regular spring military maneuvers in and around Poland. A State Department spokesman reminded Moscow that any ''outside intervention, in whatever form, would have the gravest consequences.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Poland's top dissident was detained for seven hours by the police and told he was under investigation for allegedly slandering the state, his family said. The detention of Jacek Kurnon, who is an adviser to the independent union, prompted its leadership to call a national meeting tomorrow. (A3:6.)

title: LUTHER- A NIGHT OF MUSIC FOR, AGAINST AND BY
description: Music decrying Martin Luther will be included in a concert of work by, about and in honor of the Protestant Reformation leader Sunday night at 7:30 when Cappella Nova, the choral group that specializes in Renaissance sacred works, investigates the little-known repertory of ''The Great Revolt.''

title: EL SALVADOR NAMES AN ELECTION BOARD
description: The Salvadoran Government appointed a three-man electoral commission today as a first step toward promised elections for a constitutional assembly next year.

title: Lassoing the Sacred Dairy Cow
description: President Reagan and the public won a big economic battle when the Senate Agricultural Committee voted to suspend an automatic increase in dairy price supports next month. But this one success will not win the war to purge dairy subsidies from the Federal budget. Unless the House moves quickly, the Senate committee's brave stand against a heretofore invincible lobby will have been in vain.

title: HOW ART AND ARCHITECTURE LOOK AT THE 80'S
description: Imagine a bridge above Manhattan joining the World Trade Center and the Chrysler Building. Or a 22-foot-high glass waterworks construction on the traffic island in Times Square. Or two restaurant pavilions, with colored ceiling glass designed to look like seasonal foliage, in Bryant Park.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Denies 'Sellout' Plot on Ulster
description: In an unexpected visit to Northern Ireland, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today denied charges by Protestant militants that she had agreed secretly to the eventual union of the province with Ireland.

title: THE FEDERAL RESERVE'S INVITATION TO DISASTER
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 MORE MENINGITIS DEATHS ARE REPORTED IN NASSAU
description: Two Nassau County children have died of meningitis in the last 12 days, county health officials said today. Their deaths were announced only two days after it was reported that three teen-agers in the county had contracted meningitis and that one had died of the disease.

title: TV Coverage Today Of News Conference
description: President Reagan's news conference will be televised live at 2 P.M. today on the CBS, NBC and ABC networks, Channels 2, 4, and 7 in New York.

title: Power Memorial, Molloy Gain Catholic Semifinals
description: Power Memorial rallied to defeat St. Raymond's, 42-36, and Cardinal Hayes held off Archbishop Molloy, 41-39, last night at Fordham University to advance to the semifinals of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association playoffs.

title: News Analysis
description: This was a week when New York City passed yet another of what some have begun to call ''stations of the cross'' on the long road to fiscal credibility. For the first time in six years, Standard & Poor's gave the city's bonds an investment grade. This meant that, in the view of one of the leading rating agencies, New York was a fairly good risk for anyone with money to put into municipal securities. For a city that defaulted on its notes not too many years ago, it was an achievement of some consequence, and not surprisingly the Koch administration accepted the news as an endorsement of its stewardship of municipal finances.

title: Afghan and Cambodia Issues Cited by U.N. Rights Unit
description: The United Nations Human Rights Commission accused Vietnam today of occupying Cambodia and criticized the Soviet Union for its intervention in Afghanistan.

title: Balloonist Lands, Saying He Has Set a Record
description: A balloonist, Kris Anderson, landed in West Virginia today after a flight of nearly 600 miles from Minnesota and asserted that he had set a record for distance traveled in a hot-air balloon.

title: A NONPOLITICAL REGULATOR
description: Paul L. Gioia, the man Governor Carey nominated today to head the state's Public Service Commission, is a political person who has never registered in a political party.

title: MAN IS CONVICTED IN MURDER OF OFFICER DRAGGED BY A CAR
description: A 22-year-old Brooklyn man was convicted yesterday of murdering a police officer who was shot several times and then run over and dragged nearly half a mile beneath the speeding car of the fleeing killer.

title: DAIMLER: TACKLING U.S. TRUCK MARKET BY ACQUISITION
description: The agreement reached yesterday between West Germany's Daimler-Benz A.G. and Consolidated Freightways of San Francisco whereby the German company would take over the latter's Freightliner truck-making operation catapults Daimler-Benz into the forefront of efforts by Western European truck makers to establish a bridgehead in North America.

title: TWO THIEVES, 8 AND 14 YEARS OLD, HELD IN SAO PAULO AFTER A HOLDUP
description: An 8-year-old boy armed with a .22-caliber air pistol was arrested by the police in Sao Paulo last night after holding up a night watchman, a police spokesman said today.

title: KNICKS LOSE, 122-111
description: Several hours before last night's game, the Knicks learned that Marques Johnson, the Milwaukee Bucks' top scorer, was ill at the hotel and would not play.

title: Britain Foresees Less North Sea Oil
description: Britain has sharply lowered its forecast of 1981 North Sea oil production and has reduced its oil-output growth predictions for the next four years, Energy Secretary David Howell told the House of Commons today.

title: Study Links Toxic Shock Illness To Middle-Class White Families
description: Doctors investigating toxic shock syndrome say 99 percent of the victims studied were white and most of them were from middle-class families.

title: COAST SCHOOL POLICY UPHELD ON TEACHING OF EVOLUTION
description: The policy of the California Department of Education and Board of Education on science textbooks does not violate the rights of religious fundamentalists who object to the teaching of evolution, a Superior Court judge ruled today.

title: STATE SUPPORT FOR GRASS-ROOTS CANDIDATES
description: By Richard N. Gottfried, Vincent Marchiselli, John Flynn, Derick P. Berlage

title: Denison to Sell Stake In Scott to Brascan
description: Denison Mines Ltd. of Toronto said in a filing with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission that it had agreed to sell its 5.37 percent interest in the Scott Paper Company, amounting to 2,087,500 shares, to Brascan Ltd. for $29 (United States) a share.

title: MALE HORMONE TIED TO AGGRESSIVE ACTS
description: Children exposed before birth to drugs that mimic the action of male sex hormones are more likely than their nonexposed siblings to respond aggressively to hypothetical conflict situations, according to a study published yesterday in Science magazine.

title: Mission Impossible in Newark
description: This week, 35 of those well-tailored state police officers who like to pass out speeding tickets on the New Jersey Turnpike began patrolling the streets of Trenton. Their new mission is preventing violent crime; they are part of an anti-urban crime program drafted by former Attorney General Degnan and adopted by Governor Byrne. The plan calls for placing ''metro task forces'' of state police in Newark, Jersey City, Paterson, Camden and other cities. But so far only Trenton has cooperated with this worthy experiment. Some city leaders seem to feel as threatened by this use of troopers as by crime.

title: 6 Argentine Rights Activists Are Ordered Freed by Judge
description: Judge Martin Anzoatequi ordered the release today of six human rights advocates who were arrested last week on charges of violating national security laws.

title: INSTALLMENT DEBT ROSE IN JANUARY
description: The nation's consumers increased their installment debt for the sixth consecutive month in January, buying $869 million more on credit than they paid off, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Jimmy Carter to Receive Truman Award
description: The eighth recipient of the Harry S. Truman Public Service Award will be Jimmy Carter, it was announced yesterday by Mayor E. Lee Comer of Independence, Mo., Mr. Truman's hometown.

title: TO KEEP BURGLAR ALARMS HONEST
description: To the Editor:$

title: Reagan Friend Named to Post
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Charles Z. Wick, a longtime friend who was co-chairman of the 1981 Presidential Inaugural Committee, to be director of the International Communication Agency. The agency handles American public relations efforts overseas, including broadcasts, exhibits and libraries. It was previously known as the United States Information Agency.

title:
Patents;
Improving The Quality Of Cotton
description: WASHINGTON THE Department of Agriculture received three patents this week for inventions to improve the quality of cotton fibers and the textiles made from them. Devised by staff members in Louisiana and Mississippi, the inventions will help get rid of lint, add strength to the material and increase clothing's durable-press properties.

title: THREE VOLUNTEERS END SIMULATED DIVE TO RECORD DEPTH
description: Three volunteer divers who were subjected to simulated water pressure equal to that at 2,250 feet below sea level, a new record, emerged yesterday from 43 days in a pressure chamber at Duke University in Durham, N.C., apparently none the worse for their experience.

title: Amax Star Of Dull Day For Market
description: Takeover fever struck Wall Street yesterday with securities of Amax Inc. providing the big excitement in an otherwise dull market. Amax's common stock bounded ahead 19 3/4 points, to 58, following a rebuffed acquisition offer from the Standard Oil Company of California valued at nearly $4 billion.

title: E.Y. HARBURG, LYRICIST, KILLED IN CAR CRASH
description: E. Y. (Yip) Harburg, who wrote the lyrics for ''Over the Rainbow,'' ''April In Paris,'' ''Brother, Can You Spare a Dime'' and the musical ''Finian's Rainbow,'' died Thursday when the car he was driving swerved into oncoming traffic and collided head-on with another vehicle on Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles. He was 84 years old. The driver and a passenger in the other car suffered minor injuries.

title: An Angel Successfully Tries Out His Wings on a Musical
description: The owner of the Penn House Cleaners, at 339 Eighth Avenue, at 27th Street, is Murray Holtzer, who in 20 years has built up a loyal clientele. Yesterday, Mr. Holtzer, in an interview, talked happily about the good fortune that had come his way with the aid of one of his customers.

title: Putting Mayor Koch Through His Paces
description: Cincinnati-born Karin Baker has a show business job resume that lists credits such as ''dancer in 'George M' and 'Coco' on Broadway and member of the Carol Burnett television show dance troupe, choreographic assistant to Gower Champion on the musical '42nd Street' and choreographer for the Equity Library Theater production of 'Anything Goes,' opening March 12.''

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: City dwellers have different New Yorks, and many of us occasionally live for a while in a city that exists mostly in memory. But nostalgia's grip on William H. Miller, who is only 32 years old, is tenacious.

title: AMAX STOCK SOARS AS SALES RESUME
description: Stock in Amax Inc., trading for the first time since a $4 billion takeover bid from the Standard Oil Company of California caused a trading halt early Thursday, soared nearly $20 a share yesterday with more than $50 million worth changing hands.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17. 1. President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador had intended to visit West Germany. 2. Mayor Koch sang and danced for members of the Inner Circle, a group of New York City reporters, after they had presented a show, ''King Koch, or, Who'm I Doing?''

title: MISGUIDED ECONOMICS
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: 'PARIS SCIENCES'
description: Once upon a time - to be specific, on Thursday night - it was raining at the Kitchen. Actually, it was raining on two television screens that were part of Wendy Perron's ''The Paris Sciences,'' a 40-minute piece for five women and five television sets.

title: No Headline
description: Workmen trying to get back onto the tracks one of 12 railroad cars that derailed yesterday in Gibbstown, N.J.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Palace Clarifies Title Even so solid an institution as Buckingham Palace makes mistakes, and yesterday it conceded it had been wrong earlier this week in suggesting that Lady Diana Spencer could be known after her marriage as ''Princess Charles.''

title: HAWKS HAND NETS 7TH STRAIGHT LOSS
description: Dan Roundfield scored 24 points and Eddie Johnson 20 as the Hawks defeated the New Jersey Nets, 109-106, last night in Atlanta. The loss was the Nets' seventh in a row.

title: No Headline
description: Lieut. Gen. Roberto Viola, who has been designated by the Argentine armed forces to take over the presidency from Jorge Rafael Videla, another general, will be received by President Reagan during an unofficial visit here starting March 15, Argentine diplomatic sources said today.

title: Honda Recalling 300,000 Cars
description: The American Honda Motor Company is recalling 300,000 1980 Accords, Preludes and Civics to replace charcoal canisters in the emission control systems. A company spokesman said yesterday that the original canister can become unplugged, making it hard to restart the car once it is warm.

title: AMITY AT THE HARLEY
description: To the Editor:

title: Midshipman Is Convicted In Roommate's Auto Death
description: Midshipman Michael Olmstead was found guilty today of involuntary manslaughter in an automobile crash that killed his roommate.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday misstated the 1980 earnings for Amax Inc. The correct figure is $470.4 million.

title: WARDROBE TIPS
description: Tips on dressing for work: Clothes should be sober, but accessories can brighten the look.

title: 'VISIONS OF NEW YORK CITY' TO BE EXHIBITED IN TOKYO
description: "Visions of New York City," an exhibition of more than 100 paintings, prints and drawings by 49 artists closely identified with New York, will be sent to the Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum for a show from March 27 through May 24.

title: Kerr-McGee Suit Dropped
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation, a leading uranium producer, was dismissed today from a multimillion-dollar antitrust suit brought by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation following an out-of-court settlement.

title: YUGOSLAVIA PUNISHES A DISSIDENT HISTORIAN
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMUNIST PARTY SHATTERS FRATERNITE OF FRENCH LEFT
description: An imaginary line drawn from Montigny, a drab bedroom suburb to the north of Paris, to Vitry, an equally drab place to the south, would just about pass through Place Colonel Fabian. The French Communist Party headquarters is there, a spiffy glass building designed by Oscar Niemeyer in the days when the party and its intellectuals were on good terms.

title: AMID THE FUSS, CRONKITE SAYS A QUIET 'GOOD NIGHT'
description: Amid tributes, telegrams, yet another award and a healthy dose of pomp and hoopla, Walter Cronkite yesterday closed out his 18-year career as anchor of ''The CBS Evening News.''

title: DESIGN, GOOD AND BAD, IN FOOD
description: Although not generally considered as such, a recipe is a design - a plan for a procedure that results in a particular form. A bad dish, like a bad chair, may be the result of poor execution of the original design, or it may be due to a design that was inferior at the start.

title: REVLON ACQUIRES THOMPSON HEALTH-AID COMPANY
description: Revlon Inc., the nation's leading retail cosmetics company, which has been increasing its stake in the health-care field, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Thompson Medical Company, the largest seller of over-the-counter appetite suppressants.

title: ANGLO AMERICAN'S AMBITIONS
description: ''We want to expand in North America,'' says Harry Oppenheimer, chairman of the Anglo American Corporation and De Beers Consolidated Mines, the world's largest gold and diamond mining companies, which are based here.
