title: China Names Defense Chief And 11 Other High Aides
description: China announced the appointments of 12 high-ranking officials today, including the designation as Defense Minister of Deputy Prime Minister Geng Biao, an associate of Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader.

title: 95,00 DELAYED IN L.I.R.R. RUSH-HOUR BREAKDOWNS
description: Equipment breakdowns in yesterday morning's rush hour delayed nearly all 95,000 of the Long Island Rail Road's commuters, including 2,000 who were stranded under the East River for three hours after a train stopped in a tunnel.

title: Charles DeWolf Gibson, , 85, Dies; Businessman Active in Charities
description: Charles DeWolf Gibson, retired vice president of the Air Reduction Company and active in philanthropic work in New York City, died Wednesday at his home in Wakefield, R.I. He was 85 years old.

title: THE 'JELLYBEAN' NEWS CONFERENCE
description: The Administration's attempt to lend decorum to Presidential news conferences by choosing questioners by lot from President Reagan's jellybean jar was rued as an experiment in tepidness today.

title: 76ers 131, Nuggets 112
description: Julius Erving scored 26 points for Philadelphia, which took a one-game lead over the Boston Celtics in the Atlantic Division.

title: SWISS TAKES GOLD, MISS ZAYAK SECOND
description: Fifteen-year-old Elaine Zayak of Paramus, N.J., perhaps the most athletic female figure skater ever, reached for the gold medal tonight and almost got it. Instead, she settled for second place and the silver medal in the women's singles of the world figure skating championships.

title: SAVINGS GROUP SETS AID PLAN
description: An organization representing practically all the savings and loan associations in the country expects to announce next week a plan to infuse fresh capital from a Government-managed insurance fund into associations whose profits and net worth have been squeezed by high interest rates.

title: U.S. DECIDES TO SELL EQUIPMENT TO SAUDIS TO BOLSTER F-15 JETS
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it had decided to sell additional military equipment to Saudi Arabia as part of a policy of halting a ''serious deterioration'' in Western security interests in the Middle East and Persian Gulf.

title: Asbestos Ruling To Be Appealed
description: The Asbestos Corporation. Ltd. of Montreal, a unit of the General Dynamics Corporation of St. Louis, said it would appeal to the Supreme Court of Canada a lower court decision that upheld the right of the province of Quebec to expropriate the company's assets.

title: Price Cut Cited On Kuwait Oil
description: Weak oil demand has prompted Kuwait, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, to cut its sales price by $1.50 a barrel on substantial quantities of oil exported to South Korea and Taiwan, industry sources said yesterday.

title: All-American Moves Career Close to Home
description: Before each basketball game, Kris Kirchner stuffs three pieces of bubble gum into her mouth. Next, she makes sure that a bouquet of flowers is given to her mother, who often travels to watch her play. Then, after making sure her two younger brothers have seats on the Rutgers bench, she begins to limber up her 6-foot-4-inch frame.

title: German Hotel Lease
description: Canadian Pacific Hotels Ltd., a unit of Canadian Pacific Enterprises, said it would lease and operate a 240-room hotel to be built in Bremen, West Germany. The company said the hotel is scheduled to be open in September 1983, but would not disclose further details.

title: FOOD MACHINE RIVALRY FLARES
description: Two former allies in the food processor industry, Robot-Coupe S.A., and Cuisinarts Inc., have locked blades in the news media and in the courtroom over the use of the Cuisinart trademark in a struggle to dominate the high-priced end of the $204-million-a-year food processor market.

title: A HEY NONNY GEORGE
description: Every time the teams go south for spring training I think back to the year George Steinbrenner bought Sweet Will Shakespeare from the Globe Theater Cats. In those days, of course, we didn't go down to Florida or Arizona. Our idea of fun in the sun was Lyme Regis.

title: TWO KILL A JERSEY MAN WHO GAVE TESTIMONY ON MOBSTER ACTIVITIES
description: George A. Franconero, who had twice given law enforcement officials information concerning alleged organized-crime activities, was shot to death this morning outside his home in a fashionable section of nearby North Caldwell, the police said.

title: Inspector General Leaving Fire Dept.
description: Paul Kotch, the inspector general of the Fire Department for nearly three years, has submitted his resignation, effective May 1. Mr. Kotch, who is 34 years old, said he had several offers in the insurance industry.

title: The Economy
description: Producer prices rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Labor Department reported, propelled by continuing large increases in energy prices. Overall, goods ready for shipment to retailers were priced 10.4 percent higher than a year earlier. Analysts said the higher energy costs reflected OPEC action in December and January and the decontrol ordered by former President Carter. The effects of President Reagan's further decontrol in late January will be reflected in the finished goods index next month, they said. (1.)

title: BRIEFS
description: * Crane Company extended until March 13 its offer to purchase up to 1.6 million shares of Harsco Corporation and said that about 47,000 Harsco shares had already been tendered. Elscint Ltd., an Israeli manufacturer of high-technology, medical diagnostic imaging systems, said it would open a plant in Brookline, Mass.

title: SMITH ISSUES RULES FOR NAMING JUDGES
description: The Reagan Administration will apparently place less emphasis on appointing women and blacks to Federal district judgeships than the Carter Administration did but will retain, with some modifications, the use of senatorial patronage in choosing those judges, under procedures announced today by Attorney General William French Smith.

title: WATER FINES AT $9.2 MILLION BUT COLLECTIONS ARE LAGGING
description: The total of fines for violating water rationing in northern New Jersey has climbed to at least $9.2 million, according to a survey of major water companies.

title: Coldwell Proposal
description: Coldwell, Banker & Company announced it had made a proposal to acquire the First Newport Corporation, a real estate management company with headquarters in Newport Beach, Calif., for about $21 million in cash and stock. Coldwell, a nationwide real estate and real estaterelated service company based in Los Angeles, said directors of First Newport were considering the offer. In the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, 1980, First Newport had a net profit of $5.6 million, including an extraordinary gain of $4.2 million.

title: REAGAN SAYS BAN ON ABORTION MAY NOT BE NEEDED
description: President Reagan, who in his election campaign strongly supported a constitutional amendment prohibiting abortions, said today that such an amendment would not be necessary if Congress determined that a fetus was a human being because then its life would already be protected.

title: Reichmann Family Gets Abitibi
description: The Reichmann family, through its privately owned Olympia and York Company, was confirmed today as the victor in the takeover battle for Abitibi-Price Inc., the Toronto-based company that is the world's largest newsprint producer. They immediately extended the olive branch to the losing Thomson family by asking Thomson's representatives to remain on the Abitibi board.

title: PARACHUTE EXPERT
description: Stanley Switlik, a New Jersey conservationist also known for his work in perfecting the parachute, died Wednesday of an apparent heart attack at Fisherman's Hospital in Marathon, Fla. He was 90 years old.

title: York Times/Dith Pran
description: TRAMWAY SERVICE RESUMES BETWEEN ROOSEVELT ISLAND AND MANHATTAN Tramway car approaching Manhattan from Roosevelt Island across East River. Service was halted four months ago for mainte-nance and one of its cables broke while repairs were under way. Until yesterday, residents of Roosevelt Island had to take bus to Queens in order to travel to Manhattan.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times on Wednesday about Meharry Medical College incorrectly identified the financial institution with which John F. McGillicuddy is affliated. He is chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: BERNARD POSTAL, ASSOCIATE EDITOR OF THE JEWISH WEEK AND A WRITER
description: Bernard Postal, associate editor of The Jewish Week and co-author of 10 books, died of a heart attack Thursday near his home in Oceanside, L.I. He was 75 years old.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 47. 1. A head of state canceled a trip, apparently out of fear of a right-wing coup. Who is he, and what country had he intended to visit?

title: PACERS 110, CELTICS 104
description: Billy Knight scored 32 points and Indiana came back from a 5-point fourth-quarter deficit to beat Boston.

title: PLASTIC PLANT EXPLOSION
description: The B F Goodrich Company said today that it would expand by 30 percent its output of a specialty plastic at its Avon Lake, Ohio, plant by early next year.

title: YANKEES SEEK ACE IN PACK OF HOPEFULS
description: All winter the Yankees talked about their quest for an established right-handed starting pitcher. ''I thought we were going to be able to make a trade,'' Manager Gene Michael said today. ''At the winter meetings I thought we had some things going.''

title: UNC Begins Talks To Acquire N.C.C.
description: UNC Resources, which has outstanding an offer to acquire Western Airlines, said it had begun preliminary talks on the possible acquisition of N.C.C. Energy Ltd., a London-based energy and minerals company.

title: LAW ON YOUTH SEX STIRS FUROR ON COAST
description: The Rev. W.B. Timberlake, a Southern Baptist preacher who is executive director of the Committee on Moral Concerns, has the State Legislature in confusion with his efforts to block repeal a 28-year-old statute requiring health professionals to report evidence of sexual activity by women under 18 years old.

title: DE MORTUIS NIL NISI BUNKUM
description: On March 5, 1953, Joseph Stalin died and the Zentral-grundschule Gross-Glienicke closed for a week. All the children ran out of school screaming with glee. But even a second-grader like Stefan, even the dimwitted Baer brothers couldn't help noticing, that day or at the latest the next, that if there was cause for satisfaction in the great man's death, it was in bad taste to flaunt one's pleasure. Wherever you went, gloom and depression prevailed, even when the radio with its stream of tragic music and mournful communiques was turned off. You felt guilty cruising the lake in a canoe with too obvious relish, or taking a spin on your bike, just for the fun of it, heading nowhere in particular. We played soccer after a while - no one was telling us not to - but kept our voices below their usual frenzied pitch, out of respect for our mourning elders. Both my parents seemed genuinely sad. Alma, looking at Stalin's portrait hanging over the piano in the living room, remarked, as she had at previous times but with more feeling, what a remarkably human, kind, and wise face the man had; and I, looking at his enigmatically twinkling eyes, dimpled chin, and picturesque mustache, and hearing how lovingly she spoke of him, and how grandly Mozart's Requiem commended his soul to the highest heaven, I was deeply moved, and felt privileged to be able to join, if only for a moment and to a feeble, juvenile degree, in ''the world's deep sorrow and gratitude.''

title: C.A.B., Court Deny Bar to Texas Air Bid
description: Both the Civil Aeronautics Board and a Federal court judge in Los Angeles turned down requests by Continental Air Lines for orders staying Texas International Airlines from purchasing all Continental shares it has received in its tender offer.

title: NASSAU AIDES DENYING EPIDEMIC LIST FOUR NEW CASES OF MENINGITIS
description: The number of reported cases of meningitis in Nassau County since the start of the year rose to 14 today as health officials announced four new ones. Officials insisted, however, that the cases were unrelated and that there were no signs of an epidemic.

title: BALANCED U.S. GROWTH
description: The report of the President's Commission for a National Agenda for the 80's recently urged the United States to adopt a policy that not only accepts but actually encourages the current population shift from the Northeast, the Midwest, and the Appalachian states to the Sun Belt. This recommendation, if translated into policy, has the potential of hurting everyone, while helping no one.

title: DOWNHILL TITLE TO WEIRATHER
description: In a dramatic confrontation, Harti Weirather of Austria outdueled the Canadian Steve Podborski and won the World Cup downhill season title today.

title: Court Upholds Air Permit For Virginia Oil Refinery
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld a Federal air quality permit for a proposed $1 billion oil refinery in Portsmouth, Va.

title: CONSERVATIVES' OMINOUS DECISION NOT TO CONSERVE
description: To the Editor:

title: IT'S A GREAT DAY FOR IRISH WHISKY
description: One of the best kept secrets about Irish whisky in this country is that it tastes good. Despite its reputation for being coarse and heavy, it is possibly the most delicate and gentle of all whiskies. It is lighter-tasting than bourbon and most American blended whiskies and subtler than Scotch.

title: Ex-Town Judge Gets 3-Year Term in Theft
description: A former town justice and lawyer from Pound Ridge was sentenced to three years following his guilty plea in December to a charge of grand larceny.

title: THE SAVAGING OF AMERICAN SOCIETY
description: To the Editor:

title: TO KEEP BURGLAR ALARMS HONEST
description: To the Editor:

title: DRESSING FOR THE INTERVIEW--THEN THE JOB
description: To ease the culture shock of moving from the casual mode of campus dressing to the greater formality of the business world, Mary Fiodorek, the owner of Streets & Company, has developed a concept she calls ''the interview suit.'' This is a low-keyed, classic design a woman can wear with confidence on her first forays into the business and professional world. Later, when she has secured her job, she can be more expressive, but it is wise for a woman to look as conservative as she can for the initial job interview, Mrs. Fiodorek believes.

title: LADY OF THE SEAS IS RETIRED
description: After covering more miles during her 27-year career in the interest of science than any other vessel in history and making an extraordinary variety of discoveries, the Vema came home yesterday for the last time as a Columbia University research vessel.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I hope that the public would understand this - that one of the things that must be realized is we're not promising any instant cure. We don't believe that in the matter of several months, or probably even in the first year, we're going to see more than beginning signs of recovery.'' - President Reagan. (10:2.)

title: China Cancels Steel Mill Pact
description: Three Japanese companies have received formal notices from China canceling orders for plants and equipment for use in construction of a giant steel mill near Shanghai, officials said today.

title: BULLETS 105, ROCKETS 104
description: Mitch Kupchak made four free throws late in the fourth quarter to thwart a comeback by Houston.

title: U.S. ABSTAINS IN GENERAL ASSEMBLY IN VOTE ON SOUTH AFRICA SANCTIONS
description: The United States joined four other Western powers pressing for independence in South-West Africa in abstaining today as the General Assembly voted for trade sanctions against South Africa.

title: THROUGH THE EYES OF GEORGE KALINSKY
description: Every time the gates open at Madison Square Garden, George Kalinsky has the best vantage point in the house. He is the Garden's photographer, which means he can go where he wants and click away.

title: County Head Fined In Insurance Scheme
description: The Onondaga County Executive, John H. Mulroy, was fined $5,000 in State Supreme Court here for his participation in a 17-year insurance fee-splitting scheme that benefited the local Republican Party and Mr. Mulroy's own re-election efforts.

title: DIALYSIS FOR SCHIZOPHRENIA? DOCTORS DEBATE EFFECTS
description: The possibility that schizophrenia might be caused by a mysterious substance in the blood, and cured by removing it with the hemodialysis technique used in kidney disease, is sustaining a continuing scientific debate about the merits of this costly, dangerous therapy in treating mental illness.

title: Buffalo Forge Bows To Ampco Takeover
description: The Buffalo Forge Company, ending nine weeks of sometimes bitter opposition to takeover attempts by the Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation, said today that it had decided to merge with the machinery and rail-car manufacturer in an $80.25 million transaction.

title: SYRACUSE, VILLANOVA GAIN FINAL
description: Syracuse could not be happier with the location of the Big East Conference basketball playoff - the enclosed Carrier Dome, its home court, where the fans scream all game long for the Orange.

title: Marisabel V. Schumacher
description: In the Gulf of Fonseca, a Salvadoran patrol launch halts a fishing boat to search for arms.

title: PLAN TO SELL RIKERS LAND REVIVED BY MAYOR KOCH
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced that the city had proposed to sell land and two jail facilities on Rikers Island to the state. He said the city would use the money from the sale - from $160 million to $200 million - to help finance the building of three new city jails in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn, and the renovation of a state office building in lower Manhattan for use as a city jail.

title: Derailment Isolates Part of Jersey Town
description: Twelve derailed freight cars, seven of which contained hazardous materials, blocked 100 residents from leaving a section of this Gloucester County community for about two hours early yesterday, the police said.

title: Spaniard Says Government Will Rule Until 1983 Vote
description: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo, holding his first news conference since forming his Cabinet last week, said today that his Government would stay in power until the next general election in 1983.

title: Latin Hydroelectric Loan
description: The jointly owned Brazilian-Paraguayan hydroelectric project, Itaipu Binacional, will have to borrow another $210 million abroad this calendar year to meet its financing needs, the consortium's director general, Jose Costa Cavalcanti, said today. Foreign borrowing needs in 1981 total around $450 million, of which $180 million came from a recent $266 million syndicated Euroloan and a further $60 million from an external financing from the Banco do Brasil, he said.

title: Term of Up to 4 Years Is Imposed in Slashing
description: A Brooklyn man who was convicted in December of slashing the throat of a decoy police officer in Times Square nearly two years ago was sentenced to a maximum of four years yesterday.

title: Hooker Safety Issues Going to Arbitration
description: The Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corporation and the United Glass and Ceramics Workers agreed to submit to an arbitrator safety issues that led to a walkout by the employees on Feb. 23.

title: WEINBERGER OUTLINES $1.7 BILLION IN CUTS IN '81-82 MILITARY OUTLAYS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger disclosed today how his budget cutters had shaved $1.7 billion from the original military budgets for the fiscal years 1981 and 1982 by eliminating a few projects and delaying others.

title: 8 STATES URGE TALKS WITH JAPAN ON AUTOS
description: President Reagan met today with the governors of eight states heavily involved in the automobile industry and was urged to negotiate voluntary restrictions with Japan on auto imports to help restore the American industry to health.

title: U.S. AIDES CHALLENGE EL SALVADOR REPORT
description: State Department officials today described as ''spurious'' and ''unofficial'' a 29-page paper on El Salvador cited in The New York Times as a dissent paper that was prepared by officials from the National Security Council, the State and Defense Departments and the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Ford Borrows Again From Foreign Units
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would use $1.2 billion borrowed from its British and German subsidiaries to pay off bank loans, to meet cash needs of its money-losing North American operations and to support expensive development plans.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 1981
description: International Increased American military aid to El Salvador was defended by President Reagan on the ground that the United States was ''helping the forces that are supporting human rights in El Salvador'' against left-wing ''terrorists.'' He said that the United States would view with ''the gravest concern'' any right-wing attempt to overthrow the Government. He also said that the guerrillas fighting the Government were the principal human rights violators in El Salvador. (Page 1, Cols. 2-5.) A 29-page policy paper on El Salvador discussed in a foreign affairs column in The New York Times yesterday was called ''spurious'' and ''unofficial'' by the State Department. The paper, reportedly prepared by officials of the National Security Council, the State and Defense Departments and the Central Intelligence Agency, challenged the policy of increased American military aid for El Salvador supported by the Administration. (7:1.)

title: Musical 'Birdie,' 'Macbeth' Closing
description: ''Bring Back Birdie,'' the musical sequel to ''Bye Bye Birdie,'' by Michael Stewart, Charles Strouse and Lee Adams, will close tonight at the Martin Beck Theater.

title: LELAND D. BALDWIN
description: Leland D. Baldwin, a former professor of American history at the University of Pittsburgh and an authority on the history of western Pennsylvania, died today in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: 'VILLAGE' CHURCH DESTROYED BY FIRE
description: St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Greenwich Village - the third oldest church in Manhattan - was destroyed early this morning by a three-alarm fire, the Fire Department said. The first alarm for the fire at the church, founded in 1820, was t urned in at 11:56 last night, a fire department spokesman said.

title: U.S. BUDGET CHIEF FAVORS LOAN GUARNTEE FOR CITY
description: David A. Stockman, the Director of the Federal Office of Management and Budget, says that he favors Federal loan guarantees to the city and that the Reagan Administration will not try to force cities to end rent control, as a transition team had recommended.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE OFF SLIGHTLY TO 7.3% IN FEBRUARY
description: Employment in the United States rose slightly in February as the national unemployment rate edged down to 7.3 percent after being at 7.4 percent for two months, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: BERRIGANS AND SIX ARE CONVICTED IN ATTACK ON MISSILES
description: The Rev. Daniel Berrigan and his brother Philip, the 1960's antiwar activists were found guilty with six other antinuclear activists tonight of breaking into a General Electric Company facility where they damaged two missile nose cones with hammers and poured blood on official papers.

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP BY 0.8% IN FEBRUARY
description: Continuing large increases in energy prices resulted in a rise of eight-tenths of 1 percent in producer prices in February, the Labor Department reported today.

title: BIRMINGHAM TRIES TO FILL TRANSIT GAP
description: It is an unusual assemblage of churchowned vans, old school buses and trucks parked in front of City Hall. But it is, though it might not give that impression, the new, and the only, mass transit system in the city.

title: REAGAN AIMS TO CUT 37,000 FEDERAL JOBS, SAVING $1.3 BILLION
description: President Reagan announced today that he was replacing his temporary hiring freeze with ''new permanent ceilings'' that were to reduce Federal employment by 37,000 jobs by Sept. 30, 1982, at a two-year saving of $1.3 billion.

title: PHILLIES' OWNER SEEKING TO SELL
description: The world champion Philadelphia Phillies were offered for sale today by Ruly Carpenter, who said he was fed up with escalating player salaries and the baseball owners' willingness to pay them.

title: POLISH TROOPS LEAVE BARRACKS AS WAR GAMES NEAR
description: Polish troops moved out of their barracks today in apparent preparations for major maneuvers, but Western military attaches said there was no sign that they had linked up with troops from the Soviet Union or other Warsaw Pact forces.

title: Head of Job Safety Institute Out
description: (The Washington Star) WASHINGTON, March 6 - Dr. Anthony Robbins, head of the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health, was notified Wednesday that Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, had decided to dismiss him immediately. Dr. Robbins had come under attack from business groups.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ON HIGH

title: BUDGET OFFICE PUTS A FREEZE ON LOANS
description: The Office of Management and Budget said today that it had ordered various agencies to stop approving applications for loans and grants to prevent officials in those agencies from frustrating President Reagan's intentions to cut spending below appropriated levels.

title: Ramirez, McEnroe Win For 1-1 Tie in Davis Cup
description: Raul Ramirez, playing his first match in three weeks after having torn a tendon in his left leg, outlasted Roscoe Tanner today, 3-6, 8-6, 6-3, 8-10, 6-3, to tie the first round of the United States-Mexico Davis Cup competition at 1-1.

title: TRADE IN MOST WHALE PRODUCTS IS OUTLAWED
description: International trade in the oil, meat and bones of three species of whales was outlawed here today over the opposition of Japan, while the United States and the Soviet Union abstained in the vote.

description: MATTERS

title: BODY OF ATLANTA BOY, 20TH MISSING YOUTH, IS DISCOVERED IN RIVER
description: The body of a 13-year-old Atlanta boy was pulled from a small, muddy river south of Atlanta today, bringing to 20 the number of black children found slain in the last 19 months.

title: BEHIND THE STATISTICS ON SOVIET EMIGRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: STRINDBERG'S 'A DREAM PLAY'
description: In an author's note to ''A Dream Play,'' his own favorite of all his works, August Strindberg indicated that he had tried to imitate ''the logical shape of a dream.'' In a dream and in the play, ''the imagination spins, weaving new patterns, a mixture of memories, experiences, free fancies, incongruities and improvisations. The characters split, double, multiply, evaporate, condense, disperse, assemble.''

title: PRESIDENT TERMS AID FOR SALVADOR A HELP TO RIGHTS
description: President Reagan defended increased military aid to El Salvador today, saying that the United States was ''helping the forces that are supporting human rights in El Salvador'' against left-wing ''terrorists.''

title: EX-DEAN OF TUFTS NAMED PRESIDENT OF CITY COLLEGE, ENDING LONG HUNT
description: Dr. Bernard W. Harleston, former dean of arts and sciences at Tufts University, was appointed president of City College yesterday by the trustees of the City University of New York, ending a sometimes tumultuous two-year effort to fill the post.

title: NEW YORK CITY JOBLESS UP TO 9.4%
description: The unemployment rate rose last month in New York City, held steady in the state and dropped in New Jersey.

title: WHEN INFLATION STRIKES; Books Of The Times
description: THE PENNILESS BILLIONAIRES. By Max Shapiro. Times Books/Truman Talley. 308 pages. $15.

title: Less Federal Help: Who'll Get It?
description: Mayors and governors have complained for years about regulations and rigidities in Federal programs. Some have even said they'd settle for less money if only there were also less red tape. As they say on television, you asked for it, you got it. That's exactly what the Reagan Administration now proposes to do.

title: HAITI UNDER DUVALIER II: 'IT IS THE SAME SITUATION'
description: In the village of Gros Morne, in Haiti, the local Roman Catholic priest gives a can of dried corn for each rat tail that parishioners bring him. They stand in line waving four or five tails and tell how they killed the rats. It is one priest's version of a food-for-work program.

title: LORD AVIE WINS FLORIDA DERBY
description: Lord Avie, the 2-year-old champion of 1980 who was beaten back to third in his last race, finished with his customary rush in the quarter-million-dollar Florida Derby today and re-established his stature as early favorite for the Kentucky Derby, at least temporarily.

title: Fans Disrupt White Sox
description: A taunting crowd of about 150 fans, shouting insults related to the players' dispute with major league club owners, forced the Chicago White Sox to move indoors today for their annual meeting with Marvin Miller, executive director of the players union.

title: CHILE'S REWARD
description: To the Editor:

title: MICROCOSM OF THE TUDORS IN 6 VOLUMES OF LETTERS
description: Henry VIII, courtiers and commoners march across the pages of some remarkable letters that are coming to light for the first time after having survived, among other perils, the bombs and fires of the London Blitz. English historians are calling the collection of letters one of the richest contributions ever made to a portrait of the British people four centuries ago.

title: A Proposal for Housing In Pinelands Approved
description: State authorities gave the go-ahead today for construction of a new city to house 20,000 people in an environmentally sensitive coastal region.

title: HIJACKERS IN KABUL KILL PAKISTAN ENVOY
description: Hijackers today fatally shot a Pakistani diplomat being held hostage aboard a Pakistani jetliner in Kabul, the Afghanistan radio said.

title: TESTING SAFETY OF ELECTRICAL PRODUCTS
description: For almost 90 years, Underwriters Laboratories, the venerable non-profit organization that tests electrical safety, has been examining thousands of products. Last year alone, UL tested some 52,000 products, in the process opening and closing refigerator doors thousands of times, knocking over coffee pots and trying to set fire to various kinds of building materials.

title: IRAN REJECTS PROPOSAL FOR A TRUCE IN ITS WAR WITH IRAQ
description: Iran announced today that its Supreme Defense Council had unanimously rejected proposals for a cease-fire and a negotiated settlement of its war with Iraq made Wednesday by a commission of Islamic leaders.

title: SPORTS OFFICIALS RESIST KOCH PLAN ON LEGAL BETTING
description: The commissioners of four major professional sports met yesterday with Mayor Koch about his proposal to legalize some forms of sports betting, but there was no meeting of minds - the commissioners remained adamantly opposed to the idea.

title: SALVADOR NAVY, DOWN TO THREE BOATS, TRIES TO HALT ARMS FLOW
description: The Salvadoran Navy lists 11 boats in its inventory. Two are capsized hulls, four have been stripped for parts, and of the rest, only three are operational.

title: 2 Returned to Philadelphia In Theft of Spilled Million
description: Joseph Coyle, an unemployed longshoreman accused of stealing $1.2 million that fell out of a Purolator Armored Service Inc. car in Philadelphia last week, and Francis Santos, who the police say was helping Mr. Coyle to leave the country, were returned to Philadelphia yesterday from New York City by two detectives.

title: A MONARCHIST'S KILLERS
description: To the Editor:

title: GEORGIA, MARYLAND SCORE UPSETS
description: Third-ranked Louisiana State and fourth-ranked Virginia were upset in the semifinal rounds of their conference tournaments last night.

title: 2 Robbery Suspects Seized in Car Chase
description: Two robbery suspects were captured yesterday after an automobile chase by the police that started on the Lower East Side, continued across the Williamsburg Bridge and ended in Brooklyn after the two men allegedly tried to run down a police officer.

title: Policeman's Killer Gets Life
description: Patrick O'Shea, 39 years old, was sentenced by Judge Herbert Travers Jr. of Superior Court today to life imprisonment without parole for the fatal shooting Dec. 10 of Police Sgt. Walter Conley of Milford in an attempted robbery outside a branch of the Milford Savings Bank. Mr. O'Shea had changed his plea to guilty.

title: Your Money; Insurance Boon In Law Change
description: It seems too good to be true, but it is. The Northwestern Mutual L ife Insurance Company of Milwaukee has told 1.5 million of its p olicyholders that if they agree to a change in their contracts, t heir life insurance coverage would increase by an average of 15 p ercent, without an increase in premium payments.

title: DANCE: 5 BY DANIEL LEWIS COMPANY
description: ''I am an open book to my boss,'' a dancer proclaimed about half way through Daniel Lewis's new ''Open Book.'' ''And a complete mystery to your friends,'' another dancer said. Count this perplexed observer on the side of the angels. Odd dance succeeded odd dance on a program of five pieces choreographed by Mr. Lewis and performed by the Daniel Lewis Dance Repertory Company on Thursday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. The one exception was ''Beethoven Trio,'' a pretty, buoyant little opening dance. But the fact that the choreography was ''after Jose Limon'' may explain its sensible, deliberately crafted look.

title: REAGAN ASKS CANADA TREATY ACTION
description: President Reagan said today that he had asked the Senate to ratify an East Coast boundary treaty with Canada but that he had at the same time asked it to drop consideration of a proposed fisheries agreement.

title: No Headline
description: Thailand officially turned down today a plea by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, for non-Communist Southeast Asian countries to support a regional conference on the Cambodia conflict. Foreign Minister Siddhi Savetsila said the Soviet proposal refused to go to ''the root of the problem, which is the complete withdrawal'' of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia.

title: Don't Drink It, Governor
description: Governor Carey's offer to drink a tumbler full of polychlorinated biphenyls from a contaminated state office building in Binghamton recalls a hallowed political tradition. One thinks of Richard Nixon eating cranberries to show his disdain for an herbicide scare; of Jimmy Carter traipsing around Three Mile Island to prove that the nuclear accident was, finally, under control; of James Schlesinger, as atomic energy chief, braving the wilds of the Aleutian Islands to dispel fears of an underground nuclear explosion.

title: MARKET RESPONSE IS COOL
description: In the largest initial public stock offering in United States corporate history, the Cetus Corporation, an advanced biotechnology and genetic engineering company, entered the market today with 5.2 million shares priced at $23 a share. The response from investors was decidedly cool.

title: JUSTICES REJECT APPEAL TO HALT EXECUTION OF INDIANA MURDERER
description: The Supreme Court today rejected a bid to block the execution of Steven Judy, a convicted murderer in Indiana who has refused to do anything to prevent his electrocution on Monday.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.3 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply declined $1.3 billion in the week ended Feb. 25 after increasing $5.3 billion in the previous three weeks.

title: Westchester Journal
description: STATE SENATOR Joseph R. Pisani, Republican of New Rochelle, surprised many in the county when he indicated some time ago that he was considering running for governor in 1982. He restated that hope in November, when he was re-elected easily to a fifth term.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Hugo Montenegro by The Associated Press in some editions of The Times on Feb. 8 incorrectly credited the musical theme for the film ''Hang 'Em High.'' The theme was composed by Dominic Frontiere.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGALLY SUPPLYING HEROIN TO ADDICTS IS NOT THE ANSWER
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Lyon Fiancee Of A. K. McIntyre
description: The engagement of Leslie Deanne Lyon to Alexander Keith McIntyre has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Lewis Lyon of Wenham and Centerville, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Keith McIntyre of White Plains and the late Katherine McIntyre.

title: Paperbacks; New and Noteworthy
description: THE NICK ADAMS STORIES, by Ernest Hemingway. Scribner's, $5.95. Growing from child to adolescent to soldier to veteran to writer to parent. This collection, first issued in 1972, assembles the stories in the order that the events occurred, supplements them with fragments Hemingway pruned, and includes eight tales never previously published. Indispensable for an understanding of Hemingway's development as man and artist.

title: Leigh Carrere Barbour, Systems Planner, Fiancee of William Deehan, an Economist
description: Leigh Carrere Barbour, a planner for the systems-development division of the Coradian Corporation in Albany, and William Joseph Deehan, an economist for the New York State Public Service Commission in Albany, will be married in May.

title: VERMONT SOCIALIST PLANS MAYORALTY WITH BIAS TOWARD POOR
description: Olive branches and soothing balm seemed in order, and so Bernie Sanders, a 39-year-old, self-styled Socialist from Flatbush who surprised Vermont on Tuesday by narrowly being elected Mayor of its largest city, was being careful to sound conciliatory.

title: Jane Ann Kleinberg Fiancee Of Eric Lebowitz, Ad Man
description: Armand J. Kleinberg of New York and Mrs. Abraham Katz of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Ann Kleinberg, to Eric Lebowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Lebowitz of the Bronx.

title: Corn Fodder, J.Z. Leader Advance to Pacing Final
description: Corn Fodder, J.Z. Leader and Golden won the final eliminations in the New Faces pacing series for 3-year-olds at the Meadowlands last night. The $100,000 final in the series is scheduled for Friday night.

description: When Jimmy Carter lost the Presidential election, prospects appeared equally dim for Mr. Carter's look-alike, Ed Beheler in Elm Mott, Tex. Could

description: THE elimination of $64 million in minimum state aid to 234 school districts, as called for in Governor Byrne's 1982 education budget, has teachers, administrators, school-board members and parents on the warpath.

title: Consumers And Caveats
description: In view of William Safire's linguistic skills, I write with trepidation (''Let the Reader Beware,'' On Language, Feb. 1).

title: MAKE NO SECRET OF IT, THE RIGHT TO PRIVACY STILL HOLDS
description: ALTHOUGH the United States Constitution does not explicitly guarantee it, most Americans regard the individual's right to privacy as a constitutional protection.

title: DIG THEY MUST, AGREE U.M.W. AND BIG COAL
description: B.R. ''Bobby'' Brown, a pin-striped former Texas oil executive, is leading the coal industry's triennial bargaining bout with the United Mine Workers of America. And Mr. Brown, president of the largest employer of U.M.W. man-and womanpower, the oil-companyowned (by Conoco) Consolidation Coal Company, is doing considerable poor-mouthing these days.

title: SKI THEFTS ARE A GROWING PROBLEM
description: CORNWALL WALTER SCHOENKNECHT remembers when, back in a more innocent era, skiers would leave their skis in a snowbank outside a lodge overnight and rest assured that they would still be there in the morning.

title: Judith Anne Splittorf Fiancee of Gregory Brooks Arnold
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Richard Splittorf of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Anne Splittorf, to Gregory Brooks Arnold, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Arnold of Meriden, Conn.

title: E.P.A. PLANS TO EASE RULES ON CLEAN AIR, VICE PRESIDENT SAYS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will propose on Monday a change in clean air regulations that is intended to ease restrictions on new industrial development while continuing to protect against air pollution, Vice President Bush announced today. The regulatory change would affect the entire industrial area of the nation, about 17 percent of the nation's land mass, including the Northeast corridor, southern California and the industrial Middle West.

title: Music View; COMPOSERS OF VANISHED FAME
description: The standard romance in music concerns the composer who labors throughout his career under a cloud of neglect and abuse, dies with his genius recognized by only a handful of his peers, and many years later is enshrined in the pantheon of old masters where his bones can be venerated forevermore. Actually, you will have to search a long time before finding a composer whose life matches that romance: Schubert's comes as close as any, but even he enjoyed considerable contemporary acclaim from the band of enthusiastic admirers whose musical evenings were known as ''Schubertiads.''

title: PRESERVING RARE SPECIES IS AN IRONIC SUCCESS
description: NEW DELHI IN Hong Kong, customs agents last year seized dozens of airfreighted boxes marked '' mink,'' and found the pelts of 319 cheetahs, more than 5 percent of the world's cheetah population. In Fiji, bales of confiscated crocodile skins are crumbling in a humid shed. In many parts of the world, illicit trade in endangered species, sold as living or dead cargo, is growing and, ironically, this development is cheered by conservationists. The proliferation of underground markets means that the larger legal commerce is drying up. ''It is clearly getting harder and harder to export these things,'' said Nicole Duplaix, a member of Biologists for Traffic, a Washington-based research group which monitors the flow of animals and plants. ''The treaty is working.''

title: Nonfiction in Brief; by James Traub
description: THE ESSAYS OF MARK VAN DOREN: (1924-1972) Selected, with an Introduction by William Claire. 270 pp. Westport, Conn.: Greenwood Press. $25.

title: 9-YEAR-OLD SUSPECT POSES ETHICAL ISSUE
description: Mike Pearl covers the criminal courts for The New York Post. Ten days ago, he got a tip that a 9-year-old boy was about to surrender to the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a bank-robbery suspect. There was no doubt in Mr. Pearl's mind about the kind of story he had.

title: No Headline
description: Hecklers, some of them Iranians, disrupted a lecture yesterday by Richard Morefield, a former hostage. Mr. Morefield, speaking at South Seattle Community College, warned that Americans might be seized somewhere in the world as a test of the Reagan Administration.

title: ARTHUR PENN PREPARES A STREAMLINED 'WILD DUCK'
description: ''It seems to me to be the kind of play no respectable repertory company can omit,'' said Arthur Penn, restlessly tugging at the front of his khaki work shirt. The director, lean and energetic at 58, was talking about his staging of Ibsen's ''The Wild Duck,'' which opens Thursday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music as the season's third production of the BAM Theater Company.

title: U.S. COUPLES FINISH 5TH AND 6TH
description: The five-day world figure-skating championships ended tonight with the final of the ice dancing. They also ended with new appreciation for the distinct styles of women's skating - the artistic as personified by Denise Biellmann of Switzerland, the new women's champion, and the athletic, as exemplified by 15-year-old Elaine Zayak of Paramus, N.J., the runner-up.

title: On Language; REAGANESE; by William Safire
description: Considering the enormity of the President's error when he says, quote-unquote, ''lay-izon'' - is that cause to be hung in effigy? The preceding sentence contains two mistakes in word usage, one pronunciation stumble and a curious form of oral punctuation. All can be tracked to Ronald Reagan.

title: Alayne Smith Will Be a Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Smith of Jersey City of the engagement of their daughter, Alayne Smith, to Jeffrey Cyk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Cyk of Clifton, N.J.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: TWO Princeton University graduate students are playing a key role in what may result in the renovation of one of Trenton's most blighted sections.

title: Sarah Hildreth Gilmore Bride of Mark Gordon, Rancher
description: The marriage of Sarah Hildreth Gilmore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John James Gilmore of Greenfield, Mass., to Mark Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Crawford Gordon of Kaycee, Wyoming, took place yesterday afternoon in the Second Congregational Church in Greenfield. The Rev. Lloyd H. Dunham performed the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Hickok, B.K. Smith Jr.  Are Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. H. August Kuehl of Barrington, R.I., and Raymond Tiffany Hickok of Rochester of the engagement of their daughter, Kimberly Remsen Hickok, to Bromley Keables Smith Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of Washington.

title: AN AMATEUR HISTORIAN
description: THE WAR BETWEEN THE GENERALS Inside the Allied High Command. By David Irving. Illustrated. 446 pp. New York: Congdon & Lattes. $17.95.

title: Dresden
description: To the Editor:

title: G.E. Porter Fiance Of Lindsay Gates
description: Mr. and Mrs. Caleb Frank Gates Jr. of Denver have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lindsay Gates, to Gerald E. Porter, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Porter of Mamaroneck, N. Y.

title: VIRGINIA TO REQUIRE GARBAGE COLLECTION FROM SHIPS
description: Late this month the state will begin requiring dozens of foreign coal ships anchored off the Virginia coast to contract for garbage and sewage collection.

title: Brechtian Generosity
description: To the Editor:

title: Sound; CAPTURING THE PIANO'S ODD CHARACTER; by Hans Fantel
description: O f all musical instruments, the piano has been most consistently mistreated by the phonograph. The earliest recordings reduced the sonorities of the concert grand to a sort of xylophone tinkle; even after electric recording replaced the tin horn, piano sound captured on disks did not always fare better. Instead of tinkling, it now clanged. The percussive phase of the piano tone - the moment when the hammer hits the strings - was often so distorted that it gave the impression of an instrument consisting of pot-lids struck by soup ladles.

title: TWO AGENCIES PUSH DDT BURIAL INQUIRY
description: BARNEGAT THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency and the state's Department of Environmental Protection have begun to investigate reports that drums containing DDT residues were buried on property of the Ocean County Mosquito Exterminating Commission here.

title: MARYLAND IS LEADING AT IC4A'S
description: Maryland gained the jump on its rivals in the IC4A indoor track and field championships today by capturing the top three places in the long jump and producing the winner in the weight throw at Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: RYE'S 'BORDER WAR'
description: AFTER halting a 12-year influx of office buildings at a point at which they produce about 25 percent of its tax revenues, Greenwich is now seeking to halt construction in other communities, even those across state lines, whenever such development is perceived to be a threat to the Greenwich environment and its way of life.

title: L.I.U. Topples Iona And Captures Berth In N.C.A.A. Tourney
description: Long Island University gained its first Division I national postseason tournament berth today, erasing a 14-point second-half deficit and defeating Iona, 77-72, in the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro New York-New Jersey championship game at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: THE 187 members of the General Assembly apparently have a lot of ideas they think should be law, and entering a bill has become their way of saying so. This year they have entered more than 3,300 bills and resolutions, thousands more than can be given serious consideration in committee, let alone on the floor of either house.

title:
The Lively Arts;
DRAMATIZING ARTS ON CABLE
description: ''QUIET on the set,'' said a technician. ''This one we are going to tape.'' ''Ready on the floor,'' said a voice coming into the silent television studio over an amplifier from the control booth. The dancers Starr Danias and Gregory King stood waiting in Grecian tunics for a taping of ''Autumn Bacchanale,'' an enticing bit of choreography originally performed by Anna Pavlova at the turn of the century.

title: FIRST IN SPACE WITH A NETWORK FOR BUSINESS
description: ROBERT C. HALL sits at the wheel of an enterprise that has been running on little more than faith. In the five years since it was established here, Satellite Business Systems hasn't recorded a penny of revenue, to say nothing of profits. Yet, three substantial investors the International Business Machines Corporation, the Aetna Life and Casualty Company and the Comsat General Corporation - have committed $525 million just to get the company started.

title: 'Revitalization,'; Military Style
description: In 1975, Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger called his a ''turnaround defense budget'' (critics called it ''the camel's nose''). Last week, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger called his ''rearming America.'' Only the label has changed.

title: Bitterman Is Found; Dead in Colombia
description: ''Prayer is our greatest weapon,'' the Wycliffe Bible Translators said after one of their number, Chester A. Bitterman, was kidnapped by leftist guerrillas in Bogota on Jan. 19. The California-based missionary group refused demands that its local affiliate leave Colombia, and yesterday, after several of their ''deadlines'' had passed, the kidnappers killed Mr. Bitterman and left his body in a stolen bus on a Bogota street.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: ARMAGEDDONS AVOIDED
description: THE HILL OF SUMMER A Novel of the Soviet Conquest. By Allen Drury. 484 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95. THE TRADE By William H. Hallahan. 324 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $12.95. By PATRICK ANDERSON

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: A LOOK UP THE TRACKS FOR L.I.R.R. RIDERS
description: DIX HILLS ''THERE'S no mystery about what the problems are,'' said Francis S. Gabreski, reflecting on the difficulties that forced him out of his job as president of the Long Island Rail Road.

title: DEVELOPMENT FUNDS INSPIRE SUGGESTIONS
description: IN Huntington, taxpayers have suggested that the Community Development Agency ''clean up the trash and staff a recycling center,'' ''build a swimming pool in North Huntington'' and ''rehire town employees for the municipal golf course.''

title: SMITH STIRS DISPUTE WITH PLAN ON CRIME
description: Attorney General William French Smith wants to lead a national campaign against violent crime, but several specialists in the field say that there is relatively little the Federal Government can do and that such crime may not have increased as much as some statistics suggest.

title: Administration Diversifies the Line on Salvador
description: Robert D'Aubisson, a cashiered army major, came out of hiding last week hinting broadly that a coup was in the offing in El Salvador and asserting that the Reagan Administration ''would not be bothered'' by it. Denials thundered forth from Washington and, as if on cue, after weeks of stressing the military nature of an alleged Soviet-and Cuban-supported insurgency, the Administration directed attention to political and economic concerns.

title: RAY BILLINGTON, CHRONICLER OF NATION'S MOVE WEST
description: Ray Allen Billington, a chronicler of America's westward expansion and a senior research associate at the Huntington Library in San Marino, Calif., died yesterday of heart failure at his home in San Marino. He was 77 years old.

title: Leisure; A PRIMER FOR SPRINGTIME PRUNING
description: ''When you understand how to do a thing the doing is easy: if you find it difficult you do not understand it.'' This Chinese proverb applies to pruning. To understand what happens when you prune a tree, shrub or vine, you must have a clear idea of how and why the plant responds.

title: l8 Food Establishments Are Cited for Violations
description: New York City's Department of Health released the names of 18 food establishments last week that it said had violated the health code. The department also listed the names of 12 places that had reopened after correcting earlier violations.

title: EGYPT PONDERING FATE OF ITS MUMMIES
description: The fate of the contents of the Royal Mummy Room at the Egyptian Museum continues to spark discussions among Government officials, museum personnel and antiquities experts.

title: Freighter Aground in Canada
description: The Star Philippine, a 570-foot freighter, ran aground today in the Seymour Narrows about six miles north of this Vancouver Island community.

title: BARBARA COOK -- POP AND POLISH
description: The technique of pop singing over the past 50 years - since the microphone enabled a Whispering Jack Smith to make a rhythmic mumble pass for singing and gave Bing Crosby a means of taking advantage of his casual, intimate style - has put more emphasis on phrasing and styling than on vocal technique. Technique, in fact, has been diminished to a point where it is perceived as getting in the way of a pop singer, of interfering with the appearance of a natural, almost conversational flow which is the interpretive goal of the pop singer.

title: GREENWICH SUITS ASSERT REGIONAL SPHERE OF INTEREST
description: AFTER halting a 12-year influx of office buildings at a point where they produce about one-third of its property tax revenues, Greenwich is now seeking to block similar construction in other communities, even those across state lines, whenever it appears to threaten the Greenwich environment or way of life.

title: A DISPARATE TRIO
U.S. Study of Paroled Convicts Reports a Success Rate of 75%
description: A Justice Department study of 64,000 convicts paroled in 1974 and 1975 has found that the paroles of 25 percent were revoked and they were returned to prison before parole ended.

title: MISS PIGGY SHE'S SWEET
description: NORTHPORT ''ONE of these days I would like to make a cake for Miss Piggy,'' said Larry Stempler, the owner of the Valley Bake Shop. It's not that Mr. Stempler is a particular fan of the plump, pink movie queen, but he feels she might appreciate one of his cakes. ''A Kermit cake, of course,'' he added.

title: CONFERENCE TO EXPLORE MYTHS OF JEWS' MIGRATION
description: The great Jewish migration to the United States from Eastern Europe at the turn of the 20th century is the focus of many myths: Jews, fresh from Russian pogroms, lived on the Lower East Side in abject poverty after harrowing journeys across the oceans. Jewish youths crowded public libraries devouring the works of Marx and Spinoza, while their fathers debated socialism in musty coffee shops and their mothers sewed in the sweat shops.

title: 'ATTILA' BY VERDI: 131 YEARS LATER
description: It only took four years for Verdi's ''Attila'' to cross the Atlantic after its world premiere in Venice on March 17, 1846 - Verdi was, after all, Italy's foremost young composer with ''Nabucco,'' ''I Lombardi,'' ''Ernani'' and ''I Due Foscari'' in production all over Europe. An outfit called Marty's Havana Italian Opera Company brought ''Attila'' to New York City on April 15, 1850, and the opera was unveiled at Niblo's Garden with Ignazio Marini in the title role, the same bass who created the part in Venice. On the podium was Luigi Arditi, the celebrated composer of ''Il Bacio,'' a salon waltz-song still favored by coloratura sopranos.

title: OPPOSITION TO CASINOS CALLED 'PATERNALISTIC'
description: OPPONENTS of casino gambling are always ready to insist that gambling is immmoral or that it is an open invitation to organized crime and corruption. Neither assertion can survive a rigorous examination, however.

title: Norman Mitchell 3d to Marry Susan Cogger
description: The engagement of Susan Elizabeth Cogger to Norman Edward Mitchell 3d, son of Colonel Mitchell 2d, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Mitchell of Pawling, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Everett Banks of Clearwater, Fla. An April 25 wedding is planned in the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Indiana 69, Michigan State 48
description: Ray Tolbert and Landon Turner combined for 33 points to lead Indiana to its second consecutive Big Ten title tonight with a 69-48 victory over Michigan State.

title: LAST WEEK'S WATER CONSUMPTION IN CITY LOWEST SINCE MARCH 1970
description: New York City users consumed less water last week than at any time since March 1970, according to officials of the Environmental Protection Department. Consumption, which had been going down steadily, dropped dramatically toward the end of the week, the officials said.

title: To Saudi Arabia, With Extended Arms
description: Secretary of State Haig wants to make his first trip to the Middle East next month bearing gifts for the House of Saud: missiles and fuel tanks to enhance the power and range of the F-15 fighter planes Jimmy Carter sold to Saudi Arabia with a pledge that they would never be thus equipped.

title: The Careful Shopper; by Jeanne Clare Feron; Clinton Tableware Expands Outlet
description: D. Clarkson Ltd., a manufacturing wholesaler in Clinton, has supplied major department stores in several dozen states in the last four and a half years. The factory produces tablecloths, runners, placemats and napkins designed to complement both contemporary china and earthenware in easy-care and soil-release fabrics under the name Table Accents by Deborah.

title: Stage View; ELLINGTON-STILL FULL OF LIFE; by Walter Kerr
description: ''Sophisticated Ladies'' is a sleekly fashioned, dynamically paced, irresistibly friendly medley of some 35 songs written in part or entirely by the masterly Duke Ellington, and one of the nicest small tricks in it is a bit of staging I don't think I ever ran across before. Simple, but makes you purr with delight as it happens. It may even be relevant.

title: Mississippi Captures S.E.C. Title, 66 to 62
description: Elston Turner led Mississippi from a 12-point deficit to a 66-62 victory over Georgia tonight, giving the Rebels their first Southeastern Conference basketball championship.

title: HAWKES'S MANY SELVES
description: A QUEST OF LOVE By Jacquetta Hawkes. 220 pp. New York: George Braziller. $10.95.

title: The Concrete Circuit
description: To the Editor:

title: Raymond Walsh to Wed Mary C. Skahen May 2
description: Surrogate Judge John F. Skahen of Rockland County, and Mrs. Skahen, of Stony Point, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Catherine Skahen to Raymond J. Walsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Walsh of Castleton Corners, S.I.

title: Lagging Northeast
description: To the Business Editor: Anyone who wants to know why the Northeast has such a low rate of economic growth should look at the list of Democratic legislators who are least supportive of business. Most of them are from east of the Mississippi and north of the Mason-Dixon line.

title: No Headline
description: In other Davis Cup action yesterday, Britain took a 2-1 lead over Italy by winning the doubles at Brighton. Jonathan Smith and Andrew Jarrett beat Adriano Panatta and Paolo Bertolucci, 6-1, 3-6, 6-3, 3-6, 7-5.

title: Undertaker for Pets
description: The Bonheur Memorial Park Cemetery in Elkridge, Md., calling itself the only pet cemetery in the world where humans could be buried next to their pets, reported last November that it would expand. It asked the Howard County Board of Appeals for a zoning variance to develop an economy cemetery for the pets of ''blue-collar workers earning $10,000 to $12,000 a year.''

title: CAN REAGAN LIFT THE CLOUD OVER NUCLEAR POWER?
description: Julian W. Davis was barely out of Clemson University a decade ago when the Duke Power company began to plan a giant, three-unit, nuclear-powered electric generating plant in this remote northwestern corner of South Carolina. Now 34 years old and the project's senior construction engineer, the lanky Mr. Davis stood last week on a bluff overlooking his handiwork, a venture once dubbed ''P-81'' after the year it was to be finished.

title: Kidnapped Italian Is Freed
description: Kidnappers today freed Pier Luigi Bardanzellu, a 42-year-old landowner abducted Jan. 15, after receiving a ransom of over $500,000, the police said. He appeared to be in good condition.

title: Susan Jean McGettigan Fiancee of Richard T. Carroll
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Thomas McGettigan of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Jean McGettigan, to Richard Thomas Carroll, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Joseph Carroll of Stratford, Conn. A December wedding is planned.

title: Mary L. Riesmeyer, Editor, Bride of Dr. Peter C. Sutton
description: Mary Lynn Riesmeyer, managing editor of Photo Researchers Inc. of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Peter C. Sutton, assistant curator of European paintings at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: GABRIEL WINS THREE; KENNEDY NO. 1 TEAM
description: Nigel Gabriel of Boys and Girls High School and the John F. Kennedy squad shared top billing yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League indoor track and field championships at the 102d Engineers Armory. Gabriel won three events, and Kennedy won the team title for the first time.

title: STATE PANEL ASSAILS MANAGEMENT OF A SCHOOL FOR RETARDED
description: A state commission charged today that lax monitoring had allowed the owners of a private school for mentally retarded adults to reap hundreds of thousands of dollars in public funds improperly and to violate state regulations ''with impunity.''

title: FRENCH RAISING TAX ON WORKERS' FAVORITE DRINK
description: If the Fifth French Republic ever goes under, it may turn out that the beginning of the end was a rise in the price of Calvados, the over-the-bar staple of the French workingman.

title:
Dining Out;
DEEP IN THE HEART OF OLD BRIDGE TWP.
description: FOR anyone with a hankering for rattlesnake, buffalo steak or wild boar chops, there is a restaurant in Old Bridge Township that actually serves up such fare. Called Lily Langtry's Saloon and Eating Place, this raffish little roadhouse was modeled after Judge Roy Bean's Gay 90's saloon in Texas. Judge Bean was apparently an ardent fan of Miss Langtry, the British actress who was known as ''The Jersey Lily.''

title: Friends of Animals: A View of Hunting
description: BECAUSE Friends of Animals is one of the best-known national organizations opposed to hunting, it seemed only fair, as a hunter, to arrange an interview with its president, Alice Herrington.

title: Design; BOUTIQUE FABRICS: INNOCENCE FROM ABROAD; by Marilyn Bethany
description: Small stores featuring those 'pretty little prints' from Europe have been proliferating in one of the most sophisticated shopping neighborhoods in America. ver the past couple of years, observers of the shopping scene have watched upper Madison Avenue and its immediate environs sprouting a series of boutiques specializing in textiles for the home. Not so surprising? After all, where better to reach fashion-conscious New Yorkers than on their most fertile turf? But the curious fact is that not one of these stores sells the sort of fabrics generally associated with chic interior design. Indeed, these shops feature a look that would appear to be the sophisticate's natural enemy: colorful, small-scale, floral-printed imports that evoke images of rose-covered cottages on dusty European country lanes. Hardly the thing for New York, one would think. But one, it is clear, would be wrong, for these pretty little prints are enjoying a boom here; moreover, they are selling out in Paris and London, too. (The French sometimes call it le style anglais; here we call it ''country'' without specifying which one.) How is it that cosmopolitans all over the globe have been bitten by the same cuteness bug? Apparently, small-scale prints satisfy a longing that high design cannot touch. And it seems that few are immune to their charms. No less mighty a modernist than the architect Charles Gwathmey has been known to slip his clients gifts of traditional French provincial print pillows from the Pierre Deux boutique.

title: NEWSDAY GOES TO 75 ON SUNDAY
description: Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, said it was raising the price of its Sunday edition from 65 to 75 cents, effective today. The newspaper attributed the increase to rising costs of newsprint and energy. The price of the daily paper will remain 25 cents.

title: No Headline
description: Reacting to a high inflation rate, domestic frustration and perceived impotence abroad, the United States has recently elected a leadership that, in the eyes of many, is inclined to choose military rather than diplomatic solutions to problems abroad. We have appointed a career military man to our top diplomatic post.

title: Lauren MacMannis to Wed
description: Donald R. MacMannis of Larchmont, N.Y., and Mrs. Gene Patton Odell of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Jean MacMannis, to William I. Huyett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William I. Huyett of Reading, Pa. An August wedding is planned in Larchmont.

title: MOYNIHAN OPPOSES REAGAN PLAN FOR STATES TO PAY AID TO CHILDREN
description: Poverty and child dependency on welfare are growing problems, not diminishing ones, as advisers to President Reagan have suggested, according to an analysis by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: TURNING OFF PARTY MACHINES TURNED ON THE CANDIDATES
description: Back in the days when political machines ruled the state, the selection of a New Jersey governor always was an efficient and tightly-controlled process. This year, however, encouraged by the availability of public financing, no fewer than 20 candidates have already entered the Democratic and Republican gubernatorial primaries and, with others sure to follow, many people are becoming nostalgic.

title: Mortgage Debt
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding Adam Smith's perceptive comments in ''Houses and Houses of Cards'' (Feb. 22), I would respectfully suggest the drastic increase in mortgage debt during the 1970's was a reflection of the soaring cost of land and construction - plus the apartment-tocondominium conversion boom - not an attempt by borrowers to best the lenders.

title: ART NOUVEAU:A RECURRING THEME
description: ART nouveau writhes again - at the William Benton Museum (University of Connecticut at Storrs, through March 15). Numbering more than 100 posters and drawings, this show, called ''La Belle Epoque,'' is one of several cultural events associated with the ''Belgium Today'' program, which, inaugurated last year, celebrated the 150th anniversary of Belgium's independence. As such, it is sponsored by the National Endowments for both the Arts and the Humanities, as well as the Belgian-American Educational Foundation and other bodies, public and private, and is circulated by the International Exhibitions Foundation.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; FRED MUSTARD STEWART
description: Fred Mustard Stewart says he was sitting with his wife in a Rome restaurant four years ago when the idea just came to him: Why not write a saga about two Italian brothers, one who stays in Rome and one who goes to America?

title: THE AMERICAN PRISON: A TINDERBOX
description: Like the Attica riot, the uprising at the New Mexico State Prison at Santa Fe earned a place in the nation's collective consciousness of terror. For 36 hours last year, gangs of convicts seized control of the maximum-security penitentiary on the outskirts of a city whose name, to much of the rest of the nation, had formerly meant sun on stucco, working ranches and Indian art. Now it became the focus of an intense hell: Prisoners, wielding knives, clubs, stolen riot gear and acetylene torches, took 12 guards hostage, stripped them and dragged them through the 24-year-old fortress, savagely beating, slashing and in some cases sexually assaulting them. But the worst was reserved for fellow prisoners, especially suspected informers and other outcasts of prison life, such as the mentally disturbed or retarded. Gangs raped them repeatedly, blow-torched their eyes and genitals, lynched men from tiers, decapitated them or fired tear-gas canisters point blank into their faces. When it was over, authorities counted 33 bodies. Physicians treated about 90 more for drug overdoses, stab wounds, fractures and traumatic amputations. Just as disturbing as the fact that Santa Fe happened at all are the strong indications that similar horror could now erupt at any moment at any one of several major prisons in the United States because of severe overcrowding. These conditions have resulted in large part from a revolutionary wave of new legislative sentencing policies that have been aimed at curbing judicial inconsistency and leniency in American criminal courts.

title: Strife Among; The Hasidim
description: The longstanding feud between the Belz and the Satmars, two of the many Hasidic sects in Brooklyn, erupted again last week. More than 500 persons, many claiming to be Satmars, pelted a Belz synagogue in Williamsburg with eggs and bottles and threatened to harm the Grand Rabbi of Belz, Yisucher Dov Rokeach, if he dared visit his followers in the borough.

title: EXPLAINING RATIONAL EXPECTATIONS
description: MINNEAPOLIS T HE theory of rational expectations has taken on national prominence recently as the new Administration, in framing economic policy, takes into account how people make economic decisions. Yet, those of us who have an affinity with the theory find ourselves wary rather than jubilant.

title: No Headline
description: Andre Hawkins scored 24 points and grabbed 15 rebounds in leading Malverne to a 77-61 victory over Elmont today for the Nassau County boys' scholastic Class B championship at Nassau Community College.

title: Reality News; Broad Street
description: The Goldmach Sachs Company, an investment banking concern, has leased the 7th through the 9th floors comprising 34,000 square feet of office space for 10 years with an aggregate rent of more than $5.5 million. Broker: Merrill L. Roth of Edward S. Gordon Company.

title: DEPAUL BASKETBALL SUCCESS: COLLEGE GAME HAS CHANGED
description: CHICAGO TEN years ago, there was no full-time assistant coach to hunt for basketball players for De Paul University, and even if there was, there was no budget to pay for recruiting. The campus facility was not getting any younger, and neither was the coach. The whispers were becoming louder - at the age of 57, in his 29th year of coaching, the game had passed him by.

title: WASTE-SITE MEASURE BECOMING HOT ISSUE
description: TRENTON LEGISLATION that would establish sites for hazardous-waste disposal plants could make the issue of such wastes even more volatile than it has been in recent years.

title: DELIGHTS, SURPRISES-AND GAPS
description: In mounting an exhibition called ''The Abstract Expressionists and Their Precursors,'' the Nassau County Museum in Roslyn, Long Island, treads ground that many a larger and more famous institution would have left well alone. For there are no two ways about it: a definitive survey of Abstract Expressionism would be very hard to bring about in the conditions of today.

title: COAST TO COAST, AT HALF FARE, WITH A COUPON
description: If you act quickly, for about $85 you can buy a coupon that will let you fly between the East and West Coasts for only half the cost of the normal economy or first-class fare.

title: Atlanta's Bells Toll For Another Victim
description: Despite the efforts of the police and the vigilance of the citizens, somebody keeps killing black children in Atlanta. Last week, the body of a 20th victim, a 13-year-old boy, was found and a 16-year-old boy disappeared.

title: AUTONOMY PLAN FOR PALESTINIANS IS FADING AWAY
description: There was once hope among Egyptian, American and Israeli officials that the most intractable problem of the Middle East - the Palestinian problem - could be addressed by granting ''autonomy'' to Arabs in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Art View; 'WE FEEL THE IMPATIENCE LEADING DIRECTLY TO REBELLION'; by Hilton Kramer
description: Now that Realism has once again achieved a significant following among the painters and, in the realm of scholarship, 19th-century Salon painting has proved to be an eminently respectable subject for academic research, it was to be expected that some enterprising curator would be inspired by this timely conjunction of interests to organize an ambitious exhibition of 19th-century Realist painting. This, more or less, is what Gabriel P. Weisberg, the curator of art history and education at the Cleveland Museum of Art, has attempted to do in the exhibition called ''The Realist Tradition: French Painting and Drawing, 1830-1900,'' which opened yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum. Some 250 paintings and drawings by 70 artists, most of them now very obscure, have been resurrected for the occasion, and the result is an event likely to offend, or perhaps only baffle, almost as many people as it pleases.

title: Laurie Susan Engel To Be Wed April 11
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey J. Engel of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Susan Engel, to Mark Lawrence Jr., son of Mr. Lawrence of Boston and Nan Hoyt Luter of Honolulu. An April 11 wedding is planned in New York.
