description: KENT ''YOU wouldn't print that,'' more than one resident here said, referring to a report by the town's auditors that listed the names of people who owed money to the Sewer Commission.

title: ESSEX COLLEGE GETS THE GOOD NEWS FIRST, THEN MORE GOOD NEWS
description: NEWARK AFTER weathering three years of crises, Essex County College officials and students finally have something to cheer about. The first good news came less than two weeks ago, when T. Edward Hollander, Chancellor of the state's Department of Higher Education, lifted the threat of economic sanctions against the financially ailing school, thus allaying fears that the college might be forced to close. Several days later, the school's board of directors decided to elevate its popular acting president, A. Zachary Yamba, to permanent status.

title: WILL 'STAR WARS' LURE YOUNGER LISTENERS TO RADIO?
description: LOS ANGELES Tomorrow night, the ''Star Wars'' battles resume. The Millennium Falcon will be traveling through space at light speed again, and Luke Skywalker, Princess Leia, Ben Kenobi and Darth Vader will be back, locked again in a struggle between the forces of good and the forces of evil.

title: Saving Money? No, Preserving Justice
description: So it isn't the cost, after all, that bothers Mr. Reagan about legal services to the poor. It's the very idea of this program, which has enriched American justice, that sticks in the craw of a President who tilted against its lawyers when he was Governor of California. He offers to let the states use some of their other Federal money to sustain the program, if they like. But he knows not many will. Mr. Reagan aims to kill the Legal Services Corporation. He should be stopped.

title: THE SECOND, SECULAR LIVES OF 2-CAREER CLERGYMEN
description: FIVE days a week, Robert Bugbee of the Sussex County community of Hopatcong heads for the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan, where he is director of the School of Radiologic Technology. On Sundays, however, he trades in his white laboratory coat for the clerical garb of a ''circuit-rider preacher'' at Presbyterian churches in northwestern New Jersey.

title: Editors' Choice
description: million-year-old prehuman skeleton and its effect on evolutionary theory. THE SHOCK OF THE NEW, by Robert Hughes.

title: RISE IN DRUG USE SWELLS TREATMENT CENTERS
description: ASURGE in heroin abuse in Westchester County and an increase in the use of most other kinds of narcotics is straining county drugtreatment centers beyond their capacity, according to local officials.

title: CARD PLAYERS IN QUEENS CLUB LOSE $100,000 IN A ROBBERY BY 6 MEN
description: Six men with shotguns and revolvers took $100,000 in cash and jewelry yesterday from 100 people who were playing poker and other card games at a social club in Ridgewood, Queens.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Uncertain start. What's the mood along Publishers Row as the nation makes what President Reagan calls ''a new beginning''? We asked that question at the major paperback houses, which together sell over 30 million books each month through racks placed in 100,000 bookstores, supermarkets and variety stores across the country. When we asked it in times past, we were told almost everywhere, ''We're having lots of fun.'' This time we heard the phrase only once.

title: Susan Sheinhaus Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert L. Sheinhaus of Fresh Meadows, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Meg Sheinhaus, to Robert Douglas Africk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Africk of Glen Cove, L.I. A May wedding is planned in Great Neck, L.I.

title: AT VIRGINIA, STUDENTS ARE CONTENTED WITH A WINTER OF SUCCESS
description: According to Henry Adams, that proper Bostonian, the spring in Virginia is ''depraved.'' The students here prove him right every year: ordinarily it is impossible to get much of their attention after mid-March, when the weather starts warming up. But this year the depravity has started early, for Virginia basketball has been, as the athletic department's official slogan predicted, ''Red Hot.'' set ital-- One of the ways I tried to get the attention of the students in my Intermediate Composition class was by asking them to write about the season. What has been the impact of the team's success on the rest of the university? One hundred well-chosen words, I told them, are worth 10,000 pictures. A good writer knows how to find a vivid, concrete detail that will tell most of his story. So here are seven moments in which my students record the season of our vast content.

title: Business and Prayer
description: To the Business Editor: Many thanks for the sensitive treatment of the prayer movement in ''Businessmen Who Pray Together'' (Feb. 15). There are some who would view Ken White as a miracle worker for persuading Mayor Koch to become involved in these events.

title: U.S. HOLDS SOVIET RESPONSIBLE
description: The State Department said today that the United States expected the Russians "to use their influence" to help end the Kabul hijacking and held Moscow ultimately responsible for the safety of the hostages.

title:
Gardening;
FROM SEED TO PLANT TAKES KNOW-HOW
description: WHILE commercial greenhouses and garden centers are filled to the rafters with spring garden plants each year, many gardeners choose to start their own from seed.

title: MEETING THE CHALLENGE OF THE PIANO'S ODD SONIC CHARACTER
description: Of all musical instruments, the piano has been most consistently mistreated by the phonograph. The earliest recordings reduced the sonorities of the concert grand to a sort of xylophone tinkle; and even after electric recording replaced the tin horn, piano sound captured on disks did not always fare better. Instead of tinkling, it now clanged. The percussive phase of the piano tone - the moment when the hammer hits the strings -was often so distorted that it gave the impression of an instrument consisting of pot-lids struck by soup ladles.

title: CRUCIAL REPAIRS SET FOR SPACE SHUTTLE
description: Repairs on the space shuttle Columbia's huge fuel tank are scheduled to begin today in a crucial operation, expected to take two weeks, that will probably determine whether the nation's first re-usable spacecraft will be ready for flight early next month.

title: City College Search; Finally Bears Fruit
description: For two years, successive search committees have juggled ethnic, political and educational considerations in a sometimes tumultuous search for a successor to Robert E. Marshak as president of City College. Last week the Trustees of City University said that in Dr. Bernard W. Harleston, 51 years old, former dean of arts and sciences at Tufts University, they had found the right person for the job.

title: Chess; TAIMANOV'S RECOVERY
description: Ten years ago, after suffering a drastic 0-6 defeat at the hands of Bobby Fischer in the quarterfinal Candidates Match in Vancouver, the Russian grandmaster Mark Taimanov, who is also a concert pianist, moaned: ''Well, I still have my music.'' At that time no one would have thought it would be his brilliantly victorious opponent who would be the one to slide into oblivion.

title: HELP IS URGED FOR 36,000 HOMELESS IN CITY'S STREETS
description: A yearlong study by the Community Service Society of New York has concluded that the problem of homeless people on the streets of the city has ''reached such extraordinary proportions'' that emergency housing must be set up.

title: SOCAL'S BID
description: Standard Oil of California last week bid some $4 billion for Amax, a major coal and metals producer. It was the largest merger offer on record, but Amax's board turned it down.

title: Kollontai
description: To the Editor:

title: Deborah Capone Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Dolores Capone of Elmont, L.I., and Charles Capone of White Plains of the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ann Capone, to Richard Edward Koch, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Koch of New York. Miss Capone, a media planner with the Marschalk Company, and her fiance, an account coordinator with Abraham & Straus, plan to be married in September.

title: MONDALE, IN LECTURE SERIES, DEFENDS CARTER'S POLICIES
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale has defended Carter Administration policies and dodged questions about a possible Presidential candidacy in 1984 in a lecture series.

title: Braves Trade Burroughs To Mariners for Reliever
description: The Atlanta Braves traded the outfielder Jeff Burroughs to the Seattle Mariners today for Carlos Diaz, a relief pitcher, and ended an impasse caused by a loan the Braves made to Burroughs that is still unpaid.

title: Texas Lifts Its Quarantine On Produce From California
description: Agriculture officials and avocado growers reached a settlement yesterday that lifts the quarantine that Texas had placed on California produce after an outbreak of the highly destructive Mediterranean fruit fly was reported in California.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS BACK SEX EDUCATION PLAN IN JERSEY
description: New Jersey's Roman Catholic Bishops have endorsed the state's plan for mandatory sex education in the state's public schools, provided ''religious and cultural beliefs of individual students and their families be given due respect.''

title: Tax-Makers Leave; No Pebble Unturned
description: No doubt because it has so steadfastly avoided large taxes (especially an income tax), the Connecticut Legislature has over the years been compelled to enact 27 small ones. Last week, confronted by a budget deficit this year of $45 million, Democratic legislative leaders did what comes naturally and proposed number 28 - a one percent tax on real estate sales.

title: CAPITAL INSPECTS ARCHITECTURE
description: HARTFORD IF all the buildings that are being planned for the 1980's are in fact built, the landscape of downtown Hartford will be more drastically altered than it has been in more than 100 years, according to a member of the Hartford Architecture Conservancy's design review committee.

title: NORTH CAROLINA BEATS MARYLAND FOR CROWN
description: Jimmy Black's steal and layup with 2 minutes 55 seconds to play put North Carolina in front and the Tar Heels held on to defeat Maryland, 61-60, tonight to win their ninth Atlantic Coast Conference championship in the last 14 years.

title: On the Fire at Carey High: Decency Still Prevails
description: The Long Island Opinion article by Andy Edelstein (''Did a Spark From the 1960's Start the Fire at Carey High?,'' Feb. 15) is, in my judgment, an appalling distortion of reality. The good name and honorable reputation of more than 1,900 students, as well as the professional faculty and the clerical, custodial and cafeteria staff who successfully and competently service them, have been unjustly and unfairly slandered through snide innuendo and alleged guilt by association.

title: WHY FRESHMAN GET OLD ON CAPITAL HILL
description: WASHINGTON ALTHOUGH she has been a Congresswoman for little more than two months, Marge Roukema of Ridgewood, a peppy civic activist with moderate Republican beliefs that now appear to fit in nicely with most of President Reagan's programs, already reads that she is a ''prime candidate for extinction.''

title: Dance View; MARTHA GRAHAM'S VENTURE INTO NEO-CLASSICISM
description: ''Acts of Light'' is quite possibly one of the most controversial works that Martha Graham has created in some time. After its recent premiere at the Kennedy Center in Washington, it was easy to hear it proclaimed as nothing less than a major piece within her entire repertory of 55 years - just as it was impossible to ignore the disappointment of those who considered it clearly minor.

title: Westchester Housing; HOMEOWNERS ASSAIL FULL ASSESSMENT
description: AGROUP opposing full-value assessment has been organized by Lillian Koegler of White Plains, and it is racing the State Legislature's May 15 deadline, when the law must be implemented or repealed.

title: Miss Weinberger, Major in Marines, Married to a Pilot
description: Maj. Barbara Weinberger, U.S.M.C., joint public-affairs officer of the Third Marine Air Wing and Marine Corps Air Statiion at El Toro, Calif., was married yesterday to Maj. Paul Brown, U.S.M.C., a pilot assigned to the operations department of the Third Marine Air Wing. Lieut. Comdr. Eugene P. Winterfeld, U.S.N. Chaplains Corps, performed the nondenominational ceremony in the chapel at the Air Station.

title: 2 Unbeaten Fighters Have Issue to Settle
description: There were two news conferences in town last week involving undefeated heavyweight boxers from the Metropolitan area. Gerry Cooney drew a full house at Madison Square Garden, where he will fight Ken Norton on May 11. Renaldo Snipes was surrounded by more seconds than reporters. His bandwagon may start rolling today.

title: Miss Kilpatrick Fiancee of Andrei Navrozov
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Kilpatrick of Litchfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Spencer Kilpatrick, to Andrei Navrozov of New Haven, editor and publisher of The Yale Literary Magazine.

title: LESS PAPER FOR THE PENNY
description: Readers of The Dauphin Daily Bulletin, The Swan River Report and The Fort Frances Daily Bulletin may not know it, but they had something in common last year. According to a survey conducted by the American Newspaper Publishers Association, these three Canadian newspapers are the last vestiges of a dying breed: the 5-cent daily newspaper.

title: Future Events Art and Dancing
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. A Different Ploy March 12 -The exhibition and sale of graphic art that opens with a champagne reception at the Susan Caldwell Gallery in SoHo from 6 P.M. to 9 P.M. doesn't follow the usual benefit format, though to be sure it will enrich the coffers and further the work of The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind. Prints in limited editions of 250 were created by six contemporary artists specially for the beneficiary's 75th anniversary. Collectors may be hard put to decide between Joanna Pousette-Dart's delicate painterly abstract and Graham Nickson's realistic bather standing on her head, but many will undoubtledly snap up the whole series, adding works by Frances Barth, Robert Swain, Ray Parker and Stuart Shedletsky. To round out the show, which runs through April 4, paintings by the contributing artists will be displayed. Leo Castelli, the art dealer, is chairman for the evening. Tickets, $25. The commemorative graphics at $500 each are also available from The Lighthouse and such stores as B. Altman, Bloomingdale's and Brooks Brothers.

title: ST LUKE'S CHURCH, RUINED BY FIRE, PLANS TO REBUILD
description: With his 160-year-old church in ruin before him and the stench of fire still hanging in the air, the rector of St. Luke in the Fields, the third oldest church in Manhattan, vowed yesterday that ''we will rebuild.''

title:
ART;
FOR 4 ARTISTS, SHOW IS THE PRIZE
description: RIVERHEAD THE top award in last year's juried exhibition at the East End Arts Center was shared by four artists. Rather than a simple accolade with no practical benefit, their prize was a group exhibition that gives each a chance to show the range of his or her current work. As this reviewer was one of the three jurors and therefore helped establish the criteria for selection, it is particularly interesting to see whether the qualities considered outstanding in a single example are reflected in the artist's other works.

title: Headliners; New Hearing for Carter
description: It's been more than 15 years since Rubin (Hurricane) Carter swung a gloved fist in a boxing match. He still fights, but in a different arena and for different stakes. Last week, the former middleweight scored when the New Jersey Supreme Court ordered a hearing to determine whether the prosecution withheld evidence in his 1976 trial for a triple murder in Paterson. It was the second trial for Mr. Carter and his co-defendant, John Artis, but the verdict (guilty) and the sentence (life) were the same. Mr. Carter hopes to win a third trial on the same grounds as before - misconduct by the prosecution.

title: ANXIETY OVER ROAD PLANS

title: Food; A FACSIMILE OF FISH POACHING
description: The classic method for poaching or steaming a fish in Western culture is by cooking the fish in a specially designed fish cooker or poacher. These vessels are shaped more or less like a long oval and are outfitted both with a rack and a lid. A common lament is that these cookers are expensive, take up a lot of storage space and, in some households, might not be put to all that much use during the course of a year. While we would feel deprived, indeed, if we did not own a fish poacher, there is a solution for those who do not: Place a fish or fillet in a length of heavy-duty aluminum foil, add wine and seasonings and fold the foil to enclose the fish. The fish may then be baked and served either hot or cold. Although it is not technically poached or steamed fish, the result of foil baking is similar enough to seem almost interchangeable with that of the more proper method.

title: A Critic and Modern Music
description: Harold Schonberg's article ''A Lifetime of Listening'' (Feb. 8) reveals a man with a number of attractive qualifications as a music critic: an extraordinarily early interest in music, enthusiasm, the urge to discover beauty and to make comparisons. title: SOVIET SUPPORT OF TERRORISM
description: The hard intelligence data released by the State Department to prove that the Soviet Union and its Cuban proxies have provided large-scale support to terrorism in Central America come as no surprise to those of us who have followed the Communist world and its targets around the world. As long ago as 1971, Czechoslovakian weapons en route to the Irish Republican Army were seized in Amsterdam, and for some years it has been known that the infamous (and seemingly ubiquitous) "Carlos," the Western European terrorist ringleader who disappeared from view in 1975, received training in Cuba and the Soviet Union, as well as in the Middle East. The State Department's revelations, however, provide virtually inconvert ible proof for what has long been treated skeptically or gingerly. Skepti- cally, because, before Jimmy Carter discovered that Leonid I. Brezhne "lied" to him about the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, the dominant attitude in Washington was far too mature to sponsor the deadly antics of international terrorism. Gingerly, because those in the United States intelligence community who knew better found their memorandums spiked and their careers amputated if they made their knowledge available to their superiors. Firm documentation of Soviet and Soviet-satellite support for terrorism is therefore not new, although welcome. What would be even more welcome from the academic community is a serious attempt to place the Soviet support of terrorism in perspective. Those few journalists and scholars who have documented this support in the past generally have been more concerned with proving their case than with explaining the purposes of Soviet involvement.

title: ALL FOR THE CAUSE OF NEW MUSIC

More than that, they need good performers, since their work may be in an unfamiliar idiom, and, unless it is presented accurately, they are likely to be blamed for the performance's failings. Music history is full of painful instances in which work subsequently admired has been sabotaged at its premiere by inadequate execution. Thus any attempt to rectify the situation now - to make possible committed, technically expert interpretations of new music on a steady, longterm basis -can only be applauded.

title: YEMENI WEALTH DECIMATES RHINOS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya Arhinoceros horn is a compacted mass of hair and gelatin weighing about four and a half pounds. Pounded into a powder, sometimes mixed into a potion, it is valued, wrongly, over much of Asia as a cureall. In certain Arab states, particularly North Yemen, it forms the carved handles of ''jambias,'' bejewelled daggers worn by men as a symbol of masculinity. Since 1970, the popularity of the horns, as medicine or machismo, has resulted in the deaths of 90 percent of the rhinoceroses in Kenya, Uganda and northern Tanzania. At present poaching rates, there will not be a single rhino left in the East African wild by 1990.
