description: PISCATAWAY ''I'M WELL, my friends. You are not responsible. I'm innocent. Long live the Modern School!'' So shouted Francisco Ferrer, the Spanish educator and martyr, as he faced execution by a firing squad in Barcelona in 1909 for plotting to assassinate the King of Spain.

title: RAVITCH AND WAGNER ASSAILED AT 'TRANSIT SPEAKOUT'
description: Irate neighborhood groups and community associations from various sections of the city crowded into the auditorium of Public School 87 on West 78th Street yesterday to tell state and city officials in no uncertain words how they felt about the city's subway and bus service.

title: TOURISM OFFICE OPEN, LOOKING FOR TRADE
description: WESTCHESTER a tourist paradise? you ask. Package tours to Yonkers? Surfing and sailing in New Rochelle? Touring the historical sights of Tarrytown?

title: Mexico Leading U.S. in Cup, 2-1
description: Raul Ramirez and Jorge Lozano, teamed in doubles for the first time, defeated Marty Riessen and Sherwood Stewart, 6-4, 3-6, 9-7, 0-6, 6-3, and gave Mexico a 2-1 lead over the United States in the first round of the Davis Cup tennis competition today.

title: PIANO 'VOICES' ON DEBUT DISKS
description: Debut recordings of pianists generally are not too flattering to their subjects. Players are stripped of physical presence when they need it most. In concerts, incompletely realized musical intentions can be communicated with gestures made by the body and hands; in recordings, only the sound is heard, unadorned and uncompromising.

title: Pitt 64, Duquesne 60
description: Lennie McMillian scored 20 points and led a strong defense that carried Pittsburgh to a 64-60 victory over Duquesne tonight in the championship game of the Eastern Eight Conference tournament.

title: ONE-LINER SUCCESS
description: ''IN space no one can hear you scream.'' Barbara Gips, a New Rochelle mother of five, thought of that line for advertising the movie ''Alien'' while riding along Riverside Drive one evening. ''I looked out at the water,'' she said, ''thinking how lonely it seemed at night, how lonely it must be in space. My husband, Phil, a graphic artist, had been working on the advertising for 'Alien,' and I had attended a screening with him. All of a sudden, that line occurred to me.''

title: NEW ON THE GALLERY TOUR: ARNOLD & PORTER
description: The Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter is definitely still in the business of practicing law, but there are times when some of the partners wonder. Unfamiliar heads peer around conference room doors; strangers wander in and out of private offices.

title: No Headline
description: It gave me the greatest pleasure to see due recognition given to a distinguished music critic who actually loves his art. Harold Schonberg has proved himself not only by the quality of his judgment but also by having shown considerable courage in speaking out the truth when so many of his colleagues all too eagerly extolled the ''greatness'' of the nonsinging, never-hearing serialist composers. WARNER S. BASS, New York City

title: Drillers Turn Back Sting For N.A.S.L. Indoor Title
description: The Edmonton Drillers, led by Andre Oostrom, who scored the winning goal, beat the Chicago Sting, 5-4, today to capture the North American Soccer League indoor season championship.

title: WINTERING AT PUNTA DEL ESTE IN SOUTH AMERICA'S SUMMER
description: Suddenly, Uruguay's Punta del Este resort is glamorous. Its beaches are crowded with sleek men and women wearing the skimpiest and most extraordinarily well-fitting of bathing suits. In the late afternoons the streets are crowded with strolling young people. Around 10 P.M., considered a civil hour to begin the evening, adults begin to fill the restaurants and discotheques; the revelry goes on until the first rays of the morning sun send merrymakers home.

title: SEX-EDUCATION DILEMMA
description: To the Editor:

title: Averil Payson Meyer Affianced
description: Averil Payson Meyer and Dr. Timothy Gerrish Haydock plan to be married in Manhasset, L.I., on July 4. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Sandra Payson of Manhasset and Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and William B. Meyer of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., parents of the future bride.

title: LABOR LEADERS SPLIT OVER CAREY NOMINEE
description: The deep split in the state's labor movement over Governor Carey's appointment of Meyer S. Frucher as Labor Commissioner became public this week as two groups of union leaders joined the bitter battle over Senate confirmation of the nominee.

title: PANEL WOULD RAISE DRINKING AGE TO 19
description: A New York State Senate committee, concerned about an increase in alcohol abuse, particularly among the young, received support last week for legislation that would raise the legal drinking age by one year, to 19, and close bars in the state an hour earlier.

title: Birmingham Buses Reach Dead End
description: Though the Birmingham transit system already had the highest bus fare in the nation - 80 cents a ride - the system's managers had claimed for some time that it wasn't nearly enough to keep the wheels turning.

title: Pamela Hart To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Ridgefield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Warfield Hart, to Matthew Thomas Mallory, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Mallory of La Jolla, Calif.

title: Miss Coles Fiancee Of T. T. Scudder
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael H. Coles of Larchmont, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Mary Coles, to Timothy Tracy Scudder, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Scudder of Great Falls, Va.

title: About Westchester; by Lynne Ames
description: PURCHASE SEVERAL students are wandering about the Neuberger Museum, viewing an exhibition of sketches, detailed drawings and a scale model of the state university campus here. One, a transfer student from Kings College in Briarcliff Manor, says he wants to orient himself to his new surroundings. One is interested in the history of the campus. Another is simply trying to ''get a feeling'' of a place that she uses every day.

title: Bob Feller's In Uniform Again; TUCSON, Arizona
description: The night before, Bob Feller was sitting in the Sheraton Pueblo lobby when two Cleveland friends strolled by. ''You'll see me out there tomorrow at the ballpark,'' he told them with a grin. ''I'll be blowing it by those kids.'' In his time, Bob Feller blew it by everybody. Three months after joining the Cleveland Indians as a rookie in 1936 from his family's Van Meter, Iowa, farm, he had 17 strikeouts in one game. And he was only 17 years old. When he stopped pitching after the 1956 season, he had 266 victories along with 2,581 strikeouts. And he had missed four seasons during World War II while he was in the Navy.

title: SUMMIT DELAY DURING MILITARY BUILDUP IS PART OF REAGAN STRATEGY
description: WASHINGTON AT his first press conference, President Reagan castigated Soviet leaders as ''immoral,'' ready to stop at nothing, including lying and cheating, to advance their goal of world domination. Leonid I. Brezhnev, reconfirmed as the Soviet Communist Party leader last week, replied in an unexpected way. He offered in his speech to the 26th party congress to open an active dialogue, even to meet with the new American chief executive, on a number of pressing arms control issues.

title: Linda Sue Lerner Engaged to Intern
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard B. Lerner of Westbury, L.I.., and Lauderhill, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Sue Lerner, to Dr. Theodore Casper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Casper of Pearl River, N.Y. A wedding in August is planned.

title: 'TIFFANY' ILLUMINATES CRAFTSMAN AS ARTIST
description: BROOKVILLE ONE of the most popular exhibitions on the Island this season is ''The Age of Tiffany,'' a display of Louis C. Tiffany's work at Long Island University's C.W. Post Art Gallery. Much of the show's success is undoubtedly linked to the prestigious Tiffany name as well as to the beautiful objects he designed and to the popularity he now enjoys.

title: Home Clinic; PLASTICS EASING THE JOB FOR THE DO-IT-YOURSELF PLUMBER
description: THOSE do-it-yourselfers who used to be reluctant about tackling such jobs as installing a new sink or faucet - in fact, any appliance or fixture having to do with water - are now completing plumbing projects of this kind with increasing frequency.

title: REAGANOMICS' DEBT TO THE UMBRELLA LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: Princeton 52, Cornell 46
description: Neil Christel scored 7 points in overtime, including a 3-point play with eight seconds left and led Princeton to a 52-46 Ivy League victory over Cornell tonight at Jadwin Gymnasium. The Tigers' victory set up a one-game playoff with Penn for the league title.

title: Fashion; THE COUNTRY LOOK
description: THE COUNTRY LOOK Even the most sophisticated woman occasionally likes to shed her aura of worldliness and dress up like a simple maiden of the English countryside and French provinces - or at least the way she likes to think such women dressed in bygone days. Delicate floral prints gathered into full skirts with petticoats rustling underneath create a country-maidenlike look that makes a modern city woman feel soft and feminine - even innocent in a coquettish sort of way.

title: Gulf War Defies; Another Peace Bid
description: Invoking brotherly Moslem sentiments, four Islamic presidents, a prime minister and the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization tried shuttle diplomacy last week to end the Iran-Iraq war. They failed.

title: Westchester Guide; by Eleanor Charles; EVENING OF MOLLY PICON
description: At the age of 15 she toured the United States as Topsy in ''Uncle Tom's Cabin,'' and she was required to deliver her lines in Yiddish, German or English. Many years later, she appeared on the screen as Frank Sinatra's mother in ''Come Blow Your Horn,'' and among her legitimate theater roles was one in which she demonstrated ''How to Be a Jewish Mother.'' Last year, her autobiography was published, titled ''Dolly.''

title: Las Vegas Hotel Plans to Install A $5 Million Fire Safety System
description: A $5 million computer-controlled fire safety system will monitor virtually every corner of the MGM Grand hotel-casino when it reopens next July, eight months after it was damaged by a fire that killed 84 persons.

title: THE FAIRY TALE THAT TURNED NIGHTMARE?
description: TIME CHANGE An Autobiography. By Hope Cooke. Illustrated. 285 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: Numismatics; NEW BOOK SPOTLIGHTS COMMEMORATIVE COINS; by Ed Reiter
description: A major new book has just been released on United States commemorative coins that may, if the authors are correct, help fuel substantial new interest in the series.

title: Critics' Choice; ART
description: One of the things that has lately been missing from the galleries in New York is the disconcerting art of Marisol. What Marisol does in the way of portraiture is literally irreplaceable, in that no one else does anything like it.

title: A CONTEMPORARY ROMANCE
description: TICKETS By Richard P. Brickner. 254 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title: Sunday Observer; WRINKLES ON TV; by Russell Baker
description: The faces of television newswomen are never wrinkled. Not like the reliable faces of Walter Cronkite and Morley Safer. The faces of television newswomen always seem to have arrived fresh from the presser two seconds ahead of the camera.

title: Philadelphia
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: CITY'S 'LA BOHEME'
description: If opera is a delicate balance between singing and acting, Friday's performance of ''La Boheme'' at the City Opera could be thankful for its attractive faces, trim figures and agile stage movement. While every actor-singer on stage convincingly conveyed Puccini's sad little tale of Bohemian love, not a single singer-actor had the authority to demand our attention solely on vocal terms.

title: Camera; THE PHOTOGRAPHER MUST MAKE THE FINAL CHOICE; by Robin Perry
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robin Perry is a freelance writer and photographer, and the author of several books.

title: Index; New York Times Magazine March 8, 1981
description: William Safire 11 On Language Reaganese Russell Baker 20 Sunday Observer Wrinkles on TV Douglas Bauer 22 Why Big Business Is Firing the Boss Corporate America has been hit by a rash of firings of top executives. Why is this happening? And, as President Reagan tries to 'unleash' free enterprise, what does it say about big business's ability to manage itself? James Lieber 26 The American Prison: A Tinderbox Legislators are overcrowding prisons as a result of efforts to deal with crime, and experts say these prisons are in danger of erupting at any moment. John W. Dower 36 Japan's Photographic Legacy Pat Covelli 62 Health New Hope for Diabetics 72 Fashion The Country Look Marilyn Bethany 74 Design Boutique Fabrics: Innocence From Abroad Craig Claiborne 78 Food with Pierre Franey A Facsimile of Fish Poaching 82 Puzzles Answers, Page 91 102 Letters Cover: Photograph of A. Robert Abboud by Arnold Newman Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: Study Says Medical School Debts May Influence Choice of Careers
description: Medical school debts facing young doctors have doubled in three years, and the trend could force physicians to concentrate on the most lucrative branches of medicine so they can pay their bills, a study concludes.

title: 'A SWEET FELLOW...'
description: Speaker Tip O'Neill was complaining about President Reagan the other day in an amiably gruff sort of way. Even if the President talked the most obvious nonsense, the Speaker observed, the press seemed to say it was wonderful.

title: Sheri Pfizenmayer Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Pfizenmayer of Freeport, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheri Anne Pfizenmayer, to Christopher G. De Gray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony P. De Gray of Rockville Centre, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla. A wedding in July is planned.

title: Connecticut Housing; PRESSURE GROWS FOR APARTMENTS IN HOMES
description: FIFTEEN years ago, the five-bedroom colonial home in Westport that Linda Reilly, her husband and two small children moved into fitted her family's needs to perfection, especially since she was expecting a third child.

title: 'HISTORICAL DANCE' MAKES A COMEBACK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Barry Laine writes frequently about dance. By BARRY LAINE

title: NATURE OF NEUTRINOS STILL UNCLEAR AFTER NEW RESEARCH IN CALIFORNIA
description: Ten months ago the world of physics was astonished by reports that neutrinos, subatomic particles believed to be completely without mass, may not only have mass but may also oscillate between different states of mass. Further experiments described in recent reports have left the issue unresolved.

title: FERRAGAMOS OF FLORENCE: AN EMPIRE IN SHOES
description: FLORENCE, Italy W HEN Salvatore Ferragamo died in 1960, he was on his way from rags to riches for the third time. Born to a poor Neapolitan family, he rose from illiterate urchin to shoemaker for royalty, was ruined by the Depression, again by World War II and recovered more spectacularly each time.

title: RAIN AND SNOW BRIGHTEN THE WATER PICTURE BUT OFFICIALS REMAIN CAUTIOUS
description: ALL the rain last month, coupled with the snow that fell last week, has lifted the thoughts of doom and dried-up reservoirs that gripped the state's principal water planners just a month ago.

title: Philadelphia
description: To the Editor:

title: City Hall Notes
description: As best as can be determined, none of the principals have discussed it with one another in any significant fashion. Nevertheless, one of the more engaging political notions to arise at City Hall is the possibility of cross-endorsements, in which the Comptroller and the City Council President would form a ticket with the Mayor as they all seek re-election this year. Aides to the three officials have tentatively discussed the idea among themselves, and some are convinced that, at the least, a joint race by Mayor Koch and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin is a reasonable expectation. That would be highly unusual. Mayors and Comptrollers usually get in one another's way; Mr. Koch and Mr. Goldin, though, get along fine.

title: GRAND CONCOURSE REVIVES AS REHABILITATION PROCEEDS
description: When Louis A. Risse designed and laid out the Grand Concourse at the turn of the century, he wanted to create a boulevard as sweeping and spacious as the Champs-Elysees in Paris. In time, large apartment buildings lined the broad, curving avenue, complementing it with their extravagant facades, Art Deco designs and grandeur of scale. The Grand Concourse became the borough's most elegant residential thoroughfare, a Park Avenue of the Bronx.

title: RETURN OF THE MUTUAL FUNDS
description: A FTER the stock market's boom-and-bust cycle in the late 1960's, the aim of many disgruntled owners of equity mutual funds became ''to get out even.''

title: Van Sertima Wins Prize for Book on Africa; Van Sertima Wins $7,500 Book Prize
description: Ivan Van Sertima, a linguist and anthropologist, has won the 1981 Clarence L. Holte Prize for his book ''They Came Before Columbus.'' Published in 1976 by Random House, the book presents evidence that Africans sailed west to the Americas for trade and exploration 2,200 years before Columbus arrived.

title: ENERGY PUTS PRESSURE ON PRODUCER PRICES
description: Wholesale prices, as measured by the Producer Price Index, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, or at an annual rate of 9.6 percent. Rapidly rising energy costs pushed prices up while food costs fell, the Government said. The increase followed a gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent in January. Energy costs rose 3.6 percent, the fourth straight big monthly increase. They included a 6.5 percent jump in fuel oil prices and a 4.7 percent increase in gasoline costs at the wholesale level. The consumer foods index declined six-tenths of 1 percent in February after showing no change in January.

title: AMERICAN INDIAN REAL ESTATE
description: THE SECOND LONG WALK The Navajo-Hopi Land Dispute. By Jerry Kammer. Illustrated. 239 pp. Albuquerque, N.M.: University of New Mexico Press. $14.95.

title: TV View; EXIT CRONKITE, A CONSCIENTIOUS SUPERSTAR OF TV NEWS; by John J.O'Connor
description: It's official. Walter Cronkite is no longer the anchorman of the CBS Evening News. Tomorrow at 7, Dan Rather takes over the position. Mr. Cronkite, who turns 65 in November, has not retired. He will remain at CBS for several more years as a special correspondent and as the host of a new science series called ''Universe.'' But his depature from the daily news program has attracted enormous attention, prompting much talk about the end of an era. Tributes to ''Old Ironpants'' have been pouring in steadily, sometimes effusively. A UPI senior editor writes: ''It can be said of three men that, in their time as communicators, this nation hung on their words, waited in eager anticipation of what they were going to observe and report and treat in their special way - Mark Twain, Will Rogers and Walter Cronkite.'' In the past four months, Mr. Cronkite has been given 12 major awards, including the Presidential Medal of Freedom and an Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University special citation for ''continuing heroic service in informing the American public and maintaining the quality of broadcast journalism.''

title: Carpenter's Motive: Prod Other Owners
description: Ruly Carpenter said today that he was selling his world champion Philadelphia Phillies in the hope that baseball's owners and players would realize the ''never-ending vicious cycle'' of rising salaries and might decide: ''Hey, this is it.''

title: REAGAN STICKS TO AGENDA THAT WON HIM THE ELECTION
description: Arguments that President Reagan could create a second Vietnam in El Salvador or trigger a new Depression with untested economic theories do not get much attention at the White House these days. The President's advisers are convinced that his hardline anti-Communism and supply-side economics are sound policies and, beyond that, smart politics.

title: Depression Methods Recalled
description: IT may not be much consolation to car salesmen, but this is not the first time things have been bad in the automobile business. Nor is it the first time that new ideas have been needed to lure customers into domestic showrooms.

title: Reading and Writing; BRINGING BACK FATHER
description: In novels written by men, fathers and sons seem to go through cycles of affection and disaffection. In the 19th-century novel, fathers were moral landscapes. In the American novel between the 1950's and the early 70's, fathers shrank, as old men shrink in their bones. In a significant number of books of that period, fathers were oversimplified, caricatured or condescended to.

title: Abby Peyton Is Married To Dr. Timothy Howson
description: Abby Peyton of New York, an administrative aide at the Henry Krumb School of Mines at Columbia University, was married yesterday to Dr. Timothy E. Howson, a research associate at the school. Joseph Chuman of the Society of Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony at the Silvermine Tavern in Norwalk, Conn.

title:
Sports of the Times;
His Lordship and Friends
description: AN unprecedented 430 horses have been nominated for the Kentucky Derby, including 16 fillies. The latter figure is evidence that Genuine Risk has done more for women's lib among her species than Gloria Steinem among hers. Only 31 girl horses have tried the big heat in Louisville since the first Derby 106 years ago, and only two have won Regret in 1915 and Genuine Risk 65 years later.

title: Wishful Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: USING '80 CENSUS, SUFFOLK TO SHIFT DISTRICT LINES
description: MEMBERS of the Suffolk County Reapportionment Commission have privately pledged to deliver to the County Legislature by early May new district lines for the November elections for the County Legislature. The lines will reflect the 1980 census.

title: Bailey Symington To Be Wed in May To Ronald Hurley
description: Mr. and Mrs. Macduff Symington of Berwyn, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Grace Bailey Symington, to Ronald Alan Hurley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Hurley Jr. of Virginia Beach, Va.

title: Dresden
description: To the Editor:

title: DANGERS IN THE ATTACK ON ANTITRUST
description: Antitrust is in trouble. Around the turn of the century, a national consensus formed in favor of controlling monopoly power and preserving a competitive environment. The ''antitrust question'' all but disappeared from public view and became the special concern of a small group of lawyers and economists. Now antitrust is under sharp attack from left and right, and the survival and direction of antitrust enforcement is likely to be a lively political issue.

title: Conservation Vacations
description: The National Wildlife Federation, one of the nation's largest conservation-education organizations, conducts a series of vacations designed for the entire family each summer, but since the outings are open to the public and fill up fast, now is the time to make reservations.

title: J.S. Amling to Wed Cynthia Stautberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald J. Stautberg of Fallston, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia S. Stautberg, to Jeffrey S. Amling of New York, son of Dr. and Mr. Frederick Amling of Potomac, Md.

title: Heather Smith Will Be Bride
description: Heather Campbell Smith of New York, promotion manager at Alfred A. Knopf Inc., publishers, plans to be married in June to Jeffrey Michael Collins of New York, an assistant vice president and manager of the commodity news department at E.F. Hutton & Company.

title: EYESORE BUILDING: A LEGACY OF IMPASSE
description: A NESCONSET building that looks like something out of the South Bronx stands as a crumbling monument to an impasse among government, its neighbors and its owners.

title: A MUSEUM FOCUSES ON BELTER'S FURNITURE
description: Two decades after the revival of interest in John Henry Belter's furniture, his vehemently Victorian designs are the subject of the first major museum exhibition on his work. The show, ''John Henry Belter and the Rococo Revival,'' which opens Tuesday and runs through May 24 at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, 2 East 91st Street, presents a memorable assemblage of the riotously carved, exuberantly shaped furniture designs of the cabinetmaker who produced the finest and most innovative work in mid-19th-century America.

title: EL SALVADOR'S DANGEROUS FRIENDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Kate Edmondson Engaged to S. P. Gilmore
description: The engagement of Kate Huber Edmondson to Steven Preston Gilmore has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Edmondson of New York and New Milford, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. B. Preston Gilmore of Easton and New Preston, Conn., and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: A FREE SPIRIT
description: SHADOW WORK By Ivan Illich. 152 pp. Boston: Marion Boyars. Cloth, $15. Paper, $5.95.

title: MICHIGAN SEEKS TO CURB LOW MILITARY TRAINING FLIGHTS
description: Gov. William G. Milliken of Michigan has asked Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger to postpone some high-speed, low-level maneuvers by the Ohio Air National Guard over Michigan's woods and lakes.

title: AT CUNY, THE POLITICS ISN'T JUST ACADEMIC
description: In January 1979, three of the most important positions in the City University of New York became vacant when the presidents of Brooklyn, City and Hunter Colleges announced their retirements. A university official speculated at the time that, politically, their ideal replacements would be a white Jewish male for Brooklyn College, a white Catholic female for Hunter College and a black male for City College.

title: Blues Rout Rangers, Clinch Division Title
description: The Rangers, battling to reach a playoff berth from the lower reaches of the National Hockey League standings, stayed on even terms with the St. Louis Blues, the team atop the standings, for one period today. Then the Blues broke through for four goals in the second period, added three in the final period and routed the Rangers, 7-2, before 16,077 fans in the Checkerdome.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Music; MUSICAL CALENDAR SAYS SPRING IS NEAR
description: SPRING has not quite sprung, but there seems to be a renaissance of musical activity in Westchester, with an extraordinary array of important recitals, chamber performances and orchestral programs coming up.

title: AMERICAN HEROINES, AMERICAN LOVERS
description: PIONEER WOMEN Voices From the Kansas Frontier. By Joanna L. Stratton. Introduction by Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. Illustrated. 319 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: AT OREGON STATE, BASKETBALL IS PLEASING, NOT ALARMING
description: College professors are supposed to hate sports. One popular image has the stodgy academic jeopardizing the welfare of the school's football or basketball team by threatening to flunk the star player. Another version of faculty opposition to college sports is more serious. The eminent historian or physicist insists that the function of a university is to teach and do research, not to field championship athletic teams. He votes at Faculty Senate meetings to abolish athletics altogether.

title: Reflections on a Woman 'Immortal'
description: Deborah Trustman's article is a most sensitive portrait of Marguerite Yourcenar (''France's First Woman 'Immortal,' '' Jan. 18). Volker Schlondorff did a movie version of ''Coup de Grace''; it is a most subtle and sophisticated version and a work of art, which deserves wider circulation and which does much to enhance Marguerite Yourcenar's much deserved reputation. KARL-LUDWIG SELIG, Chairman, Interdepartmental Committee for Comparative Literature, Columbia University, New York City

title: The Careful Shopper; by Jeanne Clare Feron; Selection of Closeouts On Leather Goods
description: Gallery of Closeouts, on Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains, has discounted leather goods, soft luggage, desk accessories, jewelry and permanent-press tablecloths and placemats. There are the ubiquitous designer names on some accessories, umbrellas, belts and luggage. There are no seconds.

title: Sweat and Grind of Yank Spring Training
description: The players ran from home plate to second base and from second to home. They ran from first to third and home to third. They ran from home to home. See the Yankees run! Run, Yankees, run!

title: WHY WOMEN ARE PAID LESS THAN MEN
description: I N the 40 years from 1939 to 1979 white women who work full time have with monotonous regularity made slightly less than 60 percent as much as white men. Why?

title: WHEN HOME SELLERS ARE AT MERCY OF LINKED DEALS
description: Marcie and Joel Rudell are in their middle 30's. He is a partner in a small law firm, she has her own public-relations concern. Between them they earn almost $100,000 a year.

title:
Gardening;
FROM SEED TO PLANT TAKES KNOW-HOW
description: WHILE commercial greenhouses and garden centers are filled to the rafters with spring garden plants each year, many gardeners choose to start their own from seed.

title: Blowing Up Housing
description: Some communities fret about how to put up homes quickly. In New York City a major concern has been how to knock them down faster.

title: Katherine McCormack Fiancee
description: Dr. and Mrs. James E. McCormack of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Ann McCormack, to Theodore E. Kagy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Kagy of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The future bride is a graduate of Mount Holyoke College, and her fiance of Miami University in Ohio. They plan to be married in October. Dr. McCormack, a physician, is director of the New York Academy of Medicine. Mr. Kagy's father is a vice president of the Lang, Fisher, Stashower advertising agency in Cleveland.

title: DANCE: ARA FITZGERALD AND 2 BY YEATS
description: Making dances is hard enough, one would think, without adding the element of words. And having chosen to dance to William Butler Yeats, Ara Fitzgerald didn't stop at the ''Plays for Dancers'' the poet wrote some 65 years ago. A smidgeon of Noh-theater here, a little incantatory rapture there, and Miss Fitzgerald would have been ready to go. Instead, she and the composer Wall Matthews chose poems from Yeats's ''A Woman Young and Old'' and ''Words for Music Perhaps'' and presented them Friday at the American Theater Laboratory in a seamless collaboration of words, music and dance.

title: Mary Gale Scudder Fiancee of Eugene Doe
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wallace Scudder Jr. of Summit, N.J., and Lake Placid, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Gale Scudder, to Eugene Francis Doe.

title: Critics' Choice; by Peter G.Davis
description: Each week several Times critics will offer tips on attractions around town.

title: THE PHONE COMPANY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Martin Mayer's most recent book is ''The Fate of the Dollar.'' THE BIGGEST COMPANY ON EARTH A Profile of A.T.& T. By Sonny Kleinfield. 352 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $14.95. By MARTIN MAYER

title: Tina Lynn Gorovitz Affianced
description: The engagement of Tina Lynn Gorovitz to Richard Mark Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome H. Kaplan of Wayne, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Gorovitz, also of Wayne.

title: Emma Lathen
description: To the Business Editor: Like Carl D. Bernstein, who was quoted in ''Wall Street's Agatha Christie'' (Feb. 22), I too am a big fan of Emma Lathen books. Unlike Mr. Bernstein, I do not go around telling the ''who-dunnit'' endings of murder mysteries. Or perhaps the blame should fall on the The Times for printing the item. JOANNE HAYES

title: A DISCOVERY ON THE SHORES OF SPACE
description: OFTEN, I think back with longing to those very crisp, clear winter mornings in Oneonta, N.Y., where I went to college. The sun always seemed much brighter there somehow, just as the winters were colder and the springs greener. I think of the ways I grew up amid all that, making life simpler.

title: NEW SWISS SUBWAY LIFTS SKIERS TO SLOPES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- NIKKI ENGLISH is a writer based in London who has often skied in the Alps. By NIKKI ENGLISH

title: LAYTON OF PEOPLE'S TEMPLE WINS ROUND IN HIS FIGHT TO BE CLEARED
description: A Federal appeals court, rebuffing the Government, has agreed to hear a request that murder-conspiracy charges against Larry Layton, a former People's Temple member, be dismissed. Oral arguments were set for April 9 in Los Angeles. The 34-year-old Mr. Layton has been indicted by a Federal grand jury for conspiracy to kill Representative Leo Ryan in 1978 at the jungle airstrip in Guyana near the People's Temple commune at Jonestown.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: EL SALVADOR'S DANGEROUS FRIENDS
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN WIGEON; Anas americana
description: Size: 21 inches. Color: Brownish body, grayish neck. Male (shown) has conspicuous white crown and wing patch.

title: Louisville 42, Cincinnati 31
description: Derek Smith and Lancaster Gordon scored all but 2 of Louisville's 20 second-half points today as the Cardinals defeated Cincinnati, 42-31, in the championship game of the Metro Conference tournament. The victory gave Louisville a berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament, which it won last March.

title: APPEALS TO WALLET AND APPETITE
description: BEDFORD HILLS FUND raising, often an arduous chore, is the domain of volunteers who are constantly searching for innovative ways to encourage contributions. Several groups in northern Westchester have combined an appeal to the palate with an appeal to the pocketbook, succesfully using food-related projects to raise money.

title: Issue and Debate; THE NEW 'LOFT POLICY': A SWEEPING CHANGE NEARS FINAL TEST
description: For the last several years, the city's and state's housing and building regulations have been ignored blatently in loft neighborhoods as people have moved into commercial buildings to live. The result has been a chaotic legal situation that has defied planning principles and the city's official zoning philosophies.

title:
Antiques;
LOOKING-GLASS HISTORY
description: HARTFORD A DISPLAY of looking glasses used or made here from about 1750 through the 1860's -probably the only such exhibit ever set up in this country - is on view at the Connecticut Historical Society, 1 Elizabeth Street. Of even greater importance to Connecticut collectors is the fact that all of the 27 examples shown were made in Hartford or were owned by Connecticut families.

title: BUILDING PICKUP REOPENS THE ISSUE OF HARASSMENT
description: ''The nature of the marketplace creates an elemental antipathy between landlord and tenant.'' - Judge Elliott Wilk, in a decision handed down recently in Civil Court in Manhattan.

title: Triple-B'd
description: Standard and Poor's, the bond rating people, have welcomed New York City back from five years in fiscal exile. The raters have given the city's long-term bonds an ''investment-grade'' rating, meaning you can buy them and expect to be paid principal and interest on time.

title:
Gardening;
FROM SEED TO PLANT TAKES KNOW-HOW
description: WHILE commercial greenhouses and garden centers are filled to the rafters with spring garden plants each year, many gardeners choose to start their own from seed.

title: SIMPLICITY OF LINE AND A BRITISH CLUTTER
description: THE SITUATION IS HOPELESS By Ronald Searle. Illustrated. Unpaginated. New York: A Studio Book/The Viking Press. $12.95.

title: Nuggets 121, Pistons 109
description: Dan Issel scored a total of 30 points, 20 in the first half, in leading the Denver victory over Detroit. Denver held a 60-52 halftime advantage, but Detroit, sparked by 6 points apiece from Larry Wright and Terry Tyler, pulled into a 70-70 deadlock with 8:17 left in the third period.

title:
Film View;
CAN ANYBODY OUT THERE SPARE A FEW ANSWERS?
description: This may be heresy, especially to acknowledge in public, but movie critics do not know everything. To go even further, it's probably correct to say that they know a lot less about a number of particular subjects than many of their readers, though it's obligatory that they affect a positive tone, which, if not omniscient, implies that what they don't know isn't worth going into. The following questions are not a test but a brisk run-down of some of the things that have recently been bothering me - questions for which I don't have the answers but subjects about which I'm genuinely curious. There may be no conclusive answers to some of them. Others, conceivably, might be answered by searching in the right telephone book. Responses will be appreciated.

title: BOSLEY CROWTHER, 27 YEARS A CRITIC OF FILMS FOR TIMES, IS DEAD AT 75
description: Bosley Crowther, the film critic of The New York Times from 1940 to 1967 and for many years one of the nation's most powerful and respected voices on the cinema, died of heart failure yesterday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.

title: Rosamond Grant, Teacher, Engaged
description: The engagement of Rosamond Williams Grant to Jonathan Gautier Witherbee, son of John H. Witherbee of Avon, Conn., and the late Mrs. Witherbee, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Grant of Dedham, Mass.

title: FOR SOME,THE FIRST SIGN OF SPRING
description: WENDELL STICKNEY squinted into the sun and adjusted his battered red-and-white checkered hat as yet another group of youngsters and their parents gathered around a red maple tree to watch his treetapping demonstration last Sunday at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center.

title: ITALIAN COMMUNISTS NEVER HAVE A NICE DAY
description: Rome has had two major transit strikes recently. One, ten days ago, was a wildcat called by a local action committee; it tied up traffic for a day as bus drivers and tramway conductors stayed home almost to a man. The second, last week, was called by the three national labor federations; it was observed by white collar workers but, except during the morning rush, many buses kept running.

title: Speaking Personally; FOR SALE: REMNANTS, SLIGHTLY USED, OF A LIFE TOGETHER
description: IT WAS a neighborhood of opulent homes, the kind with a stainedglass transom over the front door and long windows and split-rail fences to define the acres they stood on. Expensive.

title: Stamps; NEW GUIDE PUBLISHED FOR TOPICAL COLLECTORS; by Samuel A.Tower
description: The most rapidly growing facet of philately is topical collecting, as the ever-increasing number of countries has turned the world of stamps into a universe, and as the ever-increasing cost of stamps has propelled the hobby into the reaches of outer space.

title: Philadelphia
description: To the Editor:

title: 'GOT IT!' PROGRAM FAILS TO GET IT IN BYRNE'S PROPOSED BUDGET
description: TRENTON WHEN it came to putting more money in Governor Byrne's proposed budget for the next fiscal year, the ''New Jersey's Got It!'' program didn't get it.

title: THE SAVINGS BANK: DEEP IN THE RED
description: It is intended to furnish a secure place of deposit for the savings of Mechanics, Manufacturers, Mantua-makers, Cartmen, Seamen, Laborers; in short, of all who wish to lay up a fund for sickness, for the wants of a family or for old age. - Founding statement, The Bank for Savings, June 1819

title:
Gardening;
FROM SEED TO PLANT TAKES KNOW-HOW
description: WHILE commercial greenhouses and garden centers are filled to the rafters with spring garden plants each year, many gardeners choose to start their own from seed.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT CNAUCKS, 3-1
description: Nearly every Islander agreed that tonight's game against the Vancouver Canucks had been a grinding, defensive struggle. Until the third period, only two goals had been scored, one for each team, and some of the fans at Nassau Coliseum were even seen yawning.

title: THE STOICS AND TRUDGERS
description: AMERICAN ROSE By Julia Markus. 303 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $11.95.

title: THE ARTS IN EDUCATION
description: THE ''arts,'' according to Roger Kennedy, director of the Smithsonian's Museum of American History, are ''the application of craft to the expression of feeling.''

title: Martha Grace McCurdy a Bride
description: The marriage of Martha Grace McCurdy, daughter of Mrs. Joseph R. McCurdy of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. McCurdy, to Warren Carl Moran Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Moran of Wilmington, Del., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in Hartsdale, N.Y. Msgr. James M. Connolly and the Rev. Dr. Olin J. Shockley, a Methodist minister of Wilmington, performed the ceremony. The bride is a national sales manager for KTRK-TV in Houston, where her husband is an account executive with the marketing services division of Dun & Bradstreet.

title: A SCHOOL IN A CLASS BY ITSELF
description: PISCATAWAY ''I'M WELL, my friends. You are not responsible. I'm innocent. Long live the Modern School!'' So shouted Francisco Ferrer, the Spanish educator and martyr, as he faced execution by a firing squad in Barcelona in 1909 for plotting to assassinate the King of Spain.

title: Churchill
description: To the Editor:

title: Escaped Convicts With Girl Sought in Hills of Arkansas
description: State police officers and sheriff's deputies today took four-wheel drive vehicles, bloodhounds and horses into a mountainous region of northwest Arkansas in search of three escaped convicts and an 11-year-old girl.

title: W.H. AUDEN: ODE TO THE GEORGE WASHINGTON HOTEL
description: On Jan. 26, 1939, two literary emigrants from England, W.H. Auden and Christopher Isherwood, arrived in New York and took rooms at the George Washington Hotel. Soon Auden was telling friends, ''I adore New York'' - unlike Isherwood, who lost little time before moving to southern California. Auden found the sturdy unostentatious comfort of the George Washington one of the city's main attractions. When Benjamin Britten was planning to visit America in June 1939, Auden told him: ''Anyway, when you come to N.Y. stay at the Hotel George Washington corner of 23rd Street and Lexington Avenue. It's much the nicest hotel in town and the manager Mr. Donald Neville-Willing (and don't forget the hyphen) is expecting you. There is a good piano.''

title: Long Islanders; A VARIED AD CAREER TAKES A SALTY TWIST
description: IF Norman Gladney of Manhasset were the sort of man content to rest on his laurels, then he might be willing to go down in history as the self-proclaimed originator of the watch torture test.

title: MUSIC: CALLIOPE SINGERS
description: The New Calliope Singers' ''Sixth Annual Recital of Choral Chamber Music'' on Friday night at Alice Tully Hall won no prizes for stylistic coherence - the music ranged gleefully from Billings to Gibbons to Russell Pinkston to Marga Richter to Hindemith to Brahms to Bartok to Monteverdi to Maurice Wright. But the nature of the choral medium imposed a certain unity to the evening, and the general excellence of the performances under Peter Schubert's direction kept things buoyant.

title:
Dining Out;
WELL-KNOWN SWISS DISHES OFTEN BEST
description: SINCE it opened eight years ago, Gipfel's in White Plains (which no longer has any affiliation with Gipfel's in Rye) has been a popular place that serves good stick-to-the-ribs food in an atmosphere of European welcome. Wood and brick walls, flashes of copper and brass, ample tables, amiable Swiss waitresses in redbodiced peasant dress and an impressive Alpine photomural above the bar make the restaurant an agreeable refuge from the bustle of Mamaroneck Avenue outside.

title: Laughable Notion
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN IT'S MAN,WOMAN AND DOG
description: IT should have been a wonderful time. He had just landed a juicy, jump-up-the-ladder writing job in Manhattan. We were moving up, and in toward the city.

title: by James Lieber
description: Behind the revolution in American sentencing - the taking of discretionary power away from judges and, in effect, turning it over to state legislatures - lay a general concern abount inequalitites of punishment.

title: Physician Is Appointed As Columbia's Provost
description: The deputy director for science at the National Institutes of Health has been appointed provost and vice president for health services at Columbia University by the university's trustees. The new provost, Dr. Robert Frank Goldberger, will assume the posts July 1.

title: SUNDAY, MARCH 8, 1981
description: International More military aid for the Middle East, including Persian Gulf, is planned by the Administration to build up security in those areas. Officials said a formal announcement as expected to be made this week. (Page 1, Column 6.) West Germany plans to cancel or delay several military programs because the financing is not available, Defense Minister Hans Apel announced. ''There are enormous difficulties facing us,'' he said at a news conference after a three-day meeting in Bonn between West German generals and other experts on military development programs. He said the Defense Ministry's nominal share of the national budget would decline from 18 to 16 percent by 1984. (1:5.)

title: 'NO ONE MENTIONED AL LOWENSTEIN'
description: A YEAR ago, former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein was fatally shot in his Manhattan law offices. Several months after his death, members of my Oceanside Senior High School class, torn and sorely divided 10 years earlier by a political battle involving Representative Lowenstein, met for their first reunion.

title: AN OHIO FAMILY'S STRUGGLE TO SURVIVE IS CLOUDED BY PLAN TO CUT FOOD STAMPS
description: This is one of a series of occasional articles that will follow one program the Reagan Administration wants to cut - food stamps - through the legislative process.

title: A SOPRANO'S ARDUOUS JOURNEY TO A CAREER
description: On one side of a shabby gold curtain in a Manhattan hotel suite the Santa Fe Opera company is holding auditions for summer apprenticeships. On the other side, Lauren Wagner, a young soprano, waits for her turn in her best dress and high-heeled shoes.

title: THE SECOND, SECULAR LIVES OF 2-CAREER CLERGYMEN
description: FIVE days a week, Robert Bugbee of the Sussex County community of Hopatcong heads for the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan, where he is director of the School of Radiologic Technology. On Sundays, however, he trades in his white laboratory coat for the clerical garb of a ''circuit-rider preacher'' at Presbyterian churches in northwestern New Jersey.

title: Dr. Diana Bianchi To Be Wed in Fall
description: Doris Balin Bianchi of Manhattan and Mahopac, N.Y., and Carlo Bianchi of Oakland, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Diana Willa Bianchi, to Dr. Timothy F. Beckett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Beckett of Trumbull, Conn.

title: MOSCOW
description: Ivan Goncharov is one of those novelists who is remembered, at least by the public at large, for one character and one character only. Goncharov, a contemporary of Dostoyevsky, created in the eponymous hero of his novel ''Oblomov'' an archetype of the man with no real role in life. Paralyzed by self-doubt, dithering and dreaming, often too trapped by inertia to rise from his bed, he fritters away every opportunity afforded him, whether professional, financial or romantic.

title: RAPID STRIKE FORCE A WEAK LINK IN PLANS
description: IN assembling proposals for the CX, a new long-range transport plane, the Lockheed-Georgia Company and the Boeing Company each spent more than $40 million and employed more than 500 workers to submit thousands of documents.

title: Pennsylvania 76, Columbia 71
description: George Noon and Dave Lardner each scored 14 points as Pennsylvania held off Columbia today for a 76-71 victory in an Ivy League game.

title:
Art;
FAMILY VIEW OF EARLY ROCKLAND
description: AN altogether beguiling exhibition is on view at the Historical Society of Rockland County in New City this spring. Entitled ''The Historic Charm of Rockland County,'' the show is focused on 19thcentury views of the region as well as on 20th-century portrayals of its historic sites.

title: Sahomi Tachibana to Mark 50 Years as a Dancer
description: Sahomi Tachibana will mark her 50th anniversary as a Japanese classical dancer with performances March 19-21 at the Theater of the Open Eye, 316 East 88th Street.

title: by Barbara Delatiner; ST. PATRICK'S CELEBRATION
description: Apparently, it's never too early to mark St. Patrick's Day. So, more than a week before the event - perhaps to get everyone in the proper frame of mind - we will have a rash of programs celebrating the Irish this week. For example, today at 2:30 P.M. at the Shelter Rock Public Library, 165 Searingtown Road in Albertson, the actress Shirley Blanc Romaine will offer ''The Crock of Gold'' - readings of Irish literary gems by such writers as James Joyce, Sean O'Casey, W.B. Yeats and George Bernard Shaw. The program is free.

title: Bridgeman Delivers as Bucks' Swingman
description: Ulysses Lee Bridgeman is a name that will someday be on the door of a law firm. But now Junior Bridgeman is known by many as the best sixth man in basktball.

title: Churchill
description: To the Editor:

title: Ipswich, Nottingham Tie on Goal by Thijssen
description: Frans Thijssen, a Dutch soccer star, scored the equalizer today as Ipswich tied Nottingham Forest, 3-3, in an English Cup quarterfinal match and stayed in contention for three major soccer titles.

title: L.I. SCHOOLS PRESS EFFORT TO AVERT A BOOK-BAN TRIAL
description: A school district in Nassau County plans to continue its fight to avert a trial over the removal of nine books from school libraries. The books, including several by well-known authors, were removed in 1976 by the Island Trees Union Free School District in the Town of Hempstead. The school board said they contained offensive and vulgar material, but some parents sued the board and obtained a ruling requiring a trial.

title: Hughes Estate Is Valued At $460 Million by I.R.S.
description: Howard Hughes, long believed to have been a billionaire, actually left an estate valued at $460 million by the Internal Revenue Service, it was reported today.

title: GALLUP POLL REPORTS MORE PEOPLE ARE IDENTIFYING WITH THE G.O.P.
description: More Americans now call themselves Republicans than at any time in the last nine years, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Pressure Test for; Spain's New Leader
description: The second week in office of Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo, sworn in as Spanish Prime Minister after a thwarted military coup, was not much calmer.

title: David Krieger, Cellist Trained in Israel
description: David Krieger played the cello with fire, spirit and a dashing impetuosity in Carnegie Hall on Friday night. He complemented his strikingly physical response to the instrument with some arresting and persuasive ideas about a fairly standard program from the cellist's repertory, including sonatas by Debussy, Brahms (Op. 38) and Beethoven (Op. 102, No. 1), as well as Schumann's ''Fantasy Pieces'' (Op. 73) and a Couperin suite.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Society Has Its; Own Debt to Pay; - To the Prisons
description: If more people are going to be imprisoned because of crackdowns on crime, it seems obvious that there must be more prisons to hold them. Obvious or not, recent legal actions involving prison overcrowding indicate that this corollary is widely ignored.

title: J.F. Tomlin to Wed Eliza Frazer in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Gilfillan Frazer Jr. of Sewickley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eliza Halliday Frazer, to John Frederick Tomlin, son of Henry B. Tomlin of Greenville, S.C., and the late Elsa Ludtke Tomlin. A July wedding in Ligonier, Pa., is planned.

title: Critics' Choice
description: THEATER It's always fun to watch an otherwise serious actress step out and have a high time in a comedy. That's what Roberta Maxwell (''Equus,'' ''Ashes'') is doing right now, in the title role of ''Mary Stuart'' at the Public Theater.

title: Connecticut Guide; by Eleanor Charles; EXPLORER TO TALK
description: Dr. Bradford Washburn, 71-year-old head of the Boston Museum of Science and a noted explorer-cartographer, will describe five years in the 1970's when he mapped the 100 square miles of the Grand Canyon by laser, donkey and helicopter at 7:30 this evening in New Canaan High School.

title: North Stars 8, Penguins 5
description: Third-period power-play goals by defensemen, Craig Hartsburg and Gordie Roberts, gave Minnesota its first victory in seven games and ended a Pittsburgh winning streak at six.

title: FUNDS ASKED FOR SITES TO CONTAIN VIOLENT PATIENTS
description: Finding that young men who are ''assaultive and difficult to manage'' now account for one of every 16 new admissions to state psychiatric hospitals, the state's Mental Health Commissioner has asked the Legislature for $4.5 million to establish secure wards to hold these violent patients.

title: Politics; G.O.P. LAYS PLANS FOR 1982 CAMPAIGN
description: HARTFORD THERE may be 20 months to go before Connecticut elects a Governor again, but the first stirrings of the campaign have already begun, especially on the Republican side.

title: Elizabeth Marran Bride Of Kimball Hull, Lawyer
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Ann Marran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Marran of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., to Kimball Erskine Clement Hull, son of Rear Adm. Harry Hull, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Hull of Manchester, Mass., took place yesterday.

title: NEW HANDICAP PLAN IS PROPOSED FOR GOLF
description: By JOHN RADOSTA Golf handicaps theoretically assure a close match between any two players and in four-ball matches. Ostensibly they assure equitable competition in tournaments. Most golfers know they do not work that way.

title: THE U.S. WAGE WOES
description: Increases in hourly wage rates among manufacturing workers in industrialized countries outpaced rises in the cost of living during the 1970's, according to a recent Citibank analysis of gross pay rates and employer contributions to Social Security and other employee benefit programs. Since tax and benefit systems vary so widely from country to country, estimates of take-home pay were not attempted.

title: Laurie Laurenson Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Laurenson of Brookfield, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Marie Laurenson, to Robert Alvin Brooks, son of Harold Brooks of Astoria, Queens, and the late Mrs. Brooks. A June wedding is planned.

title: Crime; by Newgate Callender
description: The fifth Janice Law mystery featuring private eye Anna Peters is DEATH UNDER PAR (Houghton Mifflin, $9.95). Now married to Harry Radford, who has appeared in her previous adventures, she is with him in Scotland, where he is doing a series of drawings of the British Open for a news magazine. But somebody is vandalizing the course, a brilliant young American player has received a note threatening him with murder if he competes, and the organizers of the Open call Miss Peters into action.

title: No Headline
description: In his article on the future of the Democratic Party, Tom Wicker quoted extensively such party leaders as Walter Mondale and Gary Hart. For some reason, however, Mr. Wicker failed to include a single statement by the man whom many of us Democrats consider our real spokesman - Senator Edward Kennedy. JOHN ADAMS, Somerset, N.J.

title: SYRACUSE BEATS VILLANOVA IN 3 OVERTIMES FOR CROWN
description: Leo Rautins was 11 years old in 1972 when he underwent back surgery and was told he might never walk again. But Rautins, a 6-foot-8-inch native of Toronto, who said he never really believed that, has come a long way. He scored a basket today with three seconds left in the third overtime period that enabled Syracuse to beat Villanova, 83-80, in the final of the Big East Conference playoffs.

title: PHIL MAHRE DEFEATS STENMARK
description: Phil Mahre of the United States, coming from behind on the second run of the day, scored a rare giant slalom victory today over Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden in World Cup skiing competition on Aspen Mountain.

title: SMALL COMPANY RISES IN TELEPHONY
description: SHELTON A COMPANY founded 10 years ago in a garage in Greenwich now carries a value on the stock market of $125 million. The concern, TIE Communications Inc., which makes and sells sophisticated telephone systems for small businesses, already accounts for several hundred jobs in the long-depressed Naugatuck Valley. And while TIE's future is not without significant risks, expansions already under way in Shelton will create dozens of new jobs this year alone.

title: A Vanguard of Warhorses
description: In a fitting finale to the Soviet Union's 26th and least revolutionary Communist Party Congress, the leadership last week reelected itself, intact, for five more years. No delegate said out loud what many must have been thinking - that Leonid I. Brezhnev, 74, and the 13 other full Politburo members, average age 69, all may not live out their terms.

title: Peter Tarnoff, Donna Driscoll Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. George T. Padula of Milton, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Padula's daughter, Donna Marie Driscoll, to Peter Tarnoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Tarnoff of Norwalk, Conn.

title: Art Sampler
description: LEONARDO'S faces of madonnas, saints and fashionable Renaissance ladies may seem a bit treacly to some, but there's no doubt he was one of the greatest artistic geniuses and produced some of the world's most important paintings and drawings.

title: Roy Stillman Is the Fiance Of Jane Rush
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. Gross of Greenwich, Conn., and Deal, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Gross's daughter, Jane Rush, to Roy Allan Stillman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Stillman of Rye, N.Y., and Lake Worth, Fla. The wedding will take place this month.

title: Older Executives
description: To the Business Editor:

title: City Schools Win Cash For Attendance Gains
description: In an effort to increase attendance in city schools, Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola announced yesterday that 78 schools with the highest or most improved attendance records would receive cash awards.

title: Frank Zappa to Take Part In April 17 Varese Tribute
description: Frank Zappa, the American pop composer and singer, will join in a ''Musical Tribute to Edgard Varese'' at the Palladium on April 17. He will offer a reminiscence and appreciation of the late composer, whom Mr. Zappa has called ''the idol of my youth.''

title: SMOKING AND GUILT
description: WHENEVER Helen Lefor took out a cigarette in recent months, her husband, Arnold, would say: ''Do you realize what you're doing to me? You might be giving me emphysema! Would you please go outside to smoke.''

title: Muhammad to Fight
description: Eddie Mustafa Muhammad, the World Boxong Association light-heavyweight champion, has agreed to a title fight against Murray Sutherland, the promoter Art Dore said. The time and place of the bout have not been set, but Dore, who has promoted many of Sutherland's fights, said it would be held before May 30, probably in Atlantic City, The Detroit Free Press reported in today's editions. Sutherland, 26 years old, of Bay City, Mich., has a 30-3 record with 27 knockouts as a pro.

title: News Analysis
description: Figures from the 1980 Census showing the nation's rural areas to be growing faster than cities or suburbs, in a reversal of a 160-year trend of migration to urban areas, point up an emergent national issue that many authorities consider basic to the kind of nation this will become in the decades ahead.

title: L.I.U. Savors First N.C.A.A. Bid
description: Long Island University has qualified for the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament for the first time. The Blackbirds (18-10) will play Virginia Commonwealth (23-4), champion of the Sun Belt Conference, Friday night in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Red Smith;  The Boys Of Spring
description: THIS is the time of year when the Happiness Boys live it up in the sunshine, when every jeweled day is a joy and the future is golden for 26 baseball teams and 26 managers, when 20 million fans eagerly look ahead to the opening of another season and the goose hangs high in the national pastime.

title: Haig's Connecticut Home Picketed by 35 Protesters
description: Singing ''We Shall Overcome'' and carrying placards, about 35 opponents of United States involvement in El Salvador marched today in front of the home of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: FOOD SHORTAGES IN RUMANIA REPORTED TO SET OFF PROTESTS BY WORKERS
description: Rumania, a land fabled as the breadbasket of the Balkans, is experiencing difficulties in providing enough food for its inhabitants, a situation that has provoked factory strikes and demonstrations, according to reports reaching here.

title: NICARAGUA AT THE CROSSROADS: U.S. IS FORCING A CHOICE
description: The crisis in Nicaragua's relations with the United States over alleged arms shipments to El Salvador appears to have confronted the Sandinist Government with the choice of moderating or radicalizing its domestic and foreign policies.

title: Advertising Agencies Aroused by Cable Talk
description: IF it did nothing else, the First National Conference on Advertising on Cable TV at the New York Hilton last week demonstrated that Madison Avenue's interest in the medium is more than just talk.

title: A FITTING WAR OF WORDS
description: They are each thought to be absolute wizards with words, and last year, as more than 100 of them gathered for the third annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament at the Marriott Hotel here, one of the hotel managers got up to explain a few housekeeping rules.

title: THE STANDARD SCENARIO FOR AFRICAN FAMINE
description: The news report was familiar. More than 150 million Africans faced famine, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said last September. What could prevent such a disaster? Wealthy Western nations must provide ''massive emergency shipments of cereal by the end of the year,'' the F.A.O. was quoted as having said.

title: QUEENS PARENTS ENDING BOYCOTT AT 2 of 3 SCHOOLS
description: Saying that they had succeeded in highlighting problems of security and overcrowding, leaders of a five-week-old school boycott in Rosedale, Queens, yesterday called off the action at two of three schools. They also hinted that the boycott might end at the third school as well.

title: U.S. PULLS OUT CUP VICTORY, 3-2
description: Always in command, John McEnroe eased the United States into the quarterfinals of this year's Davis Cup tennis competition today by defeating MexRaul Ramirez of Mexico, 6-4, 6-3, 6-0, in the decisive fifth match of the opening round.

title: DANIEL SCHREIBER, 71, EDUCATOR WHO WORKED WITH POOR YOUTHS
description: Daniel Schreiber, former assistant superintendent of the New York City Office of Junior High and Intermediate Schools, died Friday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 71 years old.

title: Mary-Kathleen Smith Bride
description: Mary-Kathleen Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Smith Jr., was married at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Atlantic Highlands, N.J., yesterday to Robert Stuart Palamara. He is the son of Mrs. Gerard Palamara and the late Mr. Palamara. Both families are of Highlands, N.J. The Rev. Felix Venza performed the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Pope Marks Women's Day As Marchers Back Abortion

title: 250 Workers to Get $305,000 From Westinghouse in Suit
description: A Federal judge here has approved a $305,000 settlement for about 250 employees of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation who charged that the company's maternity leave policy discriminated against them.

title: Sporting Gear; Multipurpose Exercise Computer
description: The Genesis Exercise Computer is a compact, three-ounce device that is strapped to the wrist like a watch and has a variety of functions. It can be programmed for minimum, maximum and resting pulse rates, and it will automatically signal when the upper or lower limits are violated. A sensor that attaches to any finger on the hand wearing the device supplies the necessary data. The computer also can be used as an exercise timer and to read recovery time from strenuous exercise. A variable speed metronome offers a steady tone for pacing. Finally, the computer, manufactured by Biometrics Inc. of Minneapolis, can be turned into a watch simply by pressing two buttons. The computer, including complete directions, sells for $160 at Macy's Herald Square.

title: Kite Rallies on 2 Birdies, Beats Nicklaus by Stroke
description: Tom Kite birdied two of the last three holes to beat Jack Nicklaus by a stroke today in the American Motors Inverrary golf tournament.

title: 3 Prison Escapees Surrender To Farmer in Arkansas
description: Three escapees from the Washington State Prison surrendered to a farmer here today, giving up a sevenweek flight that ended with pursuit by 200 officers using four-wheeldrive vehicles, planes, bloodhounds and horses in a rugged area of Arkansas.

title: TRACK TITLE TO TERPS
description: Villanova's four-year reign as IC4A indoor track and field champion ended today, with Maryland winning the title and the Wildcats finishing third behind Fairleigh Dickinson. The Terrapins gave their new head coach, Stan Pitts, extra cause to celebrate his 42d birthday with a sparkling team effort.

title: ROCK DEBUT: TEARDROP
description: TWO Liverpool rock bands - the Teardrop Explodes and Echo and the Bunnymen - have recently been publicized as spearheading a musical ''renaissance'' from the birthplace of Beatlemania. The style of both bands also owes a good deal to mid-1960's ''Psychedelic'' bands like the Doors and also to the more primitive American garage bands of the era.

title: FLORIANA INTERVIEWS CHIA-CHIA; by William Safire
description: Floriana Fallacy, the intrepid interviewer bidding fair to become the Italian Barbara Walters, scooped the world yet again with her intimate colloquy with Chia-Chia, the giant panda sent to Washington from the London Zoo this week. Chia-Chia's not-sosecret mission is to impregnate Ling-Ling, gift to the United States on the occasion of a Presidential trip to China, who has so far resisted the feeble advances of Hsing-Hsing, her assigned mate, thereby ruining the National Zoo's dream of being first to breed and raise a baby giant panda. The transcript of Ms. Fallacy's exclusive interview: *

title: JERSEY REACTOR CREATES TAX GAINS AND RADIOACTIVE WASTE PROBLEM
description: In the dozen years since the nation's second-largest nuclear power station began moving in next door, Lower Alloways Creek Township and some of its Salem County neighbors have been showered with $45 million in tax revenues. But amid this largesse, which includes several thousand jobs, the 1,400 townspeople find something unwelcome emanating from the reactor - radioactive waste.

title: Somalis, Facing Famine, Issue an Appeal for Food
description: The Government of droughtstricken Somalia made an international appeal today for nearly half a million tons of food to meet projected shortfalls for 1981.

title: Rosenfeld Agency Has A Winner and a Loser
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson had a hit and a miss last week.

title: CONCERT:WARSAW CASTLE PLAYERS PRESENT MUSIC BY COUNTRYMEN
description: AT least one listener yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall was wary when Lucjan Kydrynski, a master of ceremonies, came on stage speaking rapid Polish; he was more wary when Cezary Owerkowicz lighted a candle on his piano before beginning a performance of Chopin's ''Rondo a la Krakowiak.'' Differences in language and taste have, after all, frustrated many a concertgoer.

title: Monday, March 9, 1981
description: THE ECONOMY

title: STAGE: JOSEPH CHAIKIN'S BECKETT SOLO
description: A HEAD with a curly corona of hair rises like the sun over a hillock. With a startled look, the face searches the landscape - a boardwalk zigzagging over a mountaintop - then seems to pull its body into view. Standing erect, the man continues his endless journey through a strange ''inextricable place.'' In ''Texts, '' adapted by Joseph Chaikin and Steven Kent from Samuel Beckett's ''Texts for Nothing,'' combined with an excerpt from ''How It Is,'' Mr. Chaikin is our witness on an interior adventure, a quest for identity, for locus, as man inches from birth to death.

title: French Singer Dedicates Royalties to Unicef
description: He's a French singer who two years ago became the first Jewish entertainer in 30 years to perform in public in Egypt. Now Enrico Macias is giving an international air - literally and figuratively - to Unicef, the children's aid organization.

title: Debra Turkat Is Married To Stephen Friedlander
description: Debra Turkat, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Miles I. Turkat of Fresh Meadows, Queens, was married at the Hillcrest Jewish Center in Jamaica Estates, Queens, yesterday to Stephen Friedlander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Friedlander of Oklahoma City. Rabbi Israel Moshowitz performed the ceremony.

title: OPPOSITION TO MX MISSILE GAINS STRENGTH IN CAPITAL
description: A groundswell of state and regional opposition to the MX mobile missile system is rolling into Washington to add to the complexity of what is likely to be the most difficult military decision the Reagan Administration plans to make this year.

title: Reaching New Peaks
description: As a basketball player, Ralph Drollinger has literally been a follower of Bill Walton. Drollinger was a high school sophomore when Walton was a senior at a rival high school in La Mesa, Calif., and Drollinger likes to tell the story of how he scored 12 points against the schoolboy all-American who was about to become a college star at U.C.L.A. Drollinger jokingly says, ''We usually don't like to tell people how our team lost, 104-48.''

title: CHALLENGE TO THE WHITE, MALE LEGAL ESTABLISHMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Exxon Finds Gas
description: The Exxon Company, U.S.A., a division of the Exxon Corporation, reported a natural gas discovery in the Gulf of Mexico, 51 miles east of Corpus Christi, Tex.

title: DONOVAN'S RASH DECISION ON HAZARDOUS CHEMICALS
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain Frees 80 Who Tried To Take Over Parliament
description: About 80 of the 150 Civil Guards who stormed the Spanish Parliament in an attempted coup two weeks ago have been released, Spanish newspapers reported today.

title: TV GAMBLE: HIGH SALARIES VS. LOW RATINGS
description: LOS ANGELES THE other actors on ''Three's Company'' were off rehearsing. But on a recent weekday afternoon Suzanne Somers sat in the sun-filled living room of her seven-level house overlooking the Pacific Ocean and tried to explain why she has virtually disappeared from the hit ABC-TV comedy series that started her to stardom four years ago.

title: Abbey Bluestein, Teacher, Married to Marc Reisman
description: Abbey Bluestein, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sanfurd Bluestein of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married there yesterday to Marc Reisman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Reisman of Lederdorp, the Netherlands.

title: REAGAN BUDGET LIFTS CONNECTICUT HOPES
description: While President Reagan's plan to cut Federal spending has aroused much concern in the Northeast, there is one state that stands to gain: Connecticut, which will benefit from the President's proposal to increase defense expenditures.

title: Jury Bars Indictment In Crash Fatal to 3
description: An Oneida County grand jury has rejected criminal charges against a 34-year-old Utica man who was arrested Feb. 7 after his car swerved into a group of Orthodox Jewish students, fatally injuring three of them.

title: COMPTROLLER GENERAL REVIEWS HIS TENURE
description: When Elmer B. Staats became Comptroller General of the United States on March 8, 1966, accountants made up 96 percent of his professional staff. When he retired last Friday, half of his staff consisted of lawyers, economists, engineers and computer specialists.

title: CRITICS OF THE MONEY FUNDS
description: Ten years ago they did not even exist. Today, money market funds have become a financial way of life for millions of Americans, many of whom had never before thought in terms of investment.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE;
description: She's had to wait a while, but Carol Burnett is expected to get her day in court this week in her $10 million libel suit against The National Enquirer.

title: MUSIC: HANDY'S NIGHT, 50 YEARS LATER
description: WHEN W.C. Handy, who wrote ''St. Louis Blues,'' brought to Carnegie Hall on April 28, 1928, a program of what was known then as Negro music - the first evening of black music presented in this bastion of white classical music - the white influence on black composers and performers was still dominant. In fact, Mr. Handy's fame was a consequence of this. Despite his identity as ''the Father of the Blues,'' he did not invent the blues. His role was to gather and, for the first time, put in written form what had been a black oral music, thus making it available and acceptable to whites.

title: Celtics Use Muscle and Height To Overwhelm Knicks, 115-94
description: The Knicks took their usual pounding from the Boston Celtic front line today. This time they did not fight back. With Larry Bird, Robert Parish, Cedric Maxwell, Kevin McHale and Rick Robey dominating the game, especially in the second half, the Celtics scored an overwhelming 115-94 victory at Boston Garden.

title: New Publisher at The Dial
description: Having cut his magazine-publishing teeth working in ad sales, management and marketing at Esquire and Sports Illustrated, Richard B. Barthelmes, 42 years old, then went along to The Saturday Review where he became assistant publisher.

title: NATIONAL STOCK LINK EXPANDING
description: A three-year-old pilot system linking the nation's stock exchanges is being used increasingly to execute customer's buy and sell orders, according to a study by the Securities and Exchange Commission released today.

title: Owners Criticized
description: Marvin Miller, executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, said today that unfair practice charges may be filed against the owners.

title: Sonnenfeldt
description: Barbara A. Hausman and Richard W. Sonnenfeldt were married yesterday at their home in Port Washington, L.I. Rabbi Martin S. Rozenberg of the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, L.I., performed the ceremony. The bride was attended by her daughter, Elizabeth Hausman.

title: N.C.A.A.  Tourney Snubs Syracuse
description: De Paul, Louisiana State, Oregon State and Virginia were given the top-seeded berths yesterday in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship tournament, which opens Thursday, even though L.S.U., Oregon State and Virginia were beaten during the last week.

title: AMTRAK MOVE TO L.I. STUDIED
description: Amtrak is nearing a decision to move its central reservations operation from Pennsylvania Station to Nassau County, following four months of efforts by City Hall to dissuade the company from moving.

title: LIBERAL GROUPS ARE JOINING FORCES TO DEFEND THEIR GOALS AND GAINS
description: A coalition of liberal groups, in an expression of concern about potential ''radical changes'' in Congress on social issues, is seeking to blunt conservative moves to limit civil rights legislation and to curb the powers of the Federal judiciary.

title: 2 'SKYWALKS' CHANGE LEXINGTON AVE. VISTA
description: Motor traffic on Lexington Avenue was banned between 67th and 68th Streets over the weekend to permit construction work on dual ''skywalks'' that, for the first time, break the avenue's long vista from Gramercy Park into Harlem.

title: TORONTO BANK PRESIDENT
description: Robert W. Korthals, 47, has been elected president of the Toronto Dominion Bank, the fifth-largest bank in Canada, effective June 1. He will succeed J. Allan Boyle, who will retire at the mandatory retirement age of 65.

title: An Older View
description: George Moore also announced his probable retirement from basketball this month. Columbia University honored Moore in a recent game against Yale with a ceremony.

title: Michael Surveys Crowded Field
description: When the Yankees began today's workout with fielding practice, Dave Winfield and Lou Piniella were in left field; Ruppert Jones, Bobby Brown and Elliott Maddox were in center and Reggie Jackson, Oscar Gamble and Bobby Murcer were in right.

title: Cosmos Win, 5-2
description: Julio Cesar Romero celebrated his Paraguayan homecoming tonight with two goals and an assist to lead the Cosmos to a 5-2 exhibition victory over the Paraguayan national team. It was Romero's first appearance in Paraguay since he joined the Cosmos in December 1979. Giorgio Chinaglia had a goal and three assists, and Seninho added two goals for the winners.

title: OPERA: JUNE ANDERSON'S 'HOFFMAN' TRIPLE
description: AFTER Hoffmann finishes telling his three tales - immortalized in Offenbach's opera -his sidekick spells out the significance of the poet's bizarre loves: ''Olympia, Antonia, Giulietta are only one woman!''

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Train Crash in Argentina Kills 45 and Injures 120

title: BUDGET WORRIES FOR ATOM PLANS
description: The Reagan Administration has limited proposed increases in Government spending for nuclear development to levels well below industry expectations, according to Congressional and industry sources that follow the budgetary process closely.

title: JOHN PAUL II'S SOURCE OF UNIQUE AUTHORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Clinical Lab Comeback?
description: ON the chart, the path traced by shares of the Damon Corporation resembles the descent from a rocky mountain. A glamorous and highflying stock - it hit 70 in mid-1972 - the Damon Corporation has had a bumpy stock market ride since then. In the bear market of 1974, the stock dropped to 6.

title: 3 BIG EAST TEAMS IN N.I.T. FIELD
description: Three teams from the Big East Conference - St. John's, Syracuse and Connecticut - were among 30 that accepted bids last night for the 44th National Invitation Tournament. The two remaining berths were expected to be filled today or tomorrow.

title: Zungul Has 7 Goals In Arrows' Victory
description: A goal by Steve Zungul at 3 minutes 21 seconds of the overtime period, his seventh of the game, enabled the New York Arrows to beat the Chicago Horizons, 8-7, in a Major Indoor Soccer League game today at Nassau Coliseum.

title: By Jim Benagh
description: Sports World Specials Ounces of Prevention

title: Howard Captures N.C.A.A. Berth
description: SALEM, N.C., March 8 (UPI) - Bernard Perry and Rodney Wright hit two free throws each in the final 17 seconds today to give Howard University a 66-63 win over North Carolina A.& T. in the final of the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference tournament.

title: WITH LYNN, BURLESON AND HOBSON, ANGELS HAVE A RED SOX LOOK
