description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. THEIR sox are still red. All red actually; no blue and white stripes. Red and blue are still the dominant trim colors on their uniforms. But the name across their shirts now is Angels, not Red Sox.

title: Miss McKinney Wins Giant Slalom
description: Tamara McKinney of the United States turned in a fast second run today to win the women's giant slalom in World Cup competition at Aspen Mountain.

title: COURTS USING STATE CONSTITUTIONS TO BAR BIASED SELECTION OF JURIES
description: Because the Federal courts have refused, on constitutional grounds, to throw out some convictions of black defendants over the intentional selection of all-white juries, state courts have begun to place legal obstacles to such trials by relying on state constitutions.

title: HEMPSTEAD MAN HELD IN SLAYING OF WIFE AND HER SISTER
description: A 35-year-old dividend supervisor for a Manhattan investment brokerage house shot his estranged wife and her sister to death early today, the Nassau County police said. The slayings apparently followed an unsuccessful attempt by the man to arrange a reconciliation.

title: St. Dominic's Victor
description: St. Dominic's of Oyster Bay rallied from a 20-18 half-time deficit and defeated St. Anthony's of Smithtown, 46-39, tonight to win the Nassau-Suffolk Catholic High School Athletic Association bbasketball championship at Hofstra University.

title: Sayers Takes 5-Miler
description: Mike Sayers of the Greenery Track Club of Staten Island won the 20th annual Bob Preston memorial five-mile run yesterday at Central Park in 24 minutes 7.7 seconds.

title: Miss Navratilova Beats Miss Jaeger
description: Martina Navratilova changed speeds on her shots to keep Andrea Jaeger off balance today and scored a 6-4, 6-0 victory in the final of a $150,000 Avon tennis tournament. It was her third victory on the winter tour.

title: CHRYSLER'S MEXICAN SUBSIDIARY FLOUSISHES
description: In the bustling offices of Chrysler de Mexico, where executives have turned their attention from last year's record sales and profits to this year's ambitious expansion program, the crisis at its parent company in Detroit is an unwelcome topic of conversation.

title: PRESIDENT REPLACES TOP U.S. DIPLOMATS AT LAW OF SEA TALKS
description: Less than 48 hours before the resumption of the United Nations Law of the Sea Conference, the Reagan Administration abruptly dismissed from the United States delegation the top officials who served during the Carter Administration.

title: INDIANA MURDERER EXECUTED AT PRISON
description: At 12:12 this morning, 24-year-old Steven Timothy Judy was strapped into the electric chair at the Indiana State Prison and put to death for the murders of a 21-year-old Indianapolis woman and her three children in 1979.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Man, a Former Prisoner, Ponders Politics
description: Since his release in 1973 following 20 years of imprisonment in China, John T. Downey has received a law degree, set up a private practice, become Secretary of Business Regulation in Connecticut and taken over as chairman of the state's Division of Public Utilities Control.

title: STEP UP AT HUGHES TOOL
description: James R. Lesch, the 59-year-old president and chief executive officer of the Hughes Tool Company, has been named to the additional post of chairman, effective next month after the annual meeting. He will succeed Raymond M. Holliday, 66.

title: Commodities; Key Topics At Industry Convention
description: WHENEVER 700 top figures of the commodity industry gather for the annual meeting of the Futures Industry Association, there are usually more than that many trade topics discussed. But last week's meeting of the group in Boca Raton, Fla., was decidely unusual.

title: MAJOR FIGHT EXPECTED OVER EFFORTS TO EXTEND VOTING RIGHTS MEASURE
description: A major fight is shaping up in Congress over efforts to extend the Voting Rights Act of 1965, widely regarded as one of the most effective pieces of civil rights legislation ever passed.

title: RANGERS TIED AS WINGS GET 2 LATE GOALS
description: The Detroit Red Wings scored twice in the final period to tie the Rangers, 4-4, last night at Madison Square Garden. It was the third successive home game in which the Rangers had played to a tie. Glenn Hicks scored at 3 minutes 12 seconds of the third period on an assist from Gary McAdam. Then Dale McCourt, on passes from Mike Foligno and John Barrett, tied the score at 4:38.

title: WHITE HOUSE URGING SIZABLE REDUCTIONS IN LOAN GUARANTEES
description: The Reagan Administration plans to propose sharp cutbacks in Federal loan guarantees, particularly for housing, to accompany reductions in direct Government lending already announced.

title: Murray Hampered By Stomach Pains
description: Eddie Murray, the Baltimore Orioles' first baseman, worked out briefly today despite complaining of pains in his abdomen and back.

title: WILLIAM A. SPIVACK
description: William A. Spivack, director of arbitrage of Loeb Partners, a New York City investment concern, died Thursday of cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. Spivack, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 41 years old.

title: Oil-Rig Technology
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said that it was negotiating the right to license its technology on the building of oil rigs to the Wah-Chang International Marine Industry Company of Hong Kong and to the Guangdong Shipbuilding Corporation of China. Bethlehem said that the possible sale of several of its patents for the manufacture of offshore oil rigs was also being discussed. A spokesman said that the value of the sale was unknown.

title: New Dances to Highlight Series by Philharmonia
description: New dances by Annabelle Gamson, Pearl Lang and Barbara Roan will highlight ''Music Plus Dance,'' a celebration of 20th-century music and dance presented by the Brooklyn Philharmonia at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on March 19 and 20.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on hormone research in The Times on Saturday incorrectly named a Rutgers University scientist. She is June Machover Reinisch.

title: SCHOOLS HELP LATCH-KEY CHILDREN COPE
description: As Linda Berman was driving home from the office the other night, the pasta pot in her kitchen began to boil and the scent of oregano filled the air. Her live-in help, 12-year-old Michael and Debbie, 11, had dinner under control.

title: GEORGE T. WOHLPART
description: George T. Wohlpart, a retired treasurer of Alexander's department store, died Friday after a heart attack at University Hospital. Mr. Wohlpart, who lived in Manhattan, was 81 years old.

title: Flores Takes Title
description: Pedro Flores of Mexico won the World Boxing Association junior flyweight championship tonight by stopping Yoko Gushiken of Japan in the 12th round.

title: PIANO RECITAL: MONA GOLABEK
description: CRISP, forceful, direct and intense, Mona Golabek is the sort of pianist whose playing may cause disagreements, but few would deny that her recital yesterday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall was filled with a fierce, uncompromising honesty on both the interpretive and technical levels. Winner of the 1979 Avery Fisher Recital Award, Miss Golabek has not performed here since 1973, but there should be many more New York concerts by this stimulating musician in the future.

title: CHINA TO ISSUE FIRST BONDS SINCE 50'S
description: The Government announced plans today for the sale of up to $3.3 billion in treasury bonds this year, the first such bonds issued in China since the 1950's.

title: Washington Watch; Tax Incentives For Savers
description: WASHINGTON IN one shape or another, tax incentives for savings are likely to emerge from the new Congress. The Administration is still fighting to keep its tax bill ''clean'' in the interests of speedy passage. But already more than three dozen bills have been introduced to get more earnings into savings accounts and long-term investments.

title: Service for Bosley Crowley
description: A memorial service for Bosley Crowther, the film critic of The New York Times from 1940 to 1967, will be held at the Princeton Club, 15 West 43d Street, at 3 P.M. Thursday. Mr. Crowther, who was 75 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y., died of heart failure Saturday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Scanlon Triumphs
description: Bill Scanlon won the $200,000 World Championship Tennis Invitational today by defeating Vijay Amritraj of India in the final, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4, 3-6, 6-4.

title: John Henry Takes Santa Anita 'Cap
description: John Henry, ridden by Laffit Pincay, captured the 44th running of the $418,150 Santa Anita Handicap today by a length over King Go Go. Exploded finished third and the heavily favored Flying Paster was fourth in the field of 11.

title: Small-Sized Television
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, which markets in the United States under the Panasonic and Quasar names, said it would market in April a black-and-white television set smaller than a paperback book with a screen measuring 1.5 inches diagonally. The set, which would cost about $200, weighs less than a pound, and can operate on household current, rechargeable batteries or an automobile battery, Matsushita said.

title: THE URGE TO FISH IS UPON NORTHEAST ANGLERS
description: For SportsMonday By NELSON BRYANT

title: NCK Moves into Vienna
description: The NCK Organization, which already has 23 branches overseas, has acquired an agency in Vienna, which now will be called Marketing Studio NCK, and plans to open a second office in Italy, adding Rome to Milan. And in the Netherlands, TBWA Advertising has opened its eighth European office, TBWA Netherlands.

title: Nuclear Rationale
description: To the Editor:

title: ACHIEVERS GUIDE BLACK STUDENTS
description: They are young black women with hope in their eyes and a burning desire to succeed. Last week 25 sophomores and juniors from Spelman College in Atlanta came to New York to be learn from 50 black women achievers in law, medicine and business what it is like in the world out there.

title: CASINO SHUT FOR 2 HOURS BY A THREAT
description: The Caesars Boardwalk hotel was evacuated of about 750 guests today because of a bomb threat that proved to be a hoax. In addition, some 1,200 casino and hotel employees were removed form the hotel or told not to report for work until the emergency was over.

title: Mrs. Melton Scores Four-Stroke Victory
description: Nancy Lopez-Melton shot a 68 today to win the $125,000 Arizona Copper golf tournament by four strokes from Pat Bradley. She finished with a 14-under-par total of 278.

title: No Headline
description: ''If they haven't figured out how to get rid of the stuff after 30 years, they ought to shut the plants down.

title: CHRONIC PROCRASTINATION: THE ROOTS OF LATENESS
description: The fact that last week was National Procrastination Week may have eluded a lot of people who observe the habit year round. They are the late ones who dally in the shower and in front of the mirror; the people who must run for trains and who arrive at airports in a state of panic; the people who regularly keep friends, relatives and lovers waiting in theater lobbies and on street corners, and who make bosses send quick, frowning glances at the clock.

title: Boom Boom II
description: It reads like a movie scenario: Lenny (Boom Boom) Mancini has a chance to win the lightweight title in 1942 but he is drafted into the Army. He comes out in 1946 at age 26 with a Purple Heart and too many pounds to fight in the lightweight division. A generation later his 20-year-old son Ray, also nicknamed Boom Boom, wins all 16 of his fights as a lightweight, 13 of them by knockouts - seven in the first round, four in the second. His obsession is to win the lightweight title that was denied his father. ''This is for you, Pop,'' he'll say as he hands over the championship belt.

title: The Better Way to Cut Business Taxes
description: The promise of revival in the Reagan tax cut appears at first to come mostly from a 30 percent reduction in the personal tax rates. In fact, over the long term, the real benefit is likely to flow to busi-ness through the simultaneous liberalization of depreciation rules and increases in the investment tax credit.

title: Bridge: Dutch Team Is Setting Pace In Tournament in Shanghai
description: The first internatioanal tournament ever played in China began here yesterday with attention focused on a strong Dutch team. A foursome representning Rotterdam and including a former world pairs champion, Hans Kreyns, took the lead in one of the qualifying sections.

title: Upsala Advances In Division III Play
description: Upsala College won the championship of the South Atlantic Region of the N.C.A.A. Division III basketball playoffs last night, defeating Montclair State, 86-64. Upsala (23-5) advanced to a national quarterfinal game against Ursinus (21-7), the Mid-Atlantic Region champion, on Saturday at the Viking Memorial Hall here.

title: REV. FRANCIS D. DOINO
description: The Rev. Francis D. Doino, S.J., who had been chaplain at Goldwater Memorial Hospital for 29 years, died there Friday.

title: TURKEY'S JUNTA LOBBIES TO STAY IN EUROPEAN 'CLUB'
description: Turkey wants to remain part of Western Europe's democratic community and is concerned over what is seen as a campaign to expel it.

title: Snipes Gains Unanimous Decision Over Cummings
description: Renaldo (Mr.) Snipes survived a bruised right hand, several butts, a few low blows and three bites today and scored a unanimous decision over Floyd (Jumbo) Cummings, who could have been charged with violating his parole if he had performed such deeds outside the ring.

title: Iowa Swimmers End Indiana Streak at 20
description: Iowa snapped Indiana's string of 20 consecutive championships in the Big Ten swimming and diving meet yesterday, defeating the Hoosiers, 710.5 points to 680.5.

title: SENATE TO CONSIDER CREDIT CARD FEES
description: Amid mounting opposition, the Senate this week will consider legislation that would extend a ban on charging credit card users an extra fee when they use their cards.

title: No Headline
description: IRANIAN DEMENDS DISMISSAL AND TRIAL OF BANI-SADR

title: Mayer Conquers Sadri in Final, 6-4, 6-4 01.5-
description: Gene Mayer, winner of the United States indoor title, defeated an erratic-serving John Sadri, 6-4, 6-4, todaya nd won the $125,000 United Bank tennis tournament for the second y ear in a row.

title: STAGE: YOSHI OIDA'S OWN 'INTERROGATIONS'
description: YOSHI OIDA is a classically trained Japanese actor who has worked with Peter Brook since 1968. He has also created his own pieces, based on Japanese tradition and culture, and in 1979 he presented an hourlong performance called ''Interrogations'' at the Avignon Festival in France.

title: DECISIONS MAY SHAPE FUTURE OF TRANSIT IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Decisions expected to be made in Washington and Albany this week could well shape the futures of the New York City metropolitan area's mass-transportation system and of the Westway, the superhighway project proposed for Manhattan's lower west border.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BURIED TREASURE

title: Edythe Westenhaver Bride Of William Darrow, Lawyer
description: In the Loyola Chapel at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola yesterday, Edythe Mary Westenhaver of Riverdale, the Bronx, an editor and staff writer at Religious News Service, was married to William Lawrence Darrow, also of Riverdale, a lawyer. The Very Rev. Daniel F. Fitzpatrick performed the ceremony.

title: Cooke Offers Mass For Slain Children
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke, the Archbishop of New York, offered mass yesterday at a Harlem church for the 20 black children who have been slain in Atlanta.

title: BALLET: 'SYLPHIDE' UPSTAGED IN TORONTO
description: The vagaries of a live performing art are such that the unexpected can be counted on even when it is least expected. When the National Ballet of Canada announced that its fourth annual gala in Toronto's O'Keefe Center would consist of a few divertissements and a full program of August Bournonville's ''La Sylphide,'' with Carla Fracci, Ib Andersen and Erik Bruhn as guest artists, there was no doubt where the chief interest lay.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MARCH 9, 1981
description: International The Administration dismissed without notice the top United States delegates to the United Nations Law of the Sea Conference, which opens today in New York. Deputy Secretary of State William P. Clark told George H. Aldrich, the acting head of the delegation appointed by the Carter Administration, that his resignation was being accepted and that the Administration wanted ''a clean break with the past.'' The dismissals followed the Administration's announcement last week that it would would not go along with plans to conclude the treaty dealing with the use of the oceans and their resources. (Page A1, Column 1.) Students, professors and unionists held a rally in Warsaw to commemorate the suppression of student demonstrations in March 1968. The gathering of about 3,000 people was almost festive, and speeches advocated tolerance and free speech. At the same time, at another rally in Warsaw, several hundred older men and women, attracted by anonymous posters, gathered to hear speeches attacking the ''Zionist clique,'' the Jews who held positions of power during the Stalinist 1950's and who were said to have murdered and tortured Polish patriots. (A1:4.)

title: KINGMAN PREPARES TO ERASE THE PAST
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. DAVE KINGMAN sits in the locker room at Payson Field, takes the questions and weighs the adjectives, which accompany any discussion of his career.

title: Article 034494 -- No Title
description: A Federal court jury has returned a $92,300 verdict against three former Larned State Hospital doctors because they discharged a mental patient who killed his mother and brother six days after the discharge.

title: VIBRAPHONE: ELLIOTT PLAYS FAVORITES BY YIP HARBURG
description: DON ELLIOTT, who divides his playing time between vibraphone and mellowphone (and sometimes plays a few bars on both together), had the death of E.Y. (Yip) Harburg on his mind while his jazz quartet was playing over the weekend at Bechet's, Third Avenue near 75th Street, where the group continues through next Sunday.

title: Katz Forms Radio Group
description: The Katz Agency, largely broadcast advertising representatives, has acquired five radio stations and has started the Katz Broadcasting Company. The stations are WEZN, Bridgeport, Conn.; WZZK, Birmingham, Ala., and WAAF and WFTQ, Worcester, Mass., all owned by Park City Communications, and KWEN, Tulsa, Okla.

title: Fires Damages 2 Buildings At a University in Texas
description: Two fires believed to have been started by an arsonist heavily damaged two buildings at Texas Christian University early today, the authorities said.

title: Lisbon Urges Peace in Salvador
description: Portugal has told the a United States delegation sent to seek Portuguese support for the ruling junta in El Salvador that a peaceful solution should be found to the conflict there and that all external interference should cease, Government sources said. Foreign Minister Andre Gon,calves Pereira told the delegation that Portugal stood by the principle of noninterference established in the United Nations Charter, the sources added.

title: 3 DEAD, 11 ARE SAVED AS WAVES SLOW EFFORT TO RESCUE ISRAELI CREW
description: An Israeli bulk carrier ship with 35 crewmen aboard sank today in heavy seas 96 miles southeast of Bermuda, leaving three crewmen dead and others floundering in rough seas while they awaited rescue, the Coast Guard said.

title: No Headline
description: The skating is over, but the controversy lingers:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dayton Hudson Corporation, Minneapolis, has named James T. Hale senior vice president, general counsel and secretary.

title: THE MEANEST WAY
description: Despite the relaxed banter of the President in news conferences and despite the approving polls, there is a low, mean hiss to be heard in the land.

title: Camden Residents Warned of Fumes
description: State environmental officials were taking air samples in the aftermath of a fire that leveled a large lawn-andgarden center here, according to police and fire authorities.

title: NEW ARGENTINE UNIT FOR BANK OF AMERICA
description: The Bank of America's recent $150 million purchase of Banco Internacional, Argentina's 13th-largest commercial bank, gives the Bank of America the largest branch system of any foreign bank operating in Argentina.

title: Daniel Nagrin to Present 'Poems,' a New Dance Solo
description: Daniel Nagrin will present ''Poems Off the Wall,'' a new dance solo, from March 31 through April 18 at the Studio Theater, 555 Broadway.

title: Wrestling to Palacio
description: Al Palacio of Long Beach High School was named the most valuable wrestler in the New York State scholastic wrestling championships last night after he scored a 6-0 victory over Brian Keyes of Port Jervis to win the 105-pound title.

title: WALL STREET FIGURE READY FOR TREASURY
description: Roger W. Mehle Jr. the Wall Street municipal finance specialist who has been nominated by President Reagan to be Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, says his training and background should stand him in good stead for the Federal post.

title: 38-CENT PICTURE SHOW?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Islander Slips Quietly onto TV
description: Mintzer, Trostler & Rothschild very, very quietly took its client Fire Islander sportwear onto television in Buffalo, Charlotte, N.C., Denver, Green Bay, Madison and Peoria on Feb. 28. It is a test and could be a first TV advertising for this product category. When alerted to this situation Leo Greenland, chairman of Smith/Greenland, who thought he'd be the first into the medium with his client Russ, said, ''They're hiding it under a barrel.''

title: MARTIN MARIETTA OFFERING BONDS AT LARGE DISCOUNT
description: High interest rates are encouraging issuers and investors in the bond market to experiment: This week's sale of new 7 percent Martin Marietta Corporation debentures, due 2011, is an example of how borrowers might reduce their interest but still attract investors.

title: Saudi Prince Urges West To Oppose Soviet Advances
description: Prince Saud al-Faisal, Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister, reportedly urged Western powers today to directly oppose Soviet intervention in other countries and to bolster the defenses of countries threatened by the Kremlin.

title: TV: NUREYEV-JOFFREY BALLET TRIBUTE TO NIJINSKY
description: ''NUREYEV and the Joffrey Ballet/In Tribute to Nijinsky,'' tonight's ''Dance in America'' presentation at 9 on WNET-TV, Channel 13, was recorded last August in Nashville. Previously, this collection of three ''reconstructed'' ballets had been seen in a special limited run on Broadway.

title: Elizabeth Cuts Water For Conrail by a Half
description: The City of Elizabeth cut water supplies to Conrail by half after the line failed to meet a deadline for paying $224,810 in water surcharges, city officials said.

title: New York's New Credit Rating
description: Long before Standard & Poor's judged New York City bonds to be investment grade securities suitable for prudent investors, many private analysts had come to the same conclusion.

title: HEDE MASSING, 81 EX-SOVIET SPY WHO WAS WITNESS AGAINST HISS
description: Hede Massing, a former Viennese actress and confessed Soviet spy who testified against Alger Hiss at his second perjury trial, died yesterday of emphysema at her home on Washington Square. She was 81 years old.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt PAPER MONEY. By Adam Smith. 335 pages. Summit. $13.95. UNDERSTANDING INFLATION. By John Case. 228 pages. Morrow. $9.95.

title: BRADSHAW LEADS DEPAUL VICTORY
description: With emotions running wild and everything going against De Paul University's chance for a top national basketball ranking, Clyde Bradshaw asserted himself quietly and efficiently today.

title: Carl Pilz, 63, Nabisco Executive, Killed in Auto Accident in Tuscon
description: Carl R. Pilz, vice president for supervising-purchasing of Nabisco Inc., died last Friday in an automobile accident in Tucson, Ariz., where he had been attending a business meeting. He was 63 years old and a resident of Mendham, N.J.

title: 3 Are Killed and 3 Injured as Fire Races Through a Home Upstate
description: Three persons died and three survived last night when fire engulfed a home in this Oswego County town.

title: F.H.A. Loan Rates To Climb to 14%
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development said Friday that it would increase to 14 percent from 13 1/2 percent the interest ceiling on single-family home loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration.

title: DANCE: GREENHOUSE TROUPE OFFERS 3 CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: ''ENSEMBLE'' may be an apt word to characterize the Greenhouse Dance Ensemble, which offered a Saturday night concert at the Theresa L. Kaufmann Concert Hall of the 92d Street Y. Its members appeared to enjoy dancing together and the performance featured works by three choreographers. Moreover, the troupe displayed an admirable interest in contemporary music and the scores for several dances were performed live.

title: AMBIVALENT EGYPT PONDERS ITS PLACE IN U.S. STRATEGY
description: As the Reagan Administration begins to fashion a revised Middle East policy to counter what it sees as Soviet influence in the area, an ambivalent Egypt is facing the task of defining its role in the American strategy.

title: by Francis Carling
description: With the Reagan Administration reshaping Government philosophy so extensively, it is likely that labor-relations policy will come under review, too. The need to fill two of the five seats on the National Labor Relations Board will provide an opportunity for a change in direction.

title: Dispute Develops On Flynn's Contract
description: Doug Flynn and the Mets acknowledged today that a dispute had arisen over Flynn's five-year contract, an agreement both sides announced with fanfare six weeks ago in a New York nightclub.

title: A DEATH KNELL BECOMES A SIGN OF ECONOMIC LIFE
description: ''In a musty old hall in Detroit they prayed, in the Maritime Sailor's Cathedral. The church bell chimed 'til it rang twenty-nine times, for each man on the Edmund Fitzgerald.''

title: No Headline
description: Giles, Phillies' Aide, Seeking to Buy Club

title: Teen-Ager Stabbed to Death In a Fight at Disneyland
description: A teen-ager was stabbed to death at Disneyland in what spokesmen say is the first killing in the amusement park's 25-year history.

title: N.C.A.A. BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT
description: MIDWEST At Austin, Texas Thursday - Lamar (24-4) vs. Missouri (22-9); Arkansas (22-7) vs.

title: HINSON, FACING A MORALS CHARGE, SHUNS CLAMOR TO QUIT CONGRESS
description: Republican and Democratic Party officials in Mississippi continue to call for the resignation of United States Representative John Hinson, arrested last month in Washington on a sodomy charge. But the Fourth District Congressman will hear nothing of it.

title: Don't Sink the Sea Treaty
description: Properly enough, the Reagan Administration wants to examine all the fine print before it decides what to do about a complex diplomatic legacy, the Law of the Sea treaty. What is worrisome is the note of dismissal in the terse announcement that it wants to defer any final action on this bipartisan venture. The good faith and credibility of the United States as a negotiator are now bound up with this decadelong effort to bring the oceans under international agreements.

title: Some Unrehearsed Drama for Play's Top Performers
description: It was, the associate producer said, ''a case of life imitating art imitating life.'' It happened Saturday night when the leading lights of ''Jitters,'' a new play-within-a-play comedy about the backstage jitters of a provincial theater troupe, found themselves in a reallife predicament that didn't seem all that comical.

title: GOAL OF RETIRING AT 65 RECEDES UNDER ECONOMIC PRESSURE AND POPULATION CURVE
description: Retirement at age 65, the dream proffered to working Americans for a half century and more, is fading under the pressure of economic and social trends that appear irreversible.

title: The Police Blotter
description: An off-duty corrections officer shot and wounded a man who threatened him with a gun early yesterday in Queens, the police said. Melvin Walker, 50 years old, had threatened a bar owner's son and Corrections Officer George Ramos with a handgun when he was shot in the shoulder. The incident occurred at about 4:30 A.M. at Mary's Idle Hour Bar and Grill at 169-16 Jamaica Avenue in Jamaica. ... - A Brooklyn man, Darryl Arner, 27 years old, was found about 4:10 A.M. at the corner of Rochester Avenue and President Street in Brooklyn after having been shot once under the left arm Mr. Arner, of 463 17th Street, was pronounced dead at Kings County Hospital, according to a report by United Press International. ... - A man in his mid-20's was found dead in the street in front of 145 Lincoln Road, Brooklyn, about 5:30 A.M. The victim, who had been shot twice, was identified by the police as Ricardo Ceballos.

title: A RALLY IN WARSAW MARKS SUPPRESSION OF PROTESTS IN 1968
description: About3,000 students, professors and representatives of the independent union Solidarity held a rally at Warsaw University today to commemorate the suppression of student demonstrations in March 1968.

title: ELIZABETH CUTS WATER FOR CONRAIL BY A HALF
description: The City of Elizabeth cut water supplies to Conrail by half after the line failed to meet a deadline for paying $224,810 in water surcharges, city officials said yesterday.

title: ABOUT WASHINGTON
description: The strange sound drifted through the Pentagon at the end of a long day when admirals actually had talked of resurrecting battleships and sailing them about the world through old paths of glory. The main lobby corridor of the Pentagon was dim, shadowy and almost empty at 10 o'clock at night but a wanderer was attracted there by the sound of music being played, the sound of a country hoedown, not a military march.

title: Tolentine Advances, As Does All Hallows
description: Tolentine, the defending champion, and All Hallows advanced to the semifinals of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association intersectional basketball playoffs Saturday night at Fordham University.

title: MISSIONARY MURDERED IN COLOMBIA HAILED AS MARTYR AT HOME CHURCH
description: The congregation of a suburban church where Chester A. Bitterman 3d, the missionary slain by his kidnappers in Colombia yesterday, was a member, thanked God today for letting him be martyred.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Player A loses the puck to Player B in a National Hockey League game. Player A grabs the jersey of Player B, who immediately starts to punch him. Player A does not retaliate. What is the ruling?

title: Japan Car Curb 'Speculative'
description: A spokesman for Bill Brock, United States Special Trade Representative, described as ''speculative'' a published report that Japan's automobile manufacturers have agreed to voluntarily reduce the level of their exports to the United States.

title: Zachry, Jones Excel In Intrasquad Game
description: Pat Zachry and Randy Jones, who may have to carry the burden of the New York Mets' front-line pitching this year, made their debuts in a training camp game today and pitched impressively.

title: DEPARTURE SIGN BEMUSES RIDERS
description: While Amtrak officials have been puzzling over their corporate destination, their customers in New York City's Pennsylvania Station have been doing some puzzling of their own.

title: YOUTH GROUP TIED TO BONN ASSAILS NATO MISSILE PLAN
description: A youth organization associated with the Free Democratic Party of Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has urged West Germany to abandon NATO's decision to station new medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe on the ground that the program represents only the interests of the United States.

title: City to Press Case Against Plant for S.I.
description: New York City will press its case against a state plan to build a power plant on Staten Island.

title: Heller Skeptical Of Reagan Plan
description: Walter Heller, the designer of the 1964 tax cut that revived a flagging United States economy, said today that he believed the Reagan Administration is kidding itself about the prospects for its economic recovery plan.

title: ROCK: IRISH U2, A YOUNG QUARTET, PLAYS AT THE RITZ
description: THE Irish rock quartet U2, which has received extravagant critical praise in the British press, made a strong showing at the Ritz on Saturday. For such an accomplished band, U2 is unusually young.

title: MET MURDER HEARING KEY TO SUSPECT'S CASE
description: A hearing that is to open in State Supreme Court today could determine whether Craig S. Crimmins stands trial for the murder of a violinist at the Metropolitan Opera House last summer.

title: Why No Budget Cuts for Nuclear?
description: Most Federal energy programs are being cut, but nuclear energy is headed for a costly, and indefensible, boost. Full details won't be known till Tuesday, but Senate Majority Leader Howard Baker has told reporters that the heavily subsidized Clinch River breeder reactor, which the Carter Administration wisely tried to kill, will continue to be built in Senator Baker's state of Tennessee. And Energy Secretary Edwards has urged the Government to buy a huge plant for reprocessing nuclear fuel in his state of South Carolina. Both projects are a waste of money.

title: Morosco Fails to Get U.S. Historic Status
description: Federal officials have turned down a request by the Actors Equity Association to declare the Morosco Theater, on 45th Street west of Times Square, eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places. The theater is scheduled to be demolished with three others to make way for a hotel to be built by a group headed by John Portman, the Atlanta architect.

title: THE PRESIDENCY AND THE PROFLIGACY
description: To the Editor:

title: INDEXING: 'A VERITABLE ENGINE OF INFLATION'
description: To the Editor:

title: Irregular Moves From Lorillard
description: Lorillard is doing a couple of surprising things with one new product. First of all it is bringing out a regular version of a menthol-only brand.

title: DEFENSE CHIEF SEEKS A FLEXIBLE RESPONSE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has asserted that an attack by the Soviet Union on American interests or allies would be met by a United States response aimed not at the point of attack but at Soviet weaknesses.

title: Report Notes Level Economy
description: A study of various indicators shows that the nation's economy in February was basically unchanged from the preceding month's level, according to the monthly report of the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: TORO CHIEF'S MOVE RAISE QUESTIONS
description: In the tightly knit business circles of Minneapolis, where executives of General Mills, Honeywell and 3M lunch together at private clubs and sit on one another's boards, the decision of David T. McLaughlin, chairman and chief executive of the Toro Company, to become the president of Dartmouth College has people wondering.

title: Limon Is Outpointed
description: Cornelius Boza-Edwards of London knocked down Rafael Limon in the fifth round then withstood a comeback effort by the Mexican fighter and won the World Boxing Council super-featherweight championship by unanimous decision.

title: THE PRESIDENCY AND THE PROFLIGACY
description: To the Editor:

title: 3-MILE ISLAND STUDY PREDICTS CLEANUP WILL EXTEND TO '88
description: Government specialists said today that the disabled nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island could be cleaned up with considerably less risk to the workers than had been estimated but that the job probably would take at least until 1988.

title: JUDGE IS ASKED TO EXCLUDE PRESS AT HEARING ON MET MURDER CASE
description: Lawyers for Craig S. Crimmins asked a judge yesterday to bar the public and press from a hearing on whether a purported confession may be used at his trial for the murder of a violinist at the Metropolitan Opera House last summer.

title: CHINESE, SHEDDING PROUD FACADE, SEEK FOREIGN AID
description: Accustomed to hiding its troubles and boasting of its successes, China withheld for years the news that 242,000 people died and 164,000 were seriously injured in the earthquake of July 28, 1976, which leveled the city of Tangshan and badly damaged Tianjin and Peking. Offers of disaster relief were refused.

title: Indians' Thornton Breaks Finger
description: Andre Thornton, counted on by the Cleveland Indians to provide much-needed right-handed power, suffered a broken little finger on his right hand when hit by a pitch yesterday in the Indians' 11-2 exhibition victory over the Hanshin Tigers of Japan. He is expected to be out four weeks.

title: STANFORD GROUP ATTEMPTS A HEART-LUNG TRANSPLANT
description: Surgeons at Stanford University yesterday transplanted a human heart and both lungs in an effort to save the life of a 45-year-old woman.

title: HARVESTER, IN CREDIT PACT, HALTS LOAN REPAYMENTS
description: The International Harvester Company, struggling to stay afloat under the burden of more than $3 billion in highinterest, short-term borrowings, has announced a moratorium on repayments of principal on loans maturing between Feb. 3 and May 15. The company will continue to pay interest on those loans, however.

title: Lord Rhyl Dead in Britain at 74; Quit Cabinet in 1958 Over Policy
description: Lord Rhyl, a 25-year veteran of Parliament who as Nigel Birch quit the Cabinet of Harold Macmillan in a policy dispute in 1958, died yesterday at his home in Hampshire, his family said.

title: Novo Industri Net Up 67.8% in 1980
description: Novo Industri A/S, the world's leading producer of industrial enzymes and the second-largest producer of insulin after Eli Lilly & Company, reported yesterday that net income for all of 1980 rose 67.8 percent on a sales increase of 23.6 percent.

title: School Board Chief Quits In Ohio Teachers' Strike
description: The beleaguered president of the Ravenna Board of Education resigned today, citing the mounting strain of a bitter 66-day teachers' strike.

title: PAKISTANI KIJACKERS FREE HOSTAGES BUT THEY THREATEN DRASTIC MOVE
description: uf814DAMASCUS, Syria, March 9 (AP) -Three armed hijackers holding a Pakistani jetliner here with more than 100 hostages aboard freed one of them today but threatened to take an ''extremely drastic measure'' if Pakistan did not agree to free 92 imprisoned opposition activists.

title: Ogden Ends Offer
description: The Ogden Corporation said it had ended its offer to acquire the Buffalo Forge Company after the latter's board on Friday accepted a $37.50-a-share cash tender offer from the Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation. Ogden said it planned to tender its 425,000 Buffalo Forge shares to Ampco-Pittsburgh and ''will pursue legal remedies'' if Ampco-Pittsburgh persists in its refusal to purchase them.

title: AUDIT FINDS STATE ENERGY OFFICE HAS 'IMPORTANT' ROLE
description: The State Energy Office, which this year faces a review mandated by the Legislature to see if it is should stay in business, received a passing grade today from State Comptroller Edward V. Regan. He said the agency ''serves an important function in the development and coordination of an overall energy program.''

title: Sports of the Times; Comeback for Cup
description: THE most commendable comeback in sports this year might be made by a trophy instead of an athlete.With a new format and new prize money, the Davis Cup has an opportunity to regain its lost prestige after too many years in eclipse. Now that the United States team has qualified to oppose the current holder of the huge silver chalice, Czechoslovakia, in the July quarterfinals, perhaps the American tennis public will realize that the Davis Cup has more appeal than all those weekly jackpot tournaments that the same players seem to cut up.

title: Adela Holzer Begins Term for Larceny
description: Adela Holzer, an investor in the rock musical ''Hair'' and producer of several Broadway plays, surrendered to begin serving a prison term of two to six years for stealing $77,500 from investors.

title: John Gnagy, Painter Who Gave Drawing Lessons on Television
description: John Gnagy, a painter who gave drawing lessons on NBC-TV and CBS-TV from the late 1940's to the mid-1950's, died Saturday at his home in Idyllwild, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: BALLET: CANADIAN TROUPE OFFERS BRIAN MACDONALD'S 'NEWCOMERS'
description: Nationalist ballets about hardy pioneers have not been a staple of the dance repertory in the United States since the 1940's. But here in Toronto, the National Ballet of Canada has been featuring a recent work on such themes expressly designed as a piece of Canadiana.

title: CONSENSUS BROKERS AT THE WHITE HOUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Pittsburgh, has elected Clayton A. Sweeney executive vice president and chief administrative officer; Graemer K. Hilton executive vice president and chief financial officer; and Raymond S. Fries executive vice president.

title: GANNETT, HOWARD BAKER AND 6 BUY KNOXVILLE PAPER
description: The Gannett Company and a group of Tennessee investors that includes Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. and Gov. Lamar Alexander said yesterday that they had agreed to buy The Knoxville Journal.

title: WEEHAWKEN LAYOFFS FORCED BY COLLAPSE OF SEATRAIN
description: The financial collapse of the Seatrain Lines containership operation here has forced officials of this Hudson County community of 12,000 to lay off almost a third of its 150 government workers and to predict a sharp increase in taxes.

title: Kroc's Goal: Manageable Deficit
description: Ray Kroc, owner of the San Diego Padres, says he will keep the money-losing National League club ''forever,'' if he can expect only what he called reasonable losses.

title: San Francisco in N.C.A.A.
description: Quintin Dailey scored 32 points tonight to help San Francisco beat Pepperdine, 96-82, in a playoff for the West Coast Athletic Conference championship. The victory gave the Dons (24-6) a berth in the West regionals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. They will play Kansas State Thursday night in Los Angeles.

title: No Headline
description: How ''Fridays'' stole ''Saturday Night's'' thunder C7 Gore Vidal's 17th novel, ''Creation,'' is reviewed C9 ''Roads of Exile,'' film about Rousseau's late years C9 Telly Savalas in ''Hellinger's Law,'' movie on CBS-TV C19 National Ballet of Canada presents ''Newcomers'' C20 Obituaries Alexander O. Vietor, former cura- tor of maps at Yale B17 Dr. Marjorie Hope Nicolson, former Smith College dean B17 Sports Fisk plans to sign with White Sox B13 Mets' Cashen says club has outside chance to be a contender B13 Yanks beat University of Florida in spring opener B13 Well Decorated captures the Bahamas at Hialeah B13 De Paul gets top ranking in both basketball polls B13 Rebounding is a debit item in Knicks' ledger B14 Dave Anderson on the Davis Cup's comeback B15 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A18

title: Policeman Is Indicted In New Orleans Shooting
description: A policeman who fired a .45-caliber pistol in a struggle with a high school band chaperone in the midst of a Carnival crowd, wounding two people, was indicted by a grand jury today.

title: Caesars World Gets 4 New Bomb Threats
description: ATLANTIC CITY (AP) - The Caesars Boardwalk Regency Hotel has received at least four telephoned bomb threats since Sunday, when the state police ordered the 504-room building evacuated after a $6.5 million extortion attempt and bomb threat.

title: U.S. Accused On Phenol
description: The Common Market is investigating alleged dumping of American-made phenol and phenol derivatives in Western Europe, a spokesman for the market's executive commission said today.

title: IN LIEU OF U.N. HELP FOR PALESTINIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Janus Pleads Not Guilty in Fraud
description: Christopher G. Janus pleaded not guilty today to charges that he defrauded banks and private investors of $640,000 to make a movie about his search for the bones of Peking man. Federal District Judge Frank J. McGarr ordered Mr. Janus, 69 years old, of Wilmette, a north Chicago suburb, to surrender his passport and remain in the country for an April 7 hearing. He was allowed to remain free on a $4,500 bond.

title: MINERS PROTEST PLANNED REDUCTION IN U.S. AID TO BLACK LUNG PROGRAM
description: Led by Lane Kirkland of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., who marched hand in hand with the president of a coal miners' union that left the labor federation 33 years ago, a chanting, taunting throng of thousands of miners filed by the White House today to protest the Reagan Administration's proposed budget cuts.

title: CONTROVERSIAL CLINCH RIVER REACTOR PLAN IS POISED TO PROCEED
description: tailed deer dashing through the stands of loblolly and shortleaf pine that run down the lush green valley and up nearby Dug-Hood Ridge, whose dark silhouette looms across the river.

title: Ford Endorses Kean For Jersey Governor
description: Gerald R. Ford will campaign in New Jersey on April 2 on behalf of Thomas H. Kean of Livingston, a former Assembly Speaker seeking the Republican nomination for Governor in the June 2 primary.

title: BELL SEEKS REDUCED ROLE ON BIAS LAWS
description: Secretary of Education T.H. Bell said today that the Federal role in monitoring and enforcing laws against discrimination in the nation's schools and colleges should be trimmed dramatically.

title: PPG Industries Plans Modernization
description: PPG Industries said it had started a more than $100 million modernization program designed to save approximately 500,000 barrels of fuel oil at its Lake Charles, La., chemicals complex.

title: DOES SICKNESS HAVE ITS VIRTUES?
description: ''FEELING good about ourselves'' as we jog, eschew fatty foods and cigarettes, picket industrial polluters and read up on preventive medicine, we rally to Juvenal, the Roman poet who urged the virtue of a healthy mind in a healthy body.

title: Soviet and China Renew Accord On Navigation of the Amur River
description: China and the Soviet Union today renewed an accord on navigation rights in the Amur River, which forms their eastern border.

title: RETHINKING FOREIGN AID
description: In public discussion about which types of foreign-aid programs will best serve the United States' national interest, foreign-aid issues have been viewed, unfortunately, in terms of confrontation between the Office of Management and Budget and affected agencies anxious to protect their foreign-aid turf. Personality clashes and bureaucratic infighting, however lively, should not obscure the real issues at stake.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard CREATION. By Gore Vidal. 510 pages. Ran- dom House. $15.95.

title: Pistons to Let McAdoo Drill
description: Threatened by the National Basketball Players Association with a grievance that would have led to an arbitration hearing, the Detroit Pistons told Bob McAdoo yesterday that he could practice with the team and dress for games. However, General Manager Jack McCloskey said, McAdoo has no chance of playing in any of the 10 remaining games.

title: LESSONS OF HISTORY APPLIED TO THE PRESENT
description: IN the early 1950's the Pennsylvania legislature prohibited the dumping of industrial waste in rivers and other surface water. Manufacturers responded by digging lagoons on their own properties, so now the state faces underground water pollution.

title: Reclaiming Coal Mine Sites
description: Three years of research at an abandoned coal mine at the Argonne National Laboratory in Argonne, Ill., have resulted in findings that scientists believe can help reclaim thousands of mine disposal sites that scar the coal-rich regions of the United States.

title: The Gipper Will Finally Get a Notre Dame Degree
description: It will be a nostalgic reunion on May 17 when the University of Notre Dame awards honorary degrees to two men who scored great triumphs at the South Bend, Ind., campus. They are Pat O'Brien, who played the title role in the 1940 movie ''Knute Rockne - All-American,'' and his co-star, Ronald Reagan, who portrayed Notre Dame's famous halfback, George Gipp.

title: Exxon Cuts Prices On 3 Heavy Fuels
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A., the nation's largest oil refiner, yesterday reduced its East Coast wholesale price of No. 4, 5 and 6 heavy fuel oils, used by utilities to generate electricity and by large apartment houses for heating.

title: Princeton Provides Yale Business Dean
description: Burton G. Malkiel, chairman of the department of economics at Princeton and author of ''A Random Walk Down Wall Street,'' will become dean of Yale's School of Organization and Management on July 1, A. Bartlett Giamat@ti, Yale's president, announced yesterday.

title: THE SWEATER'S BAROQUE PHASE
description: The sweater just might be the prototypical modern fashion. It can be protective or provocative, a body covering or a decorative art object. It can be made by human hands holding two needles or by elaborate machines tracked by computers.

title: Crude Output Fell 4% in 1980
description: Crude oil production worldwide dropped 4 percent last year, to 59.7 million barrels a day, as demand declined, the Oil and Gas Journal reported today. The industry weekly said war between Iran and Iraq had reduced output by 4.5 million barrels a day, but that supply problems expected by some industry analysts had not occurred.

title: OFFICIALS VOICE CONCERN
description: ASERIOUS and potentially fatal bacterial infection - a prime cause of meningitis - is on the rise this year in the United States. Federal health officials are concerned about the bacterial problem - called meningococcal infections - and they are puzzled why the rise is occurring.

title: SMITH COLLEGE DEAN FOR 11 YEARS
description: Dr. Marjorie Hope Nicolson, the dean of Smith College for 11 years and a leading scholar on the relationship of poetry and science, died yesterday at White Plains Hospital. She was 87 years old and had lived in a nursing home in White Plains since 1974.

title: S.I. Nurses Agree on Pact
description: Registered nurses at Staten Island Hospital have reached agreement on a new contract with hospital administrators, a spokesman for the nurses said yesterday. The nurses had been working without a contract since Dec. 31, and the settlement averted a strike scheduled for today by the hospital's 500 registered nurses. Under the agreement, the starting salary is increased from $15,700 a year to $18,540.

title: Home of Junta Member's Relative In El Salvador Damaged by Bomb
description: The home of the father-in-law of a liberal junta member was bombed today, ripping out much of the first floor.

title: 5 NEW MET PRODUCTIONS ARE SCHEDULED FOR '81-82
description: Five new productions are planned by the Metropolitan Opera for its 1981-82 season, including a triple bill of 20th-century works. The official announcement is expected later this week, when the company will disclose its full repertory and casts for the season.

title: CREATIONISM, POLITICS AND PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: LAST week's widely publicized case before a California judge in Sacramento began with a demand that pupils in California's public schools be informed by their science teachers that evolution is not the only theory that explains the creation of humankind. The trial concluded with a ruling by Judge Irving Perluss that existing state education policies did not violate the religious rights of people who object to the teaching of evolution.

title: Well Decorated Wins Bahamas
description: With undefeated Cure the Blues back in the barn, Herbert Allen's Well Decorated rushed down the rail to win the $25,000-added Bahamas Stakes this gray and showery day, then survived a foul claim.

title: SCHRAFFT PLANS TO SHUT DOWN; CITES BOXED-CANDY SALES SLUMP
description: The Schrafft Candy Company, which entered the candy business by making gumdrops in 1861, will shut down its operations by the end of this week because of declining consumer interest in expensive boxed chocolates.

title: RATE HOPES LIFT DOW BY 11.80
description: Spurred by hopes for further declines in interest rates, the stock market staged a brisk rally yesterday in moderately active trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which posted only modest gains by midsession, spurted ahead in heavy late activity to finish with a rise of 11.80 points at 976.42. It was the biggest gain since Feb. 26, when the blue-chip average rose 12.41 points, to 966.81.

title: 'TRUTH IN TESTING' IS:(A)(B)(C)
description: The effects of New York State's ''truth-intesting law,'' which took effect Jan. 1, 1980, are being assessed by the Educational Testing Service. The law gives students the right to request copies of their standardized college-admissions-test questions and answer sheets. My analysis of the law's impact is presented in a familiar form.

title: U.S. ASSURES BONN OF WILLINGNESS TO TALK WITH SOVIET
description: The United States assured West Germany today that despite the Reagan Administration's stress on the need for bolstering Western defenses, it was ready in principle to open negotiations with the Soviet Union at all levels and on many issues.

title: U.S. TO SEEK BIDS FOR PHONE SERVICE
description: The Federal Government, in a shift away from its customary reliance on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said today that it would put up for competitive bidding a substantial part of its long-distance telephone service.

title: 18% Prime at Ohio Bank
description: The Ameritrust Corporation, parent of the Ameritrust Company Bank in Cleveland, said today that it had lowered its prime rate to 18 percent from 18 1/2 percent, effective immediately. Most major banks now have an 18 1/2 percent prime rate, which is the rate banks charge their most creditworthy customers.

title: A SCIENCE AIDE'S ROLE
description: My experience in bringing science advice to the apex of Government in past years leads me to hope that President Reagan will find it appropriate to appoint a science adviser at an early date.

title: No Headline
description: British Civil Servants Strike, Closing Government Offices

title: TV: TELLY SAVALAS AS NICHOLAS HELLINGER, LAWYER
description: ONCE upon a time in television land, just a couple of years ago, Telly Savalas played a New York detective named Kojak. The character was tough, smart, sarcastic and irresistible to women. Now, perhaps as soon as next season, Mr. Savalas may be playing a Philadelphia lawyer named Nicholas Pericles Hellinger. The character is, not surprisingly, tough, smart, sarcastic and irresistible to women.

title: HEBREW UNIVERSITY AGAIN CALLS MOUNTIAN ITS HOME
description: After one of the largest construction jobs in Israel's history, Hebrew University is returning to its original home on Mount Scopus, a majestic site that lies in what was from 1948 to 1967 the Jordanian sector of Jerusalem.

title: Yields Fall at Treasury Auction; 6-Month Bills Now at 13.43%
description: The Treasury sold new three- and six-month bills yesterday at rates lower than a week ago. New three-month bills averaged 14 percent compared with 14.46 percent last Monday, while six-month bills averaged 13.43 percent, compared with 14.13 percent.

title: REAGAN HINTING AT ARMS FOR AFGHAN REBELS
description: President Reagan said today that, if Afghan insurgents fighting Soviet forces asked for weapons, he would consider complying with the request.

title: ISRAEL DEPLORES JET-GEAR SALE TO SAUDIS
description: The Israeli Cabinet today assailed the Reagan Administration's decision to sell extra equipment that would enhance the abilities of F-15's sold to Saudi Arabia.

title: Prince of Wales Upstaged at Concert by Financee
description: It was the couple's first official public appearance since their engagement was announced, and when they arrived at London's Goldsmith Hall last night for a benefit concert, it wasn't the Prince of Wales who drew the gasps of delight from the elite audience. It was his fiancee, Lady Diana Spencer, and her off-the-shoulder black chiffon gown.

title: STATE PROGRAM FOR CORPORATE TAX RELIEF IS DISPUTED
description: The following article is based on reporting by Blake Fleetwood and Robert D. McFadden and was written by Mr. McFadden.

title: No Headline
description: Fisk Going to White Sox

title: Texas Air Lifts Continental Stake
description: Texas International Airlines, acting on a stock purchase offer made in its battle for control of Continental Air Lines, bought nearly one-third of Continental's outstanding stock over the weekend at a cost of $62.1 million, a spokesman said.

title: U.S. Loan for Nigeria 737's
description: The Export-Import Bank said today that it would lend $56.9 million to Nigeria Airways to help it purchase four Boeing 737 aircraft and spare parts.

title: 1982 COST TO CITY OF REAGAN CUTS PUT AT $415 MILLION
description: A private analysis of the impact of President Reagan's proposed budget cuts suggests that New York City stands to lose at least $415 million in Federal aid for the 1982 fiscal year that begins July 1.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Nucorp Energy Inc. plans to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of not less than $40 million of coordinated convertible subordinated debentures.

title: JERSEY HOMES FOR AGED DRAW CONGRESSIONAL ANGER
description: The presence of tens of thousands of infirm elderly people and medicated former mental patients in old, converted boarding homes was sharply criticized today before a Congressional committee investigating safety and multiple-death fires in recent months.

title: BANKER'S DEPARTURE SWEETENED
description: When A. Robert Abboud resigned as chairman and chief executive officer of the First Chicago Corporation last April, the bank holding company gave him more than a golden handshake for his 22 years of service. It also gave him a lifetime financial security blanket, according to the proxy statement issued for the company's annual meeting.

title: WOMAN IS DENIED AWARD IN LIBEL SUIT
description: A jury ruled today that while Tommy Thompson's description of Ann Kurth as a provocative sex object in his book ''Blood and Money'' was certainly defamatory, it also was true, and therefore decided against any award in her $3 million libel suit against the author.

title: Steel Output Up by 0.4%
description: Steel production rose to 2.56 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.55 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Colombia Detains 40 In Slaying of Missionary
description: Colombian security forces have detained more than 40 people for questioning in connection with the murder of Chester A. Bitterman 3d, the Lancaster, Pa., linguist and lay missionary whose body was found here on Saturday, military sources said today.

title: A TRANS-ATLANTIC BRIDAL BROKER
description: It pleases Rita Barker immensely that so many ''lovely American gentlemen are seeking English ladies as their wives''; it pleases her that she has been able to provide for one of her Americans, a California man in his 80's, introductions to a succession of eligible women in their 60's, and it pleases her most of all that she manages it all without benefit of computers, ''which after all do not have hearts.''

title: Israeli Bank Earnings
description: Bank Hapoalim B.M., a leading bank in Israel, reported yesterday that earnings in 1980 rose 48.9 percent, to $84.7 million, from $56.9 million in 1979. The bank said that its assets rose 21.4 percent, to $17 billion, from $14 billion.

title: 381 BURROS ARE SLAIN BY MARKSMEN TO CLEAR NAVAL CENTER ON COAST
description: Sharpshooters with rifles have killed hundreds of wild burros after a Navy decision that the animals were endangering planes and ground traffic by straying onto runways and roads at the China Lake Naval Weapons Center.

title: U.S. Requests Fairness By U.N. Rights Agency
description: The United States called on the United Nations Human Rights Commission today to be ''worthy of its name'' by not following ''one standard for the Soviet bloc and its friends and another for all other countries.''

title: SECRETARIES HAVE PICK OF JOBS
description: She is 21 years old, has no college degree and has worked for only a year and a half. Yet Carmela Girello makes more than $300 a week, about $2,000 a year more than the average recent college graduate, and her salary is likely to keep rising.

title: ONE-HOUR STRIKE SET IN POLISH CITY
description: Talks aimed at averting a strike in the textile center of Lodz broke down early today despite efforts of the Government and national leaders of the independent union to a preserve a labor truce.

title: Angels Renew Burelson Pact
description: The California Angels failed to reach agreement on a new contract with their new shortstop, Rick Burleson, so they automatically renewed his old contract today to prevent him from becoming a free agent immediately.

title: A. T. & T. PLANS SALE OF $600 MILLION ISSUE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced plans yesterday to sell publicly $600 million of 10-year notes. A spokesman for A.T.& T. said that proceeds of the 10-year issue would be used for advances and equity investments in subsidiary companies as well as general corporate purposes. He added that no decision had been made about which subsidiaries would receive the funds. He stated that the parent company intended ultimately to replace the 10-year financing with equity, but that the 10-year maturity was selected as the best source of capital at this time.

title: SILVER LINING FOR JOBLESS YOUTHS
description: To the Editor:

title: REPAYMENT ORDERED IN RIGGS CASE
description: The Federal Government, in a shift away from its customary reliance on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said today that it would put up for competitive bidding a substantial part of its long-distance telephone service.

title: New Post for Brewster
description: Kingman Brewster Jr. recently stepped down as Ambassador to Britain but he's taken a new position that will keep him close to British-American affairs.

title: Commerce Secretary Is Heading for His First Roundup
description: As Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldridge is the Reagan Administration's envoy to the nation's business executives, who, as everybody knows, spend a good deal of their spare time on the golf course or tennis court.

title: No Headline
description: Broncos Reportedly Oust Miller and Hire Reeves

title: Advertising; Our Hero Dons His New 'Mask'
description: WHEN the courts stripped Clayton Moore of his Lone Ranger mask a year and a half ago, he was deeply hurt (he seems to talk about it constantly), but it seems to have helped his career.

title: U.S. GETS REPRIEVE ON RELEASE OF TAX DATA
description: The Supreme Court granted the Federal Government a last-minute reprieve today from the required release of computer tapes that the Internal Revenue Service says provide a guide to sophisticated tax-cheating.

title: Loan to Colombia
description: Finance Minister Eduardo Wiesner of Colombia said today that he will sign a $254 million loan agreement with the Bank of America on March 14 in San Francisco. Bank of America is the agent for a pool of banks.

title: A HANDYMAN IN CHINA ALONE ON JOB SINCE '45 MAY GET U.S. PENS
description: ION By A.O. SULZBERGER Jr.

title: MR. CAREY, WESTWAY IS THE WRONG WAY
description: Governor Carey stated flatly last week that ''Westway is going to be built.'' A few days earlier, Senators Moynihan and D'Amato had said that ''trade-in'' funds for Westway were dead.

title: Spain to Court-Martial 21 In Bungled Coup
description: The army ordered today that Lieut. Gen. Jaime Milans del Bosch and 20 other officers be court-martialed on charges of attempting to overthrow the civilian Government.

title: HOW 'FRIDAYS' BEAT 'SATURDAY NIGHT'
description: LOS ANGELES WHEN ''Saturday Night Live'' attempted a topical satire last weekend based on the film ''Altered States'' after the ABC-TV comedy show ''Fridays'' had done the same thing -and much more ambitiously - it served as a symbolic changing of the avant-garde.

title: Chemical Control Indicted for Pollution
description: TRENTON (AP) - The Chemical Control Corporation, whose plant in Elizabeth was the site of an explosion and fire of hazardous wastes last year, has been indicted on charges of polluting state waters and endangering the public.

title: THE THEATER: 'KNUCKLE'
description: DAVID HARE'S ''Knuckle'' at the Hudson Guild Theater is both a parody of detective thrillers and a commentary on urban blight. First produced in London in 1974, the play has a curious, out-ofkilter time frame. Some of the social issues under scrutiny, such as land-grabbing for property development, continue to have a relevance, but the style of the writing and even the background music reach back to the 1950's.

title: Planning an Avalanche
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill has received an avalanche of post cards supporting President Reagan's budget-cutting proposals, but the Massachusetts Democrat has good reason to know the mail doesn't necessarily represent a cross section of public opinion.

title: AN ASTRONAUT PREDICTS SHORT SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: Declaring that the space shuttle in time will ''absolutely revolutionize the way we do business on earth,'' the astronaut who is scheduled to command the first such craft on its maiden voyage early next month said yesterday that he, his co-pilot and the ship, named Columbia, were at long last ''just about ready to go.''

title: Ford Workers To Vote on Pay
description: Steelworkers at the Ford Motor Company's Rouge plant will vote later this week on whether to accept a pay cut to save about 3,200 jobs, an official of the United Automobile Workers union said today.

title: No Headline
description: Author Files 2d Lawsuit In Scientology Dispute

title: SILVER LINING FOR JOBLESS YOUTHS
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR INDIA CENSUS TAKERS, BACK ALLEYS AND BYWAYS
description: Thousands of census workers are busy scouring the back alleys, railroad platforms and parks in India's cities in an attempt to count the country's homeless population.

title: ABC-TV Will Test Ads On Issue
description: The ABC-TV network announced yesterday that it would accept issueoriented commercials during late-night programs this summer as an experiment.

title: BUSINESS LEADERS AND CITY OFFICIALS MEET TO PROTEST MASS-TRANSIT CUTS
description: High-ranking mass-transit officials and business leaders from cities around the nation gathered here today to protest proposed cuts in public transportation financing by the Reagan Administration.

title: BOISTEROUS CONVENTION OF POLISH FARMERS TRIES DEMOCRACY
description: The old opera house here had never seen a show quite like it. Four hundred and ninety farmers from around Poland used the elegant, prewar building for the first national congress of their still-unrecognized union. The two-day session ended today.

title: REAGAN SEEKS BIG FOREIGN-CRISIS FUND
description: The Reagan Administration hopes to gain approval for a $350 million foreign aid ''contingency fund'' to be used at its discretion during foreign policy emergencies, Congressional aides said today.

title: Q. Why does sound sometimes seem to travel farther on cold days?
description: A. When a layer of cold air close to the ground is covered by a layer of warmer air, sound waves traveling upward may be bent, or refracted, by the difference in temperature and redirected toward the ground. An observer standing where the descending sound is focused may therefore hear a sound he would not ordinarily have heard because of his distance from its source.

title: Westchester Board Blocks Acting Sheriff
description: In a rebuff to County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Board of Legislators refused to confirm the nomination of his newly appointed acting commissioner/sheriff.

title: Bay Shore Five Wins Title
description: Mike Schlegel scored 26 points and Thorne Powell added 25 to lead Bay Shore to an 82-71 victory over Port Jefferson tonight for the Suffolk County boys scholastic basketball championship at Ward Melville High School.

title: REFUSAL TO TESTIFY GIVEN NEW SUPPORT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a criminal defendant who chooses not to testify in his own defense is entitled to have the judge instruct the jury that no inference of guilt can be drawn from that choice.

title: THE SOUTH KOREAN PRESIDENT'S COURSE
description: To the Editor:

title: BOEING GETS US AIR PUSH ON 737-300
description: USAir, formerly called Allegheny Airlines, yesterday announced a $570 million program of new aircraft acquisition. It includes plans to buy 10 Boeing 737-300's - if the Boeing Company decides to develop and manufacture this fuel-efficient jetliner.

title: Japanese Loan to Africa
description: A consortium of 20 Japanese banks and life insurance companies has signed a note for 15 billion yen, or $75 million, in loans to the African Development Bank, the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan said today.

title: VIOLINIST: IDA KAVAFIAN IN RECITAL
description: IDA KAVAFIAN, who made her New York solo debut as a Young Concert Artists auditions winner in 1978, gave a recital at Alice Tully Hall last Tuesday night as the 1980 winner of the organization's Michaels Award. As her past performances especially those with the chambermusic ensemble Tashi -have made clear, Miss Kavafian is a violinist and musician of superior quality.

title: GREENSPAN'S WIDENED INFLUENCE
description: In the week or so surrounding the disclosure of President Reagan's economic package, Alan Greenspan, by his own account, made five separate trips to Washington, appeared on seven television news programs and attended countless White House meetings.

title: DISPUTE RISES ON WORKING AT HOME FOR PAY
description: Working at her knitting machine in a quiet room looking out on snow-covered fields, tall trees and craggy hills, Audrey Pudvah does not feel the least bit exploited. In fact she thinks that her job knitting ski hats in her own pleasant log home at her own pace is a pretty good deal.

title: RICHARD R. B. ADAMS
description: Richard Russell Blaine Adams, an expert in languages, died last Friday in Bergen Pines Hospital in Paramus, N.J., after a short illness.

title: PAN AM ELECTS CRONKITE
description: Walter Cronkite, who ended 19 years as anchorman and managing editor of the CBS Evening News last Friday, has been named a director of Pan American World Airways Inc. The announcement was made yesterday by William T. Sewell, chairman and chief executive officer of the airline.

title: ALEXANDER VIETOR, FORMER MAPS CURATOR AT YALE DIES AT AGE 67
description: Alexander O. Vietor, former curator of maps at Yale University and an authority on marine Americana, died yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 67 years old.

title: Bucks Top Cavaliers
description: Pat Cummings scored 30 points, matching his career high, to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to a 118-100 victory tonight over the Cleveland Cavaliers. The Cavaliers, who lost their seventh straight game, received 30 points from Mike Mitchell.

title: North Stars Tie Canadiens; Beaupre Makes 40 Saves
description: Don Beaupre, the rookie goaltender, made 40 saves tonight for Minnesota as the North Stars played a 1-1 tie with the Montreal Canadiens.

title: N.C.A.A. List Large, Not Select; Sports Analysis
description: With 80 of the 264 Division I basketball teams in the nation entered in either the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship (48 teams) or the National Invitation Tournament (32 teams), it is easy to see why college administrations are so devoted to this sport. Big rewards are possible without making the costly investment required for football. Some persons think, however, that there are too many undeserving teams in these tournaments. Wayne Duke, the chairman of the N.C.A.A. Basketball Committee, even admitted Sunday that the teams in his tournament are ''not necessarily the best 48 teams in the nation.''

title: GRANT APPLICATIONS BY U.S. CITIES FROZEN
description: The Reagan Administration has frozen and apparently intends to kill hundreds of applications from across the country, including 13 from New York City, for Federal grants to encourage the economic revitalization of cities.

title: SENATE PANEL TRIMS SOME REAGAN CUTS FROM BUDGET PLANS
description: A Republican-controlled Senate committee voted today to reject some of President Reagan's proposed cuts in financing for social welfare. But it adopted reductions that would bring the budget to $9 billion less than former President Jimmy Carter had recommended for the fiscal year 1982.

title: PUPILS RETURN IN ROSEDALE
description: Laden with lunchboxes, book bags and accounts of lazy afternoons at home, youngsters returned yesterday to two Queens elementary schools that parents had boycotted for five weeks as part of a protest against the closing of a school annex in which most of the students were white.

title: Transcanada Report
description: Transcanada Pipelines Ltd. said its exports would rise by 360 billion cubic feet of natural gas a year if six agreements signed with five separate United States customers were accorded regulatory approval. The company said in its annual report that it was also working with Canadian distribution companies on plans for service extensions to several areas in Manitoba and Ontario not currently served by natural gas.

title: Computervision To Sell Cobilt Unit
description: The Computervision Corporation, a producer of computer systems, said it had agreed to sell its Cobilt division to Applied Materials Inc. of Santa Clara, Calif., for an estimated $15 million in cash and a note.

title: Richard Thomas to Join Wilson's 'Fifth of July'
description: Richard Thomas, best known for his role as John-Boy on the television series ''The Waltons,'' will take over the starring role in Lanford Wilson's ''Fifth of July'' on March 27 at the New Apollo Theater.

title: Slow Steel Growth Predicted in Japan
description: Hiroshi Takano, the executive vice president of steel making for Nippon Kokan K.K., Japan's second-largest steel company after the Nippon Steel Corporation, said yesterday that the era of rapid expansion for the Japanese steel industry had come to an end and that his company foresees growth in steel output falling to 2 percent to 3 percent a year.

title: Venezuela Oil Output Up
description: Venezuelan oil output from Jan. 1 to March 4 averaged 2,204,000 barrels a day compared with a daily average of 2,168,000 over all of 1980 and an average daily production target for this year of 2.2 million barrels, the Ministry of Energy and Mines said today. This year's output consisted of 28.21 percent light crudes, 34.94 percent medium grades and 36.85 percent heavy crudes. Shipments to Feb. 26 were 1,823,000 barrels daily compared with 1,836,000 daily for the whole of 1980 and a target of 1.8 million for 1981, the ministry said.

title: Britain Plans Stock Sale
description: The British Government has decided to sell almost 50 percent of its shares in Cable and Wireless Ltd., the state-owned telecommunications company, for about $220 million, Industry Minister Kenneth Baker told Parliament today.

title: SUDDEN SEA CHANGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sallie Mae Plans Market Borrowing
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, Sallie Mae, will begin borrowing under its own name this year as it phases out its dependence on the Federal Financing Bank, the Treasury announced yesterday.

title: GENERALS DIVIDED OVER MOBILE FORCE
description: An interservice rivalry over control of the Rapid Deployment Force that has rumbled through the ranks of senior generals and admirals for a year broke into the open today before a Senate subcommittee.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny Beverage Corporation and Sea Galley Stores Inc. agreed in principle for the cash purchase of Allegheny's Family Fish House Restaurant chain by Sea Galley for an undisclosed price.

title: Brenda de Banzie, 65; Film and Stage Actress
description: Brenda de Banzie, a British-born actress who worked on the stage and in films on both sides of the Atlantic, died on March 5 following surgery. She was 65 years old.

title: TELESFORO MONZON
description: - Telesforo Monzon, leader of the Basque political party Herri Batasuna, died today in a clinic in Bayonne, France, sources in his party said. He was 76 years old. Mr. Monzon, a lawyer, returned to Spain from exile in France in 1977 along with 10 members of the Basque separatist organization E.T.A.who had been banished to several European countries. He won a seat in Parliament in the 1979 general elections.

title: REAGAN DECIDES NOT TO ABOLISH ENVIROMENT PANEL
description: President Reagan has decided to retain the Council on Environmental Quality, the Cabinet-level body that advises the White House, but will slash its budget, Government officials reported today.

title: SPERM FOUND ESPECIALLY VULNERABLE TO ENVIRONMENT
description: AMID disputed reports that the sperm count of American men is falling, scientists are finding that a wide variety of environmental and industrial chemicals can interfere with the normal development of sperm and possibly cause birth defects and infertility. While past studies have focused almost exclusively on the mother's contribution to fetal malformations and other pregnancy abnormalities, it is now becoming increasingly clear that the father may also play an important role in pregnancy mishaps.

title: METS' CASHEN CAUTIOUS OPTIMIST
description: For Reggie Jackson, the Yankees' first exhibition game became a stomach turner. But for Dave Winfield, it was an eye opener.

title: Ranger-Sedco Pact
description: Ranger Oil Ltd. and Sedco Inc. said they had formed a joint venture to build, own and operate a Sedco heavyduty semisubmersible drilling rig.

title: The U.N. Today; March 10, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 10:30 A.M.

title: SYNTHETIC FUEL CUTS QUESTIONED
description: Michael D. Dingman, chairman and chief executive of Wheelabrator-Frye Inc. , who voted for President Reagan and worked for his election, now is disconcerted about what could happen to his company as a result of the Administration's synthetic fuels strategy.

title: Union Oil Test Well
description: The Union Oil Company of California said its exploratory well off Kalimantan, Indonesia, had tested at a rate of 5,857 barrels of light, low-sulfur oil daily and 22.5 million cubic feet of gas daily. The oil was tested from three zones and the gas from two zones at various depths between 6,782 feet and 8,614 feet. The company said further drilling was planned to determine the significance of the discovery, which is south of the Sepinggan field in an area held by a Union Oil subsidiary.

title: BAR UNIT ASKS KLEINDIENST PENALTY
