description: The Arizona State Bar Association recommended here today that former United States Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst be suspended from practicing law in Arizona for one year.

title: Police Officer Indicted In Queens Drug Inquiry
description: A New York City police officer was among five persons indicted last week by a special narcotics jury on charges of participating in a million-dollar-a-year cocaine ring, the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: KOCH NOMINATES 9 CITY MARSHALS TO 5-YEAR TERMS
description: Mayor Koch, who has tried unsuccessfully to have New York City's 325-year-old marshal system abolished, yesterday nominated nine persons to replace marshals who had been convicted of corruption and reappointed 10 other marshals to new five-year terms.

title: Carey on Florida Trip
description: Governor Carey has complained about what he considers favored treatment for Sun Belt states in the proposed Reagan Adminstration budget, but is not averse to finding a place for himself in the sun. That was evident on Sunday when he left a gray Albany for a brief trip to the more pleasant climes of Florida.

title: Owner Decides to Sell Alouettes to Skalbania
description: Sam Berger, unable to work out a suitable partnership with Nelson Skalbania, has sold the Montreal Alouettes to Skalbania, it was announced today. The transaction ends 50 years of involvement in the Canadian Football League for Berger, 81 years old.

title: Court Turns Down Appeal On Suit by Black Panthers
description: A Federal appeals court ruled unanimously today that John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, did not act illegally in authorizing wiretaps by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the California Black Panther Party in 1969.

title: Swiss Inflation Up
description: Switzerland, which for years has enjoyed one of the world's lowest inflation rates, experienced its worst inflation in six years in February, when consumer prices jumped 1 percent from the previous month, the Government said today.

title: ECONOMIC-AID REQUESTS AFFECTED BY FREEZE ON GOVERNMENT FUNDS
description: Following are the Economic Development Administration grant and loan applications from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut that have been frozen by the Federal Government: New York State New York City Grants Caring Community, $600,000 to rehabilitate the old Food and Maritime High School, 208 W. 13th St., as a cook-training school. Harlem Commonwealth Council, $400,000 to develop commercial site. Harlem Interfaith Council, $875,000 to rehabilitate building. Vita and Phillips buildings, $75,000 for rehabilitation. Brooklyn Army Terminal, $4.5 million for acquisition by city for industrial site. Fordham Plaza, $2.7 million to convert former post office to business use. Harlem Community Council, $500,000 to construct jobs processing center. Transit Authority, $300,000 to weatherize building in Bronx. New York Community Trust, $593,000 to weatherize several buildings. New York City, $600,000 to weatherize several buildings. New York City Cultural Affairs Dept., $315,000 to weatherize several sites. New York City, $700,000 to rehabilitate 55th St.

title: IRAN AND IRAQ REPORT AIR ATTACKS AS WAR'S PACE KEEPS QUICKENING
description: Iraq and Iran reported new air attacks and artillery exchanges along their 300-mile front today as the pace of the six-month-old Persian Gulf war continued to increase.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MARCH 10, 1981
description: International Washington assured Bonn that, despite the Reagan Administration's stress on the need to upgrade Western defenses, it was ready and willing to open negotiations with Moscow at all levels and on many issues. In turn, the West German Foreign Minister said that Bonn would meet its military commitments to NATO. (Page A1, Column 2.) Protests against President Reagan were planned by Canadians on the eve of his visit to Ottawa. The Reagan Administration has taken positions divergent from those of Canada on many issues, including a decision to scrap a treaty to manage fish stocks off the East Coast. (A12:4-6.)

title: A Threat to Public Education
description: Defeated three years ago but undaunted nonetheless, Senate supporters of tuition tax credits are back to do battle. Senators Moynihan, Packwood and Roth have introduced legislation that would allow parents of private and parochial school pupils a credit against their income taxes of up $500 for each child. Given President Reagan's enthusiasm for the idea, the prognosis is brighter this time. Yet passage would deal a severe blow to public schools - and to taxpayers who foot the bill for tax expenditures.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SHUTTERS UNSHUTTERED

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: She is the stepgranddaughter of W. Averell Harriman, and she is a Whitney. One of her partners is the daughter of Jane Engelhard, the patron saint of the Metropolitan Museum. Another partner is a cowgirl with northwestern Pacific money. Together, Alida Whitney Morgan, Sophie Engelhard and Josephine Kerr are opening a new kind of store in Washington, and it is called, appropriately enough, the Right Stuff, and is at 3214 N Street, N.W.

title: U.S. JURY INDICTS 12 AFTER INQUIRY ON CONSTRUCTION
description: Five construction union officials, four officers of contracting companies and three other persons were charged yesterday with racketering or other crimes. They were alleged to have been involved in schemes for illegal payoffs to permit nonunion labor to work on construction and rehabilitation projects in the New York area.

title: 2 Workers Killed in Accident At Unfinished Nuclear Plant
description: A steel form on the cooling tower of a $4 billion nuclear plant under construction collapsed today, causing two workers to fall 70 feet to their deaths and injuring a third worker.

title: Bowater Special Charges
description: The Bowater Corporation said today that it plans to show extraordinary charges of up to $63.8 million in its 1980 accounts to cover last year's closure and employee terminations at its Ellesmere Port newsprint mill in England. It said the exact figure would depend on amounts realized from asset sales.

title: THE HASSLE CURVE IS RISING
description: I'm tired of being cheated by unresponsive bureaucracies and reimbursement systems. They're not trying to rob me, necessarily. It's just that complex organizations are so unyielding that eventually I give up in frustration.

title: HOUSE TOLD OF NEED FOR 'ORPHAN DRUGS'
description: For years, victims of serious but rare diseases have sought in vain for helpful drugs. Pharmaceutical manufacturers say the drugs simply are too costly to develop and produce because of limited use.

title: CBS WIDENING THE ROLE OF ITS FEATURE-FILM UNIT
description: CBS Inc. yesterday announced an expanded commitment to film-making through the formation of a group to produce and distribute films. The plan is expected to require an investment of several hundred million dollars over the next five years.

title: Talking Business with Moore on Trade Balances; Recalculating Oil Import Effect
description: It is commonly accepted that America's oil bill has been a drain on the economy, but, according to Geoffrey H. Moore, that drain has been even more severe than is generally recognized. Mr. Moore, an economist and a leading student of business cycles, suggests that our practice of looking at economic activity in ''real'' terms - that is, after the effect of inflation has been factored out - has in this instance provided a misleading and overly optimistic impression. Relying on a different technique of adjusting for inflation, Mr. Moore concludes that paying the import bill has reduced America's real purchasing power substantially more than official figures show.

title: Grumman Buses Set To Return in April
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday it would begin returning its reinforced Flxible buses to New York City's streets close to schedule in mid-April at the rate of eight buses a day.

title: Three Oppose Car Import Bill
description: Three members of President Reagan's auto industry task force told a Senate panel today that they opposed legislation to restrict Japanese auto imports.

title: 'REAGAN REVERSAL' DISMAYS CANADIANS ON EVE OF VISIT
description: American and Canadian flags are giving a festive air to Ottawa's streets, but on the eve of President Reagan's visit to Canada officials here are displaying little joy after a series of decisions and statements by Washington that run counter to Canadian policy on a long list of issues.

title: No Headline
description: Greg Gonsalves, who played football for four years at Falmouth (Mass.) High School on Cape Cod, will give up that sport when he enters college next fall. He showed why tonight at the Eastern States schoolboy track and field championships in Jadwin Gymnasium when he set an East Coast indoor record in the high jump at 7 feet 3 inches.

title: CONGRESS CHIEFS PREDICT BIG CHANGES IN TAX PLAN
description: Amid mounting criticism of President Reagan's tax cut package, Congressional leaders predicted today that the Administration's proposals would be substantially altered before they are passed into law.

title: DR. KAUVAR OUT AFTER FIVE MONTHS AS CHIEF OF CITY'S HOSPITAL SYSTEM
description: Less than an hour after Dr. Abraham J. Kauvar said that he had no intention of resigning as president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, Mayor Koch announced yesterday that the official had ''decided to resign.''

title: A WINNER AT BLACKJACK, BARRED IN CASINO, APPEALS
description: A three-judge panel took under advisement today an appeal by a card-counter barred from an Atlantic City casino for beating the house at blackjack.

title: Market Place; Electric Cars: The Outlook
description: CAN a small manufacturer of electric cars make money in the fiercely competitive United States automotive market? The U.S. Electricar Corporation says it can, but anyone who reads the company's prospectus filed prior to its public offering last spring might argue no.

title: Buying Arms Instead of Strength
description: American defenses are deficient and the nation is not so poor that they cannot be set right. But that proposition does not justify the shape of President Reagan's new military budget.

title: 'HOW TO GET RICH' BOOKS ENJOY A BOOMING MARKET'
description: The economy may be playing havoc with household budgets, but it has proved to be pure gold for books telling how to avoid financial disaster or turn it to personal advantage. ''A lot of publishers ask if I have any of those books that they can look at,'' said Jay Acton, echoing the view of many other literary agents.

title: INTELLIGENCE GROUPS SEEK POWER TO GAIN DATA ON U.S. CITIZENS
description: The Reagan Administration's newly appointed intelligence officials are asking for renewed authority to gather information on Americans in this country and abroad, using such techniques as searches, physical surveillance and the infiltration of domestic organizations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is New York, and I'm a small-town boy.'' - Dr. Abraham J. Kauvar on leaving his post as president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation. (A1:4.)

title: Indiana Standard Reorganizing Units
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said it is reorganizing operations of several subsidiaries worldwide, effective April 15.

title: MIRACLE AT U.S. STEEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Rebounding a Debit Item in Knicks' Ledger
description: The Knicks are the second worst rebounding team in the National Basketball Association, and one of the major reasons has been their inability to get the crucial second and third shots, whereas most of their opponents do.

title: Busboy Must Stand Trial As Suspect in Nevada Fire
description: A judge ruled today that Philip Bruce Cline, a busboy at the Las Vegas Hilton Hotel-Casino, must stand trial on charges of setting fire to the resort hotel last month in which eight people died.

title: Chess: Kovacevic Wins in Maribor As Speelman Takes Second
description: Vlado Kovacevic, a Yugoslav grandmaster, won the Maribor, Yugoslavia, international tournament, scoring 10-3 in the 14-player round-robin event. Jonathan Speelman of Britain captured second place with 9 1/2-3 1/2, thus attaining grandmaster rank.

title: SOVIET DANCER, HOMES SAYS RUSSIANS EXPLOIT HIM
description: A Soviet ballet dancer who defected to the United States and returned to Moscow last year did so ''because I was of afraid of reprisals against my family,'' and not, as the Soviet press asserted, because he was disillusioned with the American way of life.

title: U.S. ADVISERS TAKING CARE IN EL SALVADOR
description: uf881 By EDWARD SCHUMACHER

title: KEY TO IMPROVING NEW YORK SERVICES
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CALIFORNIA (AL) - Renewed con- t racts with Rick Burleson, shortstop, and B obby Clark, outfielder, pending further ne- g otiations. NEW YORK METS (NL) - Agreed on o ne-year contract for Scott Holman, rookie p itcher.

title: MEDIATOR IN NEED OF SAME
description: The director of the city's Dispute Resolution Center - which mediates disagreements between friends, workers, neighbors and families -and seven staff members walked off the job yesterday because of a dispute with the center's management.

title: ERIK MODEAN
description: Erik Modean, director of the news bureau for the Lutheran Council in the United States of America for 31 years, died Sunday at his home in Maywood, N.J. He was 69 years old.
To the Editor:

title: Markets
description: The stock market rallied strongly on expectations that interest rates would decline further. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.80, to 976.42. Volume was 46.2 million shares. Automobile, oil, blue-chip and airline stocks led the advance. (Page D1.) The interest-rate outlook sent the dollar down against other major currencies. Gold rose $7.90 an ounce, to $471.90, on the Comex and was slightly higher in Europe. (D10.) In commodities markets, metal and grain futures prices closed higher in quiet trading. (D10.)

title: DR. PETER J. KESSELER
description: Dr. Peter J. Kesseler, a former attending surgeon at St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center in Manhattan, died Feb. 28 at his home in Manhattan.

title: Paris-Cairo Atom Plant Accord
description: France and Egypt today initialed an agreement for France to supply two nuclear power plants to Egypt. Officials said the plants, with a capacity of 1,000 megawatts each, would cost about $2 billion.

title: Midshipman Is Dismissed For Cadet's Death in Crash
description: A military jury at the United States Naval Academy today ordered Midshipman Michael Olmstead dismissed from the Navy for his conviction on involuntary manslaughter charges in the death of another cadet in a sports car crash.

title: PRESSURE OF NO.1 RATING FOLLOWS MEYER
description: The tapes from Creighton and St. Joseph's had not arrived yet, and the high from De Paul's victory over Notre Dame had not worn off. There was no practice for the nation's newest topranked college basketball team. ''I took a vacation today,'' Coach Ray Meyer said.

title: 'ROADS OF EXILE'
description: APPARENTLY inspired in part by the late Roberto Rossellini's great ''teaching'' films (''The Rise of Louis XIV,'' ''The Age of the Medicis,'' among others), Claude Goretta, the Swiss director best known here for ''The Lacemaker'' and ''The Wonderful Crook,'' has made ''The Roads of Exile,'' an exceptionally beautiful, eloquent film about the last, feverish years of Jean-Jacques Rousseau (1712-78), the Swiss-born philosopher whose ideas so profoundly influenced the principal figures in the French Revolution.

title: Bridge: Dutch Team Is Still on Top In Tournament in Shanghai
description: After four rounds of qualifying play in China's first international bridge tournament, a powerful foursome from Rotterdam dominated one of the two sections. Unless the Dutch lose heavily tonight when they play a New York team led by Kathie Wei, it seems unlikely that they'll be overtaken.

title: REAGAN TO SEEK JOB REQUIREMENT TIED TO WELFARE FOR UP TO 800,000
description: The Reagan Administration announced plans today to tie welfare benefits to a work requirement, known as ''workfare,'' that it said could place as many as 800,000 people in community jobs.

title: Rear Adm. Boris Akulov, Helped Build Soviet Nuclear Submarines
description: Rear Adm. Boris Akulov, who helped develop the Soviet Union's first nuclear submarines, has died after a long illness, the armed forces newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda said today.

title: LEADERS OF UNITED AUTO WORKERS VOTE TO REJOIN LABOR FEDERATION
description: The executive board of the United Automobile Workers union voted today to recommend reaffiliation with the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the trade union federation.

title: Miklos Gafni, 59, Singer Survived World War II Concentration Camp
description: Miklos Gafni, a tenor who gave up a professional singing career 15 years ago to form Michel's Magnifique, a Bronx-based packaged gourmet food concern, died of a heart attack Sunday at Kennedy International Airport on arriving from a business trip to California. He was 59 years old and lived in White Sulphur Springs, N.Y., where he had recently moved from Manhattan.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS REJECT CAREY PLAN TO AIDE M.T.A.
description: The Senate's Democratic minority announced today that it had rejected Governor Carey's plan to help the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. It complained that the plan did ''nothing for the riding public today'' and required substantial fare increases later.

title: SUSHI AND SASHIMI: CLASSES FOR PREPARING YOUR OWN
description: AS Kazuo Yamazaki put the finishing touches on a rose with petals made of deep pink slices of raw tuna, he remarked that sushi was the most nihilistic form of art. ''It's destroyed as soon as it has been completed,'' he said.

title: GIVE THE JUNTA A CHANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: MAYOR, IN FLUSHING LISTENS TO CONCERNS OF THE HOMEOWNER
description: New York's own type of town-hall democracy arrived in Flushing, Queens, last night as Mayor Koch answered questions in the gymnasium of Public School 200.

title: Mired In The 1930's
description: One of the papers ran a picture of Indiana's electric chair the other day to illustrate a story about an impending execution. The curious thing was that it looked exactly like the first electric chair I ever saw.

title: G.& W. Buys Stake In Two Companies
description: Gulf & Western Industries Inc., continuing an aggressive investment campaign, has bought into two additional companies. The B.F.Goodrich Company said yesterday that it had been notified by Gulf & Western that Gulf has purchased 1,009,200 shares, or 5.96 percent, of the tire manufacturer's stock at a cost of $21.8 million.

title: People
description: * Robert J. Somerville named vice president, director of sales, Metromedia Television, and Robert E. O'Connor vice president and general manager of WNEW-TV, Channel 5, Metromedia's flagship station.

title: STOCKS DROP AFTER EARLY RALLY
description: Responding to a decline in prime lending rates by several major banks, the stock market rally that got under way on Monday gained momentum in a burst of activity at yesterday's opening, then reversed direction and prices drifted lower in heavy trading.

title: by Terry Robards
description: IN their efforts to challenge the best wines of France, producers in California have scored success after success in recent years with a number of European grape varieties - especially the cabernet sauvignon and zinfandel among the reds and the chardonnay among the whites. But the effort to produce competitive pinot noirs, made from the basic red grape of Burgundy, has proved more difficult.

title: Lois Pitts Named John Muir Agency
description: As they were almost destined to, Jerry Rubin, the converted Yippie, and George Lois, the ebullient, indefatigable adman, have found one another. And since the former member of the Chicago Seven is now in effect ad director of John Muir & Company, that means that Lois Pitts Gershon has become its agency.

title: Rabbi Pleads Guilty to Fraud
description: Rabbi Sholom Teitelbaum, a 33-year-old assistant rabbi at the Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street, pleaded guilty yesterday to stock-fraud charges. He admitted using checks with insufficient funds to buy more than $20,000 in stock options from major brokers. He could face five years in prison on each of two counts when sentenced next month in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Bilingual Teaching Plan Offered for Texas Schools
description: The Justice Department today submitted a proposal to carry out a ruling requiring bilingual instruction in the Texas public schools for all Mexican-American children whose ability to speak English is limited.

title: B-52's in Maine Placed on Alert After Soviet Subs Are Detected
description: Some B-52 bombers at Loring Air Force Base in Maine have been placed on increased alert because several Soviet missile-firing submarines have been detected in potentially threatening positions in the Atlantic Ocean, sources in the Defense Department said today.

title: THEATER: 'HEDDA GABLER' BY YALE REP.
description: NEW HAVEN THE setting for Lloyd Richards's production of ''Hedda Gabler'' at the Yale Repertory Theater is blood red - from the wallpaper in Tesman's house to the threatening sky outside - a symbolic backdrop for the fire and ice of Dianne Wiest's performance as Hedda. Miss Wiest, a stunning young actress, is playing this challenging role at exactly the right stage of her burgeoning career.

title: STUDY URGES BASING OF MX MISSILES ON SUBMARINES
description: A Congressional assessment of the MX missile asserted today that the current plan to base it on land would leave it vulnerable to Soviet attack and suggested instead that the missile be put aboard small submarines.

title: HOW TO KNEAD A 4-YEAR LOAF
description: This is a primer for new Federal appointees, especially those who are cutting budgets to the bone, wiping the slate clean, clearing out deadwood, helping the country make a new beginning, and who harbor other such fantasies.

title: Q. Four years ago I received two cases of Chateau Garraud 1970, Lalande de Pomerol, in magnums. What can you tell me about this chateau and its wine?  JACK Z. GARDY Upper Montclair, N.J.
description: A. Chateau Garraud is one of many little-known estates producing red wines mainly from merlot grapes in Lalande de Pomerol, a district that lies just north of Pomerol in the eastern part of the Bordeaux region of France. The wines of Lalande de Pomerol do not often reach the same quality levels as those of Pomerol, but they can be an excellent value in good vintages. And 1970 was a very good vintage all over Bordeaux. I cannot recall tasting a Chateau Garraud 1970, but the chances are that it is a decent wine. I have yet to be disappointed by a 1970 Bordeaux that has been properly stored.

title: Deep-Fried Marinated Chicken; Marinade (see recipe) 2 pounds boned chicken Oil for deep frying 1 cup flour.
description: 1. Cut chicken, with skin, into generous bite-sized pieces. 2. Add chicken pieces to marinade and mix thoroughly with your hands. Marinate 30 minutes. 3. Bring a generous amount of oil to medium temperature (340 degrees) in a heavy-bottomed pot or deep-fryer. 4. Drain the marinade from the chicken and dust the chicken lightly with flour. Use your hands to toss and coat individual pieces thoroughly. Letcoated chicken rest for two to three minutes.

title: A JAPANESE GASTRONOME AND HIS SECRETS
description: OSAKA, Japan SHIZUO TSUJI leaned back in his maroon plush armchair, surveyed his ornate dining room with its chandeliers and Oriental rugs, and cut a slice of chocolate cake freshly baked by one of his students. ''Let's not talk for a few minutes, just eat,'' he said, with the air of one who knows how to savor the good things. As Japan's most famous gastronome, he has turned his appreciation of fine food into a career. An expert on French and Japanese cuisine, Mr. Tsuji heads the leading professional cooking school in Japan and has written 29 books on cooking, travel, music and medieval French banquet fare.

title: REAGAN DELIVERS HIS BUDGET TO CONGRESS WITH A WARNING TO REMEMBER 'OUR MANDATE'
description: President Reagan sent to Congress today a proposed $695 billion budget for the fiscal year 1982 that he portrayed as the centerpiece of his plan to ''stop runaway inflation'' and ''revitalize the economy'' by shrinking the role of the Federal Government.

title: HOW TO BUY THE FISH FOR SASHIMI
description: THE abiding rule, when it comes to fish used raw for sushi and sashimi, is that it must be fresh. That means not only recently caught, within the last 24 hours if possible, but also maintained in good condition. Proper cleaning and careful refrigeration are as important as freshness. Fish that has been frozen is not suitable.

title: Short-Term Rates Dip Slightly; Long-Terms Are Moribund
description: Short-term interest rates declined slightly yesterday, but longterm rates barely moved - an indication that investors continue to prefer short-term securities, while they wait for signs that inflation is subsiding.

title: Inquiry Under Way On Horse-Drugging
description: A Federal grand jury is looking into allegations that harness horses at Roosevelt and Yonkers raceways were drugged, a Justice Department lawyer revealed yesterday.

title: RANGERS BEATEN 6-4
description: Off the ice, the Rangers made a move today that is expected to help them prepare for the National Hockey League playoffs. On the ice, they suffered a 6-4 loss to the Quebec Nordiques tonight that may have hurt their chances of making the playoffs.

title: CORRECTION
description: In SportsMonday this week, a chart of the pairings for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball tournament was incorrect. In the Mideast region, the bracket containing Indiana and the one containing Wake Forest should have been transposed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I urge the members of Congress to remember that last November the American people's message was loud and clear.

title: NETS COULD CLAIM MCADOO
description: Bob McAdoo, who lives in Ramsey, N.J., could become a member of the New Jersey Nets by the weekend. The Detroit Pistons have said they do not want McAdoo to play for them the rest of the season, and are expected to place him on waivers later this week rather than have him report to practice.

title: A FOOD STORE TO MAKE IRISH EYES SMILE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Anne Gerard-Flynn is a freelance writer based in Dublin. By ANNE GERARD-FLYNN DUBLIN

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ROSANNE CASH, who will be performing at the Bottom Line tonight and tomorrow night, said recently that she felt ''country music is turning left a little bit.'' ''And,'' she added, ''I hope I'm helping it.''

title: ENIGMATIC WEST GERMAN ROCKET CONCERN FINDS A HOME IN LIBYAN DESERT
description: A West German rocket company, whose opaque activities led to its expulsion from Zaire after complaints by other African governments and the Soviet Union, is asserting that it has successfully launched a suborbital rocket from a new test site in Libya.

title: CITY MAY REQUIRE NEW EQUIPMENT IN CABS: MAPS
description: Confronted with mounting evidence that many taxicab drivers cannot find their way around New York City, the Taxi and Limousine Commission is expected to pass a regulation today to require all drivers to carry a detailed street map in their cabs.

title: Cassoulet Toulousain La Cote Basque
description: 1 1/2 pounds white navy beans 5 quarts water 2 4-pound ducks Coarse salt to taste 2 carrots, whole 1 onion, chopped 1 onion studded with cloves Bouquet garni (thyme, parsley and bay tied in a cheesecloth) 2 pounds boned loin of pork 1/2 pound fresh pork rind 2 pounds lamb shoulder cut in 1 1/2-inch pieces 1 cup beef, pork or chicken stock 3 cups dry vermouth or white wine 1 tablespoon tomato puree 6 cloves garlic, peeled 1/2 pound salt pork, coarsely chopped 4 shallots, peeled 8 Toulouse sausages (see note) Approximately 1 pound saucisson a l'ail (garlic sausage) in one piece.

title: MODEST CLEANING TOOLS
description: WITHOUT making an obsession out of it, I try hard to keep my pots and pans clean. And I do it as I go along, cleaning each pan after its use, so that at the end of preparing a meal I don't have to look at an enormous pile that will propel me into despondency. Many good cooks have worked out effective systems for washing kitchen equipment; I offer mine as a suggestion.

title: A WIZ OF A WIZ
description: ONE afternoon in March 1980, as I waited in a taxi for a light to change, Yip Harburg crossed the avenue directly in front of us. I thought to leap out and greet him - I had known Yip all my life, but I hadn't talked with him in a month or so. I held back, thinking it over, not wishing to be intrusive, until the moment was lost, until Yip was gone from sight and we had moved along to some other corner way down the road.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MARCH 11, 1981
description: International Detering Moscow from intervention in Poland was discussed Monday by President Reagan, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany. They agreed to try to use the expressed interest of the Soviet leadership in a meeting with Mr. Reagan as a form of leverage to avert any intervention. (Page A1, Column 1.) Poland's month-long labor peace ended as workers in the city of Lodz staged a one-hour warning strike and the authorities announced that large-scale military maneuvers would be held by the Warsaw Pact countries later this month. Lech Walesa, the leader of the independent union, conferred with the Prime Minister over charges of harassment against unionists in Lodz and other issues. (A8:4-6.)

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT is the premise of this column, of course, that the preparation of a first-rate meal within the span of 60 minutes requires neither hocus-pocus nor a great deal of prestidigitation. Generally speaking, when working within that time I have limited myself largely to main courses with accompanying side dishes such as rice or noodles plus a salad with cheese.

title: WESTCHESTER COMMUNITIES COMPETING TO BE HOST FOR NEW CONVENTION CENTER
description: Envious of recent economic development to the north, Westchester County's three aging southern cities are competing with White Plains and other communities to win a proposed multimillion-dollar convention center project that they say would serve as a magnet for local growth.

title: Doubleday Appoints New Dell President
description: Robin Smith, president of the Doubleday book clubs since 1974, has been named president and general manager of the Dell Publishing Company, also a unit of Doubleday & Company, effective April 1. Carl Tobey, Dell's president since 1976, will become chairman, a position vacant for several years.

title: DEMOCRATS IN HOUSE AGREE TO SPEED ACTION ON BUDGET
description: House Democratic and Republican leaders agreed today to speed consideration of the budget for the fiscal year 1982 and adopted a timetable calling for final budget action by mid-July, to be followed immediately by final action on a tax cut.

title: L.I. COUPLE BACK REAGAN--AND HIS BUDGET
description: Joseph and Joanne Spinella eat amply if not lavishly and own their split-level house. Their two cars date from the early 70's and are used much less than in the past because of the rising cost of gasoline.

title: JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA MOVING TO RESOLVE THEIR DISAGREEMENTS
description: Japan has agreed to sell more than 400,000 tons of surplus rice, valued at close to $200 million, to South Korea following the failure of much of the 1980 Korean rice crop, officials announced here last weekend.

title: ARETE ENCYCLOPEDIA MISSES SALES TARGET
description: Late last August, the Arete Publishing Company began to distribute the first volumes of a new encyclopedia called the Academic American Encyclopedia, aimed at what Arete perceived to be a gulf in the market between World Book and the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

title: CHIEF OF SECTION ON THE DISABLED LEAVES SCHOOLS
description: The executive director of the New York City Board of Education's Division of Special Education and Pupil Personnel Services has resigned after a series of meetings with Frank J. Macchiarola, the Schools Chancellor.

title: The Hospital Search, Continued
description: It took New York City only half a year to chew up and disgorge its latest chief of hospitals. Last August a much-touted nationwide search led to the choice of Dr. Abraham Kauvar to become president of the troubled Health and Hospitals Corporation. He came with fine credentials: a distinguished record in Denver running a public hospital, organizing outpatient care and harmonizing race relations. He seemed just the man to bring stability to an agency whose top officers typically counted their tenure in months.

title: Brooklyn Woman, 18, Is Arrested In Dec. 26 Armored-Car Robbery
description: A second person has been arrested in connection with the $700,000 armored-car robbery Dec. 26 in Brooklyn, the police said yesterday. The new suspect - Donna Calvacante, 18 years old, of 1455 Loring Avenue, in the East New York section of Brooklyn -was arrested at her home by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and detectives from the Police Department's major cases squad.

title: Constitution, Look Out
description: The legislatures of Missouri and Washington are close to petitioning Congress for a national convention for the purpose of amending the Constitution to require a balanced Federal budget. They would be the 31st and 32d states to join the call, only two short of the required two-thirds of the state legislatures before Congress would have to respond. That number 32, like every other aspect of this method of constitutional change, is disputed. But one thing is clear: a constitutional crisis may be imminent.

title: WHAT HAVE THE FEDS AND JOHN LOCKE TO DO WITH MIAMI'S ART DECO
description: To the Editor:

title: Tudor City's Tenants Get Notice on Plan for Parks
description: Tenants of Tudor City have been given 15-day notice that representatives of Harry B. Helmsley, the developer, ''intend to exercise their rights'' on two parks in the housing development.

title: Three New Judges Join Criminal Court
description: Mayor Koch swore in three new Criminal Court judges, all of whom had been recommended by the Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary and reviewed by a committee of the New York City Bar Association.

title: TAPE OF ACCUSED IN MURDER AT MET PLAYED FOR COURT
description: A Metropolitan Opera stagehand's initial videotaped version of his activities last summer on the night a violinist was murdered at the Met was introduced in State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Reagan's Hidden Persuaders
description: The Battle of the Budget will be fought on two levels: in the Congress, and between private organizations in the nation that support or oppose President Reagan's economic program.

title: A SENATE PARTY MARKS CENTURY IN SAME ROOM
description: The State Senate threw a lavish cocktail party in the lobby today to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Senate's move from a temporary room in the Capitol to the vast, goldleafed chamber on the third floor. The party featured a seven-foot cake and ice sculptures forming the numeral 100, an apple representing the state fruit and the state beaver.

title: MAJOR BANKS CUT PRIME RATE 1/2 POINT, TO 18%
description: Most of the nation's major banks lowered their prime lending rates yesterday by half a percentage point, to 18 percent, amid predictions by economists that further declines in this key rate are in the offing.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: There is no trick to getting on a bus and sitting down in an empty seat. Standing in a crowded bus and getting a seat within a few stops is another matter. This involves a little game known as positioning, and what it boils down to is getting a seat ahead of the other standees, without doing anything as crass as knocking over fellow passengers, elbowing or stepping on feet. The seat is achieved by standing in the right place, in front of the right person.

title: WALL STREET PLEASED BY PROSPECT OF INCREASED CREDIT BUSINESS
description: Wall Street executives said yesterday that they were heartened by the Reagan Administration's program to reduce Government borrowing and by the resulting prospect of more business for their own firms.

title: I.C.I.- BRITAIN'S FLAWED GIANT
description: Imperial Chemical Industries, a symbol of strength as Britain's largest industrial company, holds a special place in this nation's economy.

title: CUT SOUGHT IN FEDERAL BORROWING
description: The Reagan Administration today proposed to cut the rapid growth of Federal borrowing in an effort to reduce the pressures on credit markets that have contributed to high interest rates.

title: 2d Envirotech Departure
description: Berne A. Schepman, 53, has resigned as president of the Envirotech Corporation, a manufacturer of antipollution, underground mining and industrial processing equipment. He was succeeded by Robert L. Chambers, 61, who continues as chairman of the Menlo Park, Calif., company.

title: TEACHER'S STRIKE DIVIDES A RURAL OHIO TOWN
description: The longest teacher strike now under way in the nation is approaching its fifth month of bitterness and recrimination in this little rural town, and there seems to be little chance of a settlement until the local school board attains its goal of dismissing many of the remaining strikers.

title: TRANSPLANT PATIENT OFF RESPIRATOR
description: Mary D. Gohlke was taken off a respirator and breathed normally today, a day after receiving a heart and lungs from a dead donor.

title: MARY BROOKS PICKEN
description: Mary Brooks Picken, an authority on dress, fabric, design and sewing, died Sunday at a nursing home in Williamsport, Pa.

title: WHITE HOUSE HIT A LAST-MINUTE SNAG ON CANADA TRIP
description: Reagan Administration officials disclosed today that the White House had to make last-minute efforts to prepare President Reagan for his Canadian trip after normal preparations through the State Department and National Security Council staff proved inadequate.

title: FOUNDATION'S BID TO DISBAND
description: CARSON CITY, Nev. March 10 (AP) The Fleischmann Foundation, which distributed almost $200 million in line with the wishes of the late Max Fleischmann, petitioned the Carson City District Court yesterday for permission to dissolve.

title: MINNESOTA CHEESES, IN THE DUTCH MANNER
description: There's a touch of Holland in this little farm community some 45 miles northeast of Minneapolis, where an adventurous dairy farmer and his wife are making gouda on their farm just the way the Dutch do. And after years of struggling to squeeze a living out of 70 milking cows, Joe Eichten is now sitting on a more comfortable tuffet, feeding the curds from half that number of cows to a fast growing clientele of cheese lovers and fattening his pigs with the whey.

title: Gas Price Up 9.1, To $1.50 a Gallon
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs said gasoline cost an average of $1.50 a gallon during the last week in February, jumping 9.1 cents in only four weeks.

title: Shared Loss
description: St. Luke in the Fields is an old brick church at the lower end of Manhattan Island. It is not, strictly speaking, an architectural treasure, but it is pleasing to look at.

title: Advertising; Media Role Seen for Ad Complaints
description: A panel of the National Advertising Review Board recommends that the media be more attentive to consumer complaints about advertising and take pains to screen out inaccurate or misleading advertising.

title: YOGURT FROM FRANCE MOVES EAST IN U.S.
description: It had to happen sometime, and now it has. France, the land of rich Normandy butter, creme fraiche, omelets with extra yolks, cream sauces and triple-creme cheeses with at least 72 percent butterfat, is now sending another dairy product to the northeastern United States. It is - are you sitting down? - yogurt.

title: METS CLOUT 3 HOMERS IN OUTSLUGGING JAYS
description: The Mets opened another exhibition season and another so-called new era today, but this time they did it with a certain clatter, overpowering the Toronto Blue Jays, 10-7, in a salvo of home runs by Lee Mazzili, Rusty Staub and Dan Norman.

title: Ex-Boston Official Sentenced
description: A former Boston School Committee member, Gerald O'Leary, was sentenced to a year and a half in prison today for trying to extort $650,000 from a school bus ompany.

title: IN THE EYE OF THE STORM OF BUDGET-CUT PLANNING
description: ''I have to suggest here,'' said David A. Stockman, pausing at what seemed for him the rare difficult question, ''that I'm not running this Government single-handed.''

title: No Headline
description: BASKETBALL ALL-AMERICANS; N.C.A.A. Pairings; Basketball All-Americans; First Team

title: G.M. Layoffs in Brazil
description: General Motors do Brasil S.A. has laid off 900 of its 20,000 workers and cut output by 150 cars a day, to 700, because of falling sales, a company spokesman said today. The spokesman attributed the recession in the car industry to tight credit and higher gasoline prices. The largest Brazilian car maker, Volkswagen do Brasil S.A., announced in January a 6 percent reduction in the work force and three weeks' extra paid holiday for 7,400 workers.

title: BRITAIN RAISES TAXES AND REASSERTS THAT CUTTING INFLATION IS KEY GOAL
description: The Thatcher Government in Britain presented a stark austerity budget today that raised taxes and reasserted the Government's priority that inflation, not unemployment, must be its principal target.

title: HOW TO UPDATE AND EXPAND A NEW JERSEY SHOPPING MALL
description: One of the nation's greatest exercises in updating and expanding a regional shopping center is under way here. It took another step forward last week when Abraham & Straus opened a two-level store of 240,000 square feet.

title: SUIT ALLEGES INSIDER DEAL ON AMAX
description: A Chicago brokerage firm sued two other brokerage houses yesterday in Manhattan Federal court on charges that they had helped customers with inside information on a proposed takeover to make huge profits in Amax Inc. stock options.

title: Defense Rests in Trial Of Alleged Nazi Guard
description: Lawyers for John Demjanjuk, who is accused of lying about his past to obtain United States citizenship, rested their case today after presenting a statement from a former guard at a Nazi death camp that he did not recall ever seeing the defendant there.

title: PROGRAM TO CLEAN UP MEDITERRANEAN SEA IS APPROVED
description: Emerging from the Festival Palace in Cannes last week, where a six-day United Nations conference on cleaning up the Mediterranean had just ended, one of the participants looked out at the sea and said: ''It looks cleaner already.''

title: SOVIET CITES COMMENT BY REAGAN AS JUSTIFYING ITS AFGHAN ACTION
description: President Reagan's remark that he was prepared to consider supplying arms to the insurgents in Afghanistan was depicted in the Soviet press today as further justification of Soviet military support for the Afghan Government.

title: CLANCYS AND CHIEFTAINS, IRISH OF YORE
description: TWO recent concerts at Avery Fisher Hall - the Chieftains on Sunday and the Clancy Brothers last Friday - illustrated the breadth and vitality of Irish traditional music. The Chieftains have been performing for 16 years and the Clancy Brothers for 22, but neither has gone stale. The Chieftains are the acknowledged masters of an 18th-century Celtic tradition, and the Clancys' forte is the simpler, more rugged Irish folksongs of the 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: Zimmer Talks About 'Sad' Sox
description: Don Zimmer didn't exactly leave his heart at Fenway Park, but he worked in Boston long enough to feel sad over the exodus of much of the Red Sox talent.

title: TRAVELING COMPANIONS AND PANTS PATCHES
description: 1. Jean Filips

title: PAKISTANI HIJACKERS TRIM THEIR DEMANDS
description: Hijackers holding more than 100 hostages on a Pakistani jetliner reduced their demands today but threatened to blow up the plane and all aboard unless Pakistan met a deadline tomorrow for freeing political prisoners, Syrian and Pakistani officials said.

title: RESCH, TAMBELLINI DEALT TO ROCKIES
description: In the final minutes before yesterday's National Hockey League trading deadline, the Islanders sent Glenn (Chico) Resch, their goaltender for seven seasons, and Steve Tambellini, a second-year center, to the Colorado Rockies. In return they got Mike McEwen, a defenseman, and Jari Kaarela, a rookie goalie.

title: CASSOULET: VARIATIONS ON A HEARTY THEME
description: THE art of cassoulet-making is taken so seriously in France that many cooks treat it like a souffle. Lest a draft ruin the dish, the oven door is not opened until the cassoulet is ready to eat. Hence the cobbler's shop with the notice outside: ''Closed against currents of air - cassoulet in oven. Please return tomorrow.''

title: Index; International
description: Soviet cites Reagan remark as justifying its Afghan action A3 Mediterranean nations approve plan to clean up the sea A3 Turkey welcomes Greece's easing of Aegean flight restrictions A3 Hijackers trim demands but threaten to blow up hostages A3 Japan and South Korea moving to patch up disagreements A4 Around the World A5 Enigmatic West German rocket company finds a home in Libya A6 U.S. envoy in Beirut unhurt in sniper attack on his car A6 Polish dissidents allowed to travel abroad A8 White House hits a last-minute snag on Canada trip A11 Reagan unveils military loan pro- gram for American allies B5 Government/Politics In the eye of the hurricane of budget cut planning B4 Three Federal agencies said to drop objections to Westway B7 Senate chamber's 100th year marked with Albany party B7 Bar groups denounce Reagan plan to end legal aid to poor B20 General Around the Nation A12 Auschwitz deaths disputed in Cali- fornia lawsuit A16 Report urges putting MX missiles on submarines A16 Westchester cities compete for convention center B2 Court bars press from hearing statements made by Crimmins B3 Industry/Labor 5 New York newspaper unions agree to joint negotiations B2 Education/Welfare New York City's special education chief resigns B2 The Living Section Food A Japanese gastronome and his secrets C1

title: CHRYSLER SEEKS TO GET BY WITHOUT MORE LOAN AID
description: Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that his company had found possible savings of about $150 million in its effort to accumulate a $300 million nest egg to help it endure sales slumps without further Federal aid.

title: ; PRESSING FOR 2 MORE
description: The United States Postal Service said today that it would raise first-class postage rates to 18 cents from 15 cents on March 22 and would petition the Postal Rate Commission to grant its earlier request for an increase to 20 cents.

title: 9 Injured in Fire In Newark Project
description: NEWARK (AP) - Nine persons were injured in a three-alarm blaze at an 18-story apartment complex, forcing the removal of several hundred residents, Fire Director John Caufield said.

title: AUSCHWITZ SURVIVOR SUES FOR PRIZE FOR PROVING GERMANS GASSED JEWS
description: An unusual legal confrontration is under way in the Superior Court of Los Angeles County in which the principal issue is whether Nazi Germany used gas to murder Jews at Auschwitz.

title: Continental Delays Meeting on Merger
description: Continental Air Lines, now largely owned by Texas International Airlines, postponed indefinitely the special meeting it had scheduled for Thursday for stockholders to vote on a proposed merger with Western Airlines.

title: Careers; Accounting Moves Into New Fields
description: DO accountants take too narrow a view of their career possibilities? Herbert Schnur, a certified public accountant and an instructor at Baruch College, believes they do. He says they should concentrate on putting their expertise to work in many new and exciting fields.

title: George Wallace Plans to Marry a Singer
description: George C. Wallace, the former Governor of Alabama, confirmed yesterday that he planned to marry Lisa Taylor, a country and western singer who traveled with him during his 1968 Presidential campaign.

title: U.S. Reinstates Two As Law of Sea Delegates
description: The State Department today reinstated two career officials who had been dropped from the delegation to the United Nations Law of the Sea Conference on Saturday.

title: NETS INTERESTED IN MCADOO
description: The New Jersey Nets have indicated they would be interested in claiming Bob McAdoo, expected to be waived by the Pistons this week. Page A20

title: THOUSANDS JOIN IN QUEST WHEN IT'S LOBBYING DAY
description: Thousands of constituents in search of state funds came teeming through the Capitol's hallways today, jamming the elevators, clogging staircases and fairly bowling over legislators in their pursuit.

title: Brazil May Borrow $15 Billion in 1981
description: Brazil borrowed $2.81 billion abroad in January and February and may borrow up to $15 billion from foreign commercial banks this year, the central bank president, Carlos Geraldo Langoni, said today.

title: Kellwood Head Leaves Over 'Differences'
description: John R. Barsanti Jr., president and chief operating officer of the Kellwood Company since 1976, has resigned from the St. Louis-based apparel manufacturer. In a prepared statement, Fred Wenzel, chairman and chief executive officer of the corporation, cited ''differences in management style and the direction of the company'' as reasons for the resignation.

title: TV: 'THE KILLING OF RANDY WEBSTER'
description: IN ''The Killing of Randy Webster,'' the television movie on CBS at 9 this evening, a 17-year-old is shot to death by a Houston policeman, who, supported by his fellow officers, maintains that the young man emerged from a stolen van wielding a gun. The incident of February 1977 is quickly, almost routinely, dismissed as justifiable homicide. Randy's parents, however, are not fully satisfied, and a long and frustrating search for the truth begins.

title: BEST BUYS
description: PLAIN winter vegetables such as greens, carrots, cabbage and celery continue to be the best buys in the market this week, and prices are reasonable also for onions and potatoes.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATES O.P.M. COMPUTER LEASES
description: A major computer leasing company has come under scrutiny after reports that it put together questionable leasing arrangements for some of the country's biggest corporations.

title: FEDERAL CARETAKERS OF AMERICA'S FILMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Keogh, I.R.A.  Investments
description: MANY people don't seem to realize that Keogh and Individual Retirement Account money can be invested directly in stocks and bonds as well as in savings bank certificates or mutual fund shares.

title: News Analysis
description: When Dr. Abraham J. Kauvar was chosen five months ago by New York City as president of its municipal hospital system after a nationwide talent hunt, his friends offered both their congratulations and condolences.

title: NOTES FROM CITY'S BLIGHTED UNDERGROUND RAILWAY
description: Some date the current travails of the city's subway system to 197l, a period when Dr. William J. Ronan's suzerainty over the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was total. That year the voters rejected a $2.5 billion transportation bond issue, an act, according to these historians of our decrepit system, that hastened the decline and stall of the wholly Ronan empire.

title: DO MOVIES' TITLES AFFECT BOX OFFICES?
description: ''Resurrection,'' ''Carny'' and ''The Great Santini'' have two things in common. All three 1980 movies got a number of excellent reviews but all three also had rotten titles that may have contributed to their difficulties at the box office.

title: Bernard Person, Winner Of Dutch Honors in War
description: Bernard Person, who delivered daily broadcasts to the Nazioccupied Netherlands during World War II and was later decorated by the Dutch Government, died Monday in Albuquerque, N.M., where he was visiting his daughter. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Willard King, Lawyer; Was a Lincoln Scholar
description: Willard L. King, a senior partner in a Chicago law firm and a Lincoln scholar, died last Thursday in Barbados, where was vacationing. He was 87 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: TURKS HAIL GREEK MOVE TO EASE AIRSPACE RULES
description: Turkey has welcomed a Greek move to ease restrictions on airspace over the Aegean Sea as a positive ''gesture of good will'' before the resumption of talks next week between the two nations.

title: Aviation Talks Are Set in Tokyo
description: Japan and the United States will reopen civil aviation talks in Tokyo between April 6 and 10, the Transport Ministry said today. According to Transport Ministry sources, American negotiators are expected to present demands including the opening of regular flights to Japan by United Airlines. Japan has been seeking a revision of the current agreement because it believes the 1952 pact favors the United States on the lucrative trans-Pacific route.

title: Shot by Husband, Wife Wins Damages
description: A jury awarded $425,000 to Virginia Bonsignore, who was seriously wounded in 1976 when she was shot by her husband, Blase Bonsignore, a 48-year-old New York City police officer who shot himself to death.

title: News Analysis
description: A year ago, the Carter Administration quietly resumed ''nonlethal'' military aid to El Salvador's junta, arguing that it would help the Salvadoran armed forces to respect human rights while combating leftist insurgents. But last year more than 13,000 people were killed in El Salvador, most of them reputedly by the security forces.

title: News Analysis
description: ''I can remember being arrested at the City Hall lunch counter in Atlanta in 1960,'' Julian Bond, a Georgia State Senator, said the other day, recalling how Southern states resisted efforts by civil rights activists to end racial discrimination.

title:
RED SMITH;
More on Beaverkill
description: A RECENT column in this space told of the plan of a New Jersey company called Titan Group Inc., to develop a 954-acre tract in the Catskills as a recreational facility with a pipeline to carry treated sewage to nearby Roscoe, N.Y., to be discharged into the Beaverkill River, the beloved stream that was the cradle of flyfishing for trout in America.

title: LEWIS PLEDGES DEEP CUTS IN FEDERAL AID FOR AMTRAK
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis, in the strongest terms so far, today declared his aim to slash Federal financing of Amtrak deeply, asserting that the energy-efficiency of passenger trains was a ''myth.''

title: CRONKITE DEFENDS TAKING PAN AM POST
description: Walter Cronkite yesterday defended his decision to join a corporate board while continuing as a correspondent for CBS - an arrangement prohibited by both rival networks, ABC and NBC.

title: Juror on Disabled Bus Hit by Truck Sues City
description: A Manhattan juror who was injured last Thursday on the Staten Island Expressway when a truck hit a Transit Authority bus carrying the jury he was on filed a $31.5 million claim for damages against the city yesterday.

title: AGENCY HEADS CONFIRMED
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI)The Senate today confirmed the nominationss of Roscoe L. Egger Jr. as head of the Internal Revenue Commission and Robert Blanchette as head of the Federal Railroad Administration.

title: Nuggets Sign Coach Moe To a Long-Term Contract
description: The Denver Nuggets announced today that Doug Moe had been signed to a multiyear contract as head coach.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AN elderly Minnesota man was taking five drugs, only one of which, a sleeping medication, he could identify. After suffering a heart attack he was sent home with two more prescription drugs, which he began alternating with the old ones so that none would be ''wasted.'' What resulted was a bizarre combination that, fortunately, was discovered because it could have proved fatal.

title: New Thai Cabinet Formed, Ending a 10-Day Crisis
description: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda formed a new Thai Cabinet today, ending a 10-day crisis, the official Thai radio announced.

title: Ex-Jet in College Post
description: Billy Joe, 40-year-old former New York Jet running back, was named football coach at Central State University today. He previously coached at Cheyney State for seven years. He played on the Jets' 1969 Super Bowl team.

title: Brascan Scott Offer
description: Brascan Ltd., a Toronto-based investment and mining concern controlled by the Bronfman family, said in a filing with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission that it intended to purchase up to 20 percent of the outstanding shares of the Scott Paper Company. Brascan also said in the filing that it now owned 4.53 million shares, or 11.6 percent, of Scott's common stock. Last week, Scott disclosed that Brascan intended to acquire at least 15 percent of Scott's common stock and that the Toronto company had said it might seek 20 percent.

title: POLAND LETTING DISSIDENTS VISIT ABROAD
description: For three years, Stanislaw Baranczak, a poet and scholar, has been listed in the Harvard University catalogue as an associate professor of Slavic languages and literature. But Mr. Baranczak has not been able to give his courses, or even visit the United States. His applications for a passport have been consistently refused because of his dissident activities.

title: Emery Air Freight To Purchase Planes
description: The Emery Air Freight Corporation, a company that serves small-package and air-cargo customers, said it planned to spend $63 million to expand its 66-plane fleet by acquiring 12 Boeing 727 aircraft from other carriers.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard BRICKS TO BABEL. A Selection From 50 Years of His Writings, Chosen With New Commentary by the Author. By Arthur Koestler. 697 pages. Random House. $20.

title: France's President Says He Sold Bokassa Jewels
description: President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France said tonight that jewels given him by Jean-Bedel Bokassa, the former leader of the Central African Republic, had been sold and the money given to charities in the African nation.

title: Water, Water...
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I've just finished reading your article ''New York's Water Flows in Hollywood'' (March 4). As a conscientious citizen and resident of Manhattan (who has been recycling rinse water for my thirsty plants, turning off the shower between latherings, and laundering only once every 10 days), I am incensed at:

title: WORKERS IN LODZ STAGE A ONE-HOUR STRIKE
description: Workers in the city of Lodz staged a one-hour warning strike today, ending Poland's monthlong labor peace, as large-scale Warsaw Pact maneuvers in Eastern Europe were announced for later this month.

title: Europeans Urged to Aid Disabled
description: About 200 blind people demonstrated outside the European Parliament today demanding increased Common Market support for the disabled. The demonstration was held to coincide with discussion of a parliamentary report on the community's approximately 20 million disabled; the report urges member states and the commission to provide increased financial aid and facilities for them.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Benjamin Stephens of 219 Bainbridge Steet in Brooklyn, a 16-yearold student at Boys and Girls High School, was shot in the head outside the school after an argument with a nonstudent. He was reported in critical condition at St. John's Episcopal Hospital. The youth's assailant is being sought. ... Joe Forem, 62, the manager of the Pioneer Supermarket at 3131 Grand Concourse in the Bronx was killed and Damian Cartino, 17, and Neil Gleason, 23, two of his employees were wounded when two armed men opened fire after robbing the store. ... The theft of 40,000 watches, which the police said were worth $240,000, and a truck apparently used to haul them away was discovered by employees reporting to work at Frank and Tony's Airfreight Warehouse near Kennedy International Airport in Jamaica, Queens.

title: HUMANITIES AGENCY LISTS PROGRAMS TO BE CUT BACK
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities released today a drastically reduced budget for fiscal 1982. It was prepared as a result of the Reagan Administration's plans to slash spending for cultural programs.

title: BUDGET CUT DATA LEAVE QUESTIONS
description: President Reagan's budget message today listed additional reductions in the proposed Federal budget for the fiscal year 1982 totaling $13.8 billion, with cuts made in anticipated spending for more than 200 programs. They follow $34.8 billion in cuts announced for 83 programs on Feb. 18.

title: REAGAN PROPOSALS DETAIL FURTHER TRIMS IN BUDGET
description: The Reagan Administration today identified more than 200 proposed budget reductions affecting almost every department and agency in the Government.

title: Moshe Dayan Visits Cairo And Confers With Sadat
description: President Anwar el-Sadat met today with former Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel. Contrary to practice, the press was barred from Mr. Sadat's Nileside resthouse 20 miles north of Cairo, where the hourlong meeting was held, to avoid any appearance of interference in Israel's parliamentary election campaign. Only photographers and television cameramen were admitted for a few minutes, then were asked to leave.

title: NOW, MARK THATCHER IS PROMOTING A BRITISH PRODUCT
description: Mark Thatcher, the son of the British Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, got her into some embarrassing political trouble a year or so ago when he signed up with a Japanese textile company to model its clothes in exchange for sponsoring him in an auto race.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Puerto Rico's Electrical Power Authority filed a $189 million suit today against the General Electric Company for bribing a Government official to buy an allegedly defective generating plant.

title: NEW LOOK PLANNED AT U.S. LABOR LAWS
description: Republicans on the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee served notice today that they planned to reexamine a broad spectrum of laws designed to protect the wages, hours and conditions of workers and, possibly, to relax some restrictions in those laws.

title: 3 POLICEMEN ARE SEIZED, 2 FOR INSURANCE FRAUD AND ONE IN COCAINE CASE
description: Three New York City police officers were arrested yesterday, two on charges that they took part in automobile insurance frauds and the other for allegedly participating in a $1-million-a-year cocaine operation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amerace Corporation has elected to its board Richard M. Danziger, counsel to the firm of Danziger, Bangser, Klipstein, Goldsmith & Greenwald.

title: EXCERPTS FROM A FACT SHEET ISSUED BY WHITE HOUSE
description: Following are excerpts from a fact sheet issued by the White House today on President Reagan's budget for the 1982 fiscal year: The President's Budget Reform Plan

title: Key Rates
description: Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Tough Rent-Control Law Is Struck Down on Coast
description: A judge has struck down key provisions of one of the nation's toughest rent-control laws, saying the measure must be rewritten within three months to allow bigger rent increases for landlords in this coastal community.

title: U.S. PLANS MILITARY LOANS FOR 15 NATIONS
description: The Reagan Administration today unveiled a $982 million program of low-interest loans to enable countries to buy American weapons and military training.

title: REAGAN ARRIVES IN CANADA TO HECKLING AND APPLAUSE
description: President Reagan heard more heckling than applause today as he began an official visit to Canada with a pledge of cooperation on issues dividing the two neighbors.

title: THREE U.S. AGENCIES SAID TO DROP THEIR OBJECTIONS TO WESTWAY PLAN
description: Three Federal environmental agencies have dropped their objections to the Westway project, a move that sets the stage for the final Federal permit for the Manhattan highway, an official in Washington said yesterday.

title: Quiet Birthday for a Prince
description: He's been largely overshadowed by his older brothers, Charles and Andrew, but, for the record, yesterday was the 17th birthday of Prince Edward, third in line to the British throne.

title: Miss Zayak Happy to Be Back in School
description: Elaine Zayak wanted to watch ''The White Shadow.'' Nancy Brupbacher preferred ''Little House on the Prairie.'' The two girls quarreled, reached for an invisible television dial, snapped the dial and then mockingly cried, ''Mommy! Mommy!''

title: Comforts of Singing Verdi's Rarely Performed 'Attila'
description: The New York City Opera is dusting off one of Verdi's least-heard operas, ''Attila,'' for a performance Friday night, and when the bass Samuel Ramey appears in the title role he will be the first person to sing publicly the role in New York in 131 years.

title: PAPP PROVIDES A STAGE FOR 'LONG DAY'S JOURNEY'
description: PLANNED for only a limited engagement, the highly praised revival of Eugene O'Neill's ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' seemed headed for oblivion last week after only nine performances at the Theater at St. Peter's Church on East 54th Street. But Geraldine Fitzgerald, who directed it for the Richard Allen Center, made a strategic phone call - to Joseph Papp at the Public Theater.

title: 'ANTIHUNGER' LOBBYISTS START THEIR ROUNDS
description: Senator Carl Levin was getting impatient. Four constituents were sitting in his office, urging him to oppose cuts in the food stamp program, and they were in no mood for compromise. But, finally, Senator Levin, a Michigan Democrat, could no longer hold his tongue. ''My message is not new,'' asserted Senator Levin, who has one of the most liberal voting records in Congress. ''We've got to be more sensitive to where the problems are in our own programs. The nutrition community has been too doctrinaire.''

title: Military Analysis
description: Western European military sources are reporting stepped-up deployment of the Soviet Union's mobile SS-20 nuclear missile. The reports add a note of urgency to the United States' programs for modernizing its strategic and tactical weapons.

title: Shawmut Is Seeking Worcester Bancorp
description: Worcester Bancorp Inc. of Worcester, Mass., said yesterday that it had received a merger proposal from the Shawmut Corporation, and said it anticipated management approval for the combination.

title: ATLANTA
description: Sammy Davis Jr. and Frank Sinatra, two of the top names in entertainment, tonight joined thousands of people around the world who are giving moral and financial support to the people of Atlanta in their efforts to live with and solve the murders and disappearances of 21 black children.

title: Csonka Trying to Make Comeback With Dolphins
description: Larry Csonka is again looking to the Miami Dolphins for a positive ending to his pro football career.

title: The Caretaker
description: Every day for 35 years a man named Zhao Wenjin went to the American consulate in Xiamen, on the coast of China, and raked the yard. He probably swept the floors too.

title: News Analysis
description: If the Reagan Administration, Congress or the public require any reminder of the difficulty of holding down Federal spending, they need look no further than the budget package unveiled today.

title: Wine Calendar
description: The annual California barrel tasting held by the Four Seasons Restaurant will take place March 23 at 7 P.M. The restaurant reports that all tickets, at $130 each, have been sold.

title: C.I.A. DEPUTY DENIES SEEKING CHANGE ON SURVAILANCE
description: The Deputy Director of Central Intelligence this afternoon denied suggestions that the top leadership of the intelligence community had asked the White House for increased authority to spy on Americans at home and abroad.

title: HOW TO PREVENT MISHAPS
description: There are some easy ways to help prevent drug-related mishaps to those of any age and especially to the elderly:

title: by Richard Shepard
description: HISTORY ON THE RUN

title: 5 NEWSPAPER LOCALS AGREE ON PLAN
description: Five newspaper union locals have agreed to join in an effort to negotiate an economic package in new contracts with The Daily News and The New York Times, and with The New York Post in a separate negotiation, George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, announced yesterday.

title: Casino Revenue Rose in February
description: The New Jersey casino industry bounced back from a slow December and an only fair January with gross revenues of $67.8 million in February, the Casino Control Commission reported.

title: Mitsubishi to Raise Chrysler Output
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said that it would step up production of cars and trucks for the Chrysler Corporation because of a recent improvement in sales in the United States.

title: MUSIC: LIEDERKREIS SINGS
description: ALL the best virtues of chamber music could be heard Monday night in Alice Tully Hall: musical agreement among peers, tonal refinement and elegant interpretations polished to a high sheen of technical excellence. While one expects such qualities as a matter of course from superior instrumental groups, this time they applied to the less frequently encountered art of vocal chamber music, specifically to the four singers and pianist that make up the Liederkreis Ensemble, winners of the 1980 Naumburg Chamber Award.

title: A JOURNEY INTO THE CITY'S NETHERWORLD
description: Ellen Baxter and Kim Hopper are as unlikely a pair of after-hours street people as ever roamed the Port Authority Bus Terminal and Grand Central Terminal or bedded down in a Bowery flophouse or the municipal Women's Shelter.

title: FROM PETER TO PAUL
description: To the Editor:

title: A U.S.-SOVIET PARLEY IS LINKED TO POLAND
description: The United States and West Germany have agreed to try to use the interest expressed by the Soviet leadership in a summit meeting with President Reagan as a form of leverage to deter the Russians from intervening militarily in Poland.

title: IF SAUDI F-15'S CAN THREATEN ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution's Fender-Bender
description: That case in California last week was billed as a replay of the 1925 Scopes ''monkey trial,'' pitting the biological theory of evolution against fundamentalists who believe the biblical story of divine creation. Instead, it turned out to be merely, as the judge said, ''a very long road to a very little house.''

title: Searle Research Plan
description: G.D. Searle & Company said it plans to invest more than $74.5 million in worldwide pharmaceutical research and development this year, an increase of 26 percent over 1980. The ethical-drug and health-care equipment producer said the increase for 1981 follows a 22 percent rise in its research investment in 1980 over the previous year. The company said its research would focus on biological products and compounds to treat cardiovascular disease, gastrointestinal disorders, cellular-endocrine diseases, diseases of the central nervous system and infectious diseases.

title: Marcol Is Charged
description: Misdemeanor charges were filed today against Chester Marcol, former Green Bay Packer place-kicker. He was accused of reckless use of a weapon and eluding the police, after having been arrested Sunday at the home of his estranged wife here.

title: HOCKEY
description: EDMONTON (NHL) - Traded Blair Mc- D onald, wing, to Vancouver for rights to K en Berry, wing, and Garry Lariviere, who h ad been obtained by Canucks from Quebec e arlier in the day. LOS ANGELES (NHL) - Acquired Rich- a rd Martin and Don Luce, forwards, from B uffalo, and Jim Rutherford, goalie, from T oronto, for future considerations.

title: Alaska Borough Adds to Big Debt
description: Alaska's North Slope Borough, which lies entirely above the Arctic Circle, has only 9,000 residents. But heavy spending on roads, sewers, airports, schools, health, education and police facilities has pushed their per capita debt to $44,000.

title: SHORT-TERM PLAN OFFERED BY KOCH TO IMPROVE JAILS
description: The Mayor's office announced a short-term plan yesterday to ease the overcrowding in city jails. It would include the purchase of two $1.8 million prefabricated housing units to hold 600 prisoners on Rikers Island.

title:
ADVERTISING;
Columbia Pictures Set To Add
description: Winston Network, the country's largest transit advertising company, is about to be acquired by Columbia Pictures Industries, which is getting into the advertising media business under the direction of Karl Eller.

title: West New York Cool To 'Vigilante' Plan
description: Mayor Anthony DeFino is unreceptive to an offer from a group of gang members to battle street crime in this Hudson County community. The 23-member group known as the Wolves recently announced they would take to the streets as the Guardian Angels have done in New York, Los Angeles and several New Jersey cities.

title: Toyota Eastern Distributor And Dealers Sued on Prices
description: The Pennsylvania Attorney General filed a price-fixing suit today against Toyota's East Coast distributor and 48 automobile dealers, charging that they had conspired to make 10,000 car buyers pay $5 million in overcharges.

title: Fugitive Hijacker Arrested In an Indiana Auto Theft
description: The Federal authorities have unwittingly caught up with a fugitive airplane hijacker they thought was still in Cuba.

title: MET TO BEGIN '81-82 SEASON ON SEPT. 21
description: The Metropolitan Opera will begin its 1981-82 season on Sept. 21 with Bellini's ''Norma,'' and the 30-week season that follows will include five new productions and 13 revivals. In announcing details of the season, the Met noted that ''Fidelio,'' ''Hansel and Gretel,'' ''The Magic Flute'' and ''La Traviata,'' all being performed this season, will be repeated next year.

title: Dr. Elizabeth R. Daley Dead at 76; A Specialist in Treating Arthritis
description: Dr. Elizabeth Roylance Daley, who became a specialist in arthritis after practicing family medicine in Bronxville, N.Y., from 1934 to 1967, died Monday at Roper Hospital in Charleston, S.C. She was 76 years old and had lived in Charleston since 1970, after moving from Cutchogue, L.I.

title: THE SELLING OF THE GIRL SCOUT COOKIE, 1981
description: IF you believe Vonda Blanton of Wichita, Kan., the history of the Girl Scout Cookie began, as did much of our earlier history, in Lexington, Mass., and she has the recipe. On the other hand, Bob Wilson of Jupiter, Fla., swears it all started in his little bakery in Wilmette, Ill. in 1932. Not so, according to Catherine Cavelti, who says she was around when the first original Girl Scout Cookie was baked in Philadelphia in 1930. Certainly not so, says Amy Munsie, who claims to have baked the first Girl Scout Cookie in Buffalo in 1931.

title: Security Agency Head Selected
description: Lieut. Gen. Lincoln D. Faurer of the Air Force was named today to become director of the code-breaking National Security Agency. General Faurer, now deputy chairman of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Military Committee in Brussels, will will replace Vice Adm. Bobby Ray Inman, who has become Deputy Director of Central Intelligence.

title: IF SAUDI F-15'S THREATEN ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Schedule Is Announced For Pope's Swiss Visit
description: Pope John Paul II will visit the three different language-speaking regions of Switzerland during a four-day trip that will begin June 1 in Zurich, the country's German-speaking financial and business capital, it was announced today.

title: Q. I have an old French menu that speaks of sweetbreads Cavour. Can you tell me what this dish is and why it is called Cavour?
description: A. Camillo Benso Cavour, an Italian count who lived from 1810 to 1861, was thought by many to have been the greatest Italian statesman. It was largely through his efforts that Italy became a free and united state shortly before the American Civil War.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Airlines bought three Boe@ing 747 freighter aircraft from Flying Tiger Line, a unit of Tiger International Inc., for an undisclosed price.

title: Economic Scene; Stockman: Voice Of a Revolution
description: The Reagan Revolution is moving fast to sweep out the old order, and David A. Stockman, the zealous young director of the Office of Management and Budget, is its Robespierre. Yesterday he sharpened up his guillotine and marked more than 300 social assistance programs - including food stamps, child nutrition, welfare, housing, unemployment benefits, jobs and training, education, scientific research, Medicaid and black lung, fuel-oil subsidies, legal aid for the poor, environmental protection, disaster and flood insurance, and veterans' benefits - for cuts totaling $48.6 billion in the 1982 fiscal year.

title: WHAT HAVE THE FEDS AND JOHN LOCKE TO DO WITH MIAMI'S ART DECO
description: To the Editor:

title: BAR GROUPS SUPPORT FUNDS FOR LEGAL AID
description: Leaders of 11 state and city bar organizations from around the country convened here today to dramatize their opposition to the Reagan Administration's plan to abolish the Federal program that finances legal aid to poor people in civil cases.

title: Budget Revision Highlights
description: Budget: The budget for the fiscal year 1982 would total $695.3 billion, up 6.1 percent from this fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30. Spending: Reductions of $13.8 billion were added to the $34.8 billion in cuts made public on Feb. 18. In each case the reductions are as compared with spending levels if current programs were continued unchanged. The latest, relatively small reductions involve more than 200 programs. The large cuts last month affected 83 programs. Total savings, including changes in user charges and off-budget payments, have now risen to $55.9 billion from $49.1 billion. Revenues: Revenue projections are slightly reduced, to $650.3 billion from $650.5 billion. Deficit: Remains unchanged from earlier Reagan Administration forecast of $45 billion. Government Borrowing: There is to be a reduction in total Federal credit demand of $21 billion from what President Carter proposed. The Reagan Administration will take $127.9 billion from the capital markets. Programs: Cuts affect nearly every department and agency.
