New reductions involve, among others, the programs of the Department of Agriculture for food and nutrition, the Department of Education, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the National Science Foundation, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Rural Electrification Administration. Significant policy changes proposed included deferring or canceling new Veterans Administration hospitals; providing less money for Commerce Department shipbuilding programs; reducing credit assistance for the Small Business Administration; broadening cuts in the Labor Department's Comprehensive Employment and Training Act programs; dropping or cutting several Army Corps of Engineer water projects; providing less discretionary money for the Department of Health and Human Services; deferring unfunded pension increases of the Railroad Retirement Board; reducing mortgage insurance and loan guarantees for the Federal Housing Administration and the Government National Mortgage Association, and terminating the mortgage association tandem and Indian housing programs.

title: Sambo's to Alter Northeast Names
description: Sambo's Restaurants Inc., which operates 1,117 restaurants nationwide, is changing its name in the Northeast in the hope that a new image will win back customers, officials said today.

title: The U.N. Today; March 11, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 10:30 A.M.

title: The Economy
description: President Reagan sent a $695 billion budget for fiscal 1982 to Congress; the plan projects revenues at $650 billion, leaving a $45 billion deficit. It includes new plans to curb spending for manpower training, shipbuilding subsidies, mortgage underwriting and small business loans. The President warned legislators to heed the public's ''loud and clear'' mandate for change. (Page A1.) The budget included proposals to tie welfare benefits to a work requirement that could place as many as 800,000 people in community jobs. (A1.) House leaders adopted a timetable calling for final budget action by mid-July, followed by final action on a tax cut. (B4.)

title: Massey Sees Gains Later
description: Victor Rice, chairman of Massey-Ferguson Ltd., forecast a recovery for the beleaguered farm machinery maker in its fiscal fourth quarter, ending next Oct. 31, but he repeated that the company expects to report a loss of about $100 million for the Jan. 31 quarter.

title: FORDHAM IS OUSTED BY DAYTON IN N.I.T.
description: Fordham was eliminated from the National Invitation Tournament in the opening round tonight, losing to Dayton, 66-65, in double overtime before 7,100 fans.

title: TEXT OF THE PRESIDENT'S MESSAGE TO CONGRESS
description: Following is the text of the budget message President Reagan sent to the Congress today: On Feb. 18, I spoke to a joint session of Congress about the economic crisis facing America. I pledged then to take the action necessary to alleviate the grievous economic plight of our people. The plan I outlined will stop runaway inflation and revitalize our economy if given a chance. There is nothing but politics-as-usual standing in the way of lower inflation, increased productivity and a return to prosperity.

title: Mana-Zucca Cassel Dead at 89; Composed the Song 'I Love Life'
description: Mana-Zucca Cassel, the composer of several hundred songs, including ''I Love Life,'' died Sunday in Miami. She was 89 years old. Mrs. Cassel was born in New York on Dec. 25, 1891.

title: PROFITABLE SKIN-CARE PROGRAMS
description: In the past two years, Patricia Story, a 38-year-old executive, has experimented with skin-care products from Irma Shorell (''evolved by one of the world's foremost plastic surgeons!'') to Lauder's Prescriptives (''a new intelligence in skin care''), before settling on Erno Laszlo (''the finest skin-care system in the world'').

title: Bridge: New York B Team Leading In Tournament in Shanghai
description: With two rounds of qualifying play remaining in China's first international bridge tournament, an American team and a Dutch team seemed headed for a meeting in the final playoff here tomorrow.

title: GUITLY
description: I want to confess publicly right now. I can no longer bear my burden silently. I was a welfare mother for eight years and I was not truly deserving. Moreover, I exploited many Government programs to improve my lot when I should have pulled myself up by my own bootstraps.

title: AMERICAN AMBASSADOR IS UNHURT IN AN ATTACK ON HIS CAR IN BEIRUT
description: Ambassador John Gunther Dean of the United States escaped unharmed today from a sniper attack on his car as he was riding from the Christian sector of Beirut to the Moslem side. The shooting occurred as President Elias Sarkis met President Hafez al-Assad of Syria in Damascus to discuss continuing political violence in Lebanon.

title: PRINCETON TOPS PENN FOR IVY LEAGUE TITLE
description: Princeton, executing to near perfection the aggressive defense and patient offense espoused by its coach, Pete Carril, whipped Pennsylvania, 54-40, tonight to win the Ivy League title. The victory gave the Tigers the 48th and last berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO EASE RULE ON DISABLED AND TRANSIT
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis said today that he would ask Congress to pass a law to relieve cities of the requirement to provide equal access to transportation for the handicapped. The cities say that requirement would cost them billions of dollars.

title: Performers and Songwriters Join for Evening of Honors
description: ''It's the greatest honor I could ever receive,'' Tony Bennett said Monday night, and who could argue. After all, Mr. Bennett's Lifetime Achievement Award came from the National Academy of Popular Music, an association of songwriters, and whose accolades could a singer cherish more.

title: L.I. Woman's Death Is Laid to Meningitis
description: Suffolk County health officials reported the death of a 57-yearold Centereach, L.I., woman of meningococcal meningitis at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Arts Panel Rejects Plan For Project Along Potomac
description: The United States Fine Arts Commission has reversed itself and rejected plans for a controversial $154 million residential and commercial development along the Potomac waterfront in Georgetown.

title: A BUDGETARY ARGUMENT THAT SWIMS AGAINST LOGIC
description: To the Editor:

title: PATERSON GRANTED LICENSE TO RUN HYDROELECTRIC PLANT
description: This Passaic County community became one of the few cities in the country today to enter the energy business when the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission unanimously approved an operating license for a municipally owned hydroelectric generating plant.

title: Low-Fuel Car for France
description: France will spend $200 million to develop a new fuel-efficient car, a Cabinet spokesman said today. Renault and Peugeot are working on prototypes.

title: IRAQ RULES OUT TRUCE IN WAR AND RENEWS DEMANDS
description: Iraq today ruled out an early cease-fire in its war with Iran and renewed its demands that Teheran accept its terms for ending the conflict.

title: Stolen Watches Recovered on L.I.
description: More than 40,000 imported wristwatches with an appraised value of $1.56 million were seized in a garage on Long Island by Federal agents and police officers of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: GLASS WORKS AT GALLERY
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., has elected to its board Ricardo Cisneros, vice president and chief operating officer of the Cisneros Group of Companies in Caracas, Venezuela.

title: Ecuador to Lift Oil Production
description: Ecuador, one of the smallest members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, plans to raise its oil production by 35,000 barrels a day by the end of 1982, the OPEC news agency reported today.

title: I.T.T. Net Rose 89% in Fourth Quarter
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday that earnings for the fourth quarter of 1980 were $285 million, or $1.95 a share, an 89 percent increase over $151 million, or $1.05 a share, earned in the final period of 1979.

title: Lance Loses Bid to Halt Subpoena on Campaign
description: Bert Lance, the former Federal budget director, lost a plea to the Supreme Court today to block an order that he testify in a inquiry into financial irregularities in his 1974 Georgia gubernatorial campaign.

title: Hecla Lifts Stake
description: The Hecla Mining Company said it had notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has increased its stake in Day Mines Inc. to 6.74 percent from 5.69 percent.

title: LABOR SECRETARY URGES CHANGES TO CURB DEBT IN BLACK LUNG PROJECT
description: Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan told Congressmen today that the debt for the black lung program would reach nearly $7 billion in seven years unless changes were made.

title: U.S. FREEZE ON GRANTS PERILS PROJECTS IN NEW YORK REGION
description: President Reagan's proposal to eliminate almost all Economic Development Administration financing over the next two years would cut deeply into more than 60 factory expansions, industrial parks, small-business loan funds, theater rehabilitations and other projects in depressed areas in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Notes on People; One View of Why a New York Project Was Spared
description: When the Reagan Administration put $14.5 million worth of New York City economic development grants in the deep freeze the other day, it was no accident, some say, that the only project left cooking on the front burner was a $150,000 grant to the Second Annual New York City Salute to the Fashion Industry.

title: U.S. AIDES HINT CUBA CUTS ARMS TO SALVADOR LEFT
description: Administration officials said today that recently acquired information indicates that the anti-Government insurgents in El Salvador are running low on ammunition because of an apparent decision by Nicaragua and Cuba to reduce their assistance.

title: Heinz Profit Up 52.3% in Quarter
description: The H.J. Heinz Company, a major member of the domestic and foreign food industry, reported yesterday that net income in the third fiscal quarter, ended Jan. 28, increased 52.3 percent, to $33.5 million, or $1.42 a share, from $22 million, or 94 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of the preceding fiscal year.

title: ADOLESCENT SEX: MORALITY AND REALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Dissident Guerrillas in Zimbabwe Reportedly Murder White Couple
description: Gunmen shot and killed a white couple early today at their farm homestead east of Fort Victoria in southern Zimbabwe, the police said.

title: Nureyev and Baryshnikov In Paul Taylor Gala Opener
description: Rudolf Nureyev and Mikhail Baryshnikov will be part of the cast of Paul Taylor's ''From Sea to Shining Sea'' in the gala performance that opens Mr. Taylor's three-week season at City Center on April 14.

title: HOME BEAT
description: FOR Susan Wood, a photographer, shown above, an interest in flowers grew into oversized portraits -which are being shown through April 30 - in a real flower- and plant-filled environment - the store of Jean-Jacques Bloos, above left, at 1018 Lexington Avenue, at 73d Street. The photographs range in size from about 2 1/2 feet by 3 1/2 feet to 6 feet by 8 feet and include lilies of the valley, Queen Anne's lace, various weeds, anemones and ranunculus, a favorite.

title: Continental Air Loses Appeal
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit refused today to grant Continental Air Lines an injunction to halt a $13-a-share tender offer for 6 million of the carrier's 15.3 million shares by Texas International Airlines.

title: Around the World; Guerrillas Said to Kill 8 In Raid on Colombian Town
description: About 300 guerrillas of the April 19 Movement seized the capital of Putumayo Territory in southern Colombia for two hours today, killing at least eight people, including the local police commander, reports from the area said.

title: Technology; Extended-Wear Contact Lenses
description: RELATED technology can be conveniently divided into innovations that extend vision, such as television, and those that sustain it, such as glasses or contact lenses.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt EIGHT YEARS IN ANOTHER WORLD. By Harding Lemay. 246 pages. Atheneum. $10.95.

title: SPREAD OF 'MIRACLE' RICE LAGGING IN ASIA
description: In parts of Asia, the shift from the use of hand knives called ani-ani to sickles during the 1960's brought a major technological revolution. The number of workers for each rice paddy was reduced. The time of harvesting was shortened. The community structure changed.

title: Notes on People; Reagan, on Tape, Will Greet Oscars Audience
description: In his years as a Hollywood actor, Ronald Reagan never won an Academy Award nomination. But now that Mr. Reagan has moved on to another profession, he's been invited to appear on the Academy Awards program on March 30.

title: Uncomfortable Waiting
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I wholeheartedly agree with Ada Louise Huxtable's description (''The Unreal World of Waiting Rooms,'' March 5). However, she did not mention two characteristics of both doctors' and corporate waiting rooms: the seats, whatever their heritage, are anything but comfortable, they are just plain too low. Probably no doctor or executive ever sits down and then tries to get up in his own waiting room. The other characteristic of doctors' and dentists' waiting rooms is the aquarium. Watching tropical fish is a hundred times more soothing than staring at assembly-line ''art'' or leafing through dogeared magazines.

title: GROUP-RIDING CAB PROGRAM TO BE TRIED AT KENNEDY
description: The group-riding program of sharing taxicabs from La Guardia Airport will be expanded to Kennedy International Airport later this month, New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission announced yesterday.

title: AM Selling Assets
description: AM International Inc., a Los Angeles-based multinational supplier of business graphics and information processing equipment, said it was completing negotiations to sell certain of its assets for about $19 million. It also said it intended to sell five business units or product lines having a book value of about $55 million. The units and lines are its micrographics operation, the Documentor division, general office supplies, the Infortext Management Control system and the Emeloid system, the company said.

title: 6 Injured in Leaps From 2d Floor To Escape Jersey Apartment Fire
description: Six persons were injured early today when they jumped from the second floor of an apartment house to escape a fire.

title: BOB COOK
description: Bob Cook, one of the nation's top bicycle racers and a member of the 1980 Olympic team, died Monday of brain tumors. He was 23 years old.

title: SOME BANS ON OUTDOOR WATER USE EASED IN 372 JERSEY COMMUNITIES
description: The Byrne administration today modified some bans on the outdoor use of water in the 372 communities that have been under either mandatory rationing or milder forms of water controls. However, rationing allocations and fines for excessive use were not changed.

title: WHEN THE KREMLIN ALLOWS EMIGRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: BUILDER TARGET OF HORSE INQUIRY
description: A Federal grand jury's inquiry into the alleged fixing of harness races through the drugging of horses at Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways centers on the possible involvement of an indicted building contractor as a supplier of the drugs, according to a source familiar with the investigation.

title: by Carolyn G. Heilbrun
description: THOMAS MERTON'S name was often mentioned when I first came to Columbia as a graduate student. The year before, in 1948, he had published ''The Seven Storey Mountain,'' a perhaps somewhat too solemn account of how he became a Trappist monk. We knew he had earned a master's degree in English at Columbia with the highest distinction.

title: ADOLESCENT SEX: MORALITY AND REALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR REAGAN AND TRUDEAU, THE PERSONAL CHEMISTRY APPEARED TO WORK
description: President Reagan likes to tell stories and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau likes to listen to them. The fact that, according to all reports, the two men enjoyed each other's company, despite their different backgrounds and philosophies, appeared to be one explanation for the satisfaction that both expressed today at the end of the President's visit to Canada.

title: A BUDGETARY ARGUMENT THAT SWIMS AGAINST LOGIC
description: To the Editor:

title: TEEN-AGE BIRTHS AND WELFARE
description: A New York City study has confirmed teen-age pregnancies as ''primary precipitating factors leading economically marginal'' women to seek public assistance. The study also found two-thirds of young welfare mothers reporting ''negative attitudes concerning contraception.''

title: Hanson, Fasler Adds Two Firms
description: Hanson, Fasler & Associates, a 10-year-old, largely industrial agency with some $7.5 million in billings, has acquired two other firms. One is Blatt Advertising, specialists in health-care promotion, billing about $1 million, which will become the Blatt Health Care division. The other is Hubbard Associates of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., also 10 years old, which is largely in technical publishing and which will be an autonomous subsidiary.

title: FAMED EX-CHIEF OF BRITIAN'S M.I.6
description: Britain's former chief of intelligence, Sir Maurice Oldfield, believed to be the inspiration for George Smiley in John Le Carre's spy novels and ''M'' in Ian Fleming's James Bond books, is dead, the Government announced tonight.

title: Rooney Says He Was Victimized
description: A lawyer told Mickey Rooney that he embezzled $10,000 from the actor, court transcripts have revealed. Mr. Rooney testified on Feb. 23 that he had confronted the lawyer, David A. Williams of Marina del Rey, telling him to make restitution or he would press charges. Ten days later, Mr. Williams supposedly said he could not. The lawyer was charged with writing a contract for a movie, signing Mr. Rooney's name to it and depositing a $10,000 fee in his own bank account last summer.

title: Interest Rates Little Changed
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday as traders waited for the Federal Reserve to supply clues about short-term interest rates and for economic data to give some direction to long-term interest rates.

title: Pudding on a Stick, Giraf Malt Liquor, et Al.
description: New-product introductions in January inched up to 78 from 74 in January 1980, but both figures fell a good deal behind January 1979, when there were 90.

title: NEW PRODUCTS THAT MAKE IT EASIER FOR A DO-IT-YOURSELFER
description: ANEW line of electronic power tools recently introduced by Black & Decker includes a compact, portable electronic drill press with a built-in microcomputer that provides versatile control features and a monitoring system. Called the Model 9413 electronic drill press, it is priced to sell for about $150. The computer enables the tool to maintain a preselected constant speed under all load conditions.

title: C.I.A. AIDE CLARIFIES STAND ON RESTRAINT
description: Adm. Bobby R. Inman, the Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, says he is doing his utmost to prevent a ''series of repugnant changes'' in legal and administrative restraints on the activities of the intelligence agencies and suggests he might resign if such changes were adopted.

title: ITALIANS DOMINATE PRODUCT DESIGN
description: For the first time since it woke up to industrial design in the 1950's, the International Business Machines Corporation has engaged an Italian-based designer as its chief consultant.

title: BROOKLYN OPERA TO GET ACOUSTIC SHELL
description: A new acoustic shell has been designed for the Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The shell is based on a design by Christopher Jaffe, an acoustic consultant who has been responsible for major outdoor acoustic frames across the country, along with the interior acoustics of the Boettcher Concert Hall in Denver and Mexico City's Sala de Conciertos Nezahualcoyotl. The design was applied and executed by Mr. Jaffe's former associate, Gordon W. Clark. Construction of the shell should begin next summer and be completed in time for the opening concert of the Brooklyn Philharmonia in late October.

title: People
description: * Mike Drexler and Ruth Ziff named executive vice presidents at Doyle Dane Bernbach, New York.

title: THE FICTITIOUS LINK BETWEEN CRIME AND POVERTY
description: To the Editor:

title: Computer: Oregon State No. 1
description: Oregon State is No. 1 in the first computer ranking of majorcollege basketball teams by The New York Times. With the postseason tournaments getting under way, only 33 of the 48 teams in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's championship event are ranked among the top 48 by computer analysis. Three teams placed in the top 48 by the computer are not in the N.C.A.A. tournament or the National Invitation Tournament - Ohio State, which is 44th; North Carolina State, 46th, and Oklahoma State, tied with Georgia for 47th.

title: THE REGION
description: Governor Byrne yesterday named James R. Zazzali, counsel to the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, to succeed John J. Degnan as New Jersey's Attorney General.

title: RISING TREND OF COMPUTER AGE: EMPLOYEES WHO WORK AT HOME
description: Louise Priester used to key-punch insurance claims into a computer in the office of Blue Cross-Blue Shield of South Carolina. Now she does the same thing from a bedroom in her house in Columbia, S.C., using a terminal connected to the office's computer by telephone.

title: Cuisinart Competitor Can't Use Its Ad
description: A Federal judge ordered a French company not to use an advertisement that he said had misled some readers into thinking Cuisinarts Inc. had gone out of business.

title: No Headline
description: AMTRAK OFFICIALS WARN OF EFFECTS OF PROPOSED CUTS

title: Uruguay Orders 737's
description: Pluna, the airline of Uruguay, has ordered three Boeing 737-200 twin-jets at a cost of $35 million, the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company said today. The planes will be delivered in early 1982. Total orders for the 737 now stand at 892, Boeing said.

title: Sailor's Death Laid to Bacteria
description: Tests showed that a 19-year-old sailor at the Naval Training Center had died of a bacterial infection, not meningitis as had been feared, the Navy said today. A spokesman said doctors attributed the death of Cory York of Searcy, Ark., to an organism that causes hemorrhaging of organs. Lieut. El Ahlwardt described the bacteria as a highly infectious strain, transmitted by respiration and probably found in 20 to 25 percent of the recruits.

title: Lubovitch Dancers to Open
description: The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company will appear at City Center from April 1 through 5, in its first New York engagement in two years.

title: Aleksandr Aleksandrov, 74, Dies; Russian Helped Build Aswan Dam
description: Aleksandr P. Aleksandrov, a hydroelectric expert and former Deputy Minister of Electric Power, died Monday, the press agency Tass reported today. He was 74.

title: TV: 'MILLION DOLLAR FACE,' RUTHLESSNESS IN COSMETICS
description: Television movies have a delightful way of spewing forth quality trash, the kind of product that theatrical releases regularly achieve with, say, ''The Betsy'' or ''The Other Side of Midnight.'' Being fiercely competitive, television can respond with, say, ''Scruples.'' Touchingly faithful to the Judith Krantz novel, the television movie served up heaping portions of sublime junk food.

title: Eleanor Kojassar Felder Wed To Thomas Leo Morrissey
description: Eleanor Kojassar Felder, widow of Dr. Leonard Felder, and Thomas Leo Morrissey, a lawyer of Deal, N.J., and Westport, N.Y., were married on Tuesday in St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anaconda Industries, a unit of the Atlantic Richfield Company, completed the aquisition of half ownership of S.A. Marvin Brazil, held by Delta Metals Overseas Ltd. of London.

title: Dorothy Alexander to Get '81 Capezio Dance Award
description: Dorothy Alexander, a founder of the Atlanta Ballet and the architect of the regional ballet movement in America, will receive the 1981 Capezio Dance Award.

title: DEEP CUTS EXPECTED IN ECOLOGY AGENCIES
description: President Reagan's budget proposals would make deep cuts in a variety of antipollution and resource conservation programs adopted over the last decade.

title: VARIED BOOKS ON ENERGY ARE AVAILABLE BY MAIL
description: ENERGY now has its own nook in many bookstores, but the nook may not have some of the more interesting books, which are not widely distributed. Here are some new and slightly older books that you might look or write away for:

title: RETAIL SALES UP BY 0.9% IN FEBRUARY
description: The Commerce Department reported today that retail sales in February rose nine-tenths of 1 percent over January figures, the ninth straight monthly gain. The growth was viewed as an indication of strength in the national economy.

title: Business People; Lincoln National Life Names 2 Executives
description: C. David Silletto, 49 years old, has been elected president of the Lincoln National Life Insurance Company. He succeeds Ian Rolland, 48, who was named chairman, while continuing as chief executive officer of the company, with headquarters in Fort Wayne, Ind. Mr. Rolland is also head of the parent corporation, the Lincoln National Corporation, which also owns the Chicago Title and Trust Company and the Chicago Title Insurance Company.

title: Auditing Is Blamed For Medicaid Loss
description: Connecticut overpaid nursing homes by more than $8.2 million in Medicaid expenses in 1977-79 because of poor auditing and administration by the state and the accounting firm of Ernst & Whinney, according to a Hartford grand jury report released yesterday.

title: BANKRUPTCY PETITION IS FILED BY O.P.M.
description: O.P.M. Leasing Services Inc., which is under investigation because of reports that it put together questionable computer leasing arrangements, filed for reorganization yesterday under the Chapter 11 provisions of the Bankruptcy Act.

title: SEAGRAM MAKES BID FOR ST. JOE
description: In a suprise announcement less than 24 hours after an unexplained flurry of trading in stock of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, Joseph E. Seagram & Sons said yesterday that it was offering $45 a share, totaling more than $2 billion in cash, for the nation's No.1 lead producer.

title: Man, 22, Sentenced In Officer's Slaying
description: A 22-year-old Harlem man with a previous record of nine arrests was sentenced to a maximum 25 years to life for the murder of Police Officer Robert Bilodeau a year ago. The defense lawyer said he would appeal.

title: by Randy Cohen
description: Q. What do we know about the roots of the problem? A. We know that it is a deeply rooted problem. Q. What about its facets? How many does the problem have? A. It is a multifaceted problem. Q. Is it very complex? A. It is a problem of incredible complexity. Q. What sort of implications does the problem have? A. It has profound implications for all of us. And for our children. Q. How many aspects of our day-to-day life does it touch upon? A. It touches upon nearly every aspect of our day-to-day life. Q. Would it be fair to say that we face a deeply rooted, multifaceted problem of incredible complexity with profound implications touching upon nearly every aspect of our day-to-day life?

title: Quality Care Announces Appointment of President
description: Gerardo Canet, 35, has been appointed president of Quality Care Inc., which supplies in-home health care services to the infirm and handicapped. He succeeds Dr. David A. Scheinman, 39, who was named to the vacant post of chairman and remains chief executive officer of the Rockville Center, L.I., company.

title: Rev. Thomas Burke, 60, Fairfield U. School Dean
description: The Rev. Thomas J. M. Burke, dean and founder of the Fairfield University Graduate School of Corporate and Political Communication, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Park City Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn., after being stricken at the university. He was 60 years old.

title: Around the Nation; 2 Murder Charges Dropped In a Miami Riots Case
description: A circuit judge today dismissed all charges against two black men accused in the slaying of a white man in the race riots last May in Miami.

title: CANADA TIED ITS OWN CONSTITUTIONAL 'KNOT'
description: To the Editor:

title: Atlas at the Wheel
description: Isaac Dahan, who drives a medallion taxi, is unhappy about the new rule that requires New York City cab drivers to carry street maps on the job. ''The map I have is up here,'' he told a reporter, pointing to his head.

title: Karen Rogers Is Injured After Spill at Aqueduct
description: Karen Rogers, who returned to riding after spending almost six months on the sidelines, was hospitalized yesterday with a dislocated sacroiliac following a spill at Aqueduct.

title: Evolution of a Down-Wear Retailer
description: In 1923 Eddie Bauer, a young sporting-goods store owner, was on a winter fishing trip in Washington state when he contracted hypothermia.

title: HOTELS FACE DIP IN SALES IN NEW YEAR
description: New York City's hotel industry has fallen on leaner times since the pre-Christmas boom. Hoteliers say a variety of factors are to blame. Higher airline fares and a prolonged national recession have cut domestic travel. And weakened currencies in Western Europe have made visits to New York and the rest of the United States less attractive to foreigners.

title: CHRIS VON WAGENHEIM, 39, TOOK INNIVATIVE FASHION PHOTOGRAPHS
description: Chris von Wangenheim, a fashion photographer whose work has been called daring, provocative and brilliantly inventive, died Monday night in an automobile crash on the island of St. Martin in the Caribbean. He was 39 years old and lived in Washington Depot, Conn.

title: Aquarium Fears Cuts In Budget Will Close It
description: The 108-year-old National Aquarium, home for more than 1,000 sea creatures, is destined to close because of President Reagan's budget cuts, its director said today.

title: Nyerere Visits Japan Tuesday
description: President Julius K. Nyerere leaves here Tuesday for his first visit to Japan, a trip that reflects Tokyo's growing interest in Africa and Tanzania's hopes for increased Japanese aid. Planners in Tokyo are looking for trade opportunities and for new sources of raw materials, diplomats say.

title: INTERIM STAMPS TO USE 'B' INSTEAD OF 18 CENTS WHEN MAIL RATE RISES
description: The Postal Service will sell stamps carrying the letter "B" instead of "18 cents" for use on an interim basis when the cost of mailing a first-class letter goes up March 22, officials said today.

title: GOVERNOR CAREY'S 'FINEST HOUR'
description: To the Editor:

title: Mize, Foster Elected to Hall
description: Johnny Mize, who hit 359 home runs and starred in both major leagues from 1936 to 1953, and Andrew (Rube) Foster, the founder of the Negro National League, were elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame today by the shrine's veterans committee, which was meeting here.

title: MORE TEEN-AGERS ARE PREGNANT DESPITE RISE IN CONTRACEPTION
description: EVEN though teen-agers are using contraception more conscientiously, increasing numbers are becoming pregnant because more are sexually active.

title: Ozark Air Expands
description: Ozark Air Lines announced an expansion of its flight system and said it would spend $10 million to upgrade its facilities at Lambert Field in St. Louis.

title: TIMES RANKS COLLEGE TEAMS
description: Oregon State is No. 1 in the first New York Times computer ranking of major-college basketball teams. The Times evaluated all 264 Division I teams, and only 33 of the 48 teams that are in the National Collegiate tournament are among the computer's top 48. Details on Page D23.

title: Addenda
description: * Scharff, Witchel & Company merged into Kanan, Corbin, Schupak & Aronow Inc.

title: TOWER RISING ON EAST SIDE APOLOGIZES FOR ALL THE MESS
description: New York has its first construction site that apologizes - and maybe it's about time. With detours and debris inconveniencing pedestrians during the mid-Manhattan building boom, the 40-floor office tower at 767 Third Avenue, at 48th Street, began a one-way conversation with passers-by yesterday, expressing regrets for the mess and recounting interesting facts about its construction.

title: Georgia and Minnesota Advance Easily in N.I.T.
description: Dominique Wilkins, a sophomore, paced a balanced Georgia scoring attack with 21 points to power the Bulldogs to a 74-60 first-round victory over Old Dominion in the National Invitation Tournament tonight.

title: CONCERT: HAYDN'S 'CREATION' PERFORMED BY MUSICA SACRA
description: THE otherwise sensitively accomplished choral concerts of Richard Westenburg and his Musica Sacra have sometimes been accused of sedentary slackness. Haydn's ''The Creation'' has sometimes been accused of an excessively bucolic vision of the world's beginning.

title: SEARS QUARTERLY NET RISES 9.5%
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the world's largest retailer, reported yesterday that earnings in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Jan. 31, rose 9.5 percent on a 4.6 percent increase in sales.

title: COLLEGES TAKING STEPS TO BOLSTER CURRICULUM IN LIBERAL ARTSSTUDIES
description: For the first time in at least 15 years many colleges and universities have begun systematically reworking their liberal arts curriculums.

title: Boston Ballet Cancels Plans for South Africa
description: The Boston Ballet has decided to cancel plans to perform in South Africa in the summer because of ''intense political debate'' over the country's racial policies.

title: THATCHER BUDGET IS DENOUNCED AS 'SAVAGE'
description: The British Government's new austerity budget came under sharp attack today not only from the opposition Labor Party but also from some businessmen and even members of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party.

title: Walton Says His Career Is Over
description: Bill Walton said tonight that although he still wants to return to professional basketball, ''I know I can't ever play again.''

title: Around the Nation; 2 in Tennessee Plead Guilty In the Selling of Clemency
description: A top legal aide and a state trooper assigned to former Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee, who was ousted from office, pleaded guilty today to Federal charges of selling executive clemency to state prison inmates.

title: OVERCROWDED CITY JAILS PRESENT A TANGLE OF PROBLEMS
description: State and city officials said recently that overcrowding in New York City jails had reached ''crisis proportions.'' Currently, jails built to house 8,300 inmates hold 9,200, and 1,300 of them entered the system in the last two months. Mayor Koch has proposed both a long-term and a short-term plan to deal with the city jail problem. Following are some questions and answers about how the jail crisis developed and what the city plans to do about it: Q. Why is the jail population growing so quickly? A. City jails house inmates awaiting trial who cannot make bail or who have been denied bail, inmates sentenced to a year or less and those headed for state prisons. Prosecutors and judges said they thought the increase in jail inmates came with stricter laws passed by legislators reacting to a rise in crime and a public call for ''get tough'' measures.

title: MUSIC: JENKINS CONDUCTS CHERUBINI'S 'LODOISKA'
description: When Beethoven sat down to write what was to be his only opera, ''Fidelio,'' the model he had in mind was Luigi Cherubini's ''Lodoiska.'' The theme of both works is the bravery of a faithful lover in rescuing a partner from the clutches of a tyrant. Even without hearing the Cherubini version, you might suspect that Beethoven's is better. Certainly Wednesday night's concert performance of ''Lodoiska'' by Newell Jenkins and his Clarion Concerts colleagues did nothing to undermine that suspicion; ''Lodoiska'' is a decidedly minor, though historically fascinating, work.

title: News Analysis
description: So far the Reagan Administration has avoided the usual pitfalls of Middle East diplomacy, but some experienced diplomats caution that the calm will prove deceptive if Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. pursues a single-minded anti-Soviet strategy in the region.

title: GRIFFIN SHAKY IN FIRST TEST FOR STARTING JOB
description: He is the only one of the contenders who has pitched for the Yankees in a regular-season game, but now he also is the only one of the contenders who has allowed a run this spring. Mike Griffin did not plan it that way.

title: TOOLS THAT MEASURE; by Barbara L. Eisenberg and Mary Smith
description: LIKE everything else these days, buying tools can be an investment in high quality and good looks. Such tools, of course, have a price but their extra quality shows up in appearance, function and durability.

title: A Relief Team Arrives in Uganda To Begin Distributing Famine Aid
description: A Swedish relief team arrived in Uganda today to distribute food and seed to the west Nile region where about 250,000 people are facing starvation.

title: POLISH WORKERS THREATEN A STRIKE AT SITE OF '76 CLASH
description: Only hours after the settlement of a labor dispute in Lodz, a new strike threat arose today in Radom, an industrial city 60 miles south of Warsaw that was the scene of violent clashes between workers and the police in 1976.

title: Harold Zabrack Returns To the Pianistic Past
description: Neo-classicism of the 1920's and 30's created a version of the tonal past heard through the modernist present. But when Harold Zabrack, a professor of piano at Westminster Choir College, played his piano compositions in Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night, it was as if another ''neo'' were added to the first - there was a return to that earlier return.

title: Around the World; Israel Legislators Reject Bid To Annex Golan Heights
description: Israel's Parliament today rejected a bill introduced by hard-line opposition members calling for the annexation of the Golan Heights.

title: ARMING THE ARABS; by William Safire
description: In its most misguided decision to date, the Reagan Administration has announced it intends to sell equipment to Saudi Arabia that will enable its American-built F-15 air superiority fighters to reach Tel Aviv.

title: Eric Stumacher, Pianist, In Mussorgsky 'Pictures'
description: Eric Stumacher's piano recital at the Abraham Goodman House on Sunday evening was another of those confrontations between freedom and discipline. In Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' Mr. Stumacher's imagination wandered in very attractive directions; and even though his fingers sometimes stumbled under this music's weird pianistic demands, the composer's imagery emerged in all its fantastic light and shade.

title: F.C.C. BACKS PHONE RULE THAT RAISES USERS' COSTS
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday approved a change in accounting rules for the nation's telephone system that will increase costs to consumers over the next decade, while reducing the borrowing needs of the phone companies.

title: Notes on People; Liddy Opening a Security-Consulting Concern
description: G. Gordon Liddy, known for his unsuccessful effort to thwart security at the Watergate office building in Washington when he helped mastermind the break-in of Democratic Party headquarters in 1972, is opening an international security consulting concern.

title: COMMENT BY HAIG DRAWS FIRE IN SPAIN
description: A remark by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that the seizure of Parliament by rebel Civil Guards on Feb. 23 was a Spanish ''internal matter'' has drawn harsh criticism from both the right and the left here.

title: CHOREOGRAPHING INVISIBLE CHARACTERS
description: Fran Smyer's recent choreographic adaptation of Virginia Woolf's ''The Waves'' at the Merce Cunningham Studio was severely flawed. Yet one thing about it was provocative. Miss Smyer tried to invent an invisible character, someone who was never seen yet whose presence was felt by everyone else. The attempt failed. Nevertheless, it made one think about how unseen presences can be treated theatrically.

title: Pool Seeking Quebec Power
description: New England's electric utilities, which have formed a group called the New England Power Pool, said yesterday they had agreed to put up $2.5 million to finance a study on how to create an electrical interconnection with Hydro-Quebec.

title: OFF BROADWAY: A LOVE STORY WITH EPITHETS
description: THE Georgia in ''Marching to Georgia'' at the Players Theater is a plump, married woman - no, let us not mince words; no one in this play minces words - a fat, married woman. ''You ugly-looking puke,'' her husband calls her, while some of his other salutations are ''fat heifer,'' ''blue rhinoceros'' and ''floppy gut.'' In fact, these are not so much epithets as endearments. The author, Barbara Daniel, has written a sudsy love story.

title: No Headline
description: The chairman of an umbrella group representing railway labor unions today threatened job actions if President Reagan's proposed financial cuts in Amtrak and Conrail, the quasi-public rail corporation, were adopted by Congress.

title: Bavaria to Strengthen Its Police To Combat Violence by Squatters
description: Bavaria is to give its police rubber bullets and nauseous gases to fight a wave of street violence by squatters, the state government announced today.

title: Ted Bates Upholds Autonomy
description: IT is quite the vogue these days among major agencies to acquire other shops and let them operate autonomously under their own names and with their own managements. The hope is that this will overcome the nagging conflict problem, and, in fact, it frequently does.

title: CLAIR BEE, 85, LOVES THE GAME
description: The blind man sat in the corner of the darkened room, writing on notebook paper on the clipboard in his lap. His white-maned head, with hollowed cheeks and dignified chin, was held level as he guided the pen in his right hand with the thumb of his left. He spends most of his time here, writing or listening to the television set beside him. The only light was cast by a small lamp across the way from him.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Around the Nation; 6 in North Carolina Plead Not Guilty to Conspiracy
description: Six American Nazis and Nazi supporters pleaded not guilty in Federal Court today to charges of conspiring to terrorize the Greensboro area last November if six Ku Klux Klansmen and Nazis had been convicted in a murder trial.

title: Article 038081 -- No Title
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. lost at least $30 million last year, a company official said yesterday. VW thus joins the four other major United States auto makers in having 1980 losses totaling more than $4 billion.

title: SUSPECT QUESTIONED IN 7 TEXAS SLAYINGS
description: A suspect was implicated in seven ''extremely brutal'' slayings that occurred here and in San Antonio in a seven-year period after he was questioned about a double murder in Dallas, the authorities said today.

title: GIRL REFUSES TO TESTIFY AGAINST MOTHER BEFORE A GRAND JURY IN LAS VEGAS
description: In a case that may be without precedent, Federal officials here are trying to decide whether to pursue contempt proceedings against a 16-year-old girl who refused to answer questions about her mother before a Federal grand jury.

title: OREGON MAN CONVICTED IN A FOOD-POISONING PLOTT
description: - A Federal jury today convicted a 63-year old jeweler on a charge of trying to extort diamonds from San Diego area supermarkets by spiking jars of dill pickles and teriyaki sauce with cyanide.

title: STATEMENTS BEFORE ARREST CITED IN MET MURDER CASE
description: A Metropolitan Opera stagehand would have been arrested at 6:40 P.M. last Aug. 29 if he had refused to accompany detectives who wanted to question him again about the murder last July 23 of a violinist, a detective testified yesterday on the second day of a pretrial hearing on the admissibility of evidence.

title: Carbon Monoxide Kills Bronx Boy, 14
description: A 14-year-old Bronx boy died and his parents were hospitalized yesterday after they were overcome by carbon monoxide fumes that officials said might have come from their oil burner.

title: FEDERAL PERMITS IN, CAREY NOW PRESSES FOR WESTWAY START
description: With the final Federal permit for the Westway highway project in his pocket, Governor Carey called yesterday for the start of construction of the Westway as ''a new beginning for transportation and recreation on New York City's West Side - and thousands of jobs.''

title: Prudential Planning Energy Investments
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, which manages close to $60 billion in investments, the most of any insurance company in the country, announced plans yesterday to increase sharply its financing of oil and gas exploration.

title: DISPUTE OVER CHRISTO CENTRAL PARK 'GATES' CONTINUES
description: Parks Commissioner Gordon Davis, who last month rejected a proposal by the artist Christo to install a series of bannerlike fabric ''gates'' in Central Park, is embroiled in a controversy with Theodore W. Kheel, the artist's lawyer, over a deadline for filing for reconsideraton of the Commissioner's decision. The controversial proposal, for the temporary planting of 11,000 to 15,000 metal-framed fabric banners arching over 25 miles of Central Park's walkways in 1984 or 1985, was rejected last month by Mr. Davis in the context of an elaborate report on park philosophy and usage.

title: Bridge: Rotterdam and Tokyo Play In Shanghai Tourney Final
description: Following a day of triumph and disaster for the United States, teams from Rotterdam and Tokyo clashed in the final of China's first international tournament here today. At the midpoint in the 48-deal match, the Japanese held a slim lead of 11 internatonal match points.

title: Notes on People; Erma Bombeck Tries Her Hand at a TV Sitcom
description: She's written a string of best sellers, turns out a syndicated humor column and appears regularly on ABC-TV's ''Good Morning, America.'' But for all her comic background, Erma Bombeck has never written a situation comedy of her own.

title: SYDNEY A. TRUNDLE
description: Sydney A. Trundle, former senior vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company of New York, died Monday at his home in Deming, N.M., where he had lived since his retirement in 1973.

title: VIDEODISKS OFFER CONTROL OVER TV FOR CHILDREN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Elin McCoy writes frequently on childhood and education. By ELIN McCOY

title: FORMER ENVOY TO EL SALVADOR SAYS HIS VIEWS HAVE LED TO HIS OUSTER
description: The former Ambassador to El Salvador, Robert E. White, said today that the Reagan Administration had dismissed him from the Foreign Service because he opposed growing United States military aid to the Central American country.

title: Brooklyn Boy Dies Playing With a Gun
description: A 15-year-old boy was fatally wounded by a shot from a .38-caliber revolver that he and two friends were playing with in an upstairs bedroom of a home in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Irving Trust Rate Cut
description: The Irving Trust Company yesterday lowered its broker loan rate to 16 1/2 percent from 17 percent, effective immediately. Irving is the first bank to lower the rate to this level, with others still quoting a 17 to 17 1/2 percent rate. The rate, considered a bellwether for the direction of the prime lending rate, is what banks charge on loans to finance stock purchases.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Eunice Shriver's article makes an eloquent case for shifting pregnancy-prevention programs for teen-agers from ''mechanical to the moral,'' a noble goal indeed.

title: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION TO CONDUCT INQUIRY ON SALVADOR
description: The United Nations Human Rights Commission decided today to have a special representative investigate the reported "grave violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms" in El Salvador.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., has elected to its board Ricardo Cisneros, vice president and chief operating officer of the Cisneros Group of Companies in Caracas, Venezuela.

title: Belfast Man Sentenced to Death In Dublin for Slaying a Policeman
description: A 36-year-old Belfast man living in Ireland was sentenced to death by the Special Criminal Court today for the fatal shooting of a policeman Oct. 13.

title: KNICKS BOW TO 76ERS, SAGGING IN LAST HALF
description: Knick problems continued to mount tonight, marked by the shooting slumps of Ray Williams and Michael Ray Richardson.

title: Around the Nation; Spending and Tax Limit Rejected in New Hampshire
description: A proposal to put a 5 percent limit on tax and government spending increases in New Hampshire has been rejected by voters in 42 of 68 towns that considered it, initial returns showed.

title: Bob Elson Is Dead at 76; A Baseball Broadcaster
description: Bob Elson, whose 40-year broadcasting career won him entry to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1979, died last night at the age of 76. He had been suffering from a heart ailment.

title: ATLANTA MAYOR URGES U.S. FUNDS FOR INQUIRY INTO CHILDREN'S DEATHS
description: Mayor Maynard Jackson, acutely mindful of the city's problem of financing the investigation of 21 missing and slain children, is asking people to write their Congressman urging support of additional Federal funds.

title: The Economy
description: The Democrats will offer an alternative budget that would preserve many social welfare programs that the Administration wants to cut, party leaders said. They said they hoped that Congressional action on the budget and tax cuts would not be delayed. (Page A1.)

title: Around the World; Ugandan Paper Confirms Massacre by Militiamen
description: The Government-owned daily newspaper in Uganda confirmed today that militiamen went berserk and massacred old men, women and children last month in northern Uganda.

title: BUDGET AMENDMENT BACKED AT HEARING
description: Citing pressure from public opinion and legislatures, backers of a constitutional amendment that would require the Federal budget to be balanced took their proposal optimistically into hearings before the new, more conservative Senate today.

title: Ruling on Amax Delayed
description: Federal Judge Morris E. Lasker yesterday postponed until 4 P.M. today a decision on whether to lift a temporary restraining order preventing two brokerage firms from distributing profits on clients' trades in shares of Amax Inc. The firms have been accused of helping their clients to profit from insider information involving a proposed takeover of Amax.

title: GRAND JURIES DECLINE TO INDICT 2 POLICEMEN IN 2 CITY KILLINGS
description: Grand juries in Manhattan and Brooklyn have found no basis for indicting two New York City police officers in two recent fatal shootings, according to announcements yesterday.

title: Iberia Airlines Is Returning to TV
description: With its new agency, Avrett, Free & Fischer, Iberia Airlines is returning to television after an absence of 10 years.

title: Follow the Leader - but Where?
description: President Reagan, in contrast to his predecessor, has offered bold leadership in attacking the nation's economic problems. In a few short weeks he has managed to present a plan for massive cuts in the Federal budget that many in Congress endorse and tax changes that he says can end stagflation. Now, Mr. Reagan says, all that stands in the way of reducing inflation, improving productivity and restoring prosperity is ''politics as usual.''

title: Greece Tackles a New Quake
description: Government rescue workers were sent to western Greece today, where an overnight earthquake killed at least two people, injured six others and damaged more than 1,000 homes. The quake, measuring 5.6 on the open-ended Richter scale, was centered 211 miles northwest of Athens. It was unrelated to a series of tremors that began Feb. 24.

title: HIJACKERS EXTEND DEADLINE ON BLOWING UP JET IN SYRIA
description: Three Pakistani hijackers who had threatened to blow up an airliner with more than a hundred people aboard today at noon extended their deadline to tomorrow in response to a plea from a Syrian officer and gave the Pakistani Government 30 hours more to comply with their demands.

title: STUDY LINKS COFFEE USE TO PANCREAS CANCER
description: A statistical link between the drinking of coffee and cancer of the pancreas, the fourth most common cause of cancer deaths among Americans, was reported yesterday by scientists of the Harvard School of Public Health. The discovery was unexpected, and its significance is not yet clear.

title: 'Happiness Research' Planned by Dr. Levy
description: The latest venture of Dr. Harry A. Levy, an entrepreneural physician, is called Health Opinion Research.

title: DANCE: STEVE CLORFEINE'S 'BLUE SERGE SUITE'
description: STEVE CLORFEINE'S ''Blue Serge Suite,'' from which an excerpt was presented Sunday at the Warren Street Performance Loft, creates an evocative landscape of the mind, despite its unfortunate title and flotsam ''performance art'' scenario.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOOKING SOUTH

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 12, 1981
description: International President Reagan promised Canada continued American friendship, but, in a speech to Parliament in Ottawa, made no concessions for resolving disputes over American military aid to El Salvador and such issues as fishing rights and pollution. The speech matched the tone and outcome of Mr. Reagan's meetings with Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and their advisers. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) A setback for the Salvadoran rebels was suggested by officials of the Reagan Administration. They said that new information indicated that the left-wing insurgents were running low on ammunition because of an apparent decision by Nicaragua and Cuba to reduce their assistance. (A1:2.)

title: FURNITURE THAT CONCEALS AND REVEALS
description: There are chairs that rock, roll, recline, retract, revolve, fold, inflate, stack, attach to or are reshaped by the sitter. There are ladders concealed inside a table and under a chair. There is a bed that looks like an upright piano and a bathtub that could pass for a sofa.

title: St. Luke's Ensemble Plays Premiere of Rzewski Work
description: The concert given by the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night was held just one day after the group's home base, the Church of St. Luke in the Fields, in Greenwich Village, was destroyed by fire. Despite this doleful event, the musicians vigorously went about their tasks, the principal one being the world premiere of Frederic Rzewski's ''Moonlight and Memories'' for bass trombone and six accompanying instruments.

title: TAMBELLINI, RESCH BEST RANGERS, 4-3
description: ''What a storybook ending!'' That was Chico Resch's reaction last night after the former Islander goalie and Steve Tambellini, a former Islander wing, helped their new team, the Colorado Rockies, beat the Rangers, 4-3, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Notes on People; Will Cable TV Station Keep Red Sox Games? Stay Tuned
description: John F. Gault does not sound to Jonathan Schwartz like an evil man. Indeed, Mr. Schwartz says, Mr. Gault comes across on the telephone as ''a reasonable fellow.''

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS
description: West Side Antiquarian Book Fair, Mar- cus Loew Auditorium of Congrega- tion Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83d Street

title: DANCE: JUNE ANDERSON TROUPE MAKES USE OF LIGHT EFFECTS
description: LIGHT is the stuff of which June Anderson makes dances. In dances performed on Tuesday by her Connecticut-based Frolic & Detour company at the Cunningham Dance Studio, those effects seemed a little paltry at times, considering the leap of imagination their creation must have demanded.

title: Gas Well Yields Oil in Arctic
description: Panarctic Oils Ltd. of Calgary announced today that an offshore exploratory natural gas well in the eastern Arctic had yielded oil, only the second time that a well in the Arctic islands has done so.

title: GUIDE TO VIDEO SYSTEMS: DISK AND CASSETTE
description: IN the fierce, worldwide struggle that will decide the future shape of home entertainment, a new front opens March 22 when RCA starts its videodisk system. As nearly everyone knows by now, a videodisk system is a kind of picture-phonograph - a record player hooked up to your television set that plays records containing both sight and sound in motion and color.

title: Staub Battles Pounds To Fatten Bankroll
description: Every morning at 7:45, a solitary figure can be sighted jogging three miles around the perimeter of the Mets' training camp, working his 226-pound, 36-year-old body into shape for the day's business.

title: Carol Wincenc, Flutist, Plays Hindemith at the Y
description: When Carol Wincenc played Hindemith's ''Acht Stucke'' for solo flute in her recital at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night, she established subtle breathing pulsations, tapered phrases and intricate dialogues of manner and character.

title: Q. We increased the insulation under the roof of our country house recently and the snow just remained on the roof during the last snowfall. The roof is made of ordinary shingles with a moderate slope. The house is now nice and warm, but we are worried - will we have roofing troubles later on? - Mrs. S.M.S., New York City
description: A. Snow on the roof should not hurt at all - unless there is something structurally wrong with it.

title: KRAUSKOPF EXPECTED TO GET HUMAN RESOURCES POST
description: James A. Krauskopf is expected to be named Commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, replacing Stanley Brezenoff, city government sources said yesterday.

title: Horn & Hardart Seeks Acquisition
description: The Horn & Hardart Company said yesterday that it intends to spend up to $25 million in the near future to make a ''significant'' acquisition in the fast-food business. The company did not disclose any particular target.
