Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MACMILLIAN BLOEDEL BID IS MADE
description: The British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation took a major step in its expansion into forest products by offering $285.2 million (Canadian) to increase its stake to 49 percent in MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., Canada's largest forest-products company.

title: DEMOCRATS IN HOUSE PLEDGE ALTERNATIVE TO REAGAN'S BUDGET
description: House Democratic leaders today initiated a counteroffensive to President Reagan's economic package and vowed to offer an alternative plan that would preserve many social welfare programs.

title: JERSEY TO USE TRAILERS TO REDUCE CROWDING AT PENAL INSTITUTIONS
description: Governor Byrne gave his ''reluctant'' approval today to the purchase of 52 construction-type trailers for use as temporary homes for prisoners in the state's overcrowded mediumsecurity prisons.

title: PICKFORD-FAIRBANKS MEMORABILIA FOR SALE
description: LOS ANGELES THEY were the first royal family of American movies and in the 1920's their Beverly Hills home was the equivalent of Buckingham Palace. To Pickfair, their 45-room mansion with its 100-foot swimming pool and its separate house for the servants, Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks brought steamer trunks full of curiosities bought in exotic lands and gifts bestowed by their rich and famous friends.

title: Son of Operation Chaos
description: In the name of anti-terrorism, some people in the Reagan Administration are pushing a proposal to put the Central Intelligence Agency back into the business of spying on Americans. In the name of decency, the President should shoot it down.

title: Navy Cancels G.E., McDonnell Contract
description: The Navy announced cancellation of a $100.5 million contract for a new mine weapon because the program is being reviewed to speed development and delivery.

title: Bunker Ramo Says It Is Talking Merger
description: The Bunker Ramo Corporation of Oak Brook, Ill., responding to a New York Stock Exchange query about recent heavy trading activity in its stock, said yesterday that it was holding preliminary merger talks with another company. It would not identify the other company, however.

title: Arm & Hammer's Carpet Contender
description: Even though it has been promoting the odor-eliminating qualities of its Arm & Hammer Baking Soda, the Church & Dwight Company Inc. is only now getting into the booming carpet deodorizer business. In lieu of a name like Smell Kill, the company has decided on just Arm & Hammer Carpet Deodorizer.

title: Why Must New York Pay More for Steel?
description: If domestic steel producers get their way, New Yorkers will soon be more upset than usual over the high price of state government. Big Steel pressed the Legislature to prevent the state from buying foreign steel products even when such purchases could save tax dollars. The Legislature has agreed. Only a veto by Governor Carey can keep the bill from becoming law.

title: WHITE HOUSE PICKS ARMS AGENCY CHIEF
description: The White House is attempting to clear the way on Capitol Hill for the appointment of Edward L. Rowny as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, despite initial objections from Senate liberals and Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, according to Congressional sources.

title: REAGAN PLAN LOOKS TO STRING OF BASES IN MIDEAST AND INDIAN OCEAN
description: The United States has embarked on a fiveyear plan to construct or expand a string of military bases across the Middle East and the Indian Ocean in support of American naval, ground, and air forces in the area, Administration officials said today.

title: The U.N. Today; March 12, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 10:30 A.M.

title: VIDAL: 'I'M AT THE TOP OF A VERY TINY HEAP'
description: IN Gore Vidal's books, there is a pervasive cynicism, a tone of tart disillusion. Politicians, whether in Rome or Washington, plot and swindle; people couple and uncouple carelessly in search of pleasure, and the world proceeds stupidly toward an ignominious end. The satire, as critics have pointed out, is glib and frequently artful, but the vision remains a cold one, admitting little hope and even less charity. Like his prose, Mr. Vidal's conversation also possesses an air of erudite exasperation: his sentences are not only footnoted with classical allusions, but are also punctuated by sighs and yawns. He is afflicted, it seems, by a kind of spiritual fatigue, and he does little to hide it.

title: New Jail Officials Named in Nassau
description: The Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell, announced the appointment of Carmine Tavalaro as sheriff. He succeeds Michael P. Seniuk, who resigned two weeks ago after Mr. Purcell criticized the operation of the overcrowded county jail.

title: TAMBELLINI, RESCH BEAT RANGERS, 4-3
description: Bob Bourne scored twice tonight, one of them his seventh short-handed goal, a club record, to lead the New York Islanders to a 6-3 victory over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: News Analysis
description: The gap between students who are reading at grade level and those who are trailing tends to widen as they move out of elementary school and into junior high, a situation emphasized in a report on reading scores released recently by the

title: Index; International
description: Apartheid spontaneously crum- bles on South African beaches A2 Spaniards criticize Haig's remark on coup A3 A new strike threat arises in Po- land A3 Canadian officials express satis- faction with Reagan visit A4 Around the World A7 White House picks new chief ofarms control agency A11 Iran's former Deputy Prime Minister to go on trial Tuesday A12 Iraq rules put truce in war with Iran A13 Government/Politics A House panel resists immigra- tion service budget cuts A16 C.I.A. deputy fights ''series of re- pugnant changes'' A17 Change is urged to curb debt in the Federal black lung program A18 Reagan budget to cut deeply into ecological programs A19 Brezenoff deputy expected to get Human Resources post B3 General Around the Nation A14 Trial of Carol Burnett libel suit begins on West Coast A14 Las Vegas girl declines U.S. jury's questions about mother A14 Amtrak warns of effects of Rea- gan plan A15 New York City hotels going through a slump B3 Grand juries decline to indict 2 New York policemen in killings B4 Jersey to use trailers to house prison overflow B9 Group-riding program for taxis to be tried out at Kennedy B9 Statements by Met murder sus- pect before arrest are cited B11 Suspect implicated in seven Texas slayings D23 Desire for walrus tusks spurs il- licit traders D23 The Home Section Home Decorating without a decorator C1

title: Wife of Senator Randolph Dies
description: Mary Katherine Randolph, wife of Senator Jennings Randolph, Democrat of West Virginia, died yesterday at her home. She was 75 years old. A spokesman for the Senator said that Mrs. Randolph died of cancer.

title: HOUSE JUDICIARY MEMBERS RESIST IMMIGRATION SERVICE BUDGET CUT
description: Members of Congress from both parties told Attorney General William French Smith today that they were deeply distressed by the Administration's proposal to reduce the staff and budget of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. They said that the agency did not have enough resources to do its job even now.

title: Around the World; Britain and Guatemala Clear Way for Belize's Freedom
description: Britain and Guatemala signed an agreement today that settles their century-old dispute over the Central American colony Belize, the Foreign Secretary, Lord Carrington, announced.

title: DECORATING WITHOUT A DECORATOR
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Dupuy Warrick Reed is a freelance writer who specializes in design and art. By DUPUY WARRICK REED

title: PUERTO RICO FEARS EFFECTS OF U.S. CUTS
description: Budget cuts proposed by the Reagan Administration will have a greater impact on Puerto Rico than anywhere else in the nation, the island's leaders say, and that impact will be devastating, they agree.

title: New M.T.A. Unit To Focus on Conrail
description: Arthur G. Perfall, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportion Authority, said the agency was reorganizing its staff to set up a separate division that would ''focus directly'' on Conrail's operation of the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven commuter lines.

title: Sports of the Times; Arnold Palmer, a Grandfather and Vintage Golfer
description: ACROSS fairways that resembled green velvet, Arnold Palmer was playing a practice round for the Vintage Invitational senior tournament that begins here today. And on the 503-yard 18th hole he was vintage Palmer - pushing his drive into the rough but slashing a 3-wood onto the fringe of the green, chipping up within six feet and holing a side-hill putt for a birdie and applause from about three dozen spectators who trooped around with him.

title: STOCKS FALL AMID PROFIT TAKING
description: Stock prices, beset by profit-taking pressures, drifted lower yesterday. Takeover talk pushed some issues sharply higher. The Dow Jones industrial average, which lost 3.76 points Tuesday after having been ahead more than 6 points, was off an additional 4.99 points yesterday, to 967.67, despite two afternoon rallies. Volume contracted to 47.4 million shares from the previous session's 56.6 million. Over all, declines on the Big Board outnumbered advancing issues by almost a 9-to-7 ratio.

title: The Talk of Cape Town
description: No country has gone further than South Africa in relying on statutes to shape society and social custom. But after decades of legislating on every conceivable aspect of race relations, the lawmakers are starting to find that changes occur spontaneously, without having been entered on their agendas.

title: Stockman Repeats Firm Budget Stand
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, last night reiterated the need for sharp budget cuts and other strong fiscal moves, but conceded that there could be some tough times ahead for housing.

title: CONNECTICUT GENERAL ACTS TO EXPAND AS AN INSURER
description: The Connecticut General Insurance Corporation has long stood slightly apart from the clannish insurance community that dominates Hartford.

title: A $500 MILLION CUT IN TAXES IS VOTED BY THE STATE SENATE
description: The State Senate today staked out its position on business and personal income-tax relief by approving about half a billion dollars in tax cuts. Twenty-five tax bills were ushered through by the Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, Republican of Binghamton. But only three of the bills, totaling $22 million in tax cuts, have been passed by the Assembly - and it has no plans now to grant more relief for the coming fiscal year.

title: IRAN TO TRY FORMER DEPUTY PREMIER ON CHARGES OF ASSISTING THE C.I.A.
description: Former Deputy Prime Minister Abbas Amir Entezam will go on trial Tuesday on charges of helping the C.I.A. and of opposing Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Iran's revolutionary leader, the official Pars press agency said today.

title: ALL THE DIRT ABOUT LIVING WITH A GARDENER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Eden Lipson is an editor with The New York Times Book Review. By EDEN LIPSON

title: by Kenneth C. Bass 3d
description: Ironically, the proposed increased role for the Central Intelligence Agency in domestic clandestine activities through infiltration, surveillance, and searches, conflicts with the recommendations of the (Rockefeller) Commission on C.I.A. Activities Within the United States, on which Ronald Reagan, then a private citizen, served. The proposal is contained in recommendations for sweeping changes in regulations governing intelligence activities that intelligence agency representatives have developed and that the C.I.A. leadership and others are reviewing.

title: U.S. Carrier Rescues 17
description: Seventeen people, the crew and passengers of an Indonesian helicopter en route to an oil drilling site in the Natuna Islands, were rescued by the United States aircraft carrier Midway when the helicopter crashed in the South China Sea, the newspaper Sinar Harapan reported today.

title: THE LIBERAL TASK; by Anthony Lewis
description: In the tough economic philosophy of the Reagan Administration, the watchwords are efficiency and self-reliance. There is no room for Government handouts to enterprises that cannot compete. Everyone is subject to the discipline of the market.

title: Student, 16, Charged With Stealing Bus
description: A 16-year-old Queens youth was arrested and charged with stealing a city bus last month.

title: Chief of American Cinema Inc.  Now Adds the Post of Chairman
description: Norman B. Katz, the 61-year-old president and chief executive officer of American Cinema Releasing Inc., a motion picture distributor, has been named to the additional post of chairman. American Cinema, whose most recent release is ''Charlie Chan and the Curse of the Dragon Queen,'' is a subsidiary of American Communications Industries Inc., with headquarters in Hollywood.

title: NETS DEFEAT BULLETS TO END SLIDE
description: The Washington Bullets, who have reached the National Basketball Association playoffs the last 12 seasons, continued to stumble tonight in their bid for a postseason berth. They were defeated by the New Jersey Nets, 109-104, before a crowd of 7,279 in the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: DESIGN TRENDS: SKINNY LAMPS, SMALL SQUARE PILLOWS
description: Although trends in home furnishings are not quite as volatile as those in fashion, some current design developments are increasing the rate of change. In fashion, extended shoulders, colored stockings and flat-heeled shoes are au courant. In decorating, rough-edge marble, small square pillows, halogen lamps and anthropomorphic chairs are 1981's up-to-the-minute accessories.

title: A DIVORCE TRAUMA: TELLING THE PARENTS
TRIAL OPENS IN CAROL BURNETT'S LIBEL SUIT
description: The trial of Carol Burnett's $10 million libel suit against The National Enquirer began here today, a case that the entertainer said had plagued her like ''a 5-year-old toothache.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's a time bomb. If all this occurs, unemployment will rise from 19 percent to 30 or 40 percent.

title: McAdoo Is Put On Waivers
description: Bob McAdoo, as expected, was placed on waivers by the Detroit Pistons yesterday, clearing the way for the Nets to pick him up by 5 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Kidnapped Italian Is Freed
description: A businessmen held for 10 months in a mountain cave was freed here today after his family paid an undisclosed ransom, the police reported. Giovanni Arcudi, 66 years old, of Reggio Calabria, was in fairly good condition.

title: REVUE: 'THE APPOLLO, ' RECALLING THE PAST
description: THE audience may be slightly more restrained than its legendary Apollo Theater counterpart, but the joint is jumping at the Richard Allen Center for Culture and Art, at 36 West 62d Street, where ''The Apollo ... It Was Just Like Magic'' is serving up a dose of lovingly recreated past.

title: DIFFERENCES ON EL SALVADOR REMAIN
description: President Reagan addressed the Canadian Parliament today with a speech full of pledges of friendship but devoid of concessions for settling the disputes over American military aid to El Salvador and such issues as fishing rights and pollution.

title: Trident Sub's Delivery Delayed
description: The Navy said today that delivery of the first nuclear-powered Trident ballistic missile submarine has been delayed until at least December.

title: For Children; St. Patrick's Day
description: CHARLENE CORBETT & COMPANY, a St. Patrick's Day celebration with Miss Corbett, a young fiddler and singer of Irish tunes; Michael O'Shea, who will play the bodhran, an Irish drum; Collette Corbett, a dancer, and other costumed youngsters who will perform Irish step dances and reels, Sunday at 3 P.M., at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. Free. Call 534-1672. A SHANACHIE ENTERTAINS, an afternoon with Joe Heaney, Irish storyteller and balladeer, who will entertain for an hour on Friday at 4 P.M., at the 67th Street Library, in the Children's Room, 328 East 67th Street. Free. Call 734-1717. THE JIG IS UP!, a program of Irish dancing by the Margaret Pike Dancers, Sunday at 3 P.M., at the White Plains Public Library, 100 Martine Avenue, White Plains. Free. Call (914) 682-4400. Play Workshop ACTING BY CHILDREN PRODUCTIONS WORKSHOP, an open workshop for the play, ''7-Come-11,'' by Jeanne Niederlitz, where youngsters see how a play is directed, Saturday, 11:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. Free. The play will be presented on April 11 at the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street. Call 255-4968.

title: KOCH PUTS COST OF AID CUTS TO THE CITY AT $353 MILLION
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that President Reagan's proposed spending cuts would cost New York City $353 million in Federal aid for the 1982 fiscal year, but he insisted that while ''there will be pain,'' he would be able to produce a balanced budget.

title: Military Analysis
description: ''We don't want to fight,/But, by Jingo, if we do,/ We've got the ships, we've got the men,/We've got the money, too.'' Ships, men and money have been considered the essential ingredients of military preparedness since long before that music hall ditty became popular at a moment of tension between the British and Russians in the 1870's.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph in The Times on Monday, accompanying the obituary of Hede Massing, former wife of Gerhart Eisler, was misidentified. It showed Mr. Eisler's second wife, Hilde Eisler.

title: B.Y.U. OUST TIGERS
description: James Madison University of Harrisonburg, Va., did not have a men's athletic program 10 years ago. It became a Division I competitor in basketball only four years ago. And tonight James Madison made a memorable debut in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament by upsetting Georgetown, 61-55, in the opening round of the East regional playoffs.

title: Nets, McAdoo Stuck On Contract Terms
description: Negotiations between Bob McAdoo's agent and the Nets have stalled. The Nets have been trying to sign McAdoo since he was placed on waivers Tuesday by the Detroit Pistons.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT OILERS, 5-0
description: With their No. 1 line of Bryan Trottier, Mike Bossy and Bob Bourne accounting for 10 points tonight and Billy Smith stopping 36 shots in goal, the Islanders routed the Edmonton Oilers, 5-0, at Northlands Coliseum.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE WHITE HOTEL. By D.M. Thomas. 274 pages. Viking. $12.95.

title: ETHEL MERMAN BELTS OUT SONGS ON CONCERT CIRCUIT
description: ''I've played every city, every stage you can think of, some you can't,'' says Ethel Merman. ''People love me.'' It would seem they do, for Ethel Merman, everybody's indomitable Annie Oakley, who was born in Astoria, Queens, on Jan. 16, either in 1908, 1909 or 1912, and dropped the ''Zim'' from her parents' Zimmerman, long before she became Panama Hattie in 1940, has carved out a new career on the concert stage. These days she is belting out the Broadway show tunes with which she is identified as a soloist with symphony orchestras.

title: An Economy Of Brains
description: The reshuffling of tenants in Government offices is nearly completed now, until the next time. The former Washington ins are out.

title: 2 SOVIET ASTRONAUTS LOFTED INTO ORBIT
description: The Soviet Union sent aloft a manned capsule Soyuz T-4, carrying two astronauts, toward a linkup with the orbiting Salyut 6 space station, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, announced today.

title: Postmaster Asserts 9-Digit ZIP Could Avert Cuts in Mail Service
description: Postmaster General William Bolger said today that the Postal Service could withstand proposed budget cuts without reducing service only if it could adopt a nine-digit ZIP code to get the full benefits of automation.

title: 155 INDICTED AS TWO-YEAR FEDERAL DRUG INQUIRY ENDS
description: Federal grand juries in Florida, Louisiana and Georgia indicted 155 persons today on drug-smuggling charges as Federal agents concluded a two-year undercover investigation of the multimillion-dollar enterprises that ship marijuana from Colombia to the United States.

title: L.I.U. Starts N.C.A.A. Play
description: Long Island University, which defeated Wagner, Fordham and Iona in the Eastern College Athletic Conference's Metro playoffs last week, plays in the National Collegiate basketball tournament tonight for the first time.

title: ART: 'TWISTED CHAINS' FROM BARRY LE VA
description: THE Sonnabend Gallery (420 West Broadway) is now the scene of an event called ''Twisted Chains (of Events),'' by Barry Le Va. It consists of cardboard cylinders, glued together by the dozen, ovals and semi-ovals of homosote, chunks of gray wallboard and wood beams, cut into lengths of about 18 inches. The cylinders dominate the scene, often combined with the ovals into structures suggesting coffee tables. The remaining elements, also glued into place, are strewn about the floor and the whole thing averages about 3 feet in height.

title: ADMIRAL ASSAILS MANAGEMENT OF SUBMARINE BUILDER
description: The Navy today criticized the Electric Boat Company of Groton, Conn., for poor management and defective workmanship that, it said, had increased the costs and delayed deliveries of strategic and attack submarines.

title: Addendum
description: * Grey Advertising has acquired a minority interest in a Singapore agency now called Adcom & Grey Advertising.

title: Comforts of 'Home' Soothe Miss Austin
description: It was always easy for Tracy Austin. She would hop out of bed every morning and go play tennis as long as she needed, as long as she wanted. Then, two months ago, she felt a pain.

title: CRITICAL APPROACH TO REAGAN'S BUDGET IS URGED BY WRIGHT
description: Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the majority leader, is urging his Democratic colleagues in the House to take a critical, hard-line approach to President Reagan's economic package of tax and budget cuts.

title: ISLAMIC MISSION FOR IRAN-IRAQ TRUCE SAYS IT FAILED
description: An Islamic mission that has tried to bring an end to the six-month-old war between Iraq and Iran admitted today that it had failed.

title: DANCE: REDLICH COMPANY
description: THE Don Redlich Dance Company's opening at the Riverside Church was packed Wednesday night, with the draw very possibly being not only Mr. Redlich's own work but also a premiere by Hanya Holm.

title: REAGAN'S CABINET SPLIT ON IMPORTS OF JAPANESE CARS
description: With his Cabinet split, President Reagan has put off one of the most important economic decisions of his young Administration, whether to seek relief for the troubled American automobile industry by asking Japan to voluntarily restrain its car exports to this country.

title: No Headline
description: Police Blame Guerrillas For Raid in San Salvador

title: Words Count
description: On what is called ''conditional liberty,'' Argentina has wisely released six human rights defenders after days of detention and isolation. Officials of the Reagan Administration say this vindicates their policy of withholding public criticism of such a brazen crackdown.

title: SOMARY LEADS 2D CONCERT OF SWITZERLAND'S MUSIC
description: Johannes Somary, who was born in Zurich, presented the second and final concert of a series called ''Great Music From Switzerland'' on Tuesday at the Abraham Goodman House. Not much of it was ''great,'' by any reasonable criterion.

title: The Region; Dumping in Harbor On L.I. Draws Fine
description: A Port Washington tugboat company was fined $250 on a charge of illegally dumping concrete blocks, cement and other fill into Hempstead Harbor.

title: Multimedia and Jazz Concerts at Kitchen; Multimedia and Jazz At Kitchen This Weekend
description: Two concerts are scheduled this weekend in the ''Contemporary Music'' series at the Kitchen Center for Video and Music, 484 Broome Street.

title: Another American Is Detained in Mozambique
description: The official Mozambican news agency AIM said today that a second American had been detained in Mozambique, which earlier this month expelled four United States Embassy staff members on charges they were spies for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: The Region; Ketter to Leave Post At State U. in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO (AP) - Dr. Robert L. Ketter, who guided the State University at Buffalo through the Vietnam War era, has announced his resignation after nearly 11 years.

title: Companies
description: Standard Oil Company of Ohio will buy Kennecott for almost $1.8 billion in cash, the two companies announced. The pact was the third multibillion-dollar takeover to be announced in the last week, and the second involving a major American oil company. (A1.)

title: BALLET: THE OHIOANS OPEN IN BROOKLYN
description: The Ohio Ballet, which has made a few brief appearances in and around New York, is a little more familiar to New Yorkers than the companies that have preceded it in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Ballet America festivalthis season. Still, the company is something of a rarity in New York these days -- a polished ensemble dancing to well-crafted chamber ballets set to classical skilled musicians. And the Ohio Ballet's opening at the Brooklyn Academy last night did not disappoint. If there were no jolts of discovery in the program of four works by Heinz Poll, the company's founder and raison d'etre, this was an evening of intelligent, tasteful ballet. "Fantasy in F Minor," which takes its name from its schubert s core for two pianos, is Mr. Poll at his most lyrical and i nventive. The dancers flow on and off singly, in twos and t hrees and in rippling flocks of men or women. The pace is n on-stop but gentle, punctuated by fleeting duets for Andrew C arroll and Tricia Vandor, all elegiac line, and trios for a c lear, strong women's ensemble that consisted of Debra Force, J udith Schoaff and Judith Denman. Solos for earthy Louis Russo r evealed him as the dancer with the strongest whole-body attack i n a company in which unfurling limbs are at a choreographic p remium. . Those lyrically placed arms and legs distinguished "Duet," too, a pas de deux seen in its New York premiere.

title: CHARLES W. DAVIDSON
description: Charles W. Davidson, former executive director of St. Luke's Hospital, now St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, died yesterday in the Community Hospital at Naples, Fla., where he lived.

title: 23 Dead in Egypt as Houses Fall
description: Two neighboring houses collapsed Tuesday night in the provincial capital of Beni Suef 80 miles south of Cairo, killing 23 people and injuring 15 others, the newspaper Al Ahram said today. A court had ordered one of the houses demolished two months ago, the paper said, but the landlord had ignored the ruling.

title: Savings Merger In Connecticut
description: The Connecticut Savings Bank and the Burritt Mutual Savings Bank have agreed to merge, they announced today.

title: Polish Workers in Radom Threaten Factory Strikes
description: Workers in the central Polish city of Radom threatened today to call warning strikes and general walkouts at more than 300 factories unless the Government negotiated 17 demands by the trade union movement known as Solidarity.

title: Around the Nation; Ex-Hostage Sues for Libel On Report of Drug Dealing
description: Jerry Plotkin, one of the 52 hostages released by Iran, filed a $60 million libel suit today against a suburban Los Angeles newspaper and its parent, The Chicago Tribune, over an article that, he says, implied that his trip to Iran involved illegal drug deals.

title: DR. HEINRICH E. K. HENEL
description: Dr. Heinrich E. K. Henel, Sterling Professor Emeritus of German at Yale University, died last Saturday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital.

title: Young Dancers in Jersey
description: Sleeping Beauty, Red Hiding Hood and other fairy tales will be performed in dance and mime by Les Petites Ballet tomorrow at 1 P.M. in the Fine Arts Theater at Ocean County College on College Drive in Toms River, N.J. The dance troupe is composed of youngsters, some of whom have danced with professional companies. Tickets are $1. Information: (201) 255-1131.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Advent Corporation, a maker of stereo systems and big-screen televisions, said it would file a petition to begin proceedings under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Act by March 16.

title:
RED SMITH;
Youngest Trekker
description: MIAMI MICHAEL COGSWELL said he and his parents planned to ride across the continent on a bicycle built for three, then go to China and float the Yangtze River some 3,000 miles. Michael, 6 years old, is the youngest hiker who ever walked the 2,106 miles of the Appalachian Trail from Springer Mountain in Georgia to Mount Katahdin in Maine, and he has a certificate to prove it. He is 40 pounds of dynamite, blond, at ease with grown-ups.

title: Around the Nation; Search for Ship Crewmen In Sinking Is Called Off
description: By United Press International A search for 12 missing crewmen of the Israeli freighter Mezada was called off yesterday, the Coast Guard announced.

title: A ROUSING FOE FOR THAT HUN 'ATTILA'
description: All prima donnas like to make grand entrances. But Marilyn Zschau seems to specialize in them. The Juilliard-trained soprano's City Opera debut three years ago was as Minnie in ''The Girl of the Golden West,'' a role that she had already made very much her own on the European opera circuit. In Puccini's horse opera, Miss Zschau first bursts on the scene with six-shooters blazing, laying down the law in no uncertain terms to a saloon packed with hard-bitten cowboys.

title: Fire Ruins Paddlewheel Steamer
description: The Julius C. Wilkie, a paddlewheel steamer that has been a landmark 25 years, burned today in what officials said they believed to be an arson case. The boat recently was taken from the river.

title: CENSUS FINDS U.S. BENEFITS REACH 1 OUT OF 3 FAMILIES
description: The Census Bureau, in its first look at who gets help from the Government, said today that Federal benefit programs reached one out of every three American households in 1979.

title: MAKING JOB BENEFITS FLEXIBLE
description: Until 1978, the American Can Company of Greenwich, Conn., offered a comprehensive program of benefits to its employees. It provided vacation time, a retirement plan, disability pay, and medical, dental and life insurance - the works. But Ellen Devey, a systems programmer at the company's headquarters, was not impressed.

title: Milan Factory Foreman Shot
description: Guerrillas shot and wounded a foreman at the Alfa Romeo car plant today as he arrived for work, the police said. The Red Brigades claimed responsibility for the shooting.

title: Transactions; BASKETBALL
description: BOSTON (NBA) - Signed Nate Archi- b ald, guard, to multiyear contract.

title: PLAINS WARRIOR REUNITES WITH HIS SON
description: ''WINDWALKER'' comes from Pacific International Enterprises, the outfit behind the Wilderness Family movies, which have been wholesome, cheerful, moderately interesting and (for anyone who can tolerate those qualities) not half bad. ''Windwalker'' is more of the same, but it's also a feather in the company's cap, so to speak. It is performed by a mostly Indian cast in the Cheyenne and Crow languages, and takes care not to represent its Indian characters in the ways Hollywood traditionally has.

title: Fox and Time End Talks on Film Sale
description: Time Inc. and the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation have terminated negotiations for the sale to Fox of most of the assets of the feature film and television divisions of Time-Life Films, a wholly owned subsidiary of Time.

title: TRADE CENTER TO GET FIRE SPRINKLERS AT $45 MILLION COST
description: The Port Authority decided yesterday to install fire sprinklers throughout the World Trade Center complex at a projected cost of $45 million. It is expected to take three to five years to complete the project.

title: LITERARY AGENTS' DURABLE 10 PERCENT
description: To the Editor:

title: 'THE HOWLING,' WEREWOLVES AND FRIENDS
description: ''THE HOWLING,'' which opens today at the Cinerama 1 and other theaters, is a horror-hoot for people who think the height of eroticism is watching people in raccoon coats and bad tempers making love. The thing is that they really aren't people, but werewolves, and the unique contribution of ''The Howling'' to the lore of werewolfdom is that werewolves, like other animals, have sex.

title: ARCHITECTS HONOR GOLDBERGER
description: The American Institute of Architects has selected Paul Goldberger, architecture critic for The New York Times, as winner of a 1981 A.I.A. medal.

title: SALLY FIELD STARS IN RITT'S 'BACK ROADS'
description: CONSIDERING the fact that Martin Ritt's ''Back Roads'' appears to be bent on the sentimental canonization of two waifs who would have trouble surviving in heaven, much less the real world, the film is extremely appealing and occasionally gutsy and very funny. Whereas the energy of some movies is provided by hate or love or outrage, the energy of ''Back Roads'' comes from a passion that might be called fond affection. This is apparent in almost every shot of the movie and gives it point even when ''Back Roads'' appears to have no place special to go.

title: CONGRESS REJECTS RAISES FOR ITSELF, JUDICIARY, CABINET AND U.S. EMPLOYEES
description: In a nearly unanimous show of fiscal restraint, the House and Senate today rejected a proposed 16.8 percent pay increase for members of Congress, the judiciary, the Cabinet and 37,000 senior Government employees.

title: THE $18-BILLION GIFT TO THE TREASURY
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region; Bus Service Depot Planned in Nassau
description: Nassau County officials announced a proposed $23.5 million bus service depot at Mitchel Field.

title: Comic Book Mart Sunday
description: Collectors of rare comic books, baseball cards, movie posters and other articles of pop culture will gather Sunday at the Statler Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street, for the Comic Book Marketplace. The browsing, buying and swapping will take place from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is free. Information: 736-5000.

title: BRIAN ENO, NEW GURU OF ROCK, GOING SOLO
description: ''ENO is God,'' say the graffiti spray painted on the walls of Greenwich Village and SoHo. Why Brian Eno? In the past, rock musicians were considered worthy of deification only if they were powerfully sensual singers like Elvis Presley or virtuoso instrumentalists like the guitarist Eric Clapton. But Brian Eno sings only occasionally and self-consciously, and he is not a virtuoso on any instrument. Or perhaps he is. His collaborations with David Bowie, the Talking Heads, Robert Fripp and other artists, and his own electronic compositions have established him as rock's most creative conceptualist and sound processor; the ''instrument'' he can be said to play is the recording studio.

title: IMMEDIATE PROBLEMS CONFRONT HIM
description: Stanley Brezenoff was elected president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday at a meeting of the corporation's board of directors that was repeatedly interrupted by demonstrators from the Municipal Hospital Workers Union.

title: Friday
description: TOP JAPANESE CAMERMAN

title: Film for LBJ Library Salutes Lady Bird Johnson
description: It was nostalgia time for Great Society figures of the Johnson Administration at the National Academy of Sciences in Washington Wednesday night.

title: Transamerica Sets Discount Bonds
description: The Transamerica Corporation announced plans yesterday to sell $175 million of deep discount 6 1/2 percent bonds due in 2011 at a price not to exceed 50, or $500 a bond.

title: TRANSCANADA PIPELINES
description: - Transcanda Pipelines Ltd., Canada's biggest pipeline transmission company for natural gas, applied for an increase in its rates and tolls effective July 1, the National National Energy Board said today. The company wants he rates raised by amouns sufficient to insure a rate of return on charges of 12.90 percent, up from the current 11.10 percent.

title: The Evening Hours
description: TWO of the most popular members of the New York social scene these days are Kenneth Taylor, the Canadian Consul General here, and his wife, Pat. The personable couple seem to turn up at the best parties in town, where everyone, it seems, wants to talk with them and congratulate them and shake their hands.

title: Russian Piano Music
description: A recital of Russian piano music will be given by Edward Lee on Sunday at 8 P.M. at the Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street. Mr. Lee, an American with a Ph.

title: The City; Deadline Extended On Tax Grievances
description: The New York City Council extended the homeowner property-tax grievance period for two weeks, until April 1. About 550,000 owners of one- and two-family homes in the city now have more time to study their assessments and challenge them if they wish.

title: FRIENDS OF INFLATION
description: To the Editor:

title: MAYORS CRITICIZE REAGAN BUDGET CUTS, SAYING MUNICIPALITIES ARE HURT WORST
description: Representatives of the nation's cities attacked President Reagan's budget proposals today, contending that state and local governments were being asked to bear the brunt of the cuts.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''By rejecting these increases, we not only attain some savings to the taxpayers but we further state once again that we are, at long last, truly serious and determined to ultimately balance the Federal budget.'' - Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., speaking of the rejection of raises for members of Congress, the judiciary and senior Government employees. (A15:3.)

title: The Region; Jersey Judge Limits Law on Drug Devices
description: A Superior Court judge has struck down as unconstitiuonal portions of New Jersey's ban on drug paraphernalia.

title: MUSIC: CHERUBINI'S 'LODOISKA' PERFORMED BY CLARION CONCERTS
description: When Beethoven sat down to write what was to be his only opera, ''Fidelio,'' the model he had in mind was Luigi Cherubini's ''Lodoiska.'' The theme of both works is the bravery of a faithful lover in rescuing a partner from the clutches of a tyrant. Even without hearing the Cherubini version, you might suspect that Beethoven's is better. Certainly Wednesday night's concert performance of ''Lodoiska'' by Newell Jenkins and his Clarion Concerts colleagues did nothing to undermine that suspicion; ''Lodoiska'' is a decidedly minor, though historically fascinating, work.

title: HIGH OFFICIAL NOW PLAYS DOWN EL SALVADOR
description: A senior State Department official sought today to play down the importance of the Reagan Administration's effort to help El Salvador defeat leftist insurgents.

title: PORT AGENCY PLANS 3 INDUSTRIAL PARKS
description: The Port Authority, announcing its first major venture into industrial development, said yesterday that it was ready to spend $33.6 million on industrial parks in the South Bronx, on Staten Island and in Elizabeth, N.J.

title: HOLMES SUBPOENAED TO TESTIFY AT INQUIRY
description: Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, was subpoenaed yesterday to appear today before a Federal grand jury in Manhattan that is investigating boxing.

title: DR. MAX DELBRUCK, PIONEER OF MODERN MOLECULAR GENETICS, DIES AT AGE 74
description: Dr. Max Delbruck, one of the foremost pioneers of modern molecular genetics, died Monday evening at Huntington Memorial Hospital in Pasadena, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: Fawcett Appoints Leona Nevler Chief
description: Leona Nevler, who has been associated with Fawcett Books for 25 years, has been named vice president and publisher of the Fawcett Books Group of the Consumer Division of CBS, of which Robert J. Krefting is president. In an announcement, Mr. Krefting said that Miss Nevler would replace Kenneth B. Collins, who resigned.

title: PAKISTANIS ACCEPT HIJACKERS' DEMAND TO FREE PRISONERS
description: The Pakistani Government agreed today to release 55 prisoners at the demand of hijackers who had set a deadline to kill three American passengers they are holding with about 100 others in an airliner here.

title: The Region; 5-Hour Class Day Asked in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Students at Connecticut elementary and high schools would have to put in more classroom hours each year under a bill approved by the State Senate Education Committee.

title: Market Place; Johnson Ready In Radio Field
description: THE E.F. Johnson Company, a manufacturer of mobile radios that lost heavily when citizens' band radios from the Far East flooded the American market in 1977, may soon enjoy much improved prospects.

title: by Mimi Sheraton; Dazzling array from North China.
description: FOR several months following its opening in July, the Sichuan Pavilion exhibited a marked unevenness, both in service and cooking. But based on about eight visits in the last five or six weeks, the 10 chefs from China have certainly hit their stride, and so has the dining room staff.

title: DUTCH SHELL TUMBLES 27% IN '80
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of companies, the world's secondlargest petroleum company after the Exxon Corporation, reported yesterday that currency translations, chemical losses and increased taxation caused earnings for 1980 to plunge 27 percent as revenues climbed 15.5 percent.

title: Charles's Wedding Day a Holiday
description: Prince Charles's wedding day, July 29, will be a public holiday throughout Britain, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced in the House of Commons today. Public pressure for a national holiday has been growing since the engagement of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer was announced two weeks ago.

title: No Ouster at Ford, Despite the Rumors
description: The Ford Motor Company board meeting came and went yesterday, and, despite speculation to the contrary, Philip Caldwell remains the company's chairman and chief executive. Earlier this week, a flurry of rumors had him at the brink of ouster.

title: 3 Killed, 60 Hurt on Italian Road
description: Three persons were killed and 60 injured, 20 seriously, in a chain crash of dozens of vehicles in the fog near this northern Italian city today, the police reported.

title: RATES SLIP A BIT AS FED LETS UP
description: Interest rates declined yesterday for short- and long-term issues, and there were signs that the banking system had sufficient credit available to permit a modest decline in overnight rates.

title: by Robert L. Nessen
description: For one moment, while listening to President Reagan's State of the Union Message, I was electrified. He made a statement that, if I heard it correctly, struck at the very heart of our tax system. But since it was the night before my 49th birthday, and my faculties are not what they once were, I thought it possible that I had been mistaken.

title: by Mike Rosenberg
description: It is nearly two months since Jimmy Carter left the White House. The man who was, until Jan. 20, the most powerful in the nation now plays no part whatsoever in our national life. Perhaps he thinks it is unseemly to comment on the actions of his successor. Perhaps he is busy on his memoirs. No matter what the reason, Jimmy Carter's silence is depriving us of a valuable resource, the unique perspective of one of the 39 men who have served as President.

title: Harvester Wins Bid For Iraq Truck Sale
description: The International Harvester Company, the financially troubled farm-equipment and truck maker, said it had contracted to sell 1,800 heavy-duty dump trucks worth more than $100 million to the Government of Iraq.

title: F.T.C. Fighting Office Closings
description: David A. Clanton, the newly appointed acting chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, today submitted to Congress budget cutbacks for the regulatory agency as proposed by the Reagan Administration and then asked Congress not to carry out the entire Reagan proposal.

title: South Africa Claims Rebel Sweep
description: West Africa, March 12 (AP) - South African soldiers have killed 58 black nationalist guerrillas in clashes over the last two weeks, a South African military spokesman said today. According to South African figures, a total of 278 guerrillas, members of the South-West Africa People's Organization, have been killed so far this year in this mineral-rich territory, which is also called Namibia.

title: RUSSIANS SEIZE BALLET DANCER WHO FLED AND RETURNED
description: Yuri Stepanov, the ballet dancer who repudiated a Soviet press account of his life as a defector in the United States, was seized on the street today while on his way to an appointment with an American reporter.

title: Libya Reported to Sign Contract to Buy Missiles
description: Official Moroccan sources said today that the Libyan Government had signed a contract with a private West German company to buy medium-range missiles capable of carrying nuclear warheads to any target in the Middle East or southern Europe. The report was carried by the official Moroccan news agency.

title: 2 SIDES TAKE A BREAK AS DEADLINE FOR A COAL INDUSTRY STRIKE NEARS
description: With only three days of bargaining left to avoid a possible strike by 160,000 miners, negotiators for the coal industry and the United Mine Workers interrupted their talks here today to assess their positions.

title: Social Security Can Be Trimmed
description: When President Reagan dropped the other budget shoe this week, it landed squarely on some of Congress's pet programs. But Mr. Reagan has refused so far to tackle a major source of ''uncontrollable'' Federal spending: the indexing of benefit programs, like Social Security, to consumer prices.

title: The U.N. Today; March 13, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on the Charter of the United Nations and on the Strength- ening of the Organization's Role - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.-9 P.M.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Frank J. Hoenemeyer, 61, has been elected vice chairman and chief operating officer in charge of investments, the third-ranking post at the Prudential Insurance Company of America. Robert A. Beck, 55, whose background was in life insurance sales, continues as chairman and chief executive officer, while David J. Sherwood, 58, who came to the Newark-based corporation to organize its property-casualty insurance subsidiary, remains president and chief operating officer.

title: COMMUTERS FINDING NEW WAYS TO BEAT THE CRUSH
description: The commuter force of two million that invades Manhattan every weekday is meeting increasingly strong resistance as trains, buses and roads deteriorate and repairs are put off for lack of money.

title: Alabama Ousts St. John's, 73-69
description: St. John's disappointing season ended last night at Alumni Hall with a 73-69 overtime loss to Alabama in the opening round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Good News for Viewers of Red Sox Games
description: Score one for Jonathan Schwartz. The campaign waged by the New York disk jockey to restore the Boston Red Sox to Manhattan Cable TV's programming schedule has been won.

title: TRUST HOUSES BIDS $130 MILLION TO BUY SAVOY HOTEL GROUP
description: Trust Houses Forte Ltd., the international hotel and catering chain, made a $130 million bid today to acquire the Savoy Hotel group, which runs four of London's most luxurious hotels.
