title: Trade Center to Get Fire Sprinklers at $45 Million Cost
description: The Port Authority decided yesterday to install fire sprinklers throughout the World Trade Center complex as a projected cost of $45 million. It is expected to take three to five years to complete the project.

title: INVESTMENT PLANS UP FOR YEAR
description: The Commerce Department reported today that American businesses plan to increase capital investment 10.2 percent this year, to about $325.7 billion.

title: Article 039473 -- No Title
description: The United States Steel Corporation, noting that it expects to sell more of its mineral assets this year, said in its 1980 annual report that it will have more than $1 billion in cash in 1981 for ''redeployment into existing businesses or into new businesses.''

title: WEST GERMANY MAY TRIM ROLE IN SOVIET NATURAL GAS DEAL
description: West Germany has agreed to review the extent of its planned participation in a natural gas deal with the Soviet Union regarded by some members of the Reagan Administration as raising Western Europe's dependence on Soviet energy supplies to a dangerous level.

title: REGAN SOUNDING A CALL TO REOPEN TRANSIT CONTRACT
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday that wasteful spending resulting largely from an ''amateurish piece of bargaining'' to end the 11-day New York City transit strike last April was costing the Metropolitan Transportation Authority as much as $200 million a year.

title: TEXACO, SHELL TRIM SOME GAS PRICES
description: Texaco and Shell yesterday announced small reductions in their wholesale gasoline prices because of near-record inventories, sluggish demand and price competition at the retail level.

title: Around the Nation; Blanton Is Indicted Again In a Liquor License Case
description: A Federal grand jury indicted former Gov. Ray Blanton today on charges of using his influence to peddle liquor licenses, in the second such case involving him.

title: ART: ITALIAN DRAWING OF THE 19TH CENTURY
description: ITALY in the late 18th century and throughout the 19th century is, as far as the visual arts are concerned, vastly more familiar to us as a picturesque setting for illustrious visitors and talented expatriates than for the native artistic activity that occurred there. Only a few centuries earlier, of course, Italy had been the unrivaled artistic nerve center of the Western world. But in this period it produced no painter whose work commands the kind of attention we readily grant to David or Turner or Corot - to mention but three among the many great foreign artists who produced unforgettable masterpieces during their Italian sojourns. For talents of comparable stature, we are obliged to turn to Italian literature or opera - to Manzoni and Leopardi and Verdi - rather than to painting or sculpture.

title: Mets' Pitching Is a Puzzlement
description: Fred Wilpon, the president of the Mets, was throwing some left-handed pitches from the mound at Huggins-Stengel Field today while Manager Joe Torre sat on a bench nearby and pondered the No. 1 question: If the baseball season opened tomorrow, who would pitch?

title: THE NEW MUSIC HALL OFFERS 'AMERICA' FOR A 27-WEEK RUN
description: There are those who can express love of country in a phrase, a poem or a sigh, but turn the folks at Radio City Music Hall loose and they will get the idea over, starting today, with a cast of 76, including the Rockettes, an orchestra of 35, two pipe organs, a synthesizer and a curtain that is 94 feet wide, 64 feet high and bespangled by half a million mirrors. This patriotic package of sound and music is called ''America,'' and it will run for 27 weeks, the longest any live spectacle has been booked into the 5,882-seat hall.

title: ROCK: L.A.-COUNTRY AND FOLK
description: THE Bottom Line offered a two-night bill of two forms of Los Angeles country-rock and folk-rock this week, with Rosanne Cash providing the former and Randy Meisner, the latter.

title: Ford France Sets Layoffs
description: Ford France said today that it will lay off the 3,650 workers at its Bordeaux factory for periods of 12 to 26 days from now until the end of April because of the low demand for cars in the United States and Europe. Ford said the April layoffs could be reduced if orders increased.

title: American Embassy Says Soviet Set Up 2 Attaches
description: The American Embassy, breaking its silence on a two-month-old incident, accused the Soviet authorities today of having subjected two of its military attaches to a ''crude attempt at blackmail and recruitment.''

title: ALBERT BROOKS 'ROMANCE'
description: Albert Brooks's ''Modern Romance'' is actually funnier in retrospect than it is while under way. That's because Mr. Brooks, co-writer, director and star of the film, favors skewed logic and a delivery so deadpan it's positively flat-footed. Together, these things make Mr. Brooks's craziest notions seem reasonable, if only for a while. It takes time for the full measure of this movie's meandering, heartfelt nuttiness to make itself known.

title: Iowa Squad Leads N.C.A.A. Wrestling
description: Coach Dan Gable of Iowa brought his squad to the 51st National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championships with the idea of capturing the team title for the fourth straight time.

title: CHINA'S LEADERS TRY FOR UNITY IN PARTY
description: The Chinese Communist Party has replaced its stick with a carrot in a conciliatory effort to draw dissidents back into the fold behind the party's senior depouty chairman, Deng Xiaoping, and his policies.

title: WHERE TO FIND DANCE ACTIVITY
description: Following are details on weekend ballet activity: Joffrey Ballet, Metropolitan Opera House. Sunday at 8. Tickets are available at $200. Information: 265-7300. Ohio Ballet, Brooklyn Academy of Music. Tonight and tomorrow at 8, Sunday at 2. Tickets are $6, $8 and $12. Information: 636-4100. Oakland Ballet, Whitman Hall, Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues, Brooklyn. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 (family matinee) and 8, Sunday at 2. Tickets are $6 and $7. Information: 780-5291.

title: Egyptian Festival to Open In Washington on Monday
description: ''Egypt Today,'' a two-month-long festival of cultural activities and exhibits celebrating the people and culture of modern Egypt as well as its history and traditions, will open here Monday with a keynote address at the National Academy of Sciences by Jihan el-Sadat, wife of the Egyptian President, Anwar el-Sadat.

title: British Air Marshal Is Appointed NATO Force Deputy Commander
description: Britain's Air Chief Marshal, Sir Peter Terry, has been appointed NATO's Deputy Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, the Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers in Europe announced today.

title: Armed Robber Rapes 2 At Dental Office on S.I.
description: A gunman raped two women and robbed them and six other persons at a Staten Island dentist's office yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Washington Looks for Security
description: His teammates tease him and call him Jesse James, but Claudell Washington can live with that. The fans have not started calling him names, but if they do, Washington says he will live with that, too.

title: STAGE: 'THE WILD DUCK' IN BROOKLYN
description: IN Henrik Ibsen's impassioned tragicomedy, ''The Wild Duck,'' a ''fever of moral rectitude'' infects a household, shattering illusions and destroying the play's one pure spirit, the young girl who tends the tame ''wild duck,'' a symbol of wounded innocence. Arthur Penn's production for the BAM Theater Company, opening last night, tips the tragic into the melodramatic, the comic into the farcical. Mr. Penn, who has had such notable success with contemporary drama, has taken a perverse approach in his first attempt at a classic, and has managed to drown ''The Wild Duck.''

title: Miss Fitzgerald Singing
description: Geraldine Fitzgerald will present her program of ''Street Songs'' tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the Downtown Cultural Center of the Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association, 111 Willoughby Street.

title: SENATE VOTES TO EXTEND BAN ON CREDIT CARD FEES
description: Despite opposition from consumer groups and the Federal Reserve Board, the Senate today passed legislation that would extend for three years a ban on charging credit card users an extra fee when they use their cards. The ban expired Feb. 27

title: New Comex Chairman
description: David T. Johnston, the 59-year-old senior vice president in charge of commodities at E.F. Hutton & Company, has been named chairman of the Commodity Exchange, the top volunteer position at the New York metals futures exchange. Mr. Johnston, who has long been active on the Comex board, previously served two years as chairman.

title: Doyle Dane Earnings Increase 25% in Quarter
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach International yesterday reported its fourthquarter earnings. The revenues were up 25 percent to $42.1 million from $33.7 million in the same period in 1979, while net income was $4.2 million, up 7.7 percent from $3.9 million.

title: About Real Estate; REFINANCING COSTS TROUBLE APARTMENT OWNERS IN CITY
description: The property is on Sanford Avenue, a busy residential thoroughfare in Flushing, Queens, but it could be in any middle-income community in the city.

title: WHY NEWARK WILL GET NO STATE TROOPERS
description: To the Editor:

title: PHOTOGRAPHERS TRYING TO KEEP LOFTS
description: When John Pilgreen discovered a space at 91 Fifth Avenue five years ago, it was just a big, dirty, drafty Manhattan loft. But he was struck by the 12-foot ceilings. They were just what he wanted.

title: Benton Unit Chairman
description: Manning, Selvage & Lee, a subsidiary of Benton & Bowles, has named Charles A. Russell as chairman and chief executive of the Chicago office, replacing Herbert M. Kraus, who becomes chairman of the Middle West division. The division also gets a name change to MS&L/Mid-America, which makes it sound rather cosmic.

title: Simone Forti to Present Her Avant-Garde Dances
description: Simone Forti, a leading avant-garde choreographer, will present her new ''Jackdaw Songs'' at the Performing Garage, 33 Wooster Street, Mondays through Wednesdays from March 30 through April 15.

title: Shoving Them Out
description: President Reagan's natural Nice Guy manner (''How can you say that about a sweet fellow like me?'') is being needlessly compromised by some rude, even vindictive dismissals perpetrated in his name.

title: LOSS IN U.S. AID SEEN FORCING CUT IN SCHOOL GUARDS
description: New York City school officials said today that Federal spending cuts sought by President Reagan would force the dismissal of half the city's school security guards and other cuts in school services.

title: MUSIC: ASHKENAZY IN BARTOK CONCERTO
description: WHEN the Pittsburgh Symphony and Andre Previn, its music director, made their New York plans for this season, they did not opt for a modest visit. Instead, they signed up Avery Fisher Hall for three concerts in five days, did the same with Vladimir Ashkenazy and - aware that the Bartok centenary was at hand - announced that Mr. Ashkenazy would play all three of Bartok's piano concertos in the course of the three concerts.

title: A day in the life of George S. Kaufman coming to the stage
description: GEORGE S. KAUFMAN, the playwright, director, play doctor, drama newsman, one time actor and mighty wit who died in 1961, is headed for Broadway once again, more in resurrection than in revival.''Kaufman at Large'' is a new play, the first ever written by John Lithgow, the actor, who will also star in the title role. It will be directed by Mike Nichols who is also its co-producer with Lewis Allen; the two are part of the producing team of the Broadway musical ''Annie.''

title: Bucks 131, Nuggets 113
description: Mickey Johnson scored 23 points, including 12 in the third quarter, to lead Milwaukee.

title: P.S.C. APPROVES 15.5% RATE RISE FOR CON EDISON
description: The State Public Service Commission today granted Consolidated Edison a 15.5 percent increase in its electric rates - the full amount the utility requested last April.

title: Sunbeam Kitchen Account To Cunningham & Walsh
description: Sunbeam Kitchen Appliances and Home Care Products is moving its advertising assignment to Cunningham & Walsh, Chicago, from Foote, Cone & Belding, that city. There goes a 20-year relationship.

title: LEVESQUE CALLS A VOTE IN QUEBEC AS HIS SUPPORT APPEARS TO EBB
description: Premier Rene Levesque was expected to dissolve Quebec's National Assembly tonight and call an election for April 13 in a bid to obtain a new mandate for his pro-independence forces.

title: BEHIND EDITH SITWELL'S 'FACADE' AT JUPITER CONCERT
description: Janet Bookspan has uncovered an amazing world of naughtiness in the 21 poems of Dame Edith Sitwell's ''Facade,'' and she will share her feelings about them Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall. Miss Bookspan will be the narrator, and her introduction of heat into Dame Edith's otherwise cool world of virtuosity will be part of a Jupiter Symphony concert, which also includes music by Bach and Czerny.

title: LAWMEN AND 'MASTERPIECE' ANTHOLOGY
description: ''Riker,'' a new series starting on CBS-TV tomorrow night at 10, is all about Tom Riker, a man known around town, an unspecified town, as a busted cop. Supposedly his methods were a touch too unorthodox for the force. The truth, though, is that Riker is working undercover for the deputy attorney general, a fact that is not disclosed until about three-quarters of the way through the premiere episode. In any event, David Gerber, producer of ''Police Story,'' ''Police Woman,'' and countless other action adventures, is off on another typical quest for weekly fortunes.

title: ABC HAD ADVISER KNOWN AS A 'PSYCHIC'
description: Fred Pierce, president of ABC-TV, consulted intermittently during the last two years with a woman known in Hollywood as a ''psychic.'' She was under contract to ABC as a ''creative consultant'' and provided opinions about scripts and series that ABC was considering.

title: British Policeman Is Killed In First Such Case Since '70
description: Sgt. Michael Hawcroft today became the first British policeman killed in the line of duty since 1970.

title: Standard of Indiana Oil Reserves Higher
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the nation's sixth-largest oil company, said its domestic crude oil reserves rose 6 percent last year, to 1.66 billion barrels, compared with about 1.57 billion at the end of 1979, marking the first annual increase since 1968.

title: A SLICE OF VOLUNTEER LIFE IN THE PEACE CORPS
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Astro Drilling Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of 500,000 shares of common stock.

title: Weathervane for sale
description: A gilded weathercock, which may have been the one Henry Wadsworth Longfellow had in mind when he wrote of the midnight ride of Paul Revere in ''Tales of a Wayside Inn,'' will be offered in a sale at 2 P.M. on March 28 at Phillips, Son & Neale, Madison Avenue at 72d Street. Ralph Sessions, a weathervane specialist, describes the hand-hammered copper rooster as ''the most historically significant weathervane ever to come to auction in this century.'' Mr. Sessions was guest curator of ''The Art of the Weathervane'' show at the Museum of American Folk Art a year ago.

title: WHAT F.D.R. TOLD HOOVER MARCH 3, '33
description: It was March 3, 1933, the day before the inauguration of President-elect Franklin Delano Roosevelt. The four women reporters who had been assigned to cover Eleanor Roosevelt during the long summer campaign were gathered in a room at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington, where she had summoned us: Lorena Hickok of The Associated Press, Ruby Black of United Press, Dorothy Ducas of Hearst's International News Service, and myself, of Universal Service, the night side of I.N.S.

title: SHA NA NA REVISITS THE 50'S AND 60'S
description: With rock-and-roll more than a quarter of a century old, rock nostalgia no longer simply means the 1950's, ducktail haircuts and oldies but goodies. It also embraces the 1960's and pop memorabilia from mod to psychedelia. This weekend the Beacon Theater on Broadway near 74th Street will be resounding with the hits of two decades. Sha Na Na, the original 50's revival group, has a repertory of 500 songs, most of which were originally recorded between 1955 and 1962 by countless East Coast doo-wop groups. Their special guest, John Sebastian, led the mid-60's folk rock quartet, the Lovin' Spoonful, whose music picks up almost where Sha Na Na's leaves off.

title: HE LIKES IT, AND IT'S BIG IN HIS STATE
description: When the Labor Department's Job Corps program joined a select list of projects in escaping the path of Budget Director David A. Stockman's spending scythe, the savior of the program was not a liberal Democrat but one of the Senate's leading conservative Republicans: Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, chairman of the Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources.

title: SOHIO IS PAYING $1.8 BILLION TO BUY KENNECOTT AS MERGER BIDS QUICKEN
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) will buy the Kennecott Corporation, the nation's largest copper producer, for almost $1.8 billion in cash, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Economic Scene; A Warning On Trade Curbs
description: WITH the Reagan Administration's decision on whether to impose import quotas on Japanese cars hanging fire, Count Otto Lambsdorff, the Minister of Economics of West Germany, has come over to warn that rising protectionism now poses a greater threat to the world economy than at any time since World War II.

title: March 17, a Great Day for . . . the Vikings, of Course
description: In his current newsletter to members of the Leif Ericson Society, the society's president, Ivar Christensen, of Media, Pa., laments the fact that when James Cagney, the actor, was recently honored at the John F. Kennedy Center in Washington, he was described as ''one of the great Irishmen of all time.''

title: PRIME RATE CUT TO 17 1 2% AT CHEMICAL
description: Amid declining short-term interest rates and falling demand from business borrowers, the Chemical Bank yesterday announced a cut in its prime lending rate, to 17 1/2 percent from 18 percent.

title: FOR HAIG DEPUTY, ON-THE-JOB TRAINING
description: William P. Clark, the new No. 2 man at the State Department, has been thrust into the midst of the crisis in El Salvador and says that unless the Government there survives, other countries in the region, including Mexico, could be threatened by Cuba.

title: A Trip That Was Well Worth It
description: He lives less than 100 miles from Atlantic City, where he can gamble all he wants to, but Adam Gorr, of Millburn, N.J., went to Las Vegas, Nev., for a gambling vacation and he's not sorry.

title: Priest Faces Sex-Case Sentence
description: A Roman Catholic priest will be sentenced April 14 on sex charges involving three boys. The Rev. Donald Patrick Roemer, 36 years old, pleaded no contest Tuesday, to making sexual advances, in an agreement with prosecutors to drop some charges. Superior Court Judge Robert Shaw ordered a psychiatric examination before sentencing.

title: TOURISM, IN 3,000 PHRASES
description: They have been submitted singly and in batches of 100 and more. They have come from almost every town in Connecticut and from outside the state and even from foreign countries. Some are clever and amusing, others obtuse or cynical. A few are obscene and a couple of them indecipherable.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Central Louisiana Energy Corporation, Lafayette, La., has appointed Carl E. Jameson president of its gas and oil subsidiary, the South Louisiana Production Company.

title: Ukrainian Cloths on View
description: More than 50 woven and embroidered rushnyky, Ukrainian ritual cloths, will be on view through March 20 at the Ukrainian Museum, 203 Second Avenue (between 12th and 13th Streets).

title: People
description: * James A. Kennedy has been named president of East/West Network, publisher of airline inflight magazines.

title: Franklin's Lawyers Cite Evidence for a New Trial
description: Attorneys for Joseph Paul Franklin, convicted in the shooting deaths of two black men near a Salt Lake City park, asked today for a new trial on the ground that they have discovered new evidence that could discredit the testimony of a key witness, Robert Herrera, a Salt Lake County jail inmate who was in a cell near Mr. Franklin.

title: SOVIET EMBARKS ON BLITZ IN U.S. OF NEWS MEDIA
description: In the last month the Soviet Union has embarked on a blitz of the American news organizations worthy of a well-run Madison Avenue public relations operation.

title: Boom Boom II Stops Goins in 2d Round
description: Like a fresh breeze from the past, Ray (Boom Boom II) Mancini, son of Lenny (Boom Boom I) Mancini, a former No. 1-ranked lightweight contender, stirred some pleasant memories and made a spectacular debut last night. He scored a second-round knockout of Norman Goins in a scheduled 10-round lightweight bout at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: 2 Sunday Celebrations for St. Patrick's Day; Two Sunday Celebrations For St. Patrick's Day
description: Irish music and dance will be offered in midtown and the Bronx on Sunday, in anticipation of St. Patrick's Day, which falls on Tuesday. On Sunday at 7 P.M. in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and 50th Street, Geraldine O'Grady, a violinist from Dublin, will play such traditional Irish tunes as ''Danny Boy'' and ''Coulin'' and light-classical pieces.

title: Cosmos Lose in Mexico
description: Guadalajara's local soccer team beat the Cosmos, 1-0, last night in a game celebrating the Mexican team's 75th anniversary. Eduardo Cisneros scored his team's goal after 40 minutes.

title: Coopers Firm Lifts Earnings
description: Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, reported yesterday that its earnings in the fiscal year ended last Sept. 30 rose 20.8 percent, to $208 million, from $172 million a year before.

title: WINNERS AND SINNERS; Stacked Deck
description: Kenneth Uston graduated Phi Beta Kappa in economics from Yale, earned a master's degree from the Harvard Business School and was a whiz at computers and economic forecasting. So how does he spend his time? Playing blackjack. At least he wants to, but Resorts International, the Atlantic City casino, is bringing suit to keep him away from the tables. The casino regards him as offensive -not because he drinks too much, annoys the other customers or hangs out with mobsters. His offense is that he wins.

title: THE DANCE SEASON IS SPRINGING ALIVE
description: DANCE activity gets going in a lively way around the city this weekend after several weeks of between-season doldrums. And it is a mark of the variety and quality of New York dance that, although no major city-based troupes will be in residence, there is enough quality dance to keep enthusiasts of all persuasions happy.

title: Canadiens 4, Blues 3
description: Steve Shutt and Guy Lafleur scored two goals each last night to lead the Canadiens to a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Blues in Montreal.

title: CASINO REVENUES APPEAL TO BAY STATE
description: The possibility that Massachusetts will join New Jersey in legalizing casino gambling seems to be growing as the Legislature weighs the projected revenue of $50 million annually against a period of Federal spending cuts, local budget cuts and widespread layoffs of public employees.

title: No Headline
description: St. Joseph's, Maryland Advance in Mideast

title: POP: THE SUGAR HILL GANG
description: RAPPING, a kind of rhythmic versifying with skeletal instrumental or unrecorded accompaniment, began in Harlem, the South Bronx and other black communities in the New York area. A white rock group, Blondie, has carried the rapping style into the national Top 10 with the hit single, ''Rapture,'' but the champion rappers are the Sugar Hill Gang, Grand Master Flash and the Fabulous Five, and other groups that have sold large quantities of records but seldom perform for white audiences.

title: by Chris Chase; Candice Bergen gets to play one of her idols.
description: IN a couple of hours, Candice Bergen will be leaving for India. She has had tetanus shots, gamma globulin shots, shots against cholera. Now, dressed in a sweatshirt and pants, she sits on one of the white couches in her balconied, two-story-high living room, grabbing a breath. Her hair is yellow, her eyebrows straight and dark, her eyes gray-blue. In this huge place, she seems smaller than she does on screen. A wall of mirrors reflects brightness from a wall of windows that looks out on Central Park; light and air and beautiful things are everywhere.

title: Marine Who Was Held Hostage Leaves Corps
description: Rodney Sickmann, one of the Marine Corps hostages who spent 444 days in captivity in Iran, has taken a sudden, early discharge from the corps. He is the first of the nine Marine hostages to decide to leave the service.

title: St. Joe Board Rejects Bid by Seagram Unit
description: Directors of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation yesterday rejected as ''grossly inadequate'' a $2.1 billion takeover bid by the United States unit of Canada's Seagram Company Ltd.

title: DIVIDED U.S. ADVISORY PANEL URGES CHANGES IN SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM
description: A divided advisory commission recommended today several changes in the Social Security System including a gradual shift towards later retirement, partial use of general tax revenues to pay benefits and adoption by Congress of a 2 1/2 percent surcharge on individual income taxes.

title: Two Iranian Policemen Are Killed Near Soviet Embassy in Teheran
description: Two Iranian policemen were killed outside the Soviet Embassy in Teheran today in a gun battle that brought differing explanations from the police and the official Pars news agency.

title: VATICAN ASSAILS FETAL DIAGNOSIS IF USED TO ENCOURAGE ABORTIONS
description: The Vatican issued a document today that said modern medical diagnostic techniques that enable a pregnant woman to determine whether her child will be born deformed should not be used to encourage abortion.

title: ABORTION BECOMING A TOP PRIORITY ISSUE IN CONGRESS
description: A campaign by conservatives to end legalized abortion, coupled with the appointment of prominent antiabortion figures to key jobs in the Reagan Administration, has turned the delicate and potentially volatile abortion issue into a priority item in Congress, ranking just behind the economic issue.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MARCH 13, 1981
description: International Acceding to demands by hijackers, the Pakistani Government agreed to release 55 prisoners. The hijackers had threatened to kill three Americans they are holding with about 100 others in an airliner at the Damascus airport. (Page A1, Column 1.) A Soviet ballet dancer was seized on a Moscow street. The dancer, Yuri Stepanov, defected 14 months ago while on a tour of Italy, but returned home voluntarily two and a half months later. He recently denied a Soviet press account of his allegedly miserable life as a defector in the United States and said he had returned to Moscow only because he feared Soviet reprisals against his family. (A6:1-3.)

title: No Headline
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged Litton Industries Inc., a major defense contractor, with improper accounting procedures and violations of Federal securities laws in connection with hundreds of millions of dollars in cost overruns on Government and commercial shipbuilding contracts.

title: Denmark Bans Fishing Near Site Of Toxic Seepage Into North Sea
description: Denmark today banned all fishing around the western coastal town of Harboore after the authorities reported discovering that toxic waste had seeped into the North Sea from a nearby storage depot for agricultural pesticides.

title: FOES OF BUSING HAIL LOS ANGELES VICTORY
description: Opponents of mandatory busing here have won a surprise victory that may lead to a dismantling of the city's busing program and end the 18-year battle over the desegregation of the city's schools.

title: WIDE RALLY LIFTS DOW BY 22.15
description: Excitement over takeover bids and declining interest rates pushed stock prices sharply higher yesterday across a broad front in heavy trading.

title: ART: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS OF 18TH-CENTURY FRANCE
description: ONE of the most rewarding of all domains in which to collect at this time is the illustrated book. The field is vast. From Gutenberg to the present day, wonderful things have been done. The level of esthetic achievement is remarkably high, even where the name of the illustrator is known only to the specialist. There is magic in the very act of opening a book and finding a memorable image inside it; and the illustrated book, though subject to inflation, like everything else, can still be a bargain, if we calculate in terms of the unit price of the plates.

title: Savings of $1.4 Million Seen Over Jobless Rules
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan told a House subcommittee today that the plans of the Reagan Administration to revise work requirements for unemployment compensation would cut the 1982 budget by $1.4 billion.

title: by Walter F. Mondale
description: For any Vice President to play an active, useful role in the Government, he must first of all have the confidence and trust of the President. But, basing my opinion on four years' experience in office, I think that President Carter and I had more than a personal relationship. There is a set of institutional conditions that a Vice President should be aware of for the relationship to succeed. There is a set of rules he should follow - for him to strengthen the Presidency.

title: Stoner Loses Account Over Tampered Crypt Ad
description: Someone tampered with an ad for a New Jersey burial crypt before it arrived at The Daily News for last Sunday's paper and, as a result, the ad agency will be losing the account.

title: Garvey Wins Award
description: Steve Garvey, the Los Angeles Dodgers first baseman who has played in 835 consecutive games, was named the winner today of the 1981 Roberto Clemente Award as the player who best exemplifies the game on and off the field.

title: STAGE: 'BLACK ELK,' SIOUX INDIAN LITANY
description: ''BLACK ELK LIVES,'' which opened last night at the Entermedia, is in part a pageant, in part a history lesson and in part, although blessedly not a large part, a diatribe. It is also an exploration of the thoughts of Black Elk, a holy man of the Oglala Sioux. In this, it is least successful. Respectfully, one may say that in this play it is not the clarity of Black Elk's vision that survives; what survives is its conviction. Black Elk was a mystic.

title: TURKS, ANGRY AT 'PASSIVITY,' MOURN SLAIN DIPLOMATS
description: With indignation and sorrow, Turkey held a state funeral today for two Turkish diplomats who were murdered last week in Paris by gunmen who claimed to be Armenian nationalists.

title: LEADER OF 'MARCH FOR LIFE' SEES ISSUE AS APOCALYPTIC
description: For Nellie Gray, abortion is an apocalyptic issue. ''I find it the most odious thing that could happen, that Americans have to fight for the right to live,'' said Miss Gray, a 56-year-old lawyer who is in the forefront of the antiabortion movement.

title: RELEASED BY HIJACKERS, A U.S. WOMAN TERMS CONDITIONS INTOLERABLE
description: Charlotte Hubbell, who was freed last week from a hijacked Pakistani airliner while her husband remained aboard with about 100 other hostages, recalled that she ''really cracked up'' when one of the passengers was killed by the hijackers.

title: WITH TREATY DROPPED, TRUDEAU ASKS REAGAN TO ACT ON FISH STOCKS
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau called on the Reagan Administration today to act quickly to save fish stocks in the Atlantic after its scrapping of a treaty signed with Canada two years ago.

title: Bridge: Tokyo Outlasts Rotterdam To Win Shanghai Tourney
description: A tough team from Tokyo that had seemed out of contention earlier in the week triumphed today in the final of China's first international tournament. The Japanese team - made up of Hiroshi Hisatomi, Yoshiyuki Nakamura, Akihiko Yamada, Hidenobu Kimoto, Chiaki Hamada and Takahiro Kamiyo - took a big lead in the first 12 deals against its favored Dutch opponents and won the 48-deal match by 13 international match points.

title: BOOKS
description: Books: Irony in Russia By Anatole Broyard WINTER GARDEN. By Beryl Bainbridge. 157 pages. George Braziller. $8.95.

title: Watt Says He'll Expedite Alaskan Oil-Gas Search; The Washington Star
description: Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt said today that he would try to expedite oil and gas exploration on the Arctic Wildlife Range of Alaska's northeast coast.

title: TOWN'S BEST IRISH COFFEE AND WHERE TO FIND IT
description: Along with shamrocks and shillelaghs, corned beef and cabbage and the city's most definitive parade, St. Patrick's Day will be celebrated next Tuesday with countless glasses of Irish coffee. Purists who prefer their Irish whisky neat may shudder at the thought of adulterating it with sugar, black coffee and heavy sweet cream, but to the rest of us, this steaming hot and bracing drink instills a soothing sense of ease and well-being.

title: JUDGE DROPS ONE ORDER, KEEPS ONE IN AMAX SUIT
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday lifted a temporary restraining order against A.G. Becker Inc., allowing the brokerage firm to distribute profits to customers who had traded recently in Amax Inc. options. A similar order was left standing against Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: U.S. PLANS INQUIRY INTO SEX-FOR-VOTE REPORTS INVOLVING 3 IN CONGRESS
description: The Justice Department said today that Attorney General William French Smith had ordered the department's criminal division to review whether three Republican members of Congress got money or sexual favors in exchange for a vote.

title: Advertising Publishing Mergers On the Rise
description: THE publishing industry, which is now in the midst of a firestorm of acquisitions, is next going to see a rash of mergers for economies of scale, Porter Bibb, a Bankers Trust executive, told a roomful of publishing parties yesterday.

title: FOR WEDDING PHOTOGRAPHERS, SOMETHING NEW
description: At 68, after 40 years as a photographer and 3,800 weddings, Bill Stockwell is still at war with what he likes to call ''The Candid Bandit'' - the amateur who is still the photographer of choice at a third of America's weddings.

title: NBC Opts To Televise Colleges
description: NBC Sports, which last week lost the television rights to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball tournament beginning next season, decided yesterday to continue televising regular-season college basketball games for some years to come.

title: BELGIUM'S TROUBLED STEELMAKER
description: On a bend of the Meuse River in the hills of French-speaking Wallonia is a Baroque palace that houses the corporate offices of Cockerill, Belgium's oldest and biggest steelmaker.

title: Orthodox Jews Mount An Anti-Israeli Protest
description: About 5,000 Orthodox Jews gathered outside the Israeli Consulate in Manhattan yesterday to protest what they called the oppression of religious Jews in Israel and the ''pogrom-like storming'' by the Israeli police of a synagogue in Jerusalem last weekend.

title: PUBLISHING: 1942 BOOK FINALLY GETS BORGES'S NAME
description: WHEN E.P. Dutton & Company brings out ''Six Problems for Don Isidro Parodi'' this month, 39 years after it was published in Buenos Aires, the most important change will be in the name of the author. The 1942 edition carried the name H. Bustos Domecq; this edition will use the authors' real names: Jorge Luis Borges and Adolfo Bioy-Casares.

title: Newsprint Price to Rise
description: Consolidated-Bathurst Inc. advised customers in Canada and the United States today that its newsprint prices will be raised 6.4 percent, or $30 a ton, effective July 1.

title: JERSEY GIVES HACKENSACK COMPANY WATER RATE INCREASE OF $4.2 MILLION
description: A New Jersey regulatory agency today granted the Hackensack Water Company, the largest supplier to rationed areas of the state, a $4.18 million rate increase. The company was also allowed a return of 14.5 percent on its equity investment, a record level for utilities in New Jersey.

title: FRENCH CANDIDATES, OFF AT LAST, JOSTLING FOR POSITION
description: Starting the presidential campaign here is as difficult as organizing the croquet game in ''Alice in Wonderland.'' The players assemble and wander off; so do the wickets; and the issues, flamingolike, writhe up and goggle back at the players.

title: COUPLE'S DESIGN: FIT FOR A QUEEN
description: As soon as the engagement of Prince Charles to Lady Diana Spencer was announced, the speculation began. Who would design the wedding dress of the future Queen of England? Would it be a sober establishment designer such as Hardy Amies or an iconoclastic original such as Zandra Rhodes? As it turned out, it was neither of the above.

title: SCM Appeal Is Rejected
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld a judge's ruling in 1978 that threw out a jury's decision giving $111 million to the SCM Corporation in an antitrust case against the Xerox Corporation.

title: GAF Discloses Financing Package
description: The GAF Corporation, until recently a major diversified company with operations in chemicals, building materials, the graphic arts, paper, photographic and stereo products, announced its agreement with a consortium of 17 banks for a three-year, $225 million revolving credit facility that completes financing arrangements under a corporate restructuring plan announced on Dec. 30.

title: REMEMBER THE TRANSPORTATION BOND ISSUE?
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Nevada Moves to Tighten Hotel-Casino Fire Safety
description: Gov. Robert F. List yesterday ordered Nevada's fire code tightened and requested new safety laws to prevent a repetition of the two hotel-casino fires in Las Vegas that took 92 lives.

title: The City; Vigil Set in Harlem On Atlanta Murders
description: The mothers of two of the 20 children murdered in Atlanta over the last 19 months will lead a candlelight vigil and march in Harlem tonight to show solidarity with other black mothers whose children have been killed and to demand an end to such deaths.

title: FOR EMPLOYERS, DIALING A JOKE ISN'T SO FUNNY
description: Last December, the United States General Services Administration decided it was time to get serious about Dial-a-Joke. By its reckoning, employees of various Government agencies at 26 Federal Plaza in Manhattan were spending so much time ringing up Dial-a-Joke - and 25 other New York Telephone Company Dial-It Services lines that offer everything from recorded horoscopes to betting results - that it was adding up to $3,000 a month to the Federal Government's local phone bill.

title: A CONNECTICUT WOMAN, TAKEN OFF RESPIRATOR, DIES
description: A 23-year-old woman died tonight after being removed from a respirator that had kept her breathing since Jan. 30. A judge had ruled earlier in the day that she had suffered brain death, though he refused her family's request to order her removed from the equipment.

title: SUSPENSE STORIES
description: THE MORDIDA MAN. By Ross Thomas. 284 pages. Simon & Schuster. $13.95. THE ANTS OF GOD. By W.T. Tyler. 278 pages. The Dial Press. $10.95.

title: ATLANTA BALLET TO PERFORM IN BROOKLYN MARCH 28-29
description: The Atlanta Ballet will perform at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College on March 28 and 29 as part of the center's regional ballet festival.

title: EX-HEAD OF REUTERS
description: Lord Barnetson, a leading British news executive and chairman from 1968 to 1979 of Reuters, the international news agency, died Thursday in Westminster Hospital in London five weeks after undergoing heart and lung surgery. He was 63 years old and lived in Crowborough, East Sussex.

title: Solo for Cello, With a Shakespearean Twist
description: ''The repertoire for the solo cello is severely limited, almost to a point of nonexistence,'' said Sharon Robinson, who, as one of the most promising young cellists around, should know what she's talking about.

title: West Bank Mayor Accuses Israel of Stealing Land
description: Occupied West Bank, March 13 (Reuters) - The Mayor of this West Bank village accused the Israeli occupation authorities today of stealing Arab land to build a new Jewish settlement and said villagers would form a human chain to prevent the bulldozers from continuing their work.

title: Banks, Duke's Top Scorer, Out After Wrist Surgery
description: Gene Banks of Duke, leading scorer in the Atlantic Coast Conference, underwent surgery on a fractured wrist today, ending his collegiate career.

title: West Virginia 67, Penn 64
description: Greg Nance scored 16 points and Greg Jones 14 to lead West Virginia to a 67-64 victory over Pennsylvania tonight.

title: REAGANOMIC'S MISSING LINK
description: To the Editor:

title: RESCUE SQUAD
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTOR INTEREST IN ST. JOE EASES
description: Despite some expectations of higher bids for the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, its shares fell 1 1/2 points, to 47 1/2, in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: WHERE THERE'S FIRE THERE'S SMOKE: WHY, AND WHICH WAY OUT?
description: To the Editor:

title: LIBYANS ARE WILLING TO HELP IN FREEING HIJACKERS' CAPTIVES
description: Libya agreed today to receive the prisoners to be released by Pakistan at the demand of three hijackers who are holding more than 100 passengers and crew members aboard a Pakistani airliner here.

title: JUDICIAL CONFERENCE CAUTIONS JUDGES ON PRIVATE CLUBS
description: The top policy-making body for the Federal courts voted today to leave the question of membership in discriminatory private clubs up to the consciences of individual Federal judges.

title: Observer; THE NEW CLASS; by Russell Baker
description: What the Reagan people seem to be saying is that it no longer makes sense to talk about haves and have-nots. True, there is undeniably a cluster of have-nots always at hand - ''the truly needy'' who deserve a Government ''safety net,'' as the cliche-of-the-month has it - but there are several other groups between the haves and the true havenots that need to be dealt with sternly.

title: ASPARAGUS: DELIGHT, SINGULAR OR PLURAL
description: Asparagus is about to come into full season. Asparagus are about to come into full season. And thereby hangs the good news and the bad. If few vegetables give as much cause for celebration, few arouse so much controversy.

title: MEXICO DISMAYED THAT ACTOR MIGHT BE U.S. ENVOY
description: Tall, dark and handsome, dressed in a tuxedo, a brandy glass warming in his palm, he stood in the woodpaneled billiards room of an elegant mansion, exuding all the urbanity of a wealthy Latin diplomat in a Hollywood movie.

title: Your Money; Small-Business Pension Plans
description: AS providers of retirement benefits, the nation's small businesses have long been the laggards of corporate America. A Bureau of the Census study found that companies with fewer than 100 workers employ 31 percent of all nonseasonal workers over 25 years old. Yet, employees of these smaller concerns represent 67 percent of all workers not covered by some type of pension program.

title: Sperry-Sun Sold To NL Industries
description: NL Industries Inc., a New York-based chemicals, metal fabricating and oilfield-services concern, said it had entered into a definite agreement to purchase Sperry-Sun Inc., the oilfield services subsidiary of the Sun Company, a large oil concern, for $252.3 million in cash.

title: BOSTON BALLET: A NEW 'SWAN LAKE'
description: Imagine a ''Swan Lake'' lifted out of its customary fairy-tale setting and plunked down in 19th-century Bavaria and you have some idea of the Boston Ballet's new full-length production that had its premiere here last night at the Metropolitan Center.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES UP BY 8.5%
description: Despite one of the most lucrative customer rebate programs in the auto industry's history, the Big Three auto makers reported today that sales rose only 8.5 percent in early March from the comparable period last year. Some analysts attributed the slow sales to continuing problems in the general economy.

title: STAGE: SONDHEIM COLLEGE
description: Songs are cut from Broadway shows for a variety of reasons that, at least in the case of Stephen Sondheim, have little to do with the quality of the composer's work. There are 16 numbers by Mr. Sondheim in the new musical collage ''Marry Me a Little,'' now at the Actors' Playhouse after an earlier showcase engagement at the Production Company. The songs never made it to Broadway, but almost all of them are far from marginalia. They further consolidate Mr. Sondheim's position as our pre-eminent Broadway composer and lyricist.

title: 68 Argentines Held Briefly In Protest Over Relatives
description: Sixty-eight relatives of people who disappeared during an Argentine Government antiguerrilla campaign in the mid-1970's were detained briefly yesterday and freed last night, the police said in a communique today.

title: TO CLEAN OR NOT TO CLEAN DOWN COATS
description: This winter, sales of down coats soared. Buses and subways resembled a convention of Michelin Tire figures. With temperatures below freezing, there was no doubt that the down-filled coat was the warmest possible garment in relation to its weight.

title: WHY RISK BLACKENING A GOLDEN COAST?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Distinction Between Types Of Doubles Can Prove Vital
description: Bidding theorists have tended increasingly to use low-level doubles to request partner to act rather than to look for a penalty. But it is important to distinguish clearly between the two types of doubles. Nothing is more annoying than to have partner remove a double intended for penalty, thus saving the opponents from disaster, or to have him pass a takeout double through misunderstanding, giving the enemy doubled overtricks.

title: POISONS AT HOME: HELP IS AVAILABLE
description: YEAR-OLD Harry Rosenberg Seigel, bored after a week indoors with the chicken pox, amused himself recently by eating about 70 vitamin pills. Alarmed, his mother called the New York City Poison Control Center (by dialing P-O-I-S-O-N-S, the number for all five boroughs) and was told to induce vomiting with syrup of ipecac. Because the 70 pills contained a potentially lethal dose of iron, the on-call pediatrician had a rush blood test taken. Harry was fine.

title: BELGIUM IN WORST SLUMP SINCE WAR
description: At the edge of this city, on the site of a former railroad yard, Banque Bruxelles Lambert just moved into a gleaming concrete and glass building. But all around it in a sprawling urban renewal area are empty lots, reflecting a wait-and-see attitude among other builders.

title: COAL MINERS' TALKS AT A CRUCIAL STAGE
description: The president of the United Mine Workers of America today drew a bargaining line that is expected to complicate negotiations with the industry.

title: All 26 on Japanese Boat Are Lost When It Sinks
description: A Japanese fishing vessel sank in the stormy Bering Sea today minutes after radioing for help. All 26 crewmen were lost, the Coast Guard said.

title: Pratt & Whitney Plans to Lay Off 600
description: Pratt & Whitney Aircraft, despite a $1 billion order backlog for its latest generation of jet engines, said today that it will lay off 600 employees at three Connecticut plants beginning next week because of a cutback in demand for commercial jet engines and spare parts.

title: U.S.-Soviet 'Differences' Imperil Peace, Haig Says
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that ''outstanding differences'' between the Soviet Union and the United States ''have brought the state of world peace to a rather precarious level.''

title: THE FIRST NIGHTERS AT A FIRST FOR SONDHEIM
description: It was the producers' first production, Stephen Sondheim's first off-Broadway musical, and, when their ''Marry Me a Little's'' first night was over at the Actors Playhouse, it was surely the first time that that many people had tried to squeeze into the W.P.A. restaurant in SoHo.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a review of the movie ''Modern Romance'' yesterday, a reference to the film ''Starting Over'' identified the director incorrectly. He was Alan J. Pakula; the screenplay was written by James L. Brooks.

title: U.S., IN RETALIATION, CUTS MOZAMBIQUE FOOD AID
description: The Reagan Administration today revoked $5 million worth of credits for food purchases by Mozambique because of the Maputo Government's expulsion last week of six United States diplomats, State Department officials said.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about trends in furnishings gave an incorrect address for Light Inc. The store is at 1162 Second Avenue (at 61st Street).

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 17.50-18.00** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A PLACE TO TRY ON A TURTLE'S SHELL OR WALK ON A WEB
description: The good news from the Bronx is that late in May that neglected and often maligned borough will open the city's newest and most exciting outdoor classroom.

title: A HEALTHIER PLAN FOR THE SOUTH BRONX
description: To the Editor:

title: SYRACUSE SETS BACK MARQUETTE BY 88-81
description: Tony Bruin scored 26 points tonight and Syracuse University held off a late Marquette rally to post an 88-81 victory in a National Invitation Tournament opening-round game.

title: P.S.C. Official Backs Lilco Rate Increase
description: ALBANY (UPI) - The Long Island Lighting Company should be given a rate increase of either 10.6 percent or 12.4 percent, an administrative law judge for the State Public Service Commission recommended. The increase would total either $135.6 million or $158.5 million, said the judge, David Schechter.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOHO ON THE GO

title: MONEY SUPPLY RISE REVERSES RATE DROP
description: Short-term interest rates declined sharply for a while yesterday, then abruptly reversed direction after the Federal Reserve announced a $3.2 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply.

title:
PATENTS;
Reagan Budget Asks Rise In Patent Office Funds
description: The Reagan budget message sent to Congress this week has proposed increased funds and additional personnel for the Patent and Trademark Office. The increases are subject to Congressional approval and the lifting of the freeze on hiring.

title: OPTIMISTIC H.R.A. CHIEF: JAMES ARTHUR KRAUSKOPF
description: In 1966, at a time of blossoming financial commitment and optimism in ministering to the poor and disadvantaged, James A. Krauskopf was a young assistant to the chief of the city's new Human Resources Administration and helped to establish its initial policies. Yesterday, against a backdrop of fiscal belt-tightening and frustration in social service programs, Mayor Koch named him to head the agency.

title: No Headline
description: Northeastern Advances in West Regional

title:
PATENTS;
Optical System Enhances Images on a Microscope
description: An illumination and filter system for biomedical research microscopes, intended to give better images of living cells and other transparent or opaque objects, is the subject of patent 4,255,014, issued this week to Gordon W. Ellis, associate professor of biology at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia.

title: Royal Dutch Unit Names McNamara
description: Robert S. McNamara, who retires July 1 as president of the World Bank, has been nominated for membership on the supervisory board of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, it was announced yesterday.

title: PANEL PICKS REAGAN CONSERVATIVE TO HEAD STATE G.O.P.
description: George L. Clark Jr. of Brooklyn was chosen by a screening panel today to head the Republican Party in New York State.

title: CANADA'S PROBLEMS DISTRESSING BRITAIN
description: The British Government is becoming increasingly embarrassed and distressed by an anachronistic problem intruding from an unlikely corner of its former empire -Canada.

title: SOLARZ PROPOSES ALTERNATIVE CUTS TO REAGAN PLAN
description: Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, urged yesterday what he described as ''more equitable'' alternatives to President Reagan's budget package.

title: by Ronald Fraser
description: One way or another, we must all learn, as individuals and organizations alike, to deal with an uncertain future. We have been repeatedly told that what is to come will not resemble the past, that tomorrow's styles of life and work will differ markedly from today's.

title: LAUGHING CHILDREN OF 50'S NOW A MEMORY IN ATLANTA;
description: Very soon now, 9-year-old Sean Broughton's mother will begin taking him to a firing range so he can learn to use the .38-caliber pistol that is kept atop a dresser in their home.

title: Hinson to Quit Congress, He Tells Governor
description: Representative Jon Hinson, Republican of Mississippi, who faces charges of attempted sodomy, announced today that he would resign from Congress April 13.

title: CONCERT: 3 PREMIERES BY SPECULUM MUSICAE
description: When Speculum Musicae first surfaced 10 years ago as a young group of musicians dedicated to serving new music, the chances of its surviving even one season must have seemed slight enough. New music groups generally are born and die each year like mayflies, and most leave just about as much evidence behind of ever having existed. But here it is 1981 and the ensemble with the odd Latin name - it means ''mirror of music'' - is still with us. That certainly is all to the good, because Speculum not only performs with a corporate skill and professionalism denied to most such groups but also has built a solid organization that promises to keep its wings beating for years to come.

title: BYRD CALLS REAGAN FISCAL PLAN 'ROSY' AND SEES TAX CUT HELD TO ONE YEAR
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, contended today that the Reagan Administration was promoting its economic package on ''overly rosy'' assumptions for the national economy, but he predicted that it might take a year for the public to see the difficulties and cause a political backlash.

title: MAYOR YIELDS TO PROVIDENCE COUNCIL AS IT ACTS TO STAVE OFF BANKRUPTCY
description: Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. agreed late last night to surrender control over city spending in return for approval by the City Council of a 20 percent property tax increase needed to stave off municipal bankruptcy.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A news item in Metropolitan Report on Wednesday identified Sholom Teitelbaum as an assistant rabbi at the Sutton Place Synagogue. He gave that occupation when he pleaded guilty to stock-fraud charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The synagogue's rabbi, David B. Kahane, said yesterday that ''this man has never been retained or in any way ever occupied the position of assistant rabbi at Sutton Place Synagogue.''

title: RESOLUTE HAMILTON
description: THEY are finalists in the city high school basketball tournament, but when they went to their gym three weeks ago the Parks Department had taken away their rims.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Get caught splashing your technicolor trash on our subways and stations and I'll send you to Rikers Island until your spray cans dry up.'' ---Criminal Court Judge Jerome Becker. (28:1.)

title: 2 MEN ARE CONVICTED OF EXTORTING PAYOFFS FROM BROTHELS IN CITY
description: Two men were convicted yesterday of extorting weekly protection payoffs from houses of prostitution in Manhattan. One of the men, Salvatore A. Panico of Brooklyn, was tried in absentia because he failed to appear for the trial in Federal District Court.

title: Ex-Im Bank Israeli Loan
description: The Export-Import Bank yesterday announced its tentative approval of a $172.6 million loan and guarantees covering $23 million in private credits to Israel for the purchase of six airliners and related equipment from the Boeing Company of Seattle. The aircraft, four 767 jetliners and two 737's, will be used by El Al, the Israeli airline, to replace aging planes. The export credit agency notified Congressional leaders that its loan, at 9 1/4 percent interest, and other financing would help a total Israeli purchase of $230.2 million.

title: AIDE SAYS CUT WOULD HOBBLE PRODUCT SAFETY AGENCY
description: Stuart M. Statler, acting director of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, told a House subcommittee today that he was opposed to a proposal by the Reagan Administration to cut the agency's budget by 30 percent for the fiscal year 1982. He contended that the commission had already been operating on ''a nofrills budget for several years.''

title: REAGAN BUDGET HELD UNFAIR TO NORTHEAST AND MIDWEST
description: A number of Republican and Democratic senators and representatives from the Northeast and the Middle West today overrode their ideological differences to unite in assailing President Reagan's proposed budget cuts as an unfair assault on their regions.

title: THROWN BY HORSE, PRINCE IS UNHURT
description: With his bride-to-be looking on, Prince Charles of Britain was thrown from his horse yesterday in an amateur steeplechase race at Sandown Park.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MARCH 14, 1981
description: International Libya agreed to receive prisoners that Pakistan is releasing at the demand of three hijackers holding more than 100 hostages aboard a Pakistani plane in Damascus, Syria. A Pakistani diplomat said 49 prisoners were being assembled in Karachi, Pakistan, for a trip ''in the direction of Libya.'' He said his Government had no record of 6 of the 55 prisoners whose release was demanded by the hijackers. The feeling in Damascus was that the issue of the six prisoners could be crucial to the completion of the agreement to release the hostages. (Page 1, Column 1.) More aid for El Salvador was decided on by the Administration. The Its proposals to send 15 members of the Army's Special Forces and to provide an additional $60 million in economic assistance was discussed by members of the Senate Appropriations Committee and officials of the State and Defense Departments and the Central Intelligence Agency. (1:2.)

title: FINALLY, A VANDAL-RESISTANT BENCH?
description: After years of experimentation, the Parks Department says it has come up with a vandal-resistant bench. ''Not vandal-proof,'' Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis says quickly. ''But vandal-resistant.'' Let the semanticists argue the difference. What Commissioner Davis is saying is that the department has developed two new types of benches that have so far seemingly withstood all efforts to dismantle them. They have been tested in a variety of parks and playgrounds, such as Lyons Park in the South Bronx and the Forest Park bandshell in Queens.

title: Article 040674 -- No Title
description: The United Nations Children's Fund raised $17.1 million from the sale of greeting cards and other items in 1979. Unicef said today that 113 million cards, 694,505 calendars and 283,956 packs of stationery and related items were sold in 135 nations in 1979. It said its net income for 1980 was expected to exceed $20 million.

title: STAGE: 'CATONSVILLE NINE'
description: The drama of a courtroom often makes a difficult transition in becoming the courtroom drama of a theater, but this certainly does not seem to have affected the powerful and tasteful performance of ''The Trial of the Catonsville Nine'' now being re-enacted in the comfortable new home of the Spectrum Theater on Vandam Street.

title: IRANIAN CITY, STRUCK BY MISSILES, IS A VIRTUAL GHOST TOWN AT NIGHT
description: Ahwaz, the capital of oilproducing Khuzistan Province, has become a virtual ghost town at night because of Tuesday's Iraqi missile attack, witnesses said today.

title: LEGAL SERVICES LAWYERS DECRY PLAN TO HALT FUNDS
description: President Reagan's proposal to eliminate all Federal financing of legal services for the poor in noncriminal cases would devastate a network of 22 storefront offices throughout New York City, according to lawyers in charge of the offices.

title: Record in Weight Throw
description: Joe Brancaccio of Queens College set a meet record of 48 feet 7 inches in winning the 35-pound weight throw last night at the City University of New York track and field championships.

title: ABOR
description: RUSSIANS IN ORBITAL FLIGHT: Vladimir Kovalyonok, left, and Viktor Savinykh at the Baikonur launching site in Kazakhstan before the liftoff of Soyuz T4. Their craft docked yesterday with the orbital laboratory, Salyut 6, on a mission whose duration and goals have not been disclosed. Salyut 6 has been in orbit since 1976.

title: by David Sarasohn
description: To a resident of Oregon, the current deepening of the country into Sun Belt and Snow Belt is somewhat perplexing. It's not that we object to the other states' choosing sides; it's just that it's not clear which side we're on. Neither sun nor snow is the dominant feature of our climate; mostly it tends to be cloudy, with chance of showers.

title: Error-Plagued Mets Bow to Phillies by 6-1
description: For the first time since they won the World Series five months ago, the Philadelphia Phillies played a ball game today, and they marked their return by cruising past the Mets, 6-1.

title: KNICKS DEFEAT BULLS AND GAIN PLAYOFF STRENGTH
description: Ray Williams and Michael Ray Richardson pulled out of their scoring slumps last night as the Knicks routed the Chicago Bulls, 127-117, at Madison Square Garden.

title: by John W. Hanley
description: The nation is now undertaking the solution of one aspect of the hazardous-waste issue - that of cleaning up past mistakes. But the Superfund, signed into law by Jimmy Carter, will take care of only the easiest part of the problem.

title: Edgy Nationalisms of the North
description: With such ill wind on both sides of the Canadian-American border, some good was bound to come from Mr. Reagan's trip to Ottawa. And he achieved a personal success despite his decision before the trip to withdraw a Canadian-American fisheries treaty that the Senate was unlikely to ratify. Scrapping the treaty before the visit surely made more sense than risking outrage by doing so just after.

title:
PATENTS;
A SYSTEM TO CONTROL OFFICE ENTRY
description: A CRYPTOGRAPHIC system that keeps unauthorized persons from entering offices, plants and hotels was patented this week by a staff mathematician for the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Schmidt to Go to France Sunday
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt will travel to France on Sunday for an unscheduled private meeting with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France. The French Embassy said today that the meeting would take place outside Strasbourg and that no political or Government officials would be present.

title: Warner Amex Cable
description: Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. said it had been awarded the cable television franchise for Wakefield, Mass., a suburb of Boston.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. 4. 2. The conference had got unanimous approval on a three-year development program to help clean up the Mediterranean from nations bordering the sea, including Libya, Israel, Lebanon, Tunisia and Syria, nations that usually agree on very little.

title: LANCASTER COUNTY MOBILIZES IN FIGHT TO SAVE FARM LAND
description: Amos Funk was sitting at the kitchen table in his farmhouse southwest of town, varicolored maps of Lancaster County spread out in front of him.

title: SALE EXPECTED TO AID KENNECOTT
description: The sale of the Kennecott Corporation to the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) for almost $1.8 billion in cash was hailed on Wall Street yesterday as a rescue plan for a company squeezed by low copper prices and outdated mining facilities.

title: Savings Industry Aid Studied
description: The Reagan Administration is working out plans to provide a safety net for beleaguered savings and loan associations, and one of the steps may be measures to lessen the competitive attractions of money market mutual funds, R.T. McNamar, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, disclosed in an interview yesterday.

title: MacMillan Bloedel Head Bars Takeover
description: Calvert C. Knudsen, chairman of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., the Vancouver-based forest products concern, rejected a $285.2 million (Canadian) takeover bid by the British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation as ''too low'' and said that he did not welcome the bid.

title: HARLEY-DAVIDSON MAPS GROWTH
description: During a recent week of motorcycle races here, an executive of AMF suggested that a visitor count the number of motorcyclists sporting Harley-Davidson tattoos. ''How can you match that kind of product loyalty?'' he asked. ''I haven't seen anyone with Honda or Yamaha tatooed on their arm.''

title: Moscow Is Said to Release Ballet Dancer It Seized
description: Yuri Stepanov, a Soviet ballet dancer who was seized on the street by plainclothesmen yesterday, was released after being held for two hours, it was reported here today.

title: ALBANY STUDYING PROPOSALS TO AID RACING INDUSTRY
description: New York State officials, troubled by a decade of financial losses in the state's racing industry, are considering several proposals to reverse the trend and increase the state's diminishing share of racing revenues -including the possible abolition of the New York Racing Association.

title: M.T.A. TAKES A STEP TOWARD JULY 1 RISE IN 60
description: After an angry political wrangle, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted 8 to 6 yesterday to pave the way for a probable July 1 fare increase.

title: A Bad Bet on Ball Games
description: Not satisfied with just the ponies, Mayor Koch and New York's Offtrack Betting Corporation now want a lottery on the results and scores of ball games. John Keenan, the chairman of OTB, estimates that New Yorkers gamble $3 billion a year on these games illegally and has persuaded the Mayor that the city, not the organized-crime interests that book these bets, should reap the profits.

title: Oil Licenses Off England
description: The Texas Gas Exploration Corporation said today that it had been granted two production licenses by the British Government. The company said the licenses are in the English Channel, southeast of the Isle of Wight. Each license covers 55,000 acres.

title: 2 Get 15 Days in Jail For Subway Graffiti
description: A judge sentenced two youths to 15 days in jail for scrawling the name of their street gang in a subway station in Brooklyn. ''Get caught splashing your Technicolor trash on our subways and stations and I'll send you to Rikers Island until your spray cans dry up,'' was the warning of Judge Jerome Becker of Criminal Court in Brooklyn to the graffiti painters who have defaced the city's subways, buses and structures in recent years.

title: Fund Set Up to Pay Asbestos Suit Claims
description: NEWARK (UPI) - A $9.4 million trust fund has been established to settle the claims of hundreds of employees who said they had developed asbestos-related diseases, including cancer, while working at the Raybestos-Manhattan plant in Passaic.

title: SATURDAY, MARCH 14, 1981; Companies
description: Sales of the Big Three auto makers gained 8.5 percent during the first 10 days of March, compared with the year-earlier period. But the rise was considered disappointing because it came amid one of the most aggressive rebate programs in the industry's history. (Page 29.)

title: Michael T. Enserro, an Actor, 62; Performed on Stage, Film and TV
description: Michael T. Enserro, a character actor who played on the Broadway stage and in films but who was best known for his roles in television commercials, died March 4 following a heart attack in his home in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

title: New Sanitation Deputy Sworn In
description: A 26-year veteran of New York City's Sanitation Department was sworn in yesterday as deputy commissioner for sanitation operations, in charge of the agency's primary functions. The new deputy, Vincent P. Whitfield, was sworn in by Commissioner Norman Steisel at the department's offices at 125 Worth Street. Also sworn in by Mr. Steisel were five senior and field management officials, seven district superintendents and 37 new foremen.

title: Zellerbach Outlay
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation, a major San Francisco-based producer of newsprint, paper packaging and other forest products, said it planned to modernize its pulp and paper mill at Camas, Wash., at a cost of more than $375 million. The funds are to be provided from internal cash and external financing, the company said. The company said that the improvements, part of a $1.2 billion capital spending program, could begin immediately and be completed in about three years.

title: June Summit Meeting In Mexico Is Delayed
description: A summit conference of industrialized and developing countries that had been planned for early June in Mexico was postponed today until Oct. 22-23, Foreign Minister Jorge Castaneda of Mexico said.

title: Coffee and Cancer
description: So now it's coffee that's a possible carcinogen. Researchers at the Harvard School of Public Health have found a statistical link between drinking coffee and cancer of the pancreas, a gland that secretes digestive juices. They think coffee may cause more than half the 20,000 deaths from this lethal disease each year.

title: THE FOLLY OF CUTTING TRANSPORT PROGRAMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Burleson Signs $4.2 Million Pact
description: Rick Burleson agreed to a six-year contract worth $4.2 million with the California Angels today, making him the highest-paid shortstop in baseball history.

title: SALVADORAN DISCLOSES NEW EVIDENCE IN MURDER OF FOUR U.S. MISSIONARIES
description: Jose Napoleon Duarte, the president of the Salvadoran junta, said today that important new evidence had been uncovered concerning the murders here in December of three American nuns and a lay missionary.

title: REAGAN PROVIDES MORE AID FOR INVESTIGATION IN ATLANTA
description: President Reagan, describing the unsolved murders of 20 black children and the disappearances of two others as ''one of the most tragic situations'' ever to confront an American community, today directed that $1.5 million be given to this city to help defray the costs of the investigation.

title: GRUBBS IS A QUIET KEY TO DE PAUL'S BID
description: To hear those around him talk, it sounded as if Teddy Grubbs had been somewhere far, far away. Last Sunday his De Paul teammates welcomed him back, after Grubbs had scored 14 points against Notre Dame to close out the regular season, the first time in many games that they had seen the confidence and the shooting and jumping ability that made Grubbs a high school all-American two years ago.

title: TRADE-OFF
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN, VISITING CITY, PLANS WESTWAY TALKS WITH KOCH
description: President Reagan, who arrived in New York City last night for his first visit since he took office, plans to confer today with Mayor Koch about plans for the Westway.

title: Radioactive Steam Is Released
description: Workers repairing pipes yesterday at the Quad Cities Nuclear Generating Station accidentally released radioactive steam in the unit's No. 1 reactor, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today. The release involved a small amount of radioactive steam that escaped into a vent, a spokesman for the nuclear agency said, adding that the workers had not been overexposed to radioactivity and monitors outside the nuclear had recorded no unusual increase in radiation.

title: TAKING UP THE CAUSE OF NURSING HOME ELDERLY
description: Having made the painful, often guilt-ridden decision to put an elderly person in a nursing home, what do you do when you find that your parent, husband, wife or friend is ill cared for or neglected by the nursing home staff?

title: SALES RISE OUTPACES INVENTORIES'
description: Business inventories rose in January, but sales increased at an even greater rate and the inventory-tosales ratio dropped to 1.36 from 1.37 in December, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Time Inc. Opens Talks on Unit Sale
description: Time Inc. and Columbia Pictures Industries Inc. said they had opened discussions on a deal in which Columbia would acquire the money-losing feature film and television divisions of Time-Life Films Inc., a Time subsidiary.

title: 43,000 Seeking 200 Police Jobs
description: About 43,000 candidates have applied for 200 positions as Transit Authority police officers, an authority spokesman said yesterday. The applicants will take a written test that will be given at 27 city high schools today at noon.

title: ROBERT H. TAYLOR
description: Robert H. Taylor, a retired agent of the Secret Service who served under five Presidents, died of cancer yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: PHILADELPHIA FACES TRANSIT STRIKE
description: The city's transit workers are threatening to walk off the job when their contract expires at 12:01 A.M. Sunday. The financially troubled system carries an average of 400,000 riders on weekdays on buses, subways and trolleys.

title: PIRATES OF LAGOS: ONCE AN ANNOYANCE, NOW A MAJOR THREAT
description: Piracy in the harbor here, for years a petty annoyance, has reached such an outrageous level that shipping agents representing lines from the United States, Europe and the Far East are concerned that their maritime unions might boycott the port.

title: REAGAN APPOINTS A COMMUNICATIONS LAWYER TO F.C.C.
description: Mark S. Fowler, a Republican lawyer who specializes in communications law, was nominated by President Reagan today to a seat on the Federal Communications Commission and, ultimately, to become its new chairman.

title: I.B.M. PACT IN JAPAN IS DENIED
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has denied reports that it has proposed that Matsushita Electric Industrial Company sell to I.B.M. small-business computers that I.B.M. would market.

title: REAGAN PROPOSAL SEEKS SHARP CUT IN STUDENTS' AID
description: A Reagan Administration proposal could sharply reduce the amount of Federal education grants for about 1.5 million college students in the next school year.

title: Officer Hurt in 5th Ave. Shootout Is Now in Satisfactory Condition
description: A New York City police officer wounded last week in a midtown shootout on Fifth Avenue was reported in satisfactory condition yesterday, but doctors still do not know if he will walk again.

title: Brazil Oil Output Up
description: Brazilian oil production in February rose to an average 220,980 barrels a day, the national oil company, Petrobras, said today.
To the Editor:

title: EXCERPTS FROM ADMINISTRATION'S STATEMENT TO SENATORS ON HELPING EL SALVADOR
description: Following are excerpts from a statement by Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs Walter J. Stoessel Jr. before the Senate Appropriations Committee today on proposed assistance to El Salvador:

title: C.I.A. AIDE REASSURES SENATE PANEL
description: Adm. Bobby R. Inman, deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, met today with a Senate committee and reportedly reassured its members about changes that the Reagan Administration intends to make in President Carter's executive order imposing restrictions on the nation's intelligence agencies.

title:
PATENTS;
Device May Promote Cleaner-Burning Fuel
description: A device that electrostatically atomizes all liquid hydrocarbons regardless of their conductivity has been invented at the Exxon Research and Engineering Company's research laboratories in Linden, N.J. The atomizer is called a spray triode.

title: L.I.U. EIMINATED FROM N.C.A.A.
description: Charlotte, N.C. March 13 - Long Island University received a rude awakening from its National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament dreams tonight. The Blackbirds lost to Virginia Commonwealth, 85-69, in the opening round of the East Regional.

title: NIXON GUEST OF HONOR AT CONSERVATIVES' DINNER
description: The guest of honor at an exclusive fund-raising event for conservative Congressional candidates, to be held March 25 at the Union League Club in New York, will be Richard M. Nixon.

title: WORLD MARK, 56-9 1 2, IS SET IN TRIPLE JUMP
description: The 17th annual National Collegiate indoor track and field champioships began today with finals in three track and four field events. The races were good, but the field events were sensational.
