title: AMAX INQUIRY FOCUSES ON COAST BUSINESSMAN
description: Thomas C. Reed, a former Secretary of the Air Force, denied today through his attorney that advance knowledge of a $4 billion takeover bid for Amax Inc. led him to buy 500 call options for Amax stock the day before the takeover offer was announced.

title: World Bank Aide Resigns
description: Colbert King, who was appointed by President Carter as the American executive director at the World Bank, resigned today before being replaced by President Reagan.

title: ARTHUR C. DECK
description: Arthur C. Deck, executive editor emeritus of The Salt Lake Tribune, died last night after suffering a heart attack at a hospital, where he had been about a week.

title: Torstar Sells Stake In Broadcast Unit
description: The Torstar Corporation, publisher of The Toronto Star and other Canadian newspapers, said that it had agreed to sell its 33 percent interest in the Western Broadcasting Company of Vancouver for $25.4 million (Canadian).

title: Donovan Says He'll Aid Dropped CETA Workers
description: Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan said today that his department would assist more than 300,000 workers hired under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act who are to lose their jobs in September because of President Reagan's budget cuts.

title: A Tale of King Frog, in the City Hall Log
description: ''Edward I. Koch, Mayor,'' is a nom de plume of Evelyn Strouse, poet, teller of children's tales, and professional correspondent, one of 12 people who work full time answering about 1,000 letters the Mayor receives daily.

title: CUT SUBSIDY REQUEST, AMTRAK IS URGED
description: Senator Howard W. Cannon, who has declared his support for subsidized passenger train service, offered some friendly advice to Amtrak today: Compromise on your request for Federal assistance for next year or risk reductions that could eliminate all service except for the Northeast Corridor.

title: Moody's Air Ratings
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc. said it had cut its rating on the debt of Barniff Airways Inc., Continentl Air Lines Inc. and Western Airlines Inc. The bond-rating agency said its action reflected the continuing deterioration in debt-protection measurements among the three carriers and the uncertain outlook for the industry, especially the large trunk airlines.

title: Tulsa 81, Pan American 71
description: Phil Spradling scored 17 points and Greg Stewart 15 to lead Tulsa to an 81-71 victory over Pan American tonight.

title: PRESS IN INDIA UPSET BY IMPORT DUTY ON NEWSPRINT
description: The newspaper industry in India is becoming nervous over a new 15 percent import duty on newsprint imposed by the Government recently.

title: CITY'S JOB OUTLOOK IS WORSENING FOR 40 PERCENT WHO QUIT SCHOOL
description: Antonia Huntley dropped out of Fashion Industries High School in 1977 after spending two years in the ninth grade. She liked her courses in cutting patterns for men's clothing, she said, but somehow she could not keep up with her academic subjects.

title: Dayton Press Rescue Failing
description: Dayton Press Inc. said today that a $140 million employee buy-out plan would not succeed and indicated that the company's aging printing plant may be closed by the end of the year.

title: ASIANS CHOOSE SINGAPORE ENVOY TO HEAD U.N. LAW OF SEA PARLEY
description: The conference to write a sweeping code for the deep seas today chose Tommy Koh of Singapore as its president.

title: News Analysis
description: A largely unsuccessful effort by a Hartford television station to show portions of a figure-skating championship on its evening newscast has become an unusual test of competing claims of commercial rights and press freedoms.

title: by Robert A. Gerard
description: Nearly six years to the day after New York City's fiscal crisis officially began, Standard & Poor's Corporation on March 5 proclaimed it over by assigning an investment-grade credit rating to the city's more than $6 billion of general obligation bonds.

title: CARTER SELLS MEMOIRS TO BANTAM BOOKS
description: Jimmy Carter's Presidential memoirs have been sold to Bantam Books, which plans to publish a hardcover edition late next year and a paperback reprint in 1983. The financial details of the deal were not announced, but it is expected that the book would eventually earn the former President several million dollars.

title: MCADOO JOINS NETS FOR 140-125 VICTORY
description: Bob McAdoo, making his first appearance in a New Jersey uniform after being claimed on waivers earlier today from the Detroit Pistons, scored 4 points in four minutes of play tonight as the Nets beat Cleveland Cavaliers, 140-125.

title: HIS COMPANY FACES SUITS AND DEBTS
description: John Ross Greer is pictured by acquaintances as an affable, articulate young man whose goal was to emulate Nelson Bunker Hunt, the Texas billionaire. To many he appeared well on his way. Now he has disappeared, and his company, the Virginia Gold and Silver Trading Company, is in disarray.

title: JERSEY RAIL YARD'S WATER CUT FOR NOT PAYING DROUGHT FINE
description: Water supplies to a sprawling Conrail freight and repair yard in Elizabeth, N.J., were cut off for five and a half hours yesterday because of Conrail's failure to pay a $95,385 fine for exceeding its rationing quota, local and state officials said.

title: PULLING UP THE PRIVATE PENSION COVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Record for Pins Is Sought By a Syracuse Wrestler
description: Gene Mills, the 118-pound senior from Syracuse, pinned his opponent at the National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championships this afternoon and claimed he had set a record for career falls. Tonight, after he won another match by a decision, he changed his mind.

title: POLISH BISHOPS REQUEST CALM AS LABOR TENSION GROWS
description: In the face of rising labor tension, this time in the central city of Radom, the Polish Conference of Roman Catholic Bishops called today for discipline and calm in what it said was a ''complex and delicate'' situation.

title: Jersey Panel Rejects Proposed Prison Site
description: TRENTON (UPI) - A state commission that reviews construction projects rejected Annandale as the site for a $34 million, 400-bed medium-security prison.

title: 15 U.S. GREEN BERETS TO AID SALVADORANS
description: The Reagan Administration disclosed today that 15 of the American military advisers being sent to El Salvador are members of the Army's Special Forces who would train troops in counterinsurgency.

title: No Headline
description: Vincent Reed, former superintendent of public schools in the District of Columbia, was nominated by Mr. Reagan today to be Assistant Secretary of Education for elementary and secondary education. Mr. Reed, 53, has held various positions in the District's school system since 1970.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration has succeeded in focusing world attention on El Salvador, but its monthlong campaign has also produced some negative side effects not to Washington's liking. Many key members of Congress and foreign governments that were only dimly aware of El Salvador's problems before are now openly concerned about the possibility of ''another Vietnam,'' even though the Administration insists such a comparison is unfounded.

title: WROTE ON RELATIVES AND THE WAR
description: Robert Cecil Romer Maugham, the British author who wrote under the name Robin Maugham, died yesterday after a long illness in Brighton, England. He was 64 years old.

title: Ford Steelworkers Approve Pay Cut to Save Operation
description: Steelworkers at the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant voted overwhelmingly tonight to take an average cut of 20 percent in incentive pay in exchange for keeping about 3,200 jobs, a union official said.

title: COURT TOLD WHY STAGEHAND WAS HELD IN MURDER AT MET
description: An assistant district attorney testified yesterday that by last Aug. 29 he believed the police had gathered enough information to show that ''Craig Crimmins was the killer of Helen Hagnes Mintiks'' at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Court Rules for Detroit On Razing for G.M. Plant
description: The Michigan Supreme Court gave General Motors and the City of Detroit permission today to raze buildings in the Poletown neighborhood and replace them with a Cadillac assembly plant.

title: GREEKS ASSESS DAMAGE TO ANTIQUITIES IN QUAKE
description: The Greek Government said today that recent earthquakes had caused $2 million in damage to its antiquities and added that the figure was expected to rise.

title: Sale of Staterooms On a Ship Is Barred
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York has moved to prevent a California company and its Long Island agent, Carlino & Phillips Advertising Inc. of Plainview, from continuing a ''$4 million scheme'' to sell ''condominium'' staterooms aboard a cruise ship and promising buyers luxurious voyages to Pacific island ports.

title: Marxists Who Back Mrs. Ghandi Organize Separate Party in India
description: A new Communist party, supporting Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, has been set up in India. The first congress of the All India Communist Party, a breakaway group of the pro-Moscow Communist Party of India, opened in Meerut last night.

title: BRITISH HOSPITALS TO END FREE CARE OF FOREIGNERS
description: Britain is ending free hospital care for foreigners after 32 years of extending to visitors the benefits of socialized medicine.

title: U.P.S. Employees Remain Off the Job
description: Employees of the United Parcel Service stayed off the job in most of the metropolitan New York area for a second day despite a court order directing union leaders to get their members back to work.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Cyanamid Co. has agreed to purchase a 20 percent equity in Molecular Genetics Inc. for $5.5 million.

title: Jackson and Michael Huddle
description: Reggie Jackson met with Manager Gene Michael after the game, but neither would say what they discussed.

title: BANKING ON YAP: OLD AND NEW
description: When the Bank of Hawaii decided to become known as ''the bank of the Pacific,'' the area between Honolulu and Manila seemed ripe for trade and investment. The islands were small, but there appeared to be potential for development and tourism. There was little competition, and sometimes none at all.

title: Brown Banking on Switch in His Fortunes
description: It is obvious that Bobby Brown does not do the obvious. Example: Mickey Mantle, one of the greatest switch-hitters in baseball history, has been in the Yankees' spring camp when Brown has been here each of the last two years. But Brown, relatively new at switch-hitting, has not sought any advice from him. ''I don't like to bother people,'' Brown said today. ''Mantle has so many obligations. It's tough to say, 'Hey, Mick, help me with my hitting.' ''

title: FORMER NEW YORK JUDGE
description: John V. Flood, a retired justice of the Court of Special Sessions in New York, died Thursday in Denville, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Denville.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 21. 1. Despite an increased use of contraceptives (2/4/6) girls out of every 10, now 14 years old, will become pregnant in their teens, according to a study by the Alan Guttmacher Institute.

title: STOCKS END MIXED AFTER EARLY SURGE
description: The New York Stock Exchange had its busiest first hour in history yesterday, after Thursday's sharp advance sparked a flood of overnight buy and sell orders. The burst of activity was short-lived, however, as traders sought to cash in their profits, and prices finished mixed in heavy trading.

title: JURY IN JERSEY INDICTS 8 FOR DISTRIBUTING DRUGS FROM A 'STRESS CENTER'
description: Eight persons - including two physicians and a psychologist - have been indicted by a state grand jury for illegally distributing drugs through a ''stress center'' in Fort Lee, officials announced today.

title: Tolentine Defeats Power For 2d C.H.S.A.A. Title
description: Ernest Myers scored 7 of his game-high 23 points in the final minute and led Tolentine to its second straight Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship, a 64-62 triumph over Power Memorial at Fordham University last night.

title: Times Mirror Cable Adds Movie Service
description: the Times Mirror Cable Television Company said it planned to set up its own movie service to purchase programming directly from film studios rather than from movie wholesalers.

title: 'FUNHOUSE' BY TOBE HOOPER
description: ''Funhouse'' is a horror movie, not a really good one, but considering that its central horror is a standard monster (fangs, drool, stringy hair and a sour expression) who pursues four standard teen-agers (dope, fornication, mopey expressions), it is not a really bad movie, either. Tobe Hooper, the director, was in there trying.

title: ON THE EXECUTION OF STEVEN JUDY
description: To the Editor:

title: AMIABLE LITTLE TORTOLA, A CARIBBEAN ISLAND OF TRANQUILLITY
description: Cane Garden Bay is a curve of white sand. A tin-roofed shed sheltering a few tables stands on the beach; a steel band practices on the sand nearby. An old automobile tire hangs on a rope from a palm tree.

title: IT'S A GREAT DAY FOR THE IRISH, BUT WILL DEATH TAKE A HOLIDAY
description: I'm Irish,'' and at Fifth Avenue and 86th Street, where Manhattan's annual St. Patrick's Day parade ends, thousands of high school and college students will celebrate the day in their own style. They will get drunk.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
NEW JERSEY OPENS THE FAUCET A BIT
description: It will be harder than ever for New Jersey to live up to its nickname this spring. Despite an above-average amount of rain last month, residents in 372 communities still may not legally water their gardens.

title: ARKANSAS' REED HITS 49-FOOTER AT BUZZER TO TOP LOUISVILLE
description: Louisville's bid for a second straight National Collegiate basketball title ended stunningly today when U.S. Reed made a 49-foot shot at the buzzer that gave Arkansas a 74-73 triumph.

title: Behind the Best Sellers
description: ''I never again want to be in a position where I'm at the mercy of anyone else.'' That is what Mary Ellen Pinkham says she told herself five years ago when her husband lost his job as the public relations man for the Minnesota Vikings. So Mrs. Pinkham, who had been toying with an idea for a book on household hints, went to work in earnest. With help from her mother, Pearl Higginbotham, she collected tidbits from strangers, along with advice handed down from her grandmother, on such matters as how to keep flies away from garbage pails and how to thread a needle, and came up with ''Mary Ellen's Best of Helpful Hints.''

title: HIGH POINT, N.C.: THE FURNITURE MAKERS ARE COMING UNGLUED
description: sized maker of high-quality wood and upholstered furniture that is sold in stores like W.& J. Sloane, Abraham & Straus and Bamberger's. It uses machines for such tasks as cutting, boring and shaping its wooden frames, but that's pretty much the extent of automation at Carson's.

title: Of Shoes and Politics
description: When the Secretary of Commerce announced in April 1980 that his department would spend $2.2 million for a new technology center in Philadelphia for the shoe industry, opponents of Jimmy Carter said the decision was political.

title: Other Business; THOSE WHO MIGHT BUY CHRYSLER
description: Investor Wanted: Large North American auto manufacturer. Has high visibility and large, hungry sales network. Seeks partner or new owner. Assets include large loans guaranteed by the U.S. Call L. Iacocca, (313) 956-5252.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Working With Fabrics For Home Decorating
description: Rosemarte Inc., a year-old Stamford company at a site known for four years as Harbour Point, supplies custom orders to home decorators and stores. Rosemary Horsting, the owner, whose experience in the business began 20 years ago in Georgia, has opened the Company Store to sell surplus wares to the public. There is a Thursday-to-Saturday schedule at prices 40 percent off a department store's charge.

title: AID RIFT IMPERILS DISABLED YOUNG
description: NORFOLK, CONN. AS A result of bureaucratic confusion over jurisdiction involving almost a dozen agencies in New Jersey, Connecticut and the Federal Government, 28 retarded children in a home for the handicapped here are not receiving the kinds of comprehensive therapy and education that are required by Federal law.

title: THE ASCENT OF ADRIAN MALONE
description: Marshall Ledger is associate editor of The Pennsylvania Gazette, the alumni magazine of the University of Pennsylvania. By Marshall Ledger ith an arrow in his neck - Marlon Brando is improvising an Indian's death - the actor staggers around the living room of his Beverly Hills home, groping for the rod sticking through his carotid artery. He settles on a ''stump'' - his couch - his eyes glazing.

title: CONCERT: TOTALLY MOZART
description: Nowhere in Europe did Mozart find a more appreciative audience than in Czechoslovakia, and an echo of that historical fact could be heard at the New York Philharmonic subscription concerts in Avery Fisher Hall this weekend. Two Czechoslovakia-born musicians were the philharmonic's guests - Rafael Kubelik led the orchestra and Rudolf Firkusny played the Piano Concerto in C minor (K. 491).

title: Food; TAMING WILD RICE
description: One of the greatest delicacies native to America is wild rice, which is actually produced from a water grass, not from a ''grain'' like regular rice. Wild rice was first harvested by American Indians hundreds of years ago, mostly from water that is several feet deep along the banks of the Great Lakes.

title: LAND PROGRAM IS TAKING HOLD IN EL SALVADOR
description: A year after its inception, El Salvador's bold and disputed land redistribution program is taking hold. The first crops are in and, despite predictions of economic disaster, the harvests on newly formed cooperatives were about the same as they were last year under the former owners.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MARCH 15, 1981
description: International South African military officers arrived in Washington last week apparently to visit State Department and Defense Department officials, but were preparing to return home after the State Department raised questions about their status and canceled an appointment. The trip by the five senior military officers, made under ''misleading circumstances,'' according to an Administration official. (Page 1, Column 6.) Pakistani hijackers surrendered in Damascus after Syria agreed to give asylum to 54 prisoners who had been released by Pakistan in compliance with the hijackers' demands. Three Americans were among the more than 100 hostages who had been held aboard the hijacked Pakistani airliner for two weeks. The plane was first flown to Kabul, Afghanistan, and then to Damascus. (1:4.)

title: IN DREAMS AND REALITY, TEAM OWNER AIMS TO COVER ALL THE BASES
description: WEST BABYLON WHEN Dave Goldstein was a young boy growing up in Plainview, he played a modified backyard version of baseball. Fantasizing, he batted clean-up behind Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle of the Yankees. Although his childhood dreams seemed to concern on-the-field activities, now Mr. Goldstein is concerned with behind-the-field events and plans as he enters his second year as the owner of the West Haven A's minor league baseball team.

title: Politics; A FIRST TERM STARTS WITH PLANS FOR SECOND
description: ANTICIPATING a tough campaign for re-election next year, Representative Gregory W. Carman has begun his 1982 campaign even as his first term in the House gets under way.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Some Gift Sales Go Unheralded
description: The Studio for Your Gifts has no mailing list for sales because it may be just a whim on a particular day to cut prices. It may also be a special occasion, such as the celebration of the first year at the Palmer Avenue location in Larchmont, with a two-week 20 percent-off sale for selected merchandise, beginning today.

title: HOLLERING 'FIRE'
description: It's the kind of case that may discomfit even the most ardent defender of press freedom. The National Enquirer last week wrapped itself in the First Amendment as a libel suit brought by actress Carol Burnett finally came to trial.

title: HOUSE UNIT URGES FINANCING FOR PINELANDS
description: WASHINGTON DESPITE opposition from the Reagan Administration, a House committee recommended last week that the Federal Government spend $4 million for land purchases in the Pine Barrens in fiscal 1982.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: 62), America's quintessential sex symbol, told through 100 off-screen pictures taken by 24 photographers and more than 110,00 exuberant words by Norman Mailer. On its publication in 1979, our reviewer Pauline Kael called this ''a metaphysical cocktail-party book''; it is now available in large paperback format.

title: Jacob Oleiski Dies at 80; Led Israeli ORT Schools
description: Jacob Oleiski, former director of ORT, the Organization for Rehabilitation through Training, a network of vocational schools in Israel, died last night at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: Bethany Nazarene Takes N.A.I.A. Basketball Title
description: Todd Thurman scored 5 of his 39 points in overtime tonight as he led Bethany Nazarene of Oklahoma to an 86-85 victory over Alabama-Huntsville for the championship of the 44th N.A.I.A. basketball tournament.

title: PROPOSAL BY REAGAN OPENS AN OLD WOUND
description: To Ralph Abascal, general counsel of California Rural Legal Assistance, the announcement from Washington awakened memories of a bitter fight, once won, that might now be lost because his old opponent, Ronald Reagan, had become President.

title: St. Louis's Papers Lose Suits to Get Police Files
description: A divided panel of Federal judges has ruled that the public and the news media have no constitutional right of access to police files sealed by sections of Missouri law.

title: On the Isle; by Barbara Delatiner; COLLECTIONS, ANYONE?
description: What do collectors collect? That depends. If the collectors are museums, then it's usually a little bit of everything. For example, for its current exhibition, the Northport Historical Society Museum has dug deep and come up with ''Choices From Our Collection'': things like an 18th-century square piano, a mid-19th-century chest of shipbuilding tools, a dollhouse reproduction of a vintage village home, and the original roll-top desk that graced the Village Hall. These and other ''choices'' will be on display from 1 to 4:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Sundays through June 14. The museum is at 215 Main Street and admission is 50 cents; for children and the elderly, 25 cents.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title:
Gardening;
ROCK WALLS: BEAUTY ENHANCED BY UTILITY
description: THE campus of my alma mater is noted for its quiet beauty, its towering century-old trees, spacious lawns and masses of flowering shrubs, all of which create a serene and relaxed environment conducive to studying. On warm spring days, students, as I remember, used to pop up here and there on the lawns, books spread on the grass before them, like so many spring flowers responding to the warmth of the sun.

title:
MAILBOX;
N.B.A Owners Should Adopt Rules of the College Game
description: To the Sports Editor: For most of my 10 years of coaching, I have been a teacher of fundamentals and attitude. Most of my teams were forced to win by intangibles: heart, desire, intelligence, and pride.

title: Hog Jogging
description: A group of unlikely joggers - pigs -took to a grassy track at Arizona State University in Tempe in April 1980 to help two researchers study the effects of jogging and diet on health. For the joggers, the sport ended before the summer was out.

title:
Business Forum;
HOW TO DISCOURAGE JOB HOPPING
description: COMPANIES take for granted that half the graduates recruited on campus will have moved on to other organizations within five years. One group of Harvard M.B.A.'s, in fact, has been tracked over a three-year period after graduation: 70 percent changed jobs. A major oil company reports a 30 percent annual turnover in its exploration geologists. Leading accounting firms are said to lose 27 percent of their professionals annually. One out of three middle managers are estimated to have resumes in circulation at this moment.

title: QUEBEC SEPARATISTS TRAIL IN CAMPAIGN FOR APRIL VOTING
description: The referendum defeat suffered last year by Premier Rene Levesque and his Parti Quebecois appears to hang like an albatross around their neck as they embark on what seems at the moment to be a losing campaign for re-election in Quebec April 13.

title: Stamps; THE UNITED NATIONS ADDS A FRESCO TO ITS ART SERIES; by Samuel A. Tower
description: The United Nations has reached into its rich repository of works of art and chosen a 13th century fresco in its General Assembly building for the eighth selection in its long-running series that started more than a decade ago.

title: INTEGRATION BATTLE CONTINUES IN DALLAS
description: The Dallas School Board and a coalition of black community groups have approved a proposal aimed at ending courtordered busing in the nation's eighth largest school district.

title: STATE JOBLESS FUND SERIOUSLY DEPLETED
description: New York State's unemployment insurance fund, hard hit by recessionary periods of the last six years, is critically low, prompting labor and business groups to call for legislation to keep the fund from insolvency.

title: Chess; CRACKING THE MOLD
description: Max Euwe once said of the man with whom he split two world championship matches: ''Even if there are a thousand general reasons for rejecting a move, Alekhine is always ready to consider it.''

title: 2 PROFESSORS WARN OF 'COMING SCARCITY'
description: MAL LUBER is someone who believes that ''when you look down the road, 1981 will seem like the good old days.'' He and his partner, John B. Scippa, co-directors of the American Survival Center in New Haven, describe themselves as ''survivalists,'' committed to preparing for what they see as ''the coming decades of scarcity.''

title: Art View; CRUSADER FOR THE EARLY AVANT-GARDE; by Hilton Kramer
description: There are careers in the arts that acquire in time the quality of an archetype, or fable, and Herwarth Walden's was one of them. Walden, whose real name was Georg Lewin, lived from 1878 to 1941. Today he is remembered as one of the pivotal figures of the European avant-garde in the decade or so following 1910, the year that he founded Der Sturm (The Assault) in Berlin. It is in this role that he is now being commemorated in an attractive exhibition called ''Herwarth Walden and Der Sturm,'' which Helen Serger has organized at La Boetie, 9 East 82d Street (through May 31st).

title: THE VALUE OF CENTRAL MANAGING OF ENERGY
description: President Reagan's economic plan and budget proposal have much to commend them, and his early moves to put the oil-refining industry and gasoline sales on a competitive basis was sound energy policy. But even if these actions work, the economy's Achilles heel will remain. Any major interruption in the world's supply of oil could again more than double the price of oil, throw all industrialized countries into a depression, threaten our national security, and even begin to unravel our social fabric.

title: Leisure; LETTUCE IS THE FIRST SPRING CROP TO PLANT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Ellen Henke is a landscape consultant and teacher. By ELLEN HENKE

title: CURBING THE GOVERNMENT'S BIG APPETITE FOR BORROWING
description: Sallie Mae is going to market. The money market, that is. No longer, the Reagan Administration decreed last week, can she borrow at the Treasury the funds she uses to buy bundles of student loans.

title: 40 U.S. ADVISERS NOW IN SALVADOR
description: A Defense Department spokesman said today that of the 54 United States military personnel authorized to go to El Salvador, 40 have already arrived there and the rest are expected to arrive soon.

title: A FEW LOWER VOICES
description: After about eight weeks in office, the new Adminstration is moderating its policies and even its language - not much but some. It has convinced the country that El Salvador is not a five-cent cigar, but it is no longer talking as if the crisis in Central America were a threat to world peace.

title: THE ECONOMIC EQUIVALENT OF WAR
description: What Richard Nixon wrote to Lyn Nofziger may be right, but it misses the point. In a letter that President Reagan's political adviser has had framed, Mr. Nixon wrote about ''your media friends and those beautiful people from the Washington establishment'' now fawning over Mr. Reagan because he is a winner. Before long, Mr. Nixon wrote, they will turn on him viciously: ''they're just waiting for the day when they can safely attack him again.''

title: Poetry Readings
description: To the Editor:

title: Nonfiction in Brief; by Timothy Ferris
description: IN THE BEGINNING ... By Isaac Asimov. 234 pp. New York: Stonesong Press/ Crown Publishers. $10.95.

title: MAILBOX
description: To the Sports Editor: While it is true that Baruch College is a Division III team by N.C.A.A. standards, this rating does not reflect our academic status (''Basketball at Baruch: No Frills but Plenty of Fun,'' The New York Times, Feb. 21).

title: A FILM SET RESTORES STEINBECK'S WORLD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Karen Stabiner is a West Coast writer with a special interest in film. By KAREN STABINER LOS ANGELES

title: SETON HALL PROFESSOR, A NUN, IS HOPEFUL OF IMPROVING CHRISTIAN-JEWISH
description: TIES By BART BARLOW SOUTH ORANGE SHE uses words like ''chutzpah,'' ends letters with ''Shalom'' (peace) and wears a combination cross and Star of David around her neck.

title: WASHINGTON ; 'WORKFARE' AND THE WORK ETHIC
description: IN Louisiana, welfare recipients were once given the task of beating snakes to death to earn their state payments. In California and New York, in Utah and Massachussetts, the jobs given to welfare recipients were less exotic - school crossing guards, baby sitters, lunchroom aides, park sweepers and school bus helpers.

title: CONTINUING TRAGEDY OF TEEN PREGNANCY
description: While the controversy on what to do about it rages all around them, American adolescents are getting pregnant in prodigious numbers and with unhappy consequences, according to a report published last week by the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a Planned Parenthood affiliate.

title: PAOLO GRASSI, 62, LED LA SCALA IN MILAN
description: Paolo Grassi, a former director of La Scala Opera House and former general manager of Italy's state-run R.A.I. broadcast network, died today at a London hospital, four days after he underwent coronary bypass surgery, La Scala officials said. He was 62 years old.

title: ADVICE FOR RICHARD: DON'T PITCH IN '81
description: PHOENIX THE comeback of J.R. Richard is progressing. Every other day the Houston Astros' 6-foot-8-inch right-hander throws for maybe 10 minutes. ''And he's been throwing fairly hard,'' reports an Astros official, ''with no restriction.'' He takes batting practice. He participates in the bunting drills. He fields ground balls to redevelop the eye-hand coordination on his left side, which was virtually paralyzed last July 30 by a stroke. Although his doctors will not predict when J.R. Richard will actually be pitching again, when he was asked about that the other day, he had an answer.

title: THE CHOKING WHITE COLLAR
description: THE OPPRESSED MIDDLE Politics of Middle Management. Scenes From Corporate Life. By Earl Shorris. 393 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $13.95. By RICHARD SCHICKEL

title: Denise Fraser Betrothed to James Sweeney 3d, Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Duncan A. Fraser of Garden City and Mattituck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Denise Maureen Fraser, to James F. Sweeney 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sweeney Jr. of East Williston, L.I. A Sept. 12 wedding is planned at St. Joseph Roman Catholic Church in Garden City.

title: Lisa Goldberg, Crichton Ogle Graduate Students, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Goldberg of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Robin Goldberg, to Crichton Laird Ogle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Laird M. Ogle of New York.

title: Providence Wins Title In Hockey
description: The Providence hockey team routed Cornell, 8-4, to capture the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I championship tonight before 10,362 fans at the Boston Garden.

title: 3 ATLANTA MOTHERS VISIT HARLEM GROUP
description: The mothers of three of the 20 children who have been killed in Atlanta over the last 19 months met yesterday with church leaders and city officials to talk about the slayings and what could be done to prevent such a thing from spreading to other cities.
