Gardening;
ROCK WALLS: BEAUTY ENHANCED BY UTILITY
description: THE campus of my alma mater is noted for its quiet beauty, its towering century-old trees, spacious lawns and masses of flowering shrubs, all of which create a serene and relaxed environment conducive to studying. On warm spring days, students, as I remember, used to pop up here and there on the lawns, books spread on the grass before them, like so many spring flowers responding to the warmth of the sun.

title: ARTS GROUPS PONDER FUTURE FUNDING
description: NOT long after President Reagan had announced his intention to cut back funds for the National Endowment for the Arts by about 50 percent, Christopher Bruhl, executive director of the Council for the Arts in Westchester, and his nine-member staff sat in their White Plains office and performed an unpleasant task.

title: Lawyer Will Wed Elizabeth Greason
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Greason of Lincroft, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth McClelland Greason, to John P. Holmes Jr., son of Mrs. Gray Thoron of Ithaca, N.Y., and the late Mr. Holmes.

title: MEDITERRANEAN BLUES
description: The Mediterranean, that sea of poets and tourists, is today the most polluted of the world's major waters. Last week, the latest in a series of United Nations conferences unanimously approved $13 million for preliminary steps to clean the mess up.

title: A PERSISTENT MYTH ABOUT VIETNAM
description: To the Editor:

title: SUMMARY PUNISHMENT
description: The court will now consider the cases of two expressions charged with being so overused, wrongly used or pompously used that they should be added to this page's list of verbal enemies. Opposed as we are to capital punishment, we normally recommend only banishment for such enemies.

title:
Westchester Housing;
THE REWARDS OF RESTORATION
description: SOUTH SALEM THE urge to renovate may not be as basic as the survival instinct. For certain people, however, it can become a consuming passion. Ed Russell, for example, doesn't consciously start out to rescue neglected buildings, but he has come across several whose potential he couldn't resist.

title: STOP TAX CHEATS, HELP THE ECONOMY
description: The Internal Revenue Service has estimated a revenue loss of $35 billion for 1976 and of $50 billion for 1979. Such is the extent of the ''underground economy,'' which pays no income taxes.

title: Reality News; Broadway
description: Capital Market Sources, a subsidiary of Citibank, has leased approximately 35,000 square feet of office space at 39 Broadway for 10 years at an aggregate rent of about $3.8 million.

title:
SOMERSET STABLE FILLS A THERAPEUTIC ROLE;
BRANCHBURG
description: THERE is a place in this Somerset County community where anyone can saddle a horse and ride until sunset through game-filled gullies or fields - even if they've never set feet in stirrups before. Even if they're handicapped.

title: Draft Revival Proposed To Bolster the Reserves
description: A Pentagon advisory board has proposed reviving the draft and giving youths a six-month taste of military life before they are given a choice between longer active or reserve service.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 21 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 2 2 9 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) A fantastic tale about the Sun, the Moon and a lost treasure. 3 3 12 ANSWER AS A MAN, by Taylor Caldwell. (Putnam's, $12.95.) A man who has made it big in early 20th-century America struggles against the corruption that engulfs his life. 4 4 5 BRAIN, by Robin Cook. (Putnam's, $11.95.) A young physician copes with a conspiracy of medical researchers who steal young women's brains to create an artificial intelligence. 5 6 22 COME POUR THE WINE, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $12.95.) A woman's long journey to self-discovery. 6 8 4 CENTURY, by Fred Mustard Stewart. (Morrow, $13.95.) Saga of an Italian-American family. 7 5 25 THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $12.95.) German espionage in Cairo during the desert campaigns of 1942.

title: Children's Books
description: A FABULOUS CREATURE By Zilpha Keatley Snyder. 240 pp. New York: Atheneum. $9.95. (Ages 11 to 15) By PATRICIA LEE GAUCH

title: Liliane E. Pappalardo Married
description: Liliane E. Pappalardo, a stockbroker for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, was married yesterday to Lorin Carl Barker, who is studying for a master's degree in taxation at New York University. The Mormon ceremony was performed in the Temple of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Washington. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest D. Pappalardo of Fresh Meadows, Queens. Mr. Barker is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Barker of Ogden, Utah.

title: PLEASURES OF HANGING
description: CITIES OF THE RED NIGHT By William S. Burroughs. 332 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $14.95. By THOMAS M. DISCH

title: A SEND-UP OF SOVIET RUSSIA
description: THE RADIANT FUTURE By Alexander Zinoviev. Translated by Gordon Clough. 287 pp. New York: Random House. $13.95.

title: CARTER IS AN UNEASY RIDER AT ATLANTA POLITICAL EVENT
description: Former President Jimmy Carter emerged from political seclusion here last night, but only barely. Attending his first political event since Election Day last November, Mr. Carter smiled and waved, but did not speak at the Georgia Democratic Party's Jefferson-Jackson Day fund-raising dinner.

title: Nina Francomano, Teacher, Is Married
description: Nina Angelo Francomano, who teaches first grade at the Princeton (N.J.) Day School, was married in Princeton yesterday to Henry Gardner Rulon-Miller, assistant head of Princeton Day's Middle School. The Rev. Carl Reimers, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's brother, Patrick Rulon-Miller.

title: Miss Roberts To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard H. Roberts of Rosemont, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Averel Wistar Roberts, to John Dudley Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald O. Wilson of Downers Grove, Ill.

title: ON THE EXECUTION OF STEVEN JUDY
description: To the Editor:

title: HEADY ON STARS AND HOMESPUN SCIENCE
description: Science has become so expensive and complex that it is now almost the exclusive domain of professional teams employed by big institutions subsidized by Government grants. The place of the gifted amateur in the mainstream of science has dwindled to the vanishing point, while many professional societies warn of a growing alienation between scientists and the nonprofessional public.

title: STEAMBOATING AT 10 M.P.H., WITH CALLIOPE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JERRY KLEIN is on the staff of The Peoria Journal Star. By JERRY KLEIN

title: W. P. Prowell, Jane G. Olberg To Wed in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. F. Forbes Olberg of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jane Glynn Olberg, to William Parsons Prowell, son of Mrs. Richard P. Prowell of New York, and the late Mr. Prowell. A July wedding is planned.

title: Long Island Journal
description: FOOD power, and the importance of good nutrition despite a tight budget, will be the subject of a workshop open to the public at Molloy College in Rockville Centre next Saturday.

title: STATE'S IRISH STEALING A MARCH
description: JERSEY CITY SELDOM is New Jersey able to steal a march on New York City, but that's what is happening today as six St. Patrick's Day parades step off as a tuneup for the big Fifth Avenue event on Tuesday.

title: Critics' Choice
description: Each week several Times critics will offer tips on attractions around town.

title: THATCHER'S BUDGET: 'THE TUNNEL AT THE END OF THE TUNNEL'
description: Britons last week had to pay more for gin to go with the bitters in the Conservative Government's new austerity budget. Sir Geoffrey Howe, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced steep increases in taxes on alcohol (a bottle of Scotch now costs nearly $3.50 more in London than it does after crossing the Atlantic to New York), cigarettes and gasoline as well as measures that will raise income taxes for most people and add thousands of low-income families to the rolls.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: KINETICS ARE THEME OF EXHIBIT IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON MANY paintings are smug despots. They rule their space tyranically, expecting the viewer to subject himself almost submissively to their artistic dictates.

title: ROBIN KRASSNER ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Robin Beth Krassner, daughter of Lois Neustein Krassner of Roslyn Heights, L.I., and Marshall M. Krassner of New York, to Gary Stuart Beckerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Beckerman of East Meadow, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's mother. The wedding is planned for June 28.

title: REPRESSION, REFORM KEEP MANY SALVADORANS OFF THE BARRICADES
description: SAN SALVADOR MAO Zedong said guerrillas should be like fish swimming in the sea, relying on the local populace for support. In El Salvador, the guerrillas more and more appear to be swimming in a lake. The consensus among supporters of both the military-civilian Government and the guerrillas is that the guerrillas do not enjoy the popular support they were thought to possess before their ''final offensive'' failed in January. The guerrillas had predicted a general uprising that never materialized, though it would be unfair to use that alone as an indication of their popular strength. Fighting and dying are the ultimate step that a people can take. But clearly the repetition of the Nicaraguan experience feared by the Reagan Administration, hordes of people taking to the streets, is not happening in El Salvador.

title: Architecture View; LE CORBUSIER'S HOUSING PROJECT- FLEXIBLE ENOUGH TO ENDURE; by Ada Louise Huxtable
description: I have been to Pessac to see the future and contrary to popular belief and the conventional wisdom, it works. Pessac is the town near Bordeaux, in France, where Le Corbusier designed and built a community of 51 houses in the 1920's under the sponsorship of the French industrialist, Henry Fruges, who meant them to be a laboratory of new domestic, structural and esthetic ideas.

title: Business Conditions; NONPROFIT THEATERS
description: In spite of rising costs and shrinking disposable incomes among playgoers, the performance of nonprofit theaters across the country exceeded expectations last year. The Theater Communications Group said 147 of these professionally managed but tax-exempt theaters had total revenues of $113.6 million, and an aggregate deficit of only $31,000 in 1980, a showing that David Visser, director of management services for the group, thinks was ''better than anyone dared hope.''

title: UPDATE ON CO-OPS: RIVERDALE IN TIDE OF CONVERSIONS
description: Five more cooperative conversion plans appeared in Riverdale in the last few weeks, causing no surprise among apartment-house tenants. The plans, with the red lettering that has made them known as ''red herrings,'' have become a familiar sight in the sedate northwest corner of the Bronx.

title: CHURCHMEN SEEK A METHOD OF REVIVING SOCIAL CONCERN IN THE CITIES
description: ''Liberation theology'' could revive Christian social concern in the cities, according to several speakers at a conference on ''The Church and the City'' at Riverside Church.

title: PENTAGON IS RICH BUT MONEY ISN'T EVERYTHING
description: When Caspar W. Weinberger was named Secretary of Defense, his marching orders were to ''rearm America.'' For the past two weeks or so, Mr. Weinberger has been telling the Congress and the public how the Pentagon intends to carry out those orders with a $32.6 billion addition to the military budget this year and next.

title: NEWSCASTS AND 'SOAPS' MARCH TO HIS TUNES
description: One of the most familiar pieces of music on television is the ABC News theme, a punchy, martial tune that lasts exactly one minute and two seconds. Variations on this incisive ditty are used by the network for most of its news-oriented programming. For ''ABC's World News Tonight,'' it was recorded with a symphony orchestra to suggest the grand surge of events. For the network's coverage of the 1980 elections, it was arranged for a fife-and-drum corps to evoke patriotism.

title: FLEXIBLE FAILS A TEST, CASTING DOUBT ON APRIL RETURN
description: The Grumman Corporation's first attempt to correct the faulty Aframe of its Flxible buses has failed, raising doubts about the promised return in mid-April of the first of New York City's 637-bus fleet.

title: Miss Durst Fiancee Of William Meyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerry R. Durst of West Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Denise Suzanne Durst, to William A. Meyer of Ocean Ridge, Fla., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur I. Meyer of Harrison, N.Y., and Palm Beach.

title: Food; STIRRING THE POTS IN GREAT NECK
description: GREAT NECK FOR the first time in several years, Great Neck has a serious cookware shop. It is called Kitchen Privileges and was installed in September at 5 Bond Street, half a block from the railroad station.

title: LARGER THAN LIFE
description: MARIA CALLAS The Woman Behind the Legend. By Arianna Stassinopoulos. Illustrated. 383 pp. New York; Simon and Schuster. $15.95. By JOAN PEYSER

title: A NOVEL OF NEUROSIS AND HISTORY
description: THE WHITE HOTEL By D.M. Thomas. 274 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $12.95.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
A DOUBLE TAKE ON NURSING HOMES
description: Worried about paying too much for too little, Connecticut hired an accounting firm five years ago to audit the state's nursing homes and help officials determine how much in Medicaid they should receive. Last week, an audit of the audits indicated that there still was plenty to worry about.

title: MUSIC THAT TRAVELS WELL
description: An academic friend of mine, who gets three months off in summer, is already planning his vacation. He is going to pick up a brand-new car in Munich and then break it in all across western Europe. As if that in itself weren't sufficiently enticing, he also has - quite literally - orchestrated his trip in a unique way. He hit on the idea of matching the music on the car's tape player to the landscape traversed: Johann Strauss for the Vienna Woods, Wagner for the Rhine, ''The Fountains of Rome'' for Rome, and so on. According to plan, Albeniz will enliven his Iberian journeys and Delius's ''North Country Sketches'' will go with him to the North Country.

title: FREEZING THE BLOOD AND MAKING ONE LAUGH
description: THE COMPLETE POEMS OF MARIANNE MOORE 305 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company/The Viking Press. $16.95.

title: ON THE EXECUTION OF STEVEN JUDY
description: Your editorial on Steven Judy was the clearest defense of life I have ever seen in print. I wonder how many executions we would have if juries were required to participate in the actual killing? How many "eye-for-an-eye" proponents would be capable of dropping the cyanide pellet or pulling the switch? How many capital-punishment groupies are prepared to watch a man die under their own hands? Or could it be that the act, under official sanction and at a safe remove, satisfies a primitive blood lust while insulating them from the reality?

title: PURCHASE RIGHTS BOUGHTS AND SOLD
description: Ellen Wynn was worried. The building on Manhattan's East Side where she rented an apartment was going through cooperative conversion. Miss Wynn did not have the money nor did she know anyone who could lend her the money to purchase the studio apartment at the insider's price of $45,000. Under the co-op conversion plan, she would be evicted when her lease expired and show no financial profit from letting the apartment revert to her landlord.

title: ECOLOGY DOLLARS GET CONSERVED
description: Given the depth and range of painful incisions, it may not have been the unkindest cut of all; still, the reductions proposed for a variety of environmental programs in President Reagan's budget announcement last week were substantial enough to provoke immediate alarm in conservationist quarters.

title: BIKINIANS SUING U.S. FOR $450 MILLION OVER A-TESTS
description: The displaced people of Bikini, the Pacific atoll used for nuclear tests after World War II, plan to sue the United States for injuries to themselves, damages to their islands and what they say is the failure of the American Government to fulfill its obligations as trustee for the Bikinians under the United Nations.

title: 19 DIE IN FIRE AT CHICAGO RESIDENTIAL HOTEL
description: Nineteen persons died here early this morning as fire swept through a four-story residential hotel in the Edgewater district on the city's North Side.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Washington is no longer standing in the way of this project. Westway has the green light, and it's up to New York to drive through.'' - President Reagan. (1:1.)

title: STAGE: LEVIN THRILLER AT PROVINCETOWN
description: Ira Levin has a talent for thrillers, and his thrillers grab the public, as ''Death Trap,'' ''Rosemary's Baby'' and ''The Boys From Brazil'' indicate. While ''Death Trap'' continues, seemingly inexhaustibly on Broadway, Mr. Levin's ''Veronica's Room'' has moved into the Provincetown Playhouse on Macdougal Street - where it flies very nicely indeed - until it comes in for a landing at the very end.

title: U.S. CHALLENGES VISIT BY TOP MILITARY MEN FROM SOUTH AFRICA
description: Five senior South African military officers arrived in Washington this week using visas that Reagan Administration officials said they had obtained without having identified themselves as military men. They were to depart tonight after the State Department raised questions about their status.

title: Critics' Choice
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC The Czech Philharmonic, which will appear at Carnegie Hall Wednesday and Thursday and at Lehmann College in the Bronx Saturday as part of its first American tour since 1967, cannot be classed with the American Big Five. But it remains a worthy ensemble, to judge from its recordings.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
WHY PRO SPORTS ARE OPPOSED TO LEGALIZED GAMBLING
description: AS the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, I am deeply opposed to any legislation that would legalize betting on professional team sports.

title:
MAILBOX;
Women's Race Walking Deserves Prime Time
description: To the Sports Editor: I am writing both as a race walker and as a track fan to protest the policy of The Athletics Congress in holding the women's race walk finals during the sparsely attended afternoon trials of the USA/Mobil indoor track championships, instead of during the evening program, when the vast majority of the public is present.

title: Ann Bolton Rogers Is Married
description: The marriage of Ann Bolton Rogers, a vice president of Bonwit Teller, to John Edward Grimm 3d, vice president of the Colgate Palmolive Company, took place yesterday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Bruce Forbes performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay S. Rogers of Clinton, Conn. Mr. Grimm is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Grimm Jr. of New York.

title: No Headline
description: Every time I read an article like ''Thunder From the Right'' and see political figures like Jesse Helms described as ''ultraconservatives'' and depicted as ''extre@mists,'' I have to wonder why politicians like Senator Edward M. Kennedy, George McGovern, et al., are not similarly described as ''ultraliberals'' and ''extre@mists.''

title: CONRAIL MAKES PLANS TO COPE WITH 'CRISIS'
description: PLANS for dealing with disruptions to Conrail passenger service resulting from power shortages on its New Haven line are being developed by state and railroad officials.

title: Reading and Writing; IDENTITY PROBLEM
description: In ''The Left-Handed Woman,'' by Peter Handke, the woman of the title complains that she has ''to turn corners to go from one room to another: always at right angles and always to the left.'' In ''The Twyborn Affair,'' by Australia's Nobel laureate Patrick White, the hero is an androgynous young man who lives on the French Riviera as the putative wife of an elderly Greek. From there, he goes home to Australia to work as a ranch laborer, then returns to Europe to become the madam of London's most fashionable bordello.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: or whomever else she is attempting to whip into shape.

title: INSTITUTE SEEKS TO IMPROVE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR AGED
description: An effort to improve the quality of life for elderly people will be undertaken by the Mount Sinal Medical Center through a new Institute of Gerontology made possible by two gifts totaling $4 million.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
HOSPITALS JOB STILL A HEALTH DANGER
description: Exactly five months after he took the job and, in the view of many, three months after he actually lost it, Dr. Abraham J. Kauvar was forced out as president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation last week. Mayor Koch, who announced Dr. Kauvar's resignation, was immediately ready with a replacement - Stanley Brezenoff, the city's Commissioner of Human Resources and a member of the hospitals corporation board, who was formally elected later in the week.

title: YALE DIVINITY OFFERS BALLET ABOUT DYING
description: IN conjunction with their annual symposium on religion and the arts, the Yale Divinity School has commissioned a new ballet from the Connecticut Ballet entitled ''Faces at the Exit,'' choreographed by the company's associate director, Robin Welch. The work will premiere at the Yale University Theater, 222 York Street between Chapel and Elm, on March 19 and run through March 21 in the Connecticut Ballet's spring season.

title: CHARGE OF MEDICAID FUND ABUSES STUDIED BY ASSEMBLY LABOR UNIT
description: The New York State Assembly's Labor Committee is investigating what unions allege is the improper use of Medicaid and Medicare funds in antiunion activities at hospitals and nursing homes.

title: Richard Petrucci Jr. Is Fiance Of Elizabeth Irene O'Gorman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. O'Gorman Jr. of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Irene O'Gorman, to Richard E. Petrucci Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Petrucci, also of White Plains.

title: Frank Kittridge Jr. to Wed Cynthia Briggs
description: Mr. and Mrs. Taylor R. Briggs of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Jane Briggs, to Frank Dutton Kittridge Jr., son of Barbara Bradshaw Kittridge of Marblehead, Mass., and Frank D. Kittridge of Miami.

title: Julia Gore Talbott, a group-planning supervisor with Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, and Michael Ronald Katz, manager of the convertible bond department at Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., plan to be married in Bardstown, Ky., on May 23.  Mrs. John Cotton Talbott of Bardstown has announced her daughter's engagement to the son of Mrs. William W. Katz of Magnolia, Mass., and the late Mr. Katz.
description: Miss Talbott, daughter also of the late Mr. Talbott, was graduated from the University of Kentucky. Her father was attorney for Nelson County, Ky. Mr. Katz, an alumnus of the Deerfield Academy and Franklin and Marshall College, received an M.B.A. degree from Babson College.

title: Pope Sees 600 From Venice Area After a Weeklong Lenten Retreat
description: Pope John Paul II today ended a work-free, weeklong retreat for Lent and met at the Vatican with a group of 600 Roman Catholics from around Venice.

title: Canadiens 2, Rockies 1
description: Guy Lafleur broke a 1-1 tie with his 26th goal of the season at 6:10 of the third period and Montreal extended its undefeated home streak to 22 games.

title: Banker Fiance Of Miss Poor; Bridal May 2
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Barton Poor of Garden City and East Hampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Lisbeth Rome Poor, to Joseph H. Cromarty 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cromarty Jr. of Waterville, Me.

title: CASH-POOR KENYA MAY RETURN TO BIG GAME HUNTING
description: Big game hunting was banned in Kenya in 1977, to the applause of conservationists worldwide. Now it is widely speculated here that the international sportsmen are going to be invited back, and though the Government will not comment officially, even some local conservationists say lifting the ban is all right with them.

title: FOR A REGIONAL APPROACH TO HOSPITAL CARE
description: RECENTLY, public debate has resurfaced regarding the emergency of a university medical center within Westchester County. A fundamental issue has been raised, that of regionalization of medical care and whether it benefits the total community.

title: B.Y.U. GAINS IN EAST, AS DOES NOTRE DAME
description: Brigham Young helped carry on the upset trend of the 43d annual National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament today as Danny Ainge scored 37 points to lead the Cougars to a 78-55 rout of U.C.L.A, which was seeded No. 3 in the East regional.

title: PROPP'S GOAL TIES ISLANDERS, 3-3
description: Don't talk to the Islanders about long airplane rides. After playing the Philadelphia Flyers to a 3-3 tie tonight at Nassau Coliseum, the Islanders blamed it on fatigue caused by consecutive games in Winnipeg and Edmonton, a 6 A.M. wakeup call and a 2,500-mile flight that landed them in the middle of New York's rush hour.

title: A Correction
description: In an article in the New Jersey Weekly last Sunday, it was reported erroneously that Greg Roukema, the son of Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of Ridgewood, had died of leukemia at the age of 20. Greg Roukema is living; it was his brother, Todd, who died of the disease at the age of 17.

title: Linda Stern Has Nuptials
description: Linda Karen Stern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stern of New York, was married yesterday to Duncan Duer Irving, son of Michael Irving of Rowayton, Conn., and Flora M. Irving of New York. Civil Court Judge John A.K. Bradley performed the ceremony at the Stern home.

title: TWILIGHT OF THE OPERA SUPERSTAR
description: Can we possibly be living in an age of operatic superstars? A casual observer might think so if he happened to be in New York City this week. Joan Sutherland, Marilyn Horne and Luciano Pavarotti hold forth in Avery Fisher Hall on Friday afternoon, a concert to be repeated on March 23; Montserrat Caballe and Jose Carreras join voices in a recital of arias and duets at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday night; the Met unveils a new production of ''La Traviata'' on Tuesday starring Ileana Cotrubas, Placido Domingo and Cornell MacNeil, while on the same evening Katia Ricciarelli and Agnes Baltsa appear in Carnegie Hall with the Opera Orchestra in a concert performance of Mercadante's ''Il Giuramento.'' With such a plethora of starry names on the horizon, a new millenium of operatic glamour suddenly seems to have burst upon us.

title: J.G. Mead Fiance Of Cornelia Dana
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Dana of New York and Washington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cornelia Marshall Dana, to James Gerald Mead, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald N. Mead of Owego, N.Y.

title: 'THE FIVE TOWNS' STIRS FIVE TOWNS
description: WOODMERE ''THE FIVE TOWNS,'' a new novel that takes a quasi-affectionate look at the people and life in that South Shore area after World War II, is stirring interest and debate in, predictably, the Five Towns.

title: RACING AIDE SAYS YALE SCRATCHED COURSE
description: NEW HAVEN AS the general manager of the Teletrack Theater here, William Drew says he has noticed that the majority of the clientele at the nation's only off-track betting theater are over the age of 30, and that many of them are at least twice that age. At times, that has prompted him to wonder whether members of the younger generation would eventually become customers at the facility, where bettors can make wagers on thoroughbred and harness races televised from New York tracks.

title: Argentine Leader Flying to U.S. For Talks With Reagan and Haig
description: President-designate Roberto Viola left Buenos Aires tonight for a three-day visit to the United States, hoping to establish what an aide called ''a personal relationship'' with President Reagan.

title: On Language; TAKING IT NEAT; by William Safire
description: Taking It Neat Kimble Mead

title: STATES DISPUTE AID FOR RETARDED
description: AS a result of bureaucratic confusion over jurisdiction involving almost a dozen agencies in two states and the Federal Government, 28 retarded children in a Norfolk home for the handicapped are not receiving the kind of comprehensive therapy and education that is required by Federal law.

title: U.S. Intends to Purchase Cobalt To Add to Stockpile of Materials
description: The Government yesterday announced plans to purchase 1.2 million pounds of cobalt in what would be the first addition in 20 years to the national stockpile of strategic raw materials.

title: OIL DRILLERS OFF CANADA BATTLE NATURE AND POLITICS
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland - A fuzzy dawn is breaking in the foggiest part of the North Atlantic, where four men cling to a basket dangling 160 feet above a choppy, cobalt-blue sea. By stomach-churning tugs, they are being hoisted to their jobs on the world's largest drilling rig, the 15,000-ton Ocean Ranger.

title: Paradoxes
description: To the Business Editor: ''Antitrust: Big Business Breathes Easier'' (Feb. 15) contains a barrage of eloquent criticisms of antitrust under the sub-heading ''New attitudes and the realities of world markets have cooled efforts to break up giants like A.T.& T.''

title: Jersey Inmate Stabbed to Death
description: An inmate serving a life sentence for murder was stabbed to death today while standing in line for his lunch at the Trenton State Prison. The victim, Archie Murphy, 32 years old, of East Orange, was stabbed several times in the back at 11:53 A.M.

title: 92 IN NASSAU'S OVERCROWDED JAIL ARE FLOWN TO INSTITUTION UPSTATE
description: Ninety-two prisoners were quietly taken from the Nassau County jail early this morning and flown in two chartered planes to Buffalo for transfer to the Erie County jail to reduce overcrowding in Nassau.

title: THE EDGE OF PIERCE
description: ''People put psychics down here, because they're on every streetcorner,'' said Beverly Dean. At least one, however -Miss Dean - was not on a Los Angeles streetcorner, but for two years was on the payroll of ABC-TV, advising its president, Fred Pierce, on scripts and series. Miss Dean said that, though she met Mr. Pierce while working as a psychic, she does not consider herself one, but simply someone with ''very good instincts.''

title: JERUSALEM'S SABBATH FEUD IS GROWING
description: In what has become almost a ritual, every Saturday afternoon hundreds of ultra-Orthodox Jews, wearing the traditional sidecurls and long black coats, walk down to Jerusalem's Ramot Road and throw stones at cars.

title: JONES BEACH WINTER: CROWDS AND REPAIRS
description: JONES BEACH was a barren, deserted sand spit when Robert Moses discovered it in the winter of 1921. It is anything but deserted on weekends in the winter of 1981.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
A Plan for Curbing A 'Needless Misery'
description: MOST New Jerseyans are all too sadly familiar with nursing-home horror stories. For example, the poor woman in Bergen County who, although quite ill herself, had to care for her paralyzed father because she could not afford to pay private rates for his care at a nursing home.

title: WILL THE SHOW GO ON FOR PAF?
description: THIS space was reserved for a review of ''Day Six,'' by Martin Halpern, starring John Cullum and Emily Frankel - the fifth and penultimate production of the PAF Playhouse season. But you won't be reading it and the theater's 8,400 subscribers and projected 1,500 single-ticket buyers won't be seeing the play, or an original musical, ''The Raft,'' that was supposed to follow it.

title: 'TEST TUBE' SEX
description: This country's first clinic for the fertilization of human reproductive cells outside the womb opened in Norfolk, Va., on March 1, 1980, and a month later it reported no success with its first patient to undergo the procedure.

title: Haig Identifies the Critic Of El Salvador Coverage
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. disclosed last night that the official who complained that reporters were overplaying their accounts of El Salvador developments was John A. Bushnell, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs.

title: Palm Sunday: An Autobiographical Collage
description: ''I DELIVERED a speech at the University of Virginia maybe eight years ago, which mercifully has been lost, so I do not have to paste it in here somewhere,'' says Kurt Vonnegut, in the middle of this odd miscellany of prefaces, introductions, letters, talks, reflections and what might generally be described as bathtub singing. An address that he does include, delivered in 1978 at Fredonia College, seems worth preserving, but, on the other hand, his commencement chat at Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N.Y., four years earlier was not. His funeral eulogy for a friend named Lavina Lyon is embarrassing to read, but he gave an effective lecture at a motel in Morristown to the Mental Health Association of New Jersey, in which S.S. Lieut. Dampfwalze of Auschwitz recognizes ''nature's little danger signals early'' and puts himself into the hands of modern medicine, whereupon his eyes start shining again and his appetite comes back.

title: Dr. Machac To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Miloslav Frank Machac of Bohemia, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Miloslava Ann Machac, to Dr. J. Michael Mervart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jaroslav Mervart of Toronto.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
WEAVER: BALTIMORE WILL BE IN IT
description: POMPANO BEACH, FLA. EARL WEAVER sat bareheaded in the sun beside the visitors' dugout waiting for his Baltimore Orioles to open their exhibition season against the Texas Rangers. Either the sun has bleached his hair or there is more gray in the thatch than ever before, but the round face is still that of a mischievous boy.

title: DR. BLUM CAPTURES HANDICAP EASILY
description: Dr. Blum scared off most of the potential opposition from the Toboggan Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, and he decisively defeated the horses who ran. Romping to a 2 1/2-length triumph in the $53,900 stakes, Dr. Blum won his third straight added-money race.

title: POLO MAKES A GALLOPING COMEBACK
description: D.C. Denison is a staff writer for The Boston Phoenix. By D.C. Denison en minutes before game time, Tommy Wayman trots his polo pony out onto the main field at the Royal Palm Polo Club in Boca Raton, Fla. The field - wide, long, flat and green - is deserted; most of the crowd, and many of the players, are still watching a late-finishing game on the other side of the steel bleachers. A world-class polo player, Wayman has a reputation for riding aggressively, but now he's interested only in testing his horse's responsiveness, wheeling in tight circles or sprinting down the sidelines. Occasionally, he charges the length of the field to pull up short just before the end line, checking his steed's ability to brake hard and fast. When play starts, he will be less restrained. An explosive player who can crack the hard plastic polo ball 120 yards with one swing and likes to be first on the spot when it lands, Wayman drives his horses so hard it seems cruel to the uninitiated observer.

title: FINISHING TOUCHES, AND RETOUCHES, FOR THE REAGAN BUDGET
description: Since Election Day, Ronald Reagan's budget and management master, David A. Stockman, and his many apprentices have been working out the sketches and priming the canvas. Last month, Mr. Reagan's message to Congress blocked in the outlines. Last week, the new Administration's formal request for revisions to the 1982 Federal budget painted in the numbers - with a tint projected by some political and economic realities.

title: Tracy Caulkins to Florida
description: Tracy Caulkins, one of the best all-around women swimmers in the world, will attend the University of Florida. She won the 1978 Sullivan Award as the top amateur athlete in the United States.

title: 36 FOOD PLACES LISTED AS VIOLATORS
description: The New York City Health Department named 36 food establishments found in violation of the city's health code. In addition, the report cited six restaurants that had reopened after correction of violations, four that were closed and one - the Silver Slipper, 946 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn - that went out of business.

title: Anne Salmson Engaged To David Wilson Altchek
description: Jean-Francois Salmson of Jouy-en-Josas, France, and Mrs. Alain Danet of Paris have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Anne Laure Salmson, to David Wilson Altchek, son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Altchek of Middletown, N.Y.

title: STUDY OPPOSES A HOME ON THE RANGE FOR THE MX MISSILE
description: Red menace or no, many residents of the West rank the Pentagon's scheme for protecting MX missiles by hauling them from burrow to burrow, all over their still somewhat unspoiled countryside, right up there with the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit.

title: RICH HISTORY, FEW COMFORTS ON TURDEY'S TURQUOISE COAST
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- MARVINE HOWE is chief of the Ankara bureau of The New York Times. By MARVINE HOWE

title: The Swiss 'Discontented'
description: Paul Hofmann's article ''The Swiss Malaise'' (Feb. 8) made me reflect on a recent incident in my office. A teenager, a high-school dropout, had come to get a medical excuse from his work.

title: ON THE EXECUTION OF STEVEN JUDY
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET, ITS OIL DECLINING, LOOKS TO LIQUID FUEL FROM COAL
description: The Soviet Union, apparently concerned about a slowdown in the growth of domestic oil production, has announced a synthetic fuels strategy similar to one being advocated in the United States.

title: Other Business; HEADACHES
description: Sandoz Pharmaceuticals, a company that specializes in developing prescription drugs for headaches, conducted a survey recently to determine whether workers in some jobs get headaches more often than those in others.

title: THE SCARCITY OF TOMORROW'S WATER
description: WILL people have to line up for drinking water the way they lined up for gasoline? The answer is, ''quite possibly,'' even in usually water-rich Connecticut.

title:
MAILBOX;
Happy Chandler's Stand On Integration Supported
description: To the Sports Editor: I have been following the debate between John B. Holway (''A Vote for Happy Chandler, an Ignored Pioneer,'' The New York Times, March 1) and Harry Simmons (Mailbox, March 8) with much interest, since my biography of Branch Rickey will be published next year by Atheneum.

title:
Stock Analyst;
THE PROMOTER WHO'S BULLISH ON BACHE
description: WALL STREET has always cherished its eccentrics and been leery of them at the same time: It is hard to tell, after all, what an off-beat individualist with a lot of hustle might be up to. Take an outspoken, Budapest-born securities analyst and stock promoter named Andrew G. Racz.

title: A Two-Week Journey of Fear
description: What started March 2 as a Pakistani domestic flight from Karachi to Peshawar became a terrifying journey into the twilight zone of political terrorism. It finally ended last night on the tarmac in Damascus, Syria.

title: Exemplary Concreteness
description: To the Editor:

title: COSMOS EXPERIMENTING ON PRESEASON TOUR
description: The championship of the North American Soccer League has always been the first goal of the Cosmos, but they have also emphasized winning on their preseason and postseason tours.

title: A KILLER GETS HIS DEATH WISH
description: At his trial, Steven T. Judy described in detail how, in April 1979, he had raped and strangled a young woman and then drowned her three children. Mr. Judy told the jury that he should be sentenced to death, and he got his way. Last week, sedated with tranquilizers but denied the beer he wanted, Mr. Judy was executed in Old Betsy, the state of Indiana's electric chair.

title: COUNTY UNCERTAIN OF REAGAN BUDGET'S IMPACT
description: DESPITE a briefing by President Reagan in Washington last week, which was attended by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, Westchester officials remain unsure about what impact the President's budget proposals will have locally.

title: DEFYING THE VICAR
description: His self assurance ''is matched only by his iron will.'' He is forceful, swift, brilliant, determined, careful, consistent. When his future wife first saw him, she said ''he's like a Greek god.''

title: LEGISLATORS' DISPUTE DELAYS ELECTION OF 2 TO REGENTS BOARD
description: A dispute within the often fractious Manhattan delegation to the Legislature forced legislative leaders this week to postpone the election of two new members to the state's Board of Regents.

title: THIS TIME, IT'S COFFEE THAT GIVES CAUSE FOR CONCERN
description: Along with their morning juice and toast, some 106 million coffeedrinking Americans got unwelcome news last week. While investigating possible links between cigarette smoking and cancer of the pancreas, researchers at Harvard University's School of Public Health found a statistical link between pancreatic cancer and coffee. The culprit does not seem to be caffeine.

title: Palm Sunday: An Autobiographical Collage
description: ''I DELIVERED a speech at the University of Virginia maybe eight years ago, which mercifully has been lost, so I do not have to paste it in here somewhere,'' says Kurt Vonnegut, in the middle of this odd miscellany of prefaces, introductions, letters, talks, reflections and what might generally be described as bathtub singing. An address that he does include, delivered in 1978 at Fredonia College, seems worth preserving, but, on the other hand, his commencement chat at Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N.Y., four years earlier was not. His funeral eulogy for a friend named Lavina Lyon is embarrassing to read, but he gave an effective lecture at a motel in Morristown to the Mental Health Association of New Jersey, in which S.S. Lieut. Dampfwalze of Auschwitz recognizes ''nature's little danger signals early'' and puts himself into the hands of modern medicine, whereupon his eyes start shining again and his appetite comes back.

title: Crime; by Newgate Callendar
description: Even for Ross Thomas, THE MORDIDA MAN (Simon and Schuster, $13.95) is a tour de force. Ever since his first novel, ''The Cold War Swap,'' was published in 1966, Mr. Thomas has consistently proved to be one of the best American storytellers. He handles intricate plots with the ease of a master, he has a smooth and sophisticated prose style, his ear for dialogue is admirable, his characters ring true even when they are idealized. In ''The Mordida Man'' he has brought all his talents together in a wild melange.

title: STUMBLING BLOCKS FOR THE GIFTED CHILD
description: The article by Rita Watson "Programs for Talented Students Gain Praise Amid Criticism," Feb. 22 touched on the heart of a problem I have been dealing with as a parent of a gifted sixth-grade middle-school student. It conveyed an accurate sense of both the gratitude for the existence of some gifted programming but frustration with the way it is both superimposed on and fragmented within the curriculum.

title: Narcissa Vanderlip Is Wed to Parmer Fuller
description: At the Swedenborgian Church in New York yesterday, Narcissa Cox Vanderlip, an associate film producer and writer, was married to Parmer Fuller, a composer and conductor. The Rev. Clayton Priestnal performed the ceremony.

title: ST. JOSEPH'S STUNS DEMONS, 49-48
description: Mark Aguirre did not weep this year, at least not when the crowds were watching. For the second consecutive year, his top-ranked, once-beaten De Paul team lost in its first game of the National Collegiate basketball tournament.

title: ANTI-SEMITISM WITHOUT JEWS? A POLISH RIDDLE
description: At first there were only a few isolated incidents. A Star of David was scribbled on a Solidarity poster. A crude poem was scrawled on a wall in northern Warsaw; it said Lech Walesa, the Solidarity union leader and a devout Roman Catholic, was Jewish.

title: Robin E. Walker, Nurse, Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Robin Eleanor Walker to Reuben Jeffery 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffery Jr. of Wilmington, Del, formerly of Darien, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Willard Walker Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

title: STRIKE MORATORIUM DOESN'T LAST LONG
description: After meeting with the Polish Prime Minister, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, for four hours last week, Lech Walesa, the labor leader, said glumly, ''We did some things; we didn't do other things, and that's all.''

title: LEGAL AID FOR THE POOR DID WORK, AND THAT'S THE RUB
description: The Administration's proposal to wipe out the $321 million Federal program that pays the salaries of most of the nation's 6,000 legal aid lawyers was submitted to Congress last week as a budget-cutting measure. The proposal, which would take the Government out of the business of providing poor people with free lawyers in noncriminal cases, marked a renewal of an old feud between President Reagan and legal aid lawyers.

title: BALLET: OHIOANS PRESENT HEINZ POLL'S 'PAVANNE'
description: The Ohio Ballet mixed the familiar with the unfamiliar in several ways at its Friday night performance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: PRAISES LEVEL OF CARE AT COUNTY HOSPITALS
description: A recent article concerning the Westchester County Medical Center contained some remarks by Roy Ashikari, M.D., that implied that Westchester community hospitals do not provide their patients with the latest methods in cancer diagnosis and treatment. The implication was unfortunate. The Westchester Division of the American Cancer Society is extremely concerned that in his attmept to paint a glowing picture of the Westchester County Medical Center, Dr. Ashikari may have created false image of the quality of cancer care in Westchester's community hospitals.

title: AMERICAN RELEASED IN SYRIA IS SOUGHT IN DRUG CASE
description: One of the three Americans freed yesterday from a hijacked Pakistani jetliner in Syria with more than 100 other hostages has been identified as a 24-year-old Californian who has been sought by United States authorities since Feb. 20 as the alleged leader of a heroin-smuggling ring.

title:
ANTIQUES;
Springtime Is Show Time
description: PRINCETON THE first weekend of spring is approaching, and with it three antiques shows appealing to a variety of interests. From Thursday through Saturday, the 22d annual Princeton Antiques Show will take place at the Princeton Day School on Great Road. The show is sponsored by the Wellesley Club of Central New Jersey.

title: RELOCATION OF APPALACHIAN TRAIL IN CONNECTICUT HALTED BY PROPOSALS TO CUT US BUDGET
description: A proposed relocation of the Appalachian Trail in the rolling hills of northwestern Connecticut has been halted by impending Federal budget cuts, leaving some local landowners angry and frustrated.

title: LIBRARY CHIEF TO HEAD WOODROW WILSON FUND
description: Richard W. Couper, president of the New York Public Library since 1971, has been named president of the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation, Dr. Frederick Seitz, the foundation's board chairman, announced yesterday.

title: 'DON'T BOTHER MOTHER - SHE'S WRITING
description: WHEN she was 7 years old, growing up in the St. Albans section of Queens, Patricia Reilly Giff read her first book - ''The Bobbsey Twins at the Seashore'' - and decided she wanted to be a writer.

title: Travelers Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SYDNEY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- COLIN CHAPMAN contributes to The New York Times from Sydney. By COLIN CHAPMAN

title: RANGERS END SLIDE BY BEATING HARTFORD, 6-2
description: Earlier in the day at the Rangers' morning skate in Rye, N.Y., Carol Vadnais said, ''There's nothing wrong with us that a couple of wins won't cure.'' Then Vadnais added, ''One thing I know, we've got to win this game.''

title: STOCKMAN CALLS CRITICISMS OF ECONOMISTS 'CYNICAL'
description: David A. Stockman, the Federal budget director, today described as ''cynical and destructive'' the contention by three economists this week that the economic forecast advanced by the Reagan Administration was too optimistic.

title: Singular Pampa
description: To the Editor:

title: Carol A. Fucillo Engaged To Mark S. Sunderland
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Fucillo of Halesite, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Ann Fucillo, to Mark Scrivener Sunderland, son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Sunderland of Asharoken, L.I.

title: Jacqueline Russell Is Betrothed
description: Edwin F. Russell of Brookville, L.I., and Lady Sarah Spencer-Churchill of Beverly Hills, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Dorothy Russell, to Eugene F. Williams 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams Jr. of St. Louis and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Sheila M. Kennedy Wed To Richard A. Holtzman
description: St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Binghamton, N.Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Sheila Marie Kennedy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Francis Kennedy of Binghamton, to Richard Akin Holtzman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Edward Holtzman of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Raymond J. Balduf of Jersey City officiated.

title: NO OPTION IN WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Television in The Courtroom
description: In ''Television's Day in Court'' (Feb. 15), Martin Bass successfully presented the viewpoints of lawyers, judges, jurors and witnesses on the question of whether or not justice is hampered or facilitated by opening a trial to public scrutiny. While it is important to discuss the merits and drawbacks of broadcast trials as they relate to such issues as professional accountability and the honesty of witnesses, I think it equally crucial to approach the Supreme Court decision from the perspective of the person on trial - the one individual Mr. Bass neglected to represent fully.

title: Business Conditions; INTEREST-RATE SWINGS
description: Some economists and politicians view the recent period of volatile interest rates as an aberration, and assert that time and restrictive monetary policies will restore stability to the credit markets. But a recent review of interest rate movements over the last 150 years suggests something else.

title: The Conservative Agenda
description: It seems to me, a registered Republican for 55 years, that ''Thunder From the Right'' (by Peter Ross Range, Feb. 8) is somewhat scary. I am particularly disturbed at the apparent power and views of Jesse Helms and his colleagues.

title: DIARY OF A TENNIS CAMPER: FROM 'GAH-BIDGE' TO 'SOO-PAH'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ROBIN HERMAN is a reporter in the Albany bureau of The New York Times. By ROBIN HERMAN

title: WIDE IMPACT SEEN IN DEPOSIT-BOTTLE BILL
description: YEAR-OLD Jamie Laager had to climb up on a chair so that he could see over the top of the lectern and reach the microphone. Once up there, he sighed deeply, smoothed out a piece of paper that contained his notes and began talking in a high but clear voice.

title: HOW TAX EVASION HAS GROWN
description: RICHARD LAWSON is a 34-year-old financial executive with an ascending career at a big New York corporation, an Ivy League pedigree and Hollywood looks. He lives on Manhattan's West Side in a brownstone that he bought four years ago when it seemed a candidate for the wrecker's ball and has since renovated the building with his own money and toil. He is a runner, doesn't smoke, and prefers Perrier to stronger libations. A friend describes him as ''upbeat, positive, a straight-arrow type.''

title: Prospects; Flirting with 1,000
description: Reductions in the prime interest rate and news of renewed takeover activity sent the stock market into paroxysms of delight last week, and pushed the Dow Jones industrial average up near the 1,000 level. Activity was especially pronounced among energy issues, prime movers in the current acquisition market.

title: Margot Ellis Is Betrothed to Hugh Starkey
description: Mrs. John Adams Blanchard of Needham, Mass., and Dr. F. Henry Ellis Jr. of Brookline, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margot McClintock Ellis, to Hugh Van Antwerp Starkey, son of Dr. and Mrs. George W.B. Starkey of Brookline and Norfolk, Conn. A May wedding is planned at the home of the future bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Blanchard.

title: Turkey Plans to Prosecute In 14 of 68 Torture Cases
description: Prime Minister Bulent Ulusu announced today that criminal proceedings had begun against people accused of torture in 14 cases out of a total of 68 incidents alleged by international organizations.

title: THE RETURN OF SAINT-SIMON
description: THE CAT AND THE KING By Louis Auchincloss. 183 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $10.95. By DORIS GRUMBACH

title: OPERA THRIVES, UNDAUNTED BY BUDGET WOES
description: HARTFORD THE Connecticut Opera, soon to launch into its 40th season with a mammoth production of ''Aida,'' is a thriving professional company that belies today's problems of budget cutbacks in the arts, maintains a touring company and is about to round off its current season performing such works as ''Macbeth'' and ''Porgy and Bess.''

title: Sound; PREPARING MUSIC THAT TRAVELS WELL; by Hans Fantel
description: A n academic friend of mine, who gets three months off in summer, is already planning his vacation. He is going to pick up a brand-new Rabbit in Munich and then break it in all across western Europe. As if that in itself weren't sufficiently enticing, he also has - quite literally - orchestrated his trip in a unique way. He hit on the idea of matching the music on the car's tape player to the landscape traversed: Johann Strauss for the Vienna Woods, Wagner for the Rhine, ''The Fountains of Rome'' for Rome, and so on. According to plan, Albeniz will enliven his Iberian journeys and Delius's ''North Country Sketches'' will go with him to the North Country.

title: U.S. STUDY SAYS CONSERVATION COULD SLASH ENERGY USE
description: The United States could cut its energy consumption almost 25 percent by the end of the century without sacrificing economic growth, according to an unpublished study conducted for the Department of Energy.

title: Floyd's 71 for 205 Takes Doral Lead by a Stroke
description: Although troubled by poor putting, Ray Floyd shot one-under-par 71 and took the lead by a stroke today after the third round of the $250,000 Doral-Eastern open golf tournament.

title: LOUISIANA COUNTRY BLUES SINGER
description: Robert Pete Williams, a powerful blues singer whose music helped win him a pardon from the state penitentiary, has died at the age of 66.

title: NEW DEPARTURES
description: We've mentioned before that the departure board at Pennsylvania Station doesn't always work. We've lately learned that comparable boards in Newark, Trenton, Wilmington and Baltimore don't always work either.

title: Westchester Journal
description: STATE Assemblyman William B. Finneran says he thinks that the State Legislature will ''very definitely'' pass a $1.9 million appropriation to absorb the back mortgage on the Mental Retardation Institute's building at Valhalla, giving the facility ''a fresh start.''

title: Linda Jean Schlichter Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest S. Schlichter of Sudbury, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Jean Schlichter, to John F.X. Reiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Reiser of New Canaan, Conn. A Sept. 5 wedding is planned.

title: REAGAN TAX-CUT PLAN FAVORS THE WELL-TO-DO, SOME ECONOMISTS FIND
description: President Reagan's tax-cutting program would provide greater relief for most upper-income Americans than for middle-@ and lower-income taxpayers, despite contentions to the contrary by some advocates of the plan, a variety of tax experts say.

title: Peter B. Sessa Will Marry Cynthia D'Auria on June 27
description: The engagement of Cynthia Gerard D'Auria to Peter B. Sessa of Osterville, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Sessa of Brooklyn and Shelter Island, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Adam D'Auria 2d of Flushing, Queens. A June 27 wedding is planned at Our Lady of the Isle Roman Catholic Church in Shelter Island Heights.

title: Stage View; THE SURRENDER OF BROADWAY TO AMPLIFIED SOUND
description: At ''Evita,'' the sound mixer presides over a huge console installed by Abe Jacob that monitors seven footlight mikes, separate mikes over various sections of the orchestra, 14 house speakers, 55 different inputs, six body mikes worn by the principals in the show, and special effects involving tape, films, and echo machines.

title: BUSH VISITS FAMILIES OF MURDERED CHILDREN IN ATLANTA
description: Vice President Bush today visited the families of five of Atlanta's 20 slain black children, discussed the case with local officials and said he hoped that the $1.5 million in Federal aid that President Reagan announced yesterday would end ''the trauma to the city and indeed the trauma to the entire country.''

title: IS IT THE KING OF INSTRUMENTS?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn is a freelance writer with a special interest in music. By ALLAN KOZINN

title: No Headline
description: Since the liberal agenda of the past quarter century does not seem to have worked, is it not time for a new look at our approach to governance? And, second, if the approaches of the conservative movement seem attractive and correct to a large majority of our citizens, is not there some chance that they are right in being right? BARRY L. RICH, Gaithersburg, Md.

title: ALWAYS A PARTY, BUT NEVER ON THE 17TH
description: I DON'T know when St. Patrick's Day is this year. My neighbors, who gave an annual party, have moved a thousand miles away. It was always at this time of year that Peg would tell me, ''Now remember, we're having the St. Patrick's Day party, but not on the 17th, because that's a Wednesday, and we can't have it that Saturday, because Neil will be away, but the Saturday after that, O.K.?'' Or a variation, because it was never on the 17th.

title: Itel
description: To the Business Editor: The article ''Itel in Bankruptcy: Trying to Salvage the Little That's Left'' (Feb. 15) says the giant leasing corporation's new chairman will also receive - in addition to a $250,000 salary - ''a bonus based on performance, which was fixed at $75,000, regardless of what happened. For the next three years the bonus cannot go below $50,000 ...''

title: Matthew Watkins to Wed Nancy Rockwell
description: Mr. and Mrs. John R. Rockwell of Weston, Conn., and Kennebunk Beach, Me., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Griffin Rockwell, to Matthew Watkins, son of Dr. and Mrs. John N. Watkins of Manhattan, Kan.

title: IT'S EXPERIMENTAL, BUT CARDS BEAT METS, 5-3
description: Two of the most resolutely changing teams in baseball, the Mets and St. Louis Cardinals, met today and began to test their risky experiments in upheaval.

title: TIPS FOR EARLY-BIRD DINERS IN MADRID
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- STEPHANIE REED MARKHAM is a writer who lives in Madrid. By STEPHANIE REED MARKHAM

title: SECONDHAND DISKS CAN BE FIRST-RATE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Sam H. Shirakawa writes frequently about recordings. By SAM H. SHIRAKAWA

title: Labor and Taxes
description: To the Business Editor: I do not find Lane Kirkland's reason for opposing the proposed income tax cuts in ''Labor on Reagan'' (March 1) at all convincing. He bases his objection on the fact that a married couple with two children (i.e. claiming four exemptions) and a taxable income of $10,000 would get a cut of only $52, while a similar couple with a taxable income of $30,000 would get a cut of nearly 7 1/2 times as much, about $390.

title: David Cholst Is Fiance of Laura Richman
description: Laura Diane Richman and David Jacob Cholst, students at the University of Chicago Law School, plan to be married Aug. 30 in Closter, N.J. Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Richman of Closter have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Betty Cholst and Dr. Sheldon Cholst, both of New York.

title: DETROIT, G.M. AND COURT ACT TO DOOM NEIGHBORHOOD
description: The Rev. Joseph Karasiewicz was standing in his church the other day wondering about the city of God and the city of man. Specifically, he was wondering why the City of Detroit was buying his church with its lovely statues, its burnished tiles and soaring arches, its dark, wooden pews, its communion rail and the red leather polished from decades of contact with the knees of humbled Polish-Americans, and was knocking it down to build a parking lot.

title: Sending Cables
description: To the Editor:

title: Flanagan of Orioles Striving to Regain 1979 Pitching Form
description: Earl Weaver, the elder statesman among major league managers, sent his Baltimore Orioles against the Yankees today for the first time since last August, and he observed the occasion by using two members of his ''Cy Young'' pitching staff.

title: Dance View; 'ROMEO AND JULIET'-A BALLETIC CHALLENGE
description: The Hartford Ballet's recent production of ''Romeo and Juliet'' served as a reminder that, with its rhapsodic sweep and majesty of utterance, Sergei Prokofiev's score for this work must be one of the greatest of all ballet scores. Yet it is a score that gives choreographers trouble.

title: LICKING INFLATION, AFTER A FASHION
description: If a Bronx cheer could be made to fit inside a 4'' x 10'' envelope, the United States Postal Service might have sent one, special delivery, to the Postal Rate Commission last week.

title: SALVADOR BECOMES A SMALLER BIG DEAL
description: Having drawn the line in El Salvador, the Reagan Administration tried last week to redirect public attention to the big picture of United States-Soviet relations.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: FROM the air, a well-insulated house will show up on heat-sensitive film in black, with a little white circle identifying the chimney or furnace exhaust, explained a spokesman for Northeast Utilities. If there is too little insulation in the attic, white patches will be visible on the roof. Heat escaping from a picture window will appear as a white aura outside the house, he said.

title: Laura Hunter Performs In Saxophone Recital
description: Laura Hunter, who made her New York debut as a saxophonist Tuesday evening, is a musician not easily ignored. Imposing of stature and possessing an equally imposing technique, Miss Hunter virtually overpowered her audience at Carnegie Recital Hall with muscular virtuosity.

title: STATE'S ECONOMY UP OR DOWN, G.O.P. SAYS
description: New York State's economy has improved substantially or is still in serious decline, and the reason may or may not be competition from states in the Sun Belt, depending on which of two Republican economic analyses one accepts.

title: A LIVING MEMORIAL
description: AN old copper beech tree, which was saved from the bulldozers during the construction of the new County Courthouse in White Plains, will now be preserved by a resident of the city as a living memorial to her husband.

title: QUESTIONS ON AGING EXPAND TO A CAREER
description: In 1965, as a 19-year-old exchange student in Sienna, Italy, Lynn Tepper lived in an extended Italian family and saw the support system it provided for the older members. Later, she lived in Berlin for eight years and worked as a rehabilitation psychologist with military personnel. "Many of them were in their late 30's and early 40's," she recalled. "They had parents who were becoming dependent and needed care, but they couldn't help because the military is a mobile career. They felt helpless."

title: JOHN P. ROWAN
description: John P. Rowan, consumer marketing representative for The New York Times in eastern New York State, died Friday after a long illness at Ellis Hospital in Schenectady. Mr. Rowan, who would have observed his 46th birthday today, was a resident of Clifton Park, N.Y.

title: NASSAU AND CITY: A WATER BATTLE?
description: SOMETIME next summer, New York City may begin pumping an additional 100 million gallons daily of water from the aquifer underlying Brooklyn and Queens to help alleviate its current shortage. Prolonged pumping of so much water from what is actually the western edge of geographic Long Island may create serious problems for the interconnected Nassau ground-water system, which is the only source of public water supply in that county of 1.5 million people.

title: KURT VONNEGUT SINGING IN THE BATH
description: PALM SUNDAY An Autobiographical Collage. By Kurt Vonnegut. 330 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $13.95. By EDWARD HOAGLAND

title: No Headline
description: The article on Jesse Helms brought to mind in a flash those wonderful undergraduate years in Durham, N.C., when it was mandatory to avoid late afternoon classes so as not to miss that back-to-back intellectual television treat of ''Popeye Theater'' and the local news with Cousin Jesse's editorial tirades.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: UNTIL last fall, Ken Warren had spent most of his working life tarring and shingling roofs, building additions on houses and doing general carpentry work. But then his hobby got the best of him, and he retreated to horse and buggy days - literally.

title: THE PERELMAN PAPERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Herbert Mitgang is a cultural news reporter for The New York Times. By HERBERT MITGANG

title: Sunday Observer; RICHES OF THE TUBE; by Russell Baker
description: Patrick McDonnell

title: MR. CRANE'S SUSPICIONS
description: In Washington, nothing is as simple as it appears. Representative Philip M. Crane, for example, has discerned a potential danger to the republic in what had been viewed merely as an embarrassment to three of his Republican colleagues.

title:
Comment;
SUPPLY SIDE'S BAD SIDE
description: We live in an era when there is a yearning for simple solutions; a susceptibility to false promises. In this situation people can be manipulated by easily comprehended slogans. The Reagan economists assert that the Government, particularly in the area of Federal deficit spending, is responsible for inflation, falling real wages, and economic stagnation.

title: SUDDENLY, HEAVY WEATHER FOR TALKS ON LAW OF THE SEA
description: AMID last-minute storm warnings hoisted by the Reagan Administration, the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea reopened last week in New York for the 10th and, it had been expected, final session. The expectations were premature.

title: GIRL ON BOYS' TEAM: A MIXED WELCOME
description: FAIRFIELD SHARON WILLIAMS could have gone out for volleyball, field hockey or softball or any of the sports that Roger Ludlow High School offers its freshman girls.

title: Students Vote to Bar Magazines
description: Students at Franklin Pierce Law Center have voted to ban Playboy, Penthouse and Hustler magazines from the campus bookstore because they found the magazines offensive. The bookstore is run by a cooperative to which almost every student joins for a $10 membership fee, giving them a voice in its management. At a recent meeting the students voted, 55 to 47, to ban the magazines.

title: Ireland
description: To the Editor:

title:
Economic Affairs;
THE LEAKS IN THE GRAIN EMBARGO
description: On Jan. 4, 1980, President Carter imposed an embargo on grain sales to the Soviet Union in reaction to the invasion of Afghanistan. As was the habit of the Carter Administration, economic sanctions were imposed as a diplomatic response. But it is poor logic and bad practice to trade economic apples for diplomatic and strategic oranges. Worse than that, the economic apples may not be any good.

title: ''Getting Chummy''
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Are Killed in Texas Bus Crash
description: A bus carrying high school students to a track meet veered out of control and crashed into a piece of heavy construction equipment today, killing three teen-agers and injuring eight other persons, the authorities said.

title: THE TIES THAT BIND ARE ALSO STRESSED
description: El Salvador followed Ronald Reagan to Canada last week, not to mention acid rain. Demonstrators noisily, and Canadian officials privately, protested Administration policies on foreign and bilateral issues from the Alaska pipeline to Great Lakes pollution to overfishing in Georges Bank.

title: Suzanne Louise Barcomb Wed
description: The marriage of Suzanne Louise Barcomb, daughter of Mrs. Floyd D. Gushea of Canton, N.Y., and the late Garrison J. Barcomb, to John Raymond Pearson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pearson of New Vernon, N.J., took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon. The Rev. George E. Chorba performed the ceremony. The bride is a legal assistant with the Morristown, N.J., law firm of Pitney, Hardin & Kipp. Mr. Pearson is a surety underwriter with Chubb & Son, a New York insurance company.

title: Lucia B. Phinney Bride Of Robert D. Dripps 3d
description: Lucia Bradford Phinney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Davis G. Phinney of Glastonbury, Conn., was married yesterday in Hartford to Robert Dunning Dripps 3d, son of Mrs. John T. Dorrance of Gladwyne, Pa., and the late Dr. Robert D. Dripps. The Rev. Nathaniel Lauriat, a Unitarian minister of Hartford, performed the ceremony at the Old Statehouse.

title: Law Clerk Is Fiance Of Pamela Murphy
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. William Gerhart of Grantville, Pa., and Robert Murphy of West Rutland, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Murphy, to Richard D'Avino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond E. D'Avino of New City, N.Y.

title: NYAMBUI WINS MILE, FAILS AT 2
description: The unbeatable Suleiman Nyambui was beaten once and almost twice today as the 17th annual National Collegiate indoor track and field championships ended.

title: PARK SLOPE SHOPSTEADS
description: Fifteen city-owned buildings in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn have been selected for a shopsteading program, according to Anthony Gliedman, Commissioner for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

title: Heilo Aalde, Tenor, Weds Joan Sumner
description: Joan de Beixedon Sumner and Heilo Aalde were married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Francis B. Creamer Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Virginia Convict Petitions For Stay of Execution
description: Defense lawyers are petitioning the United State Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for a stay of execution for James Dyral Briley, a 24-year-old convicted murderer who is scheduled to die in Virginia's electric chair Wednesday.

title: Jill E. Abramson Is Bride Of Henry Little Griggs 3d
description: Jill Ellen Abramson and Henry Little Griggs 3d were married yesterday at the Hampshire House in New York by Walter Lawton, a leader of the New York Ethical Culture Society.

title: HOT DOGS, BEER AND A REUNION: THE JOY OF THE NATIONAL PASTIME
description: During the deepest recesses of winter, I author a letter about baseball and sultry summer days. It is an annual letter, sent to friends sprinkled across the continent and to some who have gone beyond. The tradition began three years ago, inspired on an autumn evening in 1977, with cheers echoing in the Bronx night, when a championship came home on three powerful swings.

title: Daryl Buchanan, Teacher, Affianced To Peter J. Veysey
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. Campbell Buchanan of East Sandwich, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Daryl Henderson Buchanan, to Peter John Veysey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Veysey of Old Greenwich, Conn., Nantucket, Mass., and Stratton, Vt. A June wedding is planned.

title: Margot Slade Fiancee of Nicholas Baxter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Melvin S. Slade of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margot S. Slade, to Nicholas St. Clair Lund Baxter, son of Brig. Gen. Harry J.P. Baxter, British Army, retired, and Mrs. Baxter of County Down, Northern Ireland.

title: Children's Books
description: PERFECT CRANE By Anne Laurin. Illustrated by Charles Mikolaycak. 31 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $8.95. (Ages 6 to 9) By NATALIE BABBITT

title: ORGANIST: RAVER OFFERS 3 PREMIERES
description: Organists walk among us just like ordinary folk. Contemporary organ music makes use of the same techniques and bows to the same fashions as music for ordinary instruments. But organists still live in a separate world, bound by the church - where most organs live - and by the homey verities of mid-America. In that sense, organ music is closest to band music and choral music, inherently conservative and sometimes rather corny, too.

title: SECURITY BIG ON MENU AT REAGAN DINNER
description: It wasn't hard to guess who was coming to dinner last night at Le Cirque, the fashionable East Side restaurant at which President and Mrs. Reagan joined friends after the theater. Each of the 100 or so patrons enjoying a stylish Saturday afternoon lunch could sense the mounting excitement in the posh rose-beige dining room.

title: Personal Finance; IT PAYS TO SHOP FOR AIR FARES
description: AIRFARES and airline scheduling are changing so fast and becoming so complicated that even the shrewdest consumer can get confused and lose out. But the traveler who studies the options carefully can find some very good deals indeed these days.

title: About Westchester
description: "WHAT can I expect after our first date,"the man in the open-neck shirt and wearing a gold chain asked in studiously smooth tones. "In order to find out," replied the blonde woman carefully, her voice nervous and slightly choked, "you'll have to ask me out first."

title: St. Joseph's of Toms River Wins N.J. Parochial Title
description: St. Joseph's of Toms River defeated St. Joseph's of Montvale, 67-60, and won the parochial Class A state basketball championship today.

title: Kimberly Lucchesi Betrothed
description: The engagement of Kimberly Ann Lucchesi to William Arthur John Marshall Jr., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John A. Lucchesi of Danbury, Conn. Mr. Marshall is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall of Trumbull, Conn.

title: Geologists
description: To the Business Editor: ''Finding The People Who Find The Oil'' (Feb. 15) lays undue stress on the plight of major oil companies - and fails to articulate the present worth of an accomplished ''oil finder.''

title: Soviet Computer Links Capsule and Space Lab
description: A Soyuz T-4 capsule carrying two astronauts made a computer-directed linkup with the orbiting Salyut-6 space laboratory, Tass, the official Soviet Government press agency, said today.

title: Editors' Choice
description: million-year-old prehuman skeleton and its effect on evolutionary theory. THE SHOCK OF THE NEW, by Robert Hughes.

title: The Week in Business; BIG MERGERS AND LOWER RATES EXCITE THE MARKET
description: The stock market rose last week on investors' hopes for lower interest rates and on a spurt of merger activity. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 4.05 points on Friday but still gained 21.15 points on the week to finish at 985.77. Stocks soared 22.15 points on Thursday.

title: STRENGTHENING THE BONN CONNECTION
description: More than $1 billion in cost overruns has made the Tornado the world's most expensive military airplane and forced deep cuts in Bonn's defense budget. The fighter-bomber is under joint development by West Germany, Britain and Italy.

description: New York City's Public Schools Athletic League had more than twice the first places registered by Section XI (Suffolk County), but the Long Island section ended up as the champion today in the New York State schoolboy track and field championships at Cornell's Barton Hall.
