description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- FRED FERRETTI is a reporter for The New York Times. By FRED FERRETTI

title: DEMOCRATIC RIFT STALLS CONNECTICUT BID TO CUT DEFICIT
description: A rift between Gov. William A. O'Neill and his Democratic majorities in the General Assembly has complicated Connecticut's efforts to increase taxes to avert a deficit in the state's fiscal year ending June 30.

title: April Concert by Students Of Community Schools
description: The 22 community schools in New York that teach music, dance and visual arts in New York will present 200 of their best music students in a concert at Alice Tully Hall on April 2.

title: Virginia Jones Married
description: Virginia Lydia Jones, an associate with the Florida Department of Health and Rehabilitation Services in Clearwater, was married yesterday to Dr. Willard M. Bright.

title: Frances Todd to Be Fall Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Burt K. Todd of Ligonier, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Frances Hays Todd, to Charles Prescott Stewart 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Jr. of Pittsburgh. A fall wedding is planned.

title: D. J. Meltzer Weds Ellen M. Semonoff
description: Ellen M. Semonoff and Daniel J. Meltzer, 1975 graduates of the Harvard Law School, were married at the Essex House yesterday by Rabbi Alan Flam, brother-in-law of the bride.

title: Panel Backs White Air Controller In 1976 Job Discrimination Case
description: A former Navy air traffic controller who accused the Federal Aviation Administration in a job discrimination case, will be given a job and collect about $120,000 in back pay, his lawyer says.

title: Connecticut Housing; FOUR HOMES REVEAL SOLAR SECRETS
description: AFTER they had their fourth child two years ago, Ann and Robert Lindquist realized that their 40-year-old saltbox in Easton no longer fit their family. It was time to build an addition.

title: DAVID STOCKMAN: THE PRESIDENT'S CUTTING EDGE
description: Sidney Blumenthal is the author of ''The Permanent Campaign,'' a book about political consultants. By Sidney Blumenthal ithin a week of the inauguration, David A. Stockman began summoning the members of the Reagan Cabinet, one by one, into his high-ceilinged conference room in the ornate Old Executive Office Building to inform them how he intended to slash their budgets. In a polite but relentless manner, the 34-year-old director of the Office of Management and Budget, a generation younger than the Cabinet secretaries, was defining the limits of their jobs.

title: EXPRESSIONIST SHOW DESERVES APPLAUSE
description: This exhibition was not mounted to trace the genesis of the movement as Miss Harrison suggests.

title: MAPLE SYRUP IS LOSING GROUND TO COAL MINING IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: When Dale Jeffrey decided to expand his maple sugar camp by 100 acres, he approached a nearby landowner with a lease offer. The landowner, Mr. Jeffrey recalled, decided that the coal below the soil was worth more than the maple trees above it.

title: S.D. Sussman Weds Miss Tisch
description: Laurie M. Tisch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Preston Robert Tisch of New York and Rye, N.Y., was married last evening to S. Donald Sussman, son of Beatrice Zimmerman of Miami and the late William Sussman. Rabbi Irving Lehrman performed the ceremony at the Regency Hotel.

title: Theater; A CAREER 'TOUCHED WITH LUCK'
description: IN its publication and program notes the Hartford Stage Company has described the Arthur Schnitzler play ''Undiscovered Country'' - in a version by Tom Stoppard that is playing through March 29 - as ''Freud in waltz time''; its characters are people living ''in a terrifying void in which nothing changes ...'' Stefan Schnabel plays one of these characters, Dr. von Aigner, who is the manager of an elegant hotel in the Dolomites. Mr. Schnabel refers to the play as ''a wicked comedy. It is a mixture of Noel Coward and Ibsen. You know, on top it's full of 'tennis anyone' and terribly gay, and underneath it's full of depths.''

title: WOODY HERMAN JAMS
description: Woody Herman, who will be 68 years old in May, has been leading a big band for more than 46 years. Yet, aside from the glory days of his First and Second Herds between 1945 and 1950, this year may be one of the richest and most rewarding of his long career. In the fall he will open his own club in a New Orleans hotel where, for the first time in his life, he will be able to settle down with his band for more than 30 weeks each year (the club is supposed to be completed in January but, as anyone who has dealt with building contractors knows, nothing is ever finished on schedule).

title: Arkansas County Defaults On Pay for 700 Employees
description: Pulaski County's arrangement with local banks to borrow $1 million for the payroll and other expenses collapsed at the last minute yesterday, leaving 700 employees without paychecks.

title: REINFORCING A LEGAL RIGHT TO BE SILENT
description: A defendant's silence in the courtroom is theoretically golden; his right not to testify is guaranteed by the Fifth Amendment. In reality, that silence often speaks as loudly as a trumpet to jurors, who expect the accused to explain his alleged actions.

title: Ursinus Ousts Upsala
description: Ursinus upset Upsala, 71-69, tonight to move into the final four of the National Collegiate Division III basketball championships against Potsdam State next weekend in Rock Island, Ill.

title: College Trustee Resigns In Racial Joke Dispute
description: A trustee of Mount Holyoke College, who helped supervise the college's policy of not investing in companies doing business with South Africa, has resigned after he was accused of telling a racist joke to students and faculty members at a college lounge.

title: An Unexpected Bump Ruins a 'Lovers' Lane'
description: A freighter came loose from her moorings at a Brooklyn lumberyard pier about 5:30 A.M. yesterday, crashed into an abandoned pier - a ''lovers' lane,'' of sorts, in the Greenpoint section - and knocked a parked car with four young people inside into the chilly waters of the East River.

title: Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: Israel Sees Peril if Saudis Buy U.S. Radar Aircraft
description: Deputy Defense Minister Mordechai Zippori has declared that a reported sale of United States electronic surveillance and command planes to Saudi Arabia would be ''very dangerous'' and would expose Israel to hostile forces.

title: Music View; CONTEMPORARY OPERA JUST DOESN'T 'SING'
description: The disappearance of song from contemporary opera is one of the great unsolved crimes of our time. It is well known that the victim was alive and frequenting opera houses all over the world just before World War I. Since then there have been occasional rumors to suggest that song, once famously hearty, still survives in certain dark corners, though in a sadly emaciated condition. So, optimists and other innocent folk who remember song with some affection make sure to hurry to the opera whenever a new work is announced. Only recently, for instance, the unregenerate lover of rhapsody and lyricism could sift through Thea Musgrave's ''Mary, Queen of Scots'' at the New York City Opera in hope of turning up significant traces of the vanished art form. Vain hope.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. OFFICERS DOUBT A CARIBBEAN ABILITY
description: If President Reagan decides to make a show of military force in the Caribbean, the Pentagon will be hard put to carry out his orders because the armed forces are already stretched thin around the world, in the view of senior officers.

title: Connecticut Guide; NEW HAVEN AND ST. PATRICK
description: Today, and through the end of the month, Yale University's facsimile of the Book of Kells will be exhibited at the Sterling Library ''as part of improved town-gown relationships,'' said Byrne Stoddard, spokesman for New Haven's St. Patrick's Day Parade.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: At Home
description: MY college roommate, Elise, calls me from her Cleveland suburb every year or so. It's usually an emergency. Ten years ago, a disciple of Sassoon gave her a crewcut. Six years ago, her youngest son gave her the measles. Two years ago, she wondered what I thought of artists' communes. She was considering taking a year off from car pools, plumbers, and the institution of marriage. She didn't. Her husband disapproved and on closer inspection, the commune's warehouse living quarters seemed to be infested with rats. All I generally have to do is throw in a few ''uh-huh's'' and ''no kidding's'' to help Elise arrive at her own solution. But this year's emergency is a rat of a different stripe. She is sure, she said on the phone last week, that she is insane.

title: 20,000 to Be Married By Unification Church
description: The Unification Church will have a mass marriage for 20,000 of its members this year and will hold revival meetings to promote interracial marriages, church spokesmen have said.

title: AFTER 'NAPOLEON'- ANOTHER FILM BY ABEL GANCE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Harvey is the coordinator of special film projects at the Museum of Art's Department of Film. By STEPHEN HARVEY

title: KNICKS' TENSION DISAPPEARS AFTER VICTORY
description: Michael Ray Richardson was under the shower when Sonny Werblin walked into the room. ''When we win the championship,'' Richardson told Werblin, ''I'm going to throw you into the shower.'' ''I'll be happy to go,'' said Werblin, the president of Madison Square Garden Corporation, which owns the Knicks. The Knicks are a long way from winning the National Basketball Association championship. All their 127-117 victory Friday night over the Chicago Bulls did was clinch a playoff berth.

title: Leisure; A LUCKY CROP CHARMS MILLIONS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Walter Masson is a freelance writer and photographer. By WALTER MASSON

title: Design; WHAT DO CHILDREN WANT?; by Marilyn Bethany
description: One of the difficulties of designing children's rooms is that when the question ''What do you want?'' is posed, precious little comes out of the mouths of babes. Unlike their elders, children have not had time to form a bevy of prejudices that they can hardly wait to air. They have design preferences, to be sure, but these are often expressed more by actions than by words.

title: Killing of Seals Is Protested In Paris and The Hague
description: About 300 people gathered outside the Canadian Embassy today to protest the killing of baby seals and other furred animals. A similar protest was held in The Hague, where 250 people demonstrated outside the Canadian Embassy.

title: REPORT ON OFFSHORE OIL SITE STIRS ECOLOGISTS
description: ALTHOUGH the third mid-Atlantic oil-lease sale is not scheduled until December, a report issued by the Department of the Interior has come under criticism from environmentalists and state officials. They say that sensitive ecological areas should be excluded from the proposed sale site.

title: EGYPT-ISRAEL TOURISM: MOSTLY ONE-WAY
description: A remarkable meeting took place recently in the offices of the Lucky Tours Company on Abdel-Khalek Sarwat Street here. It was all the more remarkable because it happens almost weekly.

title: Senator Dole Leaves Hospital
description: Senator Robert J. Dole, Republican of Kansas, returned to his Washington home today after 22 days in Walter Reed Army Medical Center, where he underwent a kidney stone operation Feb. 20.

title: PARKS DEPARTMENT TO START HIRING FOR FIRST TIME SINCE FISCAL CRISIS
description: For the first time in at least 13 years, the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation plans to begin adding to its permanent work force.

title: CUBAN HEADS MISSIOIN STARTING NEW ATTEMPT TO END IRAQ-IRAN WAR
description: Cuba's Foreign Minister, Isidoro Malmierca Peoli, who heads a four-member delegation from the countries professing nonalignment, arrived here today at the start of a new mission to try to mediate the war between Iraq and Iran.

title: No Headline
description: In describing Jesse Helms's fellow conservatives in the Senate, you specifically indicated that both Utah Senators, Jake Garn and Orrin Hatch, are Mormons. Why did you fail to mention the religious orientation of the other six senators pictured? Am I to assume that Mormonism is inherently political? Or am I to assume that religion is somehow less important to the other six men? Or should I just shake my head in the face of petty bigotry? PATRICK J. O'HARA, Salt Lake City

title: SHOPPING KIDDY BOUTIQUES
description: All babies wear diapers and most teen-agers wear jeans, but there are moments in between when children need special clothes, both solemn and whimsical. There are days when kids insist upon being cowboys and nurses, and there are formal weddings when little girls may want to wear white organdy dresses beribboned in silk.

title: PHILADELPHIA TRANSIT STRIKE STARTS
description: The 4,900 members of the city's transit workers' union went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today after negotiators failed to come to an agreement on a new contract.

title: CITY OPERA: MARILYN ZSCHAU SINGS VERDI'S 'ATTILA'
description: Verdi's ''Attila'' is not his finest opera by any means, or even in the top 10, so an opera company that puts on this blood-and-guts epic had better have good reasons. The New York City Opera's production Friday evening was reasonable on enough grounds to make it worth any Verdi enthusiast's while. First of all, it had a genuine conductor in Sergiu Comissiona, who knew how to drive the music excitingly when excitation was called for, but who also could search out and exploit the rarer moments of delicate orchestral poetry in the score.

title: Fire Erupts in French Oil Depot
description: Hundreds of firemen battled a huge blaze today that broke out in an oil tank depot near this central French city, the police said. Several tanks, each containing 88,000 gallons of gasoline, caught on fire. The cause of the blaze was not immediately known.

title: Leavata Johnson Sings Brahms and Strauss
description: Leavata Johnson introduced her dark and dramatic soprano voice to New York's solo recital stage last Sunday afternoon with a program of German and American songs at the Abraham Goodman House. Her Brahms was warm and intense, and Richard Strauss's ''Allerseelen'' and ''Traum durch die Dammerung'' conveyed a real sensuality.

title: Westchester Guide; ETHEL MERMAN AT LEHMAN

After lifting her voice over countless pit orchestras on Broadway for decades, Miss Merman began taking on symphony orchestras in 1976 when she appeared with Arthur Fiedler and the Boston Pops.

title: Ellen Stopsky Plans Wedding in August
description: The engagement of Ellen Stopsky to Jay Steinberg has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. David C. Stopsky of Plainview, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Steinberg of Huntington, L.I.

title: Iowa Takes Wrestling Crown
description: The University of Iowa's well-rounded squad gained its fourth straight National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championship today with surprising ease. The Hawkeyes had the title assured even before the start of tonight's program of 10 final matches.

title: Gary S. Davis Will Wed Marsha Dale Pilat Oct. 3
description: Dr. and Mrs. Howard L. Pilat of Dallas, formerly of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marsha Dale Pilat, to Gary Stuart Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Davis of Denver.

description: MERRICK WHILE ''The Pirates of Penzance'' delights sold-out Broadway audiences, many getting their first taste of Gilbert and Sullivan, the very model of a modern Gilbert and Sullivan troupe is flourishing on the Island.

Ferguson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ferguson of Loudonville, N.Y. description: Janos Kadar, the Hungarian Communist Party leader, called on the United States today to reply to a Soviet proposal for a summit meeting.

title: CONNECTICUT SAYS FARE ON CONRAIL MUST RISE 25% TO MEET EXPENSES
description: Connecticut has told the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that Conrail's New Haven commuter line needs a fare increase of 25 percent to meet operating expenses this year.

title: Seasickness Cure: It's All in the Wrists
description: A New York doctor who learned acupuncture to alleviate the pain of his cancer patients has combined his knowledge of this ancient treatment and his love of sailing to create a device to help prevent seasickness.

title: TH ; Mount St. Helens in the foreground; Mount Adams, rear; Tours to Mount St. Helens
description: It has been less than a year since thousands of people fled from the vicinity of Mount St. Helens in Washington, but at least one tour operator is organizing groups of tourists to visit the site of the volcano's eruptions.

title: OWNER PUTTING BRONCOS IN YOUNGER HANDS
description: Robert (Red) Miller, the successful coach of the Denver Broncos, was summoned to the club's downtown offices last Monday for an apparent orientation meeting with the new owner, Edgar F. Kaiser Jr. But before Miller left his home, a friend phoned and mentioned reports out of Dallas that Miller would soon be replaced by Dan Reeves from the Cowboys' staff.

title: Hamilton Captures P.S.A.L. Title, 91-87
description: It was up to Andre Ervin. He walked to the foul line, bounced the ball twice and shot. One point. He shot again. Two points. He jumped, grinned and slapped his teammate, Jerry Reynolds, on the palm. They were safe. Hamilton High School was 12 seconds from its first New York City Division A championship.

title: PUTTING 'IDOMENEO' IN A CLASS BY ITSELF
description: Only a few decades ago, musicology was an infant discipline. Today, musicologists are making a profound impact on the way we hear music. This is partly a matter of performance practice - how to play the notes in a score. It is also a matter of what the notes should be in the first place. Scholars have become ever more active in their researches into alternate variants, first versions and the like.

title: GREENWICH FIRE TRAINING: THE EASY WAY
description: THE Greenwich Fire Training Center controversy is yet another issue dividing our town. On the one hand, we have the enraged North Street residents who are threatening to bring a lawsuit to keep the facility out of their area; on the other hand, we have the cooler, more judicious and unbiased thinkers, all of who, strangely enough, live in some other part of town, and the we have the firemen. All they want is something to burn. And I say let's give it to them.

description: O nly a few decades ago, musicology was an infant discipline. Today, musicologists are making a profound impact on the way we hear music. Scholars have become ever more active in their researches into alternate variants, first versions and the like.

title: IS WESTINGHOUSE OUT OF THE WOODS?
description: OVER the past decade, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation has demonstrated that it is among the best of the nation's industrial heavyweights when it comes to absorbing a punch. But can it throw one?

title: 3 TO BID TO WIN CONRAIL FREIGHT
description: WETHERSFIELD THE Connecticut Railroad freight system, traumatized in recent years by the bankruptcy of the Penn Central and the creation of Consolidated Rail Corporation, may be reorganized yet again.

title: Air Controllers' Talks Extended
description: The Government and the union representing air traffic controllers have recessed negotiations until Monday, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration said today. The Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization's current contract expires at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

title: 22 - COUNT 'EM, 22 - IN RACE FOR GOVERNOR
description: THE state's Election Law Enforcement Commission has sent out its first checks, totaling $1.1 million, to five candidates for Governor in the June 2 primary.

title: AMERICAN PIE, IN SOME SKY
description: There's something disconcerting about standing in line at the checkout counter behind someone using food stamps. Especially when one is paying for one's own order with the family mortgage money.

title: Myra R. Green Engaged to Richard Gipstein
description: Dr. and Mrs. Michael Green of Springfield, Mass., and Guilford Center, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Myra Ruth Green, to Richard Falk Gipstein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Gipstein of New London, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Georgia Parole Board Set Early Release for 1,100
description: The state parole board has approved the release of 1,100 Georgia prison inmates serving time for nonviolent crimes in order to relieve overcrowding, parole officials confirmed today.

title: RAILROAD SEEKS TO OFFSET POWER FAILURES
description: Plans for dealing with disruptions to Conrail passenger service resulting from power shortages on its New Haven line are being developed by state and railroad officials.

title: HOUSING IN STATE GAINED IN 70'S
description: WASHINGTON THOSE parents badgered by a passel of youngsters under foot may not believe this, but the Census Bureau has the figures: Households in New Jersey today are less crowded than they were a decade ago.

title: SOME OTHER WAYS TO ENCOURAGE SAVINGS
description: WASHINGTON IN hopes of curing inflation and flagging productivity, Congress is considering a broad assortment of bills to give generous tax relief to investment income and capital gains.

title: Investing; GETTING TECHNICAL ABOUT STOCKS
description: W ITH the stock market becoming increasingly volatile, investors might consider asking their brokers more pointed questions than ''How's the Dow doing?''

description: MY college roommate, Elise, calls me from her Cleveland suburb every year or so. It's usually an emergency. Ten years ago, a disciple of Sassoon gave her a crewcut.

title: HE DOESN'T GO BY THE BOOK
description: EDISON ''REMEMBER the number five, boys and girls,'' the man on stage was telling the pupils at Woodbrook School. ''That's how many whales will be killed while I'm talking to you this morning.''

title: KOCH TO MEET STOCKMAN TO DETAIL HIS OBJECTIONS TO REAGAN BUDGET
description: The Koch administration will take its objections to President Reagan's proposed budget cuts directly to David A. Stockman, the Budget Director, at a meeting in Washington some time this week.

title: The Council Calendar For the Coming Week
description: The following City Council meetings have been scheduled for this week: MONDAY - Committee on Consumer Affairs, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Housing and Buildings, City Hall, 12:30 P.M. WEDNESDAY - Committee on Transportation, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Youth Services, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. FRIDAY - Committee on Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, 250 Broadway, 23d floor, 11 A.M.

title: RETHINKING THE UNTHINKABLE
description: Wade Greene has written widely on social and technological issues. By Wade Greene In the 1950's and early 1960's, an unsettling fear of nuclear holocaust imprinted itself on the consciousness of the American people. ''We will all go together when we go,'' sang a lyrical satirist by the name of Tom Lehrer, and for a while, apocalypse seemed imminently possible. The eschatological potential of nuclear war had been made horrifyingly clear at Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and all thoughtful citizens wondered whether an exchange of nuclear bombs might somehow erupt between the United States and the Soviet Union - and whether humanity itself might be destroyed in the crossfire.

title: Business Conditions; MORE JOIN 'OWN BOSS' CATEGORY
description: Those who worry about a decline in America's entrepreneurial spirit should be heartened by a recent employment survey conducted by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: SECOND THOUGHTS AND A HOUNDED LIFE
description: Soviet propagandists had a field day last year when Yuri Stepanov, a Russian ballet dancer, returned to Moscow after a brief stay in the United States as a political defector. American authorities, the newspaper Izvestia alleged, had tried to recruit Mr. Stepanov as a spy; other Soviet defectors he met were either alcoholic, despairing, or both.

title: Francis Whitten 3d, Teacher, Fiance of Susan Alicia Mann
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard O. Mann of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Alicia Mann, to Francis Whitten 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitten of Stoneham, Mass.

title: DIARY OF A CUNNINGHAM DANCE
description: During the six-week work period of the most recent film/dance that Charles Atlas and I have made, I kept a diary of the work in progress, ''Channels/Inserts.''

title: No Headline
description: Concerning Senator Helms's support for free enterprise, I will believe that when he uses his power as chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee to eliminate the tobacco subsidies. KENAN JARBOE, Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: March 15, 1981
description: NONFICTION AMERICA'S TECHNOLOGY SLIP. By Simon Ramo. 18 BEGINNING TO SEE THE LIGHT: Pieces of a Decade. By Ellen Willis. 9 THE IMAGE OF ETERNITY: Roots of Time in the Physical World.

title: Propane Propulsion
description: Hoping to cut fuel costs 40 percent, as well as conserve petroleum, the Rocky Hill Police Department announced in April 1980 that it would become the first in Connecticut and among the first in the nation to use liquefied propane rather than gasoline in police cars. It planned to convert two of its four cars.

title: Film View; WHY KATHARINE HEPBURN HAS SURVIVED AS A LEADING LADY
description: Katharine Hepburn: In the beginning there is the face, especially those fine, precisely chiseled cheekbones that discipline time. There is the voice, strong, slightly nasal, distinctively, unashamedly upper-class American, something she refused seriously to tamper with even in ''Spitfire'' (1934) when she was supposed to be playing a Southeastern mountain girl. Appalachia was never like that, but this Appalachia was her own creation. As she is now, Hepburn in 1934 was a serious-business movie star. Then, too, there is the physical presence, a fusion of long, lithe body with grace of movement and an intelligence that can be as scratchy as sandpaper and surprisingly sophisticated for someone who so frequently identifies common sense as an exclusively Yankee virtue, and someone who puts that intelligence to uses that can be as cruel as kind.

title: UNMANAGEABLE CLASS SIZE STILL CITY SCHOOL PROBLEM
description: When a fifth-grader had trouble subtracting two-fifths from onehalf at Public School 163 on Manhattan's Upper West Side, Celeste Franzblau, his teacher, paused in the lesson to spend three or four minutes helping him find the common denominator. Such one-on-one instruction, however, is a luxury that Mrs. Franzblau and many others throughout the city with overcrowded classrooms can afford only in unusual moments.

title: ON THE EXECUTION OF STEVEN JUDY
description: To the Editor:

title: REVERTING TO THE RELAY PRINCIPLE
description: The number of spoken languages in the world is over three thousand. The number of bidding languages in bridge is distinctly short of that total, but the gap is closing. Esoteric systems, each known to a handful of adherents and incomprehensible to everyone else, are springing up in many parts of the world.

title: Sandra Seefeld Gives New York Flute Premiere
description: Sandra L. Seefeld, who studied the flute at the Eastman School and Northwestern University and teaches at Miami University of Ohio, made a strong and effective New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday evening. Her program of Bach, Kuhlau, Copland, Alain, Sheppard and Prokofiev displayed a warm full tone, an evenness of execution and serious interpretive instincts.

title: A HISTORY LOST IN PARADE REVEL
description: BY Tuesday, Hallmark will have sold a lot of cute cards with leprechauns on them. And on that day itself, peddlers will hawk buttons emblazoned, ''Kiss Me -I'm Irish,'' and at Fifth Avenue and 86th Street, where Manhattan's annual St. Patrick's Day parade ends, thousands of high school and college students will celebrate the day in their own style. They will get drunk.

title: Elizabeth W. Mohr, TV Aide, Married To Charles McKee
description: In the First Presbyterian Church of Lake Forest, Ill., yesterday afternoon, Elizabeth Winn Mohr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Mohr Jr. of Lake Forest, became the bride of Charles Russell McKee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph V. McKee Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Things to come. What do the next 10 years hold for humankind? Herewith some prophecies:

title: NASSAU POLICE TRAINING COMES UNDER SCRUTINY
description: BALDWIN THE call crackled over the radio in the police car: ''Man with gun, down an alley.''

title: Dr. Susan Weathers Married
description: Dr. Susan Wheeler Weathers and Dr. Richard Larrey were married yesterday at the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. J. Scottie Griffin performed the ceremony.

title: DANCE THEATER PLANS BIRHTDAY CELEBRATION
description: WESTCHESTER'S Rondo Dance Theater is celebrating its 10th anniversary this week with two performances at SUNY Purchase Center for the Arts. ''Stages in Ages,'' a full-length program of music and dance of 16th-century England and 20th-century America, will be presented by the eight-member modern dance repertory company and two musical groups, the New England Brass Works and the Hopewell Consort.

title: Anne Wadsworth Symington, a Lawyer, Wed to Charles H. Rhodes 3d in St. Louis
description: Anne Wadsworth Symington, an associate with the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, was married in St. Louis yesterday to Charles Harker Rhodes 3d, a candidate for a Ph.D. degree in the biological sciences at Rockefeller University and an M.D. at the Cornell University Medical College.

title: WHERE TAXING BEGINS
description: HARTFORD BOOSTERS often point out that Connecticut has no income tax. But the state has 26 other taxes, which the average resident pays most of his life. For those who die, there is a 27th.

title: At Home
description: MY college roommate, Elise, calls me from her Cleveland suburb every year or so. It's usually an emergency. Ten years ago, a disciple of Sassoon gave her a crewcut. Six years ago, her youngest son gave her the measles. Two years ago, she wondered what I thought of artists' communes. She was considering taking a year off from car pools, plumbers and the institution of marriage. She didn't. Her husband disapproved and on closer inspection, the commune's warehouse living quarters seemed to be infested with rats.

title: CAREY LABOR CHIEF NOMINEE SAID TO WANT TO WITHDRAW
description: After three months of political battling, Governor Carey's choice for New York State Industrial Commissioner has asked that his nomination be withdrawn, senior state officials said yesterday.

title: TWO LOW-COST WAYS OF GETTING CLOSE TO EUROPE'S GLORIES USING A TRAILER
description: BY THE RIVER THAMES AS A VACATION BASE --------------------------------------------------------------------- JOHN M. GRAY teaches English at a high school in North Eastham, Mass., and is sports editor of The Cape Codder. By JOHN M.GRAY

title: MARTIN BUCKLEY TO WED LUCY KNOWLES, LAWYER
description: Lucy M. Knowles, assistant solicitor for the Second Judicial Circuit of South Carolina in Aiken, and Martin B. Buckley, an architect in Columbia, S.C., plan to be married April 25 in Aiken.

title: PERSIAN GULF FORCE SUBJECT OF DISPUTE
description: Fundamental differences over the composition of United States military forces and their strategy to counter threats to American interests around the Persian Gulf came into full view at Senate hearings this week.

title: MEMORIAL FOR MRS. GRASSO GAINSHARTFORD
description: LEGISLATORS who failed in their attempt to honor the late Gov. Ella T. Grasso by renaming the state's major airport for her may instead commission a statue at the State Capitol.

title: ...BUT ECONOMIC WEAKNESS UNDERMINES STABILITY IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: MEXICO CITY Afew months ago, when a Salvadoran guerrilla leader was asked how the left, if victorious, would develop the country, he responded quickly that it would bring justice to the poor and break the stranglehold of the oligarchy. But just how, his questioner persisted, would the left convert the tiny, overcrowded rural-based society into an economically viable nation? The young rebel paused and then admitted softly, ''I don't know.''

title: Military Analysis
description: The rapidly expanding Israeli arms industry now ranks seventh among the world's exporters of weapons and defense-related equipment with sales for the year ending April 1 of about $1.3 billion, a 40 percent increase over those of the previous year, according to a British military publication.

title: Nature Watch; NATURE WATCH; RAZORBILL; Alca torda
description: Size: 16 to 18 inches. Color: Black above, white below. Adult in winter (shown) resembles juvenile with white cheeks and throat.

title: J.E. Frankel to Wed Jill Susan Wollman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Steven A. Wollman of Purchase, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Susan Wollman, to James Eagle Frankel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Frankel of Newburgh, N. Y.

title: SEMINAR PROMOTES CAREER AS VOLUNTEER
description: ''I CAN'T conceive of working for a bank. For me the idea of commitment is what's important. I guess I'm an idealist at heart.'' For Ellen Boyle, a senior urban-affairs major at Connecticut College, the statement explains the interest in a conference ''Careers in Public Service Organizations'' held recently at the New London college.

title: HELP OLD CITIES OR ENCOURAGE THE CROWD TO ESCAPE THEM?
description: THE United States Conference of Mayors last week joined those labeling President Reagan's budget proposals unfair to the nation's cities, but a longer-range argument about the cities and the Government's role in their survival continues, stimulated in part by the report of a recent Presidential commission. The Week in Review asked Donald A. Hicks, professor of political economy at the University of Texas at Dallas and author of the urban section of the report, Edward I. Koch, Mayor of New York City and Richard P. Nathan, director of the Regional Center at Princeton University, to discuss the commission's findings. Excerpts of their talk with Clyde Haberman, chief of The New York Times's City Hall Bureau, John Herbers, national correspondent of The Times, and Caroline Rand Herron and Richard Levine, editors of The Review, follow.

title: WOODY HERMAN-JAMMING AS OF OLD
description: Woody Herman, who will be 68 years old in May, has been leading a big band for more than 46 years. Yet, aside from the glory days of his First and Second Herds between 1945 and 1950, this year may be one of the richest and most rewarding of his long career. In the fall he will open his own club in a New Orleans hotel where, for the first time in his life, he will be able to settle down with his band for more than 30 weeks each year.

title: A 'RUN FOR SIGHT'
description: With spring just around the corner, many joggers are happily returning to the highways and byways. Next Sunday, they will have an early chance to check their progress and get a mild competitive workout in a minimarathon. It is called the ''Run for Sight,'' and it will be held in Millburn, starting at 1 P.M.

title: Melissa Zwanger Engaged to Wed David J. Weisenfeld
description: The engagement of Melissa Zwanger, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Zwanger of Massapequa Park, L.I., to David J. Weisenfeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer L. Weisenfeld of Roslyn Heights, L.I., has been announced by Miss Zwanger's parents.

title: OF SAWS AND PRAYERS AND CHAMPIONS
description: It was a five-ounce block of wood that was to be carved into a five-ounce racing car. I murmured aloud that it seemed a fairly impossible task. My little Scout replied: "Come on, Mom, all the fathers know how to do it. The derby is three days away, and we didn't even start on the car yet. All the others boys have theirs practically finished."

title:
Gardening;
ROCK WALLS: BEAUTY ENHANCED BY UTILITY
description: THE campus of my alma mater is noted for its quiet beauty, its towering century-old trees, spacious lawns and masses of flowering shrubs, all of which create a serene and relaxed environment conducive to studying. On warm spring days, students, as I remember, used to pop up here and there on the lawns, books spread on the grass before them, like so many spring flowers responding to the warmth of the sun.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times last Sunday about conservative appointments in the Reagan Administration misstated the period in which 150 people from a list of 450 campaign supporters and loyalists had been tapped for appointments. The selections took place in the last month.

title: PRESIDENT, VISITING NEW YORK, FREES AID FOR 2 CITY PROJECTS
description: President Reagan sampled some of the city's pleasures yesterday on his first visit since the inauguration and then reversed a freeze of Federal money for two of the city's cherished projects - rehabilitation of the Brooklyn Army Terminal and rebuilding of the Elgin Theater in the Chelsea section of Manhattan for local dance companies.

title: TOXIC DUMP FOUND IN UPPER FREEHOLD
description: UPPER FREEHOLD APPROXIMATELY 40 drums containing leaking hazardous substances have been discovered in a field behind a liquor store here. Investigators for the state's Department of Environmental Protection said last week that they had not yet determined if the substances, in the form of paints, lacquers and solvents, posed a threat to underground water supplies in the area or to surface waters.

title: Jones Prefers Farm To Grand Prix Grind
description: Alan Jones, the current Formula One world champion, is the son of a racing driver, but he doesn't want his 3-year-old son to become one. ''I'd rather that he was a farmer or something,'' said Jones. ''I think that I'd worry too much about him if he raced.'' Jones has recently become a farmer. He sold his large home in southern California, near Long Beach, where he is competing in today's United States Grand Prix West, and purchased a 1,500-acre farm outside his native Melbourne, Australia.

title: JAPAN PLANNING SPECIAL TANKERS FOR ARCTIC OIL RUN
description: The biggest names in Japanese shipbuilding are joining forces to construct revolutionary spertankers to carry oil from the Arctic Ocean.

title: INVESTIGATORS FEEL MANY KILLERS, SEPARATELY, SLEW ATLANTA CHILDREN
description: Law-enforcement officials and forensic scientists now theorize that fewer than half, and possibly only a handful, of the 20 black children who have been found slain here since July 1979 were victims of the same killer.

title: DEBATE STIRS OVER LEAD SHOT
description: THE death of thousands of Canada geese in a small area of east central Wisconsin this winter might trigger a general awareness that in many regions the problem of waterfowl's ingesting spent lead pellets is a real one.

title: Miss Andrews And a Broker Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stockton A. Andrews of Bar Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Douglas Andrews, to Timothy von Fuelling Straus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Straus Jr. of Boston. A June wedding is planned.

title: Practical Traveler; BOOKING AHEAD IN EUROPE'S SMALL HOTELS
description: A few years ago, making reservations at the small, charming and often inexpensive hotels that can make Europe such a delight to tour was beyond reach - unless one was on the spot or could reserve by mail. Getting a reply to a letter often took weeks, though, and letters often went unanswered.

title: Tragedy of East Timor
description: As one member of Congress who has long been concerned with the tremendous suffering that has occurred in East Timor, I found Henry Kamm's article ''The Silent Suffering of East Timor'' (Feb. 15) a fine essay on this sadly overlooked situation. Mr. Kamm has provided us all with needed information on this subject. But, however difficult the situation may now appear, it would compound this tragedy for the world to accept Indonesia's annexation of East Timor as final.

title: U.S. EDUCATION CHIEF DISARMS HIS CRITICS
description: For weeks, members of Congress, angered over proposed reductions in Federal aid to education, had been muttering, ''Just wait until we get Terrel Bell up here so we can tear into him.''

title:
Antiques;
ANNUAL SHOW IN OLD TOWN
description: WETHERSFIELD IN order to be successful, an antiques show must be managed in such a way that a special camaraderie exists between the exhibitors and the manager and, concomitantly, between that professional alliance and the sponsors of the show. When this kind of mutual admiration and respect is achieved, it is reflected in the attitude of those who attend the shows. Such a special glow of friendship among all concerned has long been part of the reputation of the Old Wethersfield antiques show, which this week will celebrate its 21st anniversary under the management of Betty Forbes.

title: HOUSES OUT OF PAST SERVE AS OFFICE PARK
description: At first glance the two handsome buildings on a hill south of Lyme appear to be simple Cape houses, one red, one cream. A closer look reveals that these houses are two among four restorations of early New England dwellings offering rental space as an office park.

title: LORDI IS EXPECTED TO RETIRE IN JULY AS GAMING COMMISSION HEAD
description: TRENTON COME July, and Joseph P. Lordi will complete his fourth year as the first and only chairman of the state's Casino Control Commission, testament to his staying power in the face of determined efforts by Governor Byrne to force him out more than a year ago.

title: GREAT SWAMP: REFUGE OR SEWER BASIN?
description: BASKING RIDGE IT WAS a late-winter sunny day, and a woodpecker perched on a tree outside the headquarters building of the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge while a male cardinal fluttered its wings on the ground below. Adjacent to the headquarters, a flock of plump Canada geese browsed lazily in a field of grain.

title: Deborah Richman Bride Of Stephen Val Arbogast
description: The marriage of Deborah Jean Richman, daughter of Mrs. Carl Tippenreiter of Matawan, N.J., and the late Alex Richman, to Stephen Val Arbogast, son of Mr. and Mrs. Valentine Arbogast Jr. of Jacksonville, Fla., took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Andrew J.W. Mullins.

title: No Headline
description: Relaxing, a 5-year-old mare, raced to a three-length victory over Irish Tower today in the $138,600 John B. Campbell Handicap, richest race ever run in the 67-year history of Bowie Race Course.

title: NOTHING BETTER THAN A GOOD FIGHT
description: BEGINNING TO SEE THE LIGHT Pieces of a Decade. By Ellen Willis. 320 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95. By ELINOR LANGER

title: PLANE HIJACKERS SURRENDER IN SYRIA, ENDING 13-DAY ORDEAL FOR HOSTAGES
description: Three hijackers who had been holding more than 100 hostages aboard a Pakistani jetliner surrendered tonight, ending a 13-day ordeal that began during a domestic flight over Pakistan.

title: Notes; AUTOMOBILE TRAVEL ON THE RISE?
description: More Americans are apparently yielding to the urge to get behind the wheel and take the family on an automobile trip despite the continuing rise in gasoline prices. The American Automobile Association reports that recreational auto travel in the fourth quarter of 1980 was up 9.5 percent over the same quarter of 1979.

title: THE SUPER SINGER
description: PAVAROTTI My Own Story. By Luciano Pavarotti with William Wright. Illustrated. 316 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95. BY STEPHEN WADSWORTH

title: Children's Books
description: EXTRAORDINARY STORIES BEHIND THE INVENTION OF ORDINARY THINGS By Don L. Wulffson. Illustrated by Roy Doty. 96 pp. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $6.95. (Ages 8 to 11) By JACQUELINE van ZANTEN

title: DOWNHILL RACER OVERCOMES THE FLATLANDS
description: CHAPPAQUA IN view of the fact that Westchester County has no lofty elevations resembling the Alps, let alone the modest-size Catskills, it comes as a surprise to many that Doug Powell, a determined, compactly built 23-year-old skier who lives in the Seven Bridges area of this community, is a key member of the United States World Cup downhill team.

title: HOME SELLERS DRAW BACK AS HIGH RATES CHILL MARKET
description: High mortgage rates and fewer listings of houses for sale are taking their toll on home selling in the metropolitan area, new figures suggest, but the picture is uneven depending on location.

title: IS IT FAIR TO LIMIT JAPANESE CARS?
description: The drive to limit imports of Japanese cars is heating up, and so is the rhetoric of protection. Old-fashioned jingoism has not worked: scare stories about a Foreign Menace seem downright absurd in 1981. But sophistic appeals to the American sense of fair play may, unfortunately, accomplish what flag-waving cannot. Consider these questions:

title: POLITICAL POT BOILING FOR LIVELY BATTLES IN BUFFALO
description: While critics of Mayor Koch search for a candidate to prevent the mayoral election in the nation's biggest city from being a one-man race, the liveliest 1981 election in New York may be shaping up at the other end of the state.

title: GUNS-AND-TAX CUTS MAY PROVE AS DIFFICULT A TRICK AS GUNS-AND-BUTTER
description: WASHINGTON THE three weeks of debate and analysis since President Reagan's address to a joint session of Congress Feb. 18 and the release of last week's 176-page budget document have brought into full focus the ambitiousness of the Adminstration's effort. It lies not just in the specific cuts proposed but the willingness to pursue so many major and potentially conflicting goals at once.

title: Putting It All Together; For the French Horn; by Peter G. Davis
description: Like so many musicians who give debut recitals in New York, William Purvis is scarcely an unfamiliar face on the local concert scene. His expertise on the French horn has been admired with such chamber groups as Speculum Musicae, the Orpheus Chamber Ensemble and the New York Woodwind Quintet, and so his concert Thursday night in the Abraham Goodman House with Robert McDonald at the piano seemed only a natural extension of his many musical activities.

title: BUSING BAN STANDS CALIFORNIA TEST
description: The dispute over desegregating Los Angeles' public schools, bitterly debated in and out of courtrooms for 18 years, took a decisive turn last week.

title: BECKONING LIGHT IN THE HOUSE OF LABOR
description: When the late George Meany stepped down as president of the A.F.L.- C.I.O., it seemed only a matter of time before the United Auto Workers, which quit the federation in 1968, would rejoin. Last week, the auto workers executive board, motivated in part by Ronald Reagan's presence in the White House and a sense of growing conservative clout on Capitol Hill, concluded that it was time for labor to circle up the wagons.

title: MOUNT VERNON TO GET PUBLIC-ACCESS PROGRAMS
description: I would like to clarify a point in the article "Cable TV: A Plus and Minuses" Feb. 8 regarding the demand for public-access programming in Mount Vernon. Contrary to the statement in the article, there is a strong interest in cable TV in Mount Vernon.

title: WITH ITS NEW ARENA, MEADLOWLANDS INFLUENCE IS STILL GROWING
description: By GERALD ESKENAZI EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. Looking east across the Meadowlands you see an angular white building, its stark lines surrounded by ministering equipment. The building blocks the view of all but the tallest towers of the New York City skyline. Blocked, too, is Madison Square Garden, perhaps the world's most famous arena.

title: ARMS EXPORTER FACES CHALLENGE
description: As the giant engineering and arms concern Steyr Daimler-Puch can testify, it is not easy being in the weapons-exporting business in neutral, Socialist-governed Austria.

title:
Gardening;
ROCK WALLS: BEAUTY ENHANCED BY UTILITY
description: THE campus of my alma mater is noted for its quiet beauty, its towering century-old trees, spacious lawns and masses of flowering shrubs, all of which create a serene and relaxed environment conducive to studying. On warm spring days, students, as I remember, used to pop up here and there on the lawns, books spread on the grass before them, like so many spring flowers responding to the warmth of the sun.

title: by Andrea Skinner
description: FRESH AS GARDEN FLOWERS The new summer clothes for children have been colored with the sunny brights and gentle pastels of a flower garden. But don't be fooled by the flowery hues, for there is nothing fragile about these clothes. Of sturdy cotton and blends, they are constructed to withstand romping and washing. sweet peas petunias forget-me-nots Saul Leiter Saul Leiter Saul Leiter spread one, left to right. In the pink. Far left: Striped seersucker teddy in polyester and cotton has handkerchief-finished bodice and lace-trimmed legs. By Janie Press. Sizes 2-4, $18; sizes 4-6x, $20. At Pat-Rick Children's Store, 930 Madison Avenue. Dottie Dolittle, San Francisco. Mignon, New Orleans. Near left: Plaid seersucker jumpsuit in cotton and polyester is smocked at yoke and ankles. By David Charles. Sizes 2-6, $42. At Bloomingdale's, second floor. Tuesday's Child, 1904 Avenue M, Brooklyn. The Purple Turtle, Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Dining Out; WHERE THE SIMPLE DISHES TRIUMPH
description: THE warmth of the welcome at Harrald's in Stormville is something you can count on. Particularly on weekdays, by a brisk fire in winter or in the breeze of the terrace in summer, you are likely to feel thoroughly cosseted by the excellent professional service, as a team of unobtrusive waiters keeps wine in your glass, brushes away your careless crumbs and replaces butter plates you may have used to share bites with companions. The presentation of the blackboard menu may in fact seem something too warm, infantilizing diners as they are painstakingly schooled in the deliciousness of this or that ingredient.

title: Numismatics; SOME AFTERSHOCKS FROM THE CC DOLLAR SALE; by Ed Reiter
description: Time heals all wounds they say, but the healing process may take longer than usual in the case of the U.S. Government's now-concluded ''Great Silver Sale'' of 19th century Carson City dollars. That's particularly true following the issuance of a report by a House of Representatives subcommittee which sharply criticizes the manner in which the sale was carried out.

title: Victim of Gunman Dies in Miami
description: A 19-year-old woman, shot twice after she sprayed Mace into the face of a gunman who had jumped into her car and demanded money, died yesterday, the police said. Clarivel Benitez died at a hospital just hours after she was shot in the chest.

title: Seaway Sections Open March 25
description: The 1981 navigation season on the St. Lawrence Seaway between Montreal and Lake Erie will begin on March 25, the second earliest season opening on record. The St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation and the St. Lawrence Seaway Authority of Canada said yesterday that the only earlier season start for the Montreal-Lake Ontario and Welland Canal sections was recorded last year, when the sections opened March 24.

title: Catherine Jane Ross and Jonathan Rieder, Assistant Professors at Yale, Are Married
description: Catherine Jane Ross, daughter of Alexander I. Ross, was married yesterday evening at the Yale Club, to Jonathan Rieder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fredric N. Rieder of Drexel Hill, Pa., and Margate, N.J. Rabbi Edward E. Klein of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, officiated.

title: Salisbury
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO LOW-COST WAYS OF GETTING CLOSE TO EUROPE'S GLORIES PITCHING YOUR TENT OF THE GROUNDS OF A FRENCH CHATEAU?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- KAREN LOHELA WOODWORTH is a writer and a French instructor at Ohio University. By KAREN LOHELA WOODWORTH

title: Art; A SHOW OF LATIN AMERICANS' WORK
description: NEW ROCHELLE THERE can be very few cities in the Northeast without a colony of Hispanics, and Spanish is beyond doubt the second language of greater New York. Yet, for a group that brings with it so distinctive a style and whose ancestors were among the first to explore North America as well as South, its effect on the culture has been slight, except in the Southwestern United States.

title: Camera; PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS; by Morgan Luciana Danner
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Morgan Luciana Danner is a freelance photographer and writer. If you are a serious photographer -or even a photography student - who is interested in getting involved in the photography business as a full-time or part-time photographer, then chances are you will benefit greatly from becoming affiliated with one of the many professional photographic organizations that are active in this field.

title: Other Business; GROUNDSCRAPERS
description: Who should be rooting around in the underground economy but the Control Data Corporation - not, it should be emphasized, the murky world of tax evasion, but the one where the worms are.

title: PHILADELPHIAN INSPIRES SEA OF GREEN RIBBONS FOR ATLANTA'S VICTIMS
description: Georgia Dean, a retired Philadelphia factory worker, was watching the return of the American hostages from Iran on television last January when she began to wonder why people were not just as concerned about the murdered and missing children of Atlanta.

title: Susan Halpern Is Bride of Bruce Jacobson, Law Student
description: Susan Carol Halpern, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Joseph Halpern of East Meadow, L. I., was married last evening to Bruce J. Jacobson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Jacobson of East Hills, L. I. Rabbi Norman Kahane performed the ceremony at the Engineers Country Club in Roslyn Harbor, L. I.

title: L.I.U.  Is Proud In Defeat
description: Villanova has slipped into Long Island University's Cinderella role, now that the Blackbirds have been eliminated from the National Collegiate East Regionals. Long Island was beaten by Virginia Commonwealth, 85-69, in the opening round last night, then Villanova defeated Houston, 90-72.

title: REAGAN DAIRY PRICE BILL OPPOSED BY IOWA FARMERS
description: Keith Kerr and Earl Baudler are dairy farmers from Iowa. Last fall both men voted for Ronald Reagan, but this week they were in Washington to lobby against one of the President's first economic proposals: to delay a scheduled increase in dairy price supports.

title: CAREY BILL THREATENS COURT REPORTER FEES
description: MINEOLA COURT stenographers, who for decades have sat quietly in state and county courtrooms taking down every word without comment, are angrily speaking out against a budget proposal by Governor Carey that could drastically change their lives.

title: Jonestown Documentary On Public Radio April 23
description: ''Father Cares: The Last of Jonestown,'' a 90-minute documentary based on tapes of Jim Jones and his People's Temple followers, 913 of whom committed mass suicide and murder in Guyana on Nov. 18, 1978, will be broadcast by National Public Radio on April 23 at 9 P.M.

title: THE PRODUCT'S TEST IS IN THE KITCHEN
description: WHITE PLAINS IMAGINE consuming two strips of bacon, four spoonfuls of creamy salad dressing, a few slivers of frozen yogurt pie and several sips of diet lemonade. For Peggy Kohl, that was breakfast one recent morning.

title: Television Week
description: Living in the Present Children faced with life-threatening diseases learn to develop a positive outlook at the Center for Attitudinal Hearing in Tiburon, Calif., founded in 1975 by Gerald G. Jampolsky, a psychiatrist. ''We define health as inner peace,'' Dr. Jampolsky says. ''Healing is when you know how to let go of fear. The kids help each other let go of fear, and let go of yesterday and tomorrow.'' At the center, which is free, they learn to value the moment, and they do this, he explains, through love.

title: SOME LESSONS FROM THE BBC
description: The Museum of Modern Art's ''A Salute to the BBC,'' which begins tomorrow at noon and runs through Tuesday, March 24, is a stunning reminder that the best of British television has the disconcerting ability to leave American broadcasters clinging to their tired formulas with increasing defensiveness. It isn't that the overall British television picture is better than its counterpart in this country; in the great middle programming area of weekly situation comedy, action adventure and soap opera, the American product is, in the best sense, slicker and livelier. Even the British public agrees: witness the enormous success in England of series such as ''Kojak'' and ''Dallas.''

title: U.S. PUBLISHERS INVITED TO SOVIET FAIR
description: Three high-level members of a Soviet publishing and copyright delegation have arrived in New York on a good-will mission to encourage American publishers to attend the third international book fair opening in Moscow next Sept. 2. A fourth member, Vadim Dunin, was denied a visa by the State Department.

title:
Art;
'REFUSES' SHARE SPOTLIGHT WITH 'SALON'
description: HUNTINGTON IN 1863, when the official French Salon rejected the entries of all the most innovative modern artists, a separate show of the rejected works was set up as a consolation prize. This celebrated ''Salon des Refuses'' has naturally enough become a paragon to artists who feel excluded from the regular selection processes that characterize the juried and invitational exhibitions that have taken the place of the academic salon in the minds of many.

title: WAVES ARE EYED FOR SANDS OF TIME
description: A LONE beachcomber gazing out at the waters of Long Island Sound may not seem like much of a scientific study. But watching the waves - measuring their height, their speed and the angle at which they hit the beach - is basic to an evaluation of erosion along the shoreline, according to Prof. Henry Bokuniewicz of the Marine Science Research Center at the State University at Stony Brook.

title: OSCAR JUNQUERA TO MARRY AMELIA DEL ROSARIO FELIX
description: Beatriz de Felix of New York and Madrid has announced the engagement of her daughter, Amelia del Rosario Felix, to Oscar J. Junquera of New York, an investment banker with Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. Miss Felix, an assistant with Wyse Advertising, and her fiance plan to be married May 16 in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: Miss Aloi Engaged To David Rivkin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Aloi of Brockton, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marilyn Frances Aloi, to David Wolfe Rivkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Rivkin of New York. A September wedding is planned at the Dwight Memorial Chapel of Yale University.

title: Home Clinic; HOW TO KEEP CLEAR HOUSEHOLD PLASTIC LOOKING BRIGHT
description: CLEAR acrylic plastic (Plexiglas and Lucite are two well-known brand names) is widely used in homes these days for many decorative accessories, as well as for storm doors, storm sashes, basement windows and similar openings where glass may pose a hazard.

title: Russian Wins Giant Slalom
description: Aleksandr Zhirov of the Soviet Union won a World Cup giant slalom ski race today. Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden finished third, but lost no ground in his bid for the overall cup title.

title: Dining Out; AN EMPHASIS ON NOUVELLE CUISINE
description: COS COB JARDINE'S, a new restaurant in Cos Cob, advertises ''elegant waterfront dining,'' and the multi-windowed, two-tiered interior facing the Mianus River is attractive. The ground floor dining room is a stylish and comfortable combination of polished brass railings, big picture windows and dark wood-paneled walls. Large sculptural plants, strategically placed, embellish configurations that give considerable privacy. A large bar, really a step-down ''conversation pit,'' is next to, but separated from, the dining area, with sound containment that keeps the bar chatter from reverberating through the dining space. Up a winding staircase, the second floor is also pleasing, though some patrons might not appreciate the disco-type flashing lights that are really not in keeping with the rest of the decor.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Subways Are for Politics as New Fare Debate Opens
description: Transit deadlines, like transit promises, seem made to be broken. Governor Carey found that out last week when a deadline he set came and went, leaving his plan to build Westway, rebuild the city's transit system and guarantee a ''fair fare'' for mass transit riders very much up in the air.

title: FINDING NEW VALUE IN OLD PAPER
description: They treasure trash and trivia and call themselves ephemerists. Virtually any form of printed paper made to be used and then thrown away is what they collect. And that includes theater programs, travel brochures, flyers, tickets, postcards, posters, labels, bills, receipts, stock and bond certificates, trade catalogues, broadsides, playing cards, shopping bags, and Valentines. Even stamps qualify, but ephemerists do not usually mention these collectibles because stamp buffs rarely become involved in other paper collectibles.

title: DOWN THE COLORADO: SEEING THE CANYON FROM A DORY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- MARY OERTEL-KIRSCHNER is a writer based in Albuquerque, N.M. By MARY OERTEL-KIRSCHNER

title: LORRAINE LAZARUS, ACTRESS, FIANCEE OF JONATHAN WEISS
description: Lorraine Robin Lazarus, an actress appearing in California in the national touring company of "Camelot," and Jonathan David Weiss, stage manager of the production, plan to be married in October in New York.

title: Stage View; A SERIOUS, SOBERING DISAPPOINTMENT; by Walter Kerr
description: Have you ever tried to explain the plot of ''The Seagull'' to someone who is perfectly sane? I'm sure you had your work cut out for you. Well, have you ever tried to explain Chekhov's play to a madman? That is what actor James Woods feels obliged to do in Percy Granger's ''Vivien,'' now on a triple bill of one-acters at the Lincoln Center's Mitzi E. Newhouse, and Mr. Woods's desperation is as amusing as it is real. It is, in fact, despair doubled. For it is perfectly plain that he has abandoned all hope of ever communicating Chekhov's complexities to his unstable companion. And, having been forced to chart those complexities anew for himself, he has almost given up on ''The Seagull'' as well.

title: New York Times Magazine March 15, 1981
description: William Safire 8 On Language Taking It Neat Russell Baker 17 Sunday Observer Riches of the Tube Sidney Blumenthal 22 David Stockman: The President's Cutting Edge Marshall Ledger 26 The Ascent of Adrian Malone D.C. Denison 40 Polo Makes a Galloping Comeback Wade Greene 45 Rethinking the Unthinkable After more than a decade during which the idea was all but dismissed, the possibility of nuclear war is again on many people's minds. Some strategists believe it's an option that must not be ruled out - indeed, that such a war can be won. Others fear the entire world will lose.
