Craig Claiborne 86 Food with Pierre Franey Taming Wild Rice 109 Puzzles Answers, Page 92 110 Letters Cover: Photograph by Harry Benson Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: JAZZ: BOBBY ROSENGARDEN LEADS HIS ALL-STARS AT RAINBOW ROOM
description: the nine-piece ensemble that Bobby Rosengarden is leading at the Rainbow Room through next Sunday is an all-star variation of the groups he has brought to the room in recent years. It includes the clarinetist Kenny Davern, who rarely works as a sideman any more and has sworn that he would never play baritone saxophone again.

title: A CLOSE-UP VIEW OF THE STRUGGLE IN EL SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a computation error by the Federal Economic Development Administration, an article in Metropolitan Report last Tuesday incorrectly reported the status of a loan guarantee sought by the Beattie Manufacturing Company of Keansburg, N.J. The guarantee was approved.

title: Former Navy Secretary To Be Envoy to O.A.S.
description: President Reagan has nominated a former Secretary of the Navy, J. William Middendorf, as the United States representative to the Organization of American States.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Crown Zellerbach, San Francisco, elected George L. Pearson senior vice president with general management responsibility for the company's United States timber and wood products operations.

title: International
description: Britain's economy is likely to move deeper into recession as a result of the Government's budget proposals, some bankers and economists fear. Many expect industrial output to decline as much as 3 percent this year, while the number of unemployed persons could approach three million. (Page D1.)

title: Washington Watch; Rents as Gauge Of Housing Cost
description: WASHINGTON SOME $200 billion of Federal spending is now indexed to the Consumer Price Index, meaning that when the inflation indicator rises, outlays for Social Security, Federal retirement, veterans benefits and other income-transfer programs also increase.

title: Jones Captures Coast Grand Prix
description: Alan Jones of Australia opened the defense of his Formula One world auto-racing championship by winning the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach today.

title: PARIS OPERA'S LEFORT: HARD MAN, HARD JOB
description: PARIS THE Palais Garnier, home of the Paris Opera, is constructed on the opposite principle from the egg. In a maximum of volume, it encloses a minimum of producing capacity.

title: REAGAN CUTS SAID TO IMPERIL NORTHEAST RAIL PROJECT GAINS
description: Despite the expenditure of more than $2 billion to modernize the Northeast rail corridor, connecting Washington, New York and Boston, passenger train schedules on that route are likely to show little or no improvement by late 1984 if Congress approves the Administration's proposed cuts in the project, according to government figures.

title: What Comes of Trucking With Teamsters
description: The President promises to get Government off our backs. But not every friend of Ronald Reagan seeks such relief. ''We want someone who does not have a maniacal devotion to the free market,'' said one Teamster offical in promoting his union's choice for chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission. And the Teamsters, the only powerful union that campaigned for Mr. Reagan, may well get its way.

title: Red Smith; The Pressure On Cerone
description: Fla. REPLYING to a question here a year ago, Rick Cerone said he was asked about the pressure of succeeding the late Thurman Munson about five times a day, on the average. However, Dick Howser, the Yankees' manager then, said the heaviest burden the young catcher would have to bear would come from his hometown fans from Newark. ''They'll all expect him to know them by name,'' Howser said, ''and stop and talk with them and give autographs.''

title: A YEAR LATER, KIDNAPPING VICTIM IS TRULY AT HOME
description: Steve Stayner, a quiet boy who spent half of his life as a kidnapping victim, is now just another teenager with grade problems, a steady girl and dreams of playing high school baseball.

title: Pointing to the Top
description: When a 16-year-old freshman showed up for the fencing team at Baruch College in 1978 and earned a trip to the National Collegiate finals, that was something. But when a 35-year-old freshman teammate equaled the teen-ager's success that same year, that was something else.

title: Brown Still Pondering Nets' Job
description: Larry Brown, who is still the basketball coach at U.C.L.A., had 11 hours on the trip home to Los Angeles Saturday night to ponder his future. The Bruins had lost, 78-55, to Brigham Young at Providence, R.I., in the National Collegiate East Regional tournament and then had taken a bus to Boston for a transcontinental flight.

title: New Tuskegee President
description: Benjamin F. Payton, a 48-year-old program officer at the Ford Foundation, has been named president of the Tuskegee Institute in Alabama. Mr. Payton, who takes over on Aug. 1 as the school's fifth president, will succeed Luther H. Foster, who is retiring after 28 years as head of the predominantly black college, which was founded by Booker T. Washington 100 years ago this year.

title: Notes on the U.N.
description: Nearly one woman in four working at the United Nations says she has been sexually harassed, pursued for sexual favors in return for a promotion or some other job benefit. This, at least, is the finding of a survey conducted by a team of activists here, the Ad Hoc Group on Equal Rights for Women.Some 144 women replied to a questionnaire put out by the group and 32 said they had been victimized by approaches from their superiors and others. Lower-ranking women are particularly vulnerable since many are in the United States on alien visas that permit them to stay in the country only if they work at the United Nations.

title: Economists See A Budget Snag
description: The Shadow Open Market Committee, a private group of economic forecasters, asserted yesterday that a slowing of inflation would cut tax revenues, leaving a Federal deficit that would prevent the balanced budget sought in 1984.

title: Soft-Coal Talks Resume; Union Deadline Approaches
description: With most major contract issues still outstanding and an informal strike union deadline approaching, talks between the United Mine Workers of America and the Bituminous Coal Operators Association resumed this morning.

title: STAGE: 'BROADWAY FOLLIES' OPENS AT THE NEDERLANDER
description: P. T. BARNUM would have blushed at the flimflammery of ''Broadway Follies,'' a small brash vaudeville show that opened last night at the Nederlander Theater. The title tune labels the evening an ''extravaganzicle,'' which elasticizes the English language and leaves the show open to charges from a Bureau of Standards and Practices. The producers have searched the globe for top-flight variety talent and have come up with, as headliners, the Ken and Barbie dolls of pantomimists and a supporting cast that features six boxer dogs chasing balloons and wrestling with a roly-poly woman.

title: Two Contenders For Mem Account
description: The Mem Company has been looking for a new agency for its English Leather men's fragrances to replace Norman, Craig & Kummel.

title: LARGER STRUCTURES ON CITY'S WEST SIDE PROPOSED BY PANEL
description: A long-awaited report by a panel of architects on how to reshape construction in midtown Manhattan has proposed allowing buildings on the West Side to be a third larger than the biggest towers now permitted in most of the city.

title: Nyerere Says Tanzania Is Facing Major Famine
description: President Julius K. Nyerere says the East African drought has pushed Tanzania to the brink of ''a serious famine,'' but he does not know where his impoverished Government will get the money to feed the millions who may face starvation.

title: News Analysis
description: The State Department made every effort yesterday to avoid saying that a group of high-ranking South African military officers, including the army's chief of staff for intelligence, had been expelled from the United States for misrepresenting themselves and their mission when they applied for their visas.

title: Spreading Quantas's Word
description: Cunningham & Walsh/San Francisco, which already does the United States advertising for Qantas, the Australian Airline, has also been picked to do the ads in Britain and Europe. The actual servicing of the account on a day-to-day basis by Redheads Advertising, the American agency's English affiliate.

title: Patty Hayes Wins
description: Patty Hayes shot a four-under-par 69 today to capture the $100,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Sun City Classic by two strokes over Sandra Palmer.

title: Market Place; Oil Companies' Mineral Offers
description: THE sudden rush by major oil companies to acquire mineral producers seems likely to continue, according to analysts. That's good news for investors. Prices of the shares of Amax Inc., the St. Joe Minerals Corporation and the Kennecott Corporation have nearly doubled since it became known that these companies are takeover targets.

title: Michigan Downs Toledo in N.I.T.
description: Mike McGee and Johnny Johnson led a second-half drive that carried Michigan to an 80-68 victory over Toledo in the second round of the National Invitation Tournament today.

title: FAREWELL, PUBLIC TELEVISION; by William Safire
description: Taxpayer-supported television is an idea whose time has come and gone. The handwriting is on the screen: David Stockman, the President's blow-dried Grim Reaper, has notified the Corporation for Public Broadcasting that the Reagan Administration wants to reduce its subsidy by 25 percent, or $43 million.

title: Japan-Indonesia Gas Pact
description: Four Japanese utility companies said Friday that they had agreed with the Indonesian state-owned Pertamina Oil and Gas Corporation to buy 3.2 million tons of liquefied natural gas a year for 20 years, beginning in 1983. The companies include Chubu Electric Power, Kansai Electric Power, Toho Gas and Osaka Gas. The statement gave no details of pricing, but said formal signing of the agreement will take place in Jakarta in early April.

title: RECORD NUMBER ASK GUN PERMITS IN NEW YORK CITY
description: In the seven months since the New York State Legislature enacted a tougher handgun law, a record number of New York City residents have applied for licenses to own guns - for their homes and businesses, for target shooting or to carry on the street.

title: CONGRESSIONAL INQUIRY FINDS ALIENS GETTING FEDERAL SUBSIDIES FOR RENTS
description: Preliminary inquiries by Congressional investigators strongly suggest that substantial numbers of illegal aliens receive Federal housing subsidies while hundreds of thousands of citizens wait months or years for similar assistance.

title: AFTER 105 YEARS OF CANDY MAKING, BANKRUPTCY FOR DETROIT INSTITUTION
description: This city has felt the brunt of the nation's current economic woes perhaps more than any other metropolitan area in the United States. It is not just the automobile companies that are suffering hard times in the Motor City. Even the candy store is in danger of going broke.

title: A.T .& T. ISSUE LEADS WEEK'S CORPORATE LIST
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is this week's largest issuer of new corporate debt. A.T.& T.'s notes are expected to yield more than the 12.70 percent that was available late Friday on 13 percent Treasury notes due in 1990.

title: OR, WHO DID IN MISS SMIT
description: They discovered a body here this chilly Ides of March weekend in a rambling turn-of-the-century hotel on a remote mountaintop in the foothills of the Catskills where 300 mystery buffs had gathered.

title: TO RESUSCITATE THE SUBWAYS
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELIS FORM PARTY TO URGE WEST BANK WITHDRAWAL
description: A small group of Israelis associated with the Peace Now movement announced the formation today of a political party to press for Israeli disengagement from the occupied West Bank.

title: Anastasio Wins Run
description: Bob Anastasio, former all-American at Cornell, won the Manufacturers Hanover five-mile Bronx challenge run yesterday through the streets of Riverdale in 24 minutes 36.4 seconds.

title: A NONLYRICAL VIEW OF THE IRISH TROUBLES
description: With a shy smile and a steady glance, P.J. McClean came into the kitchen and said hello. As an Irishman visiting from the North, from County Tyrone, he had been invited to the friendly house here on Ogden Street to talk of his country's endless troubles before some of this city's unofficial human rights community. As it turned out, they told him of troubles of their own.

title: KUYKEN QUARTET MARKS TELEMANN'S TERCENTENARY
description: Last Saturday was George Philipp Teleman's 300th birthday, a fact not lost on the Kuyken Quartet, which devoted its entire program to Telemann's music Saturday night at the Metropolitan Museaum of Art's Grace Rainey Rogers a Auditorium.The group could give only a sampling of the industrious composer's huge output in every Baroque form imaginable, but at least the chamber music was well represented.

title: Bridge: Sontag Takes New Tack By Signing With the Aces
description: One of the country's finest players is taking a new tack this year in more than one respect. Alan Sontag of New York, with his regular partner, Peter Weichsel, also of New York, has joined the Aces team. They will team with Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman of Dallas, Fred Hamilton of Los Angeles and Ira Rubin of Paramus, N.J.

title: Study Points to Wiring As Source of Chicago Fire
description: Bomb and arson squad officials said today that a preliminary investigation showed the hotel fire that killed 19 persons and injured 14 others was caused by faulty electrical wiring in the basement laundry room.

title: WANTING CHILDREN: FACTORS INVOLVED
description: FOR the last four years, Mary-Joan Gerson, a clinical psychologist at the New School for Social Research, has been plumbing the female psyche, seeking to find out what kind of woman wants or does not want children today.

title: LIBYA EXPLAINS BALKING IN HIJACKING
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said today that his nation had turned back a plane carrying prisoners who had been released in exchange for hostages held by hijackers because it did not know enough about the incident.

title: Georgia Halts Payments For Most Abortions
description: The Georgia Department of Medical Assistance has eliminated state payments for abortions as of today except in cases in which the mother's life is endangered or for victims of rape or incest.

title: CONNECTICUT PENSION FUND WILL PROVIDE MORTGAGES
description: Starting next month, Connecticut will invest $25 million of the pension fund for its state employees and teachers in what state officials call a ''socially responsible'' new venture - home mortgages.

title: Fire Ruins S.I. Car Dealership
description: A three-alarm fire that burned out of control for nearly two hours destroyed an automobile dealership on Staten Island last night, the Fire Department said. The blaze caused the collapse of a section of the roof of the one-story brick building of Island Chevrolet, at 1316 Castleton Avenue. No injuries were reported.

title: Pope Asks Tolerance of Trips
description: Pope John Paul II asked Romans today to be understanding of his frequent trips outside the Vatican because he must carry out his ''pastoral service'' to all Roman Catholics. The Pope also told a crowd of 50,000 gathered in St. Peter's Square of his plans to celebrate mass on Thursday for the workers at Terni in central Italy.

title: COLLEGES IN MICHIGAN CUT PROGRAMS AND INSTRUCTORS
description: While hard times and high unemployment are pushing record numbers of young people onto the state campuses in Michigan, economic problems are forcing the state's 13 public universities and colleges to dismiss faculty members, eliminate entire programs and even to reduce enrollments.

title: PHILIPPINES CULTIVATES FRUIT AS SOURCE OF FUEL
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos has ordered the immediate propagation throughout the Philippines of a tall tree bearing fruit somewhat bigger than a golf ball whose orange pulp, when pressed, yields a sticky oil that some experts say is an alternate fuel source.

title: MILITARY HORSE OR CART
description: The big new defense budget has been delivered to Congress and studies are now under way for early decisions on major new weapons systems.

title: No Headline
description: REPUTED PHILADELPHIA CRIME FIGURE IS KILLED BY EXPLOSION AT HIS HOME

title: MERGER BIDS QUICKEN THE PACE ON WALL ST.
description: At lunchtime on Friday, outside the members' entrance to the New York Stock Exchange on Broad Street, there was a line to get a Mister Softee ice cream cone and a line to get a frankfurter, but no wait to get your blood pressure checked for free in the Seventh Day Adventists' van.

title: ZIA CALLS HIJACKING PART OF CONSPIRACY
description: Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, tonight called the 13-day hijacking of a Pakistani airliner part of a conspiracy to turn Pakistan from its Islamic path and warned opposition politicians that he would crush ''anti-state elements.''

title: THE CHILDHOOD 'INDUSTRY': CONFLICTING ADVICE
description: Peter Bergson, father of two, described his immense frustration as he found himself hurling the book on how to be a parent across the bedroom one night awhile ago. He said, ''I was thinking, 'It's impossible! I just can't remember all this stuff!' Sure, I felt better for throwing it, but it's still confusing for a parent to separate the fads from the valid approaches.

title: Kentucky, Wake Forest Upset; Boston College Gains in Mideast
description: Glenn Marcus sank 12 free throws in the final five and a half minutes today to give Alabama-Birmingham a 69-62 upset of Kentucky in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Mideast Regional.

title: RICHARD COOPER IS NAMED PRESIDENT OF WILSON FUND
description: Richard W. Couper, the first president of the New York Public Library, who is leaving his post in May, will become president of the 36-year-old Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation. Mr. Couper announced last year that he would resign in 1981 after 10 years as the library's chief executive.

title: Most Alabama Counties Under Forest Fire Alert
description: Nearly 41 of Alabama's 67 counties were under a fire alert today after 227 forest fires scorched more than 12,000 acres over the weekend, state officials said.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Into the fairly static yet highly competitive motor oil market, the Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation, the leader, is adding a new ingredient: a lifetime warranty.

title: A Historic Exchange
description: IT'S only a spring training exhibition game, but for the first time in major league history, two black managers will exchange lineup cards today when Frank Robinson of the San Francisco Giants and Maury Wills of the Seattle Mariners meet with the umpires at home plate. If this is a footnote to baseball's belated sociological progress, it's also a tribute to the two managers' patience and persistence.

title: A New Product From Standard Brands
description: Inside Standard Brands there are many products, perhaps one of the best known of which is Chase & Sanborn Coffee, which was closely associated with some of the great personalities of the Golden Age of radio.

title: Mets Top Cards, 11-7
description: Like the big horse kept in the barn on race day, Bruce Sutter stayed in the dugout today while five other pitchers for the St. Louis Cardinals were taking an 11-7 pounding from the New York Mets.

title: FLOYD REPELS GRAHAM IN DORAL
description: Ray Floyd shot four-under-par 68 today to hold off David Graham and win the Doral open golf tournament for the second straight year.

title: U.S. IS SEEKING TO IDENTIFY A MAN ON THE HIJACKED JET
description: Officials at the State Department said last night that they were trying to determine whether a former hostage on a hijacked Pakistani airliner was a Canadian traveling on a false United States passport instead of an American as he was originally identified. The officials also said that the passport of another man, an American under indictment on heroin-smuggling charges in New York City, was revoked by the department.

title: Allen Products President
description: Joseph Sestak, 48, has been appointed president of the Allen Products Company, a subsidiary of the Liggett Group. He succeeds James W. Murray, 51, whom the company said was looking into another business opportunity.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Is there such a thing as a 1-point safety in college football?

title: Ursinus Tops Upsala
description: Ursinus upset Upsala, 71-69, last night to move into the final four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III basketball championships against Potsdam State, set for next weekend in Rock Island, Ill. Upsala, which finished at 23-6, was hurt by a technical foul called in the last minute when its fans threw debris on the court.

title: City Will Get a Chance To Voice Budget Views
description: New York City's Director of the Budget, James R. Brigham, will present the city's objections to the Reagan Administration's proposed budget cuts at a meeting in Washington this week, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: SOVIET JEWISH ACTIVIST IS WARNED TO STOP HER SEMINARS
description: Irina Brailovsky, wife of the jailed Jewish activist Viktor Brailovsky, said today that she had been threatened with expulsion from Moscow if she continued using her apartment as a gathering place for Jews who have been refused exit visas for Israel.

title: Ads Are Adjusted In 6 of 10 Inquiries
description: The investigations of six of the 10 claims that came before the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus were resolved when the advertisers changed the claims or discontinued the contested advertising for one reason or another. In the other four cases the advertisers substantiated their claims.

title: TOM WEISKOPF, AT 38, IS STILL REACHING FOR HIS POTENTIAL IN GOLF
description: MIAMI ''WHEN I joined the pro tour as a regular in 1965,'' Tom Weiskopf said, ''I knew it would be tough, I was 22 years old and all I wanted to do was stay alive.''

title: Yarborough Takes Atlanta 500 Race
description: Cale Yarborough took advantage of engine troubles that knocked out most of the strong cars today and scored an easy victory in the Atlanta 500 stock-car race today.

title: Susan Schraub, Editor, Bride of James Dubin, Lawyer
description: At the Westchester Jewish Center in Mamaroneck, N.Y., yesterday, Susan Hope Schraub, features editor of Harper's Bazaar magazine, was married to James Michael Dubin, an associate with the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. Rabbi Irving Koslowe officiated.

title: Commodities; The Plight Of Small Speculators
description: IF experience holds, most small commodity-futures traders will not dread the April 15 tax deadline because they will not have any gains to report. In fact, about 90 percent of them again will show losses. The only difference this year will be that the losses they report will be much larger than those of previous tax years.

title: MICHAEL BUXBAUM WEDS MISS GRAEBER
description: Laurel Sheldon Graeber, daughter of Mrs.Rowland P.Graeber of Syracuse, and the late Dr.Graeber, was married yesterday in New Haven to Michael Alan Buxbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs.Martin Buxbaum of Hamden, Conn. Rabbi Charles Davidson performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's brother, Barry Buxbaum.

title: Bethany Nazarene N.A.I.A. Champion
description: Todd Thurman scored 5 of his 39 points in overtime last night as he led Bethany Nazarene of Oklahoma to an 86-85 victory over Alabama-Huntsville for the championship of the 44th N.A.I.A. basketball tournament.

title: A Second I.R.A. Prisoner Begins Hunger Fast for Political Status
description: Frank Hughes, a convicted Irish Republican Army gunman, began a hunger strike today, joining another jailed guerrilla in Northern Ireland's Maze Prison fasting for political status, prison officials said.

title: FEDERATED EXPANSION IN CHICAGO
description: Bloomingdale's, whose efforts to enter the Chicago market have been frustrated for months because of opposition from Marshall Field & Company, that city's largest department-store chain, may be closing in on its goal.

title: EQUAL RIGHTS LEADERS SHIFT PLANS FOR SURVIVING CONSERVATIVE TIDE
description: Even the most ardent supporters of the proposed equal rights amendment to the Federal Constitution are conceding that there is little chance this year of adding to the 35 states that have ratified the measure.

title: Spanish Police Disperse 1,000 Basque Separatists
description: Policemen firing rubber bullets and tear gas today dispersed a crowd of 1,000 demonstrators shouting slogans in support of the Basque separatist group E.T.A. No injuries or arrests were reported.

title: KNICKS USE BACKCOURT, BEAT 76ERS BY 120-109
description: With Michael Ray Richardson and Ray Williams at their best, Campy Russell on target with long jump shots and Marvin Webster playing intimidating defense, the Knicks beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 120-109, yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Polish Strike Still Planned, Although 2 Officials Resign
description: Union leaders in the Polish industrial city of Radom went ahead today with plans for a two-hour strike on Wednesday despite the resignations of the local governor and the regional party leader.

title: ELSIE DUGLIN IS MARRIED
description: Elise Susan Duglin, daughter of Mrs.Gordon H. Harris of Tenafly,N.J. was married yesterday at the White Beeches Golf and Country Club in Haworth, N.J., to Joseph L. Steinfeld Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Steinfeld of New York. Rabbi Stephen Pinsky performed the ceremony. The bride is an associate broker with the stockbrokerage firm of Johnston & Lehman Associates in Washington, where Mr. Steinfeld, a lawyer, is with the law offices of Eric Meierhoefer.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BRITISH,YOU KNOW

title: TV: DONAHUE WILL KIDS FACING DEATH
description: TV series of periodic prime-time specials for young people, turns this evening to Phil Donahue and the distinctive talk-show format he has developed into a multimilliondollar business. ''Donahue and Kids'' will be broadcast at 8 o'clock.

title: MINERAL TAKEOVERS CRITICIZED
description: For the nation's big oil companies, it has been quite a shopping spree. In little more than a week, the Standard Oil Company of Califonia has offered to buy Amax Inc. for $4 billion, the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) has agreed to buy the Kennecott Corporation for $1.77 billion and Joseph E. Seagram & Sons is trying to buy the St. Joe Minerals Corporation with $2 billion of the money it made selling its oil assets last year.

title: PAKISTAN AIDE LAUDS ACTIONS OF SYRIANS IN ENDING HIJACKING
description: A Pakistani Defense Ministry official, hailing Syria's role in ending a 13-day airline hijacking, said today that it was up to Syria to decide what to do with the three men who commandeered a Pakistan International Airlines jet with more than 100 passengers aboard and killed a Pakistani diplomat. The hijackers surrendered here last night.

title: PROBLEMS PERSIST FOR PAN AM
description: The long travail of Pan American World Airways continues, although the carrier's management says that a recovery is in sight. In addition to labor and logistical difficulties stemming from its merger last year with National Airlines and the industry-wide problems of lagging passenger traffic and rising fuel costs that led to its $130 million loss in 1980, Pan Am has been losing passengers to competing airlines, according to the latest passenger traffic statistics.

title: 10 of 11 Who Fled Boys' Home Retaken
description: One youth remained at large following an escape by 11 juveniles who overpowered supervisors at the Passaic County Juvenile Detention Center, authorities said.

title: HARRIS ROSENBAUM
description: Harris Rosenbaum, co-founder of the Milford, Conn., Academy and a teacher and administrator at the institution for almost six decades, died Saturday after a brief illness. Mr. Rosenbaum, a longtime resident of Milford, was 94 years old.

title: 3 KILLED IN INDIAN CASTE VIOLENCE
description: New Delhim March 15 (Reuters) Three young people were killed and four seriously wounded today when the police opened fire to stop caste violence in Ahmadebad, the Press Trust of India reported. About 135 people were arrested, it killed in Ahmedabad and other parts of Gujart state in western India in two months of unrest over reservation of medical college seats for harijans, sometimes called untouchables, and others.

title: 850,000 BUTTERFLY SPECIMENS PLEDGED TO UNIVERSITY OF FLORIDA
description: One of the largest private butterfly collections in the Western Hemisphere, one that had been coveted by several American museums, has been donated to the University of Florida in Gainesville, university officials have announced.

title: Connors Wins Final, Defeating Gottfried
description: Jimmy Connors won the $175,000 Belgian indoor tennis championship today with a 6-2, 6-4, 6-3 victory over Brian Gottfried.

title: China Assails Soviet Offer Of Summit Talks With U.S.
description: China today dismissed the Soviet Union's offer to hold a summit meeting with the United States and other proposals for easing tensions as ''mere propaganda stunts'' and applauded President Reagan's ''firmer'' policy toward Moscow.

title: Genentech Has Cattle Hormone
description: Genentech Inc., and the Monsanto Company of St. Louis said Friday that they had succeeded in producing a natural hormone that promoted meat and milk growth in cattle by means of recombinant DNA technology.

title: CAREY URGES FRUCHER TO 'PUSH ON' FOR POST DESPITE FOES IN SENATE
description: Governor Carey has turned down an offer by his nominee for New York State Industrial Commissioner, Meyer S. Frucher, to withdraw his name from consideration by the Legislature.

title: MILITARY PERVADING TURKEY'S CIVIL LIFE
description: Turkey's military men, who assumed power last September to restore law and order, are trying to bring stricter discipline into Turkish life.

title: BUILDING ACTIVITY GAINS IN MONTREAL
description: Building cranes have begun to fill the Montreal skyline again, and with their return has come a new optimism about the future of French Canada's most important urban center.

title: A MEDITERRANEAN FORCE IN AEROSPACE
description: In aircraft hangers sprawled over a 475-acre site adjacent to the Tanagra air base, 38 miles north of Athens, Hellenic Aerospace Industry is repairing or modifying jets and missiles of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as well as commercial planes from a long list of countries.

title: World Bank Resignation
description: Colbert King, who was appointed by President Carter as the American executive director at the World Bank, resigned Friday before being replaced by President Reagan. As one of five executive directors at the bank, which specializes in multilateral loans for international reconstruction and development, Mr. King served at the pleasure of the President. Mr. King, one of the highest-ranking blacks appointed by Mr. Carter, was reported planning to accept a position as the international vice president for African and Middle East affairs at Riggs National Bank in Washington.

title: By Jim Benagh
description: Sports World Specials Looking Back and Ahead

title: HIGHLY QUALIFIED CITY U. TEACHERS NOW CONFINED TO REMEDIAL WORK
description: Although Wolfgang R. Hirschberg, chairman of the Germanic and Slavic languages department at City College, has a doctorate in Russian literature, he has not taught a course in the Russian language since 1977. His entire class load now consists of English as a second language for students in the institution's remedial education program.

title: Pressure Defense
description: Last fall, Mike Jarvis, the basketball coach at Cambridge (Mass.) Rindge and Latin High School attempted to take the pressure off Pat Ewing, regarded by many as the most soughtafter schoolboy basketball player in the country. Jarvis set up guidelines that college coaches had to follow in recruiting his talented center. Jarvis sent letters to several colleges informing them of Ewing's criteria for selecting a school. Then, with the information in, Ewing chose Georgetown University last month and proceded to enjoy his final high school season.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The problem with busing is that at the end of the bus ride you're still back in that racially isolated neighborhood.'' - Secretary of Education T. H. Bell. (A15:1.)

title: WILLIAM C. KNOX JR.
description: William C. Knox Jr., a partner of the law firm of White & Case, died of a heart attack on Friday while attending a function at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Mr. Knox, who was a resident of Ridgewood, N. J., was 64 years old.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MARCH 16, 1981
description: International Syria must decide what to do with the three men who hijacked a Pakistan International Airlines jet and took more than 100 passengers as hostages, an official of the Pakistan Defense Ministry said. The hostages were released when hijackers surrendered in Damascus Saturday night. The official, Mohammed Rahim Khan, who is also head of the Pakistan airline, said that the fate of the 54 Pakistani prisoners freed by Pakistan in compliance with the hijackers' demands, was also a matter for Syria to decide. (Page A1, Col. 4.) Iraq's President offered arms to Iranian minorities fighting the Teheran authorities. In a speech reported by the Baghdad radio, President Saddam Hussein said ''we are ready to extend all types of aid, including guns, to those Iranian people so they may achieve their national rights and estabish good-neighbor relations with Iraq.'' He reiterated that Iraq was ready to occupy more Iranian territory if Teheran continued to ignore Iraq's demands for ending the Persian Gulf war. (A3:4-6.)

title: Hunts Cleared in Oil Dispute
description: A Federal judge dismissed a $231 million antitrust suit Friday against Herbert, Nelson and Lamar Hunt, ruling that facts stipulated by both sides indicated the wealthy brothers did not violate Federal law in a dispute involving oil from a nationalized Libyan oil field.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: In the past few years, many American racetracks have introduced computerized mutuel machines that allow bettors to buy tickets of any denomination, and cash in their winners at the same window. Though it has brought shorter, quicker lines for bettors, it has produced one casualty: the colorful tote tickets that the old machines use to punch out.

title: 4 Hurt as Plane Runs Out of Fuel
description: A Delta Airlines pilot and three stewardesses were injured yesterday when a private single-engine airplane they were in ran out of fuel and crashed into the woods near Smithville Airport.

title: LEWIS ROTBERG
description: Lewis Rotberg, a lawyer active in Newark for almost 50 years, died Saturday in Miami Beach after a long illness.

title: Deborah W. Rothschild Bride of William A. Cadel
description: Deborah W. Rothschild, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest L. Rothschild of Roslyn, L.I., was married there yesterday to William A. Cadel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Cadel of Hewlett, L.I., and Great Barrington, Mass. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center.

title: by Jay Angoff
description: In his State of the Union Message, President Reagan said that ''the taxing power of Government must be used to provide revenues for legitimate Government purposes. It must not be used to regulate the economy or bring about social change.'' But he has said nothing about the provisions of the tax code that in fact are used to bring about social change: tax expenditures.

title: CARTER IS TROUBLED AT SCUTTLING OF PROGRAMS
description: Jimmy Carter, speaking for publication for the first time since he left the White House, is concerned about the dismantling of his programs by the Reagan Administration, but he feels it is too soon to criticize his successor.

title: American Ski Victor
description: Bill Koch became the first American to win the Engadin cross-country ski marathon today.

title: ARIZONA STATE LOSES
description: Tony Guy scored a career-high 36 points to give Kansas an 88-71 upset victory over Arizona State in the National Collegiate Midwest Regional basketball tournament today.

title: Nicaraguan Opposition Meeting Prevented by Sandinist Backers
description: Supporters of Nicaragua's ruling leftist Sandinist movement seized parts of the town of Nandaime and prevented what would have been the opposition's first public meeting since the leftists came to power in 1979, opposition spokesmen said today.

title: MAURICE WOLLIN
description: Maurice Wollin, who had been community superintendent of schools on Staten Island from 1960 until his retirement in 1975, died of a heart attack Saturday at his Brooklyn home. He was 72 years old.

title: MORGENTHAU SEES OBSTACLES TO PROSECUTIONS
description: Despite a record number of felony convictions last year, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday that his office had been hampered by inadequate court and police resources.

title: JACQUES ZUCKER
description: Jacques Zucker, an artist whose paintings in post-Impresssionist style were seen in many one-man shows in the United States and abroad, died Friday at Beth Israel Hospital after a long illness. Mr. Zucker, who lived in Manhattan, was 80 years old.

title: Sterling Bancorp Stock
description: Trafalgar Industries, a manufacturer of vending equipment, said Friday that it had agreed to acquire from Gerald Gutterman & Company 239,200 shares of Sterling Bancorp common stock, or about 4.9 percent of Sterling's outstanding shares.

title: POLITICIANS UNITE ON MASS TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: by James C. Webster
description: America's farmers are determined capitalists and fervent Americans. Mention ''embargo'' and you get the same reaction as if you'd said ''Communist.'' They want to sell what they grow, without Government interference, even if the buyer is the Kremlin.

title: FORMER MILL TOWN AWAITS SEWER PROJECT UNEASILY
description: A red line of brick row houses on Oella Avenue wavers where the central street matches the contours of wooded rises and ravines along the winding, swift-running Patapsco River. The millrace of a mile and a quarter, now dry and leaf-lined, once provided power for the Union Manufacturing Company, chartered by Maryland in 1809 but now shut.

title: Oil-Tool Thefts Rising Sharply
description: The oil exploration fever has reportedly spawned a black market for hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of oilfield equipment.

title: PROGRESS AND PROBLEMS CONFRONT SHREVEPORT, LA.
description: Late this spring, the people of Shreveport will join the so-called ''chosen few'' cities in America to be home to an assembly plant owned by the General Motors Corporation. Historically, having an automobile assembly plant in one's community is equivalent to having a money machine at home.

title: Learning Experience
description: Jim Lynam was four years out of college at St. Joseph's (Pa.) when he became the head basketball coach at Fairfield University in 1968. Several times that summer, he made the trip to West Point to talk with Bobby Knight, who was preparing for his third season at Army.

title: EX-HOSTAGE AND HIS WIFE SPEAK OF SPIRITUAL CHANGE
description: Against the backdrop of the serene high altar decorated with flowing sprays of yellow forsythia, Moorehead Kennedy Jr., a former hostage in Iran, and his wife, Louisa, told the congregation at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday that the 444 days of captivity had led each to a deep spiritual transformation.

title: Central African Republic Holds Presidential Election
description: For the first time in 17 years, a presidential election was held in this country today. Five candidates, including the incumbent, David Dacko, were on the ballot.

title: f813
description: THE Oakland Ballet Company made its New York debut over the weekend as part of a series of out-of-town ballet troupes at Brooklyn College's Center for the Performing Arts. The first impression is that this is a very California company, free of customary inhibitions.

title: BRITISH BUDGET CRITICIZED
description: The British Government's new austerity budget, which is intended to reduce inflation, is likely to push the nation's economy deeper into recession, according to some bankers and economists. ''This budget could be extremely damaging to the economy,'' said Gavyn Davies, an economist at the London brokerage firm of Phillips & Drew.

title: Cosmos Lose Again
description: Goals by Cristobal Ortega, Juan Antonio Luna and Miguel Angel Gamboa led the America team of the Mexican Soccer League to a 4-2 victory over the Cosmos of the North American Soccer League today before more than 100,000 fans in Azteca Stadium. Francois Vander Elst and Giorgio Chinaglia scored goals for the Cosmos, who dropped their second game in a row in Mexico. The America team had lost its last eight regular-season matches.

title: SAFEGUARDS ON RESOURCES ARE NOT PRIORITY FOR WATT
description: Explaining to Congress last week what he wants to stop doing and how much this should save, James G. Watt, the Secretary of the Interior, gave more indications of how the Reagan Administration hoped to manage the country's public lands and natural resources.

title: ROCK: KOOL & THE GANG HEAD FUNK-MUSIC BILL
description: The triple bill of Kool & the Gang, the Gap Band, and Yarbrough & peoples on Thursday at the Radio City Music Hall offered a revealing cross-section of mainstream black music. The program showed that funk - the stuttering rhythmic impulse that was elevated into an esthetic by acts like Parliament and Funkadelic five years ago - has been assimilated in the black mainstream as the predominant up-tempo style.

title: 5 GAIN SETTLEMENTS FOR F.B.I. ACTS IN 70'S
description: The Justice Department has agreed to pay five persons $10,000 each for violation of their constitutional rights because of illegal Federal Bureau of Investigation wiretaps, burglaries or mail openings in the early 1970's, civil liberties lawyers said yesterday.

title: NORTH CAROLINA WINS
description: Al Wood, hampered by early foul problems, made three straight baskets midway through the second half today to shut off a Pittsburgh comeback and help North Carolina gain a 74-57 victory in the second round of the National Collegiate West Regional basketball tournament.

title: IN SPORTS, MONEY IS THE MAIN ISSUE
description: IN a tearful clubhouse address, Ruly Carpenter recently announced that he is selling the Philadelphia Phillies because he is disturbed about the high salaries in the free-agency era of sports.

title: Another Sad Ending for Aguirre
description: The morning after the De Paul season ended abruptly and painfully, for the second straight year, the only consolation for the Blue Demons was that it was over. The expectations have vanished. The crowds have already stopped following them. The demands on their time have to do with final examinations, not the Final Four.

title: VIRGINIA RALLY STOPS VILLANOVA
description: There was a lot of drama but no upset in this portion of the National Collegiate Athletic Association East Regional basketball tournament today.

title: FOR REAGAN'S SECOND NIGHT ON TOWN, A SPECIAL BALLET
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, finally got their first chance last night to see their son, Ron, perform professionally as a dancer, and a beaming Mr. Reagan pronounced it ''pretty remarkable.''

title: FOR SALVADOR PEASANTS, FRUITS OF CHANGE SEEM GOOD
description: When Government soldiers came a year ago and claimed the plantation here on behalf of the peasants, one of the first things the peasants did was to vote out the administrators.

title: DANCE: LUCINDA CHILDS OFFERS 4 OF HER WORKS
description: If Lucinda Childs were not a choreographer, one could imagine her as a watchmaker. Her dances are as exquisitely and intricately constructed as the finest Swiss watches, and the dancers in them are required to keep perfect time.

title: JOHNLEE N' HAROLD UPSET WINNER
description: Inactive since late December because of a dispute over his ownership, Johnlee N' Harold scored a three-length victory today in the San Rafael Stakes for 3-year-olds at Santa Anita.

title: REAGAN'S PROTOCOL CHOICE: A PENCHANT FOR PERFECTION
description: Leonore Annenberg has always known how to please her guests. Richard M. Nixon took refuge at the sprawling Annenberg estate near Palm Springs, Calif., after Watergate. Frank Sinatra married Barbara Marx there. Spiro T. Agnew was an occasional visitor. Gregory Peck and Sammy Davis Jr. have been guests, as have Leonard Firestone and Ronald and Nancy Reagan. Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi was invited to stay after leaving Iran (he decided not to).

title: Texaco Find Off Louisiana
description: Texaco Inc. announced on Friday an oil and gas find off the coast of Louisiana in the Gulf of Mexico, while, separately, its Canadian subsidiary said it would sharply reduce spending on exploration in several regions of Canada.

title: OUTLOOK FOR INFLATION KEY TO BOND YIELDS
description: The tea leaves traditionally used by bond market experts and prognisticators are strained from data about the economy and its growth, and the flow of funds among the public, government and business.

title: Miss Navratilova Takes 4th Tourney
description: Martina Navratilova overcame Pam Shriver today, 6-2, 6-4, and won her fourth tournament on the Avon winter tour. Then the two singles finalists teamed to win the doubles.

title: From Movie Actress to Role in a Student Play
description: The Yale freshman had never appeared on stage or performed an improvisational scene, but after what she described as a ''weird'' audition, she got the part anyway.

title: Italy-Abu Dhabi Oil Hunt
description: The Italian oil drilling company, Saipem, has signed a $30 million petroleum exploration contract with ADCO of Abu Dhabi, company officials said Friday. Saipem, part of the Italian state-owned energy consortium, ENI, signed a two-year contract with the Abu Dhabi company for onshore oil operation and will begin drilling in the Middle Eastern country this spring.

title: Small Earthquake in Washington
description: A small earthquake measuring 3.6 on the Richter scale rumbled through part of western Washington late last night, rattling some houses in Snohomish and King counties but causing no damage. Scientists said the quake was centered five miles west of the old mining town of Monte Cristo.

title: A CLOSE-UP VIEW OF THE STRUGGLE IN EL SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda Harris, Biophysicist, Wed on L. I. to Jerrold D. Liebermann
description: The marriage of Linda Jean Harris to Jerrold D. Liebermann took place yesterday at the Jacob Philip Rudin Chapel of Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson officiated.

title: IRAQI PRESIDENT OFFERS TO ARM IRANIAN REBELS
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has offered to provide minorities in Iran with weapons and other assistance, the Baghdad radio reported today. The offer seemed to be an attempt to dismember Iran.

title: Olin Pickett Boone, 56, Director Of Marketing for an Ink Producer
description: Olin Pickett Boone, marketing director of the ink division of the J.M. Huber Corporation of Edison, N.J., died of a heart attack Friday in a diner in Westfield, N.J. Mr. Boone was 56 years old and lived in Westfield and Jacksonville, Fla.

title: Yankees' Guidry Not Gone, Not Forgotten, Just Starting Slowly
description: Tommy John pitched today for the second time this spring. Yesterday Tom Underwood pitched for the second time. Rudy May will pitch for the second time later this week. Ron Guidry might not pitch for the first time until next week.

title: LOWER WORLD TRADE PREDICTED BY GATT
description: The 85-nation agency that oversees the world's commerce said today that the volume of international trade increased only 1 percent last year, against 6 percent in l979, and that there were no signs of a recovery.

title: HOW TO PROMOTE SCHOOL SEGREGATION
description: To the Editor:

title: JOFFREY BALLET'S GALA: DIANA ROSS AND RON REAGAN
description: President and Mrs. Reagan joined hands last night, as did more than 4,000 other spectators, at the Metropolitan Opera House to sway and sing, ''Reach out and touch somebody's hand, make this world a better place if you can.''

title: Vilas Wins in Egypt
description: Guillermo Vilas of Argentina defeated West Germany's Peter Elter today, 6-2, 6-3, to win the $15,000 first prize in the Egyptian open tennis tournament.

title: Tass Points to Killings in Atlanta As Sign of Racist 'Terror' in U.S.
description: The Soviet Union charged yesterday that the killing of black children in Atlanta showed that the ''real terror'' of racist violence was rampant in America.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE CAT AND THE KING. By Louis Au- chincloss. 183 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $10.95.

title: Almay Account Shifted To Geer, DuBois Inc.
description: On Friday, Almay Inc., after a three-month search, decided that its future advertising happiness should be in the care of Geer, DuBois Inc. The agency will be replacing Hicks & Greist, which had been doing the advertising for the cosmetics, skin care and toiletries products for 16 years.

title: MID-SIZED AMERICAN CITIES GETTING NEW ATTENTION
description: This northwestern Louisiana community shares more with Fort Wayne, the hub city of northeastern Indiana, than the widely held view that both are ''hick towns,'' ''neither here nor there,'' existing with ''no identity'' in the shadow of Dallas or Chicago.

title: 3 Die in Allendale; Monoxide Suspected
description: Authorities are investigating the death of a business executive, his wife and a handyman who apparently succumbed to carbon monoxide poisoning from a car left running.

title: LET DISCIPLINE FIT THE OFFENSE, NOT THE QUOTA
description: To the Editor:

title: Chrysler Plans To Shut Plants
description: The Chrysler Corporation plans to close small plants in Indianapolis and Michigan City, Ind., by the end of the year, idling 300 workers, the company told the state's Board of Public Depositories on Friday.

title: First Came the Set, Then Came the New Musical
description: Since it has no dialogue and is made up entirely of Stephen Sondheim songs, it might be supposed that the new Off Broadway musical, ''Marry Me a Little,'' was inspired by its music.

title: Calleo Sings Pinkerton In City Opera 'Butterfly'
description: The first ''Madama Butterfly'' of the season arrived at the New York City Opera on Saturday afternoon, and with it came Riccardo Calleo's first Pinkerton.

title: BELL WILL NOT PUSH LAWSUITS ON BUSING
description: Secretary of Education T. H. Bell said today that his department would not actively press lawsuits for achieving school desegregation through busing.

title: News Analysis
description: An effort by conservatives in Congress to strip the Supreme Court and lower Federal Courts of jurisdiction in cases involving school prayer, busing and abortion could lead to a fundamental shift in Government checks and balances, in the view of concerned legal experts.

title: Advanced Systems Shift
description: William R. Roach, 41, has been elected president and chief executive officer of Advanced Systems Inc., a producer of multimedia training courses for use by corporations. He succeeds John M. Deano, 39, who resigned from the company after about a year and a half in the position.

title: Boarding Homes Can Be Made Safe
description: The House Select Committee on Aging picked the right place for its hearing on boarding home fires: Keansburg, New Jersey. Of the 130 old people who have died over the past 18 months in such fires nationally, 31 died in Keansburg, 64 in New Jersey. There are ways to prevent further tragedy: by planning carefully, and by paying for safety.

title: LACK OF COURT TRANSCRIPTS BRINGS PLEA FOR REVERSALS
description: Citing the failure of court stenographers to supply transcripts necessary for appeals, the Legal Aid Society of Nassau County has filed a court action in behalf of 54 indigent defendants convicted of felonies, seeking a reversal of their sentences.

title: The Rough Riders' Coalition
description: The transit situation in New York has deteriorated so badly that 24 civic groups that often fight each other are getting together to see what they can do. They want to rally behind them an army of outraged and weary subway, bus and rail travelers who will remember the politicians who forget them. Such a coalition is needed. It would be still more useful if it could find a program that holds promise, something its opening statement doesn't quite accomplish.

title: Iroquois-Acorn Link
description: Iroquois Brands Ltd., a manufacturer and marketer of beverage, nutritional and specialty-food products, said that Acorn Investments, an investment company based in Luxembourg, and other foreign investors based in England had bought 31,000 shares of Iroquois common stock recently. Iroquois said that the purchase brought its total ownership in Iroquois to 140,900 shares.

title: Ford, Visiting Gulf, Is Told of Link Between Palestinians and Bases
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford was told today that this federation of Persian Gulf states would not consider the establishment of American military bases without concessions on the Palestinian issue, a Government spokesmen said.

title: Providence Takes E.C.A.C. Hockey
description: Providence routed Cornell, 8-4, to capture the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I hockey championship last night before 10,362 fans at Boston Garden.

title: LYMAN RECALLS ANOTHER ST. JOSEPH'S UPSET
description: For just a moment, time was frozen in Jim Lynam's mind. He was not coaching the basketball team at St. Joseph's University; he was a senior at St. Joseph's College. The coach was Jack Ramsay. The year was 1962. The opponent was Bowling Green, with Nate Thurmond and Butch Komives, a team that was topranked in some preseason polls.

title: Suntory's U.S. Unit Appoints New Chief
description: Masao Yuri, 51 years old, has been named president and chief executive officer of Suntory International, the American subsidiary of Suntory Ltd., a Japanese producer of spirits and soft drinks. He succeeds Gary Saji, 35, who will return to Japan next month to work in the marketing and sales division of the parent corporation.

title: Geralyn Krupp Is Married to Martin Lobel, a Lawyer
description: Geralyn Krupp, legislative coordinator of the Democratic Study Group, an organization of Democratic members of the House of Representatives, was married in Washington yesterday to Martin Lobel, a senior partner in the law firm of Lobel, Novins & Lamont. Rabbi Robert Baruch performed the ceremony at Mr. Lobel's home.

title: Phil Mahre Takes Cup Slalom
description: Phil Mahre of Yakima, Wash., scored his second World Cup slalom victory of the season today and moved closer to overtaking Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden in the overall standing.

title: G.O.P. IN HOUSE GEARS FOR BUDGET DEBATE
description: In the last session of Congress, Democrats and Republicans in the House of Representatives clashed repeatedly in an atmosphere of partisan bitterness. Then, in last fall's campaign, the Republicans used those clashes as ammunition against their opponents and made a net gain of 33 seats in the November balloting.

title: F.C.C. RENEWS WNYC-TV'S BROADCAST LICENSE
description: The Federal Communications Commission has renewed the broadcast license of the Municipal Broadcasting System's WNYC-TV, Channel 31, in New York, and in the process has rejected the three-year-old application of the True Witness Ministries to take over the station.

title: SCREEN: 'NINE MONTHS,' HUNGARIAN FACTORY TALE
description: Some of Marta Meszaros's films, like "Women" (1977) and "Just Like at Home" (1978), have had a bracing plainness. But her earlier "Nine Months" (1966) is sullen and sour. Sulky, plain, plump, uncommunicative, unfriendly: these are the chief qualities of July (Lili Monori), who takes a job in a factory as the film begins. Janos, the foreman (Jan Nowicki), a very handsome fellow, takes one look at July and falls desperately in love. He wants to date her. He wants to marry her. But July, described by Miss Meszaros in an interview as "the most conscious and most mature of all the female characters in my films," says no, no, no.

title: CELTICS BEAT NETS, 133-125, AND MOVE WITHIN A HALF-GAME OF 76ERS
description: Larry Bird and Cedric Maxwell led a third-quarter rally that carried the Celtics to a 133-125 victory over the Nets yesterday in Boston.

title: RENE CLAIR, FRENCH FILM DIRECTOR-WRITER, DIES AT 82
description: Rene Clair, who ranked with Marcel Carne and Jean Renoir as one of the grand old men of the French cinema, died yesterday at his home in Neuilly, a suburb of Paris. He was 82 years old.

title: Rev. Vincent D. O'Beirne, S.J., 82; Ex-Department Head at Fordham
description: The Rev. Vincent DePaul O'Beirne, S.J., who was head of the department of communication arts at Fordham University from 1948 to 1952, died Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital.

title: THE FIARNESS DOCTRINE IS DYING
description: Is the fairness doctrine in television, like the rooftop antenna, headed for oblivion? For decades, Congress and the Federal Communications Commission have believed that broadcasters should cover public issues and be evenhanded about it. Why? Because the broadcast spectrum has been historically a scarce resource. The Government saw a public interest in requiring ''fairness'' from those it licensed as broadcasters.

title: PHILADELPHIA BRACES FOR FULL EFFECT OF TRANSIT STRIKE
description: Transit workers went on strike today, halting bus, trolley and subway service in the nation's fourth largest city and forcing 400,000 commuters to hunt for other ways to get to work tomorrow.

title: GRIT, A RURAL WEEKLY, IS SOLD, BUT STAFF'S ATTITUDE REMAINS BRIGHT
description: Its name is Grit, as in true grit. Few city people have ever heard of it, but for millions of others who grew up in rural and small-town America, Grit has been, as its slogan still proclaims, ''America's Greatest Family Newspaper.'' For a national circulation of about 900,000 a week, it continues, as it has for nearly a century, to follow the admonition of its founder, Dietrich Lamade, a German immigrant who told his editorial staff: ''Let us make every issue of Grit ring the joybells of life.''

title: Week's Steel Output Up
description: Steel production rose to 2.570 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.560 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Stockman Attacks F.T.C.
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, who recently retreated from a proposal to end antitrust enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission, bitterly criticized major F.T.C. antitrust cases today.

title: By Sports of The Times; Confessions of a computer
description: ITS hum was mum. Silently, it hid there behind a locked door deep inside the New York Times Building as if in exile, a computer in disgrace.

title: State Officials Say Cuts Will Hurt Buying Power
description: State and local governments will lose more than half the buying power provided by Federal aid in five years because of cuts proposed by the Reagan Administration, an organization of governors and state legislators said today.

title: Chess: No Choice for Christiansen Between Safety and Action
description: If the choice is between a somewhat loose tactical defense that might generate counterplay and a solid passive safe defense, it need not be asked what course such an adventurous player as Larry Christiansen will take. In the Linares International Tournament in Spain, the 24-year-old grandmaster from Modesto, Calif., ran true to form in his encounter with Miguel Quinteros, an Argentine grandmaster, and reaped the reward of a sharp tactical eye.

title: Suriname Says It Has Foiled An Anti-Government Coup
description: The Government said today that it foiled an attempted coup yesterday and that one of the plotters had been killed.

title: Demonstrators Assail Decontrol Of Domestic Oil Prices at Capital
description: Several hundred chanting demonstrators protesting President Reagan's decontrolling of domestic oil prices blocked the entrance to the building housing the offices of the American Petroleum Institute today.

title: U.S. Threatening to Boycott A U.N. Meeting in Havana
description: The United States said today that it would not attend a conference on North-South relations if the United Nations accepted Cuba's offer of Havana as host city.

title: Perceiving Justice
description: In sensational criminal trials, defense lawyers often make the sweeping charge that once an open pretrial hearing has been held, it's impossible to pick an unbiased jury. Therefore, they argue, judges should bar the press from the hearing.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The City of New York has established that it's a long-distance runner and you can depend on us.'' - Mayor Koch, in Miami to sell municipal bonds. (B6:1.)

title: Conspiracy Trial Of 6 Croatians Starts
description: Six advocates of Croatian independence went on trial in Federal Court in Manhattan on charges of plotting to kill a political foe and bomb buildings in New York.

title: Asbestos Corp.  Loses Appeal
description: The Supreme Court of Canada has refused to hear an appeal by the Asbestos Corporation Ltd. of Montreal, a unit of the General Dynamics Corporation of St. Louis, against a lower court decision that upheld the right of the province of Quebec to expropriate the company's assets, an official of Asbestos Corporation said today.

title: U.S. ACCUSES SOVIET OF IGNORING APPEALS TO HALT HIJACKING
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the Soviet Union had spurned repeated American appeals to use its influence in Afghanistan to end the hijacking of an airliner by three Pakistanis and that it had allowed the hijackers to obtain automatic weapons in Kabul.

title: Young & Rubicam Now No. 1, Sort Of
description: After more than 35 years in the No.1 spot among American ad agencies, the J. Walter Thompson Company has been replaced by Young & Rubicam.

title: 24 POLITICIANS URGE U.S. ROLE IN ENDING ULSTER STRIFE
description: Twenty-four American political figures, most of them of Irish ancestry, today urged an end to ''the fear and the terrorism and the bigotry'' in Northern Ireland and proposed that the Reagan Administration find a way to promote a peaceful settlement of the Ulster conflict.
