title: Controllers Picket Airports As Negotiations Continue
description: Air traffic controllers picketed the nation's airports today for the second consecutive day, but pledged not to interrupt air travel so long as contract talks continued with the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: JERSEY AGENCY ASKS 50% FARE INCREASES ON RAILS AND BUSES
description: A strike by transit workers in Philadelphia forced hundreds of thousands of commuters to find alternative ways of getting to work. Page A14. By ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ Special to the New York Times

title: Seagram Is Sued On Takeover Effort
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation filed suit in Federal court, in Kansas City, Mo., yesterday to block a $45-a-share, $2.07 billion takeover bid by Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc., the American subsidiary of Canada's Seagram group.

title: CATLEDGE ON EDITORS: 'PEOPLE WON'T LET YOU RETIRE
description: Eleven years retired and on the eve of his 80th birthday, Turner Catledge still has the hunger to know and the compulsion to tell that made him one of the leading journalists of his time.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Eric Clapton Ailing, 47 Concerts Are Canceled Add Eric Clapton to the sick list. The British rock star has been hospitalized with a gastric ulcer in St. Paul, forcing the cancellation of 47 scheduled concerts.

title: News Analysis
description: More than half the people in the country with incomes below the official poverty line either receive no protection from what President Reagan has termed the ''social safety net'' or get, at most, a free lunch for their children on school days.

title: THE SMALL INVESTOR UNDER ATTACK
description: To the Editor:

title: BACHE BUYS SMELTER, DENIES DILUTION GOAL
description: Bache Group Inc., a leading brokerage house, announced yesterday the purchase for stock of Jackson Precious Metals, a private smelter in Jackson, Ohio. It was Bache's second acquisition in a week.

title: LEATHER REPORT: IT'S UBIQ UITOUS
description: Leather clothing never dies, it just keeps coming back in new, more wearable incarnations. And those who are dedicated to this fashion staple, such as the New Yorkers shown here, couldn't be happier about it - because there seem to be more variations on leather this spring than seen in some time.

title: Atlanta Police Oppose Plan Of Youths to Guard Blacks
description: The police said today that they would not condone the formation of a band of school dropouts armed with baseball bats to watch over black children.

title: MOSLEMS WHO WERE HELD IN HIJACKING FLY TO MECCA
description: The Moslem hostages who had been held aboard a hijacked Pakistani airliner for 13 days flew to Saudi Arabia today for a pilgrimage to Mecca to pray and thank Allah for their release.

title: Kennan Wins Peace Prize
description: The Albert Einstein Peace Prize Foundation has chosen George F. Kennan, the former diplomat and expert on Soviet affairs, as winner of its second annual peace prize, worth $50,000.

title: Whitney Show to Trace Disney Characters
description: Greg Ford is mounting what the Whitney Museum of American Art has announced as ''the first museum exhibition to explore the special characteristics of Disney animation drawings and films.'' Mr. Ford is guest curator of ''Disney Animation,'' which will run from June 24 to Sept. 6.

title: Egypt Says It Is Assisting Anti-Libyan Rebels in Chad
description: Egypt confirmed today that that was supplying arms to rebel forces in Chad.

title: Cemetery Concern Has New President
description: ''It's a real estate business like any other,'' said Richard Kaufman, 39, who has been appointed president of Morlan International Inc., an owner and operator of 19 cemeteries in the United States and Canada. ''The ground has to be maintained well, or else we have nothing to sell.''

title: NICARAGUANS TRAIN IN FLORIDA AS GUERILLAS
description: Former members of the Nicaraguan National Guard are training openly alongside the Cuban exiles in camps in Florida, preparing, they say, for guerrilla attacks on the Sandinists in Nicaragua.

title: White Sox Top Mets But Long to See Fisk
description: The Chicago White Sox, recast with new owners and free agents, scored four runs in the eighth inning off Neil Allen today and defeated the Mets, 6-5. But the question before the house remained: Where was Carlton Fisk?

title: Q. What is ringworm?
description: A. Ringworm is not a worm at all, but an infection of the dead outer layers of the skin caused by fungi known collectively as dermatophytes. It is often the result of poor hygiene, and is frequently associated with hot, humid climatic conditions. Ringworm is communicable, and can be transmitted by infected humans and animals.

title: Argentine, in U.S., Says Ties Are Sure to Improve
description: Gen. Robert Viola, the President-designate of Argentina, met with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today and said he was ''absolutely sure'' that relations between the two nations would improve sharply.

title: WROTE SCREENPLAYS
description: Eleanor Perry, the screenwriter whose credits included ''David and Lisa'' and ''Diary of a Mad Housewife,'' died of cancer at her home in Manhattan on Saturday. She was 66 years old.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt SHAKESPEARE'S DIVISION OF EXPERI- ENCE. By Marilyn French. 376 pages. Summit. $15.95.

title: Prime 17 1/2% AT CHASE, IN CHICAGO
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank and the First National Bank of Chicago reduced their prime lending rates yesterday to 17 1/2 percent from 18 percent, increasing the likelihood that other banks would soon join the downward movement.

title: DEFICIENCY BUDGET PASSES IN ALBANY
description: The Legislature passed a $165.8 million deficiency budget today that gives Governor Carey spending authority to cover cost overruns by state agencies in the 1980-81 fiscal year.

title: People
description: * Thomas R. McNamara named senior vice president of Dancer Fitzgerald Sample Inc.

title: TRUMAN: LOOKING THE OTHER WAY ON DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DIGITAL CLOCK AS A TIMESAVER
description: Young children are not the only ones who have trouble telling time because of the need to discern the position of the big hand in relation to the little hand. Adults, too, can tell the hour much more quickly from a digital presentation than from a traditional clock face, according to a study reported in The Journal of Experimental Psychology.

title: Police Head Terms Morgenthau 'Unfair'
description: Robert J. McGuire, the New York City Police Commissioner, charged yesterday that the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, was ''unfair to the cops'' by asserting that the District Attorney's office had been hampered in prosecuting felony cases by inadequate post-arrest investigations and preparation for trial by the police.

title: Barclay's Account
description: It has not been made official yet, but it is understood that Barclay American Bank, with headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., is moving its advertising account to Henderson Advertising in Charlotte from McCann-Erickson's Atlanta office. The ad budget is around $2 million.

title: Guard at Harley Hotel Charged With Starting Two Blazes There
description: A security guard at the Harley Hotel on East 42d Street was charged with arson last night after he admitted that he started a fire in that hotel last Feb. 18, the hotel's opening day, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: LET'S DRAW THE LINE IN BELIZE
description: I'm unsure whether El Salvador is Munich or Vietnam. It's like Munich because we have to draw the line in Central America and stop appeasing aggression. And it's like Vietnam because those running the country are corrupt and brutal. If we back them, it will look awful, and we will probably end up on the losing side once more.

title: Food Fair Losing Chapter 11 Status
description: Grant C. Gentry, chairman and chief executive officer of Food Fair Inc., said that emergence of the financially troubled supermarket chain from protection of Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act ''is believed to be imminent.'' The company has been operating under Chapter 11 since October 1978.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Company News item in Business Day on Feb. 28 incorrectly reported an agreement involving the Madison Gas and Electric Company and the Cross Plains Electric Company. The agreement in principle provides for Madison Gas to purchase the assets of Cross Plains in exchange for Madison Gas common stock.

title: Prof. John MacDonald Dies at 75; Headed State Law Revision Unit
description: John W. MacDonald, professor emeritus of law at Cornell University and former chairman of the New York State Law Revision Commission, died Saturday at Tompkins County Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: ISRAELI SAYS FRIENDSHIP WITH U.S. HAS BEEN DAMAGED BY SALE TO SAUDIS
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir accused the Reagan Administration today of damaging the friendship between Israel and the United States by agreeing to sell sophisticated weapons to Saudi Arabia.

title: Trade Surplus Cited for China
description: China probably had a trade surplus of more than $1 billion last year and is expected to continue holding its solid financial position, the Central Intelligence Agency said in a report issued today.

title: ALLIED STORES GAINS
description: The K mart Corporation, the nation's second-largest nonfood retailer behind Sears, Roebuck and Company, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter dropped by 10.2 percent, while sales in the period increased 8.7 percent.

title: WEST VIRGINIA GAS FIND
description: Amax Inc. said today that the J. Moyle No. 1 well it owns in Randolph County, W. Va., had tested at a maximum rate of l.16 million cubic feet of natural gas a day from three zones, the deepest of which was 5,100 feet.

title: N.B.A. ADDS COUNSELING SERVICE
description: The National Basketball Association yesterday became the first professional sports league to hire a 24-hour-a-day counseling service to help its players deal with a wide range of problems. The league and the National Basketball Players Association will share the cost of $100,000 a year.

title: Partial Liquidation Set by Dillingham
description: The principal executives of the Dillingham Corporation, a diversified, Honolulu-based concern with operations in real estate, shipbuilding and other fields, said they expected to submit a plan for partial liquidation to the company's shareholders.

title: SUSPECT'S PARENTS TESTIFY AT HEARING IN MET SLAYING
description: The question of whether Craig S. Crimmins was able to grant ''an intelligent waiver'' of his rights during questioning by police officers was raised in testimony at his pretrial hearing yesterday.

title: WEINBERGER NAMES PANEL TO STUDY WHERE TO PLACE MX MISSILE SYSTEM
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today named a 15-member panel of nongovernmental experts to study where to base the MX missile system.

title: 8 Die in Highway Pileup in Brazil
description: Eight people were killed and 19 were injured yesterday in a seven-vehicle crash on the main highway between Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, according to Brazilian news agecies. The accident involved five trucks, a car and a bus.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Compugraphic Corporation, Wilmington, Mass., a supplier of photocomposition equipment and related supplies and accessories, has named Edward A. Klemm Jr. head of its newly formed Software Products division.

title: EXPERT ON VIOLENCE AND GERIATRICS
description: Dr. Monica D. Blumenthal, program director of geriatric psychiatry at Western Psychiatric Institute and Clinic, died today at her home here after a long illness. She was 50 years old.

title: Western Electric Worker Slain
description: SALEM, N.C., March 16 (UPI) - A Western Electric Company employee fatally shot a security superviser today, slit his wrists and then was wounded in an exchange of gunfire with the police, the authorities said. The dead superviser was identified as Ransom Calvin Sells, 52 years old. His assailant was identified as Kenneth Odell Warren.

title: LEGISLATOR WARNS OF CAR QUOTAS
description: If President Reagan decides not to ask the Japanese to restrain their auto exports to the United States voluntarily, Congress would mandate trade quotas ''just as soon as we get the budget out of the way,'' the House Budget Committee chairman, Representative James R. Jones, said today.

title: Ireland's Friends
description: St. Patrick's Day is at once a clarion of spring, a saint's day and the celebration of a people. At least 20 million Americans are of Irish descent - including, it happens, both the new President and Secretary of State. But numbers alone fail to explain why today's rites strike so universal a chord. Troubles bring nations as well as families together, and the sorrows of Ireland evoke a compassion that transcends ties of blood. In a real sense, the violence that scars a distant land has become local news.

title: Teleprompter Picks Altschiller, Reitzfeld
description: Altschiller, Reitzfeld, Jackson, Solin/NCK has become the ad agency for the Teleprompter Corporation, the country's largest cable TV operator, with 115 systems in 540 communities.

title: REVUE: 'AMERICA' STARRING ALL THE 50
description: RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL was built to house spectacles, but it does not seem possible that its spectacular potential has ever been used as fully as it is for ''America,'' a huge, colorful, fast-moving singing and dancing paean to the United States. It is such an unabashed orgy of self-admiration that it might have seemed smug. But it is filled with so much eye-catching color, such a variety of music and a bubbling, enthusiastic spirit that even the most caustic viewer must be swept up by its contagious energy.

title: 2 U.N. SOILDERS AND 4 CIVILIANS ARE SLAIN IN LEBANON
description: Two United Nations soldiers from Nigeria and four civilians were killed in southern Lebanon today in an artillery bombardment by Israeli-backed Christian forces.

title: SYRIA DETAINS A FREED PASSENGER AS CANADA UNSNARLS HIS IDENTITY
description: A man who spent almost two weeks as a hostage aboard a hijacked Pakistani airliner is being detained in a Syrian jail awaiting possible extradition to Canada.

title: Of Coffee and Cancer
description: The discovery of a statistical link between coffee drinking and pancreatic cancer, reported last week, foreshadows far more attention to the health effects of this stimulant used by at least 100 million Americans.

title: THE SMALL INVESTOR UNDER ATTACK
description: To the Editor:

title: Williams: No-Nonsense Jumper
description: Annie Laurie Williams of Muncie, Ind., sat in Joe Louis Arena with her two sisters Saturday, watching the high-jump final of the National Collegiate indoor track and field championships.

title: Katherine A. Park Is Dead at 78; Long a Backer of Fresh Air Fund
description: Katherine A. Park, a longtime supporter of the Fresh Air Fund and a member of the board of the Morningside House Nursing Home on Pelham Parkway in the Bronx, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 78 years old and also lived at the Onteora Club in Tannersville, N.Y.

title: RANGER'S SUNBERG SEES A GOOD CHANGE
description: The Texas Rangers had a meeting today with their board chairman, president and chief executive officer. All those positions are filled by one man, Eddie Chiles, and he is the man, the Rangers say, who has instilled some semblance of stability into an organization whose revolving door always seemed to be turning at full speed.

title: Nit-Picking the Reagan Program
description: Now it's Congress's turn to wrestle with the details of the new Reagan economic program, and it might start by ignoring the flap over the accuracy of the Administration's economic forecast.

title: New 6-Month Bills Dip to 12.1%; A.T.&T. Notes Set at 13.25%
description: Prices in all sectors of the credit market moved up yesterday, with corresponding declines in yields on fixed-income and other securities. The softening of rates was particularly notable at the weekly sales of Treasury bills, as well as in the pricing of the new American Telegraph and Telephone Company notes scheduled for sale today.

title: MAYOR CHARGES THAT JUDGES 'DISPUTE' GUN CONTROL LAW
description: Mayor Koch charged New York City's judges yesterday with ''diluting'' the state's new gun control law and said he would ask the State Legislature to toughen that law by virtually eliminating the judges' sentencing discretion in gun cases.

title: FROM SCAASI, STARFISH AND OTHER CUSTOM-MADE IDEAS
description: Consider the starfish. This may very well be the year it enters fashion's menagerie alongside the butterfly, tiger and leopard, which have lent their markings to prints for so long they are as familiar as checks and flowers.

title: News Analysis
description: If you leave out the British Embassy and a chic shop or two on the Faubourg St. Honore, the American Embassy is virtually cheek by jowl with Elysee Palace, the official quarters of the President of France.

title: HOPES FOR IMPROVING MEMORY GROW, BUT ITS PRECISE NATURE IS STILL DEBATED
description: ''Suppose we try to recall a forgotten name. The state of our consciousness is peculiar. There is a gap therein, but no mere gap. It is a gap that is intensely active. A sort of wraith of the name is in it; beckoning us in a given direction, making us at moments tingle with the sense of closeness and then letting us sink back without the longed for term. If wrong names are proposed to us, this singularly definite gap acts immediately so as to negate them.'' WILLIAM JAMES By WALTER SULLIVAN

title: Gulf Curtailments
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said its United States unit would close its Toledo, Ohio, refinery and a portion of its Venice, La., refinery because of declining demand for petroleum products and excess refining capacity in the industry. Gulf said the two refineries represent about 8 percent of its United States refining capacity.

title: Schmidt-Giscard Accord Reached on Most Issues
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France agreed fully on world issues in talks last night but apparently did not bridge their differences on the European Economic Community.

title: POLES CALL OFF PLANS FOR A WALKOUT AFTER 2-LOCAL OFFICIALS LOSE POSTS
description: The Solidarity trade union movement called off plans tonight for a series of work stoppages in this industrial city after the authorities accepted the resignation of two local officials whose ouster had been sought by the union. The authorities also agreed to discuss other demands by the local branch of the union.

title: REAGAN ASSAILS BUREAUCRATS WHO CRITICIZE BUDGET CUTS
description: President Reagan returned to the task of selling his economic program today by lashing out at bureaucrats who run Government social programs and by complaining that critics have distorted his plans to curtail such programs.

title: Advertising; People Ads Please Time Inc.
description: WHEN Time Inc. introduced People magazine seven years ago this month with its unusually high circulation rate base of one million, there was no surprise that the big advertisers were the tobacco, alcoholic beverage and automobile industries. In fact, they accounted for 55 to 60 percent of all advertising in the weekly, according to Richard B. Thomas, associate publisher and ad director.

title: LOS ANGLES SCHOOLS END BUSING PROGRAM
description: The Los Angeles Board of Education voted tonight to end a program of mandatory busing that was designed to integrate the nation's second largest school district.

title: IRISH FACE GROWING BROOD OF JOBLESS, BORED TEEN-AGERS
description: On most weekdays and especially on weekends, the Late Night Village candy store on Malahide Road here is packed with young people. Most are high school age, some are dropouts and many are unemployed graduates.

title: MARYLAND TOWN PROTESTING POSTAL TRAINING CENTER
description: The United States Postal Service has committed $28 million to establish a school for supervisors on 83 rolling acres in this community, one of the wealthiest in the nation. Some civic groups are objecting, asserting that the agency's activities will mean traffic, noise, congestion and unwanted change.

title: STRINDBERG ANTIFEMINIST? A LOUD, CLEAR 'NO' VOTE
description: It isn't essential to be Swedish to direct Strindberg but it can't hurt. So for the Circle in the Square production of the playwright's 1887 classic ''The Father,'' Theodore Mann, the company's artistic director, reached across the Atlantic for Goran Graffman, one of the leading lights of the Royal Dramatic Theater in Stockholm.

title: Jersey Aide Ousted In CETA Inquiry
description: TRENTON (AP) - A State Labor and Industry Department official has been dismissed and three others have been transferred in an investigation of job-training funds provided under the Federal Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.

title: Riders Group Backs DelBello Rail Plan
description: The Council of Commuter Organizations, a group representing Long Island and Conrail riders, announced its support yesterday of Westchester County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's plan to remove the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven commuter lines from the jurisdiction of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and put the lines under a separate commuter-rail authority.

title: Flynn Signs 5-Year Pact
description: Doug Flynn finally signed his contract with the New York Mets today, ending several weeks of controversy over language and guarantees, and also ending any chance that he would become a free agent.

title: 62 FEDERAL GRANTS RESTORED, INCLUDING 7 IN THE STATE
description: The Federal Government announced today the unfreezing of 62 Economic Development Administration grants and loan guarantees across the country, including seven projects worth $10.5 million in New York State.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S WARNING EMBRACE
description: To the Editor:

title: 1980 FOREIGNERS' TRADING IN U.S. STOCKS UP BY 72%
description: Foreign buying and selling of American stocks increased dramatically last year, according to an analysis by the Securities Industry Association, a Wall Street trade group.

title: MAKING A PITCH FOR ILLUSTROIUS SHORTSTOPS
description: To the Editor:

title: BENIGN TUMORS OF THE HEART WERE KILLERS ONCE
description: ADOCTOR does not have to be very old to remember diseases that were once barely mentioned in medical school because not only were they incurable, they could not even be diagnosed. Today, doctors are curing tumors of the heart that were almost invariably fatal only 30 years ago because they could be diagnosed only after death. The heart tumors are called myxomas and they are so rare statistics on their frequency are not kept. Although noncancerous, they are potential killers if not detected in time. Usually myxomas are painless and small ones may never cause symptoms. But larger myxomas can kill, sometimes suddenly, sometimes over a period of years.

title: Host Pajamas' Executive Foresees Sales Growth
description: Milton Margolis, 58, has been named president of Host Pajamas Inc., a major manufacturer of pajamas, robes and loungewear. He succeeds Irving Cohen, 65. Mr. Cohen will become chairman while continuing as chief executive officer.

title: YOUTH OUTWITS MERIT EXAM, RAISING 240,000 SCORES
description: Persuaded by a Florida schoolboy that his ''wrong answer'' was in fact correct, the Educational Testing Service has raised the scores of nearly a quarter million high school students who took the Preliminary Scholastic Aptitude Test in October.

title: MAURITANIA REPORTS IT HAS FOILED AN ATTEMPTED COUP BY 2 EXILES
description: The Mauritanian radio said today that a Moroccan-sponsored attempt to overthrow the military government in Mauritania had been foiled.

title: Dancer Keeps Audience Waiting an Hour in Vain
description: Gelsey Kirkland, for many years a leading dancer with the American Ballet Theater in New York until her dismissal last December for missing a dress rehearsal, failed to show up Sunday for a performance with the Tidewater Ballet Company at Goucher College in Towson, Md.

title: Iranian Defects to Turkey
description: An unidentified Iranian colonel forced an Iranian transport plane to land at Van in eastern Turkey today and has asked for political asylum, according to Turkish news agency reports. The Iranian officer has requested temporary asylum in Turkey but hopes to go to the United States, official sources said. He was accompanied by his wife and 10 other people.

title: THEATER: 'REQUEST CONCERT,' A WOMAN ALONE, AT INTERART
description: FRANZ XAVER KROETZ'S ''Request Concert,'' staged by JoAnne Akalaitis at the Interart Theater, is a strange, unsettling monodrama, a kind of voiceless equivalent of Jean Cocteau's ''The Human Voice.'' A middle-aged woman comes home to her apartment and goes through her nightly ritual. She hangs up her coat, prepares a dinner for one and immediately cleans up after herself. In this tidy studio apartment and in this equally tidy single life, there is a place for everything. She has sanitized, deodorized and compartmentalized herself into an ordered, empty existence.

title: TV: THE RETURN OF 'PALMERSTOWN'
description: ''PALMERSTOWN, U.S.A.,'' created by Norman Lear and Alex Haley, had a brief run on CBS-TV early last year. Tonight at 8 o'clock, the series is returning as simply ''Palmerstown.'' There's no explanation for the title adjustment, but the first new episode indicates that the producers are now aiming to establish a niche somewhere between ''Little House on the Prairie'' and ''The Waltons.''

title: A Lucky Role Once Again for Placido Domingo
description: A happy man today is Placido Domingo. Tonight he is scheduled to sing the role of Alfredo in the premiere of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''La Traviata,'' and he considers it a lucky role in his life.

title: Water Level Drops In City's Reservoirs
description: The water level in the 18 reservoirs feeding New York City dropped for the first time in six weeks as a result of a ''discouraging'' amount of precipitation in the first two weeks of March, Francis X. McArdle, the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner, said. The reservoirs are at 65.9 percent of capacity compared to a normal level of 90 percent, United Press International reported.

title: Market Place; Manufacturing CAT Scanners
description: THE computerized axial tomographer, or CAT scanner, was once viewed as a costly option in medical practice, but now it is perceived as a way of reducing a hospital's overall costs. That could be good news for what is left of the scanner industry.

title: 'Broadway Follies' Closes
description: ''Broadway Follies'' opened - and closed - Sunday night at the Nederlander Theater.

title: South-West African Group Hints U.S. Will Support It
description: Dirk Mudge, head of a South Africanbacked delegation from South-West Africa that came to the United States against State Department wishes, said today that he had ''vibrations'' that the Reagan Administration may switch United States support in favor of his group, rather than continuing to back the South-West Africa Peoples' Organization, a black-led insurgent movement fighting to end South Africa's rule in the territory.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Agrifuel Corporation directors have elected to sell the controlling interest in the company.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: J ON Baker needed a cigarette. Tall, 20 years old and tattooed, with two silver hoops piercing one ear and chain link around his neck, he was in from London to oversee the installation of his clothing store, Axiom, in SoHo, and he'd been up all night. ''Right, then,'' he said, lighting up and then exhaling a cumulus of smoke.

title: 'Hit Men' Hinted in Killing Of Philadelphia Mob Figure
description: The bomb that killed Philip C. Testa, the reputed organized crime leader here, was packed with finishing nails and shotgun pellets and may have been detonated electronically by ''hit men'' who watched from a car as their victim arrived home, investigators said today.

title: LSB Unit's Chinese Pumps
description: LSB Industries Inc. said yesterday that the Hercules Energy Corporation, its newly established oilfield service division, had started marketing in the United States a full line of pumps manufactured in China. LSB, which makes air-conditioning and heating equipment and markets machine tool products, said it had been involved in the machine tool business with China for about seven years.

title: Uniroyal Co. Halts Heavy-Duty Tires
description: The Uniroyal Tire Company, a division of Uniroyal Inc., said it had stopped making heavy-duty, off-road-vehicle tires for the mining and construction industries.

title: New York Banks Urged Delaware To Lure Bankers
description: DOVER, Del. - Gov. Pierre S. du Pont 4th of Delaware has been crisscrossing the country shopping for large banks interested in increasing their profits. The Governor wants them to relocate in Delaware and, as his aides put it, take advantage of the state's "hospitable climate" of "political stability and predictability."

title: The Police Blotter
description: A man suspected of robbing $15,000 from 20 banks in the last four months was arrested by detectives staked out at a Citibank branch at 250 Broadway after he passed a note to a teller demanding money. The suspect was identified as Nathaniel Harrington, 36 years old, of 9 Madison Street, Mount Vernon, N.Y. ... The manager of a Bronx jewelery store was shot when he tried to wrest a gun from one of two armed men during a robbery.

title: SENATE BUDGET PANEL SET TO EXCEED REAGAN'S SWEEPING SPENDING CUTS
description: The Senate Budget Committee prepared today to exceed the large budget cuts recommended by President Reagan, beginning a draft of legislation that senators said would result in the most sweeping curtailment of Federal programs and spending in the nation's history.

title: DRUGS THAT PROMISE HELP BUT NOT PROFIT RESIDE IN LIMBO
description: WASHINGTON EVERY so often a box full of brownish powder, a chemical called 5-HTP for short, arrives at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in upper Manhattan from a chemical manufacturer in San Diego. At Mount Sinai, staff workers in the laboratory of Dr. Melvin Van Woert funnel the powder, which costs about $1,000 a pound, into little capsules by hand. They dispense them to patients suffering from a rare but severely debilitating neurological disorder called myoclonus, which seems to respond to no regularly marketed drug.

title: 25 EXPECTING A TRIP TO CASINO ARE GIVEN SHORT BUS RIDE TO JAIL
description: When the fellows from the Good Buy crew gathered at Sullivan's Bar yesterday morning, they thought they were going on a gambling trip to Atlantic City. Indeed, the big blue and white bus parked in front of the tavern had a sign in the front window that read, ''Good Buy Charter.''

title: Talking Business with Macklin of Nasdaq O-T-C Trading: A Busy Field
description: More than 3,000 over-the-counter securities are quoted in the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotation system, known as Nasdaq. Trading in these securities is up 14.1 percent so far this year from the level of a year earlier. By contrast, turnover on the New York Stock Exchange in 1981 is down about 10 percent, and on the American Stock Exchange it is down about 32 percent.

title: United Parcel Workers End Wildcat Walkout
description: United Parcel Service's 4,200 employees in the New York metropolitan area returned to their jobs yesterday following a wildcat strike, and the company said the backlog in deliveries would be cleared up immediately.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: METS (NL) - Signed Doug Flynn, second b aseman, to a five-year contract with a base p ay of $1.9 million. The contract, which b egins at the start of the 1982 season, could r each as much as $2.46 million with incen- t ive clauses and bonuses. MONTREAL (NL) - Fined Bill Lee, p itcher, $300 for being late for a workout S unday. Lee had used an off-day Saturday to f ly to Montreal to attend a St. Patrick's Day p arty. NATIONAL LEAGUE - Announced the r etirement, effective immediately, of Andy O lsen, an umpire for 12 years. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Assigned Tim B urke, Cecilio Guante, Jeff Horne, Rafael V asquez and Ben Wiltbank, pitchers; Mar- v in Clack, Brad Garnett and Rich Renteria, i nfielders, and Scott Kuvinka, catcher, to its m inor-league training camp.

title: NEW YORK BANKS URGED DELAWARE TO LURE BANKERS
description: Gov. Pierre S. du Pont 4th of Delaware has been crisscrossing the country shopping for large banks interested in increasing their profits. The Governor wants them to relocate in Delaware and, as his aides put it, take advantage of the state's ''hospitable climate'' of ''political stability and predictability.''

title: KOCH PROPOSES NEW TAXES AS ALTERNATIVE TO FARE RISE
description: Mayor Koch has given Governor Carey a list of new taxes, including increases in the sales tax, the payroll tax, the gasoline tax and automobile registration fees. He asserts they would be better than a 10 to 15 cent increase in New York's 60-cent bus and subway fares.

title: Stay of Execution Granted To Convicted Virginia Killer
description: A Federal appeals court today granted a stay of execution to James Briley, who had been scheduled to die Wednesday in the electric chair for the rape-slaying of a pregnant mother and the shooting of her young son.

title: BELL PLANNING TV PHONE LINK
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked the Federal Communications Commission yesterday for permission to provide a television-conference service linking 41 cities.

title: Major Drug Raid in Texas Seizes 14 Men and 16 Tons of Marijuana
description: Drug agents arrested 14 persons and seized 16 tons of marijuana already loaded into a tractor-trailer in a major raid here yesterday.

title: A STRUGGLING RUBBER INDUSTRY
description: Despite sharp cutbacks in production capacity, a series of belt-tightening moves and new marketing strategies taken to revitalize operations, the domestic rubber industry is still about a year away from recovery, industry officials here say.

title: BROWN OF U.C.L.A. TO BE NAMED COACH OF NETS TOMORROW
description: The New Jersey Nets have called a news conference for tomorrow morning at Giants Stadium at The Meadowlands to name Larry Brown their coach for next season.

title: G.&W. Increases New Holdings
description: Gulf and Western Industries Inc. said it had increased its holdings in the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company and the Mohasco Corporation and planned to raise its stake in Libbey-Owens-Ford to 15 percent.

title: DEBATE OPENS ON CUTS IN FOOD STAMPS
description: As the Senate Agriculture Committee opened hearings today on the food stamp program, Senator Jesse Helms said he might push for even deeper budget cuts than those proposed by the Reagan Administration.

title: Kendall Reviews Grey
description: The Kendall Refining Corporation, a division of the Witco Chemical Corporation, is reviewing its relationship with Grey Advertising, which has been its agency for about three years. The product is Kendall Motor Oil. It is now in the process of screening agencies for its $2 million account, and hopes to be able to announce that selection on May 1.

title: Armco Raises Energy Stake
description: Armco Inc., the nation's fifthlargest steel producer, now earns more than half of its operating profits from energy-related businesses, the company said in its annual report.

title: RHINOS REAPPEAR UNEXPECTEDLY IN BORNEO'S JUNGLES
description: Deep in Borneo's jungles, wildlife experts have found tracks belonging to the Sumatran rhinoceros, which was long thought to have vanished from the island.

title: HOW THE RECOLLECTIONS OF WITNESSES OFTEN GO AWRY
description: In January 1979, the first of eight robberies took place in the suburbs of Wilmington, Del. After a few crimes, a pattern began to emerge from store clerks' description of the robber: a white, middleaged male, who wore a dark coat and walking hat and carried a small chrome-plated pistol. He was always polite, the clerks said, and the press soon labeled him the ''gentleman bandit.'' After the police put together a composite drawing from witnesses' descriptions, an anonymous phone call said the drawing resembled a local priest.

title: Cutbacks Assailed At Rally of Elderly
description: Four hundred elderly people rallied to start a campaign against Reagan Administration budget cutbacks. At the rally, at the offices of District 65 of the United Automobile Workers at 13 Astor Place, William Hutton, executive director of the National Council of Senior Citizens, assailed proposals for cuts totaling $41.4 billion in 83 major programs.

title: Toyota Raises Prices
description: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc. said it had raised prices of its cars and trucks an average of 3.9 percent, or about $252.

title: CHOICE OF 2D ECONOMIC AIDE REPORTED
description: William A. Niskanen, who was dismissed as chief economist of the Ford Motor Company because he opposed the company's advocacy of automobile import restrictions, has been chosen by the Reagan White House for the Council of Economic Advisers, Administration officials reported today.

title: WHAT OIL DECONTROL WON'T DO FOR AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, in proxy material for the company's April 6 annual meeting, asked shareholders to approve authorization for an issue of 50 million shares of preferred stock.

title: Don't Tamper Much With Building Success
description: New York's City Council is debating changes in the law that offers local tax benefits to those who recycle old buildings into new apartments. The 25-year-old law, called J-51, has recently, it seems, become too successful. So many buildings are being remodeled that some people think the incentives must be too generous to builders and too costly for the city.

title: BUSH STUMPS IN FLORIDA FOR REAGAN'S ECONOMIC PLAN
description: Vice President Bush has taken the selling of the Reagan economic program on the road with an eagerness that makes news conferences sound like pep rallies, urging one Florida group after another not to let it be ''fillet@ed,'' ''dissected,'' or ''whittled away.''

title: Accounts
description: * Columbia Pictures to Ogilvy & Mather for media buying in all but New York, Los Angeles and Florida.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STAND-UPS

title: Textron Units to Merge
description: The consumer products unit of the Jacobsen division of Textron Inc. will be merged with Textron's Homelite division in Charlotte, N.C., it was announced today by Textron, parent company of the two concerns.

title: TWO MAJOR OIL CONCERNS TO WIDEN COAL HOLDINGS
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Kemmerer Coal Company, one of the largest and oldest coal producers in the West, for $325 million. The purchase was the latest in a series of oil company acquisitions of natural resource concerns that has stimulated Wall Street.

title: Bridge: Grand National Event Won By Weichsel's Strong Team
description: Nearly all of New York's top-ranked players were in action Sunday when the unit stage of the Grand National teams took place at the New York Statler Hotel. The winners, with a 77 percent game, were Peter Weichsel, Alan Sontag, Mike Becker and Ron Rubin, a powerful foursome that could well give New York its first victory in the event, which will conclude in Boston in July.

title: MET OPERA: 'MANON LESCAUT' STARS TERESA ZYLIS-GARA
description: THE longest nights at the opera are not, as you might suppose, the nights when the singing is unequivocally bad. Genuine, unadulterated badness is so rare that an evening devoted to exploring it in depth can actually be an engrossing experience. No, the truly long nights are the ones that offer endless stretches of generally respectable but generally dull vocalism by artists who are either miscast or who fall into the category of perfect mediocrity.

title: PHILADELPHIA COMMUTERS COPE WITH TRANSIT STRIKE
description: Hundreds of thousands of commuters poured into the center of the city in cars, on bicycles, on motorcycles and on foot on rainy streets today as they faced their first regular workday after the start of a strike that has paralyzed the city's transit system.

title: BOMB DEVICES DEFUSED IN HARLEM
description: Two bomb devices were found in the basement of a Harlem apartment house yesterday. The second was found by bomb squad detectives as they were dismantling the first.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan, whose economic program is based on diminishing the Federal pork barrel, showed this weekend during his visit to New York City that the Reagan White House also understands how to hand out Government largess with political sensitivity.

title: Banks Sets U.S. Record Of 56-7 3/4 in Triple Jump
description: Willie Banks, former Olympian, set a United States triple-jump record yesterday, reaching 56 feet 7 3/4 inches on his final attempt during the U.C.L.A.-Long Beach State dual meet.

title: Poland Raises Prices of Drinks
description: Poles will have to pay up to 55 percent more for alcoholic drinks starting tomorrow under price increases announced tonight. The price increases are part of an official campaign against alcoholism in Poland. The official press agency P.A.P. said the price of vodka would go up by as much as 55 percent, beer by 10 percent and wine by 15 percent.

title: DOW ADDS 17.02, ENDS AT 1,002.79
description: The Dow Jones industrial average surged 17.02 points in a spectacular late rally yesterday to finish at 1,002.79. Thus, the stock market's favorite indicator burst with a flourish through the 1,000 barrier that has proved to be its nemesis so often in the past.

title: DEFYING COURT, PHYSICIANS PLAN TO STRIKE TODAY
description: About 2,000 physicians-in-training at seven municipal and two private voluntary hospitals in New York City were scheduled to strike at 7 this morning despite a State Supreme Court injunction barring strikes by public employees.

title: ALBANY FABRIC MAKER JOINS WAR ON INSECTS
description: The Albany International Corporation, a manufacturer of felts and fabrics for the paperindustry, has tapped its fabric treatment technology to produce a new method of insect control.

title: Finland's St. Uhro Growing in Popularity
description: They've never heard of him in Finland, but that doesn't make any difference to James Honkanen and thousands of other Finnish-Americans in Michigan and five other states. To them, St. Uhro drove the pests out of Finland and so yesterday they celebrated St. Uhro Day.

title: THE DAY I LOST MY CITIZENSHIP
description: On Jan. 21, I awakened, still a Soviet citizen, in the Holiday Inn at Yuma, at the juncture of the borders of Arizona, California, and Mexico. It was an ordinary morning, with no particular sense of premonition. After breakfast we began the last day of our car trip from Michigan to California.

title: Redford Wins Directors' Prize
description: In his directorial debut, Robert Redford has won the 1980 award of the Directors Guild of America for ''Ordinary People.'' The prize, conferred by the 6,200 members of the guild for the best-directed motion picture, usually foretells an Academy Award. There were four other nominees, Michael Apted, ''Coal Miner's Daughter''; David Lynch, ''The Elephant Man''; Richard Rush, ''The Stunt Man,'' and Martin Scorsese, ''Raging Bull.''

title: DONOVAN SAYS U.S. WILL LIMIT ROLE IN LABOR-MANAGEMENT WAGE TALKS
description: Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan said today that collective bargaining worked best without Government intervention and that the Reagan Administration would ''never'' propose a wage guideline or other income policies to fight inflation.

title: TURKEY STILL HOLDS NON-COMMUNIST LABOR LEADERS
description: ''They accuse my father of trying to overthrow the state but he is only a trade unionist and a district leader of Ataturk's party,'' the teen-age girl said. ''How could he threaten the state?''

title: A LEADING U.S. CRITIC OF AID TO EL SALVADOR HAS TALK WITH DUARTE
description: Representative Clarence D. Long, a leading critic of military aid to El Salvador, met here today with Jose Napoleon Duarte, President of the ruling junta, and said afterward that their talks were ''very forthcoming.''

title: State Raising Fees At Park Camp Sites
description: ALBANY (UPI) - Rental rates for both state park camping areas and cabins are to be increased effective next month, the State Office of Parks and Recreation said. In separate statements, the agency said the cabin fees would be increased by $8 to $20, depending on the size of the cabin.

title: A REAGAN NOMINEE IS ACCUSED OF CONFLICTS OF INTEREST
description: James L. Malone, nominated as Assistant Secretary of State for the Bureau of Oceans and International, Environmental, and Scientific Affairs, was accused today before a Senate panel of conflicts of interest.

title: OREGON STATE COACH AGAINST BYE SYSTEM
description: Oregon State's coach, Ralph Miller, does not want any more firstround byes in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: Sauce Squad
description: The dinner preparations were extraordinary - but then so was the guest. Before Ronald Reagan visited Le Cirque, a fashionable East Side restaurant, last Saturday night, innumerable inspectors paid their calls.

title: 'BANISHED' IN SOUTH AFRICA, SHE VOWS TO OVERCOME
description: A white woman called from across the street as Winnie Mandela got out of her car in front of the post office here today. She hadn't seen her in a while, the woman said in a friendly voice, and hoped that didn't mean Mrs. Mandela was cross with her.

title: KEY FIGURE IN FEDERAL JAILBREAK ATTEMPT RELEASED
description: A Legal Aid Society employee who had been described as a ''major engineer'' of an attempted helicopter escape from a Federal jail in Manhattan last January was ordered released without bail yesterday because of allegations that the Government had arrested the wrong man.

title: LET THERE BE LIFE
description: Sometimes it's hard to keep up. First it was life created in a test tube. Then patented life forms. And now we're told that all Congress has to do is pass a statute redefining ''life'' - by declaring fetuses to be ''persons'' from the moment of conception - and, presto, Roe v. Wade, the United States Supreme Court's 1973 decision preventing legislative interference with abortions until late pregnancy will disappear. No muss, no fuss, and, most important, no struggle for all the votes it would take to amend the Constitution the old-fashioned way.

title: Profits in Amax Options Freed
description: A Federal judge lifted a temporary restraining order against Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. yesterday, allowing the brokerage firm to distribute profits made by customers who bought Amax Inc. options.

title: White Motor Set For Canadian Sale
description: The United States Bankruptcy Court in Cleveland has approved the sale of the White Motor Corporation's Canadian assets, the company said today.

title: RENTALS STARTING FOR APARTMENTS NEAR THE BATTERY
description: Advance rentals began yesterday for apartments in Gateway Plaza at Battery Park City, which is to be the first luxury-priced housing development built in lower Manhattan. Prices begin at $619 a month for a studio apartment.

title: KOCH,IN MIAMI, MAKES BOND PITCH
description: Edward I. Koch, an unlicensed bond salesman, traveled to this city of sunshine today to convince local bankers and investors that New York City, at last, was a sound financial risk.

title: 'THE FACT OF EVOLUTION IS BEYOND DISPUTE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Markets
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.02 points, to 1,002.79, in a late-afternoon rally. This brought the index within 12 points of its best level in four and a half years. Strong performers included computer, steel, brokerage, technology, railroad and precious metal stocks. Turnover on the Big Board, however, dropped to 49.9 million shares from 68.3 million on Friday. (D1.)

title: MRES. THATCHER'S AUSTERITY BUDGET IS APPROVED, BUT SOME TORIES REBEL
description: The House of Commons approved Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's new austerity budget tonight, despite a revolt in the Conservative Party by some 30 members who voted against the bill or abstained and the defection of one who resigned from the party to protest the budget.

title: A DAY IN THE LIFE OF A SCHOOL PRINCIPAL IS, MAINLY, LONG
description: Ask Jules Linden, the principal of Intermediate School 54, the key to his success, and his answer is deceptively simple. ''Look behind you,'' he tells a visitor in his office, pointing to his open door. Through the door come all the school's disciplinary and learning problems, labor disputes, health emergencies and just about every other difficulty of daily school life - from the girl who jams her finger in a doorway to the ninth-grade boy who still cannot read, from a group of teachers irate about the food in the cafeteria to a student caught in the lunchroom with a knife.

title: MILITARY JET CRASH IN ALASKA KILLS 5
description: Five crewmen were killed and seven were injured in the crash of an Air Force reconnaissance jet yesterday at the isolated Shemya Air Force Station in the Aleutian Islands, military officials said tonight.

title: DELAYS MAY COST CITY MILLIONS IN AID FOR HEAD START
description: Thousands of poor preschool children in New York City have been kept out of the Head Start program because the city has failed to complete a federally financed expansion begun in 1978, according to Federal officials. They are threatening to withdraw several million dollars from the program.

title: N.H.L. Suspends Two
description: The National Hockey League yesterday suspended two additional players and levied fines totaling more than $15,000 as a result of numerous brawls Feb. 26 between the Boston Bruins and the Minnesota North Stars at Boston Garden.

title: College Students Polled on Drug Use
description: A survey of drug use among college students released yesterday by the New York State Division of Substance Abuse showed that two out of three had used some illegal substance or drug at least once in the six months before the statewide poll was taken.

title: Virginia Railroad Nominates President
description: The board of the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad Company has nominated John J. Newbauer Jr., 57 years old, as president, effective May 1. If elected by stockholders at the annual meeting on April 20, he would succeed Stuart Shumate, who will retire from the railroad's chief executive position at the age of 65.

title: THE MIDDLE SCHOOL IS 20 YEARS OLD AND STILL CHANGING
description: THE junior high school, says Paul S. George, chairman of the middle school program at the University of Florida, was ''the Edsel of American education, but for several decades few were aware that it wasn't selling.'' It was intended as a buffer between elementary and high school, a safe haven in which preadolescents, roughly from age 10 to 14, would be protected from the corrupting influence of high schoolers. At the same time, of course, they would presumably not corrupt grade schoolers.

title: DU PONT NAMES NEW LEADERS
description: Two executives who began their careers at E.I. Du Pont de Nemours & Company as research chemists 30 years ago were named today to lead the huge chemical company when Irving S. Shapiro, 64 years old, retires to private law practice on May 1.

title: AMID THE HIGH DRAMA OF THE SHUTTLE, A MECHANIC PLAYS A PAINSTAKING ROLE
description: hour shift, he empties his pockets, pulls a tight, knitted sleeve over his wrist watch, and runs a bandage lashed around his wrist through the wedding ring on his finger. He then rides an elevator high above the windswept flats of Cape Kennedy and goes to work on the space shuttle Columbia.

title: IRISH EYES ON HUNGER
description: If there are Reagan roots in Tipperary, the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick surely will ferret them out for attention and celebration today. President Reagan's connection with the Irish predates his portrayal of The Gipper. ''Dutch'' was just a childhood nickname. His surname assigns him to the ranks of Irish-Americans whose forebears were the ''boat people'' of the 1840's.

title: T.W.A. CUTS SOME FARES 50-70%
description: In a major effort to stimulate its sluggish passenger traffic, Trans World Airlines said yesterday that round-trip coach and economy fares on most domestic flights would be held to a maximum of $298 for a five-week period starting April 20.

title: G.M. Talks in Mexico
description: The General Motors Corporation is negotiating a joint venture with a Mexican company to build heavy-duty diesel engines in Mexico, a trade journal, Metalworking News, reported today. It said the venture, involving G.M.'s Detroit Diesel Allison division, would fall in line with the division's expansion plans outside the United States. A General Motors spokesman said, ''We are interested in doing business in Mexico and have been talking with the Mexican Government for some time,'' but he added that no agreements had been signed.

title: HOUSING, INFLATION AND TAXES
description: Interest rates, energy scarcity, and demographic changes are widely perceived as principal causes of unaffordable and scarce housing, but the Federal tax code is equally a factor, and is more readily modifiable.

title: ROWDY AND DRINKING TEEN-AGERS WIDESPREAD IN MIDTOWN
description: Thousands of teen-agers in Manhattan used St. Patrick's Day as an occasion to drink openly in the streets and to push and shove each others and passers-by. In Central Park, some of them climbed a 50-foot-tall flagpole and swung from a high weather vane.

title: PLEAS TO REOPEN ROSEDALE SCHOOL DENIED BY COURT
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday rejected a motion to reopen a predominantly white annex to a Queens junior high school. Leaders of a six-week boycott are considering whether to continue their protest.

title: AUTO WORKERS MAY SOON REJOIN FEDERATION BUT OTHERS SEEM COOL
description: The United Automobile Workers union may rejoin the A.F.L.-C.I.O. later this year, but other major independent unions, including the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the United Mine Workers are not now moving toward the welcome mat laid out by the labor federation.

title: CRANSTON SEES IRAQ AS NUCLEAR POWER BY '82
description: Senator Alan Cranston of California, the Democratic whip, said today that Iraq could develop a nuclear weapon by the end of this year and that Pakistan could produce ''assembly line'' nuclear weapons by the end of next year.

title: Disapproval of Reagan Up Sharply in New Poll
description: President Reagan's handling of his job after eight weeks in office wins less approval from the public than any newly elected President in 28 years, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Foremost-McKesson Selects President for Its New Division
description: Foremost-McKesson, Inc., the $4 billion chemicals, liquor, food and pharmaceutical corporation, has established a fifth major unit called a development group and appointed Roy B. Miner, 57, as its president. Mr. Miner will continue to be based at the parent company's San Francisco headquarters.

title: TV STARS TO TAKE LEADS IN 'OUR SONG' ON APRIL 7
description: DIANA CANOVA and Ted Wass will take over the leading roles in ''They're Playing Our Song'' on April 7, replacing Anita Gillette and John Hammil. Although Miss Canova is new to Broadway, and Mr. Wass was there only once - in ''Grease'' - the casting is considered a mild sort of coup for Emanuel Azenberg, the producer. Miss Canova and Mr. Wass are television stars.

title: URANIUM TRUST SUITS SETTLED OUT OF COURT
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced separately today that they had reached out-of-court settlements with a group of multinational concerns accused of conspiring to rig the price of uranium and cheat the nation's utilities out of millions of dollars.

title: DETROIT MAYOR IS FACING TROUBLED DRIVE FOR 3D TERM
description: When the Reagan Administration decided to spare from its budget-cutting a $30 million Federal grant toward construction of a new General Motors assembly plant in downtown Detroit, the announcement came not from the project's ardent champion, Mayor Coleman A. Young, but from the Governor's office in Lansing.

title: 4 in OPEC Confer, Perhaps on Output
description: Four Arab oil ministers met privately today amid speculation they were discussing possible cuts in production.

title: Bonn Assails Soviet Bid To Sway Public on Arms
description: A West German official said today that Bonn was deeply concerned about recent Soviet attempts to influence German public opinion against accepting a NATO decision to deploy mediumrange nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: TRACY NELSON'S 2 WORLDS
description: blues singer who played the Bottom Line last Sunday, has never had much commercial success. During her 15-year career Miss Nelson has recorded on most of the major labels and won a goodly amount of critical acclaim, but her records haven't always received the promotion they deserved and her performing career has been erratic.

title: Another Kind of Green
description: We've been seeing a lot of green around town. Yesterday, of course, was St. Patrick's Day. But for the last month or so another green has shown up on people's lapels - an upside-down V of green ribbon, and it is a sign of life, and mourning, for the 20 slain children of Atlanta.

title: Swan Goes 3 Innings With Flying Colors
description: Craig Swan pitched in a game today for the first time in almost seven months, and, after three snappy innings without pain, he received a standing ovation from his teammates in the Mets' dugout.

title: PROSPECTS GOLDEN FOR INDIANA'S THOMAS
description: For Isiah Thomas, the most difficult part of life is behind him, but the most complex part is ahead. One by one, the doors are opening on and off the basketball court, just as he has always hoped. At the age of 19, in his sophomore year at Indiana University, Thomas will soon be faced with the decision of which doors to walk through, and when.

title: Brown Catalyst in Nets' Shifts
description: Joseph Taub, principal owner of the Nets, confirmed yesterday that Larry Brown had been appointed head coach effective the end of the season, replacing Bob MacKinnon, and that this was only one move in a shake-up of the New Jersey coaching staff and front office.

title: JERSEYANS SAY FARE INCREASES MAY COST JOBS
description: Hardened commuters, tempered by regular fare increases, delays, overcrowding and malfunctioning air-conditioners, were unusually upset by proposals for sharp fare increases as they trudged through the midtown Port Authority Bus Terminal yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Action on Milk Price Bill Delayed to Improve Its Chances
description: After failing today to block an amendment they feared would imperil their chances of repealing the April 1 adjustment in milk price supports, Republican leaders in the Senate postponed action on the question until Thursday.

title: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -Personal income of Americans rose seventenths of 1 percent in February, the smallest monthly gain since last summer, the Commerce Department reported today.
description: The department also said the rise, down from 1 percent in January, was outstripped by the rise in personal spending for the second consecutive month.

title: Bobby Short Providing a Chance He Never Had
description: He started playing the piano professionally at the age of 9 and never had formal studies, but now Bobby Short, the nightclub singer who got his early training in a roadhouse near his Danville, Ill., home, has lent his name to an effort to see that other promising young pianists get off to a better start. A scholarship is being established in his name at the Stecher & Horowitz School of the Arts in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: U.S. STEEL SOHIO END COAL TALKS
description: Because of a dispute over price, a plan by the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) to buy $750 million worth of coal and mining facilities from the United States Steel Corporation has collapsed, the companies announced yesterday.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: A NEIGHBOR recently pointed out to me what he considers an important omission over the years in this column and that is the lack of dishes tailored especially for Sunday brunch. That is probably because I rarely serve a meal on weekends that I could specifically label as lunch in my own home. As often as not the Sunday meal will consist of a simple fish soup or broiled fish or lobster, depending on the season, and, if there are guests or the children around, a substantial meal that might involve a roast or some sort of ragout.

title: DANCE: MERCE CUNNINGHAM COMPANY
description: MERCE CUNNINGHAM'S choreography and approach to dance are so different from anyone else's that no matter how often his work is seen, a certain adjustment process by the viewer is always in order.

title: FOUR ARE HURT
description: A suspicious four-alarm fire, fanned by heavy winds, destroyed an Orthodox synagogue in Astoria, Queens, last night, and spread to an adjoining synagogue and two frame houses before being contained.

title: Retail Sales Revised Upward
description: Retail sales by American merchants rose slightly more last month than previously reported, the Commerce Department said today. Department officials also said sales for all of last year grew faster than estimated.

title: Kush Jury to Begin Deliberations Today
description: Jurors here are expected to begin deliberating sometime tomorrow on whether Frank Kush, the former Arizona State football coach, and others responsible for overseeing the university's athletic program should pay a former player $2.2 million in damages.

title: Market Place; Highway Back From Default
description: INVESTORS take note: The highway from nowhere to nowhere finally appears to be getting somewhere. Back in 1952, planners of the West Virginia Turnpike billed it as the nucleus of a highway system that was to stretch from the Great Lakes to Florida. But the north-south connecting routes were delayed for many years and some were never built.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION SUFFERS FIRST DECLINE IN 7 MONTHS
description: The index of the nation's industrial production declined five-tenths of 1 percent in February after six consecutive monthly increases, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: U.S. Jury Indicts 10 As Labor Racketeers
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn returned indictments against 10 persons, including the president, the former president and the secretary-treasurer of Local 29 of the Blasters, Drillers and Miners Union.

title: Giscard Accused Anew On African Diamonds
description: President Valery Giscard d'Estaing's most persistent journalistic critic has accused him anew about diamonds given him by Jean-Bedel Bokassa, former Emperor of the Central African Empire.

title: Advertising;  New Flavor For Cutty Sark Ads
description: DEDICATED advertising readers with a proclivity toward whisky promotions are in for a shock when the new Cutty Sark Scotch campaign is introduced later this month.

title: Fashion Institute Loses in Tourney
description: DeWayne Shepard scored 22 points tonight and four of his teammates scored in double figures as Westark, Ark., routed the Fashion Institute of Technology of New York City, 87-55, in first-round action of the 34th annual National Junior College basketball tournament.

title: GUERARD RETHINKS NOUVELLE CUISINE
description: Michel Guerard, the high priest of nouvelle cuisine, is experiencing a minor loss of faith: What was intended as a breath of fresh air, he says, is inducing claustrophobia.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: FOR the past decade, Duncan G. Steck has been collecting old postcards during his travels about Manhattan. Not just any old postcards, mind you, but only those that cost less than a dollar - and some as little as 15 cents. He has found them in bins and boxes in secondhand shops all over town, on Canal Street especially, and on Columbus Avenue in the years before the quiche invasion.

title: Hard Days For the Democrats
description: When President Reagan presented his budget, he invited the Democratic Party to come forward with a better recovery program of its own, if it had one. So far, no party response.

title: MacNamara & Clapp Open In Hyde Park Hotel
description: MacNamara & Clapp, one of the agencies in competition for Mem's English Leather business, is a new agency that opened its doors in the Hyde Park Hotel. Jeffrey W. Clapp, 42 years old, is president, and Frank W. MacNamara, 41, executive vice president.

title: FORD FUND STRESSES WOMEN'S ISSUES
description: A FRESH perspective on women's roles, job opportunities and sex stereotypes is coming these days from the Ford Foundation, and it is a change that could shake up traditional thinking well beyond the world of philanthropy.

title: U.S. MAY END EMBARGO ON ARGENTINE MILITARY AID
description: Administration officials said today that President Reagan was considering a request to Congress to repeal the embargo on military aid to Argentina.

title: Fire Department Gets Its First Female Medical Officer
description: When Dr. Kerry J. Kelly reported for duty yesterday at the New York City Fire Department's medical division, the 30-year-old family care specialist became the first woman in the department's 116-year history to be a medical officer

title:
RED SMITH;
Jim Frey and His Young Royals
description: FORT MYERS, Fla. WHEN James Gottfried Frey was managing Bluefield, W.Va., in the Appalachian League, he thought it was a pretty big deal, qualifying him as a prominent figure in the community. At a party, a guest asked Cindy Frey what her daddy did.

title: TV: 'THE GREATEST AMERICAN HERO
description: IT'S about this schoolteacher who is given unearthly powers by some alien beings floating around in eerily shimmering Unidentified Flying Objects. Reaching hurriedly for your dial would be perfectly understandable. But, as it turns out, ''The Greatest American Hero,''a two-hour movie on ABC-TV tonight at 8, is considerably more diverting than its premise might indicate. This is not merely a variation on ''Mork & Mindy.'' It has a devilish little mind of its own.

title: New Coach Knows Pro Game
description: It is often said of Larry Brown, without much exaggeration, that he was raised on a basketball court. As a youth, he spent almost all his spare time, summers and winters, on an outdoor concrete court near the bakery his mother operated in Long Beach, L.I.

title: 'WORKFARE' PROGRAM IN CALIFORNIA GOT MIXED REVIEWS
description: When Gov. Ronald Reagan announced his ''work for welfare'' program for California in December 1971, he called it ''the very cornerstone'' of his welfare reform plan.

title: STRIKE ON MARCH 27 CALLED UNAVOIDABLE
description: Last-minute efforts to overcome a deadlock in the coal labor negotiations here failed late this afternoon, and leaders of the United Mine Workers of America sent the union's 39-member bargaining council home. With that action, a strike on March 27 is unavoidable, union leaders said.

title: COST OF THE WEEKLY MARKET BASKET DECLINES
description: THE average weekly cost of feeding a family of four in New York City went down 44 cents to $102.69 during the period of March 2 through March 13. Shoppers paid 12 percent more during this time than they did a year ago. The 41 items in the weekly market basket cost an average of $103.13 during the period ended Feb. 27.

title: A Seat on the Bus
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: CAREY EXPECTED TO ASK LEGISLATURE TO END BUSINESS TAX AID PROGRAM
description: The state's Job Incentive Program, which has come under attack for granting millions of dollars in tax relief to businesses that did not need it, would be abolished under a proposal expected to be presented by Governor Carey tomorrow.

title: BLACK FIFERS ARE MARCHING IN
description: Black fife-and-drum bands that play a mixture of marching music and blues are still popular attractions at country picnics in north Mississippi, and tonight and tomorrow night the first of these bands to play in New York will be at Tramps, l25 East l5th Street (777-5077).

title: CAROL BURNETT AND ENQUIRER CLASH IN COURT
description: Carol Burnett, the actress, testified today that her body began to shake and ''to do flip-flops'' after she learned that she had been depicted by The National Enquirer as ''boisterous'' and apparently drunk at a 1976 meeting with Henry Kissinger.

title: JUICY TOMATOES FROM ISRAEL
description: The tomato has been losing its clientele in recent years. That pale, pulpy, hard-as-a-rock fruit marketed across the country in cellophane-windowed cartons bears little resemblance to the juicy red tomato ripened on the vine.

title: DOW FALLS 10.26 POINTS
description: A late sinking spell sent the Dow Jones industrial average sharply lower yesterday following Monday's 17-point surge that had carried the indicator above the 1,000 mark that often has touched off selling.

title: Refugee Linked to Nazis Loses His U.S. Citizenship
description: A Federal judge today revoked the citizenship of a 76-year-old immigrant accused of war crimes in World War II.

title: The Talk of Kannapolis
description: Any week now, the Chamber of Commerce here is going to reconsider the merits of incorporating this town of 34,000 inhabitants about 25 miles northeast of Charlotte, in the heart of textile country.

title: Bridge: Asking Bids Are Still in Use,; But Few Try to LearnThem
description: In the mid-1930's the leading authority of that period, Ely Culbertson, offered to the bridge public his method of asking bids. He regarded these as a technical triumph but conceded that they were a public failure: Few players were willing to make the effort to learn them.

title: Panel to Monitor Cleanup At Three Mile Island
description: The owners of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant have hired a panel of top scientists to monitor safety while the plant is being cleaned up.

title: BILL ON CREATIONISM PASSES IN ARKANSAS
description: Arkansas schools would be required to give balanced treatment in public schools to the theories of evolution and scientific creationism under a bill approved today by the Legislature.

title: TIME OF TRIAL FOR ENERGY CHIEF
description: Energy Secretary James B. Edwards leaned forward at the witness table, his feet crossed at the ankles, his hands fidgeting with a large rubber band.

title: BOMB BURNS TWO DETECTIVES OUTSIDE BUILDING OF YIPPIES
description: Two bomb squad detectives were burned yesterday morning when an incendiary device they were examining exploded outside the Bleecker Street publication office of the Youth International Party, known in the 1960's as the Yippies.

title: Wife of Syrian Dissident Is Slain in West Germany
description: Two gunmen shot and killed the wife of a leader of the Moslem Brotherhood, a Syrian group opposed to President Hafez al-Assad, at her home in exile in West Germany today, the police said.

title: SHERIFF OF WESTCHESTER SUSPENDED BY DELBELLO ILLEGALLY, JUSTICE RULES
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's suspension of Thomas J. Delaney as Commissioner/Sheriff of Westchester was ''invalid and illegal.''

title: 6 1/4% Discount Rate Set By Japan Central Bank
description: The Bank of Japan, in a move to help stimulate the country's economy, reduced its discount rate by one percentage point today, to 6 1/4 percent, and lowered the amount of reserves that banks must maintain on deposit at the central bank without interest.

title: MEDICAID BOTTLENECKS ARE PUTTING THE SQUEEZE ON HOSPITALS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN LIFE BEGINS
description: To the Editor:

title: String Beans With Wasabi and Tamari Dip
description: 1 pound string beans 1 tablespoon wasabi paste (Japanese green horseradish) 1/2 cup tamari soy sauce.

title: Air Force Team to Study Crash Fatal to 5 in Alaska
description: An Air Force team flew to a remote landing strip in the Aleutian Islands today to determine what caused the crash of a Strategic Air Command reconnaissance plane with a crew of 24 aboard.

title: National Guard Planes Intercept Soviet Aircraft
description: Two Soviet reconnaissance planes were intercepted about 190 miles off the coast shortly after dawn today by two Massachusetts Air National Guard F106 fighters, from Otis Air Force Base, the Air Force announced.

title: GUNMEN SPRAY FIRE ON U.S. EMBASSY IN EL SALVADOR
description: In the second such attack in two weeks, two gunmen sprayed the United States Embassy with automaticrifle fire today just half an hour after an American Congressman ended a news conference in the heavily guarded building.

title: Q. Is it true that some caviars are colored with a black dye?
description: A. According to that reliable publication Sea Secrets, published by the International Oceanographic Foundation in Miami, the eggs of numerous fish, including whitefish, lumpfish and carp, are dyed black and sold as caviar. Originally the dye used on these eggs was carbon black, but the Food and Drug Administration banned this as cancer-causing. Vegetable dye is now most commonly used.

title: E. SCHUYLER ENGLISH, BIBLICAL SCHOLAR, 81
description: E. Schuyler English, a biblical scholar, author and a prominent figure in the evangelical Christian community, died Monday at Lankenau Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 81 years old and lived in Merion, a suburb of Philadelphia.

title: Accounts
description: * Pollio Dairy Products Corporation to Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler and Beaver Inc.

title: A SIMPLE, 30 SECOND EXAMINATION CAN HELP DETECT TESTICULAR CANCER
description: RONALD was 25 years and the father of a 2-month-old when he noticed a small lump on his right testicle. At his wife's insistence he called his doctor, who sent him to a urologist at a leading cancer center.

title: Turkey Weighs Asylum For Iran Air Force Defector
description: Turkey's ruling military authorities are considering a request for ''temporary asylum'' by an Iranian Air Force colonel who forced an Iranian Air Force plane to land at Van in eastern Turkey yesterday.

title: THE FISH DISH THAT CHANGED HIS LIFE
description: THERE have been times when taste sensations quite palpably shaped my career. I recall distinctly the first time I tasted classic French cooking, and the sensation was of such dimension as to seem almost spiritual.

title: Common Market Gives Food To China to Fight Starvation
description: The European Economic Community granted $6.2 million worth of food to China today in response to appeals from Chinese officials who say millions of people in two provinces are facing starvation.

title: BONDS GAIN ON HOUSING NEWS
description: The credit markets rallied in late trading yesterday after the Government reported that housing starts had plunged 24.6 percent last month. The news was considered a further indication that the nation's economy was slowing and that the demand for credit would ease further.

title: G.M. CHAIRMAN SAYS JAPANESE MIGHT WELCOME CAR RESTRAINT
description: Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said today that the Japanese might eagerly agree to restrain their auto exports voluntarily to avoid even more restrictive American legislation that could lead to a trade war.

title: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 18, 1981; The Economy
description: New-home construction fell 25 percent last month to 1.2 million units from 1.6 million, the Commerce Department said. The decline indicated that the U.S. economy may be slowing. But economists warned that a one-month change is not sufficient evidence of an economic trend. (D1.)

title: THE '81 CAMPAIGN FOR MAYOR OF NEW YORK OPENS AS A ONE-MAN SHOW
description: With few outward signs, the 1981 campaign for Mayor of New York City has started, and like the administration in City Hall, it is a one-man show.

title: NETS RALLY TO BEAT 76ERS IN OVERTIME
description: With Phil Jackson serving as head coach for most of the final quarter tonight the Nets staged a strong comeback and defeated the Philadelphia 76ers in overtime, 126-120.

title: IRAN MAY OUST 3 OFFICIALS TO EASE STRIFE
description: A senior Islamic cleric, who is Speaker of Parliament, and two legislators are likely to be ousted from Iran's Supreme Defense Council under Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's new formula for ending strife among Iranian leaders, the Ayatollah's office said today.

title: MUSIC: DA CAPO TOASTS COPLAND
description: THE Da Capo Chamber Players had a party for Aaron Copland and his friends Monday night, and for a few hours Carnegie Recital Hall seemed like a repository for American musical history.

title: 3 DEATHS LINKED TO MOB'S INTEREST IN JERSEY CASINOS
description: Three recent gang-style murders in Philadelphia, one of them Sunday, stemmed from members of organizedcrime maneuvering to infiltrate the Atlantic City casino industry, G. Michael Brown, director of the New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement, said today.

title: OPERA: ILLEANA COTRUBAS STARS IN 'TRAVIATA' AT THE MET
description: ONE of this Metropolitan Opera season's backstage crises came when Ileana Cotrubas backed out of the new production of ''La Traviata'' after deciding she could not agree to John Dexter's plan for restaging the Verdi classic. The soprano backed in again, however, when the opera was turned over to Colin Graham, a director with whom Miss Cotrubas found it possible to agree. Without attempting to decide who was right in the Cotrubas-Dexter disagreement, it can be noted that last night's premiere of ''La Traviata'' turned out to be one of this strike-shortened season's pure triumphs.

title: The Prince Falls Again
description: Prince Charles did it again yesterday, for the second time in four days, falling off a horse in another bid to qualify as a steeplechase jockey.

title: WOOLWORTH INTENSIFIES SPACE USE
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company, one of the nation's largest retailers, told analysts yesterday that it was seeking to increase profits by reducing the size of its retail stores, re-examining its use of existing space and converting some stores to different use.

title: CONSOLIDATED-BATHURST LIFTS NEWSPRINT 6%
description: A Canadian company's move to raise newsprint prices is expected to be followed by other major producers, but analysts say that future price increases will be more difficult to get because of additional new capacity and flat demand from the publishing industry.

title: CAREY PROPOSES RISE IN STATE SHARE OF M.T.A. COSTS
description: Governor Carey today informally sent legislative leaders a plan for the state to assume a greater share of the cost of operating the Metropolitan Transportation Authority over the next five years.
