But officials said that despite the plan, a fare of $1.10 on New York City's buses and subways would be needed in 1985.

title: Wes Unseld Retires
description: Wes Unseld, the 6-foot-7-inch center who was once said too short to play his position, announced his retirement today after having been a mainstay of the Washington Bullets for 13 seasons.

title: Delta Adds Routes
description: Delta Air Lines said that it had added four cities to its route system at Dallas-Fort Worth Airport and had increased service to four other cities. The new routes, effective April 26, include twice-daily, nonstop service between Dallas-Fort Worth and Fort Lauderdale and Tampa, Fla., and one daily nonstop between Dallas-Fort Worth and Tulsa, Okla., and Columbia, S.C. More frequent service will be provided between Dallas-Fort Worth and Baton Rouge and Monroe, La., and Houston and San Antonio.

title: by Richard Shepard
description: MUSIC MAN

title: HOW A ROCK TYCOON GOT TO THE TOP
description: LOS ANGELES ''HOW much do you want for the tapes? As much as you can get? Is this extortion?'' Irving Azoff covered the telephone receiver so that the party at the other end wouldn't hear him laughing at his own bravado. At 32, the small, bearded, intense Mr. Azoff is Hollywood's most formidable rock tycoon and a power in the film world as well. His Front Line Management guides the careers or handles the Eagles, Boz Scaggs, Steely Dan and other members of rock's platinum elite. He conceived and produced the successful film ''Urban Cowboy''; more important, he picked the music for the movie and issued the soundtrack album on his Full Moon label. The album was one of last year's biggest sellers and is widely credited with turning a movie that might otherwise have been a flop into a box-office smash.

title: JACKSON, BRISTLING, IS EAGER FOR SHOWDOWN
description: Reggie Jackson, describing himself as a ''walking keg of dynamite,'' said today that he was eager to have a confrontation with George Steinbrenner over the way he said Steinbrenner had treated him in recent weeks.

title: MOODY'S CONTINUES RATING CITY'S BONDS AS SPECULATIVE
description: New York City was set back yesterday in its efforts to re-enter the long-term borrowing markets when Moody's Investors Service reaffirmed its finding that the city's bonds were still a speculative investment.

title: Hinson Resigns From House
description: Representative Jon Hinson, Republican of Mississippi, who is facing a morals charge, submitted his resignation from Congress today, effective April 13.

title: WOMEN TO GET COMBAT TRAINING
description: 16 rifles, the Marines announced today. Included in the 44 hours of combat training scheduled this week are drills in handling, loading and firing the M-16, throwing grenades, rappelling from high towers and a night movement course to teach the recruits how to evade capture hidden mines and booby traps.

title: ROYAL BANK OF SCOTLAND BACKS OFFER BY STANDARD
description: In a move that represents the biggest shake-up in British banking in more than a decade, the Standard Chartered Bank and the Royal Bank of Scotland said today that they were discussing a merger valued at more than $1 billion.

title: EXPERTS FIND ENVIROMENT A FACTOR IN VULNERABILITY OF SLAIN ATLANTA CHILDREN
description: William Bohanon was sitting atop a low railing in front of a supermarket, waiting for a chance to push a grocery cart or carry a sack.

title: SHIPYARD, 2D LARGEST EMPLOYER IN CONNECTICUT, FORSEES LAYOFFS
description: Electric Boat said today that the Navy's decision to award contracts for three nuclear attack submarines to a competitor in Virginia would lead to ''substantial layoffs beginning later this year'' at the company's shipyards in Groton, Conn., and Quonset Point, R.I.

title: Carter Seeks Privacy During Princeton Visit
description: At his own request, Jimmy Carter's two-day visit to Princeton University, which began yesterday afternoon, is supposed to be a lowkey affair, during which he hopes to pick up some pointers on writing his memoirs.

title: HOW FACTS CAN DEVELOP FICTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Quintuplets Born At Rochester
description: ROCHESTER (AP) - An Ontario, N.Y., woman went into labor seven weeks prematurely at Strong Memorial Hospital here, then had three boys and two girls.

title: Jones Made $1 Million In His Last Year at G.E.
description: Reginald H. Jones, retiring chairman and chief executive of the General Electric Corporation, was paid $1 million in salary last year, an increase of $100,000 from 1979, plus $51,908 in expenses, the diversified manufacturer reported yesterday in its 1980 proxy statement to shareholders.

title: Commuters in Philadelphia Adjusting to Transit Strike
description: Striking mass transit workers today vowed to stay away from the negotiating table until they got a better offer, but most of the transit system's 400,000 daily riders appeared to be adjusting to the shutdown of bus, trolley and subway service.

title: West Point Net Down 14%
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc. reported today that its earnings for the second quarter, which ended Feb. 28, fell 14 percent, to $8.5 million, or $1.76 a share, from $9.9 million, or $2.18 a share, in the comparable period in 1980. J.L. Lanier Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of the textile company, said sales for the quarter dropped 3.5 percent, to $297.2 million, from $307.8 million in the second quarter a year ago.

title: GREEK PRICES SOARING SINCE COMMON MARKET ENTRY
description: Greece's entry into the Common Market on Jan. 1 has been marked by steep, almost daily, price increases and the Government is struggling to prevent the surge of inflation from bringing it defeat in elections next November.

title: ISLANDERS FIGHT JAPAN'S PLAN TO DUMP ATOM WASTE
description: Micronesian governments and antinuclear activists believe that they have succeeded in halting, at least for this year, a plan by the Japanese to dump radioactive waste from their 21 nuclear reactors into the Pacific, north of the Mariana Islands.

title: JOEL SCHLESINGER
description: Joel Schlesinger, an industrial real-estate broker and appraiser, and chairman of the board of the Schlesinger Company, an industrial real-estate concern of Clifton, N.J., died Monday at the Orange Memorial Hospital.

title: Nicaraguan Airline Fails
description: Nicaragua's Government-owned airline, La Nica, has declared bankruptcy and canceled all future flights, the Transportation Ministry said in a statement today. The airline's losses total $3.3 million, and it faces a $3.3 million lawsuit in the United States over allegedly delinquent lease payments on two Boeing 727's, the ministry added.

title: Ex-N.A.A.C.P. Aide Surrenders on L.I.
description: James Davis, 53 years old, of Glen Cove, former Long Island regional director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People surrendered to the Nassau County District Attorney after a grand jury indicted him on charges of forgery and attempted grand larceny.

title: Chris-Craft Tackles Fox Merger Obstacle
description: In an attempt to clear the way for a $700 million takeover of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, Chris-Craft Industries Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy back 300,100 of its shares from the Reliance Group for $40 apiece, or about $12 million.

title: THE FLOUR SIFTER
description: IN one of my restaurant jobs, as I recall, it was necessary to sift great quantities of flour, thousands of pounds of it, in the ordinary course of the work. Time and again as I would look down onto the sifting screen I would notice impurities in the flour, insects that had crept in, and worse. To this day, although screening out contaminants is not the main job of a good sifter, every time I use one of these gadgets I have a certain sense of the hygienic sagacity of it.

title: CUNNINGHAM AND CAGE AND A LIVELY DINNER
description: AT the opening night party for the Merce Cunningham Dance Company last evening, guests were invited to a lavish dinner of rich French food. But Merce Cunningham and John Cage weren't having any. Their dinner was homemade peanut butter sandwiches that they brought along in a brown paper bag.

title: FROM THE JUNGLE AND HAIR TO BOOKS AND HANDBAGS
description: 1. For Hemingway Heroines

title: City Sues to Block Tudor City Project
description: New York City's Housing and Preservation Commissioner sued in State Supreme Court to prevent Harry B. Helmsley's real-estate interests from building apartment towers in their two private Tudor City parks.

title: FURTHER LIBERALIZATION OF BANKING LAWS IS NOT PLANNED
description: - Key legislative leaders said today they had no plans to liberalize further New York State's banking laws to counter efforts by the State of Delaware to lure banking business through deregulation and tax cuts.

title: A CRY OF 'NO FUTURE' RALLIES WEST GERMANY'S YOUNG
description: ''Germany all downhill now - fire and flames,'' the scrawl in one place says. ''No future,'' another of the messages reads.

title: Car-Import Rift Lingers
description: A Cabinet-level committee agreed today that tax and regulatory relief should form the main components of aid for the domestic auto industry, but it remained divided over the need for import restraints against the Japanese.

title: THE U.S. TAKES A WRONG TACK ON THE LAW OF THE SEA
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; A Risky Course On Forecasting
description: THORSTEIN VEBLEN, renowned as the author of ''The Theory of the Leisure Class,'' was once asked how he would distinguish between history and conjectural history. ''It's like the difference,'' he said, ''between a horse and a sawhorse.'' Without resorting to analogies, one might say that history is what actually happened, according to the best evidence available, and conjectural history is what some author says might have happened.

title: Paupiettes de Sole au Vin Blanc (Sole rolls with white wine sauce)
description: 8 small, skinless, boneless fillets of sole or flounder, about 2 pounds 1 1/4 cups shrimp mousse, approximately (see recipe) 2 tablespoons plus 1 teaspoon butter 3 tablespoons finely chopped shallots Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste 8 small snow-white mushroom caps, stems removed 1/2 cup dry white wine 3/4 cup fish veloute (see recipe for veloute de poisson) 1 cup heavy cream Juice of half a lemon.

title: QUINN SIGNS 5-YEAR PACT
description: The Philadelphia Flyers announced today that Coach Pat Quinn had signed a new five-year contract.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Borg-Warner Acceptance Corporation has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement providing for the issuance of $50 million in 10-year notes due April 1, 1991, to be offered through underwritters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The offering of the notes is expected in early April.

title: General Goodpaster Will Retire Once Again
description: Lieut. Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster, the soldier-scholar who came out of retirement in 1977 to take command of the United States Military Academy when it was embroiled in the worst cheating scandal in its history, will retire for good in June.

title: 100,000 STEP UP FIFTH IN SALUTE TO ST. PATRICK
description: Fifth Avenue resounded to the joyful noises of the annual St. Patrick's Day parade yesterday, becoming a wintry canyon awash in green as New York's Irish celebrated their patron saint and themselves.

title: by Terry Robards
description: WHENEVER the Commanderie de Bordeaux, a group of oenophiles with a taste for Bordeaux wines and a passion for discourse, holds a dinner in mid-March, it is likely to be called a Parlement de Saint Patrice, and such was the case last week when the Commanderie gathered at the Laurent restaurant. Not a drop of whisky, Irish or any other kind, was in sight, and any resemblance to a typical St. Patrick's Day celebration ended with the appearance of the Irish saint's name in its French version on the menu covers.

title: ISRAELIS ON BUYING SPREE AND OPPOSITION IS ANGRY
description: Some weeks ago the Israeli Government was erasing the color from foreign films shown by the state-run television station in an effort to deter citizens from spending hard currency on color sets.

title: U.S. NOW VOICES REDUCED CONCERN THAT RUSSIANS MAY INVADE POLAND
description: After expressing apprehension for more than a week about impending Warsaw Pact maneuvers in and around Poland, the United States said today that intelligence information and Soviet assurances had reduced concern about possible Soviet military intervention in Polish affairs.

title: JERSEYAN MAY GET DUBLIN POST
description: raiser for the Republican Party, as Ambassador to Ireland, a White House source said today. Mr McCann, 50 years old, accompanied Mr. Reagan to a luncheon today at the Irish Embassy in Washington and was not immediately available for comment.

title: POLES MAY SEEK ASHES OF WORLD WAR II HERO
description: - Gen. Mieczyslaw Moczar, a Politburo member who heads the War Veterans Association, said today that he planned to seek the return of the ashes of Gen. Wladyslaw Sikorski, leader of Polish forces fighting against the Axis on the Allied side in World War II.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Acme General Corporation, San Dimas, Calif., announced that Herbert Hezlep 3d, chairman, had assumed the additional post of chief executive officer, and R. Bruce Hezlep had become president and chief operating officer. Also, the following were elected to the board of directors: Gregory R. Brundage, vice president-finance and corporate development of the Oasis Petroleum Corporation; Richard L. Daugherty, owner-operator of the David Copperfield Restaurant in Arcadia, Calif.; Robert L. Hemmings, chairman of Smith-Hemmings-Gosden, a marketing company, and E. James Murar, president of Recreactions Inc., a privately held real estate company.

title: Four Enter Guilty Pleas In Bogus Fence Arrests
description: Four of the men arrested Monday in an undercover operation by police officers posing as fences pleaded guilty last night to charges of criminal possession of stolen property.

title: Victory Declared in Battle to Make Camp Coed
description: Wonder Woman and Little Wonder Woman have struck again, this time winning a victory over New York State in their struggle against sexism.

title: MET OPERA: NEW MANON
description: THE longest nights at the opera are not, as you might suppose, the nights when the singing is unequivocally bad. Genuine, unadulterated badness is so rare that an evening devoted to exploring it in depth can actually be an engrossing experience. No, the truly long nights are the ones that offer endless stretches of generally respectable but generally dull vocalism by artists who are either miscast or who fall into the category of perfect mediocrity.

title: Heinz Sees Growth Without Mergers
description: The H.J. Heinz Company will not merge with other companies as a way of increasing its sales volume, the food concern's president, Anthony J.F. O'Reilly, told securities analysts.

title: CONGRESS PROPOSES 8 CANDIDATES TO REAGAN FOR COMPTROLLER POST
description: Congress has recommended eight persons to President Reagan for possible appointment as the next Comptroller General of the United States.

title: Index; International
description: The sense of beauty, shriveled in China, is budding again A2 In effort to end strife, Iran's De- fense Council may drop three A3 Cranston sees Iraq as a nuclear power by the end of the year A3 Bonn assails Soviet effort to sway public against new atom arms A4 Around the World A5 Micronesians fighting Japanese plan to dump waste in sea A7 Reversal sends Israelis on buying spree and angers opposition A9 Greece's entry to Common Mar- ket brings a surge of prices A12 Government/Politics Detroit Mayor faces troubled re- election campaign A16 Congress lists 8 possible choices for U.S. Comptroller General A18 Computer convention in Washing- ton falls on hard times A20 How Reagan ''workfare'' pro- gram fared in California A22 Koch begins his re-election cam- paign B1 No further liberalization of New York banking laws expected B4 Hearings on cable TV franchises end, with issue still unresolved B6 General Around the Nation A16 Environment found a factor in vulnerability of Atlanta youths A24 The Region B2 Jersey official links 3 killings to mobsters' interest in casinos B2 Judge says Westchester sheriff's ouster was illegal B2 Jersey bus commuters upset over higher fare prospects B2 The City B4 Open drinking by youths wide- spread on St. Patrick's Day B6 Health/Science Binghamton fire raises concern over toxic contaminants D20 The Living Section Food Cunningham and Cage and a lively dinner C1

title: Footsteps In The Dark
description: Is he Prince David the Goliath slayer or Attila the Hun? The media buildup to which he is being subjected leaves no middle ground for David Stockman to hold at the moment. Subtleties, shadings of character, a striving for accuracy - such stuff gets in the way and slows down the pace of the story, and rapid pacing and swift characterization are everything in the media launching of a new government, as they are in launching a new TV series.

title: The Exposed Side
description: Lay one face of a certain pyramid upon another; how many faces are there now? Given the pyramids suggested by the Educational Testing Service in a recent Preliminary Scholastic Aptitude Test, the only right answer was supposedly seven. Daniel Lowen, a Florida 17-yearold, answered five.

title: PLAN TO PUT OFF AIRBAG RULE A YEAR IS OPPOSED BY FORMER CARTER AIDE
description: William Nordhaus, formerly a member of President Carter's Council of Economic Advisers and a foe of Federal regulation, warned today against a Reagan Administration plan to postpone for one year a requirement to put airbags or other passive crash protection in new automobiles.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Harold C. Schonberg JACQUES OFFENBACH. By Alexander Faris. Illustrated, with musical exam- ples. 275 pages. Scribner's. $25.

title: Six Guatemalan Guerrillas Killed; Dean of Law School Is Kidnapped
description: An armed forces spokesman said today that troops killed at least six guerrillas yesterday in two separate areas.

title: CELLO RECITAL: SHARON ROBINSON
description: SHARON ROBINSON'S cello recital at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon offered two things -first, a further acquaintance with Miss Robinson's lovely, controlled sense of Romantic style and second, an introduction to Ned Rorem's nine-movement suite for solo cello entitled ''After Reading Shakespeare.''

title: Sony's Earnings Increase by 3.1%
description: The Sony Corporation reported today that it had a 3.1 percent increase in its earnings for the first quarter of the 1981 fiscal year as sales increased 17.7 percent, to $1.266 billion, from $1.07 billion in the same period of 1979.

title: NEW WITHOLDING TAX RULE SOUGHT
description: The Internal Revenue Service, cracking down on tax cheats, has issued a new regulation on the number of dependents a taxpayer may list in withholding statements.

title: AWARD OF TV CABLE FRANCHISES BY CITY STILL AT ISSUE
description: Two days of hearings before the Board of Estimate on cable television franchises for the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island ended late yesterday afternoon with the issue still about a year away from resolution.

title: Flight Out of New York Diverted To Charleston After Bomb Threat
description: An Air Florida jetliner on a flight from New York to Miami was diverted to Charleston International Airport late today because of a bomb threat by a passenger, the authorities said.

title: Celtics Trounce Bullets, 112-91
description: Larry Bird scored 25 points to pace the Boston Celtics to a 112-91 National Basketball Association victory over the Washington Bullets tonight.

title: KNICKS SHOOT 57%, ROUT PACERS, 114-89
description: The Knicks' late-season turnaround continued last night and the Indiana Pacers, a team that had not lost to New York in three previous games this season, were the latest victims.

title: Learning Difficult Truths About Sex
description: A child can be a liar, a cheat or a thief and still be defined as a child. But sexual precocity implies an irrevocable loss of innocence, an access to knowledge that renders one, if not quite grown up, no longer wholly young.

title: Colorado Site Is Selected As Military Space Center
description: Peterson Air Force Base, east of here, has been selected by the Air Force as the site of a proposed $400 million control center for American military spacecraft, including military missions of the manned space shuttle.

title: BUDGET FREEZE CHILLS COMPUTER EXPOSITION
description: The CPT 8000 Temptest word processor with dual diskettes and automatic repagination glowed and hummed before the eyes of William Johnson, the communications manager for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, who could only blink back and yearn wordlessly, like a pauper lad watching the latest electric train.

title: Real Estate; Industrial Park Set For Bronx
description: OUT of the rubble of abandoned and demolished housing in the Bathgate section of the South Bronx a new industrial building is emerging. It symbolizes the quest for new private jobs in an area that, devastated as it appears, is well served by roads and city services.

title: COPING WITH TERRORISM
description: The United States has not yet experienced anything like the full potential of international terrorism. And we are quite unprepared to absorb that impact because of our current attitudes, lack of organization, and lack of contingency planning.

title: O'Connor Loses Again on Amax
description: A Chicago options trading firm was rebuffed in court again today in its attempt to get an order blocking distribution of profits from certain recent trading in Amax Corporation options.

title: THE SENSE OF BEAUTY, SHRIVELED IN CHINA, BUDS AGAIN
description: They closed all the flower shops in China in 1966 and ordered people who kept goldfish to dump them into sewers and rivers.

title: Vivitar, Southern Pacific Report Some Changes
description: There seems to be a lot of activity out on the Coast, where in Los Angeles the Vivitar Corporation has picked up a replacement for Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, and in San Francisco, Southern Pacific Communications has decided to give up its in-house advertising operation.

title: Portugal Recalls Diplomat From Cuba in a Protest
description: Portugal recalled its charge d'affaires from Cuba today to protest Cuban accusations that the diplomat had worked with the United States Central Intelligence Agency in planning the weeklong seizure of the Ecuadorean Embassy in Havana last month.

title: BANK CUT PRIME TO 17 1 2%
description: The prime rate fell to 17 1/2 percent from 18 percent yesterday at major banks across the country. The new level is the lowest since Nov. 26, when this key lending rate jumped to 17 3/4 percent from 17 percent.

title: Devolution
description: The recent ''evolution'' trial in California prompted a friend to think about her own education in evolution. She recalls that during tenth-grade science class, the nun would scornfully ask: ''Would you want to believe your great-great-great-grandfather was an ape?'' Gosh no, she and the other 15-year-olds said.

title: 3 TRADERS SUING BEAR, STEARNS ON KENNECOTT TRADING
description: Three local market makers in Kennecott options on the Chicago Board Options Exchange have filed suit in Federal court here against Bear, Stearns & Company, charging that, because of improper activites by insiders, the three suffered losses of more than $5 million.

title: Court Halts Allbritton Bid
description: A Federal judge issued a preliminary injunction today barring Joe L. Allbritton's offer to buy 600,000 shares in Riggs National Bank, a purchase that would give the former owner of The Washington Star a controlling interest in the bank.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MARCH 18, 1981
description: International Fear about possible Soviet intervention in Poland during Warsaw Pact military exercises has eased in Washington. The Reagan Administration said intelligence information and Soviet assurances had diminished its concern over the prospect. The maneuvers in and around Poland are due to begin today. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) Improved United States-Argentine ties were sought by President Reagan. He conferred with Gen. Roberto Viola, who is to become Argentina's president on March 29. Administration officials said Mr. Reagan was considering a request to Congress to repeal an embargo on military aid to Buenos Aires. About 6,000 people are believed to have been arrested or abducted by Argentine security forces. (A1:3-5.)

title: Love That Fella Wins
description: Love That Fella took command midway through the backstretch tonight and won the $90,250 Four Leaf Clover pacing series final at the Meadowlands by 1 1/4 lengths.

title: 5 in Fraternity Face Marijuana Charge
description: Five Syracuse University students were arrested as they and several of their fraternity brothers attempted to strand a group of youths in the countryside about 35 miles north of Syracuse as part of the fraternity's initiation of new members.

title: Bally Loses Its Bid To Change Slot Law
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation, the nation's largest slot machine producer, lost its challenge of a New Jersey regulation barring Atlantic City casinos from buying more than 50 percent of their slots from a single company.

title: Reagan Said to Pick Ex-Im Bank Head
description: William H. Draper 3d, a 53-year-old Palo Alto, Calif., investment banker and a member of the state Republican committee, will be nominated as chairman and president of the Export-Import Bank, a White House source said yesterday. A spokesman for the bank said, ''I have no information on it.''

title: Cases Are Rested In Crimmins Hearing
description: Both sides rested their cases in a hearing on a defense motion to prevent statements made to the police by Craig S. Crimmins from being used as evidence at his trial.

title: United Airlines Joins In Fare Cuttting
description: Following actions by Trans World Airlines and American Airlines on Monday, United Airlines, a unit of UAL Inc., said it will reduce fares on several routes during the next eight to twelve weeks. Other major carriers said they were studying the fare-cutting actions.

title: Dayton Hudson Off
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, a retailer based in Minneapolis, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth fiscal quarter fell 17.6 percent despite a 23.3 percent gain in revenues.

title: HELPING HAND & WHEEL
description: To the Editor:

title: A REDUCED DELEGATION
description: To the Editor:

title: FEELING YOU HAVE ARRIVED
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Burger King Corporation said it would begin opening units in South Korea.

title: Islanders Tie Canadiens, 3-3; Kallur Gets 2
description: Two goals by Anders Kallur, the second of which was short-handed with less than six minutes to play, lifted the Islanders into a 3-3 tie tonight with the Montreal Canadiens. The deadlock at Nassau Coliseum extended the Islanders' unbeaten string against Montreal to nine games.

title: 8 HOSPITALS IN CITY STRUCK BY DOCTORS
description: Nearly 2,000 physicians-in-training struck six municipal and two private voluntary hospitals in New York City yesterday morning. They demanded guaranteed minimum staffing levels for nurses, aides, technicians and other support personnel and an end to what they called chronic shortages of lifesaving medical equipment.

title: HOME STARTS DOWN 25% IN FEBRUARY
description: Construction of new homes plunged by 25 percent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.2 million units, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, indicating that the country's economy may be slowing.

title: Esposito Sees His Records Safe This Year
description: Some day his records will be broken, Phil Esposito says, but he also says they are safe for this season. The records, 76 goals and 152 points, are extraordinary and have stood since 1970-71. They are under assault by two players, but each has barely enough games remaining for the attempts.

title: Careers; Aid Offered To Women In Business
description: JANIE PRESS, a manufacturer of children's clothes under her own name, and Cindy Annchild, who operates The Bath House (fragrances, bubble bath, hair care products, bath accessories), have something in common: membership in a mutual help group.

title: DISHES THAT REFLECT A COUNTRY'S TASTE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lorna J. Sass's cookbook ''Christmas,'' on historic Yuletide feasts, will be published by Irena Chalmers Cookbooks this fall. By LORNA J. SASS

title: INVITATION TO HOMEWORKER ABUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Must MX Be a Shell Game?
description: Why, Defense Secretary Weinberger has been asking his military advisers, does the mobile MX missile have to be part of a ''shell game''? Why must it be based in concrete shelters in Utah and Nevada, tearing up the countryside and fomenting wide public resistance? Why not base it at sea, perhaps aboard small submarines in deep ocean, a few hundred miles off the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts?

title: Wine Calendar
description: In response to rising consumption of Italian wines in this country, the Italian Trade Commission will open a 2,000-bottle Enoteca, or wine library, Tuesday in its new headquarters at 499 Park Avenue.

title: JAZZ TRUMPET: JOE NEWMAN BACK WITH 'HIGH ENERGY'
description: JOE NEWMAN, the trumpet player who starred with Count Basie's band in the 1940's and 1950's, has been a relative stranger in the United States in recent years, playing most of his engagements in Europe. His appearance last weekend at Sweet Basil with Harold Mabern on piano, Earl May on bass and Bill English, drums, provided a rare opportunity to catch up with recent developments in his work.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All these price increases just make you want to give up.

title: Guard Held for Fires At the Harley Hotel
description: A 19-year-old guard at the Harley Hotel has admitted he set a fire at the midtown hotel on its opening day Feb. 18, Fire Department officials said.

title: Reputed Crime Leader Indicted In 1968 Death in Massachusetts
description: Raymond L.S. Patriarca, the reputed New England crime chieftain, was arrested at his hospital bedside yesterday on a Massachusetts charge of ordering the 1968 slaying of an accused bank robber.

title: POISONS FROM BINGHAMTON FIRE STIR FEAR ON TRANSFORMERS USING PCB'S
description: The spread of deadly toxic contaminatants through a New York State office building after a chemical insulating solution escaped from a transformer in a fire has raised concern about millions of similarly insulated electrical devices in use throughout the country.

title: 'THE WOBBLIES,' EGALITARIANS
description: ''The Wobblies'' was shown at the 1979 New York Film Festival at Avery Fisher Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times on Oct. 11, 1979.

title: Zambia Cuts Cobalt Price
description: Zambia has reduced its cobalt price to $20 a pound from $25, the Metal Marketing Corporation announced today.

title: TEAMED WITH BROTHER ON CARDS
description: Paul (Daffy) Dean, who with his older brother, Dizzy, pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to the World Series championship in 1934, died after a heart attack today. He was 67 years old.

title: REAGAN CHALLENGES REPORT BY CONGRESS ON BUDGET FOR 1982
description: President Reagan today rejected a Congressional proposal to reduce cost-of-living benefits for Social Security recipients and retired Federal employees. He also denounced an analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that the Administration had underestimated its spending figures for the fiscal year 1982 by $20 billion to $25 billion.

title: PRESIDENT OPPOSES DOMESTIC C.I.A. ROLE
description: Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to President Reagan, said today that the White House was ''absolutely opposed'' to any change in intelligence regulations that would permit the Central Intelligence Agency to conduct domestic spying.

title: A LAUNDRY WHERE NOT ONLY COINS JANGLE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Peter Applebome contributes to The New York Times from Dallas. By PETER APPLEBOME AZLE, Tex. MARSHALL HOLMES says he and T. J. Schulze didn't plan on making history that January night 18 years ago when they decided to do a little kicking along with the sloshing at the Holmes Coin-O-Mat.

title: Fire at Plush Hotel in Mexico City Kills at Least Three and Hurts 18
description: A fire swept through the top floors of the plush Hotel Maria Isabel Sheraton tonight, killing at least three people and injuring 18.

title: DERBY HOPEFUL BEATEN
description: - Century Prince captured the $32,350 Hirsch Jacobs Stakes at the opening of Pimlico's spring-summer meetmeeting yesterday, Classic Go Go, the favorite and a Kentucky Derby hopeful, finished a distant fourth.

title: William V. B. Van Dyck, 105, Dies; Joined G.E. at Turn of the Century
description: William Van Bergen Van Dyck, an electrical engineer and former assistant to the president of the International General Electric Company in Schenectady, N.Y., died Friday at his home there. He was 105 years old.

title: A MISSIONARY FOR CHINA'S REGIONAL COOKING
description: LONDON WHEN Kenneth Lo came here in 1936, he never expected to become a missionary for Chinese culture and cooking. Yet, 45 years later, he has written more than 20 cookbooks on Chinese cuisine that have sold over 1 million copies throughout the world. Five years ago he started the Chinese Gourmet Club, designed to educate his friends in the delights of Chinese regional cooking. And last summer, he opened a restaurant, putting into practice the varied cooking he has espoused over the years to a public accustomed mainly to the Cantonese variety of Chinese food.

title: 130 Civilians Are Suspects In Thwarted Spanish Coup
description: More than 130 civilians and 127 national policemen are under investigation for complicity in the abortive attempt last month by right-wing military men to overthrow the Spanish Government, Defense Minister Alberto Oliart has told Parliament.

title: O.& M. Adds Belgian Unit
description: Determined to become a major force in international public relations as it already is in advertising, Ogilvy & Mather International, through O.&M. Public Relations has just acquired the largest Belgian public relations firm. Its name is Information et Entreprise and is in Brussels. It and the parent firm have a client in common, American Express.

title: Stouffer's Inn, Where 26 Died In Arsonist's Fire, Will Reopen
description: Stouffer's Inn of Westchester announced that it would reopen to the public on April 6, four months after a fire there that killed 26 persons.

title: METROPOLITAN IRENEY, 88, PRIMATE OF ORTHODOX CHURCH UNTIL 1977
description: Metropolitan Ireney, retired primate of the Orthodox Church in America, died yesterday of a heart attack in St. Vincent's Medical Center on Staten Island at the age of 88.

title: Helpful Hardware; POPULAR SELF-HELP AIDS; by Barbara L.Isenberg and Mary Smith
description: ONCE in a while we ask a hardware store what some of its bestselling items are, and often the answer is surprising. That many of these items are kept near the cash register may account for their popularity; but their popularity can also account for why they are kept by the cash register, a chicken-or-the-egg situation.

title: SIHANOUK CALLS PACT WITH POL POT UNLIKELY
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's former chief of state, said today that his talks last week with Khieu Samphan, the Prime Minister of the ousted Communist regime, had convinced him that there was no hope of forging an alliance against the Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia.

title: CELLO: JENSEN PLAYS A SUITE BY BRITTEN
description: Hans Jorgen Jensen's cello concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday evening was the work of an earnest and forceful young professional. Mr. Jensen plays more with vigor than with elegance, and some of the latter was very much missing in Stravinsky's Suite Italienne for Cello and Piano. But elsewhere his craggy musical intensity was an asset, especially in Britten's fascinatingly original Suite for Cello (Op. 72) and the Brahms F major Sonata (Op. 99).

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AUDITORS END ONE-WORD RIFT
description: For more than three three years, the accounting profession had been consumed by a spirited debate over changing a handful of words in the auditor's standard report. And ultimately, the controversy boiled down to one word -''fairly.''

title: Reagan Is Said to Offer Javits a U.N. Position
description: President Reagan has offered to appoint Jacob K. Javits, former United States Senator from New York, as United States representative at the European office of the United Nations, White House sources said yesterday.

title: SENATOR ASSAILS CAREY PROPOSAL TO CREATE JOBS
description: Governor Carey's proposal to replace the state's Job Incentive Program with a new system that would give the tax advantages to investors in ''severely distressed areas'' was attacked today by the chairman of the Senate Committee on Commerce and Economic Development.

title: 2 Jurors Are Dismissed In Enquirer Libel Suit
description: Two jurors were dismissed from Carol Burnett's $10 million libel suit against The National Enquirer today after they heard the entertainer Johnny Carson attack the publication on ''The Tonight Show,'' but the judge denied a motion for a mistrial.

title: Herald Tribune in Paris Names New Executives
description: The International Herald Tribune announced the appointment of Philip M. Foisie today to the new position of executive editor.

title: MIDTOWN TARGET OF ENFORCEMENT ON PARKING LAW
description: The Koch administration yesterday announced a plan to fight illegal parking in midtown Manhattan that would prohibit double parking even if the driver or a passenger remained in the car.

title: The Great Ripoff
description: Four years ago, a few of us began beating our spoons against our highchairs in outrage at the proposed Law of the Sea treaty, which was characterized in this space as ''history's greatest attempted ripoff.''

title: Marley to Be Sold For $325 Million
description: The Marley Company, which manufactures water-cooling towers and heat exchangers used in power plants, said yesterday that it had reached a final agreement to be acquired for $325 million in a leveraged buy-out set up by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: S.C.I. CALLS FOR REMOVAL OF TRUSTEES OF TEAMSTER FUND
description: The bipartisan State Commission of Investigation called yesterday for the resignation or removal of Barry Feinstein and fellow trustees of the welfare fund of a teamster local.

title: CRUDE DECONTROL BY REAGAN
description: When President Reagan decontrolled crude oil, gasoline, and home-heating oil, he did so without formal counsel from Congress and the public. His desire to act on his own came at the expense of public-hearing requirements set out in The Economic Stabilization Act of 1971, which Congress later incorporated into statutes governing oil-price controls.

title: SENATE UNIT SPENDS SHARP BUDGET CUTS SOUGHT BY REAGAN
description: Acting with a swiftness seldom seen on Capitol Hill, the Republican-dominated Senate Budget Committee today recommended $23 billion in budget cuts. Those decisions, coupled with the panel's actions a day earlier, accounted for a total of more than $35 billion in proposed reductions in two days.

title: ECONOMICS OR POLITICS?
description: When challenged on the human impact of his proposed budget cuts, President Reagan defends them as economically essential. He and his aides argue that only by cutting across the board can they get the budget under control and open the way for economic growth. Every interest has to share the burden, they say. The only exception is the ''truly needy.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bow Valley Resource Services Ltd. agreed to purchase a semisubmersible drilling vessel from Blanford Shipping Company, London, for $112 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times last Sunday on money-raising efforts in connection with the killing and disappearance of black children in Atlanta misstated the purpose of one fund. Money sent to the Committee to Stop Children's Murders, 334 Auburn Avenue S.E., Atlanta, Ga. 30303, will be given to the families of the victims for food, rent and other aid, but not for investigation of the crimes.

title: JUDGE RULES DISRICT IN GEORGIA ILLEGALLY SELECTED JURIES
description: A Federal judge has dismissed 51 criminal indictments in the Northern District of Georgia because of discrimination against blacks, women and the elderly in the jury selection process.

title: The Cost of Not Raising Utility Bills
description: It happened here, but it could just as easily have been Ohio or Alabama. A year ago Con Edison asked for a whopping 15 percent rate increase. Only now, in the face of consumer protests, has it finally been approved. The pattern is widespread. All over the country, utilities are struggling for rate relief. They often win. But typically, relief is long delayed and insufficient to pay the real cost of service.

title: Soviet-Bloc Troops Begin Polish Area Maneuvers
description: Soviet-led Warsaw Pact military forces began maneuvers in and around Poland today as the Government faced a sit-in by farmers seeking to unionize and a strike threat by timber workers.

title: Oldsmobile Worker Recall
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that its Oldsmobile division here would recall about 1,500 Oldsmobile and Fisher Body division employees from layoff by the end of the month. The company said the production rate at its Lansing Cutlass assembly center would be increased to 60 cars an hour from 55, beginning April 6.

title: STUDY SAYS HEART ILLS CAN BEGIN IN CHILDHOOD
description: A competitive, overeating, restless child shows signs of behavior that may increase his chances of heart disease in later life, scientists involved in a major study said here.

title: HYDERABAD, INDIA
description: TWO years ago, when William Mulder, a professor of American literature at the University of Utah, was offered a second stint as director of the American Studies Research Center, a resource facility for Indian scholars of Americana in this historic city, his wife, Helen, agreed to the move on one condition: that they would find something old and interesting to live in.

title: RANGERS TRIUMPH OVER BRUINS, 3-2
description: The New York Rangers, who have been saying that they would rather play good teams than mediocre ones, played one of the National Hockey League's better teams, the Boston Bruins, and defeated them, 3-2, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: NAVY VS. BURROS
description: To the Editor:

title: PANAMA OIL PIPELINE JOB IS ASSIGNED
description: The Morrison-Knudsen Company announced yesterday that it had won a contract to construct much of a $250-million storage system and 78-mile oil pipeline that is to cross the Republic of Panama by late 1982, competing with the Panama Canal.

title: Reagan's Luncheon Joke, Reconstructed
description: Eavesdroppers at the next table caught only the punch line, but the joke told by President Reagan last week at lunch in Manhattan's Little Italy section sent his dining companions into gales of laughter.

title: UPDATING OR REPLACING THAT OLD FURNACE
description: HEATING experts agree that many homeowners are still overlooking opportunities to make substantial fuel economies by upgrading their furnaces or boilers to make them more efficient or by replacing them with the latest technology. If the efficiency of the furnace or boiler (a furnace heats air, a boiler heats water) is increased the homeowner will get more B.T.U.'s out of each dollar's worth of fuel.

title: Paul Huber, Character Actor, 85; Was in the Theater for 50 Years
description: Paul Huber, an actor for 50 years, died Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: OFF-DUTY OFFICER HELD IN SLAYING OF SERGEANT IN CAR ON LONG ISLAND
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was charged with second-degree murder today after he allegedly shot and killed an off-duty police sergeant while they were riding home in a private car, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Alphonse Cimber, Drummer, is Dead
description: Alphonse Cimber, the Haitian-born drummer who was considered the doyen of traditional musicians of African ancestry in the United States, died Monday of respiratory ailments in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Harlem.

title: KNICKS WIN, 116-103, STOPPING BUCK RALLY
description: The Knicks played three quarters of superb basketball tonight, then managed to keep the roof from falling in and defeated the Milwaukee Bucks, 116-103.

title: TEACHING MOVES UP
description: To the Editor:

title: Disaster Declared in Kentucky
description: President Reagan declared a major disaster today in Kentucky, enabling Federal money to be used to help repair damage caused by sewer explosions in Louisville on Feb. 13, the White House announced. A White House statement said the Federal Government would pay 75 percent and state and local governments 25 percent of the cost of sewer and street repair.

title: MARSHALS SEEK CAUSE OF BLAZE AT SYNAGOGUE
description: Fire Department officials said yesterday they had not yet established the cause of a four-alarm fire that destroyed an Orthodox synagogue Tuesday night in Astoria, Queens, but that they did not believe it was an anti-Semitic act.

title: IF THE POOR LOSE THEIR LAWYERS
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW U.S. AID SAVED A SMALL OHIO PLANT
description: When the Aeroquip Corporation announced in 1978 that an aging subsidiary here, the Republic Hose Manufacturing Company, was no longer profitable and would be closed, employees quickly asked the Government for money to help them take over the plant.

title: VIOLIN: GALASSO PLAYS HIS OWN WORKS
description: THERE was something oddly Baroque about Michael Galasso's compositions when he performed them on the violin at the Dance Theater Workshop on Tuesday night. The oddness came from the hypnotic repeated patterns.

title: CONRAIL FUND CUTS POSE NO PERIL, OFFICIAL ASSERTS
description: The Reagan Administration's plan to slash financing for the Consolidated Rail Corporation should not be viewed with alarm, according to Stephen Berger, chairman of the United States Railway Association, which oversees the financial fortunes of Conrail for the Government.

title: TV: PROFILES OF 4 SOLDIERS OF FORTUNE
description: ''ABC News Closeup'' continues its provocative ways tonight with an hourlong documentary entitled ''Soldiers of the Twilight.'' Produced and directed by Malcolm Clarke, written by Mr. Clark and Marshall Frady, the program explores the strange, often unsettling world of mercenary fighters, of soldiers of fortune.

title: Ayer Wins Bidding For Chemical Account
description: The Ayer force has landed the worldwide Chemical Bank wholesale banking business that two other agencies were in competition for. It has billings of about $3 million.

title: FIRST DROP SINCE JULY
description: In a new indication that the national economy may be slowing down, the Government reported today that industry's use of production capacity dropped in February for the first time in seven months.

title: Advertising; Dole Finds Labeling Profitable
description: WHILE there is mounting concern in packaged goods circles about the growth of nonbrand generic goods, at the same time things that never before were branded are getting brand names.

title: G.N.P. RISE OF 5% SEEN FOR QUARTER
description: Propelled by a rise in automobile buying, the American economy appears to be headed for a surprisingly strong growth rate of 5 percent in this year's first quarter, the Council of Economic Advisers reported today.

title: DESTRUCTIVE TRUCKS
description: To the Editor:

title: BENDIX BRINGING IN A NEW PRESIDENT
description: Alonzo L. McDonald Jr., a 52-year-old Carter Administration official and former managing director of the international management consulting firm of McKinsey & Company, has been elected vice chairman of the Bendix Corporation, effective immediately, and will become president on June 1. As president, he will succeed William M. Agee, 43, who will remain chairman and chief executive officer of the multinational company, based in Southfield, Mich.

title: A.T.&T. Seeks Data Satellite
description: The American Telephone & Telegraph Company has asked permission to use its satellite system for highspeed commercial data transmission for the first time.

title: Du Pont in Ulster
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said it would double its capacity to produce Hypalon, a synthetic rubber, by building a $91 million plant near Londonderry, Northern Ireland. Construction of the plant is to begin this year and be completed in mid-1983, Du Pont said. The company said the plant was required to meet growing demand for Hypalon, which is used for wire and cables, automotive components and coated fabrics.

title: New Savings Off in February
description: New savings deposits at the nation's savings and loan associations fell last month to the lowest February level in 11 years, according to a report yesterday by the United States League of Savings Association. The group added that mortgage lending activity for the month was at a six-year low.

title: by The Associated Press
description: Len (Truck) Robinson and Walter Davis combined for 23 points in the third quarter to break open a close game and lead the Suns to a 126-114 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers last night at Phoenix.

title: LAWRENCE KELDER
description: Lawrence Kelder, a former director of the Beneficial Corporation, died Monday at his home in West Shokan, N.Y. He was 72 years old and also lived in Ormond Beach, Fla., and Barbados, West Indies.

title: The Region; 54 Lose Bid to Void Convictions
description: A motion to reverse the felony convictions of 54 Nassau County prisoners because court stenographers had failed to supply trial minutes necessary for their appeals, was unanimously denied yesterday, without explanation, by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 19, 1981
description: International Another attack on Soviet policy was made by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. At a House hearing, he accused Moscow of responsibility for ''international terrorism'' and of having a ''hit list'' for Communist domination of Central America. (Page A1, Column 4.) A satellite-killing weapon test by the Soviet Union was successful, according to Pentagon sources. It was the first such test since 1977 in the Soviet antisatellite development program, which is considered to be ahead of the United States program. (A1:5.)

title: Gardening; USING SUN TO GET A HEAD START ON SPRING
description: IN spring the solar energy that makes gardens grow generates impatience because gardeners are eager to start planting but cannot. Killing frosts threaten, so there is no point in starting until the middle of April or even later.

title: Fugitive British Train Bandit Reported Missing in Brazil
description: Ronald Biggs, who escaped from a British jail after being sentenced to 30 years for taking part in Britain's ''Great Train Robbery,'' is missing and may have been kidnapped from his place of refuge in Brazil, a federal police source said today.

title: SOVIET JEWISH EMIGRATION DECLINES AFTER BRIEF SPURT
description: A monthlong surge in the issuance of emigration visas to Soviet Jews appears to have stopped as abruptly as it began, according to Jewish activists and Western diplomats in close touch with the situation.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: SHIPBUILDING EXPANDS IN JAPAN
description: Japan escaped a global decline in shipbuilding last year to capture almost half the world market, while the United States fell to third place among shipbuilding nations behind Brazil, Lloyd's Register of Shipping reported today.

title: RIGHTS PANEL BIDS BRITAIN REVISE LAWS ON ULSTER TERROR SUSPECTS
description: The International League for Human Rights today urged the British Government to consider immediate revision of Northern Ireland's emergency laws for the interrogation and trial of suspected terrorists.

title: A PRUDENTIAL OFFER FOR BACHE ACCEPTED
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest insurance company, has reached a tentative agreement to buy the Bache Group Inc., the parent company of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, one of the biggest brokerage houses in the country, Wall Street sources disclosed last night.

title: Activists in Atlanta Vow To Begin Armed Patrols
description: Black activists said today they were convinced that Atlanta's child slayings were racially motivated and vowed to go ahead with armed patrols despite warnings by Mayor Maynard Jackson that vigilante groups would not be tolerated.

title: Prime Cut to 17% By Chemical Bank
description: The Chemical Bank lowered its prime lending rate yesterday to 17 percent from 17 1/2 percent amid signals that the lower rate could spread throughout the industry.

title: Swifter Justice for New York
description: Judges are not innocent bystanders in the battle against crime. They are supposed to be neutral, but inefficiency on the bench means more crime on the streets. Snail-pace justice is both a violation of the defendant's rights and a bonanza for the guilty. Defendants can postpone justice indefinitely or plea-bargain for excessive leniency when they know that the court system can't deal with its own caseload.

title: Key Rates
description: * Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty, Hartford, has named James S. Dailey vice president and treasurer.

title: MILITARY SPENDING: DEBATE IS GROWING
description: President Reagan's plan to sharply increase military spending has heartened the defense industry, which is now looking forward to more lucrative arms contracts.

title: DANCE: SENEGALESE VISITORS
description: The National Dance Company of Senegal has its stiltwalkers and acrobats, its exciting drummers and its traditional story ballets and surveys of local dance styles. The company, which opened on Tuesday at the Beacon Theater in New York, is also full of vivid dancers. But most of all the Senegalese dancers are an intriguing mix of elegant, stylized gesture and movement that bears some resemblance to everyday activity.

title: TWO POLICEMEN ARE NOT INDICTED IN BOY'S KILLING
description: A Brooklyn grand jury declared yesterday that it had found no basis for criminal charges against two police officers in the case of a 17-year-old youth who was shot to death inside a stolen automobile five weeks ago.

title: A. T. & T. CLIMBS 8.6% IN QUARTER
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, parent of the Bell System, reported yesterday that earnings in the fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28 rose 8.6 percent, while revenues increased 11.8 percent.

title: Bullets Appoint Unseld
description: Wes Unseld, the 35-year-old center who yesterday announced his retirement from the Washington Bullets effective the end of the season, will remain with the team as a vice president and will also become a vice president of the Capital Centre, the Bullets' home.

title: ANTITRUST PROBLEM IN CAR-IMPORT CURBS
description: Attorney General William French Smith has warned that any voluntary agreement by Japan to curb auto exports to the United States could be jeopardized by private antitrust suits in this country unless the agreement were approved under Japanese law.

title: Former Roosevelt Yacht Sinks
description: The Potomac, once the Presidential yacht of Franklin D. Roosevelt, sank early today at a Navy dock where it had been moored since late last year after a Government marijuana raid. The ship went down in 35 feet of water at Treasure Island. It will be the responsibility of the Customs Office to salvage the boat, which has been valued at up to $300,000.

title: Waiting Rooms
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I am surprised by Ada Louise Huxtable's (''The Unreal World of Waiting Rooms,'' March 5) negative appraisal of waiting rooms. To me a waiting room is the ideal place to people watch.

title: SHELL CUTS WHOLESALE GASE PRICES 2 IN SOME AREAS
description: The Shell Oil Company cut its wholesale gasoline prices by 2 cents a gallon yesterday in Brooklyn and Queens and on Long Island after six months of steady increases.

title: TUGBOAT CREWS' STRIKE IN WASHINGTON STATE HALTING MOST SHIPPING
description: A strike by 1,000 tugboat crewmen in the state of Washington has brought shipping to a near standstill, and officials today cautioned that the walkout could cut food supplies to parts of Alaska and spread to other West Coast ports.

title: AMERICA'S HANDICAPPED COW
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Needless Deaths' and a Needless Strike
description: The young doctors on strike at municipal and private hospitals have made some sensational charges that deserve prompt and thorough investigation. Their leaders allege that three patients have died needlessly in two city hospitals because emergency equipment malfunctioned or overworked staffs failed to watch over them.

title: Home Improvement; ROOM DIVIDERS HAVE VARIOUS FORMS AND USES
description: MANY homes and apartments have living-dining areas that run together or are separated only by a low counter or wall. Others that have dining areas that are actually part of the kitchen, set off in a separate alcove or by a low counter or a storage unit.

title: 3 IN 'SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE' CAST AND 4 WRITERS ARE DISMISSED
description: Three members of the cast of NBC-TV's ''Saturday Night Live'' - Charles Rocket, Gilbert Gottfried and Ann Risley - and four of its writers were dismissed yesterday by the show's new producer, Dick Ebersol.

title: SOME EASY WAYS TO SAVE KILOWATTS
description: ONCE upon a time the cost of electricity had to be figured in kilowatt-hours to mean anything. Now, with Consolidated Edison's 15.5 percent rate increase effective this week, it is almost as easy to calculate electricity's cost on a momentary basis. New Yorkers are paying about half a cent to toast a slice of bread, 2 cents to brew a pot of coffee, 5 cents to watch the evening news and 8 cents for light to read a short novel.

title: Reagan Seeking a Delay In a Budget Amendment
description: The Reagan Administration today urged Congress to hold off immediate action on a constitutional amendment to balance the budget and, instead, to focus entirely on the President's proposed tax and spending cuts.

title: STRIKE CONTINUES
description: The Chief Medical Examiner of New York City said yesterday that he would investigate charges by striking physicians-in-training that patients at two municipal hospitals had died as a result of negligent care.

title: by Peter G. Davis
description: SINCE its formation in 1972, the Orpheus Ensemble has presented ample proof that 25 musicians can play together quite superbly without a conductor. If anything, the group's performances over the years have become even more polished and sensitively attuned to musical considerations.

title: THE BATTLE OF THE FUEL ADS
description: ''Could deregulation mean my neighbor's $1,400 gas bill would be as much as $4,000 next year?'' asks a woman in a radio commercial being broadcast in the metropolitan area. ''Probably so'' is the answer.

title: Ex-Investment Banker
description: Bradley Gaylord, a retired investment banker who was chairman of the board of the Madison Fund, a financial investment concern, died Tuesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 85 years old.

title: Carter, at Princeton, Advocates 6-Year Presidency
description: Reflecting with a group of Princeton University students yesterday on his one-term Presidency, Jimmy Carter said he believed the single six-year term Presidency was a good idea, his listeners reported.

title: The Region
description: Governor Byrne and the chairman of the Assembly committee that handles casino legislation said today that the state should relax regulations on casino operations while retaining stringent controls to thwart criminal infiltration.

title: STOCKS INCH UP WITH AUTOS IN LEAD
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday as investors waged a tug-of-war on the heels of two days of turbulent activity. Automotive stocks were strong, while energy issues continued under pressure.

title: OPERA: ILLEANA COTRUBAS IN MET'S NEW 'TRAVIATA'
description: ONE of this Metropolitan Opera season's backstage crises came when Ileana Cotrubas backed out of the new production of ''La Traviata'' after deciding she could not agree to John Dexter's plan for restaging the Verdi classic. The soprano backed in again, however, when the opera was turned over to Colin Graham, a director with whom Miss Cotrubas found it possible to agree. Without attempting to decide who was right in the Cotrubas-Dexter disagreement, it can be noted that Tuesday night's premiere of ''La Traviata'' turned out to be one of this strike-shortened season's pure triumphs.

title: OPENING UP CABLE TV
description: New York City and other municipalities are in the process of selecting companies that will distribute cable television. Before the pattern of a vast communications industry is set, some implications of a ''wired nation'' should be considered.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We had a new fireplace built about three years ago. It functions beautifully, but the brick chimney on the outside has settled excessively. As a result the top of the chimney has pulled away from the side of the house as much as two to three inches, a space too wide for caulking. We have had the spaces filled with mortar twice, but it continues to settle. How we can correct this? - D.J.H., Ocean, N.J.

title: BONN EXPANDING LOANS FOR POLAND
description: The West German Cabinet agreed today to increase the Government's guarantees for private bank credits to Poland by $71.4 million, a Government spokesman said.

title: HOUSE PANEL SUPPORTS DAIRY LOBBY ON INCREASE IN MILK PRICE SUPPORTS
description: President Reagan was set back today in his effort to block an April 1 increase in milk price supports when a House subcommittee scrapped an Administration amendment and substituted one supported by the dairy lobby.

title: COAL STRIKE EFFECT ON MARKETS FEARED
description: Concern in the coal industry over the loss of potentially profitable new export markets if there is another long miners' strike began to emerge today after the collapse of contract negotiations.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN PLANES RAID ANGOLA
description: South Africa said today that its jets attacked a base belonging to South-West African guerrillas deep inside Angola. Separate reports said that South African ground forces clashed with troops of neighboring Mozambique.

title: No Headline
description: A spokesman for President Reagan said tonight that Mr. Reagan did telephone Dan Sullivan, drama critic of The Los Angeles Times, to discuss Buddy Ebsen's musical, but simply to tell Mr. Sullvian he hoped it would still be playing when he visited Los Angeles late next month.

title: Swing Time
description: Remember those nightclubs? The tables were terraced and the dance floor was huge, the men wore black tie and the ladies crepe that clung to the coccyx. Remember how Fred and Ginger would saunter out, absolutely in step? How they'd turn to one another, hands raised, palms facing, before they slid into a quick scatter of taps? Those were the days when movies weren't a slice of life but an escape from it.

title: The Region; Jean Harris to Get Physical Exam
description: Jean S. Harris, convicted of murdering Dr. Herman Tarnower, was taken from the Westchester County Jail to the neighboring Medical Center for a medical examination.

title: U.S. REPUDIATES A HARD-LINE AIDE
description: The White House and the State Department issued statements late today disavowing an interview by a ''high United States official'' who was quoted as saying that war with the Soviet Union was inevitable if the Russians did not change their system and that Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany was susceptible to Soviet persuasion.

title: STAGE: TALKING BAND'S 'SOFT TARGETS'
description: AS an outstanding descendant of the Open Theater, the Talking Band uses variations of that seminal company's performance techniques to tell its own dramatic stories, which, in the case of the group's latest work, ''Soft Targets,'' can express a social urgency and moral courage. ''Soft Targets,'' at the La Mama Annex through March 29, has as its nucleus a play by Ben Maddow about the harmful effects of nuclear energy. The title refers to the Pentagon's term for people unprotected against nuclear attack.

title: Layoffs at Flxible
description: The Grumman Flxible Corporation, which makes the problem-plagued Flxible 870 bus, announced a threeweek layoff of 1,300 workers at its plants in Delaware and Loudonville, Ohio. Most of the workers are involved in final assembly of the 870, which has been taken out of service in New York and other cities because of structural faults. The company said that because it was emphasizing reinforcing frames on the 2,600 buses delivered, the supply of components for new buses had been interrupted.

title: LONG SHOTS NOTHING NEW TO U.S. REED
description: When Arkansas Coach Eddie Sutton called time out with five seconds left and Louisville ahead by a point last Saturday, he instructed his team to get the ball to U.S. Reed.

title: 'IMAGE BEFORE MY EYES,' JEWISH LIFE IN PRE-WAR POLAND
description: ''Image Before My Eyes,'' which opens today for an eight-day engagement at the Manhattan II theater, is a fond and thoughtful attempt to recreate the quality of life among Poland's Jews, from the turn of the century to World War II. This enterprising documentary, directed and edited by Josh Waletzky, consists chiefly of photographs, old home movies, and interviews with emigres who remember their Polish childhoods. The film has the quality of a photographic exhibition, which is indeed the form in which this material was previously presented.

title: POLITICAL BATTLE FORMING ON CHICAGO'S TRANSIT WOES
description: The stage is being elaborately set for a showdown on the fiscal crisis that is threatening to halt mass transportation in the six-county Chicago metropolitan area.

title: STOCK EXCHANGE OFFICIALS OF THE WORLD CONFER
description: For the first time in history, the working committee of the International Federation of Stock Exchanges - the staff executives who provide the documents that the exchanges' top brass use in policy making at their annual meetings - met in the United States this week. And J.G.N. de Hoop Scheffer, the 59-year-old Dutch chairman of the committee since 1974, spent the last three days in sessions at the New York Stock Exchange working with his associates from other countries on matters affecting exchanges around the world.

title: IRAQ SAYS IRAN TAKES BIG LOSSES
description: Fighting today between Iran and Iraq, on two fronts, inflicted the heaviest casualties in weeks on Iranian forces, Iraq asserted in a communique.

title: LEGISLATIVE VETOES FACE LEGAL ATTACK
description: Attorney General William French Smith said today that the Reagan Administration planned to argue before the Supreme Court that legislative vetoes, an increasingly popular Congressional device, are unconstitutional if they intrude upon the President's power to manage the executive branch.

title: ILLEGAL ALIENS GET 1ST SCHOOLING IN SPECIAL CLASSES
description: Until two months ago, 9-year-old Julio had never held a pencil, used scissors or sat at a desk. He still has trouble writing, cutting paper and speaking English.

title: News of Music; 6 COMPOSERS TO RECEIVE ACADEMY-INSTITUTE PRIZES
description: THE American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, one of this country's pre-eminent cultural organizations, will present its music awards this year to four composers - Edwin Dugger, Robert Erickson, Meyer Kupferman and Ursula Mamlok. The awards provide a cash prize of $5,000 along with a recording by Composers Recordings Inc. (C.R.I.), the nonprofit record company specializing in 20th-century music.

title: PLANNING AGENCY BACKS FIREHOUSE AIR-RIGHTS SALE
description: A plan to sell the unused development rights over a midtown firehouse on Manhattan's West Side to a private developer was approved by the City Planning Commission yesterday. It is the first proposal the commission has reviewed that would sell such rights above city-owned property.

title: EX-U.S. AIDE DEFENDS POSITION ON ABSCAM
description: Charles B. Renfrew, who as Deputy Attorney General of the United States settled the investigation of leaks to reporters in the Abscam case with letters of reprimand, says most unauthorized disclosures by Government officials are a necessary part of the democratic process.

title: BUILT-INS MADE TO TAKE OUT
description: AFEW years ago the design passion of the moment was built-in furniture - sleek sleeping platforms, bookshelves and cabinets constructed to look as if they were an architectural part of the rooms they inhabited. The operative word was seamless. Then someone realized that the trouble with built-ins was that you could not take them with you.

title: SON'S ANTI-SEMETIC 'PRANK' SHOCKS FAMILY ON L.I.
description: On the morning of Feb. 24, Joseph McCloskey, 16 years old, the eldest son of a working-class Long Island family, stood before Judge Thomas Ryan Jr. in Nassau County District Court in Mineola. His left hand wadded a handkerchief. The right clutched the beads of a rosary. Trembling, he heard the judge sentence him for his first offense, the desecration of a synagogue.

title: WEINBERGER ASSERTS U.S. MAY FIND A NEW CONTRACTOR FOR TRIDENT SUBS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he was considering having Trident-class submarines built somewhere other than the General Dynamics Corporation yard in Groton, Conn.

title: CALENDAR: ANTIQUES, IN THE CITY AND SUBURBS
description: New York Antiques Show, New York Coliseum, Columbus Circle

title: KOCH TELLS BRONX 'TOWN MEETING' HE'LL ASK REVIEW OF BUDGET CUTS
description: Mayor Koch conducted his 50th ''town hall'' meeting last night, this time in a central Bronx neighborhood, where residents complained about run-down housing, uncollected garbage, poor bus service and President Reagan's proposed cuts in social programs.

title: Ailing Stomach Delays Swan
description: Craig Swan of the Mets, who tested his right shoulder in a game yesterday for the first time in almost seven months and reported no pain, suffered an unexpected setback today: a stomach disorder that will delay his pitching comeback.

title: Layton Trial Is Kept on Coast
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the murder conspiracy trial of Larry Layton, a former member of the Peoples Temple, would be held in San Francisco, not in New York City as Mr. Layton had sought. Defense attorneys had argued that Mr. Layton's trial in the 1978 shooting death of Representative Leo Ryan at an airstrip in Guyana should be in New York.

title: LOBBY FOR ARTS GIVES CONGRESS V.I.P. TREATMENT
description: The maestro lifted his baton. The orchestra struck the opening chords of Rimsky-Korsakov's Symphony No. 2. And the nation's lawmakers, resplendent in evening dress, relaxed in their red velvet theater seats and prepared to be lobbied.

title: KUSH TRIAL SENT TO JURY
description: In their final arguments before a jury in Maricopa County Superior Court, attorneys for a former Arizona State University punter and the coach he said punched him during a 1978 football game disagreed strongly today over what the evidence in a $2.2 million damage suit has shown.

title: SITTING IN SHIPSHAPE CHAIRS
description: THEY'RE big and bulky and just what he wanted. ''They're for steamships and yachts, and maybe zeppelins,'' said Jay Spectre, the well-known interior designer, of his new chairs.

title: QUAKE DRIVES GREEKS FROM NEW RUINS TO OLD ONES
description: The Persians besieged the town and tried to poison its water source as a means of forcing submission; the Spartans destroyed it as punishment for its alliance with the Athenians. But what history has done to Plataea pales before the destructive force of the earthquakes that have struck the area in recent weeks.

title: PISTONS BEAT NETS, 118-115, 76ERS TRIUMPH AND REGAIN FIRST PLACE
description: Kent Benson scored 24 points and Phil Hubbard added 22 last night to lead the Detroit Pistons to a 118-115 victory over the New Jersey Nets at Pontiac, Mich.

title: The City; N.Y.U. Votes Rise Of 15% in Tuition
description: New York University's board of trustees approved a 15 percent tuition increase for its undergraduate students and 12 percent for graduate students.

title: Crerar Harris, Former Desk Chief In London for The Times, Is Dead
description: Crerar Harris, former desk chief of the London bureau of The New York Times and a retired copy editor on The Times's foreign desk, died Tuesday at his home in Port Jervis, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: Ontario Holds Elections For New Legislature Today
description: A legislative election in Ontario tomorrow will give the 5.5 million voters of Canada's most populous and economically most powerful province a chance to pass electoral judgment again on the Progressive Conservative Party, which has controlled the provincial government for 38 years.

title: CONTEMPORARY CRAFTS IN AN ORIENTAL MODE
description: all in a gallery shop in Scarsdale that offers contemporary American crafts.

title: Revocation of Checkoff For Teachers Is Upheld
description: A Federal judge yesterday upheld the provision of the New York State Taylor Law under which unions can be stripped of their right to deduct dues from members' paychecks.

title: CONTINENTAL GRAIN REALIGNS TOP MANAGEMENT STRUCTURE
description: In a restructuring of the top management of the Continental Grain Company, the world's largest commodity trading corporation, an office of the chief executive was established yesterday. Continental, founded in Belgium in 1813 by the Fribourg family, now has its headquarters in New York.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Advanced Semiconductor Materials International N.V. is planning to offer 900,000 common shares in late April at between $12 and $15 a share.

title: Hers; by Mary Kay Blakely
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For several weeks, it will be written by Mary Kay Blakely, a newspaper columnist in Fort Wayne, Ind., and co-editor of ''Pulling Our Own Strings: Feminist Humor and Satire'' (Indiana University Press, 1980).

title: Fashion Magazine Revived
description: Ideal Publishing, whose 36 titles include Teen Beat, Soap Opera Guide and Flair, a fashion and beauty magazine for blacks, will bring out L'Officiel as a bimonthly beginning in September. The fashion magazine's previous co-publisher, Evan Katz, suspended publication last September while looking for new financing. It was four years old at the time.

title: Fisk Finally Signs White Sox Contract
description: Carlton Fisk ended his flight from the Boston Red Sox today when he signed a five-year contract with the Chicago White Sox for $2.9 million.

title: Apartment Gardener
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Eden Lipson's description of life with an apartment gardener (''All the Dirt About Living With a Gardener,'' March 12) kept me laughing all morning. Eight years ago one small geranium led me into an adventure with apartment gardening that ballooned to over 500 plants, tier upon tier of lights, a makeshift alpine garden constructed in the bedroom window to overwinter hardy perennials, and every conceivable corner of my three-and-a-half-room apartment being stacked with pots, compost and a staggering array of ''plant aids.''

title: THE BIG QUESTION: OIL OR GAS HEAT?
description: THIS is the time of year, as the last oil trucks of the heating season are winding up their hoses, when many homeowners assess their oil-damaged budgets and resolve to make their heating systems more efficient - before the bills start sliding under the door again. The question many of these homeowners face is whether to switch to natural gas or to upgrade an oil-fired system. From now until fall heating contractors expect their telephones to be ringing ("Off the hook," said one in Queens) with orders for conversion burners or all new gas systems. But many homeowners, wary of being victimized by sudden gas price changes, will be calling to have existing oil equipment upgraded. The decision on gas is difficult primarily because no one knows the effect deregulation policies will have on prices and supply.

title: Verderosa Stops Mullins At 0:38 of First Round
description: Undefeated John Verderosa won the United States Boxing Association junior lightweight championship and earned a probable world title shot tonight with a stunning knockout of previously unbeaten Robert Mullins at 38 seconds of the first round of a scheduled 12-rounder at Ice World.

title: SOVIET REBUKES REAGAN ON GUNS FOR AFGHAN REBELS
description: The official Soviet press agency Tass accused President Reagan today of making ''provocative and hostile'' pronouncements about Afghanistan that would make a Southwest Asia political settlement more difficult.

title: Loans for Colombia
description: Nineteen international banks have agreed to lend Colombia $200 million to expand its two energy companies, Carbocol and Ecopetrol. Also $54 million will be lent to the city of Medellin to finance municipal development. Managing the loans are the Bank of America, Toronto-Dominion Bank, Algemene Bank Nederland and the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan.

title: A Cousin of Gambino Acquitted in Drug Case
description: A jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday acquitted Giuseppe Gambino, a cousin of the late reputed mobster Carlo Gambino, of charges that he had conspired to import into the United States millions of dollars worth of heroin last year from Milan, Italy.

title: Helen Breen Kumblad Dies at 77; Formerly an Interior Decorator
description: Helen B. Kumblad, a former interior decorator who worked under her maiden name, Helen Breen, died Tuesday at St. Clare's Hospital, after a long illness.

title: French Find Oil in Africa
description: The state-owned oil company, Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, said today that a subsidiary had found oil and gas at a test well in Cameroon. The well is 55 miles northwest of Victoria.

title: Bishop Loughlin Girls Win Track Crown for a Sweep
description: Bishop Loughlin made it a sweep of Catholic High Schools indoor track titles with a victory in the girls' championships last night at Pratt Institute.

title: AN ARGENTINE JUDGE'S LESS-THAN-SCANDALOUS 'CRACKDOWN'
