description: To the Editor:

title: Technology; Controlling Ignition Timing
description: AS engineers have worked to meet the often conflicting goals of improving fuel economy while meeting ever-stiffer standards for exhaust emissions, automobile and truck engines have grown more complicated. Pumps to inject additional air, plumbing to recirculate exhaust gases, catalytic converters and computer-controlled carburetors have been added, increasing costs and adding to maintenance difficulties.

title: THERMOSTAT AND AQUASTAT CAN BRING BIG SAVINGS
description: AN efficient heating system can provide exactly the amount of comfort that you require and not a bit more. Enter the thermostat and aquastat, the brains of the heating system. As one might expect, the more sophisticated the control, the more comfortable the house.

title: Jackson Chided by Steinbrenner
description: Calling yesterday's outburst by Reggie Jackson that of a ''4-year-old running into a corner and having a tantrum,'' George Steinbrenner said today that he wanted to sign Jackson to a new contract and would try to do it at what he called a propitious time.

title: DONORS GIVE O0ER $375,000 TO REFURBISH WHITE HOUSE
description: Contributors have donated more than $375,000 to the private fund established for redecorating Ronald and Nancy Reagan's living quarters, 88 percent more than the goal of $200,000, White House officials said today.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Wins in Return
description: Chris Evert Lloyd overwhelmed Iva Budarova of Czechoslovakia, 6-0, 6-1, in a first-round match of a $150,000 tennis tournament last night. Mrs. Lloyd said her four-month layoff had been good for her game.

title: Ward Foods Candy Unit To Thompson, Chicago
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company's Chicago office has just picked up a sweet assignment, the Ward Foods confectionary division.

title: TEXT OF BLESSING
description: Following is the text of Joseph Smith Jr.'s blessing to his son, Joseph 3d, when the son was 12 years old. It was supplied by the Rev. Wesley Walters, pastor of the Marissa Presbyterian Church, Marissa, Ill., who acquired it in his research into Mormon history.

title: HAIG CITES 'HIT LIST' FOR SOVIET CONTROL OF CENTRAL AMERICA
description: The Reagan Administration made another attack on the Soviet Union today, with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. accusing it of being responsible for ''international terrorism,'' of having ''a hit list'' for domination of Central America, and of posing ''the most serious threat to world peace that we're facing.''

title: Administration Rejects Tax Break for Military
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has suggested special tax breaks for military personnel to induce them to stay in uniform, but President Reagan has rejected the proposal, Administration sources said today.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt GORKY PARK. By Martin Cruz Smith. 365 pages. Illustrated with map of Moscow. Random House. $13.95.

title: Barber Again Sets Liquidation Payout
description: The Barber Oil Corporation declared a $22-a-share liquidating dividend, payable April 8 to holders of record March 30, the second such distribution under the company's liquidation plan. The first distribution, $40 a share, was made Jan. 30.

title: FAST POKER, DROPPING 6 ZEROS FOR EASE
description: Budget cutting Senators put in an 11-hour, $20 billion day in a windowless room, leaving it cluttered with numbers and the rhetoric of winners and losers. And when the participants of the Senate Budget Committee emerged from the staleaired room into the sharp cold night, there seemed a tinge of Las Vegas in the air.

title: An Ex-Governor Waiting in the Wings
description: He was an actor who became a governor and helped make politics safe for Ronald Reagan, but now, two months after the inauguration of his fellow professional, John Davis Lodge is still awaiting a call to return to government service.

title: 19 Leftist Guerrillas Reported Killed in Colombia
description: Soldiers have killed 19 members of the M-19 leftist guerrilla group and captured 74, including some top leaders of the group, the Government said today.

title: WHITE HOUSE DISPLACES STATE DEPT. IN PLANNING FOR REAGAN'S MEXICO TRIP
description: The White House has taken control of planning for President Reagan's trip to Mexico next month, in part because of what aides described as dissatisfaction with the State Department's preparations for Mr. Reagan's visit to Canada last week.

title: Index; International
description: Mexico, crushing a maverick, razes a neighborhood A2 White House takes over planning for Reagan's Mexican trip A3 U.N. makes progress on deploring troop deaths in Lebanon A3 Rights body bids Britain reform Belfast laws on terror suspects A4 Around the World A5 Iraq says heavy fighting costs Iranians heavy casualties A6 Soviet press agency criticizes Reagan on Afghanistan A6 South African Premier faces down hecklers at boisterous rally A7 South African planes raid Angola A8 White House and State Dept. disavow aide's hard-line comments A8 Earthquake sends Greeks from new ruins to older ones A12 Government/Politics Donations for redecorating the White House exceed $375,000 A14 Ex-Justice aide defends soft penalties for Abscam leaks A15 Judge finds discrimination in Georgia jury selection A18 Connecticut Democrats agree to cut spending by $5.2 million B2 Planning agency approves sale of firehouse air rights B3 Carey proposal to revamp Job Incentive Program criticized B5 New site being considered for Trident submarine construction B14 General Around the Nation A14 Illegal aliens get first schooling in Texas classes A21 A family seeks to come to terms with son's anti-Semitic 'prank' B1 Co-op maintenance charges rise up to 12% average B4 Firemen seek cause of blaze that destroyed Queens synagogue B5 Off-duty New York City officer charged with slaying sergeant B5 Police study debris for clues to bomb maker B9 The Home Section Home The built-ins made to take out C1

title: People
description: * David M. Roethgen has been appointed director of advertising-United States for Avon Products Inc.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: Comment: ''When marrying, one should ask oneself this question: Do you believe that you will be able to converse well with this woman into your old age? Everything else in marriage is transitory, but the most during the association belongs to conversation.'' Friedrich Nietzsche DR. FRITZ F. BLUMENTHAL
description: Middletown, N. Y.

title: N.C.A.A. Resumes Tonight
description: The quest for the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship resumes on two fronts tonight. In Atlanta, the East Regional semifinals open with Virginia playing Tennessee and Notre Dame playing Brigham Young.

title: By Sports of The Times; Larry Brown and His Vocation
description: ON Jan. 30, 1979, the Denver Nuggets were in the closing minutes of a game they would lose, 82

title: Brown Views Arena, Says 'It's Fantastic'
description: ''I think it's fantastic,'' Larry Brown said as he stood inside the uncompleted 20,000-seat Meadowlands Arena today. ''It has great sight lines. It sort of reminds you of the Rupp Arena in Kentucky.''

title: Market Place; Growth Stocks Around World
description: INVESTORS have always sought out growth companies and for good reason: the best market gains have been associated with such stocks. But most investors have limited their commitments to growth companies in this nation, ignoring some fine growth companies based overseas. Obviously, this makes sense for those who fear foreign devaluation and political turmoil.

title: Going Out Guide
description: WELL MET

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I wouldn't call it necessarily a domino theory. I would call it a priority target list - a hit list, if you will - for the ultimate takeover of Central America.''

title: The U.N. Today; March 19, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Law of the Sea Conference, Commit- tee on the Seabed - 10:30 A.M.

title: INDIA'S POPULATION GROWTH UNCHECKED IN 10 YEARS
description: India's population is 684 million, at least 12 million more than was estimated in earlier official projections, and despite huge expenditures on birth control programs the rate of growth over the last 10 years remained the same as in the previous decade.

title: WORK ON MX SYSTEM SPEEDS ON THOUGH ITS BASE ISN'T YET PICKED
description: For the construction crews pouring cement and erecting steel girders on this windswept strip of the Pacific Coast, there is no debate about the MX missile. They are building a complex that will be used for 20 test flights beginning in 1983.

title: ALASKA PIPELINE BACKERS SEE PRIVATE FINANCING
description: Sponsors of the Alaska Highway Pipeline Project say they expect to reach an agreement by the end of the month on a plan to raise the $8.2 billion needed for the crucial Alaskan leg on purely commercial terms.

title: Design Notebook; HOUSEHOLD PLANNING BY EARLY FEMINISTS
description: THE design of the physical environment of the home itself and the way that it can help or hinder the modern woman in her struggle to balance independence and domesticity has not been a major theme for contemporary feminists.

title: REAGAN ASKS COAST CRITIC TO PLUG SHOW
description: President Reagan telephoned Dan Sullivan, drama critic of The Los Angeles Times, on Monday to put in a good word for Buddy Ebsen's new musical, ''Turn to the Right.''

title: 37 CIVIL JUDGES WILL ASSIST CITY IN FELONY TRIALS
description: A plan to increase the number of judges trying New York City felony cases in State Supreme Court was announced yesterday by the state's chief judge.

title: Sumitomo to Study Sharing Technology
description: Sumitomo Metal Industries Ltd., producer of seamless pipe used to drill for oil, said it had agreed to study sharing its technology with the Pittsburgh-based Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation.

title: Critic's Notebook; WHEN A FLASH OF TRUTH LEAPS OUT AT A THEATERGOER FROM THE STAGE
description: I ALWAYS like it when a spot of truth leaps out at you, whether you're wildly happy with the show you are looking at or not. I wasn't ecstatic over ''Piaf,'' for instance, because it uses a jumping-jack narrative style that keeps leaping over the big emotional scenes, the urgent intimacies, that I most wanted to know about. A hastily brushed-in line of exposition, tossed our way after the fact, just isn't enough.

title: On Marriage
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: In reference to the Hers column (March 5), Carolyn Heilbrun is quite mistaken that W.H. Auden was as unmarried as Jane Austen. He married Erika Mann to get her out of Germany. One might say he was a true gallant, as well as a first-rate anti-Fascist. LOUISE THOMPSON

title: WOODY ALLEN TALKS- A LITTLE- ABOUT A 'LIGHT BULB'
description: The word was out and the message was adamant. Woody Allen would appear for a picture-taking session with the cast of his new play, ''The Floating Light Bulb,'' before rehearsal yesterday at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. But the elusive author would not talk to the press.

title: TENANTS RALLY ROUND A TREE
description: By the end of the afternoon yesterday, the residents of 245 East 36th Street and the demolition crew were still at a standoff. Kathy Cleveland, bundled in a down coat, was perched on the fifth rung of a crude ladder nailed up on the trunk of an old ailanthus tree, glaring across the ruined garden behind the building at the crew of men, who had taken shelter in a vacant apartment on one side of the garden.

title: HORACE S. PECK
description: Horace S. Peck, who until he retired in 1965 was manager of the New York State Unemployment Insurance office on Staten Island, died Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital after a brief illness.

title: SOCCER VOTE ON ROSTERS UNDER WAY
description: The players of the Major Indoor Soccer League are in the midst of a vote in which they are asked if they want to try to reverse a rule whose effect would be to limit the number of Canadian players next season.

title: MATTHEWS TO TALK WITH PHILS
description: The Atlanta Braves gave Gary Matthews permission today to talk with the Philadelphia Phillies to see if he would approve being traded to them.

title: POLICE ANALYZING DEBRIS FOR CLUES TO BOMB'S MAKERS
description: Police scientists were analyzing fragments of a timer and other debris yesterday, seeking clues to the maker of an incendiary device that injured two bomb squad detectives on Bleecker Street on Tuesday.

title: POLICE ENDING REQUIREMENT ON CARRYING GUNS OFF DUTY
description: Off-duty New York City police officers will no longer have to carry their guns at all times, under a new order announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire. The order gives them the discretion to be without their weapons in some ''social situations,'' such as when they participate in sports, go to the beach and attend parties.

title: FANNIE MAE TIGHTENING MORTGAGES
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, which holds some two million mortgages that it has purchased from savings banks and other mortgage lenders, announced a program today to reduce the number of its mortgages still outstanding at bargain rates of 8 or 9 percent or lower.

title: Bridge; PLAYERS HEADING FOR DETROIT AND GRAND NATIONAL FINALS; Bridge: Players Heading for Detroit And Grand National Finals
description: A small contingent of players is already in Detroit, competing in the finals of the Grand National Pairs, which serve as a curtainraiser for the 10 days of the Spring National Championships. Thousands more are en route today, to compete in the men's and women's pairs, beginning tomorrow, or in minor events. More will follow in time to enter the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams Sunday.

title: Gasoline Inventory Climbs to Record
description: Gasoline inventories reached a record high last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Stocks climbed to 284.3 million barrels as of March 13, up from 281.7 million barrels in the week before.

title: CO-OP MAINTENANCE CHARGES ROSE 8% TO 12% IN 1980
description: Spurred by the continuing rise of the cost of heating oil, maintenance charges for cooperative apartment buildings in New York City increased by 8 to 12 percent in 1980, according to an informal canvass of directors and managing agents. It marks the second straight year that the upper increase in average cooperative maintenance charges was pushed into double-digit levels by soaring fuel costs.

title: Eugene Rostow Reported Picked As Chief of Arms Control Agency
description: Eugene V. Rostow, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs in the Johnson Administration, has been asked to serve as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, Reagan Administration sources said today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG'S REPLIES BEFORE HOUSE PANEL
description: Following are excerpts from responses by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to questions during today's hearing in the House Foreign Affairs Committee, first from Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida, and then from Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of New York:nm Special to the New York Times

title: E.F. Hutton to Buy Finance Company
description: The International Paper Company and E.F. Hutton Group Inc. said they had signed a letter of intent for the sale of International Paper's financial services subsidiary to E.F. Hutton for an undisclosed amount. Completion of the sale is expected in the second quarter of this year.

title: BOTHA FACE DOWN AFRIKANER HECKLERS
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha ventured tonight into the eastern Transvaal, where a white backlash supposedly threatens his National Party with the loss of a few seats in the coming national election, and faced down hecklers at a boisterous campaign rally that seemed at one point to be headed for a free-for-all.

title: The City; More Inspectors Asked for Kennedy
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey asked for a 25 percent increase in the number of immigration inspectors at Kennedy International Airport to reduce delays in the clearance of foreign visitors, especially during the summer.

title: Conceits From a Judge's Lofty Perch
description: It was Judge William Hughes Mulligan's final decision before leaving the United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan. The case involved smuggling rare swans from Canada, and so, in what he called his ''swan song,'' Judge Mulligan filed a 12-page decision this week peppered with painful puns and other attempts at judicial humor.

title: EXPORTS SPUR SOUTH AFRICAN COAL MINE GROWTH
description: In the last five years South African coal exports have increased nearly fourfold. In the next five years they are expected to nearly double further. This growth has catapulted coal into second place as a South African export earner, trailing only gold.

title: MORMON DOCUMENT RAISES DOUBTS ON SUCCESSION OF CHURCH'S LEADERS
description: A document almost a century and a half old has been acquired by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints that raises questions about the succession of church leadership after the death of Joseph Smith Jr., the Mormon prophet, in June 1844.

title: CONTINUING BOND RALLY DROPS YIELDS SHARPLY; 2-Year Notes Bring 12.65%
description: Prices continued to surge in the credit markets yesterday as buyers rushed to lock in current yields on the belief that the prime and other interest rates were headed lower. As it was, rates crumbled in all sectors of the credit markets.

title: Minter, Ex-Champion, Is Winner by a Decision
description: Alan Minter, former world middleweight champion, scored a 10-round decision over Ernie Singletary of Philadelphia last night at Wembley Arena. Minter furthered his chances of a rematch with Marvin Hagler, who dethroned him last year.

title: Reagan Held to Emphasize Needs In Plan to Raise Military Outlays
description: President Reagan's proposals for a big rise in military spending are more than just throwing money at a problem, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger told Congressional Democrats today.

title: Chemical Warfare Tests By Army Are Disclosed
description: The Army dropped 22 tons of tiny glass beads and fluorescent-treated cork particles over a 4,800-square-mile area of Texas in 1966 in simulated chemical and biological warfare, according to Army documents made public today.

title: Blacks in Congress Offer Alternative Budget Plan
description: The Congressional Black Caucus today offered an alternative budget that would restore most of the cuts in social programs proposed by President Reagan, and with a deficit $1.5 billion smaller than that expected by the Administration.

title: U.N. COUNCIL STALLED ON LEBANON ISSUE
description: The Security Council appeared to be stalled today, after three days of wrangling, in its efforts to put together a statement expressing concern over the killing Monday of at least two Nigerian members of the United Nations peacekeeping forces in Lebanon and the wounding of 20 other United Nations soldiers.

title: PREJUDGING THE C.I.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: MEXICO CRUSHING A MAVERICK, RAZES A NEIGHBOR
description: Isabel Arroyo de Garcia sat on a rickety wooden chair and watched her husband and brother slowly demolish the tiny cement-block house that they built with their savings six years ago. She seemed close to tears. ''We've been given 24 hours to rescue what we can,'' she said, ''then the bulldozers are coming.''

title: The City; Carey Gives Notice On Westway Buying
description: Governor Carey has begun to notify community planning boards on Manhattan's West Side that the state and Federal governments intend to purchase land along the Hudson River to build the Westway highway project, the Governor's office reported yesterday.

title: DEMOCRATS IN CONNECTICUT AGREE ON CUT IN SPENDING
description: Democratic legislative leaders, trying to avert a deficit, agreed today to a $5.2 million cut in state spending that could mean layoffs for about 550 state employees.

title: Companies
description: Prudential has reached a tentative agreeement to buy the Bache Group for an estimated $375 million, Wall Street sources said. The board of directors of Bache, the parent of one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, unanimously approved the surprise deal, which presumably thwarts an unwanted takeover by the Belzberg family of Canada, which owns nearly 23 percent of Bache's stock. (Page A1.)

title: 70 STUDENTS HELD IN SEOUL PROTEST
description: Seventy students at Seoul National University were arrested yesterday by the police and Government authorities in the first major student protests since Chun Doo Hwan became President.

title: Notes on People; SINGING AND COMMUNICATING IN HIS OWN SPECIAL WAY
description: He is deaf and can't speak, but when the New York City Gay Men's Chorus gives a concert at Bond's International Disco on Times Square Sunday night, Bruce Hlibok plans to be right there singing away in a style that is uniquely his own.

title: PUBLISHING: HEALTHY DIET OF FICTION AT ST. MARTIN'S
description: WHAT book company published the most novels last year? There is no official scorecard, but St. Martin's Press, whose total output of 342 titles in 1980 included 164 works of fiction, thinks it holds the distinction. ''If I'm not mistaken,'' said Thomas J McCormack, president of St. Martin's, ''only one other publisher, Doubleday, does as many as 100 fiction titles in a year.''

title: The City; Strike Authorized At Nursing Homes
description: About 1,500 of the 15,000 people employed at 82 metropolitan-area nursing homes voted to authorize an April 1 strike. All of the nursing homes are within the city limits except for two in Rockland County and one in Sands Point in Nassau County.

title: NORTH CAROLINA OUSTS UTAHz
description: Danny Ainge drove the length of the court in less than 6 seconds, avoiding all five Notre Dame defenders, to make a spectacular layup with 2 seconds left and give Brigham Young a 51-50 victory in the National Collegiate East Regional semifinals tonight.

title: BRIDGE PARTNERS CROSSING INTO SPRING
description: The winds still howl over the East River and the Watchtower thermometer seems stuck around the freezing point. But according to the calendar, spring arrives today. And when, sometime this morning, my friend the bicyclist hobbles past me on the Brooklyn Bridge promenade, I would like to stop him and extend him a fraternal handshake. Together, we've made it through another winter, colder than the last, solitary figures suspended between two boroughs each day as we make our ways to work. It is no mean feat and congratulations would be in order - if only I knew his name.

title: SWISS, DETERMINED TO SURVIVE, DIG NUCLEAR SHELTERS AND SHOW OTHERS HOW
description: The success of Switzerland's civil defense program, which emphasizes shelters against nuclear fallout, has resulted in the neutral country's becoming a civil defense instructor for much of Western Europe.

title: NORTH CAROLINA OUSTS UTAH
description: North Carolina nullified Utah's inside scoring game and its home-court advantage and advanced to the N.C.A.A. West Regional final with a 61-56 victory tonight.

title: THE PROBLEM WITH TAXING SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS
description: To the Editor:

title: MARJORIE MORSE CONNELLY
description: Dr. Marjorie Morse Connelly, director of continuing education at the College of Mount St. Vincent in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, died Wednesday at White Plains Hospital. She was 61 years old and a resident of Purchase, N.Y.

title: Notes on People; SERPICO BEMOANS THE POWER OF TECHNOLOGY; Serpico Bemoans the Power of Technology
description: At the close of the hit movie based on the life of Frank Serpico, the New York City detective who battled police corruption for five years, he was reported living in lonely disillusionment in Switzerland.

title: JUDGE PERMITS A LIMITED INQUIRY ON READER'S DIGEST
description: A judge ruled yesterday that the Federal Election Commission could go ahead with a sharply limited investigation of the Reader's Digest for distributing videotapes about Senator Edward M. Kennedy's automobile accident at Chappaquiddick.

title: PATIENT AT A STRUCK HOSPITAL DIED OF CAUSES NOT CITED, AUTOPSY FINDS
description: State and city medical investigators and review committees at Lincoln and Coney Island Hospitals began simultaneous inquiries yesterday into charges by striking physicians-in-training that two patients died needlessly because of staff shortages.

title: 'FINAL CONFLICT,' THE LAST OF DAMIEN
description: THE good news, for the devout and the moviegoing, is that Damien the Antichrist is no more. At the end of ''The Final Conflict,'' the third and last installment in the ''Omen'' story, he vanishes in a cloud of quack theology and headache-inducing hymns. The bad news is that Damien has a whole movie to get through before he gives up the ghost, and that the movie is a grisly one. One of the many fatalities here, a monk who is incinerated while hanging by one foot and wrapped in a sheet of plastic, is even enough to make the hard-hearted Damien go ugh.

title: Around the Nation; New Round of Transit Talks Fail in Philadelphia Strike
description: Newly resumed contract talks in the city's five-day transit strike broke off today, with negotiators for both sides reported unwilling to compromise on the issue of hiring part-time workers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Apple Computer Inc., Cupertino, Calif., has named A. C. Markkula Jr. president and chief executive; Steven P. Jobs chairman and Michael M. Scott vice chairman.

title: CITY'S TAX-INCENTIVE PROGRAM BENEFITS GOVENMENT, TOO
description: So diverse and extensive are the neighborhoods and the housing of New York City that it is impossible to devise a single technique for housing improvement that is perfect for every situation. When tax incentives are used, the charge will inevitably be leveled that this or that project needed no special tax benefit to proceed.

title: Lenders Briefed on Harvester Debt Plan
description: Officials of the International Harvester Company, the troubled manufacturer of trucks, farm machinery and construction equipment, faced sharp questioning from some of its lenders yesterday when it presented its $4.9 billion debt restructuring plan to 300 representatives of 200 banks.

title: Home Loan Bank Choice
description: Richard Pratt, a financial consultant, has been chosen chairman of the board of the Federal Home Loan Bank, the White House announced. Mr. Pratt, 40 years old, has been president of Richard T. Pratt Associates since 1970. He is also a professor of finance at the business college at the Univesity of Utah. From 1970 to 1979, Mr. Pratt was director of the Seattle Federal Home Loan Bank.

title: POLISH POLICE BREAK UP FARMER PROTEST
description: Riot policemen in the central Polish city of Bydgoszcz broke up a demonstration last night by farmers seeking to form a union, evicting the protesters from a government building and beating some so severely that they were hospitalized, according to the Solidarity trade union movement.

title: Oil Reserves Up in Mexico
description: The state oil monopoly, Pemex, announced increases in Mexico's hydrocarbon reserves but gave no hint of plans to raise oil production beyond this year's target of 2.75 million barrels a day.

title: U.N. SECURITY COUNCIL CONDEMNS LEBANON KILLINGS
description: After four days of diplomatic haggling over wording, the United Nations Security Council reached agreement early today on a statement condemning the killing of two United Nations peacekeeping soldiers in southern Lebanon on Monday.

title: Matthews Happy to Go to Phils
description: Gary Matthews, one of the first players to become wealthy through free agency, said today that he didn't know why the Atlanta Braves were so eager to trade him but that he was thrilled to be going to the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Around the World; Pakistani Plane Hijackers Are Allowed to Stay in Syria
description: A Syrian official said today that his Government would allow three Pakistani plane hijackers to remain in Syria until another country took them in.

title: STUDY SHOWS PLANNED WELFARE CUTS WOULD HURT POOR WHO WORK
description: President Reagan's proposed budget cuts would reduce the disposable income of poor workers who also receive welfare by so much that their families would be little better off than those who relied entirely on public assistance, according to the first comprehensive study of the potential effects on individual families on welfare.

title: Around the World; Leader Wins Six-Year Term In Central African Republic
description: President David Dacko has been elected for a six-year term as head of state in the Central African Republic, the Supreme Court announced tonight.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE JOBS CUT THROUGHOUT U.S.
description: President Reagan's decision to withhold funds for public service jobs is having a quick and substantial impact as local governments and community organizations around the country are being forced to lay off thousands of workers.

title: Syracuse Gains N.I.T. Semifinal
description: Syracuse made its first 16 shots in the second half and offset a 30-point performance by Michigan's Mike McGee tonight for a 91-76 quarterfinal basketball victory in the National Invitation Tournament before a crowd of 20,695 in the Carrier Dome.

title: CONSTRUCTION CONCERN ADMITS PAYING UNIONS TO SECURE LABOR PEACE
description: A construction company involved in a multimillion-dollar renovation of a building in lower Manhattan pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to charges that two company officers paid $50,000 to officials of two unions to secure labor peace at the site. The site is at 405 Hudson Street.

title: SENATE BUDGET PANEL REJECTS PROPOSED PUBLIC-BROADCAST CUTS
description: The Senate Budget Committee today unanimously defeated a proposal by the Reagan Administration that would have cut the Corporation for Public Broadcasting's budget next year by 25 percent.

title: Staring Into a Union Grab Bag
description: In a tough, detailed new report, the State Investigation Commission calls attention to three facts that will startle most New Yorkers:

title: Bridge: Detroit Means a Beginning, But Also, for a Few, an End
description: For thousands of players arriving here today, ready to battle for 10 days in the Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League, it was a beginning. But for a handful of experts it was an end - the last day of play in the Grand National Pairs, which began at club level last August.

title: Notes on People; QUICK TRIP TO STARDOM; Quick Trip to Stardom for 50 Producers
description: They are rarely recognized, and their names are hardly household words, but now 50 Broadway producers have become certified celebrities. Their caricatures have been added to the Sardi's collection of stars.

title: The Region; 15 Tenants Unhurt In Connecticut Fire
description: Fifteen apartment tenants, including a monthold baby, escaped injury when a fire badly damaged the frame building they lived in, officials said.

title: Jailed Employee of U.N.  Asks Poles for Clemency
description: Alicja Wesolowska, the United Nations employee sentenced to seven years in prison in her homeland for spying, has petitioned Poland's Council of State for clemency, saying she exhausted all other legal channels.

title: by Mimi Sheraton; East Side steak and side dishes of Japan.
description: ALTHOUGH widely disparate in the styles of their settings and the kind of food they serve, Elmer's and Aikahana, the two restaurants reviewed this week, share a common condition. Both merit only a single star for the overall performance of their kitchens, yet both offer a number of specialties that deserve two stars. Because both kitchens are inconsistent and turn out many disappointing dishes, the rating represents an average. But if the right choices are made on each menu, it is possible to have an interesting and thoroughly satisfying meal at either place.

title: The City; 5 Arrested by F.B.I.  In Tin Hijacking
description: A hijacking ring that stole nearly $1 million worth of tin at gunpoint was broken up with the arrest of five men, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

title: 86 Hurt on Hong Kong Hydrofoil
description: A hydrofoil ran aground on an outlying Hong Kong island in heavy fog today and at least 86 people were injured, authorities said. The hydrofoil was bound for the Portuguese colony of Macao, about 40 miles west of this British colony.

title: RARELY SEEN OPERAS NOW GAINING SPOTLIGHT
description: OPERAGOERS with a taste for the offbeat will be treated to a generous selection of novelties in this opera-rich city over the weekend when a particularly varied selection of works outside the standard repertory are offered by the companies in residence.

title: STILL BEATING DRUM FOR FRANCO, MADRID NEWSPAPER IS BESIEGED
description: The alcazar is under siege again. The fortress in Toledo became a legend in the Spanish Civil War, surviving an epic two-month Republican siege until it was finally relieved by Francisco Franco's advancing armies on Sept. 28, 1936.

title: Around the World; Conservatives Win Handily In Elections in Ontario
description: Premier William G. Davis's Progressive Conservative Party, which has governed Ontario since 1943, won a strong victory in elections for the provincial Parliament today and regained the legislative majority it lost six years ago.

title: HERMAN A. Gray, 86; A.F.L.-C.I.O. ATTORNEY
description: Herman A. Gray, a labor lawyer and arbitrator who taught at the New York University Law School for more than 30 years, died yesterday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 86 years old and lived in Pine Plains, N.Y.

title: HIRING FREEZE FOR CETA WILL AFFECT 11,500 IN CITY
description: A Reagan Administration order that cuts New York City's annual allocation for public-service jobs by 40 percent midway in the year confronts the city with a difficult choice.

title: 4 AT WELLS FARGO NAMED BY BOXING FIGURE IN FRAUD
description: Harold J. Smith, the boxing promoter who has been accused by the Wells Fargo National Bank of defrauding it of $21.3 million, asserted last night that at least four bank officials were involved who have not previously been mentioned in connection with the alleged fraud.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in some copies of The Times on Wednesday incorrectly identified a lawyer, E.D. Bronson Jr. Mr. Bronson, of Bronson, Bronson & McKinnon, is the lead attorney for the entertainer Carol Burnett in her case against The National Enquirer.

title: Where to Skate, Hours and Prices
description: Following is a list of some roller disco sites in Manhattan with prices and times for skating. The Roxy, 515 West 18th Street near 10th Avenue (675-8300). Friday and Saturday, 9 P.M. to 4 A.M., admission $12. Saturday and Sunday, noon to 6 P.M., adults $6; younger than 12 $5. Sunday, 8 P.M. to 3 A.M., admission $8.

title: W. Virginia 80, Minnesota 69
description: West Virginia, with 21 points from Greg Jones and three other players in double figures, upset Minnesota, 80-69, in the N.I.T. tonight.

title: No Headline
description: Afghanistan today denied a United States suggestion that it might have supplied arms to the hijackers of a Pakistani airliner at the Kabul airport earlier this month, the Soviet press agency Tass said.

title: Auerbach Signs 10-Year Contract
description: Red Auerbach, the Boston Celtics' president and general manager, has agreed to a 10-year contract after abandoning thoughts of retirement at the end of the season.

title: Morley and Eichelberger Share Lead at 68
description: Sawgrass, the mean-spirited golf course that is the site this week for its fifth and last Tournament Players Championship, challenged a field of 144 of the country's best golf pros today with winds of 30 miles an hour and more. This is the way it usually is here in March.

title: POPS AND BLUES WITH BONNIE KOLOC
description: BONNIE KOLOC, a singer from Chicago who made her first appearance at Michael's Pub a year ago, is back again singing a program of pop songs and blues that often hover on the edge of folk music.

title: New Talent Is Hired At Muller Jordan Weiss
description: A lot has been going on at Muller Jordan Weiss that could affect the future of the agency. There is new business, about $3 million worth of it, but mostly there are two new people, young or youngish packaged-goods hot shots.

title: 2-TERM SENATOR FROM COLOADO
description: Peter H. Dominick, a conservative Republican from Colorado who served 14 years in Congress, including two years in the House of Representatives and 12 years in the Senate, and briefly represented the United States as Ambassador to Switzerland in 1975, died Wednesday night of a heart attack in his winter home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 65 years old.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MARCH 20, 1981
description: International An effort to develop an anti-Soviet belt across the Middle East will be pressed by the Reagan Administration, according to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. The aim, he said in Senate testimony, will be a strategic ''consensus'' stretching from Egypt to Pakistan, and including such disparate nations as Turkey, Israel and Saudi Arabia. (Page A1, Column 6.) Bonn officials welcomed disavowals by Washington of statements by a Reagan Adminstration security adviser that questioned the ability of West Germany's Foreign Minister to withstand Soviet pressure and suggesting that war with the Soviet Union was inevitable unless the Russians abandoned Communism. (A3:1-3.)

title: 'WHO WILL STAND UP FOR YURI STEPANOV?'
description: To the Editor:

title: BOAT GIG OVER, TEDDY CHARLES RETURNS TO HIS VIBES
description: LIKE Rip Van Winkle returning from his long slumber, Teddy Charles, the vibraphonist and composer who disappeared from the jazz world in the mid-1960's, is back in town, looking for a familiar face or a familiar sound.

title: MINE STRIKES SPREAD DESPITE UNION PLEA
description: Nearly 13,000 miners kept mines shut for a second day in the nation's soft coal fields yesterday as new wildcat strikes started in Pennsylvania.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We feel it is fundamentally important to begin to develop a consensus of strategic concerns throughout the region among Arab and Jew and to be sure that the over-riding danger of Soviet inroads into this area are not overlooked.'' - Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. (A4:3.)

title: 'CUTTER AND BONE,' AN IVAN PASSER MYSTERY
description: IT'S about time that Ivan Passer, the gifted Czechoslovak director (''Intimate Lighting'') who has been making films (among others, ''Born to Lose,'' later retitled ''Born to Win'') in this country and Western Europe in recent years, came up with the winning film he is certainly capable of making. As it is, he seems to be bent on establishing his own genre -throwaway movies of mystery, espionage and sometimes black comedy, movies full of occasionally remarkable sequences that ultimately add up to zero.

title: Topics; SCREENING PROCESSIS PAPER CHASE; Paper Chase
description: Biographers of Presidents are in for slim pickings in manuscripts if Jimmy Carter's memoirs are any precedent. When he wrote his autobiography a few years ago, he pecked out every word on a portable typewriter.

title: OH! KENTUCKY'S ECLECTIC CROWD
description: The invitation read, ''Dress Country Chic.'' But when the party is at Bloomingdale's and the guests number 500, you can bet that dress code will be interpreted in a variety of ways. Or simply ignored.

title: INTERIM NUCLEAR LICENSES ARE URGED
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission asked Congress today to let it issue interim licenses for nuclear power plants to be started at low power before public hearings have been concluded.

title: PANEL BRIEFS REAGAN ON AUTO AID
description: A Cabinet-level task force briefed President Reagan today on its recommendations for aiding the depressed auto industry. But its members were still split over whether to ask Japan to limit car exports to the United States.

title: Stargell Injury A Worry
description: Is Willie Stargell, limping on one knee at the age of 40, the symbol of the Pittsburgh Pirates' conquering past and uncertain future?

title: 'Damn Yankees' designated for season at Jones Beach.
description: March with its annual summer production - a revival of a popular Broadway musical lavishly mounted under the stars on the theater's floating stage. But this year's production was up in the air until a few days ago, when the New York State Parks and Recreation Department came through with $1.7 million to finance the project.

title: The Region; 2d Youth Admits Vandalism at Temple
description: A 16-year-old youth who was charged in an incident of anti-Semitic vandalism at the Community Reform Temple in Westbury, L.I., last fall pleaded guilty in Nassau County District Court in Mineola to criminal tampering in the third degree.

title: For Children; Family Concert
description: 4120. Sea Chanties and a Play SEA CHANTIES, with music by a banjoist, fiddler and a guitarist, and IN A PICKLE, a music, mime and puppet show, by the Loon & Heron Theater, Saturday at 2 P.M., at the Whitman Theater, Brooklyn College Center for the Performing Arts, Brooklyn College. Admission, $3. Call 462-3525 or 284-4835.

title: CITY EMPLOYEES DESERVE A MEDAL, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: USAir Has Loss in Month
description: USAir reported today that it lost $518,000 in February, compared with net earnings of $2.3 million for the month in 1980. The airline said its showing this year was affected by severe weather and the lag of fare increases behind rises in fuel costs.

title: STAGE: KILEY IN A REVISION OF BULGAKOV'S 'MOLIERE'
description: Mikhail Bulgakov survived both Stalinist suppression and patronage. In his play, ''The Cabal of Hypocrites,'' Bulgakov saw Moliere as an earlier equivalent of himself, as a writer victimized by a ruler, in Moliere's case, by Louis XIV. As translated and adapted by Michael Lessac, the play was presented several seasons ago at the Colonnades Theater Lab under the title ''Moliere in Spite of Himself,'' and proved to be - with certain reservations about the production and the performances - a provocative investigation of the abuses of power. At the same time, the work did not have the richly textured characters of the author's play and novel, ''The White Guard'' or the symbolic complexity of ''The Master and Margarita.''

title: Bans March by Neo-Nazis
description: Home Secretary William Whitelaw announced today that he had banned a planned march Sunday in the northern city of Leeds by the National Front, a neo-Nazi organization, to avert threatened clashes with nonwhites and leftist groups.

title: REAGAN AIDES SEEK MORE FUNDS FOR SPACE WEAPONRY
description: Amid fresh indications that the Soviet Union is again testing space weapons, the Reagan Administration is seeking major increases in funds for military equipment for orbital operations, including the development of two systems for shooting down enemy satellites, according to military sources.

title: A WORKER IS KILLED
description: The space shuttle Columbia passed another crucial milestone in its preflight preparations yesterday, but the successful countdown rehearsal in Florida was marred two hours later by an accident that left one technician dead and two others injured, one critically.

title: INDUSTRY STUDY TERMS PLAN FOR WASTE PLANT INADEQUATE
description: A plant to treat hazardous waste, proposed for construction in New York State within the next six years, will not be able to dispose of all of the hazardous chemical wastes generated in the state, the chief of a lobbying group for business interests said today.

title: American art on paper
description: THE list of artists represented in an auction of prints, posters, drawings and watercolors next Thursday and Friday at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, reads like a Who's Who of American art for the 19th and early 20th centuries. In this bounty of 675 works are more than 100 by James McNeill Whistler, carrying estimates from $100, for ''The Pool,'' an etching with drypoint, to $9,000, for ''The Doorway,'' an etching and drypoint, which Christie's describes as an exceptionally fine impression. The top lot in the sale is Grant Wood's ''Study for American Gothic,'' a pencil-on-paper drawing on the back of an envelope, showing the complete composition of his most notable painting. The drawing may sell for as much as $22,000. Other major works include Childe Hassam's ''Rockport Quarry,'' a watercolor and colored-chalk work on paper laid down on board (up to $20,000); William Glackens's ''The Gazebo-Hartford,'' a pastel on paper, and George Bellows's ''A Stag at Sharkey's,'' a 1917 lithograph of a boxing match (up to $10,000).

title: GARDEN MAY COST CHURCH EXEMPTION FROM TAXES
description: Looking down at the small garden boxes on the corner of Ninth Street and Avenue B on the Lower East Side, the Rev. William Purdy wondered if the plants lying dormant in the cold spring sunshine might end up being the most expensive produce in town.

title: Auto Layoffs Dip; Output Up
description: Improving sales by the auto industry were reflected in layoff and production figures this week: Output rose slightly and the number of layoffs dropped slightly, according to industry reports issued today.

title: Lord Avie Out of Race
description: A leg injury will keep Lord Avie out of the March 28 Flamingo, one of the tune-up races for the Kentucky Derby, and may jeopardize his chances to race in the Triple Crown series, the colt's trainer said yesterday at Hialeah.

title: BLOCK GRANTS
description: In addition to seeking a cut of more than $40 billion in domestic programs in the fiscal 1982 budget, President Reagan has proposed a large-scale shift to the use of block grants. He would shift responsibility for more than $15 billion in education, social, and health services to state and local governments.

title: 'A NEW 'POSTMAN ALWAYS RINGS TWICE'
description: ''Next day I was alone with her for a minute, and swung my fist up against her leg so hard it nearly knocked her over. '' 'How do you get that way?' She was snarling like a cougar. I liked her for that. '' 'How are you, Cora?' '' 'Lousy.' ''From then on, I began to smell her again.'' In this passage early in his 1934 novel ''The Postman Always Rings Twice,'' one of the great titles in popular modern American fiction, James M. Cain seems to have perfected that laconic style that begins as Hemingway parody and achieves a classic kind of vulgarity that is erotic, funny and all its own. The characters in Cain are not fancifully third-rate, as they are in Martin Ritt's ''Back Roads.'' They are the genuine article. They snarl like cougars, sometimes just for the hell of it. They don't just put plates on a table - they slam them down. They exchange banalities at a fever pitch.

title: The Economy
description: A Cabinet-level task force on aid to the auto industry remains split over whether to seek restraints of auto imports from Japan. A White House spokesman said further talks would be held, and that President Reagan wanted to discuss the issue with key legislators next week. (D1.) In Tokyo, Japan's trade minister said his country might have to mandate cutbacks in auto exports to the U.S., rather than rely on voluntary reductions, in order to avoid private antitrust suits in the U.S. (D4.)

title: Mexico Buys Surplus Milk
description: Mexico has bought nearly one-fourth of the Government's surplus of nonfat dry milk in a transaction worth about $7.35 million, the Agriculture Department said today. An official of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service unit said Mexico had bought 60,000 metric tons of the product for $1,225 a ton. Deliveries are scheduled over the next 12 months.

title: Wildburgers
description: A city friend who heads regularly for the hills writes that spring is getting closer:

title: 65% in Poll Say Religion Aids in Solving Problems
description: Two of three Americans believe religion is relevant to modern society, and the number of people expressing confidence in religious answers to contemporary problems has remained relatively stable since 1974, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: The U.N. Today; March 20, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Apart- heid meets on International Day Against Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.

title: Notes on People; TRIBUTE TO JAVITS; Tribute to Javits
description: When the Center for New York City Affairs of the New School for Social Research holds its ninth annual Fiorello H. La Guardia Award Dinner next Tuesday, the person to be honored, former Senator Jacob K. Javits, will get more than the usual statuette portraying the late Mayor La Guardia.

title: UNSUITABLE CODE
description: To the Editor:

title: by Anthony Austin
description: Until 10 A.M. on May 23, 1979, Vladimir Feltsman, a pianist, was a rising star on Soviet and international concert stages, with critical acclaim lavished on him in the Moscow press. Then, as far as Soviet audiences were concerned, he ceased to exist.

title: 5 French Children Die As Old Shell Explodes
description: A World War II mortar shell exploded in this Alsatian village today, killing five children and injuring three others.

title: FIRST BOSTON SPARKED BACHE TIE
description: The First Boston Corporation, one of Wall Street's most prominent investment banking houses, emerged yesterday as the marriage broker that brought together the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest insurance company, and the Bache Group Inc., the parent of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, the nation's eighth-largest brokerage house.

title: Rite of Eggs Downtown
description: An egg ceremony, led by the artist Donna Henes, will herald the spring today at 12:03 P.M. in the plaza of the World Trade Center.

title: LIBYA, ANGERED, HALTS OIL TO GREECE
description: Libya has cut off oil deliveries to Greece, apparently in retaliation for the granting of political asylum here to a Libyan military pilot and an official visit to Israel by a member of the Greek Government, official sources here said today.

title: WHERE TO ROLLER SKATE TO A DISCO BEAT
description: SOMEWHERE around 3500 B.C., man invented the wheel. Nearly 5,500 years later, he came up with disco music. The connection between the two events seems tenuous only to those who have never been to a roller disco, where human projectiles from all walks of life, wearing stretch fabrics of every hue, regularly hurl themselves around a fast track to a thumpity-thump beat.

title: Texaco Again Trims Gas Reserve Figures
description: Texaco Inc. disclosed its fourth cut in estimates of its proven domestic natural gas in about two years and a possible $815 million extra liability to meet its gas supply contracts.

title: Loss for Australia G.M.
description: Australia's largest auto manufacturer, General Motors-Holden, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, said today that it lost a record $149.27 million (United States) for 1980.

title: BAGHDAD AND TEHERAN ASSERT FIERCE FIGHTING GOES ON IN WEST IRAN
description: Heavy fighting continued today in the six-month-old war between Iran and Iraq, with the two sides issuing conflicting claims.

title: AMID LAWSUITS, STOUFFER'S NEARS REOPENING DATE
description: Amid plans to reopen next month, Stouffer's Inn of Westchester is facing multimillion-dollar damage suits and a continuing arson investigation of the fire last December that swept its conference rooms and left 26 business executives dead.

title: Topics; SCREENING PROCESSES PROMISING SELECTION; Promising Selection
description: Efforts to name presidents to the four-year colleges of City University have too often involved political battles, and sometimes ethnic ones as well. Thus the search committee that took more than two years to select Dr. William V. Harleston, a former dean of arts and sciences at Tufts University in Massachusetts, to head City College deserves credit just for getting its job done.

title: Index; International
description: Libya cuts oil to Greece, perhaps over pilot defector A3 Around the World A5 Reagan proposals seek greater ''flexibility'' in foreign policy A6 Jesuit is accused of trying to bring down Philippine Government A9 Iran and Iraq say fierce fighting continues A11 Iran prosecutor indicates inquiry on Bani-Sadr will continue A11 Mexico jails American on charge he imported chemical wastes A12 Swiss, digging nuclear shelters, teach others how to survive A14 Rightist newspaper in Madrid under siege A15 Government/Politics New guidelines issued for select- ing U.S. Attorneys A24 Degnan formally joins race for governor of Jersey B2 Manhattan Democratic leader plans to resign B3 General Around the Nation A16 Philadelphia crime chief's death not expected to end violence A16 Limited inquiry on Reader's Di- gest permitted A20 Amid plans to reopen, Stouffers faces huge damage suits B2 Yippie seized in dispute with po- lice officers B2 Carey revives plan to merge trial courts B3 Congregation faces loss of site where church stood B3 Health/Science Study says most U.S. teen-agers drink alcoholic beverages A16 Obituaries Peter Dominick, 2-term Senator from Colorado B5 Frederic O. Hess of Philadelphia, industrialist and inventor B5 Weekend Weekender Guide C1

title: Around the Nation; Carol Burnett and Enquirer Rest Cases in Her Libel Suit
description: Attorneys for Carol Burnett and The National Enquirer rested their cases today in the entertainer's $10 million libel suit against the tabloid.

title: LEONTYNE PRICE, SKIPPING OPERA THIS YEAR, MAKES ONLY NEW YORK APPEARANCE
description: And why is there no grand opera in your life this season, Miss Leontyne Price? ''Because I'm not in the mood,'' answered the great American soprano with laughing good humor. ''That's the luxury and the privilege of success -doing what you want to do.''

title: SENATORS TO SELECT U.S. ATTORNEYS
description: Attorney General William French Smith announced today the criteria for selecting United States Attorneys, acknowledging that political patronage would be a factor but emphasizing that merit was the most important qualification.

title: Baseball Cards To Buy or Swap
description: The baseball season may not open for a couple of weeks yet, but impatient fans can warm up with Willie Mays, Sal Maglie and Ed Kranepool this weekend, at the New York Superstar Baseball Card Show in the Armenian Church, 630 Second Avenue, between 34th and 35th Streets. The three-day show, opening today, will feature card flipping contests and the trading, buying and selling of baseball memorabilia in the church's grand ballroom.

title: Around the World
description: The People's Daily newspaper, echoing an accusation Monday by the Reagan Administration, said in a commentary today that the Soviet Union had aided the hijackers of a Pakistani jetliner and that it had sought to use the incident to ''blackmail'' Pakistan into recognizing the Soviet-backed regime in Afghanistan.

title: TOLERANCE ON MERGERS INDICATED
description: The Reagan Administration's newly designated Assistant Attorney General for antitrust told the Senate today that he would be unlikely to oppose mergers between companies in different industries unless it could be shown that such combinations would diminish competition for a single product.

title: CONCERT: BARBER'S 'KIERKEGAARD' OFFERED BY BROOKLYN ENSEMBLE
description: SHORTLY before Samuel Barber died this year at the age of 70, he was able to look back over his composing career and find little reason to feel sorry for himself. He had been one of music's golden boys from the start; famous artists hurried to perform his works with a promptness not often awarded to living composers. Some of his works, of course, fared better than others in this respect. Last night at Abraham Goodman House, for instance, a relative rarity, his ''The Prayers of Kierkegaard'' received what was described as the score's ''first performance in a major New York City concert hall.''

title: 18 NOW SEEKING POST
description: John J. Degnan, who resigned two weeks ago as State Attorney General, became the 18th formal candidate for Governor today.

title: Friday; TWO NEW OLD-MOVIE HOUSES
description: Rising like a phoenix from the site of a former pornographic movie theater, the Hollywood Twin Cinema, on Eighth Avenue at 47th Street, has been renovated by three movie buffs who hope to revive not only good old films but the street as well. The Twin Cinema is envisioned as a catalyst to bringing business and people back into the area. It opens today with two double features. At Cinema 1 are two musical revues, ''Hollywood Hotel'' (1937), with Dick Powell, Benny Goodman and the Lane Sisters, and ''Hollywood Canteen'' (1944), with Bette Davis, Jack Benny and Joan Crawford. At Cinema 2 the fare is ''Casablanca'' (1942), with Humphrey Bogart, Ingrid Bergman, Paul Henreid and Claude Rains, and ''Citizen Kane'' (1941), starring Orson Welles and Joseph Cotten. Admission is $3.50, Sunday through Thursday, and $4, Fridays and Saturdays; $2 for children. Information: 246-0717. JAPANESE ART MILLENNIUM

title: Belgian Royalty to Visit China
description: King Baudouin and Queen Fabiola of the Belgians will pay an official visit to China from May 25 to June 5, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: JAPAN HINTS AT ITS PLANS
description: The Japanese Government may have to use legal powers to force cutbacks in auto exports to the United States, a top Goverment official indicated today in testimony before a parliamentary committee.

title: THE DEMAND SIDE
description: Almost daily, the news media report the Administration's assault on social spending. Black-lung programs for miners, legal aid for the poor, school guards funded through the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, and the 60-cent fare in New York City are among public benefits likely to be condemned at the Federal chopping block.

title: Morgan Stanley Appoints Director
description: Edwin H. Yeo 3d, 46 years old, who resigned from the First National Bank of Chicago 15 months ago, reportedly because of personality clashes with other top executives, has been appointed a managing director of Morgan Stanley Inc., effective April 2. He will be concerned with the New York investment banking concern's fixed-income activities, particularly in such matters as government securities and money markets.

title: FOR THE BARTOK CENTENNIAL, ALL 6 QUARTETS IN ONE CONCERT SUNDAY
description: ''I'm not poking fun at you!'' says the traveler to the Hungarian peasant woman. ''I mean what I say! That's why I've made this long, long journey all the way from Budapest, specially to look for these very old songs that nobody remembers except here.''

title: LOUISE FLORIAN
description: Louise Florian, who managed the careers of Beverly Sills, Norman Treigle, Nell Rankin and other singers, died Wednesday at her home in Washington, Pa.

title: G.M., FORD UNIONS BAR PAY CUTS NOW
description: Representatives of General Motors and Ford auto workers voted today to resist any effort by the companies to press for wage cuts similar to those accepted by workers at the Chrysler Corporation.

title: WHITHER THE GUARDIAN ANGELS?
description: To the Editor:

title: S.&P. Cuts Rating Of 6 Savings Units
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it had downgraded its commercial-paper ratings for six large savings and loan associations because of their alleged "deteriorating financial condition."

title: WHITE HOUSE KILLS BUDGET LOBBY THAT REAGAN FRIENDS HAD SET UP
description: An ambitious fund-raising and lobbying drive organized by President Reagan's friends in support of his economic program was abruptly killed by the White House today after some corporations complained that they felt they had been dunned for contributions.

title: SUCCESSION DOCUMENT ACCLAIMED BY MORMON BRANCH
description: The president of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, a great-grandson of the Mormon prophet Joseph Smith Jr., said today that a recently discovered document confirmed ''the historical view long held'' by his Missouri-based church that Smith intended the presidency of the church he founded to be conveyed to his lineal descendants.

title: YONKERS REJECTS PLAN TO REDRESS SCHOOL BALANCE
description: The nine-member Board of Education voted unanimously tonight to ''remove from the table permanently'' a controversial proposal to redress the racial balance in this city's five high schools by redrawing school attendance lines.

title:
RED SMITH;
The Sport of Children
description: UNTIL a few years ago, appointment of state inspectors for Florida horse parks was strictly political. The recipients of this patronage fulfilled a single requirement: they voted right. Keen eyesight, good manners and Solomonic judgment were not deemed indispensable. They displayed a certain tolerance when bookmakers, pickpockets and mobsters sought admission, but they vigilantly enforced the state law against minors' entering a gambling joint.

title: Jesse R. Liscomb Is Dead at 72; Coached 3 Olympians in Track
description: Jesse R. Liscomb, a retired track and field coach and administrator who coached three Olympic gold medalists, died Wednesday at his home in the Bronx of a heart ailment.

title: BONN OFFICIALS PLEASED WITH U.S. DISAVOWAL OF PIPES
description: West German officials reacted with satisfaction today to the immediate disavowal by the White House and State Department of statements by a Reagan Administration official who questioned the ability of Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher to withstand Soviet pressure.

title: Concannon, Former Bear, Charged in Sale of Cocaine
description: Bond was reduced today from $500,000 to $50,000 for Jack Concannon, the former Chicago Bears quarterback charged with selling 2.2 pounds of cocaine to an undercover law-enforcement agent.

title: G.O.P. SOLIDARITY UPHOLDS CUTS IN THE FOOD STAMP BUDGET
description: The hour was late and the senators were tired. Eye-watering smoke and ear-numbing rhetoric filled the room, and many of the lawmakers were shedding their jackets for comfort and chewing apples for sustenance as the last vote of a long day in the Senate Budget Committee approached last night.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON THE BIG BOARD UP 4 MILLION SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 4 million shares, in the month ended March 13, to 74.1 million. The short interest for March 14, 1980, totaled 49.2 million shares.

title: Advertising; Universal Face of Hunger
description: SOMEWHERE in this world -probably in Pakistan and surely starving - is a young child who is about to become an American media star. Around a photograph taken recently of his tear-stained visage, an Advertising Council volunteer ad agency has created a print advertising campaign that will make the face of this unknown and unidentified child - described as ''the universal face of hunger'' - one of the best-known faces in the country.

title: PIPE ORGAN: HEINZ WUNDERLICH AT TULLY
description: HEINZ WUNDERLICH, the German organist, appeared at Alice Tully Hall late Wednesday afternoon to give the second in the 1981 series of ''Interlude'' organ recitals presented by Lincoln Center. His program consisted of Buxtehude's Prelude and Fugue in F sharp, Bach's Prelude and Fugue in D and Trio Sonata No. 3 in D minor and Reubke's Sonata on the 94th Psalm.

title: Consumer Interest and Banking Interests
description: It seems too good to be true. By parking your cash in a ''money market'' mutual fund, you can earn 16 percent interest and still have instant access to your nest egg. But it is true, and both banks and savings and loans are worried that the money market funds are draining enormous sums from their deposits. To counter the threat, they are trying to chop the funds down to size by pressing for changes in Federal and state regulations.

title: REAGAN SEEKING MORE 'FLEXIBILITY' TO SET FOREIGN POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration today unveiled a set of legislative proposals designed to provide greater ''flexibility'' in the conduct of foreign policy, including the creation of a $350 million fund to aid foreign buyers of American arms.

title: by Chris Chase; Melvyn Douglas doesn't talk of quitting now.
description: WORKMEN are installing new windows in the bedrooms, and Melvyn Douglas is closing doors against the draft blowing through the big old apartment on Riverside Drive. The probabililty is that nobody from Architectural Digest will come begging to photograph this living room, with its faded Oriental rugs and well-worn furniture. It has the look of a place where people actually sit and read the papers and listen to Stravinsky on the record player and argue with friends.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE EXCEEDS REAGAN BID IN REDUCING BUDGET
description: The Republican-dominated Senate Budget Committee today unanimously adopted a package of budget cuts totaling $36.4 billion for the coming fiscal year, $2.3 billion more than recommended by President Reagan.

title: MORE VIOLENCE FEARED IN PHILADELPHIA CRIME FAMILY
description: Both of Philip Charles Testa's families, his kin as well as those reputed to have been linked to him in a brief reign marked by bloody violence, are expected to attend the last rites for the slain crime chieftain tomorrow.

title: How Free Is Free Enterprise?
description: Steel makers, like leaders of the automobile industry, complain about imports. The free world's steel-producing capacity, says Thomas C. Graham, president of Jones & Laughlin, is now about 20 percent above need.

title: THAT OLD ROCKER: BO DIDDLEY, ROLLS ON
description: Is rock-and-roll a young man's game? Mick Jagger of the Rolling Stones once remarked that he would probably feel silly prancing around a stage and singing ''(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction'' at the age of 40, and as rock stars grow older, they often attempt to make a transition into record or film production or other, more settled, ''adult'' occupations. But for many of rock-and-roll's black originators, the music was never strictly a youth phenomenon. ''I never could dig singing that teen-age stuff like 'Lollipop, Lollipop,' man,'' says the first-generation rocker Bo Diddley. ''I just tick with my good old rhythm and blues.''

title: THIS TIME, NICOL WILLIAMSON FEELS CLOSER TO ROLE
description: ''It's been a tiring and hazardous few weeks,'' Nicol Williamson said, tossing his lanky 6 foot 2 inch frame onto a makeshift plywood couch in the men's communal dressing room at the Roundabout Theater the other day. Mr. Williamson opened there recently as the star of John Osborne's ''Inadmissible Evidence'' and has been working at a marathon pace ever since, for although the play has a cast of eight, it is virtually a three-hour monologue for the Scottish actor.

title: JESUIT PRIEST CHARGED WITH PLOTTING TO OUST REGIME IN PHILIPPINES
description: The Rev. Jose Blanco, a militant Jesuit, has been charged with seeking to destabilize the regime of President Ferdinand E. Marcos by means of violent acts, including a series of bombings last year.

title: Christie's Names Officer
description: Christie's International Inc., the New York auction house and subsidiary of Christie International Ltd. of Britain, has named Georges de Montebello, 46, as secretary and chief operating officer, effective April 1. As chief operating officer, he will succeed G. Raymond Perman, 40, a longtime Christie's official who came to the United States in 1977 with the opening of its first American salesroom and who will return to the parent company.

title: Founder of L'Officiel Disputes Plan to Republish
description: In quick response to the Ideal Publishing's announcement that it plans to bring out the high-fashion magazine L'Officiel in September, Evan Katz, who founded the magazine four years ago and suspended publication in September, said that he never went bankrupt and still had rights to the name. He says he is trying to sell the name and that Ideal never had any contact with him or with the French company that licenses the use of the name in this country.

title: Around the World; Colonel Shot in Basque City, Apparently by Separatists
description: An army colonel was shot and gravely wounded as he was leaving church in the Basque city of Bilbao today.

title: STAGE: ALBEE'S ADAPTATION OF 'LOLITA' OPENS
description: AFTER weeks of delays, Edward Albee's ''Lolita'' finally opened at the Brooks Atkinson last night, and all one can do is wonder why it did. This show is the kind of embarrassment that audiences do not quickly forget or forgive. It's not just that ''Lolita'' is incompetent or boring or that it lays waste to a masterpiece of modern literature: those are pardonable sins that have been known to occur in Broadway theaters. What sets ''Lolita'' apart from ordinary failures is its abject mean-spiritedness. For all this play's babbling about love, it is rank with indiscriminate - and decidely unearned - hate.

title: NEWSPAPER IN PEKING LOWERS MAO'S PEDISTAL A BIT
description: Mao Zedong was ''a great Marxist'' but only one of dozens of outstanding leaders the Chinese people should be proud of, The People's Daily, the official Communist Party newspaper, declared today.

title: German Writing Is Focus Of Conference Next Month
description: European and American authors and editors will participate in a series of panels on literature during German Book Week in Deutches Haus at New York University beginning April 2. At the same time, an exhibition of 1,000 books will be on display representing a crosssection of works published in Austria, West Germany and Switzerland. The exhibition will be open in the Deutsches Haus at 42 Washington Mews from noon till 8 P.M. through April 12.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Petrofina Inc. intends to sell its Port Arthur, Tex., refinery and terminal facilities to American International Petroleum Corporation for an undisclosed price.

title: ART: LEON POLK SMITH, UPTOWN AND DOWNTOWN
description: ONE of the best painters around, though not one of the most famous, is Leon Polk Smith, whose recent work can be seen at both branches of the Washburn Gallery (uptown at 42 East 57th Street, downtown at 113 Greene Street). Now nearing his 75th birthday, Mr. Smith was born a Cherokee in territory that later became Oklahoma. Like many another aspirant painter in New York in the 1930's, he was changed forever by the sight of the A.E. Gallatin collection when it went on public view. Above all, he was changed by the Gallatin Mondrians. More than 30 years later he said to Robert Hughes that he hadn't seen a painting since Mondrian that gave him ''one single idea about form, composition, anything.''

title: Vatican's Lay Workers Threaten To Hold Protest March Over Pay
description: The Vatican's lay employees threatened today to hold an ''orderly, silent and without-signs'' protest march within the Vatican early next month if salary increases and other demands are not met.

title: INVENTOR-INDUSTRIALIST IN TECHNOLOGY OF HEAT
description: Frederic O. Hess, an inventor and industrialist who revolutionized the industrial heating industry by his advocacy of ''heat technology,'' died Tuesday in Tucson, Ariz. Mr. Hess, former board chairman of the Selas Corporation of America, lived in Philadelphia. He was 79 years old.

title: Fresh Rebate Drive Is Started by G.M.
description: In an attempt to keep a rebate-inspired sales surge alive, the General Motors Corporation began a two-week incentive program today, offering $500 to $700 rebates on certain sporty and midsized models.

title: TAMMANY LEADER SAYS SHE PLANS TO RESIGN
description: Miriam Bockman, the first woman and first member of the ''reform'' faction to be a Democratic county leader in New York City, announced last night that she would resign from the Tammany leadership post she has held for nearly four years.

title: The Evening Hours; CANARSIE WOMAN IS THE STAR
description: THE Bruno Walter Theater of the Lincoln Center Library for the Performing Arts was awash with celebrities the other night for the premiere of the documentary film of pre-Nazi Poland, ''Image Before My Eyes,'' and people craned their necks to see the likes of Joseph Papp, Molly Picon and Irving Howe milling about.

title: DOW OFF 7.48 AS VOLUME CLIMBS
description: Energy, computer and transportation stocks showed weakness yesterday, while the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 7.48 points, to 986.58. Takeover conjecture provided gains in some issues.

title: TWO B'S GET AN A RATING FROM RANGERS
description: The Rangers, in contemplation of the modest revival that is their two-game winning spurt, are giving most of the credit to the players they call Bubba and Bakes.

title: DEFENSE INDUSTRY GEARING UP
description: The Rockwell International Corporation is building a $20 million plant in El Segundo, Calif., and has leased 300 acres in Palmdale, Calif., for more facilities, all in the hope that its ill-fated B-1 bomber program may be revived under the Reagan Administration.

title: GROTON SHIPYARD WORKERS SKEPTICAL ABOUT LAYOFFS
description: The Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics, which says it builds submarines better than anyone else, shows its pride by handing out felt-tipped pens at launchings inscribed, ''We build the best,'' with the ''e'' in ''the'' and the ''b'' in ''best'' in heavy letters forming the shipyard's initials.

title: Fish and Wildlife Appointment
description: Bob Jantzen of Scottsdale, director of the Arizona Game and Fish Department, was appointed director of the Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service today, the office of Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, announced. The service operates a network of refuges, game ranges and wildlife programs.

title: Purim Tour in Brooklyn
description: The festivities of the Jewish holiday of Purim can be enjoyed firsthand today with a tour of the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, sponsored by the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue.

title: OLD MEMORIES ARE RELIVED AT POSTCARD AND POSTER SHOW
description: Postcard collecting - a nostalgia pastime that has become a consuming passion for thousands of Americans -is more popular today than when picture postcards first caught on at the turn of the century. Just how intense postcard enthusiasm is will be seen this weekend when 19 American and European card dealers gather for the New York Poster and Postcard Show at the New York Sheraton, Seventh Avenue at 56th Street. The event, at which there also will be 61 poster dealers, is open tomorrow and Sunday from noon to 7 P.M. Admission is $4.

title: A WALL-TO-WALL BASH FOR BACH'S 296TH BIRTHDAY
description: Tomorrow will be Johann Sebastian Bach's 296th birthday, and his friends on the Upper West Side plan to celebrate with abandon. From 11 A.M. to 11 P.M., the music of Bach and of his sons - and even of the notorious P.D.Q. -will resound through the Symphony Space on Broadway at 95th Street, played by distinguished soloists, the American Symphony Orchestra and anybody else at all who cares to join in. And it's all free.

title: News Analysis
description: During the Presidential campaign, Ronald Reagan often took the Carter Administration to task for vacillation and confusion in its foreign policy statements, and last month his counselor, Edwin Meese 3d, assured a national television audience that, by contrast, the Reagan Administration ''will speak with one voice.''

title: Shutt, Clackson Suspended For Abuse of Officials
description: Steve Shutt, a wing for the Montreal Canadiens, has been suspended for three games, and Kim Clackson, a defenseman for the Quebec Nordiques, has been suspended for two games for physically abusing officials in separate incidents, the National Hockey League said today.

title: YIPPIE IS SEIZED AFTER A DISPUTE NEAR BOMB SITE
description: A member of the Youth International Party was arrested yesterday outside the party's Greenwich Village offices, where two police officers were injured when a bomb exploded Tuesday.

title: The Region; Williams Criticizes Abscam Prosecutor
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., whose trial in the Government's Abscam investigation of official corruption is scheduled to begin in two weeks, has charged in United States District Court in Brooklyn that the chief prosecutor, Thomas P. Puccio, should be disqualified from the case.

title: McLaughlin to Capital
description: John P. McLaughlin, 48, former partner and president of Keenan & McLaughlin, has turned up in Washington, D.C., as executive vice president, director of creative services of Abramson/Himelfarb. He is part of the new administration.

title: RISE IN TEEN-AGE DRINKING FOUND
description: Most American teenagers drink alcoholic beverages, and one-third of the nation's high school students are ''problem drinkers,'' a research team reported today.

title: Country Gazette Concert
description: Bluegrass tunes, new and old, will be played by the Country Gazette tonight at 8 in the Loeb Student Center of New York University, 566 La Guardia Place.

title: The City
description: New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs charged the Chase Manhattan Bank with ''repeated, multiple and persistent'' violations of the city's Consumer Protection Law by offering depositors free watches that were not free.

title: Police Officer Is Accused Of Murdering a Sergeant
description: A New York City police officer charged with the second-degree murder of a fellow policeman was arraigned today and ordered held without bail.

title: 'Fantasia' at the Ziegfeld
description: ''Fantasia,'' the animated film classic by Walt Disney, will be shown through April 13 at the Ziegfield Theater, 141 West 54th Street.

title: Reichmanns Raise Holding in Trustco
description: The Reich@mann family of Toronto, which owns Canada's largest real estate development company and controls the world's largest newsprint producer, has emerged as the largest single shareholder in Royal Trustco Ltd., the parent of Canada's largest trust company group.

title: STUDENTS LIKE COED DORMS DESPITE PROBLEMS
description: ''The most difficult aspect of coeducational living, at least for me, was finding how hard it was for men to accept me as an authority figure,'' said Elizabeth Conn, a Barnard student who is assistant head of residence in one of the college's coed student dormitories.

title: CAREY REVIVES PLAN TO MERGE 7 TRIAL COURTS
description: Governor Carey, resurrecting a proposal he has made every year since 1976, called yesterday for a constitutional amendment to merge the state's seven trial courts into a single, statewide court with appointed judges.

title: Orioles Leave Field and Forfeit
description: Manager Earl Weaver pulled his Baltimore Orioles off the field today in the seventh inning of an exhibition game with the Kansas City Royals because of a lineup squabble. Kansas City was awarded the game on a forfeit, making the score 9-0.

title: A Record $3.7 Billion Flows Into Money Funds
