description: A record $3.7 billion in new cash flowed into the nation's money market funds in the most recent week, ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Around the World; Zimbabwe Bids U.S. Rebuff Anti-Marxist Angola Rebels
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe called on the United States today to withhold any military backing for anti-Marxist rebels in Angola and accused Western nations of supporting South African ''aggression.''

title: Eastern to Revive $99 Fare to Miami
description: Eastern Airlines, responding to the latest round of fare-cutting among the nation's air carriers, said it would reinstitute its January-level, $99 one-way unrestricted coach fare between Miami and New York for certain weekday flights.

title: MEXICO JAILS AMERICAN ON CHARGE HE IMPORTED U.S. CHEMICAL WASTES
description: The Mexican authorities have jailed a 75-year-old American and seized a shipment of PCB's and other hazardous chemical wastes from the United States that they say he imported illegally for disposal in Mexico.

title: PLAGUED BY CORRUPTION, PROMOTER SAYS OF BOXING
description: Harold J. Smith, who until he disappeared in January was the most powerful promoter in boxing, said this morning that he had tapes and documents ''that could put a lot of boxing people in jail.''

title: A PHYSICAL AND ACOUSTIC FACELIFT WAITS IN THE BEAUMONT'S WINGS
description: The Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center may soon be facing the kind of physical and acoustic renovation that Avery Fisher Hall underwent in 1976 and that is scheduled for the New York State Theater in the near future. Plans for the Beaumont are not as drastic as those that involved Avery Fisher Hall, which was gutted and completely made over. But a proscenium theater is being planned for the Vivian Beaumont, as well as a completely different seating arrangement. The cost is estimated at between $4 million and $5 million.

title: Getty Acquisition Rejected by Canada
description: The Canadian Government has refused to approve the Getty Oil Company's acquisition of an 86 percent stake in Canadian Reserve Oil and Gas Ltd., touching off speculation that Getty may be forced to sell its interest in the company.

title: Around the World; State Dept. Cites 'Omission' In South Africans' Entry
description: Four South African military officers were granted permission to enter the United States this month because of an ''inadvertent omission'' in the South African Government's visa applications, the State Department said today.

title: St. Joe Suit Moved
description: The scene of legal arguments in the takeover dispute between St. Joe Minerals Corporation and Joseph E. Seagram & Sons was shifted yesterday from a Federal court in Kansas City to the court of Judge Milton Pollack, of the Southern District of New York. In the suit filed last Monday, St. Joe charged that Seagram had made ''false and misleading'' disclosures in its March 11 offer to pay $45 a share in a bid to gain control of St. Joe. Seagram, which denied the charges, asked that the case be moved.

title: 1980 TRADE SURPLUSES REPORTED
description: The nation's current-account surplus narrowed in the fourth quarter of 1980 to $687 million from $4.49 billion in the previous three months, the Commerce Department said today, For all of 1980, the the surplus totaled $118 million, the first time since 1976 that this broad measure of foreign transactions was not in deficit.

title: Brooklyn College Aims for Division I
description: In a surprising disclosure, Joe Margolis, athletic director at Brooklyn College, said yesterday that his college was making plans to change its National Collegiate Athletic Association status from Division III to Division I.

title: First Pennsylvania To Revamp Board
description: The First Pennsylvania Corporation, parent of the First Pennsylvania Bank, has agreed that by the end of 1983 a majority of its directors would be new members who were not on the board when the bank nearly collapsed last spring.

title: David C. Anderson Is Appointed To Editorial Board of The Times
description: David C. Anderson, editor and president of Criminal Justice Publications, has been appointed to the editorial board of The New York Times.

title: PROFIT TAKING ENDS 3-DAY RALLY
description: A three-day rally in the credit markets came to an end yesterday as dealers and investors moved to convert some of their large paper profits into cash.

title: The Region; State Urged to Run Lilco Atomic Plant
description: Four Democratic Assemblymen on Long Island called for the state to take over the Shoreham nuclear plant being built by the Long Island Lighting Company. At a news conference outside the plant, they urged that it be acquired by the Power Authority of the State of New York.

title: 7 TRADERS SUSPENDED BY C.B.O.E.
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange has declared seven individuals ineligible for trading as a result of losses suffered after the Standard Oil Company of California surprised the financial community by offering $62 a share for the stock of the Kennecott Corporation.

title: 10 Rule Changes for N.F.L.
description: The National Football League owners passed 10 rule changes at a session of their annual meeting today. The most important changes prohibit the use of foreign substances by players and set a new definition of a legal catch.

title: BBC Films Series at the Modern Museum; BBC Films Retrospective At Museum This Weekend
description: A retrospective of 12 films produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation over the last 20 years is being shown this weekend at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. Included are four early films by the director Ken Russell.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Your editorial of March 13 misconceives the nature of the Social Security system. You hold that Social Security benefits (1) involve transfers from the working population to retirees and (2) therefore belong to the taxpayer, making benefits a gift.

title: FREDERICK G. SIMMON
description: Frederick G. Simmon, co-founder of Simmon Brothers Inc., manufacturers of Omega photographic enlargers, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Monsey Park, L.I. He was 76 years old.

title: MORE AND MORE, LAW FIRMS TURN TO PUBLIC RELATIONS CONCERNS FOR THEIR
description: ADVICE By LESLIE BENNETTS

title: HAIG SAYS U.S. SEEKS CONSENSUS STRATEGY IN THE MIDDLE EAST
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the Reagan Administration would try to develop a strategic ''consensus'' to counter the Soviet Union in an area stretching from Pakistan to Egypt and including such disparate nations as Turkey, Israel and Saudi Arabia.

title: KOCH NOW SAYS M.T.A. WILL GET MORE CITY FUNDS
description: Mayor Koch agreed today to a substantial increase in New York City's contribution to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's operating costs over the next five years. His consent would appear to remove a major obstacle to agreement on a broader program to rebuild the transit system.

title: White House to Dismiss the Staff Of Environmental Quality Council
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would seek to dismiss the 45-member professional staff of the Council on Environmental Quality.

title: CREDIT-CARD DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard REFLEX. By Dick Francis. 295 pages. Put- nam. $11.95. DEATH IN A TENURED POSITION. By Amanda Cross. 156 pages. Dutton. $10.50.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., parent of Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth fiscal quarter rose 16.9 percent on a sales increase of 9.4 percent.

title: The Brass Gathers to Make and Talk Music; The Brass Is Gathering To Make and Talk Music
description: Dizzy Gillespie, Roy Eldridge, Doc Cheatum and Phil Farkas are among the brass players of many musical persuasions who will gather this weekend for the ninth New York Brass Conference at the Roosevelt Hotel, Madison Avenue and 45th Street. Also appearing will be professional studio and band musicans from the metropolitan area and across the country, as well as amateur instrumentalists.

title: BIG BROKERS BORROWING AT BELOW NORMAL RATES
description: Several leading New York banks have quietly been lending at preferred rates to about a dozen securities firms to finance the margin accounts of their customers, according to commercial and investment bankers.

title: ART: MODERN SHOWS OFF ACQUISITIONS OF DRAWINGS
description: THE periodic exhibitions devoted to ''Recent Acquisitions'' at the Museum of Modern Art can usually be counted on to offer us precisely that mixture of the expected and the unexpected that we are not likely to find in shows more systematically organized around a single style, period or artistic career. The pleasures to be derived from these ''Acquisitions'' shows are frankly the pleasures of a miscellany. On many later occasions, we may be sure, these newly acquired objects will be assigned to their appropriate historical or artistic slots and thus made to serve more serious, or at least more systematic, purposes. But for their official debut as part of the museum's permanent collection, these works of art are allowed to shine for themselves, and to keep some surprising company.

title: IRAN AIDE DEFENDS ACTION ON BANI-SADR
description: Iran's Prosecutor General, Ayatollah Moussavi Ardabeli, indicating that a criminal investigation of President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr would continue, explained his course of action today by suggesting that no one, not even Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, was above the law.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 17.00-17.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Citicorp Begins Restructuring In Senior Management Shifts
description: In what may be the first of several moves in lining up the succession to Citicorp's top management, George J. Vojta, 45, has been named deputy to G.A. Costanzo, the 64-year-old vice chairman of the giant bank holding company who is scheduled to retire in November.

title: ART: MARISOL'S FRIENDS, IN WIT AND WOOD, COME TO LIVE AT THE JANIS
description: GALLERY By GRACE GLUECK

title: Resch Battles Emotions; Resch Battling His Emotions
description: One of the most emotional events in sports occurs when a team trades a popular player and then has to play against him shortly afterward. Such a moment may occur tomorrow night when the Islanders face the Colorado Rockies and Glenn (Chico) Resch, the Islander goalie for seven years until he was traded last week.

title: Market Place; The Popularity Of Orion Capital
description: THE Orion Capital Corporation, which emerged from the ashes of the scandal-ridden Equity Funding Company to become a highly profitable multiline insurance company, is one of the hottest acquisition candidates around.

title: Economic Scene; Political Costs Of Reagan Cuts
description: ACCORDING to the Gallup Poll, public approval of President Reagan's handling of his job after eight weeks in office has dropped to 59 percent - a lower score than any newly elected President has received in the past 28 years. Disapproval of the Reagan Presidency, the poll found, has climbed rapidly, from 13 percent at the end of January to 24 percent last week.

title: Where to Find Offbeat Operas
description: Following is a guide to some of the rarely produced operas being performed around the city this weekend. Four offbeat works are being offered by the City Opera at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center, Broadway and 65th Street.

title: TWO HOMELESS PERSONS ADRIFT IN GRAND CENTRAL
description: Madeline is a slender woman who seems larger because of the three sweaters and a layer of plastic sheeting she wears under her coat to ward off the cold. The other night, as the stream of suburbanites hurrying for their trains was slowing to a trickle, she stopped near the entrance to Track 23 and set down the shopping bag that contained all of her possessions, odd bits of paper and clothing.

title: Around the Nation; Suspect Pleads Not Guilty In Fatal Fire in Las Vegas
description: Philip Bruce Cline pleaded not guilty today to eight charges of murder and one of arson stemming from the fire at the Las Vegas Hilton Hotel last month. A judge ordered him to stand trial July 6.

title: Barclays American Corp.  Changes Ad Agencies
description: Barclays American Corporation, which is a subsidiary of Barclays Bank in London and operates in 36 of the United States, has indeed moved its advertising from McCann-Erickson, Atlanta, to Henderson Advertising, Greenville, N.C. The billings for the commercial and consumer divisions are $3 million.

title: Notes on People; Barry Rosen Returning to Columbia to Write on Iran
description: Barry Rosen, who spent 444 days in captivity in Iran, returned to Columbia University yesterday to resume his doctoral studies as the first recipient of a presidential fellowship.

title: No Headline
description: o the Editor:

title: BARBARA COOK, THE 50'S AND GALA ON CHANNEL 13
description: AS public television continues its campaign for more moneycontributing subscribers, the schedule is heavy on razzle-dazzle anthologies, crammed with stars of past and present. The best moments, however, are provided by a relatively modest production out of KCET-TV, the Los Angeles station run by Hartford Gunn. ''An Evening With Barbara Cook'' can be seen on Channel 13 tonight at 10:45.

title: MUSIC: GUARNERIS PLAY MOZART
description: THE Guarneri String Quartet brought two kinds of novelty to its concert at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday evening - first, some very familiar music in an unusual setting and then some music we don't hear very much at all.

title: It's Last Shot That Counts
description: Eleven of the 40 games played in the N.C.A.A tournament through last night were decided in the last five seconds when a shot either broke a tie or brought a team from 1 point down to a 1-point triumph.

title: Cuba Assails Envoy's Expulsion
description: The Cuban Government said last night that Portugal was not justified in ordering the Cuban Ambassdor in Lisbon, Manuel Estevez Perez, out of the country last Wednesday. The expulsion came amid a growing dispute over Cuba's accusation that a Portuguese charge d'affaires here, Francisco de Sales Mascarenhas, had been in touch with the Central Intelligence Agency and had helped plan last month's seizure of the Ecuadorean Embassy in Havana.

title: News Summary; NEWS SUMMARY; SATURDAY, MARCH 21, 1981
description: International A nationwide strike alert in Poland was ordered by the Solidarity union in response to a police attack on union activists in Bydgoszcz, in north-central Poland. Meanwhile two-hour strikes were held in four northern industrial regions. Solidarity announced suspension of all talks with Government officials and told all union chapters, representing 10 million workers, to be ready to strike by Monday. (Page 1, Column 6.) Food assistance to Mozambique was suspended by the Administration in retaliation for the expulsion of United States Embassy personnel there two weeks ago on charges that they were working for the Central Intelligence Agency. It emphasized the Administration's determination to be firm with Cuba and the countries that solicit its assistance. The State Department said the expulsion was instigated by Cuban intelligence agents. (1:5-6.)

title: Inmate Kills Himself In a Cell at Rikers
description: A man who murdered his mother in 1972 and stabbed his grandmother last July committed suicide in a Rikers Island prison cell, the police said.

title: ...AND IN VIETNAM
description: Following is an excerpt from the forthcoming book ''Everything We Had: An Oral History of the Vietnam War as Told by Thirty-Three American Soldiers Who Fought It,'' edited by Al Santoli, who served with the 25th Infantry Division in Vietnam in 1968-69. Bruce Lawlor was a Central Intelligence Agency officer in Vietnam from November 1971 to December 1973.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48. 1. ''I wouldn't call it necessarily a domino theory. I would call it a priority target list - a hit list, if you will - for the ultimate takeover of Central America.'' Who made this statement and to what does it refer?

title: Reagan Asks New Curb On Funds for Abortions
description: The Reagan Administration wants a new curb on Federal spending for abortions obtained by poor women on Medicaid and military personnel and their dependents, Administration officials said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: Two-Way Protest By ANATOLE BROYARD TAR BABY. By Toni Morrison. 306 pages. Knopf. $11.95.

title: L.S.U., WICHITA WIN IN MIDWEST
description: Louisiana State, led by its burly front line of Greg Cook, Durand Macklin and Leonard Mitchell, romped to victory tonight over Arkansas and will meet Wichita State, a 1-point winner over Kansas, in Sunday's Midwest Regional final at the Superdome.

title: PRESIDENT RESIGNS AT O.P.M. LEASING
description: Mordecai Weissman has resigned as president and half-owner of O.P.M. Leasing Services, which has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and is being investigated for allegedly illegal computer leasing practices involving millions of dollars.

title: N.F.L. Loses Plea on Shift
description: An appeals court turned down today a bid by the National Football League to have the Raiders-N.F.L. antitrust suit tried outside Los Angeles.

title: JURY FINDS FOR KUSH IN SUIT BY EX-PLAYER
description: A jury of six women and two men cleared Frank Kush, the former Arizona State University football coach, of two charges in a $2.2 million damage suit late this afternoon. Additional questions in the civil suit, filed by a former Arizona State punter against the coach and others from the athletic program, remained to be litigated.

title: THE ECONOMIST ACTS TO EXPAND IN U.S.
description: In common with the Rolls-Royce, the monarchy and fine highland malt whisky, The Economist magazine is one of those British symbols of excellence in its field that calls to mind the days when Great Britain really was great.

title: WAR'S EFFECTS
description: More than 100 physicians from the United States, the Soviet Union and other nations gathered today at a conference center in the placid Virginia countryside to pursue what most of them feel is their ultimate healing duty - the prevention of nuclear war, the ultimate medical emergency.

title: ISRAEL'S LABOR PARTY LEADER CONFIRMS PARLEY WITH ARABS
description: Shimon Peres, the Labor Party's candidate for Prime Minister, confirmed today that he met this week with Arab leaders, but would not say with whom. He said he had obtained express approval from Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

title: IRVING JAFFEE, 74, SPEED SKATER, DIES
description: Irving Jaffee, who grew up in the Bronx and went on to win speed skating races in the Winter Olympic Games of 1928 and 1932, died yesterday in a San Diego hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: U.S. AGENCY DISTRIBUTES PAMPHLETS BY MILLIONS
description: colored building on the windswept prairie near the Pueblo Memorial Airport is the center of a mail-order business that millions of Americans write to every year. They write in response to advertisements on late-night television, on afternoon talk shows and in family magazines.

title: Oyster and Clam Areas Closed
description: The health authorities in Maryland today closed more than 2,000 acres of oyster beds and clam bars on the Choptank River after a blocked sewer line spewed raw waste into a creek that feeds the river.

title: EAGLES OUSTED, 42-41
description: Only 24 hours before, the Hawks from St. Joseph's University in Philadelphia were walking around in the cold, knocking on the doors outside Assembly Hall here, trying to find a way inside for their practice.

title: RECITAL: HAKAN HAGEGARD
description: If Hakan Hagegard's recital at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday night was typical of his performances, he must be one of the world's finest male lieder singers at the moment. Appearing with Thomas Schuback, a superior accompanist, the 35-year-old Swedish baritone offered firstclass interpretations of a fascinating assemblage of 19th-and 20thcentury songs by Schubert, Brahms, Ravel, Wilhelm Stenhamer, Ture Rangstroem and Frank Martin.

title: Stocks Move Higher; Dow Index Up 6.22
description: With demand appearing for precious-metals stocks, the market moved higher yesterday to finish an erratic week on a note of optimism. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.22 points, to 992.80. It had closed above 1,000 on Monday, but promptly sank 10 points Tuesday, then bobbed up and down the rest of the week.

title: ONTARIO VOTERS GIVE VICTORY TO PREMIER
description: Rejecting the criticisms and warnings of two opposition political parties, the voters of Canada's most populous province have re-elected the conservative government of Premier William Davis, giving him a strong mandate to confront persistent problems.

title: Western Sixes Dominate
description: All four Eastern hockey teams lost to their Western opponents in National Collegiate Division I quarterfinal playoff games last night. Providence College, the Eastern College Athletic Conference playoff champion, fell behind Michigan Tech in the first minute of play and lost, 7-3, at Providence's Schneider Arena.

title: NETS DEFEAT HAWKS AS ROBINSON GETS 29
description: With Larry Brown, who will take over as New Jersey's coach after the season, watching from the stands amid a crowd of 8,415 in Rutgers Athletic Center tonight, the Nets never trailed and defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 108-96.

title: White House to Dismiss the Staff Of Environmental Quality Council
description: The Reagan Administration said Thursday that it would seek to dismiss the 45-member professional staff of the Council on Environmental Quality.

title: ELECTRONIC CONCERN IN PROFIT DROP
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation, a major manufacturer of semiconductor components, reported yesterday that earnings in its third fiscal quarter plunged 41.1 percent, while sales increased 7.3 percent.

title: MOVE TO LIMIT RISE IN FARES IMPERILED BY FIGHT ON OIL TAX
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority may have to increase New York City's bus and subway fares more than it had expected because of the refusal of two oil companies to pay the state's gross-receipts tax, state officials said today.

title: SCATTERED STRIKES IN POLAND PROTEST ATTACK ON UNIONISTS
description: Two-hour strikes broke out in at least four northern cities today, and the Solidarity union declared a nationwide strike alert in an angry response to last night's police attack on union activists in Bydgoszcz.

title: Head of Morgan Library
description: The appointment of Haliburton Fales 2d as president of the Morgan Library has been announced by the trustees of the library. For the first time in its history the library has a president who is not a member of the Morgan family.

title: BONN DISCLOSES PRISONER TRADE WITH EAST BERLIN
description: West Germany announced today that it had exchanged a group of prisoners with East Germany. Sources close to the Government said the exchange took place yesterday. A spokesman, Kurt Becker, said it was done ''for humanitarian reasons,'' but he did not elaborate nor say how many were involved.

title: Khomeini Seems to Approve Investigation of Bani-Sadr
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini appeared to give his tacit approval of a criminal investigation of President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr on charges of inciting supporters to violence in a speech March 5 at Teheran University. The Ayatollah said today that ''in Islam everyone, whether he be the Prophet or an ordinary individual, is equal under the law.'' ----

title: TUITION TAX CREDITS' ECONOMIC PROMISE
description: To the Editor:

title: YOU'RE NOT ENTITLED
description: To the Editor:

title: Jaeckel, 70-139, Takes 1-Stroke Lead; Watson, 80-152, Misses Cut
description: The answer to this golf tournament is still blowing in the wind. ''I feel like I've been in a prize fight,'' said Barry Jaeckel today after struggling to a one-shot lead in the second round of the Tournament Players Championship with a 70-139.

title: G.O.P.'S NEW STATE CHIEF
description: In 1973, Nelson A. Rockefeller, then the Governor of New York and all-powerful party leader, decided that the Republicans should run Robert F. Wagner for Mayor. George Clark remembers it well.

title: Mrs. Reagan Alters a White House Tradition
description: Ever since she began living at the White House, Nancy Reagan has been changing the old order of things, and yesterday it was becoming clear that she's even revising the tradition of the annual East Egg Roll.

title: Kansas State Leader At His Best in Clutch
description: Rolando Blackman is not among the leading scorers in college basketball this season. In 11 of the last 13 games, he has not even been Kansas State's top scorer.

title: 5 Arrested in Bronx On Fencing Charges
description: Five persons were arrested on charges of operating what was described as a major stolen-goods fencing operation in the Bronx that dealt in cameras, radios, jewelry and guns, the police reported.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $2.1 BILLION
description: The basic measure of the nation's money supply rose $2.1 billion in the week ended March 11 and economists said the increase might bring to a halt the recent swift decline in interest rates.

title: NEW YORK CITY FIREMAN HELD AS DRUG RING LEADER
description: A New York City fireman who the police said was the head of a ring that supplied $500,000 worth of cocaine a month to the Staten Island area was arraigned yesterday on charges of selling the drug to an undercover policeman.

title: A Well-Known 'Juliet' Leaves the Royal Ballet
description: When the Royal Ballet opens its American tour June 15 at the Metropolitan Opera House, it will do so without one of its longtime stars, Lynn Seymour. She has resigned to form her own rock band, with which she plans to perform.

title: ST. JOE'S ATTRACTIVE DIVERSITY
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation, flush with record profits and the prospect of even higher earnings after a decade of diversifying into natural resource properties, is disconcerted to find itself a takeover target, but its management says it is determined to remain an independent company.

title: FALSE SIGNAL IS FOCUS OF SPACE CENTER INVESTIGATION
description: Investigators of the fatal accident at the space shuttle's launching pad at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida met yesterday with one overriding question in mind: Why was a ''clear for return to normal work'' signal given while a working compartment inside the spacecraft was still purged of all oxygen.

title: GOLD UP $30 ON CONCERN OVER POLAND
description: Fueled by concerns over the unrest in Poland, the gold market erupted in a spurt of heavy buying yesterday, sending the price of gold soaring by $30 an ounce in New York trading.

title: Chrysler Decreases Its Rebate Program
description: The Chrysler Corporation today announced a scaled-down rebate program to replace the rebates that end this week. The General Motors Corporation extended its rebate program yesterday to increase auto sales.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TREASURE CHEST

title: Australia Airbus Order
description: Trans Australia Airlines has converted one of its three options on the A300-b4-100s European Airbus into a firm order, Airbus Industrie said today. This will increase the airline's firm orders for the 269-seat wide-bodied aircraft to five.

title: ...AND IN KOREA
description: I hadn't thought much about Willie - I just can't recall his real name - in the last 28 years. He wasn't, after all, much of an influence in my life. I hardly knew him. But something about the court martial of Pfc. Robert R. Garwood, the Marine who was convicted of collaborating with the enemy and assaulting a fellow prisoner while a captive in Vietnam, got me thinking about him again.

title: E.E.C. Sales to Iran Up
description: Common Market exports to Iran rose by 64 percent in last year's first nine months from 1979 levels, despite the community trade embargo imposed last May.

title: BOTTLE BILL VOTE ON L.I. VIEWED AS TEST OF ISSUE
description: A vote that is expected next Tuesday on a bill requiring a 5-cent deposit on bottles in Suffolk County, L.I., may have repercussions throughout New York State.

title: Waldheim Expects Poland To Release U.N. Aide Soon
description: A spokesman for Secretary General Kurt Waldheim said today that Alicja Wesolowska, a Polish United Nations employee sentenced to seven years in prison for spying, might be set free soon.

title: Chris-Craft Industries
description: Chris-Craft Industries, operator of two independent television stations and a producer of chemicals and plastics, anannounced that earnings in the second fiscal quarter rose 32.7 percent, to $1.3 million, or 35 cents a share, from $980,000, or 26 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenues increased 10.2 percent, to $14 million, from $12.7 million.

title: 2 ECONOMIC INDICATORS ARE MIXED
description: In mixed news for the national economy, the Commerce Department reported today that factory orders for durable goods rose slightly in February while an indicator of future industrial investment fell sharply.

title: Officer Free on Bail In Slaying on L.I.
description: A suspended New York City police officer was freed on $10,000 bail after his arraignment on second-degree murder charges for the shooting of a fellow officer during an argument in Brentwood, L.I.

title: William Lawrence, 85, Composer And Pianist Accompanied Singers
description: William Lawrence, a pianist and composer who accompanied such singers as Roland Hayes, Marian Anderson and Dorothy Maynor, died Tuesday in Bellevue Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Harlem.

title: SMALL MOVIE COMPANIES GAMBLE FOR 'ONE BIG HIT'
description: Recent reports that Lorimar is about to retreat from the movie business have been greatly exaggerated, according to Merv Adelson, the company's founder and chairman.

title: Bomb Scare Empties Centre St. Building
description: The State Supreme Court building at 60 Centre Street in lower Manhattan was evacuated after the discovery of what appeared to be an explosive device. The device turned out to be four dry-cell batteries that had been wired together.

title: Leary Stars in Met Victory
description: Tim Leary, the rookie from U.C.L.A., pitched four shutout innings today as the Mets rallied to defeat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-4.

title: SATURDAY, MARCH 21, 1981; Companies
description: The Exxon Corporation canceled development of what it once called an energy-saving motor control to work on an alternative design. Two years ago, the company had announced with fanfare that the electronic control was a breakthrough. Critics renewed charges that Exxon used unsubstantiated assertions for the motor to overcome opposition to its acquisition of the Reliance Electric Company, but Exxon disputed the contentions of the critics. (Page 1.)

title: CONCERT: SUTHERLAND, HORNE, PAVAROTTI
description: Some people are already calling it the concert of the century - a bit rashly, perhaps, considering the number of starry musical events that have received a similar designation over the last 80 years. Still, the experience of hearing the likes of Joan Sutherland, Marilyn Horne and Luciano Pavarotti join voices in a program of arias, duets and trios in Avery Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon very definitely qualifies as an extraordinary event, one that will be repeated Monday night when the entire occasion is televised nationwide on PBS's ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series.

title: Marathon-B.P. Site Deal
description: The Marathon Oil Company said today that it had agreed to sublease three oil-exploration blocks in the Celtic Sea off Ireland to the British Petroleum Company. Under the agreement, B.P. will earn a 50 percent interest in any future production from the three blocks by overseeing and conducting the drilling operations on them, Marathon said. After B.P. has finished earning its interests, Marathon will take over as operator on the blocks, it said.

title: 2 in Atlanta Citizens Patrol Seized on Weapons Charges
description: The police arrested two members of a newly formed citizens' patrol group on weapons charges today at the start of the group's efforts to protect a predominantly black public housing project from the person or persons who have slain 20 children in 20 months.

title: A Photographer Says He Was Glad to Join the Marines
description: What many agree is the most memorable photograph to come out of World War II is a 4-by-5-inch black and white picture of Marines raising an American flag on Iwo Jima.

title: Bulls Gain Playoff Spot
description: Ricky Sobers scored 29 points, and David Greenwood added 28 as the Chicago Bulls beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 120-108, and earned a berth in the playoffs for the first time in four seasons.

title: Lonrho Sets Accord In Observer Link
description: Roland Rowland, the chief executive of Lonrho Ltd., the British mining conglomerate, will acquire a 50 percent personal interest in The Observer, Britain's oldest Sunday newspaper, Lonrho said today.

title: TO EACH HIS OWN
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DANCE: CUNNINGHAM
description: The first thing that strikes the eye in Merce Cunningham's new ''Fielding Sixes,'' which had its New York premiere Thursday night at City Center, is Monika Fulleman's fetching backcloth.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 17.00-17.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title:
PATENTS;
PRODUCING FLEXIBLE CIRCUITS
description: WASHINGTON A MACHINE invented by two engineers is credited with increasing by more than 20 percent the production of flexible circuits, used by the millions by the Bell System.

title: Farmer Who Defied U.S. Cleared
description: A Federal grand jury has refused to indict Wayne Cryts, the farmer who defied the Federal authorities and removed his crops from a bankrupt grain elevator. In a report yesterday to Federal District Judge H. Kenneth Wangelin, the grand jury said that its members did not agree that Mr. Cryts was guilty of a crime.

title:
PATENTS;
Leaching Process For Precious Metals
description: Methods by which gold or silver may be leached from ore tailings, or waste, were patented this week for the Interior Department.

title: MEXICO ORDERS BODYGUARDS TO ADD ETIQUETTE TO SKILLS
description: As the first car weaved aggressively through the evening traffic, one passenger held up a sawed-off shotgun for all to see while another shouted impatiently at other drivers to pull over. Then came a shining black Ford LTD, with antennas sprouting from front and back, followed just a few feet behind by a third car carrying four sinister-looking men.

title:
PATENTS;
Swift Allocation Of Satellite Channels
description: A new satellite communications technique, which can serve many transmitting earth stations, was patented this week for Satellite Business Systems, McLean, Va. Channels can be allocated within fractions of a second among various users.

title: CASES DISMISSED FOR 10 DOCTORS ACCUSED BY CITY
description: Indictments charging that 10 physicians who formerly treated inmates at Rikers Island had cheated the city by falsifying time records were dismissed yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

title: Ramon Jaime Machado Marries Bryna Taubman
description: Bryna Taubman and Ramon Jaime Machado were married yesterday at the home of the bride in Manhattan. Criminal Court Judge Luis M. Neco performed the ceremony.

title: Skipper in Crash Reprimanded
description: The skipper of the Coast Guard cutter Blackthorn was given the lightest punishment possible this week, a reprimand, for dereliction of duty in a collision with a tanker in which 23 of his crewmen died. Lieut. Comdr.

title: T.W.A. Cuts Fares
description: Trans World Airlines, responding to a growing fare war among the nation's airlines, cut its standby and Super Apex fares between London and two United States cities sharply and announced a $99 New York-Miami one-way weekday coach fare from March 23 to April 26.

title: CIGAR-SMOKE SCIENCE
description: Two leading Congressional scientists, Senator Helms and Representative Hyde, anticipate the Nobel Prize for their researches into the nature of life. These have given birth to the Helms-Hyde theory which states that scientific fact can be established by a majority vote of the United States Congress.

title: Williams Wins Heavyweight Final
description: The 55th New York Golden Gloves championship boxing tournament came to a dramatic close at Madison Square Garden last night when the second in Ronald Turner's corner leaped into the ring in the second round to save his fighter from further punishment in the heavyweight open final.

title: DEFIANT JEAN HARRIS SENTENCED TO MANDATORY 15 YEARS
description: An angry Jean S. Harris was sentenced today to a minimum of 15 years to life in prison for the murder a year ago of Dr. Herman Tarnower. Judge Russell R. Leggett of County Court said he wished ''the events of March 10 had never taken place.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Agronomics Corporation purchased Precision Plastics Corporation for $2.625 a share, or a total of about $1.8 million in cash.

title: Pierre Hotel Sued
description: The cancellation last Dec. 31 of a 21-year lease to operate the Pierre Hotel resulted in a $27.5 million suit against the hotel by companies contending they transformed it from a ''badly deteriorated'' condition into the city's ''premier'' hostelry.

title: Aide to Kennedy Resigns After Making Up Threats
description: An aide to Senator Edward M. Kennedy has resigned after telling the police that a series of death threats against him were a hoax.

title: ONCE-VIBRANT MICHIGAN TOWN IS PARALYZED BY DEBT, DESERTION AND PERVASIVE POVERTY
description: ''Every city has its ghetto,'' said Terry Kelly, editor of The Benton Harbor Citizen. ''The difference here is that the ghetto fills the city's corporate limits.''

title: Transactions; AUTO RACING
description: The actor Paul New- m an announced that Teo Fabi, a Formula T wo driver from Italy, will join his March T eam for the 1981 Sports Car Club of Amer- i ca Can-Am Challenge series. Fabi will join A l Unser on the team.

title: Three Defendants Removed From Suit Against Enquirer
description: A judge removed the editor of The National Enquirer, a gossip columnist and the tabloid's distributor today as defendants in the $10 million libel suit brought by Carol Burnett, the entertainer. But the judge declined to dismiss the suit against the publication.

title: CBS-TV TO ADD TO NEWS AND HALVE 'KANGAROO'
description: TV announced yesterday that it planned to add five hours of news programming a week to its daytime schedule, including an afternoon program and an expanded version of its morning news program, which will replace a half-hour of ''Captain Kangaroo,'' the venerable children's show.

title: Indictment Identification Wrong
description: In an article on the indictment of 12 persons in the construction industry published in The New York Times on March 10, one of those indicted was identified in court documents as the business manager of Bricklayers and Tenders Local 59. Federal investigators said yesterday that the the identification in the documents was incorrect. The proper name of the labor organization is Local 59 of the Laborers International Union of North America, which is also known at times as Mason Tenders Local 59.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. made the remark about alleged Soviet plans in an appearance before the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

title: RECITAL: CABALLE, CARRERAS
description: Anyone who came to the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday night expecting to hear two great voices raised in song could scarcely have gone away disappointed. Montserrat Caballe, soprano, and Jose Carreras, tenor, with Martin Katz at the piano, appeared in a joint recital, and both these popular operatic constellations were in optimum vocal condition. This inevitably meant a generous amount of glamorous sound from two of today's most prodigiously endowed singers.

title: EXXON ABANDONS MOTOR CONTROL IT ONCE CALLED A SAVER OF ENERGY
description: The Exxon Corporation announced yesterday that it had abandoned the electronic control for electric motors that it introduced as an energy-saving breakthrough two years ago. The company had invoked the promise of development of the control as justification for its controversial $1.2 billion acquisition of the Reliance Electric Company.

title: Lawyer Questioned on Map Linked to Slaying of Judge
description: The Federal authorities questioned a lawyer, Joe Chagra, today about a map found at his home allegedly pinpointing the hiding place of a rifle used to kill a Federal judge.

title: THE RISING COST OF A SHOESHINE
description: When there's a shine on your shoes There's a melody in your heart. - HOWARD DIETZ

title: Paris Police Seize 2 Peruvians
description: Two Peruvians, one of them a customs officer, were arrested with 17 pounds of cocaine in their luggage today after arriving in Paris on a flight from Lima, the police said. The cocaine's street value was about $630,000, according to the police.

title: THE FEDERAL STAKE IN EFFICIENT APPLIANCES
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Peron Gets 8 Years, But a Pardon Is Expected
description: A Federal judge convicted former President Isabel Martinez de Peron today of two corruption charges and sentenced her to eight years in prison.

title: 200,000 JOBLESS LIKELY IN PUBLIC SERVICE LAYOFFS
description: The Reagan Administration expects some 200,000 people to apply for unemployment compensation benefits as a result of the termination of public service jobs under the Comprehensive Training and Education Act, Congress was told today.

title: WARTIME IN EUROPE
description: The war was coming, of course. In the late 1930's, growing up in a small town in Massachusetts, I could sense that we would have to fight Hitler sooner or later. But the awareness was vague and founded mainly on newsreel segments of the German Army conquering Poland.

title: I.R.A. Apologizes for Killing
description: Irish Republican Army terrorists expressed regret today for killing an ''innocent'' man in an ambush. It issued a statement saying that it was responsible for the murder last night of a man the police identified as Gerry Roland, 45 years old. The statement said the I.R.A. had intended to assassinate Maurice Lutton, 35, a former soldier in the Ulster Defense Regiment.

title: WHITE HOUSE URGES SALE OF STOCKPILED U.S. SILVER
description: The Reagan Administration proposes to sell all the silver in the national stockpile to raise money to buy materials it regards as having far greater strategic importance.

title: JERSEY DOCTOR ACCUSED OF PLOT TO KILL WIFE
description: A physician who directed the emergency rooms of two hospitals in northern New Jersey was accused with three other men yesterday of plotting the murder of his estranged wife, also a physician.

title: Jersey Legislator Says Casinos Harassed Him
description: An Assemblyman who recently sponsored legislation to bring back $2 gaming tables contended today he had been harassed and threatened after being accused of counting cards in blackjack at two Boardwalk casinos.

title: U.S. Wins an Appeal In Margiotta Case
description: The Federal Government won an appeal of a trial judge's order to revise a key count in an indictment charging Joseph Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican leader, with fraud involving more than $500,000 in insurance kickbacks.

title: REAGAN'S 'KITCHEN CABINET' IS TOLD TO VACATE OFFICE IN U.S. BUILDING
description: President Reagan's top aides have evicted the informal advisers known as his ''kitchen cabinet'' from the offices they used in the Executive Office Building. It was the second move to limit the activities of the group of wealthy friends of the President who have attempted to influence the Administration's appointments and policies.

title: TOXIC-WASTE INVESTIGATORS ARE NOT DISASTER-MONGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Tulsa 69, South Alabama 68
description: Greg Stewart and Paul Pressey each had 15 points to help Tulsa recover from a 12-point first-half deficit and defeat South Alabama, 69-68, tonight.

title: A SPECIAL APPOINTMENT FOR S.E.C. REPORTED SET
description: The Reagan Administration is seeking a highly unusual five-year appointment to the Securities and Exchange Commission for John S.R. Shad, the New York investment banker whom the White House intends to nominate as the agency's next chairman, Congressional and industry sources say.

title: ISLANDERS SET BACK RESCH AND ROCKIES
description: Glenn (Chico) Resch called it ''interesting but overwhelming'' to play against his former Islander teammates. Steve Tambellini said it was hard to look into his old friends' faces. But the Islanders seemed to take things in stride tonight as they beat the Colorado Rockies, 5-3, at McNichols Arena.

title: A LEVER FOR PUERTO RICO
description: To the Editor:

title: Ainge Is Man In Clutch
description: Daniel Ray Ainge is a 22-year-old athlete with such superb skills that he plays college basketball and professional baseball. He used all of those skills for just under six seconds last night, drove 30 yards and scored the basket with two seconds left that gave Brigham Young a 51-50 victory over Notre Dame in the East Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: BUSINESS INVESTMENT BOOM SEEN
description: Defending the Administration's economic policy in the face of criticism from Congress and some economists, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan released new figures today that project year-by-year increases in personal savings and business investment through 1986.

title: HENRY ST. HOUSE AIDED IN COPING WITH FUEL COSTS
description: For 86 years, the small, attached brick buildings owned by the Henry Street Settlement House have served as a busy center for neighborhood activity on the Lower East Side as well as being a national landmark.

title:
PATENTS;
New Circuit Boards For Electronic Parts
description: The RCA Corporation received a patent this week for what it calls a major advance in the field of circuit boards. Kenneth W. Hang and Wayne M. Anderson of the RCA Research Center in Princeton, N.J., were granted patent 4,256,796 for metal boards coated with a specially developed porcelain that can be reheated many times without deforming.

title: CITY MOVING 25 PATIENTS FROM STRUCK HARLEM HOSPITAL
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation ordered the transfer of 25 patients from the Harlem Hospital Center to Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday as a strike by interns and residents continued for a fourth day. Seven municipal and two private voluntary hospitals are affected.

title: MILWAUKEE FIREMEN RESUME STRIKE
description: Firefighters, angered by a city council committee's rejection of a settlement that ended a walkout earlier this month, have gone on strike again.

title: BL HAS HUGE LOSS, BUT CHIEF IS HOPEFUL
description: BL Ltd., the state-owned British auto giant formerly known as British Leyland, said today that it lost the equivalent of $875.7 million last year, more than three times its loss in 1979.

title: Mrs. Melton Leads by 2
description: Nancy Lopez-Melton, trying for her second straight victory on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour, shot an even-par 72 in 40-mile-an-hour winds today to take the lead after the second round of the $200,000 Desert Inn golf tournament.

title: Purdue and Tulsa In N.I.T. Semifinals
description: Drake Morris scored 28 points, and Brian Walker and Russell Cross led a second-half surge that carried Purdue to an 81-69 victory over Duke in the quarterfinal round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: A Ravel Patron's Legacy May Aid Composer Once More
description: Eighty-two years ago, when he wrote his now-famous ''Pavane for a Dead Princess,'' Maurice Ravel dedicated it to his longtime patron, the Princess Edmond de Polignac. She later married into the Singer sewing machine family and fortune, which enabled her to continue to support artists, including Ravel.

title: TOKYO AIDE TO FOCUS ON 2 ISSUES IN U.S.
description: Japan is expected to explore United States attitudes on two key issues - exports of Japanese autos to the United States and Japan's contribution to security in the Far East - when Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ito visits Washington next week.

title: REPORT DOUBTS INFANT DEATH RISE FROM THREE MILE ISLAND MISHAP
description: In a final report, the Pennsylvania Health Department said today that radiation released in the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant near here on March 28, 1979, did not cause the deaths of infants or fetuses.

title: Sports of The Times; View of The George-and-Reggie Show
description: BOB MARSHALL wakes up happy these days, knowing that his favorite Punch-and-Judy show is back in business after a long and boring winter.

title: Celtics 128, Bullets 116
description: Robert Parish led an 8-point fourth-quarter surge that carried the Boston Celtics to a 128-116 victory over the Washington Bullets tonight.

title: Correction
description: An article in The Times on Wednesday about the environment of the black children killed and missing in Atlanta gave an incorrect headquarters city for the Children's Defense Fund. It is based in Washington.

title: TRAMWAY SHUT DOWN FOR 3 HOURS
description: The Roosevelt Island Tramway was out of service for more than three hours yesterday morning after a faulty electronic chip was detected on a safety control panel.

title: CORPORATE EARNINGS
description: MALLORY RANDALL CORP (O) Qtr to Dec. 31 1980 1979 Sales 953,000 684,000 Net income b638,000 c2,204,000 Share earnings .31 - Yr sales 2,965,000 2,305,000 Net income b677,000 c1,172,000 Share earnings .33 - b-After gain from tax loss carryforward of $62,000 in the quarter and $105,000 for the year. c-Net loss after $2.1 million loss from discontinued operations in quarter and for $570,000 in the year. MAPI INC (O) Qtr to Jan. 31 1981 1980 Sales 5,939,000 6,681,000 Net loss 844,000 296,000 9-mo sales 19,331,000 22,171,000 Net loss 1,515,000 246,000 MARCUS CORP (O) Qtr to Feb. 7 1981 1980 Revenue 21,521,000 21,056,000 Net income 757,000 b658,000 Share earnings .16 .14 9-mo revs 71,848,000 67,855,000 Net income 4,387,000 b4,123,000 Share earnings .92 .86 b-After losses of $11,000 in the quarter and $74,000 for the nine months from discontinued operations. MARYLAND REALTY TRUST Qtr to Feb. 28 1981 1980 Revenue 248,000 288,000 Net income 20,000 b131,000 Share earnings .01 - b-Net loss. MATTEL INC (N) Qtr to Jan. 31 1981 1980 Sales 205,362,000 204,343,000 Net loss 15,468,000 b6,897,000 Share earnings - .28 Yr sales 915,690,000 805,064,000 Net income 7,898,000 30,553,000 Share earnings .12 1.38 b-Net income.

title: MINERS' CHIEF SEES RECORD STRIKE
description: The president of the United Mine Workers warned today that a coal strike that he called ''inevitable'' a week from today might be longer than the record 111-day walkout of three winters ago.

title: 'ATTACK' ON A NUCLEAR PLANT NOW CALLED SURVIVAL LESSON
description: This country town of 3,000 people in west-central Florida was swarming with Federal agents and a small army of reporters today after 13 men wearing mottled jungle fatigues and carrying exotic weapons were caught practicing hand-to-hand combat two miles from a nearby nuclear power plant.

title: No Constitutional Shortcut on Abortion
description: The Right to Life movement, which has sought for several years to ban abortions by constitutional amendment, now claims to have found an easier route. Encouraged by no less a personage than President Reagan, the anti-abortion forces are pressing Congress for a law declaring that human life begins at conception and that the unborn are legally ''persons.'' That sounds simple, yet it is aimed at change of constitutional magnitude.

title: 'FRESH' CAN MEAN NOT QUITE
description: ''Fresh,'' as it is used to describe food, is a word of many meanings, varying with individual evaluations. It is absolute only in the negative: Fresh water is not salt water, fresh food is not stale or rotten. ''Fresh,'' to most people as well as to the Department of Agriculture and the dictionaries, refers to food that is not frozen, canned or otherwise preserved; at least one dictionary also notes that fresh food has not been in storage, nor have any of its original qualities been impaired.

title: Conner and Li of China Top Gymnastics Qualifiers
description: Bart Conner placed in the top three of all six events and posted two victories tonight, but Yuejiu Li of China led eight qualifiers for the all-round title Sunday by capturing three individual titles in the opening of competition in the American Cup gymnastics championships.

title: MAJOR DONORS TO REAGANS' FUND
description: The list of contributors of more than $1,000 to the White House redecoration fund, released by Nancy Reagan's office today, were as follows: The Annenberg Fund, Inc., Radnor, Pa., $70,000. Jack L. Hodges, Oklahoma City, Okla., $50,000.Mr. and Mrs. Earle M. Jorgensen, Los Angeles, $50,000. Marjorie L. Everett, Beverly Hills, Calif., $25,000. Janes A. Hooker Charitable Trust, Radnor, Pa., $25,000. Mrs. Vincent Astor, New York, $20,000. Armand Hammer, Los Angeles, $20,000. Carl Anderson, Oklahoma City, Okla., $10,000. John M. Beard, Oklahoma City, Okla., $10,000. Bing Fund Corporation, Los Angeles, $10,000. Alfred Bloomingdale, Los Angeles, $10,000. H.E. Chiles, Fort Worth, Tex. $10,000. Charles Cook, City of Industry, Calif. $10,000. Mike Curb, Los Angeles, $10,000. Justin Dart, Los Angeles, $10,000. William C. Douce, Bartlesville, Okla., $10,000. Guilford Dudley Jr., Nashville, $10,000. Jan S. Choate, Hennessey, Okla., $10,000. Michael A. Elder, Norman, Okla., $10,000. C. Richard Ford, Oklahoma City, Okla. $10,000. Edward L. Gaylor, Oklahoma City, Okla. $10,000.

title: Burroughs Layoffs
description: The Burroughs Corporation said it will reduce employment by a total of 460 workers at five plants this month and early in April.

title: Floods Afflict Somalia Refugees
description: Seasonal flooding and a severe outbreak of measles have wreaked havoc in Somalian refugee camps housing about a million people from the Ogaden region, relief officials said today.

title: INDUSTRY GROUPS SEEKING CHANGES IN CLEAN AIR LAW
description: Contending that the Clean Air Act is too costly, inflexible and insensitive to other national goals, such as energy development, two of the country's most influential business organizations are calling for major changes in the law.

title: PENTAGON SAYS 18 OF 54 ADVISERS ARE TO LEAVE EL SALVADOR BY JULY
description: The Defense Department said tonight that 18 of the 54 United States military advisers sent to El Salvador would return to this country by July after completing their assigned training missions.

title: REAGAN VOWS SHIFT IN FEDERAL POWERS
description: President Reagan declared today that his economic program was just a first step in reordering the relationship between citizens and government. ''Our time is now, our moment has arrived,'' he said in a speech to a group of conservatives meeting here this weekend.

title: HELMS EXHORTS TOBACCO BLOC TO FIGHT BUDGET CUTS
description: ''Now repeat after me,'' Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, solemnly told the gathering of more than 500 farmers and warehousemen today. ''There is no tobacco subsidy.''

title: WHITES AT SOUTH AFRICAN UNIVERSITY SHOUT DOWN BLACK-AFFAIRS MINISTER
description: Hundreds of students at the University of the Witwatersrand here, most of them white, shouted down the Government's minister in charge of black affairs, Pieter G. Koornhof, when he tried to speak today.

title: 2 Drop Prime Below 17%
description: United Missouri Bancshares, a large regional bank holding company based in Kansas City, lowered its prime lending rate to 16 3/4 percent from 17 1/2 percent today as the tiny Southwest Bank of St. Louis, a locally owned bank that often undercuts its bigger competitors on business-loan interest rates, cut its prime rate a full percentage point, to 16 1/2 percent. Most other banks are quoting a 17 1/2 percent prime, although Chemical Bank in New York, the nation's sixth-largest commercial bank, and Manufacturer's Bank of Los Angeles have cut their rate to 17 percent.

title: THE DEBILITATION OF A GUN LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.& T. Waiver On Rule Sought
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today sought to offer some advanced services to the public without complying with a key regulation designed to safeguard competition in the telephone industry.

title: Modern-Dance Festival
description: At SUNY Purchase

title: News Analysis
description: With varying degrees of intensity, Democrats on the Senate Budget Committee spent much of the last three days assailing what they considered the ''perversion'' of the budget process and the product that emerged. The poor were being made to suffer, they said, and so were members of minority groups, urban dwellers, the sick, the elderly, the Northeast and the Middle West.

title: WHITE HOUSE WITHDRAWS SUPPORT OF LONG ISLANDER TO BE V.A. HEAD
description: The Reagan Administration has decided not to nominate John Behan, a Vietnam War amputee from Long Island, to head the Veterans Administration, a White House official said today.

title: KOCH FAILS IN TRY TO CHANGE PLANS FOR TRANSIT CURBS
description: Mayor Koch said today that he had ''struck out'' in his attempts to convince the Reagan Administration that it should not seek to end the program that provides Federal subsidies for mass-transit fares.

title: No Headline
description: In the advertising column Wednesday, the parent company of the Buckingham Corporation was incorrectly identified. It is Northwest Industries.

title: Bridge:; Couple From Maryland Get First National Title of Year
description: The first national title to be decided in 1981 was won here last night by a married couple from Maryland. In the final of the Grand National level last August, Robert and Helen Blakey of Columbia, Md., outdistanced their rivals, and now have a chance to be one of the pairs to represent the United States in the 1982 World Pair Championship in Biarritz, France.

title: Shelter
description: When Ellen Baxter and Kim Hopper asked a bag lady at Grand Central to talk about her life, she answered: ''What difference does it make?'' Her fatalism is understandable. Yet it could make a difference that Mr. Hopper and Miss Baxter, Ph.D. candidates at Columbia, spent a year studying the people most visibly down and out in New York City - those without homes or even regular shelter. The results of their poignant study ought to impel the city to action.

title: Gerald (Gee) Walker, Outfielder In Major Leagues for 15 Seasons
description: Gerald H. (Gee) Walker, a major league baseball player for 15 years, died today in the Mississippi State Hospital at Whitfield after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Pillsbury Net Up 9.6%
description: The Pillsbury Company reported record third-quarter earnings of $21.7 million, or $1.08 a share, up 9.6 percent from the same period a year ago, citing continued growth in its consumer foods business. Earnings in the quarter ended Feb. 28 came on sales of $825 million and compared with earnings of $19.8 million, or 99 cents a share, on sales of $751.7 million in the same period a year earlier.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''North Carolina is in the catbird's seat as never before as far as tobacco is concerned.'' - Representative Charlie Rose 3d, Democrat of North Carolina, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Tobacco and Peanuts. (9:2.)

title: ANKARA ABOLISHES 2 HOLIDAYS AND TURKS ASK WHY
description: Turkey's military rulers have abolished two holidays in May, and this seemingly simple measure, announced by the ruling National Security Council this week, has stirred controversy as well as questions about the intentions of the regime.

title: 6 Permits on Sludge Canceled by E.P.A.
description: Nassau County and five New Jersey sewerage authorities were ordered to stop dumping sewage sludge in the ocean by mid-April, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency said.

title: Correction
description: In the advertising column Wednesday, the parent company of the Buckingham Corporation was incorrectly identified. It is Northwest Industries.

title: CITY SHIVERS IN CLUTCH OF SPRING
description: Rejoice. The plane of the earth's orbit has intersected the celestial equator and it is, arguably, spring. Meteorologists proclaimed it so at 12:03 P.M. yesterday, the moment of the vernal equinox.

title: Kelly Brown, Actor and Dancer Was Soloist With Ballet Theater
description: Kelly Brown, an actor and dancer who had been a soloist with the American Ballet Theater, died March 13 in Phoenix. Mr. Brown, the father of Leslie Brown, who starred in the films ''The Turning Point'' and ''Nijinsky,'' suffered a heart attack while teaching a class at his ballet school. He was 52 years old.

title: Pickets in Philadelphia Disrupt Commuter Trains
description: The six-day transit strike that has hurt Philadelphia business and halted city buses, trolleys and subways for 400,000 riders intensified today as pickets disrupted most commuter train service.

title: Comptroller Regan's Travels
description: Junketing Congressmen are familiar news, but Edward Regan may be setting a new intrastate mileage record for a state comptroller. Travel has clearly broadened his view of his office. Constitutionally, he is sole trustee of the state's employee pension funds, and the guardian of its credit and accounting methods. Freed from the fetters of Albany and tradition, Mr. Regan now sees himself as adviser to the state's citizenry and its independent authorities. His advice, so far, has been either meaningless or bad.

title: MADDOX YANKEE DAYS DWINDLE
description: Elliott Maddox, in the Yankees' camp in search of a job, may soon be seeking that job elsewhere. Although the Yankees, by agreement with the outfielder-third baseman, have until next Thursday to let him know his status, it's very likely that they will tell him in the next few days that they have no need for him. No one among the Yankee hierarchy will say that publicly, but the feeling seems to be that Maddox has not impressed the club sufficiently to be offered a contract.

title: KOCH ASSAILS GUN-LAW STUDY'S RESULTS
description: A report released yesterday on sentences under the state's sevenmonth-old gun-control law shows that defendants in 61 of 192 cases in New York City received less than so-called mandatory one-year jail terms, and Mayor Koch singled out nine of the cases as particularly disturbing.

title: CAIRO'S CITY OF THE DEAD
description: It was raining mud in the City of the Dead. A freak midwinter sandstorm had mixed with a rare desert rain to drop fat pellets of wet dirt on the 1,000 acres of ancient underground tombs and mausoleums that some 500,000 homeless people have converted into a bustling ''city,'' complete with traffic jams.

title: I.R.A., KEOGH ACCOUNT SHIFTS
description: MANY people tend to treat their Individual Retirement Accounts or Keogh pension accounts as money to be sent off to the same institution each year, in time to qualify for a tax deduction, and then forgotten. This is a costly mistake that could mean the difference between a comfortable retirement and a relatively strained one.

title: Msgr. Vincent J. Powell, 69, Dies; Headed Brooklyn Diocese's C.Y.O.
description: Msgr. Vincent J. Powell, the director of the Catholic Youth Organization in the Diocese of Brooklyn from 1940 to 1966, died March 12 at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: TEXACO'S DRY HOLE OFF JERSEY
description: Texaco Inc. reported yesterday that it had drilled yet another dry hole in the Baltimore Canyon, casting a pall over prospects that oil or natural gas will ever be produced off the Middle Atlantic coast.

title: SLAIN DOCTOR'S FRIENDS CONTRIBUTE $200,000 TO PROJECTS IN HIS HONOR
description: Friends of Dr. Herman Tarnower have contributed about $200,000 toward projects in his memory since the Westchester County cardiologist was slain last year.

title: 'ABOLISH INDUSTRIAL HOMEWORK'
description: To the Editor:

title: KNICKS WIN, GAIN HOME-COURT ADVANTAGE
description: The National Basketball Association playoffs will open for the Knicks against either the Pacers or the Chicago Bulls at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night, March 31.

title: Sound; NOVELTY IN LOUDSPEAKERS
description: Running counter to hallowed rules is often risky and rarely rewarding. The odds are always stacked in favor of orthodoxy, which is why there are so many sacred cows. But occasionally a maverick comes along and twists the cow's tail.

title: KATHARINE DUANE IS WED TO SCULPTOR
description: Katharine Clark Duane, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard B. Duane Jr. of New York, was married yesterday afternoon in Locust, N.J. to Jene Abel Highstein, son of Mrs. Gustav Highstein of Baltimore, and the late Dr. Highstein. Mayor Frank Self of Middletown, N.J., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandfather, Richard Bache Duane.

title: 2 Killed by Gunman in Hospital
description: A man opened fire in a hospital emergency room with a 12-gauge shotgun last night, killing a doctor and a visitor, the police said. He remained at large today. The police said that Ruth Rybolt, 54 years old, and Dr. Marc Beck, 25, both of Kansas City, Kan., were killed immediately when they were shot at the University of Kansas Medical Center.

title: MORE L.I. ARTISTS FORMING CO-OPS
description: ''THE situation that produces cooperative galleries,'' the critic Lawrence Alloway has written, ''is imbalance between the production and distribution of art.'' It is certainly true of the Island that, while there is a large, varied and active community of artists here, there is not a sufficient number of commercial galleries to represent them fully.

title: FUTURE EVENTS
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. --------------------------------------------------------------------- Middle Eastern Unity March 25 - Jihan el Sadat, Egypt's First Lady, will receive the World Rehabilitation Funds first Achievement Award for her service in establishing the Rehabilitation Center at Wafa-Wa-Amal Hospital in Cairo at the fund's 25th anniversary dinner celebration. Theother guests of honor - Aliza Begin, wife of Israel's Prime Minister, and Ofira Navon, wife of Israel's President - will get Distinguished Service Awards for their endorsement of the fund's program to help brain-damaged patients patients in Israel. Proceeds from the even in the New York Hilton's Grand Ballroom will go toward training Egyptian and Israeli doctors at the New York University Medical Center's Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine to treat brain damage and spinal chord injuries. The menu has been selected to comply with dietary laws. Tickets, $200.

title: ON A SEA SYMPOSIUM AND ART OF DECOYS
description: TWO events of unusual appeal to those interested in seas, oceans and their coastal areas, or in waterfowl decoys, a truly American art form, are scheduled for the weekend of March 28-29, one in Manhattan, the other on Long Island.

title: BACKDOOR DECONTROL
description: NOW that the Reagan Administration has decontrolled oil prices, it has begun to consider the more politically troublesome and economically volatile issue of natural gas deregulation. Even though candidate Reagan campaigned on a platform calling for immediate decontrol of natural gas prices, it is becoming more and more likely that President Reagan will not ask Congress to vote on the issue. Instead, he will probably embark on what some have called ''the backdoor approach'' to decontrol, an approach that requires no legislated change in the current law, the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978.

title:
Gardening;
EXTENDING THE BLOOM OF DRY-WALL FLOWERS
description: IN last week's column, we discussed the functional and esthetic merits of rock walls - especially those of dry walls. The spaces between the stones provide ideal pockets for many interesting plants, giving dry walls a distinct advantage over other garden walls.

title: TRYING TO TAX BIG OIL
description: ON the eve of debate in the Kansas House this month over his controversial tax on oil and gas production, Gov. John Carlin left a reception winding down at his Topeka mansion to join the press corps at the Caravan Club, a nightspot where tired legislators let their hair down and where he rarely ventures. Suddenly you could hear a pin drop, says one observer, the way someone always does just before John Wayne shoots the bad guy in a class Western.

title: LOUDSPEAKER DESIGN IGNORES TRADITION
description: Running counter to hallowed rules is often risky and rarely rewarding. The odds are always stacked in favor of orthodoxy, which is why there are so many sacred cows. But occasionally a maverick comes along and twists the cow's tail.

title:
Food;
CREATING NEW DIET MENUS
description: MANHASSET WHEN bottles of wine, jars of peanut butter and bags of popcorn were surreptitiously brought in to the Weight Watchers test kitchen here recently and furtively tucked away in corners and cupboards, the otherwise effusive staff tried, as best they could, to keep the recipes using the hitherto ''illegal'' foods safely under their toques.

title: WHAT'S CODED, COMPUTERIZED AND ESSENTIAL TO THE PRESIDENT
description: When Ronald Reagan's Cabinet was first assembled, the similarities of the members - in age, in convictions, even in dress - were so remarkable that they seemed to some to blend into a faceless whole. Today the Cabinet is divided, on issues ranging from the embargo on grain shipments to the Soviet Union to the automobile industry's demand for limits on imports from Japan, and there is sometimes drama under the homogeneous surface.

title: MARITAL TIPS FOR CHARLES
description: Everyone in the United Kingdom is very happy that Prince Charles is to marry Lady Diana Spencer. The Queen is happy, the Duke of Edinburgh is happy, Margaret Thatcher is happy, the press is happy, the Tourist Board is happy and the Bank of England is happy. The agricultural workers are happy and the sewage workers are happy and the keeper of the Eddystone Lighthouse is probably not unhappy.

title: Drifting Into an African Policy
description: Just two months at sea, the Reagan Administration seems headed into a foreign policy fog of its own making. Each day brings a correction of yesterday's bold pronouncements - on El Salvador, on Poland, on Soviet-American relations. The style is not only disquieting; it may be destructive. Even before policies have been charted, the choices are being narrowed by heedless remarks and public posturing.

title: RALPH BAKSHI-ICONOCLAST OF ANIMATION
description: Ralph Bakshi, the kid from Brownsville who has successfully revolted in subject matter and style against the art of animation as practiced by Walt Disney and his disciples, visited Washington, D.C., recently and hustled off to the National Gallery with Carl Bell, one of the animators of Mr. Bakshi's sixth and latest feature, ''American Pop.''

title: SALEM ON THE COMEBACK ROAD
description: SALEM FIVE years ago, 19th-century houses here with leaking roofs, bad plumbing, peeling walls and all the other signs of a slum sold for less than $10,000.

title: Lady Oakley Victor By a Head in Distaff
description: It's in the Air, a $1.6 million mare, made a gallant try to overtake Lady Oakley in the stretch at Aqueduct yesterday, but the weight disadvantage proved too much and she had to settle for second place, a head behind the Irish import, in the $56,500 Distaff Handicap.

title: No Headline
description: I spent my childhood claiming the discarded rugby (stained) and button-down (oversized) shirts from my older brothers.

title: music; A COUNTY VERDI'S REQUIEM
description: ONE of the greatest choral pieces ever written, Verdi's Requiem, is coming to Westchester this week, in what is thought to be its first performances presented here by a county-based group.

title: GIRDING FOR A NEW GYPSY MOTH ATTACK
description: CONFIRMING widespread concern about another severe onslaught of gypsy moths, hundreds of area residents turned out recently at two public seminars to hear entomologists, foresters and conservationists discuss methods of controlling the destructive insect.

title: Suspect Wounded in a Shootout After Robberies at Cash Machine
description: A suspected holdup man was shot and seriously wounded last night by the police as he and an associate tried to flee after allegedly robbing patrons of an automated banking facility at Second Avenue and 32d Street in Manhattan, the police said.

title: ONCE AGAIN, POWER PENDULUM SWINGS TOWARD THE EXECUTIVE BRANCH
description: Richard E. Neustadt, the celebrated professorial chronicler of executive power, wrote in 1960 that, although the Founding Fathers were said to have created a government of ''separated powers,'' the constitutional convention did nothing of the sort.

title: NANCY DINKELACKER MARRIED TO ROBERT A. GEDAROVICH
description: The marriage of Nancy Elizabeth Dinkelacker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Dinkelacker of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., to Robert Albin Gedarovich, son of Dr. and Mrs. Albin Gedarovich of Bayside, Queens, took place yesterday morning in St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Mario Costa, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Bridge; FATHER KNOWS BEST
description: This is an age of specialization, and Renaissance men and women are rare. If one surveyed all the world's bridge players in search of one with a wide range of talents, the following qualifications would certainly attract attention.

title: HEAT FROM THE SUN: SOME PROS AND CONS
description: MY solar hot-water system is a year and a half old now, just completing its second winter, and I think all the bugs are out of it. The bugs included squirrels, which were the big surprise. I had worried about plumbing problems, and got some; naysayers, who, as I expected, told me I had wasted money; and disappointing fuel savings, but, as it turned out, the savings were substantial.

title: THE PERILS OF CONSUMER ELECTRONICS
description: THE commercials begin tonight on all three networks. ''Bring the magic home,'' they'll say. Giant ads are set for leading magazines and newspapers in 115 cities. With a promotion budget approaching $20 million, the company that was built on breakthroughs in radio, black-and-white television and then color television, now is bringing out SelectaVision.

title: ELYSE RENEE RAME IS AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Rame of Roslyn, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elyse Renee Rame, to David Beyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Beyer of New York. Miss Rame is a student at the Benjamin Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University. Her fiance, a graudate of Hofstra University, is a stockbroker with Advest Inc.

title: U.S. CALLS OFF INQUIRY ON BURIAL OF DDT
description: BARNEGAT THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency has discontinued its investigation into allegations that drums of DDT were buried on the property of the Ocean County Mosquito Exterminating Commission here.

title: CONSTRUCTION WOES BESET SCHOOL POOLS
description: HALF HOLLOW HILLS EVENTS have not gone swimmingly in the construction of pools at high schools in Half Hollow Hills and Deer Park. Now, as school officials prepare for final testing of the waters, they're holding their breath - wondering what else can go wrong.

title: An Unhappy Nettles Meets With Michael
description: The start of the season is less than three weeks away, but Gene Michael, the rookie Yankee manager, already is a veteran at holding meetings with players.

title: No Headline
description: A screaming, jeering crowd of about 100 people confronted the police at an Atlanta housing project today, chanting ''We ain't gonna take this junk no more!'' to protest police actions concerning their self-defense patrol and the unsolved murders.

title: THORNS HAVE BEGUN TO APPEAR IN REAGAN'S ECONOMIC GARDEN
description: EVEN before he discovered supply-side theory, President Reagan liked to use broad brush strokes and bold colors to paint an idealized economic landscape. Therein, hardy capitalists, cheerful workers and an inherently fair free market produced inevitable prosperity, while enlightened local officials and private charities cared for the poor until they got their share of the economic pie.

title: SUSAN WALDRON MARRIED
description: Susan Joyce Waldron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Preece of Senaca Falls, N.Y. and Chesterfield, England, was married yesterday to Lawrence M. Polans of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irving E. Polans.

title: Westchester Journal
description: KEEPING a close eye on Congress is what Gerald A. Norlander plans to do for the next couple of months. Mr. Norlander is executive director of Westchester Legal Services, an organization financed primarily by the Federal Government to provide legal services in civil matters for the poor. (Free legal help for indigent defendants in criminal cases is guaranteed by law).

title: LOS ANGELES It was after the third or fourth letter came asking where she was buried that Barbara Stanwyck ended a self-imposed retirement to appear in a ''Charlie's Angels'' television segment last year. She had starred in more than 80 movies, but the last was 16 years ago, and Hollywood makes little room for stately age.

title: Art View; A CHOICE RANGE OF JAPANESE ART
description: Many people in New York hear about the glories of the Cleveland Museum of Art, but relatively few, I suspect, ever get around to seeing them. The reason for this is obvious and understandable. Except for the museum, Cleveland offers the visitor interested in the visual arts few other attractions worth the trip. Yet the museum itself, though much smaller than the Met and no rival to it in the scale of its collections, has a reputation for great quality, and it is a reputation well earned. Cleveland's permanent collection of Western European art is one of the finest in the country, and even its collection of modern art - a field that many of the museum's critics have accused it of neglecting - is actually ampler and contains more treasures than outsiders have been led to believe. The effort required to see the Cleveland Museum is therefore worth making.
