title: Food; THE VERSATILE CORNISH HEN
description: rench chefs and many serious home cooks often lament the fact that here they are unable to find the small poussins or young chickens that are so widely available in the markets of France. Poussins differ from just any young chickens in that they have reached maturity and developed flavor, yet they generally weigh only about one pound or slightly more. On rare occasions one can buy these little chickens in rural areas where poultry farms exist. An excellent substitute for the small birds, however, is the Rock Cornish hen, which is said to be a cross between a White Rock and a Cornish game bird. The word game, in the case of these hens, has long since lost its meaning, for the chickens do not smack in the least of a wild bird. Nonetheless, they are a delicacy and are remarkably easy to prepare. One unstuffed bird, roasted or grilled, will serve one. When filled with a meat stuffing, one bird will suffice for two servings. Here are two recipes for Cornish hens, one with a sausage stuffing, another for deviled, breaded Cornish hens.

title: FROM MILAN, A FIRST LOOK AT FALL
description: When fall comes via Milan, hemlines will both scoot up and slide down. A woman's body will be either cloaked in voluminous layers or sheathed by clothes with carefully pared-down lines. Last season's ubiquitous pants will continue, but skirts will definitely make a comeback. The coat will all but disappear, replaced by a warming, blanketlike cloth rectangle. Shoulders will still be important but the leg, waistline and hipline are places to watch for changes. The color palette will have flashes of brilliant red or blue, but most of it will be misted, smokey hues or somber mustards, greens, browns or black. There will be lots of leather, velvet and corduroy worked in subtle and intricate patterns, often quilted for extra punch. The low-heeled boot or shoe will remain the key to balancing the new proportions. And, though there will be robust clothes inspired by turn-of-the-century ''country'' men's attire, the pervasive influence will hail from the East - from 19th-century Russia, Mongolia and Japan.

title: No Headline

Good plays could be revived if the actors, musicians and theater owners were to get together to make such a change financially viable. A vast part of the public cannot afford the current inflated prices of tickets, and lots of good actors who are without work would welcome roles in such companies. J.B. MILGRAM, Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: STRANGERS IN THE HOLY LAND
description: Bill Kurtis is a reporter-anchorman for WBBM/TV in Chicago. By Bill Kurtis Dimona rises out of the Negev desert in dusty-brown apartment complexes. Old men sit in a small park near the central shopping mall, exactly as they sat in the sun of Poland or Russia, trading stories in the language of Europeans, their faces wrinkled with the indelible furrows of a difficult life lived elsewhere. The old men have much to talk about - but their conversation does not concern Israel's pressing economic problems or the controversial settlements in the West Bank. The old men talk about the blacks from the United States who live in the ''slums'' at the western edge of the city, who brought their American ''ghetto'' to Dimona. They talk about the Black Hebrews.

title: Stage View; IBSEN, ALAS, IS A DEAD DUCK
description: There's a tin ear at work in Brooklyn these nights, where Ibsen's ''The Wild Duck'' has just been added to the seasonal repertory at the Academy of Music, though precisely whose ear is responsible for the most flagrant damage isn't easy to say. Certainly Thomas Babe, who has adapted the text from a translation by Erik J. Friis, will not soon be forgiven his more obvious and more labored updatings: one's nerve-ends do flinch from each casual ''what the hell'' or each self-conscious ''horny'' that falls from the lips of frockcoated, frog-chested 19th-century gentlemen. And director Arthur Penn, trying his hand at Ibsen after a distinguished career dealing with contemporary stage and screen materials, has at the very least been guilty of letting so many leaden out-of-kilter epithets stand. He's even let stand some of Mr. Babe's more painful flippancies. After all the talk that's gone on about the wounded duck kept on a pile of straw in the Ekdal family's attic, a doctor strolls in to ask cheerfully what everyone's chattering about now: ''More duck dropping?'' he asks. Some things should be taken out and buried on the night before rehearsals begin.

description: A woman believed to be a Basque guerrilla killed a retired army colonel today.

title: TV TOWER ANGERS A PINELANDS TOWN
description: WTERFORD TOWNSHIP WHAT goes up, as the old saw says, must come down. And what has gone up in this Camden County community, its Mayor vows, will certainly come down.

title: BELL SAYS REDUCED AID FOR COLLEGE STUDENTS IS NOT AIMED AT POOR
description: Education Secretary T.H. Bell told black educators yesterday that most of the Reagan Administration's proposed cuts in aid to college students would be at the expense of middleincome and upper-income students, not the poor.

title: BARGAINING SCHEDULED FOR NURSING HOME CONTRACT
description: Bargaining aimed at averting a threatened strike at 81 nursing homes with 20,000 patients in the New York metropolitan area is scheduled to get under way tomorrow at the Sheraton Centre.

title: READERS DISPUTE WHY WOMEN EARN LESS
description: To the Business Editor: In addition to missing two major factors - job segregation and undervaluation of women's jobs - Professor Thurow ignored a low rate of unionization. Fewer working women than men belong to labor unions, depriving them of the strongest force available to improve wages. MORTON BAHR Vice President Communications Workers of America

title: WARM SPELL WAS LUCKY FOR MAPLE SYRUP PRODUCERS
description: A plume of white steam floated lazily above Beards Hollow Road here, a telltale sign that the evaporator at the Putnam Maple Farm was in operation, producing this year's crop of maple syrup.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Right now, the second largest party in Great Britain has adopted as part of its official platform the renunciation of nuclear weapons. We are even hearing in other countries the contemptible 'Better red than dead' slogan of a generation ago.'' - Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser. (13:2.)

title: STATES TRANSLATING PROPOSED BUDGET IN TERMS OF LOST DOLLARS AND PROGRAM
description: CUTS By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

title: Reasoning
description: To the Business Editor:

title: NEW INN HAS FRIENDS AT THE OPERA
description: EAST HADDAM ON March 1, when East Haddam's only guesthouse opened its doors for business, there was a distinctly familiar presence helping Julie Bishop, the owner, greet guests at her open house. Goodspeed Opera House patrons recognized Spring Fairbank presiding at the punch bowl. Miss Fairbank, who starred in the Goodspeed production of ''Very Good Eddie'' both in East Haddam and on Broadway, is a friend of the owner of the new guesthouse.

title: Long Island Journal
description: THE proverbial cookie seems to have crumbled somewhat for Girl Scouts and Brownies in Suffolk County, where annual cookie sales are off by 15 percent. Jean Cochran, Suffolk County council president, said that sales would continue until April 14, about two weeks longer than planned, to make up for the shortfall in anticipated revenues. Cookie sales provide approximately 65 percent of the council's $1.2 million annual budget.

title: Mrs. Melton's 77-216 Leads by 2
description: Nancy Lopez-Melton faltered with a five-over-par 77 today, but managed to maintain her two-stroke lead after three rounds of the $200,000 Desert Inn pro-am golf tournament.

title: U.S. Speaks of Replacing Its Advisers in Salvador
description: Defense Department officials, elaborating on their disclosure yesterday that 18 of the 54 United States advisers in El Salvador would return home in July after completing their training missions, said today that they could not rule out the possibility that the advisers would be replaced by new instructors.

title: Television Week
description: Trio of Superstars

title: Tumbling Interest Rate
description: Recent declines in the prime interest rate, currently hovering at 17 percent, have put the Federal Reserve back in the spotlight. Three months of high interest rates have slowed growth in monetary aggregates and dampened loan demand.

title: New Yorker Is Reported Choice for Envoy in Italy
description: White House sources in Washington said last night that President Reagan was expected to nominate Maxwell M. Rabb, a New York lawyer active in Jewish affairs, as ambassador to Italy.

title: POP MUSIC
description: Millie Jackson and Muddy Waters are more than singers; they are chroniclers of American mores. Miss Jackson, a salty soul singer who will be at Bond's International Casino, 44th and Broadway, on Monday and Tuesday, dispatches periodic reports from the sexual battlefield.

title: Philadelphia in A Familiar Fix
description: Philadelphia's public transit workers are among the quickest in the land to hit the bricks. Last weekend, 4,900 operators and mechanics walked off the job again - for the third time in six years - idling the public buses, trolleys and subways and leaving 400,000 commuters to make do with car pools and long-distance bike rides.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
THE IMPERFECTIONS OF THE BUDGET
description: FOR most of my life I have puzzled over the widespread view that the Federal budget should be balanced. Not one in 10 can describe the conceptual basis of the Federal budget, yet 70 percent think the bottom line should definitely be in black ink.

title: SUSAN ZIEGLER ENGAGED TO FREDERIC T. BARROWS
description: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Ziegler of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Glenn Ziegler, to Frederic T. Barrows, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin H. Barrows of Cincinnati. An Aug. 8 wedding is planned at the Talmadge Hill Community Church in Darien.

title: RIO STUMPED BY 'GREAT TRAIN ROBBER': WAS HE KIDNAPPED, OR WAS IT A HOAX?
description: Ronald Biggs, the best known of Britain's ''Great Train Robbers,'' was carried feet first out of a crowded barbecue restaurant at the foot of Sugar Loaf Mountain here Monday night, and the police have been trying to figure out since if the incident was a kidnapping or a publicity hoax.

title: FEAR LINKED TO KILLINGS RISES AMONG ATLANTA YOUTHS
description: Pamela Crumbey saw two men approaching as she and her little brother walked from school. She saw the men grab her brother. The 13-year-old girl fought the abductors futilely, her small fists flailing, as they took her 9-year-old brother away and left her in tears.

title: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Prudential offered to buy Bache for $385 million, or $32 a share. The move, which took Wall Street by surprise, was seen as a strategy by the big brokerage firm to head off an unwanted takeover by the Belzbergs, a Canadian family of investors. The move was also expected to touch off competition among insurance and other companies to increase their array of financial services, and some on Wall Street see more brokerage firms as takeover targets.

title: DOCTORS ANGRILY REJECT PACT TO END WALKOUT AT 7 MUNICIPAL HOSPITALS
description: Striking physicians-in-training at seven of New York City's municipal hospitals last night angrily and overwhelmingly rejected a tenative agreement to end their five-day walkout. The agreement had been worked out earlier in the day with the city by leaders of the physicians' union.

title: No Headline
description: The problems of the nursing profession might better be addressed if nurses were organized and truly represented.

title: CATHERINE BATTAGLIA WED
description: Catherine Ann Battaglia, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell J. Battaglia of New York and Point Lookout, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert John Frye, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Frye of Denver.

title: PENNY DASH BRIDE OF CARDIOLOGIST
description: A. Penny Dash and Dr. Alan G. Wasserman were married yesterday at the Warwick Hotel in New York, by Rabbi Albert L. Sturmer of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: A RADICAL BY INSTINCT
description: AT THE BARRICADES Forty Years on the Cutting Edge of History. By Wilfred Burchett. Introduction by Harrison E. Salisbury. 328 pp. New York: Times Books. $15. By THOMAS POWERS

title: Setting Sights On Rye-Bayville Bridge
description: It's a good thing for the people of Oyster Bay that Joseph Colby serves as the Town Supervisor and not the coroner. His pronouncement of death for legislative efforts to construct a Long Island Sound crossing by means of a bridge from Rye to Bayville was not only unfounded, but could instead sound a death knell for efforts by government, business and labor to revitalize a sagging Long Island economy.

title: About Westchester
description: SOMERS THERE was a time not too long ago when the school-age set regarded brawn as superior to brains. Sports were the ''in'' activity, and the intellectual was represented by the likes of Dilton Doily, a character in the Archie comic books who wore suits and ties and was considered the ultimate egghead.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Survivors. Almost every bookman has had the experience: Someone dashes up to him bearing a bulky manuscript and begs his assistance in getting it published. Seldom does such an encounter have a happy ending. Here are accounts of two exceptions, both centered around gutsy Irish women who, no matter what, managed to survive.

title: STALKING THE ELUSIVE RYE STATION
description: I AM unequivocally in favor of highway reform. Our representatives should enact legislation to reduce the number of, or do away with entirely, the multiple highways that parallel, crisscross and cloverleaf one another. In addition, they should put up better signs.

title: Sabres 6, Maple Leafs 2
description: Ric Seiling and Danny Gare, wings, scored two goals each to lead Buffalo.

title: FRAUD TIED TO RISING VISA ABUSE BY VISITORS TO U.S.
description: Showing visas obtained with bribes or fraudulent documents, hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants are openly entering the United States each year, posing as tourists, business executives or other visitors and then simply taking up residence in the ethnic neighborhoods of the nation's big cities.

title: A PRIVATE DETECTIVE FOR SMALL-TOWN CASES
description: KILLINGWORTH GEORGE F. FEELEY doesn't drive an old Thunderbird convertible and he doesn't live on a houseboat. He doesn't have a beach house in Malibu or an office on Sunset Strip. But he is a real private detective.

title: MANHASSET OPERA SHOWS ITS PROMISE
description: A COMMUNITY opera company when it started six years ago, giving performances in a local church parish hall to piano accompaniment, the Manhasset Bay Opera grows on. It attracts audiences from all over the Island, presenting talent with impressive and extensive professional credentials, and now boasts a full orchestra.

title: Dance View; TV'S RECENT LOOKS AT TAP AND NIJINSKY
description: No two dance presentations on public television would seem further apart than ''Nureyev and the Joffrey Ballet/In Tribute to Nijinsky,'' a part of the ''Dance in America'' series, and the film entitled ''No Maps On My Taps'' about three veteran tap dancers. Yet both were seen on WNET/Channel 13 recently, and in format, if not entirely in content, they share several of the same concerns.

title: Zoning and Safety On Route 347
description: With all due respect for John Luchsinger, who has indeed supported a restrained approach to the development of Route 347 (''Commercialization Stirs Town's Ire''), the proposed new zoning classification is a direct response to the citizens in the area and the pressure applied by local civic associations.

title: Florida Southern Wins N.C.A.A. Division II Title
description: John Ebeling scored 23 of his 29 points in the second half as Florida Southern built a 13-point lead and then held off Mount St. Mary's of Maryland, 73-68, tonight in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II championship basketball game at the Civic Center.

title: Miss Talavera Leads Qualifiers in Gymnastics
description: Tracee Talavera, shared two first places with her American teammate, Julianne McNamara, at the American Cup championships tonight and led all qualifiers into the all-round competition tomorrow.

title: Music; OPERA TROUPE OFFERS SAVOYARD AND POTPOURRI
description: ''IT certainly is off the beaten track for us,'' said Sheldon G. Gilgore, president of the Connecticut Grand Opera, about the company's presentation of ''An Evening With Gilbert and Sullivan'' at 8:15 P.M. on Saturday. ''But when we were designing this year's lineup, a lot of us on the board felt that, since our other operas were so somber - with the heroines always dying or going mad - we ought to try something in a lighter vein to balance the season.''

title: No Headline
description: I am grateful to Paula Span for her intelligent and accurate article.

title: INFIELDER WITH A JUMP SHOT
description: ATLANTA EVERY so often, Danny Ainge kept looking up at the big four-sided clock above the court at the Omni yesterday, checking to see how much time was left in the East Regional final that Brigham Young would lose to Virginia, 74-60, in the National Collegiate basketball tournament. But in another sense, it was how much time remained in his career in sneakers. When the game ended, Danny Ainge knew he soon would be on his way with his wife, Michelle, and their 15-month-old daughter Ashlee to Dunedin, Fla., where the Toronto Blue Jays were awaiting his arrival for spring training.

title: READERS DISPUTE WHY WOMEN EARN LESS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: SHE SINGS QUEEN MARY IN DONIZETTI AND MUSGRAVE
description: Several weeks ago Ashley Putnam stood tall over her music stand, working on a recitative in preparation for her performances of Donizetti's ''Maria Stuarda'' with the New York City Opera. Lots of light brown hair curled carelessly toward her shoulders, but the rest of her was riveted to the problem at hand, an ascending scale to a pianissimo high A. She was characteristically hard on herself: ''Yuck.''

title: JESSIE BRINKLEY ENGAGED TO GEORGE PACKARD
description: Jessie Atwell Brinkley, manager of the contributing membership program at the Smithsonian Institution, and George Randolph Packard, Dean of the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies, plan to be married in June.

title: Budget Panel Goes Reagan One Better
description: Beating all speed records, the Senate Budget Committee last week sliced through Federal social-service programs like a surgeon - or, depending on your perspective, a butcher. In three days of hacking and paring, the Republican-run committee adopted budget reductions totaling $36.4 billion for the coming fiscal year, $2.3 billion more than the President asked for.

title: PROFICIENCY TESTS IMPAIR LEARNING
description: THE results of the second annual ninth-grade proficiency test have been unveiled, and they have surprised no one. Nevertheless, they have been taken seriously.

title: PAIGE LAVENGOOD TO BE WED MAY 30
description: Dr. and Mrs. Russell Wilson Lavengood of Pelham, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Paige Lavengood, to Gordon Louis Heminway, son of Mrs. Norman Louis Heminway of Elkhart, Ind., and the late Dr. Heminway.

title: Maple Sugar
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadiens 5, Canucks 3
description: Robert Picard, Larry Robinson and Mark Napier scored second-period goals to help Montreal extend its home undefeated streak to 23 games.

title: Antonio Baciero, Pianist, Plays Cabezon and Bach
description: Antonio Baciero, a 44-year-old Spanish pianist, created a gentle, refined tone as he began his debut concert in Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday evening. The piano sounded like a clavichord.

title: MYSTICS ON THE POTOMAC
description: One insider's joke making the rounds here these days among the top Reagan officials is: ''Don't just stand there -undo something!'' And when Murray Lew Weidenbaum, the new chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, is asked how he feels about the future of the Administration's recovery program, he says: ''I'm not pessimistic, I'm not optimistic, I'm a mystic.''

title: MUSTANG REKINDLES A FLAME
description: MAYBE it's just me, but it seems that brand loyalty has gone the way of cheap gasoline and a free windshield wash at the corner station.

title: SPAIN'S DEMOCRATS SEEKING A BRIDGE OVER THE PYRENEES
description: Jittery Spanish democrats are trying to speed their country's entry into the European Economic Community to deter nostalgic generals from attempting a rerun of last month's failed putsch. And, to give soldiers a higher purpose than conspiracy, Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo's center-right Government hopes, too, to hustle Spain into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Long Islanders; A YOUTHFUL DECISION ALTERS A LIFE'S TONE
description: ''I NEVER set out to be a businessman,'' said Velvel Pasternak of Cedarhurst. ''I was never interested in business.'' But by way of an education toward the rabbinate and a talent for music, the 47-yearold Mr. Pasternak has turned out to be deeply involved in business - the business of Jewish music.

title: EMPLOYMENT FOR BLACK AND HISPANIC RESIDENTS AT LOW EBB
description: WITHIN a few blocks of the gleaming corporate office towers that distinguish Hartford and Stamford, Connecticut has a serious unemployment problem. Despite vigorous economic conditions and slow population growth, which have kept the state's unemployment rate below the national average for four years, joblessness remains at Depression levels among portions of Connecticut's black and Hispanic population.

title: THE CULTURES OF THE ALTIPLANO
description: Approaching the 11,909-foot-high city of La Paz, Bolivia, by air offers a bird's eye view of the Andes. Flying south from Lima, Peru, you pass over the brown and barren mountains before spying Lake Titicaca, 110 miles long and 35 wide, northwest of La Paz. As the plane banks to make its landing, a crop of jagged, snow-covered peaks comes into view. Then you see the city in a thousand-foot-deep natural basin in the Cordillera Real. Although the peaks seem menacingly close, the plane eases onto the runway at El Alto Airport, which is perched at 13,300 feet on the rim of a high plateau overlooking the city.

title: OLD TENSIONS SURFACE IN QUEBEC ELECTION CAMPAIGN
description: With the campaign for the April 13 elections for a new government in Quebec a week old, many of the tensions that bedevil this French-speaking province and Canadian society have come to the surface and embittered the debate. Premier Rene Levesque of Quebec is telling the voters he is not a racist, and the Liberal Party leader Claude Ryan is telling them he is not a traitor.

title: RENTAL PRODUCTION AT POSTWAR LOW
description: Unsubsidized rental housing starts and completions last year were the lowest annual production figures since World War II, according to a national housing survey conducted by the Advance Mortgage Corporation of Detroit, a mortgage banking affiliate of Oppenheimer & Company.

title: THE HARTMAN REVIVES MOLIERE
description: STAMFORD WHEN Edwin Sherin talks of giving audiences ''a dose of very, very big productions,'' he means it. Look at ''Moliere in Spite of Himself,'' the second of four plays in Mr. Sherin's first season as artistic director of the Hartman Theater. Here is a panoramic, kaleidoscopic, cinematically conceived spectacle that realizes, unstintingly, Mr. Sherin's expressed intention of making ''a large and bold theatrical statement for the year.'' It is also a play with levels of meaning appropriate to a regional theater fighting for recognition and survival.

title: Dutch Officials to Meet Reagan
description: Prime Minister Andreas A.M. van Agt and Foreign Minister Christoph A. van der Klaauw will visit Washington on April 1 for talks with President Reagan, Mr. van Agt said last night.

title: GIRDING THE GYPSY MOTH
description: CONCERN about another severe onslaught of gypsy moths this year drew hundreds of area residents to two recent public seminars on methods of controlling the destructive insect.

title: Westark Junior College Victor
description: Brian Kellibrew scored 26 points to lead Westark of Arkansas to a 67-50 triumph over Lincoln of Illinois tonight in the championship game of the 34th National Junior College basketball tournament.

title: MINI-SCHOOLS SEEK TO DRAW NONMINORITY SCHOOLS
description: Between East Harlem and the more affluent Upper East Side, a cluster of new public mini-schools has been seeking the attention of parents who want ''innovative programs'' with ''a private-school approach'' for their children.

title: 7 ARE INJURED BY ROCKS AS CONNECTICUT RALLY BY KLAN IS BROKEN UP
description: A march by 23 white-robed members of the Ku Klux Klan was routed by rock-throwing counterdemonstrators this afternoon. At least seven persons, including several Klan members and police officers, were treated at a local hospital for injuries they received in the melee.

title: National Gallery to Set Up A Graphic-Art Archive
description: A gift of contemporary American graphic art will establish an archive at the National Gallery of Art, the director of the gallery, J. Carter Brown, has announced.

title: GENESIS, DARWIN AND HUMAN FALLIBILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: POST-MODERN DANCE TAKES SPOTLIGHT
description: BAYVILLE TURNING another avant-garde leaf, the Intermedia Arts Center is scheduling Contemporary Dance Spectrum, a highly ambitious series of modern-dance performances, films and videotapes, that will begin here Thursday and run through April 25.

title: Cost of First-Class Mail Increases to 18 Today
description: Postal rates are scheduled to rise tomorrow for the fifth time in 10 years, and another increase may be waiting in the wings.

title: Two Drive-In Banks Bombed
description: Explosions ripped through two drive-in bank facilities in small towns near Farmington early today, causing extensive da mage, a highway patrol spokesman said. The bombs damaged the Mercantile Drive-In Bank in Leadington, Mo., about 65 miles southwest of St. Louis, and the Commerce Drive-In Bank in nearby Desloge.

title: SUSAN MCWILLIAMS, LIBRARIAN, BRIDE OF SURESH BHIRUD
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church yesterday Susan E. McWilliams, periodicals librarian at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was married to Suresh L. Bhirud, a vice president of the First Boston Corporation in New York. The Rev. Herbert Anderson performed the ceremony.

title:
MAILBOX;
A Cure for Boxing: Ban the Knockout
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Speaking Personally; WHEN A PICTURE IS WORTH MORE THAN A THOUSAND WORDS
description: DAN, my 5-year-old son, often does things that remind me of myself at that age. Yesterday, I watched him play in the backyard with our neighbor's deaf son.

title: ELIZABETH BISSELL TO BE WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving B. Kingsford of Titusville, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Kingsford's daughter, Elizabeth Bissell, to Alan Moore Campbell, son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Colin Camobell of Bernardsville, N.J. Miss Bissell is a daughter also of Louis G. Bissell Jr. of Stamford, Conn. A May 9 wedding is planned.

title: TV View; DISTRESS SIGNALS AT CHANNEL 13
description: It was ''Mother Wore Tights'' that finally got to me. For at least a year now, I have been increasingly dismayed by certain trends in the public-television schedule, which, as far as viewing habits in the metropolitan New York area are concerned, largely means the schedule of WNET/13, a small but decidedly powerful entity within the Public Broadcasting Service. One of the trends in question involved the repackaging of old movies. WNET/13 suddenly seemed bent on becoming the electronic equivalent of the Thalia or New Yorker movie houses in Manhattan, conveniently forgetting that television is capable of creating and refining its own forms, that the medium does not have to be a mere conduit for old films.

title: Art; PRINTMAKERS' ART ON VIEW AT RUTGERS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK LIKE other enterprises, the art world is guilty of overkill. When it finds a popular, saleable item, it will go to almost any lengths to merchandise it and inundate our galleries and museums.

title: The Tarnish on Copper
description: Declining interest rates, tender offers and the rattle of sabers have been a boon to copper prices lately. After dipping to 77 cents a pound on the futures market early this month, prices have rebounded more than 10 percent, and talk of 90-cent contracts is surfacing.

title: READERS DISPUTE WHY WOMEN EARN LESS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Westchester Housing; A VIEW OF SIX SOLAR SUPERSAVERS
description: IF reading about solar homes and their small fuel bills makes you grouchy, taking the Mount Pleasant League of Women Voters solar-home tour next Sunday may make you feel worse. Some of the new houses are almost sinfully self-sufficient. Others - older houses with conservation improvements - induce more moderate levels of jealousy. But no matter what your reaction, the houses being opened to the public may suggest solutions to an energy crisis in your own home, which is what the league has in mind.

title: OPPONENTS STEP UP ATTACKS ON SCHOOL BUSING PLANS
description: After being almost stalled in recent years, busing as a vehicle for school desegregation now shows signs of shifting into reverse.

title: CABARET: LU ELLIOTT AT COOKERY
description: Since 85-year-old Alberta Hunter collapsed from exhaustion after a performance several weeks ago at the Cookery, East Eighth Street at University Place, where she has been singing for three and a half years, several stopgap performers have filled in for her. Now Barney Josephson, the owner of the Cookery, thinks he has found a suitable replacement for Miss Hunter.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
Home Resale Market: Pattern Shifts
description: IT IS not news that the home resale market has been less than active in the last few months. What is news is that many of the sales are being arranged beyond the ken of traditional mortgage lenders, such as savings and loans and savings banks.

title: ELEANOR EARLE FIANCE OF MARK MASCHERONI
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Earle 2d of Haverford, Pa., and Narragansett, R.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor Forbes Earle, to Mark Mascheroni, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Mascheroni of New York and Easthampton, L.I. A May 30 wedding is planned.

title:
On the Isle;
MUSICAL SUNDAYS
description: If it's Sunday, it must be time to visit the local library - not for books necessarily, but for a free concert. And all over the Island today, there are enough musical programs to entice varied appetites. For example, at 2:30 P.M. Martha Schrempel, a pianist who participated in last summer's Beethoven Festival at Planting Fields, will play at the Massapequa Library, 40 Harbor Lane in Massapequa Park. At the same time at the Great Neck Library on Bayview Avenue, the Trio Sonata, an ensemble of flute, oboe and classical guitar, will perform Baroque, classical and contemporary sonatas.

title: Man and Woman Found Shot to Death in Jersey
description: A young New Jersey man and woman were found shot to death in the woman's car off the Garden State Parkway near Sayreville, N.J., early yesterday, the New Jersey State Police reported. There were no known witnesses, no weapon was found and the motive for the slayings was unclear, the police said.

title: APPEALS COURT EQUALIZES UNION DUES FOR ALL ACTORS
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has confirmed an order that Actors Equity discontinue its two-tiered dues policy, which requires that foreign actors pay higher dues than citizens.

title: Travel Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Arezzo
description: To the Editor:

title: YANKS, ASTROS FAVORED
description: The New York Yankees and the Houston Astros are favored to win the pennants of their respective leagues, according to odds compiled by Harrah's Reno Race and Sports Book.

title: Men's Wear for Women
description: The chic of men's clothes for women is anything but ''throwaway'' (''Borrowed From Men,'' by Mary Russell, Feb. 22).

title: Congress and the Reagan Cannonball
description: The Gallup Poll says President Reagan is less popular after eight weeks in office than any of his recent predecessors. There's no sign of that in Congress. For weeks, the spotlight has been on the vaunted Reagan economic program. There has been briefing after briefing. Budget Director David Stockman has made the cover of most national magazines. Not until last week did Congress finally get its first crack at the program.

title: FORBES BUYS SALON PANELS OF NORMANDIE FOR $90,000
description: Malcolm S. Forbes was extremely busy yesterday afternoon. At noon he entertained about 40 guests at a pre-wedding luncheon party for his son Robert Laidlow Heritage Forbes, a photographer, and his fiancee, Lydia Appel Raurell-Soto, held at the publisher's town house at 13th Street and Fifth Avenue. They dined on salmon mousse, filet of beef Bordelaise, asparagus and new potatoes, sipping champagne all the while.

title: A Fatal Aftermath For Shuttle Test
description: Considering all the things that might have gone wrong last week as the men and machines of America's space shuttle program rehearsed countdown procedures at Cape Canaveral, Fla., the thing that did go wrong was fatally unexpected. Two hours after the test successfully ended, five technicians entered a nitrogen-filled engine compartment in the spacecraft.

title: A SCHOOL WHERE HOPE A PASSING GRADE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK LILLIAN TOMMOSONE knew something was wrong with her son, Michael, by the time he was 20 months old. He was not walking, crawling or talking and his behavior - he banged his head against the wall, screamed and rocked back and forth almost incessantly - was bizarre. Worse, Mrs. Tommosone recalled, Michael seemed to be in a world of his own.

title: LIEUT. ERIC J. NELSON, A PILOT, WEDS MARGARET WALKER ALLEN
description: Margaret Walker Allen and Lieut. Eric Jeffrey Nelson, U.S.A., were married yesterday at St. Luke's Epsicopal Church in Darien, Conn., by the Rev. David Watson Boulton, the bride's uncle, and the Rev. Walter H. Taylor.

title: GRANTS EXTEND A LIFETIME WORK
description: NEW HAVEN AT age 83 and 15 years after his retirement as professor of English at Yale, Frederick A. Pottle arrives about 9 A.M. each weekday at the university's Gothic-style Sterling Memorial Library.

title: Spending Drought Foreseen
description: After months of defying logic which holds that high interest rates and declining disposable income should make spending levels shrink, not rise, many economists think conditions are ripe for a drop in consumer spending. Price-cutting campaigns in automobile showrooms and department stores, two areas of strength this winter, are not expected to continue.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Rosedale Parents Lose Final Round
description: It came down to a choice between allaying anxieties and enforcing rights, and a Federal judge last week chose the latter, denying a motion to reopen the mostly white Rosedale annex to Intermediate School 231 in Queens. The decision by District Judge Edward R. Neaher dashed the last hope of the Rosedale parents, most of them white, who had held their children out of school since Jan. 30 to protest the annex's closing and the transfer of its 326 students to the main building.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK CITY'S DECLINE IN MANUFACTURING GAINED MOMENTUM IN 1980
description: The falloff in manufacturing in New York City accelerated in 1980, according to the regional commissioner of Labor Statistics. He said the number of people employed in industries dropped below the halfmillion mark to set a record low.

title: Antiques; VICTORIAN SILVER TO BE AUCTIONED
description: Last year Victorian silver was the subject both of a major exhibition at the New-York Historical Society and an important book by Mary Grace and Charles H. Carpenter, Jr. Both bore the same title,''Tiffany Silver,'' and both attracted enthusiastic audiences.

title: LISA HEDSTROM STANLEY MARRIED TO ROSS WINTER
description: Lisa Hedstrom Stanley and Ross Gilbert Winter, both of Short Hills, N.J., were married there yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. David B. Earnest.

title: SHUTTLE PROBLEM LAID TO WORKMANSHIP
description: After a two-month investigation, space agency engineers have determined that poor workmanship, rather than design or materials defects, was primarily responsible for large patches of insulation tearing loose from the external fuel tank of the space shuttle Columbia in tests in January at the launching pad in Florida.

title: Gretzky Sets Record For Assists
description: Wayne Gretzky scored his 52d goal and had four assists as the Oilers played to a 6-6 tie with the Los Angeles Kings last night in Edmonton, Alberta. Gretzky set a league record for assists by a center and took a step toward breaking an even more important record.

title: TROOP ISSUE SNARLS MADRID CONFERENCE
description: With its target date for finishing already overshot by two weeks, the Madrid conference on human rights and cooperation in Europe is deadlocked over conflicting East-West approaches to a proposed subsequent meeting to discuss mutual notification procedures for military maneuvers.

title:
MAILBOX;
Trading Henderson Was a Met Mistake
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: JUDITH ELLEN FISHER MARRIED TO JONATHAN FURER IN JERSEY
description: Judith Ellen Fisher and Jonathan Russell Furer, graduates of George Washington University, were married yesterday at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi James Perman of Mount Vernon, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: CHURCH IN SALVADOR NOW FOLLOWS THE MIDDLE PATH
description: One year ago Tuesday, Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero was delivering a homily at a funeral mass when he was shot and killed by an unidentified gunman. The archbishop, a humble and courageous man, had been a harsh critic of Government repression. His assassination, presumably by the right, outraged the world, galvanized the Salvadoran left and appeared to commit the country's Roman Catholic Church to the path of revolution.

title: MOVING IMAGES: INVISIBLE ON CAMPUS
description: HERE it is 1981, and most public, private and parochial schools still do not offer any single course, required or elective, dealing with student analysis of the moving visual image.

title: Banking
description: To the Business Editor:

title: 6,000 MARCOS FOES PROTEST AT MANILA RALLY
description: Thousands of opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos rallied here tonight to denounce amendments to the Constitution that they contended would institutionalize his rule.

title: SPECIAL SCHOOL DUE AT COINDRE HALL
description: AFTER seven years, Suffolk County may at last have found a tenant for Coindre Hall, a 31-acre estate overlooking Huntington Harbor. The Eagle Hill School for Learning Disabled Children intends to open at the hall in September, according to Dr. James Cavanaugh, director of the Eagle Hill Foundation. He said was satisfied with the site and financing.

title: PIANO STATESMEN DISPLAY THEIR STYLES
description: Arthur Rubinstein, Vladimir Horowitz, Wilhelm Kempff and Claudio Arrau are among the most prominent piano personalities of the 20th century, each boasting a career that spans from 60 to 75 years. Recent recordings from all four of these elder statesmen vividly demonstrate some of the reasons why they have held concertgoers in thrall for over three generations. Interpretively, these pianists could not be more various in their ideas and artistic goals, but they all express extremely individual and provocative points of view.

title: IS THE GOLDEN AGE OF GARBAGE UPON US?
description: ''ONE word, son: Garbage!'' That's the sage advice that the businessman probably would give Ben (Dustin Hoffman) if the script for the 1968 film ''The Graduate'' were written today.

title: FIRST EDITION: AN INFORMAL GLOSSARY OF REAGANOMICS
description: IT all started with the idea that high taxes are a drag. Cutting them, goes the theory, gives people more incentive to work, save and invest. Such pushing on the supply-side of the economy, instead of pulling on the demand side, will reduce inflation. But cutting taxes at a time of mammoth Governent deficits, which themselves contribute to inflation, requires cutting Government spending. Otherwise, the lost revenues might merely rekindle inflation.

title: REAGAN BUDGET FORCING REGION TO RETHINK GOALS
description: President Reagan's proposed budget retrenchments have led state and local governments in the New York metropolitan area to re-examine social and economic programs that have been virtual articles of faith since the 1960's.

title: Nepal Sets May 9 as Date For First Elections Since '59
description: The election commission announced today that the first elections in 22 years would be held May 9.

title: THE NORTHWEST GATE TO CHINA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- R. V. DENENBERG is traveling and writing as a fellow of the Alicia Patterson Foundation. By R.V.DENENBERG

title: SENATE IS ASKED TO RATIFY TREATY ON ALASKA SEAL KILL
description: The Senate is being asked to ratify a treaty permitting the killing of thousands of seals in Alaska, over protests by some conservationists that the practice is an ''annual rite of slaughter.'' But other conservationists, including the Humane Society of the United States, say the treaty will prevent a far worse slaughter in the open sea.

title: LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE: GETTING MATERIALS TO BUILDING SITE
description: At 2:40 on a recent rainy afternoon, a secretary brought a telephone message to Robert Fee, project executive of the Turner Construction Company, at his noisy, temporary sheetrock-and-plywood office on the third-floor level of the 43-story I.B.M. building at 56th Street and Madison Avenue.

AN ENTICING exhibition of American art of the 1930's and 40's is on view at the State Museum, where it will remain through April 19. The show, ''American Abstract Artists: The Early Years,'' focuses on a number of abstract painters who, ignored by New York City's museums and galleries, formed a group to exhibit their work themselves.

title: CONSUMER RATES
7 Council Committees Will Meet This Week
description: The following City Council meetings, including those of seven Council committees, have been scheduled for this week: MONDAY - Committee on State Legislation, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Public Safety, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. TUESDAY - Committee on Governmental Operations, 250 Broadway, 23d floor, 1:30 P.M. WEDNESDAY - Committee on Civil Service and Labor, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Finance, City Hall, noon; Committee on Rules, Privileges and Elections, City Hall, 2:30 P.M.

title: U.S. TO CRACK DOWN ON MISUSE OF FUNDS
description: A White House spokesman said today that, as part of President Reagan's attack on waste and fraud in the Government, the Administration would soon announce a number of criminal and civil actions charging misuse of Federal funds.

title: Faceless Funds
description: The Coalition for a New Beginning, the private campaign to sell President Reagan's economic program to America, is dead, a victim of too much demand on the supply side. Big giv-ers coughed up $800,000 before some tightwads killed the plan with their complaints about high-pressure fund-raising.

title: Mt. Vernon Wins Title
description: Mount Vernon routed Bay Shore of Long Island, 96-64, today and won the New York State Eastern Class A basketball championship. The victory was Mount Vernon's 26th against one loss; Bay Shore finished at 22-3. The victors were led by Ricky Burton's 25 points.

title: No Headline
description: My interest in Paula Span's article is not only due to the fact that I am a registered nurse, but, as a member of the Maryland General Assembly, it was my privilege to sponsor legislation last year which created a Commission on Nursing Issues. Throughout our investigation of nursing in Maryland, we will take a broad look at what the definition of nursing is in our society and how that definition affects and is altered by (1) the evolution of the doctor-nurse relationship from hierarchical to collaborative practice, and (2) the shift in our health-care institutions from long-term care to acute-care facilities. MARILYN GOLDWATER, R.N., Chairman, Commission on Nursing Issues, House of Delegates, Annapolis, Md.

title: W.B.L. Fillies Walk Out And Draw a Suspension
description: Members of the Minnesota Fillies were suspended indefinitely tonight after they left the floor before a scheduled Women's Professional Basketball League game against the Chicago Hustle, apparently in a protest over unpaid wages and other disputes with management.

title: RANDI MALLEN IS MARRIED TO CLIFFORD LANE AT PIERRE
description: Randi Mallen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman J. Mallen of West Orange, N.J., was married at the Pierre last evening to Clifford P. Lane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard C. Lane of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbis Harold Mozeson and Robert S. Widom officiated.

title: ELEANOR KIRBY MCMANUS IS WED TO J. GARY MOFFAT
description: In the Heinz Chapel on the campus of the University of Pittsburgh yesterday morning, Eleanor Kirby McManus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. McManus of Pittsburgh, formerly of Short Hills, N.J., became the bride of J. Gary Moffat, son of Mr. and Mrs. ohn W. Moffat Jr. of Delray Beach, Fla. The Rev. John Gallagher, a Roman Catholic priest performed the ceremony.

title: GREETING THE THAWING PERIOD
description: THE days lengthen, snowbanks snuggle down, ice goes out of the ponds and weeping willows start yellowing to the shade of watery mustard ... flowering snowdrops blooming amid ground ivy as the vagaries of weather cause their petals to throw wide-open arms for sunshine's warmth ... an optimistic renter of fishing skiffs at Norwalk's Hickory Bluffs putting out moorings already and turning his boats bottom up on sawhorses for the coming season's need for antifouling copper paint ... dogs, their biological clocks at work, running loose, seemingly everywhere ... beach strollers hand-in-hand watching others in Rowayton hand-feeding Canada geese, black ducks, cautious gulls and even a pair of swans whose belligerence matches their grace and beauty ... a brave jogger wearing shorts, a sloop under sail and an old convertible greeting the thawing period with its top down ... impatient yachtsmen visiting boatyards to check on the cocoon-like winter covers they had placed on their craft at last season's end ... as the calendar's countdown goes on, the birds seem more excited than usual, perhaps in some romantic anticipation while, in the silence of the night and in the wake of a great, swollen snow moon, there comes a sudden flurry of snow that is a reminder that winter is still here even if spring has arrived.

title: BLATENT IN CITY, LATENT ON ISLAND?
description: ONE morning as I ascended the steps leading from Penn Station on my way to work, a fistfight erupted directly in front of me on Seventh Avenue. The young combatants, one black and one white, clearly felt that mere physical punishment would not suffice, for they commenced to assault one another with every racial epithet known to man, and a handful of new ones invented especially for the occasion.

title: 2 SLAIN BY OFFICERS IN SEPARATE CASES
description: An off-duty policeman shot and killed a 19-year-old cook as he allegedly attempted to hold up a Howard Johnson's restaurant in the Bronx Friday night and an officer on patrol killed a 30-year-old knife-wielding burglary suspect after a block and a half chase in Queens at 4:30 A.M. yesterday.

title: SCRAP METAL
description: Sagging fortunes in the nation's steel mills and foundries caused a 13 percent reduction in domestic purchases of scrap iron and steel last year. In spite of declining conditions in steel industries overseas, export demand for American scrap remained comparatively buoyant and rose 1 percent. For the year, total sales amounted to more than $6 billion.

title: SPY STORIES
description: THE EMPIRE BLUES By Taylor Branch. 408 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: MEDICAL OFFICERS SEARCH FOR KEYS TO L.I. DISEASES
description: MINEOLA SURROUNDED by detailed maps and trend charts, Dr. Norman Schell, Deputy Health Commissioner of Nassau County, pointed to markers denoting the incidence of such public enemies as meningitis, hepatitis, influenza, measles and venereal diseases.

title: THE AUSTRIAN ECONOMY IS A STRAUSS WALTZ
description: EVERY February at the famous Vienna Opera Ball, the season's debutantes, dressed in white with little silver crowns on their heads, perform a waltz with elaborate ritualistic pirouettes around a specially constructed dance floor in the Vienna opera house. Their formal entry into society - for which each father has paid $700 - is then made with sweeping curtsies to the gilt-encrusted red velvet imperial box where Emperor Franz Josef once sat. In it today sit the applauding members of Chancellor Bruno Kriesky's Socialist Government, in white tie and tails, sipping champagne.

title: Setting a Price on Rights Violations
description: The case has spanned a full swing of the pendulum. In the early 70's, the Federal Bureau of Investigation illegally wiretapped, opened the mail and burglarized the homes of five people, watching for associations with Weather Underground fugitives.

title: Dining Out; PLEASANT FARE AT BARGAIN PRICES
description: BRANFORD THE Bittersweet Cafe, a tiny, unpretentious restaurant, is one of a number of enterprises that form Bittersweet Farm, a cluster of shingle-sided buildings housing potters, woodworkers and other artisans.

title: An Unofficial Ambassador for Tennis
description: PRINCETON ''GOOD MORNING, Mr. Ambassador, how was your trip?'' When he hears that greeting at the United States Tennis Association's Education and Research Center here, Doug MacCurdy smiles and waves his racquet at the kibitzers.

title: EQUAL PAY DEBATE NOW SHIFTS TO A FAR WIDER CONCEPT
description: The time has passed when the slogan ''equal pay for equal work'' had a radical ring. The notion that men and women should get the same pay for doing the same work is the law of the land, embodied in the Equal Pay Act of 1963. While compliance is not universal, the concept is one to which even opponents of the Equal Rights Amendment pay at least lip service.

title: 'BIG BROTHER' IS RACING '1984' DEADLINE
description: GEORGE Orwell's novel, ''1984,'' exploded onto the American scene in 1949. The war was over. People were getting re-established. Troops had come home. Readjustment to a normal life was the prime objective. ''1984'' -hardly the type of book demanded of the times - was hardly written to satisfy folk wishing to forget living under wartime government controls. The book's chilling vision of life in a totalitarian society was startling. It stunned millions who could not believe such a way of life would ever develop. It shocked thousands who saw that such a society was possible but thought it would never come about in their lifetime.

title: THE NATION IN SUMMARY
description: President Reagan took the time on his travels to Capitol Hill last week to challenge the Congressional Budget Office on its home ground. He used the word ''phony'' (though later he said he shouldn't have) for the agency's assertion that the White House may have undercounted 1982 Federal costs by as much as $25 billion. ''Actually what they (the figures) really are,'' the President went on, more judiciously, ''is differing assumptions'' about the future course of the economy.

title: A BREED APART: BUILDING A BETTER COW
description: ADVANCED breeding techniques have transformed much of the United States livestock industry, producing such wonders as the dairy cow that produces two and one-half times as much milk as her foremothers only 30 years ago, and the commercial turkey, a creature so top-heavy that it can no longer mate naturally. These made-to-order meat and milk machines were made possible in part by nothing more exotic than the simple technique of artificial insemination, which enables the best of a breed to reproduce on a scale beyond nature's wildest fantasies.

title: Flyers 4, Black Hawks 4
description: Reggie Leach's goal with 3:46 gone in the third period gave Philadelphia the tie. Leach's goal, his 34th, came on a slap shot from the right boards past Tony Esposito, the Chicago goalie.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: JULIUS J. ABESON
description: Julius J. Abeson, a lawyer who specialized in bankruptcy matters and was counsel to the New York City law firm of Hahn & Hessen, died yesterday of cancer in Roosevelt Hospital. Mr. Abeson, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 78 years old.

title: EDUCATORS, REBUTTING REAGAN, OPPOSE CUT IN FUNDS FOR JOB TRAINING
description: President Reagan's suggestion that many people who are unemployed are ignoring available jobs has been challenged by officials of the American Vocational Association, an organization of teachers and administrators of vocational education.

title: March 22, 1981
description: NONFICTION AT THE BARRICADES: Forty Years on the Cutting Edge of History. By Wilfred Burchett. 12 GEORGE ORWELL: A Life. By Bernard Crick. 1 GRANT: A Biography.

title: OUTCRY OVER RAPE CASE ACQUITTAL PROMPTS HEARING ON HAWAII LAW
description: In response to the public outcry following the acquittal of four youths charged with raping a tourist, the Hawaiian Legislature will hold a public hearing next week to consider amending the law covering sexual assaults.

title: BONDS THAT AREN'T MERE BONDS
description: NOT so long ago, corporate bonds were a pretty humdrum investment. The customer bought them, clipped the coupons and went about his business.

title: New Jersey Guide; BENEFIT FOR CHANNEL 13
description: Frederica von Stade, the young Metropolitan Opera mezzo-soprano from Somerville who rapidly became an international star, will return Friday for a concert in Trenton.

title: READERS DISPUTE WHY WOMEN EARN LESS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Headliners; Higher Aptitude
description: Critics have long contended that the Educational Testing Service, like Ozymandias, has feet of clay; now Daniel Lowen, a 17-year-old Florida high school student, has proved it.

title: MY LOVE AFFAIR WITH ENGLISH
description: From time to time The Book Review has invited both new and established writers to comment on various aspects of their craft: their imaginative and autobiographical sources, their practices of composition, their experience of the literary culture. These essays are intended to provide a forum for American writers to consider the rewards and perils of their vocation.

title: CASINO REGULATIONS LIKELY TO BYE EASED
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE gambling-casino industry received strong indications from regulators and leaders of both political parties last week that the state's Casino Control Act would be amended and Casino Control Commission rules relaxed.

title: AIRLINE FILES COMPLAINT IN NEAR-COLLISION INQUIRY
description: Argentine Airlines has filed a strong complaint with the Federal Aviation Administration in that agency's inquiry into why an Argentine jet descended so low it threatened to hit a television mast atop a World Trade Center tower in lower Manhattan the night of Feb. 20.

title: ASBESTOS ACCORD REACHED
description: NEW LISBON THE state's Department of Human Services and unionized employees at the New Lisbon State School for the mentally retarded have agreed to a plan under which the union will begin testing airborne asbestos levels.

title: IN EAST HARLEM, INTEREST FOCUSES ON HOUSING SITES
description: The gradual improvement in housing in the East 90's has led to reports of land assemblages for possible future construction north of 96th Street, the southern boundary of East Harlem.

title: ROGER SESSIONS, NEARING 85, IS STILL A MAVERICK COMPOSER
description: Within America's cadre of distinguished octogenarian composers, Roger Sessions counts as among the most venerable; indeed, there are those who have excitedly proclaimed him America's greatest composer. Mr. Sessions's music has never entered the mainstream, however, which has been taken by some as a sign of its intractability and by others as proof of its purity. But things may be changing. In the last decade more of his music has appeared in print than in the previous decades combined. More of it is being performed, too, and not just by worthy outsiders who have made it their mission to champion it.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MARCH 22, 1981
description: International Talks to prevent a national strike in Poland tomorrow were scheduled to start today between the Solidarity union and the Government. Workers called for a general strike following the police attack on union activists in the city of Bydoszcz last week. Lech Walesa, Solidarity's leader, told several thousand union members who gathered in Warsaw that ''we want to settle the problem without further conflict,'' and that Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski ''can be trusted.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) Despite ''outright pacifist sentiments'' in Europe, the United States is determined to deal with the Soviet Union from a position of strength, President Reagan's national security adviser said in an address on the ''mood of Europe'' before the Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington. This was Richard V. Allen's first formal public statement since the Reagan Administration took office. (1:5.)

title:
Stamps;
U.S. GOING FROM A TO ?
description: Not long ago Columbia put out a simultaneous issue of some 30 stamps with each one bearing a letter of the alphabet. Moving much more slowly - a letter at a time - the United States may eventually also run through the alphabet, if inflation persists and the cost of stamps keeps going up.

title: TRISTATE: 'NEW DIRECTIONS'
description: THE Tri-State Regional Planning Commission, a planning organization for New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, drew renewed attention recently after a blue-ribbon task force, appointed by the Governors of the three states to investigate ''mounting criticism,'' issued a 223-page report, ''New Directions for Regional Planning.''

title: First Ski Trip
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Attack Stirs Tensions in Poland
description: Discussion degenerated into violence in Poland last week for the first time in eight and a half months of labor unrest. Riot policemen in the city of Bydgoszcz evicted farmers and trade union supporters from a provincial assembly hall where they had gathered to present their case for a rural union; three of them were badly beaten and had to be hospitalized.

title: J.K. GLEN IS FIANCE OF SHARON E. COE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Coe of White Plains, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Elizabeth Coe, to Jonathan Keilder Glen of London, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Glen, Brig O'Turk, Perthshire, Scotland.

title: Leisure; PLAN A RAINBOW OF SUMMER PERENNIALS
description: Perennial borders are filled with colorful exuberance in spring. By July, those, not already packed with annuals, look dispirited. There is no need to fret. Dozens of showy perennials shown now in catalogues can take the garden out of summer doldrums. They can be ordered now or plans can be made to purchase plants later in spring from local nurseries and garden centers.

title: Haliburton Fales Named Head of Morgan Library
description: The appointment of Haliburton Fales 2d as president of the Morgan Library has been announced by the trustees of the library. For the first time in its history the library has a president who is not a member of the Morgan family.

title: SHAKESPEARE GENDRIFIED
description: SHAKESPEARE'S DIVISION OF EXPERIENCE By Marilyn French. 376 pp. New York: Summit Books. $15.95.

title: BRENDA TURNBULL, ROBERT TOMASKO TO WED ON MAY 9
description: Dr. and Mrs. William W. Turnbull of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Brenda Jean Turnbull, to Robert Michael Tomasko, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael O. Tomasko of Drexel Hill, Pa. A May 9 wedding is planned.

title: THEFT AND FRAUD IN FINE ART
description: BURNISHED by publicity and promotion, the art market has acquired the reputation among many investors as an almost-sure thing. Indeed, the multimillion-dollar sales that are reported on the television news shows and in newspapers are often cited as further evidence of ''the art boom.''

title: LAURIE ANN IMPERATORE A BRIDE
description: Laurie Ann Imperatore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Imperatore of Great Neck, L.I., was married there yesterday afternoon to Charles H. Kenney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenney of Canandaigua, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the bride's brother, The Rev. Geoffrey R. Imperatore, an Episcopal priest, who was assisted by the rector, the Rev. Gary E. Maier. The bride's father, who is a sales executive with Robinson-Lloyds Ltd., distributors of wine in Batavia, N.Y., and Hicksville, L.I., is a former Mayor of the Village of Great Neck.

title: MISS LANDOW AND A LAWYER TO WED MAY 2
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Landow of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Harolyn Sue Landow, to Michael H. Cardozo 5th of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cardozo of Washington. A May 2 wedding is planned at the Washington (D.C.) Hebrew Congregation.

title: TWO POLITICAL LIVES
description: GEORGE ORWELL A Life. By Bernard Crick. Illustrated. 473 pp. Boston: Atlantic-Little, Brown. $17.95.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: On Language; DO YOU SPEAK ASPIC?
description: Do You Speak Aspic? Kimble Mead

title: TURNABOUT FOR ATLANTA BALLET
description: The Atlanta Ballet, which was founded in 1929, likes to call itself America's oldest ballet company. And it very probably is, for the only other notable contenders to the title are the Metropolitan Opera Ballet and the San Francisco Ballet. But the former is an adjunct to another organization and, similarly, the latter was originally attached to the San Franciso Opera. Therefore the Atlanta Ballet's performances Saturday and next Sunday at Brooklyn College may indeed be called performances by America's oldest ballet company, a company that has been a pioneer of the regional ballet movement.

title:
FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
Bullish Verdict
description: Jung Ja Malandris, a 34-year-old Korean immigrant in Denver, lost $30,000 in the stock market but won $4 million in damages from Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in 1977. She charged that the nation's largest broker had sold her stock and reinvested the funds without her consent.

title: Latter-Day News For the Mormons
description: Prophets can be an inconvenience to their followers, especially if they commit their thoughts to paper. Thus, the Mormon church last week was mildly discomfited by a document, apparently the work of the original Mormon prophet in 1844, which threw doubt on the divinely mandated succession of the church's leaders.

title: HIGHER FARE LOOMS AT THE END OF THE TRANSIT TUNNEL
description: The negotiations to rebuild the metropolitan area's ailing transit system have appropriately assumed the character of New York City's subways: Noisy, shaky and plagued with frequent breakdowns, they lurch along and no one is quite sure where they are headed.

title: ROBIN L. CUMMINGS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. S. Stuart Cummings of Rockville Centre, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Linda Cummings, to Gary Warren, son of Mrs. Edward Wartenberg of Maspeth, Queens, and the late Mr. Wartenberg. A June wedding is planned. The future bridegroom changed his surname.

title: CONGRESSIONAL MAIL ON BUDGET SHIFTING
description: WASHINGTON ''IAM 100 percent behind the tax and Federal spending cuts that President Reagan proposed in his speech,'' reads a typical letter. Another says, ''I was pleased that he had the courage to put forth a plan that broke with the bankrupt economic policies of previous administrations and Congress.''

title: PLANS FOR A 'SEXLESS' BIBLE DENIED BY NATIONAL COUNCIL OF CHURCHES
description: Assertions that the National Council of Churches planned a feminist version of the Bible have produced a flood of negative mail to the council and a strong denial from it.

title: Keeping the C.I.A. Away from Home
description: President Reagan is due to issue an order within the next few weeks disclosing how much extra leash he wants to give the Central Intelligence Agency. Last week, in an apparent attempt to douse a controversy over proposals urging a much freer hand, drafted by officials of the C.I.A. and other intelligence agencies, a senior White House aide asserted that his boss wasn't contemplating a return to the agency's old ways.

title: HOLLYWOOD EMBRACES THE DIFFICULT NOVEL
description: ''They told me I was crazy, that it was too much off center, that it was not linear enough and that the characters weren't straight enough,'' says Mark Rosenberg, senior vice president of production at Warner Bros., in talking about initial responses to his interest in making a movie of John Irving's ''The World According to Garp,'' a complex, critically esteemed novel about a writer's life.

title:
Camera;
POINTERS ON CHOOSING A SUITABLE CAMERA BAG
description: Photography is a demanding hobby for those who choose to take it seriously, so it is helpful to be supported by equipment you trust. This includes a suitable bag or case to carry your cameras and other equipment while walking around or traveling. It is no fun to work with an aching shoulder that is the result of a camera bag that's too heavy, but it's also frustrating to have left behind a lens, filter, closeup attachment or some extra film just because your camera bag was too small for these essentials.

title: WENDY COLLISON FRENCH IS WED
description: The marriage of Wendy Collison French, an assistant manager in the Chemical Bank's real-estate department, to William J. Nolan 3d, a Banker's Trust Company vice president, took place in Locust Valley, L.I., last evening. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery of St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond French, parents of the bride.

title: Notes; SPECIAL-INTEREST TOURS ABOARD
description: If you have a special interest that you would like to indulge while on vacation overseas this year, there is probably a tour already designed around it. Music, glass, skiing, pot-throwing, wine and food: These subjects and others are available in package tours that make it possible to go abroad and still stay within a budget. Here is a sampling:

title: 100,000 STUDENTS FACE CUTS IN AID
description: TRENTON STATE higher-education officials estimate that as many as 100,000 New Jersey college students who would have been eligible for state and Federal financial aid next September will lose some or all of it as a result of proposed budget cuts. Many are expected to have to give up college.

title: 39 Workers Overcome by Fumes
description: Thirty-nine employees of Clifton Precision Products were taken to three area hospitals yesterday after being overcome by what a hospital spokesman said was freon fumes. Only one person was hospitalized, the authorities said.

title: No Headline
description: Nell's Briquette, given a superb ride by Bill Shoemaker, scored a wire-to-wire victory today in the $138,800 Santa Susana Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Santa Anita.

title: 'PUNK ROCK' FLOURISHES IN LOS ANGELES
description: Pop music, which is generally invisible in New York City except for modest wall posters and an occasional line of fans waiting to get into a club, is very visible in Los Angeles. There aren't as many giant billboards advertising new pop albums as there used to be; the minimum cost for a billboard on Sunset Strip is now about $10,000 and record companies have been cutting back on such lavish expenditures. But along Sunset one can still see gigantic likenesses of Neil Diamond, Eric Clapton, Jermaine Jackson and even Elvis Costello, along with crowds of teen-agers and young adults waiting to get into the Roxy or the Whisky A Go Go or picking up the latest albums at Tower Records.

title: Eastern Sixes Are Ousted
description: For the first time since the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship hockey tournament was instituted in 1948, no Eastern college team will be represented when the four semifinalists meet in Duluth, Minn., on Thursday.

title: WOMEN JOIN BATTLE ON ALL-MALE DRAFT
description: The case against the all-male military draft was brought by men on the ground that being singled out for compulsory service violated their rights to equal protection. But a number of women's groups have filed briefs with the Supreme Court arguing that the all-male draft also violates the constitutional rights of women.

title: Architecture View; WHERE ARE THE 'FORM-GIVERS' OF TODAY?
description: There was a time - and it was not so very long ago - when the architectural profession was led by people whose work was at once popular and profound, at once of interest to the public at large and to their most serious colleagues. The work of a few crucial practitioners seemed to provide the key to understanding an entire time. In the 1950's, for example, Eero Saarinen's buildings seemed to sum up everything that decade was about - a sense of technological daring, a sense of bold geometric forms, and yet also an underlying respect for the status quo. Buildings like Saarinen's TWA terminal at John F. Kennedy International Airport or his Dulles International Airport outside of Washington, D.C., both completed after the architect's death in 1961, were of interest to architectural cognescenti and laymen alike. Their swooping forms and sense of adventure excited everyone, and though the buildings challenged no fundamental notions of what architecture was about, they seemed to herald a new age.

title: BLACK POP TURNS TO FUNK HYBRIDS
description: Last year, with the waning of disco, it looked as though the black pop mainstream was ready for a revival of soul. Smokey Robinson, the great Motown tenor, was enjoying a commercial and critical comeback, while Michael Jackson's phenomenally successful ''Off the Wall'' album promised that the former teen idol might eventually be as influential a singer as Mr. Robinson. With its rapid success in mass-producing wholesome black pop, Solar Records, the young Los Angeles-based label, was being compared to Motown, while veteran vocal groups like the Whispers (on Solar) scored with music that echoed the street corner harmonies of the late 1950's. Most of this music was made in Los Angeles.

title: Apocalyptic Rabbi
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT CAN WE DO FOR THE ECONOMY?
description: THE conclusion of the Commission for a National Agenda that the migration of jobs and people to the Sun Belt should be encouraged has been thoroughly and, in my view, properly discredited by a variety of sources and needs no further objections to demonstrate its dangerous implications.

title: LISA RUSSELL, R.B. STOCKMAN HAVE NUPTIALS
description: Lisa Anne Russell and Robert Bernard Stockman were married yesterday in St. James' Episcopal Church in New York, where the Rev. Anne Brewster Jones and the Rev. Donald J. Schell performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Linda Peyton of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: PIANO ELDERS SHOW STYLE
description: Arthur Rubinstein, Vladimir Horowitz, Wilhelm Kempff and Claudio Arrau are among the most prominent piano personalities of the 20th century, each boasting a career that spans from 60 to 75 years. Recent recordings from all four of these elder statesmen vividly demonstrate some of the reasons why they have held concertgoers in thrall for over three generations. Interpretively, these pianists could not be more various in their ideas and artistic goals, but they all express extremely individual and provocative points of view.

description: Top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd overcame fluridden Kathy Jordan tonight, 7-6, 6-2, and advanced to the final of a $150,000 Avon tournament.

Gardening;

description: IN last week's column, we discussed the functional and esthetic merits of rock walls - especially those of dry walls. The spaces between the stones provide ideal pockets for many interesting plants, giving dry walls a distinct advantage over other garden walls.

title: CAVALIERS DOWN B.Y.U., 74-60
description: Ralph Sampson became the awesome, dominant influence he had been expected to be in the National Collegiate basketball tournament, scoring 14 of his 22 points in the second half and leading Virginia to a 74-60 victory over Brigham Young today.

title: IN THE KINGDOM OF VIDEO UNCERTAINTY REIGNS
description: HOLLYWOOD You might not go to Hollywood looking for trouble, but these days it seems that trouble is the only show in town. Of course, what Hollywood terms a crisis might not play that way in Peoria. A community that earns its living by creating and merchandising fantasies can't help but acquire a certain dreamy insularity, a concept of crisis all its own.

description: The team of Hurley Haywood, Brian Leven and Al Holburt cruised into the lead with under two hours left in the 12 Hours of Sebring endurance race tonight and went on to win the 29th running of the tradition-rich event for sports cars.

description: Dr. and Mrs. Kurt J. Isselbacher of Newton and Woods Hole, Mass.,have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Theo Isselbacher, to Alan Epstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Epstein of Yonkers.

description: A ''significant displacement'' of oil by natural gas in New York State's ''energy mix'' has been reported by James L. Larocca, State Commissioner of Energy, in a new quarterly review of energy.

title:
Dining Out;
AN OLD ITALIAN STANDBY IN BELLEVILLE
description: PROBABLY the most numerous and, from all appearances, the most popular restaurants in New Jersey are those serving Italian food. Although many of them coast by with mediocre kitchens and little effort, a select few are deserving of their brisk trade.

description: I related to Annette Kaminsky's recent article (''Winter's Delights? Not at My House,'' Opinion Page) so completely, with total empathy.

THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Crime, Punishment And Consequences
description: Statistics on judges may not be as notoriously inaccurate as statistics on criminals, but they can be misleading nevertheless. Last week a plan to shift 37 civil court judges to try New York City felony cases was announced by Chief Judge Lawrence H. Cooke.
