description: The Arrows scored four consecutive goals in the last period tonight to defeat the Phoenix Inferno, 10-6, and keep their playoff hopes alive.

title: BENEFIT INCREASES MAY SLOW
description: Employers spent $390 billion on employee benefits in 1979, an annual average of $5,560 per worker. As a share of wages and salaries, the United States Chamber of Commerce estimates that benefit programs have risen from 3 percent to 32 percent since 1929.

title: Crafts
description: ''IN THE COMPANY OF CATS,'' an exhibition currently on view at the America House Gallery in Tenafly, brings together an assembly of several dozen feline forms in clay, cloth, enamel, suede and metal.

title:
Photography View;
GLORIES OF OLD FRANCE
description: In the mid-19th century - as the interesting and innovative exhibition of French architectural photographs at the new Godwin-Ternbach Museum at Queens College reminds us - the art of photography was not nearly so highly regarded as it is today. Four of the photographers in this exhibition are now rightly ranked among the great photographers of their century. Yet, almost as soon as these photographs were taken, they were put away in a government office. They were not shown or circulated in their time - many of them were never even printed - and some of them are being shown for the first time ever.

title: QUESTIONABLE ROLE OF LAW REVIEWS IN EVALUATING YOUNG LAWYERS
description: To the Editor:

title:
Antiques;
AMERICANA IS THEME OF BENEFIT FOR SCHOOL
description: MILLINGTON AMERICANA will be the theme of an antiques show to be held next Saturday and Sunday at Bonnie Brae, an education center here for emotionally disturbed children. Proceeds from the show will aid the school's Scholarship Fund.

title: BRITAIN TURNS ON THE POMP FOR NIGERIAN PRESIDENT
description: President Shehu Shagari of Nigeria came to Britain this week, in a glittering state visit full of symbols of his nation's expanding role in the world.

title: 'HOMEFINDERS' RESISTS RESEGREGATION
description: Robert and Joan Ulick wanted to buy a house in this village on Long Island's South Shore, but a five-month search with half a dozen real-estate agents turned up nothing. ''They all told us this wasn't our kind of place,'' Mr. Ulick said.

title: LAW ON CREATION THEORY PROVES BOON FOR GOVERNOR OF ARKANSAS
description: Facing a stack of about 450 bills churned out by the Arkansas Legislature in the closing days of its session, Gov. Frank White plucked a creation-science bill from the bottom and signed it.

title: Correction
description: In The Times Magazine today, two photographs have inadvertently been transposed. The picture on page 60 shows Dr. Ruth Moulton; the one on page 62 shows Dr. Eleanor Maccoby.

title: HAMILTON WINS INTERCITY GAME
description: In command almost all the way, Alexander Hamilton High School of Brooklyn defeated Philadelphia's Benjamin Franklin High, 86-75, today in the first Big City Basketball Classic before a crowd of 3,000 at the Palestra. In the first game of the doubleheader, the girls' team of West Philadelphia High defeated the girls' team of John F. Kennedy of Riverdale, 58-42.

title: MAIL TO LEGISLATORS BACKS CUTS, WITH RESERVATIONS Moynihan
description: The reaction to President Reagan's budget proposals, as reflected in mail to Senators and Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, was almost unanimously in support of the President at first and - although the level of support has slipped as details have become known - most of it still backs his programs.

title: ALLETTA SMITH BETHROED
description: Announcement has been made by Elizabeth Morris Smith of Newport, R.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of her daughter, Alletta Morris Smith, to William J. Cooper Jr. of Newport, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cooper of New Haven and Sarasota, Fla.

title: Roderick, Steel Executive, To Head Met Fund Unit
description: The corporate arm of the Metropolitan Opera Centennial Fund Campaign, which is seeking to raise $100 million by 1983-84 - the Met's 100th anniversary season - will be presided over by David M. Roderick, chairman and chief executive officer of U.S. Steel. An announcement by John K. McKinley, chairman and chief executive officer of Texaco and overall fund chairman, and Frank E. Taplin, president of the Metropolitan Opera association, said the fund would provide an endowment ''which will be permanently invested to generate income,'' but ''will not replace the need for annual fundraising to cover operating costs'' - which last year exceeded $46.5 million.

title: Connecticut Housing; VICTORIAN HOUSES CUT FROM A PATTERN
description: BRIDGEPORT WITH a large mustard-colored volume tucked into his dusty workclothes, Jeffrey Colendo, a young builder and restoration specialist, has been spending the winter months restoring a twofamily Victorian house on Myrtle Avenue.

title: THE ROAD TO EXTRADOM
description: Susan Squire is a senior editor on Los Angeles magazine. By Susan Squire Gina and Philip Picerni, 23 and 25 respectively, betray the fact that they are brother and sister by their nearly identical dark Mediterranean looks and compact, athletic bodies. They look right together, out on the crowded disco dance floor. The one thing that's not right is that there is no music.

title: Expectations
description: To the Business Editor:

title: FOR COSTA RICA, 2 BOMBS BRING A TASTE OF FEAR
description: Terrorist bombs that injured three United States Marine guards and damaged the Honduran Embassy here this week have stunned Costa Ricans with the realization that they are no longer immune to Central America's violence.

title: IPSWICH AND ASTON VILLA BEATEN BRITISH SOCCER
description: Ipswich and Aston Villa, both in contention for the English soccer championship, lost their matches day. Ipswich, with four regular players sidelined with injuries, bowed to Manchester City, 2-1. Gartn Crooks and Steve Archibald scored as Tottenham Hotspur beat Aston Villa, 2-0.

title: SUNDAY WORK IS KEY ISSUE AS MINERS PREPARE TO STRIKE
description: The $7 million mechanical monster that is roaring and clanking and gnawing out the entrails of Washington County, Pa., 720 feet below the West Virginia-Pennsylvania line, is a perfect, obedient pet to Frank Bartus, the union coal miner who presses the buttons that operate it.

title: Capitals 3, Blues 3
description: Two third-period goals by Tim tookey gave 17thplace Washington the tie with league-leading St. Louis. The tie gave the Blues 100 points in 73 games.

title: JACOB STONE, 86, LEADING FIGURE ON STOCK EXCHANGE FOR 50 YEARS
description: Jacob C. Stone, a leading figure on the New York Stock Exchange for 50 years until his retirement in 1969, died yesterday at his winter home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 86 years old and lived at 465 Park Avenue in New York.

title: CAROL RETTIG MARRIED TO THOMAS A. BRUNO JR.
description: Carol L. Rettig, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin L. Rettig of Milan, Ill., was married yesterday morning in Manhattan to Thomas A. Bruno Jr., also of Manhattan, son of Mr. Bruno of West New Brighton, S.I., and Edith A. Bruno of Ward Hill, S.I. The Rev. Donald D. Ostroth performed the ceremony in the Marble Collegiate Church.

title: ACCOMPLICE TO TERROR
description: General Roberto Viola, Argentina's President-designate, has just visited Washington. By the warm welcome it gave him the Reagan Administration dramatically underlined its new human rights policy. That is to condemn ''totalitarian'' Communist regimes but avoid criticizing ''authoritarian'' governments of the right.

title: Arbour Tries to Keep Islanders From Looking Too Far Ahead
description: With only eight games to play in the regular season, it was becoming very difficult for the Islanders not to look ahead.

title: JAECKEL, NERVOUS BUT RESOLUTE, SHOOTS 72-211 FOR 3-STROKE LEAD
description: For a golfer who is as nervous as Barry Jaeckel says he is, Jaeckel is bearing up pretty well. Fatigued and feeling ''the choke setting in'' on the last six holes, Jaeckel managed today to lengthen his lead to three strokes in the third round of the Tournament Players Championship.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
No-Frills Transit, First-Class Fares For N.J. Commuters
description: Many commuters are finding themselves between the rock of rising costs and the hard place of shrinking subsidies, but few may be squeezed so tightly as those in New Jersey. Last week, 326,000 of the state's bus and rail passengers, who often endure coaches and cars that are hot in the summer, cold in the winter and dirty all year long, faced the prospect of paying 50 percent more for the privilege.

title: In the Grit Tradition
description: Unlike the sale of The Times of London last month to Rupert Murdoch, the sale this month of Grit, which in its own way is as much an American institution as The Times is a British one, attracted scarcely any notice. Possibly because the management and staff of ''America's Greatest Family Newspaper'' practice what the title preaches.

title: ALBERT W. PROTZMAN
description: Albert W. Protzman, a communications engineer, died Thursday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y., after a heart attack. Mr. Protzman, who lived in Bronxville and was 79 years old, started his career with Bell Laboratories and went into radio engineering in the early 1920's with stations WEAF and WJZ.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: PARAMESWARAN KUMAR WEDS SUSAN GEWIRTH
description: At St. Paul' Chapel of Columbia University yesterday Susan J. Gewirth, a graduate of Columbia's School of General Studies, was married to Parameswaran Kumar , a doctoral candidate in mathematics at Columbia. The Rev. James H. Potts, a minister of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ,) performed the ceremony.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
ONLY THE RING IS SQUARE
description: TEDDY BRENNER, who used to make fights for Madison Square Garden, and Barney Nagler, the indestructible columnist for The Daily Racing Form, have just finished a book entitled ''Only the Ring Was Square.'' It is, as the title should make clear, Brenner's account of the fun and games he experienced during a lifetime in boxing.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: LINER IS SOLD FOR HAWAIIAN CRUISES
description: The once-elegant liner United States, which has been idle at a pier in Norfolk, Va., for 12 years, has finally been sold to a Seattle company for cruise service to the Hawaiian islands.

title: Cambodia Holds Local Elections; Ousted Regime Denounces Them
description: Cambodians voted today in municipal elections in preparation for the country's first general election since Vietnamese forces installed the Heng Samrin Government in January 1979.

title: DICKSON JAY HARTWELL
description: Dickson Jay Hartwell, an author, journalist and public relations executive, died yesterday at the Tripler Army Medical Center in Honolulu. Mr. Hartwell, a resident of Kaneohe, Hawaii, was 74 years old.

title: Parked Up
description: Mayor Koch is to be congratulated for discovering double parking. It reportedly took a lady at a dinner party to tell him what many already knew - that the intended thoroughfares of midtown Manhattan are in fact just elegant parking lots.

title: Drinking Water: Quality Is the Essence
description: The recent article on Long Island's water was most important. Clean water is second only to clean air for the continuation of life. Long Island may have water for ''500 years,'' but quantity is not the criterion - quality or potability is the essence.

title: 2 IRAQI MISSILE ATTACKS REPORTED AS IRANIANS START THEIR NEW YEAR
description: As Iranians celebrated the beginning of the Persian New Year, Iraqi forces reportedly launched missile attacks todat on two cities in the Iranian oil-producing province of Khuzistan.

title: Nan Nall, Soprano, Sings Mozart and Stravinsky
description: The first half of Nan Nall's concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on March 14 constituted one of the more impressive vocal debuts heard in New York City in recent months. In four songs by Mozart, Miss Nall phrased with natural grace and handled the melismatic demands of Mozart's familiar ''Alleluia'' with effortless elegance.

description: THORPE:VICTORIAN STYLE --------------------------------------------------------------------- EDWARD MORAN is a writer and photographer who is restoring an 1843 stone house in Jim Thorpe, Pa. By EDWARD MORAN

title: New Jerseyans
description: ABOUT seven months after fire destroyed the Paper Mill Playhouse, Ulyesse J. LeGrange of Short Hills, vice president and comptroller of the Exxon Corporation, was named a trustee of the nonprofit group that runs the Millburn theater.

title: CRIME WATCH BEGINS IN ATLANTIC COUNTY
description: MAYS LANDING THE neighborhood crime watch, something normally associated with populous cities, has come to the Atlantic County rural scene. The area has been afflicted by a crime wave, mostly daytime house burglaries, that authorities believe has been caused principally by an influx of undesirables attracted to casinos in nearby Atlantic City.

title: ART
description: From the time of his first solo exhibition at Alfred Stieglitz's "291" Gallery in 1916, the late Paul Strand (1890-1976) was recognized as one of the preeminent artist-photographers of his time. Whether their subjects were drawn from the world of industrial machinery or lyrical landscapes or humble figures encountered on the street of New York, Strand's photographs were characterized by a flawless pictorial intelligence.

title: DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL COMMITTEE NAMES 3 SENIOR STAFF MEMBERS
description: The new chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Charles T. Manatt, has announced the appointment of three members to the committee's senior staff.

title: Amnesia Victim in Florida Reportedly Identifieds
description: Doctors believe an amnesia victim found naked and near death in a state park seven months ago is the daughter of a suburban Chicago couple who have not talked to her in seven years, a newspaper reported today.

title: WHAT EXXON LEARNED ABOUT MOTORS
description: ON May 18, 1979, the Exxon Corporation announced what it said was a major invention - an electronic control system for motors that could reduce their energy consumption up to 50 percent.

title: Art; REGIONAL ARTISTS' WORK AT ATHENEUM
description: HARTFORD VENERABLE though it is, Wadsworth Atheneum has scarcely been unresponsive to modernism, especially in the shows it has mounted in the Matrix Gallery. In fact, regular patrons of this small ''concession'' inaugurated six years ago, should by now be fully briefed on the directions of contemporary work.

title: Potsdam Wins in Division III
description: Leroy Witherspoon scored on a layup to give Potsdam State a 5-point lead in overtime en route to a 67-65 victory over Augustana in the championship game of the N.C.A.A. Division III basketball tournament.

title: SPORTS BENEFITS CITED
description: GARDEN CITY THIS week, the office of State Senator John R. Dunne, Republican of Garden City, will release an analysis of sports in New York State entitled ''From Little League to the Olympics.'' The study is expected to lay the foundation for legislative projects that might help communities take better advantage of the economic opportunities afforded by the sports industry.

title: STUDENTS FIND BOCES IS ATTRACTIVE OPTION
description: VALHALLA TO many Westchester residents, the Board of Cooperative Educational Services may be little more than a name glimpsed on a passing school bus. But Boces, as the board and the school it oversees here are called, has become an increasingly popular option for high school students in the county.

description: If this article was meant to elicit sympathy for such a character, it fell far short of the mark.

Gardening;
EXTENDING THE BLOOM OF DRY-WALL FLOWERS
description: IN last week's column, we discussed the functional and esthetic merits of rock walls - especially those of dry walls. The spaces between the stones provide ideal pockets for many interesting plants, giving dry walls a distinct advantage over other garden walls.

title:
Dining Out;
REBIRTH OF A JAPANESE RESTAURANT
description: COUNTY diners-out, enured to seeing decent kitchens disappear almost overnight to be replaced by overpriced, underimagined ones, can every so often be pleasantly startled by the reverse. In our round-up of Japanese establishments last summer, Shimizu-ya in Hartsdale came in last; shortly after, it temporarily closed its doors, and now it is with us again - reborn, reclassified and turning out some good Japanese food.

title: Again, the Coal Mines Smolder
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan apparently had no specific case in mind last week when he recited the Republican canon on collective bargaining - it works best without Government intervention, goes the theme. But a specific case may be soon at hand.

title: Art; PHOTOGRAPHS REVEAL AN EXPERIENCE IN MULTIPLE PERCEPTION
description: PORT WASHINGTON WYNN BULLOCK'S ''Child in Forest,'' on view at the Port Washington Library, has become a staunch symbol of his photographic achievements. Exhibited in 1955 in the acclaimed Museum of Modern Art exhibition ''Family of Man,'' organized by Edward Steichen, the photograph stirred reaction as much for its eerily intriguing beauty as for its provocative subject matter.

title: NAVAL AIDE TO BE NAMED ASSISTANT DEFENSE CHIEF
description: President Reagan announced yesterday that he would nominate Francis J. West, dean of advanced research at the Naval War College, a former Deputy Defense Secretary in the Ford Administration, to be Assistant Secretary of Defense for international security affairs.

description: THE CHEER By William Meredith. 62 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $8.95.

title: SMALL TOWN REJECTS ZONING FOR 6TH TIME
description: BETHLEHEM VOTERS in this small rural community turned out in large numbers last weekend to defeat, for the sixth time in almost two decades, a proposal to adopt zoning.

title: FAIR TO CELEBRATE COUNTY HISTORY AND INITIATE 1983 TRICENTENNIAL
description: THE Westchester Heritage Festival and History Day, a daylong county fair and conference, will celebrate the area's people and their history on Sunday May 3, kicking off observances for the 1983 Westchester Tricentennial.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS IN SUMMARY
description: Busing to achieve school desegregation has traveled a long, rancorous legal and political road in many communities. Last week, school boards in two of the nation's largest school districts moved to put on the brakes and bring busing to a halt.

title: Electing a President
description: Former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's article, ''Reforming the Electoral Reforms'' (Feb. 22), was thought provoking. However, it is unfortunate that he, like some other prominent statesmen and political scientists, advocates a single six-year term for our future Presidents.

title: Apartment House Fire Kills Several in New Orleans
description: Fire swept through a four-story apartment building here late tonight, killing an undetermined number of people and injuring at least 15 others before being controlled, the authorities said.

title: LAWRENCE OF DARTMOUTH HONORED AS TOP IVY PLAYER
description: Larry Larwence of Dartmouth and Randy Melville of Princeton, senior forwards, were unanimous choices for the 1980-81 all-Ivy League basketball team.

title: CRIME'S FAVORABLE ODDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Clinic; VINYL CEMENT EFFECTIVE FOR SMALL PATCHES
description: NOW that the weather is turning warmer, and homeowners in this area finally have a chance to get outside and look around a little, many are finding that the cold spells we had this winter have caused damage to mortar joints in brick and concrete-block walls, as well as to concrete walks and patios. Although the damage may not be serious - or even very noticeable -prompt repairs are still advisable to insure against the condition getting worse before the year is over.

title: DAVE DEBUSSCHERE: A FRIEND'S MEMORY
description: DAVE DeBUSSCHERE is a man whose simple tastes were constantly at war with New York stardom. His great basketball ability earned for him the loyalty of New York's basketball fans. His shock of dark hair, powerful legs, and wide smile made him a striking public figure. Drawn toward personal friends, his family, neighborhood bars, and other athletic men, he keeps himself apart from the New York celebrity atmosphere, which he regards as phony. Yet, he is a part of it and slowly he has come to live his role although he is never comfortable as an idol.

title: THERESA JANKA TO BE BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francisco Sabate of Manila have announced the engagement of their daughter, Theresa Janka of New York, to Dr. Edward A. McFarland, son of Nettie McFarland of Brunswick, Me.

description: A 40-hour strike by Milwaukee firefighters ended today after the city's Common Council, in a predawn meeting, voted to approve a new contract.

description: Sara and Jerry Pearson are a husband and wife team that shone brightly in the Murray Louis Dance Company from 1974 to 1979. Since then they have struck out on their own, choreographing and dancing for their own company, which will perform at Riverside Church Wednesday, Friday and Sunday.

description: WITH the first space shuttle due to go into orbit next month, the business executives upon whom its ultimate success depends will regard it with wonder. They'll wonder whether, as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has promised, there will really be anything in it for them.

description: The Federal Neutrality Act prohibits conspiracies against any country with which the United States is not at war, but that has not stopped Cuban exiles from training here for two decades to overthrow Fidel Castro. Now the Cubans have been joined by exiles with a fresher grievance - the revolution that overthrew Nicaragua's Somoza dictatorship 18 months ago.

title: Speaking Out And Its Consequences
description: Clearly Sharon Launer is one of those courageous, forthright individuals - to judge from her recent Opinion Page article (''Enough Is Enough, Somebody Ought to Put a Stop to It'') - whom all of us should respect. Why then do we not also emulate her course of action? Why aren't we more willing to mount our figurative steeds and tilt with the forces infringing on our well-being and impinging on our peace of mind?

title:
Antiques;
ENGRAVER'S YEARNING WAS PAINTING

He grew up in the Wooster Square section of New Haven. The son of an engraver and clockmaker, Jocelyn was apprenticed first to his father and later, through the influence of Eli Whitney, a business acquaintance of the elder Jocelyn, to other engravers in Philadelphia.

The Rev. Robert M.G. Libby, assisted by the Rev. Ralph W. Ahlberg, performed the ceremony.

description: Lebanon today recalled its United Nations delegate for consultations after criticizing what it termed American intransigence in a Security Council debate on incidents in southern Lebanon.

title: PEEKSKILL GIRL SCOUTS IN DAY-CARE EFFORT
description: EVERY afternoon from 2:30 to 6 P.M., and every day during school holidays, about 35 inner-city children in Peekskill now have somewhere to go. Since last September, they have attended an afterschool day-care program that was designed for children older than 6 who come from low-income families whose parents usually work.

title: No Headline
description: Nurses are the backbone of modern hospitals, and the sooner physicians realize that their former ''handmaidens'' are wellinformed and well-educated colleagues, full partners in the care of patients, the sooner we can move forward to accomplish the goals espoused by both organized medicine and organized nursing. TERENCE W. RODERICK, R.N., Assistant Director Nursing Service, St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, New York City

title: President Reagan Mends the Fences South of the Border
description: With the change of Administration in Washington, Argentina has moved from an arms-length relationship with the United States to a handshake. President Reagan last week warmly received Gen. Roberto Viola, who will become Argentine President next Sunday, and extended ''my best wishes for his tenure.''

title: CARLYLE AND FRIENDS
description: NEIGHBORING LIVES By Thomas M. Disch and Charles Naylor.351 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $14.95.

title: MORE TROUBLE AT DEVON SCHOOL
description: PEACE BREAKS OUT By John Knowles. 193 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $10.95.

title: FRANCE WINS RUGBY
description: France defeated England, 16-12, at Twickenham today and won the Five Nations Rugby Union tournament.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Footwear Store Opens At Outlet Center
description: At the Norwalk Factory Outlet Center, all the stores at the ground level except one are open. The Quoddy Moccasin Factory Outlet opened last weekend on the second level. The nearby hammering and sawing continues to provide additional space for women's clothing at Jack Winter's Clothes Works and the Old Mill, each, by the way, seeking sales help before openings the first week of next month. The center's Spring Fashion Show and Festival will be April 11-12.

title: THE NATION IN SUMMARY
description: Despite warnings that metropolitan Chicago's public transportation system may go bust by April 1, the authority's board last week voted to delay indefinitely an increase in the fare, now 80 cents. Mayor Jane M. Byrne, who reportedly influenced a number of votes (and who has already launched her 1983 re-election campaign), opposes the increase - it would be the second in less than a year - unless the state first kicks in substantial financial assistance.

title: 30,000 March in Milan to Protest Acquittal of Bombing Suspects
description: Some 30,000 people marched through Milan today to protest the verdict yesterday clearing neo-Fascists and anarchists of a 1969 bombing that killed 16 people and injured 100.

title: Research Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater; FROTHY FUN AT 'NO, NO, NANETTE'
description: IN describing itself as ''the new 1925 musical,'' the key word for this ''No, No, Nanette'' is ''new.'' What you are actually seeing is the 1971 Broadway revival, which redesigned the show almost 50 years after the original production to suit an audience accustomed to more sophisticated fare.

title: ANNE BIGELOW TO BE BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Bigelow 3d of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Church Bigelow, to Stephen Neil MacFarlane, son of Prof. David Livingstone MacFarlane, professor emeritus of McGill University, and Dr. Gertrude Straight MacFarlane of Montreal, Canada.

title:
Long Island Housing;
TITLE INSURANCE: WHO GETS THE PROTECTION?
description: OFTEN it takes a disaster to focus attention on dormant problems, and just such a potential disaster recently raised sobering questions about whether most homeowners have adequate title insurance protection.

title: A FERTILIZER SHORTAGE?
description: The nation's fertilizer producers are optimistic about their prospects this year. They're bouyed by predictions of sharply higher crop prices, which, according to some economists, will cause farmers to plant nine million additional acres this year.

title: About Long Island
description: WHEN the world is too much with me, late and/or soon, I often feel and answer a terrible urge to get away from people, who will offer patent remedies for my special complications.

title: Sunday Observer; NO FREE LUNCH
description: No Free Lunch Patrick McDonnell

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times last Sunday on money-raising efforts in connection with the killing and disappearance of black children in Atlanta misstated the purpose of one fund. Money sent to the Committee to Stop Children's Murders, 334 Auburn Avenue S.E., Atlanta, Ga. 30303, will be given to the families of the victims for food, rent and other aid, but not for investigation of the crimes.

title: Politics; DEMOCRATS' BASH 'UNITY' IN NAME ONLY
description: THE State Democratic Committee will stage its $150-a-person ''unity'' dinner in Edison Thursday night. There will be hot food and hotter gossip; in fact, the only thing missing will be the unity.

title: ELISBETH CHALLENER AND BRETT BACHMAN PLAN JUNE WEDDING
description: Prof. and Mrs. Richard D. Challener of Pennington, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisbeth Jane Challener, to Brett Louis Bachman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Bachman of Downers Grove, Ill. A June wedding is planned at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: THEATER: 'ANYTHING GOES' REVIVED
description: Between 1929 and 1941, Cole Porter turned out a succession of musical-comedy scores that sparkled with songs that have become standards of the pop repertory. Most of these scores had two or even three songs each that have worn well over the years. But in 1934, with ''Anything Goes,'' Porter reached a peak, with a score that had five memorable songs - ''You're the Top,'' ''I Get a Kick Out of You,'' ''Anything Goes,'' ''All Through the Night'' and ''Blow, Gabriel, Blow.''

title: SIGHT OF EAGLE EVOKES FLIGHT OF FANCY
description: LAST winter, I was driving down I-684 just past exit 4 between Bedford Hills and Armonk when I spotted a large bird in the distance. It caught my eye because even far away it was obviously out of the ordinary. As I approached, it appeared larger and larger until finally I realized it was an eagle. Like a cadet in military dress, it stood on the side of the road, its enormous breast held proudly, its head erect, its stance rigid. It was both majestic and awesome.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: SUM SOCIETY, by Lester C. Thurow. (Penguin, $4.95.) Recently, America's economy has been one in which growth in some segments is offset by losses in others; to break the stalemate, the Federal Government should guarantee jobs to everyone, but at a wide range of salary levels. This work of an M.I.T. economist has been widely praised for its lucid exposition of our present plight, but critics have differed widely in their reactions to the solution it proposes.

title: 2 New York Partnerships Leading At Title Brigde Event in Michigan
description: Two New York partnerships led into the final session of the women's pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here tonight. In the men's pairs, a partnership representing Oregon and Florida dominated the field.

title: WARSAW TALKS SET FOR TODAY ON CRISIS OVER POLICE ATTACK
description: Searching for a way out of the crisis caused by a police attack on union members in Bydgoszcz, the Solidarity labor movement's leadership and the Government agreed today to hold emergency talks in Warsaw tomorrow.

title: TWO PENNSYLVANIA TOWNS RECALL DAYS WHEN COAL WAS KING
description: In a corner of the tiny room, on the wood floor worn smooth from the shuffle of a coal miner's boots and the bare feet of his wife and children, lies a neatly rolled straw sleeping mat. In the equally small and crowded adjoining room, the miner's overalls hang behind the cookstove. His lard-oil lantern sits on a shelf alongside the tin plates on which the family ate meat and potatoes when work was steady, and potatoes alone when it was not.

title: DEBORAH G. MALLOW IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas T. Mallow of Manhattan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah G. Mallow, to Brian Chenensky of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Chenensky, also of Kew Gardens Hills.

title: KNICKS' RICHARDSON: 27 POINTS, 19 ASSISTS
description: Michael Ray Richardson gave one of the outstanding performances in Madison Square Garden's long basketball history last night. He scored 27 points, had a career-high 19 assists, grabbed 15 rebounds and made 2 steals as the Knicks defeated the Cleveland Cavaliers, 119-105.

title:
OTHER BUSINESS;
HOT AIR IN ADVERTISING
description: It was 3 A.M. when it appeared, flying over Cambridge and along the coast of eastern England. Local police switchboards got alarmed calls from otherwise sober Britons reporting the sightings. A bird? A plane? An unidentified flying object? No, a gigantic, illuminated light bulb, emblazoned with the trademark of Osram, a leading British light bulb maker.

title: Penguins 3, Rockies 1
description: Paul Gardner of Pittsburgh scored what proved to be the winning goal at 12 minutes 15 seconds of the second period. Pat Price, a defenseman, maneuvered around the Colorado defenseman Joel Quenneville and made a perfect centering pass to Gardner, who put the puck past Phil Myre in the Colorado goal. Pittsburgh added to its lead when Rick Kehoe scored his 51st goal of the season on passes from Gardner and Price.

title: 3 Slain in Jersey Apartment
description: Three persons were shot and killed yesterday in what the police described as an ''executionstyle'' slaying.

title: RUTGERS BATTLES BUDGET CRISIS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK HIT BY cutbacks in aid on the state and Federal levels, Rutgers University is caught up in one of the most complex budget battles in recent history, according to Edward J. Bloustein, president of the state university.

title: DANCE: BAROQUE COMPANY
description: The growth of dance groups that reconstruct court and opera-ballet dances from the Renaissance and Baroque periods has paralleled the growth of Early Music groups, and it is no surprise these musical and dance ensembles now perform, in fact, ensemble.

title: REAGAN'S HIDDEN POLICY
description: We all recognize the need to respond to the economic decline that now threatens to destroy our industrial base. And we all recognize that some painful decisions and hard choices need to be made if we are going to turn things around. But President Reagan's economic plan, instituting some much needed fiscal restraint, does something else as well: It substantially modifies the nature of government.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
A Nickel Here, A Nickel There
description: Balancing Connecticut's budget without passing any major new taxes may be akin to making an omelette without breaking any eggs, but that hasn't stopped some Democrats in Hartford from trying.

title: STAGE: ELIZABETH DIGGS'S 'CLOSE TIES'
description: There is a problem in a family play when the most appealing and the most sympathetic character is the one nonrelative on stage. This is precisely what happens in Elizabeth Diggs's ''Close Ties'' at the Long Wharf Theater's Stage Two.

title: The Imam Speaks, But Is Not Obeyed
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the constitutional deus ex machina of Iran's Islamic republic, descended last week into the midst of his country's cutthroat politics, but even he could not impose an instant truce.

title: MICRONESIANS WORRY ABOUT FATE OF PACT WITH U.S.
description: Leaders of Micronesia, the United Nations trust territory governed by the United States since World War II, are concerned by the uncertainty in Washington over the attitude of the Reagan Administration toward a pending agreement on the future political status of more than 2,000 strategic Pacific islands and atolls.

title: CHOICE FOR U.S. POST EXPERIENCED IN ROLE
description: On Aug. 31, 1978, after William and Emily Harris of the Symbionese Liberation Army pleaded guilty to kidnapping Patricia Hearst, D. Lowell Jensen made one of his rare and characteristically guarded statements to the press.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS MOUNTING DRIVE TO REDUCE IMPACT OF BUDGET CUTS
description: Democrats on the House Budget Committee say they are preparing major changes in President Reagan's proposed budget for the fiscal year 1982 that will provide less drastic reductions for child nutrition, student loans, Medicaid, job training and other social programs serving poor and vulnerable Americans.

title: CONCERN RISES IN PHILADELPHIA OVER TRANSIT STRIKE
description: Commuters here have demonstrated that the third transit strike in six years was easier to cope with than the first. But concern was nevertheless increasing that the economic and social costs of finding alternative transportation for 400,000 daily riders of buses, subways and trolleys would snowball if 4,900 members of Transit Workers Local 234 stayed out much longer.

title: WALKING ON FIRE ISLAND'S SEASHORE IN THE DIRECTION OF SPRING
description: PUBLIC beaches in winter are usually sad and lonely places - vast parking lots stand empty, picnic tables and neatly stacked trash cans lend a ghost-town atmosphere that even a few huddled gulls can't change. Shouldering my knapsack, I hurried away from last summer's ghosts and headed west into an unbroken expanse of beach that held more promise of spring.

title: 'Creation Science' Wins in Arkansas
description: In the beginning, there was the Bible's story of creation. Then came Charles Darwin's theory of evolution and natural selection. In the end, evolution was found geologically, anthropologically and in other ways good enough to teach in public schools.

title: CAPISTRANO HOPES A TALL TOWER WILL INDUCE SWALLOWS TO RETURN
description: The swallows of San Juan Capistrano have all but abandoned the earthquake-ravaged church to which the tourists flock each spring.

title: B.K. Morse, 81, Builder Of World War II Pipeline
description: Birney K. Morse, a pipeline expert who helped build the World War II fuel line across the Himalayas into China, died Thursday in a Philadelphia hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: GENSIS, DARWIN AND HUMAN FALLIBILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearing-Aid Soloist
description: Sam Posner is a dedicated music lover, even though he is hard of hearing. With great frequency, the short, 85-year-old Bronx man clamps on a hearing aid and heads for a concert at the Lincoln Center of the Performing Arts.

title: Lillian Block, Ex-Editor At Religious News Unit
description: Lillian R. Block, an editor with the Religious News Service in New York City for 37 years, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. She was 72 years old and lived in Montclair.

title: PEKING DISARRAY MAKES DEMOCRACY A THREAT, NOT A PROMISE
description: With great fanfare, the Chinese Government last year began holding what it said were the first free and democratic county-level elections since the Communists came to power in 1949. Anyone nominated and seconded by three voters could run. Voting would be by secret ballot. And, the Government promised, there could be many more candidates than positions in China's 2,757 counties and equivalent constituencies - in other words, a choice.

title: REGEN theater mailbag page 9
description: To the Editor:

title: Music View; PAYING HOMAGE TO BARTOK
description: Like the rest of the musical world, New York is paying its respects this week to Bela Bartok, a rather famous emigre who died 35 years ago in a West Side hospital. This season, which marks the 100th anniversary of the Hungarian composer's birth, arrives at its apogee Wednesday evening, on his birthday, when the New York Philharmonic under Rafael Kubelik presents a concert version of his ''Bluebeard's Castle,'' the Detroit Symphony plays an all-Bartok program under Antal Dorati featuring Yehudi Menuhin playing the Violin Concerto No. 2, and the Guarneri Quartet plays three of the six string quartets. And that night only touches the surface of the Bartok week: tonight the intrepid Emerson Quartet will give the entire cycle of quartets, all six of them in one program; tomorrow night Mr. Dorati will lead his own ''Bluebeard's Castle,'' and on Saturday night the Juilliard Quartet begins a series in which Bartok and Brahms will be compared and contrasted. Perhaps other major Bartok celebrations have been overlooked in this brief survey. If so, sorry.

title: Colombia's M-19 Runs Out of Luck
description: One year ago, Colombian guerrillas of the tactically unorthodox and ideologically murky group known as M-19 were in the midst of a two-month occupation of the Dominican Embassy in Bogota, demanding the release of hundreds of jailed comrades as ransom for diplomat hostages. They lost that demand but got the Government to let outsiders monitor guerrilla trials.

title: No Headline
description: In most hospitals, the one area where a nurse is granted greatest leeway in decision making and actual treatment is critical care. Here nurses administer lifesaving drugs without prior consultation.

title: MATTHEWS, AVOIDING TRADE, REJECTS OFFER FROM PHILLIES
description: The Philadelphia Phillies said today they were unable to sign Gary Matthews, the Atlanta outfielder, thus canceling a trade agreement that would also have sent Bob Walk, Phillie pitcher, to the Braves.

title: Reading and Writing; LIFE AND DEATH OF LANGUAGE
description: The current spate of books on language usage might suggest that we are concerned about our speech and intent on improving it. But what these books deal with is the politics of language: whether or not its regulation should be democratized. They are etiquette books, recipe books, quizzes, an extension of the crossword-puzzle approach.

title: 33 FOOD PLACES FOUND UNSANITARY
description: The New York City Health Department last week released the names of 33 food establishments that it said had violated the city's health code.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; LOUIS L'AMOUR
description: Literary critics will occasionally admit to a weakness for science fiction, whodunits or other category books, but it's a rare critic who has a kind word for westerns. The dominant view is that westerns are little more than juvenile morality tales in a frontier setting.

title: READERS DISPUTE WHY WOMEN EARN LESS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: WOMEN GETTING HELP ENTERING JOB MARKET
description: WOMEN who are creating anxieties for themselves by making New Year's resolutions to find a job for the first time or to re-enter the job market can relax a bit. Numerous programs are available to help build self-confidence, set comfortable goals and, in general, lessen the fears, uncertainties and feelings of inadequacy that tend to make the preliminaries of working for pay a painful ordeal.

title: KEYNES, LIKE SUPPLY-SIDE THEORY, WAS HOTLY ARGUED
description: AMID the frantic groping for an economic policy suitable to today's economic problems, it is easy to look back and wish for another John Maynard Keynes, a Renaissance man to whom both the economic problems of the day and their solutions were obvious.

title: THE CINDERELLA SYNDROME
description: Copyright c 1981 Colette Dowling. All rights reserved including the right of reproduction in whole or in part in any form.

title: Pakistan Is Said to Seize 24 In Crackdown on Opposition
description: The police is reported to have seized 24 people in Karachi in a crackdown on opposition groups.

title: VETERAN KOREAN POLITICIAN SEEKS TO MAKE NEW START
description: Oh Se Eung, fighting for his political life, walked down the main street, shook hands with the Mayor and greeted several hundred other citizens of this town in the hazy valleys some 20 miles southeast of Seoul.

title: THE CHILD SAVERS
description: Robin Marantz Henig is a science writer. Her book, ''The Myth of Senility,'' will be published in August. By Robin Marantz Henig One thousand grams is about the weight of three good-sized grapefruits, a typical Sunday newspaper or two dense loaves of bread. And it's about the weight of the human being that was presented to Roni Handler last Halloween as her first baby, a boy.

title: MAY BRIDAL IS SET BY SUZANNE GRACE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Porinton Grace of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., formerly of Darien, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Grace, to Louis Watjen Pemberton, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Clifford Pemberton 3d of New York. The wedding is planned for May.

title: THE MYSTERY OF WOMEN MYSTERY WRITERS
description: DEATH IN A TENURED POSITION By Amanda Cross. 156 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $10.50.

title: Revamped Jet Staff Maps Recovery Plan
description: The wreckage of the New York Jets is on the film that Joe Walton watches every day from morning to night, and on the blackboards that Joe Gardi fills with decimal points and percentages.

title: A CALL FOR SUPPORT OF WILDLIFE TRAPPING BILL
description: ANIMAL lovers and trappers are heating the halls of Hartford's General Assembly these days in a battle over the leg-hold trap. Friends of Animals Inc., a nonprofit, animal protection group supported by 4,500 Connecticut members, is fighting again this year to get passage of Senate Bill 62.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BOLOGNA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- PAUL HOFMANN is a former Times correspondent based in Rome. By PAUL HOFMANN

title: Bernadette Devlin Discloses She Will Run for Parliament
description: Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, the civil rights leader who is recovering from an assassination attempt, said today that she would be a candidate in an election next month to fill a vacant seat for Northern Ireland in the British Parliament.

title: University's Net Gain
description: Arthur C. Allyn Jr. has had considerably more success in 14 years of collecting butterflies than the Chicago White Sox did collecting pennants during the 10 years he owned the team. Now, Mr. Allyn has made the University of Florida the beneficiary of his success. His collection of about 850,000 specimens from throughout the world, which had been coveted by several American museums, will go to the university after his death. Mr. Allyn, who got out of baseball in 1970, now devotes full time to butterfly collecting and research.

title: Policy Review Doesn't Stop Action
description: Unmasked as having entered the United States with phony visas, five South African military intelligence officers quietly flew home last week. But not before they had been received on Capitol Hill, at the National Security Council and the Pentagon.

title: STUDY STRESSES LINK BETWEEN HEROIN DEPENDENCE AND INCIDENCE OF CRIME
description: Recent research shows that the link between crime and heroin addiction is closer than previously suspected. Researchers found that the incidence of crime rose sharply in periods of addiction and fell dramatically in periods of abstinence or minimal drug use.

title: ROYAL ROMANCE AND PRINCELY DUTY
description: Now that he's getting a wife, isn't it time he had a proper job as well?'' While blunt, this statement by a London radio announcer pinpointed the problem behind the happy news of Prince Charles's engagement last month to Lady Diana Frances Spencer, an endearingly shy and lovely 19-year-old aristocrat.

title: HOW TO BE A BETTER REGULATOR
description: JUST before the Carter Administration was ushered out into political darkness, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration indulged itself in one last orgy of rule-making.

title: JEAN LYBROOK PLANS TO BE WED IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Reynolds Lybrook of Clemmons, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Ferrell Lybrook, to Rowland Goodrich Turner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Turner of Henderson, N.C. The wedding will take place in May.

title: KAREN RAE SPAR MARRIED TO JAY BENNET KASNER, LAWYER
description: Karen Rae Spar, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving L. Spar of Rochester, N.Y., and Jay Bennet Kasner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Kasner of Roslyn, L.I., were married last evening at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn by Rabbi Myron Fenster.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: FOR the third year in a row, legislators in Hartford have been unable to raise Connecticut's legal drinking age of 18. The latest move, aimed at making 19 the age, was killed, 10 to 8, by the General Law Committee.

title: NUCLEAR ATTACK AND SUBWAYS: WAYS SOUGHT TO GUARD POWER
description: The planning is still in the ''embryonic stage,'' the New York City Transit Authority said yesterday, but officials are looking for ways to protect the subway system's power supply in case of nuclear attack.

title: Slaying of Mobile Black, 19, Not Tied to Race, Police Say
description: The beating and strangulation of a 19-year-old black youth found hanged in a tree was not racially motivated, the police said today after a preliminary investigation.

title: Italy Devalues Lira And Lifts Interest
description: The Italian Government announced today that it would devalue the lira by 6 percent against the other currencies in the European Monetary System.

title: Tolentine Wins Title
description: Kevin House sank a layup with 10 seconds left to play, giving Tolentine of the Bronx a 68-67 victory over St. Dominic's of Oyster Bay for the New York State Class B Catholic basketball championship tonight at Maria Regina High School. The victory brought Tollentine's record to 25-6. St. Dominic's finished with a 24-3 mark. Tim Kempton of St. Dominic's, a 6-9 center, was the game's high scorer with 28 points.

title: Sanchez Retains Featherweight Title
description: The World Boxing Council featherweight champion, Salvador Sanchez of Mexico, stopped the No. 1 contender, Roberto Castanon of Spain, at 1 minute 9 seconds of the 10th round today.

title: DANCE: ANNA SOKOLOW OFFERS PROGRAM OF 3 OF HER NEW WORKS
description: ABRAHAM GOODMAN HOUSE was jammed Wednesday with people one normally sees on dance stages. The occasion was a program of three new works by Anna Sokolow, performed by her New Players' Project. The excitement of this single performance was understandable. Miss Sokolow is a master craftsman, and the new company featured some of the best performers on the modern-dance gypsy circuit. But it was a disappointing evening, with an unfinished look surprising from a choreographer of Miss Sokolow's long professional experience.

title: O. JOHN ROGGE, 77, ANTI-NAZI ACTIVIST
description: O. John Rogge, a former assistant United States attorney general who won convictions that broke up the Huey Long political machine in Louisiana and who went on to fight Nazi influence and champion civilrights causes, died yesterday of cancer at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: Homebodies
description: John and Vicki Kresse are staying put. John, an assistant to Lou Carnesecca for 14 years, at St. John's and from 1970 to 1973 with the Nets, has decided to continue as the basketball coach at the College of Charleston, S.C.

title: ISLANDERS SET BACK HAWKS, 6-2, EXTEND UNBEATEN STREAK TO 10
description: The New York Islanders' stretch drive continued today with an emphatic 6-2 defeat of the Chicago Black Hawks that extended their unbeaten streak to 10 games. It was also New York's sixth straight victory on the road, coming against a club that had lost only once at Chicago Stadium since Jan. 1.

title: Junior-College Talent Uplifts Tulsa Team
description: They call themselves the Golden Hurricanes, and they have four starters and a coach who took the long way to college. In fact, they had to go to another state to get recognized.

title: MARKETPLACE TAX-EXEMPT BOND YIELDS
description: Investors drawn to near-record yields now available in long-term United States Treasury bonds may be overlooking an interesting alternative. Tax-exempt bonds of the best quality can provide higher net yields, particularly for investors in high Federal income tax brackets.

title: Young Audiences' Bills To Mark 29th Anniversary
description: Young Audiences, in observance of its 29th anniversary, is presenting 115 programs of dance, drama and music by professional artists to an estimated 20,000 New York City schoolchildren through Saturday.

title: Don't Buckle on Auto Safety
description: ''Regulatory action shall not be undertaken unless the potential benefits to society ... outweigh the potential costs.'' That's timely common sense. But it may soon embarrass the Administration, which is searching for ways to reduce the regulatory burden on the financially pressed auto industry. For one regulation they hope to kill - the requirement to install automatic crash restraints in new cars - would generate benefits far in excess of the cost.

title: Transit Talks at a Standoff In Strike in Philadelphia The second week of a transit strike affecting 400,000 daily commuters began today with talks at a standoff and the police investigating bomb threats and vandalism.
description: A Philadelphia police detective said it was believed that the threats, both false alarms, were intended as harassment.

title: Investment Job Shift At Ford Foundation
description: Katherine Busboom Magrath, director of equity investments at the Ford Foundation, has relinquished management of its $1.5 billion investment portfolio because of differences with Jon L. Hegler, Ford's treasurer.

title: Sampson Is the Focus of Attention, but Virginia Has More to Offer
description: When Ralph Sampson of Virginia took charge in the second half against Brigham Young yesterday with his slam dunks, hook shots, and rebound scores, he was putting on the show the fans had paid to see. It was reminiscent of the seasons when Kareem Abdul-Jabbar (then Lew Alcindor), then Bill Walton, led U.C.L.A. to five N.C.A.A. championships in the late 1960's and early 1970's. Most fans want to see the big centers dominate and seem to feel cheated if the big men do not score much.

title: Miss Eisenberg, Lawyer, Bride of Richard Mellen
description: Viviane Eisenberg, a lawyer, and Richard Mellen were married yesterday at Club El Morocco. Rabbi Morton Gordon of Little Neck, Queens, performed the ceremony.

title: Repairs Are Planned On 2 Subway Routes
description: A project to repair an eroded track bed on portions of the IRT No. 2 and No. 3 subway lines will disrupt service at night for 15 months beginning tonight, the Transit Authority announced.

title: ABOUT WASHINGTON
description: Facing the cool, glyphic muse of his computer terminal, Jimmy Carter showed up on the front pages here the other day as he sat down to tap out Prsidential memoirs on his own home cathode ray tube.

title: Bridge: New Yorkers Gain 2 Titles In Spring Nationals Event
description: Experts from the New York area dominated the first two major events to be decided at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here last night. Two world champions had a runaway victory in the women's pair championships, but the men's pairs was a foto finish, with 9 match points separating the first five partnerships.

title: Milkman
description: Dyar Miller, a 35-year-old right-handed pitcher trying to win a job in the Mets' bullpen, has done well in exhibition games in Florida. He has made three appearances, pitched 3 1/3 innings and allowed no runs.

title: Miss Caponi 3-Shot Victor
description: Donna Caponi shot a four-under-par 68 today and captured the $200,000 Desert Inn Pro-Am women's golf tournament for the second consecutive year.

title: News Analysis
description: After a number of high-level meetings, public statements, news leaks and sometimes retractions, the Reagan Administration has still not given its Western European allies much sense of the specific policies it will adopt toward the major questions before the alliance.

title: Brooke's Pockets Are Lined With Green
description: Nothing may come between 15-year-old Brooke Shields and her jeans, but as a result of her eye-catching series of television commercials, she has a lot of loose change to put in them.

title: Kush Says Style Won't Change
description: Even before a jury found in his favor on a charge he punched one of his former players, the former Arizona State University football coach Frank Kush had already reached ''a personal decision.''

title: Officials Shifted At the F.T.C.
description: The new head of the Federal Trade Commission on Friday carried out a shake-up of his staff, reassigning the two top consumer protection officials in the agency.

title: General Host to Sell Cudahy's Meat Unit
description: The General Host Corporation, a specialty food retailer and food processor, said it had agreed in principle to sell the major part of the fresh and processed meat business of its Cudahy Foods Company unit to a management group headed by Timothy T. Day, president of Cudahy Foods and executive vice president of General Host.

title: PARAMOUNT CUTTING 'OUTSIZE' FILMS TO SIZE
description: not village idiots, not dummies - two years ago. We were discussing two projects. Each would cost $6 million. We decided that one project was not risky at all at $6 million because it was an entertainment about a zany lady, and we had a big television star, Robert Blake, as the leading man. We made the movie, 'Coast to Coast,' and it was a disaster. The movie we decided was too risky to make - but we went ahead and made it anyway - was 'Ordinary People.' ''

title: AN ARAB DEBT
description: This is in reply to the March 10 letter ''In Lieu of U.N. Help for Palestinians,'' by Hazem Nuseibeh, Jordan's Ambassador to the United Nations.

title: Tides of Taste
description: It's hard not to smile at a report that the great chef Michel Guerard is bored with nouvelle cuisine, the movement toward simpler, lighter dishes that now all but dominates expensive French restaurants everywhere. The new cooking was, even before Mr. Guerard, a worthy revolt.

title: U.N. AGENCY'S VITAL JOB IN THE MIDEAST
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: CZECHS HONOR OWN DVORAK
description: WHEN the Czech Philharmonic, Antonin Dvorak and Carnegie Hall were united on Wednesday night in a performance of the ''New World'' Symphony, the participants had quite a history behind them. The composer conducted the Czechoslovak orchestra in its first concert in 1896. He also attended the world premiere of the work in 1893 - in Carnegie Hall.

title: SQUIRES OF N.Y.A.C. WINS HALF MARATHON
description: Pete Squires of the New York Athletic Club, who took the lead at the 10-mile mark, went on to register a 5-yard victory yesterday over Odis Sanders in the New York Road Runners Club Brooklyn Half-Marathon.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Captures Boston Final, 6-4, 6-4
description: Top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd, coming off a four-month layoff from competitive tennis, recovered from deficits in both sets today to score a 6-4, 6-4 victory over Mima Jausovec of Yugoslavia in the final of the $150,000 Avon championship of Boston.

title: RAPID RISE REPORTED IN NATION'S HOUSING
description: The number of housing units in the United States increased at a rate more than double that of the population from 1970 to 1980, reflecting an accelerating trend toward fewer persons in each household, the Census Bureau reports.

title: L.S.U. Captures Midwest Final, Defeats Wichita State by 96-85
description: With Durand Macklin, their captain and leading scorer, in the locker room with an injured finger for most of the second half, Louisiana State maintained a large lead and beat Wichita State, 96-85, today in the Midwest regional final to earn a place in the Final Four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: Gunmen in West Beirut Fire at the U.S. Embassy
description: Unidentified gunmen in a speeding car fired automatic weapons at the American Embassy in the western sector of Beirut early today and Lebanese guards returned fire, an embassy spokesman said. No injuries or damage were reported.

title: LEGACY OF BOB COOK, CYCLIST: THERE ARE MOUNTIANS TO MOVE
description: DENVER THE Mount Evans Hill Climb is an arduous 28-mile bicycle race that ends on the highest paved road in the United States - 14,264 feet above sea level. Bob Cook holds the record for the race: one hour 54 minutes 27 seconds. He won it the last six times, a feat easily comparable to the three consecutive Boston Marathons won by Bill Rodgers.

title: Sporting Gear; Watercycle for the Adventurous
description: The Wetbike handles like a motorcycle and offers a different kind of excitement on water. Weighing 350 pounds, it has a molded fiberglass hull. It is 7 feet 8 inches long, 2 feet 1 inch wide and 3 feet 6 inches high. It holds two adults on padded seats and has a maximum speed of 30 miles an hour, provided by a two-cylinder, 50-horsepower engine. A safety switch and a spring-loaded throttle automatically shut off the engine if the driver takes a spill. The Wetbike can be hauled on a boat trailer and it can be wheeled across sand with the aid of an accessory, the Beach Buddy. The 1981 model costs $2,795, the trailer $295 and the Beach Buddy $95. For information on retail outlets, write to Nero Equipment Division, P.O. Box C-51, 1370 County Road 8, Canandaigua, N.Y. 14424, telephone (716) 398-3950.

title: W.B.L. Fillies Draw League Suspension
description: The Minnesota Fillies postponed a game set for tonight against the Dallas Diamonds after the league suspended their coach and eight players last night.

title: U.S. STUDY OF VETERANS TIES COMBAT STRAIN TO SEVERAL IMPAIRMENTS
description: Six years after the Vietnam War, the Government's principal study of the war's effect on the lives of Vietnam combat veterans has concluded that they are plagued by ''significantly more'' emotional, social, educational and job-related problems than those who were not in battle.

title: MONASTIC LIFE RESURGENT 1,500 YEARS AFTER ORIGIN
description: Hundreds of Roman Catholic monks, nuns and lay people met at St. Anselm's College here today to close a year of celebrations marking the 1,500th anniversary of the birth of St. Benedict, whose book, ''The Rule,'' a handbook on monastic life, inspired the movement that influenced Christianity more than any other single activity since the preaching of the Apostles of Jesus.ters of temporal power they were in the monastic practice of disciplined community prayer is becoming more popular among Christians.

title: CARD SWAPPING AND WILLIE MAYS STAR AT NEW YORK BASEBALL SHOW
description: When Adam Levy of Westport, Conn., turned 13 two months ago, his mother gave him $40. Yesterday, he brought it into New York City to invest.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The idea that's been established over the last 10 years, that almost in life ought to be provided, financed by the Government as a matter of basic right, is wrong.

title: JUMBO ELLIOTT OF VILLANOVA IS DEAD: LONG AN OUTSTANDING TRACK COACH
description: James F. (Jumbo) Elliott, track coach at Villanova University in Philadelphia since 1935, died yesterday morning of cardiac arrest at his winter home in Juno Beach, Fla. He was 66 years old.

title: OIL IMPORTS DOWN SHARPLY SINCE DECONTROL
description: The United States has sharply cut its imports of oil since the Reagan Administration lifted all remaining price controls on gasoline and heating oil in late January, Energy Department figures show.

title: Rebates to Continue On Some Ford Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would extend its 10 percent cash rebate program on certain 1981 models through April 5, following announcements by the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation that they would extend their own rebates programs.

title: THEATER: STORIES OF ALEICHEM READ IN YIDDISH AT TOWN HALL
description: THE real world of Sholem Aleichem comes to life on the stage of Town Hall where, ''Die Kleine Mentchalach,'' a reading of his stories - but what a reading! -given this weekend and next in the writer's original Yiddish by three actors who could not be better chosen.

title: Dena Wolf Bride Of Richard Yeskoo
description: Dena Lynn Wolf and Richard C. Yeskoo, New York lawyers, were married yesterday at the Fort Lee, N.J., home of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Scheiman, friends of the bride's family. Judge Sylvia B. Pressler of the New Jersey Supreme Court, Appellate Division, performed the ceremony.

title: THE MORNING LINE; by William Safire
description: Now that Ronald Reagan has been President for all of two months, it is time to start asking, "Who's next?"

title: AT A FUND RAISER FESTIVAL, THE ARTS AND POLITICS MEET
description: It is fast becoming a familiar Washington scene: the mix of political celebrities, corporate chairmen and stars from the worlds of the dance, opera, country music, Hollywood and Broadway.

title: INDIANA GAINS FINAL FOUR, ROUTING ST. JOSEPH'S, 78-46
description: For the three seasons that Jim Lynam has coached basketball at St. Joseph's, the concept has been called four-to-score. It's a delay offense that was supposed to carry the Hawks home to Philadelphia and the Final Four.

title: MAYOR BYRNE PLANS MOVE TO A PROJECT
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne says she and her husband are moving from their stylish Gold Coast apartment to live in a crime-plagued public housing project called Cabrini Green. The Mayor says she will live there for ''as long as it takes to clean it up.''

title: Two Baseball Fans Looking for a Hit From Casey
description: Some plays are written for money and some for fame, but one now seems to have been written at least partly so its authors can meet a certain celebrity.

title: C. Peabody Mohun, Ex-Governor Of Stock Exchange, 76, Is Dead
description: C. Peabody Mohun, a partner in the stock investment firm of Stern, Lauer & Company and a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange, died Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness. Mr. Mohun, who lived in Manhattan, was 76 years old.

title: Pope Says Catholics Have a Duty To Fight Legalization of Abortion
description: Declaring that abortion is the ''killing of an innocent creature,'' Pope John Paul II said today that Roman Catholics had a duty to work against laws legalizing the practice.

title: RANGER SHOOTOUT WITH NORDIQUES ENDS 7-7
description: The New York Rangers scored with just under five minutes left to play last night and tied the Quebec Nordiques, 7-7, as the air in Madison Square Garden was full of pucks flying goalward.

title: The Washington Star
description: Budget cuts proposed by the Reagan Administration threaten a Federal program that paid for research that led to the new effort to reduce Government spending. The Administration's proposals would reduce National Science Foundation financing for research in social and economic sciences by about 80 percent, foundation officials say.

title: First of four articles.
description: Here beside the Red Sea, 20,000 foreign workers are building a $30 billion industrial city of refineries, petrochemical plants, oil storage tanks and piers for supertankers. On the Persian Gulf a thousand miles to the east, another industrial city is rising at Al Jubail at a projected cost of $50 billion; 30,000 foreigners are doing the work.

title: uf813
description: Sheraton Hotel.

title: Connors Triumphs
description: Jimmy Connors won a $175,000 World Championship Tennis tournament today, defeating Gene Mayer, 6-1, 2-6, 6-2. The match was played before a capacity crowd of 7,000 at the Ahoy Sports Hall.

title: Seagram Claims Takeover Truce
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, the Canadian distiller involved in a contested takeover bid for the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, said yesterday that both companies had agreed to end or suspend the various law suits they had filed against each other.

title: Vigilante Patrol Continues At Atlanta Housing Project
description: Vigilantes armed with handguns and baseball bats patrolled the city's largest public housing project today, despite appeals from police officers investigating the slayings of 20 black children and the disappearances of two.

title: MORRIS ABRAMS
description: Morris Abrams, board chairman of the Arrow Fastener Company of Saddle Brook, N.J., died last Friday at the Englewood (N.J.) Hospital.

title: CHINA'S PRIESTS, STICKLERS FOR LATIN, DISAVOW VATICAN
description: Five masses were celebrated this morning in Holy Mary, Mother of God Cathedral, as has happened every Sunday since it reopened in November 1979. Hundreds of Catholics attended each mass, and many remained for religious instruction,

title: HERZOG JUNGLE FILM HALTS AS ILL ROBARDS LEAVES
description: The fate of Werner Herzog's new film, ''Fitzcarraldo,'' on which production was suspended last month, after six weeks of shooting in the Amazon jungle of Peru, has become a mystery. Production stopped when Jason Robards, one of the stars, became seriously ill with amoebic dysentery and was forced to return to his home in Connecticut to recuperate.

title: Babcock Coal Plants
description: Babcock Woodall-Duckham Ltd., a subsidiary of Babcock International Ltd., said it had signed an agreement with the state government of Sao Paulo, Brazil, to supply two coal gasificiation plants worth $60 million. One plant would produce 15 billion British thermal units of power a day and use about 300,000 tons of coal a year. The second would produce three billion B.T.U.'s a day and use about 60,000 tons of coal annually, Babcock said.

title: ARCHITECTS' MIDTOWN PLAN SEEKING A BALANCED CITY
description: In their new offices in the restored Villard Houses at 51st Street and Madison Avenue, the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects has put the finishing touches on one of its most ambitious projects - a development strategy for midtown Manhattan - and is awaiting the reaction of public and planners.

title: ERUPTION ENDS AT MT. ETNA IN SICILY
description: Mount Etna spewed ashes from its main crater today, but experts said the weeklong eruption by Europe's most active volcano appeared to have ended.

title: SPOORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Hockey, and not merely a player in a brawl, may be on trial in a case pending in New Haven, where an official is suing a player, contending that the player assaulted him. The repercussions could go beyond the Connecticut courts.

title: RUTHERFORD CAPTURES 150-MILER IN PHOENIX
description: Johnny Rutherford, the defending national driving champion, scored an easy victory in the Kraco-Jimmy Bryan 150 today at Phoenix International Raceway.

title: ACCIDENT INVESTIGATION MAY SLOW PREPARATION FOR SHUTTLE LAUNCHING
description: The investigation into the fatal launching-pad accident at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida continued yesterday amid growing signs that it would cause further delays in preflight preparations for the space shuttle Columbia and preclude a launching in the week of April 5.

title: Coal Company Is Fined In Fatal Mine Explosion
description: The Westmoreland Coal Company has been fined $255,450 by the West Virginia Department of Mines for violations at a mine where an explosion killed five men.

title: City May Not Meet Air-Quality Deadline
description: Increased car use caused by deteriorating subway service has made it impossible for New York City to meet current Federal clean-air standards without federal mass-transit funds and other assistance, the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner said.

title: 6 Arrested in Coast Clash Of Khomeini Demonstrators
description: About 1,000 jeering demonstrators, supporters and opponents of the Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, clashed today in MacArthur Park, closing down a section of Wilshire Boulevard with scuffling that resulted in six arrests.

title: NORTH CAROLINA RELIES ON BIG THREE AS IT HEADS INTO FINAL FOUR
description: Al Wood had the open jump shot but passed instead to James Worthy. With an almost certain 2 points from close range, Worthy sent another pass to a leaping Sam Perkins, who stuffed the ball and then dropped in a foul shot for a 3-point play.

title: DR. MORRIS JACOBS, EX-HOSPITALS CHIEF
description: Dr. Morris Abraham Jacobs, a former Commissioner of Hospitals in New York City, died yesterday at his home in Pompton Lakes, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: Mauritania Tries Plot Suspects
description: A group of people accused of taking part in the abortive coup in Mauritania last Monday have gone on trial there, the Algerian news agency reported today. The Mauritanian news agency said in a statement last night that the trial was opening, but gave no further details, the Algerian agency reported.

title: CLUB THAT NUTURED PRIDE AND FRIENDSHIP
description: Club 16, though somewhat amorphous, is alive today, not in the black-painted rented-basement Lower East Side clubhouse at 16 Ridge Street, a building that no longer exists, but in the heads and hearts of its former members. They are a group of successful men who have forgotten neither their roots nor one another.

title: Puerto Rican Forum Gets Grant
description: The National Puerto Rican Forum has been awarded $353,000 under the Federal Comprehensive Employment and Training Act to train 125 New York City workers facing termination of CETA public service jobs because of budget cuts. Fernando Camacho, deputy executive director of the forum's New York operations, said a six-month program would focus on clerical skills, such as typing, and would start April 13 at the forum's human development center, 151 West 51st Street. It calls for placing all 125 persons in unsubisidized employment on completion of training.

title: JERSEY POLITICS KEYED TO A LAME-DUCK GOVERNOR AND REDISTRICTING
description: Governor Byrne driving his own car and lawmakers walking around with crayon stains on their hands are two signs of the changes that are taking place in New Jersey in this election year.

title: Pacers 107, Cavaliers 101
description: Billy Knight scored 16 of his game-high 33 points in the third quarter, leading the Pacers to a 107-101 victory over Cleveland.

title: Lincoln Tunnel Adds An Extra Toll Lane
description: A new toll lane for buses and car pools is to open today at the Lincoln Tunnel to improve traffic flow into Manhattan and save time and fuel for motorists, according to Alan Sagner, chairman of or the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: HELCA BIDS $165 MILLION FOR DAY
description: The Hecla Mining Company has offered to acquire Day Mines Inc. in an exchange of stock valued at about $165 million. Completion of the transaction would make Hecla the nation's largest silver producer.

title: Advertising; Executive Drawn by Compton
description: IT wasn't easy for Robert H. Savage to leave the presidency of KM&G International, the country's 25th-largest agency, and the chairmanship of its Botsford Ketchum office in San Francisco. But the offer from O. Milton Gossett, chairman and chief executive officer of Compton Advertising, was just too good. Besides it would mean returning to New York, the fastest track of all.

title: Susan Sicher Married to Lawrence Kudlow
description: Susan Cullman Sicher and Lawrence A. Kudlow were married yesterday in Washington by Federal District Court Judge John J. Sirica. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar M. Cullman of New York and Stamford, Conn., is president of Call for Action, a national nonprofit volunteer organization that operates an action and referral service in 40 cities. Mr. Kudlow is assistant director for economic policy in the Office of Management and Budget.

title: NETS LOSE TO MILWAUKEE, 125-116
description: Since the Milwaukee Bucks have already clinched first place in the Central Division and gained a bye in the first round of the playoffs, about the only goal left for them in the regular season is to win 60 games.

title: FRENCH REINFORCE TROOPS IN BANGUI
description: France was reported to have reinforced its garrison today in the capital of the Central African Republic because of demonstrations following the election victory of the French-backed incumbent President, David Dacko.

title: Big Men on Campus
description: In only his second full year of running, Ian Daley, a 23-year-old junior at Maryland-Eastern Shore, has become a national figure in track competition. In the last month, he has been a finalist in the 600-yard runs of the two major national indoor championships - the USA/Mobil Feb. 27 in Madison Square Garden and the National Collegiate March 14 in Detroit.

title: WHAT JOEL SIEGEL IS DOING FOR OSCARS
description: The broadcast of the 53d annual Academy Awards, beginning at 10 P.M. next Monday on ABC-TV, will be preceded at 7:30 P.M. on WABC-TV by ''The Joel Siegel $10 Oscar Show,'' a program of film clips of nominees, a behind-the-scenes Oscar poll and predictions by New York film critics.

title: A Wish Comes True for a 'Fair Lady' Understudy
description: Milo O'Shea, the Irish actor who has been touring in ''My Fair Lady,'' now playing in Chicago, says it happened just this way: Mr. O'Shea's mother died last week, and when he returned to Chicago after the funeral, he and his wife, Kitty Sullivan, the understudy for the part of Liza, went to church together, supposedly to pray for his mother's soul.

title: Coors Gets Approval Of Pollution Unit
description: The Adolph Coors Company said that the United States Environmental Protection Agency had approved an airpollution permit for its proposed brewery in Rockingham County, Va.

title: Mugabe Supporters Hurl Stones At Political Rivals in Zimbabwe
description: Hundreds of followers of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe threw stones at some of his political opponents until troops dispersed them with tear gas, officials said today. No injuries were reported.

title: U.S. UNIT IS RELYING ON SLEEK NEW ARMS
description: The Ninth Infantry Division here has plunged into what its officers call a renaissance in military thinking. The object is to prepare the division for combat as a light infantry unit in the Rapid Deployment Force, ready for combat in the deserts of Southwest Asia or the Arctic wastes.

title: CHALLENGE TO BUSING; News
description: TheCalifornia Supreme Court's recent decision to allow the dismantling of a program to integrate the Los Angeles schools through busing may be of greater national significance as a symbol than as a legal precedent.

title: WATCHING DAVID
description: STOCKMAN To the Editor:

title: FOR ISLANDERS' BILLY SMITH, THR GAME IS A
description: JOB, THE GOAL IS HIS TURF By GEORGE VECSEY

title: The Economy
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, promised some results in the inflation battle by the end of the year. But he said it was too much to expect consumer prices to be held to the 8.3 percent rate projected by the Administration for 1982. (Page A1.)

title: DISCIPLINE PROBLEMS WITH A CHILD
description: ''W E'RE trying to bring stepparents out of the closet so they can feel better about themselves,'' said Tamara Engel, a family therapist, who has designed T-shirts for them to wear out of the closet. One shirt is emblazoned with ''wicked stepparent,'' but the ''wicked'' is crossed out and a heart encircles ''stepparent.''

title: RACE TO SUCCEED STOCKMAN TESTS HIS COATTAILS VERSUS MORAL MAJORITY
description: Moral Majority, President Reagan's economic recovery plan and the political coattails of David A. Stockman will be tested Tuesday in a Congressional primary election in southwestern Michigan.

title: 22-YEAR BATTLE BY SON OF BARTOK OVER ESTATE IS NEARING DECISION
description: After a 22-year legal battle over the estate of the composer Bela Bartok, a decision is near in Manhattan Surrogate's Court on whether to award $1.3 million in ''legal fees and expenses'' to the composer's son Peter, a sound recording technician who has been representing himself in the case.

title: WEIGHT-LIFTING MARK BETTERED BY RUSSIANS
