description: Vladimir Marchuk of the Soviet Union broke the world record in the super-heavy-weight clean and jerk today at an international weight-lifting tournament in the Ukrainian city of Lvov, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When did major league teams start wearing numbers on their baseball uniforms?

title: COAL BARGAINING RESUMES AGAIN IN SURPRISE TALKS
description: Union and coal company negotiators returned to the bargaining table at 1:45 A.M. today in a surprise resumption of stalled contract talks that, even if successful, cannot avoid a strike on Friday by 160,000 miners.

title: Apple Computer Chief Named Vice Chairman
description: At the age of 38, Michael M. Scott, president and chief executive officer of Apple Computer Inc., the home computer maker, has been named vice chairman.

title: 12 Die as Landslide in Yugoslavia Sweeps 2 Cars of Train Into River
description: At least 12 people were killed and 35 injured when a landslide swept two cars of a train into the Morava River today, rail officials said.

title: MORMONS OF MISSOURI HUMBLE, HAPPY, DOCUMENTED
description: ''We feel humble about the whole thing,'' Wayne Qualls, a retired welder, was saying as he made his way slowly through the chill drizzle and into the warmth of the old Stone Church. ''We have known this all the time.''

title: SON CHARGED IN SLAYING OF PARENTS
description: A 22-year-old man was charged yesterday with stabbing his parents to death in their apartment in the Windsor Park development in Bayside, Queens, the police said.

title: REGULATORS BATTLE OVER FUTURES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission have been engaged, virtually since the founding of the futures agency in 1975, in a jurisdictional battle little noticed outside of their respective regulated fields.

title: VULNERABLE IN ATLANTA
description: The tragedy of Atlanta is not only a tragedy of murdered children but also of poor children. Only the police will stop the killing. But poor children are always vulnerable to trouble of one kind or another. They need help.

title: T.W.A. Sets Cuts in Overseas Fares
description: In a move aimed at boosting its sluggish trans-Atlantic traffic, Trans World Airlines announced steep reductions in discount and standby fares for flights to London from New York and Los Angeles.

title: NEW ELECTRIC RATE CHILLS HOMEOWNERS
description: ''When we moved in, this was a big open place, that's all,'' said David Brody, gesturing toward his airy living room. But now, he says, the room is a white elephant, abandoned for the winter.

title: Red Smith; On Losing For Profit
description: AGROUP in Nashville, Tenn., that includes a couple of country and western singers has a tentative agreement to buy 42 percent of the Minnesota Twins from Gabriel Murphy of Washington. If the deal goes through, the absentee buyers will not have control of the club because Calvin Griffith will continue to vote 52 percent of the stock - his own 26 percent and the 26 percent owned by his sister, Mrs. Thelma Griffith Haynes. This should ease any doubts that might be entertained by Bowie Kuhn, who looks with horror upon absentee owners not named George M. Steinbrenner 3d.

title: HEAVY BORROWING EXPECTED
description: Public and private borrowers are expected to flood the fixed-income debt market this week to take advantage of the recent decline in credit costs. Indeed, the slate of announced new offerings is far from complete, according to several investment bankers, because many of the new issues were only filed last Thursday and Friday.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MARCH 23, 1981
description: Talks were suspended in Warsaw between the union leader Lech Walesa and Deputy Prime Minister Mieczyslaw Rakowski without any resolution of the crisis caused by a police attack on union members last week. The official press agency said the talks would resume on Wednesday. Mr. Walesa said that the top leaders of the union, known as Solidarity, would meet today to decide whether to call a national protest strike. (Page A1, Column 4.) Western influence in Saudi Arabia and its impact on Islamic traditions is worrying the Saudis. The Western encroachment began with Saudi Arabia's industrial development made possible by its huge oil revenues and the help of foreign laborers and technicians. The Saudi boom has attracted 2.5 million foreigners, almost half of the total native population of 5.5 million. (A1:3-5.)

title: QUEBEC ELECTIONS COULD AVERT TAKEOVER
description: The Asbestos Corporation and its American owner, the General Dynamics Corporation, which have been battling for three years to stave off expropriation by the Quebec government, may finally be saved by the bell.

title: Reader Cues Writer
description: The way Sir John Mills, the British actor, tells it, when he and his wife landed at Kennedy International Airport last week, they couldn't find the driver they had expected to meet them.

title: Weaver Suspended 3 Games by League
description: Earl Weaver, the Baltimore Orioles' manager, was suspended today for three spring training exhibition games.

title: YAMANI DENIES PLAN TO CUT OIL OUTPUT
description: Sheik Ahmad Zaki Yamani, the Saudi oil minister, has denied recent reports suggesting that Saudi Arabia might reduce its current crude oil production of about 10.3 million barrels a day.

title: A.M.C. Cancels New Stock Offer
description: The American Motors Corporation said it had decided against offering 20 million new shares of common stock to its existing stockholders as contemplated in its new financing arrangement with the French auto maker Renault.

title: DALLAS JUDGE QUITS DESEGREGATION CASE
description: The surprise withdrawal Friday of the judge who presided over this city's school desegreation case for more than a decade has added an element of complexity to the case, already one of the nation's longest-running school desegregation battles.

title: Donna Terranella and Stephen Leeb, Editors, Married
description: The marriage of Donna Terranella to Stephen Leeb took place yesterday at the Manhattan home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Ross. Surrogate Millard L. Midonick performed the ceremony.

title: A BIG QUESTION MARK IN ISRAELI ELECTION CAMPAIGN: MOSHE DAYAN'S INTERMITTENT CANDIDACY
description: The unpredictable and enigmatic Moshe Dayan has thrown Israel's election campaign into uncertainty.

title: RAVITCH EXPECTS THE PASSAGE OF NEW TAX ON OIL RECEIPTS
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday he expected the State Legislature to amend and reenact the gross-receipts tax on oil companies if the tax was found unconstitutional because of a clause prohibiting the companies from passing it along to consumers.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Friday incorrectly gave the year that the prototype of the B-1 bomber was unveiled. It was in 1974.

title: Piscataway Obtains Apology From NBC for Skit
description: It was a mock television commercial for the fictitious ''United Chemical Company'' of the very real Piscataway, N.J., and it portrayed a supposedly brain-damaged worker eating his lunch amid clouds of noxious chemical dust.

title: Police Say Passenger May Have Shot Pair
description: A young couple who were found dead in their car on Saturday may have been shot by someone else in the auto, the police said.

title: by Charles Fager
description: As the Reagan Administration searches relentlessly for more and more Federal programs to cut, it is incredible that Federal subsidies to the maritime industry, which total about a billion dollars a year, have thus far largely escaped the knife.

title: Texaco to Shut Plant
description: Texaco Inc. said it would close its Lockport, Ill. refinery because of decreased petroleum product demand.

title: STAGNATION EXPECTED IN U.S. SOVIET TRADE
description: Soviet-American trade, reduced to a trickle after the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan, is unlikely to improve substantially for some time, even without new political crises.

title: OUTDOORS: NO SNOWSHOE RABBITS, JUST GOOD COMPANY
description: brewed beer and some splendid hard cider.

title: Kogler of Austria Wins Ski Jump Title
description: Armin Kogler of Austria was second in the 90-meter jump today and won the World Cup ski jump title.

title: A SUNNY STROLL AMID POTSHOTS MARKS GULF WAR
description: Grinning cheerfully, the bearded Iranian commando patted his Kalashnikov assault rifle and pointed to the western edge of Susangird.

title: GUITAR RECITAL: SEGOVIA OFFERS A VARIED PROGRAM
description: GOVERNMENTS fall and the polar ice cap shifts, but an Andres Segovia recital does not change. The Spanish guitarist, 88 years old and returning to Carnegie Hall for the first time in more than a decade, walked onto the stage last night and received the first of several standing ovations from a sold-out house. Nothing new about that, you say? Of course not, but there is nothing new either about a glass of fine dry sherry. You can enjoy it, nonetheless.

title: U.S. Gymnasts Sweep
description: Julianne McNamara and Bart Conner captured the all-round championships today at the sixth annual American Cup gymnastics competition.

title: Sparked by Return of Dawkins, 76ers Turn Back Celtics, 126-94
description: The return of Darryl Dawkins, some hot shooting by Julius Erving and the leadership of Maurice Cheeks spelled doom today for the Boston Celtics.

title: by Francis L. Loewenheim
description: When the President of the United States, in this case Ronald Reagan, literally invents an important foreign policy statement by one of his illustrious predecessors - Franklin D. Roosevelt - that is, or should be, national news.

title: Commodities; The Lures Of Money Futures
description: DESPITE their outward complexity, financial futures continue to be the fastest-growing segment of the commodities market. One reason is that the proportion of hedgers to speculators is much higher than in most other futures markets. Another is that financial futures are basically markets in interest rates, and the volatility of interest rates in the past few years has been far greater than in most other commodities markets.

title: No Headline
description: Three deer penned in Ford Park here were shot with a bow, the police reported today. Two were killed and the third had to be destroyed. Four arrows with aluminum shafts and hunting tips were found in the pen when the dead animals were discovered yesterday, the police said, reporting that all 20 white Australian deer were in good shape Friday night.

title: Washington Watch; 'Back Door' Military Aid
description: WASHINGTON THE Federal Financing Bank, which provides money for the Tennessee Valley Authority, Amtrak, student loans, New York City and the Washington subway system, is quietly assuming an important military and foreign policy role.

title: VOLCKER FORECASTS PROGRESS THIS YEAR IN INFLATION BATTLE
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the United States would ''begin seeing some progress'' in the battle against inflation late this year and that once the corner had been turned it would become progressively easier to reduce the inflation rate further.

title: 'UNITED HANDS NEED PREVAIL' IN ATLANTA
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: 'CHUCKY'S HUNCH,' A ROCHELLE OWENS PLAY
description: THE downfallen middle-aged hero of Rochelle Owens's new, onecharacter play, ''Chucky's Hunch,'' isn't your everyday loser. He's a truly spectacular wreck. Chucky is an unemployed drunk who suffers from high blood pressure, rotten teeth and almost terminal loneliness. He lives in a dilapidated house in upstate New York with his 82-year-old mother, a dog and some cats. For amusement, he fights with his mom and writes letters to Elly, the second of his three former wives. Elly is on Chucky's mind because he's just read in the paper that she won the state lottery. But Chucky apparently isn't on Elly's mind: she never bothers to write him back.

title: NET LOSS
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGHER MAIL RATES TIPTOE IN AS PATRONS GRUMBLE
description: The self-service stamp machines at the General Post Office were offering some new supermarket-style "combination specials" yesterday. On sale were five 18-cent stamps for 90 cents; five 3-cent ones for 15 cents or, for 20 cents, one 18-cent stamp and two 1-cent ones. Window clerks were already supplied with books of the purple "B" stamps - the interim 18 cent stamps - 24 for $4.32.

title: SPAIN MOVES TO COUNTER BASQUE REBELS
description: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo and a group of Cabinet ministers decided today on new measures to try to curb terrorism following last night's assassination of a second Spanish Army colonel, apparently by Basque separatists.

title: Proud Appeal Wins the Bay Shore Easily
description: Proud Appeal won the $54,900 Bay Shore at Aqueduct yesterday, sprinting the seven furlongs in 1:22 1/5 on a cuppy surface that was listed as fast but appeared to be at least two seconds slow.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ANOTHER BELLE VUE

title: POLISH REGIME ENDS PARLEY WITH UNION WITHOUT AGREEMENT
description: Nearly five hours of talks between the Government and the independent labor union movement ended inconclusively today, with no public statements to reassure the country that it had surmounted the crisis caused by a police attack on a group of union members last week.

title: WOMEN SPEAKING OUT ON EFFECTS OF DUTY IN VIETNAM
description: In the spring of 1979, a siren sounded at a volunteer firehouse in West Islip, L.I. Lynda Van Devanter, a guest in a nearby house, began to scream. The last time she had heard that wailing noise she was an Army nurse in the central highlands of South Vietnam. It was identical to the sound of the red-alert siren that signaled rocket and mortar attacks over Pleiku.

title: Economists Unclear About Rate Outlook
description: Many economists, a bit stunned after last week's sharp rise and then fall in the credit markets, say they are uncertain about the outlook for interest rates in the week ahead.

title: Pakistan Asks Syria To Extradite 3 Hijackers
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq said today that he had asked Syria to extradite the three hijackers of a Pakistani jetliner who surrendered in Damascus on March 14 and released more than 100 hostages after holding them for 13 days.stani prisoners.

title: 2 Employees in Massage Parlor Are Shot in Dispute With Patrons
description: Two employees of a massage parlor in midtown Manhattan were shot early this morning during a dispute with three patrons over the amount to be paid for services provided at the parlor, the police said.

title: Girl Born While Doctors Began an Abortion Is 'Fine'
description: An infant girl born while doctors unwittingly sought to perform an abortion on a woman about eight months pregnant was "doing fine," hospital officials said today.

title: DEFENDANT IN A MURDER PUTS THE DEVIL ON TRIAL
description: In the Book of Matthew, an encounter between Jesus and two demon-possessed men is described, and the demons beg: ''If you drive us out, send us into the herd of pigs.'' He does, the passage recounts, ''and the whole herd rushed down the steep bank into the lake and died in the water.''

title: U.S.-JAPAN TRADE TIES ON AGENDA
description: Japan's Foreign Minister, Masayoshi Ito, who arrived here last night for talks with the Reagan Administration, is expected to convey his country's willingness to examine requests for voluntary restraints on Japanese auto exports.

title: THE P.A. HAS THE WRONG IDEA ABOUT INDUSTRIAL PARKS
description: To the The Port Authority, which has just decided formally to build a series of industrial parks in and around the city, is in principle adopting a certain model of economic trend here and in other Northeastern cities: it assumes that manufacturing and other industry are shrinking primarily because of shortages of suitable land and buildings and that removing these shortages by public action will retain manufacturing firms and indeed attract new ones.

title: JOHN GILHOOLEY, 59, EX-TRANSIT OFFICIAL
description: John J. Gilhooley, who served as senior commissioner of the New York City Transit Authority from 1962 to 1968, died yesterday at his home in Franklin Lakes, N.J., after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

title: Two Co-op Accounts Move to New Agencies
description: There are two switched co-op advertising accounts in the news this morning. The National Bowling Council has moved to Colarossi-Griswold-Eshleman from Needham, Harper & Steers.

title: FRIENDS BY SALE OF ARMS
description: March 22 - Even Congressional critics of the sale of advanced fighter planes to Taiwan, such as New York's Representative Stephen Solarz, now feel there isn't likely to be any significant opposition to it in the Administration.

title: U.S. Acts to Restore Conviction Of Ex-Army Doctor in 3 Slayings
description: The Federal Government has asked the Supreme Court to reinstate the 1979 conviction of Dr. Jeffrey MacDonald for the murder of his wife and two daughters at Fort Bragg, N.C., 11 years ago.

title: Sports World Specials; Revenue Sharing
description: Five years ago, when Indiana won the National Collegiate basketball championship at Philadelphia, the victory produced more than $143,000 for the university. This year, a trip to the Final Four at Philadelphia is expected to earn $400,000.

title: STEINBRENNER PUTS GRIFFIN OUT OF YANK'S PICTURE AFTER LOSS TO METS
description: Before the game, George Steinbrenner said: ''I used to put more importance on winning exhibition games. I didn't know what I was talking about. We didn't have young players to look at. Now we do and it's more important to look at them than to win.''

title: The U.N. Today; March 23, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 5 to 6 P.M.

title: Salvador Rebels Said to Kill 24 in Hit-and-Run Attacks
description: Twenty-four people were found dead in El Salvador today as leftist guerrillas kept up hit-and-run attacks against Government forces, an army spokesman said.

title: Jaeckel Gets Day Off
description: For the last four Tournament Players Championships, Barry Jaeckel has missed the cut and spent the weekend in his motel room watching basketball playoffs. Jaeckel, who is an avid fan, watched his fill of televised basketball today, but not because he had missed the cut.

title: 2 Die in Brussels Storm
description: Winds of up to 65 miles per hour lashed Belgium today, killing at least two people in the capital, officials reported. A police spokesman said a child was killed by a falling tree branch in the northern part of Brussels. High winds also felled a tree that struck a parked car, killing one person inside the vehicle, the spokesman said.

title: COAL'S PROSPECTS AND PROBLEMS
description: Coal strikes used to be different. John L. Lewis, a thatch of unruly hair falling across his grizzled face, would thunder at the mine owners, ''Time, as it shrinks your purse, may modify your niggardly and antisocial propensities.''

title: Callaghan Is Visiting India
description: Former Prime Minister James Callaghan left today for an eight-day visit to India. Mr. Callaghan will deliver a lecture and tour northern India, where he is to watch the shooting of a movie based on the life of Gandhi.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE UNFORGETTABLE SEASON. By G.H. Fleming. Foreword by Lawrence Ritter. 334 pages. Illustrated. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $16.95.

title: Margaret Ditmars, Banker, Bride of Keith H. Swartley
description: Margaret Emerson Ditmars and Keith Hamilton Swartley were married yesterday in Larchmont, N.Y., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Earl E. Ditmars. The Rev. William B. Heyward, a Presbyterian minister of Clearwater, Fla., and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: SUSPECT SHOT AFTER 12 ARE ROBBED AT CASH MACHINE
description: A dozen customers at a Citibank electronic banking center on the East Side were forced to turn their banking cards over to two robbers, who withdrew more than $3,000 from the victims' accounts Saturday night, the police said.

title: Off-Duty Police, Off-Duty Guns
description: There was tragic timeliness in Police Commissioner McGuire's announcement that city police officers will no longer be required to carry their guns while off duty. The order came only hours after the fatal shooting of one policeman, reportedly by another, on the way home from an extended St. Patrick's Day celebration.

title: Voluntary Cuts Of Imports Sought
description: The Reagan Administration will concentrate on a voluntary rollback of Japanese automobile imports and will not support legislative curbs, Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis said.

title: Associated Press
description: FORD CARRIES MESSAGE TO CHINA: Former President Gerald R. Ford meeting with Foreign Minister Huang Hua in Peking. Mr. Ford, who said a purpose of his visit was to convey messages from President Reagan, met with Deputy Prime Minister Deng Xiaoping, apparently to ease Chinese concern over future U.S. relations.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dan River Inc. has appointed Arthur C. Wiener president of the Apparel Fabrics Marketing Division.

title: Savarin Now Promoting Instant Coffee on TV
description: El Exigente, the demanding one, long-time symbol of excellence for Savarin ground coffee, makes his debut today in the New York as a TV spokesman for Savarin instant coffee.

title: Dr. Allan Joshua Tobin Weds Dr. Janet Hadda
description: Dr. Janet Ruth Hadda and Dr. Allan Joshua Tobin, teachers at the University of California at Los Angeles, were married there yesterday at the Hillel Jewish Student Center. Rabbis David Berner and Chaim Seidler-Feller performed the ceremony.

title: Index
description: Priests in China, practicing again, disavow Vatican A2< Weeklong eruption has apparently ended at Mount Etna in Sicily A3< French reportedly reinforce troops in Central African city A4< Around the World A5< Moshe Dayan throws Israel's election campaign into uncertainty A6< Sharp probes and surprise raids mark 6 months of gulf war A7< American infantry unit counts on technology to give it an edge A11< Government/Politics About Washington: Apres moi le deluge A12 Michigan tests Stockman coat- tails versus Moral Majority A14 Election year brings unusual sights in Jersey B2 Ravitch predicts reenactment of gross-receipts tax on oil B4 Reagan budget cuts threaten the research that led to them B10 Congressmen try to trim $2 billion Government printing costs B10 Energy With new electric rates, home- owners cede a room to winter B6 General Around the Nation A12 Queens man is charged with stab- bing his parents to death B4 Suspect shoot after robbery at bank cash machine B4 Baseball card aficionados splurge at 3-day show B8 Religion Missouri Mormons humble but happy with new standing A12 Monastic life resurgent 1,500 years after Benedict B15 Health/Science Inquiry on fatal accident may delay space shuttle launching A12 SportsMonday Baseball: Steinbrenner upset after Yankees lose to Mets C8 Basketball: Indiana routs St. Jo- seph's and reaches Final Four C1

title: Knight Wins It His Own Way
description: ON other occasions, Bobby Knight has grabbed the public-address microphone in Assembly Hall and chastised the spectators for not cheering enough. In the moments after Indiana had toyed with St. Joseph's, 78-46, yesterday, and qualified for the Final Four of the National Collegiate basketball tournament, he picked up the microphone and thanked all the hometown Hoosier loyalists who had ''hung in there with us'' when his team had been struggling with a 7-5 record early in the season.

title: Inquiry Is Scheduled Into Bronx Shootout
description: The Bronx District Attorney will investigate a shootout between the police and a teen-ager at a closed roller disco rink Saturday night that left one rink employee dead and another wounded, authorities said.

title: CONGRESSMEN TRYING TO TRIM GOVERNMENT'S $2 BILLION PRINTING COSTS
description: Efforts are under way n the Senate and the House to reduce the Federal Government's annual printing bill, which has been estimated at nearly $2 billion a year.

title: Dokes Outpoints Cobb in 10-Rounder
description: Michael Dokes, the World Boxing Council's No. 3-ranked contender, scored a majority decision over Randy Cobb today in a nationally televised 10-round heavyweight fight.

title: LIBERALS MUST TAKE COURAGE AND FIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: DOCTORS' UNION VOWS TO CONTINUE WALKOUT
description: Citing the backing of its membership, the leaders of the strike by physicians-in-training at nine hospitals in New York City announced yesterday that the walkout would continue.

title: STAGE: 'GLASSHOUSE,' ABOUT APARTHEID
description: FATIMA DIKE'S ''Glasshouse,'' at the Theater at St. Peter's Church, is yet another demonstration that great subjects alone cannot automatically deliver rewarding evenings of theater. In this South African drama, a black playwright is writing from first-hand experience about the moral blight of apartheid. Miss Dike knows whereof she speaks, but, alas, she is less knowledgeable about writing plays. In ''Glasshouse,'' some undeniably powerful thoughts and feelings suffer from theatrical malnutrition.

title: Wurzburger Hofbrau Beer
description: The latest roll out of Wurzburger Hofbrau, Anheuser-Busch's entry into the imported brew business, continues as it started, market by market rather than state by state. Yesterday, the beer began its distribution in parts of Maine, Rhode Island, Vermont and western Massachusetts, having earlier achieved distribution in Boston, Hartford and Atlanta, which had been the test markets, and last spring in seven other markets: Washington and two markets each in Maryland, Kentucky and Ohio. TBWA Advertising is the agency. It has created the line, ''A man's beer is his castle'' to go with the castle on the label.

title: Spain Adopts an Army Plan To Fight Basque Guerrillas
description: Spain's leaders bowed to pressure today and agreed to send the army into the Basque country to reinforce police fighting separatist guerrillas.

title: Lisbon Accused by Communists Of Handing Island Over to NATO
description: The Portuguese Communist Party accused the Government today of handing over to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization the island of Porto Santo, off Morocco.

title: Two Women and a Man Slain in a Queens Home
description: Two women and a man were found dead from gunshot wounds in the basement of a Jamaica, Queens, house early this morning, the police said.

title: With Left Shoulder Injury
description: The Toronto Maple Leafs' all-star defenseman, Borje Salming, has a separated left shoulder and is expected to miss the rest of the regular season.

title: 'THE CON EDISON SERVICE COMMISSION'
description: To the Editor:

title: Agency Roster Cut Is Set by Mennen
description: The Mennen Company's decision to cut its agency roster from three to two has had a positive impact on Grey Advertising, a negative impact on McCann-Erickson and no impact whatsoever on SSC&B.

title: Reading Digital Clocks
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES: The conclusion drawn by the psychologists noted in your article ''The Digital Clock as a Timesaver'' (March 17) is totally without foundation. Their experiment involves the comparing and converting of written words to digital or analog (a clock face) information and has essentially nothing whatever to do with time or the reading of time.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MARCH 24, 1981
description: International A planned aid program for Pakistan was disclosed by Reagan Administration officials. They said that the Administration had tentatively decided to offer Pakistan about $500 million in military and economic assistance in the coming fiscal year. That is more than double the amount that was offered by the Carter Administration and rejected by the Pakistanis as insufficient. (Page A1, Column 3.) An increase in aid to Zimbabwe, to a total of about $225 million over the next three years, has been backed by the Reagan Administration. The pledge to seek Congressional approval for the increase is to be made public today at a conference called by Prime Minister Robert Mugabe in Salisbury to seek international support for a three-year development program costing about $2 billion. (A1:1-2.)

title: COAL NEGOITIATORS IN TENATIVE ACCORD ON NEW 3-YEAR PACT
description: The United Mine Workers of America and the major coal operators in Appalachia and the Middle West agreed today on a proposed new contract after five hours of overnight bargaining.

title: Ceremony Tomorrow To Herald Literary Week
description: By proclamation of Mayor Koch, next Saturday through April 3 will be Literary Week in New York City.

title: 3 Governors Urge House To Back Water Project
description: The governors of Alabama, Mississippi and Tennessee urged a House subcommittee today to support completion of the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway in their states.

title: Steel Production Rises
description: Steel production rose to 2.62 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 1.9 percent from the previous week's 2.57 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. Estimated figures for the year to date showed production at 28.368 million net tons, an increase of 1.3 percent from the 28.004 million net tons in the previous year.

title: BRONX LEADS CITY IN CONVICTIONS UNDER TOUGH JUVENILE OFFENDER ACT
description: Since the state's juvenile offender law went into effect more than two years ago, the Bronx has had the highest conviction rate and longest sentences in New York City cases involving 13-, 14- and 15-year-olds, according to figures that will be released today.

title: COURT BACKS LAW TO NOTIFY PARENTS BEFORE AN ABORTION ON A TEEN-AGER
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a state may require a doctor to inform a teen-aged girl's parents before performing an abortion on her or face criminal penalties, at least when the girl is still living at home and dependent on her parents.

title: DR. KENNETH SHULMAN, 52, A CHIEF OF NEUROLOGICAL SURGERY IN BRONX
description: Dr. Kenneth Shulman, chief of neurological surgery at several Bronx hospitals and a department chairman at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, was found dead yesterday at his home in Mamaroneck, N.Y., an apparent suicide. He was 52 years old.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Kaiser Foundation To Sell 17% Stake
description: The Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation said today that it had agreed to sell its remaining 17 percent stake in the Kaiser Steel Corporation, amounting to 1.2 million shares, for $47.87 a share to Roger E. Tamraz, a Lebanese financier.

title: William H. Butler, 77, Musician; Arranger for Fletcher Henderson
description: William H. (Billy) Butler, a musician, composer and arranger, died on Thursday in Roosevelt Hospital in New York. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan and Wurtsboro, N.Y.

title: TOUGH MINE UNION CHIEF
description: It was as American as apple pie when about 100 shirt-sleeved union staff members and the headquarters office workers at the United Mine Workers of America gave an al fresco birthday party last year for Samuel Morgan Church Jr., their new president.

title: Scott Paper to Sell New Stock to Brascan S00.2-
description: The Scott Paper Company announced yesterday that it would raise $102.2 million in new equity from Brascan Ltd., a transaction that diffused speculation that Brascan planned to acquire Scott.

title: WAYS TO CONTROL GYPSY MOTHS
description: Authorities say there are several things a homeowner can do to control gypsy moths around his property. From now until mid- or late April, when the gypsy moth eggs begin to hatch, a knife or scraper can be used to remove the buff-colored egg masses that may be present on trees, buildings, stone walls and around woodpiles.

title: No Headline
description: Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan said today that his Administration colleague, David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, went too far when he said yesterday that Americans were not entitled to any social services from the Government.

title: Addenda
description: * Family Circle magazine increased advertising page rates 5 percent, effective with the July 1 issue.

title: THE SCIENTIST'S REALM IS THE OCEANS,THE AIR, THE FORESTS
description: pine forest in Upton, L.I. It is leagues away from Woods Hole, but in the mind of George Woodwell, the Center's director, the circle and its significance are quite close.

title: TIME FOR AUTO MAKERS TO BITE THE BULLET
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Friend's Advice A Tonic for Macklin
description: Yesterday afternoon, before Louisiana State overwhelmed Wichita State, 96-85, to earn a spot in the Final Four of the National Collegiate basketball tournament, Durand Macklin nervously paced his hotel room.

title: Critics Say Goat Proposal Makes Town Butt of Jokes
description: The Mayor of Vineland, N.J., recently asserted that he was considering a proposal that goats be used to keep down the grass and weeds in vacant lots, earning an angry ''bah!'' from two City Councilmen.

title: EUROPEAN FOES OF MISSILE PROGRAM SUFFER A SETBACK
description: On Jan. 10, a series of meetings of the Socialist leaders of the northern member countries of the Atlantic alliance began in Amsterdam, the acknowledged aim of the Dutch organizers being an attempt to stop the planned deployment of new middle-range nuclear missiles in 1983.

title: Ampco-Pittsburgh Gets Buffalo Forge
description: Ampco-Pittsburgh said today that it had acquired control of Buffalo Forge under a tender offer of $37.50 a share that expired Friday.

title: TV: TWO PROGRAMS FOCUS ON ISRAEL'S WEST BANK
description: ISRAEL'S West Bank is the subject of two programs on public television this week. Tonight at 10 o'clock on WNET-TV, Channel 13, ''Israel and the Palestinians - Will Reason Prevail?'' takes a fairly standard journalistic approach to disputed issues through interviews with assorted leaders, both Arab and Jewish. Tomorrow at 8 o'clock, ''West Bank Story'' offers a more personal tour of one area, in and around the city of Hebron.

title: EX-COMMANDER OF PACIFIC FORCES
description: Adm. John S. McCain Jr., a former commander in chief of Pacific forces in the Vietnam War and a World War II hero, died yesterday of a heart attack while on a military aircraft returning from Europe.

title: Oil Overcharge Settlements Set
description: The Energy Department, under Congressional attack because of plans to curtail price-enforcement efforts in the petroleum industry, initiated a program today intended to settle 400 cases involving $267 million in alleged overcharges.

title: CBS News Facing a Fine In Withholding of Tapes
description: A Federal District Court judge in Newark yesterday threatened to impose a substantial fine on CBS News if did not give him today all tapes and films from a ''60 Minutes'' program that investigated alleged fraud in a fast-food restaurant chain in New Jersey. The material had not been broadcast.

title: JERSEY PRIMARY BALLOT BILL SIGNED
description: Governor Byrne today signed a bill requiring that the names of all candidates for Governor in the June 2 primary be separated from those of candidates for the Legislature and local office.

title: To Elliott, Track Meant More Than Sport; An Appreciation
description: The hundreds of athletes who ran for James Francis (Jumbo) Elliott in his 46 years as track coach at Villanova University bore his unmistakable imprint.

title: Saudis Reject Peres Hint To Seek Peace if Elected
description: Saudi Arabia today rejected a suggestion by the Israeli opposition leader Shimon Peres that he would try to explore the possibility of peace with the Saudis if his Labor Party wins the Israeli general elections on June 30.

title: 5 Performances of 'Fidelio' For April Canceled by Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera has canceled five scheduled performances of ''Fidelio'' because of the illness of Roberta Knie, who was to sing Leonore.

title: I.O.C. Solves China Dispute
description: A dispute that has disrupted the Olympic Games for years was resolved today when China and Taiwan signed an agreement at the headquarters of the International Olympic Committee, ending two years of litigation and bickering.

title: 'GREAT TRAIN ROBBER,' KIDNAPPED FROM RIO, PRISONER IN
description: The convicted ''Great Train Robber'' Ronald Biggs, whose kidnapping from a Rio de Janeiro bar was denounced as a hoax, turned up as a prisoner here today and may be handed over to British authorities, officials said.

title: WASHINGTON PLANS $500 MILLION IN AID FOR PAKISTANIS
description: The Reagan Administration has tentatively decided to offer Pakistan about $500 million in military and economic assistance for the next fiscal year, Administration officials said today.

title: Syria Won't Hand Over Hijackers
description: Syria refused today to hand over to Pakistan three hijackers who commandeered a Pakistani jetliner earlier this month and held more than 100 passengers and crew members hostage for 13 days. An official said that extradition of the hijackers was ''not possible'' because Damascus and Islamabad had never signed an extradition treaty.

title: McDonnell Douglas
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said a subsidiary was forming a division to consolidate its activities in the field of voice and data communications. McDonnell Douglas Electronics now makes a number of devices under the trade name of Mavis, including a time and temperature announcement system offered to banks and an announcement system used by telephone companies for services such as sports informaton and stock quotations.

title: 'LET US NOT PICK THE REAGAN PACKAGE TO PIECES'
description: When Franklin D. Roosevelt in the first 100 days of 1933 proposed the sweeping Emergency Banking Act, the House Republican floor leader, Bertrand H. Snell, told his colleagues: ''The house is burning down, and the President of the United States says this is the way to put out the fire.'' He asked his fellow Republicans to support that unprecedented bill, and they did.

title: RESIGNATION LEAVES A VACENCY ON F.T.C.
description: Robert Pitofsky resigned today as a member of the Federal Trade Commission, giving President Reagan his first opportunity to appoint a new member to the five-person commission, possibly as chairman.

title: 11.43 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,004.23
description: A late buying surge carried the Dow Jones industrial average above the formidable 1,000 barrier for the second time in two weeks yesterday as the stock market pushed broadly higher in active trading, with energy stocks leading the way.

title: OKC Negotiating For Its Oil and Gas
description: The OKC Corporation, a Dallas fuel and cement company that is now in the process of liquidation, said it is holding negotiations with a major insurance company, which it did not identify, for the disposition of its oil and gas properties. However, it said no agreement has been reached.

title: Troopers Assail Inaction on Klan
description: Officials of the state police union complained that the decision of high-ranking officers not to order troopers to the Ku Klux Klan rally in Meriden on Saturday had added to the bloodshed there and damaged relations between the troopers and local police departments. Gov. William A. O'Neill ordered an investigation into the handling of the incident.

title: PERILING INDIANS' EDUCATION
description: After having been denied the opportunity to attend college for decades, American Indians are in danger of losing a group of new tribal community colleges that they chartered to provide this opportunity.

title: Pete Squires: A Runner for All Sundays
description: If you're having people to brunch Sunday, don't invite Pete Squires. Don't invite him next Sunday, either. Or the Sunday after that.

title: SAUDI OIL REVENUES SEEM TO OUTSTRIP NATION'S CAPACITY TO PUT THEM TO USE
description: The Saudi oilfields, concentrated mainly in an area 100 miles long and 40 miles wide along the Persian Gulf, are producing revenues so large that they appear to be outstripping the Saudi capacity to put them to use.

title: LEARNING THE ART OF MAKEUP
description: No matter how much a woman spends on eye pencils and blushers and foundation, unless she knows how to use them to enhance her own face, she might just as well do without wearing any of them. Makeup is an art that can be learned and there are various ways to improve one's skills, depending on how much time and money one wants to devote to it.

title: A GOOD NEW BET FOR THE OTB
description: To the Editor:

title: Texaco to Buy Its Shares Again
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy up to five million of its common shares, equivalent to 1.9 percent of the 268.6 million outstanding, for general corporate purposes.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Company has appointed Joan Edelman Spero vice president, corporate strategy-trade. * Asarco Inc. has elected Armand L. Labbe vice president.

title: CAR IMPORTS: HINTS FOR JAPAN
description: The Reagan Administration has decided on a policy of encouraging - without directly asking - the Japanese to voluntarily restrain car shipments to this country. A Japanese Government spokesman in Tokyo, however, said the Japanese would not act until the Americans made a specific proposal.

title: Coors Buying Land; May Brew in South
description: The Adolph Coors Company, the beer concern, said it would purchase for an undisclosed sum about 1,320 acres for a possible second brewery near Elkton, Va.

title: Bridge: New York Area Stars Given Good Chance to Share Title
description: The Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship has just begun here, but it seems highly likely that New York will have at least one winner when the event ends Friday. Of the eight topranked teams, seven include at least one player from the New York area. And there are seven more such teams in the next 10 in the seedings.

title: DANCE: ANNABELLE GAMSON
description: THE Brooklyn Philharmonia's Thursday night ''Meet the Moderns'' concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music was a reminder that, although some theorists believe we lack a large audience for modern music, one important audience does indeed exist for such music: the dance audience. Because choreographers like to create dances to contemporary scores, dancegoers may hear more modern music than many concertgoers do. Often, dancing to a score even helps make that score accessible.

title: WILL 'SELF' EVER BE A SPARE PART?
description: JUST how much of a person could be replaced by spare parts before turning him into someone else? The question no longer seems quite as outlandish as it did in the early years of organ transplanting, when overwhelming biological and chemical problems seemed to rule out many of the ways in which a human being might be rebuilt. These days, the scientific journals remind us with nearly every edition that immense progress has been made since peg legs began filling empty trouser legs, and that the pace of discovery and invention is quickening.

title: Pritzker-Hyatt Merger Approved
description: The Hyatt International Corporation said its board had approved a merger under which the company would become wholly owned by the Pritzker family of Chicago and minority shareholders would receive $22 a share in cash.

title: REAGAN ADSMINISTRATION PROMISES TO SEEK MORE AID FOR ZIMBABWE
description: In its first major policy decision on Southern Africa, the Reagan Administration is promising to ask Congress for an increase in foreign aid to Zimbabwe that would bring the total amount to about $225 million over the next three years.

title: The Economy
description: A tentative coal settlement was reached, after intensive bargaining between the United Mine Workers and major coal producers. The accord, considered surprisingly responsive to rank and file demands, provided a 36 percent wage rise over three years, pension improvements and continuation of a Sunday work ban. (Page A1.)

title: Ford Sets Price On 2 New Models
TRADING IN ST. JOE HALTED FOR A STATEMENT TODAY
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation, which is vigorously looking for ways to foil a $2 billion takeover bid by Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, disclosed yesterday that it had asked the New York Stock Exchange to halt trading in St. Joe stock until after an ''important announcement'' to be made today.

title: TRUSTEE IS APROVED FOR O.P.M.
description: At the request of creditors, Federal Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland approved the appointment yesterday of a trustee to manage the operations of O.P.M. Leasing Services, which has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day last Monday misstated Pan American World Airways' financial results for 1980. Pan Am's reported net income of $80 million included a $130 million operating loss and a $294 million gain from the sale of the Pan Am Building.

title: Judge Reportedly Trailed For Months Before Slaying
description: A Federal District Judge, John Wood Jr., was trailed for several months before he was felled by a sniper's bullet outside his San Antonio condominium, a Dallas newspaper reported today.

title: SOUTH KOREA SEEKS ELECTRONICS REBOUND
description: Fifteen years ago, this town 160 miles southeast of Seoul was a sleepy farm village noted only for its mountain cable car and for being the birthplace of Park Chung Hee, then the president.

title: STRIKE BY DOCTORS AT CITY HOSPITALS ENDS AFTER WEEK
description: Admitting a ''profound defeat,'' the Committee of Interns and Residents last night ended its week-old strike against municipal hospitals. But leaders of the union, which represents 2,000 doctors, said the strike against two private voluntary hospitals, which also began last Tuesday, would continue.

title: California High Court Bars New Busing Law Decision
description: California's Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its decision upholding the state's antibusing law in the Los Angeles integration case, leaving the United States Supreme Court as the last resort for proponents of busing to achieve integration.

title: From the Charts to the Witness Stand
description: The defense tried to prevent it, but several popular recording performers may be allowed to serve as star witnesses for the prosecution in a trial in Federal Court in Manhattan.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Robert C. Hyndman, 53, has been named president and chief operating officer of Morton-Norwich Products Inc., a major manufacturer of salt, chemical, consumer and pharmaceutical products. He succeeds Charles S. Locke, 52, who remains chairman and chief executive officer of the Chicago-based company.

title: HE LIKES WOMEN--AND WRITING OF THEM
description: acclaimed new novel ''The White Hotel,'' still thinks of himself primarily as a poet, and even his casual conversation about mundane things is often poetic. For example, when he was asked about the 15 years that he has spent in Hereford, a pleasant little city in the green hills of western England, he said:

title: Central Park's Pinetum
description: T O S CIENCE T IMES: I read with interest your article ''Central Park's Pinetum Flourishes as an Outdoor Lab'' and want to commend Dr. Karnosky and Mr. Ross for their efforts to use more pine species in New York's city parks.

title: News Analysis
description: Martin Anderson, President Reagan's chief adviser on domestic policy matters, likes to recall a story about his father, who had a milk route during the Depression. One morning, Mr. Anderson says, a customer with a large family met his father at the door and said that her husband had lost his job and that the family would have to reduce its regular milk order by several quarts a week. Mr. Anderson says that his father told the woman not to worry, that he would continue to deliver as much milk as the family needed and that she could pay him back when times were better.

title: Chess: Karpov Shows He Can Win With the Early Attack, Too
description: One is so used to seeing Anatoly Karpov win with hidden aggression in quiet positions that it is still something of a surprise when he sets a hectic pace of attack right from the beginning. The world champion excels in this, too, as was shown in his game with Lajos Portisch, a Hungarian grandmaster, in the second round of the Linares International Tournament in Spain.

title: Police Officer Pleads Not Guilty in Slaying
description: A New York City police officer pleaded not guilty of two counts of murder yesterday in the fatal shooting of a fellow officer while returning from an extended St. Patrick's Day celebration.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: To avoid a potential conflict of interest, David Rockefeller will resign from the boards of the Chase Manhattan Corporation and its subsidiary, the Chase Manhattan Bank, when he retires as chairman of both institutions on April 21.

title: JUSTICES BACK RAPE LAW PENALIZING ONLY THE MALE
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the constitutionality of statutory rape laws that punish males, but not females, for intercourse with an under-age partner of the opposite sex.

title: Breakdowns Slow Conrail and L.I.R.R.
description: It was a bad Monday morning rush-hour for commuters from Connecticut and Long Island yesterday. The 7:50 A.M. Conrail express from New Haven, due at Grand Central Terminal at 9:23, was 51 minutes late because of equipment problems.

title: Rates Up as View on Fed Shifts; Six-Month Bill Rises to 12.27%
description: Short-term and long-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday as traders estimated that the Federal Reserve was not trying to force interest rates downward, as was widely supposed last week.

title: U.S. SAYS MRS. KIRKPATRICK MET SOUTH AFRICA ARMY INTELLIGENCE CHIEF
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, met last week with the senior South African military intelligence officer, State Department and South African officials said today.

title: RECITAL: OVATION FOR MISS PRICE
description: WHEN Leontyne Price walked on stage in Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon before her recital for the benefit of the Whitney M. Young Jr. Memorial Foundation, the audience broke into sustained applause and a standing ovation.

title: FUEDING OVER FOREIGN POLICY ROLES IS RENEWED WITHIN ADMINISTRATION
description: A recent series of inconsistent public statements has renewed a struggle over control of foreign policy in the Reagan Administration, senior officials said today.

title: MACCHIAROLA ASSESSES THE FUTURE AFTER REAGAN BUDGET CUTS
description: SINCE he became chancellor of the New York City schools two and a half years ago, Frank J. Macchiarola has been a spokesman for education in major urban areas. Last week, in an interview Dr. Macchiarola spoke about a variety of urban school issues, including the likely effects of the Reagan Administration's educational policies on New York City. Dr. Macchiarola was first asked whether proposed cuts in the Federal Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, which now pays for school security guards, would leave the schools unprotected.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The statute plainly serves the important considerations of family integrity and protecting adolescents.'' -Chief Justice Warren E. Burger upholding an abortion restriction. (A1:6.)

title: CONVICTED KILLER, EX-POLICEMAN, TURNS HIMSELF IN
description: A former police officer, who vanished two years ago on the day he was to begin serving a four-year prison term for beating a burglary suspect to death, surrendered to authorities yesterday. He contended that he was innocent but tired of running.

title: KOCH PLAN WOULD RESCUE FIREMEN'S PENSIONS BY RAISING CONTRIBUTIONS
description: The Koch administration announced yesterday a plan to rescue the pension system of New York City's firemen, which has a $1.2 billion deficit and which officials generally agree was headed for bankruptcy by 1987.

title: Superior Oil Votes; 5-for-1 Stock Split
description: The Superior Oil Company said its board had approved a proposed 5-for-1 stock split and that the company planned to raise its quarterly dividend to 80 cents a share pre-split from 18 cents.

title: REAGAN CUT HELD TO AFFECT 20% OF WELFARE FAMILIES
description: The Reagan Administration has estimated that nearly one-fifth of the 3.8 million families on welfare would be made ineligible for benefits or have them reduced as a result of its budget proposals before Congress.

title: DIPLOMACY, TOO PAYS FOR INFLATION
description: The tune sounds familiar, but the soprano seems to be singing the tenor's part. Only a few years back, it was the United States that complained that conservative financial policies in Western Europe were spoiling the West's prosperity. Now it is Europe, particularly West Germany, that blames the Continent's recession on stringent monetary policies in the United States.

title: Turner's Progress Key to Indiana's Rise
description: When Bob Knight began to piece together his plans for the Indiana basketball team before the season, he did not include Landon Turner. Turner, a 6-foot-10-inch junior and the biggest forward Knight has coached, was perhaps the most inconsistent player then.

title: McCann-Erickson To Leave Portland, Ore.
description: Because Georgia-Pacific has moved its headquarters from Portland, Ore., to Atlanta and transferred its $9 million ad account from McCann-Erickson's Portland office to its Atlanta office, McCann will close the Western operation, which has been the biggest agency in town, on Sept. 1.

title: Riggs Bank in Accord With Allbritton
description: The Riggs National Bank yesterday announced an agreement to grant two seats on the board of a new Riggs bank holding company to Joe L. Allbritton, a Washington businessman who is seeking a controlling interest in the bank.

title: A SECOND STUDENT WINS CHALLENGE ON ANSWER TO MATH EXAM PROBLEM
description: A second high school student has successfully challenged an officially correct answer on a standardized mathematics test used in college admissions, in this case the Scholastic Aptitude Test.

title: Waldbaum Net Up 82.8% in Quarter
description: Waldbaum Inc., one of the largest supermarkets in the metropolitan area, reported yesterday that earnings in the 17 weeks ended Jan. 3 rose 82.8 percent, to $5.3 million, or $2.07 a share, from $2.9 million, or $1.17 a share, in the 16 weeks ended Dec. 29, 1979. Sales climbed 22.5 percent, to $429.4 million, from $350.4 million.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE TEMPTATION OF SAINT ANTONY. By Gustave Flaubert. Translated with introduction and notes by Kitty Mrosovsky. Illustrated. 293 pages. Cornell University Press.

title: CHICAGO MAYOR'S PLAN EVOKES DISBELIEF
description: The woman fidgeted as she waited for an elevator in her rundown building on Division Street in the Cabrini Green housing project. Her voice quivered with fear and her eyes darted from side to side as she watched people who approached.

title: OFFICIALS UNCOVER PEDIGREE OF FORGOTTEN JAILHOUSE ART
description: For the last 16 years, inmates on Rikers Island have been eating their meals under a Salvador Dali painting, whose origins and worth had been blurred or forgotten as new wardens, guards and correction officials came and went.

title: Michigan Candidate, an Ex-Nazi, Arrested as Trespasser in a Mall
description: An ex-Nazi seeking the Republican nomination for the Congressional seat vacated by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, David A. Stockman was arrested on the eve of the election today on charges of campaigning for votes at a shopping mall.

title: FIBER MAKERS GAIN AFTER 8 BLEAK YEARS
description: An eight-year war of attrition that slashed profits at major synthetic fiber producers in the United States and squeezed their ranks has apparently run its course.

title: March of Dimes: From President Roosevelt to Reagan
description: There have been 35 March of Dimes national poster children since the tradition was started in 1947, and 32 of them were back at the White House yesterday for an East Room ceremony marking the United Nations' International Year of Disabled Persons.

title: MUSEUM HOPES TO SAVE OLD U.S. SHIP IN FAR PORT
description: On Christmas Day 1866, the Charles Cooper, the last American packet ship to sail out of South Street in New York, arrived in these bleak, windswept islands in the South Atlantic ''leaky and in need of repair,'' according to the Colonial Shipping Register here. She never left, remaining mired in the mud.

title: Talking Business with Alan Greenspan; Reagan Policy And Congress
description: Although he has no formal office in the Reagan Administration, Alan Greenspan, the New York-based economist, has emerged as a major influence on the Administration's new economic policies. His experience as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Ford and his expertise as a forecaster and consultant through his firm, Townsend-Greenspan & Company, have enhanced his influence in Washington and his stature in the business and financial community. Mr. Greenspan, 55 years old, met recently with editors and reporters of The New York Times and offered observations on the economy that combined distress over present conditions with hope for the future. The President's Program

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * General Motors Acceptance Corporation intends to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering proposed offerings of $250 million of 30-year 6 percent debentures and $150 million of 10-year senior subordinated notes.

title: Library's President to Head Wilson Foundation
description: After 10 years as the New York Public Library's first full-time president, Richard W. Couper has resigned to become president of the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation in Princeton.

title: Corco Supply Pact
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company of San Antonio, which has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since March 1978, yesterday announced its entry into a supply agreement with Tradax Petroleum Inc., an affiliate of Cargill Inc., under which Tradax will assist Commonwealth Oil in obtaining crude oil and naphtha supplies after its emergence from the bankruptcy proceedings. The agreement is similar to one that Corco has with Derby Distributors Inc., a subsidiary of the Englehard Chemicals and Mineral Corporation. The company said that Tradax had also agreed to join in its working capital financing to the extent of $50 million.

title: MILAN OPENS FALL AND WINTER SHOWS
description: Temperament and drama are essential elements of the fashion world. But by adding efficiency and organization, the Italians, in a little more than five years, have made this city a major stop on the international fashion circuit. Attractive, orderly presentations have abetted appreciation of the clothes here and, indeed, a Milanese style has evolved: casual, luxurious and modern.

title: VOLCKER CONCERNED OVER HUNT SILVER PLANS
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has told two key Congressmen that he shares their ''concern'' about the compliance of the wealthy Hunt family of Dallas with Federal Reserve instructions to liquidate their silver holdings, according to a letter released today.

title: 6,500 BUY 60-CENT TICKETS TO BROADWAY MUSICAL
description: Tickets that will be on sale for $18 and $22.50 today for the new Broadway musical based on the 1930's and 40's, ''A Reel American Hero,'' were selling for 60 cents yesterday, and they quickly became the hottest items purveyed on Seventh Avenue between 42d and 43d Streets, replacing the ''loose joints'' that are usually on sale on the street.

title: Synagogue Blaze Declared Accidental
description: A four-alarm fire that destroyed the synagogue of Congregation Mishkan Israel in Astoria, Queens, last Tuesday, has been declared accidental by New York City fire marshals.

title: N.B.A. Opinion Poll Seeks Help on Rules
description: The National Basketball Association, seeking ways to improve its popularity, has turned to an opinion poll for help in deciding what to do about a number of longtime rules, particularly the one concerning the zone defense.

title: Mediator Calls New Talks In Philadelphia Rail Strike
description: A state mediator called striking transit workers and the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority back to the bargaining table today in an effort to settle the nine-day-old walkout.

title: RUSSIAN AND MONGOLIAN ASTRONAUTS JOIN UP
description: A veteran Soviet astronaut and his Mongolian copilot maneuvered their Soyuz-39 spacecraft into a complex double docking late today with an orbiting Russian space station 200 miles above the earth.

title: JAPANESE CARS WORRY BELGAINS
description: Along several miles of Antwerp harbor, in a landscape similar to that near Elizabeth, N.J., two sprawling automobile facilities lie back to back.

title: Raking Leaves
description: President Reagan has revived an idea about welfare from his days as Governor of California. ''Workfare,'' it is called, and it is advanced on the appealing ground that it builds self-esteem and enhances employability. In fact, the Reagan Administration seems to have something more punitive in mind.

title: Makeshift Fillies of W.B.L.  Beaten by Streak, 128 to 80
description: The Minnesota Fillies, with a patchedtogether lineup of six free agents and three college seniors bowed tonight, 128-80, to the St. Louis Streak in a Women's Basketball League game.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MEMORY LANE

title: TRUDEAU SWEEPS ASIDE CRITICISM OF HIS PROPOSALS FOR CONSTITUTION
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau intervened for the first time today in a long debate before the House of Commons and swept aside provincial and Conservative opposition to his proposals to establish a new constitution for Canada.

title: Egypt and U.S. Conclude Nuclear Power Agreement
description: The United States and Egypt have completed a nuclear power accord that is expected to lead to Egyptian purchases of American nuclear reactors and fuel for a 2,000-megawatt power generating program, the State Department said today.

title: EUROPE'S LEADERS IN GRIM ECONOMIC TALKS
description: Deepening gloom about Western Europe's economic prospects this year, coupled with fresh appeals to President Reagan to aid world recovery by cutting American interest rates further, marked the opening of the semiannual meeting of European leaders here today.

title: Dutch Official Opposes Accepting Neutron Arms
description: Defense Minister Pieter B.R. de Geus of the Netherlands told Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that his country did not want a neutron warhead deployed on its soil, the Defense Department said today.

title: By Sports of The Times; Baseball's Biggest Manager
description: THROUGH the years, Billy Martin and Earl Weaver, Casey Stengel and Leo Durocher, Miller Huggins and John McGraw have sculptured the popular image of a baseball manager

title: Day Mines Pushes Suit to Bar Hecla
description: Day Mines Inc. said it would press its pending Federal court action seeking to enjoin the Hecla Mining Company from buying more Day stock.

title: NEW TEST, OPEN HATCH SUSPECTED IN SPACE SHUTTLE FATALITY
description: ASPECIAL test added to post-countdown procedures, an open hatch that presumably should have been closed and sealed, the absence of security guards in a hazardous area and lapses in communicating instructions and warnings were among the important factors contributing to last Thursday's fatal accident at the space shuttle launching pad in Florida, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: T HE latest offering at the Phillips auction house, at 867 Madison Avenue, is entitled ''The Forties, Fifties and Fashion,'' its first exhibition devoted exclusively to photographs from those two decades. The auction, scheduled for 2 P.M. April 8, features a number of well-known photos by Richard Avedon, Irving Penn, Man Ray, William Klein, Horst, Baron de Meyer, Steichen and Hoyningen-Huene.

title: ANTONIONI'S 'LADY'
description: ''THE Lady Without Camelias'' (''La Signora Senza Camelie''), Michelangelo Antonioni's third feature, made in 1953, is far more than a footnote to career. It is a preface to (some might say, a warning of) the work that later was to include ''L'Avventura,'' ''La Notte,'' ''Eclipse,'' ''Red Desert,'' ''Blow-Up'' and ''Zabriskie Point'' - movies that became increasingly mannered as the director won the power to explore obsessions not easily or always coherently dramatized.

title: The Beaverkill Is for Trout
description: The Beaverkill, a stream that rises in the Catskills and flows into the Delaware River, is to trout fishermen what the Mississippi was to Mark Twain: a source of legend and wonder, a test of skill and spirit.

title: SOVIET BLOC STAGES LANDING IN POLAND
description: At a time of new tension in Poland, Warsaw Pact forces have staged a landing operation along the country's Baltic coast and held war games at several other sites on Polish territory, according to reports published today by the East German Communist Party.

title: Avon Tennis Opens Tomorrow
description: The Avon Women's Tennis Championship runs tomorrow through Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Israel's Teachers Strike for a Day
description: Israel's teachers went on strike today for the second time in two weeks to protest the Government's delay in implementing a promised pay increase. Although the strike was called for one day, the National Parents Organization said that it would keep children home tomorrow to back the teachers' demands.

title: CANCER-RATE STUDY IN AUTO PLANTS SET
description: A study of cancer rates among automobile assembly line workers was announced today by the Chrysler Corporation, its union and the Michigan Cancer Foundation in response to scattered evidence of unexpectedly high rates of the disease in the industry.

title: LEGISLATORS IN NEED OF STIFFER BACKBONES
description: To the Editor:

title: Volkswagen to Build A Plant in Egypt
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G. will build a $40 million car assembly plant in Egypt in a joint venture with Egyptian partners, a VW spokesman said from Wolfsburg.

title: NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY AND CONNECTICUT BRACING FOR NEW GYPSY MOTH ATTACK
description: As they wait for the gypsy moth caterpillars to emerge from their egg masses and begin eating tree leaves in the next three to six weeks, most experts on the problem are predicting that the damage will probably be as bad as or worse than last year, when several million acres in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut were hit.

title: Emerson, University In Deal on Scanners
description: The Emerson Radio Corporation announced that the regents of the University of California had granted a wholly owned Emerson subsidiary an exclusive license for commercial exploitation of further patent rights relating to a new generation of computerized axial tomographic scanners.

title: 41 Cubans Who Fled Plane In Miami Seek U.S. Asylum
description: Forty-one Cuban refugees who posed as tourists traveling to a Mexican holiday and then abandoned the flight on a Miami stop, have asked for political asylum, officials said today.

title: Metropolitan Life Plans TV and Cable Blitz
description: If you've got the money, you can reach the American people in a hurry. Whether you impress them or persuade them is another matter.

title: SYRACUSE AND TULSA GAIN N.I.T. FINAL
description: Syracuse, a team that believed it was good enough to get into the National Collegiate tournament but didn't, nullified a deliberate Purdue offense last night at Madison Square Garden and gained the final of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: EXXON LIFTS ITS ESTIMATE OF RESERVES
description: The Exxon Corporation said in its annual report, released today, that for the first time since 1971, its combined proven oil and natural gas reserves increased worldwide last year.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What causes a school of fish to act as one unit?

title: Drugs and Profit
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES: As mentioned in your article ''Drugs That Promise Help But Not Profit Reside in Limbo'' (March l7) not all ''orphan drugs'' for rare diseases ''promise help (for patients) but not profit (for drug manufacturers)''.

title: World Output Of Oil Steady
description: World crude oil output was unchanged in January at 57.8 million barrels a day, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly reported yesterday. Production by the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting slipped by 159,500 barrels a day, to 24.7 million, which offset rising output among non-OPEC members, the newsletter said.

title: F.T.C. CITES EXXON DATA ON RELIANCE
description: The Exxon Corporation, having announced last week the abandonment of the invention it promoted in 1979 as the reason for its takeover of the Reliance Electric Company, still faces a legal struggle with the Federal Trade Commission over the $1.2 billion takeover.

title: Eastern Increasing Its Fleet of Airbuses
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that it had exercised its options on nine A-300B4 Airbuses costing about $335 million and ordered from Airbus Industrie Inc., a consortium of French, West German and Spanish aircraft manufacturers.

title: Blast in Teheran Wrecks Offices Of Central Revolutionary Panel
description: An explosion today wrecked part of the headquarters of Iran's Central Revolutionary Committee, the official Pars news agency reported.

title: CITIBANK TO ADD TO RATROLS AT ITS ELECTRONIC CENTERS
description: Citibank said yesterday it was planning to increase surveillance patrols of its electronic banking centers as a result of Saturday night's robbery of customers at an East Side bank. The patrols will be carried out by security teams wearing civilian clothes.

title: THE FACTS ABOUT JACOBO TIMERMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Julie Schafler Bride Of Jim Dale, Actor
description: Julie Schafler, founder and owner of Julie: Artisans Gallery, was married yesterday to Jim Dale, star of the Broadway musical ''Barnum.'' Surrogate Millard L. Midonick performed the ceremony in the Lotos Club.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: A.W. Clausen, who is leaving the BankAmerica Corporation and its Bank of America subsidiary on July 1 to become president of the World Bank in Washington, has received a golden handshake from the giant San Francisco-based organization that he has headed for 11 years.

title: STATE SENATE VOTES BILL TO RESTORE DEATH PENALTY FOR SOME MURDERS
description: The Republican-led State Senate gave final passage tonight to a bill to restore the death penalty in some murder cases and quashed a manuever that would have provided mandatory life imprisonment without parole instead. Governor Carey's veto of the death penalty measure is considered virtually certain.

title: Prudential-Bache Link
description: The Prudential Insurance Company said it had begun an offer to buy Bache Group Inc. common at $32 a share. It is also offering $13.50 for each Bache warrant to buy Bache common at $18.50 a share. Prudential said the offer was conditional on a minimum of 6.5 million shares being tendered, and if less than that amount was tendered, it might return all tendered shares, or extend the offer and hold the tendered shares until the new expiration.

title: ALTERNATE TAX PROPOSALS
description: Although I share President Reagan's determination to resuscitate our economy, I am increasingly doubtful that his tax proposals will do the job.

title: Who Should Veto Whom?
description: In seeking the Presidency, Ronald Reagan and the Republican Party endorsed the ''legislative veto,'' a weapon Congress sometimes uses to block executive action it doesn't like. Now President Reagan sees the matter differently. His Attorney General will tell the courts that a legislative veto is an unconstitutional invasion of executive turf. It's not surprising that the President sees the error of the candidate's ways. He will go on to learn that, from his new perspective, there are vetoes he likes and vetoes he doesn't.

title: TENSION OVER ATLANTA KILLINGS TESTS RACIAL HARMONY
description: For years this city has been regarded as the social and economic leader of the South, and more recently it has emerged as a center of international trade. Atlanta is as cosmopolitan as almost any big city, with its brand-new airport and everchanging downtown skyline, its bustling transportation and convention industries.

title: E.E.C. Reaches Steel Cuts Pact
description: Steel producers in the European Economic Community reported today that they had reached the basis for an agreement on voluntary production cuts to prevent a return to a price war.

title: City Transit Unit Drops Plan on Nuclear Safety
description: One day after it came to public notice, the New York City Transit Authority canceled yesterday an ''embryonic'' plan to a seek a way of shielding its sophisticated new electronic power-supply equipment for the city's subway system in case of nuclear attack.

title: 88'S STILL GOING STRONG
description: To the Editor:

title: General Tire Profit Due to RKO Unit
description: The General Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's fifth-largest tire manufacturer, yesterday reported a profit of $2.1 million, or 9 cents a share, for its fiscal first quarter, ended Feb. 28. This was in contrast to a loss of $11.3 million a year earlier.

title: Gain in U.S. Population Offsets Death Rate Rise
description: The nation's population grew by 1.6 million people last year despite a rise in the death rate, according to a report by the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: UTILIZE OUR GRAYING WORK FORCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Data Plea Barred By Court
description: The oil and and pesticide industries were rebuffed today by the United States Supreme Court in separate attempts to restrict the distribution of information they supplied to the Government.

title: CITY ACTS ON OWN TO SELL BOND ISSUE OF $75 MILLION
description: For the first time since it was frozen out of the long-term borrowing markets in 1975, New York City sold bonds to the public yesterday backed by its guarantee that it could repay its debts.

title: Tremors Shake Mount Etna
description: More than two dozen light tremors shook the Mount Etna volcano today. Scientists at Catania's International Institute of Volcanology said that the tremors were centered around the fissure that opened on the north face of the 10,700-foot mountain at the beginning of an eruption last week.

title: JURY BEGINS DELIBERATIONS IN CAROL BURNETT'S LIBEL SUIT AGAINST ENQUIRER
description: A jury began deliberations today in the libel suit filed by the entertainer Carol Burnett against The National Enquirer. The panel met briefly to chose a foreman and then recessed until tomorrow.

title: Concessions Still G.M. Aim
description: The General Motors Corporation still plans to seek some type of contract concessions from the United Automobile Workers union despite rejection of such a move by U.A.W. officials, F. James McDonald, G.M.'s president, said today.

title: Midtown Campaign On Double-Parking
description: A crackdown on illegal parking, including double-parking, got under way in midtown Manhattan, with 100 extra traffic enforcement agents in the area between Third and Seventh Avenues from 42d to 59th Streets.

title: CHARLES H. JONES
description: Charles H. Jones, a former senior vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and former president of the Hershey Creamery Company in Harrisburg, Pa., died Sunday at a hospital in Winchester, Va.

title: IRANIAN BARS TRUCE UNTIL GOVERNMENT OF IRAQ FALLS
description: The speaker of Iran's Parliament said today that his country would not accept a cease-fire in the sixmonth-old Persian Gulf war until the Iraqi Government of President Saddam Hussein was overthrown.

title: FORD MEETS WITH PEKING LEADERS FOR TALKS ON RELATIONS WITH U.S.
description: When Deng Xiaoping met Gerald R. Ford this morning in the Fujian Room at the Great Hall of the People, the Chinese Communist Party deputy chairman switched chairs with the former President.

title: AVOWED RACIST GETS LIFE SENTENCES IN SNIPER KILLINGS OF 2 UTAH JOGGERS
description: After physically attacking a Federal prosecutor and screaming that his conviction was a ''farce,'' Joseph Paul Franklin was sentenced today to serve two consecutive life terms for violating the civil rights of two young black men by shooting them to death last August as they jogged near a local park.

title: CHILDREN PRETEND NEGLECT, BUT EMOTIONAL PAIN IS REAL
description: Psychotherapists in Albuquerque, N.M., have reported three cases of an affliction very rare in real life but almost universal in mythology: the Cinderella Syndrome.

title: Reunion Marks Attack on Japan
description: The Tokyo Raiders, a band of airmen led by Jimmy Doolittle, are planning a reunion here next month to mark the 39th anniversary of a bombing mission that was America's first blow at the Japanese homeland in World War II.

title: Advertising; Polish Vodka Ad Campaign
description: THE success of Stolichnaya vodka from Russia has brought on a flood of other vodkas from such countries as Turkey, China, Japan, Canada, Poland, Finland and Sweden.

title: News Analysis
description: Even in December, when Washington was alarmed over possible Soviet intervention in Poland and told allied governments that it was likely to occur at any moment, Poles carried on with the attitude that everything would all work out somehow. Now, however, there is a general sense of despair here.
