title: Market Place; 'Naked' Options Offer Big Risks
description: THE automobile industry, as everybody knew, was in the doldrums. Few people expected an imminent rise in the stock of the Ford Motor Company. So what better way to pick up some money than selling, or writing, ''naked'' Ford options on the Chicago Board Options Exchange, and pocketing the premium?

title: Caine, Athletic Director, Quits Oregon's Program
description: John Caine, the University of Oregon athletic director, resigned today rather than accept a new assignment as a fund raiser for the financially ailing athletic department.

title: HELD SEVERAL TOP POSTS IN POWER TOOL CONCERN
description: Robert D. Black, the honorary board chairman and a member of the executive committee of the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company, died Saturday at the Greater Baltimore Medical Center after an extended illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Mexico Weighs Oil Prices
description: Mexico, the fourth-largest supplier of crude oil to the United States, is considering cutting prices on its crude in April or May because of weakening world oil markets, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly reported yesterday. The newsletter said that Mexico was reviewing a possible price reduction for its heavy Maya crude ''because United States buyers complain they are losing money on refining it at its present price of $34.50 a barrel.'' The journal said that Mexico was also under some pressure to lower the price of its higher-quality Isthmus crude, now priced at $38.50 a barrel.

title: FLOYD WINS TOURNEY AND BONUS
description: Raymond Floyd won the Tournament Players Championship today on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff with Barry Jaeckel and Curtis Strange. The victory was worth more than all the money Floyd won l last year on the PGA Tour.

title: KATHLEEN RAFFERTY
description: Kathleen Rafferty, editor in chief of the Dell Publishing Company's puzzle publications and author of the Dell Crossword Puzzle Dictionary, died Sunday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Mrs. Rafferty, a native of Iowa, joined Dell in the early 1940's and was a member of the company's board of directors at the time of her death.

title: RESIDENTIAL CONSTRUCTION REPORTED AT RECORD LOW FOR NEW YORK STATE
description: Last year was the worst year on record for residential construction in New York State, according to a report by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

title: NATURE VS. NATURE: PSYCHOLOGIST URGES ACTIVE INTERVENTION
description: ''HEREDITY, shmeredity! You have to do something,'' says Dr. Reuven Feuerstein in answer to the endless argument over whether disadvantaged children do poorly in school because of inherited traits or because of their environment. The human organism, he says, ''is an open system, very plastic. It can be changed and modified.'' The question is whether educators have the will, the confidence and the instruments to ''do something.''

title: Berkey Sets Asset Sale
description: Berkey Photo Inc., a major photo film processor and photo equipment producer, said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent for the sale of substantially all assets of its graphic arts business to the Pako Corporation, a Minneapolis-based graphic arts and X-ray processing equipment maker. With execution of the agreement, Pako will assume marketing of the graphic arts product lines and, beginning in November, the manufacture of the products. Berkey said it had established a reserve of $1.1 million for the related cost and expenses, which will be reported in its 1980 results.

title: Sakharov Says Police Stole Some of His Personal Papers
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist, said in a statement distributed today that the K.G.B., the security police, had taken a briefcase containing letters, a personal diary, scientific papers and notes for an autobiography in his place of exile in Gorky.

title: Bonn Reviews; Coal Role
description: West Germany is considering reducing its 25 percent share in a three-nation group that hopes to build a $1.4 billion coal liquefaction plant in West Virginia, a West German Embassy official said today.

title: NEW 'GENE MACHINES' SPEEDING UP THE PACE OF BIOLOGIAL
description: REVOLUTION By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr.

title: 'NO PROBLEM' MACHINE POSES A PRESIDENTIAL PROBLEM
description: THE normally unflappable Jimmy Carter endured several hours of anxiety recently when he accidentally expunged several manuscript pages from his word processor. What especially hurt, the former President recalled yesterday, was that ''I had labored over them for a couple of days.''

title: BROWN IS SENT BACK TO MINORS BY YANKS
description: Bobby Brown, once a favorite of George Steinbrenner and Gene Michael, was returned to the minor leagues today following a busy major league season with the Yankees last year.

title: Swan Has 2d Outing, Is Still Free of Pain
description: Craig Swan passed another test on the road back today when he pitched four innings in a game at the Mets' camp and for the second time in a week reported no pain in his right shoulder.

title: Cancer Patients' Hair Loss
description: The side effects of some of the powerful drugs used in cancer therapy are many and unpleasant: acute nausea, lassitude, damage to the bone marrow, the heart or other organs.

title: The U.N. Today; March 24, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WHO BENEFITS?
description: One of the loudest and most frequent cries among modern demagogues is that the world is governed too much. We admit that it may be so for the full gratification of their own selfishment at the expense of other people's rights; and we take it for granted that interference with this gratification is their sole motivation to this cry. But it is not governed enough for the protection of the good against the bad, for the defense of rights, and for the prevention of wrongs. Our doctrine is that, in our own country, the freest in the world, and in England, much vaunted as the freest in Europe, mankind are not governed enough, but are left at liberty to do many things which invade the rights of others, while the invaded are left no other protection than their own sagacity, which, as a general rule, is too little for the purpose.

title: MOST LIVER CANCER CASES FOUND TO FOLLOW HEPATITIS B INFECTIONS
description: Cancer of the liver, one of the most common cancers in the world, seems to be preceded in nearly all cases by infection with hepatitis B virus, a cause of serum hepatitis, according to evidence presented here today.

title: QUARTET: BARTOK BY THE EMERSON
description: IT is nice to have a public opportunity to thank the Emerson String Quartet for its performance of the six Bartok quartets Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall. Love takes different forms.

title: China Oil Price Rise Cited
description: China has raised the price of its crude oil by more than $3 a barrel, to $37.15, retroactive to Jan. 1, Japanese petroleum industry sources said today. The new price was set in negotiations between Japan and China in Peking last Wednesday, and it will apply to Chinese crude oil shipped to Japan in the January-March period, the sources said.

title: Stricter Post-Race Testing Is Imposed at N.Y. Tracks
description: Stricter security measures at New York horse tracks were implemented yesterday by the State Racing and Wagering Board. Chairman John Van Lindt said that, beginning with yesterday's card at Aqueduct, the post-race testing program would be expanded to include examination of the two horses finishing last in all triple races, usually the ninth race of the day.

title: Police Sergeant Kills Suspected Burglar
description: A suspected burglar died in an exchange of gunfire with a city police sergeant after apparently attempting to break into the sergeant's Brooklyn apartment, the police said.

title: ALBANY LEADER WANTS TO DELAY TALKS ON TRANSIT AID
description: The leader of the Republican-controlled Senate informed Governor Carey today that he did not want to take up the issue of aiding the state's mass-transit systems until after negotiations on the state budget for the fiscal year that begins April 1.

title: WILLIAMS BID FOR NEW ABSCAM PROSECUTOR IS DENIED
description: A Federal judge tonight rejected a request by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey that Thomas P. Puccio be removed as the chief prosecutor in the Democratic Senator's trial on Abscam bribery charges, scheduled to begin in Brooklyn next Monday.

title: WESTCHESTER COUNTY AIRPORT IS SAFE, F.A.A. REPORT SAYS
description: A 30-day study of Westchester County Airport by a 10-member team of Federal Aviation Administration specialists has determined that the airport is safe.

title: BOLIVIA TO DELAY HALF ITS DEBT REPAYMENTS
description: Bolivia is close to rescheduling $400 million of debt owed to foreign commercial banks, mostly American. The agreement, covering about half of Bolivia's commercial bank debt, was sent out to the banks by telex over the weekend for formal approval, one of the recipients said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Beatrice Foods opened a trading company in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, in a joint venture with two U.A.E. nationalized companies.

title: London Paper Says Official Was a Spy for Soviet Union
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has started an investigation into a newspaper report that a former chief of counterintelligence was suspected of being a Soviet agent, Government sources said today.

title: POLISH UNION DIVIDED ON NEW STRIKE ACTION
description: A meeting of Poland's independent labor movement, convened in Bydgoszcz to plan a protest against police violence against unionists there last week, adjourned in confusion at 3 A.M. today with no decision on when or how to strike.

title: CITY'S WATER PROBLEMS SHOULD CONCERN NATION, SUBCOMMITTEE TOLD
description: New York City's water problems should be a national concern, speakers told a Congressional subcommittee hearing in Manhattan yesterday. The chairman of the subcommittee, Representative Robert A. Roe, agreed.

title: TOWN IS ACCUSED OF BIAS IN REFUSAL OF HOUSING AID
description: The Justice Department is preparing to go to trial April 14 to compel the town of Manchester, Conn., to rejoin a grant program and accept $500,000 that the town has twice voted to reject.

title: MICHIGAN LEGISLATOR WINS G.O.P. CONTEST FOR STOCKMAN'S SEAT
description: State Representative Mark Siljander, who had the support of the conservative Moral Majority organization, tonight won the Republican nomination for the Congressional seat vacated by David A. Stockman, who is now the Federal budget director.

title: Officer Cleared in Fatal Shooting
description: Officer Henry Bass of the New York City Housing Authority police has been cleared in the shooting death of a Lake Mohegan man on Feb. 7, District Attorney Carl A. Vergari of Westchester County said today. He said a county grand jury had indicted John DiDomenico, 23 years old, also of Lake Mohegan, on a charge of assault in the death of the man, Robert Conklin, 27.

title: Careers; Water Experts In Demand
description: ''W ATER, water, everywhere, nor any drop to drink.'' The plaints of many governors and mayors in the Northeast in recent months bring to mind the comment of the querulous Ancient Mariner in the Samuel Taylor Coleridge poem.

title: ISLANDERS BEAT BLUES ON 3 LATE GOALS, 5-3, AND TRAIL BY A POINT
description: The New York Islanders rallied with four unanswered goals tonight to defeat the St. Louis Blues, 5-3. Bryan Trottier, with three goals, led the way for the victors, who moved to within 1 point of the first-place Blues in the National Hockey League overall standing.

title: Beyond Bydgoszcz
description: Bloodied heads in Bydgoszcz have brought Poland to the brink of yet another crisis. Solidarity, the national trade union, says the local police beat up 23 worker and farmer demonstrators while removing them from a meeting in the city hall last Thursday. But Lech Walesa, the union's chairman, counsels against immediate massive protest strikes. He wants to give union negotiators time to press their demand that the responsible local officials be dismissed.

title: WATERBEDS AIDING PREMATURE BABIES
description: A company is donating 200 tiny waterbeds to Chicago-area hospitals because doctors found that premature babies who lie on waterbeds in their incubators grow faster and experience fewer breathing and heart problems.

title: Jersey Conductor Signs With Kansas City Group
description: Thomas Michalak, conductor of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, has been appointed music adviser of the Kansas City Philharmonic. The orchestra was forced to cancel its 1980-81 season because of financial problems.

title: Geo Magazine Increasing Its Rate Base to 250,000
description: As the result of its purchase of the subscription list of Realites magazine, Geo magazine, the troubled property of Gruner & Jahr USA, will increase its rate base to 250,000 from 220,000 with the June issue. The reason the figure is not higher is because management is being realistic about how many Realites subscribers can be converted.

title: Hugh J. Grant, Lawyer And Philanthropist, 76
description: Hugh J. Grant, a retired lawyer and philanthropist, died last Saturday while vacationing in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Today's Matches In Avon Event
description: The Avon championships run today through Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Miss Potter Making A Bid in Title Tennis
description: From the time she graduated two years ago from Taft School in Watertown, Conn., Barbara Potter has earned more than $110,000 in prize money as a tennis professional. More than half, $58,850, has come this season on the Avon winter tour, which culminates with the $300,000 championships at Madison Square Garden beginning today. The top eight women in the tour's point standing qualified for the Garden event, and Miss Potter is among the new faces, ranked No. 5.

title: National Enquirer Trial Jury Recesses Without a Verdict
description: The jury in Carol Burnett's libel suit against The National Enquirer deliberated for six hours today but recessed without reaching a verdict.

title: Judge Quits California High Court To Be Sworn In for State Dept.Job
description: William P. Clark resigned from the California Supreme Court today to be sworn in as Deputy Secretary of State in Washington.

title: Hardwicke Urged To End Ritz Link
description: Two companies that hold a combined 10 percent interest in Hardwicke Companies Inc. of New York said today that they wanted Hardwicke to sell its 50.25 percent stake in the proposed Ritz Hotel and Casino because the project ''has little chance for success.''

title: 5-CENT BOTTLE-DEPOSIT BILL PASSED IN SUFFOLK COUNTY
description: The Suffolk County Legislature passed a bill today requiring 5-cent deposits on soft-drink and beer containers sold in the county.

title: CBS NEWS, RELENTING, GIVES JUDGE '60 MINUTES' MATERIAL
description: CBS News turned over transcripts and tapes of interviews conducted for a ''60 Minutes'' program on alleged fastfood franchise frauds yesterday after a Federal judge threatened the network with a heavy contempt fine.

title: Arrows Win, Reach Semifinals
description: The New York Arrows beat the Phoenix Inferno, 6-5, last night, advancing to the semifinals of the Major Indoor Soccer League playoffs. Page A20.

title: BILL TO BLOCK DAIRY SUPPORT RISE SURVIVES BIDS TO CRIPPLE PROPOSAL
description: The Senate backed President Reagan's position today by defeating a series of attempts to cripple a bill that would block an increase in dairy price supports.

title: DEPRECIATION TAX PLAN DRAWS SOME OPPOSITION
description: Now that the initial burst of applause is subsiding, members of Congress, lobbyists, some executives and others are voicing second thoughts about the Administration's proposal to give tax relief to business solely by permitting faster write-offs for buildings, equipment and vehicles.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: REQUEST NUMBERS

title: Pickle Extortionist Sentenced
description: A 63-year-old Oregon jeweler was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in Federal prison for trying to extort diamonds by poisoning pickles in supermarkets. Federal District Court Judge Howard Turrentine said the sentence given Paul Bailleaux of Corvallis, Ore., would be consecutive to a 20-year sentence the defendant received last December in a similar case in Portland, Ore.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have been arguing with a neighbor about a dish called financier. I say that I once ate pastries in France called financiers. She tells me that it is not a pastry but a filling for meat or poultry. Who is correct?

title: Australian Diamond Bid
description: The diversified Bond Corporation, which is based in Western Australia, said today that it had used its 40 percent owned subsidiary, Endeavour Resources Ltd, to buy into the Ashton Diamond joint venture in Western Australia. The Northern Mining Corporation, which has a 5 percent stake in the diamond venture, said Endeavour had bought 2.99 million shares, or 19.76 percent of the company's issued capital.

title: Mrs. Kirkpatrick Meets Mr. Young
description: Tricky job, the U.N., isn't it, Mme. Ambassador? Funny you should use that word. But please don't wink when you say it.

title: HOMECOMING TIME FOR A BRITISH BANK
description: The Standard Chartered Bank, banker to the British Empire, has decided that the time is now right to come home. ''In 1974 we drew up our strategy with two main aims,'' said Standard Chartered's managing director, Peter Graham. ''We wanted to establish ourselves in the United States and in Britain, which, after all, are the two most important financial centers in the world.''

title: by Richard J. Willey
description: ''Defense of the socialist community is the cause not only of each state but also of the entire coalition.'' This ''Brezhnev Doctrine'' was invoked to justify the Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968. Ominously, these words appeared in the communique issued at the close of a meeting March 4 between top Soviet and Polish leaders in Moscow.

title: END TO GUIDELINES FOR BUS DESIGNS PLANNED BY U.S.
description: In a decision that may change the future design of buses operating in New York and other cities, Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis said today that he intended to eliminate the Federal Government's detailed guidelines governing the manufacture of buses for mass-transit systems.

title: Eastern Shuttle Fare
description: Eastern Airlines said it would cut to $29 its one-way fare on selected shuttle flights between New York, Boston and Washington for passengers between ages 2 and 21.

title: Market Place; Analyst Looks For Little Signs
description: EVERY successful securities analyst, like a baseball player, develops an individual approach to his craft over the years. And, in looking over companies as a prelude to issuing possible buy recommendations, the analyst often finds that details can prove significant.

title: DANCE: THE PRIMUS 'EARTH'
description: PEARL PRIMUS looked out at her audience last Wednesday night and declared, ''This is not a stage, but the red earth of Africa.'' Strictly speaking, it was indeed a stage, the stage of the Theater of the Riverside Church. But the Pearl Primus-Percival Borde Dance Company did its best to transport audiences to Africa and, later, to the Caribbean, and one could understand why Miss Primus calls her presentations ''Earth Theater.''

title: TV: A PLOT TO BREACH THE BERLIN WALL
description: THE burrowing of tunnels is a well-worn device in suspense films. Usually, somebody or other is trying to get out of a prison or detention camp. In ''Berlin Tunnel 21,'' tonight's three-hour movie on CBS-TV at 8 o'clock, Richard Thomas and several collaborators are trying to dig their way into East Berlin, under the wall that has been constructed by the Communists. The point is to bring assorted loved ones to freedom in West Berlin.

title: SHAD AND SHAD ROE, SEASONAL DELIGHTS
description: The shad, wrote the French author Grimod de la Reyniere, ''reclines on its bed of sorrel like a beauty on the ottoman of her boudoir.'' This sweet delicate, white-fleshed fish with its spectacular roe is now at the height of the season.

title: Bill Introduced in Senate To Reinstate the Draft
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, introduced legislation yesterday to restore the military draft, saying the all-volunteer approach not only had failed to muster enough troops but also discriminated against minorities and the poor.

title: NATHANIEL B. COLE
description: Dr. Nathaniel B. Cole, a plastic surgeon, died yesterday at his home in Metuchen, N.J. He was 76 years old. Until last November, when he gave up a large part of his practice, Dr. Cole maintained offices in New Brunswick and Perth Amboy, N.J., and in Manhattan.

title: OLD DOMINION GAINS A.I.A.W. FINAL FOUR.
description: Anne Donovan scored 22 points and pulled down 15 rebounds tonight as Old Dominion coasted to a 76-60 victory over Long Beach State in the quarterfinals of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women basketball tournament.

title: EMIL ROGERS
description: Emil Rogers, a real-estate lawyer in Manhattan, died Sunday at his winter home in Palm Beach, Fla., at the age of 80. Mr. Rogers became chairman of Draft Board 13 in Manhattan when the United States entered World War II and held the post for nearly 30 years. He was awarded a medal by the Selective Service Administration for his volunteer work.

title: BEYOND BUBBA
description: To the Editor:

title: Indiana Standard
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said it had begun a program to periodically buy up to four million of its common shares in the open market over the next few months.

title: CONNECTICUT SHAKESPEARE SIGNS PLUMMER AND JONES
description: grand name as a home for the Bard. Mr. Coe immediately called two long-time friends, Christopher Plummer and James Earl Jones, and got them to agree to work with him this summer. Mr. Plummer will open July 7 in ''Henry V,'' and Mr. Jones will open Aug. 4 in ''Othello.'' Mr. Coe will direct both productions.

title: Williams Asks Delay In His Abscam Trial
description: An attorney for Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey yesterday asked the United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan to put off the Senator's trial on Abscam bribery charges, which is scheduled to begin Monday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. The defense request said that certain issues needed to be resolved before the trial, including a question on electronic surveillance of the Senator that had been referred to in court papers.

title: Capping a Great Evening
description: The occasion had taken three years to arrange, and when it was all over Monday night, there was still a tingle of excitement in the air and nobody felt much like going home.

title: Canadiens' Lafleur Averts Serious Injury in Car Crash
description: Guy Lafleur, a wing with the Montreal Canadiens, underwent plastic surgery on his right ear today after escaping serious injury earlier today when he fell asleep at the wheel of his car and rammed into a fence.

title: FOR MISSONI, APPLAUSE IN MILAN
description: While the fall and winter fashion collections are unfolding here this week, there is the feeling of spring in the air. Forsythia and dogwood flower against thick green carpets of grass and it is warm enough to stroll in the sun in shirt-sleeves. The designers deny they have managed the weather, which has been balmy all winter.

title: SYRACUSE IS SOOTHED BY SUCCESS IN N.I.T.
description: Suddenly a basketball championship looms at Madison Square Garden tonight for Syracuse or Tulsa, a curious circumstance to coaches on both teams.

title: SALVADORAN TRUCE HONORS SLAIN PRELATE
description: Leftist guerrillas observed a 24-hour cease-fire today to mark the anniversary of the assassination of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero of San Salvador and Government soldiers patrolled the streets to insure calm.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Inspirational Notebooks

title: PURGED SEOUL POLITICIAN SAYS CHUN GOVERNS BY FEAR
description: Kim Young Sam, a leading politician under house arrest here since the military takeover of power last May, says that the regime of President Chun Doo Hwan has curtailed freedom of speech, has seized direct control of all media and rules South Korea by fear.

title: Jet Drops Six Bombs by Mistake
description: A jet on a routine training mission yesterday inadvertently dropped six 25-pound unarmed practice bombs and two missiles on a forest six miles from a small community, officials at Holloman Air Force Base announced today. No one was injured in the incident, Air Force officials said, nor was there any explosion or fire.

title: COTTRELL JOINS CHIEFS
description: Ted Cottrell, defensive coordinator with Rutgers last season, was named today linebacker coach for the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Newspapers Are Warned On Pace of Negotiations
description: A coalition of six New York City newspaper unions announced yesterday that it would set an early date for a strike if current negotiations were unsuccessful.

title: Iran Reports an Attack On Iraqi Border Post
description: Iranian Revolutionary Guards struck across the Iraqi border and captured an outpost more than a mile inside northeastern Iraq, the official Pars press agency said today.

title: Physicians Urge Leaders
description: To Stop the Arms Race

title: 20 SENATORS CRITICIZE PROVIDING EQUIPMENT FOR F-15 TO THE SAUDIS
description: Twenty Republican and Democratic Senators today criticized the Reagan Administration's plans to sell Saudi Arabia equipment that would enhance the performance of the F-15 fighter planes it has ordered.

title: ARROWS TOP INFERNO AND GAIN SEMIFINALS
description: The New York Arrows, seeking their third Major Indoor Soccer League title in the league's three-year history, beat the Phoenix Inferno, 6-5, in the third and deciding game of their quarterfinal playoff series at the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The union's appeal for strikes cannot be interpreted other than as an invitation for self-annihilation. Who has the courage to make out of a local incident a national cause threatening catastrophe?'' - Stanislaw Kania, Poland's Communist party leader. (A1:2.)

title: WEINBERGER PRESSES 3 ALLIES ON DEFENSE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, trying during the last two days to persuade three of America's allies, West Germany, Japan and the Netherlands, to increase their military forces, has elicited little beyond vague promises.

title: Agents Who Tailed Plane To Colombia Seize Cocaine
description: United States Customs agents who tailed a twin-engine plane to Colombia and back for four days boarded the craft today and seized 614 pounds of uncut Bolivian cocaine with an estimated street value of $217 million, reportedly the largest such haul ever taken from an airplane.

title: CAREY MAY BACK ABORTION RULE ON NOTIFICATION
description: Governor Carey said today that he might consider a change in state law that would require doctors to notify a teen-age girl's parents when she sought an abortion.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES, CITING COSTS, TRIES TO SELL PART OF NEW PLANT
description: Northeast Utilities is one of a growing number of electric utilities around the country that have been forced by high interest rates, spiraling costs and reduced growth in electric demand to try to sell parts of plants under construction. These include both nuclear- and coal-powered plants.

title: LOGIC LOSES OUT, BUT TASTE TRIUMPHS
description: WE had dined well, no doubt about that, and on some extraordinary combinations of flavors. There had been, for example, a marriage of baked lobsters with a savory, silken, vanilla-flavored sauce. Lobsters? Vanilla? It would seem to be one of the least compatible flavor liaisons conceivable. If the reflexive reaction to such a dish was a grimace, it was quickly dispelled. The combination not only worked, it was a triumph of taste over logic.

title: Funeral Mass Set for Tomorrow For Elliott, Coach at Villanova
description: A funeral mass will be said Thursday for James Francis (Jumbo) Elliott, the Villanova track coach who died of a heart attack at his Florida home Sunday at age 66.

title: WHERE TO GET TRUSTWORTHY ADVICE
description: MANY places offer sound nutritional information and advice, unbiased by the promise of financial gain and based on properly designed scientific research. But unless you have a clear-cut nutritional deficiency, such as iron deficiency anemia, you are not likely to receive a nutrient prescription that will produce a remarkable reversal of symptoms. Here are some trustworthy sources:

title: IN THE SOUTH, BARBECUE IS THE SPECIALTY
description: in movie projection shack just off Highway 321 and opened David Brown's Hickory House Pit Bar-B-Q. Building his business by word of mouth, Mr. Brown now sells more than 1,000 pounds of hickory-smoked, vinegar- and pepper-spiced pork each week. When the restaurant is closed, he caters wedding dinners and banquets.

title: The U.N. Today; March 25, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing Nonuse of Force in International Rela- tions - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PIANIST: MAURIZIO POLLINI PLAYS SCHUBERT, CHOPIN
description: RATHER than break up his Chopin group, Maurizio Pollini Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall played a very long first half. Schubert's A minor Sonata (Op. 42), with all repeats, ran more than half an hour, and so did Schumann's Fantasy in C. Then, after intermission, came the Chopin - the Polonaise in F sharp minor, two Nocturnes (C minor and F sharp minor) and the Polonaise in A flat. It was very modern programming, in that old pianists would have played the Schubert and two of the Chopin pieces, followed by the Schumann and the last two Chopin works.

title: CONSUMER UNITS: HOW USEFUL
description: When the Procter & Gamble Company recalled its Rely tampon in September after it was linked to toxic shock syndrome, it was the first time in the company's 143 years that a product was withdrawn from the market.

title: Fisk's Successor Faces the Pressure
description: Although the circumstances are different, the task Gary Allenson faces this season - replacing Carlton Fisk behind the plate for the Red Sox - is similar to the one faced last year by the Yankees' Rick Cerone when he took over Thurman Munson's job.

title: FIELD MARSHAL AUSCHINLECK, DESERT COMMANDER, DIES
description: Field Marshal Sir Claude Auchinleck, the World War II general dismissed by Winston Churchill because he refused an order to counterattack German troops, died yesterday in Marrakesh, Morocco, in his sleep. He was 96 years old.

title: LOCKED IN ON ART DECO IN MIAMI
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH COURT SAYS RADIO STATIONS CAN SHIFT TO NEW TYPES OF PROGRAMMING
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the Federal Communications Commission's view that changes in a radio station's entertainment programming are not subject to Federal regulation.

title: News Analysis
description: ''There is so much posturing. All the characters - the Governor, the Mayor, the M.T.A., the Comptroller, the legislative leaders, the Council President -trying to avoid responsibility, and meanwhile the system collapses around us.''

title: The Energy Crisis Century
description: Anyone who thinks the energy crisis is temporary or can be easily solved, as President Reagan apparently does, will be jolted by the latest international analysis of global energy needs. It concludes that shifting from fossil fuels to more sustainable sources of energy will take a century. It can be done, says the director of the seven-year study, Wolf Hafele, a West German nuclear scientist, ''but only with pain and at high cost.''

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN I wrote recently that a reader had asked why there were so few duck recipes in this column, I stated that it was impossible to prepare roast duck in less than one and a half hours. I, therefore, offered a less-than-60-minute version of a duck dish, one in which the bird was cut into serving pieces and broiled, then roasted.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Caesars World has elected Stephen H. Ackerman vice president and treasurer.

title: MARKET RETURNS IN HEAVY TRADING
description: The stock market, kindled by the rally Monday that pushed the Dow Jones industrial average through the 1,000 barrier, moved sharply higher in early trading yesterday, then floundered as investors sought to cash in their profits.

title: Tennessee 79, Maryland 67
description: Tennessee, paced by Mary Ostrowski, defeated Maryland, 79-67, tonight in the A.I.A.W. tournament. The Lady Vols held a 42-30 halftime advantage, but the Terrapins, led by Pam Reaves, battled back to tie at 61-all with six and onehalf minutes remaining. Tennessee then ran off a 13-2 spurt and was never threatened again.

title: Jockey's Spine Is Broken In Track Spill at Pimlico
description: A jockey who broke his spine in a fall at Pimlico Race Track is paralyzed from the waist down and is in critical but stable condition, a spokesman for Sinai Hospital said today.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Musical Itinerary With Mel Torme He was born in Chicago, has lived in California since 1943 and sings just about everywhere, but Mel Torme swears that something special happens when he gets to New York.

title: Steinbrenner Testimony Heard by U.S. Grand Jury
description: George Steinbrenner, principal owner of the New York Yankees, appeared before a Federal grand jury in Manhattan yesterday. After reporters had seen Steinbrenner in the Federal courthouse, United States Attorney John S. Martin Jr. issued a brief statement that said: ''Mr. Steinbrenner appeared at our request and testified in a matter. Mr. Steinbrenner is not the subject of any investigation in this office.''

title: Soviet Skier Scores 2d Straight Triumph
description: Aleksandr Zhirov of the Soviet Union gained his second successive giant-slalom victory in the World Cup today. He thus denied Ingemar Stenmark his seventh triumph of the season, but the Swede stayed ahead in the overall ski standing.

title: Brooklyn Firebombing Burns Four Teen-Agers
description: A gunman forced 15 patrons of a pinball parlor in Brooklyn to lie on the floor last night and then set off a firebomb that burned four teen-agers, the police said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said an average rate of 13.663 percent was set at yesterday's weekly auction of 91-day Citicorp commercial paper, compared with 13.885 percent last week.

title: People
description: * George C. Deecken has joined Young & Rubicam Inc. as an executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Third of four articles.
description: To the chief religious authority of Saudi Arabia, Western-style economic development is a threat to Islamic values and ''the serene and tranquil life.'' But he says he is confident the nation can avoid the pitfalls while benefiting from modern technology. ''The harm to Saudi society may happen through blind and ignorant imitation of Western ways and ideas,'' Sheik Abdel-Aziz bin Abdullah bin Baz said in an interview. But by holding ''strongly to our Islamic teachings and values,'' he added, Saudi Arabia can repel ''dangerous ideas'' and take advantage of modern technology and development.

title: PRICE INDEX UP 1.1% IN NEW YORK REGION
description: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern Jersey area rose 1.1 percent in February, with sharply higher energy costs accounting for about half of the increase, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, announced yesterday.

title: Fast Field In N.C.A.A Swimming
description: Had the United States not boycotted the Moscow Olympics last summer, it might well have won nine or 10 of the 13 gold medals in men's swimming. Most of the swimmers who would have won those medals started arriving today for the 58th annual National Collegiate championships.

title: MAYOR PROCLAIMS LITERARY WEEK; PLANS TO CUT ARTS FUNDS ASSAILED
description: Poets, novelists and other book people gathered at City Hall yesterday to hear Mayor Koch proclaim Literary Week in New York City beginning Saturday.

title: Successor to Azie Taylor Morton Sworn In
description: The new Treasurer of the United States, Angela M. Buchanan, yesterday wrote out her signature in the version it will appear on about four billion pieces of currency in the next year alone.

title: LEARNING, AT AGE 11, HOW NOT TO WORRY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Phyllis Theroux is the author of ''California and Other States of Grace.'' By PHYLLIS THEROUX

title: Fractured Skull Killed Peacemaking Teacher
description: The Medical Examiner's office said yesterday that a Brooklyn teacher who broke up a fight in his Bushwick High School home room last week died later the same day of a fractured skull.

title: BLACK LEADERS SAY THEY SEE NO 'RACIST PLOT' AGAINST ATLANTA YOUTH
description: Leaders of major black organizations expressed concern today over an ''escalation of violence and insensitivity'' toward the nation's poor and black people but said that they saw no ''racist plot'' against Atlanta's black children.

title: DATA ON SECRET HEARINGS ON CAREY NOMINEE ISSUED
description: The State Senate Labor Committee today released a report and hundreds of pages of transcripts from its secret hearings on Governor Carey's nomination of Meyer S. Frucher to be the state's Labor Commissioner. Mr. Frucher's withdrawal as the Governor's nominee for the post was accepted last weekend.

title: NATHANIEL L. GOLDSTEIN, 84, SERVED AS ATTORNEY GENERAL OF NEW YORK
description: Nathaniel L. Goldstein, New York State Attorney General from 1943 through 1954 and a leader in philanthropic causes, died yesterday at his Manhattan home, apparently of a heart attack. He was 84 years old.

title: Managing The Managers
description: Two questions have now emerged over the conduct or misconduct of foreign affairs in the Reagan Administration: first, who will be in charge of managing the crises among the nations? And second, who will manage the crisis among the managers?

title: ENERGY COST SURGE IN FEBRUARY PUSHED PRICE INDEX UP 1%
description: Soaring energy costs that in large part have resulted from President Reagan's decision to decontrol oil prices pushed the Consumer Price Index up 1 percent last month.

title: SURROGATE MOTHER-TO-BE FIGHTS TO KEEP UNBORN CHILD
description: A woman hired to bear a child for a New York couple now wants to keep the unborn child, and the resulting paternity-custody lawsuit here could have far-reaching consequences for other arrangements involving surrogate mothers.

title: by Percy Chubb 2D
description: The solution to inflation has to be monetary as well as fiscal. While the Reagan Administration vigorously attacks the problem of budgetary waste, the Federal Reserve Board's efforts to control the supply of money through high interest rates leaves a major loophole.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS MRS. KIRKPATRICK DIDN'T KNOW SOUTH AFRICAN'S ROLE
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, met last week with a high-ranking South African military intelligence official without knowing the full role of the official, the White House said today.

title: Bridge: New York Players Win One And Lose One in Big Upsets
description: Two major upsets marked yesterday's play in the Vanderbilt knockout team championship, a New York team finishing on the right side in one case and the wrong side in another. The field was cut to 16 teams in the most prestigious event of the American Contract Bridge League Spring Nationals, which end Friday.

title: CAR ACCORD STILL ELUDES U.S., JAPAN
description: President Reagan and Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ito of Japan agreed today that the two countries would continue to discuss the issue of possibly limiting Japanese auto imports, with the goal of resolving the problem before Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki visits Washington the second week in May.

title: THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GUITAR HERO; by Robert Palmer
description: 60's, was hospitalized in Madison, Wis., on March 13 with an illness subsequently diagnosed as gastric ulcers. His condition is ''serious but stable'' according to his record label, RSO, and he will probably remain hospitalized for another two or three weeks. His 1981 North American tour, which began a few days before he fell ill, has been canceled.

title: ROCHESTER FEARFUL OF CUTBACKS IN REAGAN'S BUDGET
description: News of President Reagan's proposed budget cuts came to this shrinking industrial city off Lake Ontario two days after the New York Court of Appeals ruled in February that it must refund at least $42 million in property taxes. The two developments, like rapid hammer blows to a city struggling for renewal after two decades of decline, have been followed by almost daily after-tremors with the discovery of some new impact of the proposed Federal cuts on the city, its people and institutions.

title: Transit Policeman Kills Man, 28, Who Attacked Him, Police Say
description: A 28-year-old man who was allegedly breaking into a car near Union Square was fatally shot when he twice lunged at a Transit Authority police officer with a claw hammer last night, the police said.

title: New Surprises On Ad Research
description: Starch Tested Copy, a monthly newsletter from Starch INRA Hooper, the research company, is continuing to raise eyebrows. The latest challenge to popular thinking is that there is no difference in readership scores for ads on left-hand and right-hand pages.

title: S.B.A. Nominee Advances
description: The Senate Select Committee on Small Business today unanimously approved the nomination of Michael Cardenas as chief of the Small Business Administration. Mr. Cardenas, 47 years old, is a public accountant from Fresno, Calif.

title: Output Abroad Climbed in 1980
description: A Government measure of industrial production by major trading partners of the United States grew 1.8 percent last year while production was falling in this country, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE HANGWOMAN. By Pavel Kahout. Translated from the Czech by Kaca Pola Ckova-Henley. 293 pages. Putnam. $14.95.

title: Homards Rotis a la Sauce Vanille (Roast lobsters with vanilla sauce)
description: 5 tablespoons butter 2 tablespoons finely chopped shallots 1/4 cup dry white wine 2 2-inch lengths plus one 1-inch length of vanilla bean 1/2 cup fish broth (see recipe) 1 cup heavy cream Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste 4 live lobsters, 1 1/2 pounds each 1 pound spinach 1 large bunch watercress.

title: CONCERT: LEINSDORF LEADS SCHUMANN
description: CREATIVE musical genius does not necessarily imply the ability to write for an orchestra. A notable example is Robert Schumann, who possessed musical genius in abundance. His Fourth Symphony in D minor - which formed the centerpiece of Friday's New York Philharmonic concert conducted by Erich Leinsdorf - documents Schumann's struggle; and it was the original version - written in 1841, suppressed for a decade and then reorchestrated into the version the world has come to know - that Mr. Leinsdorf chose to give us.

title: STATE ASKED TO BAR INVESTIGATORS, FROM PRETENDING TO BE REPORTERS
description: The New York Press Club has asked New York's State Department to promulgate regulations barring investigators from posing as reporters after an investigator for the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation made videotapes of striking municipal hospital doctors while pretending to be working for WCBS-TV.

title: Chemical Concern Offers to Buy Homes
description: BUFFALO (AP) - The Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation has offered to buy nine homes as part of the company's plans to clean up its Hyde Park chemical dump.

title: Massachusetts Sues to Bar School Closings in Boston
description: The state filed suit today to keep Boston's nearly bankrupt public schools from closing at the end of the month, a move that would start summer vacation 51 days early for 64,400 students.

title: Jones in Center of Yankee Plans
description: During the winter, Ruppert Jones and Bobby Brown, New Jersey neighbors, visited each other a couple of times a week. Among other activities, they played cards and backgammon.

title: Amax Stiffens Stand on Socal Bid
description: Amax Inc., the mineral concern, has stiffened its stand against the $4 billion takeover bid by the Standard Oil Company of California, telling stockholders that the offer is inadequate and raises antitrust questions.

title: Apologia For A Fleecing
description: Our large research staff is being flogged in the cellar at this very moment. This is not the semiannual horsewhipping that we administer routinely to keep them on their toes, but an impromptu beating with lead-weighted knouts such as we occasionally conduct when they bite the hand that feeds them.

title: U.S. CLOSES INQUIRY ON EX-CARTER AIDE
description: A special Federal prosecutor who investigated allegations of cocaine use against Tim Kraft, a former White House aide to President Carter, said in court papers filed here today that the evidence did not warrant an indictment.

title: Interest Rates Cut On City Bond Issue
description: New York City's first offering of its own long-term securities in six years was such a resounding success that the interest rates on the bonds were lowered slightly yesterday, at a savings to the city of $257,580.

title: 10,000 VOLUNTEERS TUTOR CITY'S PUPILS
description: Although Antonio Rosario was in the fourth grade, his reading scores were those of a second grader, and he avoided reading because it was difficult for him. ''I felt embarrassed,'' he said. ''I never liked to tell anybody my score. I would think books were boring, and I would just leave them.''

title: Plane Crash Kills Virginia Aide
description: William Lee Cooper, chairman of the Virginia Aviation Commission, died yesterday when his plane lost power and crashed in a snow-covered field about 100 feet from a house, the state police said. The 49-year-old head of Cooper Wood Products, a lumber concern, was alone in the six-seat Piper 601.

title: TAX ON OIL RECEIPTS PROPOSED IN ILLINOIS
description: Gov. James R. Thompson Jr. today proposed a new 5 percent tax on the gross receipts of oil companies doing business in Illinois to keep mass transit solvent in the Chicago area and to provide more money to build and repair the state's highways.

title: PROTESTS ON SALVADOR ARE STAGED ACROSS U.S.
description: Demonstrations, hunger strikes and candle-light vigils across the country yesterday protested the increasing United States military involvment in El Salvador.

title: Louisiana Tech 87, U.C.L.A. 54
description: With Pam Kelly scoring 20 points, undefeated Louisiana Tech routed U.C.L.A., 87-54, in the A.I.A.W. tournament.

title: CELTICS BEAT KNICKS: DEBUSSCHERE SALUTED
description: On a night honoring Dave DeBusschere, whose defense often helped the Knicks win games, it was Robert Parish's defense that enabled the the Boston Celtics to beat the Knicks, 118-116, at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Income Tax Bill Criticized at Hearing
description: A prominent business economist, Jack Carlson, recommended to the House Ways and Means Committee today that income tax relief for individuals be limited to rate cuts of 5 percent a year for three years.

title: NEWARK STATION JOB
description: WASHINGTON (UPI) - The Federal Department of Transportation has awarded a $13.7 million contract to a Connecticut company for the renovation of Penn Station in Newark, according to Representative James J. Florio, Democrat of New Jersey. The contract was given to the Acmat Corporation of East Hartford.

title: Soviet Envoy Confers With Haig In the 'Beginning of a Dialogue'
description: The Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, conferred today with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in their first substantive meeting since the envoy returned from several weeks in Moscow.

title: Economic Scene; A 'Dissensus' On U.S. Policy
description: DOES the United States, anxiety-ridden over its weak productivity performance and the loss of a share of world markets by some of its key industries, need a new industrial policy?

title: SPANISH KING URGES MILITARY TO BE CALM
description: After a Government decision to deploy army units in the Basque region, King Juan Carlos told the nation's top military commanders today to refrain from impulsive responses to a stepped-up terrorist offensive.

title: Noranda Also Seeks MacMillan Bloedel
description: Noranda Mines Ltd. entered the bidding for control of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. today, offering the equivalent of $497.4 million (Canadian) for the big forest-products concern. The combined cash and share-exchange offer exceeds by $10 a share a competing offer by the British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation.

title: TEXT OF WHITE HOUSE STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of a statement issued today by the White House press secretary, James S. Brady, on the decision to place Vice President George Bush in charge of foreign policy ''crisis management'': Special to the New York Times

title: MID-MARCH CAR SALES UP 35.3%
description: Spurred by the approaching end of broad-scale rebates, sales by the three major American automobile manufacturers surged 35.3 percent, to 322,793, in the mid-March sales period from 238,504 in the similar 1980 period.

title: KOCH DEFENDS COMMENTS OF JUDGES
description: At a sometimes heated meeting with the New York Criminal Bar Association yesterday, Mayor Koch defended his right to criticize the city's judges. And he repeated his position that ''the gun law is not working'' and challenged lawyers who accused him of proposing ''simplistic solutions to complex problems'' to come up with a better answer.

title: SOUTHERN CAL 67, CHENEY 58
description: Kathy Hammond and Kathy Doyle scored 17 points apiece tonight to lead Southern California to a 67-58 victory over Cheyney State. Yolanda Laney led Cheyney State (26-4) with 21 points and 10 rebounds. Southern Cal (26-6) led, 33-27, at halftime.

title: A SERVICE TO THE POOR AND TO LAW AND ORDER
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan on How Extra Cash Can Be Spent in a Flash
description: A hitherto-unpublished poem Ronald Reagan wrote in 1974, when he was Governor of California, indicates that the budget-cutting with which he now seems preoccupied is nothing new to him.

title: Dr. Robert Christen, 53; Ex-Head of School Board
description: Dr. Robert J. Christen, a former president of the New York City Board of Education, died Sunday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 53 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: COURT OVERTURNS IOWA LIMIT ON TRUCK SIZE
description: The Supreme Court today invalidated an Iowa law that barred a commonly used type of double tractor-trailer truck from the state's highways.

title: by Terry Robards
description: BURGESS MEREDITH squint-ed under the glare of the television lights, looked out from the dais across the shimmering pool surrounded by 224 wine enthusiasts crammed into the Four Seasons restaurant and declared: ''I'm not here because I'm in the trade. I'm here because I buy more wine than anybody else. So I deserve to be here!''

title: TAX CONSEQUENCES; Supercow
description: Consider the miracle of the Supercow. A plain old milk cow produces maybe 10 calves in her lifetime. The Supercow - As Ann Crittenden explained in The Times's Sunday Business section - can produce 50, and each will turn out to be a top-quality animal.

title: CAREY HINTS THAT HE'S READY TO PROPOSE
description: Governor Carey hinted today that he planned to propose marriage to Evangeline Gouletas, a Chicago widow who has been his frequent companion in recent weeks, but Miss Gouletas said later she had no plans to wed.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: A woman in Maine followed the advice of the late Adelle Davis and gave her daughter huge doses of vitamin A, which permanently stunted the child's growth. A damage suit against the Davis estate was settled out of court for $150,000.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MARCH 25, 1981
description: International A dispute over foreign policymaking became public in testimony by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. before a House subcommittee. He questioned a White House plan to put Vice President Bush in charge of the Administration's ''crisis management'' team. Hours after Mr. Haig had seemingly put his prestige on the line in saying that he regarded the possibility of Mr. Bush's getting the position with ''a lack of enthusiasm,'' the White House named Mr. Bush to the foreign-policy post. (Page A1, Column 6.) Polish unionists became more militant, calling a four-hour warning strike for Friday and a general strike to begin next Tuesday as a protest against police violence in Bydgoszcz last week and the authorities' refusal to make amends. But the union's leadership made clear that the stoppages would be called off if negotiations set for today with Government leaders proved satisfactory. Stanislaw Kania, the Polish leader, denounced the union's announcement as ''an invitation for self-annihilation.'' (A1:2.)

title:
RED SMITH;
Hey, Bowie Kuhn Is Right
description: ONE of the easiest ways to publicize a commercial product is through some tie-in with baseball, football or one of the other popular spectator sports. In the early years of this century, every bush-league ball park in the country had an advertisement for Bull Durham tobacco on the center-field fence, and there was a cash award of $50 or $100 for the batter who could hit the sign on the fly. Similar promotions have been going on ever since.

title: ZIMBABWE'S GUESTS PLEDGE $1.3 BILLION
description: The 31 nations and 26 international agencies that responded to Zimbabwe's invitation to come here and consider rural development programs were called on today, in a kind of auction, to start bidding on the pieces of the program they would like to back with their own hard currency.

title: COAL UNION BARGAINING COUNCIL BACKS PROPOSED CONTRACT
description: The United Mine Workers union's 39-member bargaining council approved a proposed contract settlement tonight as evidence grew that both sides were determined to limit the strike set for midnight Thursday. The vote was 21 to 14, with four members absent.

title: Ebert is Top M.I.S.L. Rookie
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League today named Don Ebert, a forward with the St. Louis Steamers, rookie of the year.

title: Cedeno Facing Surgery, May Miss Astros' Opener
description: Hemorrhoids, the ailment that plagued George Brett in the last World Series, may prevent Cesar Cedeno from being in center field when the Houston Astros open the regular season April 9 in Los Angeles.

title: Mitsui Accused On Sales in U.S.-
description: A Federal grand jury here is studying evidence suggesting that Mitsui & Company U.S.A., the American subsidiary of Japan's huge M.B.K. trading concern, carried out an elaborate scheme to dump steel in this country.

title: Mitsubishi Cancels China Steel Contract
description: The Mitsubishi Group, one of Japan's largest industrial conglomerates, said it would terminate a $400 million contract to supply hot strip steel equipment to the huge Baoshan steel mill near Shanghai because of Chinese backtracking on the $5 billion project.

title: COAST OFFICIALS TRY TO CONTROL SIZE OF ISLAND DEER HERD
description: Wildlife officials on Angel Island, a serene, undeveloped island park in San Francisco Bay, have tried for years to control the growth of a deer herd that is not threatened by hunters or predatory animals so that overpopulation will not cause many deer to die of starvation.

title: 3 Big Banks at 17% Prime
description: Three major banks lowered their prime lending rates yesterday to 17 percent from 17 1/2 percent, despite rising interest rates elsewhere in the financial markets.

title: Text of statement, page A6.
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today publicly questioned a White House plan to put Vice President Bush in charge of the Administration's ''crisis management'' team. Hours later, the Administration named Mr. Bush to the post.

title: OPERA: MARIA STUARDA'
description: THERE was a curious muted quality about the New York City Opera's ''Maria Stuarda'' revival Sunday night. Part of the reason had to do with the work, which is less melodramatic and more interior than Donizetti's other operas about British royalty.

title: WHY MUST ENGLISH-AS-A-SECOND-LANGUAGE BE 'REMEDIAL'?
description: To the Editor:

title: HANDY SPICE GRINDERS
description: EVEN at the moment they are bought, those cans of ground, dried spices that most of us keep on racks in the kitchen do not have the strength or the advantages of freshly ground spice. As time passes they lose what little they have going for them, making them worse than useless. The result is disappointment when a dish simply lacks the punch it is supposed to have.

title: BILLS IN CONGRESS SEEK SHARP REDUCTION IN IMMIGRATION
description: Senator Walter D. Huddleston and several other members of Congress today introduced a comprehensive bill that would reduce immigration to the United States and more than double the size of the Border Patrol.

title: Andersen Is Liable In Viatron Case
description: A jury hearing a Federal class-action suit in Boston found yesterday that Arthur Andersen & Company, the big accounting firm, was liable to the former shareholders of the now-defunct Viatron Computer Systems Corporation. Andersen was the outside auditor for Viatron, which the court said filed false and misleading financial statements before it went bankrupt in 1971.

title: Neo-Nazi Propaganda Is Seized in West Germany
description: The police seized banned neo-Nazi propaganda smuggled into West Germany from the United States and Canada in coordinated nationwide raids on about 450 homes of suspected neo-Nazis, the authorities announced today.

title: FRENCH CHEFS' GROUP CONVENES IN THE U.S. TO DINE AND DEBATE
description: WHO has been feeding the great chefs of France? So far this week, it's been up to the Tavern on the Green, the Hotel Pierre, the Culinary Institute of America, the New York Athletic Club and the Mayflower Hotel in Washington. The chefs, members of the Association des Maitres Cuisiniers de France, are here for their annual convention. Tomorrow they are stopping in San Francisco and on Friday, after a visit to the Grand Canyon, they will dine at the Las Vegas Hilton.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS TO FIGHT TO SAVE $3 BILLION IN PROGRAMS
description: The Senate's 46 Democrats tentatively agreed today to try to restore perhaps $3 billion to $4 billion in funds for social welfare that were deleted in the $36.4 billion in budget cuts approved last week by the Republican-dominated Senate Budget Committee.

title: Carbide Will Pare Its Metals Business
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that it had signed definitive agreements with two Norwegian companies - Elkem and Jebsens - for the sale of portions of its metals business to a consortium led by Elkem.

title: McCall's Working Mother Going to 12 Issues a Year
description: McCall's Working Mother is making a big move in September. It is going from six times a year to 12, a sure sign, if not of real success, at least of management confidence.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: LEDE DIARY, C2

title: Levi Slides 22.5%; Alexander's Off 50%; EARNINGS
description: Levi Strauss & Company, the world's leading apparel manufacturer, reported yesterday that earnings in the first fiscal quarter ended March 1 fell by 22.5 percent, while sales increased 6.1 percent. The company cited currency adjustments as a factor in the earnings decline.

title: Merrill Plans Savings Unit Loans
description: In a further expansion of its role as a lender, Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday that it planned to start making loans to cash-hungry savings and loan associations, beginning next month.

title: Sun Plans to Sell Becton Convertible
description: The Sun Company has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of $389.13 million in subordinated 25-year debentures convertible into the common stock of Becton Dickinson & Company, the Paramus, N.J., medical supply house. The debentures are convertible into Becton Dickinson common at $60 a share.

title: WHERE BARTER CAN REPLACE GOVERNMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: ATTRACTING SATURDAY SHOPPERS TO THE WORLD TRADE CENTER
description: By the end of this year, the people who manage the retail space at the concourse level of the World Trade Center expect to have a ''Saturday count.'' This should provide one clue to how successful the trade center has become in attracting noncommuter shoppers.

title: From the S.E.C.  To Merrill Lynch
description: Irving M. Pollack, who retired last June as a commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been a consultant since then, serving such clients as the Synthetic Fuels Corporation and a unit of the World Bank. His newest client, however, is closer to his work of 35 years at the commission: the brokerage firm of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith.

title: F.B.I. TO INVESTIGATE CHARGES AT ROCKWELL
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to examine alleged accounting irregularities involving the Rockwell International Corporation's space shuttle contract, the company confirmed today.

title: EX-LABOR PARTY CHIEF CALLED SPY
description: A British newspaper, which this week named the former head of the nation's counterintelligence service as a possible Soviet spy, said today that the onetime head of the Labor Party was also a double agent working for Moscow.

title: THE CITY
description: The city's Correction Department has dropped its plans to sell the Salvador Dali painting that had been hanging in a Rikers Island jail mess hall for the last 16 years, according to Benjamin Ward, the Corrections Commissioner.

title: Larry C. Morris
description: A 350-pound Statue Stolen From St. Bartholomew's Only three of ''The Four Generations'' remained after the life-size bronze statue of the fourth was stolen from a public courtyard of St. Bartholom [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] ew's Episcopal Church on Park Avenue. The work, by Francisco Zuniga, was on loan from a Madison Avenue gallery and valued at more than $400,000.

title: LESSARD CATCHES SHOOTING STAR
description: Minnesota out-shot Los Angeles, 68-19, but could not overcome the spectacular goaltending of Mario Lessard as the Kings defeated the North Stars, 4-3, tonight.

title: FRUSTRATING DEMOCRACY IN TURKEY
description: To the Editor:

title: Exxon Chairman Earned $1.34 Million Last Year
description: If C.C. Garvin Jr., chairman of the Exxon Corporation, gave away dimes to poor youths he met on the street, as the company's founder, John D. Rockefeller, used to, it would take Mr. Garvin more than 25 years to distribute the amount of money he made last year, even if he worked at it 24 hours a day, every day.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Babcock and Wilcox, a unit of McDermott Inc., said it had received a $2.7 million order for a new boiler from an Australian concern.

title: Ramsay Signs Blazer Pact
description: Coach Jack Ramsay of the Portland Trail Blazers signed a new contract today.

title: Louisiana Prisoner Loses Plea for Stay of Execution
description: Robert Wayne Williams, facing death in Louisiana's electric chair next week, failed to win a stay of execution in District Court today, and his lawyers headed for the State Supreme Court to try again.

title: THEATER: 'FORTY-DEUCE,' STREET HUSTLERS' STORY
description: THE title of Alan Bowne's first play, ''Forty-Deuce,'' is street hustler's slang for 42d Street. Let's hope that no tourists confuse ''Forty-Deuce'' with ''42d Street.'' The characters of Mr. Bowne's show, now at the Perry Street Theater, aren't singing any lullabies of Broadway; they're too busy shooting up drugs, selling their bodies and plotting crimes. ''Forty-Deuce'' takes us right into the sleaze of one of Times Square's sleaziest subcultures; it's a night in the life of a band of young homosexual prostitutes.

title: The Economy
description: The Consumer Price Index rose 1 percent last month, to a 12.7 percent annual rate of increase, mainly because of soaring energy costs that resulted in large part from decontrol of oil prices. The index would have risen only three-tenths of 1 percent if energy prices had not accelerated so sharply. (Page A1.) Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern Jersey area rose 1.1 percent. (A15.)

title: AT THIS CAFETERIA, THE LINE STARTS AT THE COULIBIAC
description: ''WE have the only three-star cafeteria in town,'' said Richard Ruopp, president of the Bank Street College of Education, chewing his cold salad of shredded chicken breasts with pesto and eyeing the crusted slice of coulibiac of salmon and vegetables still to be eaten.

title: GROWERS' POWER IN MARKETING UNDER ATTACK
description: From afar, it looks like a red haze on the horizon. But after the car swings onto the Famoso strip, a swath of pavement amid the citrus groves of the San Joaquin Valley, it becomes clear that what lies in the distance really is mounds of oranges.

title: SLAYERS OF THREE IN QUEENS ROBBERY TRIED TWICW TO KILL A FOURTH PERSON
description: The police said yesterday that three killers who entered a house in Queens early yesterday left one of their four intended victims alive after two attempts to kill her.

title: COMMON MARKET LEADERS VOW NEW AID TO POLAND
description: West European leaders said today that they were ready to give Poland new emergency aid to help alleviate its economic hardships.

title: 'LOU GRANT' STRIVES FOR THE REALITY OF THE NEWSROOM
description: LOS ANGELES ONE of the most unusual things about the acclaimed CBS-TV show ''Lou Grant'' is that it frequently has more in common with a magazine program such as ''60 Minutes'' than with the majority of other prime-time dramas.

title: ST. JOE PLANS TO BUY 38% OF ITS STOCK
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation announced plans yesterday, partly subject to its ability to sell its Canadian oil and gas properties, to buy back more than $1 billion of its own stock.

title: New York City Bond Rates Cut
description: Interest rates were lowered slightly for about $30 million of New York City's $75 million bond sale, underwriters led by Merrill Lynch and Goldman, Sachs & Company said yesterday. The bond issue sold out quickly at the higher yields announced Monday, and investment bankers said the issue remained all sold after yields were lowered.

title: GAF to Sell Unit
description: The GAF Corporation, which last month reported a loss of $246.2 million for its fourth quarter because of a large restructuring write-off, said that a group headed by Arnold Thaler, a Chicago businessman, and Integrated Resources Inc. had signed a letter of intent to acquire its worldwide pictorial products business for $24 million.

title: People Express Jet
description: People Express Airlines, a new regional airline being formed in Newark, said it had taken delivery of its first Boeing 737 aircraft under an agreement with Lufthansa Airlines.

title: POLISH STRIKE SET IF MEETING TODAY BRINGS NO GAINS
description: The Solidarity labor movement today called a four-hour warning strike for Friday and a general strike to begin next Tuesday as a protest against police violence in Bydgoszcz last week and the authorities' refusal to do anything about it.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE New York City Department of Consumer Affairs has conducted a special survey that shows people can save 20 percent on their food bills if they shop carefullly. On this basis, the average cost of feeding a family of four for a week can be driven down to $80.55, which was the cost three years ago.

title: Transfer of Principal Opposed in Brooklyn
description: Hundreds of angry parents, teachers, students and community residents rallied outside Eastern District High School in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn to protest the transfer of the school principal, David Dicker.

title: INTERNS RETURN AT 2 BRONX HOSPITALS UNDER CERTIFICATION FORFEIT THREATS
description: Striking interns and residents returned to work at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center and North Central Bronx Hospital in the Bronx yesterday.

title: U.S. ASKS END TO AID FOR CONRAIL
description: The Reagan Administration today urged Congress to withdraw Federal support from Conrail, the troubled railroad that spans the Northeast and reaches into the Middle West, and to transfer its main freight and passenger lines to private railroads or local authorities.

title: Advertising; New Chief For Bates in New York
description: FROM his five executive vice presidents for client services, Robert E. Jacoby, chairman, president and chief executive of Ted Bates & Company, has chosen Robert A. Bruns, 45-year-old worldwide supervisor of the Colgate-Palmolive account, to be president of Ted Bates/New York.

title: 3 in Family Killed, 5 Hurt In Southern Lebanon Action
description: A Lebanese man and woman and three of their children were injured and a daughter and two sons were killed today when their house in the village of Al Tiri in southern Lebanon was blown up by Israeli-backed Christian militiamen.

title: BARBECUE RECIPE
description: Short of digging a pit and buying a whole hog, it's impossible to prepare authentic pork barbecue in one's kitchen. But you can come close: South Carolina Chopped Barbecue 3 to 4 pounds pork shoulder, with bone 4 cloves garlic, peeled but left whole 1 cup apple cider vinegar 12 peppercorns The sauce: 2 cups apple cider vinegar 1 teaspoon cayenne pepper 1/2 teaspoon salt.

title: Babson College President
description: William R. Dill, a former dean of New York University's School of Business Administration, has been appointed president of Babson College in Wellesley, Mass., one of the country's oldest businessoriented colleges. On June 1, he will succeed Ralph Sorenson, who will become president and chief executive officer of the Barry Wright Corporation.

title: HOUSE PANEL, 8-7, VOTES $5 MILLION IN EXTRA MILITARY AID TO EL SALVADOR
description: A House appropriations subcommittee voted 8 to 7 today to approve the Reagan Administration's request for $5 million in military aid to El Salvador.

title: CONCEPT OF LOWER MINIMUM WAGE FOR TEEN-AGERS BACKED BY REAGAN
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it supported the concept of a lower minimum wage for young workers to help reduce teen-age unemployment but that it would not back any specific legislation at this time.

title: 23 RANDY NEWMAN SONGS
description: ''MAYBE I'M DOING IT Wrong,'' a cabaret revue of 23 Randy Newman songs directed by Joan Micklin Silver for the Production Company, 249 West 18th Street, is a noble idea that could have worked. Mr. Newman, a Los Angeles composer-performer best known for his hit ''Short People,'' is generally acknowledged as one of the two or three finest songwriters of his generation. Musically, he bridges pop, rock and Hollywood film scores, with a grasp of Americana that embraces Stephen Foster, Aaron Copland and Little Richard with equal affection. Most of his best songs are humorous dramatic monologues delivered by ordinary people with grotesque stories to tell. Together they comprise a tragicomic portrait gallery of ''typical'' Americans.

title: 4-YEAR U.S. NOTES RISE TO 13.49%
description: The Treasury sold new 13 3/8 percent, four-year notes yesterday at an average of 13.49 percent, a yield that was sharply higher than just a week ago and that shows the continued reluctance of investors to buy securities due in more than a few years.

title: British Businessman Is Shot in Dublin
description: Gunmen went to Trinity College here today and fired three shots into the legs of a British Leyland executive who was addressing local businessmen, the police said.

title: Around the World; Africans Tell Waldheim Of Concern Over U.S. Policy
description: A delegation of African diplomats met with Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today, at their request, to tell him of their concern over what they see as an apparent shift in American policy and over recent South African military raids into Angola and Mozambique.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amfac Inc. agreed to sell its airport concessions in several cities to the Marriott Corporation on undisclosed terms.

title: A.M.C. Extending 10% Price Cut, Too
description: The American Motors Corporation said it would offer 10 percent discounts on all new 1981 A.M.C., Jeep and Renault cars and some trucks, replacing a 10 percent rebate that expired March 15. The announcement followed decisions by General Motors, Chrysler and Ford Motor to renew their rebates, with some limitations.

title: by Les Daly
description: As the Administration transforms ''high-powered business executives'' into ''highly placed Government officials,'' I recall my own impression that the only similar experience must be that of an astronaut who leaves home to operate weightless in space: The view is dazzling, but new forces are at play and nothing works the way it used to.

title: The U.N. Today; March 26, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing the Nonuse of Force in International Rela- tions - 3 P.M.

title: Problems on the L. I. R. R. Delay 22,000 Riders in Morning Rush
description: About one-quarter of the Long Island Rail Road's rush-hour commuters were delayed yesterday morning by equipment problems, a railroad spokesman said.

title: PROFILE OF CARL SANDBURG: DO FACT AND FICTION MIX?
description: THE American documentary film has undergone a number of stylistic twists and turns on television in recent years. The biggest change - stemming largely from the remarkable success of ''60 Minutes'' in the form of short news documentaries presented by familiar correspondents - has resulted from the realization that news documentaries, attractively packaged, can compete in the marketplace against dramatic series, presented conventionally.

title: Index; International
description: Exceptional Shanghai restaurant demonstrates liberalized rules A3 American tells of efforts to recruit him as spy A3 Ronald Biggs's kidnappers freed A4 Around the World A5 American Embassy in San Salva- dor is attacked again A6 Soviet leaders press U.S. on talks A10 In Jidda, a million cars for a mil- lion people A14 U.S. lifts Sahara peace conditions for arms sales to Morocco A15 Government/Politics 23 oilmen contributed $270,000 to help redecorate White House A19 Desegregation issue cause confu- sion in Los Angeles schools A20 Carey and Kock testify against Reagan budget cuts B1 Jersey Republican shuns public funds in race for Governor B2 New York Assembly passes bill on joint custody in divorces B8 Feminists attack Reagan plan to curb abortion aid B13 Energy Accord reached on building refuse-fueled power plant B3 General Around the Nation A16 Police Charge three whites in the death of a black man A16 Study says crowded prisons should cut populations sharply A17 Bodies sought by Florida police in Weeki Wachee junkyard A18 Eban in New York to discuss TV series on Jews B8 Defector who dealt in false visas cites U.S. Embassy in Mexico B16 Health/Science The space shuttle Columbia has its fuel tank tested A16 University report advises genetic tests for donors of sperm A19 The Home Section Home Interior decoration among friends C1

title: Wardair of Canada Buys Airbus A310's
description: Airbus Industrie, a multinational consortium of European aerospace companies, broke into the Canadian airline market yesterday with the announcement that Wardair International Ltd., Canada's largest charter carrier, had ordered six of its A310 wide-body planes. The price comes to about $425 million (Canadian), including spare parts and technical support.

title: Ketchum, MacLeod Wins Judgment on Stouffer's
description: Ketchum, MacLeod & Grove, Pittsburgh, yesterday won a judgment of more than $350,000 against Stouffer's Foods, a former client, against whom it filed a breach-of-contract suit. The verdict was directed by Judge Sylvestri Silvestri of the Allegheny County Civil Court of Common Pleas and the jury set the judgment.

title: SUITORS ARE ENTICED BY NEW PROFITABILITY AT GERMAN PREUSSAG
description: When the word went out recently that the Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale might sell its 40 percent share in Preussag, the metals and energy concern, a number of prospective buyers lined up, including the German affiliate of the British Petroleum Company; Ruhrkohle, Germany's largest coal company, and Heinz Nixdorf, head of the computer company.

title: JUDGE HALTS COUNTER BID BY ST. JOE
description: Judge Milton Pollack of Federal District Court in Manhattan last night granted a temporary restraining order that prevents the St. Joe Minerals Corporation from going ahead with a series of proposals intended to block a $2 billion takeover by Joseph E. Seagram & Sons.

title: TULSA DEFEATS SYRACUSE BY 86-84 IN OVERTIME TO WIN N.I.T. FINAL
description: Tulsa, with its imported varsity, ended an improbable season last night by defeating Syracuse in overtime, 86-84, to capture the National Invitation Tournament championship.

title: SHOW HOUSE GUIDELINES ARE ISSUED BY DESIGNERS
description: IN response to reluctance on the part of owners of landmark properties to allow their use as designer show houses, the American Society of Interior Designers has issued guidelines to protect such sites.

title: BOOMING TULSA BACKS BUDGET CUTS, THOUGH EXPECTING SOME PROBLEMS
description: This is President Reagan's kind of town: robust, conservative and Republican, an upholder of Western individualism, full of stout supporters in resonant harmony with his thinking about Federal spending.

title: LAOTIAN NEEDLEWORK FROM RHODE ISLAND
description: FRANCINE VIDAL recently spent a week in New York, carrying about a large leather suitcase heavy with samples of the intricate and colorful needlework of the Hmong women of Laos.

title: JAZZ DANCE: DANNY BURACZEKSI AND COMPANY IN 4 OF HIS WORKS
description: JAZZ dance doesn't have to be all pelvic thrusts and smoking calves and forearms, as the Danny Buraczeski Dance Company proved last Friday at Playhouse 46. Mr. Buraczeski is a promising if low-key original. And his four dances looked both thought-through and enjoyed.

title: J-51 PUTTING PEOPLE INTO THE STREETS
description: To the Editor:

title: China Sets Up Control of Ads
description: China today announced the establishment of a nationwide advertising organization with ad agencies in the country's 25 largest cities.

title: American Samoa Disaster Area
description: President Reagan today declared American Samoa a major disaster area as a result of Typhoon Esau, which struck the Pacific island territory on March 2.

title: The City; Judge to Order City To Cut Inmate Total
