description: A Federal District Court judge said yesterday that he would order New York City to reduce the number of inmates in its overcrowded jails and that the order would contain a provision calling for the release of some jailed inmates if the city was unable to ease the overcrowding in a timely fashion.

title: G.O.P. PRIMARY VICTOR FAVORED FOR STOCKMAN SEAT
description: A candidate supported by Moral Majority is viewed as the heavy favorite to win a special election April 21 to fill the seat in the House of Representatives previously held by David A. Stockman, now the Federal budget director.

title: 'Premature' Judgment On Gun Law Criticized
description: The Citizens Crime Commission of New York City said that a review of city cases prosecuted under the state's new gun control law showed only that there was not yet enough evidence to judge the effectiveness of the law.

title: Proud Northern Wins; Cordero Is Suspended
description: Proud Northern, at 30-1 the longest shot in the race, won the $50,000-added Catskill Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: MORAL MAJORITY STARTS AD CAMPAIGN TO COUNTER CRITICS
description: Moral Majority Inc. has begun a campaign of full-page newspaper advertisements insisting that it is not anti-Semitic or opposed to equal rights for women and that the group's concerns are moral rather than political. The advertisements also state that the conservative group is ''not a religious organization attempting to control the Government.''

title: CARTIER'S SECRETS OF MYSTERY CLOCKS
description: By Rita Reif

title: DANCE: WORLD PREMIERE OF A CUNNINGHAM WORK
description: ''CHANNELS/INSERTS,'' which had its premiere Tuesday night at the City Center, is what Merce Cunningham might call one of his ''dramatic dances.'' One of his most attention-riveting works, it departs from the concentrated austerity of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company's appearances in recent years.

title: G.M. and Chrysler Increasing Output
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation today ordered increases in car production at three plants to replenish inventories, but the continuing slump in truck sales forced a cutback at another facility.

title: SOVIET, ACCUSING U.S. OF RECKLESS ARMS PLANS, PRESSES FOR START OF TALKS
description: The Soviet Union accused the United States today of plunging ahead with a reckless program of rearmament and intervention in disregard of Leonid I. Brezhnev's proposals for a new round of talks to limit tensions.

title: Market Place; A Low-Keyed Concessionaire
description: THOUGH Seligman & Latz operates beauty salons and fine jewelry departments in such exceptional stores as Harrods, Neiman Marcus, Saks Fifth Avenue and Lord & Talyor, the company is almost never mentioned in the press.

title: JAZZ: TENTET, 11-MAN ENSEMBLE LED BY LYNN WELSHMAN, IN DEBUT
description: A NEW jazz group called the Tentet (despite the fact that it has 11 members) led by Lynn Welshman, a pianist and arranger, is showing an unusually strong combination of imaginative arrangements, polished ensemble performance and distinctive soloists on Sunday evenings at J.P.'s, First Avenue at 76th Street.

title: The Message From the Mines
description: Some say that coal is different, that miners are rough individualists in a dangerous business who would rather strike for raises than submit to discipline and cut a quick deal. From this perspective, the good news of the week is that the union's leonine new president, Sam Church Jr., has negotiated a three-year contract in a critical energy industry. The miners will take a long weekend off, but they should endorse the new contract and return to the depths by midweek.

title: U.S. PLAN TO SELL CONRAIL MEETS OPPOSITION
description: The United States Railway Association, which administers Conrail's Federal funds, took issue today with Reagan Administration plans to sell most of the system to private railroads.

title: Mellon Gives $750,000 To Modern-Dance Troupes
description: Six modern-dance companies will receive grants totaling $750,000 from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation to develop fund-raising techniques.

title: The City; St. Bartholomew's Acts in Statue Theft
description: The three remaining bronze figures of ''The Four Generations'' were mounted on a raised platform visible from Park Avenue as a security measure following the theft over the weekend of the fourth - a 350 pound, 68-inch-high figure of a peasant girl.

title: 2 HOUSE COMMITTEES HEAR CAREY AND KOCH ON BUDGET
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Koch took their pleas against deep Federal budget cuts today to two Congressional hearings, where they were treated like the old friends that they are by some members of the House of Representratives who served with them.

title: 5-TIME U.S. OPEN CHESS WINNER
description: Dr. Edward Lasker, a five-time winner of the United States open chess championship, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95 years old.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Common Cause Urges Congress To Yield Veto Over Election Panel
description: Common Cause, a public affairs lobbying organization, recommended yesterday that Congress yield its veto power over regulations of the Federal Election Commission and give the commission powers similar to those of other independent regulatory agencies in the Government.

title: Philip Kappel, Maritime Etcher And Ex-Connecticut Arts Aide
description: Philip Kappel, etcher and former member of the Connecticut Commission on the Arts, died March 17 at New Milford (Conn.) Hospital at the age of 80.

title: Notes On People; Former Hostage to Retire After 31 Years in the Army
description: Col. Charles W. Scott, a military adviser in the Embassy in Teheran when he became a hostage in 1979, plans to retire from the Army after 31 years of service.

title: Zhirov Scores 3d Ski Triumph
description: Aleksandr Zhirov of the Soviet Union scored his third consecutive World Cup ski victory today, capturing the season's last slalom race. Steve and Phil Mahre, twin brothers from Yakima, Wash., finished second and third.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: RULING ON BUSING CAUSES CONFUSION FOR LOS ANGELES
description: It has not been a year of stability in the Los Angeles school system. Last summer, in a period of five weeks, four contradictory court decisions made it uncertain which schools thousands of pupils would attend until just a few days before classes opened.

title: SAUDI WEAPONS DEAL STARTS BONN DEBATE
description: Issues like arms exports, which some countries deal with easily and pragmatically, always turn out to be great questions of conscience in West Germany, as an editorial writer here put it yesterday. As an afterthought, he added, ''Thank God.''

title: BIFOLD DOORS CAN ADD CLOSET SPACE WITHOUT INVOLVING MAJOR CHANGES
description: UNLIKE a pair of regular bypassing sliding doors, a bifold door does not always keep one-half of an opening closed. Instead, the bifold door permits full access through the opening except for a couple of inches on each side that are taken up by the thickness of the doors when folded. In addition, while a single sliding door cannot be installed in p lace of an existing hinged door without creating a pocket inside thew all into which the door can slide, bifold doors can be installed in p lace of a hinged door for remodeling or changing the existing door j amb.

title: The Five Families
description: Only experienced Mafiologists understand the division of power and turf in the Reagan syndicate. Five families dominate the foreign policy scene:

title: SHOPPING FOR THE EXPANDABLE DINING ROOM TABLE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Melanie Fleischmann is a freelance writer who specializes in home furnishings. By MELANIE FLEISCHMANN

title: HOMOSEXUAL RIGHTS BILL REVIVED; CITY COUNCIL BACKERS PESSIMISTIC
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy and 12 City Council members announced yesterday that they were sponsoring new legislation to ban discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.

title: DOW GOES UP 19.09, NOW AT 8-YEAR HIGH
description: The Dow Jones industrial average surged 19.09 points in a stunning late rally yesterday to finish at 1,015.22, its highest level in more than eight years. The stock market's most widely followed indicator thus established a foothold well above the 1,000 level, a barrier that has often proved formidable.

title: KIRKLAND VOWS LABOR WILL OPPOSE LOWER MINIMUM WAGE FOR YOUTHS
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that he would not agree to support lowering the minimum wage for young people in exchange for an increase in the overall minimum wage, now $3.35 an hour.

title: DOREN ARDEN
description: Doren Arden, a poet and writer and a former senior editor at Penguin Books, died of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital on Sunday.

title: SHIPBUILDER BLAMES NAVY ON SUBMARINE
description: P. Takis Veliotis, general manager of the Electric Boat shipyard in Groton, Conn., contended today that Trident submarine construction had been delayed largely by defective equipment furnished by the Navy and by design changes required by the Navy.

title: The City; Billy Joel Testifies In Bogus Tapes Case
description: Billy Joel, the singing star, testified in Federal District Court in Brooklyn in the trial of the Sam Goody record-store chain and two of its executives on charges of dealing in counterfeit cassette and eight-track tapes of popular music.

title: U.S. DROPS SAHARA ISSUE IN ARMS SALES TO MOROCCO
description: The Reagan Administration, in its first policy statement on the conflict in Western Sahara, said today that it would no longer pursue the Carter Administration's efforts to link arms sales to Morocco with progress by the Moroccans to achieve a negotiated settlement of the territorial dispute.

title: Skull of Marcia Moore, Seattle Psychic, Found
description: Part of the skull of Marcia Moore, a psychic and writer who disappeared two years ago, was found in a Seattle suburb, the authorities reported yesterday.

title: Philadelphia Transit Talks Held
description: Negotiators in Philadelphia's 11-dayold transit strike returned to the bargaining table today for the longest session of talks since the walkout by bus, trolley and subway workers began. But there were no signs that the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority and the Transport Workers Union Local 234 were close to resolving their differences. The transit authority's proposal to hire part-time workers is a main issue in the dispute.

title: ASSEMBLY PASSES BILL ON JOINT CUSTODY
description: The Assembly today approved a bill to require judges to consider joint custody of children in divorce cases if one or both of the parents requests such an arrangement.

title: HOME BEAT
description: IT'S not the newest idea, but Ken Schliemann, the director of visual merchandising for home furnishings at Lord & Taylor, proved that it can be still be done with freshness and style. The department store's promotion, which opens today, is based on Charleston, S.C. The five model rooms, dedicated to famous Charleston residents, include an eclectic collection of furnishings and accessories inspired by the history of the Southern city.

title: Around the World; 5 Dead as Moslems Clash In Eastern Lebanon City
description: Five people were killed and 20 injured today in clashes at Baalbeck, a city of 150,000 about 40 miles east of here, between Moslem factions supporting the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Jonas B. Robitscher, 60, Lawyer and Psychiatrist
description: Jonas B. Robitscher, a pioneer in forensic psychiatry, died of cancer here today at his home. He was 60 years old.

title: Conoco Discovery
description: Conoco Inc. reported an oil discovery in Indonesia with a stabilized flow rate of 6,000 barrels a day. Conoco said the No. 3 Wiriagar well had encountered an oil reservoir at about 1,530 feet, but it gave no further details. A Conoco subsidiary holding a 25 percent interest in the project is the operator for a group that includes Pertamina, the Indonesian state company, with 50 percent, and two Japanese companies, which share 25 percent.

title: Notes On People; Benefit for a Hospital From Practically Unknowns
description: Jerry Lewis has the Muscular Dystrophy Association, Danny Kaye has UNICEF and Danny Thomas has St. Jude Hospital. But what about Neil Cohen, Lola Dunn, Mark Karpman and Su Makaleris? They, too, are entertainers, but they have no charities to lend their names to, and for good reason.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: MONSANTO SUIT ON HEALTH CHARGE
description: A group of former Monsanto Company employees and relatives of former employees has filed a $1.7 billion suit charging that the chemical manufacturer deliberately withheld information about job-related health problems.

title: Military Analysis
description: A methodical buildup by Iraq of artillery batteries and ammunition at forward bases and its deployment of Soviet-made tactical missiles known in the West as Frog-7's in support of the artillery point to a upsurge in the intensity of

title: MARK S. DONSKOI DEAD: TOP SOVIET FILM DIRECTOR
description: Dr. Edward Lasker, a five-time winner of the United States open chess championship, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95 years old.

title: COAL PACT IS LINKED TO U.S. EXPORT GOAL
description: At first glance, the coal industry's decision to accept a wage settlement that the United Mine Workers says amounts to a 36 percent increase over the next three years appears to make little sense in the face of depressed coal prices, substantial inventories and the shrinking proportion of the nation's coal mined by union members.

title: by Rita E. Hauser
description: It is odd to observe in these early months of a new Administration the ferocity of debate between some Carter and Reagan partisans on the subject of human rights as a component of foreign policy. The argument is centered on accusations that President Carter moralized to such an extent that his approach lacked all semblance of reality while the Reagan team, in pursuit of a tough stand toward our adversaries, will cotton up to the most repressive of regimes willing to back us with expressions of friendship and loyalty.

title: FEMINISTS ATTACK REAGAN ADMINISTRATION PLAN TO CURB AID FOR ABORTION
description: The Reagan Administration's proposals to seek new curbs on Federal spending for abortions obtained by poor women were sharply criticized by feminist groups today as ''callous'' and ''outrageous.''

title: T.V.A. May Enter The Bond Market
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority could reappear as a borrower in the bond market later this year, according to John Schmidt, Acting Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for debt management.

title: Winnebago Back To Profitability
description: Winnebago Industries, a major producer of recreational vehicles, today reported a return to profitability amid growing sales.

title: The Economy
description: The House will not approve the Reagan tax plan involving a threeyear, across-the-board cut, but Congress will adopt a more limited bill, the House's chief tax writer, Representative Daniel Rostenkowski, predicted. The new bill, he said, would cover only one year and would be weighted toward lower-income taxpayers. The Administration disputed this view and said it would continue to press for passage of the original Kemp-Roth legislation. (Page A1.)

title: Arab Investor Cites Kaiser's Expertise
description: Roger E. Tamraz, the 41-year-old Arab investor who announced earlier this week that he intended to buy 17 percent of the Kaiser Steel Company for $47.87 a share, believes that this acquisition will help the Middle East acquire valuable knowledge about steel technology. But, initially, he does not intend to buy more Kaiser stock.

title: Westinghouse Plans To Sell Cooler Unit
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to purchase the residential air-conditioning business of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 26, 1981
description: International The status of Alexander M. Haig Jr. created a stir. President Reagan reaffirmed that the Secretary of State was his ''primary adviser on foreign affairs,'' but Presidential aides said that the tension between Mr. Haig and the senior White House staff was much more severe than had been publicly acknowledged. A Presidential adviser said that Mr. Haig had threatened to resign eight or nine times before Vice President Bush won a key policy making post Tuesday. (Page A1, Column 6.) Opposition to policy in El Salvador is being expressed in hundreds of letters a week that are being received by key members of Congress. The letters oppose the Reagan Administration's decision to send military aid to the country and, according to legislators, the protests are beginning to influence Congressional opinion. (A7:1.)

title: PROMINENT ARTS FIGURES WARN CONGRESS ON CUTS
description: Representatives of the arts warned Congress today that if the Reagan Administration carried out its proposed reductions in the budget of the National Endowment for the Arts, the quality of life in the nation would decline.

title: Fire Forces Hospital Evacuation
description: A fire and explosion at Point Pleasant Hospital this afternoon forced the temporary removal of about 12 patients. The fire was quickly extinguished, and no one was injured, a hospital spokesman said. A worker heating tar for the roof of an addition to the hospital started the fire accidentally, the police said.

title: THATCHER STATEMENT IS DUE IN SPY CASE
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher will make a special statement to Parliament tomorrow about the allegation this week that a former head of British counterintelligence may have been a spy for the Soviet Union.

title: CULTURAL CENTER IN HAWAII FIGHTS I.R.S. TAX RULING
description: The Polynesian Cultural Center, a 42-acre museum and entertainment complex, is one of Hawaii's major attractions. It is also a business that it is estimated will gross the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints $23 million this year, bringing the church a possible embarrassment of riches.

title: FAMINE CONFRONTS 150 MILLION IN AFRICA
description: It is now estimated that 150 million Africans are facing food shortages. The reasons are more births, less rain, the rising cost of oil and the switch from subsistence crops to cash crops to pay for it, and, not the least, war.

title: Gretzky 1 Short Of Scoring Mark
description: Wayne Gretzky had a goal and three assists, and Glenn Anderson scored three goals as the Edmonton Oilers defeated the Hartford Whalers, 7-2, tonight.

title: Student Dies in Michigan Fire
description: A Michigan State University student was killed and 12 people were injured in a fire set by an arsonist last night at an apartment building near the campus.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Comp-U-Card of America Inc., Stamford, Conn., has elected to its board James M. Leahy, vice president and treasurer of Federated Department Stores.

title: Total Postrace Testing Sought
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board has asked the Joint Legislative Task Force on Racing for funds to conduct postrace drug tests on every thoroughbred and standardbred horse that competes in New York.

title: U.S. INDICTS 12 IN '79 LUNCH FRAUD
description: Twelve suspects were indicted yesterday on Federal charges stemming from a two-year undercover investigation of fraud in the summer lunch program in New York City.

title: DALI TRYING TO REPAIR BUSINESS AFFAIRS AND RESOLVE ART SCANDALS
description: With his business affairs in disarray, his health failing and his hands trembling so badly that he can no longer affix a reliable signature to a piece of paper, Salvador Dali is trying to put some order into the chaos that his life has become.

title: G.P.U.'s Net Falls 42%
description: General Public Utilities, owner of the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania, said today that its net income fell 42 percent in the first two months of 1981 despite a 22 percent gain in revenues. The earnings were $8.6 million, or 14 cents a share, down from $14.9 million, or 24 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose to $357.5 million from $292.1 million.

title: Man Arrested in New York Faces Questioning in Atlanta Murders
description: A man arrested Sunday in the abduction of a nine-year-old black child in Beacon, N.Y., will be questioned by Federal agents about any possible link to the case of Atlanta's slain and missing children, a spokesman for the East Fishkill Police Department said last night.

title: SAFETY IS NEGLECTED IN THE NUCLEAR BUDGET
description: To the Editor:

title: ASSAD SAYS HE'LL LET GUERRILLAS RAID ISRAEL FROM SYRIAN TERRITORY
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria said last night that he would allow Palestinian guerrillas to mount operations against Israel from Syrian territory, and challenged King Hussein of Jordan to do the same.

title: Lobbyist Asserts She Had Affairs With Several House Republicans
description: A lobbyist was quoted as saying tonight that she had affairs with several Congressmen, all of them members of the House and all Republicans.

title: Gas Line Planned
description: Tenneco Inc. announced that a four-company partnership that included its new subsidiary, the Tennessee Trans-Anadarko Gas Company, had applied for authority to construct a $700 million pipeline to carry 700 million cubic feet of natural gas a day from the Texas Panhandle to northern Louisiana. The cost and output of the 635-mile, 36-inch pipeline would be shared equally by the partnership members; besides the Tenneco unit, they are affiliates of Southern Natural Resources, United Gas Pipe Line and Texas Gas Transmission.

title: Around the Nation; Chicago Mayor Says Project Will Be a Part-Time Home
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne, praised both as a humanitarian and political genius for her decision to move into a troubled housing project, said today that Cabrini-Green would serve as her part-time residence.

title: Miss Allen Scores Upset, 7-5, 6-1
description: On court changeovers, some tennis players bury their heads in towels. Others study faces in the crowd. Leslie Allen writes notes to herself.

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: A man the police said robbed the Citibank branch at 4249 Broadway, near 181st Street, was tackled by a teller who chased him out of the bank and then was arrested by two fire marshals who had been driving past. The police said the suspect, Joseph Sprill, a 40-year-old outpatient at a New Jersey psychiatric hospital, had passed a threatening note to a teller and left the bank with $363. ... An unidentified gunman sprayed 10 bullets into a car on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. The driver, Melvin Assael, 32, was hit three times and critically wounded.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Long Island Lighting Company plans to sell about eight million shares of its common stock by a direct cash sale to underwriters. The underwriters plan to offer the shares on April 28.

title: A CANDIDATE FOR GOVERNOR SHUNS JERSEY'S FINANCING
description: The clock above the basketball backboard in the Stillman School gymnasium had ticked off 29 minutes of the ''town meeting'' when Charles Wark of Cresskill stood to pose the Question.

title: Notes On People; Undaunted Troupe Back With a New Production
description: As John Ferraro tells it, when Joseph Papp discovered the Cooper-Keaton acting group at La Mama a few years back, it all but rang down the curtain on the troupe.

title: CONGRESS MAIL HEAVY ON EL SALVADOR ISSUE
description: Key members of House and Senate foreign policy committees have been receiving hundreds of letters a week opposing the Reagan Administration's decision to send military aid to El Salvador and expressing concern that the United States might become entangled there in a Vietnam-like war.

title: BAN ON FRENCH STEEL LIFTED
description: In a political gesture to the French Government, the United States has ended the ban on the import of certain steel products from Creusot-Loire of France, Administration officials said today. The Carter Administration had imposed the ban in retaliation for the company's agreement to build a steel mill in the Soviet Union.

title: Donald Barr Chidsey, Biographer And Historian of the Revolution
description: Donald Barr Chidsey, a biographer and author of many books dealing with the American Revolution, died March 17 at Lawrence Memorial Hospital in New London, Conn. He was 78 years old and lived in Lyme, Conn.

title: IMPASSE ON FISHING REFLECTS E.E.C. SHIFT
description: At their semiannual meeting this week, the leaders of the 10 countries of the European Economic Community showed that the main thrust of Europe's postwar drive for unity was now shifting from the economic to the political sphere.

title: U.S. Shoe Profit Rises
description: The United States Shoe Corporation said today that its earnings in the 14-week fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31 rose to $22.3 million, or $3.10 a share, from $13.05 million, or $1.86 a share, in the 13-week quarter a year before.

title: PAPER TOWEL HOLDERS
description: Wire towel holder with shelf, $15, at Pottery Barn. Modric paper-towel holder. About $40 list, through designers and decorators. H.U.D.D.L.E. Toobs paper-towel holder, $27 (colors), $35 (chrome), at West Town House, 2276 Broadway.

title: Last of four articles.
description: In this port city of a million people there are at least a million cars, and one of the biggest junkyards in Saudi Arabia. It is run by the municipal government, which has found it necessary in the last two years to haul away 50,000 abandoned vehicles.

title: 8 Balking Senior Judges Are Ousted in Pakistan
description: Chief Justice Anwar ul-Haq and eight other senior judges were dismissed today when they refused to take a new oath of office giving President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq unfettered freedom to change the Constitution.

title: THREE WHITES HELD IN SLAYING OF BLACK
description: Three white men were arrested and charged by the police here today with the strangulation death last weekend of a 19-year-old black man whose body was found hanging from a tree.

title: Columbia Swimmer Overcomes Burden
description: Tony Corbisiero, a Columbia sophomore from Bayside, Queens, and the Flushing Y.M.C.A., will swim the 1,650-yard freestyle in the 58th annual National Collegiate championships, which begin tomorrow. His presence at the Texas Swim Center could be construed as something of a miracle.

title: COLUMBIA U. REPORT ADVISES GENETIC TESTS FOR DONORS OF SPERM
description: Donors of sperm used for artificial insemination should undergo genetic tests to make sure that they will not pass on inherited disorders, a Columbia University report says.

title: A SHOPPING CENTER-FUN PARK THAT FAILED
description: Old Chicago opened here in 1975 as America's first hybrid of shopping center and amusement park. Fifty million dollars, a bankruptcy and a foreclosure later, the prototype seems to argue against its own concept.

title: Advertising; Chiat/Day Success Formula
description: IF Jay Chiat, the West Coast whiz, expects to make it in the Big City, and he does, then he's going about it in just the right way. In the first place, he didn't open his Chiat/Day office in 666 Fifth Avenue without clients. The other way around. One of the reasons he opened in New York was to insure that he would be keeping two clients, Suntory, the Japanese distiller, and Fotomat Video. So he has started right off with $10 million in billings - that's his estimate.

title: BARBADIAN POLICE FREE KIDNAPPERS OF BRITAIN'S 'GREAT TRAIN ROBBER'
description: The police released the five kidnappers of Ronald Biggs today but the fugitive Briton who was abducted from Brazil was held in jail awaiting possible extradition to Britain.

title: AMERICAN TELLS OF EFFORTS TO RECRUIT HIM AS SOVIET SPY
description: Michael W. Straight, an American writer whose name has come up in the latest British espionage inquiry, said today that his early acquaintance with several British agents of the Soviet Union led to the exposure of a Communist spy ring in London 17 years ago.

title: Q. The unfinished and well-ventilated attic of my house has four inches of rock wool insulation between the rafters on top of the ceiling with no vapor barrier under it. Would it be unwise to put additional insulation on top without adding a vapor barrier? -P.R., Hamilton, N.Y.
description: A. I would not advise it. Instead, scrape the loose rock wool aside and put the new insulation down with its vapor barrier on the bottom, then replace the old rock wool by shoveling back on top of the new material.

title: Chester Higgins Jr.
description: HONORED BY N.Y.U.: Jihan el-Sadat, wife of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, receiving honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters from Jay L. Oliva, right, vice president of New York University, and Dr. Ivan L. Ben-nett Jr., school's acting president. Mrs. Sadat, in the U.S. to attend the openings of three Egyptian exhibits, was cited as a ''humanitarian, spirited crusader for women's rights and guardian of a nation's cultural heritage.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THOSE DRINKING DAYS. Myself and Other Writers. By Donald Newlove. 176 pages. Horizon. $9.95.

title: THE DANCE: SAHOMI TACHIBANA 50 YEARS OF CLASSICAL TRADITION
description: SAHOMI TACHIBANA celebrated her 50th year in Japanese classical dance last Thursday at the Open Eye by offering her audience a bouquet. Delicately performed and radiantly costumed, the dances and excerpts adapted from the traditional Kabuki theater's dance repertory made for an evening of quiet charm.

title: NL'S PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: Ray C. Adam, chairman and chief executive of NL Industries Inc., a supplier of petroleum equipment and services, chemicals and metals, said the company expected first-quarter net income to exceed last year's results by about 50 percent. In the first quarter of 1980, the company's earnings were $36.5 million, or $1.07 a share.

title: Around the World; Senate Panel Approves Canada Boundary Pact
description: The Foreign Relations Committee approved a 1979 boundary treaty with Canada today and sent it to the Senate.

title: CAR PLEDGE BY JAPANESE IS PREDICTED
description: Friction between the United States and Japan over Japanese automobiles is likely to be eased soon by voluntary export restraint by the Japanese, Mike Mansfield, United States Ambassador to Japan, said in an interview today.

title: Simon Seeking Film Rights To Book on Harris Trial
description: Norton Simon, the California businessman, art collector and philanthropist, is negotiating for the movie rights to Diana Trilling's book about Jean Harris, titled ''Love, Here Is My Heart: The Death of the Scarsdale Diet Doctor.''

title: CAREY GIVES MISS GOULETAS RING, BUT HE IS COY ABOUT INTENTIONS
description: Governor Carey gave a diamond and sapphire ''friendship ring'' tonight to Evangeline Gouletas, but he would not say whether they planned to wed.

title: Record Fur Sales
description: The American International Fur Fair, which concluded yesterday at the New York Coliseum, registered a record $60 million in orders, officials said. Kenneth Wagner, president of the Fur Fair, told newsmen that American fur exports to world markets, particularly West Germany and Japan, rose to $83 million last year and forecast that they would surpass $100 million in 1981.

title: STATE SENATE DEMOCRATIC LEADERS ASSAIL FIVE-YEAR M.T.A. PROGRAM
description: Leaders of the State Senate's Democratic minority released a staff report today assailing the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's five-year, $5.85 billion system-improvement program.

title: JAZZ: RUBY BRAFF LEADS SEXTET AT CHURCH
description: THE sextet that Ruby Braff led Sunday at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th Street at Fifth Avenue, in the last concert of this season's ''Heavenly Jazz'' series, was much more than a sextet. It was also three duos, a trio and a quartet, divisions of personnel that made for variety but, in the long run, tended to give the concert a chamber effect that diluted the potential of the six-man group.

title: Floyd Is on a Streak, But He Soft-Pedals It
description: Raymond Floyd has won two consecutive tournaments, the Doral-Eastern March 15 and the Tournament Players Championship Monday, but he doesn't consider himself on a streak. Winning $317,000 in eight days was not a streak, Floyd said, but a matter of playing well and with confidence all this season.

title: Jeep Offers Truck
description: The Jeep Corporation introduced a small, four-wheel-drive truck in a bid to meet stiffening competition from Japan. Officials of the company said the new Jeep Scrambler, priced at $7,288, would be aimed at a market now dominated by Datsuns, Toyotas and small Japanese-made trucks sold under the Ford Motor and General Motors names. The Scrambler will have a fourcylinder engine and four-speed manual transmission.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: EPHEMERA AND CLAY
description: Ephemera Fair, Rye Town Hilton, 699 Westchester Avenue, Rye, N.Y.

title: FIT PUNISHMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMONPLACE THINGS CAN BE GREAT DESIGNS
description: ONE commonly thinks of professional designers as disdaining the common object -as having the sort of perceptions that lean toward the exotic, the special, the rare and, all too often, the impractical. The simple, everyday object seems frequently not to be a part of the designer's world at all.

title: PROTEST AGAINST MORAL MAJORITY EMERGES AT A BAPTIST CONFERENCE
description: A year ago, forces supporting Moral Majority rolled out of the Sun Belt like thunder across the Texas plains, leaving a conservative imprint on election results around the country. Now, as a meeting of Southern Baptists here this week showed, a protest against that movement is emerging from evangelicals from the same region.

title: REAGAN AIDE SOUGHT FUNDS FROM OILMEN
description: A member of President Reagan's ''kitchen Cabinet'' solicited donations from executives and investors in the oil industry last month to help redecorate the White House living quarters, and 23 persons associated with the industry gave $270,000.

title: Chun Supporters Sweep Seoul Assembly Election
description: The party of President Chun Doo Hwan, as expected, won a majority in the new National Assembly, according to official election returns today.

title: SCHOOL PAPER'S ARTICLE ON DRUG DEALER SPURS BATTLE ON PRESS RIGHTS
description: An interview with a drug dealer on the front page of a high school newspaper, disclosing the sale of drugs to elementary students in Millville, N.J., has sparked a press-law controversy.

title: The Region
description: NEWARK (AP) - An off-duty patrolman was shot in the arm by a fellow officer who believed the man was robbing a downtown uniform store, the police said. Both men were in plainclothes.

title: 50 Policemen Hurt in West Berlin In Melee Over Squatters' Eviction
description: More than 50 policemen were injured in street clashes in West Berlin last night when demonstrators temporarily occupied two town halls in protest at police action against squatters.

title: HUNTER COLLEGE RESTORING CONCERT HALL
description: HUNTER COLLEGE, which discontinued its concert series in 1976 because of deteriorating facilities and lack of money, has just completed a study for the renovation of its Concert Hall with the aim of resuming the series.

title: Beanballs Trigger Fights In Pirates-Tigers Game
description: Tim Corcoran's ninth-inning home run gave the Detroit Tigers a 4-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates in a fight-marred exhibition game today.

title: Short-Term Rates Rise a Bit; But U.S. Issue Slips to 13.76%
description: Short-term interest rates, except on Treasury bills, rose slightly yesterday, partly because of a special, $6 billion Treasury issue that promised to attract institutional money that would normally have gone to other short-term instruments.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on March 17 incorrectly reported the extent of rate increases sought for buses operated by the New Jersey Transit Corporation.

title: The City; Alarm Issued for 3 In Queens Slayings
description: The police issued an alarm for three men wanted in connection with the murder Tuesday of a reputed pimp and two women in South Jamaica, Queens.

title: STATE AGREES TO PUT UP POWER PLANT IN SOUTH BRONX FUELED BY GARBAGE
description: ''Agreement in principle'' for a $132 million refuse-fueled power plant in the South Bronx was announced yesterday by New York City and the Power Authority of the State of New York. The authority would finance, build and operate the facility.

title: RICHARD M. HEXTER
description: Richard M. Hexter, president of the investment banking company of Ardshiel Associates Inc. in Manhattan, died Sunday while vacationing on Bonaire, the Netherlands Antilles.

title: Howard T. Walden 2d, Author Of Books and Articles on Fish
description: Howard T. Walden 2d, an author of short stories and of books and articles on fish and fishing, died Sunday at Hackensack (N.J.) Hospital after having had an accident while he was visiting his sister in Hackensack. He was 84 years old and lived in Nova Scotia.

title: ENGELHARD MAY SPIN OFF OPERATIONS
description: The Engelhard Minerals and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it was considering a spinoff to shareholders of ''most or all'' of its industrial operations.

title: MOVING IN, IN CHINA: A PUZZLED ISOLATION
description: Moving to Peking is a lot like moving into 1951, and a little like moving into 1851. It can be a humorous novelty that tends to wear thin with the first dust storm, or after the discovery that curling up with a shortwave radio to find out what's happening in the world is often the only nightlife in town.

title: REVUE: AL CARMINES SENDS T.S. ELIOT TO WONDERLAND
description: AL CARMINES'S latest musical romp at the Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South, is a satirical dissection of T.S. Eliot's move from disillusionment to, as Mr. Carmines says, his ''wholesale acceptance of traditional religion and faith.''

title: Phillies Trade for Matthews
description: Gary Matthews was acquired by the Philadelphia Phillies today in a trade that sent the pitcher Bob Walk to the Atlanta Braves.

title: LEARY'S 0.00 E.R.A. ELATES METS
description: When Tim Leary arrived at the Mets' spring training camp last month, he assumed that he would wind up in Tidewater pitching Triple A ball. Now, after 12 innings without allowing an earned run, Leary is permitting himself to hope for bigger things, and he is hoping he will not be disappointed.

title: Economic Analysis
description: The United States and Japan find themselves caught up in a drama of stylized euphemisms, all designed to let the Reagan Administration maintain its public image of free trade while getting the Japanese to curb their exports of automobiles to this country.

title: IN MILAN, ALLIANCE OF SIMPLE SHAPES, LUXURIOUS MATERIALS
description: Three blockbuster shows in a row this morning confirmed the significance of the Milan look on the contemporary fashion scene. Though there were medieval and Oriental interludes, the chief contribution of the Italian designers to the advance of fashion is the alliance of simple shapes and luxurious materials.

title: BOOK BY OKUN FINDS FLAW IN NEW POLICIES
description: In a posthumous book to be published tomorrow, Arthur M. Okun, a former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, wrote that economic policies such as those being pursued by the Reagan Administration would not alone succeed in reducing the inflation rate substantially.

title: STAGE: 'IRISH COFFEE,' A STEP BEYOND SIMPLE ALIENATION
description: MEIR Z. RIBALOW'S ''Irish Coffee,'' now playing at the 78th Street Theater Lab, on the West Side, is a curious, compelling, bloody but bloodless drama that quickens the pulse, although later you may not understand why it did.

title: SUIT ALLEGES JOHN SAMUELS SOLD PAINTING INCLUDED IN COLLATERAL
description: A Federal suit against John S. Samuels 3d, the industrialist who is chairman of the City Center of Music and Drama and the Lincoln Center Theater Company at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, alleges that he sold at auction a painting he had given as collateral for money owed to a Dutch concern. Mr. Samuels's lawyer, Roy M. Cohn, said yesterday, however, that his client had ''title and possession of the painting, and every right to sell it.''

title: LARGE LAND COMPANY TO PAY $14.5 MILLION TO REIMBURSE BUYERS
description: A major land sales company has agreed to establish a $14.5 million fund to recompense consumers who bought land that reportedly had no resale value, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Sports of The Times; Long Road Back Awaits Bert Yancey
description: BERT YANCEY had planned his comeback this week. He was going to see what was left of his golf skills since a manic-depressive illness forced him to stop playing nearly five years ago.

title: ANDERSON SAYS SENATE WILL PASS BUDGET LARGER THAN CAREY'S ON MONDAY
description: The majority leader of the State Senate said today that the Republican-controlled house would pass a budget on Monday that was $450 million more than Governor Carey's $16.2 billion proposal. The Senate budget would increase local revenue sharing and add $190 million to the Governor's school-aid package.

title: RINK PLAN RENEWS OLD DEBATE
description: 162d SUB RINK By DAVID BIRD

title: SSS/Obit Page; Dr. Theodore Rosenthal, Former City Health Aide
description: Dr. Theodore Rosenthal, a dermatologist who had served as assistant commissioner of the New York City Department of Health, died Monday at his Manhattan residence.

title: IRAQI DEFECTOR WHO DEALT IN VISAS CITES U.S. EMBASSY IN MEXICO
description: On a hot July day in 1968, George Tagerian Korkorartin, a world-class cyclist who was one of three members of the Iraqi Olympic team, stepped into the newly finished Olympic stadium in Mexico City carrying his nation's flag. But before the Summer Olympic Games were over Mr. Tagerian, as he likes to be known, decided to defect, in hopes that as an Armenian Christian he would have a chance of a better life in Mexico than in Moslem Iraq.

title: News Analysis
description: The exposure of a foreign policy struggle that has dogged the Reagan Administration since Inauguration Day has dealt a costly blow to the prestige of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., and has even damaged the standing of President Reagan.

title: Surgery Set for Plunkett
description: Jim Plunkett, the Oakland Raider quarterback, was to enter the Stanford Medical Center today for surgery to repair muscle damage in his left shoulder. Plunkett, most valuable player in Super Bowl XV, said the injury, to his nonthrowing arm, occurred during a game with the Philadelphia Eagles in November.

title: Around the Nation; New Grand Jury Convenes In Slaying of U.S. Judge
description: A new special grand jury convened today amid published reports that Federal agents were close to solving the assassination of Federal District Judge John Wood Jr.

title: 3 CITY PHYSICIANS EXPLAIN THE STRIKE
description: ? By DUDLEY CLENDINEN

title: Guidry and Yankees To Meet on Contract
description: This was the start of a busy, and possibly rewarding, five-day period for Ron Guidry, the nearly invisible man of the Yankees' spring camp.

title: IN SHANGHAI, A TASTE OF THE WEST IN FOOD AND PROFITS
description: When the 31 owners of the Kaile Zhongxicaiguan put up their shop sign on bustling Yu Yuan Road nine months ago they were doing the Chinese equivalent of keeping their fingers crossed. Now customers crowd the entrance and the owners are thriving.

title: by Richard Shepard
description: BORDER SHOWCASE

title: DECORATING AMONG GOOD FRIENDS
description: HARRIETTE LEVINE'S hairdresser asked her if she had left the city. ''I used to get my hair done religiously twice a week,'' Mrs. Levine explained. ''I was embarrassed to tell him I was still in town.''

title: Technology; The Portable Computer
description: NO sooner has the world been treated to the personal desktop computer than along comes the portable computer. Now everyone can have a computer - not only in the home or office but also in the briefcase or pocket.

title: Conoco Reduces Gasoline Prices
description: Conoco Inc., the nation's 13th-largest gasoline marketer, cut its wholesale gasoline prices yesterday by between a half a penny and 1.5 cents a gallon in several United States markets.

title: Around the World; Uganda Gunmen Kill Three In Attack on Party Offices
description: Gunmen killed three soldiers today in an attack on the headquarters of President Milton Obote's ruling party a few hours after explosions cut off electricity to much of Uganda and put the official radio off the air.

title: FLORIDA POLICE SEEK MORE BODIES IN 5-ACRE JUNKYARD
description: The police searched for more bodies today at a five-acre junkyard owned by a convicted sex offender where the authorities say partial remains of two young people have already been unearthed.

title: It's Pruning Time For Rhododendrons
description: RHODODENDRONS grow rapidly, and the longer they grow without discipline, the larger they get. Sometimes these evergreen shrubs become elephantine and block light from the front windows of a house or dwarf everything else in the garden.

title: ADMINISTRATION TO KILL OR PUT OFF 36 CARTER 'MIDNIGHT REGULATIONS'
description: Vice President Bush announced today that the Government was killing or indefinitely postponing 36 of the 172 socalled ''midnight regulations'' of the Carter Administration.

title: EBAN DISCUSSING TV SERIES IN A VISIT HERE
description: Abba Eban settled himself on a couch in a quiet corner and said that being in the United Nations once again evoked ''a remembrance of things past, a Proustian melancholy.''

title: O.P.M. BANKRUPTCY: QUESTIONS ABOUND
description: As recently as a year ago, O.P.M. Leasing Services seemed to have the winning formula. Offering deals its competitors could not match - and its customers apparently could not resist - the small, Manhattan-based company had risen from obscurity to become one of the nation's three or four largest computer leasing companies.

title: CHAMBER: MA, BUSWELL AND GOODE
description: MONDAY evening's Chamber Music Society concert at Alice Tully Hall was an intimate affair - duo sonatas by Frank Bridge and Maurice Ravel and the second of Schubert's trios, the one in E flat. Yo-Yo Ma and Richard Goode played Bridge's Cello and Piano Sonata in D minor. Mr. Ma joined James Buswell in the Ravel Sonata for Violin and Cello.

title: Ex-California Justice Is Sworn In To No. 2 State Department Post
description: William Clark was sworn in today as Deputy Secretary of State.

title: Around the Nation; Two Die Because of Fumes From Train Derailment
description: A train derailment today released ammonia fumes that killed a conductor and triggered a five-vehicle crash that left another man dead and his wife critically injured.

title: Patents Post Nominee No Stranger to Agency
description: Gerald J. Mossinghoff, the 45-year-old deputy general counsel of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration who has been nominated by President Reagan as Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, is no stranger to the problems of the agency. For Mr. Mossinghoff had two previous tours of duty at the Patent and Trademark Office.

title: REAGAN REAFFIRMS HAIG AS TOP ADVISOR ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: President Reagan reaffirmed today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. is his ''primary adviser on foreign affairs,'' but White House advisers said that the strain between Mr. Haig and Mr. Reagan's senior staff was much more severe than had been publicly acknowledged.

title: Carter and Top Democrat Confer
description: Charles Manatt, the Democratic national chairman, met with former President Jimmy Carter today and predicted that the Republican tide would soon begin to recede. Mr. Manatt also said that the former President and Gov. George Busbee of Georgia, a Democrat, were receptive to his plan for filling 10 to 15 percent of the delegate seats at the 1984 Democratic convention with elected officials.

title: Carey Vetoes Curb On Buying Steel
description: Governor Carey announced his veto today of a bill that would have required New York to give preference to domestic steel producers in buying steel under state building contracts.

title: Dow Gets License
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said it had licensed the Dow Chemical Company to manufacture and sell polyethylene resins under a Du Pont patent.

title: U.S. EMBASSY HEAVILY DAMAGED IN ARMED ATTACK IN SAN SALVADOR
description: Gunmen attacked the United States Embassy today with rocket-propelled grenades and submachine guns, extensively damaging the building, an embassy spokesman said. Leftists claimed responsibility for the attack, the fourth this month.

title: CONCERT: CADENZA BY MENDELSSOHN AT COSMOPOLITAN
description: THE cadenza of Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto must be one of the staler pieces of music around. But last Saturday afternoon in Town Hall, with the Cosmopolitan Orchestra, Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg, a 20-year-old violinist studying at the Juilliard School, gave it a fresh breath of life.

title: Notes On People; Singing 'Ghost' Starts Out on Her Own
description: That wasn't really Audrey Hepburn singing all those Lerner and Loewe songs in the movie version of ''My Fair Lady.'' Nor did Natalie Wood do her own singing in the movie ''West Side Story.''

title: by Mary Kay Blakely
description: THE young boy thrives in the limelight of family attention and affection. Three of his most steadfast cheerleaders - three familial fans -are gathered around the kitchen table for a supper celebration.

title: The Washington Star
description: America's crowded prisons should begin to reduce their populations sharply rather than build new facilities, a federally financed study has concluded.

title: Bridge: Top-Rated Team Sidelined In Vanderbilt Competition
description: Quarterfinal play in the Vanderbilt knockout teams championship began here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals with the top-ranked team on the sidelines and the second-ranked team breathing hard after a close match last night.

title: The Region; Williams Loses Bid To Delay Trial
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey lost a round in a battle to delay his trial on charges stemming from the Government's Abscam inquiry, which is scheduled to begin on Monday.

title: DAILY LETTERS PAGE SUB HAMERMESH LETTER
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITICAL TEST OF SHUTTLE FUEL TANK APPARENTLY SUCCEEDS
description: The 154-foot-tall space shuttle tank, shaped like a farm silo, was pumped full of supercold propellants yesterday in an apparently successful test at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida that could determine whether the shuttle can be cleared for flight early next month.

title: Notes On People; A Job at Disney Studios Has Some Inimitable Touches
description: There are some decided differences between working for Walt Disney Studios and some of the others, Marvin Hamlisch, the Academy Awardwinning composer, was saying the other day.

title: UNDER STRIKE THREAT, LABOR TALKS BEGIN IN WARSAW
description: Meeting under the threat of strikes to begin Friday, the Government and the independent trade union organization held unproductive talks for 80 minutes today before adjourning until tomorrow.

title: HOUSE TAX CHIEF FORECASTS DEFEAT FOR REAGAN CUTS
description: The chief tax writer in the House of Representatives said today that President Reagan's plan for a threeyear, across-the-board tax cut would never pass the House. He predicted that Congress would adopt a more limited ''consensus'' bill.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 17.00-17.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Bomb Damages Corsican Studio
description: A bomb explosion seriously damaged the local studio of the Government-run France-3 television network yesterday, the police said today. There were no injuries. No one claimed responsibility, but the police said the explosion appeared to be the work of a Corsican nationalist group.

title: THIS IS NO TIME TO SEND PUBLIC TV DOWN THE TUBE
description: To the Editor:

title: A Good Oil Crisis Weapon: Mirrors
description: The scheme is a budget-cutter's dream: a way to save $3 billion next year without losing a cent. The trouble is, it may not work. And in the process of finding out, the nation risks serious delay in building the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

title: EUROPEAN SINGERS LOSING LONGSTANDING PREDOMINANCE IN OPERA
description: IT is an ironic fact of the operatic scene that fewer and fewer major singers are coming out of Italy, France or Germany - ironic because these are the three countries that produced both the basic 19th-century repertory and, not so long ago, the singers trained to meet its vocal and stylistic requirements. Today the majority of leading artists on the international opera circuit are from the United States, Britain and Spain, with another sizable group from the Scandinavian and Eastern European countries.

title: G.& W. Raises Stake
description: Gulf and Western Industries said it had increased its stake in the General Tire and Rubber Company to 12.78 percent, or about 3.1 million shares. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Gulf and Western said it had recently purchased 329,800 shares for $7.8 million, for investment purposes only. G.& W. had stated previously that it intended to acquire additional shares of General Tire to increase its holdings to more than 15 percent of the outstanding common stock.

title: The Region; Jersey Utility Seeks More Natural Gas
description: WASHINGTON (States News Service) - The Public Service Electric and Gas Company has asked the Federal Government for permission to use more natural gas at eight of its 11 New Jersey plants.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have to take care that nobody leads us into provocation, that we are not carried away by emotions.

title: EMMITT DOUGLAS
description: Emmitt Douglas, president of the Louisiana chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died of a heart attack early today at the Pointe Coupee General Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: Rocky Mountain Elects
description: Bruce M. McIntyre, 53, has been elected president of the Rocky Mountain Exploration Company, a Houston-based corporation that invests in oil and gas leases, effective April 1. He will succeed Brad Poynter, 31, who continues as vice president of the American Exploration Company.

title: News Analysis
description: ''I am a pragmatist,'' Mayor Koch is fond of saying, and he has gone about @underscoring that point in a variety of ways lately. On several basic issues affecting New York City - the transit fare, the Westway, new construction at Tudor City, use of the Rikers Island prisons - the Mayor has altered his position, sometimes more than once. In some instances, his point of view has swung 180 degrees; in others, the shifts have been more measured.

title: SABRES SET BACK RANGERS
description: The New York Rangers, after playing the Buffalo Sabres even for 59 minutes 19 seconds, lost tonight on a shot that got into the Ranger net without any of the players seeing the puck cross the goal line.

title: CANADA CONCERN'S ENERGY PUSH
description: For 24 years, the Westcoast Transmission Company has been a sleepy, little-known pipeline concern that moved British Columbia's natural gas within this western Canadian province and delivered much of it to the United States border for export.

title: Researchers Find Snuff Dipping Increases the Risk of Oral Cancer
description: The growing habit of dipping snuff, favored by some people as an alternative to smoking cigarettes, significantly increases the risk of mouth cancer, according to a Government study.

title: LOVE-HATE RELATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Carol Burnett and Enquirer Wait Third Day for Verdict in Libel Suit
description: ''It's like waiting to have my children,'' Carol Burnett said today as she waited a third day for a jury to complete deliberations in her libel suit against The National Enquirer.

title: JOSEPH HINSEY, NOTED TEACHER OF PHYSICIANS
description: 26 By DOROTHY J. GAITER

title: War Is Peace
description: The Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights thinks we should say nothing when Argentine Jews are tortured by officers wearing Nazi emblems. The official in charge of the national forests wants to cut them down.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: DRY MARCH IS A NEW THREAT TO DELAWARE BASIN'S WATER
description: The Delaware River Basin Commission reported today that because this March was the driest on record in the four-state basin, ''the region's drought emergency may be far from over,'' despite heavy rainfall in February.

title: At the Edge of Abortion Law
description: An unwanted pregnancy forces a woman to an agonizing choice between childbirth and abortion. The Supreme Court has made clear that this terrible decision is for the woman and her doctor, free from governmental or even, in the case of teen-agers, parental interference. But now the high court says that states may require the doctor to notify parents before performing an abortion for a teenager who lives at home and depends on parental support.

title: SENATE VOTE GIVES REAGAN KEY VICTORY ON DIARY SUPPORTS
description: After nearly two weeks of dispute, the Senate today gave President Reagan his first budget victory by approving his plan to skip the April 1 increase in milk price supports.

title: The City; 6 Newspaper Unions Set Strike Deadline
description: The bargaining coalition of six newspaper unions announced an April 21 deadline for a strike against The Daily News, The New York Times and The New York Post if an economic settlement has not been reached by that date.

title: REAGAN REAPPOINTS FIVE TO BE INSPECTORS GENERAL
description: Five of the 16 Federal inspectors general dramatically dismissed by President Reagan on his first day in office were reappointed to similar positions today as Mr. Reagan signed an executive order establishing a President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency.

title: Company News; 'SAUDI-IZED' CITIBANK RETAINS STRENGTH
description: When Citibank sold a majority stake in its bank here to Saudi nationals last July, the new organization found itself without the imprimatur and vast resources of a leading international bank.

title: Three Injured in Honduras As Assembly Is Bombed
description: A powerful bomb exploded in the legislative building today as the 71 members of the constituent assembly opened a session.

title: REGULATORS REBUFF BANKS ON INTEREST-RATE REQUEST
description: The banking industry appealed today to Federal financial regulators for authority to pay interest rates that are competitive with the rapidly growing money market mutual funds, but it was rebuffed by the Federal authorities.

title: FRENCH DO 'BARNUM' IN ROUND, AT CIRQUE
description: Where better to present a show about a circus entrepreneur than at a circus? That's not to easy to do in the United States, where circuses tend to be done in tents or in vast auditoriums such as Madison Square Garden. In New York the hit musical ''Barnum'' is offered in a conventional theater, the St. James.

title: APPEALS COURT LETS JUDGES REDUCE PLEA-BARGAIN TERMS
description: New York State's highest court ruled today that a judge could change his mind and grant a sentence lighter than the one agreed to in a plea bargain, but not before getting the consent of the prosecution.

title: OIL-SAVING PLANS FACE U.S. ATTACK
description: The Department of Energy has drafted legislation to eliminate or cut back severely nearly all its programs to encourage energy conservation and to develop renewable fuel sources and other alternatives to oil.

title: A KILLER STALKS IN 'EYES OF A STRANGER'
description: In a cheap, sleazy horror movie like ''Eyes of a Stranger,'' a character like Jane (Lauren Tewes) automatically has several strikes against her. She's a woman - even worse, she's a woman with a job. And she doesn't want to live with her boyfriend, preferring to devote herself to a pretty adolescent sister, who happens to be deaf, dumb and blind. All of this would seem to make Jane irresistible creep-bait for the killer who stalks through the movie, murdering and raping young women and occasionally hacking up their male companions.

title: DANCE: JACK WALSH AND 6 CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: Dancers and choreographers who present solo programs must be unusually talented, brave or foolish. The solo performer must have exceptional presence and an experienced eye for the choreographer that shows him at his strongest. Jack Walsh, a dancer who has performed in Europe and with a number of New York fringe companies, has a gangling, well-muscled body and a boyish face that slightly resembles the Fonz's. Both attributes were well displayed in ''Jack Walsh in Concert,'' a program of solo dances by six choreographers at the Symphony Space on Tuesday. On the strength of that program, however, it seems that Mr. Walsh also has an unerring eye for mediocre choreography, to which he applies a somewhat flaccid jazzdance technique.

title: QUEENS MAN DISCOUNTED AS SUSPECT IN ATLANTA DEATHS
description: The arrest of a Queens man on charges of abducting a boy in Beacon, N.Y., generated a flurry of interest yesterday from authorities investigating the murders of 20 children in Atlanta, but the man was all but discounted last night as a suspect in the Atlanta case.

title: PAPER'S ADVISER FACES ORDER ON DRUG ARTICLE
description: A Superior Court judge ruled today that the faculty adviser of a high school newspaper must reveal the name of a student who interviewed a drug dealer if the local prosecutor could not obtain the dealer's name in a ''less intrusive'' way.

title: LUXURY FURS, CASUALLY WORN
description: The combination of Fendi technology and Karl Lagerfeld design has resulted in a new art form: the fur coat as fabulous as diamonds. It has the barbaric appeal of an animal skin thrown over the shoulders with the sophistication of intricate handwork of marvelous dexterity.

title: Article 057444 -- No Title
description: A rural high school and a roofing company have won a $2.3 million court award against the GAF Corporation of New York City, the nation's largest asphalt roofing manufacturer.

title: Joint Satellite Venture
description: France's privately owned Matra electronic and missile group and Britain's state-controlled British Aerospace group said today that they would set up a joint subsidiary called Satcom International to market telecommunications satellites. Terms of the venture were not disclosed.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Reported In New Clashes With Army
description: The army today reported new fighting with leftist Salvadoran guerrillas in the northern county of Morazan and in Guazapa, 15 miles north of here.

title: Advertising; Drackett's Shifts Accounts At Grey, but Why?
description: What is going on at Grey Advertising? The agency has resigned Drackett's Vanish Bowl Cleaners because of a conflict.

title: Puppets at Jewish Museum
description: An exhibition of 35 papier-mache puppets from the Jewish Puppet Theater of Paris, including nine designed by Marc Chagall, are on view through May 10 at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street.

title: Weekender Guide
description: A conference exploring the contributions of women in music since medieval times is taking place through Sunday at New York University, 35 West Fourth Street. Scheduled during the National Congress on Women in Music are a dozen concerts, panel discussions, workshops and the presentation of more than 80 papers on a vast array of topics. Medieval chants by women, songs of women troubadours, the works of Clara Schumann, jazz, gospel, ragtime and music by American Indian women and living women composers are among the concerns of the congress. Scholars, performers, composers and educators of both sexes, from the United States, Canada and abroad, are taking part. Some performances are at the Washington Square Methodist Church and the Park Avenue Synagogue. Admission is $15 for a day's events. For a concert only, the charge is $5 ($2.50 for the elderly); $2.50 for each nonconcert event. Information: 598-3492 or 598-3493.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Advest Group Inc. said it intended to aquire Salkin, Welsh, & Company Inc. in a one-for-nine exchange of stock.

title: Notes On People; Is It Living at the Office or Working at Home?
description: From now on, Representative James Jeffords, a Republican from Vermont, won't have to take his work home with him. He's moving into his office because, he said yesterday, he can't afford the increased rent on his Washington apartment.

title: AMNESIA VICTIM REUNITED WITH FAMILY
description: After an exhausting nationwide search, an amnesia victim known as ''Jane Doe'' found her identity today and was reunited with the family she had not seen in years.

title: LEADER IN RECORD SPENDING CUT
description: Senator Pete V. Domenici returned home early one evening to find some of his eight children watching television. He vainly sought to engage them in conversation and, in a final effort to distract them, asked for a series of snacks. His daughter Helen, then 6 years old, tired of the errands. ''Daddy,'' she said, ''you are just a Senator, you are not a king.''

title: REP. FLORIO BECOMES 20TH ENTRY IN CONTEST FOR GOVERNOR OF JERSEY
description: Representative James J. Florio formally declared his candidacy for Governor of New Jersey today, joining 11 other Democrats and eight Republicans.

title: ALBANY CASINOS STUDY FINDS MODEST BENEFITS FOR ECONOMY OF STATE
description: The net effect of legalizing casino gambling in New York may be far more modest than its proponents contend, according to a study released today by the State Department of Commerce.

title: Money Funds Swell by $3.9 Billion
description: The nation's money market funds grew by a record $3.9 billion in the most recent week, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Left-Wing Writer Flees Bogota for Mexico City
description: The Colombian author Gabriel Garcia Marquez, best known for his novel ''One Hundred Years of Solitude,'' today fled his homeland, where he feared arrest by the military authorities, and arrived in Mexico City.

title: BELLA DAVIDOVICH GIVING PIANO RECITAL AT CARNEGIE
description: Knocking on wood and spitting to the side - half-kiddingly, halfseriously -the pianist Bella Davidovich said everything is going well for her here in the United States, two and a half years after emigrating from the Soviet Union, a year and a half after her soldout debut in Carnegie Hall, and a few days before her first return to Carnegie for a recital on Sunday afternoon.

title: GEORGE LEWIS WARREN, 90, IS DEAD: U.S. COUNSELOR ON REFUGEE AFFAIRS
description: George Lewis Warren, a State Department counselor on refugee affairs for more than 25 years, died of a heart ailment here yesterday. He would have been 91 years old on Monday.

title: Amtrak Plans 9% Fare Increase On Passenger Trains Next Month
description: Amtrak, citing rising fuel prices, has announced that a 9 percent general fare increase on a passenger trains will go into effect April 26.

title: Advertising; Account
description: * Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, a division of Johnson & Johnson, to Kallir, Philips, Ross Inc. for a new product.

title: Pop Jazz; A MATCHED PAIR, BUT INDIVIDUALS
description: Gregg Burge and Hinton Battle are stopping the show in ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' beginning with the mad tap dance antics of ''I Want to Be a Rug Cutter'' on through the extravagant reprise of ''It Don't Mean a Thing'' that closes the musical at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater. They're part of the new young breed of highly skilled Broadway musical dancers, dancers so good that choreographers can allow the kind of improvisation the two do nightly in the new Duke Ellington revue.

title: 3 Airlines Cut Some Fares
description: Three major airlines - Eastern, United and Trans World - yesterday announced some sharp fare reductions between major cities to stimulate lagging passenger revenues.

title: BLACK LEGISLATORS URGE DISMISSAL OF MRS. KIRKPATRICK
description: The Congressional Black Caucus called today for the dismissal of Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, because of her recent meeting with South African military officers.

title: Soviet Wrestlers Win
description: The Soviet Union's wrestling team, including five 1980 Olympic gold medalists, defeated the United States, 7-2, last night in a dual meet. The only American winners were Rick Dellagatta of the University of Kentucky and Bruce Baumgartner of Indiana State.

title: DR. LESLIE FARBER, 68, LEADING THEORETICIAN OF PSYCHIATRIC SCHOOL
description: Dr. Leslie H. Farber, a leading theoretician of the existential movement in psychiatry, died Tuesday of a heart attack at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 68 years old.

title: Recital by Miss Jochum
description: A recital of piano music will be played by Veronica Jochum in the New York Times building auditorium tomorrow night at 8.

title: Court in Barbados Puts Off Decision on Biggs for a Day
description: Lawyers for Ronald Biggs, the fugitive British train robber who was abducted from Brazil, argued today that Barbados has no grounds to hold him while Britain seeks to extradite him.

title: BOSTON, FACING FISCAL CRISIS, MAY FORCE SCHOOLS TO CLOSE
description: A political impasse over how to resolve an impending financial crisis and over who will be forced to bear the onus of painful changes in the city government's free-spending ways has brought Boston to the brink of bankruptcy.

title: SUBWAYS ABROAD: BARGAINS ARE RARE
description: If it's a cheap subway ride you seek, head for Moscow, where it costs 7 cents. Rome is inexpensive, Paris is reasonable and so is Frankfurt. New York is steep, Tokyo is climbing and London is the worst.

title: RICHARDSON, IN HIS FIRST SEASON AT TULSA, WINS N.I.T.
description: When Nolan Richardson was proposed as Tulsa basketball coach a year ago, the alumni objected, according to Emery C. Turner, the school's athletic director. Who was Richardson, anyway, but a junior college coach - and from Texas, of all places?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Britain needs a reformed and liberated political system without the pointless conflict, the dogma, the violent lurches of policy and the class antagonisms that the two old parties have fostered.'' - statement issued yesterday by the newly founded Social Democratic Party in Britain. (A1:3.)

title: Albert C. Baugh Is Dead; Noted Medieval Scholar
description: Albert C. Baugh, who taught English at the University of Pennsylvania for almost half a century and was a distinguished medieval scholar, died Saturday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 90 years old and a resident of Philadelphia.

title: Company News; Division for Sale
description: David I.J. Wang, vice president and group executive of the International Paper Company's wood products businesses, said the company was actively seeking to sell its cabinet division. He said if the company did not sell the division within a reasonable length of time it planned ''a phase-out of cabinet operations consistent with customer requirements.'' Mr. Wang noted that the division ''is not central to our company's strategy,'' which is concentrated on basic forest products businesses. The division, which has 425 employees at its two plants, had sales of about $17 million last year.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''Don't give an inch!'' Seaver Leslie said ardently to the guests guests assembled in The Dakota apartment of John and Diane Hersey the other evening.

title: At the Movies; by Chris Chase; Lights, camera in Hollywood on the Hudson.
description: IT'S getting so you can't walk out your front door in New York without tripping over a cable owned or rented by some movie company. And the streets are full of parked trailers sheltering movie stars who are hiding or dressing or having their faces made up. Why is New York luring so many movie makers? Well, why not? We've got seasons. And as Norma Desmond, or Gloria Swanson or one of those old girls put it, we've got faces. Every second one you see isn't sun-tanned and perfect.

title: WILSON EARNS A JOB IN LEFT FIELD FOR METS
description: These days, everyone wants to know how William Hayward Wilson acquired the nickname Mookie. Wilson, the Mets' rookie outfielder, is apologetic when he says he doesn't know. But the repeated question indicates something about his status as a major leaguer.

title: 4 ELECTION STUDIES FOCUS ON PRESIDENCY
description: With 43 months to go until Election Day and no candidates yet in the field, the Presidential election system is facing academic rather than political scrutiny. Four major studies of the way it works, and how it could work better, are being undertaken by universities and foundations.

title: ART: 13 SHOW AT A GALLERY THAT IS ALSO AN IDEA
description: The gallery called Artists Space, which stands at 105 Hudson Street, was conceived in 1973 by Trudi Grace and Irving Sandler. It was to be wide open to artists who ought to be seen, but had no commercial affiliations. Artists who could be so described would be on file, and it was fundamental to the plan that, wherever possible, the choice of coming shows was to be made by artists, not by dealers, curators or critics. The gallery would function therefore as a selfgoverning artists' free city, partly funded by the State Council on the Arts and administered by someone with the energy, the knowledge and the good will to keep it steady.

title: KOCH SEEKS LAW FOR ROUNDUPS TO AID THE HOMELESS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was seeking state legislation to enable the city to collect homeless people, without their consent, and hold them for 72 hours in order to give them food, a bath and medical attention.

title: YOUNG READERS: A GOOD MARKET
description: Soon after giving birth to her latest offspring, Mrs. Long Ears scuttles off with a muskrat, leaving poor Daddy Long Ears to care for 31 bunnies. Elsewhere, Frannie is so painfully shy that she's worried she'll go through high school without being kissed. Then her girlfriends cook up The Popularity Plan, and she practically has to fight off the boys - except, alas, for Ronnie.

title: ANALYSTS SEE A SHIFT AT CAESARS
description: William H. McElnea Jr., president of Caesars World Inc., resigned yesterday, and analysts are interpreting his departure as portending a dramatic shift of strategy for the resort and gaming company.

title: APPRECIATING THE 10-5-3 DEPRECIATION PLAN
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALIAN ACCENT AT SOUTHERN PARTY
description: Naturally there was some curiosity Wednesday night as the red carpet was spotted on Fifth Avenue, leading from the main entrance of Lord & Taylor to the curb. Then the limousines and taxis began pulling up, and the strollers stopped to peer at the men and women emerging from them and into the store, where azalea trees framed charming young things in crinolines who were holding baskets of daisies and passing out fresh flowers.

title: MUDDY WATERS SINGING THE BLUES
description: In 1943, when Muddy Waters was 28 years old, he was working on a cotton plantation near Clarksdale, Miss., for 22 1/2 cents an hour. He felt he was being underpaid, but when he asked for a raise to 25 cents an hour the plantation overseer shouted and fumed. Mr. Waters worked one more week to save up a few dollars, and then he left Mississippi on a Chicago-bound passenger train. He never looked back. Within a few years he had established himself as the most popular of Chicago's many blues singers, and today, at 65, he enjoys a worldwide following. From New York to London to Tokyo, Muddy Waters is the blues.

title: OPERA: 'CESARE'S' NEW CLEOPATRA
description: THE New York City Opera has found in June Anderson an excellent new Cleopatra for its ever-stylish production of Handel's ''Giulio Cesare.'' This opera, given its third performance of the season on Wednesday night, is the one that, years ago, headed Beverly Sills in the direction of superstardom, and her role, of course, was that of Cleopatra.

title: by Andy Messing Jr.
description: In spite of apocalyptic warnings, the decade ahead will not bring a global nuclear or major conventional war between the superpowers. However, there will be conflicts on a lower level of intensity: unconventional wars, limited conventional actions and reactions, and terrorism. They will be started for a variety of social, economic, and political reasons. No matter how they are labeled, they will amount to irregular warfare.

title: SPREAD BROKERS DRAW INTEREST
description: BARRY APPEL spends a typical working day without moving more than a few feet from his spot at the south end of the American Stock Exchange's trading floor. ''I set up my own little apple stand here,'' he says.

title: Advertising; N.W. Ayer Buys Out Barker, Its British Partner
description: For the past seven years, the country's oldest agency has been known as N.W. Ayer ABH International, a name that reflected the fact that after a century of insular existence, it had moved overseas and had created a Netherlands holding company with Charles Barker Ltd. of London. Through the joint venture, they acquired a minority position in eight agencies in nine countries in Europe, Asia and the Pacific.

title: by Daniel Yergin
description: The West's economic problems have created hard times for the English language. In the middle 1970's, the British started worrying about ''de-industrialization.'' Americans soon came up with a more positive twist: ''reindustrialization.'' Now the British have struck back with ''trans-industrialization.'' Since ''reindustrialization'' was something of a Democratic Administration word, we can expect the Reagan team to come up with its own term. Until then, perhaps the language can limp along with ''industrial policy.''

title: NEGOTIATING APARTMENT-HOUSE CONVERSION
description: A peculiar thing happened on the way to the well-publicized conversion of the apartment building known as Plaza 400, at 400 East 56th Street, to a cooperative earlier this year. There was practically no negotiation between organized tenants and the sponsor on the terms of the offering.

title: Business People; Former Swingline Head Is Gestetner Corp. Chief
description: The changing of the guard at the Gestetner Corporation, a New Yorkbased business machines manufacturer and subsidiary of Gestetner Ltd. of Britain, has taken another step forward.
