David Zealand, the 64-year-old chairman, turned the job of chief executive over to Ernest M. Raasch, 54, the company's president.

title: Carey Signs Bill to Cut Delay Before Marriage
description: If Governor Carey decides to get married, he has just made it easier for himself to do so quickly. The Governor signed into law today a bill that shortens the waiting period between a required blood test and marriage to three days.

title: Pat Bradley Posts a Par 71 To Take Shot Lead in Golf
description: Pat Bradley shot a par 71 today to take a one-stroke lead after the opening round in the $175,000 Women's Kemper open golf tournament.

title: CONCERT: GROSSMAN ORCHESTRA
description: An admirable group of musicians -most of them very young - played an equally admirable program of Elgar, Bartok, Schubert and Beethoven at Alice Tully Hall Saturday evening. They are known as the Julius Grossman Orchestra, and Mr. Grossman, their conductor, gave them wise tempos to follow and persuaded them to accent in very musical ways.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN COLOREDS ARE BREACHING THE COLOR BAR
description: A white medical student who was moving into an apartment in Hillbrow, a neighborhood here that is vaguely reminiscent of Greenwich Village, was taken aside the other day in a confidential manner by the Afrikaner woman who serves as the building's caretaker. ''I hope you don't mind, but there's an Indian family living next door,'' she said. ''They're very nice and we just keep quiet about it.''

title: Advertising; Advertising Hall of Fame Grows by 3, to 84
description: More than 600 toilers in the advertising field, many of them leaders, were at the American Advertising Federation's luncheon in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria at which Tom Dillon, retired chairman of BBDO International; Shirley Polykoff, head of her agency, and the late Roy Larsen, who was vice chairman of Time Inc., were inducted into the Hall of Fame.

title: Bridge; Bridge: Some New Yorkers Survive In the Vanderbilt Semifinals
description: New York City was represented on three of the four surviving teams as the semifinals of the Vanderbilt knockout team championship began here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League Spring Nationals.

title: News Analysis
description: Celebrities whose public behavior and domestic arrangements are frequently the subjects of articles in The National Enquirer would like to stop the paper from publishing what they say are exaggerated or fictitious articles about them.

title: by Bennett Poor
description: The tragedy of El Salvador is not as complicated as we are led to believe.

title: Restaurants; by Mimi Sheraton; New, already packed and promising.
description: ALTHOUGH the two restaurants reviewed this week are newcomers, the publicity connected with their opening activities has stirred enormous interest among restaurant buffs. The nine-week-old Marylou's in Greenwich Village, and Simon's, which opened in the Lincoln Center area about six weeks ago, are playing to packed houses almost nightly, an early flush of success that apparently has caused much confusion among kitchen and dining room staffs.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG TESTIMONY BEFORE SENATE PANEL
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s testimony before the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations. Mr. Haig was questioned by Senator Robert W. Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, the subcommittee chairman, and Senators Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, and Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania. After the hearing Mr. Haig answered questions from reporters. Haig's Testimony

title: DANCE: SARA AND JERRY PEARSON OFFER 'MARITAL ARTS' AT RIVERSIDE
description: Ordinarily, the Sara and Jerry Pearson Dance Company is a company of six. However, on Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church it consisted of only Mr. and Mrs. Pearson, who met in 1966 and were married in 1970. These biographical details are by no means irrelevant, for the Pearsons offered ''Marital Arts,'' a collaboratively choreographed two-act work about marriage.

title: Elliott Is Given Final Tributes
description: The 200 or so mourners who filled University Chapel this morning rose with a shuffle when the six pallbearers entered, carrying the coffin of James Francis Elliott. Heads turned to see the small procession pass under the choir loft. The clock on the loft read 10:19. Where Jumbo Elliott was involved, time was always noted.

title: Dr. Charles Davis, 62, Chairman Of Afro-American Studies at Yale
description: Dr. Charles T. Davis, chairman of the Afro-American studies program at Yale University, died of cancer yesterday at the Yale Health Center. He was 62 years old.

title: Company News; Mobil Plans to Close Its Buffalo Refinery
description: Citing declining petroleum demand nationwide, the Mobil Corporation said it would close its refinery in Buffalo by this fall.

title: Europe's Garbage May Be Different
description: Although burning garbage to make power is said to be commonplace in Europe, no such plant in America has yet been entirely successful. Perhaps American waste, containing a higher ratio of plastics that are barely flammable, will not produce enough heat to generate electricity consistently. Whatever the reason for America's lag, someone had better find out before starting another hopeless venture in the South Bronx.

title: ROBERT FINNEY
description: Robert Finney, former chairman of Street & Finney, a family-owned national advertising agency that merged with the D'Arcy, MacManus & Masius agency, died Friday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: HAIG SAYS FUROR OVER BUSH'S ROLE SHOULD NOW END
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., breaking a 48-hour public silence, said today that he wanted to put aside the issue of Vice President Bush's appointment to the Administration's crisis management team and ''get on with the substance and the formulation of American foreign policy.'' Appearing before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee, Mr. Haig appeared Excerpts from remarks, page A12. to be seeking to appear nonchalant about the episode that has dominated talk in Washington since Mr. Bush's appointment Tuesday and led to reports that Mr. Haig was considering resignation over the seeming affront to his standing.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Robert H. Suhr has been appointed vice president-marketing for the Paddington Corporation.

title: Broadway; McCowen returning in May with 'St. Mark's Gospel.'
description: MANY actors dread facing the New York critics. Not Alec McCowen. He can't wait. The British actor is returning to Broadway on May 13 in ''St. Mark's Gospel,'' the one-man tour-de-force that he first brought to New York in the summer of 1978. It was Mr. McCowen's misfortune then, however, to open during a newspaper strike.

title: Notes On People; Coming Attractions
description: The producer of the enormously popular ''Star Wars'' and ''The Empire Strikes Back,'' George Lucas, is apparently a man who likes to think ahead.

title: Black Woman Among 4 Named to Smith's Staff
description: Attorney General William French Smith today announcedthe appointment of four top personal aides, including two former Supreme Court clerks and a black woman.

title: 2 RUMANIAN LEADERS LOSE POSTS IN CABINET AS THE ECONOMY LAGS
description: Two top leaders lost their Government posts today in a series of personnel changes apparently aimed at solving Rumania's economic problems, which have caused some labor unrest.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alcan Aluminium, Montreal, has elected to its board John L. Nichol, president of the Springfield Investment Company of Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Boston School Chief, 53, Dies of a Heart Attack
description: Boston's acting school superintendent, Paul Kennedy, who has been fighting to avert a shutdown of the city's schools, suffered a heart attack today while driving his car and died. He was 53 years old.

title: CARTEWRITIS
description: To the Editor:

title: Inspectors to Return To Chinatown Shops
description: The Federal Labor Department announced in Washington that it would send investigators back to the garment shops of Chinatown in lower Manhattan, where two years ago widespread violations of wage and hour laws were found.

title: Two-Level Silver Contracts Opposed
description: Lee H. Berendt, president of the Commodity Exchange Inc. of New York, said today that the new double silver contract on the Chicago Board of Trade would divide the little interest left in the silver futures market.

title: IN AN ABORTION CLINIC: AMBIVALENCE, GUILT AND RELIEF
description: Some arrive in blue jeans and worn sneakers, others swathed in furs. Some leave small children in the waiting room to while away the fretful time with husbands or friends; others are children themselves. Some, apprehensive and uncertain, have never been there before; others smile and greet staff members by name.

title: BRITISH SPY CASE FIGURE ABSOLVED IN A STATEMENT BY MRS. THATCHER
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher confirmed today that a former head of British counterintelligence had once been suspected of spying for the Soviet Union.

title: DAVIS ABRUPTLY CANCELS $700 MILLION BID FOR FOX
description: Marvin Davis, the multimillionaire Denver oil executive and wildcatter, surprised West Coast motion picture executives yesterday by abruptly backing out of a $700 million deal to take over the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation.

title: Bronx Auction Sunday
description: Nostagia and antiques enthusiasts will have an opportunity to bid on rare books, old newpapers, cigarette cases, etchings, trolley tickets, jewelry and other one-of-a-kind objects at the Bronx County Historical Society's annual auction Sunday, from 1 to 5 P.M. at the Gillet Auditorium of Lehman College, Goulden Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard (enter through gate 6).

title: Credit Markets; NEW 20-YEAR BOND SETS RECORD
description: The United States Treasury sold new 13 1/8 percent 20-year bonds yesterday at an average yield of 13.21 percent, the highest ever for a new Treasury issue maturing in 10 years or more.

title: Brown Dismissed As Hawks' Coach
description: Coach Hubie Brown, who guided the Atlanta Hawks to the Central Division title a year ago but whose team did not make the playoffs this season, was dismissed today by the five-member board of directors, which is meeting here.

title: THEY ALSO SERVED WHO NOW STAND FORGOTTEN
description: Their faces are unfamiliar, their deeds perhaps uninspiring, but certain individuals are forever engraved in New York history. They appear on the city landscape as statues of civic or public leaders, men who served as symbols for their times. Yet these bronze figures evoke the question ''Who?'' as well as ''Why?'' They linger on - ''forgotten but not gone,'' as George S. Kaufman once said.

title: EX-HOSTAGES' EARNINGS BECOME SURPRISE ELECTION-AGENCY ISSUE
description: Much to its chagrin, the Federal Election Commission is faced with the choice of curtailing the chances for former American hostages to make some easy money or opening a big chance for politicians to do so.

title: Company News; Air France Concorde Fare Cut Rejected
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board said it had rejected a request from Air France to reduce the supersonic Concorde's one-way fare on its Washington-to-Paris run from $1,722, to $1,651.

title: SABLON SINGS- NOSTALGIA WITH A FRENCH ACCENT
description: Forty years ago he was the ''French Bing Crosby,'' Maurice Chevalier without the straw-hatted mischief, a Clark Gable lookalike from Pigalle who could sing too, a flagrant romantic who traveled with a wardrobe of 96 suits and a French poodle named Coco (after Chanel), a performer whose very appearance on stage became synonymous with what came to be regarded as the velvety, almost crooning, Gallic technique of romantic singing.

title: NEW YORK REGENTS VOTE A PLAN FOR ACCREDITING MEDICAL STUDY ABROAD
description: The New York State Board of Regents approved a plan today to accredit foreign medical schools. The plan seeks to upgrade the training of Americans studying medicine abroad and to control their re-entry into the state.

title: U.S. WARNS RUSSIANS AND POLES ON FORCE AGAINST THE UNIONS
description: The White House expressed ''growing concern'' today over signs that the Polish authorities might crack down on the labor movement or that the Soviet Union might ''undertake repressive action in Poland.''

title: Greyhound in Glacier Park
description: Greyhound Inc. said today that it had purchased rights to operate major hotels and concessions in Glacier National Park.

title: PLANNING DREAM OR POLICY NIGHTMARE?
description: To the Editor:

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt PALM SUNDAY. An Autobiographical Collage. By Kurt Vonnegut. 330 pages. Il- lustrated with drawings by the author. Delacorte. $13.95.

title: 1-YEAR CUT IN TAXES ASSAILED
description: David A. Stockman, the budget director, asserted today that President Reagan would veto a bill that reduced individual income tax rates for only one year rather than the three years sought by the President.

title: MUNICIPAL BOND MARKET: MEANS TO LAUNDER FUNDS
description: The municipal bond market, where the debt securities of city and state governments are bought and sold, is seen as a rarefied domain, largely the province of commercial banks, big insurance companies and wealthy individuals. But it also has a shady side, serving as a vehicle for laundering tainted funds.

title: FEDERAL APPROVAL EXPECTED FOR GRANT TO PORTMAN HOTEL
description: A grant of nearly $22 million that would pave the way for construction of the proposed Portman Hotel in the Times Square area is expected to be approved by the Federal Housing and Urban Development Department, Federal and New York City officials said yesterday.

title: POLANSKI PLANNING TO DIRECT 'AMADEUS' ON POLISH STAGE
description: Roman Polanski sat on an easy chair in his single room at the Victoria Hotel here. He was on the phone to Paris, talking in French to a friend who had just had a baby girl and who had named her Tess. He hung up, jubilantly told his visitor in English about the birth, and then picked up the phone again to speak in Polish to an actor who was waiting to join him for coffee.

title: Transfers Urged In Teacher's Death
description: Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, demanded that two students involved in a fight that might have led to the death of a teacher who intervened be placed in a special school until the police investigation was completed.

title: CAROL BURNETT GIVEN $1.6 MILLION IN SUIT AGAINST NATIONAL ENQUIRER
description: A Los Angeles jury ruled today that The National Enquirer libeled the actress Carol Burnett in a 1976 gossip column. It ordered the Florida-based publication to pay her $1.6 million in damages.

title: COAST SHOW RECALLS NISEI VALOR IN WAR
description: Memories of the meeting with the tall Texan in the shell-torn forest in France brought Chet Tanaka's voice up a notch louder and made the words tumble out faster.

title: 'THIEF,' WITH CAAN AND TUESDAY WELD
description: ''THIEF,'' which opens today at the Cinerama and other theaters, takes place mostly in Chicago though the actual setting is in the twilight land halfway between gritty gangster melodrama and that world where writers meditate self-consciously on the sorrows of life.

title: 'TRUTH IN TESTING' TO BE NATIONWIDE
description: The trustees of the College Entrance Examination Board voted yesterday to begin providing students throughout the country with copies of their Scholastic Aptitude Tests as well as with their answer sheets and a list of correct answers.

title: Hijacker Seizes Armored Truck In Montreal and Gets $2.4 Million
description: A lone hijacker drove away today with an estimated $2.4 million in cash and securities in an armored truck, the police said. The three guards tried to give chase in a taxi but could not keep up, and the truck was found empty an hour later.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Anderson Greenwood & Company is offering 600,000 shares of new common stock at $13.50 a share through an Underwood Neuhouse & Company group.

title: Joseph A. Salerno, 85, Organizer Of Clothing Union in New England
description: Joseph A. Salerno, a Sicilian immigrant who became one of the foremost labor organizers in New England, died Monday at a Florida hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: Advertising; Sudler & Hennessey Names 14 Vice Presidents
description: Sudler & Hennessey, the health-care agency that grew from $26 million, to $85 million, in billings since it became a Young & Rubicam subsidiary eight years ago, announced yesterday a long list of promotions. The announcements were made by Matthew Hennessey, the 64-year-old chief executive, and some of the people in the new jobs will be relieving him of chores.

title: BURROUGHS PLANS WIDE EXPANSION
description: The Burroughs Corporation will phase out its manufacturing operations in Detroit and expand elsewhere. Company Chairman W. Michael Blumenthal told shareholders that Flemington, N.J.; Rancho Bernardo, Calif.; Florida, and Brazil would be areas of Burroughs' expansion.

title: A BOOK FAIR FOR SMALL PRESSES OPENS IN THE 'VILLAGE'
description: If the Frankfurt Book Fair is the ''Emperor'' Concerto of book publishing, the New York Book Fair is its Sinfonia Concertante. And the fanfare, beginning at 5 this evening and continuing to 7 P.M. on Sunday, will be both visual and aural, as books and magazines from the presses of more than 250 small, noncommercial publishers go on display at New York University's Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place, in Greenwich Village.

title: A GRAND TOUR OF CULTURE WITHOUT LEAVING NEW YORK
description: NEW YORK is dotted with places to travel in. Take the subway to Lisbon, a bus to Seville. Walk across a street jammed with lurching cabs and nervous pedestrians and tumble into a meditation garden from Japan. The weekend sidewalk traveler can nearly name his oasis and find that country's cultural center, one of many throughout the city that aim to create a sense of place and time through exhibitions or through sheer ambience.

title: Essex County Struck Over Contract Talks
description: NEWARK (AP) - About 1,000 Essex County workers picketed government facilities in a strike protesting a yearlong impasse in contract negotiations, officials said.

title: G.M. to Recall 105,000 '81 X-Cars To Replace a Faulty Engine Cable
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would recall about 105,000 of its early 1981 X-cars to replace an engine electrical ground cable that could break.

title: Blood-Pressure Pills Recalled
description: The Pennwalt Corporation's pharmaceutical division has recalled a quantity of Zaroxolyn tablets, prescribed for high blood pressure and edema, after a pharmacist in Indianapolis discovered one bottle contained four times the dose stated on the label, a company official said today. The case lot number was given as C-0533, which was distributed nationally after Jan. 1. The bottles were said to contain tablets of 10 milligrams instead of the 2.5 milligrams printed on the label.

title: OIL DECONTROL PUT HIGHER DEMANDS ON US
description: To the Editor:

title: Company News; Ahmanson to Buy Orion Subsidiary
description: H.F. Ahmanson & Company and the Orion Capital Corporation jointly announced an agreement for the aquisition by Ahmanson of Bankers National Life Insurance Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Orion, for $134 million.

title: Terrorists in Brazil Bomb Opposition Newspaper
description: A dozen heavily armed terrorists raided the offices of the opposition newspaper Tribuna da Imprensa early today, detonating up to 10 bombs that badly damaged the presses.

title: Notes On People; Democrats Celebrate a 1980 Kennedy Victory
description: Ronald Reagan, watch out. That, according to State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein, was the message Wednesday night when some 700 die-hard Democrats jammed into the Copacabana to celebrate the first anniversary of Senator Edward M. Kennedy's landslide upset victory in the New York primary.

title: FEMINIST GROUPS ATTACK REAGAN BUDGET CUTBACKS
description: A coalition of women's groups assailed President Reagan's budget proposals today, saying that Administration's policies ''will destroy or severely impair many of the programs and endanger the rights for which women have struggled over the last several years.''

title: LIVE AND LEARN; The Tenant
description: A few days ago Mayor Jane Byrne of Chicago was saying that she didn't intend her proposed move into Chicago's crime-infested Cabrini Green housing project to appear ''dramatic.'' But of course her melodrama instantly spotlighted the neighborhood. Agencies began tidying up the area, fixing elevators, cracking down on crime -even evicting tenants. All Chicago and the nation watched.

title: Minnesota Wins and Gains Final in N.C.A.A. Hockey
description: Minnesota beat Michigan Tech, 7-2,tonight in the semifinal round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament before 5,681 fans in the Duluth Arena.

title: Carl Brand, Stanford Professor; Authority on British Labor Party
description: Carl Brand, an emeritus professor known for his historical studies of the British Labor Party, died Saturday at Stanford University Hospital after a brief illness.

title: F.B.I. Director Foresees Solution in Judge's Slaying
description: By United Press International Federal investigators are ''very close to a solution'' in the slaying of Federal District Judge John Wood Jr. in Texas, William H. Webster, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said yesterday.

title: HARVESTER'S DEBT SNAG
description: A few of Int ernational Harvester's 225 creditor banks have refused to roll over their maturing notes and have given the debts an ''on demand'' status, meaning that the loans may be called at any time, according to documents filed by Harvester with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: REAGAN EASILY WINS HOUSE VOTE ON PLAN TO SKIP DAIRY PRICE ADJUSTMENT
description: The Administration's plan to save $147 million by skipping the April 1 milk price increase sailed through the House today, giving President Reagan an easy Congressional victory in the first test of his drive to reduce Federal spending.

title: STATEMENT ON POLAND
description: Following is the text of a statement issued by the White House today on the situation in Poland:

title: 2 Illinois Prison Guards Stabbed
description: About 20 inmates at the Stateville Correctional Center attempted to take over a cell block in the maximum-security prison's segregation unit today and stabbed two guards, prison officials said.

title: LEAR ASSAILS RELIGIOUS NEW RIGHT AS A THREAT TO 'SPIRIT OF LIBERTY'
description: Norman Lear, the television producer, warned tonight that the religious New Right had grown so strong that it threatened ''the spirit of liberty for this generation.''

title: EX-ENGINEER FOUNDED INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH
description: Maurice Holland, a retired consulting engineer who founded the Industrial Research Institute, died Sunday at the home of his son, Maurice Holland Jr., in Bloomington, Ind. He was 89 years old and lived in East Greenwich, R.I., and Pelham Manor, N.Y., before moving to Bloomington two years ago.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA, MISS JAEGER GAIN
description: There were backhand half-volleys off her shoetops and delicate forehand dink volleys. But mostly, the sparkle returned to Martina Navratilova, a relaxed, confident flair that was conspicuous by its absence on the circuit last summer.

title: Schiff to Play Mozart
description: The Hungarian pianist Andras Schiff will be the soloist in Mozart's Piano Concerto in A major with the Stuttgart Chamber Orchestra under the direction of Karl Munchinger on Sunday evening at 8 in Carnegie Hall. The program will also include Pachelbel's Canon in D major, Vivaldi's Concerto Grosso in D minor, Respighi's ''Ancient Airs and Dances'' (Op. 40) and Britten's Variations on a Theme of Frank Bridge. Tickets, at $5 to $11, are available at the box office or may be charged by calling 247-7459.

title: JULIEN LEVY MEMORIAL APRIL 24
description: A memorial for Julien Levy, the art dealer and writer who died Feb. 10 at the age of 75, will be held April 24 at 4 P.M. at Cooper Union Eighth Street at Astor Place. Among the speakers will be Norman Mailer. A 15-minute version of a film Mr. Levy made in 1972 called 'Surrealism Is ...' will be shown.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's assistant for national security affairs, with that combination of bellicosity, chauvinism and simplistic sloganeering we have come to expect from Reagan's foreign-policy cohort from General Haig down, terms ''contemptible'' the desire of Western Europeans not to see themselves incinerated in a nuclear exchange between this country and the Soviet Union. He expresses shock and horror at ''outright pacifist sentiments.''

title: Company News; Judge Refuses to Bar Weyerhaeuser's Bid
description: United States District Judge John Pratt in Washington has refused to issue an injunction barring the Weyerhaeuser Company's proposed $66.3 million purchase of the bulk of the West Coast assets of the Menasha Corporation.

title: Suspect Reported in Indiana At Time of Jordan Shooting
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has learned that Joseph Paul Franklin, an avowed racist who is a suspect in an attempt to assassinate Vernon E. Jordan Jr., a black civil rights leader, stayed in a motel here ''in the days immediately prior'' to the shooting last May, The Fort Wayne Journal-Gazette reported today.

title: STAGE: GLENDA JACKSON AND JESSICA TANDY IN 'ROSE'
description: It's one of the theater's undying myths that an audience can pretty much determine the quality of a play about 15 minutes after the curtain goes up. That myth is taking quite a beating at the Cort, where a British play called ''Rose'' opened last night. In this show's first scene, we are treated to a delicious display of technique by that most ravishing actress, Jessica Tandy - and the theater crackles with life snared, unerringly and completely, through art. After that? Well, let's talk about Miss Tandy first.

title: BURTON ILLNESS LEAVES FUTURE OF 'CAMELOT' TOUR IN JEOPARDY
description: The illness of Richard Burton, who entered St. Johns Hospital in Santa Monica on Monday suffering from a virus and chronic arm pain, has left the future of the musical in which he is starring, ''Camelot,'' in jeopardy.

title: SHOULD THE MAYOR PAY THE $25?
description: About noon yesterday, Frank C. Batey spied the empty blue Chrysler parked in front of the Plaza Hotel. Twenty minutes later, the car, which bore no special identification, was still parked there, and Mr. Batey, Traffic Enforcement Agent, Level 1, tucked a $25 parking ticket under the windshield wiper.

title: SAFETY AND HEALTH DIRECTOR ORDERS PURGING OF BOOKLET HE CALLS UNFAIR
description: A Reagan Administration official has ordered the destruction of more than 100,000 booklets on cotton dust and is holding up distribution of films and slides on other health issues by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration on the ground that they are antibusiness, a spokesman for the agency said today.

title: I.C.C. TO CONTINUE RULE-MAKING DESPITE REQUEST BY TEAMSTERS
description: Marcus Alexis, the acting chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, today rejected a request by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to halt agency policy making until the Reagan Administration installs new leadership.

title: New Rhone-Poulenc Plant
description: Rhone-Poulenc S.A., the large French metals and minerals concern, said today that it would build an ammonium nitrate plant in France at a cost of up to $60 million. A site for the plant, which will process 1,000 tons a day, has not yet been selected, the company said.

title: VOLUNTEERS HELP CITY TO PRUNE ITS TREES
description: To the raucous sputter of a chain saw, the elm branches were falling in Riverside Park this week, sinking almost lazily to the ground from 45 or 50 feet up as a few joggers and passers-by craned their necks.

title: BOEING TO GO AHEAD WITH ITS 737-300 PLANE
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it had decided to go ahead with ''full development and production'' of the Boeing 737-300, which is to be a stretched and more fuel-efficient version of the widely used Boeing 737-200 twinjet.

title: Further Details Sought On Heart Implant Plan
description: The Food and Drug Administration has denied immediate approval of a Utah medical team's request to implant the first artificial heart in a human.

title: AFTER 7 YEARS IT'S UNJUST TO MONDAY-MORNING QUARTERBACK THE SEA LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; March 27, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing Nonuse of Force in International Rela- tions - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Lobbyist Facing Inquiry Over Her Sexual Affairs
description: Paula Parkinson, a lobbyist who said she had had affairs with ''fewer than a dozen'' Republican Congressmen, will be interviewed soon by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as part of a preliminary inquiry into whether votes were traded for sexual favors.

title: CABARET: 'LERNER AND LOEWE'
description: OF the five major works by the Broadway team of Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe, one is a masterpiece- ''My Fair Lady''- and they've given us well over a dozen pop standards. Twenty-four Lerner and Loewe songs, plus two Alan Lerner-Burton Lane collaborations, are included in the cabaret revue ''Thank Heaven for Lerner and Loewe,'' the latest of the King Cole Room's Salutes to Broadway at the St. Regis Sheraton Hotel.

title: Advertising; Interwoven Takes Step Back to TV
description: ''IN its 75 years, Interwoven built its marketing position on advertising,'' said Robert J. Glass, president of the Kayser-Roth Branded Products division, which makes socks, as he prepared to show the first commercials that Interwoven has scheduled for network television in many years.

title: NEW YORK FED'S CHIEF QUESTIONS MONEY POLICY
description: In a counterattack against members of the Administration who believe that control of the money supply is enough to reduce inflation, Anthony M. Solomon, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, warned that excessive attention to this argument ''does the economy a real disservice.''

title: Bartok's Son Loses Plea on Court Fees
description: Peter Bartok's application in Surrogate's Court for $1.3 million in legal fees for representing himself in litigation over his father's estate was denied by Surrogate Marie M. Lambert.

title: SAY KOCH UNDERESTIMATES REVENUE FOR FISCAL '82
description: The City Council leadership said yesterday that Mayor Koch had underestimated how much he would have to spend in the 1982 fiscal year by $150 million. They proposed that some of the extra money be used to hire 500 more police officers.

title: STATE'S ATTEMPT TO CONVERT HOSPITAL NEAR UTICA FOUGHT
description: A bitter controversy has arisen in the towns and villages east of Utica over a ruling by the state's Office of Health Systems Management that the 70-bed Herkimer Memorial Hospital, the smallest of three serving the Mohawk Valley, should be converted from an acute-care facility into a nursing home.

title: Mayor Koch Survives Home Base Challenge
description: Opponents of Mayor Koch failed last night to get the club where he started his political career to pass a resolution criticizing him. Instead, the Village Independent Democrats approved, 147 to 86, a resolution saying that the club should ''encourage Democrats who are prepared to seriously contest the Democratic nomination for Mayor'' to declare themselves.

title: POLISH UNION STAGES NATIONWIDE STRIKES
description: A crucial round of talks between the Government and Solidarity, the independent union, was postponed yesterday and the union went ahead with a nationwide four-hour warning strike today.

title: SADIE FRIEDMAN
description: Sadie Friedman, a philanthropist, died Tuesday in Boca Raton, Fla. She was 84 years old. Mrs. Friedman, along with her husband, the late Max L. Friedman, provided funds for the Albert Einstein College of Medicine at Yeshiva University and for the university's Research Institute.

title: TOP ROLE IN AUTO TALKS: HAIG LOSES OUT TO BROCK
description: Bill Brock, the nation's special trade representative, has won out over Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. as the official who will lead the car talks with Japan, President Reagan decided today.

title: MUSIC: FRIEND OF THE TOKYO
description: Richard Stoltzman's variation on the ''and friends'' format is a clever one. Starting last Tuesday at the 92d Street Y and continuing there on April 22, May 6 and May 13, he is allying himself with four different string quartets - the Tokyo, the Guarneri, members of his own Tashi plus guests and the Cleveland - and offering one major quintet for clarinet and strings on each program.

title: Auctions
description: A COLLECTION of 70 Impressionist, modern and old-master paintings valued at about $10 million will be auctioned for Leigh B. Block of Chicago by Sotheby Parke Bernet on May 20 at its Madison Avenue Galleries. The collection includes works by Degas, Gauguin, Braque, Redon, Daumier, Toulouse-Lautrec, Picasso, Bruegel and Guardi.

title: T.S. Eliot on 29th St.
description: ''Murder in the Cathedral,'' T.S. Eliot's 1935 verse drama about the murder in 1170 of Thomas a Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury, will be performed this weekend at the Little Church Around the Corner (Church of the Transfiguration), 1 East 29th Street.

title: LABOR PARTY REBELS OFFICIALLY FROM SOCIAL DEMOCRATIC PARTY IN BRITAIN
description: The Social Democratic Party formally came into being today, with a promise that it would radically alter ''the rigid framework into which our political system has fallen.''

title: Credit Markets; Morgan Guaranty Pricing System
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced yesterday that it no longer would post a broker-loan rate. A company spokesman said that the bank had established a new pricing system under which each brokerage firm would be charged a rate tailored to its overall relationship with the bank.

title: FRANK VAN STEENBERG
description: Frank Van Steenberg, former chairman of the board of the Baker, Knapp & Tubbs Company, a furniture manufacturing concern, died Tuesday at his home in San Francisco.

title: FRIDAY, MARCH 27, 1981
description: International Washington's concern over Poland was reflected in the Reagan Administration's strongest statement about the worsening situation there. The White House said that any use of force by the Polish authorities against the independent labor movement or any ''repressive action in Poland'' by Soviet forces could gravely affect East-West relations. (Page A1, Column 6.) A general strike is set in Poland today. The independent union said it would proceed with the four-hour warning stoppage after its crucial negotiations with the Government were unexpectedly postponed. The strike would be the most massive one ever staged by the sevenmonth-old union, and the nation, faced with worsening food shortages and other hardships, was tense and apprehensive. (A1:5.)

title: A POLARIZED WESTERN ALLIANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: by Leonard Sloan; Salaries Rise, Extras Fall for Mobil Chiefs
description: The two most senior officers of the Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil company after the Exxon Corporation, received healthy increases in their million-plus salaries and bonuses last year, according to the company's proxy statement.

title: ARAB BANK TAKEOVER OPPOSED
description: The minority leader of the State Senate, Manfred Ohrenstein, has asked the State Banking Superintendent to block an effort by a group of Arab investors to gain control of Financial General Bankshares Inc., which owns two banks in New York state and is the third-largest banking enterprise in the Washington metropolitan area.

title: British Group Bids For Flexi-Van Corp.
description: The Flexi-Van Corporation, a New York-based lessor of cargo containers and other transportation equipment, said yesterday that it had received a $35-a-share takeover offer from a private British investment group. Based on the 5.73 million common shares of Flexi-Van outstanding, the indicated value of the cash offer would be about $200 million.

title: Move by Chicago Mayor Is Preceded by Evictions
description: Sheriff's deputies began evicting tenants today from a crime-ridden public housing project where Mayor Jane M. Byrne intends to take an apartment in an effort to stem rampant violence there.

title: Earth Tremor Rocks Greece
description: A strong earth tremor shook the area around the Gulf of Corinth and Athens today, causing panic but no damage or casualties, according to the police.

title: 2 Louisiana Killers Lose Bids to Delay Executions
description: Two condemned murderers lost bids today in Louisiana state courts to delay their executions, which are scheduled for next Tuesday.

title: Rutgers Player Had Brain Hemorrhage
description: An autopsy today showed that a 20-year-old Rutgers University freshman football player who died late Tuesday after complaining to his coaches of a severe headache ong the first day of spring practice had suffered a massive brain hemorrhage.

title: Iraq's Oil Exports 25% Restored
description: Iraq's exports of crude oil, disrupted when the war with Iran broke out six months ago, have risen to about 800,000 barrels a day, industry sources said today. Before the war, Iraq was exporting 3.2 million barrels a day.

title: No Headline
description: Richard Migliore, the 16-year-old jockey who escaped serious injury after a spill earlier this month, escaped injury again Thursday at Aqueduct.

title: PIANO: VIBRANT CHERKASSKY AT 70
description: Shura Cherkassky, who began a series of three consecutive Wednesday-evening recitals at the 92d Street Y this week in advance celebration of his 70th birthday, is correctly called a ''Romantic'' pianist.

title: BOOKS: LIVELY LUGGAGE
description: Books: Lively Luggage By Anatole Broyard ROWING TOWARD EDEN. By Ted Mor- gan. 240 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $10.95.

title: 9 MOSLEMS AGAIN SEEK GULF TRUCE
description: Nine Islamic leaders who tried early this month to arrange a cease-fire in the Iraqi-Iranian war have decided to make a new effort beginning Monday.

title: A SOCIAL ROLE FOR BUSINESS
description: Despite the battles raging around President Reagan among the contenders for the control of crisis management, foreign policy, economic policy, trade policy and just about everything else including the succession to the Presidency in 1985, investors are investing and the stock market appears to be radiating warm confidence that the new Administration will be a glorious success.

title: S.B.A. Head Confirmed
description: The Senate today confirmed, by voice vote, the nomination of Michael Carde@nas as head of the Small Business Administration. Mr. Cardenas, 47 years old, will succeed Arthur Vernon Weaver. Mr. Cardenas, of Fresno, Calif., had been active in Republican campaigns since 1967, and was a partner with Fox & Company, a national firm of certified public accountants that merged in 1979 with his own firm, the Michael Carde@nas Accountancy Corporation.

title: GEORGIANS WHO WERE CLOSE AIDES TO CARTER LOATH TO LEAVE THE CAPITAL S CENE
description: Jimmy Carter's former staff members may have Georgia on their minds, but with the advent of the Reagan Administration they haven't moved any farther away than Georgetown.

title: German Detective Is Suspended In the Crackdown on Neo-Nazis
description: A senior police detective here has been suspended after a police raid on his home during a crackdown on suspected neo-Nazis.

title: MUSIC: TWO VIEWS OF 'BLUEBEARD'S CASTLE' BY BARTOK
description: Bartok's only opera, ''Duke Bluebeard's Castle,'' is as simple in outline as a fairy tale but as rich in domestic complications as a daytime television serial. A duke takes a wife whose way of expressing her love is to insist on opening up all the doors to his past. ''Was I the first one?'' she coyly asks Bluebeard. As any soapopera viewer knows, that kind of feminine inquisitiveness invariably ends in trouble. And so it does for Judith, the insatiably curious wife in Bartok's musical treatment of the Bluebeard legend. Though it has been produced by the New York City Opera and occasionally turns up in a concert version, this dark and ultimately mysterious work seems destined to stand just outside the doorway of the standard operatic repertory, too important to be ignored and yet too peculiar in its appeal to be invited inside. This week, however, brought us a rare opportunity to reassess the opera, in two distinctly different concert productions performed in celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Hungarian composer's birth.

title: GEORGE CLEARY, 90, LAW FIRM FOUNDER
description: George E. Cleary, a leading New York tax lawyer and a founder of the firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, died yesterday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan. He was 90 years old.

title: Company News; Gulf Oil Chief Sees Weaker 1st Quarter
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, hurt by rising crude prices and sluggish demand for refined products, said its first-quarter earnings would be ''significantly below'' its results for the fourth quarter of 1980. Because the company's fourth quarter was lower than the first quarter of 1980, the year-to-year comparison for the first quarter of 1981 would be even worse.

title: PUBLISHING: DUTCH GROUP IS SEEKING TO SELL DUTTON
description: Elsevier, the large Dutch publishing company, is seeking to sell E.P. Dutton, the 127-year-old American publisher that it has owned for five and a half years. ''The explanation is very simple,''' said Ivor A. Whitson, president of American Elsevier Publishers, the holding company for Elsevier operations in North America. ''Our parent company decided it wants to focus on information systems in the United States instead of trade publishing.''

title: Notes On People; Re-creation and Recreation in Santa Fe
description: Dick Cavett plans to do his rope tricks, Madeline Kahn will recreate her Marlene Dietrich number from ''Blazing Saddles,'' Sam Waterston and Joe Grivasi will do Abbott and Costello's ''Who's on First?'' routine, Gilda Radner will appear in a soap opera sendup and Joseph Papp has promised not to sing.

title: Business Digest
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 27, 1981 The Economy

title: Leonard is Taking Syracuse by Storm
description: Sugar Ray Leonard quit, sort of, today. He had started out by saying that anyone who called his fight Saturday night a mismatch was doing ''an injustice to Larry Bonds,'' but before long he had to admit, ''I don't think Bonds is going to create a problem.''

title: The Bar to the Rescue of Justice
description: It is heartening to see the organized bar rallying to the defense of the Federal Legal Services program for poor people. The outcry by the American Bar Association and various state associations has already had some effect in Congress. The Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources has broken with President Reagan, voting at least to let the program continue, though with only a third of its present funds. That is progress, but hardly enough.

title: 100 Protest Against L.I. Pinball Arcade
description: Some 100 people demonstrated outside a pinball arcade in an effort to close the place, which they say has introduced a ''bad element'' to the community.

title: LEBANON TO SEND MORE TROOPS TO AREAS NEAR ISRAEL
description: The Lebanese Government, in a new attempt to expand its authority in the southern part of the country, has decided to send 900 more soldiers to serve with the United Nations peacekeeping force there.

title: DANCE: GARRY REIGENBORN TROUPE ENERGETIC AT P.S.122
description: If language can be stretched a bit in order to describe choreography, the art of motion, in terms borrowed from music, the art of sound, then Garry Reigenborn's choreography might be termed loud choreography. The music was also loud at his Sunday night program at Public School 122. He may have given his troupe the whimsical name of the Garry Reigenborn Company Dance, but there was nothing whimsical about the way his dancers moved.

title: KOCH GETS LONG COMPLAINT LIST IN HARLEM
description: Mayor Koch and other top city officials went to Public School 153 at 147th Street and Amsterdam Avenue last night for a ''constituent hour'' and got an earful of complaints on everything from housing to police protection to garbage collection.

title: TURKS IMPRISON FORMER MINISTER WHO SPOKE UP ON KURDS' BEHALF
description: A former Cabinet minister has been sentenced to two years and three months in prison for ''making Kurdish and secessionist propaganda,'' it was announced today.

TWO demigods from the Baseball Hall of Fame are lunching in the White House today with Dutch Reagan, a former sports announcer for station WHO in Des Moines. For the next week or 10 days, Administration officials will be so busy swapping autographs of Al Lopez and Waite Hoyt that they won't have time for budget-cutting.

title: Keeping Us Honest
description: The purported State Department ''dissent paper'' on El Salvador, which was masquerading as an official document, highlighted some peculiar aspects of the way controversial information is being treated.

title: U.S. Ready to Let Seoul Buy 36 F-16 Jetfighters
description: Senator S.I. Hayakawa, chairman of the East Asia and Pacific Affairs subcommittee, said today that the Reagan Administration had decided to sell 36 F-16 jetfighters to South Korea, along with related equipment, for $900 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: A fashion article in The Living Section on Wednesday misidentified the manufacturer of Missoni perfume. It is Max Factor.

title: Quit? Over That?
description: So the single voice with which the Reagan Administration intended to speak to the world has kept saying nothing more urgent than ''I quit.'' For a Secretary of State to threaten resignation eight or nine times in 65 days must be a record. For him to invoke the ultimate weapon for no discernible policy reason plainly signals the end of the vaunted system of ''Cabinet Government.'' For the White House then to cast the problem as a jurisdictional conflict between Mr. Haig and Vice President Bush is foolishly to ignite the primary campaign of 1984. And for the President to blame these multiple embarrassments on the press is just silly.

title: News Analysis
description: Wending his way from committee to committee across Capitol Hill and through television interviews and news conferences, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has sounded a constant alarm about ''aggressive Soviet activity around the world'' as he has sought to justify the Reagan Administration's proposals for higher military spending.

title: CITY OF THE PAST STAR OF CURRENT PHOTO SHOWS
description: IT is in the nature of photography to serve a multiplicity of functions. Some photographs interest us primarily for the historical information they contain, whereas others make their appeal purely through their esthetic quality. Some are impressive for the technical feat they achieve, while others - portrait photographs especially - are interesting for their delineation of character and personality, as well as for the period they depict. And then there are photographs that give us such a vivid and unexpected glimpse of the life of the times that they are irresistible for that alone.

title: Watson Has Lead With 66
description: By this time last season Tom Watson had already won two tournaments. This season he has had one second and two sixth places, and he missed the cut in the Tournament Players Championship last week.

title: TV Weekend A CLOSEUP OF HOLLYWOOD
description: ON Monday, the Academy Awards will be carried on ABC-TV. Taking neat advantage of the surrounding hoopla, CBS News has put together a 90-minute documentary called ''Inside Hollywood: The Movie Business.'' The program, to be shown tomorrow night at 8:30, begins with scenes of stars showing up at Oscar ceremonies, but quickly gets into its more significant subject, described as a look at ''the gritty business behind the dazzle.''

title: Seeger in Suffern
description: The folk singer Pete Seeger will be the featured performer Sunday afternoon at 3:30 at a wine and cheese party for the Rockland County Mental Health Association, at the Marydell Convent on Montebello Road in Suffern.

title: Ex-Nurse Convicted Of Death in Surgery
description: NEWARK (UPI) - A former hospital nurse was found guilty last night of reckless manslaughter in giving a heart surgery patient an unauthorized transfusion with the wrong type of blood.

title: Article 057512 -- No Title
description: The City Council approved a $5.8 million supplementary appropriation yesterday to build temporary detention facilities on Rikers Island to relieve overcrowding.

title: Israeli Official Opposes Elections in West Bank
description: Occupied West Bank, March 26 (Reuters) - Israel will not allow the Palestinian inhabitants of the West Bank to hold municipal elections because the voting would endanger the Camp David peace agreement, a senior Israeli official said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 17.00-17.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Plea Made in 1969 Skyjacking
description: Lester Perry Jr., who spent 11 years imprisoned in Cuba, appeared before a United States magistrate today and pleaded not guilty to all charges stemming from a 1969 hijacking of an airliner over Kansas. Mr. Perry was being taken to Los Angeles in July 1969 to face a bank robbery charge when the hijacking occurred. He was accused of demanding that the plane carrying 122 passengers be flown to Cuba. He was jailed there and released last October.

title: Lafleur Is Out of Hospital After Tuesday Car Crash
description: Guy Lafleur of the Montreal Canadiens was discharged from Montreal General Hospital today, two days after he was involved in a car accident.

title: STOCK PRICES TUMBLE IN INCREASED SELLING
description: A selling wave hit the stock market yesterday as investors sought to cash in their profits, and prices turned sharply lower in heavy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which surged 19.09 points on Wednesday to its highest level in more than eight years, retreated to 1,005.76, off 9.46 points.

title: ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Despite the battles raging around President Reagan among the contenders for the control of crisis management, foreign policy, economic policy, trade policy and just about everything else including the succession to the Presidency in 1985, investors are investing and the stock market appears to be radiating warm confidence that the new Administration will be a glorious success.

title: GOODYEAR IDEA: FREIGHT-HAULING BLIMP
description: Zoilo Vergara, the operator of a tour business in Cuzco, Peru, wrote the Goodyear Aerospace Corporation recently for a price list on passenger-carrying blimps. The trip to the Machu Pichu Inca ruins in the Peruvian Andes, first by a slow narrow-gauge railroad and then by minibus over a winding dirt road, is uncomfortable for his customers, he said.

title: Reagan Aides Reach Pact In Police-Fire Bias Dispute
description: In the first affirmative action case brought by the Reagan Administration, the Justice Department obtained an agreement today requiring the all-white Statesville, N.C., police and fire departments to hire blacks until they make up 18 percent of both forces.

title: CHRYSLER RATIONING DELIVERIES OF CARS
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it was rationing deliveries of some cars to its dealers and had put most of its assembly plants on overtime schedules to cope with increased car and truck sales.

title: EVANGELINE GOULETAS: SHE ENJOYS HER BUSINESS, AND HER PRIVACY
description: The night after the Presidential inaugural gala they were introduced to each other by Tom Quinn, a Washington lawyer. ''It was a five-minute conversation,'' Evangeline Gouletas said today in her white-on-white office at 120 LaSalle Street here. ''I totally forgot about it. Then Tom, who is a mutual friend of ours, acted as the mediator again. He reached me at my desk after a dozen different phone calls and told me that Governor Carey would like to have lunch or dinner with me.'' They had dinner.

title:
Patents;
Focusing Circuit Improves Body-Examining Devices
description: An improvement in the ultrasound equipment used to examine the internal body structure enables physicians to see details more clearly. It is an inexpensive electronic focusing circuit covered by patent 4,257,271, granted this week to William E. Glenn, director of the research center maintained in Dania, Fla., by the New York Institute of Technology.

title: Gilbert, With 66-135, Leads Heritage by 2 Shots
description: Gibby Gilbert scrambled to a five-under-par 66, with no bogeys, and took the lead by two strokes today in the $300,000 Heritage Classic.

title: SIMPLICITY PATTERN CO. REJECTS 2 MERGER OFFERS
description: The Simplicity Pattern Company, the nation's dominant maker of sewing patterns, announced yesterday that it had rejected two merger bids but was being sought by another company, NCC Energy Ltd. of Britain.

title: Berry Tracy Resigns Post As Curator at Metropolitan
description: Berry Tracy, curator in charge of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's department of American decorative arts, has resigned effective June 30, according to an announcement by Philippe de Montebello, the museum's director.

title: Reagan and Ex-Players Share Baseball Stories
description: Baseball's living legends, joking and remembering their glory days, dined with President Reagan at the White House today.

title: POP: PRINCE, A RENEGADE
description: Prince, the 21-year-old Minneapolis-bred wunderkind of black music, put on an electrifying performance at the Ritz last Sunday night. Four months ago, when Prince played the same club, it was half-empty.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX OFF A 3D MONTH
description: The Government index intended to forecast the economy's direction fell for a third consecutive month in February, the Commerce Department reported today, lending weight to widespread expectations of slowing business activity.

title: Company News; Conoco to Close Minnesota Refinery
description: Conoco Inc., the nation's ninthlargest refiner, said it would close its refinery in Wrenshall, because of sharply reduced demand for petroleum products and an excess of refining capacity in the industry.

title: Long Philadelphia Transit Strike Predicted as Negotiations Falter
description: With no contract negotiations being held, a union leader today predicted a long strike against the Philadelphia transit system, already shut down for 13 days by a walkout affecting 400,000 daily riders.

title: ALLIES SAID TO AGREE WITH U.S. ON POLAND
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the major allies of the United States agreed with the Administration that Soviet military intervention in Poland would prompt ''concerted efforts'' by the Western powers in retaliation.

title: Replacement Sought for Jeep
description: The Army said today that it had asked 61 companies, including the major auto makers and suppliers, to suggest a replacement for its most-famous vehicle, the jeep.

title: CONGRESSMEN VISIT 3 MILE ISLAND ON ANNIVERSARY EVE
description: Almost two years to the day after it became a worldwide symbol of potential catastrophe, the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant was visited this morning by a delegation of Congressmen whose leader, Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona, said after a tour of the complex that one of its twin reactors ''might very well be turned back on.''

title: SYNAGOGUE ACTS TO HELP JEWS TO RENEW THEIR FAITH
description: A year ago, Judy Weil Epstein says she knew very little about Judaism, although her family background was Jewish. Now she attends synagogue services every Saturday, studies Hebrew and keeps a kosher home.

title: Indictments of 26 Inmates Lead to Maryland Inquiry
description: Officials started an investigation of Maryland's troubled prison system today and halted a furlough program after 26 inmates who had been released to attend work or college classes were indicted on charges including drug selling, robbery, rape and murder.

title: HELMS SAYS SENATE MAY CONSIDER SOME SOCIAL MEASURES THIS YEAR
description: Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, said today that Senate conservatives had accepted that President Reagan's economic program was the legislative priority, but he asserted that they might not wait until next year to bring up social legislation.

title: INQUIRY ORDERED IN BRITISH SPY CASE
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who told Parliament yesterday that there was no proof that a former British counterintelligence chief had been a Soviet spy, said today that she had ordered an investigation into how a British journalist had obtained information that the official was once under suspicion.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Campbell Resources Inc. and Camchib Resources Inc. completed the final stages of a reorganization of the companies.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: Bail was set at $250,000 each today for three white men accused of the murder of a young black student found hanging from a tree. Civil rights leaders from across the South gathered for the victim's funeral tomorrow.

title: Company News; U.S. Helping Troubled Prudential Lines; Skouras Gets $2.6 Million
description: The United States Government has stepped in to help troubled Prudential Lines Inc., a small but far-flung ship line run by Spyros Solon Skouras, the movie heir.

title: SCHMIDT'S POPULARITY SLIPS FOR FIRST TIME AS CHANCELLOR
description: For the first time since Helmut Schmidt became Chancellor in 1974, public opinion polls are showing that he is slipping - far enough so that one such survey contends that he is no longer the country's most popular political figure.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE COMPLETES LAST MAJOR SCHEDULED TEST
description: The last major scheduled test of the space shuttle Columbia was completed yesterday, but space agency officials said that they would not know until late tomorrow if the refurbished insulation on the huge shuttle tank withstood the fueling exercise.

title: 21 Show Horses Killed In a Fire in Westchester
description: A fire at the Elmwood riding stable here killed 21 show horses valued at $300,000 to $400,000, according to Fire Chief Ed Barth.

title: 2 Airlines Plan New Fare Cuts
description: Competition for air-travel business in the sluggish spring season intensified yesterday as Eastern and Trans World Airlines announced another round of fare cutting.

title: Superior Oil-Peru Pact
description: The Superior Oil Company said today that it had signed a petroleum exploration contract with the Peruvian Government calling for an initial investment of $20 million.

title: Books of The Times
description: Mind of the Author By ANATOLE BROYARD WRITERS AT WORK, FIFTH SERIES. Edited by George Plimpton. Introduc- tion by Francine du Plessix Gray. The Viking Press. 387 pages. $17.95 cloth. $8.95 Penguin paperback.

title: A BALANCED FINAL FOUR, EXCEPT FOR SAMPSON
description: Four of the last five times North Carolina has reached the Final Four, a dominant 7-foot center carried his team to the championship while the Tar Heels settled for second, third or fourth place.

title: SOVIET'S IMPATIENCE WITH POLAND GROWS
description: The Soviet Union appears to be putting pressure on the Polish leaders to regain control of the situation in Poland by forceful measures - without, this time, any concessions to the Solidarity union.

title: BARBADOS WILL DETAIN TRAIN ROBBERY FIGURE TILL LEGAL FIGHT IS OVER
description: A judge ruled today that Ronald Biggs, the fugitive British train robber who was kidnapped and brought here from Brazil, had not been seized illegally and would be held while Brazil and Britain made legal moves to get him back.

title: Floor Wax Heir Chosen As New Envoy to Britain
description: President Reagan today named John Louis, a board member of a newspaper chain and heir to a floor wax fortune, as the new Ambassador to Britain.

title: THEATER: 'DARKNESS AT NOON' REVIVED AT THE QUAIGH
description: Thirty years ago, Sidney Kingsley's adaptation of Arthur Koestler's novel ''Darkness at Noon'' chilled Broadway with its dramatization of the Moscow trials in which Stalin purged Russia of old Communists and onetime close associates. Three decades later, there is good news for theater and bad news for mankind to report about it.

title: SEX, EDUCATION AND TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY
description: To the Editor:

title: HEADED RELIGION CENTER
description: The Rev. Weyman C. Huckabee, retired executive director of Wainwright House, the Center for the Development of Human Resources in Rye, N.Y., died Tuesday at Brunswick Memorial Hospital, Saint Simon's Island, Ga. He was 77 years old and lived on Saint Simon's.

title: Company News; Union Oil Statement
description: The Union Oil Company of California said that there were no negotiations under way for the sale of its 86 percent owned Canadian subsididary, the Union Oil Company of Canada Ltd. The statement, issued at the request of the Toronto Stock Exchange, appeared to dampen a flurry of speculative trading in the stock of the Canadian unit.

title: LUNDQUIST CAPTURES BREAST-STROKE FINAL
description: To the relief of his coaches, family and friends, Steve Lundquist of Southern Methodist has stayed away from his motorcycle since last October, when it fell on him and tore his right shoulder. Today, in the 58th annual National Collegiate swimming championships, he got down to business and swam the thirdfastest 100-yard breast-stroke in history.

title: WHEN'S A BAGEL NOT A BAGEL?
description: Is a bagel without a hole really a bagel at all? Should the Commissioner of Consumer Affairs be notified of gross misrepresentation on a menu that offers bagels when holeless specimens are forthcoming? Should such travesties be renamed breadlets or ringlets of bread or bread doughnuts? Why am I even eating this chubby round imposter?

title: George Buckner, a Former Editor Of the Christian Church's Journal
description: George Walker Buckner, former editor of World Call, the monthly journal of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), died Monday in Charlotte, N.C. He was 87 years old and a resident of Charlotte.

title: LOUISIANA TECH, TENNESSEE WIN
description: Undefeated and top-ranked Louisiana Tech held off a second-half rally by Southern California for a 66-50 victory tonight and advanced to the final of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women Division I basketball tournament.

title: Boston School Chief, 53, Dies of a Heart Attack
description: Boston's acting Superintendent of Schools, Paul Kennedy, who has been fighting to avert a shutdown of the city's schools, suffered a heart attack Thursday while driving his car and died. He was 53 years old.

title: 10 ARE DEAD AND 14 INJURED IN FLORIDA COLLAPSE
description: At least 10 construction workers were killed and 14 injured yesterday afternoon when a fivestory condominium collapsed as workmen were pouring concrete on the unfinished roof.

title: 1787 DOUBLOON SOLD FOR $625,000
description: A 1787 Brasher Doubloon sold for $625,000 on Thursday night in Los Angeles, becoming the second most expensive coin sold at auction. The gold rarity was the top lot in the fourth and final session of the record-breaking sale of coins and medals from the Garrett Collection.

title:
Patents;
Portable, Inexpensive Video Phone
description: A VIDEO telephone patented this week is designed to enable two persons to talk to and watch each other at a distance. Portable equipment with television cameras and screens can be attached at each end of a telephone line.

title: Company News; NATOMAS IS SEEKING ALL OF MAGMA POWER
description: The Natomas Company, a diversified energy, transportation and real estate concern, said yesterday that it would offer $42 a share, or $360 million, for the remaining 93 percent interest in the Magma Power Company that it does not already own.

title: Company News; Chris-Craft Purchase
description: Chris-Craft Industries Inc., a diversified company with operations in television stations, chemicals, plastics and foam rubber and a leading player in recent bids to acquire the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, said its board of directors had authorized purchase from time to time of up to 250,000 shares of the company's outstanding stock at prices not exceeding prevailing market prices. Herbert J. Siegel, the company's chairman and president, said the purchases would be in addition to the 300,100 shares of Chris-Craft common stock that the company will buy back under a previously announced agreement with the Reliance Insurance Company. Chris-Craft has about 3.1 million common shares outstanding along with about 423,700 of $1.40 convertible preferred shares. PU COMPNEWS FOLOS

title: Company News; Dow Chemical Deal
description: The Dow Chemical Company will invest $153.9 million in two petrochemical plants in the southern Argentine province of Neuquen, the Argentine Government reported. One is an ethylene plant and the other a low- and high-density polythene plant with a planned annual output of 90,000 tons. PU COMPNEWS FOLOS

title: The City; Demonstrators Seek Increase in Welfare
description: Welfare advocates demonstrated in Manhattan for a 100 percent increase in grants in the state's new budget and protested the Reagan Administration's proposed reductions in social services.

title: TIME FOR A DOLLAR TRANSIT TOKEN
description: To the Editor:

title: NORRISTOWN, PA. 1981: THE PLOWSHARES 8
description: ''Nuclear war is not on trial here in this courtroom! You are.'' These words were directed by Samuel W. Salus 2d, the judge in a recent trial in Norristown, Pa., to the anti-nuclear defendants known as The Plowshares 8.

title: Pan Am Loses Bid For Baggage Curb
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today rejected a request by Pan American World Airways to limit the amount of a passenger's baggage that can be checked on flights.

title: FILM SERIES AT MODERN APRIL 24
description: Fourteen films from 15 nations comprise the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art's 10th annual New Directors/New Films series that will begin April 24 at 6 P.M. with ''Simone Barbes, or Virtue,'' a French film directed by Marie-Claude Treilhou.

title:
Patents;
Way Devised to Produce Interferon in Vertebrates
description: A method of inducing, in man and other vertebrate animals, production of interferon, the natural body substance that fights virus infections, has been invented for Pfizer Inc., the New York drug manufacturer. The interferon inducers are amines - specifically monoamines, diamines and trimines.

title: Mount St. Helens Termed Quiet
description: Mount St. Helens appears to have gone back to sleep for the time being, the United States Geological Survey announced today. The volcano has all but stopped spitting sulfur dioxide and carbon dioxide gases, the tremors and earthquakes inside it have become rare and deformation of the mountain has stopped. One year ago exactly, the mountain in southwest Washington State erupted violently.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, MARCH 28,1981; The Economy
description: The index of leading economic indicators declined for the third straight month in February, lending weight to widespread expectations of a business slowdown. Economists noted, however, that the drops had been relatively modest - three-tenths of 1 percent in February, sixtenths of 1 percent in January and one-tenth of 1 percent in December - and did not necessarily indicate that a new recession was looming. (29.)

title: MISSES HANIKA AND BUNGE GAIN
description: Bettina Bunge says she doesn't compare her rise to that of Tracy Austin or Andrea Jaeger, her teen-age tennis rivals. ''They've done very well, very fast,'' says Miss Bunge, 17 years old, who is Swiss by birth, grew up in Peru, lives in Coral Gables, Fla., and has West German citizenship.

title: Mao Dun, 85, a Writer Who Was a Minister Of Culture in China
description: Mao Dun, a writer who said literature should not be an ''intoxication'' but whose ideology-laced works showed a psychological penetration, died today, the official news agency Xinhua reported. He was 85 years old.

title: G.O.P. IS URGED TO WORK HARDER TO BUILD UP PARTY AT LOCAL LEVEL
description: The Republican Party must concentrate on electing candidates to local offices, such as sheriffs, city councilmen and state legislators, if it is to become truly the nation's majority party, Richard Richards, the Republican national chairman, told party leaders today.

title: Penthouse Libel Judgment Cut
description: The $25.5 million awarded Kimberli Jayne Pring, a former Miss Wyoming, in a libel suit against Penhouse magazine was cut by a judge to $14 million today.

title: EL BUSHADOR
description: Once again I have been summoned in the dead of night to a country house outside Washington. I know the summoner as D. This is a shortening of his code name, D. of N., which stands for ''Dead of Night.''

title: RAIL AGENCY SHAKE-UP URGED OVER POSSIBILITY OF SAFETY PLAN ABUSE
description: A House subcommittee chairman said today that he was pressing Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis to shake up the Federal Railroad Administration in his department because of an internal report suggesting a potential for fraud and abuse in the agency's safety program.

title: TIME FOR A DOLLAR TRANSIT TOKEN
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Virginia Electric and Power Company intends to sell up to $100 million of first and refunding mortgage bonds through a public offering on April 21.

title: BEINESH EPSTEIN
description: Beinesh Epstein, consultant to the public-affairs department of the Zionist Organization of America, died Thursday in St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. Mr. Epstein, a resident of Manhattan, was 85 years old.

title: EX-HEAD OF BAR GROUP
description: Justice Joseph D. Quinn Jr. of State Supreme Court died yesterday of cancer at Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 58 years old and lived in Hyde Park.

title: A CHARTER FOR PRISON REFORM
description: The Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, the Federal funding agency for criminal-justice programs, begged Congress for its life, lost, and is being phased out. This threatens the future of the Commission on Accreditation for Corrections, a prisonreform mechanism of unprecedented potential, which has been dependent on L.E.A.A. funds.

title: Zimbabwe Reports Getting Offers Of $1.5 Billion at Aid Conference
description: Zimbabwe received pledges of $1.5 billion in aid during a five-day conference here, a Government official said today.

title: COPTER HIJACKING SUSPECT GIVEN ALIBIS
description: Several witnesses have provided evidence that the wrong man was arrested and imprisoned for six weeks for allegedly hijacking a helicopter in an attempt to free a prisoner from a jail in lower Manhattan.

title:
Patents;
Postage Meter Controlled, By a Coded Bank Check
description: Luther J. Simjian of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was granted a patent this week for a postage meter controlled by a bank check to be inserted in it.

title: Japan-Argentine Accord
description: A group of Japanese companies and banks has agreed with Argentina's economy ministry to participate in railway, steel-making, telephone and power projects here, according to a joint announcement today. The Japanese interests will invest $50 million in a project to expand output at the stateowned Somisa steel mills, will electrify a railway line, install 360,000 telephone lines and provide aid to several local power projects, the announcement said. Represented are the Nippon Steel Corporation, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd., the Ishikawajima-Harima Heavy Industries Company, the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, the Toshiba Corporation, Hitachi Ltd, the Nippon Electric Company, the Marubeni Corporation, the Mitsubishi Corporation, C. Itoh & Company, the Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd. and the Bank of Tokyo Ltd.

title: Company News; F.T.C. Cites G.&W.  In Coffin Inquiry
description: The Federal Trade Commission accused Gulf and Western Industries Inc. of moving toward a monopoly through acquisitions of two companies in the coffin industry and said it may seek a divestiture order.

title: ARMANI'S MESSAGE IS PANTS
description: If skirts become an endangered species, blame Giorgio Armani. A year ago, he decided short pants were the wave of the future and banished relics like the skirt from his runway. His alternative: breeches, knickers, shorts and other pants, some in never-seen-before shapes. Few stores bought them but many designers copied them, which is the highest form of flattery.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.5 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a $1.5 billion decline in the nation's basic money supply, a development that appeared to increase the chances that the Federal Reserve would encourage stable or perhaps slightly lower interest rates in the near future.

title: Questions appear on page 14.
description: 1. Salvadore Dali, the Surrealist, who over the years signed thousands of blank sheets of lithograph paper. The effect of this on the value of existing Dali lithographs was highlighted recently when purportedly false Dali lithographs bearing his signature and notary stamp began to appear around the world. 2. The issue of Vice President Bush's appointment to head the Administration's crisis management team, which Mr. Haig had reportedly opposed.

title: PEKING SEEMS REASSURED ON U.S. TIES
description: The Reagan Administration, in a concerted diplomatic initiative in the last two weeks, appears to have reassured China's leaders that it wants its ties with Peking to grow and that it will not rashly precipitate a confrontation over Taiwan.

title: Xaverian, Mount Vernon In State Basketball Final
description: Led by Chris Mullin, who scored 37 points and had 19 rebounds, Xaverian High School defeated Alexander Hamilton, 85-77, tonight in the New York State High School Basketball Tournament.

title: RICHARD BURTON, ILL, LEAVES 'CAMELOT'
description: Richard Burton, who was hospitalized in Santa Monica last Monday for a viral infection and chronic pain in his right arm and shoulder, will not be returning to his starring role as King Arthur in the Lerner and Lowe musical ''Camelot,'' according to Mike Merrick, the show's co-producer.

title: Mideast First Ladies Honored for Compassion
description: Ofira Navon, wife of the President of Israel, and Jihan Sadat, wife of the President of Egypt, returned home yesterday, after brief visits to New York, where they were honored by the World Rehabilitation Fund at its 25th-anniversary dinner Wednesday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SI FOR YOURSELF

title: HIGH SCHOOL DIPOLMAS ARE NOT ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMAS ARE NOT ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: Account Deficit Of Bonn Drops
description: West Germany had a current-account deficit in February of $747.6 million, down sharply from $2.3 billion in January, the Bundesbank, the central bank, said today.

title: A Song of Survival for the Performing Arts
description: Many prominent persons in the arts have testified in recent days before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee pondering proposed cuts in arts programs paid for in part by the Federal Government, but only one witness so far has put her testimony in song.

title: KOCH WILL PAY THE $25
description: Although insisting he had done no wrong, Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would not fight City Hall and would pay out of his own pocket a $25 parking ticket slipped under the windshield wiper of his official car Wednesday by a traffic enforcement agent.

title: An American Protests On a Whaler in Japan
description: An American climbed aboard a Japanese whaling vessel off Japan's east coast and chained herself to a harpoon to protest the killing of sperm whales, a spokesman for the Greenpeace conservation group said.

title: Fund for White House Is Raised to $822,641
description: A new list of contributors to a fund to redecorate President and Mrs. Reagan's living quarters in the White House shows that the total has grown to $822,641, including a $10,000 gift from Frank Sinatra.

title: OIL AND CAR IMPORTS DROP
description: The United States merchandise trade deficit narrowed in February, to a seasonally adjusted rate of $3.15 billion, largely as a result of a decline in imports of oil, automobiles and metal products, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: NOT BY LAINGEN
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Computer Venture
description: CII-Honeywell Bull S.A. said today that it had received permission from the Brazilian authorities to form a joint venture with a Brazilian concern to produce computers in Brazil. The computers will be produced by a new company, Ste Impresa Telematic S.A., which will be 40 percent owned by Honeywell Bull and 60 percent by Unipec, in which the Pereira Lopez and Brasilinvest companies are shareholders. Financial details of the arrangement were not disclosed.

title: Florence in the Spring
description: Last January, Richard N. Gardner left his post as Ambassador to Rome for the Carter Administration, with no idea when he'd return to Italy.

title: EGYPT PLANNING VAST DESERT HYDROELECTRIC PROJECT
description: It is a bumpy ride to the rim of the vast Qattara Depression south of the World War II battlefield of El Alamein. It is a ride over 35 miles of rolling gravel plain marked only by tire tracks and piles of stone the Bedouins have put there to show the way.

title: Nigerian Official Optimistic After Discussion With Haig
description: External Affairs Minister Ishaya Audu of Nigeria met today for three and a half hours with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and said later that he was optimistic that Nigeria and the United States would join in efforts to promote racial change in South Africa. Mr. Haig called the meeting with Mr. Audu ''cordial, productive and promising.''

title: Leak at Weapons Plant Frees Radioactive Gases
description: Radioactive tritium gas was released into the atmosphere today when a pipe broke at the Savannah River Plant, which manufactures material for use in nuclear weapons. The release apparently posed no danger to the area, officials said.

title: The Drums of Avarice
description: Gambling is a business based on the assumption that greed can be satisfied by luck. Naturally enough, therefore, New York's hotel and resort industries now offer a report to bolster their case for legal casino gambling that appeals shamelessly to the state's gambling instinct.
