It promises grandly that if the voters ratify a constitutional amendment to permit casinos, unemployment hereabouts will drop below the national average; $3 billion will flow into hotel and casino construction; and property values, along with local and state tax receipts, will rise precipitously. The temptation to march to this gambling drum will be strong. But it should be resisted.

title: The City; Koch Revises Plan On Aiding Homeless
description: Corporation Counsel Allen G. Schwartz told Mayor Koch yesterday that the Mayor's plan to ask for legislation to permit the city to round up homeless people without their consent and hold them for 72 hours so they could be cleaned and fed would not pass constitutional scrutiny.

title: MOODY'S SUSPENDS BOND RATINGS FOR BOSTON
description: Moody's Investors Service today suspended for at least three months its bond ratings for Boston and 36 other Massachusetts communities, citing concern over the uncertainties created by a voter-approved limit on property taxes.

title: A BROAD LOOK AT LIFE AS A JEW
description: When Sharon and Michael Strassfeld were putting together ''The Second Jewish Catalog,'' about four years ago, they wanted to include a chapter on Israel. ''But it kept on growing,'' Mrs. Strassfeld recalled, ''and finally we realized that it should be removed and put into a third book, a large chunk of which should be devoted to Israel and the Diaspora'' (everywhere Jews live outside the borders of Israel).

title: SATURDAY NEWS QIUZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 22. 1. The signature and notary stamp like the one pictured above are causing consternation in the art world. Whose signature is it, and what is at issue?

title: Typhoid Quarantine for Refugees
description: Federal public health officials have quarantined 41 Haitian refugees after laboratory tests confirmed that three of them were infected with typhoid fever, the Dade County Health Department reported yesterday. All those quarantined and three who were hospitalized arrived in south Florida on one boat Feb. 14, officials said.

title: PENNSYLVANIA TOWN LIVES WITH FIRE THAT WON'T STOP
description: For generations this was a town that Centralians loved. Those who left yearned for their valley and the surrounding hills, where green trees and flowers of summer hid old mining scars, and many returned to its modest but neatly painted homes, its gardens and fresh air.

title: Prime Up to 17 1/2% At Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific National Bank, the nation's 10th-largest bank, raised its prime lending rate onehalf percentage point, to 17 1/2 percent, today as signs multiplied that the recent downward drift of interest rates may have been blunted.

title: Chess Grandmaster On Morning Radio Show
description: Listeners of WMCA-AM will be able to match wits with a grandmaster of chess weekdays beginning April 13.

title: Your Money; Claiming a Pet As a Deduction
description: WHO among us, as April 15 approaches, has not cast a wistful eye on his dog and been tempted to claim the beast as a dependent? Perish the thought, of course; but it should not be overlooked that in some circumstances Fido the Dog and Felix the Cat can be tax deductions as well as companions.

title: Friedman Leaving S.E.C. on June 5
description: Stephen J. Friedman, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has informed President Reagan that he will be leaving the S.E.C. when his term expires on June 5. The departure, which had been expected, was disclosed in a letter dated March 26.

title: The City; Refugee, 19, Is Slain
description: A 19-year-old Cuban refugee employed at an apparel shop at 555 Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn was shot and killed during a $100 robbery by four youths, including one believed to be no more than 10 years old, the police said.

title: Military Analysis
description: President Reagan's hint that the United States might begin to supply arms to the Afghan rebels raises two basic questions: How would the arms be delivered, and to whom?

title: Article 064786 -- No Title
description: After a bitterly partisan debate, Senate Republicans upstaged the Democrats today by leading a successful move to restore $200 million that President Reagan had proposed cutting from the school lunch program. The funds were made available at the expense of foreign aid.

title: E.E.C. to Cut Steel Subsidies
description: Industry ministers of the 10 nations of the European Economic Community agreed early today to gradually reduce the large subsidies that European governments grant to their faltering steel industries. But the meeting, which lasted more than 15 hours, produced no accord on a precise schedule for making the cuts.

title: Hannah Goldberg, 79, Ex-Director of Hadassah
description: Hannah L. Goldberg, former national executive director of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Oragnization of America, died Thursday in Boston. Miss Goldberg, a resident of Boston, was 79 years old.

title: MOCK HOLDUP IS STAGED IN BRONX TO TRAIN POLICE ANTI- ROBBERY UNIT
description: ''Harry's Grocery'' in the Bronx was the target yesterday of three simulated holdups within an hour. The first time the ''robbers'' were caught by detectives who had staked out the store. The second time they were caught by members of the New York City Police Department's Mobile Robbery Alert Team, and the third time they were arrested by two detectives who had been trailing them.

title: Company News; Mercury Price Cuts
description: the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln-Mercury division is cutting prices by as much as $413 for certain optional equipment packages on five of its 1981 models, the auto maker said. The price cuts, offered by the division's dealerships for the remainder of the model year, involve the Mercury Capri, Zephyr, Zephyr Z-7, Cougar and Cougar XR-7. Savings range from $286 to $413 and include such optional equipment as tilt steering wheel, hood and bodyside stripes, styled wheel covers, interval windshield wipers, AM-FM stereo radio and special paint treatments, depending on the model.

title: Kingman Pact Extended Through 1985
description: At an al fresco news conference behind the clubhouse at Huggins-Stengel Field today, Frank Cashen, the Mets' general manager, announced that Dave Kingman's contract had been extended through the 1985 season.

title: HOW ULSTER BECAME AN AMERICAN ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Wisconsin Gains Final in Hockey
description: Bruce Driver, Scott Lecy and Ted Pearson scored third-period goals to help Wisconsin defeat Northern Michigan, 5-1, in the semifinals of the National Collegiate hockey tournament tonight at the Duluth Arena.

title: Company News; Richardson-Vicks
description: Directors of Richardson-Vicks Inc. have declared its first quarterly dividend of 33 cents a share on the common stock, payable June 1 to holders of record May 15. The company became fully operational on March 10 following the acquisition of the consumer products and chemicals businesses of Richardson-Merrell Inc. by the Dow Chemical Company. Richardson-Vicks makes health care and toiletry products.

title: WHY SHOULDN'T CALIFORNIA HAVE A CANNES FESTIVAL?
description: Thirty-four independent American movie companies threw down a gauntlet to the Cannes Film Festival this week as the first American Film Market opened here.

title: News Analysis
description: When Attorney General John N. Mitchell was challenged in 1969 by a delegation of black leaders who were unhappy about some of the Nixon Administration's public statements, he retorted: ''Watch what we do, not what we say.''

title: SCHOOL REJECTS A 'FREE' OLDENBURG
description: Claes Oldenburg's plan for a sculpture on the University of Hartford campus here has apparently rubbed the institution's regents the wrong way. It calls for a 23-foot-long toothbrush in red, white and blue.

title: News Analysis
description: When the controversy over Meyer S. Frucher's nomination for State Labor Commissioner began, he said he felt ''like the guy who walked into the room in the middle of the pie fight.''

title: WHY FORD SEEKS IMPORTS CURB
description: The Ford Motor Company, which has long overshadowed its archrival, the General Motors Corporation, with the success of its international operations, has almost paradoxically been a leader in Detroit's effort to restrict imports of Japanese cars.

title: UNDER GAZA'S CALM SURFACE: DEATH, DRUGS, INTRIGUE
description: The placid surface of everyday life here is a deception.Arab children play laughingly in the brown dust of the crowded refugee camps in this Israeli-occupied strip beside the Mediterranean, where tents gave way long ago to permanent slums of stone and concrete.

title: Police Ousted in Opossum Case
description: Two police officers who admitted dumping dead opossums outside a diner owned by blacks have been dismissed, Police Commissioner Charles Jordan said today. ''Everyone was embarrassed by the opossum incident but I can't help but feel that the professional police officers suffered the most,'' Mr. Jordan said.

title: 6 Are Indicted in Disappearance Of a Chicago Area Businessman
description: Four men and two women were indicted by a grand jury today on murder charges in connection with the disappearance of a wealthy Chicago area businessman who investigators believe was the target of a plot to get his money.

title: THEATER: TRAGICOMIC 'FATHER DREAMS'
description: Mary Gallagher's ''Father Dreams'' (at the Ensemble Studio Theater) is a family play written in rue. This is an abrasive, unswerving portrait of a family allied against itself, with each member unable to forgive past transgressions, actual or imagined. The play is incomplete, but Miss Gallagher has a genuine talent for conjuring life into theater.

title: Arrows Reach M.I.S.L. Final
description: Steve Zungul scored four goals and Branko Segota had a goal and three assists to lead the New York Arrows to a 10-1 victory tonight over the Baltimore Blast in a Major Indoor Soccer League semifinal playoff game at the Checkerdome.

title: FREEZE ORDERED ON PROFIT MADE ON ST. JOE OPTIONS
description: Judge Milton Pollack of the Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday ordered the Irving Trust Company to freeze assets placed in three accounts by a Swiss bank after the Securities and Exchange Commission alleged the use of insider information in a recent purchase of St. Joe Minerals Corporation options.

title: MENTAL PATIENTS' RIGHT TO REFUSE MEDICATION IS CONTESTED IN JERSEY
description: In 1974, John E. Rennie, a former aircraft pilot with a history of mental illness, was questioned by Secret Service agents after he allegedly threatened to kill President Gerald R. Ford. The incident resulted in his involuntary commitment to the Ancora Psychiatric Hospital, a state institution in Hammonton, N.J.

title: HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMAS ARE NOT ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDE TERMS HAIG 'WOUNDED LION' OVER BUSH'S ROLE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and his closest aides remain resentful over what they regard as the underhanded way that White House advisers orchestrated Tuesday's appointment of Vice President Bush as the Administration's crisis manager and then provided the material for a number of critical articles in the press about Mr. Haig.

title: CABRINI TO CLOSE HOSPITAL SERVING UPTOWN SECTION
description: Cabrini Medical Center announced yesterday that it would begin closing its St. Elizabeth's Division in upper Manhattan on Wednesday. It said it hoped to convert the 147-bed hospital into a nursing home.

title: STRAWBERRY PATIENT ON HIS ROAD TO METS
description: Several miles from Al Lang Stadium, where the Mets play their spring games, Darryl Strawberry and his fellow minor leaguers prepare for their season on the four fields at the Payson Complex.

title: MILLIONS IN POLAND GO ON 4-HOUR STRIKE TO PROTEST VIOLENCE
description: Millions of Polish workers held a four-hour nationwide strike today, the largest organized protest since Communism came to Poland 36 years ago.

title: TRUSTEE IS NAMED FOR O.P.M. LEASING
description: James P. Hassett, president and chief executive officer of DCL Inc., a computer leasing company now in a voluntary liquidation, was named trustee yesterday of O.P.M. Leasing Services, which has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: By Sports of The Times; Among the Final Four, It's Academic
description: ONE after the other at hourly intervals, the Final Four teams in today's semifinals of the National Collegiate basketball championship were practicing out on the court at the Spectrum yesterday when a cynic shook his head.

title: I.M.F. TO GET $4.9 BILLION A YEAR FROM THE SAUDIS
description: The International Monetary Fund announced today that it will receive $4.9 billion a year over the next two years from Saudi Arabia to support a new lending facility for poor countries.

title: U.S. May Help Pakistan In Training of Its Army
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the United States was moving toward ''a new and enduring relationship'' with Pakistan that may soon include resumption of military training for Pakistan's armed forces.

title: NAGASAKI, AUG. 9, 1945
description: In August 1945, I was a freshman at Nagasaki Medical College. The ninth of August was a clear, hot, beautiful, summer day. I left my lodging house, which was one and one half miles from the hypocenter, at eight in the morning, as usual, to catch a tram car. When I got to the tram stop, I found that it had been derailed in an accident. I decided to return home. I was lucky. I never made it to school that day.

title: WALESA, A CALM LEADER IN A DANGEROUS CONFLICT
description: Like a general darting around the battlefield to exhort the troops to greater valor and self-sacrifice, Lech Walesa toured strike-bound factories in the capital this morning. His message was different - it was for nonviolence instead of violence - but a sense of life-and-death struggle was there.

title: 3 TOP YACHTS SUSPECTED OF HANDICAP IRREGULARITIES
description: Irregularities related to handicap ratings are believed to have occurred among at least three of America's foremost offshore racing yachts, prompting the removal of two from the United States team in the forthcoming Admiral's Cup series and the re-scoring of the recent six-race series in the Southern Ocean Racing Conference.

title: Scoring the Mayor
description: It's been a time for gauging mayoral conduct. First, it appears that an official car was sent to take Mr. Koch's barber to Gracie Mansion for an emergency clipping. Is the Mayor inconsistent for using his car in a way he would not let other officials use theirs? Yes. But isn't the criticism mere quibbling? If the Mayor stopped his driver on the way uptown from City Hall and had the car wait while the barber operated, who would complain? Wouldn't it be a worse offense to interrupt business at the Mansion so that Mr. Koch could go to the barber? Certainly. Give the Mayor 10 of a possible 10.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SENATE BUDGET DEBATE
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate debate today over an amendment by Senator Jesse Helms that would shift $200 million from foreign aid into school lunch programs. Participants were Senators Edward M. Kennedy, who spoke twice; Howard H. Baker Jr., Robert Dole and Howard M. Metzenbaum. By Senator Kennedy

title: A.T.&T. ENTRY OPPOSED IN UNREGULATED BUSINESS
description: The cable television industry, phone companies and other competitors are lining up to oppose a petition by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to a Federal court in Newark asking for affirmation of its right to enter new, unregulated businesses.

title: Loyd Haberly Dies at 84; Poet, Teacher and Dean
description: Loyd Haberly, a former professor and dean at Fairleigh Dickinson University in New Jersey who was the author of more than 40 books, mostly of poetry, died yesterday in a nursing home in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old and had lived for many years in Rutherford, N.J.

title: U.S. COMPANY IN BIG VENEZUELA OIL ACCORD
description: A United States engineering and construction concern, the Lummus Company, won a $698 million oil development contract last night as the Venezuelan Government moved ahead on a vast petroleum recovery project that has been in the planning stage for years.

title: Find 'Candy Man' - Quick
description: Authorities in the South Jersey city of Millville have their work cut out for them, and no time to spare. Judge Philip Gruccio has given them a week to find a drug pusher, identified so far only as ''Candy Man,'' who has been peddling at the local high school.

title: DANCE: SOUL'S DARK SIDE
description: Peggy Cicierska and Kim Arrow, whose dances were performed last Saturday at Eden's Expressway, are interested in rendering the dark places of the soul in stylized dance terms. Their four jointly choreographed dances ranged in influence from Gogol to Hesse and Indian mythology to ''Rashomon,'' but for all that the dances tended to look curiously alike and rather bloodless, an effect, perhaps, of choreography by committee.

title: 4TH SUSPECT IS ARRESTED IN JAILBREAK
description: A 45-year-old Atlanta man picked up on a traffic violation here last night was arraigned today on Federal charges of hijacking a helicopter and using it in an unsuccessful attempt to pluck a convicted drug dealer from the roof of the Federal detention center in Manhattan on Jan. 25.

title: SAFETY AGENCY TO REVIEW STANDARDS ON COTTON DUST
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced today that it would re-examine its rules for protecting cotton workers against brown lung disease and said it had asked the Supreme Court to hold off on a case testing the rules.

title:
Patents;
U.S.-Owned Inventions Available for Licensing
description: More than 25,000 Government-owned inventions are available for domestic, and sometimes foreign, licensing.

title: A BALANCED FINAL 4, EXCEPT FOR SMAPSON
description: At 12:54 tomorrow, the basketball will be tossed into the air, and Louisiana State and Indiana will answer a question: How will it bounce? Rapidly, as the Tigers prefer? Deliberately, as the Hoosiers hope?

title: An Appraisal
description: Once called ''that scourge of old-fangled monuments'' by a New York Times critic, Claes Oldenburg has been proposing giant sculptures since the mid-1960's.

title: PLAINFIELD, N.H., 1981: AGAINST THE ARMS RACE
description: During voters' annual exercise in participatory democracy here, one man became so angry that he asserted: ''There's no place in town meeting for politics!'' This, of course, was an erroneous claim.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 17.00-17.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: JURY SELECTED FOR MARGIOTTA EXTORTION TRIAL
description: A jury was selected today in Federal District Court here in the trial of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican chairman and one of New York State's most influential political leaders.
To the Editor:

title: DOW SLIDES 10.98 POINTS, TO 994.78
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday as investors reacted nervously to signs of rising interest rates and the crisis in Poland. The Dow Jones industrial average, which gave up 9.46 points Thursday, to finish at 1,005.76, fell an additional 10.98 points, and closed at 994.78.

title: Bridge: Becker Team and the Aces Survive in Tough Semifinals
description: A New York team headed by the veteran B. Jay Becker and an Aces squad led by Bob Wolff of Dallas clashed in the final of the Vanderbilt knockout team championship here this afternoon after surviving hard-fought semifinal matches that were in doubt until the finish.

title: Phillips Oil Cites Drop in Reserves
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company's oil and natural gas reserves slipped 17 and 12 percent, respectively, last year, according to the company's annual report issued today.

title: SWIVEL-END BUS WINS PRAISE OF JERSEY RIDERS
description: Residents were treated to a free ride today on a 55-foot-long, German-made bus that can seat 61 persons in air-conditioned, cushioned comfort. Their reactions ranged from ''nice'' to ''fantastic.''

title: THE ATLANTA KILLER(S) WILL BE CAUGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ: BASIE, MISS VAUGHN AT CARNEGIE
description: Count Basie and his orchestra were the nominal stars March 20 at the third of three jazz concerts at Carnegie Hall celebrating the auditorium's 90th year. But Sarah Vaughan was the life of the party.

title: Honduran Plane Is Hijacked And Lands in Managua
description: A New Orleans-bound Honduran jetliner with 87 people on board, including two United States citizens, was hijacked over Central America today by five hijakers and ordered to land here. The hijackers later released 38 of the hostages, including one of the Americans.

title: No Headline
description: With John Stearns at first base, playing his first game since he broke a finger last July 26, the Mets lost to the Baltimore Orioles, 4-2, Friday night. The Mets' regular catcher, who plans his first appearance behind the plate within the week, had two singles in four times up. Mike Scott pitched an undistinguished four innings for the Mets, allowing four hits and two runs.

title: Composer Gets 15% Of 'Misbehavin' '
description: After nearly three years of claims and litigation, Jeffrey Gutcheon, a composer, has been declared to be one of the authors of the hit musical ''Ain't Misbehavin'.'' This will entitle him to obtain 15 percent of the amount received by Richard Maltby, the show's director, with whom he made an oral agreement in 1977, before the musical opened at the Manhattan Theater Club, for a share in the proceeds because of his creative role.

title: NEW YORK CITY'S FISCAL BATTLE IS NOT YET WON
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: DANIEL McCLUSKER
description: The dances on Daniel McCusker's Thursday night program at the Danspace of St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bowery were all well ordered. Yet there was vitality within that order. These dances were living forms.

title: U.S. Judge Dismisses Suit on Japan TV's
description: A Federal judge today dismissed a $1.5 billion conspiracy and antitrust suit filed by two American television manufacturers against their major Japanese competitors.

title: NELSON MAKES PITCH WITH POISE
description: His first name is really his middle name, but to hear people talk about him, one would think Gene Nelson's middle name was ''Poise.''

title: 2 JUSTICE DEPT. NOMINEES DEFEND U.S. ANTICRIME PLAN
description: Two of President Reagan's nominees for toplevel positions at the Justice Department encountered skepticism today when they told senators that the department could lead a fight against violent crime without spending any more money on the problem.

title: Snag in Japan-Soviet Talks
description: Four-day talks between the Soviet Union and Japan's semiofficial Export-Import Bank ended here with no major progress on a Japanese loan to finance the building of a proposed 3,000 mile, $12 billion natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe, Japanese bank officials said today. The officals said they had agreed to meet again in Tokyo or Moscow at the earliest possible time for further discussions.

title: GUESSING GAME AT U.S. EMBASSY: WINNERS GET VISAS
description: In the summertime and just before Christmas, the line extends out the back gate of the modern, cube-like building and all the way around the block to the broad Paseo de la Reforma. But in late winter, the slowest season of the year, only a thousand people a day queue up outside the United States Embassy, hoping, like the throngs standing patiently in dozens of other countries, that they will leave with what is fast becoming one of the most valuable pieces of paper in the world.

title: Gang War Kills 5 in Jamaica
description: Five people have been slain in a week of gang war in Kingston that has closed businesses and turned neighborhoods into armed camps, the police said today. The fighting started with a murder in West Kingston's Rema section that residents said was carried out by a resident of the Tivoli section.

title: ELDERLY GIVEN HELP ON REPAIRS
description: T HEIR slogan is, ''To Make Daily Living in Household a Little Easier,'' and they call themselves Geri-Pare Inc. They repair small appliances without charge, which is almost unheard of in these days of service charges, surcharges and hidden charges. But pause before you race out to Brighton Beach. The service is offered only to the elderly and then only if they live in the Brighton Beach-Coney Island-Sheepshead Bay area and make a prior call to 769-3282.

title: Critics' Choice; by Peter G. Davis
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC George Gershwin's music used to be treated with condescension by classical musicians, but no more. In fact, most of the major Gershwin performances these days are by artists from the classical establishment - even singers like Elly Ameling no longer hesitate to program his songs.

title: Annette Gail Wells Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wells of Greensboro, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Annette Gail Wells, to Scott Wilson Nichols, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Nichols of Huntington, L.I. Miss Wells is a freshman at Guilford College, where her fiance is a junior.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: EDITOR WHO PUT BITE INTO HUMOR OF PUNCH
description: Bernard A. Hollowood, who served for 11 years as editor of the British humor magazine Punch, until 1968, died in Guildford, England yesterday, his family announced. He was 70 years old.

title: Lieutenant Fiance Of Karli Forman
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Douglas Forman of Sands Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karli Elizabeth Randall Parker Forman, to Lieut. James Hagedorn, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Hagedorn, also of Sands Point.

title: DROUGHT STIMULATES INTEREST IN WELLS
description: AT cocktail parties in New Canaan the sight of ice cubes made from town water prompts conversations on the desirability, mechanics and cost of installing a private well.

title: THEY LIGHTED UP THE FAMILY FARM
description: WASHINGTON T HE largest of them supplies electrical power to more than 68,000 consumers. The smallest, in terms of users (though the largest in land area) has less than one member per mile of transmission lines. One of the newest is on a tiny island off the Maine coast, plugged into the mainland with an undersea cable. And one, whose members are scattered through the islands in Puget Sound, holds its annual meeting on a ferry boat.

title: By SECRETARY HAIG'S REACH EXCEEDS HIS GRASP
description: About 11 P.M. Tuesday, after a long, bruising day of trench warfare with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., the White House was uncertain whether he would resign. Dave Gergen, a top White House official, telephoned William Dyess, an aide to Mr. Haig, to ask: ''Is he or isn't he?''

title: CENSORSHIP BY THE C.I.A. CHALLENGED IN COURT SUIT
description: - A Federal court was asked yesterday to declare that the Central Intelligence Agency had improperly censored an article by a former C.I.A. employee that purported to describe "probable" efforts by the agency to fabricate evidence about Communist arms shipments to El Salvador.

title: MALVERNE WINS TITLE BY BEATING TOLENTINE
description: Mitchell Fisher scored on a 15-foot jump shot at the buzzer tonight to give Malverne (L.I.) High School a 55-54 victory over Tolentine of the Bronx in the New York State High School Class B basketball championship.

title: About Long Island; by Fred McMorrow; Nov. 29, 1980.
description: HAPPY birthday to me. Never mind what birthday. My brother, who knows more about living than I do because he has been at it five years longer, says it is better to be that age than not to be. I went to work early and came home early, and took a nap.

title: A DANCER REFLECTS ON CUNNINGHAM STYLE
description: AMONG the 15 members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company performing for the last two weeks at the City Center in New York City is a blonde dancer with a stirring quality for movement. She is Susan Emery, a native of Rye and graduate of the State University of New York at Purchase who has been with the company since 1977. Last week, between ballet class with Maggie Black and a noontime rehearsal, she discussed her work with Mr. Cunningham and company.

title: ANDERSON PROPOSES A SUPERTRACK TO REPLACE STATE'S RACING STRIPS
description: Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority leader, yesterday proposed the construction of a single so-called ''supertrack'' facility to replace the four existing thoroughbred and harness race tracks, which have been experiencing financial losses under private ownership and operation.

title: OF NECKTIES...
description: If there were ever any doubt about the economic proclivities of the Reagan White House, one need only observe what its occupants wear around their necks: Neckties embroidered with profiles of Adam Smith, the 18th-century political economist.

title: SHURA CHERKASSKY MAKES FERVENT PERSONALITY HIS STYLE
description: "I don't know what I'm going to do on the spur of the moment. I like it like that."

title: Paperback Talk
description: The big TV tie-in. A week from tonight and on the three nights following, 75 million Americans will be glued to the tube, watching ''Masada,'' a mini-series starring Peter O'Toole and Peter Strauss that reenacts ''an epic battle for freedom that has remained a symbol of defiance for 2,000 years.'' At least that's the hope of the ABC television network and Universal Pictures, which have staked more than $22 million on the eight-hour show. Meanwhile, three or four million of the viewers will hasten to buy the Ernest K. Gann novel on which the series is based. That's the expectation of Jove Books, which has already placed more than two million $2.95 copies in the paperback racks.

title: THE POPE'S 'DIVISIONS'
description: In one of his many moods of contemptuous mockery, Josef Stalin once asked: ''How many divisions has the Pope?'' Now his successors have the answer in their struggle with the Polish people and the Roman Catholic Church: ''Too many for comfort.''

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Measured Reply To Basque Attacks
description: Although military extremists failed in February to overthrow Spanish democracy, Basque extremists have been taunting them to try it again. In the past 10 days, they have murdered two army colonels.

title: PHIL MAHRE CAPTURES SKIING'S WORLD CUP 3
description: Phil Mahre of Yakima, Wash., today became the first American to win the World Cup, which has been awarded the last 15 years to the skier who accumulates the most points from 31 downhill, slalom and giant slalom races. The series is held over a four-month span in 10 countries.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Dethroned Queen
description: Hours before she was to pass her title as Miss North Carolina to her successor in June 1979, Debbie Shook was stripped of the title by the Jaycees, the sponsor of the beauty pageant. She had accused the service organization of reneging on promises to give her a $5,500 wardrobe and $3,000 scholarship.

title: THEATER: FIVE FULL-LENGTH PLAYS AND 12 ONE-ACTERS IN ONE WEEKEND
description: Once a year this city becomes the new-play capital of America. In one weekend, at the fifth annual Festival of New American Plays at the Actors Theater of Louisville, I saw 5 full-length plays and 12 one-acters, chosen from thousands that were submitted a year ago to Jon Jory, artistic director of the Actors Theater. Even when the quality of the writing wavered, performance and production were first-class, and there were, as usual, a few surprises. It is the cumulative event that counts. Each year the Actors Theater demonstrates the vitality in the native American theater.

title: South African Plane Fired Upon
description: A small South African plane was hit with 10 rounds of ground fire from Mozambique that narrowly missed the five people aboard, the owners of the plane said today. The plane, a Cessna 310 with a pilot and four businessmen aboard, was said to have been coming in to land near the Komatipoort border post when it was fired upon yesterday.

title: Critics' Choice; FILM
description: ''My Fair Lady'' on Eighth Avenue? Yes indeed - Saturday and next Sunday - now that the Times Square area can boast a new revival house, the refurbished Hollywood Twin Cinema. This week it features a lineup of big movie musicals from the 50's and 60's.

title: By Sports of The Times; 'Just A Tougher Zone' Stops Sampson
description: WHEREVER he plays, however he plays, Ralph Sampson is always measured against the memory of the giants who preceded him in college basketball. He snatches a rebound high above the rim, or swats away an opponent's shot, or slides into that swooping hook shot, and the comparison is inevitable. At a towering 7 feet 4 inches, Ralph Sampson resembles Kareem Abdul-Jabbar more than anyone else.

title: JUDGE IS STAYED FROM GIVING DEFENSE CBS MATERIAL
description: A Federal appeals court temporarily barred a Federal judge in New Jersey today from giving tapes and transcripts of interviews for a segment of the CBS television program ''60 Minutes'' to defense attorneys in a multimillion-dollar fraud trial.

title: BEACH JETTY PLAN BLOCKED
description: ACONTROVERSIAL Army Corps of Engineers proposal to bury the 15 existing rock groins in Westhampton Beach - jetties built by the corps to prevent coastal erosion but not believed to accelerate it in adjacent areas - has been blocked by Suffolk County's refusal to approve the $42 million project.

title: WINTER FLOUNDER; Pseudopleuronectes americanus
description: Size: Average to 12 inches; reaches 24 inches. Color: Dark brown, often with reddish tint, with black spots above; white underside.

title: No Headline
description: The youngsters at the Stratton Mountain School are indeed a highly motivated group, and they are particularly sensitive to one another's needs.

title: John Is Pondering Future as a Yankee
description: George Steinbrenner will meet with John Schneider, Ron Guidry's lawyer, tomorrow to discuss a new contract for Guidry. Steinbrenner has said he will meet with Reggie Jackson at a ''propitious'' time to discuss a new contract for Jackson.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Francis Perry Performs Guitar and Lute Program
description: Francis Perry, a New Jersey-born guitarist and lutist who teaches at Fairleigh Dickinson University, made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night. His program indicated that Mr. Perry is not a follow-the-leader performer.

title: Reading and Writing; THE ARTIST AS ART
description: People talk as if the cult of personality in literature belonged to our time only, that it is something invented by Ernest Hemingway and refined by Norman Mailer. But it was probably Lord Byron who first fostered it on a grand scale and Gabriele D'Annunzio (1863-l938) who carried it to operatic extremes.

title: ...AND THE SARTORIAL ARTS
description: ''Why graduate studies at the Wharton School include a seminar on dressing for business,'' began the full-page newspaper ad placed by Barney's, the Manhattan haberdashery. The business school at the University of Pennsylvania, the ad went on, ''now offers its students a seminar on proper business attire, thereby officially acknowledging this most important fact of business life heretofore ignored in the world of academia.''

title: Poland Closes Airspace For Military Exercises
description: State Department officials said today that Poland was closing its airspace from 12:30 A.M. to 4:30 A.M. tomorrow, Warsaw time.

title: CHAMBER: BEAUX ARTS
description: New York audiences have had the luck to hear fine performances of both Schubert trios this week - James Buswell, Yo-Yo Ma and Richard Goode playing the beautiful, yet waywardly long E flat Trio Monday at Alice Tully Hall and the Beaux Arts Trio presenting the more familiar and lighter-hearted Trio in B flat at the Metropolitan Museum Thursday night.

title: Music:Debuts in Review; Musical Offering Plays Diverse Baroque Pieces
description: If Bach's ''Musical Offering'' was a demonstration of what he could do with learned counterpoint, the debut of the chamber group Musical Offering in Carnegie Recital Hall last Monday was a demonstration of what it could do with a more diverse Baroque repertory. It succeeded admirably.

title: WHEN OIL-PAINTED SIDING BEGINS TO PEEL
description: Older houses with wooden siding are often susceptible to persistent peeling of paint caused by moisture vapor trapped inside the walls. This moisture sometimes results from leaks or open joints in the outside walls, but more often than not it enters the hollow wall spaces as vapor, which is generated by high humidity levels-especially in the winter, when doors and windows are sealed while normal bathing, washing and cooking add gallons of moisture to the confined air.

title: Gaines Sets 100 Freestyle Mark
description: When Rowdy Gaines of Auburn won the 200-yard freestyle last night in the 58th annual National Collegiate swimming championships, he was glum. His time was only the secondfastest in history for that distance, and he was disappointed that he did not break his record.

title: TROOPS IN EL SALVADOR SAID TO KILL 25 REBELS IN BRIEF, INTENSE FIGHTS
description: Government troops killed 25 guerrillas in battles at four rebel camps around Suchitoto, about 25 miles northeast of the capital, an army spokesman said today.

title: Recordings; CHAMBER ORCHESTRAS
description: I t was only five months after the end of the Second World War and Stuttgart was still not much more than a heap of rubble when a 30-year-old conductor named Karl Munchinger led his first concert with a chamber orchestra he had just assembled and named after his home town. Today, over 35 years and 3,000 concerts later, the Stuttgart Chamber Orchestra is one of the oldest and most noted ensembles of its kind, having toured five continents and made hundreds of recordings. Tonight the group pays a visit to Carnegie Hall with a program of music by Pachelbel, Vivaldi, Respighi, Mozart and Britten.

title: A GREATER THREAT TO PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: TRUELY POPULAR RELEASES
description: Acurious and potentially disturbing rock-and-roll phenomenon has grown more extreme in recent years. That is the discrepancy between supposedly enlightened taste and the taste of the mass public. The discrepancy has always existed, to some extent. Bob Dylan, for instance, was never as popular in the 60's as his reputation might lead one to believe. He was enormously influential, and prized by a collegiate elite, but it was only in the 70's, when he had become an aging icon, that his records began to sell routinely in the millions.

title: Speaking French And Spinach
description: Thank you, William Safire, for clearing up a mystery (''Haigravations,'' On Language, by William Safire, Feb. 22).

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THERE'S NO SICK LEAVE FOR THE BREADMAKER
description: THE absolute worst part of being a mother is the total lack of any sick leave. The heart of this situation is that, whereas major corporations and political systems are designed to function in the temporary absence of their leaders, households are not.

title: G.O.P. EYES L.I. FOOTHOLD IN RACE FOR GOVERNOR
description: JAMES L. EMERY, who succeeded Perry B. Duryea of Montauk as the Assembly minority leader and would like to succeed him as a Republican gubernatorial candidate against Governor Carey, has established a political foothold on the Island, the home turf of another G.O.P. gubernatorial prospect, Court of Appeals Judge Sol Wachtler.

title: 'THE COMPANIES DON'T CARE WHO'S AT FAULT'
description: SEVERAL years ago, while researching a book on the Mafia, I interviewed a Texas racketeer who had masterminded sundry swindles netting hundreds of millions of dollars. His rationale for committing the crimes went this way: ''I never steal from individuals. I steal only from institutions, mainly insurance companies. And, if the truth be known, the biggest thieves in the world are the insurance companies.''

title: Music:Debuts in Review; Rosewood Quintet Plays Kupferman's 'Infinities'
description: The Rosewood Quintet played very professionally through most of its debut recital last Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall - a little erratic and perhaps nervous in the opening Quintet in G minor by Franz Danzi but generally manipulating dynamic levels and balances among instruments with musical effect.

title: AUTHOR AND FIRST WIFE OF SINCLAIR LEWIS
description: Grace Hegger Lewis Casanova, the first wife of Sinclair Lewis, the American author and Nobel Prize winner, died Friday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 93 years old.

title: IRISH DEBATING NEUTRALITY AS TIES WITH BRITAIN IMPROVE
description: Recent signs of an improvement in relations with Britain have rekindled an emotional debate here about a political passion that is firmly rooted in the Irish national consciousness - neutrality.

title: ADMINISTRATION SEEKS GREATER ROLE FOR ENTREPRENEURS AT FEDERAL PARKS
description: The Reagan Administration is planning major changes in the way national parks are operated, including granting increasing power in running the parks to private concessionaires and possibly divesting the system of urban parks such as the Gateway National Recreation Area in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Daniel McCormick, Charlotte M. Jones To Be Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Jones of Westport, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Charlotte Mackay Jones, to Daniel Joseph McCormick, son of Mrs. John R. McCormick of Syracuse and the late Mr. McCormick.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Mark Circo Weds Susan French
description: Susan Mary French, daughter of Mrs. William Reddan French of Sayville, L.I.,, and the late Mr. French, was married yesterday to Mark Circo, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ignatius Circo of Selden, L.I. The Rev. John J. Gorman performed the ceremony at St. Lawrence the Martyr Roman Catholic Church in Sayville.

title: Traveling by Train
description: To the Editor:

title: Olivia Hirsch Trager a Bride
description: Olivia Hirsch Trager and Jonathan Bobrow Altschuler were married yesterday at their home in Manhattan by State Supreme Court Justice Richard W. Wallach. The bride, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is manager of creative recruiting at Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising Inc. She is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Marx Hirsch. Mr. Altschuler, a lawyer, is a son of Mrs. Richard Altschuler of New York and the late Mr. Altschuler. His marriage also ended in divorce.

title: Ann E. Skudlarek to Be Wed
description: The engagement of Ann Eileen Skudlarek, daughter of Ruth Jaqui Skudlarek of Metuchen, N.J., and the late Alois John Skudlarek, to Michael Frederick Fox, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Fox of Manasquan, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's mother. The couple plan to be married Sept. 26 in St. Francis Roman Catholic Church in Metuchen.

title: MORRISON'S BLACK FABLE
description: TAR BABY By Toni Morrison. 306 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: MILITARY PLANNERS VIEW THE SHUTTLE AS WAY TO OPEN SPACE FOR WARFARE
description: The blastoff of the space shuttle next month will be a benchmark in the history of warfare, in the view of Pentagon officers and military strategists.

title: Derailment Forces Evacuation
description: The derailment of two tank cars containing potentially explosive butane forced the evacuation of about 1,500 Sedro Woolley residents last night, the authorities said. Seven cars of a Burlington Northern train derailed near the center of Sedro Woolley about 9 P.M., Mayor Don Walley said. There were no explosions, no leakage and no injuries reported.

title: DAY-CARE CENTER FOR ITALY
description: WITH their first gift, an ambulance, delivered to the Italian village of Paternopoli, members of Westchester County's Italian Earthquake Committee met last week to plan the next contribution to Avellino, their ''adopted'' province.

title: CENTERPIECES TO GO
description: Sometimes, a business just naturally happens. There was Carol Rollo, who owned two fashion boutiques on First Avenue, one for men's things, the other for women. She decided to consolidate both of her Riding High shops into one store, but didn't want to part with the extra location. Miss Rollo didn't have to reach far for an idea for the now-empty shop.

title: COLLEGE CHANGING ALONG WITH THE STUDENTS
description: GARDEN CITY IN 1961, Nassau County Community College consisted of few hundred students and handful of instructors working out of a wing of an old courthouse in Mineola. Today, the two-year institution's 225-acre campus here serves 23,000 full-time and part-time students working toward about 50 different arts, science and career-oriented associate degrees.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE new $80 million arena in the Sports Complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands, delayed by labor problems and difficulties in obtaining building materials, is near completion and will be opened on June 19.

title: Jane A. Fisher Has Nuptials
description: Jane Alison Fisher and Ben Charles Swiggett, who expect to receive M.B.A. degrees in June from New York University, were married at All Saints Episcopal Church in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., yesterday. The Rev. William Ellery Arnold performed the ceremony.

title:
Gardening;
WILLOWS, THE EARLY SPRING BLOOMS
description: ONE of the more unpleasant things to taste is the aspirin that fails to go down on the first swallow. Were you to chew on a willow twig, you would find that it tastes much the same. The reason is that the willow is the source of salicin, the basic ingredient in aspirin and related painkillers. One Old World species, the shrubby Purple Osier, Salix purpurea, is still used as a source of the drug. The generic name for willows, salix, is the source of the word salicin and derivatives such as sodium acetylsalicilate, once widely used in advertising as a well-known painkiller.

title: STATE CHALLENGED ON PLANS TO ALLOW DRILLING IN PARK
description: The New York State Office of Parks and Recreation announced plans this week to lease rights to develop oil and gas deposits in a state park.

title: HAMPTON'S HOUSING SURGE
description: ''Six years ago I'd never have dreamed that I would have my own million-dollar business, own two Mercedes and be building a country house in the Hamptons for more than $300,000. But things have changed. And since I don't know how long the good times will last, I'm doing it all now.''

title: No Headline
description: William Safire discusses the word ''spinach'' in the On Language column, and I cannot resist sending the definitive origin of the expression under scrutiny:

title: 'CUT IT OUT, MR. ALLEN!'
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Regarding the article on El Salvador, an additional point bears mentioning.

title: BALLET THEATER OPENS APRIL 20
description: Ten new productions and four full-length ballets will highlight American Ballet Theater's eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera from April 20 through June 13. Featured in the opening-night benefit gala will be Mikhail Baryshnikov's new production of ''Raymonda'' (divertissements from Act II and the entire Act III of the ballet) and Sir Frederick Ashton's ''Les Rendezvous,'' which will be seen in its first production by an American troupe.

title: Doctors on Strike; Give In to Reality
description: In another year or so, many of the members of the Committee of Interns and Residents will be certified medical specialists and able to look forward to comfortable lives. But during the New York City strike that ended last week in what a union leader admitted was ''profound defeat,'' they were anything but comfortable, for Mayor Koch and others made the telling point that they were risking the wrath of the powerful at perhaps the most vulnerable period of their careers.

title: ART SAMPLER
description: ONE of the major art collectors in this country is Norton Simon, a West Coast businessman who has shown as much astuteness in his art selections as he has in commerce.

title: SUITED FOR SUMMER
description: 31 eep-toned colors, which have not always been associated with warmweather clothes, are being combined with lightweight fabrics to produce a practical and elegant way to dress for business in summer or all year round in warmer climates.

title: AUTHENTIC MODELS FOR A NEW COLONIAL
description: AN antique-loving Westchester couple couldn't find a house old enough to suit them, even among the Colonials of Bedford, so they are building one themselves, with 18th-century style post and beams, hand-made bricks, and oak dowels instead of nails.

title: IT was getting on toward 5 P.M. and Bobby Gleason's Gym was filling up when Gerry Cooney arrived carrying a leather case that could have held a small transistor radio. For something like five years now, the sweatshop on West 30th Street has been Cooney's main office, the place where he conducts his business when he isn't in a Catskills training camp or in some arena punching another heavyweight's ears off. Naturally, he knows all the regulars in Gleason's. His progress was slow as he pushed through the crowded aisle with two boxing rings at his left and the wall on his right, pausing to shake a hand here and thump a shoulder there.
description: In his dressing room one steep flight up, he opened the leather case and removed a miniature television set with a 1 1/2-inch screen measured diagonally. He fiddled with dials but couldn't bring in a picture. ''Damn!'' he said. ''It was coming in clear.'' He stepped out to the corridor to try it there.

title: Stage View; HOW ALBEE AVOIDED 'LOLITA'
description: In ''Lolita,'' Edward Albee's purported dramatization of Vladimir Nabokov's novel, actor Donald Sutherland is seen as history-teacher Humbert Humbert, and at one point in the first half Humbert Humbert is looking for a furnished room to rent. He has looked at three or four places, we learn, but has been dissatisfied with all of them. Ian Richardson, an omnipresent narrator who may also be Nabokov himself, has now escorted Mr. Sutherland to what will turn out to be the home of 12-year-old Lolita. But Mr. Sutherland doesn't meet Lolita right off. He meets Lolita's mother, played by a roly-poly apparition named Shirley Stoler and caricatured to within an inch of her girth. Lolita's mother is a widow, Lolita's mother is on the make, Lolita's mother offers not only a room but the promise that ''I might even let you take a liberty or two with me.'' The lady is a monster, and it seems likely that Mr. Sutherland is about to be devoured on the spot.

title: NEW FRONTS OPEN IN SEX-ED BATTLE
description: TRENTON NEW fronts in the state's sex-education battle opened last week, with Roman Catholic bishops and the Moral Majority in opposite camps. One anti-sex education bill has just been released by an Assembly committee and is ready for a floor vote; a second will be introduced soon in that house.

title: Roslyn Restaurant's Choice of a Name
description: I would like to correct any misconceptions about the naming of a small restaurant in the Village of Roslyn (Dining Out, March 1). First, let it be known that the ''local historic society'' has absolutely nothing to do with the naming of restaurants or the placement of signs within Roslyn Village.

title: Wisconsin in Title Game
description: Wisconsin continued its climb in the the National Collegiate hockey tournament last night with a 5-1 victory over Northern Michigan in the semifinals at the Duluth Arena. The victory set up a championship game against Minnesota tonight.

title: Q. WHAT IS THIS ALL ABOUT, ANYWAY?
description: Q. ARE you asked dumb questions? Do you ask dumb questions? A. Yes and no, but the following are some of the best.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: J. Erica Sack Wed To Robert Wiesen
description: J. Erica Sack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett Sack of Upper St. Clair, Pa., was married yesterday in Mount Lebanon, Pa., to Robert A. Wiesen, son of Dr. Leo E. Wiesen of Valley Stream, L.I., and the late Irene Wiesen. Rabbi Mark Mahler performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel.

title: Brooklyn Shouldn't Go For Division I Status
description: To The Sports Editor: As an alumnus of Brooklyn College, I would have been excited under normal circumstances about the college's planned move into Division I in the National Collegiate Athletic Association. It is an opportunity to achieve national recognition and instill pride in what has typically been a student body devoid of school spirit.

title: PHIL M. M'NAGNY Jr.
description: Federal District Judge Phil M. McNagny Jr. died today after a long illness. He was 56 years old. Mr. McNagny had been Federal District judge for the Northern District of Indiana since 1976. A native of Fort Wayne, Ind., he was an assistant United States Attorney from 1953 to 1955, a United States Attorney from 1955 to 1959 and a partner in a Columbia City law firm from 1960 to 1976.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: YONKERS THE weather is warming up, the trees are budding along the highways and the Movin' Steady Van Club is about to live up to its name. They've been gathering all winter at their storefront social center on Ashburton Avenue, and they've visited clubs in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, but now is the time for the real action - the outings to local parks and far away van festivals, the convoys that look like official processions coming down the road.

title: FARMERS RESIGNED ON PRICE SUPPORTS
description: Farmers in this tranquil dairy country and in other major milk producing states have become the first special interest group to have its ox gored by Washington budget balancing, but they appear to be taking it in stride.

title: TO JANIS, IT'S CLASSICAL THAT'S POPULAR
description: HOW are audiences attuned to Paul Anka and Joan Rivers responding to the Wurttemberg Chamber Orchestra and the Vienna Choir Boys? After tomorrow night's recital by the pianist Byron Janis, the last event in the first classical-music series at the Westbury Music Fair, the results will be in.

title: Whats Doing in Columbus, Ohio
description: THURBER'S TOWN - James Thurber made millions laugh and himself famous in part by mining experiences gained in the Ohio state capital, now a city of 562,000. Thurber, who died in 1961 and whose ashes are buried in Columbus's Greenlawn Cemetery, grew up in a turnof-the-century town where people rode trolleys, endured summers on wide porches and attended picnics. The fragile second son of a government clerk played, read and began drawing forever-childlike sketches in homes and schools just east and south of downtown Columbus.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 23 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 2 2 7 BRAIN, by Robin Cook. (Putnam's, $11.95.) A young physician copes with a conspiracy of medical researchers who steal young women's brains to create an artificial intelligence. 3 5 6 CENTURY, by Fred Mustard Stewart. (Morrow, $13.95.) Saga of an Italian-American family. 4 3 11 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) A fantastic tale about the Sun, the Moon and a lost treasure. 5 11 3 THE COMPANY OF WOMEN, by Mary Gordon. (Random House, $12.95.) One modern young woman's experience with the manners and mores of Roman Catholicism. 6 4 14 ANSWER AS A MAN, by Taylor Caldwell. (Putnam's, $12.95.) A man who has made it big in early 20th-century America struggles against the corruption that engulfs his life. 7 6 27 THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $12.95.) German espionage in Cairo during the desert campaigns of 1942.

title: The Hard Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Are Pulling For Pacers and 76ers
description: Uncertainty over whether the Knicks will meet the Indiana Pacers or the Chicago Bulls in the opening round of the National Basketball Association playoffs this week has kept Butch Beard chasing the potential rivals around the country.

title: Salvador Aid Grows; So Does Opposition
description: Mail opposing more United States arms for El Salvador was piled high on his desk last week when Representative Silvio O. Conte, Republican of Massachusetts, voted for $5 million more in military aid. The request, for this fiscal year, passed a House appropriations subcommittee by an 8-to-7 vote; under Congressional rules, no higher approval is required.

title: Gayle Garland Sets Nuptials on May 16
description: Mr. and Mrs. G. Gray Garland Jr. of Pittsburgh, Ligonier, Pa., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gayle Imogen Scott Garland, to William Howard Simpson, son of Willis Graham Simpson also of Pittsburgh, and the late Ruth Keally Simpson.

title:
Gardening;
WILLOWS, THE EARLY SPRING BLOOMS
description: ONE of the more unpleasant things to taste is the aspirin that fails to go down on the first swallow. Were you to chew on a willow twig, you would find that it tastes much the same. The reason is that the willow is the source of salicin, the basic ingredient in aspirin and related painkillers. One Old World species, the shrubby Purple Osier, Salix purpurea, is still used as a source of the drug. The generic name for willows, salix, is the source of the word salicin and derivatives such as sodium acetylsalicilate, once widely used in advertising as a well-known painkiller.

title: LUXURY-TOWER BUILDERS TURNING INTO CONDOMINIUMS
description: For first time in the history of the city, most of new luxury housing projects that are beginning to take shape are condominiums, not rentals or cooperatives.

title: DEMOCRATS, STILL DEFENSIVE, HOPE TO GENERATE OFFENSE
description: In the 1930's, in the midst of the Great Depression, public opinion supported a shift of power away from private industry and toward Government. In the 1980's, with Government in disrepute, widely regarded as fat and wasteful, many Americans apparently favor a shift away from Washington.

title: TAP SHOES SCORES IN FLAMINGO
description: Tap Shoes, whose trainer was changed, whose stride was straightened and who got over a bad skin rash last winter, passed Well Decorated with an eighth of mile to go today and won the $178,000 Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah Park.

title: Sound; TESTING A FAD- THE WATER CURE FOR DISKS
description: I n the days of my youth, a German quack named Sebastian Kneipp had mustered a sizable following for his belief in the curative and prophylactic powers of cold water. In consequence, I was compelled to take cold showers in the morning at a tender age and in all seasons. Whether my health was thereby improved is uncertain. In other respects my reaction was clearly negative. The cold showers made me deeply doubtful of Dr. Kneipp and thus predisposed me to skepticism.

title: Powerboat Racer Killed in Crash
description: A two-time national champion in offshore powerboat racing was killed today in a freakish accident during a warmup period for the Halter 200.

title: A PROGNOSIS FOR DOOMSDAY
description: WASHINGTON IN both the United States and the Soviet Union, military strategists have suggested with increasing frequency that nuclear war can be won, with enough population left on the victorious side to continue life. Last week, nearly 100 leading medical doctors, meeting at an international conference in Virginia, delivered a unanimous, though unsolicited, second opinion on the matter.

title: RECENT HOME SALES
description: Eatontown 76 Sandspring Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath Colonial $103,000 Fireplace, central air-conditioning. Taxes: $1,565 Fair Haven 539 River Road 5-bedroom, 1-bath Colonial $79,900 Beamed ceiling, country kitchen.

title: Suffolk Pops Up; With a Bottle Law
description: Since 1972, six states have swapped the seductive convenience of throwaway bottles and cans for the cleaner parks and streets that tend to result when beverage container deposits are made mandatory. Last week, Suffolk County legislators passed their own containerdeposit bill in what was widely viewed as an attempt to nudge Albany in the same direction.

title:
ANTIQUES;
ARCADE YIELDS A LODE OF FURNISHINGS
description: CHATHAM TOWNSHIP A SHOP containing a good mix of formal and country antique furnishings is hidden away in an arcade at the Hickory Square Shopping Center here.

title: HOW FAIR IS WELFARE?
description: T HE other shoe has fallen. Every day people are discovering that the Reagan budget cuts may affect them personally. Newspaper stories are getting very precise about who loses student loans, food stamps and other benefits. As a result, the mood is changing in the country and the enthusiasm for the Reagan program, though still strong, is waning significantly.

title:
AROUND THE NATION;
Tough New Address
description: Whatever her record as an administrator, Mayor Jane M. Byrne's flair for the dramatic is frequently top-notch. Last week she announced that she and her husband would temporarily set up housekeeping in Cabrini Green, a bitterly poor - and extraordinarily violent - public housing project on Chicago's Near North Side.
