Last week she announced that she and her husband would temporarily set up housekeeping in Cabrini Green, a bitterly poor - and extraordinarily violent - public housing project on Chicago's Near North Side.

title: No Headline
description: There was an error in Mike Norman's otherwise very fine story on the Sithavady family: It was the Sithavadys, and not myself, who brought up the issue of birth control. We acted as facilitators, no more.

title: Art; SMALL SCULPTURES GROW INTO GIANTS
description: HEMPSTEAD MEGALOMANIA is one of the maladies currently afflicting the art world. Many artists sternly believe that for the work to be better it must be bigger. Greater size is grander effect.

title: BURT REYNOLDS: GOING BEYOND MACHO
description: Last year, in the film ''Rough Cut,'' a dapper, tuxedoed Burt Reynolds, playing a jewel thief, attempted to charm rival thief Lesley-Anne Down with a witty vocal burlesque of Cary Grant. It was an apt device, since Reynolds intended ''Rough Cut'' to help him become, as he has wryly put it, ''the sort of unsophisticated Cary Grant of the 1980's.''

title: 'Patience' Set for April 14
description: The Gilbert and Sullivan Society's April 14 meeting will be held at the Community Church, 40 East 35th Street, between Park and Madison Avenues.

title: AT THE HELM OF A CHARITY EMPIRE
description: Traditionally, the president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York has been a man and, if possible, a very prominent man - preferably a captain of industry or a financial wizard. Past presidents have included Felix M. Warburg, Arthur Lehman, Judge Joseph M. Proskauer, Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, Gustave L. Levy and Irving Mitchell Felt.

title: GLEN COVE STIRRED BY TOWN HOUSE PLAN
description: GLEN COVE ACONTROVERSIAL proposal to build 328 town house condominiums on a 24-acre tract on Garvies Point has this North Shore community choosing sides.

title: INDIAN SPICE JAR: GOSSIP AND THE GANDHIS
description: For the columnists, editors, partygoers and social climbers who feed India's voracious appetite for gossip, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, her family and her aides are a richer source than even the film community of Bombay. All the juicy rumors of court politics are passed from wedding receptions to embassy gatherings, attracting the attention of industrialists and cab drivers alike. Often the tidbits emerge in the tabloids and then percolate into the weeklies and monthlies, gaining exposure, if not credibility.

title: BAY HEAD BEACH-RIGHTS CASE TO BE ARGUED
description: TOMS RIVER A SUPERIOR COURT judge will hear arguments here Tuesday in a longstanding suit in which the state has alleged that oceanfront property owners in the Borough of Bay Head have illegally excluded nonresidents from their private beaches.

title:
Gardening;
WILLOWS, THE EARLY SPRING BLOOMS
description: ONE of the more unpleasant things to taste is the aspirin that fails to go down on the first swallow. Were you to chew on a willow twig, you would find that it tastes much the same. The reason is that the willow is the source of salicin, the basic ingredient in aspirin and related painkillers. One Old World species, the shrubby Purple Osier, Salix purpurea, is still used as a source of the drug. The generic name for willows, salix, is the source of the word salicin and derivatives such as sodium acetylsalicilate, once widely used in advertising as a well-known painkiller.

title: GROWING UP BLACK
description: MARY By Mary E. Mebane. 242 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $12.95. By HARRY CREWS

title: HARTFORD'S TROUBLE IS LACK OF PRISONS
description: HARTFORD IN an effort to solve Connecticut's burgeoning crime problem, the Legislature last year enacted tough new rules for sentencing felons. With those rules set to take effect July 1, lawmakers here now face another problem. What is to be done with all those additional prisoners the rules are certain to generate?

title: 30 Food Establishments Called Health Violators
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 30 food establishments that it said violated the Health Code. The department also named six restaurants that had corrected earlier violations and reopened and three that had been closed for failing to do so. VIOLATIONS El Torrero Bar, 3888 Broadway. Moon Garden, 310 W. 58th St. Famous Dairy Restaurant, 222 W. 72d St. Lucky Restaurant, 504 W. 207th St. Golden Star Restaurant, 1380 E. Gun Hill Rd., Bronx. Casa Se Bana, 1460 Westchester Ave., Bronx. Three Corners Bar, 130 Westchester Square, Bronx. Labrador Restaurant, 760 E. 149th St., Bronx. Szechuan Plum, 1404 Cortelyou Rd., Brooklyn. Hurley's Bar, 1502 Cortelyou Rd., Brooklyn. Jimmy's Luncheonette, 1916 Church Ave., Brooklyn. Turkey Bar, 1916 Church Ave., Brooklyn. Fiesta Coffee Shop, 2016 Church Ave., Brooklyn. Italian Pizza Restaurant, 2523 Church Ave., Brooklyn. Four-Season Coffee Shop, 1212 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn. Orocobis Luncheonette, 654 Myrtle Ave., Brooklyn. Park Hill Restaurant, 210 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. Corrado Restaurant and Bar, 3915 First Ave.,Brooklyn. Nana's Pizza, 248 Fifth Ave., Brooklyn. Sabella Pizza, 915 E. 107th St., Brooklyn. Sandwich Board, 27-57 Jackson Ave., Queens. Tasty Donut, 58-02 Myrtle Ave., Queens.

title: Architecture View; 'LES REALISMES'- PARIS'S SUPERSHOW AS GRABBAG; Ada Louise Huxtable
description: The blockbuster exhibition called ''Les Realismes'' that has been packing them in at the Beaubourg in Paris since last December will close on April 30; after that it will move on to Berlin. The blockbuster has already become something of a Beaubourg tradition; ''Paris-New York'' and ''Paris-Moscow'' not only received deserved international acclaim, they also took the Beaubourg out of the category of architectural novelty and tourist attraction. In a sense, the building took on substance, proving once again that the meaning and value of architecture is as much concerned with what is contained as with the container itself.

title: TRANQUILIZER FOILS LIE-DETECTOR TESTS
description: A small dose of the widely used tranquilizer meprobamate allows people to lie without detection in polygraph, or lie-detector tests, according to a report in the journal Science.

title: FOOD STAMP BACKERS DRAFTING STRATEGY
description: All week Senate Democrats have been playing ''a rolling crap game,'' as one aide called it, trying to determine where they could restore money in President Reagan's trimmed-down budget. As the game reached its final stages, it looked as if the roll of the dice was going against the food stamp program.

title: A SECOND SECONDARY EDUCATION
description: HIGH SCHOOL By David Owen. 262 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $12.95.

title: HOUSE STUDY ASSAILS HERBICIDE ACTIONS
description: An unpublished staff report of the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations accuses the Veterans Administration, the Department of Defense, the Dow Chemical Company and a panel set up by President Carter of failures in dealing with the controversy over the defoliant Agent Orange.

title: AN ACTOR'S LIFE FOR THEM
description: THE QUALITY OF MERCY An Autobiography. By Mercedes McCambridge. Illustrated. 245 pp. New York: Times Books. $10.95.

title: Notes; THE THRIFT SEASON IN THE CARIBBEAN
description: With Easter arriving on April 19 this year, two weeks later than last, vacationers will have to wait a bit longer for the thrift season to begin in the Caribbean.

title: 553 SCHOOL DISTRICTS TO VOTE
description: DECLINING school enrollments, a loss of state aid, the difficulties of living with inflation under budget caps, additional state regulations and an increasing resistance of taxpayers to school budgets are some of the issues facing this year's Board of Education candidates as they seek election on April 7.

title: Ravenna
description: To the Editor:

title: Music:Debuts in Review; Peter Oundjian, Prize-Winning Violinist
description: Peter Oundjian did not seem to be making his debut recital at the Abraham Goodman House on Tuesday night. He seemed instead to be a master of the violin, comfortably displaying his prowess and musicianship for the audience that happened to crowd the hall.

title: PARADE TODAY
description: The Greek Independence Day Parade will take place todaybeginning at 1 P.M. Marchers will move north on Fifth Avenue from 61st Street to 79th Street, then turn east to Park Avenue.

title: MARAUDING PIRATES ON HIGH SEAS OF PUBLISHING
description: Five years ago, McGraw-Hill translated a diamond jubilee edition of ''Gregg Shorthand'' into Spanish for sale throughout Latin America. A fast-buck artist in Lima, Peru, bought a copy, paid a local printer to reproduce a cheap offset edition, then sold the pirated version to bookstores for a fraction of the original cost. ''He might never have been caught,'' said William Cusick, a McGraw-Hill lawyer, ''except that he had the gall to list himself on the title page as the author of the translation.''

title: Nancy Coyle Bride of Pilot
description: Nancy Wickes Washburn Coyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Coyle of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Lieut. Harold Joseph Mollomo, U.S.A.F., son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Mollomo of Boston.

title: Health Systems Agency's Role Described
description: The recent article ''Health Chief Chosen After Criticism'' depicted the Nassau-Suffolk Health Systems Agency as ''buffeted by internal criticism'' and liberally quoted the views of one disgruntled participant. Conspicuous by their absence were the viewpoints of the elected leadership of the agency or of the more than 500 other volunteers, representing every spectrum of Long Island's consumer, provider and governmental communities.

title: PRETORIA THREATENING TO SEIZE THE PASSPORT OF BISHOP TUTU AGAIN
description: The confiscation of Bishop Desmond M. Tutu's passport upon his return to South Africa because of comments he made during a trip to the United States would mark the second time in little more than a year that the authorities have seized the passport of the black Anglican Bishop.

title: Nancy O'Connor Fiancee of John Evans 4th
description: The engagement of Nancy O'Connor to John Joseph Evans 4th has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Joseph O'Connor of Glenmont, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans 3d of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Center Harbor, N.H.

title: COUPLE CRUSADE FOR THE NONSMOKER
description: ON a recent Sunday about 20 people from various parts of the state crowded into the small living room of the Bloomfield home of Kenneth and Renee Gere to listen to the latest about N.I.C.E.

title: MOVE TO SOUTH ISN'T ALL SUNNY
description: MIAMI DESPITE a sharp rise in crime here, onetime Long Islanders do not seem to regret their decision to move to balmier climes. This is not to say that they are unconcerned about the heavy increase in all categories of crime in southeastern Florida. They are - seriously. And, for the first time since they have migrated, many are taking the sort of precautions reminiscent of some crime-plagued areas of the North.

title: CHINA'S CATHOLICS: A NATION UNTO ITSELF MOVES TO MEET THE VATICAN
description: Pope John Paul II, who has based his globe-trotting pontificate on finely tuned diplomatic acumen and pastoral compassion, is going to face a severe test of those skills as he pursues his ''heartfelt longing'' for closer relations with Catholics in China.

title: Future Events April Eye-Openers
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:Prints for a PauseApril 1 -If warm weather makes you want to shed your heavy oil paintings for prints, you can have first pick tonight of some special ones for your walls at the Hirschl & Adler Galleries where ''America in Print'' opens with a 6 to 11 o'clock champagne party. The three-week exhibition offers 120 prints of paintings done between 1796 and 1940 by John James Audubon, Mary Cassatt, Childe Hassam, Winslow Homer and Maurice Prendergast, among others. Proceeds of the $50-a-ticket party, the $1 and $2 tickets on other days, and 10 percent of the $1,500 to $85,000 price for prints sold will be used by the Auxiliary of Lenox Hill Hospital to set up a centralized testing area for blood, X-ray and other tests required of patients upon admission for treatment. Tickets from 794-4507, or at the door.

title: TWO CHOREOGRAPHERS AT CITY CENTER
description: City Center will officially become two theaters on Wednesday when its intimate basement house, refurbished and renamed The Space, opens with a month-long Dance Umbrella Festival. While the Viola Farber Dance Company is inaugurating The Space and the Festival with the first of a week of Farber performances, the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company will begin a five-performance season in the upstairs theater. It's a coincidence, of course, of physical proximity. Miss Farber and Mr. Lubovitch are unmistakably individual choreographers.

title: Reagan Mail Opposes Involvement
description: President Reagan's mail has been running 96 percent against United States involvement in El Salvador, the White said today. A spokesman said the White House had opened 7,224 pieces of mail on El Salvador. He said 6,939 were against American involvement and 285 were for it.

title:
ART;
'ODD IMAGES MARK NEW CANAAN SHOW
description: NEW CANAAN THE Webb & Parsons Art Gallery here is mounting an exhibition of the work of Jim Sullivan and Marie-Louise Paulson through April 4, and, if you want to see what is most fashionable in the art world at the moment, you should find your way there.

title: THE TOAST OF PARIS
description: NAKED AT THE FEAST A Biography of Josephine Baker. By Lynn Haney. Illustrated. 338 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $17.95.

title: CLUB WHERE HE BEGAN IN POLITICS IS SPLIT OVER A 2D TERM KOCH
description: Carol Greitzer stood at the meeting of the Village Independent Democrats to speak up for Edward I. Koch, and momentarily the years rolled away. How could the club where the Mayor had started in politics abandon the man who had helped defeat Carmine G. De Sapio, who long controlled the party in Greenwich Village, the city and the state?

title: ENERGY: HOW HAWAII USES THE WIND, THE SUN AND THE SEA
description: HONOLULU A T mention of Hawaii, one thinks of sunshine, trade winds, warm seas, volcanos and verdant foliage. These assets, which have made tourism the state's main industry and economic base, have become valuable in another way, as a source of alternative energy to replace oil. According to Howard C. Wiig, chief analyst and energy officer of the State Department of Planning and Economic Development, Hawaii not only leads all the other states in projects to extract electricity from sun, wind, sea water, volcanic heat and plant life, but is ''a laboratory for the world'' in this field.

title: COACHLIGHT PRESENTS NEW 'BABES IN ARMS'
description: ''BABES IN ARMS,'' a hit in 1937, told the story of a group of youngsters, children of vaudevillians, who were left behind on Long Island while their parents were on tour. Faced with the threat of work camp, the youngsters staged a show to save themselves. The score offered five Rodgers and Hart classics: ''My Funny Valentine,'' ''Where or When,'' ''Johnny One-Note,'' ''I Wish I Were in Love Again,'' and ''The Lady Is a Tramp.''

title: Film View; WHAT THE OSCARS ARE OVERLOOKING
description: So far this year we've sat through the annual telecast of the Golden Globe awards, where there seems to be a prize for anyone who shows up. We've also slumbered our way through the telecast of the awards presented by the film critics of the Los Angeles area, an affair that always fascinates their Eastern colleagues, not one of whom has ever had the ineffable pleasure of hearing his own luminous prose - in praise of this or that film, performance, special effect or junk tune - read at such sonorous length on national television.

title: HIJACKERS FORCE INDONESIAN PLANE WITH 57 TO THAILAND
description: Seven armed assailants demanding the release of 20 Indonesian prisoners hijacked an Indonesian airliner yesterday with 57 people aboard and forced the pilot to land here. Early this morning Thai officials announced that President Suharto of Indonesia had agreed to the hijackers' demand.

title: MESSAGES FROM A DIVIDED MAN
description: ERNEST HEMINGWAY: SELECTED LETTERS 1917-1961. Edited by Carlos Baker. 948 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $27.50.

title: TESTING A FAD- THE WATER CURE FOR DISKS
description: I n the days of my youth, a German quack named Sebastian Kneipp had mustered a sizable following for his belief in the curative and prophylactic powers of cold water. In consequence, I was compelled to take cold showers in the morning at a tender age and in all seasons. Whether my health was thereby improved is uncertain. In other respects my reaction was clearly negative. The cold showers made me deeply doubtful of Dr. Kneipp and thus predisposed me to skepticism.

title: 5 TOWNS SCHOOL PLAN STIRS BOARD FIGHT
description: LAWRENCE AHEATED fight for election to a key position on the Lawrence School Board has resulted from a community controversy over the proposed school-district reorganization plan.

title: Susana Duncan Betrothed to Peter Mezan
description: The engagement of Susana Grace Duncan, daughter of Mrs. William L.J. Duncan of Coombe Mead, England, and the late Major Duncan, British Army, to Peter Bruce Mezan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Mezan of Stamford, Conn., has been announced. A late spring wedding is planned.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: DETAILS GIVEN ON COPTER JAILBREAK
description: Evidence allegedly linking an Atlanta man with the hijacking of a helicopter in the attempted rescue of a drug dealer from a Federal detention center in Manhattan last January was revealed in United States District Court yesterday.

title: Art View; DAVID- A TALENTED FANATIC
description: The career of the French painter Jacques-Louis David (1748-1825) was one of the most amazing and perplexing in the entire history of European art. At 24, he decided - how seriously, we cannot know -to let himself die of hunger because of his failure that year to win the coveted Prix de Rome. (It wasn't until his fourth attempt that the artist now recognized as the greatest of the Neo-Classical painters finally did win it.) At 35, he suddenly emerged as the most esteemed painter of his generation - a hero of the Salon who, on the basis of his spectacular artistic achievement, was given lodgings in the Louvre on orders from the King of France. Yet 10 years later, in 1793, as a Deputy to the National Convention, David cast his vote for the execution of this same sovereign - an action that gives him, among the painters we now admire, a certain distinction, to say the least.

title: A Question of a School And Rye Development
description: In the Westchester Weekly (''Rye's 'Border War,' '' March 8), Eleanor Charles correctly pointed out that the Town of Rye is trying to attract commercial development, presumably to defray a very heavy tax burden on the homeowners in the unincorporated portion of the Town of Rye. Why are taxes in the unincorporated portion of the Town of Rye so high? Could it be that Rye Town chose to build its own high school rather than to send its children to the high school in the incorporated portion of the Town of Rye? The Blind Brook School District may well be the only school district in the state of New York that contains no stores, no gas stations, no anything except single-family private homes. The situation in which Rye Town finds itself is wholly its own doing. LAURENCE G. COLE Port Chester

title: REAGAN AIDE CONCEDES PROPOSAL ON WELFARE COULD ADD PROBLEM
description: President Reagan's budget cuts would reduce the financial incentive for those on welfare to find work to an extent that planners had not anticipated, an Administration budget official acknowledged yesterday.

title: Census Bureau Meets Deadline
description: Meeting its deadline six days ahead of schedule, the Census Bureau this week finished giving the 50 states the data each needs to accomplish electoral redistricting. Files went out to California and Illinois on Thursday, the bureau said, completing a process begun Feb. 23.

title: Leisure; IT'S TIME TO FEED, WEED AND MOW
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robert D. Emmons is associate professor of Plant Sciences, SUNY, Cobleskill, N.Y. By ROBERT D. EMMONS

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: The Visible Empire In Connecticut
description: The scene was reminiscent of the civil rights marches of the 1960's: Protesters, determined to exercise their constitutional rights, take to the streets, only to be pelted by the rocks and bottles of counterdemonstrators. The marchers in Meriden, Conn., though, were robed and hooded members of the Invisible Empire, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, and last week, completing the ironic parellel, they demanded that their assailants be prosecuted under Federal civil rights laws.

title: JAIL-CROWDING STUDY CITES JUSTICE SYSTEM
description: THE major cause of severe overcrowding at the county jail is Westchester's system of criminal justice rather than an increase in crime, according to a study by the Center for Justice Planning, an independent consulting group based in Illinois.

title: Follow-Up on the News; 'Lethal' Radiation
description: When 38-year-old Douglas Crofut was admitted to St. Francis Hospital in Tulsa, Okla., his ''left nipple was gone,'' there was ''raw bleeding'' in his left arm and upper torso, and he was suffering from ''destroyed bone marrow,'' according to the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission. It said the unemployed radiographer had received a rare and probably lethal dose of radioactivity from iridium 192.

title: TOWARD A 'NEUTRAL ROLE FOR OSHA
description: As the new administrator of the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration, Thorne G. Auchter stepped into a political thicket last week. In actions that labor called ''shocking,'' he ordered the destruction of 100,000 booklets about cotton dust, a cause of brown lung disease in textile workers, and withheld distribution of several films and slide shows about workers' health and safety rights and the dangers of cotton dust and acrylonitrile, a vinyl compound.

title: NEW YORK CITY NURSING HOMES PREPARING FOR A WALKOUT
description: Facing a possible strike Wednesday by 12,000 nursing-home workers, proprietors of homes throughout New York City have begun emergency preparations to insure the safety and care of patients.

title: OCCULT CLASSES DRAW CROWDS
description: IN 1956, 45 adults assembled in a classroom in a Pompton Lakes public school to hear Son Yott discuss ''occult metaphysics.'' The subject was so popular that Mr. Yott had to trade the classroom for an auditorium to accommodate the crowd.

title: Harriet McLaren Is Bride in Bedford
description: Harriet Lamb McLaren and Parker Waite Silzer Jr. were married yesterday in St. Mathew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Arthur Hargate, rector emeritus, performed the ceremony.

title: FARMING CONNECTICUT STYLE
description: ''I'M going to The Book Barn to buy a few books,'' I told my husband one recent morning. ''Good,'' he replied. ''Why not meet me for lunch at The Chicken Coop?''

title: VIDAL'S 5TH CENTURY B.C.
description: CREATION By Gore Vidal. 510 pp. New York: Random House.$15.95.

title: Civil Service Union Head Subject of Budget Inquiry
description: The president of a New York City local of the Civil Service Employees Association is the subject of an inquiry by the union's leadership in Albany into allegations that he overspent the local's budget.

title: Television Week
description: PAGE 3 THE GUIDE BLAU

title: Judge Dismisses Indictment Of Police Chief in Louisville
description: Federal charges of obstruction of justice against a suspended police chief, Jon Higgins, and a convicted gambler, Luther James, were dismissed today.

title: PHILADELPHIA ADAPTS TO LIFE WITHOUT PUBLIC TRANSIT
description: Charles Kraus was shepherding the last of his contingent of 2,100 coaches and guests from the Sheraton Hotel here onto bright yellow school buses for a trip to the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament at the Spectrum.

title: SWAN AND STEARNS WORK AGAINST CARDS
description: For the first time in eight months, the New York Mets used their No. 1 battery today in a test of injured stars: Craig Swan pitching and John Stearns catching.

title: U. OF MIAMI, PLANNING CHANGES, NAMES NEW HEAD
description: With the selection of a new president, the University of Miami is moving to overhaul and improve its educational programs and to increase its participation in the public affairs of the Miami area.

title: TRUMP DENIED TAX ABATEMENT FOR FIFTH AVE. TOWER
description: The city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development has denied the developer Donald Trump a tax abatement worth $20 million over a 10-year period for his apartment and office tower on the site of the old Bonwit Teller building in midtown Manhattan.

title: The Other Thomas Takes Over
description: Indiana appeared to be in trouble. The Hoosiers were leading Louisiana State, 36-30, early in the second half today, but their all-America guard, Isiah Thomas, suddenly committed his fourth personal foul, prompting Coach Bobby Knight to remove him and insert the other Thomas, James, also a sophomore.

title:
Camera;
DIFFERENT WAYS TO DEPICT MOTION IN STILL PICTURES
News Summary; SUNDAY, MARCH 29, 1981
description: International Talks between Solidarity and Polish Government officials made some progress but there was no breakthrough that would prevent a general strike scheduled Tuesday to protest attacks by the police on members of the independent union movement. The atmosphere at the three-hour session in Warsaw was described as good. One of the crucial issues is that the Government has not acknowledged that the police attacked unionists in Bydgoszcz. (Page 1, Column 6.) Achieving Namibia's independence is one of the aims of an American diplomatic mission that will be sent by the Administration to southern Africa to reassure black African leaders of its concern with finding an internationally acceptable formula for ending South Africa's control of Namibia, also known as South-West Africa. Other major problems in southern Africa will also be studied by the mission. Administration officials said that a formal annnouncement would come soon from the White House, perhaps tomorrow, that the mission would be headed by Chester A. Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State-designate for African Affairs. (1:5.)

title: Poland's Fever Surges Toward A Critical Point
description: After seven months in the shadow of the rumbling volcano, Poland's experiment in union democracy seemed closer than ever to going the way of Pompeii. Under enormous pressure, the political cracks were widening and the next few days were likely to be crucial. The Communist Party Central Committee scheduled an emergency meeting for today, a general strike was planned for Tuesday, Warsaw Pact military maneuvers inside and adjoining Poland were extended indefinitely and shoppers went on a panic-buying binge. Nationwide food rationing will begin on Wednesday.

The land is mostly flat, the chateaus are relatively small and the estates modest in size, with an average planting of only about 11 acres.

According to the Audit Bureau of Circulations for the six months ended June 1980, Time had an average circulation of 4,451,816, of which single-copy sales accounted for 296,527. Newsweek's figures for the same period were 2,952,515, including single-copy sales of 230,400.

description: Pope John Paul II said today in a letter to Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the Primate of Poland, that the Polish people have an ''undeniable right'' to solve their problems alone.

title: BRAZIL'S LIBERALIZING POLICY SURVIVES SCARE
description: The liberalization policy of President Joao Baptista Figueiredo has survived a hardline military protest that prompted concern that a right-wing attempt to halt its progress was under way.

title: Children's Books
description: THE TWITS By Roald Dahl. Illustrated by Quentin Blake. 76 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $6.95. (Ages 8 to 11) By KARLA KUSKIN

description: GARDEN CITY ON this campus of old military barracks and stark new buildings, the results of four separate investigations into the financial practices of some administrators of Nassau Community College are expected to mark the end of one phase in the short life of the school and the dawn of another.

title: A FUGITIVE GREEK PUBLISHER CELEBRATES COURT VICTORIES
description: George Kouris, the publisher of the Athens newspaper Avriani, celebrated one and a half victories Friday. The total victory, he said, was a decision by the Council of State, Greece's highest court, invalidating a law that had forced him to triple the price of his paper. The half victory was an appeals court action overturning his brother's conviction on charges of disseminating false information about the Government's alleged mismanagement of a $5 million gift.

title: CITY OPERA: 'FALSTAFF' IN CALDWELL PRODUCTION
description: Verdi's ''Falstaff'' has a nimble charm and underyling wisdom that are nearly always welcome, and Friday evening's performance of the work, when it rejoined the New York City Opera repertory, had many attractive elements. Sarah Caldwell's production has a basic sense to it, even if the scenery of Helen Pond and Herbert Senn isn't very stylish. And the cast was a decently strong one.

title: Sheila Leah Epstein Is Married
description: The marriage of Sheila Leah Epstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Epstein of Kings Point, L.I., to David J. Spicehandler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ammiel Spicehandler of Lawrence, L.I., took place yesterday at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Ezra Spicehandler, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony. The bride is marketing manager of Almay Inc., a cosmetics manufacturer in New York. Mr. Spicehandler is internal auditor of the New York Health and Racquet Club.

title: The Agony of El Salvador
description: Raymond Bonner's article ''The Agony of El Salvador,'' (Feb. 22) laid out most of the facts, but failed to ask a crucial question: Why does the United States keep seeing an international Communist conspiracy behind every popular opposition movement against a rightwing, repressive, military dictatorship or government? Maybe the peasants of El Salvador are simply tired of being raped, tortured and murdered by their Government's security and military forces - while suffering malnutrition, illiteracy and poverty in the bargain.

title: Nina S. Broad Engaged To Anthony S. Borwick
description: Nina Susan Broad of New York, director of East Coast development for Lily Tomlin's production company, and Anthony Stephen Borwick of Washington, chief counsel for litigation for the General Services Administration, plan to be married in Washington May 3.

title: Uppercut by Spinks Stops Johnson in Fourth Round
description: Michael Spinks, the top-ranked light-heavyweight contender, showed deceptive strength and knocked out Marvin Johnson, the two-time champion, with a vicious short left uppercut in the fourth round of their scheduled 10-rounder today.

description: THE NEW YORK TIMES MAGAZINE/PART 2 MARCH 29,1981 --------------------------------------------------------------------- 33 LOOSENING UP FOR SUMMER By Jeffrey Miller The warmer months call for a more relaxed approach to dressing, and this spring, American designers are suggesting combining the classics in ways that reflect this attitude. --------------------------------------------------------------------- 43 SUITED FOR SUMMER Dark-toned suits help a man stay cool and still look correct for warm-weather business in the city.

title: WHY WE SHOULDN'T BUILD THE MX
description: Stansfield Turner, a retired admiral and former director of the Central Intelligence Agency in the Carter Administration, is writing a book on military strategy, lecturing and consulting. By Stansfield Turner The changing balance of strategic nuclear forces between the United States and the Soviet Union has in the last few years been a major focus of attention for the American intelligence community. Until the late 1960's, the United States was militarily stronger than the Soviet Union by virtue of its superior nuclear arsenal. We felt secure. The Soviets didn't, and they set out to correct the imbalance. The result has been that in the last several years all of the best studies have shown that the balance of strategic nuclear capabilities has been tipping in favor of the Soviet Union. It is not easy for the layman to gather enough information to make a judgment, but a careful study of the evidence shows that we do deserve to be worried. Even if the perception that there has been a change in the balance were, to some extent, overstated, that perception itself could damage the position, authority and role of the United States in world affairs. The perception as well as the fact must be redressed so that the Soviet Union sees no advantage in using its nuclear arsenal against us.

title: Archbishop of Detroit Named
description: The Most Rev. Edmund C. Szoka, Bishop of the Diocese of Gaylord, Mich., has been named Archbishop of Detroit by Pope John Paul II. Bishop Szoka, 53 years old, succeeds Cardinal John F. Dearden, who resigned last July for health reasons.

description: The North American Soccer League kicked off its 15th season last night with a distinctly different look; three of last year's 24 franchises have folded and four others have relocated.

title: PLAN TO SHIFT POPULAR PRINCIPAL CLOUDS OPENING OF NEW SCHOOL
description: When the 2,900 students of Eastern District High School in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn move into a long-awaited new building on Wednesday, their principal may not be going with them - a situation that has drawn sharp criticism from parents, community leaders and the High School Principals Assocation.

title: ZIONIST WARNING JEWS IN WEST OF HARD TIMES FOR ISRAEL
description: Israel is facing ''difficult times,'' including a growing effort to ''delegitimize'' it as a member of the world community, Arye Dulzin, chairman of the World Zionist Organization, is telling American Jews and Jews in other Western countries.

title: Moving Briskly; On Deregulation
description: Few campaign vows drew more cheers than Ronald Reagan's promise to make Big Government smaller. And in few areas has the Administration moved faster - from January's freeze on the 172 regulations written in the Carter Administration's final days to last week's initial report of the Task Force on Regulatory Relief.

title: LEARNING ROLE OF OMBUDSMAN, STUDENTS TACKLE BUREAUCRACY
description: PURCHASE ''OUR initial sense of the course was simply to open the students up to the kinds of ways in which one might actually bring about some genuine social change - perhaps on a small level,'' said Dr. Joseph Fashing, an associate professor of sociology at the State University of New York at Purchase. ''When the State Ombudsman Program appeared on the scene, and the Lieutenant Governor's office expressed an interest in locating here, it dovetailed neatly with the kinds of things we wanted to do.''

title:
ART;
AN EXHIBITION OF QUALITY AND HARMONY IN HASTINGS
description: QUITE a good exhibition of works by artists in Westchester County is on view until May 3 at the Gallery of Hastings-on-Hudson. Selected by a jury that had no knowledge of the identity of the artists whose work was being viewed, the show revealed a very interesting result of the process: It contains the work of only two men and seven women. Ironically, one of the men is the strongest artist in the show, although many of the works by the women are excellent as well.

title: The Forman Formula
description: I think Milos Forman tries to do his art as best he can and how he does it is absolutely his own business (''The Forman Formula,'' by Tom Buckley, March 1). As an actress, I also try to do my art as best I can, and I sometimes feel a lack of understanding on the part of those who might hire me to do it.

description: Vice President Bush today assailed liberals who oppose President Reagan's proposed budget cuts and singled out Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, for particular criticism.

title: D. W, Brockway to Wed Genevieve Houdry

Yet as the dollars from organized clubs and individual boosters subsidize student-athlete scholarships, new sports facilities and attractive coaching inducements, the role of the booster is causing serious problems for college administrators and the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

description: THE DEBUT By Anita Brookner. 192 pp. New York: The Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster. $11.95.

Regular haircuts, for example, are mandatory for a cool, neat appearance and, for good looks and good health, exercise is crucial.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
IN DUAL-CAREER FAMILY, A FATHER'S WORK IS NEVER DONE
description: LAST Friday was a more difficult day than usual: after a full morning in my office, I did the marketing and took the kids to the orthodontist. Then I had to prepare a special meal because we had invited my daughter's teacher for dinner. But somehow I managed. I did all my chores and even found time to hide out and read a bit before picking up my commuter at the station. I was feeling pretty pleased with myself until dinnertime, when I discovered that I had blown it after all: I had forgotten the appetizer! So much for careful planning and time-management - the amused look on my partner's face told me all I needed to know.

title: THE YANKEES' $20 MILLION GAMBLE
description: Phil Berger's novel, ''Big Man,'' will be published in the fall by Summit Books. By Phil Berger n the locker room of the Yankees' spring-training quarters in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., David Mark Winfield sits at his dressing cubicle, wearing a size 44 pin-stripe jersey and not much else. Around him, reporters, photographers and sportscasters mill, waiting for baseball's highest-paid player to go to work for the New York team.

description: To the Sports Editor: This year, the National Invitation Tournament had a chance to regain parity with the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, with the possible exception of the fabled Final Four. By its own admission, the N.C.A.A. did not field the top 48 college teams, but the N.I.T. once again seized second place.

title: Dining Out; ROBUST SAUCES ADAPTED FROM ITALY
description: THE charm of La Gondola in Williston Park is not immediately evident. What sets the small, fairly new Italian restaurant apart from so many ordinary places is the effort made with food and service.

title: Rogers's 68-208 Leads Golf by 3
description: After two balmy days that were flawless for golf, the third round of the Heritage Classic was buffeted today by strong winds that gusted and abruptly swirled into unfathomable changes of direction, causing scores to fly. There were only five subpar rounds among the field of 73 players.

title: FRANCE, 1, U.S., 0 IN RAIL RACE
description: THE figures read like lopsided basketball scores: France 132, New Jersey 79, and France 132, Connecticut 56. They represent the average passenger-train speeds, in miles per hour, that have been forecast on the completion of major construction projects in the busiest corridors of France and the United States.

title: Lori Gedon and Peter W. Pfeil to Be Married Aug. 29
description: Dr. and Mrs. Carl Gedon of Alpine, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Elizabeth Gedon, to Peter Walter Pfeil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pfeil of Zurich, Switzerland, formerly of Montclair, N.J. The marriage is planned for Aug. 29.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
THE REASON LEGAL SERVICES MUST BE SAVED
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S proposal that Congress disband the Legal Services Corporation has sent a tremor through the community of the poor in the county. If he is successful, the work of Westchester Legal Services, which receives 78 percent of its budget from the Legal Services Corporation, would be curtailed drastically.

title:
Art;
TRANSFORMING THE FAMILIAR INTO THE FOREIGN
description: ISLIP ANYONE who has ever taken a photograph - and that must be almost everyone - knows that the view through the lens is often a distorted one. The disparity between the experience of actual observation and the recording of that vision on film has been a preoccupation of both documentary and art photographers for decades, leading many to capitalize upon visual distortion as a means of heightening the subjective qualities they wish to communicate.

description: Kathleen Eve Statue and Locke Anderson Johnston, alumni of the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Prospect Heights Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Robert Glaser performed the ceremony.

title: THE STORY OF A SELF
description: A ROMANTIC EDUCATION By Patricia Hampl. 308 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $11.95.

description: New York City depends less on direct Federal aid for balancing its budget than 54 of the 57 largest cities in the United States. Only Sacramento, Calif., and Newark, N.J., rely less on direct Federal funds.

title: By SOVIET FATE IS LINKED TO POLAND
description: Poland's internal crisis last week confronted Soviet leaders once again with an agonizing decision. There is no easy answer for Moscow, no comfortable solution.

title: Retarded Woman to Get $35,000 As Settlement Over Sterilization
description: A mentally retarded woman who filed suit for $4 million on the ground that she was illegally sterilized as a teen-ager has agreed to a $35,000 settlement.

title: Practical Traveler; CHARTERING A BOAT IN THE CARIBBEAN
description: For about $115 a person a day during the spring and summer discount season, it is possible to charter a yacht that will take you and a companion into remote areas of the Caribbean with a crew that will do the sailing as well as prepare all meals, serve cocktails and canapes, in fact almost smother you with attention.

title: THE BIG PUSH IS ON TO MAKE GOVERNMENT WATCH ITS MONEY
description: In his drive to the White House, Ronald Reagan frequently railed against the sorry state of management in the Federal Government, using an evocative code phrase that seemed to embody all the evils that tighter management could eradicate - ''fraud, waste and abuse.''

title: REGULATING THE AUTO
description: The rate of myths per paragraph in William B. Johnston's ''How to Be a Better Regulator'' (March 22) puts Homer to shame. He characterizes a few modest proposals of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in January (tire pressure warnings, more comfortable seat belts, consumer information on crash test performance, and soft front ends for pedestrian protection) as an ''orgy of rule-making.''

title: Crime

title: CRAFTS
description: FAR HILLS A SUBSTANTIAL collection of new sculptural work in clay by Sy Shames of Basking Ridge is on display at the Signatures Gallery here. The gallery, whose name is intended to indicate that only original signed pieces are exhibited, was opened last fall by John Faccidomo, a sculptor, and his wife, Gail. Their policy - to show contemporary work in craft media concurrently with painting and sculpture - is well supported by a bright, informal setting in a renovated store building.

title: A CARIBBEAN SAMPLER: THREE HOLIDAYS IN THE SUN
description: It looked like a country road but actually it was a main road between the French and Dutch sides of St. Martin. Resplendent in white uniforms, a half-dozen officials from the French side marched along the road toward the boundary while a similar group, in civilian clothes, walked toward the border from the Dutch side.

title: School Yard Test For New Jersey's Tough 'Shield Law'
description: It was the kind of story young reporters dream about, a front page exclusive about a drug dealer, identified only as the ''Candy Man,'' who sold ''pot, speed, 'ludes and black beauties'' to any student with the money, even fourth-graders.

title: STATE WILL STOCK HOUSATANIC
description: FLY fishermen are delighted, they say, with the announcement last week that the state will stock the upper Housatonic River with 12,000 brown trout early next month.

title: GATEWAY PLAN SURPRISES OFFICIALS IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal to divest itself of the Gateway National Recreation Area drew expressions of surprise and disdain yesterday from Congressmen, state and local political leaders and officials of the park itself.

title: BYRNE SIGNS 2 BILLS TO HELP THE ELDERLY
description: Two bills designed to help the elderly were signed into law last Thursday by Governor Byrne, who, two days earlier, had told 800 people at the Governor's Conference on Aging that the problems of the elderly "have to fit into the mosaic" of other problems dealt with by government.

title: HE'S KEPT PACE WITH AMERICA'S MORES, ALMOST
description: LOS ANGELES This Tuesday, a man who has made a career of being sensitive to the changing mores of American society will retire. After 39 years with the National Broadcasting Company, Jack Petry is officially leaving the post he has held since 1970 as the network's West Coast director of broadcast standards.

title: TRACING THE ART OF CHINESE POTTERS
description: One thousand years ago, the potters of Northern China began turning clay into some remarkable wine jars, pillows, bowls, dishes, vases and incense burners - everyday utensils for household or temple use that were common once but are most uncommon now. These artisans settled not far from Peking in southern Hopei Province - an area that was ideal for a successful stoneware operation.

title: AN OLD BIAS CASE IS REAGAN'S FIRST
description: In the case of Statesville, N.C., the Reagan Justice Department -- whose leaders profess a dislike of numerical quotas in employment discrimination cases --inherited an all but wrapped-up investigation.

title: RED GROOMS RESHAPES HIS LOONY WORLD
description: ''It's a museum piece,'' says Red Grooms, pointing to a garbage can so beat up that it looks like a Red Grooms drawing of one. ''A great battered can we picked up on Elizabeth Street, to use as a model. The classic kind, with this rim. You couldn't find that uptown.''

title: IT'S REALLY A CASE OF AUTO- SUGGESTION
description: DURING these days of ever-increasing crime, we have all fallen victim at one time or another to an overwhelming sense of paranoia, as we are constantly bombarded by headlines and left wondering who will be the next victim.

title: HOSTAGES RELEASED FROM HONDURAN JET
description: The four hijackers of a Honduran airliner freed their hostages and surrendered tonight after flying here from Nicaragua.

title: China Gets a New; Script From Reagan

Though denied the role of foreign policy ''crisis manager,'' the Secretary of State prevailed on a substantive foreign policy issue and persuaded President Reagan to reassure Peking that the United States would not jeopardize ties with China by forging tighter links with Taiwan.

title: ALONE ON THE RANGE: THE VANISHING COWBOY
description: DENVER C OWBOYS are deserting Western ranches in droves, lured by the energy industry's eight-hour work days and wages of $10 to $15 an hour. Drilling for oil and gas and stripping coal seem to beat life on the range - living in camps, trailing herds and sleeping on the ground for weeks on end. For that, the pay runs from $400 to $800 a month plus room and board.

title:
DINING OUT;
ACCENT IN MONTCLAIR IS FRENCH, BUT -
description: AMERICANS do not often have the opportunity to taste good French bourgeois cooking, according to Monique Macary, a transplanted Parisienne. To rectify this, Mrs. Macary and her husband, Jean, opened a storefront restaurant in Montclair just over a year ago. It is called Le Petit Clos.

title: HAS GALLERIA ACHIEVED ITS GOALS?
description: LAST Aug. 4, the Galleria opened in White Plains, with only half of its mall tenants in operation and only one of its two anchor stores, Abraham & Straus, functioning. Since then, the huge center, the largest enclosed urban shopping mall introduced into the metropolitan area in years, has been the subject of considerable speculation, doubt, questions and curiosity. The other anchor store, the J. C. Penney store, has remained incomplete but is now scheduled to open in April.

title: 200 U.S. PUBLISHERS EXPECTED AT MOSCOW BOOK FAIR
description: Although the State Department turned down a request by the Association of American Publishers for $50,000 in public funds so that a cultural exhibition of about 3,500 books could be mounted at the Moscow Book Fair next September, an independent commercial company has come forward to fill the vacuum and enable American publishers to show and sell their books and periodicals.

title: Lawmaker Asks End to Cuba Ban
description: Representative George Crockett, Democrat of Michigan, called today for the United States to end its economic blockade of Cuba. Mr. Crockett, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, contended that as a result of the ban on trade, ''we have only further driven the revolution in Cuba toward the Soviet model.''

title: the hot item for summer 10&10
description: t is cool. It is comfortable and classic. And this year it is available in more colors and patterns from more designer and brandname sportswear lines than you can shake a mallet at.

title: Headliners; Worthy Opponents
description: Had he not been the victim, Ronald Biggs might have appreciated the daring of his kidnappers. The mastermind of Britain's Great Train Robbery was snatched from a bar in Rio de Janeiro and deposited last week with immigration officials in Bridgetown, Barbados, within the reach of British extradition. Mr. Biggs had been out of reach for 15 years, living openly in Brazil following his escape from prison two years into a 30-year sentence.

Hollowood, former editor of Punch 36

title: Chess; AN IMPROVED RUBINSTEIN
description: This year's victory in the 56th Hastings International Tournament by the Swedish grandmaster Ulf Andersson was his third straight in the traditional series. The 30-year-old end-game connoisseur tallied 10 1/2-4 1/2 to win the 1,000 first prize.

title: NORTHEAST RAIL PROJECT IS THREATENED
description: per-hour passenger-train speeds projected for railroads under construction in the busiest corridors of France and the United States.

The ordering period for 1981 United States proof sets opens Wednesday, and all signs point to the earliest sellout in years. It is possible, in fact, that the volume of orders may force the U.S. Mint to reduce the pre-announced limit even further - something that hasn't happened since 1968.

title: Cease-Fire in Beirut Ends A 16-Hour Bombardment
description: After 16 hours of heavy bombardment by rival Moslem and Christian factions, the guns fell silent here today as the two sides observed a midday cease-fire called by Syrian peacekeeping forces, the police reported. There was no official casualty count.

title: Face in the Crowd; Of Smiley's People
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher confirmed last week what devotees of British spy thrillers thought they already knew - that Moscow's moles once burrowed deep into British intelligence centers, not incidentally compromising secrets of their North American ''cousins.'' But these were ''events which occurred many years ago,'' Mrs. Thatcher said, putting down reports of past treachery serialized in London by The Daily Mail.

title: WHAT SHAPE FOR THE NEW FEDERALISM?
description: On the face of it, those who have been calling for basic reform in the American way of government should find much to cheer about in Ronald Reagan's ''New Federalism.'' Some of the President's proposals to cut the budget, consolidate and even eliminate some Federal programs and to turn back authority to the state and local governments mirror reforms many elected officials as well as scholars have been urging for years. But under the surface, many of the proposals now before Congress run counter in important respects to most of the reformers' plans for change - and to the policy of President Reagan's Republican predecessors. As a result, there is concern that the nation may wind up swapping old difficulties for new ones.

title: LIFE AS ELLINGTON'S SON WAS MOSTLY 'MOOD INDIGO'
description: As he lay dying in a New York hospital, Duke Ellington turned to his son, Mercer, and asked him to finish editing the tapes of the Third Sacred Concert. Although Mercer had long been a composer in his own right, it was the first time that Duke had ever really acknowledged his musical judgment, and his words of recognition were to be among his very last. Duke Ellington died several days later, and after more than 50 years in the shadow of his famous father, it seemed that Mercer was finally on his own.

title: Economists
description: To the Business Editor: In ''The Austrian Economy Is a Strauss Waltz'' (March 22) it was said that ''Wits explain Austria's economic success by saying it exported all its economists to the United States and Britain...Arthur Burns...Joseph Schumpeter, Ludwig von Mises and Gottfried Haberler, all currently with the American Enterprise Institute in Washington.''

title: Nancy Lipner, Jerry Kapchan To Be Married in September
description: The engagement of Nancy Greer Lipner to Jerry Stuart Kapchan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Kapchan of Eastchester, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Maxine Tobias of New Rochelle, N.Y. and Leonard Lipner of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: OUTBREAK OF REASON PRODUCES CONTRACT FOR COAL MINERS
description: Only two days before deadline and a half dozen sticky differences remaining, union and coal company negotiators last week found that the prospect of losses and the visions of gains wonderfully concentrated their minds. In five hours of overnight bargaining, they produced a new contract for the 160,000 miners who dig almost half the nation's coal and sent it to the fields for ratification.

title: GREEK CLERIC HOLDS OUT AGAINST NEW DIVORCE LAW
description: The 55 other bishops of the Greek Orthodox Church have reluctantly agreed to go along with a new law providing for what is known as "automatic divorce" in cases involving separation of at least seven years. But the 56th, the 73-year-old Bishop of Phlorina, continues to resist.

title: Children's Books
description: YOUNG MELVIN AND BULGER By Mark Taylor. Illustrated by Jan Brett. 44 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $7.95. (Ages 8 to 12) By JEAN FRITZ

title: James Coster Fiance Of Kathryn Leopold
description: The engagement of Kathryn Dawn Leopold to James Stanhope Coster has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Leopold of East Norwalk, Conn. Mr. Coster is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Coster of Westport, Conn.

title: SHOWING HIS COLORS
description: Every so often in our open society a public figure inadvertently displays his true character in a way that, once understood, can never be forgotten. It happened to Senator Joseph McCarthy when, cornered, he tried to distract the Army-McCarthy hearings by slandering a young lawyer. It happened the other day to Alexander Haig.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
A TRIAL OF MORE THAN A SENATOR
description: THOSE who live outside New Jersey often say that the state has an environment that breeds corrupt politicians. Whether that reputation is deserved or not, elections in the state too frequently end in victory for politicians whose subsequent conduct cannot withstand ethical or legal scrutiny.

title: CANADIANS INTENSIFY FIGHT ON CONSTITUTION
description: The Progressive Conservative Party is filibustering in the House of Commons. Eight of the 10 provincial premiers are desperately searching for agreement among themselves. An appeal is being made to the Supreme Court. The Government is alternately being urged to return to the negotiating table and challenged to hold an election.

title: British Journalist Opposes Inquiry Into Spy Articles
description: Chapman Pincher, the British journalist whose disclosures about possible Soviet penetration of Britain's intelligence services caused a furor this week, urged Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today not to conduct a witch hunt to learn where he had obtained his information.

title: WHEN OIL-PAINTED SIDING BEGINS TO PEEL
description: Older houses with wooden siding are often susceptible to persistent peeling of paint caused by moisture vapor trapped inside the walls. This moisture sometimes results from leaks or open joints in the outside walls, but more often than not it enters the hollow wall spaces as vapor, which is generated by high indoor humidity levels - especially in the winter, when doors and windows are sealed while normal bathing, washing and cooking add gallons of moisture to the confined air.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Price Slowdown is Coming

title: College Board Is Persuaded to Show and Tell
description: The wheels of change at the College Entrance Examination Board normally grind exceeding slow, but they have been considerably speeded up since last year, when New York adopted a ''truth in testing'' law. The law required the board to provide on request copies of college entrance examinations, answer sheets and a list of correct answers to students who had taken the exam. Last week, prodded by the case of a New York student who took advantage of the law and found two correct answers to one mathematics question, the board voted to extend disclosure practices nationwide.

title: Elsie Wilson to Be Wed in May
description: Elsie Dunn Wilson, corporate secretary and assistant general counsel of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation in Houston, plans to be married in May to William McIlwaine Thompson Jr., a founder and director of the Guardian Oil Company in Houston. The ceremony will take place in New York.

title: REGAN FINDS 'NEPOTISM' IN TRANSIT UNIT
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan charged yesterday that there was widespread ''nepotism and favoritism'' in the Transit Authority's Manhattan and Bronx bus division, despite knowledge of such ''questionable personnel practices'' by top transit officials. He said nepotism had contributed to its having a far worse record of bus breakdowns than its counterpart division in Brooklyn.

title: Anne C. Sherrerd Will Be Married in June To Alexander Arader, a Business Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J.F. Sherrerd of Bryn Mawr, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Compton Sherrerd, to Alexander John Arader, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Arader of Radnor, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: Bridge; CALLING A BLUFF
description: Several world leaders have enjoyed a game of bridge. Winston Churchill was playing auction when he was called away to mobilize the British fleet at the start of World War I. President Eisenhower played whenever he could, and as General Eisenhower, he squeezed in a game while waiting for news of the North African landings.

title: Kathleen McCleery Fiancee of Robert Martinez, Lawyer
description: Kathleen D. McCleery, an associate producer for public television, and Robert J. Martinez, a Washington lawyer, plan to marry on Aug. 1. Frances D. Robertson of Morrisville, Pa., and Robert B. McCleery of Allentown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joe R. Martinez of Albuquerque, N.M.

title: THE FINANCIAL GOING GETS ROUGH FOR MUSIC AND DANCE
description: ''YOU can't go on dreaming dreams before you know what they're going to cost,'' the executive director of the State Council on the Arts said last week. ''You must have financial soundness.'' The director, Eileen Lawton, was speaking about the Garden State Ballet Company, one of two major cultural organizations in New Jersey that have suspended performances because of financial problems.

title: LOOSENING UP FOR SUMMER
description: By Jeffrey Miller he traditional male uniform of a tailored jacket, dress shirt, necktie and creased trousers has been overhauled for the new season. Although the shapes of classic American sportswear continue to dominate men's fashion, top American designers are now suggesting combining these elements in a new, more relaxed way for a warmweather wardrobe that is cool, comfortable and correct.

title: If This Isn't Spring ...
description: This is how you know it is spring in New York City. If daffodils at $1.99 a bunch are showing up in the supermarket.

title: Cutting Taxes
description: To the Business Editor: A suggestion on one way to help restore a ''missing link ... in the conduit between consumer tax reduction and the reindustrialization of America'' discussed in ''A Way to Cut Taxes'' (March 8): My thought is not to cut but to defer Federal income taxes on dividends used to purchase company stock in a dividend reinvestment program, in the same way that taxes are deferred in the Individual Retirement Account and Keogh plans. Such deferrals could be for a fixed number of years, or until the stock is sold.

title: KAYAKING,AT A LEISURELY PLACE, ON FRANCE'S DORDOGNE RIVER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- DAVID BIRD is a reporter for The New York Times. By DAVID BIRD

title: CONGRESS DOWNS REAGAN'S AUSTERITY TONIC, BUT IT'S HARD
description: The House Agriculture Committee was debating a bill to block an increase in dairy price supports when Representative George Hansen, a staunchly conservative Republican from Idaho, took the floor. The White House desperately wanted this legislation, Mr. Hansen reminded his colleagues. ''It's not easy to take castor oil,'' he said. ''But in the long run you'll be better off for it.''

title: Debra Jayne Fischer Married
description: The marriage of Debra Jayne Fischer and Steven Burroughs French, graduates of Hartwick College, took place yesterday in the Garden City (L.I.) Community Church. The Rev. Ralph Ahlberg performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis A. Fischer of Garden City and Mr. French is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L.V. French of Andover, Mass.

title: Gretzky Ties Esposito's Record
description: Wayne Gretzky tied Phil Esposito's singleseason point record with an assist against the Detroit Red Wings today, but Gretzky said the record was the farthest thing from his mind.

title: ENGLISH CHOIR IN CONCERT
description: The Norwich (England) Cathedral Choir of Men and Boys, founded in what was originally a monastery built in 1096, will give a concert at 8:15 P.M. next Sunday in the sanctuary of the Scarsdale Congregational Church, 1 Heathcote Road. The group is on its first 15-day American tour and is scheduled to perform in 12 communities from Maryland to Michigan.

title: White Sox Trade Kravec To Cubs for Dennis Lamp
description: The Chicago Cubs and the Chicago White Sox traded pitchers today with Ken Kravec, a left-hander, going to the Cubs, and Dennis Lamp, a right-hander, going to the White Sox.

title: Cartwright's Basket Defeats Nets by 90-88
description: The Knicks achieved their 49th victory tonight by defeating the New Jersey Nets, 90-88, before a crowd of 8,515 at the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: Stephanie Wolmer Wed To Richard A. Kessler
description: Stephanie Rita Wolmer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David H. Wolmer of Tenafly, N.J., and New York, was married at the Regency Hotel yesterday to Richard A. Kessler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Kessler of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Stephen Pinsky officiated.

title: LUCAS VAN PRAGG FIANCE OF SUSAN M. REYNOLDS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Reynolds Jr. of Mantoloking, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Mary Reynolds, to Lucas van Praag, son of Louis van Praag of Ewelme, England, and Angela van Pragg of Athelington, England.

title: Technical Analysis
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''Getting Technical About Stocks'' (March 15), I believe that Modern Portfolio Theory as pioneered by Henry Markowitz and William F. Sharpe deserves a few lines.

title: DEMOCRATS' BATTLE RECALLS THE OLD TAMMANY DAYS
description: A contest that harks back to the old days of Tammany Hall is shaping up for the Democratic leadership of Manhattan, which is about to lose its first female leader.

title: HOOISERS ROMP AS L.S.U. OFFENSE FAILS
description: The nightmare came with little warning. Louisiana State's first half today had been far from perfect, but Indiana's was even worse. Four of the Indiana starters had made just 6 of 21 shots. The fifth, the all-America guard Isiah Thomas, was in foul trouble.

title: PRESERVING THE ARCHITECTURAL PAST IS NOT ALWAYS EASY
description: THE singling out of older parts of cities, towns and rural areas for preservation or restoration, which began more than a decade ago, is now a nationwide phenomenon. But with a few exceptions such as Cape May and Haddonfield, the trend is new to New Jersey.

title: THE JOB OUTLOOK IN SCIENCE
description: While capital spending programs are useful indicators of future trends, those seeking to monitor American industry's drive for more capital-intensive, efficient and productive technology may also want to focus on a monthly index that tries to gauge demand for technical workers.

title: EX-DEPUTY PREMIER OF IRAN GRANTED LAWYER AT TRIAL
description: The espionage trial of former Deputy Prime Minister Abbas Amir Entezam of Iran resumed here today with the announcement that a four-member revolutionary tribunal had agreed to his request for a defense lawyer of his choice. Mr. Entezam had charged that the court president had told him he did not need one.

title: IN NEW YORK, MORE LAWS ADD UP TO MORE CRIMINALS
description: ALBANY ASSEMBLYMAN Melvin H. Miller, chairman of the Codes Committee, thinks there is a ''supply-side'' theory in criminal justice, just as in economics. ''The whole problem,'' he says, ''is how to match all the tough laws we've passed in the last few years with an adequate supply of defense attorneys, judges and prosecutors to enforce them.''

title: LIGETI AND STOCKHAUSEN HAVE PREMIRES OF OPERAS
description: Gyorgy Ligeti and Karlheinz Stockhausen count as two of the leading members of the 1960's European avant-garde. But we are in the 80's, and not all 60's avant-gardists have been easily able to sustain their careers since the decade in which they came to prominence. But in recent days Mr. Ligeti and Mr. Stockhausen have each had important premieres of their first operas at two of Europe's most well-known opera houses.

description: MEDIEVAL ENGLISH GARDENS By Teresa McLean. Illustrated. 298 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $25.

description: To the Editor:

title: WABC ENDS 'AIRMAIL SPECIAL,' CITING FABRICATIONS
description: TV announced last night that it was canceling a weekly service feature, ''Airmail Special,'' because most of its segments had been inspired by station employees rather than by letters from viewers, as the feature had promised.

title: GORDON PATTERSON
description: Gordon Patterson, retired vice chairman of Eaton, Yale & Towne, the diversified machinery manufacturer that acquired the Yale & Towne Manufacturing Company, producer of locks and keys, in 1963, died Friday at his home in Shaker Heights, Ohio, after a short illness. He was 81 years old.

title: WORLD INFLATION WOES
description: Confronted with sharply higher energy prices, major industrial nations employed more restrictive monetary and fiscal policies to restrain inflation last year. In spite of the effort, inflation on average increased by 11.4 percent in the 12-month period ended in December, according to statistics recently released by the International Monetary Fund, up from a 9.1 percent rise in 1979.

title: Dunham's Gift Upsets Dr. Blum
description: Dunham's Gift, who has spent much of the winter chasing Dr. Blum, ended the three-race winning streak of his rival yesterday. Dunham's Gift put his nose in front at the wire to win the $55,000 Westchester Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: CLARK STRIVES TO BE THE LIFE OF REPUBLICAN PARTY
description: The day after his party's candidate for Governor of New York lost the 1974 election, Richard M. Rosenbaum, the Republican state chairman, called a news conference.

title: THE HOPE OF SPRING: BASEBALL'S ROOKIES
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. R ALPH HOUK peered past the palm trees and across 40 years of his life in baseball, and remembered what it was like to be a rookie. ''It's the most exciting time of your career,'' said Houk, who came out of retirement this year to become manager of the Boston Red Sox. ''Just to play alongside the guys you read about, to go first class in airplanes, or, in those days, on the trains. Just to go home and say you're in the big leagues.''

title: FOUNDATION HOPES TO STRENGTHEN U.S.-Japan TIES
description: At a time of strain in the relationship between Washington and Tokyo over trade and military-security issues, a new multimilliondollar private foundation has been established to ''strengthen cooperation and understanding'' between the United States and Japan.

title: BECKER TEAM GETS CHAMPIONSHIP IN SPRING NATIONALS BRIDGE MATCH
description: One of the world's most renowned contract bridge players, B. Jay Becker of New York, led his team to victory here in the Vanderbilt knockout team championship early this morning.

title: TWO STILL MISSING IN CONDOMINIUM COLLAPSE
description: An army of rescuers worked from this morning into the night at the ruins of a condominium here trying to uncover at least two construction workers unaccounted for in the collapse of the building yesterday afternoon that killed 10 and hurt 14.

description: To the Editor:

title: NEW ENGLAND SEAFARING CHARM
description: STONINGTON WHEN the popular Harborview Restaurant went up in flames last June, loyal patrons reportedly cried as they watched the blaze. But now the Harborview has reopened, on the same site, and its crowds of admirers are back.

title: Laotians in A New Land
description: If the Sithavady family looks somewhat pensive in the photograph accompanying the article, who can blame them (''Laotians in a New Land,'' by Mike Norman, March 1)?

title: A Spokesman Is Selected By the State Department
description: Dean Fischer, who until recently was a correspondent for Time magazine, was sworn in today as chief spokesman for the State Department.

title:
CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Town and Country Clothes For Women at Half-Price
description: Mabbett Mills Ltd., a retail store in Washington Depot for classic town and country clothes for women, has all winter wear reduced by half the regular price.

title: ILLEGAL RENT RATES HELD WIDESPREAD
description: A recent announcement by the State Attorney General that a major New York City management company had charged illegal rents for apartments has convinced many tenants and some government officials that rent overcharges are becoming a way of life in much of the city and that the rent stabilization system does not have the means to deal with violators.

SUMMER REPORT: PARIS/ MILAN By Mary Russell en's ready-to-wear clothes from Paris and Milan this spring have a breezy, sportswear feeling. In contrast to the women's collections, where innovation has continued, European men's-wear designers have again turned to classic American sport and casual wear for inspiration.

title: 'DOZENS,' A WOMAN IN PRISON
description: ''The Dozens'' was made on a shoestring budget by Christine Dall and Randall Conrad, who didn't really need a penny more. Their story, about a young mother returning to civilian life after a stint in prison, doesn't require much fuss. So ''The Dozens'' is visually so plain it looks like a home movie, and its drama unfolds with more frankness than insight. But the central character has enough fighting spirit to give the film some life.

title: HER DISCOVERY: WRITING ISN'T TAXING
description: WHEN Rosalie Minkow of Port Washington turned 40 years old, her children were grown and she came to the conclusion that she had to do something with her life. ''I didn't have enough to do,'' she said. ''I realized I wasn't the focus of their lives even though they were the focus of my life. So I had to adjust myself.''

title: Virgin and Grete Waitz Win Cross-Country Titles
description: Craig Virgin of Lebanon, Ill., and Grete Waitz of Norway successfully defended their world cross-country championships today.

title: LEADERS IN POLAND CONTINUE MEETINGS IN A 'GOOD' CLIMATE
description: Against a deadline of a general strike set for Tuesday and on the eve of an important Communist Party Central Committee meeting, Solidarity union leaders met with Government officials today for nearly three hours but did not achieve a breakthrough.

title: A.C.L.U. MOVES AGAINST DEATH PENALTY
description: punishment project for the American Civil Liberties Union, had just returned from two ''exhausting'' weeks in Indiana, where he had tried, unsuccessfully, to stave off the March 9 execution of Steven Judy. It was then that he got a call from a law student in Virginia, asking whether he was aware that an execution was scheduled there two days later.

description: To the Editor:

title: WOOD'S 39 HELP DEFEAT VIRGINIA, 78-65
description: Al Wood, North Carolina's 6-foot-6-inch forward, stole the show from Ralph Sampson of Virginia today, scoring 39 points to lead North Carolina to a 78-65 victory in the semifinal round of the National Collegiate basketball tournament.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is one country, and it does not start at the Mississippi River and go west. It starts on the Eastern Seaboard.'' - Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, dicussing an Administration proposal to drop the Gateway National Recreation Area from the Federal park system. (32:3.)

description: To the Editor:

title: MAN IN THE MIDDLE
description: NEWARK A CRITICAL meeting here and a busy schedule in three other cities kept Jerome C. Premo from taking the train on March 16. Instead, the executive director of the NJ Transit Corporation, which runs most of the state's trains and buses, drove to work in his own car. Mr. Premo spoke to NJ Transit's board of directors, seeking authorization to hold hearings on huge fare increases for 400,000 daily commuters. A drop in ridership, paired with reductions in Federal aid and the leveling off of state transit assistance, forced him to propose raising the cost of bus tickets by 50 percent by June 27 and nearly doubling train fares by the beginning of next year.

title: Long Island Journal
description: ARTISTS from all over the Island who have drawn inspiration from local scenery will be displaying their work in a monthlong environmental art show and sale in Glen Cove starting today.

title: FARMERS ARE OFF TO 'GOOD START'
description: TRENTON ABOUT 700,000 acres of New Jersey farmland will be plowed this spring, preparatory to the planting of a wide variety of crops. Under average climatic conditions, Garden State farms produce a higher vegetable yield per square mile than any other state in the country. Fruit-crop yields rank fourth.

title: RANGERS WIN, 6-2 TO END CANADIENS' UNBEATEN STREAK AT HOME
description: The New York Rangers, almost desperately in need of a victory or a tie in their effort to qualify for the Stanley Cup playoffs, thoroughly outplayed the Montreal Canadiens tonight and won, 6-2. It was the first loss for Montreal at the Forum in its last 25 games.

title: THE FALLING STAR
description: THE MISSING PERSON By Doris Grumbach. 252 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $11.95. By HERBERT GOLD

title: Dance View; A 'SMALL LOOK' THAT APPEALS
description: Unlike other out-of-town ballet companies seen this season in New York, the Ohio Ballet from Akron has a small look about it - in the number of dancers it puts on stage, the kind of works it performs and the scale of its dancing. At this point, the company lists 21 members and nothing about it suggests the aspirations to opera-house stature of the other companies in the Brooklyn Academy's ''Ballet America'' series.

title: A RARE SURVEY OF INDIAN ART COMES TO PHILADELPHIA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Monica Lawyer is a graduate student in Indian art at the Institute of Fine Arts of New York University. By MONICA LAWYER

title: COURT ORDERS CHAMBER TO REMOVE CROSS FROM STATE PARK IN GEORGIA
description: A Federal district judge has ordered the Rabun County Chamber of Commerce to remove an illuminated cross from Black Rock Mountain State Park.

title: ALONG WITH ARMS AID COME MILITARY ASVISERS
description: Memories in the capital started doing backflips and other tricks earlier this month when President Reagan spoke frankly and freely in an interview about the roles of United States military training teams in El Salvador and ''more than 30'' other countries.

title: INFLTION AND LIFE INSURANCE
description: G IVEN the way inflation batters the dollar, why would anyone buy life insurance? After all, if one bought a $100,000 policy five years ago, it would only provide $55,000 of coverage in today's dollars, and the small return on whole-life policies doesn't even match the rates paid on passbook savings accounts.

title: Agreement Near on Hearns-Leonard Fight
description: Thomas Hearns has apparently defeated Marvelous Marvin Hagler and Pipino Cuevas in the battle to be Sugar Ray Leonard's next multimillion-dollar opponent in what should be the biggest money fight in boxing history.

description: Rundale Rosalie, a 6-year-old pacing mare, brought the $61,000 top price today as 125 horses were auctioned for $673,700 in the Old Glory Sale at Yonkers Raceway.

title: ADVERTISING AGENCIES OF STATE GAIN ON MADISON AVENUE
description: AVON WHAT might someone think overhearing such remarks as, ''Did you see the dynamite stuff Mintz & Hoke ran in Industrial Equipment News for Loctite's pipe sealant?'' ''Have you picked up one of those Conn Save energy-audit brochures that Shailer Davidoff Rogers got into every bank and library in the state?'' title: Soviet Says Polish Union Is Headed by Dissidents
description: A commentary by the Soviet press agency Tass charged tonight that dissidents had taken control of Poland's labor movement and were using it for political ends.

title: Wildlife Group Names New Chief
description: Jay Hair, a professor of zoology and forestry at North Carolina State University, has been selected as the new head of the National Wildlife Federation, the group announced. Mr. Hair, 35 years old, will succeed Thomas L. Kimball, 63, who is retiring after 21 years as chief executive officer of the nation's largest conservation organization, which has 4.6 million members.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:
