title: CHAMBER ORCHESTRAS
description: I t was only five months after the end of the Second World War and Stuttgart was still not much more than a heap of rubble when a 30-year-old conductor named Karl Munchinger led his first concert with a chamber orchestra he had just assembled and named after his home town. Today, over 35 years and 3,000 concerts later, the Stuttgart Chamber Orchestra is one of the oldest and most noted ensembles of its kind, having toured five continents and made hundreds of recordings. Tonight the group pays a visit to Carnegie Hall with a program of music by Pachelbel, Vivaldi, Respighi, Mozart and Britten.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
MAILMAN OF THE 2-CENT POSTCARD ERA
description: IKNOW my father willingly made a clearing in the hedge for him so he could cut through the back of our property; my mother served him lemonade on hot summer afternoons, and we children considered him not only a friend but the happy bearer of all those telescopes, signet rings and Buck Rogers paraphernalia we ordered through magazine and radio station program offers.

title: A LAMENT FOR VIETNAM
description: When the Communists took over North Vietnam in 1954, a million refugees fled to the South. I personally heard stories of their incredible suffering. But, along with other South Vietnamese, I refused to believe them. A generation later, I could not believe Solzhenitsyn's book ''The Gulag Archipelago,'' either. I dismissed it as anti-Communist propaganda. But by 1979, I had published my own book, ''The Vietnamese Gulag.'' Can those who have suffered the horror of Communism ever convince those who have not experienced it? From 1945, when I was born in the village of Caivon in Vinh Long province, 100 miles south of Saigon, until I left Vietnam in May 1978, I never enjoyed peace. My family's house was burned three times in the war against the French. To escape the fighting, my parents moved from one village to another throughout my youth. Like the majority of Vietnamese patriots, they joined the resistance forces fighting the French. As I grew up, I myself saw how the peasants were oppressed by the local officials of the successive Saigon regimes, how they were victimized by the French bombardments. I learned the history of my country's thousand-year struggle against Chinese occupation and its century-long effort against Western domination. With this background, my compatriots and I grew up with a hatred of foreign intervention.

There were Government guarantees, Federal insurance, agencies to buy up mortgages - a cornucopia of Federal benevolence aimed at making America a nation of homeowners.

title: COLLARING THE CORRECT LOOK FOR SUMMER
description: Alan J. Flusser is a men's wear designer and author of ''Making the Man,'' a book on men's dressing, from which this excerpt was taken. It will be published in September by Simon & Schuster.any men feel that once they have selected the proper suit, the accessories can be added with little further consideration. Throw on any old shirt and tie, they seem to think, and, perhaps, grab the nearest handkerchief. Yet a man's accessories have a great deal to contribute to his overall appearance. How they are chosen and worn can alter the mood or the entire effect of his attire. And, where a man must be conservative, even extremely cautious, when buying highcost items such as suits and shoes, the relative inexpensiveness of a shirt or tie permits a welcome freedom.

title:

title: WHEN OIL-PAINTED SIDING BEGINS TO PEEL
description: Older houses with wooden siding are often susceptible to persistent peeling of paint caused by moisture vapor trapped inside the walls. This moisture sometimes results from leaks or open joints in the outside walls but more often than not it enters the hollow wall spaces as vapor, which is generated by high indoor humidity levels - especially in the winter, when doors and windows are sealed while normal bathing, washing and cooking add gallons of moisture to the confined air.

title:
Design Food;
LIVING AND WORKING UNDER ONE ROOF
description: here was a time when living above the store was something less than desirable, for it implied that a separate residence was unaffordable. But times have changed. Today, more and more people yearn to live above, below or adjacent to their businesses, a way of life that exchanges the commuter's long train ride or the exhausting fight against traffic for the convenience of walking down the stairs or across the hallway. In major cities like New York, it is not uncommon for a vacated town house or apartment to be snatched up by a neighbor whose at-home business has outgrown his present dwelling. A trend that has touched the best of neighborhoods, living above the store has become downright chic.

The principal works on her program were Beethoven's Sonata in C minor (Op. 111) and Schumann's Symphonic Etudes, which were preceded by Mozart's Sonata in A minor (K. 310), an Andantino by Galuppi and a group of short pieces by Sibelius.

Nicolaus Huber's ''Darabukka'' and Walter Zimmermann's ''Erd-Tone,'' for example, reduced the piano to the role of primitive drum - the first piece with its rhythmic variations on a single C sharp and the second with its blunted, wooden sonorities.

description: ''Save Our State'' was the chant of about 20,000 Massachusetts residents, including teachers, parents and schoolchildren, who rallied on the Boston Common today to protest budget cutbacks caused by a voter-approved limit on property taxes.

title: WHY IS YOUR WRITING SO VIOLENT?
description: IT was on a chill but sunny May morning in 1980 in an antiquated auditorium of steeply tiered seats at the University of Warsaw that the question was asked of me by an earnest young man of about 25, who, like most of the Poles we met, spoke excellent English: Why was my writing so violent? Might it be that my ''personal experience,'' ''perhaps my childhood'' and, in any case, my ''unique temperament'' had so ''distorted'' my vision of mankind and of history that the fiction of ''Joyce Carol Oates'' represented only an ''extreme attitude,'' unfortunately prevalent in contemporary American literature?

title: L.K.DANN TO WED JEANNETTE M. SMITH
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Milton Smith 2d of Dallas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jeannette Marcus Smith, to Lyman Kevin Dann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Dann of Painted Post, N.Y.

title: U.S. and Egypt Discussing Sinai Peacekeeping Force
description: The United States and Egypt resumed talks here today on forming a multinational peacekeeping force to patrol the Sinai peninsula when Israel completes its withdrawal from there next year. So far, Israel has handed back to Egypt two-thirds of the peninsula, which it occupied in the 1967 war.

title: Music View; WHEN COMPOSER AND CONDUCTOR ARE ONE
description: The relationship between the composer and the conductor is an uneasy one, charged with all sorts of psychological and musical tensions. Ask any composer. Ask any conductor. At best, the creative and the interpretive artist simply find it difficult to understand one another; at worst, there can be open disdain and open warfare. That is why the more famous the conductor, the more likely he is to want to confine his dealings to one kind of composer: the dead kind. Live composers generally want to recognize the piece being played as the one they wrote, and they have a habit of speaking up from the rear of the hall during rehearsal.

title: FAMILIAR AND OTHERWISE
description: NOTHING is immune to fashion, not even immortal words. John Bartlett, the Cambridge bookseller whose ''Familiar Quotations'' was an instant success when it first appeared in 1855, relied largely on the Bible, Shakespeare and Milton. They are generously represented in this new, 15th edition - along with Timothy Leary (''Tune In, Turn On, Drop Out''), (Leroy) Eldridge Cleaver (''You're either part of the solution or part of the problem'') and Robert Crumb (''Keep on truckin' ''). Let no one suppose the editor, Emily Morison Beck, has had her nose in a book since she brought out the 14th edition in 1968.

title: CHANNEL 21, STRONGER, BIDS FOR NEW VIEWERS
description: PLAINVIEW WHEN Arthur M. Gillick took the helm of Channel 21 last October, worried employees at the station's offices and studio here were concerned about the viability of WLIW, the Island's noncommercial video outlet.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: AFLYER in the mail the other day informed its receivers that, provided they lived in the Stamford area, they could Rent a Wife. One recipient, perhaps a little old-fashioned and always having thought of wives in a far more romantic and enduring context and traditionally available only on a life-long or at least a long-term lease, was somewhat vexed and decided to investigate further. Uppermost in her mind, of course, was the extent of services provided.

title: AMERICAN 'MASS IN D'
description: The first performance of the ''Mass in D'' by John Knowles Paine of Portland, Maine, said to be one of America's first composers, was in Germany in 1867. Information about subsequent performances is sketchy, but it is known that one was arranged in 1868 in Bostonby two of Paine's friends: James Russell Lowell and Henry Wadwsorth Longfellow.

title: NEIGHBORS' CONCERN IS AID TO BIOGRAPHER
description: STONINGTON TWO small markets, one known for good meat and the other for good gossip, stand a block apart on opposite sides of the narrow street that runs through the village of Stonington.

title: Skiing for Excellence
description: The main goal of the students at the Stratton Mountain School is to achieve excellence in skiing (''Schooling for the Olympics,'' by Holcomb B. Noble, Feb. 22). Then what motivates them just as intensely for academic achievement? Is it that having one goal - to be a world-class skier - promotes dedication and perseverance in other areas as well? Perhaps it is this one special goal that fosters the development of a special type of person who is mature at an early age.

title: LAND CRUNCH?
description: Just how much spare land is there in the United States? Agriculture Department experts believe that the country will never lack farmland, since they project that 200 million acres of land can be transformed to agricultural use if necessary. Energy Department experts expect no problems in finding sites to extract raw materials and convert them to energy, for they, too, consider 200 million acres available if needed for energy projects. Forest Service timber experts foresee a bright future for the lumber and paper industries on the 200 million acres that they, too, estimate could become new timberland.

title: A CARIBBEAN SAMPLER: THREE HOLIDAYS IN THE SUN
description: Even for someone like me, who has long insisted that nature is vastly overrated, the scene was a hard one to resist. It was a brilliantly clear day on St. John, the smallest of the United States Virgin Islands, and we were sitting in one of Caneel Bay Plantation's open-air restaurants, a converted sugar mill set on a hill surrounded by gardens. Directly ahead of us was a vast expanse of bright blue water, punctuated by a handful of graceful schooners. Off to our left was a mountain covered with dense green forest, through which a jeep was snaking its way along a winding road. To our right, on the lawn below us, three donkeys frolicked playfully and chased each other in sweeping circles. All this we took in over lunch, while sipping pina coladas.

title: Miss Doolittle And a Lawyer Plan Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy William Doolittle Jr. of Buffalo, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lusyd Wright Doolittle, to P. Nicholas Kourides, son of Peter T. Kourides of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Anne Spetseris Kourides.

title: FAMILY WINS HISTORIC SHIPYARD
description: NEW LONDON AFTER 14 years of fighting the city redevelopment agency, the Federal General Services Administration and the United States Coast Guard, it looks as if the Wronowskis will finally have a boatyard.

title: Greenburgh Officer Gets 60 Days For Robbing Store While on Duty
description: A Town of Greenburgh police officer who pleaded guilty to robbing a supermarket while on duty and in uniform was sentenced yesterday to 60 days in the Westchester County Penitentiary.

title: WETLANDS SANCTUARY IS SOUGHT BY STATE
description: A CONTROVERSY is brewing in Atlantic County over a plan under which the state would acquire 18,000 acres of land in the Mullica River-Great Bay estuary. The plan will be submitted to the Federal Government this week by the state's Department of Environmental Protection.

title: TEACHING THRIFT TO BUREAUCRATS
description: T HE pursuit of self-interest is not necessarily a bad thing. In fact, no compilation of humanitarian acts by Government can match its contributions to the general welfare of mankind. In a voluntary exchange market economy, for example, an entrepreneur cannot make a profit unless he produces something that others are willing to buy. To attract more customers, he must either improve his product's quality or produce it at a lower cost than his competitors. This profit-maximizing behavior has sparked and sustained a flurry of technological advances.

title: Carol L. Johnson To Be Wed Aug. 16
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Johnson of Teaneck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Lynne Johnson, to Roy William Hermalyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Hermalyn, also of Teaneck.

title: 35 Injured as Police in Yugoslavia Break Up a Protest by Students
description: Thirty-five people were injured this week when the police used tear gas to end a student occupation of university residence halls in the Yugoslav city of Pristina, the city's Communist Party leader said today.

title: June 1 Gala to Open Wolf Trap Arts Season
description: Jouette Shouse, founder and program chairman of Wolf Trap Farm Park in Vienna, Va., has announced the schedule for the Performing Arts Center's 10th anniversary season. It will open with a June 1 gala produced by Zev Bufman.

title: Dali's Consolation; Redeemed at Rikers
description: For 16 years a forgotten Salavdor Dali painting hung in the Rikers Island men's dining hall, providing perhaps the only esthetically redeeming aspect the place could claim. But last week, having learned the work's provenance and value and whisked it from the prison wall to administrative offices in Manhattan, officials disclosed plans to auction the Dali to raise cash for an inmates' art program.

title: TV View; CABLE OPERATORS INCREASINGLY LOOK TO THEATER
description: Stage plays of the caliber of John Osborne's ''Look Back in Anger'' or Jack Heifner's ''Vanities'' are not unknown to television. WNET/Channel 13's ''Theater in America'' series, which was absorbed into the ''Great Performances'' format, has offered viewers productions ranging from David Storey's ''Home'' to Eugene O'Neill's ''Mourning Becomes Electra.'' Even the commercial networks occasionally, very occasionally, have taken a prestige dip with, for example, Katharine Hepburn in Tennessee Williams's ''The Glass Menagerie'' and Laurence Olivier in ''The Merchant of Venice.''

title: 'OPERA ISN'T OVER TILL THE FAT LADY SINGS'
description: CHRISTOPHER KEENE, music director and conductor of the Long Island Philharmonic, isn't quite sure just which baseball personality said it, but he insists that once upon a time a fan asked the fabled player if his team would win a game.

title: On the Isle; by Barbara Delatiner; SOME BRASS
description: What's as good as a big brass band? Would you believe a small brass ensemble? If you do, you've got two opportunities to indulge yourself this week. Today at 3 P.M., the New York Brass Choir will be at the Massapequa Public Library, 40 Harbor Lane in Massapequa Park, to play some Scott Joplin, Peter Schickele and Samuel Scheitt. Then on Friday at 7:30 P.M., the Long Island Brass Guild will perform selections from the ''American Brass Band Journal'' and music by Eugene Mezza and Paul Dukas at the Middle Island Public Library on Middle Country Road. Both concerts are free. BACH SPRINGS FORTH

title: LABOR RIFT ACCOMPANIES THREE MILE ISLAND PROTEST
description: Thousands of demonstrators calling for the shutdown of all nuclear power plants rallied for a ''March on Harrisburg'' today on the second anniversary of the accident at nearby Three Mile Island.

title: BUYING THE NEW-ISSUE OIL STOCKS
description: B ORED with poker? The horses? Those polyester crowds in Atlantic City? Well, listen. If you have lots of money, an irresistible hankering to risk some it and have been looking for a tasteful, easy way to lose your shirt, you might consider betting on some of the new issues of oil and gas stocks. The reason is that you just might do very well, although analysts sternly warn that you could see your entire investment evaporate.

description: Regina Maria Lees, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Lees of Manhasset, L.I., was married there yesterday to John Patrick Hannan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil Hannan, also of Manhasset. The Rev. Roger Giglio of the Bronx performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: 'COZY' TAX SHELTER ISN'T SO COMFORTABLE
description: P.U. NEXT LINE To the Sports Editor: In Red Smith's column in The New York Times on March 23, the ownership of a baseball team was called ''one of the coziest tax shelters accountants have yet discovered.'' The notion that baseball provides some sort of advantageous tax shelter is one that has been often reported, as if repeating it would make it true. But the exaggerated claims made in the column provide an excellent opportunity to analyze the true substance of a baseball investment, and to demonstrate the fallacy of the ''cozy tax-shelter'' theory.

description: Consumer price rises returned to the double-digit range last month, the Government said. New energy costs, attributed to the Administration's decontrol of domestic oil prices, pushed the index up 1 percent - an annual rate of 12 percent.

title: Loughlin Scores Sweep Of Track Team Titles
description: Bishop Loughlin capped one of its most successful indoor campaigns yesterday by taking the boys' and girls' team titles at the annual Manhattan College Interscholastic Relays yesterday.

title: A FEMINIST REPRISE AT DOUGLASS COLLEGE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK NO EDUCATIONAL establishment has been more assiduous than Douglass College in promoting the cause of feminist art. In the last 10 years, the college has shown the works of about 150 female artists in both individual and group exhibitions. Seventy-nine of these artists are currently participating in a show that, in effect, recapitulates the decade.

description: Hearings may be forthcoming to determine whether irregularities relating to the handicap ratings of three foremost American offshore racing yachts were attributable to genuine error or the result of cheating.

description: A draft report produced by the Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that there is insufficient evidence to substantiate Administration charges that the Soviet Union is directly helping to foment international terrorism, Congressional and Administration sources said today.

description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- MICHAEL CULL covers Columbus for the Akron Beacon Journal. By MICHAEL CULL

title: NASSAU TENANTS SEEK A TOUGHER RENT LAW
description: FACED with demands for increases in rent ranging up to 60 percent, tenants in several Nassau County communities have organized to fight back and campaign for the enactment of an Emergency Tenants Protection Act in the jurisdictions that do not have it.

description: The proposal that one private carrier take on Conrail's operations in Connecticut and Rhode Island (''3 to Bid to Win Conrail Freight,'' March 15) is as foolhardy as maintaining the entire trackage presently in existence.

description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday,Priscilla Edmunds, a securities-systems analyst with the Cycliphase Corporation, was married to Peter Burr Smith, a vice president of the Pershing division of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. Msgr. James G. Wilders, assisted by the Rev. Stephen M. Rodgers of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, performed the ceremony.

title: OPPOSING THE 'NEW RIGHT'
description: The budget cuts proposed by the Reagan Administration are apparently fulfilling the fears that many people began to harbor when the ''New Right'' came into power.

title: Music:Debuts in Review; Nadine Asin, Flutist, In Water-Spirit Bill
description: An ''undine'' is a fabled female water spirit who can receive a human soul by bearing a mortal child. In a fascinating program of music in the Abraham Goodman House on Sunday night, including the ''Undine'' Sonata by Carl Reinecke, Nadine Asin made her flute sound like just such a mythical spirit.

title: WHEN OIL-PAINTED SIDING BEGINS TO PEEL
description: Older houses with wooden siding are often susceptible to persistent peeling of paint caused by moisture vapor trapped inside the walls. This mositure sometimes results from leaks or open joints in the outside walls, but more often than not it enters the hollow wall spaces as vapor, which is generated by high indoor humidity levelsespecially in the winter, when doors and windows are sealed while normal bathing, washing and cooking add gallons of moisture to the confined air.

title: MENTAL HEALTH AT A CROSSROAD
description: THE Commissioner of Mental Health in Connecticut, Dr. Eric A. Plaut, has said he will resign as of April 15, and a search is under way for his successor.

title: MARCH OF THE NINE-TO-FIVE WOMAN
description: CLEVELAND K AREN NUSSBAUM dropped out of the University of Chicago 11 years ago, moved to Boston and got a job as a clerk-typist at Harvard's School of Education. ''I was paid $2 an hour working as a casual employee,'' she said. ''Although I was on the payroll, I got no benefits, no vacation. And the day-to-day indignities really grated on me.''

title: DEFICIENCIES OF VITAMINS
description: Jane E. Brody, a science reporter for The New York Times, is the author of ''Jane Brody's Nutrition Book,'' which will be published this week. By Jane E. Brody was waiting for a drink at an office water fountain while a young man swallowed not one, not two, but six different pills and capsules. Concerned, I asked if he was all right. ''Sure,'' he replied brightly. ''These are ...'' and he rattled off an alphabet soup of vitamins and minerals, as well as other swallowable items that don't appear on any official list of vital nutrients. ''They're good for you,'' he added in response to my now-skeptical look. ''I take them three times a day.'' Vitamins and minerals -the essential micronutrients in the human diet - are macro items in today's marketplace. Never before has something we need so little of sold so big - some $1.3 billion big, at last count. According to Dr. John Vanderveen, head of the division of nutrition at the Food and Drug Administration, ''Vitamin consumption is now increasing at an extremely rapid rate. In the last two years, sales have climbed steeply, almost in a straight line upward.''

title: Theater in Review; A NEW START WITH 'ANNE FRANK'
description: LINDENHURST AFTER a succession of financial setbacks that forced the suspension of its season and threatened its existence, Studio Theater is back in business with a new production of ''The Diary of Anne Frank.'' This, too, it shall survive.

description: - The final 1980 census figures will show that the population of St. Louis dropped to 453,085, a decline of 27.2 percent since 1970, a population analyst has disclosed.

description: Last Thursday Sylvia Hanika and Andrea Jaeger had a bitter verbal confrontation after their second-round match in the $300,000 Avon tennis championships at Madison Square Garden.

description: Clocks in 20 nations of Western and Eastern Europe will be turned ahead one hour at 1 A.M. local time tomorrow, marking the first simultaneous switch to daylight savings time on the Continent.

THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Springtime Skiing And Tennis Goods
description: With prices going up winter after winter, one defensive measure is to buy at this year's prices with the bonus of seasonal markdowns. At the Pedigree Ski and Tennis Shop in White Plains, the reductions amount to 20 to 50 percent on selected merchandise.

title: A CARIBBEAN SAMPLER: THREE HOLIDAYS IN THE SUN
description: Our Boeing 707 dropped quickly and the cloud-capped peak on the island of Saba appeared below the right wing. We banked to the left, with the extinct volcano of St. Eustatius slipping by below. Moments later the lush green mountains of St. Kitts rose on the left before we settled down on the runway at Golden Rock International Airport just outside Basseterre, the Kittitian capital.

description: These are not the best of times for Pat Haden, pro football's only Rhodes Scholar and a person who has had much success and little failure in his life. Haden has lost control of his future in the sport.

description: ''IVERY much wanted to work here,'' said Danielle Lindholm of Hewlett, a 1980 graduate of the C.W. Post Center of Long Island University. ''I love Long Island and I don't like to commute. But my college career counselor said the good jobs were in Manhattan and New Jersey.''

description: The engagement of Abbie Eaton van Nostrand to James J. Schwartz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Jay Schwartz of Rowayton, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Morris Abbott Van Nostrand of New York.

description: ALL of the candidates running for Governor this year have their own agendas, their schedules of priorities designed to bring them victory.

description: Geoff Smith, a British 5,000-meter Olympian, and Andrea Chiappetta set meet records in winning the men's and women's divisions of the fourth annual Perrier 10-kilometer run yesterday at Central Park.

description: New York City announced yesterday a series of steps that it hoped would unsnarl weekday traffic in Manhattan's business districts. description: Ayatollah Rabbani Shirazi, the personal representative of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in the southern province of Fars, was slightly wounded by two gunmen in the city of Shiraz yesterday, according to official reports today.

description: Afghan rebels fighting the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul have set up their first base in western Afghanistan in a bid to extend their control over areas near the Iranian border, a guerrilla spokesman said today.

title: Advertising; TV Spots Mark New G.E. Effort
description: TONIGHT, four new commercials from General Electric during the Academy Awards program on the ABC-TV network might easily bring good things to life for the company. The batter rounds first base without touching it and goes to second on the throw to the plate. The defensive team makes a proper appeal at first base. Do the runs count?

title: Index; International
description: South African maids organize, but fear wrath of 'madam' A2 Ex-Premier confirms there was a '68 plot in Britain to oust him A3 Viola takes his turn as President of Argentina A3 Two gunmen wound aide to Kho- meini in Iran A3 Around the World A5 Pope again appeals for peaceful settlement in Poland A8 Tass steps up criticism of Polish trade union organization A9 Japanese flock to exhibition of the future A13 Government/Politics About Washington: concepts and flesh-and-blood horses A14 Mayor Byrne's move has led to flurry of action at project A14 Disputes have split Michigan's Democratic Party A16 City to experiment with civil and misdemeanor trials at night B5 State tax collections increase 9.6 percent nationwide B10 General Around the Nation A14 Jersey mill city upset by story of drugs at school B2 Parade on Fifth Avenue marks Greek Independence Day B3 Use of ''antigridlock boxes'' ex- tended in Manhattan B6 An effort to restore historic Gov- ernor's Room at City Hall B9 A man the U.S. has been trying to deport for 28 years goes on trial B12 Christian feminists divided on theological issues B13 Labor/Industry Talks with two newspaper unions focus on noneconomic issues B4 Health/Science An April liftoff is planned for the space shuttle Columbia B15 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Reutemann's Wil- liams takes Brazil Grand Prix C5 Baseball: Guidry pitches strongly after contract talks C2

title: by Robert Lekachman
description: As one must, I have been listening attentively to Edwin Meese 3d reassuring the ''deserving poor,'' David A. Stockman, et al, promising to comfort the ''truly needy,'' and George Gilder, author of ''Wealth and Poverty,'' advising us that the poor require the spur of their poverty. It all reminds me of events in other places and times, and recalls prophets long since departed.

title: Aide Talks About Davis
description: Why Marvin Davis, the Denver oil millionaire, backed out of a $700 million deal at the last minute to buy the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation may be a bit clearer by now, but not very much.

title: IN BUSINESS REGULATION NOW IN FRIENDLY HANDS?
description: Now that its cat-and-mouse game with Brascan Ltd. is over, the Scott Paper Company can focus on a more fundamental challenge: holding its ground in what has been dubbed the Great Toilet Paper War.

title: John Henry Takes San Luis Rey Stakes
description: John Henry raced to an easy victory in the 30th running of the $161,400 San Luis Rey Stakes on the turf at Santa Anita today.

title: LEROY JOLLEY HAS A COLT TO CURE ANY HORSEMAN'S DERBY BLUES
description: EVERY year, LeRoy Jolley seems to come up with two or three horses for whom most trainers would wait a lifetime. The stall list hanging from a nail in his barn, which includes Genuine Risk, Jaklin Klugman and Cure the Blues looks like a horse of-the-year ballot.

title: HAIG IS TROUBLED BY TROOP MOVES ON POLISH BORDER
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the Soviet Union, East Germany and other Warsaw Pact nations had heightened preparations along Poland's borders for possible military intervention, but he added that there were signs that a major crisis could be avoided.

title: HISTORIC ROOM TO BE RESTORED INSIDE CITY HALL
description: In 1812, when De Witt Clinton arrived at the newly completed City Hall as New York City's 51st Mayor, he learned that the large formal reception room on the second floor had already been ''appropriated as an office to his excellency the Governor of this state.'' And appropriated it remained until Alfred E. Smith retired as Governor in 1920.

title: COLLEGE OFFICIALS PUSH FOR ALTERNATIVES TO STUDENT-AID CUTS ASKED BY
description: REAGAN By EDWARD B. FISKE

title: 3 CONCERNS CITE ERROR IN GAS PRICE
description: Two of the nation's biggest petroleum companies, Texaco Inc. and Conoco Inc., have acknowledged that they submitted erroneous information to the Government about some of their natural gas wells that led in some cases to overcharges to customers.

title: Giammalva Takes All-Amateur Final
description: Sammy Giammalva of Houston, who was graduated from high school last month and became 18 years old last week, won the Congoleum Invitational tennis tournament by beating Scott Davis of Stanford, 6-3, 5-7, 6-1, today in an all-amateur final.

title: Addendum
description: * People magazine will increase its circulation rate base 2.2 percent to 2.35 million from 2.3 million, and its advertising rates will go up 5.1 percent, effective with the July 20 issue.

title: SPLIT GROWS IN HOUSE ON TAX CUT
description: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee says any tax relief bill sent to the House floor is likely to include two provisions that Administration officials have described as contrary to President Reagan's economic philosophy.

title: U.N. Should Patrol Sinai, Egypt and U.S. Agree
description: Egypt and the United States said tonight that the United Nations was being approached to form a multinational peacekeeping force for Sinai despite the possibility that the Soviet Union would veto the plan.

title: U.S. HOSTAGE IS SHOT ON INDONESIAN JET AT BANGKOK AIRPORT
description: The hijackers of an Indonesian jetliner shot and wounded an American hostage today as he tried to flee the sweltering plane hours after a British passenger managed to escape. The American was in serious condition at a nearby hospital.

title: KATHY BYRNE: A POLITICAL MOTHER
description: In a quip perhaps more revelatory than glib, Katherine Crane Byrne once said she might rename herself "Jane II." In that case the owner of Roman numeral I would be Jane M. Byrne, mother of Kathy, Mayor of Chicago, and matriarch of the highly chronicled political family.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A-T-O Inc., Willoughby, Ohio, has named Luther A. Harthun senior vice president-international, general counsel and secretary.

title: CHRISTIAN FEMINISTS SPLIT ON KEY ISSUES IN CHURCH
description: American delegates to an international conference on the role of women in religion agree that sexism is a problem for the Christian church, but a meeting here last week revealed that feminists in the church are sharply split on several key theological issues.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN MAIDS ORGANIZE, BUT FEAR WRATH OF 'MADAM'
description: As in many countries, most ''madams'' and ''masters'' - to use the forms of address by which white South Africans usually expect to be called by their black servants - find it inconvenient to give their maids the weekend off. So it is that days off for servants normally fall on Thursdays and Sundays.

title: COLLEGES STRUGGLING TO KEEP THEIR BENEFACTORS IN BOUNDS
description: THE garnet-and-gold railroad car next to Doak Campbell Stadium is a symbol of success. On any Saturday night during Florida State University's home football season, the Golden Chiefs will gather on the deck of the car to eat and drink and to discuss Seminole football and ''The Great White Chief,'' Coach Bobby Bowden.

title: Johns Hopkins No. 1 In Lacrosse Poll
description: Johns Hopkins defeated three opponents last week and remained No. 1 today in the Division I coaches' poll of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association.

title: News Analysis
description: The subject is municipal bankruptcy, but the issue is not money. Instead, the crisis facing Boston this week is a result of political paralysis as the factions that have grown up around city and state government here fight to be last on the list of those called upon to make sacrifices or take responsibility.

title: Japanese Also Divided on Auto Issues
description: United States officials expected to come here early next month to help resolve the problem of Japanese automobile exports will meet Government and industry officials who are as divided over the issue as their counterparts in the United States.

title: The Economy
description: Business bankruptcies soared 63 percent, to 2,933, in the first 10 weeks of 1981, reaching the highest level since 1963. The list was headed by building contractors, wholesalers and retailers, especially in the automotive sector, mainly because of their vulnerability to high interest rates and a sluggish economy. (Page A1.)

title: VERTLIEB RESIGNING HIS JOB WITH PACERS
description: Dick Vertlieb announced his resignation as general manager of the Indiana Pacers today, saying he wanted to keep his reasons private.

title: Correct Answer at the College Board
description: Given several choices on a tough question, the trustees of the College Entrance Examination Board have chosen the right response. They will now provide students throughout the country with copies of their Scholastic Aptitude Tests, the answers they wrote and a correct-answer index.

title: Tool Orders Extend Decline
description: Orders for machine tools fell 45 percent in February from the level of a year earlier, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday. Last month's total, $276.7 million, was down 1.5 percent from January's $281 million.

title: JANET LOB WED TO A.A. JUSTER
description: Janet Vicki Lob and Andrew Alan Juster were married yesterday in the Beth-El Chapel of Temple Emanu-El by Rabbi Richard Chapin. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Werner Lob of Fair Haven, N.J., is an administrative supervisor in the fine papers division of the Westvaco Corporation. Mr. Juster is an officer in the real estate division of the Chemical Bank. His parents, Mr. and Mrs. Howard H. Juster, reside in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Donald Kessler, Lawyer, Weds Elizabeth Weidel
description: Elizabeth Weidel, daughter of Karl Weidel 3d of Pennington, N.J., and the late Grace Hanson Weidel, was married yesterday to Donald Alan Kessler, son of Mrs. Betty Soschin of South Orange, N.J., and the late Jerome Kessler.

title: Woodchopper Wins Louisiana Derby
description: Woodchopper closed strongly in the stretch and scored a one-length victory over favored A Run today in the $190,300 Louisiana Derby at the Fairgrounds.

title: PIANO RECITAL: SCHUBERT AND CHOPIN BY BELLA DAVIDOVICH
description: BELLA DAVIDOVICH accepted two challenges in her piano recital at Carnegie Hall yesterday. The first was Schubert's B flat Piano Sonata - a work requiring abandon tempered by patience, a reverence for the moment and yet an ability to see Schubert's great temporal spaces as a whole.

title: Wriggling Ahead on China
description: Under cover of the Great Haig Flap, the Reagan Administration has deftly taken a significant turn in foreign policy. It has signaled China quietly that it wants to continue the Nixon-Ford-Carter policy that is euphemistically known as ''normalizing relations.'' That was the essence of the private assurances President Reagan gave to China's envoy to the United States - a message lately reinforced by Gerald Ford's goodwill visit to Peking.

title: Gretzky Sets Mark of 153 Points
description: Wayne Gretzky, the Edmonton Oilers' 20-year-old center, got an assist on a goal by Mark Messier in the second period against the Penguins last night in Pittsburgh for his 153d point, breaking Phil Esposito's National Hockey League single-season scoring record.

title: SEARCH NARROWS IN '79 SLAYING OF U.S. JUDGE IN TEXAS
description: After a 22-month search for the killers of Federal Judge John H. Wood, the Justice Department has apparently narrowed its list of suspects in the case to a 42-year-old Dallas man with a previous conviction of murder for hire and an El Paso drug smuggler over whose trial the judge was to have presided.

title: Canadian Voices Annoyance With U.S. Over Acid Rain
description: Canada's Environment Minister, John Roberts, said here today that his Government was growing ''increasingly impatient'' with the failure of the United States to control acid rain.

title: POLISH RULING BODY REACHES AN IMPASSE ON AVERTING STRIKE
description: Meeting in an unparalleled atmosphere of crisis, members of the Central Committee harshly attacked the Communist Party leadership today but ended by declining to accept resignations from the 10-member Politburo.

title: THE SELECTIVE REGULATOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Off Camera
description: ''There will be a sadness on Monday night,'' said Al McGuire. ''As we know the relationship now, it's probably the last call. Like 3 o'clock in the morning at a bar.''

title: A BROADER MESSAGE FOR GREEN RIBBONS
description: To the Editor:

title: McEnroe Tops Borg, 7-6, 6-4, in Milan Final
description: John McEnroe defeated Bjorn Borg, 7-6, 6-4, today to win a $200,000 World Championship Tennis tournament. It was McEnroe's fifth victory in 12 matches against Borg. The triumph, worth $35,000, was McEnroe's first in a World Championship Tennis tournament this season. A sellout crowd of 10,000 saw the match at Milan's indoor Sports Palace. McEnroe, 22 years old, who was seeded second, served powerfully, volleyed from the net and fired fine long-line passing shots throughout. Borg often missed first serve returns and forehand shots from the baseline.

title: SUSAN DEAN BRIDE OF DR. RICHARD CHODROFF
description: Susan L. Dean, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred L. Dean of Yardley, Pa., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard E. Chodroff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Chodroff of Plainview, L.I. Rabbi Bernard Perelmuter, assisted by Cantor Marshall Glatzer, performed the ceremony at Temple Har Sinai in Trenton.

title: f825Iran Anniversary Ad Credited to Toyota
description: ''Congratulations to the Islamic Republic of Iran on the occasion of the 2d Anniversary of its Revolution,'' said the ad in the Feb. 11 issue of The Japan Times, an English-language daily published in Tokyo.

title: Bridge: Mrs. Wei's Team Is Named As U.S. World Play Squad
description: The focus of attention on the final day of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here today was less on the 14 players who reached the semifinal stage of the Women's Knockout Team Championship than on two teams that have already been eliminated.

title: Fed Action On Rates Awaited
description: Monetary policy makers in the Federal Reserve meet tomorrow amid much discussion about whether short-term interest rates will rise or fall. Short-term rates have been dropping this year, but now, some analysts say, that trend may halt, or even be partly reversed.

title: CITING FABRICATIONS, WABC-TV CANCELS 'ANIMALS SPECIAL' FEATURE
description: TV canceled its weekly service feature, ''Airmail Special,'' on Saturday, after a lawsuit was filed against the station by a person who alleged that his name had been used, without his permission, as the author of a letter to the show, which formed the basis for one of its recent segments.

title: SOME BIG THEFTS PLAGUE CITY PARKS
description: Thieves are stealing chain link fencing, lampposts, statues and other metal materials from the city's parks, and Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis says the problem is growing more serious than the usual kind of park vandalism.

title: RABBI TROUPP WEDS CANTOR DANA SMOOKLER
description: Cantor Dana Smookler of Temple Beth Torah in Dix Hills, L.I., and Rabbi Leonard B. Troupp, co-director of the North American Federation of Temple Youth, an affliate of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, were married yesterday at Temple Shaari Emeth in Englishtown, N.J.

title: 1980 STATE TAX COLLECTION ROSE AN AVERAGE OF 9.6% NATIONWIDE
description: State tax collections declined in Michigan and Vermont last year, but increased sharply in California and averaged nearly 10 percent higher nationwide, the Census Bureau has reported.

title: Martina Navratilova Captures Tour Final
description: Martina Navratilova's 6-3, 7-6 victory over Andrea Jaeger yesterday for the $100,000 first prize in the Avon women's championships was a distinctive achievement.

title: CONCEPTS, ABSTRUSE, AND A HORSE, CONCRETE
description: A woman in a gold-colored outfit is at a White House entry gate, reading aloud from sheaves of scribbled notes as she seeks to inform President Reagan that she is suing fast-food franchises all across America.

title: More Mobil Oil Seen for Japan
description: The Mobil Corporation has notified Japanese oil companies that it will increase its supply of crude oil by 25 percent starting in April, industry sources said Friday.

title: FIRE DAMAGES HOTEL AT WORLD TRADE CENTER
description: A smoky fire yesterday at the new hotel at the World Trade Center led to the eviction of 55 maids, plumbers and electricians who were getting the $60 million Vista International New York Hotel ready for its grand opening Wednesday.

title: SOVIET ACCUSES UNION OF SEEKING CONTROL OF POLAND
description: The Soviet Union pressed its attack against the Polish trade union organization Solidarity today, accusing it of trying to intimidate Polish security forces and wrest control from the Government.

title: MUSIC: JULLIARD QUARTET SERIES
description: THE conjunction of Bartok and Brahms is not so strange as it might seem. At least that was the impression made by the Juilliard String Quartet at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday afternoon in the first of three concerts joining the two composers.

title: Youngstown Teachers Reject Contract Offer
description: Youngstown teachers, who have been on strike since Feb. 20, rejected a contract offer today that would have raised salaries 6.25 percent.

title: Links; What's Really Dumb
description: Detran Lloyd and Leslie Williams, two black teen-agers in Louisiana, have offered to sacrifice their places on a parochial high school golf team so that their white teammates can play in tournaments at segregated private clubs. Their concern for the team may seem noble, but it's shameful that they were put into such a position.

title: TAX BREAKS CAUSE SPLIT IN HARTFORD
description: Property taxes here are so high that realestate developers will not build if they have to pay the full rate, according to the City Council, which voted last Monday to give up $660,000 in taxes to lure a $70 million office complex.

title: Work on Queensboro Bridge
description: Because of construction, the upper roadway of the Queensboro Bridge at 59th Street will be closed until 11 A.M. today, the New York City Department of Traffic said yesterday. The Police Department advised motorists to avoid the bridge entirely, if possible.

title: Red Smith; Grandstand Romance
description: HERB SHULTZ, who has been quoted in this space before, is a gentleman and angler whose heart belongs to the St. Louis Cardinals. The attic of his home in Kingston, N.Y., is a treasure trove that compares favorably with Fort Knox, containing scorecards of every Cardinal game Herb has seen since childhood, pennants, World Series rain checks and countless other memorabilia more precious than emeralds.

title: CBS Paid Wyman $1 Million to Join
description: When Thomas H. Wyman joined CBS Inc. last June, with no previous broadcast experience, he got a $1 million inducement for signing on as president and chief executive officer. In addition, Mr. Wyman received a guarantee that his annual pay would be at least $750,000, including incentives.

title: IN THE HEAT OF BATTLE, A LITTLE PAINTING HELPS
description: According to popular legend, Nero fiddled while Rome burned. When El Salvador was on the point of going up in flames, Jose Napoleon Duarte painted.

title: Searchers Find 11th Body In Rubble of Condominium
description: Searchers fought their way through chunks of concrete and twisted metal rods today to unearth the body of the 11th construction worker killed in the collapse of a five-story condominium.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a review of a jazz group, Tentet, in The Times on Thursday, the name of the bass trombonist was given incorrectly. It was Dave Taylor.

title: AL WOOD: A LOOK BEHIND A SHOOTER
description: The label has its roots in Gray, Ga., at Jones County High School, where Al Wood first exhibited the skills that had been developed in the vacant lot across the street from his home. What was once a compliment is now almost an annoyance. Wood was labeled a pure shooter then, and has been ever since.

title: Woman, 90, Killed; Burglary Suspected
description: A 90-year-old Brooklyn woman was found dead in her apartment by the police yesterday, several days after she apparently had been beaten during a burglary.

title: Johnson Knockout Lifts Spinks's Hopes
description: Michael Spinks says he's ready for a title shot after knocking out Marvin Johnson, the two-time lightheavyweight champion, with a short, hard left yesterday in the fourth round of their scheduled 10-rounder.

title: REAGAN SAYS CITY FAILED TO CORRECT SCHOOLS' DEFECTS
description: The New York City Board of Education was criticized yesterday by the New York State Comptroller for failing to correct construction deficiencies that have plagued the Northeast Bronx Education Park, a complex of five public schools built in the early 1970's at Co-op City.

title: CHICAGO MAYOR'S PROPOSED MOVE TO HOUSING PROJECT TOUCHES OFF CLEANUP BLITZ
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne's announcement that she would move into the crime-ridden Cabrini Green public housing project started a flurry of action by city agencies that has not been seen here since the visit last year by Pope John Paul II.

title: POLITICS OF REJECTION
description: The most striking thing about the French election campaign is the public lassitude, like that shown by Americans last fall.

title: FRANK TIERI, THE FIRST CONVICTED OF HEADING A CRIME FAMILY, DIES
description: Frank Tieri, who Federal authorities said was the first person ever convicted of heading an organized-crime family, died at Mount Sinai hospital yesterday after a long illness.He was 77 years old.

title: OLIVER UNGER, SPENT 46 YEARS AS EXECUTIVE IN THE MOVIE BUSINESS
description: Oliver Unger, who began his 46-year career in motion-pictures in the film import and export business and later became a producer, exhibitor and distributor, died in his sleep on Friday in the Los Angeles home of his lifelong friend and associate, Ely Landau. Mr. Unger lived in Los Angeles and was 66 years old.

title: MANHATTAN STUDYING WASHINGTON IN EFFORT TO LIFT COURTS' EFFICIENCY
description: Last year, the 18 to 20 judges in Manhattan Criminal Court held 386 misdemeanor trials - the most since the early 1970's. In Washington, where six to eight judges sat, three times as many misdemeanor trials were held. The conviction rate in Manhattan - including pleas and guilty verdicts - was about 56 percent. In Washington, it was 70 percent. Faced with a backlog of thousands of misdemeanor cases, the administrators of Manhattan Criminal Court are looking for ways to improve their pretrial and trial procedures, and they hope to learn from the new system begun last year in Washington. Some Night Trials Planned

title: VIOLA TAKES HIS TURN AS THE PRESIDENT OF ARGENTINA
description: Gen. Roberto Eduardo Viola, former commander in chief of the army, was sworn in today for a three-year term as the 38th President of Argentina with moderate pomp, great hope and few spectators.

title: SOME CITY TRIALS WILL BE AT NIGHT FOR EXPERIMENT
description: New York City court officials are planning an experiment to speed up their badly backlogged calendars and make fuller use of limited court facilities by holding civil trials and possibly misdemeanor criminal trials in the evening.

title: Cosmos Win by 3-0; Chinaglia Scores 2
description: Giorgio Chinaglia scored two goals today to help the Cosmos to a 3-0 victory over the San Jose Earthquakes.

title: by Felicia Lamport; James Whitcomb Riley
description: When supply-side gits the bacon And demand-side's up the crick, It can start a heap uv achin' In the body politic. And when all them truly needy Git their safety nets an' stuff, That'll make the merely seedy Truly needy quick enuf.

title: Six Horses Stabbed In Barns at Calder
description: Five thoroughbreds and a pony were stabbed in the barns at Calder Race Course this morning, but security officials said none of the horses was injured seriously. No one was arrested in connection with the stabbings.

title: SUPERPOWERS' ANACHRONISTIC GAME
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: WHAT TO WATCH UNTIL THE OSCARS COME ON
description: HOLLYWOOD'S Academy Awards shindig, like baseball's World Series and football's Super Bowl, is always among the most-watched television programs of the year. ABC-TV should experience no anxiety attacks when the glitter and inevitably boring speeches get under way tonight at 10. There remains the problem, however, of what to do for a curtain raiser. The network is relying on two specials.

title: IN INDIANA, THE 'ERA OF LESS' IS A ROLLED-BACK PAYCHECK
description: The era of less that some politicians and economists have been talking about arrived at Warren Jennings's house the other day.

title: MEDDLING RIVALS
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN TURNS BACK THE WOMEN'S CLOCK
description: To the Editor:

title: Vernon Jordan Says Budget Cuts Will Assure Some 'Will Go Under'
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the civil rights leader, said yesterday that President Reagan's budget cuts would assure that some poor people ''will go under.''

title: A Dream for Brooklyn
description: A New York State Senator, Thomas J. Bartosiewicz of Brooklyn, flew off to Florida last night on a quixotic quest. He'll ask the Los Angeles Dodgers to support a new Brooklyn major league baseball franchise - to be known as the Brooklyn Dodgers.

title: TROUT ANGLERS HAVE REASONS FOR OPTIMISM
description: Rousted from their late-winter doldrums by visions of gleaming trout and festooned with new equipment, thousands of New York State anglers will be out before dawn Wednesday for the first day of the trout season.

title: Consistency and Good Luck Bring Phil Mahre Skiing's Top Prize
description: Most skiers say they would forfeit an Olympic gold medal for the chance to win the World Cup, a crystal globe worth upwards of $2,000 on the shelf and much more in potential commercial revenue.

title: The U.N. Today; March 30, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing Nonuse of Force in International Rela- tions - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Hustle Coach Back
description: Coach Doug Gleason of the Chicago Hustle, dismissed by the team Friday, showed up just before tipoff in last night's game against Nebraska with a court order allowing him to resume his duties.

title: By Jim Benagh
description: Sports World Specials Extra Rounds

title: Teheran Newspaper Shuts Down
description: A Teheran daily newspaper, Islamic Revolution, Iran's largest non-Government newspaper, will not appear for at least a week because of a shortage of newsprint, a spokesman said today. Islamic Revolution, which is controlled by President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, is one of the few dailies not supporting the dominant Islamic Republican Party. ''God willing, we shall begin publishing the newspaper again as from April 4,'' a spokesman said.

title: Mixed Emotions
description: There was a lot of emotion expended last Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden by fans watching the final of the National Invitation Tournament. Most of the cheering was for Syracuse, the ''local'' team, but a contingent of about 700 was rooting for Tulsa, which won in overtime, 86-84.

title: Report Assails Treatment Of Army Recruit Who Died
description: A military report has condemned the treatment of a 17-year-old Army recruit who died of heatstroke at Fort Benning, Ga., after collapsing on a work detail and being ordered dragged into the sun on the day he was released from a monthlong hospital stay, it was reported today.

title: ROGERS SHOOTS 70-278 FOR STROKE VICTORY
description: Bill (Buck) Rogers squandered a five-stroke lead today, then won the Heritage Classic by one. With four pursuers pressing hard, he coolly parred the last four holes. All those two-putt pars were difficult ones, from long distances.

title: PHILADELPHIA LINGUIST DRAWS THE PRAISE OF COLLEAGUES AND GIBES OF POLITICANS
description: This city, the home of the champion Phillies baseball team, of Benjamin Franklin and the Liberty Bell, is one big laboratory to William Labov, and all its neighborhoods are his testing tables.

title: A Teacher Who Never Learns
description: WHEN the Louisiana State rooter told him, ''Congratulations,'' all Bobby Knight had to say was, ''Thank you,'' and keep walking. But, no, Bobby Knight had to be himself. Bobby Knight had to gloat, however pleasantly. One word led to another, which led, Bobby Knight has acknowledged, to the Indiana basketball coach's putting the Louisiana State rooter, Lewis (Buddy) Bonnecaze Jr., ''up against the wall'' early Saturday night in the lounge of the nearby Cherry Hill Inn in New Jersey, where the Indiana team and dozens of L.S.U. loyalists were lodged for the final weekend of the National Collegiate basketball tournament.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard VILE FLORENTINES. The Florence of Dante, Giotto and Boccaccio. By Timo- thy Holme. 193 pages. St. Martin's. $10.95.

title: Louisiana Tech Defeats Tennessee, 79-59, to Win A.I.A.W. Final
description: Louisiana Tech completed an undefeated season today by beating Tennessee, 79-59, to capture the Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women Division I basketball championship. The Lady Techsters from Ruston, La., won for the 34th time and became the first major women's team to go unbeaten since Delta State in 1974-75.

title: JANE FONDA OF THE 80'S MELLOWER BUT STILL AN ACTIVIST
description: THERE in the middle of the Ocean Life Room of the American Museum of Natural History stood Jane Fonda, dressed in an ice-blue sequined gown and surrounded by 300 extras. One woman pressed a lock of Miss Fonda's hair in place, and another adjusted the draping of her dress, carefully taping a bit of rhinestone trim in place. Meanwhile, a cameraman was having trouble getting the actress in his line of focus. ''Could you move a little to the left?'' he asked. ''Always,'' she said, and several people - Miss Fonda not among them - laughed.

title: Laetare Medal to Muskie
description: Former Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie was named yesterday as the 1981 recipient of the Laetare Medal, the University of Notre Dame's highest honor.

title: CAREY AND A FRIEND HELP MARK GREEK INDEPENDENCE
description: Fifth Avenue, which turns different ethnic hues on different parade days each year, was filled yesterday with the romantic brass and drums of Greek music and the rich scent of souvlakia. It was the annual Greek Independence Day Parade, and the 160th anniversary of the end of Turkish rule in Greece.

title: Airbus Cut Protested
description: The European Economic Community Commission has formally protested to Japan a decision by Toa, a domestic airline, to reduce an order for nine European Airbuses, sources in the community said Friday. Toa ordered nine Airbuses, with a total value of $315 million, in the spring of 1979.

title: ARROWS DEFEAT ST. LOUIS FOR M.I.S.L. TITLE
description: Steve Zungul scored his fourth goal with 30 seconds remaining today to give the New York Arrows their third consecutive Major Indoor Soccer League championship with a 6-5 victory over the St. Louis Steamers.

title: Amanda Simon Is a Bride
description: Amanda A. Simon, a buyer of glass and dinnerware for the Pottery Barn in New York, was married yesterday in London to Mitchell H. Bodian.

title: A Surprise for Lillian Hellman, but No Sympathy
description: Lillian Hellman doesn't expect anybody to believe it, but she swears it came as a complete surprise when she found out that she would be an identified character in the 1977 movie ''Julia.'' The movie was adapted from Miss Hellman's autobiographical book ''Pentimento,'' but at the time the story was sold, she said, ''it literally never occurred to me that my name was going to be used.''

title: No Hitters
description: Not long after he was born 27 years ago in Brooklyn, Dick Lally became a rabid baseball fan. With his father rooting for the Giants and his mother for the Dodgers, he allied himself with the Yankees and has rooted for them since.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MARCH 30, 1981
description: International Poland's Communist leadership was assailed by members of the Central Committee in an unparalleled atmosphere of crisis. But at the end of the meeting that lasted nearly 19 hours the committee accepted no resignations offered by some officials on the the governing 10-member Politburo. The meeting produced a standoff between hard-line and moderate factions over how far to go in seeking an accommodation with the Solidarity union, which threatens a national strike tomorrow. Portions of the speeches made public included charges that the party leadership was cut off from the party's lower echelons and was moving too slowly in carrying out the country's liberalization, or ''democratic renewal.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) More troops have joined the exercises of Warsaw Pact military forces along Poland's border, according to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and other American officials. The maneuvers were supposed to have ended a few days ago, but they have been extended indefinitely. (A1:5.)

title: Nordiques 4, Canadiens 0
description: Peter Stastny and Jacques Richard each reached the 100-point mark and Dan Bouchard recorded his second shutout of the season as Quebec blanked Montreal and extended its unbeaten streak to 10 games.

title: UNLOCKING PROXIES' SECRETS
description: The corporate proxy statement, for years a perfunctory document written in soporific legal phrasing of marginal value to most shareholders, has grown into an indispensible volume of corporate literature.

title: Man Set Free After 6 Years For Murder Is Found Dead
description: Jerry Banks, who spent six years in prison before murder charges against him were dismissed in December, died of a gunshot wound to the chest tonight, the authorities said. His wife was critically wounded.

title: A Sad Parting for Charles
description: She kissed him twice, then broke into tears, and no wonder. It will be five weeks before Lady Diana Spencer sees her fiance again. The emotional parting took place yesterday at London's Heathrow Airport as Prince Charles flew off on a trip that will take him to New Zealand, Australia, Venezuela and the United States before he returns home in May.

title: PENSION LAWS SOUGHT TO AVERT SOCIAL SEVURITY GAP
description: Far-reaching legislation to mandate private pensions for virtually all workers and insure the future stability of the Social Security system is being drafted to avert the possibility that today's younger generations may not be able to afford retirement at 65 years of age.

title: Al Goldstein's Admission to Press Club Stirs a Protest
description: What's been described as a ''sizable uproar'' has erupted among members of the Overseas Press Club of America over the recent admission to membership of Al Goldstein, publisher of Screw magazine.

title: Israeli Cabinet Approves Canal to Dead Sea
description: Israel's Cabinet today approved a longplanned 50-mile hydroelectric canal between the Dead Sea and the Mediterranean and said that it would start as a tunnel under the occupied four-mile-wide Gaza Strip. Egypt has contended that such a tunnel would violate international law.

title: Ellen Gravallese Married To M. Timothy Hresko
description: Ellen M. Gravallese and M. Timothy Hresko, who expect to be graduated on May 14 from the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, were married yesterday in Andover, Mass.

title: Basque Terrorist Suspect Killed
description: The police killed a suspected Basque terrorist today and seriously wounded another in a shootout, the authorities said. They identified him as Jose Manuel Aristimuno Mendizabal, an alleged member of the Basque separatist organization E.T.A., and said he was armed with two pistols and several hand grenades. The authorities did not disclose the name of the wounded suspect, but they said four people were detained for questioning.

title: THEATER: 'THE TANTALUS'
description: IT'S unfair; they cheat in the final scene of ''The Tantalus,'' the mystery at the Harold Clurman Theater. It's not the jiggery pokey with the will that's unfair; what's unfair is the character who seems to be a rotten egg, but then puts things to right at the end. The authors, Ian Cullen and Catherine Arley, violate the canons of proper mystery writing there, but if you are willing to suspend disbelief a little you probably won't care. ''The Tantalus'' is stylish and fun.

title: Bossy's 68th Goal Beats Capitals, 5-4, and Puts Islanders in First
description: It took the New York Islanders a month and a half to do it, but Mike Bossy's 68th goal today put the defending Stanley Cup champions back in first place in the National Hockey League's overall standing.

title: Church & Dwight Move
description: Robert A. Davies 3d, 45 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Church & Dwight Company of Piscataway, N.J. He succeeds Dwight C. Minton, 46, who was elected chairman and continues as chief executive officer of the country's largest sodium bicarbonate and baking soda producer.

title: CONCERT: ANDRAS SCHIFF AND STUTTGART CHAMBER ORCHESTRA
description: THE problem of finding a convincing way to play Mozart's piano concertos continues to vex intelligent musicians. So long as performers and audiences want to hear these glorious works on the modern piano, with its mingled virtues and faults, the chances of agreement on a Mozart style are pretty slight. However, it is probably safe to say that most musicians today favor a more expressively reticent and thinner-textured Mozart than was generally heard a generation ago. They know more about the esthetic preferences of the 18th century than their fathers did, thanks to scholarly researches, and they try to put that knowledge into action.

title: A Last Chance for Conrail
description: The Reagan Administration wants to sell Conrail, line by line, to the highest bidders. Conrail's overseers, however, and the Interstate Commerce Commission contend that, at least for the present, the giant frostbelt rail system should be kept in one piece.

title: Young & Rubicam Chosen By New Mattell Unit
description: Young & Rubicam's Los Angeles office has just been named to be the agency for a newly formed unit of Mattel called Mattel Communications, which is charged with new business and new product development.

title: CONFIDENCE IN ECONOMY LESSENS
description: The nation's business leaders in recent weeks have grown less confident about the economy and about their own prospects, according to a new survey scheduled to be released today.

title: McNamara & Clapp's First
description: McNamara & Clapp has landed that much-desired first account, Taylor Rental Centers of America, a franchising operation that spends about $1.5 million for advertising. The business was formerly at Norman, Craig & Kummel, as were McNamara and Clapp.

title: Carrington Visits Hong Kong
description: Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary, arrived in Hong Kong today from Pakistan.

title: THE WOUNDED LION; by William Safire
description: The joke is being told about the archangels in heaven who were worried about the way God was walking around with a long face. ''He's depressed,'' said Gabriel. Michael agreed, and persuaded God to send for Sigmund Freud to cure His depression.

title: A NEW WAY OF LOOKING AT GOSSIP
description: The question is, why do we gossip? "It's a very curious pleasure, and a curious sin," said Dr. Maury Silver, an assistant professor of psychology at John Hopkins University. "Most people gossip, but they feel they shouldn't and they're discreet when they do."

title: POP SINGER: JEAN SABLON RETURNS
description: JEAN SABLON, who was the French crooning equivalent of Bing Crosby in the 30's and 40's and whose career has continued ever since, made his first appearance in the United States in almost 20 years on Saturday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Mr. Sablon's program was called ''A Return to Romance'' and, for all his 75 years, he can still suggest the romantic boulevardier.

title: IS BUSINESS REGULATION NOW IN FRIENDLY HANDS
description: President Reagan, in assembling his regulatory team, appears to be heeding the words of one of his favorite Presidents, Calvin Coolidge, who told newspaper editors in 1925 that ''the business of America is business.''

title: FOUR KILLED IN FIRE
description: A man and three children died in bed in a fire yesterday that damaged an apartment above a pizza parlor.

title: No Headline
description: Reutemann Is Winner of Brazil Grand Prix

title: Guidry Pitches Well After Contract Talks
description: Contract negotiations between John Schneider, Ron Guidry's lawyer, and George Steinbrenner continued this morning and Guidry improved his position in the afternoon with a strong performance against the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: FRAUD TRIAL BEGINS TODAY FOR MAN U.S. HAS TRIED TO DEPORT SINCE '53
description: Carlos Marcello, who the Government says is a major organized crime figure, was born in Tunis on Feb. 6, 1910, of Italian parents. He arrived in New Orleans when he was eight months old and, despite a 1953 deportation order upheld by the Supreme Court, has been in the United States ever since, except for a few weeks in 1961, when he was taken to Guatemala by Federal agents.

title: Carey Plans to Curb Deposits to Utilities
description: Most residential customers of gas and electric utilities would no longer have to put down security deposits under legislation being proposed by Governor Carey.

title: RELIGIOUS GROUPS PLAN ADVERTISING CAMPAIGN AGAINST WORLD HUNGER
description: Three major religious agencies, with the aid of the Advertising Council, have joined to begin an extensive advertising campaign to fight hunger throughout the world, the National Council of Churches said today.

title: CITY WINNING WAR ON POTHOLES
description: It may not be apparent to drivers whose cars must navigate the rippled surfaces of Columbus or Amsterdam Avenues in Manhattan or the disappearing streets of Douglaston, Queens, but New York City has fewer potholes than it has ever had, according to the city's Bureau of Highway Operations.

title: STORY OF DRUGS AT SCHOOL DISTURBS JERSEY MILL CITY
description: This blue-collar mill city on the Marce River in flat southern New Jersey is upset over the disclosure last week of drug dealing among students at Millville Senior High School and sales of marijuana to fourth- , fifth- and sixth-graders.

title: KATHY CRONKITE: A CELEBRATED FATHER
description: 13 By JUDY KLEMESRUD

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DERVISH

title: '68 PLOT IN BRITAIN VERIFIED BY WILSON
description: Former Prime Minister Harold Wilson said tonight that an article in today's Sunday Times was correct in reporting that Britain's counterintelligence agency investigated an alleged 1968 plot to overthrow his Labor Government. But Sir Harold strongly denied the newspaper's allegation that Earl Mountbatten, a member of the royal family, was involved.

title: 2 John Lennon Memorials Draw 4,000 in Liverpool
description: Two thousand fans, some weeping, jammed Britain's largest cathedral today for a service commemorating John Lennon, the former Beatle slain in New York last year.

title: Marjorie Schlossberg, an Aide Of Bank, Wed to Philip Dorin
description: Marjorie Schlossberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Schlossberg of Hewlett, L.I., was married yesterday at Hampshire House to Philip Dorin, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Paul Dorin of Freehold, N.J. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony.

title: STAGE: LAUREN BACALL IN 'WOMAN OF YEAR'
description: ''I WROTE the book on class,'' sings Lauren Bacall in her new musical, ''Woman of the Year,'' and you had better believe it. This star's elegance is no charade, no mere matter of beautiful looks and gorgeous gowns. Her class begins where real class must - in her spirit -and only then makes its way to her angular physique, her big, sensuous eyes and that snapdragon of a voice. Even when her leading man, Harry Guardino, dumps a pot of water over her head, she remains not only mesmerizing, but also completely fresh. As hard and well as Miss Bacall works in ''Woman of the Year,'' she never lets us see any sweat.

title: Team Tennis Revisited
description: Larry King, the former president of World Team Tennis, still believes that team competition in tennis can succeed. So King intends to revive the concept this summer. This time, the league -called Team Tennis - will have four teams, operating exclusively in California. The schedule, however, will run only from July 7 to July 26. Each team will have two women and two men, competing without guaranteed salaries for eventual purse money of $310,000 that would be distributed on the basis of final team and individual standings. Competition will be in men's singles, women's singles and mixed doubles.

title: DISPUTES BETWEEN BLACKS AND JEWS DIVIDE DEMOCRATS IN SEVERAL STATES
description: Michigan's Democratic Party is badly split, with divisions between Jews and blacks threatening its ability to raise money, defend its interests in redistricting and prepare for statewide races in 1982.

title: Music: Janet Millard Plays Flute Works
description: IN a lively program yesterday afternoon at the Abraham Goodman House, Janet Millard, the principal flutist of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra, proved to be a lively player. With the assistance of the harpist, Emily Mitchell, Krumpholtz's Sonata in F for flute and harp sounded gracious, Marc Neikrug's recent ''Rituals'' was percussive and mournful (and overly long), and Bartok's ''Suite Paysanne Hongroise'' was energetic and spritely.

title: Williams Abscam Trial Scheduled to Start Today
description: Jury selection is scheduled to begin today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn for the trial of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey, who is accused of bribery and conspiracy in the Abscam case.

title: Postal Inquiry Begun On Tips for Services
description: A practice in which postal employees in Manhattan's Murray Hill section provided special service to businesses in exchange for gratuities is being investigated by postal inspectors and the United States Attorney's office for the Southern District of New York.

title: Met Mystery Lingers
description: With only one full week left in spring training, the chief mystery in the camp of the New York Mets is as old as the franchise: Who plays third base?

title: London Marathon Ends in Dead Heat
description: Dick Beardsley of the United States and Inge Simonsen of Norway ran past an estimated 1 million spectators in the rain today and joined hands to finish in a dead heat for first place in the first London Marathon.

title: Pat Bradley's 284 Wins Kemper by 5
description: Pat Bradley shot a one-underpar 70 today to capture the $175,000 Women's Kemper open by five shots.

title: JOEL HALPERN, DEVELOPER AND RACER
description: Joel A. Halpern, a Westchester County real-estate developer and twice a national champion in offshore powerboat racing, was killed Saturday in an accident during a warmup period for the New Orleans Halter 200 Race. Mr. Halpern, a resident of Purchase, N.Y., was 41 years old.

title: NURSING-HOME STRIKE SET AS UNION BREAKS OFF TALKS
description: Union leaders broke off negotiations with metropolitan nursing homes yesterday, and a strike by nurses and other employees was scheduled for 6 A.M. tomorrow in 81 homes with 20,000 patients.

title: TRIAL OF MARGIOTTA BEGINS ON L.I. FRAUD CHARGE
description: Sharply contrasting views of Joseph M. Margiotta were presented today by opposing counsel as his trial on charges of mail fraud and extortion began in Federal District Court here.

title: COSTA RICA BUFFETED BY REGIONAL UNREST
description: Long held up as proof that democracy can prosper in Latin America, Costa Rica is suddenly being buffeted from abroad by political and economic forces that it cannot control.

title: DEPRESSION APPEARS TO AFFLICT THOUSANDS OF CHILDREN IN U.S.
description: AFTER years of debate, a growing number of psychiatrists and psychologists are concluding that even children can suffer from depression. Clinicians had long insisted that children under about 14 years of age lack the psychological capacity to experience depression, and some still remain skeptical.

title: DENVER NEIGHBORS REVEAL LITTLE ON SUSPECT
description: The parents of John W. Hinckley Jr., who is accused of shooting President Reagan and three others in Washington today, remained in seclusion at the home of a neighbor here tonight, declining to speak with the dozens of reporters who milled outside their house in below-freezing weather.

title: 8 MAJOR BANKS AGREE ON JAMAICA CREDIT PLAN
description: Eight major international banks have agreed to establish a new $70 million credit to Jamaica's recently elected centrist Government, and to refinance another $103 million in loans owed by the country, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: DEMOCRATS AGREE ON STATE BUDGET
description: Governor Carey and the Legislature's Democratic leaders were in virtual agreement tonight on revisions to Mr. Carey's proposed budget for the fiscal year that begins Wednesday. However, substantial differences remained between the Democrats and Republicans.

title: 7 Die as Philippine Bridge Falls
description: Seven Filipino villagers fell 40 feet to their deaths when a footbridge snapped and tossed them into a ravine in the northern community of Tinongdan, the Philippines News Agency said today. Eight people were injured in the accident yesterday, including a 10-year-old boy who saved himself by clinging to one of the snapped cables, the agency said.

title: Advertising; Goodyear Campaign Adds Blimp
description: THREE years ago the 80-year-old Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company broke its first corporate ad campaign with the theme ''Out front. Pulling away,'' aimed mostly at the business and financial communities.

title: MARCOS, IN A CHANGE, WILL DEBATE WITH OPPOSITION REPRESENTATIVE
description: In a departure from past aloofness, President Ferdinand E. Marcos has challenged some of his political opponents to a debate Thursday and they have accepted.

title: WALTER H. FREYGANG
description: Walter H. Freygang, former president, chairman and executive officer of domestic subsidiaries of Walter Kidde & Company, died Sunday at his home in Essex Fells, N.J. He was 90 years old.

title: POLISH STRIKE IN ABEYANCE AS PACT IS SIGNED
description: A general strike scheduled for tomorrow was put in abeyance today after leaders of the independent labor movement reached an agreement with the Government during seven hours of bargaining.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Reassigned Brooks C arey and Mike Boddicker, pitchers, and D allas Williams, outfielder, to minor-league c omplex. CINCINNATI (NL) - Reassigned Charlie L eibrandt, pitcher; Greg Mahlberg, catch- e r, and Eddie Milner, outfielder, to minor- l eague complex.

title: CAREY REJECTS TIGHTENING OF CO-OP CONVERSION LAW
description: Governor Carey said today that he would oppose legislation to increase the number of tenants required to approve turning rental apartments into cooperatives or condominiums.

title: A BULLET IS REMOVED FROM REAGAN'S LUNG IN EMERGENCY SURGERY
description: President Reagan was treated for a partly collapsed lung today, but the bullet that entered his left side and lodged in the tissue of his left lung did not do much further damage, according to doctors who operated on him. Surgeons removed a .22-caliber bullet from the President's lower left lung.

title: HOAX SWITCHES CALLS TO FEMINISTS TO PHONE PLEA AGAINST ABORTION
description: Officials of two feminist organizations were perplexed today over the way telephone calls to their switchboards were referred over the weekend to numbers that gave recorded antiabortion messages.

title: Japan Car Exports To U.S. Off a Bit
description: Japan's automobile exports in February totaled 530,452 units, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. Shipments to the United States were down, while developing nations imported more than previously.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TRANSCRIPT OF BRIEFING ON WOUNDS OF PRESIDENT AND TWO OTHERS
description: Following is a transcript of the press briefing by Dr. Dennis S. O'Leary at George Washington University Hospital last night, as recorded by The New York Times: Special to the New York Times
