title: by S. Fred Singer
description: World oil consumption peaked during 1978-79 at around 60 million barrels per day and should decline to some 20 million barrels a day during the 1990's. This statement flies in the face of accepted wisdom, which still talks of an increasing world demand, of supply shortages, and of a long-term and worsening oil crisis beginning in 1983 - that was Jimmy Carter's date - or a little later.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Sunday in The Times's New Jersey Weekly incorrectly reported the circumstances under which Thomas Michalak accepted a position as music director of the Kansas City Philharmonic in Missouri. Mr. Michalak will continue as conductor of the New Jersey Symphony. His contract with the Missouri orchestra takes effect Wednesday and calls for him to be music adviser for the 1981-82 season and to serve an unspecified term as principal guest conductor.

title: Israel Appoints Career Diplomat As Its New Ambassador to Egypt
description: Moshe Sasson, a career diplomat specializing in Arab affairs, has been named ambassador to Egypt.

title: CP Sees Slow Year
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd., a multinational transportation, resources and investment concern based in Montreal, said it expects world economic growth to be weak this year, which will limit growth in world trade and hurt the shipping business. It said in its annual report that rising fuel prices would have a negative impact on all transportation activities, with airlines being most vulnerable.

title: STAGE: 'DANCE, RAILROAD,' BY DAVID HENRY HWANG
description: year-old Chinese-American playwright, is a true original. A native of Los Angeles, born to immigrant parents, he has one foot on each side of a cultural divide. He knows America - its vernacular, its social landscape, its theatrical traditions. He knows the same about China. In his plays, he manages to mix both of these conflicting cultures until he arrives at a style that is wholly his own. Mr. Hwang's works have the verve of well-made American comedies and yet, with little warning, they can bubble over into the mystical rituals of Oriental stagecraft. By at once bringing West and East into conflict and unity, this playwright has found the perfect means to dramatize both the pain and humor of the immigrant experience.

title: Oil Bill Said to Benefit OPEC-
description: The House sponsor of a proposal to let p rivate industry finance America's strategic petroleum reserve c onceded today that oil-producing nations could buy into the reserve a nd profit from it.

title: Disney Assets Deal Opposed by Nephew
description: Retlaw Enterprises, a company owned by members of the family of the late Walt Disney, has agreed in principle to permit Walt Disney Productions, the giant entertainment corporation founded by Mr. Disney, to acquire certain Retlaw assets, including Walt Dis@ney's name.

title: EXCHANGES FIGHT OVER OPTIONS
description: The Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's largest futures exchange, and a market that it created - the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the country's biggest options exchange -have become embroiled in a struggle over the trading of options on commodities and Government securities.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Discounts Reports of 1968 Coup Plot
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's office today dismissed reports of an alleged coup to overthrow the Labor Government more than 12 years ago as ''nothing new'' and refused an opposition request to investigate it.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RETROSPECTIVE

title: Reagan Wounded in Chest by Gunman; Outlook Good After 2-Hour Surgery; Aide and 2 Guards Shot; Suspect Held
description: President Reagan was shot in the chest today by a gunman, apparently acting alone, as Mr. Reagan walked to his limousine after addressing a labor meeting at the Washington Hilton Hotel. The White House press secretary and two law-enforcement officers were also wounded by a burst of shots.

title: Barclays Profit Off 1.1% in 1980
description: Barclays Bank Ltd., Britain's largest banking organization, enjoys a strong underlying level of profitability on which it can rely as soon as interest rates fall to more acceptable levels, Anthony Tuke, chairman, said in the annual report, to be issued tomorrow.

title: RANGERS AND FLYERS PLAT 0-0 TIE
description: The New York Rangers edged one important point closer to qualifying for the Stanley Cup playoffs last night by playing a rare 0-0 tie, with the Philadelphia Flyers at Madison Square Garden.

title: CABARET: CAROL FREDETTE SINGS
description: IN view of the surroundings in which Carol Fredette is singing at the Conservatory in the Mayflower Hotel, Central Park West and 61st Street, it is probably inevitable that she leans on her instinct for comedy, even when she is singing songs that might normally be expected to be delivered soberly.

title: Schering Gets Loan
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation, a producer of drugs, toiletries and cosmetics, said the company had received a $150 million loan from the Saudi Arabian Money Agency. A spokesman said that terms of the loan were 14 percent with an average maturity of four years and added that the company expected to use the loan to retire some commercial paper debts.

title: COAST GUARDSMAN DIES, 2 KILLED ON FUTILE RESCUE MISSION IN GULF
description: A Coast Guardsmen was killed and two were injured today when their 41-foot patrol boat capsized in rough seas as they returned to their base after a search mission, officials said.

title: Writers' Panel Tonight
description: ''Books and Morality'' will be the theme of a discussion tonight at 8 o'clock in the Bobst Library of New York University, 70 Washington Square South.

title: ANGOLA, WORRIED ABOUT THE U.S., TREADS CAREFULLY
description: The Marxist Government here is deeply concerned over the Reagan Administration's growing ties to South Africa and the possibility that Washington might arm Angola's insurgents. The regime, however, is eager to dampen the crisis and is carefully avoiding criticism of Washington.

title: REGAN WAS RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Persistence and Bravery on the Subway Are Rewarded
description: In the early-morning hours of Dec. 31, 1979, Jesus Rodriguez, counterman in an East Side delicatessen, was riding a southbound E train on his way to his home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. He spotted nine persons robbing an elderly man at knifepoint.

title: Market Place; Hawaii Stocks Draw Interest
description: FOR a stock market tuned acutely to any news of undervalued resource stocks, the announcement issued in Honolulu on March 16 lighted up the eyes of investors and speculators alike.

title: Series on Boosters Concludes
description: The last article in a three-part series on the growing problem of the role of boosters in intercollegiate sports appears on page B20.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: TED WILLIAMS' baseball career with the Boston Red Sox was ending, and my medical school roommate, David J. Kudzma, was tempted. Should he go to Fenway Park to watch his hero in his last home game? Or, more dutifully, should he go to the library to read about a patient's disease?

title: John L. Simpson Dead on Coast; Banker Was Director of Bechtel
description: John L. Simpson, a former international banker and director of the Bechtel Corporation, died Saturday at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 90 years old.

title: DEMOCRATIC WOMEN ACTING LIKE WINNERS
description: There is one group of Democrats in town doing business as usual, despite last fall's Republican landslide that uprooted Democrats and gave the capital a decidedly Republican flavor. The group is the Woman's National Democratic Club.

title: TOWER AIDE GETTING ENERGY JOB
description: Charles M. Butler 3d, a 38-year-old aide to Senator John G. Tower, Republican of Texas, is to be named chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, according to a source with top-level ties to the agency.

title: Search Goes On in Florida Where Bodies Were Found
description: The authorities dug for more bodies today near the base of a chimney at a rural home where the skeletons of two women and a part of a third female skeleton have been found.

title: KOCH IS EXPECTED TO TIGHTEN RULES ON USE OF WATER
description: Mayor Koch is expected to announce tighter water restrictions today, including a requirement that businesses and industry reduce consumption even more than they have since a ''drought emergency'' was declared two months ago.

title: CHIC CASINOS ON RIVIERA ARE SCARRED BY SCANDAL
description: It looks like a seedy railroad station or a failed bank. The imposing facade is streaked with grime, its terrace littered with trash, its walls defaced with graffiti. There is nothing palatial about the Palais de la Mediterranee anymore.

title: Amoco of Canada Sees Spending Drop
description: The Amoco Canada Petroleum Company, a wholly owned unit of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), said the impact of the Canadian Government's national energy program and the Alberta government's oil production cutbacks will result in a 56 percent drop in exploration and production spending in 1981.

title: Shell Output Up 8% in Year
description: The Shell Oil Company said today that its production of oil and condensates rose 8 percent in 1980, to 165 million barrels.

title: REPORT SAYS AMERICA'S LEADER MAY UNDERRATE ROLE RELIGION PLAYS IN LIFE OF
description: PUBLIC By CHARLES AUSTIN

title: ELEVATORS OF FUTURE WILL BE SOOTHING AND SAFER
description: BEFORE World War II, riding an elevator usually involved delays, discomfort and anxiety caused by a balky and often jerky ride that ended with the car stopping several inches above or below the designated floor.

title: Steel Output Up in Week
description: Steel production rose to 2.671 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 1.9 percent from the previous week's 2.620 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: CORAZON RAMOS-ELEAZAL
description: Dr. Corazon Ramos-Eleazar, a staff physician at the Lincoln Medical-Mental Health Center in the Bronx and a resident at St. Michael's Medical Center in Newark, died Friday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 39 years old and a resident of Freehold, N.J.

title: Talking Business with Max Karl of MGIC; Home Building And the Future
description: The building of single-family houses has been a booming industry in America since World War II. Private mortgage insurers have thrived, along with real estate developers and mortgage bankers.

title: THE CASE FOR BREEDERS HONORS THE FACTS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MARCH 31, 1981
description: Shooting of the President The President was shot in the chest by a gunman, apparently acting alone, as Mr. Reagan walked to his limousine after addressing a labor meeting at the Washington Hilton Hotel. James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, and two law-enforcement officers were also wounded by a series of shots. The President was reported in ''good'' and ''stable'' condition after undergoing two hours of surgery at George Washington University Hospital. (Page A1, Column 6.) Mr. Reagan's prognosis is ''excellent,'' a top hospital official said last night, adding that the President ''is alert and should be able to make decisions by tomorrow.'' Earlier, doctors removed a .22 caliber bullet from the President's partly-collapsed left lung, but said that the bullet did not do much further damage and that neither Mr. Reagan's heart nor vital blood vessels were affected. The emergency surgical procedures found no bleeding or damage in the abdominal area, and the President's vital signs were stable throughout his ordeal. (A1:6.)

title: MAURICE B. ULLMAN
description: Maurice B. Ullman, chairman of the Strouse-Adler Company of New Haven, manufacturers of women's undergarments, died last Thursday at Griffin Hospital in Derby, Conn. He was 83 years old and lived in Stratford, Conn.

title: New Basketball Coach Named at Southern Illinois
description: Allen Van Winkle, coach at Jackson (Mich.) Community College, was named today as the new head basketball coach at Southern Illinois-Carbondale.

title: Canada Reports Threats
description: A Canadian official said today that the Government planned to establish a special antiterrorist squad to protect Western leaders attending a meeting here in July.

title: ACADEMY AWARDS POSTPONED TO TONIGHT
description: ''In deference to the tragedy in Washington,'' the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences postponed its annual awards ceremonies, which had been scheduled tonight at the Los Angeles Music Center, for 24 hours this afternoon.

title: Writers Guild Charges Stockpiling of Scripts
description: Members of the Writers Guild of America, who have threatened a strike on April 10 unless they get a contract, have accused movie and television producers of stockpiling scripts.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer $150 million in debentures due 2021, to be sold through competitive bidding April 14.

title: TAX CUTS RAISING DOUBTS OVER FUTURE OF PINELANDS
description: Standing on a wooded bluff, Floyd West, the Mayor of Bass River Township, swept an arm toward scores of whistling swans that had wintered on the Wading River in a wilderness section of the New Jersey Pine Barrens.

title: INDIANA DEFEATS NORTH CAROLINA, 63-50, FOR N.C.A.A. TITLE
description: The Indiana basketball team is getting to feel at home in the City of Brotherly Love. For the second time in five years, Indiana won the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship in the Spectrum here. The Hoosiers, sparked by Isiah Thomas, a sophomore all-America point guard, pulled away in the second half and went on to a 63-50 triumph over North Carolina tonight in the final of the 43d annual tournament. Thomas finished as the game's high scorer with 23 points, and led a 12-4 spurt at the beginning of the second half that broke open a close game.

title: RECITAL: STEVENS PLAYS BACH SONATAS ON THE MARIMBA
description: THE Bach solo violin sonatas are not generally heard on the marimba, but when one is played on that xylophonic instrument, it is to demonstrate the player's musicianship as much as the instrument's versatility.

title: POLITICIANS FEAR SHOOTING WILL IMPERIL NEW MOOD
description: Politicians and government leaders here recoiled today with the fear that the political casualty of a shocking new assassination attempt on a President's life might be the slowly returning national self-confidence rekindled lately by the release of American hostages in Iran and the start of a new Administration.

title: OUTLOOK 'GOOD' AFTER 2-HOUR SURGERY; AIDE AND 2 GUARDS SHOT; SUSPECT HELD; White House statements, pages A5 and A7.
description: President Reagan was shot in the chest today by a gunman, apparently acting alone, as Mr. Reagan walked to his limousine after addressing a labor meeting at the Washington Hilton Hotel. The White House press secretary and two law-enforcement officers were also wounded by a burst of shots.

title: N.C.A.A.  Considers 64-Team Format
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, which ended tonight with Indiana playing North Carolina in the title game, may be expanded from a 48-team field to 64 teams in 1982 or 1983.

title: LOYALTY, BUSINESS DRIVE SOME ENTHUSIASTS
description: Bob Newsome said he wanted to set up a company called the All American Insurance Agency because he liked Herschel Walker. Lloyd E. Davis said he bought college football tickets because it was good for his banking business in Lampasas, Tex.

title: WHY DOES LEAF FOLD WHEN IT'S TOUCHED?
description: ASCIENTIST who has long investigated the way insects and other animals defend themselves against their enemies believes that some plants may have the ability to deter their predators in a previously unknown manner.

title: Beardsley Overcomes Butterflies
description: Once, Craig Beardsley used to work himself into nervousness before a swimming race. ''I created problems,'' he recalled. ''I used to think, 'Oh, no, my event is coming up. I had better do good in it or else. I can't let my teammates down.'

title: Editors' Society Making Four Awards for Writing
description: Saul Pett, a special correspondent for The Associated Press, has won one of four awards given for distinguished writing for 1981 by the American Society of Newspaper Editors, the society announced yesterday.

title: AN EFFECTIVE VOICE FOR THE YOUNG
description: WHEN young people speak out in favor of changing the world, adults put them down as whippersnappers who ought to know their place. But when they are quiet and acquiescent, they are accused of being apathetic.

title: Little-Known Ingredient of a New Broadway Show
description: Sure Lauren Bacall, Harry Guardino, the director and all six producers are important to ''Woman of the Year.'' But the real power behind the show seems to be Charlene Nederlander, the new musical's ''unofficial adviser with a loud voice.''

title: 3 Killed by Fumes at British Base
description: Three men were killed by fumes at a Royal Navy base here today and a fourth was taken to a hospital after being overcome, a Defense Ministry spokesman reported. He said that the accident had nothing to do with nuclear safety. Britain's Polaris nuclear submarine force is maintained at Rosyth.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All of us who care about this country and who care about our fellow citizens bear an important responsibility in whatever way we possibly can to rid this society and to rid this country of the kind of violence and hatred that we have seen.

title: Panama Plane Will Fly Captives From Honduras
description: A Panamanian Air Force plane will pick up 15 prisoners in Honduras tomorrow as part of a deal that settled the hijacking of a Honduran airliner, Boris Moreno, a Panamanian spokesman, said today.

title: Continental Sale
description: The Continental Group Inc. said its Canadian subsidiary had agreed to sell its boxboard mills and folding carton plants to Belkin Packaging Ltd. for $60 million (Canadian). The company said the assets being sold included Continental's Toronto and Montreal boxboard mills, which produce a total of 500 tons a day, and the folding carton plants in Toronto, Montreal and in Winnipeg, Manitoba. Continental Group of Canada Ltd., the subsidiary, will continue to manufacture metal containers and produce metal stampings and leaf springs for the automotive industry.

title: The Price of Libel
description: The lawyer for The National Enquirer overstated his case when he called the $1.6 million libel award to Carol Burnett ''an affront to the First Amendment.'' The amount is indeed inflated when measured against any damage to the comedienne's estimable reputation. The trial judge or higher courts should reduce the award. But the verdict is no blow to a free press. It posts a warning for extra care where that warning is most needed, in the gossip sheets that thrive on tarnished images of celebrities.

title: WHITE SOX GET PHILS' LUZINSKI
description: Greg Luzinski, the Philadelphia Phillies' veteran outfielder, was sent to the Chicago White Sox for an undisclosed amount of money today.

title: How the Knicks and Bulls Match Up for Playoff Series
description: On March 13, in a game against the Knicks at Madison Square Garden, Coach Jerry Sloan of the Chicago Bulls made a lineup change, moving Dwight Jones to starting forward in place of Larry Kenon. The Bulls lost that game, but haven't lost since.

title: NEW PUSH FOR ANTIGUN LAW IS EXPECTED
description: The attempted assassination of President Reagan by a suspect carrying a .22-caliber revolver today was expected to bring another flurry of activity in Congress for passage of a strong national law for control of pistols.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Is it possible to get a sunburn through a piece of ordinary glass?

title: Court Delays Trial Involving CBS Tapes
description: NEWARK (AP) - A Federal judge postponed the trial of six persons charged with an alleged franchising swindle until a higher court decided whether he should give material from CBS News tapes to the defense.

title: Todd Considering Playing Out His Option
description: Richard Todd, conceding that ''because of the bad year we had'' he has little salary-negotiating power, is nonetheless seriously considering playing out his option with the Jets this season and becoming a free agent if contract talks stall.

title: OPERA: 'MAHAGONNY' AT THE MET
description: THE production first offered by the Metropolitan Opera last season of the Brecht-Weill ''Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny'' remains one of the company's and John Dexter's finest achievements, and its return to the repertory Thursday night only confirmed its excellence.

title: Ex-Inmate on Death Row Shoots Wife, Kills Himself
description: A man who spent six years on death row before being exonerated of murder charges shot his wife and then killed himself because ''everything that meant anything'' to him had been taken away, his attorney said today

title: Publication Cites Exxon Profit Jump
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, made a net profit of $3.89 a barrel on United States oil and gas production in 1980 versus $2.43 a barrel in 1979, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly reported.

title: Israel's Troops Strike At Palestinians in Lebanon
description: Israeli troops struck at Palestinian targets along the Mediterranean coast during the night, killing several suspected guerrillas, the military command said today.

title: 2 Killed and 4 Injured In Parkway Accident
description: Two women were killed and four persons, including an infant boy, were injured in a five-car wreck on the Grand Central Parkway, the police said.

title: STAGE: MUSTAPHA MATURA'S 'MEETINGS'
description: THE scene is the tropical paradise of Trinidad, and, in the background, we hear the voice of Harry Belafonte singing ''Brown Skin Girl.'' However, the view in Mustapha Matura's ''Meetings,'' which opened last night at the Phoenix Theater, is islands removed from calypso sentiments. Mr. Matura's observations on the mimicking of supposedly civilized behavior are almost as cynical as those of V.S. Naipaul.

title: DELIVERERS CONTINUE NEGOTIATIONS WITH PAPERS AS CONTRACT EXPIRES
description: Contracts between two key newspaper unions and for The Daily News and The New York Times worked into the night yesterday in an effort to reach an agreement that would avert the possibility of a strike today.

title: Elderly Shoppers To Get Police Guard
description: Elderly men and women in Coney Island will be given a police escort to do their shopping under a pilot program starting today. Officers of the 60th Precinct, which has the highest concentration of elderly people in the city, will pick up groups of men and women in police vans, running a shuttle service to and from two Coney Island shopping centers every Tuesday and Thursday from 10 A.M. until 2 P.M.

title: MAKEUP CHAIN SEEKS WIDER AWARENESS
description: In 1931, Merle Norman spent $150 to open a small cosmetics studio in Santa Monica to sell her own homemade products on a ''try before you buy'' basis.

title: CONGRESSMEN SIT IN STUNNED SILENCE AFTER HEARING OF ATTEMPT ON REAGAN'S LIFE
description: Members of Congress, shaken by the attempted assassination of President Reagan, gathered silently around television sets on Capitol Hill today and spoke in halting whispers of their outrage and despair.

title: PROPOSED CIVIL SERVICE TEST TERMED PREJUDICED IN FAVOR OF MINORITIES
description: The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and several conservatives criticized today the terms of a legal settlement in which the Reagan Administration agreed to replace a widely used examination alleged to discriminate against black and Hispanic applicants for Civil Service jobs.

title: Bridge: Women's Knockout Teams Close the Spring Nationals
description: For almost all the 5,000 players who competed here in the Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League the play is over. But for a dozen women players there is one major title to be won or lost today. In the final of the women's knockout team championship, squads led by Jo Morse of Silver Spring, Md., and Karen Allison of Toronto battled for the title.

title: Keeping Racing on the Track
description: In New York State, horses have been racing counterclockwise around the tracks for years. Should they reverse direction because horses in France race clockwise? A legislative task force will hold hearings next week on this and other revolutionary racing arrangements.

title: Isiah Thomas Sparks Hoosiers' Surge in Second Half
description: The middle-aged woman from the west side of Chicago wandered around the madness on the Spectrum floor, looking for the youngest of her 10 children. She wore corduroy slacks, a red jacket, and a smile. She also wore a red button, with a smiling face in the middle and handwritten words around the face.

title: BUSINESS AT STANDSTILL FOLLOWING SHOOTING
description: The business community reacted with shock and uncertainty and financial markets halted trading abruptly as word spread yesterday afternoon that the President had been shot.

title: It Was a Grueling, but Exciting Woprld Cup Ski Season
description: It was somehow fitting that the World Cup ski season officially ended on the day that Europeans turned their clocks ahead for what is known here as Summer Time.

title: Australia Airline's Credit
description: The Australian state-owned domestic airline, Trans-Australia Airlines, signed a $159 million export credit for four Airbus A300-B4 aircraft, its agent, Midland Bank International said today.

title: WITNESSES TO SHOOTING RECALL SUSPECT ACTING 'FIDGETY' AND 'HOSTILE'
description: ''I spotted him walking rapidly up and down outside the back door of the hotel,'' John M. Dodson said. ''He looked fidgety - agitated - a little strange, and I said to myself 'What if he takes a shot at the President?' ''

title: Esquire to Carry Insert On Pleasurable Drinking
description: The December issue of Esquire will carry an ''advertorial'' Digest-size insert called ''Cheers: A Gentleman's Guide to the Lore, Art and Science of Pleasurable Drinking.''

title: RETIREMENT CREATES A 3D VACANCY ON FEDERAL APPEALS COURT IN CITY
description: Judge Walter R. Mansfield is retiring as an active judge, creating a third opening on the 11-member Federal appeals court in Manhattan. The judge, in a letter to the White House disclosed yesterday, said he would give up his regular active service in July, when he reaches the age of 70. He said he planned to remain on the court as ''a senior judge with a moderately reduced workload.''

title: OPERA: LONDON HAILS NEW 'MACBETH'
description: LONDON OPERA audiences in London tend to be a reserved lot, but there were few signs of British restraint when the curtain fell on a new production of Verdi's ''Macbeth'' at the Royal Opera House Covent Garden on Friday night. Roars of approval were unstintingly bestowed on one and all: Riccardo Muti, the conductor; Elijah Moshinsky, the director; Renato Bruson, who sang the title role; and most particularly Renata Scotto, returning to Covent Garden after a 10-year absence to sing the first Lady Macbeth of her career.

title: Gas Could Become Prime Soviet Fuel
description: Natural gas will replace oil as the Soviet Union's main fuel by the end of the decade, according to current issue of The Oil and Gas Journal, a weekly trade magazine.

title: 2 IN REAGAN SECURITY DETAIL ARE WOUNDED OUTSIDE HOTEL
description: A District of Columbia policeman and a Secret Service agent were shot today by the gunman who wounded President Reagan.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: T HE week began with Cary Grant in a gray suit. He was in town to quietly promote Faberge's new fragrance, A Touch of Class, but he was really just passing through, on his way to a meeting at M-G-M, perhaps, or the Hollywood Park race track. He's on the boards of both. ''When you're 77, they're very kind to you,'' he said, winking. ''They make you director emeritus, but they don't let you vote.

title: JUDGES IN FRANCE BEING PRESSED TO TAKE A HARDER LINE ON CRIME
description: If King John had prevailed over the barons at Runnymede and fed Magna Carta to his horse, would British judges now wear cylindrical hats, like French judges do, instead of wigs? And would the majesty of the law be replaced by the law of his majesty?

title: Refugees' Boats Burned in Texas
description: Two fishing boats owned by Vietnamese refugees have been burned in Galveston Bay in the latest of a series of incidents over disputed shrimping rights along the Texas Gulf Coast, authorities said today. One boat valued at $25,000 was destroyed yesterday and another vessel was scorched but not seriously damaged, according to the police.

title: William J. O'Brien, Is Dead at 72;
description: Ex-Connecticut House Speaker

title: A Really Big Syzygy
description: Since March 25, the entire world -and much, much more - has fallen into a spectacular syzygy. The syzygy will last until about April 7. And, scientists say, nothing can be done about it.

title: COURT TO WEIGH BAN ON CANDIDATE'S VOW OF PAY CUT
description: In the eyes of Kentucky election officials, a political candidate who offers to take a pay cut if elected is doing the equivalent of selling his office. Today the Supreme Court, in a case that illustrates the frequent conflict between election regulation and the right of free speech, agreed to decide whether the Kentucky election law violates the First Amendment.

title: VIOLENCE AND PRESIDENTS, FROM JACKSON TO REAGAN
description: The shots fired at President Reagan yesterday marked the first assassination attempt against an American President in more than five years. It was the first time that a President had been injured in such an attempt since President Kennedy was shot and killed more than 17 years ago.

title: Job Ads Show Monthly Rise
description: Help-wanted advertising in newspapers increased slightly in February over the previous month but was still sharply down from a year ago, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: Saudi Arabia Gas Takeover
description: Saudi Arabia, which has assumed complete control of the Arabian American Oil Company, is taking over the major natural gas liquids facilities that were still 50 percent owned by its United States partners in Aramco, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly reported yesterday.

title: Kaiser Expanding
description: Kaiser Chemicals, the industrial chemicals division of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, announced a $27 million investment in a second processing plant that will bring a major expansion of its tubular alumina operations in Baton Rouge, La.

title: FMC Predicts Surge in Orders
description: Raymond C. Tower, president of the FMC Corporation, forecast a doubling of his company's defense business within the next two years. He said that out of 1980 sales of $3.4 billion, more than $500 million had come from sale of defense equipment, mainly Army vehicles.

title: A Weak Trend In Construction
description: February contracts for new construction rose only 2 percent from the level of a year earlier, signaling a further erosion of building activity this spring, according to the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company.

title: Prices Rise in Europe
description: Consumer prices climbed 1.1 percent in the 10 European Common Market countries in February, lifting the annual inflation rate to 12.4 percent, a Common Market spokesman said today. The increases brought the following yearly rates to the European Economic Community: West Germany, 5.5 percent; France, 12.7 percent; Italy, 19.9 percent; Netherlands, 6.7 percent; Belgium, 7.1 percent; Luxembourg, 7 percent; Britain, 12.5 percent; Ireland, 21 percent; Denmark, 10.7 percent; Greece, 26.5 percent. The annual rate of increase in the United States Consumer Price Index now stands at 11.1 percent.

title: WORLD LEADERS NOTE SHOCK AND CONCERN
description: Many leaders around the world expressed shock at the news that President Reagan had been wounded in an assassination attempt and conveyed their concern and wishes for a speedy recovery in personal messages to the White House.

title: CUNY LEADS IN REMEDIAL PROGRAMS
description: WHEN she was 18 years old and in the 10th grade, hopelessly floundering at Morris High School in the Bronx, Denise Riera dropped out of school, convinced she was not learning anything. Within a year, she passed the test for a high school equivalency diploma, then enrolled at Lehman College of the City University of New York, where she was assigned to remedial classes in reading, writing and mathematics.

title: SURPLUS CLASSROOMS BURDEN ONCE-THRIVING SUBURBS
description: America's maturing suburbs, which were building public schools at a rapid rate just a decade ago, are increasingly burdened with surplus classrooms and with the painful process of giving up schools that are far from obsolete.

title: by Joseph Short
description: Zimbabwe has defied the skeptics in its first year of independence. Many expected chaos, an exodus of whites, collapse of the economy, introduction of doctrinaire Marxism, or a civil war among African factions. Instead, peace, pragmatic government, economic rationality, and racial harmony have prevailed to a remarkable degree.

title: Massey-Ferguson Gets $80 Million
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the financially troubled agricultural equipment manufacturer, said in its annual report that its suppliers had recently agreed to provide it with $80 million in interim financing through payment deferrals.

title: ITALIAN FASHION'S SUCCESS: A FRESH POINT OF VIEW
description: As the fall and winter openings faded into the past, store buyers moved on to Florence, Rome and London. By the end of this week, they will reassemble in Paris. Most of them seem convinced that they have a hit on their hands. They placed orders in Milan for styles that may very well change the way women dress and think about clothes.

title: ISLAMIC PEACE MISSION IN TEHERAN MAKING A NEW CEASE-FIRE EFFORT
description: Nine Islamic leaders arrived in Teheran today for another attempt to arrange an Iraqi-Iranian truce and began talks at once with the Iranians.

title: U.S. EXPECTS TENSION IN POLAND TO EASE
description: State Department officials expressed relief today that Poland's independent union Solidarity had put aside the nationwide strike it had set for tomorrow, thereby appearing to reduce the chances for an internal crackdown or for Soviet intervention in Poland.

title: SALES OF NEW HOMES DROP 5.3%
description: Sales of new houses fell 5.3 percent last month, the Government reported today, apparently because high mortgage rates were discouraging home buyers, but January's figure was revised upward.

title: Calculator Unit Being Sold
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today it had signed an agreement to sell all of its calculator and watch operations to the newly formed Novus Electronics Corporation. The value of the sale was not announced.

title: SHANGHAI'S EX-CAPITALISTS BACK ON JOB
description: Two Mercedes-Benz cars and a British Ford of recent vintage were parked in the enclosed courtyard of the wellmaintained villa in what was once the French Concession in this most cosmopolitan of Chinese cities, and the two men who were seated in armchairs in what was once the drawing room looked as if they belonged there, or in the rear seats of the cars, despite their regulation Mao suits.

title: Winners Are Named Of Silver Anvil Awards
description: The Public Relations Society of America yesterday announced the winners of its annual Silver Anvil Awards, thereby stealing all the thunder from the Oscars, or some anyway.

title: Alleged Crime Boss Pleads Not Guilty in Massachusetts
description: A reputed New England crime boss, Raymond Patriarca, pleaded not guilty today to a charge of ordering the slaying of Robert Candos in North Attleboro, Mass., in 1968.

title: REAGAN'S PRESS SECRETARY HAS SERVED AS A LONGTIME SPOKESMAN FOR G.O.P.
description: For James S. Brady, the post of White House press secretary was the culmination of a long career as spokesman for Republican officials.

title: 'HONEY, I FORGOT TO DUCK,' INJURED REAGAN TELLS WIFE
description: Shortly before he was wheeled into the operating room, President Reagan looked up at his wife, Nancy, and told her: ''Honey, I forgot to duck.''

title: CONCERT: ORATORIO SOCIETY
description: HANDEL'S ''Joshua'' is a late work and a generally weak one compared to half a dozen masterly oratorios that preceeded it, such as ''Messiah,'' ''Samson'' and ''Judas Maccabeus.'' But any score that contains such renowned numbers as ''See, the conquering hero comes'' and ''O had I Jubal's lyre'' will arouse the curiosity of Handel enthusiasts. A respectable number of them were therefore on hand last night at Carnegie Hall where the Oratorio Society of New York gave this three-act ''victory oratorio'' in full, certainly a rare event in Manhattan's choral history and possibly an unprecedented one.

title: Floods Recede in Yugoslavia
description: Flooding of the Danube and Sava Rivers receded today, providing a respite for Yugoslavs who were affected last week by some of the worst floods of the century.

title: Mafia Meeting Is Broken Up
description: The police raided a suspected Mafia meeting near this south Italian town overnight and arrested 31 men, the authorities reported. All of them were charged with criminal conspiracy. The police said a New Yorker, Vincenzo Coluccio, a 56-year-old building contractor from Brooklyn, told them that the meeting was called to discuss the strength of the dollar and the difficulties of the lira.

title: West German Unionist Arrested
description: Hermann Gassmann, Hamburg secretary of the Metal Workers' Union, West Germany's biggest union, was arrested yesterday on suspicion of spying for an East European country, his lawyer said today. Mr. Gassmann denied the charge.

title: Queensboro Bridge Has Its 'Worst' Jam
description: As the city started its new plan for preventing traffic ''gridlock'' in Manhattan, the Queensboro Bridge was hit yesterday with what Victor Ross, executive assistant to Traffic Commissioner Thomas J. Guthrie, called the worst traffic jam in its history.

title: Uncertainty Restrains Trading
description: Trading in the credit markets slowed to a trickle yesterday after the President was shot. Prices fell and yields rose following the shooting. Activity was extremely light and the declines were more the result of uncertainty rather than an actual sell-off of securities, traders stressed.

title: Markets
description: Business came to a virtual standstill following the news that President Reagan had been shot. Trading on stock exchanges was halted abruptly and securities prices fell sharply. Economists and business executives said it was too soon to tell what effect the assassination attempt might have on the United States economy and on Administration programs. (D1.)

title: CHYN-DUOG SHIAH
description: Chyn-Duog Shiah, a chemical engineer who was chairman of the Summit Industrial Corporation and the Oceanic Petroleum Corporation, refinery and marketing companies based in Hamilton, Bermuda, died Friday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Tunisia Deal for Peugeot
description: Peugeot S.A. said today that it had signed a preliminary agreement with Tunisia to expand production of Peugeot cars and light vans by the Societe Tunisienne d'Industrie Automobile, Tunisia's state-owned auto maker. Last year it assembled 7,000 Peugeot vehicles. The new accord is expected to lift the total to 10,000 vehicles a year, Peugeot said.

title: Losses at Fay's Drug
description: Fay's Drug Company - a 115-unit drugstore chain based in Liverpool, N.Y., has just 31 of its stores in the South. But Henry A. Panasci Jr., the corporation's chairman and chief executive officer, said he believes that the marketing strategy used in the Southern stores was largely responsible for its loss of more than $2 million, falling to $959,867 in the fiscal year ended last Jan. 31 from $3,009,663 the previous year.

title: CANADIAN OFFICIAL WARNS ON ACID RAIN
description: Canada's Minister of the Environment expressed concern today that the Reagan Administration might fail to meet United States commitments to resolve the problem of acid rain originating in this country, and said that such a failure could have a substantial impact on relations between the two nations.

title: Three Killed, 1,000 Injured In a Calcutta Demonstration
description: Thousands of demonstrators fought with the Calcutta police today in violence that left at least three people dead, more than 1,000 injured and 768 under arrest, Indian news agencies said. It was the worst fighting so far in West Bengal's political conflict.

title: INSURANCE FOR BONDS ENJOYS RESURGENCE AMONG COMMUNITIES
description: The Greater Orlando, Fla., Aviation Authority wanted to tap the credit market to help finance an airport expansion project. In an effort to obtain the lowest interest rate possible, it went to the Municipal Bond Insurance Association, based here, which insured a portion of a $138 million bond issue.

title: SUSPECT WAS ARRESTED LAST YEAR IN NASHVILLE ON WEAPONS CHARGE
description: The 25-year-old son of a Denver oil executive was overpowered by police officers and Secret Service agents yesterday at the scene of an attack on President Reagan. He was charged with the attempted assassination of the President and the shooting of three other persons.

title: IT'S PATRONS, NOT ARTISTS, WHO HAVE CLOUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Raiders vs. N.F.L. Trial Encounters New Delay
description: The much-delayed trial of the Oakland Raiders antitrust suit against the National Football League ran into more roadblocks today, and the judge declined to set a new date.

title: ST. JOE SALE OF CANDEL UNDER FIRE
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation is expected to come under legal attack soon, accused of not getting fair market value for its Canadian oil and gas properties, insiders at Joseph E. Seagram & Sons disclosed yesterday.

title: India-Indonesia Plant
description: India's state-owned Projects and Equipment Corporation has signed a $71 million contract to build and design a $131 million cement plant in Indonesia, Anand Krishna, executive director, said today. The plant in Padang, West Sumatra, will have a capacity of 2,000 tons a day initially, but output can be doubled later, he said.

title: FOR THE SECRET SERVICE, A HAIL OF BULLETS DISRUPTS 'ROUTINE DUTY' WITH PRESIDENT
description: The Secret Service White House protective detail formed a loose and shifting shield around President Reagan this afternoon, a ''routine detail,'' as it does hundreds of times a year.

title: Zimbabwe Gets Loans
description: The World Bank and the International Development Association said today that they had approved loans and credits of $65 million for Zimbabwe.

title: MINERS' LEADER FINISHES TOUR ON RATIFICATION VOTE
description: After five days of appearances before frequently hostile audiences of miners, many of them angered by terms of the contract that he negotiated with the coal industry last week, Sam M. Church Jr., president of the United Mine Workers union, ended a tour today that was intended to win a rank-and-file ratification vote that could end the miners' strike on Thursday.

title: SADDENED AMERICANS REFLECT ON VIOLENCE IN NATION
description: The American people, long accustomed to the televised sound of gunshots and the ever-present danger of assassination, found themselves both saddened and outraged yesterday by the attempt on President Reagan's life.

title: PATH on Schedule
description: JERSEY CITY (UPI) - Officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said PATH commuter trains were running on schedule after the agency obtained a Federal court order barring motormen from staging a slowdown.

title: USED RUBBER MACHINERY: BUSINESS IS GOOD
description: The economy may be sluggish and interest rates may be high, but business is thriving at Akron Rubber Machinery Sales, as well as a handful of other dealers in used rubber-making equipment.

title: Espionage Case in Austria
description: Acting on a tip from a Rumanian defector, the Austrian Foreign Ministry has suspended three employees suspected of espionage activities, the ministry said today. The identities of the three were not disclosed. The investigation was started as a result of information supplied by Florian Rotaru, a former code expert of the Rumanian Embassy here who defected to the West last year, officials said.

title: REALITY TEMPERS DREAMS OF FRESHMAN LEGISLATORS IN ALBANY
description: After two and a half months on the job, the 23 freshman New York State legislators have accepted their roles as the new kids on the block-eager to learn everything there is to know about the neighborhood and anxious about how they will get along with their new friends.

title: DANCE: PASCHAL GUZMAN TROUPE PERFORMS
description: The members of the Paschal Guzman Dance Company, which performed Saturday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., appear to have been trained in both classical ballet and a variety of contemporary dance styles. Therefore they ought to be versatile. But what prevented them from making an impression was Mr. Guzman's unremittingly banal choreography.

title: U.S. Probe Of Hunts Delayed
description: A Federal court judge today ordered a 10-day delay in the Government's investigation into the activity of the millionaire Hunt brothers in the silver futures market, saying he was ''bothered'' by questions surrounding the year-old inquiry.

title: BANK-LIKE RESTRICTIONS SHOULD APPLY TO MONEY-MARKET FUNDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Tentative Agreement Is Set In Tug Strike in Northwest
description: A tentative agreement was reached today to end a 14-day-old strike by 1,000 tugboat workers in the Northwest, according to a strike coordinator for the Inlandboatmen's Union of the Pacific.

title: Broker Loan Rates Raised
description: Two of the nation's largest banks, the Marine Midland Bank and Manufacturers Hanover Trust, announced increases in their broker loan rates yesterday.

title: WESTERN BANKS HELD WARY ON POLISH DEBT
description: A consortium of Western bankers meeting with Polish finance officials in London tomorrow is expected to mark time on reworking Poland's debt situation until government efforts to arrange aid for Poland are concluded, Western bank sources said today.

title: BUSH STATEMENT AT WHITE HOUSE
description: Following is a transcript of a statement by Vice President Bush in the White House briefing room yesterday evening, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: DISTRICT 37 AIDE NAMED BY CAREY TO FILL LABOR JOB
description: Governor Carey today announced the nomination of Lillian Roberts as State Industrial Commissioner. Miss Roberts is the associate director of District Council 37, the major New York City municipal labor union,

title: JOHN E. PETERSON
description: John E. Peterson, executive vice president and director of Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J., died Saturday at the hospital after a long illness.

title: REPORT BY AIDE IN WHITE HOUSE AFTER SHOOTINGS
description: Following is a transcript of a White House statement by a Presidential aide, David R. Gergen, on the attack on President Reagan today.

title: BELL DATA PLAN HALTED PENDING HEARING
description: A Texas district court judge has ordered the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company to stop preparations for consumer testing of its Electronic Information Service, a computerized home information retrieval system.

title: NO FORMAL CHANGE IN ALERT STATUS
description: No formal changes were made in the alert status of United States military forces around the world as a result of the shooting of President Reagan, Government officials said this afternoon.

title: North Sea Well Test By Texaco Succeeds
description: Texaco Inc. said it had successfully tested a new well in the Buchan Field, in the British sector of the North Sea, that produced 9,931 barrels of oil a day.

title: BUSH FLIES BACK FROM TEXAS SET TO TAKE CHARGE IN CRISIS
description: Vice President Bush, cutting short a trip to Texas, returned to the White House this evening to take charge of the crisis in the Government and to assume the responsibilities of the Presidency if President Reagan's injuries prevented him from serving in the office.

title: GERMAN STEELMEN URGE DUTIES
description: West Germany's steelmakers called on the Bonn Government today to impose countervailing duties on steel imports from other European countries after weekend talks in Luxembourg failed to meet a Common Market deadline to agree on a system of voluntary production curbs.

title: by Dean Baker
description: Oregon's silent, seductive high desert turned to ice suddenly, ominously, at 3 A.M., halfway between Burns and Rome. Four of us city people from Eugene half-slept snug and speeding in the car, bound for wilderness adventure, rafting the mystic Owyhee in the morning. The fresh spring blizzard swirled out of nowhere and everywhere, dancing hypnotically into the headlights, instantly obliterating black sky, silver stars, silhouettes of sage and scrub pine, and distant desert hills. The world disappeared and the car stopped and stalled.

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.J. Armstrong Corporation agreed with Security Pacific Corporation on terms of Armstrong's merger into a wholly owned subsidiary of Security Pacific. Armstrong shareholders are to receive $77.20 a share in cash for their stock for an aggregate of $114 million.

title: Man Dies in Leap From Flames
description: A 51-year-old man attempting to escape smoke and flames leaped to his death early today from a threestory apartment house downtown. The victim, identified as Donald B. Jones, jumped after being trapped by flames and smoke in his thirdfloor room in the building, the Wellington Apartments, fire officials said. At least six persons, including three firemen, were injured in the blaze,.

title: Israeli Arabs Rally in Protest Against Land Requisition
description: Thousands of Israeli Arabs held peaceful demonstrations today against the Government's land requisition policies. The protests marked the annual observance of ''Land Day'' commemorating the death of six Arabs in a violent demonstration five years ago.

title: Remington Rand Reorganization Bid
description: The Remington Rand Corporation, a leading typewriter manufacturer in the United States and abroad, said it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: ROSE MASON
description: Rose Mason, president and dean of the International Career Institute, a business and technical school at 1220 Broadway, died Friday at her home in Guttenberg, N.J. She was 55 years old.

title: TV NETWORKS QUICKLY SUPPLY VIVID DOCUMENTATION OF ASSASSINATION ATTEMPT
description: Videotapes of the attempted assassination of President Reagan began running on the three major television networks less than half an hour after the shooting at the Washington Hilton Hotel yesterday. What ensued was a graphic documentation, from a variety of camera angles, of the attempt on the President's life.

title: Saudia Orders 4 Boeing 747's
description: The Boeing Company said today that Saudia, the national airline of Saudi Arabia, had ordered four 747 airliners to be delivered this year and in the first half of 1982.

title: HARRIS CASE SPURS NEW THOUGHT ON PRISONS
description: To the Editor:

title: by Murray L. Weidenbaum
description: Government bail outs of Lockheed, Chrysler, and New York City never had unanimous political or popular support. But when the U.S. Government hands over $4.3 billion in credit and credit guarantees to small business this year, hardly anyone will object. Nurturing small business, we seem to believe, is a good thing for Government to do. Let me venture to suggest, however, that the small-business sector would be a great deal healthier without this help.

title: Ex-McGraw-Edison President Retained as $250,000 Consultant
description: O.E. Powers, who resigned last August as president and chief operating officer of the McGraw-Edison Company, a manufacturer of mechanical and electrical products, has received a one-year consulting contract from the company totaling almost $250,000. The information about Mr. Powers's contract was contained in the company's proxy statement in advance of its annual meeting in Chicago on April 22.

title: One Size Does Not Fit All, So an Actor Adjusts
description: Jonathan Hadary is an actor who's learning to change his size to suit the parts he wants to play. He originated the role of the chubby Herschel Weinberger in ''Gemini.''

title: Rhode Island Faces Bias Suit
description: The Justice Department today filed a civil suit charging that the Rhode Island state police discriminated against women in hiring state troopers. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Providence, R.I., charged that as of June 26, 1979, there were no women among the state's 174 state troopers.

title: New Bishop of London Named by Mrs. Thatcher
description: A prelate who has publicly criticized both the royal family and Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Government was named yesterday as Bishop of London, regarded as the third highest post in the Church of England.

title: JACKSON, LEG INJURED, WILL MISS THE OPENER
description: Reggie Jackson tore a tendon in his right calf today and will miss the Yankees' season opener next Thursday, and perhaps several games after that.

title: Stocks Close Off a Bit in Session Cut Short by Reagan Shooting
description: The stock market closed slightly lower yesterday in a trading session abbreviated by the assassination attempt upon President Reagan in Washington. Prices had been moderately higher until it was confirmed that the President had been wounded in the attack.

title: MacMillan Bloedel: Offer Postponed
description: The Toronto Stock Exchange said the bid by the British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation for MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. shares has been postponed until April 7.

title: Together
description: First comes cold shock, deep in the pit of the mind. Not again. Not again. Not another one of those days of grim unity, with everyone remembering where they were when they heard the news. How many times have we all gathered together, tragically united around the altar of events?

title: FRANK TIERI, 77, CONVICTED NEW YORK CRIME LEADER
description: Frank Tieri, who Federal authorities said was the first person ever convicted of heading an organized-crime family, died at Mount Sinai Hospital Sunday after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: MISSING PERSONS BUREAUS GAIN INCREASED ATTENTION
description: Detroit has one detective in police headquarters assigned full time to missing persons cases. San Francisco recently added a second full-time officer for missing persons. Det. Sally Waldbacker alone has been the Miami Missing Persons Bureau for 13 years. And Boston has no central missing persons bureau.

title: BODY OF BLACK BOY IS FOUND IN RIVER IN THE ATLANTA AREA
description: The body of a black boy was found today in the Chattahoochee River in southwest Fulton County, the authorities said. He became the 21st black child to be found dead in the Atlanta area in the last 20 months.

title: THE MX MUST BE LAND-BASED, ENVIRONMENT OR NO
description: To the Editor:

title: IN TALK JUST BEFORE ATTACK, REAGAN ASSAYED CRIME RISE
description: Minutes before he was shot this afternoon, President Reagan told a labor audience that governmental straying from basic principles was to blame for a surge in ''violent crime'' in this country.

title: Chess: What, Me Worry? You Bet, Even if You're an Alekhine
description: The great Alexander Alekhine, world champion from 1927 to 1935 and from 1937 to his death in 1946, once expressed misgivings over ''the impression that I could always, or nearly always, when in a bad position, conjure up some unexpected combination to extricate me from my difficulties.''

title: PARTIES IN SENATE EXCHANGE BARBS ON AID TO AGED
description: Senate Democrats and Republicans accused each other of cruelty and hypocrisy today as the Senate rejected a Democratic effort to restore $800 million for Social Security.

title: FIRST YEAR OF LOTTERY FOR THE ARTS IN MASSACHUSETTS CALLED A FAILURE
description: A Massachusetts lottery for the arts will not yield any profits this year, officials say. Backers of the idea, modeled after a successful similar lottery in Australia, say they still bet on it to win aid for the arts in the future. But critics at both the local and state levels say the game was ill conceived and has been poorly run.

title: The U.N. Today; March 31, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing the Nonuse of Force in International Rela- tions - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: INDONESIANS STORM JET IN BANGKOK, FREEING ALL 55 CAPTIVES
description: Indonesian commandos rushed a hijacked Indonesian airliner here early today, killed four of the five hijackers who had held it since Saturday, and freed all 55 hostages aboard.

title: Mets Cut Lynch, 6 Others
description: The New York Mets dropped seven young players today and prepared to trade at least one other in a mass housekeeping move aimed at trimming the roster to the 25 men who will open the season next week.

title: OIL INDUSTRY HURT BY DROP IN DEMAND
description: In the face of sharply declining demand for petroleum products, the nation's oil companies are closing some refineries, operating others at what is believed to be the industry's lowest level ever and cutting the wholesale price of gasoline.

title: ERIC WILLIAMS,LEADER OF TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO, IS DEAD
description: Prime Minister Eric Eustace Williams of Trinidad and Tobago, the historian-politician who led his two-island nation to independence 18 years ago and had governed it ever since, died Sunday night in his official residence in a Port of Spain suburb, St. Anne. He was 69 years old.

title: FORD TO SELL JAPAN TRANSMISSION STAKE
description: The Ford Motor Company, which had a pretax loss of $2.27 billion last year, reported today that it was selling its half of the Japan Automatic Transmission Company to its Japanese partners, the Nissan Motor Company, the maker of Datsun, and the Toyo Kogyo Company, maker of Mazda.

title: SYNTHETICS GO TO NEW LENGTHS IN OUTPERFORMING NATURAL MATERIALS
description: OFTEN borrowing from the growing understanding of the chemistry of life, polymer scientists are creating new materials with such startling properties they promise technological changes comparable to ancient man's transition from stone to metal tools.

title: TV: 'STAND BY YOUR MAN, ' TAMMY WYNETTE STORY
description: THE unsettling thing about most official biographies of countrymusic stars is that they are just about as trite as country-music lyrics. The rags-to-riches sagas, presumably meant to be inspiring, tend to get trapped under a cloud of dreariness. Tonight's example, on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock, is ''Stand By Your Man,'' the story of Tammy Wynette, whose singing career began in the mid-60's.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt ERNEST HEMINGWAY. Selected Letters, 1917-1961. Edited by Carlos Baker. 948 pages. Scribner's. $27.50.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Centex Corporation, Dallas, announced that Norris R. Harris had resigned as president of the Centex Oil and Gas subsidiary, and that Frank M. Crossen, chairman and co-chief executive officer of the parent company, would assume the additional duties of president of Centex Oil and Gas.

title: DAVIS CUP IN NEW YORK
description: The United States and Czechoslovakia will meet in a quaterfinal Davis Cup match July 10 at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens, the United States Tennis Association said yesterday. This will be the first cup meeting between the nations. Czechoslovakia, with Ivan Lendl, is the defending champion.

title: Trial Opens in New Orleans For Reputed Mafia Leader
description: The bribery trial of a reputed Mafia leader, Carlos Marcello, and four other men opened today in United States District Court with the judge telling potential jurors that the trial could last more than three months.

title: CITY ASSISTANCE FOR REHABILITATING AND BUILDING APARTMENTS CLIMBS
description: Using more than $236 million in Federal money, New York City helped pay for the construction or rehabilitation of 21,776 apartments last year, the highest number of city-assisted housing starts in its history, according to data released by Mayor Koch.

title: NUCLEAR CODE BRIEFCASE REMAINED NEAR REAGAN
description: The black briefcase that holds codes needed in the event of a nuclear war remained near President Reagan after he was shot today, a White House spokesman said.

title: Navy Puts Admiral In Charge of Trident
description: The Navy today signaled its resolve to get the problem-plagued, $6 billion Trident missile submarine program back on the rails, installing a two-star admiral as supervisor of construction at the Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation.

title: Company Is Fined For Trade With Iran
description: NEWARK (UPI) - A New York State company was fined $40,000 for violating a Presidential ban on exporting goods to Iran during the American hostage crisis.

title: GUATEMALA AND BELIZE
description: To the Editor:

title: By Sports of The Times; The NBC Championship
description: OUT on the basketball court at the Spectrum, the Indiana cheerleaders were yelling, ''Here we go, Hoosiers, here we go'' when suddenly the voice of the public-address announcer drummed through the noisy anticipation of the National Collegiate basketball tournament championship game.

title: WILLIAMS JURY IS SELECTED IN BROOKLYN ABSCAM CASE
description: A jury of seven men and five women was selected yesterday for the trial of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. Senator Williams is charged with bribery and conspiracy stemming from the Government's Abscam investigation into political corruption.

title: ONE ACQUITTAL ORDERED AT GOODY MUSIC TRIAL OVER LACK OF EVIDENCE
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered that George Levy, the president of Sam Goody Inc., be acquitted of charges that he knowingly dealt in counterfeit cassette and eight-track tapes of popular music.
